column2: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 12 -- Uganda's state radio said tonight that a six-member military commission had "assumed the powers of the presidency," but it said nothing about the status or whereabouts of President Godfrey L. Binaisa.

Ronald Reagan and President Carter, despite only light campaign efforts in both states, go into today's primary elections in Maryland and Nebraska with little likelihood, according to politicians, of being derailed in their drives to nomination.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, said today that there was "no evidence" that the White House intervened to help Rupert Murdoch, publisher of The New York Post, obtain a low-interest Government loan shortly before the newspaper endorsed President Carter for renomination.

Spencer Haywood's attempts to rejoin the Los Angeles Lakers for Wednesday night's fifth game of the National Basketball Association championship series against the Philadelphia 76ers failed yesterday. With Bill Sharman, the Laker general manager, acting as an intermediary, Coach Paul Westhead refused to lift the suspension of the 6-foot-8-inch forward.

LEAD, the toxic metal that is thought to have contributed to the fall of the Roman Empire, is today a pervasive environmental contaminant that may be damaging the brain development of millions of children here and in other industrialized countries.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Had American commandos been able to get into Teheran last month, they apparently would have made their assault on the American Embassy from an abandoned construction site, according to maps and documents obtained by ABC News.

Maxie L. Anderson is the kind of man who likes bests and biggests and firsts. His childhood hero was Charles Lindbergh. He got his pilot's license when he was 15 by lying about his age, and when he was not quite 30 he became...

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 12 It was 5:13 A.M. last Saturday and dark storm clouds were sending down a cascade of showers on two four-legged figures entering the race track at Hollywood Park. Astride a stable pony sat Wayne Lukas, the 44-year-old trainer of Codex, a leading entry in this Saturday's Preakness; aboard Codex, a lovely, streamlined, chestnut 3-year-old, sat his exercise boy, Jesus Castillo.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., May 12 Parents of nearly all 750 students at Whippoorwill Elementary School here kept their children out of school today to protest the Islip town administration's refusal to close a nearby dump in which traces of vinyl chloride, a known carcinogen, were found recently.

The diplomacy of the living is too often sacrificed to respect for the dead, and nowhere more than in the battlegrounds of the Middle East. The terror killing of Israelis is regularly cited to justify terror against Arabs, and the other way around. And observers far from the danger zone are expected to fall silent before the grave, disqualified by distance from any opinion about the slaughter and the policies that produce it.

A panel of three Federal judges ruled yesterday that a Houston public television station had acted legally when it decided not to air "Death of a Princess", the controversial film that was to be shown last night on more than 130 public television stations.

Maxie Anderson, one of the balloonists who made it across the Atlantic two years ago, has achieved another first by floating nonstop from San Francisco to eastern Canada. In doing so, he has earned respect for more than a second listing in the "Guinness Book of World Records." He may be demonstrating that as far as air travel is concerned, the future could lie behind us.
Mayor Koch asked the Justice Department yesterday to join the investigation of a recent series of suspicious fires at churches with predominantly black congregations in Far Rockaway, Queens.
BONN, May 12 In West Germany as elsewhere, a young man looking for work as an auto mechanic can pick up the local newspaper and scan the helpwanted advertisements.

WASHINGTON SHIRLEY M. HUFSTEDLER, the new Secre tary of Education, called it "a weeklong salute to learning." The new Department of Education, or "Ed," as it wants to be called to avoid the embarrassing "D.Ed." inaugurated itself last week with much fanfare.

ROME, May 12 (AP) Pope John Paul II, making his first direct public comment on the case of United States Representative Robert F. Drinan, said today that "politics is the responsibility of laymen and a priest should be a priest."
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 12 Around Lampasas, Tex., they talk about Johnny Jones the way Northwest woodsmen talk of Paul Bunyan.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Two Cuban MIG fighter jets today buzzed a United States Coast Guard helicopter searching for four missing Bahamian sailors today near Santo Domingo Key, and the United States responded by sending two F-4's to the area, an Air Force spokesman said.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The Supreme Court today agreed to hear an appeal by the City of Memphis from a ruling that the Memphis City Council discriminated against blacks by allowing residents of a white neighborhood to close a street to through-traffic.

ROME, May 12 The head of the antiterrorist police force in the Venice region was shot to death by terrorists this morning in Mestre, the industrial city on the mainland opposite Venice. In a telephone call to the Venice newspaper II Gazzettino, the Red Brigades said they were responsibile for the killing.

DETROIT, May 12 American auto makers have acknowledged with fanfare in recent years the demise of the convertible, the passing of the V-8, the death of the gas guzzler. But as America's romance with the automobile fades, one jilted sweetheart is disappearing quietly from the highways, probably never to recover its past glory the standard Chevrolet.

Two men in a giant balloon completed a grueling, four-day voyage across North America yesterday, floating to rest in a field on the Gaspe Peninsula of eastern Canada. They had weathered stiff winds, skirted ominous storms and survived subzero temperatures to accomplish the first nonstop transcontinental balloon flight.

Jim Lee Howell, the main link for the football Giants with their glory years of the 1930's, 1940's and 1950's, yesterday announced he was relinquishing his duties as director of player personnel, a job he has held since he quit as head coach in 1960.
NEWARK, May 12 The top official of the United States Customs Service in New Jersey pleaded guilty today to accepting cash and liquor illegally.

SAN SALVADOR, May 12 (Reuters) United States Marine guards fired tear gas today at demonstrators at the home of the American Ambassador, Robert E. White, an embassy spokesman said. The Ambassador escaped unharmed.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, expressed concern today that the Government may have approved a Chrysler rescue plan that "does not comply" with the law authorizing Federal loan guarantees for Chrysler.
MIAMI, May 12 (UPI) Two men sought by the Federal Bureau of Investigation for about a decade have been arrested in Miami after joining the exodus from Cuba.

WASHINGTON, May 12 The two prerequisites for an independent Presidential campaign by Representative John Anderson are, first, the major parties' nominations of Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, which seem all but certain; and, second, a ...

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.VA. THOMAS A. MURPHY, chairman of the General Motors Corporation, after a speech to the Securities Industry Association's spring meeting at the Greenbrier here, spoke ebulliently to reporters about the outlook for the auto industry.

HAVANA, May 12 Faced with serious economic problems resulting from agricultural failures, the Cuban Government has been walking a fine line in the last three weeks between whipping up revolutionary fervor against the United States and calling for public discipline to avoid violence against Cubans leaving for Florida.

DALLAS, May 12 (AP) A judge who ordered The Wall Street Journal not to publish an investigative article about an oil and cement company reversed his decision today and said the newspaper could publish the article as scheduled.

Because Bellevue Hospital Center's psychiatric hospital no longer has enough nurses, staff members say troublesome patients must often be oversedated with Thorazine to keep them from hurting themselves and others.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) -- Canadian officials, increasingly unhappy over delays in the proposed Alaskan natural gas pipeline, demanded assurances from the Carter Administration today that the 4,800-mile project can be completed.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, May 12 A delegation of Cuban officials arrived here this afternoon, apparently in hopes of clarifying for the Bahamian Government the circumstances surrounding the sinking of a Bahamian patrol boat Saturday by Cuban Air Force planes.

WASHINGTON, May 12 Members of Congress, led by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, and officials of Roman Catholic charitable organizations charged today that the Administration had been slow to assist the Cuban refugees and had discriminated against Haitians seeking refuge in the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 12 The Supreme Court refused today to review lower court rulings that the Government argued could cost gasoline consumers billions of dollars.

ST. LOUIS, May 12 (AP) Ozark Air Lines and striking mechanics will resume contract talks Wednesday before Federal mediators in Washington, the union announced today. Negotiations broke off last Tuesday when 700 mechanics walked off the job. The airline immediately ceased operations to 66 cities in 21 states, idling 3,500 employees for the second time in a year.

Shareholders of Kansas State Network, a Wichita-based television and radio broadcaster and refrigeratedwarehouse operator, approved a previously announced merger with Standard Communications through a stock purchase valued at $63 million.

Howard Mumford Jones, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian of American culture and a leader in advancing the study of American literature, died Sunday at the Harvard University infirmary in Cambridge, Mass., after a brief illness. He was 88 years old.
AN elephant with a fondness for fruit drink has helped scienfists to pin down an important principle of hearing and sound perception that seems to apply to all mammals, large and small.

GENEVA, May 12 (AP) The killings of three Guatemalan lawyers this year were part of plot to deprive peasant groups, labor unions and universities of legal assistance, the International Commission of Jurists said today.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) President Carter's 10-cents-a-gallon gasoline import fee is an unconstitutional tax and should be blocked from taking effect as scheduled Thursday, a coalition of consumer groups, Congressmen and petroleum marketers told a Federal court today.
WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Fifty years ago, eight young nurses in flowing capes and shower-cap-type hats became the world's first airline stewardesses. The job required more grit than glamour.

More than 20 persons were injured and a factory and mobile home park were damaged when a tornado struck Sedalia, Mo., last night. Tornadoes also struck two Pennsylvania communities, damaging numerous homes, uprooting trees and causing extensive power outages.

It was rain hats off to both the city and its largest manufacturing industry yesterday afternoon at the start of "The New York Salute to the Fashion Industry." The opening ceremony, at the New York State Theater, was marked by assorted speeches, bushels of Big Apple symbols and a razzmatazz...

NEW ORLEANS, May 12 (AP) A law requiring that new workers in St. Mary Parish be fingerprinted, photographed and subjected to a police background check was struck down today by a Federal appeals court.

Nearly all the favorites were left far behind in the prestigious Cavendish Club Invitational Pair Championship over the weekend as Roger Bates of New York and Dan Mordecai of Denver won a convincing if unexpected victory.
KEY WEST, Fla., May 12 Suddenly, this mellow, chic village of writers, artists, fishermen and sun lovers at the southern tip of the United States has an image problem.
The tentative contract that ended last month's bus and subway strike was ratified yesterday by an overwhelming vote of the memberships of New York City's two transit unions.

TWO ballet bird-creatures fantastic on more levels than one were on the boards over the weekend at Lincoln Center. On Sunday night at the State Theater, Kyra Nichols shimmered gorgeously in a revised version of the New York City Ballet's "Firebird." On Saturday afternoon, ...

WASHINGTON, May 12 Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's opinions in Rhode Island v. Innis, in which the Court for the first time defined the "interrogation" that is prohibited under the landmark Miranda decision. The majority opinion was by Justice Potter Stewart. The minority opinions were by Justices John Paul Stevens and by Justice Thurgood Marshall joined by Justice William J. Brennan Jr.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 12 President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr's latest attempt to gain control of his own Government failed tonight when he was unable to appoint his own Prime Minister.

ICA, Peru, May 11 Holding aloft a red and white Peruvian flag and a shovel, his political symbol, Fernando Belaunde Terry, a candidate for President in next Sunday's elections, faced the crowd in the main plaza here.

The most adventurous furs in the world carry the Fendi label. Ballooning sleeves, slashed at the side, are an identifying feature of some of the newest fall styles. In mink such a balloon-sleeve coat costs about $25,000.
A judge dismissed 12 of the 136 counts yesterday in the indictment of Douglas LaChance, a newspaper union president charged with extorting cash payoffs from newspaper delivery companies.
ALBANY, May 12 Registered lobbyists spent $2.1 million in the first three months of the year trying to influence the State Legislature and regulatory agencies, a state agency reported today.

Wometco Enterprises Inc. and the Storer Broadcasting Company announced yesterday that they had made final their prior agreement for Storer to purchase Allstate Cablevision Inc., a Wometco subsidiary that operates Plainfield Cablevision and Middlesex Cablevision, both of New Jersey.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill. A few years ago, Betty J. Hoxsey was working as a bookkeeper in her hometown of Ottawa, Ill. A better job opened up with the company, but when she put in a bid, she was turned down flat.

WASHINGTON, May 12 (AP) Manufacturing and trade inventories rose six-tenths of 1 percent in March, to $437.6 billion, as sales fell for the second consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported today.

MAHWAH, N.J., May 12 Secretary of Transportation Neil E. Goldschmidt gave qualified support today to the idea of converting the Ford plant here to the manufacture of buses, a move that could save the jobs of 1,400 of the 5,000 Ford workers facing unemployment.
NEW DELHI, May 12 Afghanistan's Government has appealed to India not to withdraw its technical advisers, who are virtually the last foreign civilian experts left in the country.

The New York City administration has adopted a new policy for financing cultural activities in the city that could have seriously damaging long-term effects both on the city itself and on the programs of culture and art that are so essential to its well-being.

FAR HILLS, N.J., May 12 (AP) The United States Golf Association announced today it had received 4,812 entries below the 1978 record of 4,897 for the United States Open golf championship at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield from June 12-15.

In the diversity of its languages, probably no major city in the world matches New York, where the last census found that nearly half the 7.8 million residents had a mother tongue other than English and that 25 major languages from Arabic to Yiddish were spoken by fairly large blocs of the population.

THE kindest interpretation one can put on "Maybe," Lillian Hellman's new book, is that it is a parody of contemporary fiction. Non sequiturs, gratuitous acts, frustrating ellipses, ambiguities, a dearth of emotion: Miss Hellman...

IN Arthur Schnitzler's "The Green Cockatoo," there are two simultaneous revolutions one in the streets of Paris and the other in a wine bar, where a troupe of actors confronts an audience of aristocrats with "hair-raising tales of lives never lived."

Mayor Koch and Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin acted yesterday to prevent a 45year-old teacher at a junior high school in Queens from qualifying for a pension while he faced prosecution on charges that he had dealt in pornography involving children.

AMMAN, Jordan, May 12 (Reuters) Jordanian officials said today that there was no truth in a report by Time magazine that Jordan had agreed to allow Palestinian guerrillas to operate from its territory against the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 12 The State Supreme Court last week disqualified a state's attorney in New Haven from participating in the prosecution of a 19year-old boy on a murder charge because the lawyer had represented the boy in an accident case when he was 5 years old.

A dozen games before the National Hockey League regular season ended, the New York Islanders had a limited view of their future, and it was not in the direction of the league-leading Philadelphia Flyers. "We're only looking to win the next game," Coach Al Arbour said at the time.

THE origin of the great Maya civilization, heretofore traced back to simple farming villages of around 2500 B.C., has been extended another 6,500 years into the past as the result of major new archeological discoveries made in Belize, on the Yucatan peninsula, in just the last four months.

Negotiations for a $12 million world heavyweight championship fight between Muhammad Ali and Larry Holmes, scheduled for Rio de Janeiro on July 11, have fallen apart and the bout will not be held at that site or on that date, United Press International reported yesterday.

The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association yesterday attacked the Sanitation Department's plan to seek bids to test whether a private company could provide sanitation services more efficiently and at lower cost than the current operation.

Retail sales lagged in April for the second consecutive month in New York City and the metropolitan area generally, a spot-check has found. It also found several notable exceptions, however, in which stores catering to uppermiddle-income and wealthier customers did relatively well.

PARIS, May 12 The Common Market may face the gravest political crisis of its 23-year history at the end of this month unless a complex and increasingly bitter dispute over Britain's share of its budget is resolved.

The Garbisch collection of Impressionist and modern art was sold last night at Sotheby Parke Bernet for $14.8 million, the highest figure reached in an art auction in the United States and the highest for an Impressionist and modern art sale in the world.

ALBANY, May 12 Governor Carey signed a measure today giving $22.3 million more to the State University of New York. The Democratic-led Assembly promptly overrode Mr. Carey's vetoes of $20.3 million in additional funds for other...

Lending by the International Monetary Fund so far this year is up sharply from past levels, and all of the new credits have gone to developing countries. In the view of many experts, this trend reflects a significant evolution in the fund's role in international finance.
Takeover situations produced excitement in the stock market yesterday, while prices overall showed little change in light trading.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 12 Five years of litigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission against the Howard R. Hughes interests over acquisition of the regional airline Air West was ended today with filing of an order against the only remaining defendant, Chester C. Davis, once general counsel for Mr. Hughes's wideranging industrial and real estate activities.

IN the 1960's, when the stock market was booming, stock options were considered a sure way to in crease the compensation of top corporate executives and help them share in the company's rising fortunes. But because of the market's long decline and tougher tax laws, stock options have gradually fallen into disfavor.

Saudi Arabia's petroleum minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said in a radio interview in Rome yesterday that his country would hold its daily crude oil production at the current 9.5 million barrels until the end of June. Saudi Arabia is the United States' main foreign oil supplier.

LONDON, May 12 The British Government, saying it was "determined that London should not be a battleground for Middle East factions," announced today that it had expelled four Libyans connected with the diplomatic mission here.
Former New York State Comptroller Arthur Levitt, who died last week, left his wife, Dorothy Levitt, an estate valued at between $250,000 and $500,000.
Gerald Long, managing director of Reuters, yesterday criticized a program proposed by Unesco to improve the press in the third world and proposed an alternative approach.

WARSAW, May 13--Leonid I. Brezhnev of the Suviet Union and the East European leaders arrived here today for a two-day conference of the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet blos military alliance, that is expected to produce what Polish Government sources described as an "initiative for detente."
THE heave traffic in revivals of musicals on Broadway shows no signs of letting up. "Camelot" and "The Music Man" are scheduled to open during the summer,
JOHANNESBURG, May 13 (Reuters) -The black Anglican dean of Johannesburg was charged today with living illegally in an area reserved for whites.
ANOTHER small drop in the price of food for New Yorkers brought the average weekly cost of feeding a family of four in this area to $94.03.

When the early Puerto Ricans arrived in New York after World War II, they were nicknamed "Marine Tigers," after the steamship that brought them to the pier at Red Hook in Brooklyn. Today's Hispanic newcomers are more likely to step off a jet at Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)-- RosaIvnn Carter received the Alice Paul Award today from the National Women's. Party. The award was presented in recognition of Mrs. Carter's efforts to obtain ratification of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution ...
We hate red tape as much as anyone, but there's a battle going on now in Washington that, in the deepest national interest, the regulators should win.

WASHINGTON, May 13-Confronted with the imminent expiration of funds for food stamps, Senate budget conferees today sought to hold the 1980 food stamp program hostage in order to gain increases in 1981 military spending that the House is reluctant to grant.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP)-The Noose Banking Committee reversed itself today and rejected President Carter's plea to expand the Council on Wage and Price Stability, the Government's chief anti-inflation agency.

This is the story of a street that never existed, except in the minds of puliticians and on the maps of city agencies. No one ever lived on Verrazano Street, and even the sharpest New York cab driver would not know where to go if a fare asked to be taken there.
ADAPTATIONS of classics are often based on a simple transfer in period; costumes and accents change, but almost everything else remains the same.

The House of Saud is ashamed of itself, and, according to the precepts under which it rules, with good reason. The traditional and religious values, which this royal, tribal family is meant to protect, have been questioned ...

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday a one-way standby fare of $125 on 747 flights between New York and San Francisco and New York and Los Angeles. The fare is $10 lower than the line's previous standby fare on the routes.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (UPI)--The House Banking Committee voted some relief today for the sagging home-building industry by approving a package of programs to spur construction and subsidize mortgage interest rates.

The dispute between Albert Shanker, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, and Frank Macchiarola, the Chancellor of the New York City schools, over whether a pension may be denied to a teacher charged with child pornography has tended to obscure the central issue: What is a pension?
A small Utah oil company has just paid New York City $260,000--a bonus the city is getting for burning garbage instead of oil for some of its energy.
It should have rained. It had rained just about every other time Mike Griffin pitched or tried to pitch, and he and the Yankees sure could have used rain last night.

ORINDA, Calif.-Fifty-five million heads of iceberg lettuce from California were unloaded in New York City during the Northeastern growing season in 1978, according to the latest figures from the Department of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, May 13 (AP) -- The United States International Trade Commission decided today that the domestic color television industry would not be injured if import restrictions against Japanese sets were lifted.
The city will make its initial economic offer today to two bargaining coalitions representing 242,000 municipal employees, Bruce C. Mclver, municipal labor relations director, said yesterday.

MARIEL, Cuba, May 13-The security official remembered Rolando Martim. Mr. Martim had come here from Houston to bring back relatives and the official was handling the case. Across a desk in a makeshift office, the Cuban remembered that Mr. Martim had once fought alongside ...
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 13Princeton clinched its third consecutive Eastern Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women tennis championship today with a 5-2 victory over Penn State.

CINCINNATI, May 13--Manager Joe Torre of the cellar-dwelling Mets, who has had ample reason to be comforted by the high quality of his team's pitching in recent games, watched in anguish tonight as he saw the Cincinnati Reds bombard his hurling corps for a 15-to-4 victory.
JERUSALEM, May 13--Nearly all Arab merchants in the Old City of Jerusalem opened their shops today despite calls from a radical Palestinian group to continue a general strike.
The National Academy of Design, Fifth Avenue at 89th Street, is honoring the career of the architect Mott B. Schmidt, who died three years ago, ...
Reno Sweeney, the intimate Greenwich Village supper club that opened in 1973 and successfully evoked memories of the past, is now itself a part of the past. Last Sunday night it closed.

DUBLIN. Ga., May 13--Marines in dress blue and old men in American Legion caps solemnly saluted today as taps was sounded and Staff Sgt. Dewey L. Johnson was lowered into the sandy loam of south Georgia.
The Federal Reserve Board yesterday authorized Southwest Bancshares Inc.

In the most decisive step toward initiating a prize-money circuit fur road racing, a proposal outlining a series of sanctioned events for next fall and spring, some offering as much as $100,000, will be presented shortly to the Athletics Congress.

After a lethargic start, the stock market gathered momentum yesterday to score a broad advance. Some typically stylish ingredients--prospects of a large natural gas find and a new takeover possibility -- sent prices higher on expanded volume.

IT is so natural to think of the School of American Ballet's annual workshops-performances, really--as miniature versions of New York City Ballet programs that any thrust into a different style of dancing comes as a small shock.

BRUSSELS, May 13--Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie began his first overseas mission today by reminding the Western allies that the United States had "the right to expect" that they would carry out their pledge to impose comprehensive economic sanctions against Iran.

MIAMI, May 13--The more dramatic flight of the thousands of people leaving Cuba has all but obscured the strains that a persistent flow of refugees from Haiti has placed on Miami and other south Florida communities since the exodus from that impoverished Caribbean nation began eight years ago as a trickle.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Representative Robert Giaimo, Democrat of Connecticut, is undergoing tests at the Alexandria (Vs.) Hospital after being admitted last night complaining of stomach pains. His condition today was listed as good.

CROSSMAGLEN. Northern Ireland, May 13 (AP) -- Policemen and soldiers discovered the body of a Roman Catholic factory worker today whom Irish Republican Army guerrilias said they had killed because he betrayed them.

EACH year they come trooping into town with the gadgets they have invented, new things that they believe will ease at least one of life's burdens, change at least one traditional way of doing things, perhaps light up the sky with revelation.

Lee F. Laster has been named to head the New York field office of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the nation's busiest and the only one whose chief holds the title of assistant director of the bureau.

PARIS, May 13--The streets of Paris are changing. There will be new kiosks, new billboard columns and, above all, new vespasiennes.

BOYNE CITY, MICH. HUNTERS in quest of an elusive prey began arriving here last week, causing minor traffic jams and a shortage of coconut cream pie at Betty's Good Food Restau rant. They came for the annual mushroom festival, for this city in northern Michigan considers itself the morel capital of the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, May 13--Denis Potvin's overtime goal, his second of the game, proved the difference tonight as the New York Islanders defeated thr Philadelphia Flyers, 4-3, in the first game of their National Hockey League championship series.

HARTFORD, May 13-- Connecticut Democrats, averting a major clash between supporters of President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, elected a divided leadership tonight for the state's delegation to the Democratic National Convention.

The Loews Corporation, a major operator of hotels and movie theaters and a leading manufacturer of cigarettes through its Lorillard division, reported yesterday that its earnings in the first quarter of this year fell 16.8 percent while revenues climbed 15.6 percent.

DENVILLE, N.J., May 13--Kelley Moser of Shorehaven, combining a strong game off the fairway with steady putting over the Rockaway River Country Club course. shot a sixunder-par 66 today and took the firstround lead in the 17th annual Dodge open golf tournament.

President Carter and Ronald Reagan won the Maryland and Nebraska primaries yesterday, pushing their persistent rivals even further from any realistic hope of overtaking them for the Presidential nominations.

BOSTON--In March the gossip was going from training camp to training camp the way Paul Reveres message had spread throughout New England. Instead of "the Redcoats are coming," the message was that Carlton Fisk's arm couldn't drop a tea bag into the harbor.
PEKING, May 13--For several hours a week over the last few months, factories, offices and schools throughout China have stopped work to debate an emotionally charged subject.

ALBANY, May 13--Governor Carey, who hod promised to hold New York City's bus and subway fares at 50 cents through 1981, said today that the plan he had sent to the Legislature would hold the fares only until next spring.

WASHINGTON, May 13--Recently, a few days after he approved a letter to Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. that had been submitted by one of his Cabinet secretaries, President Carter got a second draft of the same letter, this one submitted by his own staff.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 13--A Venezuelan tax court ruled yesterday that two American oil companies, Exxon and Mobil, owe the Venezuelan Government more than $238 million in back taxes for business conducted here in the early 1970's.
Baron Philippe de Rothschild owns three Bordeaux vineyards --Chateau Mouton Rothschild. Chateau Clerc-Milon and Chateau Mouton-Baronne-Pauline.

CHATTANOOGA. Tenn., May 13 (AP) -- The Chattanooga Times said today that it was consolidating some of its operation's, including full mechanical production, with The Chattanooga NewsFree Press.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 13--The Los Angeles Lakers announced tonight that Jack McKinney would not return as head coach next season, but left open the question of whether the interim coach, Paul Westhead, would be rehired.

The credit markets rebounded yesterday afternoon in response to the Federal Reserve's purchase of Treasury notes and bonds, an action that reduced dealers' inventories of securities and pushed interest rates lower.

BRUSSELS, May 13--The defense ministers of the Atlantic alliance agreed today on quick, if limited, measures to strengthen defenses in view of a "high risk" period in the wake of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan.

Elliott Arnold, author of more than 25 novels and other books on such themes as the Western Indian frontier and World War II confrontations, died yesterday after a brief illness in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 67 years old and had homes at 151 East 83d Street and in Tucson, Ariz., and Beverly Hills, Calif.

STOCKHOLAM, May 13--Sweden's 10 days of total industrial standstill have quickened a debate here over whether a country admired for its social innovations can now deliberately program longterm decreases in wages and living standards in order to meet new economic conditions.
Michele Sindona, the Italian financier who was convicted of fraud, slashed his left wrist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan early yesterday.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, May 13 ( Reuters) -- Cuba abruptly suspended talks today on the sinking by its planes of a Royal Bahamas Defense Force vessel and the resulting deaths of four men aboard, charging that the incident was instigated by the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

Leonard B. Sang, a theatrical house manager for more than 50 years who worked principally for the Shubert Organization, died Sunday in New York Hospital of a cardiac arrest. He was 79 years old and lived at 235 West End Avenue.

J. Trevor Eyton, president of Brascan Ltd., told the annual meeting in Toronto that the company had over $1 billion "on hand" for appropriate investment opportunities and expects "substantial progress with its investment program in 1980."

Acting on a tip, New York State officials searched a major chemical waste site near Niagara Falls yesterday for a spot where an informant said highly explosive nitroglycerine was illegally buried in 1977.

The National Association of Purchasing Management announced yesterday that, according to a survey of corporate purchasing managers, the United States economy has been dropping "like a rock" in May.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) A compromise bill restricting the powers of the Federal Trade Commission and increasing Congressional control over the independent regulatory agency passed the Senate today and was sent to President Carter. The vote was 74 to 15.

Financial instrument futures continued to dominate the commodity markets yesterday as prices again advanced in heavy trading volume. Buyers were once again motivated by signals pointing to an easing of interest rates and thus sought to take advantage of existing yields.

Indiana Standard has a 50 percent interest in the well.

ALBANY, May 30--Manhattan's "reform" Democrats, the Bronx's "regular" Democrats, and Republicans joined forces long enough this week to split the judicial district that comprises the two boroughs, making them independent of each other in nominating justices for the State Supreme Court.

Pope John Paul II met privately for 45 minutes today with President Valery Giscard d'Estaing and reportedly told the French leader that he endorsed his recent summit meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

Franz Allers was in town, rehearsing the Lerner-Loewe ''Camelot,'' which opens at the New York State Theater on July 8, and it seemed a good time to talk to the conductor who had been in the pit for so many of the Lerner-Loewe successes: ''Brigadoon,'' ''Paint Your Wagon'' and ''My Fair Lady'' in addition to ''Camelot.'' The point about Mr. Allers is that he was a classically-trained musician before associating himself with Broadway; and in recent years he has gone back to his first loves, symphony and opera. At the Metropolitan Opera he has conducted ''Die Fledermaus,'' ''Hansel and Gretel'' and ''Der Rosenkavalier.'' In Europe and America he has been active as an all-around conductor who also knows more than anybody about what goes on in the Broadway pit. Thus he is in a unique position to talk about the Broadway musical stage and where it stands in the entire complex of music.

It takes a lot of guts to try to rehabilitate a classical opening variation that has been judged inferior by generation after generation of leading theorists. Yet Jon Arnason, an Icelandic international master, risked the old Sicilian counterattack against John Peters, an American international master, in the seventh round of the Manhattan Chess Club International Tournament. The key move of this defense, 5 ... B-N5, invites White to seize terrain in the center with 6 P-K5 so that Black may bring about doubled pawns after 6 ... N-Q4; 7 B-Q2, NxN; 8 PxN. The burden - most players consider it a joy - is on White to win by direct attack on the king before his weaknesses can be exploited in an ending.

The Commerce Department made it official last week, but neither Congress nor the White House needed the marker to tell the tide. Even before the report of the record 4.8 percent drop in April's Composite Index of Leading Indicators - a measure designed to forecast future economic trends - recessionary fears and politics fractured the fragile budgetbalancing alliance between Congress and the White House. Also badly bruised was the budgetmaking process itself. Following the example of the five Representatives who refused to go along with their fellow budget conferees two weeks ago - and egged on by President Carter and a pleased House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., who has been uncomfortable with Mr. Carter's curtailment of traditional Democratic programs - enough House Democrats defected, to reject, 242 to 141, a precariously balanced $613.3 billion budget. Their stated reason: It increased social spending by less than the rate of inflation while giving the military 5.2 percent more than inflation would warrant.

by Roger W. Straus Jr., by Stephen Jay Gould Roger Straus To the Editor: I had planned not to answer the letter from Arthur Orrmont that appeared in your Letters column on May 18th, for as my old grandmother used to say to me: ''Never complain, never explain.'' But a number of my confreres did not like Mr. Orrmont's letter because of its many inaccuracies, and urged that I do something about it.

ALL the clutter that is modern Nassau County was, in the 18th century, the East Meadow, a vast grazing pasture, and there were congregations but there were no churches. Circuit-riding preachers, among them Ezckiel Cooper, got off their horses at villages in the Meadow, their Bibles in their saddlebags, and preached. Cooper, a Methodist, was the first such circuit rider to visit Bethel, Sodom, Pine Mill, Milburn Corner, Hicks Neck, Lotts Landing, Hempstead South and the Baldwins and Baldwinsville. All of those colonial communities are now Baldwin, the unincorporated village of more than 32,000 people that stretches south from Hempstead and the Southern State Parkway to Freeport Bay.

MIDDLETOWN LAST Apr. 4, a 20-year-old woman student at Wesleyan University walked into a campus fraternity house at 4 A.M. and was confronted and then grabbed by two fraternity men, who picked her up, spun her around and kissed her. Badly frightened, she ran from the house. A decade ago such an episode might have passed without much notice or comment, but the incident at the Chi Psi fraternity house has aroused a bitter controversy at the small liberal arts college.

A WISE professor once said that 75 percent of the problems associated with plants occurred within the soil. To the gardener who spends most of his time fending off attacks by aphids, mites and leaf blights, this may seem to be a strange statement. Yet, considering that the roots typically make up half the volume of a plant and that they are usually obscured from view by the soil, the statement takes on credibility. To some degree, most of us are aware of those soil-borne problems caused by insects, diseases, nutrient deficiencies and lack of water. Garden centers are piled high with bags of soil insecticides and fungicides, fertilizers and irrigation equipment. Much less understood is the problem of water and air relationships within the soil.

Within hours of the formation of a 25-member committee to advise the civilian Government of South Korea, the Martial Law Command reopened communications today with the rebellious city of Kwangju. With the resumption of traffic, residents of the capital got their first accounts from witnesses of the rebellion in which students took control of the city of 800,000 for four days. The army reimposed Government control Tuesday.

The marriage of Mary Jo Ruben and David Jonathan Reich, graduates of the University of Pennsylvania Law School, took place at Temple Israel Synagogue in Norfolk, Va., yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Goldman performed the ceremony. Debbie Isaacson was matron of honor for her sister. They are the daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ruben of Norfolk, where their father is president of the Old Dominion Oil Company, a home-heating fuel distributor.

It is almost seven years since the United States Customs Service moved out of the Old Custom House at Bowling Green to new offices in the World Trade Center. Since then, a reuse for the old building has been sought. For those who are familiar with this distinguished New York landmark and have followed its fortunes, we offer a progress report. For those who do not know it, we recommend a trip to the Battery on one of these fine days to see this turn-of-the-century Beaux Arts monument in which everything that is not classical is nautical, and no expense or effort was spared for design, structure or embellishment. The good news is that the Federal Government, which owns the building, has decided to restore and remodel it for Federal offices. This sensible and desirable action is in line with a policy established in recent years by the General Services Administration, the agency in charge of all Federal construction and properties. This policy gives a higher priority to the reuse of the Government's older, and often superior structures for its own space needs than to renting commercially or building anew.

Kennedy By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. SAN FRANCISCO - President Carter seems certain to come out of the final round of Democratic primaries on Tuesday with more than enough delegates to claim renomination. He is already pointing his campaign toward the fall and an all-out battle with former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Representative John B. Anderson, the Illinois Republican running as an independent. So where does that leave Senator Edward M. Kennedy? He has been chasing in vain after the President for seven wearying months. Hardly anyone gives him a chance of winning the nomination. A clamor is building for him to get out of the race before the Democratic Party becomes disastrously divided.

As the industry axiom goes, the best advertisement for a film is a long line. And ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' currently showing in 126 American cities, has had no shortage of those. ''Empire,'' the sequel to ''Star Wars,'' has grossed George Lucas's company, Lucas Films, nearly $10 million in its first week, 60 percent above the first week's receipts for ''Star Wars.'' Of ''Empire's'' debut, Peter Meyers, senior vice president for domestic distribution at 20th Century-Fox, said, ''We had people lining up days in advance, sleeping on the street before it opened.''

LOS ANGELES FASCINATED most by the discussions and maneuvering by National Basketball Association coaches, general managers and trainers at the league meetings last week was Paul Silas, the new coach of the San Diego Clippers. During his 16 seasons as a player, six of which he served as president of the National Basketball Players Association, Silas was aware of the annual meetings, but he showed little interest in them unless they involved the players.

by Lloyd L. Brown To the Editor: It has been observed that we Americans whose forebears were involuntary ''boat people'' from Africa have been especially hard hit by the Carter-promoted recession, but little notice has been taken of the fact that Carter's boycott of the Moscow Olympics has denied black Americans their quadrennial morale-building pride in seeing members of their group as not last and least but often first and foremost.

Leslie Sewall of Plymouth, Mass., won the 52.0-kilogram (114-pound) title in the national Amateur Athletic Union weight-lifting championships today with a total lift of 182.5 kilograms. The event was the final Olympic qualifier. Miss Sewall, the lightest lifter in the competition at 50.9 kilograms, had a snatch of 82.5 kilograms and a clean and jerk of 100.

by Jeff Greenfield JOHN D. The Founding Father of the Rockefellers. By David Freeman Hawke. Illustrated. 260 pp. Harper & Row. $12.95. In his day, John D. Rockefeller was the wealthiest and perhaps the most despised man in America. His Standard Oil Trust was seen as the epitome of capitalism run amok. State legislatures and the United States Congress sought to break up his empire, and his own brother Franklin denounced his ''heartless villainy'' (though John D. supported Franklin throughout his life).

FOR its first exhibition in the converted school building that is the lustrous new Town Hall here, the Westport/Weston Arts Council is sponsoring a show of mildly avant-garde ''environmental'' work called ''Spatiality/Six Sculptors.'' With it comes a new policy, an attempt, in the words of a council press release, ''to establish an important art center'' by bringing in work by nonlocal artists that displays ''challenging new esthetic concepts.'' How the community takes to all this novelty will be interesting to know. The show was assembled by Carlus Dyer, an artist and former director of the Aldrich Museum in Ridgefield. His choices are an apt response to the council's exhibition space, a former gymnasium. This big room's brick walls make painting shows impractical, but its proportions are fine for the kind of semiarchitectural work that engages a lot of sculptors these days.

The Israeli Ambassador to Egypt, Eliahu Ben-Elissar, took a long walk through downtown Cairo today to deliver a message to President Anwar el-Sadat and to explain why Prime Minister Menachem Begin reportedly threatened that he might delay Israel's final withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula. Mr. Begin was quoted as saying during a parliamentary briefing yesterday that Israel would not give up the final third of the Sinai Peninsula in April 1982 as scheduled ''unless Egypt subscribes to a multinational force agreement'' to police their common border.

by D. E. Steward To the Editor: A paragraph in Jon Nordheimer's analysis from Miami (May 23) well answers questions about what lies behind the riots there.f in recent years Miami Beach was indeed able to enforce a de facto apartheid policy by not allowing blacks to visit from the other side of the bay after dark, causes for Miami's tragedy are all too clear.

Mr. and Mrs. John Benson of Woodbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan B. Benson, to David B. Turnbull, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Turnbull of Old Lyme, Conn. The wedding is planned for Aug. 16. Miss Benson, an alumna of the Kent School and Colby College, is registrar of the Boston Center for Adult Education. Her fiance, a graduate of Colby and the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, is a financial analyst with the General Motors Corporation in New York.

BECAUSE of the exigencies of reputation and publication, most of the comparatively small number of postwar Japanese novelists whose work has appeared in English have seen their books come before the foreign public in the wrong chronological order, done by a variety of translators (good, bad and indifferent), and with a consequent muddle about how these authors should be ranked and how they may have developed.

Clark was the third player chosen, by the Green Bay Packers, in this year's draft and the first of the defensive linemen.

Deborah Dorothy O'Connor, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. O'Connor of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Sean Callahan, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Callahan of Whitefish Bay, Wis. The Rev. William Reynolds performed the ceremony in St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont, N.Y. The bride and her husband are graduates of the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee. An alumna also of Bradford Junior College, the bride is creative director with Kaminsky Associates, an advertising agency in Milwaukee, where Mr. Callahan is an assistant editor of the Post Newspapers and editor of The Pro-Report-Milwaukee Bucks. He attended Xavier University.

Every country with an operatic tradition has a few national favorites that haven't been accepted elsewhere. Among the Germans, about the best example of that phenomenon is Albert Lortzing. Lortzing's operas, or at least four of them, appear with considerable frequency to this day on German opera stages big and small. In provincial companies unknown singers take on these parts. But the operas crop up at the major houses, too, and nearly every singer with experience in Germany has these roles in his repertory. In this country, the occasional arcane stage revival does make it impossible to say that Lortzing is never performed here. But the major companies don't bother with him, and it has been left to the record companies and importers to provide the American public with some contact with his music. As far as domestic releases are concerned, this has meant ''Zar und Zimmermann'' plus an occasional highlights disk, and a new ''Zar'' has now appeared on CBS Masterworks. But the basic imported versions of ''Der Wildschutz,'' ''Undine,'' ''Der Waffenschmied'' and ''Die Opernprobe'' have remained available despite shifts in the firms doing the importing and in the label designations and catalogue numbers.

Dark Elegies,'' which American Ballet Theater has revived this season after several years, is very likely Antony Tudor's greatest work. This is not an opinion to which all will subscribe as the British-born choreographer's early reputation was more overtly linked to ballets such as ''Jardin aux Lilas'' (1936) and ''Pillar of Fire''(1942). It was Mr. Tudor's gift for making specific characters reveal their emotions on the ballet stage in these works that captured the attention. Inner feelings and psychological dance-drama were generally not considered classical ballet's preserve. Mr. Tudor was hailed rightly as an innovator. ''Dark Elegies'', unlike these ballets, has no narrative in the strict sense nor does it have characters with names attached. Its own innovative aspects have been subject to debate - it was created by Ballet Rambert in London in 1937 -chiefly because its admirers have sought to find its roots elsewhere. British critics have seen it in the direct line of Michel Fokine's ''Les Sylphides'' or Leonide Massine's ''Choreartium.'' This is a formal link. All these works are plotless and ''Dark Elegies'' may be said, in this line of reasoning, to be chiefly an evocation of the music - not along Balanchinian lines but as a so-called abstraction of a single emotion or a mood.

THE CYBERNETIC IMAGINATION IN SCIENCE FICTION By Patricia S. Warrick. 282 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $15. CRACKS on the viewscreen, noise in the sentence-forming circuitry, thumbprints on the rear-view mirror: will we make it through interstellar dark to wherever she said we were going? Barely lifting off - 14 words into the first sentence on page 1 - we incur initial doubts about our captain: a professor of English unsure about ''may'' vs. ''might.'' On page 9 we hear her chattering on the intercom about ''the Greek word kybernetic,'' which (a) doesn't exist and (b) if it did exist would be too much like an adjective to mean ''steersman,'' a noun.

THE monitoring team assigned to the Trenton schools by Dr. Fred G. Burke, the state's Commissioner of Education, to help the troubled system is no longer just helping. It's now giving orders. Dr. Anthony R. Catrambone, retired Superintendent of Schools in Camden, was appointed ''monitor general'' eight months ago. His task was to encourage the Trenton Board of Education to correct problems that it had failed to address after coaxing and threats of aid cuts by state education officials. In addition to a declining quality of education, state officials had charged that the local board was spending Federal funds illegally, violating the rights of Hispanic and handicapped children, interfering with school administration and keeping records in such a way as to ''conceal, confuse and obfuscate the actual transaction of business.''

A POLITICALLY influential Hicksville insurance agency that handles much of the insurance for Nassau County and the Towns of Hempstead and Oyster Bay has provided a rare glimpse of the extent - and the lucrative proceeds - of municipal insurance. The agency, Richard B. Williams and Son Inc., which has been closely linked to the Nassau Republican organization for many years, disclosed its government business after the State Investigation Commission spotlighted the practice of insurance agencies' sharing commissions with politicians designated not by the insurance agency but by party leaders.

Patricia Marjorie O'Brien and Christopher Raymond Lynch were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Fatima in New London, N.H. The Rev. Timothy E. O'Connell, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Aloysius O'Brien Jr. of New London. Mr. Lynch is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Franklin Lynch of Hanover, N.H., formerly of Westport, Conn.

Something about Hal Linden seems to inspire confidence. Perhaps it is his direct and level gaze or his rich speaking voice that belongs as much to the singer as to the actor. Whatever it is, it is an integral part of the persona of an actor who is currently making a career out of being a television authority figure: the squad captain on the long-running situation-comedy ''Barney Miller,'' the narrator of ABC-TV's educational children's show ''Animals, Animals'' and the ''star'' of ''FYI,'' the quick-as-a-commercial self-help spots that ABC runs between its afternoon soap operas. This quality seems to work particularly well on television, and although Mr. Linden has spent most of his professional life on the musical stage, it is the small screen that has brought him fame. Now he is attempting to consolidate the singing and dancing that brought him to Broadway with the television career that has made him a star and the city where he was born and raised in ''Hal Linden's Big Apple,'' his second special, which ABC will present this evening at 8. In it the Bronx native is seen dancing and singing all around town, from the Fulton Fish Market to Kennedy Airport, from Madison Avenue to Times Square, and sharing comedy routines with Shecky Greene and Robert Guillaume and doing a production number backed up by the Radio City Music Hall Rockettes.
Headliners Silken Lining

The field for the 11th New York City Marathon, on Oct. 26, has been increased from 14,000 to 15,000. New York Road Runners Club race officials said they would begin accepting requests for entries postmarked no earlier than midnight Tuesday. No requests for entries will be accepted in person or over the phone. They must be sent with a stamped, self-addressed legal size envelope to New York City Marathon Entries, P.O. Box 1388, G.P.O., New York, N.Y. 10001.

MAINSTREAM jazz is alive in several restaurants and lounges in Westchester, to the particular enjoyment of those who would rather spend their evenings on the town near their homes rather than journey to Manhattan and back. That reasoning, in reverse, encourages some of the cluster of musicians who live in Westchester to stay and play in the county, rather than in New York. One of the liveliest of these is the 82-year-old pianist and singer, Bob Howard, who lives in the upper Bronx and holds forth each Friday and Saturday night from 9 o'clock until 2:30 A.M. in Ye Ole Pub, 56 Pondfield Road, Bronxville.

An Alexandria District Court judge ruled yesterday that the June issue of Penthouse magazine was obscene. Citing a photo layout of two women engaged in various forms of sexual conduct, Judge Guy Humphries said the magazine violated the community standards of Rapides Parish. David Robertson, a lawyer for Penthouse, said the magazine would appeal to the Louisiana Supreme Court.

Governor Byrne said yesterday that he planned to nominate Assistant Attorney General G. Michael Brown to be director of the Division of Gaming Enforcement. Governor Byrne said he would seek to have the nomination confirmed by the Senate before it adjourns for the summer. Mr. Brown, who is 37 years old, would replace Robert P. Martinez, who is resigning at the end of June to practice law.

Mark Fidrych pitched six innings, his longest stint of the season, as the Evansville Triplets beat the Indianapolis Indians, 4-3, in an American Association game last night. The Indians' leadoff man, Doyle Blake, got a double off Fidrych to set up the Indians' first run. But that was the only run Fidrych gave up all night. The former American League rookie of the year with the Detroit Tigers settled down to pitch shutout ball for the rest of the night until Paul Householder opened the seventh inning with a single.

A Congressional study released today contended that military pay must be increased at a total cost of $5 billion to $8.6 billion over the next five years to recruit and retain enough skilled manpower for the armed forces. The Congressional Budget Office, which does fiscal research and analysis for Congress, asserted that the Carter Administration's current proposals for military pay were inadequate and would leave the services about 15 percent short of manpower by 1985.

Ilene Joy Weinman and Daniel Ritchey Cohen were married yesterday at the Covington, La., home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Albert Harry Cohen. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Weinman of Surfside, Fla. Justice of the Peace Shirley Gottschaick of Folsom, La., performed the ceremony. The bride, a landman with the Amoco Production Company (Standard Oil of Indiana) in New Orleans, where her husband is a staff geophysicist with Amoco. She graduated cum laude from Sophie Newcomb College of Tulane University, studied art and Spanish at the University of Madrid and received an M.B.A. at Tulane, where Mr. Cohen is completing requirements for his M.B.A. The bride's father is an investor.

Juan Carlos Harriott, the Argentine team captain, scored four goals as the South American squad defeated the United States national polo team, 10-6, today at the Retama Polo Center to clinch its sixth consecutive Cup of the Americas championship. Argentina won the first game in the two-of-three-match series on May 24 by a score of 11-8. The matches marked the first time the series had been played in the United States since 1936.

IBADE New Jersey one final mental adieu as we sped along the highway en route to John F. Kennedy International Airport, where I was to board an 8 A.M. flight to Paris. I would be leaving New Jersey behind for a full year. During the six-hour flight, somewhere between my fantasies of endless baguettes and wine picnics on the steps of the Sacre Coeur and being wined and dined at Maxim's, I started to feel some apprehension at the thought of explaining to a foreigner where I was from.

Roderick, chairman of the board of the United States Steel Corporation, and Mrs. Roderick of Pittsburgh, to Thruston Ballard Morton 3d took place in Pittsburgh yesterday. Management Science America Inc., a private computer service, has leased the entire fourth floor of the six-story Fort Lee Executive Park building. The five-year lease for 36,500 square feet of office space has an aggregate rent of more than $2.5 million. In July the company will move its Northeast regional office from Englewood Cliffs to the new 240,000-square-foot building, which is now 95 percent rented. The move will quadruple the company's space.

ACTS OF UNION Reports on Ireland, 1973-79. By Anthony Bailey. 211 pp. New York: Random House. $8.95. ''FAMILIAR from a dream, perhaps,'' Anthony Bailey writes of the look of Belfast in 1973, ''or from a film of an occupied town in Europe, 1944.'' The details, as they accumulate in this collection of essays, have the grainy familiarity of newsreel - blitzed sites covered with rubble, slum windows sealed tight with cinder blocks, burned-out factories and pubs, weeds sprouting through the shattered concrete of an abandoned filling station, an army observation post shrouded by a gray-green camouflage net. But now, seven years later, we need not refer to the Second World War. Belfast has entered our museum of baleful contemporary dreamscapes, an image so powerfully simple that it expresses a truth deeper than all our efforts at explanation or understanding.

GLASTONBURY THIS year's crop of shade tobacco is growing fast in fields along the Connecticut and Farmington Rivers, the first step in an international process that will show up as next year's cigars. While the acreage planted under cloth netting has fallen 75 percent since 1965, the industry still employs thousands of teen-agers for the midsummer harvest. Growers expect to harvest over 2,000 acres this year in Portland, Glastonbury, East Windsor, Windsor, Bloomfield, Simsbury, Granby and Suffield, and several hundred more acres in southern Massachusetts. The crop is grown nowhere else in the United States, and is Connecticut's only significant agricultural export.

HER sails puffed with wind, the Modesty, a 36-foot sloop, pulled oyster dredges over the bottom of the Great South Bay when the famous bluepoint oyster was abundant and a major fishery on the Island. But the sloop last worked Long Island waters more than 40 years ago. Since that time, the boat has been used as a sailing yacht for owners on the Island and in Connecticut.

WHAT a pleasure it is to come across a family-run restaurant with hearty, honest home cooking. Louis Crecco is carrying on a tradition started by his father 32 years ago in an unpretentious building on a semi-residential street corner in the state capital. He keeps an eagle eye on the kitchen, maintains a marvelous wine cellar and personally watches over his patrons. Dozens of framed photographs lining the walls show the owners, senior and junior, with celebrities and sports figures, thus testifying to the restaurant's long-time popularity.

Can't you just hear the average guy who puts away a six-pack or two a day saying to his companion, ''Hey, Charlie, maybe we oughta go easy on the calcium disodium ethylenediaminetetraacetate, huh?'' ROBERT WARREN New York, May 28, 1980

Johns Hopkins of Baltimore, considered the Notre Dame of college lacrosse, proved again today that the estimation was correct. The Blue Jays, coached by Henry Ciccarone, won their third successive National Collegiate Division I championship by defeating Virginia, 9-8, in the second overtime period.

THE Factory Store of Church's English Shoes in Darien, the largest branch of the chain, serves a double purpose: the front is for retail shopping at normal prices; in back is the factory outlet, with unusual discounts for first-quality discontinued wares returned from the six other stores. Presale sales are held here regularly, too, with notification by mail. Church's handmade women's shoes are sold in the front shop alone, and not at any other branch in America. There are five styles at the moment, priced from $29.95 to $79.95, with 20 others to come later this year. There are 100 styles for men in sizes 6 through 13, AA to EEE. With leather uppers and soles, for the most part, and some with crepe soles, they are fully lined in leather in Church's 107-year-old tradition.

Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the former race horse trainer who was convicted in April of murdering a rival for the affections of a woman with whom he had formerly lived, escaped yesterday from the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men where he was waiting to be sentenced, the police reported. Last night, authorities said they were questioning a man who, representing himself as a lawyer, had visited Mr. Jacobson and stayed behind in the prison while Mr. Jacobson departed in his stead about 4:30 P.M.

For three nights beginning every May 21, a man now 70 years old dances barefoot across a huge bed of burning coals here, clutching icons of St. Constantine and St. Helen, as his mother did before him. The ancient ritual of firewalking, in which 20 other villagers, among them a 14-year-old girl, joined him, provides an unusual departure in the daily routine of Sotirios Liouris. He lives in a three-room stone hut and looks after nine cows, and like his mother before him he is the chief firewalker.

The New York City Opera will give three performances at Robin Hood Dell in Philadelphia, in advance of the regular season by the Philadelphia Orchestra. On June 9, Rossini's ''Il Barbiere di Siviglia'' will be sung, with Beverly Sills in the role of Rosina. Henry Price, Richard Fredricks, Spiro Malas and Donnie Ray Albert will also be in the cast, with William Fred Scott 3d as conductor. Johann Strauss's ''Die Fledermaus'' on June 10 will have Maralin Niska, Gianna Rolandi, Alan Titus, James Billings, Dominic Cossa, Jack Harrold, Gerald Grahame and Richard McKee as the singers. Imre Pallo will be the conductor. Verdi's ''La Traviata'' will complete the trio of performances June 11, with Diana Soviero, Rico Serbo and Brent Ellis in the leading roles. The conductor will be Andrew Meltzer.

The opposition Labor Party adopted a left-wing policy statement for Britain today at a special conference that was marked by denunciations of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and of American foreign policy. Delegates to the conference at the Wembley Conference Center in northwestern London adopted by an overwhelming vote a statement called ''Peace, Jobs, Freedom.'' It was approved in advance by the leaders of all segments of the party, including former Prime Minister James Callaghan, who wanted at all costs to avoid another destructive breach in party unity.

Edward Auer, who will present his fourth New York recital in as many years Tuesday night at the 92d St. Y, is a pianist with impressive credentials. From the age of 10 he studied with the celebrated pedagogue Aube Tzerko in Los Angeles, where he grew up and has mainly lived. As an undergraduate at Juilliard, he was a scholarship student of Rosina Lhevinne. After earning a Bachelor's degree, he was awarded a Fulbright grant to work with Julius Katchen in Paris. He won a prize in every international competition he entered, including the Chopin (fifth prize, 1965), the Tchaikovsky (fifth prize, 1966), and the Marguerite Long (first prize, 1967). He has played three times with the Los Angeles Philharmonic, and made five recordings. And yet, at 38, Mr. Auer remains an artist far better known to connoisseurs than to the public at large. Why, one wonders, didn't the big prizes lead to a bigger career? The question was put to the pianist some months ago in New York. ''There are three basic ways you could look at it,'' Mr. Auer replied. ''One is that it's a combination of circumstances - in other words, bad luck, or not as good luck as you would want. Or it's the type of artist that you are, that you're slightly more subtle, or a less splashy stage personality. Or it's that you're no damned good.''

WASHINGTON, May 31--Watching President Carter try to juggle all the contradictory foreign and domestic problems of the nation during a Presidential election and an economic recession, you have to wonder who can do it and who can govern America.

Of something like 250 candidates, four were chosen to guest conduct the Stamford Symphony during its recently completed season. Then the orchestra voted, the audience voted and the board voted. The same name came up every time, so Roger Nierenberg has become the orchestra's new music director. Since Mr. Nierenberg has stirred much attention and critical acclaim through his performances with the Pro Arte Chorale for the last five years, anticipation is high. ''The orchestra members kept referring to the inspirational quality he had for them,'' said Warren Dubin, president of the Stamford Symphony Society. ''In that one concert, he raised the players to a level of musicianship they never thought they could achieve, and they found it an intensely rewarding experience.''

Maple syrup production in New York State this year fell to 243,000 gallons, 23 percent below last year's crop, according to figures released today by the State Crop Reporting Service. ''It was one of the worst crops ever in terms of production,'' said Lloyd Sipple of Bainbridge, N.Y., a maple syrup farmer and editor of the Maple Syrup Digest. ''Our crop was way down, about two-thirds of an average year.''

Tommy Tune says he's not interested in credits, but it is generally agreed that he should get top billing for the new hit show ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine.'' The lanky 6-foot-6-inch-tall tap-dancing Texan choreographed and directed the revue, which combines a send-up of old Hollywood musicals with a slapstick Marx Brothers routine. The critics have hailed Mr. Tune for his remarkable achievement in evoking the lavish scale of Hollywood in its heyday with a cast of only six. Mel Gussow, for one, called him ''the toetapping Broadway heir to Busby Berkeley. What his predecessor did with 50 dancing girls and a sound stage, he can do, in cameo, with four feet.'' The first half of the show is set in the lobby of Grauman's Chinese Theater in Hollywood, with the cast dressed as ushers. Peggy Hewett sings to a Nelson Eddy made out of cardboard, Priscilla Lopez dances hysterically as a singer dreamily croons ''Sleepy Time Gal,'' and the cast plays ''Japanese Sandman'' on ukulele and chopsticks. But the piece de resistance takes place on a sliver of a stage overhead, where two dancers, Niki Harris and Albert Stephenson dance, with only their feet showing, like puppets dangling on strings. In ''Famous Feet'' the dancers impersonate Judy Garland, Charlie Chaplin, Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers, Minnie and Mickey Mouse, in what Mr. Gussow termed ''a small miracle of theatrical inventiveness.''

A very old bone is the driest thing there is. In any competition for the wettest thing there is, on the other hand, the bed of the ocean would be a strong candidate, so vivid in our imaginations is its drenched to-and-fro and ever-changing configuration. Both the very old bone and the bed of the ocean are pressed into service by Nancy Graves in the exhibition of her work of the last 11 years that is now on view (through June 15) at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo. If we add to the list of Miss Graves's primary resources some carved objects from paleolithic times, the trajectory of a jumping frog as it was recorded by a camera in 1971, and a record of the signs that were exchanged between an American Indian and a white American Army officer during the ferrying of 16 camels across the Colorado River in 1858, it will be clear that Nancy Graves is an artist who looks far and wide for her raw material and regards no given image as essentially alien.

METUCHEN ''THE kids are great,'' said Noreen Szidbat, director of physical activity at the Metuchen-Edison Y.M.C.A. ''The team breezed through the competition.'' Like any swimming team, the one at the ''Y'' here leans heavily on its coaches. But unlike other team swimmers, each of those at the ''Y'' has his own coach - a one-to-one system.

A SOUTHERN RENAISSANCE The Cultural Awakening of the American South, 1930-1955. By Richard H. King. 350 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $15.95. RICHARD H. KING, a Southerner and professor of history and philosophy, began his scholarly career in 1972 with a book called ''The Party of Eros,'' which dealt with interpretations of Sigmund Freud's thought by Paul Goodman, Herbert Marcuse and Norman O. Brown. He now undertakes a much broader subject, the cultural history of the South from the 1930's to the 50's, when the region experienced an extraordinary outburst of creative energy.
WASHINGTON States News Service

NEW HAVEN IT hasn't been an easy season for subscribers to the Long Wharf Theater. First, performances of ''Mary Barnes'' were lost when flu struck the acting company. Then ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' didn't complete its run because Mike Nichols came down with pneumonia. But, as Shakespeare put it, ''All's well that ends well,'' and the final effort of the Long Wharf season is a gem. It is ''Cyrano de Bergerac'' by Edmond Rostand, and the production is a beauty. There is a tendency to think of ''Cyrano'' as much older than it actually is. Though set in 17th-century France - that time of plumed hats and capes, and duels on almost any occasion - the play was first presented in 1897.

Buffeted by the occasional corporate bankruptcy, ignored when management turns down takeover proposals that could mean major stock profits, and often snubbed by executives in various forums, small shareholders tend to suffer from a feeling of impotence. And they got another object lesson in frustration at the annual meeting last week of the First Pennsylvania Corporation, owner of the First Pennsylvania Bank. In April, it had been disclosed that First Penn, the largest banking organization in Philadelphia and the 23d-largest in the country, was on the brink of failure and that regulators and a group of major banks had agreed on a rescue plan. The bank postponed the shareholders meeting for a month, explaining that it wanted to give voters a chance to study the plan.

Bucking stormy seas and strong headwinds in the North Atlantic, several American solo sailors still struggled last week to reach Plymouth, England, for the start next Saturday of the Observer Singlehanded Trans-Atlantic race. The 3,000-mile race to Newport, R.I., is considered one of the most rugged of sporting events.

Cancun to Chichen Itza To the Editor: In regard to Steven V. Roberts's article, ''Tour of Mexico's Yucatan and the Cities of the Mayas'' (Travel Section, May 11), those with a limited amount of time might like to know they can make the trip to Chichen Itza and Merida in one day from Cancun. If two couples share the driving, the ride can be quite pleasant. Leave Cancun at 8:30 in the morning, driving west towards Chichen. Stop in Valladolid for a rest and a bite. Continue on to Chichen and spend several hours there. Then on to Merida with several hours to spare before the sound-and-light show in English in Uxmal (about a half-hour south of Merida).

The Lebanon Correctional Institution, a large, medium-security state prison for first offenders, sits on a hill like a flattened castle, dominating the countryside for miles around. Inside its brick walls are 2,000 young men who went wrong in Cincinnati, Dayton or Columbus, most of them housed in pairs in cells designed for one. The warden, William H. Dallman, runs the prison by a book, a large loose-leaf one filled with rules and regulations. The book was written by the Federal courts, and every time there is a new decision anywhere he dutifully notes it.

Stefan Lord captured the world darts championship title for the second time today, beating Dave Whitcombe of England, 2-0, in the final at Wembley. Whitcombe, who had defeated Rick Ney of the United States and Pat Kiely of Ireland, both by 2-0 scores, on his way to the final, matched Lord dart for dart in the first leg before the Swede took advantage of having first dart with both needing double-top.

AS a year-round weekend resident on the South Shore for the last seven years, I have come to realize that it is the element of surprise that keeps luring me back. Oh, certainly, there's the beauty of the scene, the snug cottage, the abundance of wildlife, the glory of sea and sky. But it is really the endless anticipation, the challenge of trying to guess what new surprise awaits me out there at the cottage, that really sets my blood afire and hastens my steps through the massed hysteria of Penn Station.
