MARY SMITH can recall the many times when, as a child, she was kept home from school to look after the younger children in her family. Later, as a mother of four, she agonized over what she believed to be the inadequacy of the care her children received while she was working to support them. Ten years ago, determined to do what she could to see to it that other city children did not suffer the same fate, Miss Smith became one of the founding mothers of Babyland, the first infant day-care center serving the Newark-Elizabeth area.

Ronald Reagan will meet with Gerald R. Ford at Mr. Ford's home in Rancho Mirage, Calif., on Thursday to discuss the former President's role in the general election campaign, officials of Mr. Reagan's campaign said today.

THE black bass, whether smallmouth or largemouth, is a neglected game fish throughout most of New Hampshire. The reason is imbedded in custom. Resident New Hampshire anglers have traditionally favored salmonoid fish (trout and salmon), and it was not until the last decade that significant numbers paid attention to bass. That attitude has created the splendid opportunity for bass fishermen in the state, and they pursue their quarry all year. There are restrictions in May and June (the spawning period for both species of black bass) when fishermen are limited to lures and to two fish of any size. During all other periods, bait may also be used and the limit is five fish of any size.

Among the most highly paid residents of Publishers Row are the art directors of the mass-market paperback houses -highly paid because their challenging job is to design covers that will impel browsers to pick copies of their latest publications out of the racks and carry them to the check-out counters. It's not hard to concoct a design that will captivate fans of genre books - an embracing couple for lovers of romance, a screaming child for addicts of the occult. But what of the book whose appeal is wide and diverse? Some art directors attempt to solve that quandary by crowding their 7-by-4 1/4 inch covers with type and pictures describing a book's varied attractions. Pocket Books' Milton Charles, a believer in the ''neat, clean look,'' took another approach in packaging Herman Wouk's best-selling (1,600,000 hard- cover copies) novel of World War II, ''War and Remembrance.'' He designed six different covers, each emphasizing one of the book's appeals. Four of these are shown above - as a story of Navy life, a love story, a story of mother-and-child, a story of the generations on the home front. Two others conjure up thoughts of military action and of family sagas. When the six covers are displayed side by side in the racks, even the hastiest browser is quick to get the point. Mr. Charles's formula seems to be paying off. This week, for the second in succession, ''War and Remembrance'' is No. 1 on our massmarket paperback best seller list. Formula? Mr. Charles would protest that word. Every week, he says, an art director faces a new batch of challenges and must find fresh ways to solve them.

WALK into Glen Kolotkin's home in Cold Spring Harbor and you'll see a wall decorated with gold records. ''One for Barbra Streisand, two from Dr. Hook, one from Jimi Hendrix, about six from Santana,'' he said. ''That's a dead giveaway.'' If this were ''What's My Line,'' no one would have difficulty divining that he is associated with the music business. Mr. Kolotkin, at the age of 37, is to records what a director is to a movie. Sophisticated moviegoers have long accepted the idea of director as auteur. Mr. Kolotkin, a producer-engineer who now heads his own company, is the recording industry's counterpart.

THE Westchester Yellow Pages list 50 companies doing business shuttling county travelers from their homes to the New York area's three major airports and back again. Yet there are scores more, perhaps hundreds of other ad hoc hacks, who earn a buck by taking a flier. The bulk of airport-transport business, understandably, is provided by the traveling businessman whose employers reimburse him anywhere from $25 to $45 for the limo trip. Rarely is price a roadblock for most companies. Whatever the cost, it's important to get their weary Willie Lomans back to Larchmont safely and comfortably.

BEGINNING shortly after daybreak next Saturday morning, a caravan of 200 station wagons, pickup trucks and vans will line up at the entrance to the Veterans Park playing field here. Their sleepy drivers will be antiques dealers representing shops not only from throughout Connecticut but also from most of the other Eastern states. They will have traveled to Ridgefield to participate in the annual Ridgefield Flea Market and will be at the park early to register, be assigned their individual exhibit space, unpack, set up their displays and prepare for the two phases of business that make up any antiques fair. Many will have made the trip - in some instances driving three to five hours - to get to the show on time not only to sell to collectors once the market officially opens at 10 A. M., but also for the opportunity to buy, sell and trade antiques with other dealers. This sort of wholesale business helps keep stock ''fresh'' and replenishes inventories in a business that cannot ever buy anything that someone else has not owned. It is also a time to greet friends from distant areas, and talk almost incessantly about what type of antique is selling best in which market, and for dealers to buy for their own private collections.

MOST home handymen are already familiar with silicone rubber, it is a versatile adhesive and a long-lasting caulking compound that is excellent for many sealing and repairing jobs around the house. However, many do not realize that in addition to being available in its usual paste-like or mastic consistency which comes packed in tubes and in disposable caulking cartridges, silicone rubber is also available as a coating or liquid that can be applied with an ordinary paint brush or roller. Called Silicone Rubber Coating, and made by the Dow Corning Corporation, it is sold in quart cans and is available through paint and hardware stores, as well as through some lumber yards and home centers. Like the regular silicone rubber caulking compounds, this exceptionally adhesive weatherproof coating acts as a sealant and protective film that will withstand severe temperature extremes (from 65 degrees below zero to 450 degrees above). It is completely waterproof and will far outlast most ordinary plastic or asphalt roof coatings, according to weathering tests conducted by the manufacturer, and, like regular silicone compounds, it also has exceptional resistance to attack by most chemicals and solvents found around the home, or in the workshop and garage. Silicone Rubber Coating comes in only one color - a kind of medium gray, similar to what many would call a ''battleship gray.'' Its most widespread use around the home is probably for coating, repairing and waterproofing of roofs and similar areas on the outside of the house, particularly in places where there are joints or seams where two different surfaces meet.

The only known material witness to the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, remained in seclusion here today and had not talked with police investigators since the hours immediately after the assault early Thursday morning. Martha C. Anderson Coleman, a member of the board of directors of the Fort Wayne Urban League, reportedly told the police that she drove Mr. Jordan to the Marriott Motor Inn from her two-story frame home and that he was shot in the back as he got out of her red and white car.

ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario - Andrei Serban's controversial 1977 staging of ''The Cherry Orchard'' is now sifting down into the provinces. The Shaw Festival's production of Chekhov's masterpiece, featuring Carole Shelley as Mme. Ranevsky, looks like a bus-and-truck knock-off of the Lincoln Center version. Curiously enough, the director of the evening is Radu Penciulescu, who once taught Mr. Serban theater back in their native Rumania. The question is who taught Mr. Penciulescu? His ''Cherry Orchard'' is a lifeless affair that doesn't even have the courage of its own questionable convictions. Like Mr. Serban, Mr. Penciulescu has created a white-on-white ''Orchard,'' well designed by Astrid Janson, and tried for broad comic effects. But he hasn't had the guts to go all the way. Though the stage is a snowy expanse, the indoor scenes take place on conventional sets that are clumsily yanked into view by peasants.

In a 1962 article in Les Amis du Cinema in defense of Louis Aragon, the avant-garde poet and playwright whom he then admired, Jean Luc Godard wrote, ''But do not mistake the power of fashion. For its sake, ideas - like women - disfigure themselves. It can make youth ridiculous and beauty perilous.'' It is in the continuing manner of filmmaker/critic Godard that - although he subsequently turned against Aragon - his words, like his films, continue to assert a truth that appears to be independent of the man who put them together. Godard's critics express it in a different way. They say he contradicts himself. This, however, is completely to miss the point of this most questing, most innovative, most passionate of contemporary directors, who came to this Cannes Film Festival as an unrepentent revolutionary seeking publicity and a theatrical release for his newest film, ''Sauve Qui Peut La Vie,'' the English title of which is ''Slow Motion.''

Kathryn Tytler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert William Tytler of Camarillo, Calif., and Luis Abella , son of Mrs. Amelia Abella of Flushing, Queens, and the late Luis Abella of New York and Havana, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed in the Trinity Episcopal Church in Newtown, Conn., by the Rev. Francis Dunn and the Rev. David Bona, a Roman Catholic priest. The bride, a vice president with the Forum Corporation, a management and sales-training company in New York, was graduated from the University of California at Berkeley and spent four years as a Paris correspondent for The Chicago Tribune. Her father is a retired radio engineer with Trans World Airlines.

DEMOCRACY? By MALCOLM W. BROWNE Victory for a political candidate in a democratic society can depend as much on the voting system used as on voters' preferences. With another Presidential election year at an important stage, political scientists are again pondering ways of making America more ''democratic'' by tinkering with its electoral machinery. Some are lamenting what they consider a miscarriage of justice in the 1980 primaries, which end this week. Prof. Steven J. Brams of New York University contends that if Republican Party primaries this year had used a different voting system, one in which, for example, the electorate could cast ''approval'' votes for all acceptable candidates, not just one for a favorite, Gerald Ford might have perceived support for his candidacy, run and, says Professor Brams, been frontrunner instead of Ronald Reagan.

America lags far behind the rest of the world in developing youth hostels, simple overnight lodgings in scenic, historic or cultural surroundings for $3 to $5 a night. But a bill in Congress is designed to narrow the gap.

THE BUDGET: For the first time in 12 years, Congress had produced a deficit-free budget proposal. But budgetbalancing fever seems to have cooled considerably and the resolution suffered a sound defeat in the House last week. It was returned to the House-Senate conference committee for more pulling and tugging.

OMAHA, May 31 (AP)--A national land conservation group says that it plans to establish a 54,000-acre wildlife refuge near the controversial Norden Dam irrigation project on one of the nation's largest remaining expanses of prairie.

In England, Dick Francis is known as the jockey who gave up riding for writing. The champion steeplechase jockey of the 1953-54 season, he is perhaps best remembered for riding the Queen Mother Elizabeth's horse, Devon Loch, in the 1956 Grand National at Aintree.

JERUSALEM--Diplomatic convention requires governments to deal with each other and with nobody else. That is the orthodox doctrine, and like many orthodoxies, it is now under challenge. The pretense that existing governments are the only actors in the international system is now giving way, under the influence of public opinion, to a more diverse appraisal of the forces at work.

But, because he suffers from organic brain syndrome, he does not realize that he is scheduled to mark the day by leaving Central General Hospital--a departure that was delayed for almost a year, while hospital personnel sought in vain to place him in a nursing home.

To the Editor: While David Saxe's article (''No-Buy Pledge Ruled No Bar to Co-op Plan,'' May 11) may have reported accurately the situation in the Vermeer, his summary of Justice Shainswit's opinion left the impression that no-buy pledges cannot be used by tenants' groups to bargain effectively with co-op sponsors, or to defeat co-op conversions.$ Mr. Saxe should have given more emphasis to the weight given in the decision to the sponsor's apparent good faith in dealing with the tenants, evidenced by the many amendments to the co-op plan and to the particular form of the pledge. These facts limit the Vermeer case's value as precedent.

President Carter has announced that he is nominating Janet Dempsey Steiger, formerly of Oshkosh, Wis., to be a member of the Postal Rate Commission. She is the widow of Representative William A. Steiger, Republican of Wisconsin, who died in late 1978.

by Edward LaCroix To the Editor: Political analysts and politicians have recently been considering the possibility that the next President might be chosen by the House of Representatives, but another, lesser-known and potentially significant aspect of the 12th Amendment seems to have been overlooked.v.hereas the House shall choose a President ''from the persons having the highest numbers (of electoral votes) not exceeding three,'' the Senate shall choose a Vice President ''from the two highest numbers on the list.'' If President Carter should finish third in electoral votes (and this is not impossible), Vice President Mondale would be automatically eliminated from consideration by the Senate. In this case, it is quite likely that a Democratic Senate would prefer Mr. Anderson's Democratic or moderate Republican running mate to Mr. Reagan's. Such a possibility could have considerable influence on the decision in the House.

It was warm, humid and wet at times yesterday but this did not dampen the enthusiasm of the girls who competed in the outdoor track and field championships of the Public Schools Athletic League at Midwood Field in Brooklyn. Particularly unaffected by the weather was the Brooklyn Tech team. Len Malek's girls' squad captured its 17th straight P.S.A.L. title and fifth in this meet when it tallied 286 points for an easy victory. The Engineers' other titles in their string have come in cross-country and indoor track.

A KURT WEILL blitz has been one of the distinguishing features of the New York music season. In the theater, the incomparable, innovative and idiosyncratic sounds of one of its all-time great composers have sporadically burst forth over the years, but somehow, all at once, during the 80th anniversary of his birth, and just 30 years after his death, the resurgence of Weill's music has reached a peak - in concert halls and opera houses, in cabarets and legitimate theaters. What has been correctly called the Kurt Weill renaissance should enlarge the composer's cult following. One cannot reasonably expect more, for Weill's music remains too special for mass appeal.

John Wydler has been a consistent advocate of nuclear power, so it is not surprising that in his May 11 article (Opinion Page) he calls it ''the best choice'' and disparages alternatives such as coal. Naturally he ignores the two chief dangers of nuclear power, the possibility of accident - not minor accidents such as at Three Mile Island and other plants, but catastrophic accidents of the ''China Syndrome'' variety - and that from nuclear wastes, which keep accumulating and accumulating with no good solution in sight. Mr. Wydler plays up the drawbacks of coal, a resource that we have in abundance and that is our ''ace in the hole'' for beating the OPEC price pirates who have jacked up the price 15-fold in the last decade. The health risks from burning coal can be minimized by new methods developed for ''cleaning'' it, now feasible with high energy prices. The suddenly discovered ''greenhouse effect'' and acid rain make me wonder who is behind the publicity given these ''effects.'' They are a result of hydrocarbon burning, not just of coal. The increase, or theorized increase, has taken place at a time when the use of coal was declining, not increasing.

President Carter, expressing concern about the plans of European allies for a Middle East initiative, said today that the United States would veto any resolution they introduced in the United Nations Security Council on Palestinian self-determination. Although the European Common Market nations have not agreed upon a specific move, Foreign Minister Jean Francois-Poncet of France said here yesterday that because of the breakdown in Egyptian-Israeli negotiations, he expected the allies to take an initative in the next couple of weeks that would be widely regarded as pro-Palestinian.

Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, predicted today that President Carter's criticism of the Congressional budget compromise had doomed the Administration's proposed 10-cent-a-gallon oil import fee. Senator Byrd told a Capitol news conference that Congressional annoyance at Mr. Carter's statements on the budget had cost the President crucial votes needed to sustain his anticipated veto of legislation to block the import fee, which Congress is to vote on this week.

A special parliamentary commission today dismissed as unfounded an accusation against Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga that he had enabled the son of the vice president of the Christian Democratic party to escape arrest as a terrorist suspect. The vote was 11 to 9 after a bitter debate in open session. The 20 members divided along partisan lines, Christian Democrats and their Socialist allies in the governing coalition on one side and the Communists and other opposition politicians on the other.

In theory it was a test of principle: Lieut. G. Steven Suits, M.D., vs. the Marines. In practice it was no match. Lieutenant Suits, a graduate of the Medical University of South Carolina on a military scholarship, had been called into the Navy and had refused sea duty. Relying on the principle that modern medicine is divided into specialties, he argued that the job called mainly for an internist and he had not been trained as one. He had completed one of five years of surgical residency at the Spartanburg (S.C.) General Hospital and was assigned to the Marine Corps at Camp Lejeune, N.C. The Marines, standing on the time-honored principle of orders are orders, court-martialed the 26-year-old lieutenant late last year. He got four months in the brig, was fined $5,000 and was ordered to forfeit $5,000 in pay.
Allan Kozinn writes frequently on classical music. By ALLAN KOZINN

Ax blades sweep in two great arcs across a gallery wall. Planes - all two-handled versions - fill a segment of another, looking for all the world like a flock of birds in flight. And high above those compelling images, reamers are arranged to shape two awesome wheels - their handles serving as spokes, their boring-irons as sections of the rims. Hand-crafted tools used by wood and iron workers from the 16th through 19th centuries are frequently impressive to both the eye and the touch, as can be seen in an exhibition of Jan Firch's collection on view (through June 14) at the O.K. Harris Gallery, 383 West Broadway. The Czechoslovakian-born collector, who now lives in Paris, is an antiques dealer specializing in forged iron artifacts - ''but no tools'' he said the other day. The 600 tools he owns are part of his private collection which he assembled from European sources over the last 20 years and the bulk of which he hopes to sell as one unit. The price? $300,000. In addition, there is a small selection of tools for sale - about 15 to 20 examples priced at $200 to $400 each.

I'M not a rink person,'' explained Denise Claudet, a 25-year-old bookkeeper from New Rochelle. ''I like to skate outdoors. But everywhere you go, people say roller skates aren't allowed. If I go to a parking lot that's not used during the weekend, they tell me I can't skate there. They say, 'Go to a rink.' But I'm not a rink person; I don't like to go around in circles.'' Now after years of rolling around the West Coast and New York City, the outdoor roller-skating craze has swept into Westchester. First came the rink boom. Murray Skate Center in Yonkers was the avant-garde with disco roller-skating seven years ago. Then came Easy Glider in Baldwin Place, Skate City in Yorktown, the Rink in New Rochelle and roller-skating at the County Center in White Plains. This month the Ebersole Rink in White Plains put away the ice making machine; now there's outdoor roller-skating there, with exhibitions of fancy footwork, splits, spread eagles, spins, jumps and spills.

These and other dictates are among rules set out in a soon-to-bedistributed guide for the Indochinese newcomer to American shores. Jim Schankel of California Poly-San Luis Obispo became the first athlete to capture six individual national track and field championships when he won the 5,000-meter run today in the National Collegiate Division II championships at Mount San Antonio College. Schankel, who also has two cross-country championships to his credit, was timed in 14 minutes 7.50 seconds, a Division II record. The senior from Lompoc, Calif., captured the 10,000 meters in a meetrecord time of 28:58.37 yesterday.

DESTINATIONS, by Jan Morris. (Oxford University Press/Rolling Stone, $12.95.) A writer who at various times has been three persons - intrepid foreign correspondent, scholarly historian and exuberant British lady - offers impressions of 11 places around the world, from Los Angeles to Manhattan to South Africa to New Delhi. FALLING IN PLACE, by Ann Beattie. (Random House, $10.95.) A fictional survey of the culture of narcissism in Connecticut and New York by the prodigiously gifted young novelist and short-story writer. THE OAK AND THE CALF, by Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) A fragmentary yet rich, powerful memoir in which the great Russian writer recalls his struggle against the Soviet state from the early 1960's to his deportation in 1974. ORWELL: The Transformation, by Peter Stansky and William Abrahams. (Knopf, $12.95.) This second volume of his biography describes how Eric Blair's experiences in an English coal-mining town and in the Spanish Civil War, between 1933 and 1937, transformed him into ''George Orwell,'' one of the great political and literary figures of this century. SMILE PLEASE, by Jean Rhys. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) The unfinished autobiography of the late British writer, whose novels were notable for their astute, unfaltering prose. UNSETTLING EUROPE, by Jane Kramer. (Random House, $9.95.) Four elegantly written accounts of social and economic displacement in contemporary Europe: Yugoslav ''guest-workers'' in Sweden, Algerian and Ugandan refugees in France and England, and aged, alienated, orthodox Communists in Italy.

WASHINGTON BY THE time autumn arrives, they may sound like rabid Reaganites, but now, on the eve of New Jersey's uncontested Republican Presidential primary, the state's five Republicans in Congress are taking an unexcited, if not ho-hum, attitude. Representative Edwin B. Forsythe, a conservative from Moorestown, was especially frank in a recent interview. Originally, Mr. Forsythe was ''very hopeful'' for George Bush's chances, but then, as he watched those chances fade, he also determined that, instead of being concerned about the Presidential race, ''it was more important for me to get re-elected.''

Frankfurt seems dedicated to the pursuit and happiness of big business. The city is marked by shining towers of steel and glass; fast-moving, aggressive traffic shoots through streets flanked by endless rows of department stores and banks, banks and more banks. The airport, serving more than 10 million passengers a year, is surrounded by giant hotels, expensive restaurants and all the amenities to allow business people to fly in from any city in the world, conduct their business and fly out again in a matter of hours. The city's Messegelande has been the site of trade fairs and exhibitions since the Middle Ages.

I feel it is important for your readers to know that the ''Understanding Handicaps'' project discussed in the April 27 Opinion Page article, ''Understanding the Handicapped,'' by Hannah Elsas Miller, was generated by the Child Care Council and the Department of Special Education in Westport, specifically, the Coleytown Developmental Center, a regional special-education facility and part of the Westport school system. The funding of the program for this past school year came primarily from the Westport Stauffer Fund. Last week we were informed that the Title IV grant proposal mentioned in the article for continuation of the ''Understanding Handicaps'' project was rejected in Hartford. A 40 percent cut in Federal funds for innovative programs was the reason given.

Charles Addams, the New Yorker magazine cartoonist and droll master of the macabre, was married yesterday afternoon in the cemetery of his choice under appropriately gloomy skies. Naturally, the bride wore black. ''I just like the idea of the cemetery,'' said the 68-year-old Mr. Addams. ''It's kind of a pretty place.'' His bride, the former Marilyn Matthews Miller, said that she had chosen a black velvet dress and black feather fan out of respect for her new husband's sensibilities.

Data supplied to a House civil rights committee by Federal courts confirm accusations that for the most part the courts provide only lowly jobs for women and members of minorities, the chairman of the committee said yesterday in opening a hearing on the courts' employment practices. Nancy Lopez-Melton, who shot the worst round of her professional golf career 14 days ago with an 83, shot her best round this season today with a six-under-par 66 on the 6,410-yard Wykagyl Country Club course. It brought her to a total of par 216 and only two shots behind Sally Little and Janet Coles, who were tied for the lead after three rounds of the $125,000 Golden Lights Classic. Jo Ann Washam, who is Mrs. Melton's closest friend on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour, was a shot behind the leaders at 215, while Beth Daniel and Debbie Austin were tied with Mrs. Melton at 216. Behind them were Amy Alcott, Sandra Post and Kathy Martin at 217 with JoAnne Carner, the second-round leader, at 218.

Charles (Chub) Feeney, president of the National League, said yesterday he would make a decision tomorrow on Bill Madlock's appeal of a suspension for striking an umpire, obviating a threat by the umpires to eject the Pittsburgh Pirates' infielder from every game in which he appears. Richie Phillips, the attorney for the umpires' association, sent a telegram to Chuck Tanner, manager of the Pirates, saying the umpires were unhappy over delays by the National League in dealing with the Madlock appeal of a 15-day suspension and $5,000 fine. The umpires said they planned to begin their action against Madlock next Friday against the Mets in New York, and end it when the National League resolved the matter.

FOR 23 years, Mildred Russell, a slight, reticent, silver-haired woman, has had her eye on a small, boxlike structure in this Rockland County town a few miles north of the New Jersey border. But now she is doing more than just watching that building, the one where Theda Bara made her debut, where Edgar Bergen performed early in his career, where Margaret Sullavan appeared in summer stock and in which Ben Hecht, Helen Hayes and Charles MacArthur staged productions.

In an article last week on Actors Equity theaters in New Jersey, Jenkinson's Boardwalk Playhouse in Point Pleasant Beach was inadvertantly omitted. There are thus 12, not 11, Equity theaters - two of them dinner-theaters - in the state.

The oil money that has been keeping revolutionary Iran's troubled economy afloat is running out. Oil exports have fallen to 500,000 barrels a day, oil-industry sources say, in a steady decline from the roughly 4.6 million barrels produced daily for export during the rule of the Shah. Severe economic and political difficulties are foreshadowed for the new Government as a consequence of the sharp decline in oil revenues,which have been the basis of Iran's wealth, its foreignexchange power and much of its economy. Further pressure comes from an inflation rate estimated at 50 percent a year. Commenting on the situation, a young Iranian economist said: ''The signals we are seeing with the coming rate of inflation, particularly on foodstuffs, a fall of oil revenues, this year's budget in the coming emergency budget, the signals coming from industry, with the old problems of worker dissatisfaction, some raw materials and component problems in management ineptitudes - they all point to a fairly bleak picture of the economy.''

International The United States will veto any allied resolution on Palestinian self-determination in the Security Council of the United Nations, President Carter said, responding to the allies' plans for a Middle East initiative. Britain has mentioned the idea of a supplement to Security Council Resolution 242, which since 1967 has been the basis for Middle East diplomacy. President Carter said that the United States would not permit ''any action that would destroy the sanctity of and the present form of U.N. 242.'' (Page 1, Column 6.) Iran's oil revenues have declined. That and other ominous economic trends ''are heating up towards some sort of economic collapse or disaster,'' according to an Iranian economist. Industry sources estimate that Iranian oil exports, the basis of the country's economy, have declined to about 500,000 barrels a day from 4.6 million barrels daily under the Shah. (1:4-5.) Israel's envoy briefed President Anwar el-Sadat on Prime Minister Menachem Begin's reported threat to delay withdrawal from the final eastern third of the Sinai Peninsula ''unless Egypt subscribes to a multinatinal force agreement'' to police their common border. The remarks annoyed Egyptian officials, who said they had assumed that there was no disagreement about the multinational force. (5:1.) National President Carter made peace moves toward Senator Kennedy and promised ''concessions in every direction'' on the Democratic Party platform in a television interview. He praised Mr. Kennedy as a ''loyal Democrat,'' and said that he had ''no doubt that Senator Kennedy and I can work harmoniously'' to defeat Ronald Reagan. Mr. Kennedy, campaigning in San Francisco, said Mr. Carter was a ''clone of Ronald Reagan.'' (1:2.) A lead in the Vernon Jordan shooting proved fruitless. The F.B.I. said that a rifle seized from a motorcyclist in Fort Wayne, Ind., where the president of the National Urban League was shot Thursday, was not the weapon used in the attack, although it was believed to be the same type of gun. (1:3.) Government experts criticized a report last week that advised that healthy people need not reduce their intake of cholesterol and fat. The experts said that the study by the National Academy of Sciences ignored important scientific information. (1:1-2.) A survivor on Mount St. Helens was evacuated by helicopter. Ray Jennings, 74 years old, had refused to leave the mountain even after the volcano erupted two weeks ago. But a relative persuaded him to do so in the face of continued danger from a rising lava dome in the volcano's crater. Mr. Jennings's cabin is 10 miles from the mountain peak. (26:1-4.) Metropolitan Mayor Koch and Republican leaders will meet Friday to discuss his views on some Congressional and White House policies that he believes hurt cities. This unusual meeting between the Mayor, who is considered to be President Carter's strongest supporter in New York State, was at the invitation of the Republican National Committee's platform committee. Roger Semerad, executive director of the Republican platform committee, said that Mr. Koch's views ''on some issues run more parallel to Republican positions than those of his own party.'' (1:1.) Howard (Buddy) Jacobson escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention where he was waiting sentencing after his conviction April 12 of the slaying of John Tupper, a New York restaurant owner who was a rival for the affections of a model. Mr. Jacobson, a former race horse trainer, was scheduled to be sentenced Tuesday. A police spokesman said that he had just ''walked out the door.'' (1:1-2.)

The artist who falls in love with one of his creations has been a fascinating subject for thousands of years. Established in Greek mythology in the account of Pygmalion - a king and sculptor whose statue of an idealized female figure was brought to life by Aphrodite - the subject has enlivened our own era in George Bernard Shaw's famous play about a Cockney transformed into a lady and, most spectacularly, in ''My Fair Lady,'' the Lerner and Loewe musical based on the Shaw play. But our century was not the first to have a Pymalion musical. An opera-ballet by Michel de la Rorre existed as early as 1700, and on Thursday night the Concert Royal and the New York Baroque Dance Company gave the first New York performance of Jean-Philippe Rameau's ''Pygmalion,'' an opera-ballet that dates from 1748.
Michael Billington is London theater critic for The Guardian. By MICHAEL BILLINGTON

Lunchers arrive at the Pierre at 11:30 A.M., dine within the next hour and get a good look at Mrs. Navon. Israel's ''Sabra of 1956,'' she graduated from the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, received a master's degree in psychology and adult education from the University of Georgia and went on to further studies at Columbia University, where she got a professional diploma in rehabilitation counseling, and uses her skills in Israel as a working mother. The Navons, married in 1963, have a daughter Mira and a son Erez. The luncheon ends with a fashion show honoring American designers not just for their designs, but for their philanthropic efforts. Such excited speculation filled the family station wagon one recent morning as a father and three children made a pilgrimage - by car - to the birthplace of the modern automobile assembly line, Ford's River Rouge industrial complex in Dearborn, Mich. The youngsters' youthful anticipations were not far off the mark, although their imaginings did not include the excitement at seeing and feeling the orange-hot heat of steel being rolled for hoods and doors, of trainloads of molten metal making their way between buildings or car bodies descending from the ceiling to meet awaiting axles. NEWS ITEM: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has proposed an increase in commuter rail fares for Conrail. Public hearings are to be held in New York City tomorrow; in White Plains at the County Center at 2 P.M. Tuesday, and in Connecticut on Wednesday. WHEN I first began to commute to New York from the Scarborough station in Briarcliff Manor, I was not vitally concerned with what it was costing me in rail fare. After all, $18.75 a month was a manageable sum in 1950. Nor was my standard of living affected a few years later when the fare increased to $24.70. I was still able to drop a coin in the collection box every Sunday at church. In 1960 the cost of a monthly ticket jumped to $33.50. In 1970 it hit $36.50 and in 1972 $47. It was as if Conrail were bent on staking out a course later taken by our astronauts.

Residents of the Pacific Northwest learned once again last week how thin and fragile is the layer of technological civilization that covers the face of the earth. For the first time, glowing lava pushed to the surface of the Mount St. Helens crater in what geologists say may be the first stage of a dome forming. For the second time in two weeks the peak erupted, not with a cataclysmic bang but with a column of ash 40,000 feet high and spread by southwesterly winds over the populous lower Columbia River region of coastal Oregon and Washington. There gentle rains turned the drifting ash cloud into a drizzle of mud, locally interrupting electricity and communications and creating an awful mess. Some 12,000 square miles received the ashfall, which a Washington official said brought visibility to zero in Olympia, the state capital. Interstate Highway 5 was closed between Longview and Olympia when up to an inch of mud coated the road. Portland International Airport was closed for a day and a 15-mile-an-hour speed limit imposed in the city. Four local radio stations were knocked off the air, some telephone circuits and electric transmission lines failed, and search-and-rescue efforts following the eruption of May 18 were halted.

prisoner By ROBERT PEAR WASHINGTON - Five years ago, the American Civil Liberties Union and other liberal groups attacked a proposal to revise Federal criminal laws as a potential tool of government repression. Under the guise of ''reform,'' these organizations contended, the 753-page plan would create an Official Secrets Act, punish the press for publishing classified information, expand the espionage laws, strengthen penalties for marijuana possession and increase the likelihood of capital punishment. They set out to ''stop S.1'' as the Senate bill was then known, and they succeeded. Much has changed. As the House Judiciary Committee considered yet another version of the criminal code last month, the chief critic was not the Civil Liberties Union. It was the Carter Administration's Justice Department, which surprised many committee members when it offered them a package of about 30 amendments.

SAN ANTONIO, May 31 (AP)--Juan Carlos Harriott, the Argentine team captain, scored four goals as the South American squad defeated the United States national polo team, 10-6, today at the Retama Polo Center to clinch its sixth consecutive Cup of the Americas championship.

HOME BEFORE NIGHT By Hugh Leonard. 202 pp. New York: Atheneum. $9.95. HUGH LEONARD's recollections of his Dublin childhood are a charming and gritty advertisement for the past, without being quite the real thing.

NASSAU COUNTY officials are complaining that a little-known tax reassessment ruling in 1975 has become an undue burden to homeowners. Since 1978, Nassau County has paid out more than $46 million in commercial property tax refunds, has lost $30 million from the commercial assessment rolls and faces 35,000 refund claims from businesses seeking tax relief based on the 1975 State Supreme Court decision, known as the 860 Executive Towers decision. Before another decision in 1975, the better-known Hellerstein case - in which the Court of Appeals ruled that the 200-year-old tradition of assessing property in the state at only a percentage of its true value was invalid - residential property was assessed at a lower rate than commercial property. The Legislature and courts had gone along with this practice to encourage home ownership.

They're called ''jelly shoes,'' and if they'd been around when Charlie Chaplin made a meal of his boot in ''The Gold Rush,'' the little tramp would probably have selected them for dessert. Made of glossy molded rubber, the shoes come in such shimmering shades as wine, grape, root beer and cherry red; for those who prefer to be more conservatively shod they're also available in white, blue, camel, brown and smoke.

Ken Landreaux's consecutive-game hitting streak came to an end at 31 today, but he figures there is only one logical thing to do. ''We'll start another one,'' the Minnesota Twins' outfielder said after failing to get a hit in four trips to the plate in an 11-1 loss to the Baltimore Orioles. ''It's all right. Good things don't last forever.''

VOLCANO By Shusaku Endo. Translated, with an introduction, by Richard A. Schuchert. 175 pp. New York: Taplinger. $8.95. BECAUSE of the exigencies of reputation and publication, most of the comparatively small number of postwar Japanese novelists whose work has appeared in English have seen their books come before the foreign public in the wrong chronological order, done by a variety of translators (good, bad and indifferent), and with a consequent muddle about how these authors should be ranked and how they may have developed.

Patricia Lithgow Paul, daughter of Mrs. James Albert Paul of New York and the late Rev. Dr. Paul, was married yesterday to John Campbell Olive, son of Dr. and Mrs. George Melbourne Olive of Belmont, Mass., and Centre Lovell, Me. The ceremony was performed in St. James' Episcopal Church by retired Bishop Horace W.B. Donegan of New York and the Rev. Dr. Hays Rockwell, rector of St. James'. Bishop Donegan also officiated at the marriage of the bride's parents in St. James' in 1940 while he was rector.

J.R. Richard pitched a three-hitter and batted in a run with a second-inning single as the Houston Astros downed the San Franciso Giants, 5-0, today. The right-handed Richard (6-3) reduced his earned-run average to 1.85 with his second shutout of the season as he didn't allow a hit until Darrell Evans lined a single to lead off the fifth.

THE BOOK OF JAMAICA By Russell Banks. 326 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $10.95. THE HARDER THEY COME By Michael Thelwell. 399 pp. New York: Grove Press. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $7.95. JAMAICA is the seductive setting of these two novels - a Jamaica stricken with change, with moral contamination; suffering from an eroded sense of identity, from a complicated modernity. There is something backward in the exertions of development; Kingston is Babylon, dangerous and desperate; even the tropical heat becomes a metaphor for menacing, conspiratorial forces. Though the books share a setting, their perceptions are quite different and there are no similarities of style or tone. Russell Banks's ''The Book of Jamaica'' spans only a brief time and is set mostly along the northern coast of the island; Michael Thelwell's ''The Harder They Come'' is a chronicle of generations and is set primarily in the Kingston ghetto.

PLAINVIEW TODAY is Alfred Brinkman's 78th birthday. But, because he suffers from organic brain syndrome, he does not realize that he is scheduled to mark the day by leaving Central General Hospital - a departure that was delayed for almost a year, while hospital personnel sought in vain to place him in a nursing home. Mr. Brinkman's exodus leaves behind some 500 elderly patients, waiting in Nassau and Suffolk hospitals for transfer to nursing homes. Their average wait extends 60 days beyond their acute illness stage, at a cost to the taxpayer of up to $200 a day. Nursing home space, if available, costs about $53 a day and is better suited to the needs of these geriatric patients.

Who are these men in my life? Why do they keep changing with the time of day? There's the gardener who appears on sunny weekend mornings. He doesn't wear shoes. His hands are as muddy as his toes. He needs a shave, and his jeans are as scruffy as the denim cap protecting his spreading bald spot. He chuckles wildly when he sees the worms aerating his vegetable patch and everyone within earshot is summoned to share the sight. He reminds me a little of the daily dinner guest who slumps in with a rumpled suit and bulging brief case every night. He, too, needs a shave, and his posture could be improved. When he kisses me, his eyes are open and straying toward the stove. I can't compete with pot roast.

Edward T. Joyce, a former Justice Department official and former Navy fighter pilot, died Wednesday at his home in Arlington, Va., after suffering a heart attack. He was 60 years old. Mr. Joyce was born in Brooklyn. He was awarded three air medals and other citations for combat action in the Pacific in World War II. Later he received a law degree from St. John's Law School in New York and entered law practice in Brooklyn. He was recalled to active duty in the Korean War.

The Administration will send a mission to Liberia tomorrow to encourage its new military rulers to forgo further violence against former leaders in return for American cooperation and assistance, Government officials said yesterday. It will be the first special mission to Liberia by the Administration since a coup by noncommissioned army officers on April 12. The uprising resulted in the death of President William R. Tolbert Jr. and public executions of high-ranking members of his Government.

The Black and White San Francisco Classic Backgammon Tournament last weekend attracted a strong field that included all the top West Coast players. Allen van Gelder of San Francisco took top honors by defeating Michael Maxakuli, president of the Las Vegas Backgammon Club. Aram Kouleyan, last year's winner, and Alan Martin were semifinalists. In other sections: George Matthews overcame Ted Kim to win the consolation; Lynn Madlener took the last chance, and Richard Maurer beat Mike Margolis in the intermediate. With the two finalists sequestered in a closed room, several hundred spectators were able to observe the 21-point finals on closed-circuit television. In the first half of this well-played match, both players won some lucky games but neither was able to build up a lead. With the score tied 11-11, however, the luck of the dice shifted in favor of van Gelder. He won the next two games and went ahead 14-11. In the following decisive game, van Gelder (X) obtained a slight advantage, and gave Maxakuli (O) a somewhat premature double. Several rolls later the diagrammed position was reached.

The Providence & Worcester Railroad today acquired 29.5 miles of track in eastern Connecticut from the Consolidated Rail Corporation, in a move shippers hope will cut freight delays from the Norwich-Groton region to areas west of the Hudson River. The $275 million sale includes single-track line from Plainfield to the shoreline and a spur into Norwich, along with sidings and passing tracks.

He was assisted by the Rev. David Hunter McAlpin, a cousin of the bridegroom. The bride, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Gerst of Louisville, was graduated from the Sacred Heart Academy in Louisville and Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y. She is an executive secretary with H.J. Baker & Bro. Inc., New York, importers and exporters of chemicals. Her father was founder and president of Lisco Inc., manufacturer of industrial insulation in Louisville.

by JAMES RESTON WASHINGTON, May 31 - Watching President Carter try to juggle all the contradictory foreign and domestic problems of the nation during a Presidential election and an economic recession, you have to wonder who can do it and who can govern America. In the last few days, Jimmy Carter has been a cat on a hot tin roof. The Chinese Vice Premier, Geng Biao, has been in Washington wanting more money to modernize his country, and getting it. The French Foreign Minister, Jean Francois-Poncet, has been here agreeing about the crises in Israel and Afghanistan, but disagreeing about just what should be done about the Palestinians and the Soviets.

The first time I saw it, in the summer of l972, it struck me as a wildly improbable scene. I was leaving London's ever-busy Victoria Station at 2:30 in the afternoon. As I picked my way to the doors through throngs of travelers in drab, everyday dress, I saw moving toward me a stream of men in dinner jackets and women in evening gowns, many of them carrying blankets, folding chairs, picnic baskets, bottles of wine and long loaves of French bread. Where, I wondered, could these dressed-for-the-night people be going in midafternoon? And why were they carrying what looked like the makings of a beach party? Had I chanced upon a troupe of extras bound for a film production? I stopped a white-haired woman in a long purple gown and asked her destination. ''Lewes, of course,'' she replied (pronouncing it LEW-is). This turned out to be correct but not enlightening.

WHAT'S an antique that has saved lives, that fills viewers with nostalgia, that you may not want to own but that's as stirring as a Fourth of July parade? An old fire engine, that's what. Today, about 60 such pieces of equipment are expected to be driven or pulled through the streets here, with their chrome, brass and nickel trim shining and their low-pitched sirens wailing.

Asterio Takesy of Ulul, in the Truk Islands of the Pacific, may be a unique figure at the United Nations - an antifreedom fighter who seeks to delay the independence that the United States plans for his Micronesian people next year. Puffing a pipe and wearing a trim blue business suit instead of the tribal garb favored by anticolonialists, Mr. Takesy and other Micronesians are appearing before the Trusteeship Council. They are quietly arguing than an overgenerous United States has turned them into welfare wards, has destroyed their fishing and farming economy and has not left enough in its place.

A fusion device newly developed at an institute near Munich is being hailed by specialists in the field as a revival of an almost abandoned but now promising approach to harnessing the process that makes the sun shine. It has encouraged hope for development of a continuously running fusion reactor. The giant, costly and complex Tokamak reactors now being built in this country, Britain, Japan and the Soviet Union will operate in pulses, a less efficient mode.

Bert Blyleven, the prodigal son of the Pittsburgh Pirates, finally won his first game of the season tonight when he pitched the world champions to a 5-0 victory over Craig Swan and the New York Mets. The loss was only the second for the revived Mets in their last eight games, and the fifth in their last 15. It also brought them out of the month of May with 13 victories, 13 defeats and plenty of room between themselves and their longtime berth in last place in the National League's East.

by Judy Klemesrud In England, Dick Francis is known as the jockey who gave up riding for writing. The champion steeplechase jockey of the 1953-54 season, he is perhaps best remembered for riding the Queen Mother Elizabeth's horse, Devon Loch, in the 1956 Grand National at Aintree. Fifty yards from the finish line, way ahead of the field, the horse suddenly went down on his belly, all four legs out, with a startled Mr. Francis still aboard. Dramatic photographs of the fall were printed in newspapers throughout the world. Mr. Francis, then 36, continued racing for another nine months, then retired after he had a fall that badly bruised his spleen. He became a racing columnist for London's Sunday Express and, when he found he had a hard time supporting his wife and two sons on a journalist's salary, began writing mystery-thrillers with a racing background. Many of them were best sellers in England and several other countries, but it wasn't until his current and 20th book, ''Whip Hand,'' that a Dick Francis novel has shown up on The New York Times Best Seller List. ''I think the television series had a lot to do with it,'' Mr. Francis, now 59, said in an interview from his home near the Berkshire village of Blewbury, England. He was referring to the PBS series, ''Mystery!'' in which three recent episodes were based on stories by Mr. Francis and were shown under the umbrella title of ''The Racing Game.''

EL PARRAL in Syosset straddles two cuisines, Spanish and Italian. Both are featured on the menu, making it possible to pair a Neapolitan appetizer with an entree from Valencia. It would certainly benefit a group that cannot agree on where to dine. At El Parral, some can try Spanish specialties while others remain in familiar northern Italian territory. Most of the time the two cuisines merely coexist without borrowing from each other, but there are a few dishes in which the Spanish influence flavors a more typically Italian preparation. A good example of this is the clams casino. Eight littlenecks on the halfshell are topped with seasoned crumbs and, instead of the usual dicings of bacon, pieces of Spanish sausage - chorizo - add an unusually bright, peppery flavor to the dish.

Stephanie Tokar, who received a bachelor's degree last month from the University of Pittsburgh School of Health Related Professions, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael H. Forman, who graduated last week from Pittsburgh's School of Medicine. Rabbi Stephen Stein performed the ceremony at the Huntington Town House in Huntington Station, L.I. The bride, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stephen J. Tokar of Ellsworth, Pa., is an alumna of the Presbyterian University Hospital School of Radiological Technology in Pittsburgh. Dr. Forman, who will be a resident in internal medicine at Mercy Hospital in San Diego, Calif., is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour B. Forman of Huntington Station. He is an alumnus of the University of Rochester. His father is assistant superintendent for business of the Plainview-Old Bethpage Central School District and his mother, Beverly Forman, is an elementary school teacher in the South Huntington Union Free School District.

By MARTIN TOLCHIN WASHINGTON - ''Five willful men among the House conferees on the 1981 budget are attempting to destroy the bipartisan budget process and its discipline....If this gang of five thinks that by shooting our negotiations down now, that they will get further concessions, they are dead wrong,'' Senator Pete B. Domenici said two weeks ago. His doublewhammy allusion to the foes of Woodrow Wilson and Deng Xiaoping made instant celebrities of the Democratic Representatives. They took to wearing large red buttons with black Chinese calligraphy which proclaimed, they said, ''Join the Gang of Five.'' The five liberal-to-moderate Congressmen, second- and thirdtermers, mostly in their early forties, may not yet be national leaders. But they are interesting not only because of what they did, but because they represent the so-called new breed of Congressional Democrats, who depart from the party's tradition of unquestioned support of organized labor and unshaken faith in the efficacy of social programs. They are also serious-minded and respected by their colleagues, and their opposition to the House-Senate compromise budget of $613.3 billion on the ground that it gave too much to the military and took too much from social programs presaged the measure's overwhelming defeat on the House floor last week.

THEY were marching off to war, World War I, when Maria Santini first came to the Victorian clapboard house in the Fair Haven neighborhood that is still her home. Sixty-four years later she said she could never think of living anywhere else. It was here that she grew up, married, had four children and learned of the birth of her eight grandchildren.

A new series of reports on industry in New York depicts a continuing tourist boom, strong airline and motion-picture operations, a "modest revival" in printing and new potential for the garment trades, the waterfront and industrial development.

LONDON, May 31--The opposition Labor Party adopted a left-wing policy statement for Britain today at a special conference that was marked by denunciations of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and of American foreign policy.

LIKE an amusement-park operator who has to attract the widest audience possible before selling the specific qualities of his ride, Westchester County is planning to seek someone to run Playland by sending out R.F.P.'s, or requests for proposals, that have been recast to appeal to a wider audience of potential lessors. Initially drafted as technical documents with contract language, similar to those it used successfully to obtain a manager for Westchester County Airport, the Playland requests for proposals have been rewritten to appeal to as many potential operators as possible.

UMBERTO's, located in a charming, diminutive house that fronts directly on the sidewalk as though it were in an old seaport, is a restaurant that knows its mind. Inner directed, you might call it. It offers a very brief menu - four appetizers, four pastas, five main dishes, four desserts - and does well by every dish but two. Now, there is something engaging in the idea that by dining alla Italiana (appetizer, pasta, main course, sweet) a small band of determined customers can eat its way through the whole menu in a single evening, getting a comprehensive view of the state of the art in that particular kitchen at that particular moment. But there is also something downright impressive in the self-assurance of Umberto, the chef-owner, about his cooking: take it or leave it, his menu seems to say. Scanning the nearby tables as closely as we could, we saw no one leaving it. Umberto serves a lovely green salad just after the main course. If a diner asked to have it at some other place on the bill of fare, the restaurant would certainly oblige. But the waiter will emphatically fail to ask him whether he wants it with Italian, French, Russian or blue cheese dressing. At Umberto's the salad is offered only one way: Umberto's way, which is tangy and delicious - mixed lettuces with sprays of watercress, arugola and endive, dressed plainly and perfectly in oil and wine vinegar.

North Babylon won the Suffolk County scholastic girls' track championship today with 26 points. Bay Shore was runner-up with 22, followed by Patchogue, 18, and Amityville, 17. Randy Givens of Amityville and Linda Detlefsen of Sachem were double winners. Givens won the 100-meter race in 11.6 seconds and the 200 in 24.2, a county record. Miss Detlefsen took the 800 in 2:15.5 and the 1,500 in 4:42.9.

Carolyn Wesley Davenport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Wesley Davenport of Sanibel, Fla., was married there yesterday afternoon to Guy Dumas, son of Gertrude Dumas of Montreal. The ceremony was performed in the St. Michael and All Angels Episcopal Church by the Rev. James D.B. Hubbs.

by Newgate Callendar There are numerous killings in CAGED by Terry Brykczynski (Crown, $10), but the deaths are nonhuman. Mr. Brykczynski has thought up the rather original idea of an animal killer who goes around with a massive psychopathic complex and kills zoo animals to make them free.

SPRINGS A QUESTION frequently heard in East Hampton during the summer is, ''Where in the name of God can you get a decent lunch?'' The answer, of course, is the Calvary Baptist Church. On Saturdays from now through October, the church, on Springs Fireplace Road, is the place to go for fried chicken and barbecued ribs, served from noon to 6 P.M. You can also have your car washed while you eat.

HUNTINGTON SOME contemporary artists are quite uncomfortable with the past. They either revere it to the point where they become completely absorbed in it, sometimes annihilating their own sensibilities, or they spurn it unabashedly, trying with near desperation to create something new. Usually they end up fostering another kickshaw for the already overly plentiful bric-a-brac of art. Four contemporary artists, who are incidentally Long Islanders, make the neat point in an exhibition at the Heckscher Museum that they are not disturbed by the past in the least; in fact, they are quite peacefully at home with it. Their work reflects an understanding of historic art, perhaps even an admiration of it. Yet they never fall prey to deference, for they use what they have learned from traditional conceits to inform their works, using them as points of departure for self-discovery.

MENTION the letters WLIW in most any community on the Island and you are likely to be met with blank stares, yawns or directions to the Long Island Expressway. In an area already rich in history, natural beauty, culture and recreational opportunity, WLIW, Channel 21 - the Island's own public television station - could be one of our most important regional resources. The station, however, remains largely anonymous - a condition that is currently causing dire consequences in terms of audience, dollars and local programming. If the situation is not reversed, the Island will most certainly be the loser.

ALTHOUGH there is a consensus that airline deregulation has had a positive public benefit, notwithstanding the reduction or elimination of service to numerous locations, the facts that made such deregulation successful do not exist in the trucking industry. The Teamsters Union has been able, through good collectivebargaining agreements, to substantially improve the lot of many trucking industry employees, including drivers and warehousemen. Admittedly, at the same time that wages and conditions improved for employees in the industry, so also have prices charged to shippers and customers - and eventually to the public - probably risen.

More than 700 motorcycles lined the street outside Police Headquarters here today as cyclists demanded action against a state legislative leader who was in an accident last January in which a motorcyclist was killed.

Frances Eileen Coyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis N. Coyle of Cape May, N.J., was married yesterday to Thomas F. Brennan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene F. Brennan of Rochester. The Rev. William Quinn performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Chapel in Cape May Point, N.J. Ridolfi of Washington Crossing, N.J., to David Alexander Smith of New York, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Coulter Smith of Kearny, N.J. The pastor, Msgr. The bride, a systems analyst with Datronics Inc., is a graduate of the Stuart Country Day School in Princeton, N.J., and Wheaton College in Norton, Mass. Linda Keniston, daughter of Mrs. Reinhold P. Schmitt Jr. of Glen Spey and Port Jervis, N.Y., and the late Dr. Allen Hayward Keniston, was married yesterday morning in East Winthrop, Me., to Richard James Dubocq, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Dubocq of Northport, L.I. The Quaker ceremony took place in the Friend's Church. The bride, an alumna of the Northfield School, also attended Antioch College and graduated from Earlham College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She and her husband expect to receive M.D. degrees Thursday from the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Her mother, Dr. Julia C. Keniston, practices pediatrics. The bride's father was a general practitioner and anesthesiologist. Her stepfather, Reinhold P. Schmitt Jr., is an electrical contractor in Glen Spey.

Consider: One of every seven Americans over the age of 65 lives in poverty; 72 percent are unmarried women. Only half of all working Americans contribute to private pensions, and only about half of that half possess the right to carry the pension to a different job. About 11 percent of today's population is over 65; when the baby-boom generation has grayed, in 2035, the proportion will be double, approaching 22 percent.

After vocal opposition by the League of Women Voters and other groups, Governor Carey has sent back to the Legislature for possible modification a bill that would allow town and village zoning boards in the state to conduct some deliberations in private. The bill, which was drafted by the Association of Towns and supported by the New York Conference of Mayors, was approved by the Senate and Assembly without opposition. It was not until the Governor's counsel asked for public comment that the league, Common Cause and the New York Public Interest Research Group learned of it and protested.

by P. Narayanan To the Editor: The supervisory role assumed by the Federal Government in Chrysler's affairs gives a paradoxical twist to the automaker's situation. While the Government's actions in this role will be well-intentioned, I believe that this is a case of the blind leading the blind.

SOME of the games people play in the future may have been spawned this year in the Mount Kisco Elementary School. For five months, a dozen fourth and fifth graders there have been working on an art project to develop their own hand-made war games. The result is an inventive collection in which players pursue one another through black holes, quicksand, pit stops and any number of other obstacles, and in which pawns come in shapes from rocket ships and racing cars, to spiders and Hershey's Kisses.

California's 10 million registered voters, who have often swung their weight decisively in Presidential races, appear to feel that they do not matter to this year's nominations, and that attitude threatens to foil Senator Edward M. Kennedy's bid for an upset over President Carter. With Mr. Carter only 24 delegates short of a nominating majority and assured of winning that many in eight states on Tuesday, Mr. Kennedy says he must win California, the biggest in that final round of primaries, to keep alive his hopes of blocking Mr. Carter's renomination.

When the supersonic Concorde began service at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport on Jan. 12, 1979, it was greeted by crowds of excited onlookers, a 75-piece marching band and drill team, and press releases heralding a new day for international aviation in Texas. There was a good deal less excitement here this morning when the troubled Concorde made its last flight from Texas to Europe after 16 1/2 unprofitable months of service. In that time, the Concorde, the world's most expensive passenger plane, flew on the average with twothirds of its 100 seats empty.

The marriage of Louise DeAngelis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert D. DeAngelis of Feasterville, Pa., to Hugo H. Beit, son of Mrs. Julius de N. Lehmann of White Plains and the late Herbert Beit von Speyer, took place yesterday at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church. The Rev. William Walsh performed the ceremony. The bride is a secretary in the corporate relations department of The New York Times. Her husband is an officer with the Cerbani Research Corporation in Port Chester, N.Y.

The forecasts of Treasury Secretary William Miller may soon take their place next to the Government's other leading indicators of economic activity. As the Administration's leading economic spokesman, he has been remarkably, and perversely, ahead of his time - and wrong. Last summer, Mr. Miller announced that a recession he claimed not to want was half over. In fact, it had not yet begun. This week, Mr. Miller said that the worst of the recession was probably behind us. When adjusted for the Miller-lag, that tells us the worst is yet to come.

Size: 3 1/2 inches. Color: Male (shown) has iridescent green upper parts, brownish wings and tail, bright red throat, white under parts, moderately forked tail. Female is similar but lacks red throat, has rounded tail. Where found: Gardens, roadside thickets, parks and fields. Nests: Two white eggs in tiny cuplike woven nest covered with lichens and lined with plant down. Remarks: Only hummingbird in our area. Can hover, fly backward and sideways and do 60 miles an hour in straight flight. Attracted to tubular flowers, such as trumpet vine, petunia.

Mayor Koch, dissatisfied with some Federal policies toward the cities, has accepted an invitation to address the Republican National Committee's platform committee this Friday. It will be the first appearance of a prominent Democratic official before the group in this Presidential campaign. The committee's invitation to the Mayor, who is considered one of President Carter's strongest supporters in the state, reflected the feeling among some Republicans, said Roger Semerad, executive director of the platform committee, that Mr. Koch's views ''on some issues run more parallel to Republican positions than those of his own party.''

The historic Picasso exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art is clearly intended to overwhelm us, and - no question about it - it does. The legendary force, momentum and multiplicity of Picasso's gifts have not been exaggerated, after all. They are truly prodigious, and the art that resulted from this extraordinary endowment is, as promised, presented to us in this exhibition on a scale and with a discrimination never before lavished on Picasso or any other modern artist. That his art proves to be fully equal to this outsize scale - that, indeed, it requires this scale to be fully seen and understood -is but one of the many revelations this exhibition discloses to us for the first time. Thus, though Picasso has long been the most famous of modern artists, and in New York one of the most frequently exhibited, this show nonetheless gives us a new measure of his achievement. Henceforth, Picasso will live for us as the artist we will have studied and lived with - and argued about, and at times even been a little sickened by - in this exhibition.

Attendance this season in the North American Soccer League is down 3 percent from last year, with the Cosmos and the Minnesota Kicks showing the biggest dropoffs, 21 and 33 percent, respectively. The average attendance is currently 13,378, compared with 13,779 last season.

With New York City's new ''pothole bill'' going into effect Wednesday, the Koch administration has set up a special post office box for people with complaints about damaged streets and sidewalks. Under the provisions of the new law, anyone injured as a result of a defect in a street or sidewalk may not sue the city for damages unless the city has received written notice of the defect at least 15 days before the injury took place.

Nancy Ellen Pader, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elmer Pader of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Dr. Alan Marc Leiken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Leiken of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Jerome Blass performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. The bride, whose father is a cardiologist, received her degree from the State University at Stony Brook, L.I., where she is studying for a master's degree in social work. Her mother, Cynthia Pader, teaches science in an elementary school in the Bronx. Dr. Leiken, a graduate of Queens College, has a doctorate in economics from Stony Brook, where he is an assistant professor at its Health Sciences Center.

The third Salute to Women in Jazz will run for eight days at three locations in Manhattan, starting today, with a free nine-hour program at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center. The salute, which will feature more than 50 female musicians as soloists and leaders, will continue at the Jazz Gallery, 55 West 19th Street, tomorrow through Thursday, and Friday and Saturday at the Symphony Space, West 95th Street and Broadway. It will end next Sunday with another free nine-hour program at Damrosch Park. There will also be instrumental, vocal and business workshops tomorrow through Saturday at the Jazz Gallery.

The stated threat was the danger of invasion from North Korea, but the actual target last week for South Korea's Army were civilian dissenters in Kwangju. Attacking before dawn, 3,000 paratroopers in 90 minutes crushed a nine-day rebellion in the southwestern city. Also crushed in the process was the chance of an early end to military rule, reimposed six months after the assassination of Park Chung Hee had awakened hopes for democratic reform. The weak civilian Government in Seoul yesterday consented to the formation of a Special Committee for National Security Measures, whose principal member is thought to be Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan. The move came despite the reported opposition of the United States.

John Conteh, the former lightheavyweight boxing champion, hit the comeback trail tonight, stopping James Dixon of Memphis in the fifth round of a scheduled 10-round bout. Dixon was no match for the 29-year-old Briton, who suffered a fourth-round knockout at the hands of Matthew Saad Muhammad two months ago in a World Boxing Council title bout in Atlantic City.

Three persons were wounded tonight, at least two of them critically, when a passenger opened fire with a rifle aboard an Amtrak passenger train bound from Washington to Boston, authorities reported. ''One of the train crew, a conductor or trainman was shot, a woman passenger was shot and an Amtrak policeman who responded to a call and met the train at the New London station was shot,'' said Sue Stevens, a spokesman in Maryland for Amtrak, the national passenger railroad corporation.

The marriage of Cassandra Kendrick Archbold, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cornell Archbold Jr. of West Chester Pa., and John Beckley Wright 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Morton Wright of Rosemont, Pa., took place last evening in the Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity in West Chester. The Rev. William Fischler performed the ceremony. Cynthia Ann Archbold was maid of honor for her sister. Edwin W. Wright was best man for his brother. The bride, an Echols Scholar at the University of Virginia, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and from which she graduated May 18, also graduated from the Shipley School. She studied at Villanova University, the University of Pennsylvania and the Center for Medieval and Renaissance Studies, St. Michael's Hall, Oxford, England.

As Senator Edward M. Kennedy campaigned here this week, he said at a news conference: ''We have to win in New Jersey.'' He refused to speculate on what he would do if he lost the state's Presidential primary to President Carter next Tuesday, but he made it clear that a victory was vital to his continuation as a candidate. The Massachusetts Senator has a chance of getting his wish, but polls indicate an extremely close contest and the high level of those who say they are still undecided shows that New Jersey Democrats are reluctant to make the decision they thought would have been made for them long ago.
A Cook County grand jury has indicted 57 persons, more than half of them public employees, in a welfare fraud case involving $810,000.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kaylin of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randy Dorian Kaylin, to Dr. Peter Stephen Warheit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter S. Warheit of Rockville Centre, L.I. The wedding is planned for November. Miss Kaylin, who was until recently an account executive with Gordon & Shortt, a New York advertising agency, graduated from the State University of New York at Albany. Her father is executive art director of the Landis & Landan division of Nadler & Larimer Inc., a New York advertising agency.

Oklahoma State captured its fourth National Collegiate golf championship today by posting a final-round par 72 on Ohio State's 7,104-yard Scarlet course. The Cowboys, who finished four strokes ahead of Brigham Young, started the round in a three-way tie with Brigham Young and Ohio State, the defending champion, at 885 for 54 holes.

Two years ago, California voters approved Proposition 13, which rolled back real estate taxes. Last year, the state accepted Proposition 4, which limited increases in spending to increases in population and the rate of inflation. In Tuesday's California primary, there will be three such plans, including Proposition 9, intended to cut state personal income taxes by 50 percent. These propositions reflect a nationwide demand for tax reform, but they and their progeny in other states have confused reform with budget capping.

by Eugene V. Rostow To the Editor: It is always popular to grumble about one's allies, but it is a dangerous sport, and we should give it up. ames Reston's important column of May 23 contains an important error of judgment. He points out, quite correctly, that the allies are not fully cooperating with President Carter's program of ''sanctions'' because they have no confidence either in the President or in his program. Then Mr. Reston adds that if the allies ''had backed President Carter in a common front, with effective sanctions against the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan and against Iran ... this whole tragedy might have been avoided.''

THE WOOING OF EARTH By Rene Dubos. 183 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $8.95. ''CAN the world be saved?'' asks Rene Dubos, the eminent microbiologist turned ecologist, and the answer to this rhetorical ploy, just as one would expect, is ''Yes'' - why else would he bother to write a book about it? Aside from that, however, ''The Wooing of Earth'' offers little of what we have come to expect nowadays from a book on the endangered environment. Instead of doom and denunciation, there is faith, hope, a charitable view of man and an unhackneyed way of looking at his uses of nature.

ALTHOUGH ''Man of La Mancha'' has only been around since 1965, it has taken on the reputation of a classic of musical theater. I suspect the reason is ''The Quest,'' the song that is better known as ''The Impossible Dream.'' At any dinner theater at which I've seen the show - and Nanuet makes the third - the beginning of the song is greeted with sighs as if the audience were collectively taking off a pair of tight shoes. The ending is cheered. No doubt this all has something to do with a longing for hope in an unhappy world. In any case, ''Man of La Mancha'' has been chosen as the show to celebrate Coachlight of Nanuet's first anniversary, a good choice obviously, since press releases from the theater claim the largest advance sales to date on any show that has played there. Those ticket buyers can sleep at ease. Assuming one adores ''Man of La Mancha,'' Coachlight has given them an excellent production.

In March, after almost a year of acrimonious protest by local residents, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development abandoned a plan to set aside for low-income tenants 10 units in a senior citizens apartment complex to be built in Plainview, L.I. The project will be built, but for senior citizens only. More recently, protests erupted in town halls throughout Nassau and Suffolk Counties, after the Tristate Regional Planning Commission announced it was cooperating with H.U.D. in another venture - an 18-month pilot project to help 50 low-income families move from New York City to homes in the two Long Island counties closer to their jobs.

by TOM WICKER SAN FRANCISCO - A family of four with an income of only $15,000 a year is up against it economically, here in California as much as in any state. And a state income-tax bite of $225.80 doesn't help. So on the face of it, the registered voters in that family should go to the polls on June 3 and vote for Proposition 9, which would cut California income taxes by more than half - in the case of the family cited, by 69.5 percent to only $68.90, a fat savings of $156.90.
