MOORE G. E. Moore and the Cambridge Apostles. By Paul Levy. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart and Winston. $18.95. TTHROUGH the cunning of history, Paul Levy's already interesting book had a topicality by the time it was published which it did not have when he wrote it. Almost the last of the great many names cited in it of clever, well-bred young Englishmen is the portentous one of Anthony Blunt, the emeritus art historian now revealed to have been, concurrently, a Soviet agent. The Blunt affair, it is true, falls outside the time limits which Mr. Levy observes, but its enthralling social ramifications do not; they are a throwback to the summertime of Edwardian snobbery.

THE Connecticut Commission on the Arts, which will present its third annual arts awards tomorrow night at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, uses the occasion as a showcase for Connecticut talent. One of the performers this year will be an employee of the commission. She is Margaret Vazquez of Hartford, a spinto soprano who, along with her vocal studies, works full-time as receptionist at the commission's headquarters. Earlier this year, Miss Vazquez was one of 11 finalists in the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.

THE North Shore Unitarian Church's Veatch Program, a little-known but influential organization that sponsors a wide range of socialchange projects and advocacy groups on the Island, has decided to limit its expanding activities -which cost a record $6.5 million last year - in order to keep the program manageable. This will affect a number of activist groups seeking backing for projects in criminal-justice reform, mental health, energy, the environment, housing, youth advocacy and other causes. The Veatch Program has been active in such areas for the last decade.

REMIN'S, which has been in New Rochelle for nearly three decades, has always sold designer clothing at 30 to 50 percent off, but now, in a pre-vacation clearance, it is a matter of 50 to 80 percent off. Rose Remin, who founded the store with her husband, Robert, in 1950, said that 37,000 customers, half of them from out of town, had asked to be listed and notified by mail in advance of the sale. Samples at the store are quite small, about size 8, and mostly one of a kind, but the stock generally runs from size 4 to 16. There is one large room for trying on items; there are no irregulars and no seconds. By late August, new stock will be brought in.

NEWARK THIS reviewer has rarely understood why a museum chooses to show three or four artists or, say, six, as is the case in a photography exhibition now at the Newark Museum. The number in this instance is purely arbitrary, since the six are not part of a group, adherents of a particular style or proponents of similar subject matter. In fact, they are vastly different in their photographic predilections.

President Carter today praised his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, as a ''loyal Democrat'' who had waged a determined campaign and said that their contest had strengthened the party for the fall. Mr. Carter, who suggested 12 days ago that Mr. Kennedy was campaigning on ''empty slogans,'' ''false promises'' and ''distortions of issues,'' said today that he had ''no doubt that Senator Kennedy and I can work harmoniously'' to defeat Ronald Reagan in the fall. He offered concessions on the campaign platform.

A year ago, the small plots of unpaved land flanking Junior High School 22 on Columbia Street on the Lower East Side were blanketed with garbage. Recently, tulips and daffodils bloomed in well-tended beds, and a newly created reading garden was fragrant with the scent of cherry blossoms. Mollie Parnis, the fashion designer, thinks that this sort of hard work should not go unrewarded. Under a pilot project of Miss Parnis's ''Dress Up Your Neighborhood'' competition, which began its ninth season last week, Adele Unterberg's eighth-grade art class, which is responsible for the new greenery, will receive money to continue its beautification projects.

ALEXANDRIA, La., May 31 (AP)-- An Alexandria District Court judge ruled yesterday that the June issue of Penthouse magazine was obscene. Citing a photo layout of two women engaged in various forms of sexual conduct, Judge Guy Humphries said the magazine violated the community standards of Rapides Parish. David Robertson, a lawyer for Penthouse, said the magazine would appeal to the Louisiana Supreme Court.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., May 31--The Federal Bureau of Investigation has ruled out a Remington 30-caliber rifle taken from a motorcyclist here as the weapon used in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, the chief of the bureau's investigation said today.

THE Presidential primary election on Tuesday will ring down the curtain on one of the strangest political campaigns in recent New Jersey history. Senator Edward M. Kennedy and surrogates for President Carter moved in and out of the state virtually unnoticed, except for reporters, and virtually unaccompanied. Vice President Mondale stood on the stage of a high school in South Orange and said how wonderful it was to be in the district of Representative Joseph G. Minish. The only thing missing was Mr. Minish.

BRIDGEHAMPTON ELAINE BENSON opens the season in characteristically grand style with ''At the Greengrocer,'' a large and lively exhibition of fruit and vegetable subjects by 35 artists. Such theme shows are notable for their variety, and here we find the greengrocer's fare interpreted in many styles and some unusual media, including stained glass and Styrofoam. The visitors are warned not to trip over Arline Wingate's sliced banana languishing on the floor of the entrance gallery. Miss Wingate's oversized mushrooms and asparagus are finished and painted in a way that makes them appear petrified, like giant primal plants in suspended animation.

A 45-year-old Queens woman was seriously injured early yesterday morning when a burglar broke into her first-floor apartment and beat her with a shovel, the police said. The woman, Veda Sellers, was sleeping when a burglar forced open the front door of her apartment at 115-20 205th Street in Hollis, Queens, the police said. She was beaten about the head and then collapsed in her bedroom after calling the police. She was listed in serious condition at Queens General Hospital. Residents of the Pacific Northwest learned once again last week how thin and fragile is the layer of technological civilization that covers the face of the earth. For the second time in two weeks, Mount St. Helens erupted, not this time with a cataclysmic bang but with a column of ash, reaching 40,000 feet into the air, and spread by southwesterly winds over the populous lower Columbia River region of coastal Oregon and Washington, where gentle rains turned the drifting ash cloud into a drizzle of mud from the heavens, locally interrupting electricity and communications as well as creating an awful mess. Some 12,000 square miles received the ashfall, which a Washington official said brought visibility to zero in Olympia, the state capital. Interstate Highway 5 was closed between Longview and Olympia when up to an inch of mud coated the road. Portland International Airport was closed for a day and a 15-mile-an-hour speed limit imposed in the city. Four local radio stations were knocked off the air, some telephone circuits and electric transmission lines failed, and search-and-rescue efforts following the eruption of May 18 were temporarily halted.

shock of forsythia, a gold brilliance against the drab of a skeletal branch-and-twig world, is wildly acclaimed, like the lead performer in a neighborhood high school play. Certainly not the best, or the most talented. Probably never to be heard of in later years, but at this moment, with bright vivacity, transforming the colorless, bare wood gymnasium, and delighting an uncritical audience with a dazzling solo. And while the applause is still echoing, May rockets in. May is overwhelming; a pollen fuzz, a lime haze of willows. Talented, bursting with energy, May is everywhere at once, expanding, nudging, jostling. An invincible force eating up the miles of landscape, leaving a trail of bushy, tangled, boisterous new ground cover. April's tentative leaves and new shoots now grow green, grow tall. Color explodes. Magnolias unfold broad petals whose creaminess shades into rose-streaked lavender bases. Azaleas blaze in intensities of melon, pink, violet and red. Tulips jolt the eye with their vigor of color, while dogwoods, in a watercolor delicacy of pink and white, delight the senses.

Despite pulling off a triple play in the second inning tonight, the Seattle Mariners dropped a 5-2 decision to the Cleveland Indians. With runners at first and second bases in the second inning, Toby Harrah of Cleveland lined to the Mariners' first baseman, Bruce Bochte, who fired to Jim Anderson, the shortstop, to double up Ron Hassey. Anderson then relayed the ball to first base before Joe Charboneau, the baserunner, could get back.

MAYBE A Story. By Lillian Hellman. 106 pp. Boston: Little, Brown and Co. $7.95. THE central figure of this strange short memoir (if it can be called such) is not its ostensible subject, Sarah Cameron, nor the memoirist, Lillian Hellman, but the elusive, mutilated, often reeling character of memory itself. Again and again Miss Hellman tries to corner memory, forcing it to reveal the truth about the people and events she is trying to make sense of. Important epistemological questions are suggested: How valid is what we know - or think we know - about the people who dropped in and out of our lives in the past? How can we tell where memory blends into fantasy, producing a composite that takes on different shapes at different times, according to our needs? At the end of Miss Hellman's struggle with these questions, we have to settle for some very dusty answers; meanwhile we have been entertained, dismayed and, above all, tantalized.

Don Cherry says he'll be back with the Colorado Rockies in about a year. Meanwhile, the hockey team needs a new coach. The Rockies' president, Armand Pohan, who dismissed Cherry two weeks ago, originally had three candidates to become the club's fifth coach in five years.

THE SALT EATERS By Toni Cade Bambara. 295 pp. New York: Random House. $9.95. TTONI CADE BAMBARA is the author of two books of short stories, an anthology, ''The Black Woman,'' and a collection of ''Tales and Short Stories for Black Folk.'' In her highly acclaimed fiction and in lectures, she emphasizes the necessity for black people to maintain their best traditions, to remain healthy and whole as they struggle for political power. ''The Salt Eaters,'' her first novel, eloquently summarizes and extends the abiding concerns of her previous work.

What should you do if you are in flight on an airplane and you think you have been shortchanged on service? Some procedures are stipulated in regulations of the Civil Aeronautics Board or in rules that individual airlines have set and told the board they would follow. In many possible situations, however, a lot of discretion is left to the airline, and it behooves passengers who feel aggrieved to be careful about when and how they complain. Perhaps, as sometimes happens on crowded planes, the economy-class washrooms become unsanitary or run out of supplies. Perhaps you dislike a meal. Perhaps cigarette smoke is bothering you, but no effort is made to find you a different seat. Perhaps an attendant is rude.

For the last 17 years, Harvard has won the classic Yale-Harvard Regatta in New London. With eight oarsmen and one coxswain to a shell, the four-mile varsity race, longest in the country, will be rowed on the Thames River again Saturday at 6:30 P.M. downstream from Bartlett's Cove to the Gold Star Memorial Bridge at Route I-95. In the annual meetings, Harvard has won 66 times, Yale 47. Recent Crimson victories have been attributed to Harry Parker, who was described by Rick Powers, a member of the race committee, as ''the best and most innovative coach around.''

NOT many residents are aware that the New Jersey Fish and Game Council is scheduled to hold hearings this month on proposals to expand the hunting and trapping seasons in the state within the next two years. The members of the council, which operates under the aegis of the state's Department of Environmental Protection, are appointed by the Governor. What is being reviewed is comparatively simple, but what the changes could lead to has the animal welfare organizations in the state greatly concerned. Among the proposals under consideration are changes in the fish and game code that would allow legalized falconry, the trapping of river otter, wild-turkey hunting in the spring, increased beaver trapping and additional winter squirrel hunting.
States News Service

Government experts on nutrition and health in several agencies have sharply criticized as inadequate and misleading a report on diet by the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Academy of Sciences that found no reason for the average healthy American to reduce the intake of cholesterol and fat. The report, prepared by a six-member unit of the board and issued last week, said there was not enough evidence available to make a general dietary recommendation aimed at reducing the risk of heart disease.

Shortly before dawn today the heavy tanks that had occupied the center of this provincial capital since Tuesday cranked up their engines and rumbled off to the suburbs. A couple of hours later the big fountain in the main square came back to life, spraying water into the air. Communications with the rest of the country were restored after being cut off for 10 days during the occupation by student-led rebels protesting the martial law system. A swift army attack on Tuesday broke the rebellion.

A thousand Democrats who describe themselves as ''reformers'' - most of them from Manhattan - will try tomorrow to winnow the field of candidates to run against Representative John M. Murphy, Democrat from Staten Island and Manhattan in the Sept. 9 primary election. All four declared opponents of the nine-term Representative from the 17th District are taking part in the vote but two said they would not be bound by its result.

Whenever the Dow Jones industrial average goes into one of its prolonged sinking spells, there is talk in Wall Street of ''splitting the Dow,'' perhaps 10-for-1, so that the declines won't jolt the investing public unduly. Lately, however, this sort of chatter has died down. The Dow has been climbing. It finished last week at 850.85, down a bit from the previous week's close of 854.10, after 14-point drop on Thursday that was generally regarded as a long overdue correction. But the previous week had seen a 27-point runup and at its closing on Wednesday - just above 860 - the market's best-known barometer had climbed 100 points since wobbling to a two-year low on April 21.

Al Oerter, the 43-year-old discus thrower, produced the longest toss of his life, 227 feet 11 inches, to win the event today at the Track and Field Association outdoor championships. Last night at the invitation discus event here, the four-time Olympic champion from Babylon, L.I., threw only 204-1, losing by 10 feet to Ben Plucknett. Today, said Oerter, ''I really felt like throwing. There was a good wind, and I had a good night's rest.''

At St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Hingham, Mass., yesterday, Katherine Frances Doyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. Doyle of Hingham, was married to Hector Innis Guenther, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Guenther of Rye, N.Y. The bride's father, a member of the permanent deaconate, performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. James Morrissey. Elizabeth A. Doyle was maid of honor for her sister. Ian J.M. Guenther was best man for his brother. The bride, director of group sales for the New York City Opera, graduated from the Notre Dame Academy in Hingham, where her mother teaches literature and classics, and from Manhattanville College. Her father is brokerage manager for the Group Insurance Service Center in Marshfield, Mass.

From a shabby office in a one-story converted warehouse on a side street in Iwilei, a rundown waterfront industrial area, Harry Weinberg has been shaking the luxurious boardrooms of powerful Hawaiian corporations for years. Mr. Weinberg, considered Hawaii's biggest landowner and now 71 years old, is the same hard-driving, tough-talking individualist who, as owner of the Fifth Avenue Coach Line Inc., precipitated a crippling transit strike in New York City in 1962. That affair ended with the city purchasing the line at a handsome profit for Mr. Weinberg.

A national land conservation group says that it plans to establish a 54,000-acre wildlife refuge near the controversial Norden Dam irrigation project on one of the nation's largest remaining expanses of prairie. The Nature Conservancy said Thursday that it would purchase an 84-square-mile area of prairie and forest in north-central Nebraska with $10.86 million from the estate of the late Katharine Ordway, a Minnesota native who supported the preservation of prairie land.

The authorities announced today that they had evacuated a 74-year-old man and four dogs from an ash-dusted cabin 10 miles from Mount St. Helens and the hot dome of lava that is rising in the crater of the volcano. Ray Jennings had refused to leave his cabin on the south side of the mountain before and after the volcano erupted May 18, killing 22 persons and leaving 53 still missing.

Mao Zedong's former home in a closely guarded compound where Chinese leaders work is being opened to the public for a day tomorrow on the occasion of Children's Day. A selected group of children and teachers will visit the one-story brick dwelling, with its sloping roof, that is surrounded by a courtyard. It stands in a walled park that houses the offices of the Communist Party's Central Committee and is known as Zhongnanhai, or Middle and South Seas, for two lakes in the park.

At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday, Claudia Allen DeSantis, daughter of Mary Allen DeSantis of New York and Anthony DeSantis of London, was married to Peter Armistead Bowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Eugene Bowe of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. John Fisher performed the ceremony. Monica Maillet and Charles F. Phelps Jr. attended the couple as maid of honor and best man. Mrs. Bowe, formerly with Ogilvy & Mather Inc., the New York advertising agency, was graduated from the Northfield-Mount Hermon School and from Yale. Her mother is beauty and health editor of Cosmopolitan magazine. Her father, an architect, is director of projects in Britain for the American Express Investment Company.

Amy B. Fluckiger of Arlington, Va., daughter of Col. Fred Fluckiger, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Fluckiger of Richmond, formerly of Hicksville, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon in Springfield, Va., to Charles Hunsaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Hunsaker of Boca Raton, Fla. The ceremony was performed in St. Mark's Lutheran Church by the pastor, the Rev. Duane Carlson. The bride, a graduate of Longwood College in Farmville, Va., is with Ernst & Whinney, certified public accountants in Washington. Her father is director of Spectrans, a Richmond transportation company.

Roberta Kennard Jenkins, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Jenkins of Darien, Conn., was married in the chapel of the Noroton Presbyterian Church there yesterday to Jeffrey Burke Dias, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Dias of Lompoc, Calif. The Rev. Edward Danks performed the ceremony. The bride, formerly with Benton & Bowles Inc. in New York, has joined Sive Associates, a Young & Rubicam company in Cincinnati. She graduated from the University of Connecticut. Her father is senior vice president and managing partner of Eastman & Beaudine Inc., executive recruiter in New York.

Is there a future for a small, independent classical record company that makes its headquarters on an eight-acre ranch in the wilds of the Pacific Northwest? If the prospect appears dubious, consider the company's speciality - recording offbeat and contemporary chamber music that features the oboe. Given the economic uncertainties that beset the record industry today, such a minority-appeal undertaking sounds like a lunatic idea and doomed to failure. No such thing. Despite the odds, against him, Peter Christ, who founded Crystal Records in 1966, has turned this Walter Mitty dream into reality, and without the support of private grants or ''vanity'' subsidies from the artists he records. His label is just one among dozens of such hardy enterprises that, while not exaxtly earning a fortune, are making a solid go of it in many parts of the country.

Last week, the House resoundingly rejected the House-Senate compromise on the First Budget Resolution for fiscal 1981 on the grounds that it contained too much for the military, and sent it back to the conference committee. But, shortly after the vote, and the departure of many members, Republicans passed a measure directing the House conferees to insist on sticking with the military spending figures. Even if the resolution eventually passes, the budget process faces a difficult year. Indeed, it is easy to ridicule what has ocurred so far in the Congressional deliberations. Quite aside from the specifics of last week's contradictory voting, our legislators have been busily pretending that they are providing for a balanced budget in 1981 while ignoring the unpleasant fact that the economy is in a free fall that virtually guarantees a deficit exceeding $20 billion given the spending and tax policies now inherent in the first resolution. It is, in fact, not difficult to visualize a deficit far in excess of $50 billion as the bad news continues to roll in, and encourages Congress to undertake ''countercyclical'' spending increases and tax cuts.

The Spanish Grand Prix apparently will be run today without official international sanction as Formula One auto racing girds for a conflict that could be similar to the one that split championshipcar racing two years ago. The Spanish Royal Auto Club, which organizes the race, has ousted the Federation Internationale du Sport Auto officials and has announced that the Formula One Constructors Association, which represents most of the Grand Prix teams, will run the event.
The most graceful exit from the stage of rock and roll is a quick one. Old age--even middle age--is often a source of embarrassment in a music that is primarily the province of the young.

Manhattan's ''reform'' Democrats, the Bronx's ''regular'' Democrats, and Republicans joined forces long enough this week to split the judicial district that comprises the two boroughs, making them independent of each other in nominating justices for the State Supreme Court. With the support of the three factions, a bill to give the Bronx its own judicial district cleared the Democratic-led Assembly by a vote of 110 to 21 and went to the Republican-led Senate, where its passage is also expected. There it will be shepherded by Senator John D. Calandra, the Bronx Republican leader, who believes it would be easier to deal with one Democratic county leader than the current two.

The marriage of Nancy Ann Barth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Barth of New York, to Richard Stewart Heller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Heller of Iselin, N.J., took place yesterday in the Cottage of Hampshire House. Rabbi Andre Ungar performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, a lawyer, is with Cahill, Gordon & Reindel.

The 19th St. Vincent Debutante Ball was held at the Apawamis Club in Rye, N.Y., last night. Fourteen young women from Westchester County were presented to Terence Cardinal Cook at the event, the proceeds of which will benefit St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center's Westchester branch in Harrison, N.Y.

IT'S called a beanball, a knockdown pitch, a purpose pitch, an intimidation pitch, a brushback pitch, sometimes simply an inside pitch. Whatever the semantics, it's a dangerous pitch. That danger has exploded into nine bench-clearing melees already this season - six in the American League, three in the National League. After four had occurred in the American League during the first month, the league president, Lee MacPhail, issued a directive to cease and desist. But two days later Jim Spencer of the Yankees, after having been plunked on the left elbow, wanted to dismember Dave Rajsich, the Texas Rangers' left-hander. And last weekend Buddy Bell and Johnny Grubb, usually two of the more courteous Rangers, charged at the mound where Bruce Kison of the California Angels was wearing his most angelic look.

classroom By FOX BUTTERFIELD PEKING - For the past year, Li Guanghua has been going to night school six evenings a week after finishing work in his factory. A quiet, intense 26-year-old who was assigned to the automotive parts plant after high school, he had hoped to take an exam this summer enabling him to register for China's new and highly popular television university. Its students are exempted from regular jobs to watch classes on the screen, and when they graduate in three years are likely to get a better job and a pay raise, both hard to come by in China. But the Communist Party committee that runs Mr. Li's factory refused to let him and several other ambitious workers put down their names. ''They told me they couldn't afford to let us study for so long and that anything I studied would be useless for the factory,'' Mr. Li recalled. Mr. Li thinks he understands why. The party secretary was originally a peasant, and the four other committee members were poor rickshaw pullers before the Communist victory in 1949. None had more than a year or two of schooling. Hence they are distrustful of Peking's new policy calling for greater technical competence among workers and managers to help achieve modernization.

The extraordinary tape recordings of President Richard M. Nixon plotting to save himself were for the first time made available for public listening last week in Washington. All the barnyard expressions are there. So is the famous, damning ''smoking gun'' tape. For Watergate buffs, however, it was something of a modified limited hangout. Transcripts of the tapes, which were used as evidence in two Watergate trials, had already been published. And a mere 12 1/2 hours of the 6,000 hours of conversation detected by Mr. Nixon's self-activating microphones are available in the National Archives monitoring room. Mr. Nixon has sought court action to bar public access to the rest.

WASHINGTON--If all goes according to Administration plan, the rate of inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index is likely to fall as low as 7 percent by year-end. That's not only an impressive drop from the 18 percent rate posted in the first three months of 1980. The moderation that has already begun was cited by Government officials last week as "laying the groundwork" for the deepening recession to level off.

A WISE professor once said that 75 percent of the problems associated with plants occurred within the soil. To the gar dener who spends most of his time fending off attacks by aphids, mites and leaf blights, this may seem to be a strange statement. Yet, considering that the roots typically make up half the volume of a plant and that they are usually obscured from view by the soil, the statement takes on credibility.

MIDDLETOWN LAST Apr. 4, a 20-year-old woman student at Wesleyan University walked into a campus fraternity house at 4 A.M. and was confronted and then grabbed by two fraternity men, who picked her up, spun her around and kissed her. Badly frightened, she ran from the house.

WOODBURY ALL is not well in suburbia - at least that part of suburbia inhabited by the heroines of Felice Buckvar's recently published original paperback novels. A suburban housewife herself, having spent almost 18 years on the Island, Mrs. Buckvar has taken a long look at her neighbors, and, finding them wanting in happiness, has put them between the soft covers of contemporary ''romances.'' In one, a widow is pregnant by her longtime lover and upset because she has suddenly discovered that her only son is homosexual. In the other, ''a wife and mother first'' has met the enemy of idle uppermiddle-income women and found it is her own boring life. Read in tandem, ''All the Way'' and ''Happily Ever After'' present a depressing picture of life among the blades of crabgrass.

It's Safe Boating Week, and to celebrate there will be a whole slew of activities at Wantagh Park today. Starting at noon and running through 5 P.M., the park's marina will host firefighting and water rescue demonstrations and how-to sessions on small boat trailering, search and rescue, navigational aids, scuba diving and fishing. Everything is free and the park is south of Merrick Road, just east of the Wantagh State Parkway. CHAMBER MUSIC

HE first all-female class of candidates for the New Jersey State Police is nearing the end of an intense four-month training program that combines college-level academic courses with rigorous physical exercise and weapons instruction. Thirty-three of the 104 women who reported to the State Police Academy here on Feb. 13 are still in the program and expect to be graduated on June 27. The attrition rate is only slightly higher than that of the usual all-male class. Currently, the State Police force includes two female troopers. Just how difficult it is to become a trooper can be gleaned from the statistical history of the present class. At the outset, 1,631 women took the written examination - the first step - and 670 passed. Medical examinations reduced the number of candidates to 255, and oral interviews and background checks further reduced the list to 116, who were invited to report on Feb. 3. Of that number, 104 showed up.

Dominic J. Baranello, the New York State Democratic chairman, has postponed what would have been the first meeting of the state delegation to the Democratic National Convention because of disagreements between supporters of President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy on who should lead the state group. Mr. Baranello, who met Friday with Kennedy and Carter representatives at the state committee offices, 60 East 42d Street, Manhattan, sent a mailgram to delegates yesterday announcing postponement of a full meeting for a week or two to allow time for further negotiation.

By JAMES M. MARKHAM MADRID - Spain's politics of consensus died last week. ''Suarez has reached the highest level of democracy that he is capable of administering,'' complained Alfonso Guerra, numbertwo man in the Socialist Party, from the speaker's tribunal in the vaulting Cortes. ''Suarez cannot stand any more democracy, and democracy cannot stand any more of Suarez!'' The Socialist was intervening in a remarkable, three-day debate on a motion of censure - the first of its kind in post-Franco Spain - against the conservative Government of Prime Minister Adolfo Suarez. The Socialist censure motion failed, as expected, to gather the necessary majority in the 350-member lower house that would have installed Felipe Gonzalez, the Socialist leader, in Mr. Suarez's place. The vote was 152 in favor and 166 against - all from the Suarez party; the rest of the deputies abstained. But the debate itself was significant. A huge television and radio audience followed the sharp, funny, heated parliamentary give-and-take deep into the early hours of the morning, suggesting that Spaniards are not as bored with their young democracy as Madrid intellectuals and editorial writers maintain.

The defection of Bruce Clark, the defensive tackle from Penn State, to the Toronto Argonauts of the Canadian Football League last week caused more than a ripple in National Football League circles. Clark was the third player chosen, by the Green Bay Packers, in this year's draft and the first of the defensive linemen. The loss to the Packers seems devastating as Clark was to have anchored a new three-linemen, four-linebacker defense at nose tackle. Bart Starr, the Green Bay coach, blamed Clark's agent, and not the athlete, for the signing with a Canadian team. Players' agents are certain to be a subject among team owners when they meet in Atlanta this week. Last year, the first pick in the N.F.L. draft, Tom Cousineau, a linebacker from Ohio State who had been drafted by the Buffalo Bills, also chose the Canadian League.
St. John's University's gritty baseball team shocked second-ranked Arizona in the College World Series opener last night, bringing respectability back to Eastern baseball.

COMMUNITY' The view from the fifth floor apartment at 413 West 48th Street showed the kind of squalor that once made Hell's Kitchen a fitting name for the neighborhood. The wall of the tenement opposite had recently collapsed, leaving a dozen families homeless. The ground below was covered by bricks, plaster and garbage.

Seven months after they won the World Series, the Pittsburgh Pirates are still loud, loose and leading the pack. But they are also injured, short on pitching and increasingly short on temper. They even have been in a slump for the last month, raising a few eyebrows as well as the inevitable question: Is the celebrated ''family'' of baseball beginning to show the strains of old success, new adversity or even their own self-proclaimed togetherness?

Guillermo Vilas of Argentina, who won the $200,000 Italian open last Sunday, has been named Grand Prix tennis player of the month for May. The award is presented by Volvo, sponsors of the Grand Prix circuit. The consistent left-hander easily defeated Yannick Noah of France, 6-0, 6-4, 6-4, to take the title that had eluded him for the last eight years. He is currently in the running for the French open championship.

Sol Stern, a New York freelance writer, was captain of the City College swimming team in 1957. By Sol Stern ou didn't see it on ''Wide World of Sports,'' but a national championship swimming meet, sponsored by the Amateur Athletic Union, was held recently in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. It was an event of recordshattering performances, and demonstrated, as well, that high-level competitive swimming - contrary to popular perception - is not the exclusive preserve of our nation's teen-agers. Entered in the threeday meet were about 1,000 of the best ''masters'' swimmers from around the country - men and women aged 25 to 87 who have proved themselves in scores of local contests during the past year. Races were conducted in all the standard swimming events - freestyle, backstroke, breast-stroke, butterfly and individual medley - and swimmers competed against others in the same age brackets. (For example, a 50-year-old woman would compete only against other women in the 50- to 54-year-old age group.) This annual event is as much a symptom of the physical-fitness craze of the last decade was the growth of long-distance running. The difference is that the development of swimming as a sport for adults has been almost entirely by word of mouth. There have been no bestselling books by swimming ''gurus''; no inspirational television movies about middle-aged housewives taking up the challenge of longdistance swimming; no corporate funding and support of swimming meets.

1945), author of realistic satires of the South's changing society, was considered the peer of Edith Wharton and Willa Cather. Our times may not have confirmed that judgment, but this posthumously published (1954) autobiography, now returned to print, remains a moving portrait of a gifted, sensitive woman in her 60's candidly looking at herself in the mirror. ULTRA GOES TO WAR, by Ronald Lewin. (Pocket, $2.95.) An account, based on official documents, of Ultra, the operation by which the Allies intercepted, rendered intelligible and circulated the coded messages that the Germans transmitted by radio during World War II. In reviewing it, Drew Middleton called it ''truth far more engrossing than fiction. No important future history of the war can conceivably be written without consulting it.'' TERMINATION ORDER, by Philip Friedman. (Dell, $2.25.) Gregory Moore, who has identified as a Russian mole a high official in the Central Intelligence Agency at Langley, Va., goes to Vienna to see that justice is done there, only to find himself on both the C.I.A. and K.G.B. hit lists. ''Philip Friedman goes Len Deighton one better. He paints a grim picture with literary finesse,'' Newgate Callendar declared. ''One of the best spy stories of the year.''

More than a dozen years ago, when Mrs. B moved into her $112-amonth railroad flat in the low 100's off Central Park West, her building was freshly painted, the front door secure, heat and hot water were taken for granted, and her neighbors were working people. Today, that same building is scarred by graffiti, the front door hangs open and useless, and the top-floor apartments, long vacant, serve as gathering places for narcotics addicts. In one ground-floor apartment, drug dealers openly conduct business. Heat and hot water are only memories here. Last summer the landlord told his remaining tenants, mainly welfare clients, that he was giving up.

THESE days, panda bears, pink elephants and lions perch on top of the new cars at Kalaydjian Pontiac in Mount Kisco. Edward Kalaydjian, the dealership's president, hopes that the huge stuffed animals will attract customers and boost sagging automobile sales. Mr. Kalaydjian's gimmick may be unusual, but his predicament is not. In Westchester, combined sales of foreign and domestic cars are down 20 percent from last year at this time, according to Peter Gordon, executive vice president of the Greater New York Automobile Dealers' Association. (Nationally, Mr. Gordon said, sales are down approximately 35 percent.) Since the first of the year, he said, five dealerships in the county have gone out of business, leaving a total of 80.

WHITE PLAINS JUST a year after the quadruple Bedford Hills killings, the Westchester County District Attorney's office had another major slaying case on its hands last week, that of Eleanor Ryan Prouty, who was strangled in the early morning hours last Sunday in her historic Somers home. For Carl Anthony Vergari, the District Attorney since 1968, the timing was particularly depressing. The death of Mrs. Prouty, a retired senior editor at The Reader's Digest, came just as the end of the Bedford case was in sight, with two men to be sentenced Wednesday on four counts of second-degree murder.

SOME cellists spend half their lives complaining about the sparse repertory for their instrument, especially compared to that for violin or piano, while others prefer to seek out unusual pieces and fresh methods of presenting them. Heinrich Joachim, who teaches both at the Westchester Conservatory of Music in White Plains and the Armonk Village School of Music, seems clearly to be of the latter persuasion, his enthusiasm for the cello and its music matched only by his missionary zeal in bringing audiences around to his point of view. ''It's an interesting thing,'' Mr. Joachim told me, ''that the cello is much better liked in southern Westchester than in the northern communities. There are excellent cello faculties at the conservatories in White Plains and Scarsdale, to name just two, we have many interested students and a very large audience for the instrument. It's just not so in the upper parts of the county, though, and that's one of the reasons I try to put on concerts in Armonk that are novel and rather special in one way or another.''

While everyone was preoccupied this spring with Afghanistan and Iran and how they overlapped into questions of trans-Atlantic solidarity, there was a strange flutter of nervousness in Bonn and Frankfurt that got barely any attention at all. Beneath the high, jarring frequencies of discussion of war and peace, there was an undertone of concern about the West German economy. Just as West Germany was starting to fully play the political role of Europe's leading power - with responsibility for the efforts of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to shore up its Turkish and Greek flanks, more activity within the International Monetary Fund and an unprecedented visit by Defense Minister Hans Apel to Asia - the economic underpinnings of that role looked threatened.

The finals of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's national championship regatta were postponed today because high winds made the waters of Lake Onondaga too rough. The races for 92 crews from 26 colleges were rescheduled for tomorrow. It was the first such postponement in the 27 years the regatta has been held here.

It has been, as gardeners know, a vintage year for tulips and magnolias. And, from the ominous evidence along roadsides and stone walls, it is going to be a bumper year for poison ivy. The vines and their triple leaves are bigger than they have been for years and the stems are thick with deadly sap. Poison ivy, or Rhus radicans, is a peculiarly American problem. It does not grow naturally on any continent but ours. Early European naturalists who came collecting plants were fascinated by it and sent carefully-wrapped specimens of this new-world wonder back home to their patrons. (A Swede named Kalm, around 1750, told of his assistant who, like generations of fools after him, said he could handle the stuff, pulled up plants by the dozens and wound up bedecked with itching blisters.) A botanist visiting Russia not long ago was proudly shown a carefully tended century-old plant in a Leningrad arboretum. In England, however, the Royal Horticultural Society warns that Rhus radicans ''should not be planted as a climber on the house.''

St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church was the setting yesterday evening for the marriage of Karen Elizabeth Springhorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Springhorn of Blue Point, L.I., to John Zeller Gage. He is the son of Mrs. Harold S. Berry of Llewellyn Park, N.J., and Singer Island, Fla., and the late John Hunter Gage. The Revs. Raphael Monteleone and Paul Walsh officiated. Kathleen Springhorn was maid of honor for her twin. Harold S. Berry served as best man for his stepson. The bride, an editorial administrator in the corporate communications department of the Colgate-Palmolive Company, is an alumna of the Queen Elizabeth School in Warwickshire, England, and of Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y.

Four times Grete Waitz has come here from Oslo to run, and four times her race has ended with a world record. From the moment that Mayor Koch started the L'eggs Mini Marathon yesterday until race officials struggled to keep the finish line in one piece 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) later, Mrs. Waitz's closest competition was from a Department of Sanitation truck. It was decorated in orange, white and blue, that held her husband, Jack, and others who took her picture and talked about her record pace in English and Norwegian.

PATTERNS IN PREHISTORY Mankind's First Three Million Years. By Robert J. Wenke. Illustrated. 724 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $35. THE PREHISTORY OF THE MEDITERRANEAN By D.H. Trump. Illustrated. 310 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $19.95.

ASYLUM PIECE And Other Stories. By Anna Kavan. 206 pp. New York: Michael Kesend Publishing. $11.95. SLEEP HAS HIS HOUSE By Anna Kavan. 182 pp. New York: Michael Kesend Publishing. $11.95. THESE slender volumes by the much-admired English writer ''Anna Kavan'' (the pseudonym of Helen Woods Edmonds, who died in London in 1968 from a heroin overdose) are haunting and obsessive studies of what she calls the ''inexorable self, carried like the superfluous and tiresome piece of luggage which it is impossible to lose.'' Though they vary surprisingly in tone and language - ''Sleep Has His House'' is an assemblage of prose poems, ''Asylum Piece'' is a less unified collection of stories of a frequently abstract nature - they are both compulsive meditations upon the ostensible unfairness of life as it was experienced by a woman whose hatred of the ''real'' world is positively astounding. As Kavan's autobiographical heroine says in the story ''High in the Mountains'' (from Kavan's best-known book, ''Julia and the Bazooka,'' Knopf, 1975): ''I know I've got a death wish. I've never enjoyed my life, I've never liked people. I love the mountains because they are the negation of life. ... Human beings are hateful; I loathe their ugly faces and messy emotions. I'd like to destroy them all. People have always been horrible to me; they've always rejected and betrayed me. Not one of them has ever been kind. Not a single person has even attempted to understand me, to see things from my point of view. ... How can I help hating them all? Sometimes they disgust me so much that I feel I can't go on living among them -that I must escape from the loathsome creatures swarming like maggots all over the earth.''

The purchase of existing homes in rundown neighborhoods is, in total sales, ''still a drop in the national bucket,'' according to a survey, ''U.S. Housing Markets,'' published by the Advance Mortage Corporation of Detroit, an affiliate of Oppenheimer & Company, mortgage bankers. The report said there were probably fewer than 100,000 home sales in ''revitalization neighborhoods'' last year out of a total of nearly 4 million. Sales accelerated in 1979, it added, ''and it should be even stronger in the next decade as housing inflation continues and commuting costs and times keep expanding.''

Divorce reform has been creeping along at a snail's pace in New York State. Since Senator Linda Winikow, the sponsor of ''equal distribution,'' and I both represent Westchester, the county has become the center of the battle between the forces of ''equal'' and ''equitable'' in the state. Several articles have appeared in this paper and in other media that have misrepresented many of the facts relating to my ''equitable distribution'' legislation. After a divorce, property would be divided equitably according to a list of criteria that includes the duration of the marriage, age and health of both parties and contributions and services as a spouse, parent, wage-earner and homemaker. The court is charged with setting forth the factors it considered and the reasons for its decision. The Burrows-Barclay bill has broad sponsorship in the Legislature and is supported by the Office of Court Administration as well as by all of the Bar Associations.

CONDITIONS at the old health center had become so cramped and crowded,'' said Mattie Smalls, chairman of the board of the Mount Vernon Neighborhood Health Center, as she stood in front of the new facility, ''that when a patient fainted, he had to stand up,'' After three years of construction, hampered by disputes and delays, the doors to the new health center opened on May 23 to the plaudits of residents and county, state and Federal officials. The $2.5 million, 50,000-square-foot building, at 107 West Fourth Street, three blocks away from the old center on South Seventh Avenue, will serve as the 7-year-old center's permanent headquarters. The threestory, red-brick facility is the largest of four such health centers in Westchester that receive funds from the county and get some of their staff from it but maintain their independence. The other three are in Greenburgh, Peekskill and Ossining.

NEW HAVEN WITH more than a handful of relatively good Italian restaurants, residents of New Haven are luckier than most of us. This isn't many, considering the number of Italian-Americans in town and in the state; still, it is cause for some celebration to find a really good one. One of New Haven's better choices is Delmonaco's, which manages to please both the eye and the palate. This is certainly one of the prettiest restaurants we have visited lately. Its interior has a Mediterranean coolness, with Roman arches, alcoves, white stucco walls, low ceilings, a richness of tropical plants and fresh flowers on each table.

forecasts of a severe recession and a surge in unemployment, most people who put in their years at graduate school are finding the effort pays - well. Men and women with advanced degrees in business, law and engineering are moving into the work force at salaries of $20,000 and often much more, while those with no more than a bachelor's degree usually start with half as much. For a couple of years, some employment experts have been predicting that the nation's business schools would soon saturate the market, putting a squeeze on salaries. So far, though, there are few signs of that, at least at the established schools. Demand for new masters of business administration is still outrunning supply, said William Lyhne, assistant director of Executive Compensation Services, a unit of the American Management Association. ''There'll never be a glut of M.B.A.'s,'' he said.

Playing amid wind and dust on the center court of Roland Garros Stadium, Billie Jean King needed three sets to defeat 23-year-old Leslie Allen of New York, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, and reach the quarterfinals of the French open tennis championships today. ''I couldn't believe the conditions out there,'' said Mrs. King. ''I felt so foolish. I was giving it everything I had and I couldn't even reach the net with the ball.''

by John Wang The proposal made last month by the Chinese National People's Congress, the nominal national legislature, to delete the ''four big democratic rights'' from the nation's Constitution has suggested to some in the West that the Chinese Government, after a period of liberalization, is once again curtailing freedom of expression. However, I believe Americans have viewed this change only through eyes used to judging political events against their own history and, in this case, have gathered a mistaken impression. These rights - the right to speak out freely, to air views fully, to hold debates, and to write big-character posters - carry quite a different connotation for the Chinese than the free-speech, freepress and freedom-of-assembly clauses in the Bill of Rights do for us.

The nation's philanthropic foundations, already hard-hit by inflation, have expressed increasing concern about the shrinking public funds available for community services. Their preoccupation with impending cutbacks in Government spending was evident this week at the 31st annual conference of the Council on Foundations, with many of the 950 participants acknowledging that dwindling resources would curtail or even end a range of social, health and welfare services.

It was 1 P.M. on a sunny Monday last summer. Anna Thornhill noticed the young man as she ran passed him on a hill in Central Park, but she wasn't really nervous because there were other runners around. ''He didn't make a sound as I went past him, and I was running fast because I was training for a marathon,'' she recalled the other day. ''But when I had gone about 30 feet,'' she continued, ''there it was - the moment of recognition that this was it. He came bounding after me, grabbed me by my shorts and tugged at my undergarments. I tried to hit him with my elbow, but he avoided that completely. Then I lifted my hand to hit him and screamed and he let me go and disappeared into the bushes.''

Ugandans By PRANAY B. GUPTE KAMPALA, Uganda - When Ambassador Andrew Young visited Uganda earlier this year, President Godfrey L. Binaisa told him that at least $3 billion in foreign aid was needed to rebuild the economy, which had been ''totally devastated'' by civil war and the chaos of Idi Amin's dictatorship. Coffee production, the national mainstay, was a shambles, and sugar, another foreign exchange earner, lay rotting in warehouses because trucks and roads were not functioning. Between 1971 and 1979 -the Amin years - production of the key export crops, tea, coffee, sugar and cotton, fell 51 percent, the European Economic Commission reported. After President Amin expelled 75,000 Asians in the early 1970's, production of sugar, an Asian-controlled industry, dropped. Sugar refineries still are working at less than 30 percent of capacity. Mr. Binaisa tried to woo back Asian entrepreneurs such as the Madhvani family, but they have been been hesitant.

To the Sports Editor: You have done a great service to women's track and field with the article by Barbara Kevles (''Olympic Marathon Is More Than a Physical Struggle for Women,'' The New York Times, May 18), which made a plea for a women's marathon in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. However, it should be pointed out that any host organizing committee, such as the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, does not have an influence on the number of sports that will be staged. In this case, the Los Angeles group said that they would organize for all 21 sports on the approved program.

by Dean Alfange To the Editor: The continuing and often acrimonious debate between lawyers and legal scholars on the restrictive orientation of the Supreme Court under Chief Justice Burger is not likely to be abated by its recent decision in Rhode Island v. Innis. In that case a sharply divided Court held that a casual remark by a police officer that led a suspect to incriminate himself was not a departure from Miranda v. Arizona, a landmark Warren Court decision, which gave criminal suspects maximum protection against unlawful police interrogation.

The one square mile that encompasses the city of Bordentown contains more history than any other square mile in the country, according to the Bordentown Historical Society. There is hardly a house in the 298-year-old city that is not at least a century old, and many will be open to the public today for the society's annual open-house tour. Among the 21 homes, buildings and gardens to be open will be Divine Word Seminary-Bonaparte Park; this is part of the estate of Joseph Bonaparte, the exiled King of Spain and brother of Napoleon, who lived in Bordentown for 28 years in the early 19th century.

Most people simply do not listen enough and make decisions too quickly,'' says Dr. Evelyn Golding, a psychologist at the National Hospital for Nervous Diseases in London. Having administered a simple test of logic to a group of normal individuals, Dr. Golding is also saying that man's mind ''does not follow the straightforward pattern of reasoning one would expect.'' In fact, Dr. Golding believes that in most people, the right hemisphere of the brain, which is skilled in visual, spatial tasks, overpowers the less well-developed left side of the brain, which is good at abstract, logical and verbal tasks. And she has the data to prove it.

At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest yesterday, Claudia Allen DeSantis, daughter of Mary Allen DeSantis of New York and Anthony DeSantis of London, was married to Peter Armistead Bowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Eugene Bowe of Annapolis, Md. The Rev. John Fisher performed the ceremony.

CAIRO, May 31--The Israeli Ambassador to Egypt, Eliahu Ben-Elissar, took a long walk through downtown Cairo today to deliver a message to President Anwar el-Sadat and to explain why Prime Minister Menachem Begin reportedly threatened that he might delay Israel's final withdrawal from the Sinai Peninsula.

June is the traditional month to pay tribute to the rose. This year particular honors go to three of the world's leading hy bridizers for new roses they submitted to the national testing organization, All-America Rose Selections.

It has been, as gardeners know, a vintage year for tulips and magnolias. And, from the ominous evidence along roadsides and stone walls, it is going to be a bumper year for poison ivy. The vines and their triple leaves are bigger than they have been for years and the stems are thick with deadly sap.

Nancy Ellen Pader, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Elmer Pader of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Dr. Alan Marc Leiken, son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Leiken of Flushing, Queens. Rabbi Jerome Blass performed the ceremony at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J.

Jeanie Pogue Gerst and Benjamin Brandreth McAlpin 3d were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Bradford Hastings performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. David Hunter McAlpin, a cousin of the bridegroom.

Now that summer is in the air, so are mosquitoes, flies, moths, bees, gnats and wasps --to say nothing of Japanese beetles and other pests that eat up flowers and plants. It is enough to make people trigger-happy with bug sprays, ...

LOS ANGELES, May 31--California's 10 million registered voters, who have often swung their weight decisively in Presidential races, appear to feel that they do not matter to this year's nominations, and that attitude threatens to foil Senator Edward M. Kennedy's bid for an upset over President Carter.

EVEN though his family had moved to Texas and he was stationed overseas, Navy Lieut. Comdr. Robert A. En gelmann, class of '68, kept up his membership in the State University of Stony Brook Alumni Association.

BRIDGEHAMPTON ELAINE BENSON opens the season in characteristically grand style with "At the Greengrocer," a large and lively exhibi tion of fruit and vegetable subjects by 35 artists. Such theme shows are notable ...
They're called "jelly shoes," and if they'd been around when Charlie Chaplin made a meal of his boot in "The Gold Rush," the little tramp would probably have selected them for dessert.

WASHINGTON, May 31--The Administration will send a mission to Liberia tomorrow to encourage its new military rulers to forgo further violence against former leaders in return for American cooperation and assistance, Government officials said yesterday.

NIAGARA-ON-THE-LAKE, Ontario --Andrei Serban's controversial 1977 staging of "The Cherry Orchard" is now sifting down into the provinces. The Shaw Festival's production of Chekhov's masterpiece, featuring Carole Shelley as Mme. Ranevsky, looks like a bus-and-truck knock-off of the Lincoln Center version.

PARIS, May 31--Playing amid wind and dust on the center court of Roland Garros Stadium, Billie Jean King needed three sets to defeat 23-year-old Leslie Allen of New York, 6-4, 3-6, 6-2, and reach the quarterfinals of the French open tennis championships today.
SYRACUSE, May 31--The finals of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's national championship regatta were postponed today because high winds made the waters of Lake Onondaga too rough.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., May 31-- Monica Egbouno of Sewanhaka High School of Floral Park broke the state record in the 400-meter run in the Nassau County girls' track and field championships at Post College today.
HAVING read many learn-to-sail books, I have yet to encounter a single discussion of what I find critical to practical sailing --walking the boat.

AFTER more than five years of litigation, it took the state just 24 hours to issue a check for $3.248 million last Wednesday as a result of acquiring less than half an acre of land for which it now has no use. The cost to Connecticut resulted from acquisition of the land through condemnation by the Department of Transportation for a plan that was later abandoned.

NORWALK BASKETBALL coaches in Fairfield County still talk about a former high-school coach in Stamford who sometimes punished his players for losing by forcing them to stand outside the team bus after a game in the bitter cold for as long as a half-hour. And at least one present and one former high-school hockey coach in the county are noted for provoking their players into fights when their teams were trailing in a game. That has never been Tom Chrzanowski's style. In his 11 years as varsity baseball coach at Brien McMahon High School here he has acquired a reputation among many of his peers as a solid coach, a good teacher and a gentleman.

IRECENTLY returned from my first trip to Africa, and I am more determined than ever to promote understanding and cooperation between the peoples of Africa and the United States. I spent eight days in Burundi as the guest of Col. Jean-Baptiste Bagaza, the President of that Central African nation, and I also visited nearby Tanzania for four days.

The most graceful exit from the stage of rock and roll is a quick one. Old age - even middle age - is often a source of embarrassment in a music that is primarily the province of the young. Buddy Holly, who recorded all his important music in a scant twoand-a-half years before dying in a 1959 plane crash at an even younger age than Keats, was recently celebrated in a hagiographical film. But there is little reverence in rock and roll for long-lived Wordsworths. Last year, Chuck Berry, one of rock's founding fathers and now nearing 50, recorded a superb album, ''Rockit,'' full of wistful and witty reflections on racism in America and his own decline in popularity. ''Rockit,'' however, received almost as little attention as Mr. Berry's subsequent imprisonment for incometax evasion.

Automobile fads tend to idle for a while, rev up and then burn down the road. So it may be with the black car. Once the only choice for American autophiles, it was eclipsed in the 1950's and 1960's, the era of two-tone and even three-tone cars. But enough was enough, apparently, and black is back. ''We have seen a resurgence of black in both trucks and cars of all sizes,'' said George Moon, executive designer for the General Motors Corporation. ''I think it's somewhat an awareness of elegance and a feeling that a car looks more sophisticated - it's more of a machine.'' Black began to reappear around 1977, Mr. Moon said, when G.M. introduced its first group of ''more tailored, more pristine'' downsized cars.

It had a familiar ring when the open jumper championship was decided and the leading rider was announced tonight at the close of the 84th edition of the Devon Horse Show. It should have. Rodney Jenkins, a 35-year-old from Orange, Va., rode the winner of the title, Second Balcony, and also won the award as the leading jumper rider.

Ruth Elizabeth Chitwood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Randolph Chitwood of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Donald Joseph Conti. The ceremony was performed in St. Saviour's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Martyn Minns, assisted by the Rev. Robert Miner. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Conti of the Bronx.

Kirk Honeycutt, a freelance writer, frequently reports on the film scene. By KIRK HONEYCUTT HOLLYWOOD Posing between his two co-stars on a Universal Studios Tour trolley car for a photo session, Gene Kelly tooted merrily away on a clarinet. Olivia Newton-John and Michael Beck held their ears in mock anguish. In truth, Mr. Kelly's clarinet playing did sound pretty atrocious. Curious workmen on the Universal lot wandered over to discover the source of the strange noise.

Col. Keith Robertson, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Robertson of Santa Ana Heights, Calif., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Michelle Anne Robertson, to Archibald Douglas 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas 3d of Princeton, N.J. A July 19 wedding is planned in Santa Ana Heights.

For many years, it has been an axiom of community planning that people of different ages, races, life styles and incomes should live mixed together. The concept has frequently sparked community controversies, but has generally received wide support among planners.

THESE days, panda bears, pink elephants and lions perch on top of the new cars at Kalaydjian Pontiac in Mount Kisco. Edward Kalaydjian, the dealership's president, hopes that the huge stuffed animals will attract customers and boost sagging automobile sales.

In the last few decades, millions of Americans have made significant changes in the foods they eat. They've reduced their reliance on saturated animal fats, like butter and lard, and greatly increased their use of polyunsaturated vegetable oils (the net result, however, has been a higher total fat consumption). They've cut drastically the number of eggs they consume and reduced their intake of fluid milk.
HUGH LEONARD'S recollections of his Dublin childhood are a charming and gritty adver tisement for the past, without being quite the real thing.

TRENTON, May 31--As Senator Edward M. Kennedy campaigned here this week, he said at a news conference: "We have to win in New Jersey." He refused to speculate on what he would do if he lost the state's Presidential primary to President Carter next Tuesday, but he made it clear that a victory was vital to his continuation as a candidate.

Adecade ago,'' said County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, ''we were looking at a county that really had no transportation, internally, by way of buses, to speak of, except those buses which were serving the densely populated cities.'' Mr. DelBello, in a recent reflection on changes in Westchester's transportation picture, noted accomplishments over the last decade and attempted to identify suburban transportation trends. ''If there's an identifiable trend,'' he said, ''I think it is the development of the paratransit system.'' This system, he explained, is a ''second level'' of bus services beyond the fixed routes that tie major population centers together and into the more sparsely settled regions.

SOUTH ORANGE ''SOMETIMES,'' the tall woman in the navy blue pants-suit said the other morning, ''I get so angry over the way I'm treated that I fume. All I'm trying to do is get a simple answer from the doctor about my mother's condition, and I can't take being turned off so coldly.''

A new series of reports on industry in New York depicts a continuing tourist boom, strong airline and motion-picture operations, a ''modest revival'' in printing and new potential for the garment trades, the waterfront and industrial development. The conclusions have been drawn in a dozen studies in various fields and are to be published by the New York University Graduate School of Public Administration in its quarterly, New York Affairs.

Veronique de La Bruyere, daughter of Mrs. Frederic P. Herter of New York and Jean de La Bruyere of Paris and Edmonton, Alberta, was married in New York yesterday to Marc Michael James Starko, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander M. Starko of Edmonton. The Rev. Paul Zahl performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

Watson By TERENCE SMITH WASHINGTON - At one point late last month, the Federal response to an array of crises was being coordinated from one office on the second floor of the west wing of the White House. Its occupant, Jack H. Watson Jr., was coping with, among other things, the aftermath of a racial eruption in Miami and a volcanic explosion in Washington state. At the same time, the 41-year-old assistant to the President was preparing a speech to be delivered to the National Urban League in New York and dealing with a sensitive Presidential appointment and the flood of Cuban refugees. Nearby, Mr. Watson's staff was arranging his schedule for this weekend's annual meeting in Seattle of the U.S. Conference of Mayors.

Sally Jarvis Lawson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Thomas Lawson 3d of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Job Taylor 3d of New York. The Rev. Alfred H. Whisler performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan. Ellen B. Fox and Ernest J. Getto attended the couple.

Ancient coins are Greek to many collectors - the numismatic masses tend to dismiss this segment of the hobby as too complex and obscure, and they look upon its pursuit in much the way that adolescents view the study of Latin. But while Latin may be dead, ancient coins are very much alive as collector's items today - and they're growing more lively all the time. Evidence of their strength was furnished last month when an auction sale of Roman coins by Stack's of New York brought prices totaling $1.1 million. That isn't a fabulous sum when measured against the prices seen at sales of United States coins, but it's very impressive indeed when judged by the performance charts of ancient coins in the past.

Monica Egbouno of Sewanhaka High School of Floral Park broke the state record in the 400-meter run in the Nassau County girls' track and field championships at Post College today. She was timed in 54.9 seconds. Donna Geiselman of Plainedge broke her Nassau record in the 800 with a clocking of 2:12.5. Mepham of Bellmore won the team title, with Port Washington second and Malverne third.

Tom Donohue and Bert Campaneris each hit two-run homers to back the combined four-hit pitching of Bruce Kison and Dave LaRoche as the California Angels defeated the Detroit Tigers, 6-1, today. Kison (3-4) was masterful in the early innings, giving up a twoout single to Steve Kemp in the first inning and then retiring the next 13 batters in order before walking Kirk Gibson to start the Detroit sixth.

WHEN people ask about her, we tell them she is living with us, but is she really? It would be better to say she is staying with us, or better yet, that she is our sitter. You would have to look pretty closely even to know she is sitting there. She is very small and the chair is very big, and the way she sinks into a corner of it, all huddled up like a ball, she seems even tinier - hardly bigger, it seems, than the pillow she is so attached to.

Time was when the aspiring discount stockbroker would set out after investors with nothing more than a toll-free WATS line and a blurry snapshot of himself for saturation advertising in the back pages of daily financial sections. No frills, no hot tips - just order executions at bargain-basement prices. Now, just five years after the Government forced competition in setting commission rates, discount brokerage is a thriving subindustry. The discerning investor can deal with a discounter right in his own home town, find commission bargains in a widening array of investment products, and command a fair amount of service at no extra charge, including such once unheard-of ''extras'' as investment advice.

Doug Latrenta and Vin Merolla of St. John's University will lead New York against New Jersey in the first college senior all-star baseball game next Saturday at Yankee Stadium. The teams, announced last week, were selected by a board of coaches from both states. The game will be the second half of an amateur doubleheader, with the New York City Roman Catholic high school championship starting the day at noon.

coronary artery cross-sections By JANE E. BRODY In the last few decades, millions of Americans have made significant changes in the foods they eat. They've reduced their reliance on saturated animal fats, like butter and lard, and greatly increased their use of polyunsaturated vegetable oils (the net result, however, has been a higher total fat consumption). They've cut drastically the number of eggs they consume and reduced their intake of fluid milk. These changes were prompted partly by economics and partly by a growing concern for health. For all the foods that have lost in popularity are reputed to be bad for the heart.

And they got another object lesson in frustration at the annual meeting last week of the First Pennsylvania Corporation, owner of the First Pennsylvania Bank.

PORT JEFFERSON WHO owns the garbage? Village Highway Department workers are sifting through piles of rotting refuse, looking for clues, in the village parking lot here. Unless the culprits are found, summer weather will exacerbate the odor and the argument between the Mayor and merchants over who picks it up. Merchants and village officials are at odds over who is responsible for removing garbage illegally dumped next to privately owned ''dumpsters'' - locked metal containers about six feet wide and four feet high - in the village parking lot. The merchants pay a fee to private sanitation companies for the dumpsters to be emptied by forklift at least weekly, but the sanitationmen do not leave their trucks to pick up garbage strewn about the parking lot.

NEW HAVEN WITH a leadership struggle averted and Ronald Reagan coasting toward the Presidential nomination, some Connecticut Republicans are aiming for a goal that has eluded them in recent years - a decent showing in the November elections. An obstacle to party harmony was removed here the other night when Ralph E. Capecelatro, a six-term First Selectman of Orange and a veteran party worker, was elected Republican state chairman by acclamation after his only potential challenger, Louise Berry of Danielson, a former State Senator, withdrew.

Complaints against landlords in New York City are sharply on the rise, according to public and private agencies concerned with the problem. The majority of the complaints are about alleged overcharging, but apparently stricter landlord enforcement of rental leases is also prompting inquiries from tenants. Frank S. Kristof, president of a group that represents owners of rent-stabilized apartments, said the association was getting 600 calls a day, compared with 20 or 30 a day not too long ago. He said that 62 percent of the calls were from tenants and 38 percent from owners. He explained that he thought the upsurge was ''directly related to the tightness of the market.'' Landlords, he said, are being ''sorely tempted by the eagerness of tenants to find homes.''

Steve Carlton became the first nine-game winner in the major leagues this season and Mike Schmidt slammed two home runs today to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Carlton (9-2) worked seven innings. He struck out 11 for the fourth time this season and did not allow a walk while scattering four hits. Dickie Noles hurled the final two innings for the Phils.

by Polly S. Brooks To the Editor: At the time of the volcanic eruption of Mount Vesuvius almost 2,000 years ago, the Roman naturalist Pliny the Elder set off across the Bay of Naples to investigate the volcanic phenomena. He was overcome by gaseous fumes and died of asphyxiation a few miles south of the mountain. {liny} has more to offer than his death. A lover of nature, he deplored man's depredation of earth, ''ever fertile for man's benefit,'' and suggested it was not surprising that our planet became indignant from time to time, trembling in earthquakes or erupting in volcanic explosions.

At a clinic for paraplegics, Regazzoni has been allowed to get out of bed and sit in a wheelchair for 30-minute periods in the morning and afternoon.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Thaddeus J. Blank of Pelham Manor, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Eva Marie Blank, to Bouvier Beale Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Beale of Glen Cove and Bridgehampton, L.I. The couple plan to be married in Bridgehampton Sept. 20. Miss Blank, a ticket agent with Air France in San Francisco, graduated from Boston College. Her father is a project manager with Lockwood Greene Engineers Inc. in New York.

Lois Anne Wholey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Wholey of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Douglas D. Danforth Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Danforth, also of Pittsburgh. The Rev. George A. Wilt performed the ceremony in St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church in Mount Lebanon, Pa. The bride, an alumna of Northwestern University, will graduate next Sunday from the Duquesne University School of Law. Her father is owner of the Robert Wholey Company, importer and retail and wholesale distributor of seafood.

June is the traditional month to pay tribute to the rose. This year particular honors go to three of the world's leading hybridizers for new roses they submitted to the national testing organization, All-America Rose Selections. The three prizewinning roses are the culmination of years of breeding efforts by Ollie Weeks and Herbert C. Swim, two California hybridists, and Reimer Kordes, whose family has been at the forefront of German rose breeding for generations. The honored roses are Bing Crosby, an orange hybrid tea; Marina, an orange floribunda, and White Lightnin', a white grandiflora.

The domed concrete tower, which President Carter couldn't stop France from building, now soars 252 feet into the air here, on a bend in the swift-flowing Rhone about 40 miles south of Lyons. It is virtually complete, except for a big hole in one side. Through this hole, a cluster of yellow and green derricks last month gingerly maneuvered inside the first of the two gigantic steel cauldrons, one fitting inside the other, which will eventually hold the fiery plutonium heart of the Super-Phoenix, the world's first commercial-sized fast-breeder reactor.

THE BUDGET: For the first time in 12 years, Congress had produced a deficit-free budget proposal. But budget-balancing fever seems to have cooled considerably and the resolution suffered a sound defeat in the House last week. It was returned to the House-Senate conference committee for more pulling and tugging. Liberal Democrats thought the proposal gave too much to the military and cut social programs too harshly. Conservative Republicans said the budget was too high, balanced with sleight-ofhand and was without provision for a tax cut.

Paul Molitor had four hits and Ben Oglivie, Jim Gantner and Robin Yount each had three as the Milwaukee Brewers scored a 19-8 victory over the Red Sox despite six Boston home runs. The Brewers pounded four Red Sox pitchers for 22 hits, including seven doubles and Yount's eighth homer and Molitor's fourth. The 19 runs and 22 hits set Brewer records.

one of the higher absurdities of American politics. Whatever the final figure of the defense budget, Congress is plainly determined to splurge an ocean of money for national security, narrowly defined. Indeed, it is considering a 20 percent increase over a five-year period, resulting in total expenditures of nearly one trillion 1980 dollars. But what about national security, broadly defined? Money, and lots of it, seems available to narrow various gaps that the service chiefs discern: the missile gap, the naval gap, the tank gap, the aircraft gap. By contrast, only a pittance is committed to narrowing the global poverty gap, even though national security is palpably threatened by the abyss that separates the affluent from the wretched - the more so since OPEC prices began to devastate the poorest third of the world.

Sixteen nations will compete in the Young Masters Chiquita Cup international tennis tournament for players 21 years and under at Central Park Aug. 18. This is a new event organized by People-to-People Sports and the Port Washington (L.I.) Tennis Academy. Peru has named two Davis Cup players, Alberto Franco, who is attending Yale, and Pablo Arraya, a student at Arkansas. The United States team has not yet been chosen.

Now, at the age of 24, after treatment with a new and controversial technique, Sara is a hard-working model and recently started an acting career.
