But, of course, said participants, they will present a report to the Bureau of the International when it meets in Oslo June 12-13, and, of course, the subject of the hostages came up in their conversations with Iranian leaders and assorted politicians.

Harlem's Phil Rucker Summer Professional League will hold a benefit doubleheader for the family of Herman Knowings, a noted schoolyard basketball player who was killed in a car accident April 12. The benefit is next Sunday, starting at 2:30 P.M. at Brandeis High School, Columbus Avenue and 84th Street. Knowings, known to most Rucker fans as Herman The Helicopter, was killed when a car jumped the divider on the 145th Street Bridge and collided with the taxi he was driving. He was 37 years old and had seven children by two marriages.

The stamps of the United Nations have chronicled the great issues confronting it, the goals it pursues to better the lot of humanity, and the efforts it makes to maintain peace in a divided and troubled world. The newest stamps chronicle an occasion of celebration, the 35th anniversary of an organization that is still one of the most vital instruments of world peace. Six stamps and three souvenir sheets are being issued on June 26 to commemorate the signing of the U.N. Charter at a conference in San Francisco that was the culmination of four years of planning, even while World War II was still raging. Many older Americans still remember that conference for another reason - it was preceded by a few weeks by the sudden death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt who was working on his speech to the conference when he died.

Myerson of New York and the late Mr. Myerson. The Rev. Bruce W. Forbes performed the ceremony in St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church.

Because of an editing error in an article in this section last Sunday, a summary of criticisms of the Connecticut Housing Finance Authority was incorrectly reported as being a direct quotation from an audit of the agency. The material was a paraphrase of criticism from various sources. In addition, according to Leo V. Donohue, Connecticut's Auditor of Public Accounts, the document that was described as an audit signed by Chief Auditor John Connelly was instead a memorandum, a copy of which was intended for Mr. Connelly, commenting on the housing finance agency's response to an earlier audit.

President Carter has politicians, money, history and the conservative attitudes of southern Ohio and some Cleveland suburbs going for him here Tuesday as he tries for his first primary victory in an industrial state in 11 weeks. In a state where layoff announcements punctuate the evening news, Senator Edward M. Kennedy has his own intense campaigning and widespread fears about the economy working for him. Nevertheless, he trails in public opinion polls, and almost all leading Democratic politicians, most of whom support Mr. Carter, believe that the President is ahead in the contest for 161 delegates.

TIME OF DESECRATION By Alberto Moravia. Translated by Angus Davidson. 376 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. ''TIME OF DESECRATION,'' Alberto Moravia's 21st volume of fiction, is an odd and intriguing experiment in using the erotic novel as an instrument for the scrutiny of political behavior. Though occasional allusions are made to the ideal of revolution, though Marx is once actually discussed by two of the characters, scarcely anything happens in the novel that is not explicitly, claustrophobically, steamily sexual. The effect of the book, however, is quite the reverse of the conventional erotic novel. There is nothing rousing or arousing about the relentless sequence of sexual scenes: Sex for the female protagonist is alternately a sordid means to an end and a ghastly trap; and her flat-toned narration of her erotic experiences ''defamiliarizes'' them by allowing no other feelings toward them to emerge.

ZOLTAN MERSZEI, who was born and raised in Hungary, was part of a lonely crowd a decade ago. Moving up the ranks of the Dow Chemical Company, he recalled, he knew of only one foreign born executive running a big American company. That was Ian MacGregor, the Scottishborn chairman of Amax Inc., who a month ago was recruited to run Britain's ailing state-owned steel industry. These days, scores of executives who were born, raised and in some cases began their careers abroad have climbed to the top of American corporations.

By Abba Eban JERUSALEM - Diplomatic convention requires governments to deal with each other and with nobody else. That is the orthodox doctrine, and like many orthodoxies, it is now under challenge. The pretense that existing governments are the only actors in the international system is now giving way, under the influence of public opinion, to a more diverse appraisal of the forces at work. The Israeli Labor Party is now in opposition, but it has been central in Israel's history and may have a large role to play in the near future. There is a growing international interest in its attitudes on four crucial issues: populations, territories, autonomy, and settlements.

AS a professional jockey, I watched this year's Preakness in the jockeys' room at Arlington Park, outside Chicago. When ABC showed the revealing shot of Angel Cordero on Codex coming out into Jacinto Vasquez on Genuine Risk, it did not go unappreciated. ''Did you see him park that jock?'' asked one rider in the group that was comprised of jockeys, valets and assorted jockeys' room personnel assembled beneath the wide-screen television.

Far better it is to dare mighty things, to win glorious triumphs, even though checkered by failure, than to take rank with those poor spirits who neither enjoy much nor suffer much, because they live in that gray twilight that knows not victory nor defeat. THEODORE ROOSEVELT By FRED CICETTI

ANGELO PERRY remembers how ''Pop'' Smith, the principal, used to recite ''Casey at the Bat'' at school assemblies. His wife, Eleanore, remembers how her music teacher, Mrs. Williams, persuaded her parents to give her singing lessons. Billie Cataldo remembers playing volleyball, and Fay Long remembers her prize in penmanship. Half a century later, they are all back in the old red brick school house in Yonkers, but the schoolhouse has changed. Now it has Braille controls for the elevators, wide doorways to accommodate wheelchairs, emergency alarm systems and strong grab-bars with which its occupants lift themselves out of bathtubs.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has ruled out a Remington .30-caliber rifle taken from a motorcyclist here as the weapon used in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, the chief of the bureau's investigation said today. In a briefing at Parkview Memorial Hospital, where Mr. Jordan was being treated, Wayne G. Davis, the special agent in charge of the Indianapolis office, said the markings on the bullet recovered from the scene of the shooting did not match the ''lands and grooves'' in the barrel of the rifle taken from Jon T. Douglas of Fort Wayne several hours after the attack.

Sara Elizabeth Straus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Straus of New York, was married yesterday to Marcus Leslie Byruck, son of Isaac Byruck of London and the late Mrs. Byruck. The ceremony was performed at the home of the bride's parents by Walter Lawton, a leader in the Ethical Culture Society.

In the united nations of bridge, as in the United Nations of the wider world, the Americans tend to be outnumbered by those using authoritarian systems. In the 1979 world team championship in Rio de Janeiro, the American team was the only one in which all three pairs used traditional methods, treating bidding as a dialogue. Of the other 15 pairs, 13 were using rigid one-club systems, in which, in varying degree, the bidding follows a predetermined track. The extreme wing, representing the ultimate in master-and-slave bidding, was the Central American team, in which two pairs used different ''relay'' methods. Jeff Hand and John Maduro used a homemade ''Panama Relay,'' while Alberto Calvo, another Panama expert, and Alberto Dhers of Venezuela used ''Precision Relay,'' the brainchild of Bob Danielson of Hackensack, N.J. The effectiveness of the latter was remarkable, in view of the fact that the players had begun to play it just a month before the championship.

Lacy Hunt is senior vice president and economist of the Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia./ By LACY HUNT/ NEW YORK - Spokesmen for the Carter Administration concede that the recession will be somewhat more severe than they thought. Secretary of the Treasury G. William Miller said last week that the recession appeared ''moderate'' but that the worst ''may be behind us.''

The Test: Look at the top eight cards (A). Note that each has a shape (a circle or a diamond) on one half and a pattern (grey or striped) on the other half. Cover the cards so you cannot see them. Look at the four cards below (B), each half-masked. What could you find under the mask of each in turn? The alternatives are grey or striped for the first two; a circle or a diamond for the other two. Agreed? Now read the following test sentence: ''Whenever there is a circle on one half of the card, there is grey on the other half of the card.'' Your task is to name those cards and only those cards you would need to unmask in order to find whether the test sentence is true or false for the four cards. Answer: You need unmask only two cards: the one with a circle and the one with stripes. On either card, one could find a circle paired with stripes, falsifying the test proposition.

John Mahaffey, who took the lead today in the third round of the Kemper open, and Lee Trevino, who is only one stroke behind, are treating each other with the elaborate courtesy of United States Senators.

B OILING mud traveling 30 miles per hour overflowed local river banks, smashed bridges, swallowed homes and killed millions of salmon and trout. Some rivers got so hot that fish actually jumped out .... The waters of the Toutle River rose from their normal 50 degrees to nearly 90.... An estimated 70 million salmon and trout died in the river and in several state hatcheries that were engulfed by the mud flows.... At one point along the flooded Cowlitz River, which was jammed with timber carried down from the mountain, people made light of their plight - walking on the logs and scooping up steelhead trout that wriggled on the surface.''

Many of the nation's well-known football coaches tentatively approved revised recruiting standards today that would allow only three visits to a high school student at his home, but would permit unlimited visits at his school between Dec. 1 and national signing date. The resolution is expected to be adopted tomorrow by the membership of the College Football Association and forwarded to the National Collegiate Athletic Association for action at its annual convention next January in Miami.

Attendance this season in the North American Soccer League is down 3 percent from last year, with the Cosmos and the Minnesota Kicks showing the biggest dropoffs, 21 and 33 percent, respectively. The average attendance is currently 13,378, compared with 13,779 last season. The Cosmos and the Kicks have been the league's most successful franchises. The Kicks showed a $250,000 profit in 1977, something no other club has done in the league's 14-year-history.

In an effort to focus attention on national coastal-zone management and, locally, on the future of Otter Creek, the Hommocks-Graecen Point Marsh, Premium River and Larchmont Reservoir, where residential development has been proposed, more than 200 youngsters will participate next Sunday morning in the Second Annual Four Kilometer Coastal Run for Children. All fourth to eighth graders are eligible to participate in the 2.5 mile run through Orienta, beginning and ending at Harbor Island Park, Mamaroneck. Phone 834-4188 for the locations at which a $2 advance registration fee may be paid. Registration on the site at 8:30 A.M. next Sunday will cost $3.

MILWAUKEE (AL) - Recalled Paul Mitchell, pitcher, from Vancouver of Pa- cific Coast League. COLLEGES MALONE - Named Lee Erickson head bas- ketball coach. WYOMING - Named Robert Hitch athletic director.

The spread of small performing ensembles into more and more walks of life continues. Look at what's happening in New York City alone. Next season in Manhattan, Calliope, A Renaissance Band will be holding forth at Christ Church United Methodist; in Queens, the Seoul Chamber Ensemble will be functioning on behalf of the Flushing Council on Culture and The Arts of the Downtown Flushing Development Corporation and the Korea News, and in Brooklyn, the Metropolitan Brass Quartet will be sharing its knowledge and artistry at St. James Cathedral. These are three of a new set of appointments in the Paul Chamber Music Residency Program administered by Chamber Music America. What will they do? Calliope's schedule is a case in point. This group of four musicians who play Medieval and Renaissance music will devote 50 days of activity on the church's behalf in a kind of festival from October to May. It will give public concerts in the church's Romanesque sanctuary, some of them to be played free at noon. It will hold weekend workshops for amateurs, those who want to try or improve their skills with recorders, sackbuts and other Renaissance instruments. There will be lecture-demonstrations at various seminaries in town and participation in religious services. A number of children's programs will be organized for the church's day school.

DEVON, Pa., May 31--It had a familiar ring when the open jumper championship was decided and the leading rider was announced tonight at the close of the 84th edition of the Devon Horse Show. It should have.
The Maidenform woman. You never know when she'll turn up.

NEW LONDON, Conn., May 31 (AP)-- Three persons were wounded tonight, at least two of them critically, when a passenger opened fire with a rifle aboard an Amtrak passenger train bound from Washington to Boston, authorities reported.

Georgian mansion that houses the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts here still displays traces of the deterioration that caused the county to shut it down two years ago as a fire hazard. Inside, though, as the June 8 reopening approaches, the rambling manor, once the home of Childs Frick, is assuming signs of the quiet grandeur that made it a lush Gold Coast showcase. The cracked and crumbling decorative moldings that border the mansion's rooms have been seamed with plaster pieces created by making molds from the originals. The marble fireplaces, including one in the dining room with a mantel sporting a lavish bacchanal, have been scrubbed and oiled. The antique knotty pine paneling in the drawing room, brought over from England in 1919 when the Fricks acquired the estate from Lloyd S. Bryce and renovated it, has been repaired.

By Abba Eban JERUSALEM - Diplomatic convention requires governments to deal with each other and with nobody else. That is the orthodox doctrine, and like many orthodoxies, it is now under challenge. The pretense that existing governments are the only actors in the international system is now giving way, under the influence of public opinion, to a more diverse appraisal of the forces at work. The Israeli Labor Party is now in opposition, but it has been central in Israel's history and may have a large role to play in the near future. There is a growing international interest in its attitudes on four crucial issues: populations, territories, autonomy, and settlements.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board has granted three airlines immediate authority to fly from Miami and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to points in the Netherlands Antilles. Eastern Airlines received approval on Friday to fly to St. Martin; American Airlines to serve Aruba, Bonaire and Curacao, and Republic Airlines to serve points of its choosing in the Caribbean islands.

Five thousand people gathered in Middletown, Conn., yesterday to watch Wesleyan University's 148th commencement and to hear the French Foreign Minister, Jean Francois-Poncet, a Wesleyan alumnus, speak on the recent strains in relations between the United States and France.

NOYO HARBOR, Calif., May 26 With the sun well on its way to disappearing under the edge of the Pacific Ocean, a half-dozen fishing boats started lining up to enter this tiny cove. Dan Freitas, captain of the Intrepid, was one of the first to arrive, and he and his crew had enjoyed a good afternoon: They had shoveled more than five tons of rock cod out of the hold.
PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain A CALLIGRAPHY of fluttering fingers that abruptly soar like the birds in his paintings. Or march like tin soldiers across his armchair.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 1 President Carter flew here late this afternoon to visit Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, who was shot and seriously wounded early Thursday by an unknown assailant.

To the Editor: When I arrived in New York in 1926 after working my way around the world, I decided that it was a lousy city to visit but a fine city in which to live. After nearly 54 years as a resident, I still think so. To say it in correct English, I like New York.v.e don't have any earthquakes of any consequence, relatively few hurricanes and those of a rather mild sort; we have no tornadoes or forest fires or brush fires or floods or mud slides down which houses glide into the briney deep; we have no nearby volcanic eruptions, droughts or threatened dust bowls, no 30-degree-below blizzards or 10-foot snow drifts, no sand storms, no 120-degree searing heat. Indeed, no natural calamities of any great moment.

Just before the House rejected the proposed Federal budget last Thursday, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was asked why he had joined the opposition. The first thing he mentioned was a loss of 50,000 jobs under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, known as CETA. This complex jobs program is only one of dozens of domestic programs facing slashes as Congress tries to balance the budget for the fiscal year 1981, the first time in 12 years such a budget has been attempted. House and Senate negotiators will meet again this week to try to devise another compromise budget.

ALBANY2To the Editor: Since three recent articles in The Times (May 14, 18 and 23) have quoted New York State Assembly Democrats with respect to the activities of the Right to Life Party, I would appreciate the opportunity to clarify our position. or a number of months, the Right to Life Party has expressed concern about the activities of the Assembly Democratic leadership. This concern is based on reports that we have received privately from pro-life Democrats who have told us that they have been subject to tremendous pressure from the Assembly leadership whenever the abortion issue comes to a vote.

Can man live by TV Guide alone? No, he needs a TV too. Or does he? Returning from a fireworks concert by the New York Philharmonic in Central Park last summer, I discovered that my apartment had been burglarized and that my television set was missing. Given this unexpected opportunity, I wondered, could I survive without It? Like much of our generation, I was nurtured on the boob tube. So attached was I that I tape recorded the theme song from every series from 1961 to 1969. When other adolescents began dating, I had relationships only via my rabbit ears.

In his introduction to ''The French Defense'' by Gligoric, Uhlmann and Karpov, Mikhail Botvinnik dismissed the Sicilian Defense, remarking, ''It is so worn out that in the near future it will turn into rags.'' Five years later, the rags are still fluttering. The attraction of the Sicilian is its conduciveness to uncompromising struggle. Its reputation was upheld, even in defeat, by the game between John Fedorowicz and Julio Kaplan, both international masters, in the ninth round of the Louis D. Statham International Tournament in Lone Pine, Calif.

Reindustrialization: the word floats conspicuously on the political breezes. It first appeared as a theme of Jerry Brown's abortive campaign for higher office. More recently, Edward Kennedy has declared his support for a ''new economy'' based on reindustrialization; independent candidates John Anderson and Barry Commoner seem to be saying something similar. And the Carter Administration has set up a panel with organized labor to ponder the idea. No one, however, is quite certain what reindustrialization really means. One thing it seems to refer to is the widely felt need to untangle haphazard, inconsistent Government policies that impede productivity and reduce American competitiveness abroad. Another meaning has to do with helping individual communities manage after giant plant closings. But translating these worthy goals into effective policy is harder than generally imagined. It is easier to reindustrialize political rhetoric than to reindustrialize America.

The primary witness in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, maintains ''that this was a tragedy not manifested by anything she had done'' and that ''there is no domestic aspect to it,'' her lawyer said today. Robert S. Bechert, who is representing Martha C. Anderson Coleman, who had just driven Mr. Jordan to his motel when he was shot in the back at 2 A.M. last Thursday, said that Mrs. Coleman had no idea who had fired the shot or why.

To the Editor: The furor created by the recent vote of the University Club to continue barring women from its premises has prompted many lively discussions among young professional women.n our late twenties, my associates and I feel that the most effective progress we could make is to encourage the formation of a club where young women may have social access to the accomplished and powerful women in New York City. Why should we be made to feel that we are missing out on ''the same routes to power open to men''?

Details of an agreement that calls for an indefinite delay of the demolition of two parks at Tudor City were disclosed yesterday. Both sides said they would seek court approval of the agreement today. The two parks straddle 42d Street west of First Avenue. Under the agreement, the delay would permit the completion of plans for swapping the two parks for a city-owned playground on the southeast corner of 42d Street and First Avenue.

The financial recovery plan of the Consolidated Rail Corporation, the mammoth freight and commuter line that Congress created from the ruins of the bankrupt northeastern carriers, has been derailed by the recession.

In half a century the Reisinger Knockout Teams, New York's most prestigious event, has usually been won by players of vast experience. The extreme example was Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, who won in 1973 at the age of 77 and retained his title in 1974.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., June 1 (AP) Cale Yarborough dueled first with Darrell Waltrip and then with Dale Earnhart today before surviving an empty gas tank and the heat to win the NASCAR 400 at Texas World Speedway.

CHARLESTON, S.C., June 1 Alexander Godunov portrayed Othello and Alicia Alonso was Lady Macbeth admittedly not in the same ballet at a sold-out dance gala on Shakespearean themes presented last night by the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here at Gaillard Auditorium.

ELKHART, Ind., May 31 When America's appetite for recreational vehicles surged in the last decade, a multitude of related businesses strung across northern Indiana and across the border in Michigan were so busy at times that they rivaled the bustle of the spring planting season in this state's agricultural regions.
Due to computer difficulties, the supplementary list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers for the week ended May 30,1980 does not appear in today's paper.

FISHKILL, N.Y., June 1 Heather McKay, an Australian who lives in Toronto, defeated Shannon Wright of Las Vegas, Nev., 21-10, 21-7, today in the final of the Women's Professional Racquetball Association championship at the All Sports Fitness and Racquetball Club.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) For the first time in its 46-year history, the Federal Communications Commission has decided to break a deadlock over who can open a radio station by conducting a lottery.

To the Editor: There are two problems with Dr. Scoville's letter (May 18) opposing the mobile MX missile system in its original (race-track) and amended (linear) design: the absence of an intelligent context and an alternative program.

Ignoring a chill wind and gusts of driving rain that cut the expected crowd of one million in half, Pope John Paul II chided French Catholics today for the decline of the church in this country in an outdoor mass at Le Bourget Airport. Standing at the foot of a towering white cross with a backdrop of scudding gray clouds and the flat green fields of Ile-de-France, the Pope also used the occasion of Mother's Day in Europe to reiterate the church's stand against abortion and warned of the dangers of supplanting Christian faith with modern technnology.

Jacqueline McMickens used to teach reading to third-graders, a very traditional job for women. Nowadays the 44-year-old Brooklyn resident has one of the most nontraditional jobs ever held by a woman in the city: She is the first female Chief of Operations in the New York City Department of Correction. Mrs. McMickens, or ''Chief,'' as she prefers to be called, was named to the $49,000-a-year post last October after 16 years as a uniformed member of the department. She is in charge of the day-today operations of the department, and as the top uniformed member she personally responds to all escapes, suicides, homicides, inmate protests and job actions in the city's 16 correction facilities.

Carter Administration officials said today that the United States had failed to prepare for the influx of Cuban refugees despite intelligence warnings that suggested that an exodus was likely. But the officials said that the reports had not predicted the extent or timing of the flood of refugees. The statement, by a State Department officials and the Deputy Coordinator for Refugee Affairs, came in response to charges by a Congressional subcommittee and a regional expert that the White House repeatedly ignored predictions by the Central Intelligence Agency that the Castro Government was preparing to flood Florida with emigres.

Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the Army strongman, offered his resignation as acting head of the powerful Korean Central Intelligence Agency today and President Choi Kyu Hah was expected to accept it. General Chon, who is widely seen as the most powerful man in South Korea, took over as acting head of the nation's chief intelligence organization on April 14. He proceeded to streamline the agency by firing, transferring or retiring some 33 out of 40 senior staff members.

The marriage of Barbara Anne Silberstein, daughter of Mrs. Allan H. Kalmus of New York and the late Murray L. Silberstein, to George Bernard Keezell, son of Lieut. Col. George Keezell, U.S.A.F., retired, of Kansas City, Mo., and the late Mrs. Keezell, took place yesterday afternoon. Algernon D. Black, leader emeritus of the New York Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at the Carlyle. The bride, an alumna of the Riverdale Country School, received an A.B. degree in 1976 from Tufts University, and a Master of Social Work degree last month from Boston University. Her mother is an art historian and lecturer and a trustee of the Riverdale Country School. The bride's father was a partner is Oppenheimer & Company. Her stepfather owns the Kalmus Corporation, a public-relations concern in New York.

The Storer Broadcasting Company, which has headquarters in Miami Beach, said Friday that it had bought 80 percent of the stock of Howard Cable Television Associates Inc. of Ellicott City, Md. Howard Cable services 2,000 television subscribers in Howard County, Md., an area between Washington and Baltimore. No price was disclosed.

As many young women as men are now seeking help for alcoholism in Britain, the director of the country's largest alcoholism center said today.

Past the handsome buildings of this city's Czarist heritage flowed a crowd that belied the adage that people in Leningrad are more relaxed, more courteous and better dressed than elsewhere in the Soviet Union. They were just as plain and shabby as the crowds in Moscow, and they jostled just as much. ''The Leningrad manner is dead -more than half the population is from somewhere else,'' said an old Leningrader, welcoming a visitor to his communal apartment in a subdivided former mansion.

WASHINGTON Anger, helplessness, feelings of loss similar to those that follow a death and, most of all, uncertainty have weighed on the relatives of the 53 Americans held hostage in Iran, but most have gradually adopted a healthier longterm attitude, according to State Department mental health workers and others who have been in contact with the families.

Georgina Bailey Woolworth, daughter of Ann Coleman Carmack of Sausalito, Calif., and Robert W. Woolworth of Monmouth, Me., was married yesterday to Steven E. Niman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen J. Niman of Creve Coeur, Mo. State Judge Sam C. Fullerton 3d of Oklahoma, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at his home in Miami, Okla.

SAN ANTONIO, June 1 (AP) Juan Carlos Harriott, the captain, scored four goals as Argentina defeated the United States national polo team, 10-6, yesterday and clinched its sixth consecutive Cup of the Americas championship.

The credit markets last week ran into the first real roadblock since their surprisingly strong spring rally began in early April, and so the direction of least resistance this week seems to be toward higher interest rates and still lower prices.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) A bomb exploded at the Kuwait Oil Company before dawn today, sending tons of glass fragments into the fashionable Bond Street shopping area. No injuries were reported.

Beth Daniel, who is known on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour for exceptional distance off the tees and occasional displays of temper, won the Golden Lights Classic at the Wykagyl Country Club today as she beat Jo Ann Washam and Nancy Lopez-Melton by two strokes. Miss Daniel shot one-under-par 71 for a four-round total of 287, one under par. But she came up a bit short of the $18,700 first prize - she was fined $50 two days ago for throwing a club.

When the bands strike up in Moscow next month, when the athletes parade around the stadium, who will be judged the political winner of the Olympics? Now that the entries are in, those who object to the Moscow Games while the Soviets occupy Afghanistan ought to face the fact that the boycott proposed by President Carter is going to be less than a triumph. Many of the main events will indeed be second-rate affairs because of the absence of leading competitors. Track without American or Kenyan runners, swimming without the U.S., West Germany or Canada, wrestling and judo without Japan: in these and other sports the competition will hardly be world-class.

The notion of a ''prime rate'' is causing bankers headaches because they have become subjects of political criticism recently as interest rates in money markets have fallen more rapidly than their posted prime lending rates. Some, in fact, say the established concept of a prime rate has become outdated. Aggravating the squabble over rates has been a falloff in corporate borrowing, which has increased pressure on bankers to keep their rates competitive with other sources of funds.
New pricing regulations affecting the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) could raise the price of Sohio gasoline by as much as 18 cents to 20 cents a gallon, Federal officials announced.

Charges were filed in New London, Conn., yesterday against a man accused of shooting three persons on a passenger train Saturday night. One victim was a trainman who asked the suspect for a ticket, another was a passenger sitting with her young daughter and the third was a security officer who had been called to help, according to a passenger who watched. Two of the wounded were reported in critical condition yesterday, and the third was in satisfactory condition. The suspect was identified as Frank Banks by the New London police. They said he was 30 years old and unemployed, and that he had given two addresses in New Haven that proved incorrect. He used a .25-caliber revolver, they said.

Lars-Erik Thunholm appeared to be in a dour frame of mind when he arrived here this weekend for the International Monetary Conference, to which only the most elite of the world's financiers are invited. ''I didn't come here to eat,'' snapped the chairman of the Skandinaviska Enskilda Banken of Stockholm, the largest bank in Sweden, to an airport hostess who suggested that he sample the city's restaurants.

President Carter leads Senator Edward M. Kennedy among Democrats for the Presidential nomination by a margin of 2 to 1, according to the Gallup Poll. The survey, taken May 16 to 18, found that 60 percent of Democrats polled supported the President, while 30 percent backed the Massachusetts Senator and 10 percent were undecided.

Torrance Watkins of Boyce, Va., and her mount, Poltroon, captured first place in the Olympic equestrian trials that ended today at the Kentucky Horse Park. Miss Watkins and Poltroon had gone through the cross-country portion without an error yesterday and also won the dressage portion of the three-day trials, which concluded with stadium jumping. Their point total was 42.8.

This summer, in two city gardens dedicated to the memory of Shakespeare, New Yorkers are strolling down what the Elizabethan playwright once called the ''primrose paths of dalliance.'' ''The idea of a Shakespeare garden originated in Victorian England and then caught on in the States,'' said Lucy Chamberlain, supervisor of the Shakespeare Garden at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. ''It was a kind of sentimental fad in the 19th century to create a literary garden to memorialize a poet.''

Violent storms swept through the Middle West today, spawning more than 20 tornadoes that injured at least eight people, knocked down power lines, uprooted crops and blew the roofs off buildings. A tornado watch was in effect in eastern Missouri, central and southern Illinois and central and southern Indiana through midafternoon.

The tolls on the two bridges over Jamaica Bay will increase this morning to 75 from 50 cents. In addition the cost of going over the Henry Hudson Bridge, which connects the Bronx and Manhattan, will rise to 60 from 50 cents. The increases were voted last month by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, along with rises in the tolls on several East River crossings. The increases on the East River - to $1 from 75 cents - took effect May 19.

IF Klaus Tennstedt impresses as one of today's least replaceable conductors, it is not because he cultivates heroic interpretive vagaries, or feats of spit-and-polish precision. His art seems altogether more selfless, and more meaningful. A stick figure bent at the knees, bobbing and weaving, quivering with feeling, Mr. Tennstedt is an unlikely sight on the podium. It is not too much to suggest that he conducts as one possessed. He seems not so much at the service of the music as at its mercy.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has granted three airlines immediate authority to fly from Miami and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to points in the Netherlands Antilles. Eastern Airlines received approval on Friday to fly to St. Martin; American Airlines to serve Aruba, Bonaire and Cura,cao, and Republic Airlines to serve points of its choosing in the Caribbean islands.

To walk through the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel's bronze Art Deco portals, from the commercial clamor of Lexington Avenue or from Park Avenue's stately vista, is to enter a world of padded prosperity. Soothingly, the main lobby suggests an underwater palace, with green plants flourishing amid ink-blue walls, enormous puffy blue-leather sofas and a central, octagonal blue banquette topped by a two-ton bronze British clock, circa 1895. The ambiance is of luxury shops and show windows, fresh, if funereal, flower arrangements, a babble of international and American accents and cafes that include Sir Harry's Bar (''plush Africansafari setting''), the Bull and Bear (''the man's restaurant that women adore'') and Peacock Alley (''for celebrity watching'').

Lawyers for the International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department met for more than two hours on Friday in a seventh round of what Sanford Litvack, Assistant Attorney General, called ''preliminary talks'' about a possible settlement of the Government's antitrust suit to break up the No.1 computer producer. A Government spokesman refused to characterize the talks, which have proceeded sporadically since Oct. 9, 1979. An eighth meeting is to occur in early June. The 11-year-old suit has been in trial in Federal court in New York since 1975 and is expected to wind up this year.

WASHINGTON, June 1 The Cosmos, playing before 53,351 fans, the largest crowd to watch a North American Soccer League game this season, subdued the Washington Diplomats, 2-1, in a shootout today at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.
SYRACUSE, June 1 Navy's varsity crew won the championship final at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's regatta today on Lake Onondaga.

The Broadway theater, maintaining the upbeat tempo of the last seven years, has once again established highs for theater attendance and box-office revenue in the season that ended yesterday. During 1979-80, the number of ticket sales rose to 9.62 million, slightly higher than for the 1978-79 season, and box offices took in $146 million, or $12 million more than in 1978-79. It was a season that started out with only a few indicators of a successful finale. Before last January, only a handful of promising shows had started on Broadway, among them ''Evita,'' ''Sugar Babies,'' ''Strider,'' ''Peter Pan,'' ''Bent,'' ''Romantic Comedy'' and ''Oklahoma!'' Then came ''Betrayal,'' ''Home,'' ''Children of a Lesser God,'' ''I Ought to Be in Pictures,'' ''Talley's Folly,'' ''West Side Story,'' ''Barnum,'' ''Morning's at Seven,'' ''West Side Story,'' ''Nuts'' and ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine.'' Attendance for the season's second half spurted 16 percent above the same period in the previous season, and the price paid for tickets since January was 25 percent more. The difference between attendance and revenue is explainable by increased ticket prices.

Charles Albert Rheinstrom, a retired advertising executive and a former vice president at American Airlines, died Wednesday at his home at the Birnam Wood Golf Club, in Santa Barbara, Calif. He 78 years old. Mr. Rheinstrom was a senior vice pr esident and director of J.Walter Thompson Company, an advertising concern, from 1949 to 1958. He previously was a senior vice president and director of Erwin Wasey and Company and spent 18 years with American Airlines, where he was one of the original top three executives.

FOR more than 20 years, long before he was known as Muhammad Ali's doctor, Ferdie Pacheco was everybody's doctor in the Overtown neighborhood of Miami that slowly was being redeveloped. As a general practitioner, he had his fancy office across town, his ''white office'' as he called it. But in the afternoon and the early evening this physician, whose parents were Spanish and who grew up in Tampa, would stop at what he called his ''black office,'' his little Overtown Medical Center, and treat mostly elderly people. ''We handled about 100 a day,'' he says. ''Infections, colds, sore throats, hypertension, diabetes. Rat bites and stab wounds, too.'' But sometimes Ferdie Pacheco wondered if his devotion was worth it. He was once held up outside the small office, a sawed-off shotgun pointed at his face. Another time he was robbed, with a butcher's knife at his throat. He is now a boxing consultant and television analyst for the NBC network, and he also paints and writes screenplays. Ferdie Pacheco had not practiced medicine much lately, but he continued to supervise the Overtown Medical Center, where another doctor, Pablo Michel, worked on a full-time basis along with a legendary nurse, Mabel Norwood, who once helped her patients all day after having had several teeth extracted that morning.

NEWARK (AP) - As a procession of priests about to be ordained marched by, more than 20 people demonstrated at the Sacred Heart Cathedral against the exclusion of women from the priesthood in the Roman Catholic Church. Wearing blue armbands printed with the name of the New Jersey Women's Ordination Conference, the men and women protesters handed out leaflets to hundreds of people filing into the cathedral Saturday for the ordination of 10 male candidates for the priesthood. The leaflets said that sex should not be an obstacle to ordination.

There was Bette Midler and Tolly the clown and Beethoven's Ninth, but there was also a group of children who did a simple song and dance routine at the old Beacon Theater on Broadway yesterday, and in the middle of their line, in a heavy leg brace and a built-up right shoe, was Heng Ley, a 7-year-old Cambodian boy. It was the first ''Day of the Child,'' a production thrown together in 10 days by a network of producers and entertainers who make New York City their working home. An event starring Miss Midler and involving the likes of Leonard Bernstein as a consultant would normally take three to six months to produce.

Conrail, the freight and commuter line created from the ruins of the bankrupt northeastern carriers, has been derailed by the recession and is expected to seek another $750 million to $1.4 billion in Federal funding before Election Day. (Page D1.) The severe downturn in automobile sales has been especially hard on minority auto dealers. Their average tenure in business, six to seven years, is too little time to accumulate capital and obtain financing, the Commerce Department says. (D1.)

Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Marla Lynn Herman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Joseph Herman of Passaic, to Jeffrey T. Segelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Segelman of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The bride's father, spiritual leader of the temple, performed the ceremony. Cantor Isadore Singer and Cantor Jeffrey Shiovitz assisted. The bride attended the University of Paris and received a B.A. degree in French from Columbia University and a B.A. in Jewish history from the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. Her father is on the board of directors of St. Mary's Hospital in Passaic, where he is chairman the advisory board of its Community Mental Health Center.

Ideal du Gazeau, a French trotter, mastered rough track conditions to win today's $186,000 Elite Race, one of Europe's premier harness races. Driven by Eugene Lefevre, the winner took the lead in the final furlong of the mile race and held on for a victory over My Nevele, a Danish-owned horse bred in the United States. Express Gaxe, a Swedish entrant who won the first of two qualifying heats, led unitl the final turn but finished third.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 2 Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the Army strongman, offered his resignation as acting head of the powerful Korean Central Intelligence Agency today and President Choi Kyu Hah was expected to accept it.

It's been two years since California's voters fired the first big volley for a national tax revolt a constitional amendment to cut their local property taxes by more than 50 percent. The paint has begun to peel off some schoolhouse walls, and public libaries have cut their hours. Yet, all in all, thanks to a $6-billion state reserve, the $7 billion in cuts precipitated by Proposition 13 have not yet been disastrous.
The Ponderosa System, operator of steakhouses, said that it would "take all appropriate action" to prevent the General Host Corporation, a food company, from acquiring more shares of Ponderosa.

In a colorful throwback to the days when most racegoers arrived in trains drawn by steam engines and horse-drawn vehicles, and bookmakers flourished in the track's betting ring, Belmont Park celebrated its diamond jubilee yesterday. A crowd of 67,107, the largest in Belmont's history, watched the usual nine-horse program, while also taking in some of the nostalgia. There were many touches of yesteryear, when Belmont opened for the first time in May of 1905 with about 40,000 people in attendance.

Jane Herzenberg, president of Herzenberg Designs and Fashions Inc. of Northampton, Mass., was married yesterday in Springfield, Mass., to Andrew M. Reiter, general sales manager for the hand-painted textiles and women's wear company. Rabbi Dov Lerner performed the ceremony in Temple Beth-El. Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Herzenberg of Agawam, Mass., and Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Reiter of New York are the parents of the couple, who live in Northampton.

HARTFORD (UPI) - State health officials assert that they have reduced the potential danger posed by chemicals in water mains that are suspected of causing cancer. The vinyl-lined, asbestos-cement pipes will not have to be replaced, the officials added. They said over the weekend that they had been successful in reducing the amount of tetrachloroethylene found in the pipes. Tetrachloroethylene - TCE - is used in commercial dry cleaning and in cleaning septic tanks. It has caused cancer in laboratory animals.

In half a century the Reisinger Knockout Teams, New York's most prestigious event, has usually been won by players of vast experience. The extreme example was Waldemar Von Zedtwitz, who won in 1973 at the age of 77 and retained his title in 1974. A record in the opposite direction was set yesterday when Brian Glubok of New York, at the ripe age of 20, led his foursome to victory in the final. The previous record was set by Kyle Larsen of San Francisco, who won this title at the age of 23.

A bomb exploded at the Kuwait Oil Company before dawn today, sending tons of glass fragments into the fashionable Bond Street shopping area. No injuries were reported. Less than 10 hours later, an explosive was thrown from a passing car at the Saudi Arabian Embassy in Brussels, the police there said. No one was reported hurt, and only slight damage was done.

For a while today, the New York Mets were up to their new tricks, winning an argument with the umpires and ruffling the feathers of the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates. But, after using that bit of mischief to gain a 2-2 tie in the top of the fifth inning, the Mets promptly went their old ways in the bottom of the inning. With two outs and with rain threatening, the Pirates stormed seven runs across the plate and eventually buried the Mets, 13-3.

The Treasury, which had to postpone $7 billion of financing last week as Congress wrangled over the national debt ceiling, has rescheduled two note sales and will hold them this week instead. These auctions, plus an active schedule of Federal agency, corporate and tax-exempt financing, will make this another highly active week for the credit markets.

Howard Cable services 2,000 television subscribers in Howard County, Md, an area between Washington and Baltimore. No price was disclosed.

WASHINGTON, June 1--Carter Administration officials said today that the United States had failed to prepare for the influx of Cuban refugees despite intelligence warnings that suggested that an exodus was likely. But the officials said that the reports had not predicted the extent or timing of the flood of refugees.
A cache of 114 new handguns was seized yesterday as Federal agents arrested three men alleged to be part of a ring that transported 800 such weapons from Ohio to New York in the last eight months.
PARIS, June 1 (AP) Thierry Vigneron of France set a world record in the pole vault today, clearing 18 feet 10 inches on his first attempt at a track meet at suburban Colombes.

The Cuban Olympic squad, gearing for what is expected to be a powerful showing in Moscow next month, was minus one of its promising weight lifters with the defection over the weekend of Lino Diaz de Villegas Delgado. Delgado, who won the Junior Pan American title in the 181-pound class in Montreal last Thursday, had been planning the defection for six months. On Friday, he said, he sneaked away from Cuban authorities with the help of Alpha 66, an anti-Castro underground group made up of Cuban exiles, including his cousin, Jose Miguel Delgado, of Miami.

Another dispute is shaping up between Congress and the Administration over the disposition of 18.4 metric tons of gold taken from Czechoslovakia by Nazi Germany and held by the United States and Britain since World War II. Bills introduced in both houses would require the Treasury Department to sell the gold and use the money to settle in full the claims of 2,800 American citizens and companies against Czechoslovakia for property seized by the Communist Government after it took control in 1948.

A photograph that appeared in the New Jersey Weekly section of The New York Times yesterday was incorrectly identified as that of Lewis Weinstein, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the Sixth Congressional District Seat.

The American Broadcasting Companies said it had sold the assets of its Travel Network Corporation for an undisclosed amount to VAC Vacation America Inc. of New York City. ABC earlier said that losses from the subsidiary, which it acquired on June 18, 1979, more than accounted for the decline in its firstquarter profits, to $24.3 million this year, from $25.4 million a year ago.

Alexander Godunov portrayed Othello and Alicia Alonso was Lady Macbeth - admittedly not in the same ballet - at a sold-out dance gala on Shakespearean themes presented last night by the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. here at Gaillard Auditorium. ''Shakespeare in the Dance,'' as this year's gala was called, was a difficult theme, and unfortunately the program degenerated into incoherent scraps and pieces taken out of context. The Shakespearean resonance went largely unheard.

The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest auto maker, said Friday that its net profit reached record levels in the fiscal year ended in March, mainly because of brisk exports and foreign exchange gains. A Nissan spokesman said net profit in the year rose 33.5 percent, to $39 million, from $29.2 million in the preceding year. The spokesman said, however, that the company was expecting profit in the current year to be held down.

A mysterious disease has claimed at least 70 lives in the last week in three villages along the mouth of the River Ganges, the Bengali newspaper Ittefaq reported today. A medical officer said that the disease attacked mostly young men who experience high fevers and die within three or four hours.

Red Smith IT was written here recently that in all the long history of baseball, no breath of suspicion ever touched an umpire. ''Umpires have been stupid, arrogant, selfish, obstinate, lazy, ungenerous, domineering, concupiscent, quarrelsome, tasteless, profane and blundering, but never dishonest. Neither players, club owners, bankers, clergymen, statesmen, butchers nor journalists can make the same claim.''

THE 92-year-old Katz Agency, for years one of the leading broadcast advertising representative companies, has just made an acquisition that, it says, makes it No. 1 without question in both television and radio with billings approaching $500 million. In a cash deal, it has bought Field Spot Sales, Field Communications' national spot sales organization, which has repped the company's five independent television stations. And, augmented by four independent TV stations already on the Katz client roster, it will become the Independent TV Sales division.

For the first time in its 46-year history, the Federal Communications Commission has decided to break a deadlock over who can open a radio station by conducting a lottery. In a one-page public notice released Friday afternoon, the F.C.C. said it had instructed its staff during a closed meeting Thursday ''to prepare a draft decision resolving competing applications for a broadcast license by use of a lottery.''

In response to an inquiry from a reader, I noted that a funeral pie was so named because it had good keeping qualities and that it was a custom in Pennsylvania Dutch country to send this pie to the members of the bereaved family.

Andrew Vincent Galway, senior partner in the law firm of Liddy, Sullivan, Galway Vaccaro, died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 74 years old and a resident of New York City and Glen Rock, N.J.

PARIS, June 1 Ignoring a chill wind and gusts of driving rain that cut the expected crowd of one million in half, Pope John Paul II chided French Catholics today for the decline of the church in this country in an outdoor mass at Le Bourget Airport.

WASHINGTON, Monday, June 2 A group of 10 Americans, ignoring warnings from the Justice Department, flew to Teheran over the weekend to participate in a conference on Iranian grievances against the United States.

DURHAM, N.C., June 1 (AP) Grand Metropolitan Ltd. of London announced Friday that it had extended its offer to purchase all outstanding shares of the Liggett Group Inc. until tomorrow morning. The offer had been scheduled to expire at midnight Thursday.

Mike Schmidt smashed his 17th home run his third in two days to stay far ahead of all other major league hitters in the glamour category. And Dave Kingman, another slugger, blasted his ninth homer of the season. But the critical event in a 5-4 victory by the Cubs over the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday at Wrigley Field in Chicago was a wild pitch.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 1 At 2:05 A.M. Thursday, in a parking lot at the Marriott Inn here, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., perhaps the nation's best known civil rights leader, was shot in the back and severely wounded by an unknown assailant.

A group of 10 Americans, ignoring warnings from the Justice Department, flew to Teheran over the weekend to participate in a conference on Iranian grievances against the United States. The group, which included Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General, made the trip despite the Administration's ban on travel by Americans to Iran and against the advice of the State Department, which said it feared the Americans' presence would be used for propaganda purposes.
