The conventional wisdom - that Jimmy Carter may be an inept President, but is a great political campaigner - deserves closer inspection. The ineptness is spreading. He has made two forays out of the Rose Garden. In the first, a series of verbal gaffes kept his press secretary busy explaining what Mr. Carter meant to say. This may be dismissed as a sign of rustiness after so long away from the campaign trail, though it must have pained Ed Muskie, 66, to have been referred to as a ''senior citizen.'' (''He meant 'senior adviser','' explained Joseph L. Powell, the official interpreter.)

The financial recovery plan of the Consolidated Rail Corporation, the mammoth freight and commuter line that Congress created from the ruins of the bankrupt northeastern carriers, has been derailed by the recession. Freight traffic is declining steadily, and some local commuter authorities cannot always meet their bills. The result is that Conrail will probably have to return to Congress before Election Day to seek another appropriation to supplement the $3.3 billion in Federal money already authorized.

In a handwritten journal he kept before the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, President Truman expressed far more concern about the horrible effects of the nuclear weapon upon Japanese civilians than has been previously disclosed, even in his own memoirs 10 years later. The newly discovered material was written at the time of the Potsdam conference in July 1945 with Churchill and Stalin. Writing on lined sheets of a legal-size tablet in his bold but clear scrawl, Truman observed on July 25, 1945:

CHRISTOPHER CROSS'S first single, ''Ride Like the Wind,'' was a No. 1 pop hit recently. Mr. Cross made his New York debut at the Bottom Line on Wednesday night and, although he doesn't write interesting lyrics or exude a great deal of stage presence, it seems his firsttime recording success was no fluke. The man is talented, and his talent is tailor-made for American pop radio. Although he comes from Austin, Tex., where he assembled his fine band, Mr. Cross doesn't play on his country-western roots. His songs suggest influences from artists who have grafted jazz and Broadway harmonies onto rock and funk rhythms - Steely Dan, for example, or Mr. Cross's fellow Texan, Boz Scaggs. One hopes he'll grow as a lyricist, but as a melodist he shines, and his arrangements betray a pop craftsmanship that's already mature. Mr. Cross's singing voice is high and a little plaintive - at times it sounds like a bluegrass voice. Best of all, he's an economical, incisive guitar soloist who gets a lovely fat tone from his Stratocaster, has plenty of good ideas and never overplays.

Susan Zwanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Zwanger of Massapequa Park, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Steven L. Mendelsohn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris A. Mendelsohn of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Leonard Stern performed the ceremony at the New York Hilton. The bride graduated from Northwestern University, from which she expects to receive an M.D. on June 14. She will begin a residency in internal medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. Her mother, Bernice Lomazov Zwanger, is a lawyer, and her father, who is director of radiology at Central General Hospital in Plainview, L.I., is an assistant professor of clinical radiology at the Medical School of the State University at Stony Brook, L.I.

Citibank, the largest bank in New York, and Citicorp, its holding company, have named Will Sparks as vice president in charge of public affairs and head of the public relations department. Mr. Sparks, 55, a former speech writer for President Lyndon B. Johnson and for the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has been a Citibank employee for the past four years.

By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THIS LIFE. By Sidney Poitier. 374 pages. Il- lustrated. Knopf. $12.95. HIS detractors would say that Sidney Poitier's career has been a paradigm of tokenism - the case of a pretty black face that Hollywood could exploit without having to acknowledge black culture. Even Mr. Poitier believes that ''my contribution'' to breaking down the barrier against black actors in the film industry ''was no more important than being at the right place at the right time, one in that series of perfect accidents from which fate fashions her grand designs.''

Gov. Bill Clinton complained tonight that he ''may have been misled'' by Federal authorities last week when they said they would use force, if necessary, to contain any further disruptions by the Cuban refugees at the processing center here.

Candidates from Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party appear to have won office in seven of nine states that held elections last week, according to partial results made public today. All of the states were controlled by opposition parties when Mrs. Gandhi dismissed their governments soon after she was voted back into power in parliamentary elections in January.

PALMA DE MALLORCA, Spain ACALLIGRAPHY of fluttering fingers that abruptly soar like the birds in his paintings. Or march like tin soldiers across his armchair. Mock prizefighter fists that punch at the air, and sharp, clucking noises: a light switch snapping on in his mouth. Much laughter: a friendly laugh that, at times, trails off into something private. Joan Miro is talking.
Due to computer difficulties, the supplementary list of mutual funds prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers for the week ended May 30, 1980 does not appear in today's paper.
PARADISE, Mich., June 1 (AP) A financially distressed school district is trying to keep its doors open by offering donors honorary shares in the village of Paradise.
CALGARY, Alberta, June 1 Canada's state-owned oil corporation and private investors plan to build the fourth commercial oil sands production facility in northern Alberta.
Judith Toby Seligson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Seligson of Branford, Conn., was married yesterday noon to Stephen Ted Schaffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Schaffer of Woodbridge, Conn.

In a colorful throwback to the days when most racegoers arrived in trains drawn by steam engines and horsedrawn vehicles, and bookmakers flourished in the track's betting ring, Belmont Park celebrated its diamond jubilee yesterday.

Jacqueline McMickens used to teach reading to third-graders, a very traditional job for women. Nowadays the 44year-old Brooklyn resident has one of the most nontraditional jobs ever held by a woman in the city: She is the first female Chief of Operations in the New York City Department of Correction.

TOKYO, Monday, June 2 (AP) The American dollar declined against the Japanese currency today, opening on the Tokyo exchange market at 223.50 yen. It had closed Friday at 224.35 Dealers said trading was lackluster but that the dollar rallied slightly to the level of 223.60-90 yen.

The marriage of Jane Wendy Olian to Thomas Joseph Mooney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Mooney of Clinton, Iowa, took place in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Vincent R. Balletta Jr. performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Olian.

Here, as in most cities, Ronald Reagan's voice thickened with emotion as he came to the point in his standard speech where he describes what he calls the strongest yearning of his life: ''That is to say to the world there will be no more Taiwans. There will be no more Vietnams. There will be no more betrayal of friends and allies by the United States Government.'' The Republican Presidential candidate and his aides recoil at the suggestion that this is a call to arms. Campaigning in Ohio, New Jersey and California this week, Mr. Reagan insisted that his goals were not ''warlike'' or ''hostile'' and that he was not ''triggerhappy.''

There is free roller skating Sundays at an outdoor rink on Pier 84, Hudson River at 44th Street. Star Skates, a skate rental and sales company, has leased the pier from the city, and this month will open it for weekend skating. July through October, the rink will be open every day, 11 A.M. to 7 P.M., weather permitting. Skates may be rented at $5 for two hours, $2 for each additional hour, or $8 for the day; a $10 deposit is required. Information; 244-4270.

The first of America's newest and most sophisticated jet fighters, a $27 million craft of computer wizardry, has been delivered to the Navy. Twelve of the sleek McDonnell Douglas F-18 Hornets have completed their testing. A Navy test pilot flew the first of the fighters built for commercial production over the weekend at Lambert Field and accepted it for service.

When America's appetite for recreational vehicles surged in the last decade, a multitude of related businesses strung across northern Indiana and across the border in Michigan were so busy at times that they rivaled the bustle of the spring planting season in this state's agricultural regions. From South Bend to Angola and dipping as far south as Fort Wayne, a vibrant new industry grew up, ranging from the hundreds of family retail operations like Lazy Bee RV Sales in Mishawaka, run by Burton and Mary Lou Bennett, to the scores of manufacturers like Coachmen Industries in Middlebury, which started in a garage and mushroomed into the nation's largest full-line manufacturer of recreational vehicles.

The United States is ''woefully unprepared'' for new interruptions in oil imports and should cut gasoline consumption by 20 to 25 percent to insure its future international security, a Harvard University report released yesterday said.

Anger, helplessness, feelings of loss similar to those that follow a death and, most of all, uncertainty have weighed on the relatives of the 53 Americans held hostage in Iran, but most have gradually adopted a healthier long-term attitude, according to State Department mental health workers and others who have been in contact with the families. The nearly seven months of crisis have made relatives alternately tearful and optimistic, withdrawn and anxious to unburden themselves. It has strained individuals and families.

Direct Scooter, driven by Warren Cameron, registered his ninth straight victory last night, winning the $122,500 Graduate Series pacing final at the Meadowlands. A turnout of 25,404 saw the heavily favored Direct Scooter beat Tijuana Taxi by one and three-quarter lengths. The winner paced the mile in 1:56 2/5 on a track classified as good. He paid $2.60 for $2 to win. It was his fifth victory in the Graduate Series that covered six tracks, starting at Freehold Raceway on April 12.

Katherine Fletcher, a former assistant director of the domestic policy staff for environmental affairs at the White House, and Kenneth S. Winer, deputy executive director of the White House Council on Environmental Quality, were married yesterday morning at the Jefferson Memorial in Washington. Rabbi Morton Kanter performed the ceremony. The bride was graduated magna cum laude from Radcliffe College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Before becoming a Presidential aide in 1977, she was staff scientist with the Environmental Defense Fund at its regional office in Denver.

Andrew Vincent Galway, senior partner in the law firm of Liddy, Sullivan, Galway & Vaccaro, died Friday at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 74 years old and a resident of New York City and Glen Rock, N.J. Mr. Galway joined the law concern in 1930. He was an affiliated brother of the Christian Schools and former secretary of the Guild of Catholic Lawyers. He was also a trustee of the LaSalle Academy in New York City.

Mike Schmidt smashed his 17th home run - his third in two days - to stay far ahead of all other major league hitters in the glamour category. And Dave Kingman, another slugger, blasted his ninth homer of the season. But the critical event in a 5-4 victory by the Cubs over the Philadelphia Phillies yesterday at Wrigley Field in Chicago was a wild pitch. With the score tied at 4-4 in the seventh inning, Kingman looped a two-out single to right field that foiled a defensive shift to the left side of the diamond. Kingman moved up to second base when Ron Reed (3-1), a right-hander, unleashed a wild pitch with the lefthanded-batting Scot Thompson at the plate.

A financially distressed school district is trying to keep its doors open by offering donors honorary shares in the village of Paradise. The Whitefish Township school district, which serves 92 pupils, is offering certificates reserving a share of Paradise to anyone who sends a contribution. Donors also will be proclaimed honorary citizens of Paradise, a community of 450 people on Lake Superior's Whitefish Bay in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan.

There is a new kind of skyscraper going up in New York. The new model is not an isolated phenomenon, like a corporate headquarters reaching conspicuously for the sky, or a World Trade Center, setting a record in the tallest-building derby.

Susan Daryl Bauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bauer of Hicksville, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Stephen Lincer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Lincer of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Julius Goldberg performed the ceremony in the Plainview Jewish Center.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy yesterday brushed aside President Carter's olive branch, saying he did not think the two of them should sit down after tomorrow's final primaries and try to settle the platform for the Democratic National Convention.

LENINGRAD Past the handsome buildings of this city's Czarist heritage flowed a crowd that belied the adage that people in Leningrad are more relaxed, more courteous and better dressed than elsewhere in the Soviet Union. They were just as plain and shabby as the crowds in Moscow, and they jostled just as much.
ATLANTA, June 1 (UPI) The $40 million Cable News Network, which promises to make news programming available 24 hours a day to 2.5 million viewers, made its debut today.

DALLAS, June 1 (AP) The executive commmittee of the College Football Association today unanimously recommended sweeping changes in recruiting practices and academic standards for players. The association, a group of 61 schools that makes up most of the major college football powers Pacific-10 and Big Ten conference schools are not members will present the proposals at next January's National Collegiate Athletic Associaton convention.
For minority auto dealers, especially those who have been in business a decade or less, the severe downturn in the automobile market has been especially difficult, the Commerce Department said.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 1 (AP) A United States District Court jury has moved in favor of Great Western Cities Inc. in 41 of 42 suits filed by leaseholders who purchased land at Cochiti Lake from the development firm, owned by two members of the Hunt family.

Prime Minister Menachem Begin averted a Government showdown today over his proposed Cabinet shuffle by agreeing to continue as his own Defense Minister. With various factions of the governing coalition at odds over who should succeed Ezer Weizman after his angry resignation from the job a week ago, Mr. Begin was reported to have temporarily suspended his attempt to shuffle the Cabinet.

Five thousand people gathered in Middletown, Conn., yesterday to watch Wesleyan University's 148th commencement and to hear the French Foreign Minister, Jean Francois-Poncet, a Wesleyan alumnus, speak on the recent strains in relations between the United States and France. Mr. Francois-Poncet, a 1947 Wesleyan graduate and the principal commencement speaker, told the gathering, ''Our fellowship can only be meaningful if we recognize that Europe legitimately aspires to play its own role in the world scene and if we accept the fact that solidarity with the United States does not exclude independence.''

The marriage of Diane Sue Ashley, an account executive at Ted Bates & Company Inc., to Jack Etheredge Burson, a vice president and management supervisor at Grey Advertising Inc., took place at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Nathaniel T. Helman performed the ceremony in the hotel's Versailles Room. The bride is a daughter of Constance Sitomer Ashley of New York and Ted Ashley of Beverly Hills, Calif., chairman of Warner Bros. Inc., the motion-picture producers. Her mother is manager of the gift shop at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

A West German Cabinet official voiced serious doubts today about his country's ability to finance its share of the European Common Market compromise budget agreement reached on Friday, jeopardizing acceptance of the agreement by the Bonn Government. Finance Minister Hans Matthofer said in a statement issued today that he would not support the agreement, hammered out at a marathon session of European Economic Community foreign ministers on Friday in Brussels, unless his Cabinet colleagues can suggest ways for West Germany to pay its share, which is expected to be about $1.4 billion.

John Mahaffey, a 32-year-old Texan who has never been rated a long driver, beat the 7,054-yard Congressional Country Club course today to win the Kemper open with a course-record total of 275, five under par. He won with two birdies, on the 71st and 72d holes, that he did not need. Mahaffey finished three strokes ahead of Craig Stadler, who had come out of the field with a challenge that collapsed with a bogey on the 72d hole. After that mishap Mahaffey, two holes behind, could have won with pars on Nos. 17 and 18. Instead, he birdied No. 17 from 20 feet and No. 18 from 35 feet. On the last putt he was only trying to lag it to the hole.

Georgina Bailey Woolworth, daughter of Ann Coleman Carmack of Sausalito, Calif., and Robert W. Woolworth of Monmouth, Me., was married yesterday to Steven E. Niman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen J. Niman of Creve Coeur, Mo. State Judge Sam C. Fullerton 3d of Oklahoma, the bride's cousin, performed the ceremony at his home in Miami, Okla. The bride is a granddaughter of Elizabeth, Dowager Duchess of Manchester, widow of the 10th Duke of Manchester, and George L. Coleman Jr. of Miami, Okla., and Palm Beach, Fla., former chairman of the First National City Bank of Miami. She is a great-granddaughter of the late Frederick Moore Woolworth of New York, a cousin of Frank W. Woolworth, founder of the dime-store chain.

In their seventh vote since February, reporters and editors of the daily newspaper Le Monde today elected Claude Julien, editor of the paper's monthly publication Le Monde Diplomatique, to succeed the managing editor, Jacques Fauvet, who is scheduled to retire at the end of 1982. Mr. Julien had been the paper's foreign editor. Mr. Julien, 55 years old, who once studied at Notre Dame University in Indiana, got three-fifths of the vote in a runoff with Alain Jacob, the paper's Peking correspondent. About 200 editorial staff employees participated in the balloting. They control about 40 percent of the shares of the company, which is owned by its employees.

International Menachem Begin's dual role of Prime Minister and Defense Minister while a successor to the former Defense Minister, Ezer Weizman, is found, was unanimously sanctioned by Israel's Cabinet, averting a Government showdown. Mr. Begin's proposal that Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir become Defense Minister was rejected by the Democratic Movement, headed by Deputy Prime Minister Yigael Yadin. Other factions in the governing coalition also want a part in choosing a new defense minister. (Page A1, Column 6.) Doubts about West Germany's ability to pay its share of the cost of of the European Econommic Community's compromise budget reached Friday were expressed by the West German Finance Minister. Hans Matthofer said he will not support the agreement unless his colleagues in the Cabinet can suggest ways for West Germany to pay its share, which is expected to amount to $1.4 billion. (A3:4-6.) France was chided by Pope John Paul for its waning religious faith at an outdoor mass at Le Bourget Airport near Paris, attended by 500,000 people. The Pope made it clear in recent days that he was concerned about the future of the Church in France. Later at a meeting with French bishops, the Pope strongly criticized Catholic dissidents who, he said, have created a ''scandal'' in the church. (A3:1-3.) South Korea's opposition leader, Kim Dae Jung, was blamed by the Government for the recent student uprising in the provincial capital of Kwangju. In the first official report on the uprising, military investigators said that Mr. Kim had ''manipulated and agitated'' students in the city. (A5:1-3.) More than 18 million tons of gold taken from Czechoslovkia by Germany during World War II and subsequently taken into custody by the United States and Britain has renewed a bitter dispute between Congress and the Administration about what to do with it. Bills introduced in the Senate and the House would require the Treasury to sell the gold and use the proceeds to settle in full the claims of about 2,800 American citizens and companies against Czechoslovakia for property seized by its Communist Government. (A11:1.) National Senator Kennedy refused to accept President Carter's olive branch, saying that he did not think the two of them should get together after tomorrow's primaries to try to work out the platform for the Democratic National Convention. He spurned Mr. Carter's offer on Saturday to ''make concessions in every direction'' on the platform to promote party unity. Mr. Kennedy said ''I expect to be the nominee'' despite Mr. Carter's strong lead in convention delegates. (A1:3.) Cuban refugees rioted in the Fort Chaffee relocation center in Arkansas over delays in their resettlement. Police and soldiers were pelted with with stones after about 200 Cubans burst out the front gate. A dozen law enforcement officers, five civilians and four refugees were injured, authorities said. The rioters retreated when troopers used teargas and fired shots. (1:4-5.) The Vernon Jordan inquiry is stymied despite intensive probing by the police in Fort Wayne, Ind., and 20 F.B.I. agents who are seeking the assailant who shot the president of the National Urban League last Thursday. (A1:1-2.) Violent storms swept the Middle West and spawned more than 20 tornadoes that knocked down power lines, uprooted crops and blew roofs off buildings. At least eight persons were injured, three seriously, when a tornadoes struck Croton, Ohio, and Tuscola, Illinois, the authorities said. (A14:1.) Metropolitan Correction officials were warned three weeks ago that Howard (Buddy) Jacobson might try to escape, as he did from the Brooklyn House of Detention on Saturday, a spokesman for the Bronx District Attorney said. The warning came when the District Attorney learned that Mr. Jacobson had been selling his real estate holdings to obtain cash. Meanwhile, a man who pretended to be a lawyer to gain entrance to the Brooklyn House of Detention has been charged with helping Mr. Jacobson to escape. (A1:1.) Reggie Jackson's alleged assailant, who reportedly shot at the ballplayer but missed in a traffic argument early Sunday on East 83d Street, has been charged with attempted murder. The suspect was identified as Angel Viera of Manhattan. Mr. Jackson, dismayed by the publicity the shooting aroused, suggested that he may seek to have the charge against Mr. Viera dropped. The New York Yankees outfielder was on his way to a Third Avenue bar frequented by athletes when the shooting occurred. (B1:6.) A plan to delay destruction of two parks in Tudor City until they can be swapped for a public playground nearby will be presented for court approval today. Both Harry B. Helmsley, owner of the Tudor City apartment development, and its tenants' association, which opposes Mr. Helmsley's plans to erect apartment towers on the park sites, have agreed to the delay. The city has offered the playground as an alternative building site. (B1:1.) A man accused of shooting three persons on a Washington-to-Boston train Saturday night has been charged in New London, Conn., with assault and attempted murder. The suspect was identified as Frank Banks, 30 years old, a resident of New Haven. The shootings occurred near New London, and the victims were a trainman, a young woman and a security officer. (B3:1-2.) Business Digest, Page D1

The executive commmittee of the College Football Association today unanimously recommended sweeping changes in recruiting practices and academic standards for players. The association, a group of 61 schools that makes up most of the major college football powers - Pacific-10 and Big Ten conference schools are not members -will present the proposals at next January's National Collegiate Athletic Associaton convention. The proposals, which would alter recruiting and eligibility standards, included:

Judith Ellen Colodny and Alan Edward Lieberman were married yesterday by Rabbi Daniel Wolk at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark J. Colodny of Port Chester and Indian Lake, N.Y. Mr. Lieberman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lieberman, also of Port Chester.

Dr. Julian Deryl Hart, a former president of Duke University and a pioneer in the development of its medical center, died at his home today. He was 85 years old. Dr. Hart had been in declining health for several years and suffered a stroke last Tuesday. A native of Buena Vista, Ga., he came to Duke in 1930. He served as president of the university from July 1960 to August 1963 and had also served as dean of the Duke Medical School.

Linda E. Rappaport and Leonard Chazen were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Rabbi Judah Nadich. The bride, a lawyer who practices under her maiden name, is an associate of Shearman & Sterling in New York. Mr. Chazen, also a lawyer, is a partner in the law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris Shriver & Jacobson, also in New York. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Rappaport of Farmingdale, L.I. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nat Chazen of New York.

CODEX and Genuine Risk will run the Preakness over again today - over and over and over. Several hundred feet above the bend of the Pimlico oval, where first they met, the colt and the filly will stage their stretch run this time on a silver screen of beaded glass crystals. From the films of 17 cameras, 12 of them provided by ABC-TV, a projector will send the horses forward and backward, forward and backward; they will be viewed at human-eye level and bird's-eye level. They will stop and go, stop and go.
AROUND THE NATION; Fraser Says 'World Car' Poses Threat to Unions

YEOVIL, England Europe's four largest makers of helicopters are preparing for a series of joint assaults on the world helicopter market that is being expanded by rising military tension and the boom in offshore oil drilling.
The American Broadcasting Companies said it had sold the assets of its Travel Network Corporation for an undisclosed amount to VAC Vacation America Inc. of New York City.

OMAHA, June 1 (AP) Rick Bass drove in three runs with a triple and a double, and his Hawaii teammates turned three double plays as the Rainbows beat St. John's, 7-2, tonight in a second-round game of the College World Series.

ALBANY, June 1 (AP) A state audit says that some members of the now-defunct Jones Beach State Parkway police on Long Island were apparently stealing gasoline so much, in fact, that it looked as if their police patrol cars got two miles a gallon or less.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 1 The primary witness in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, maintains "that this was a tragedy not manifested by anything she had done" and that "there is no domestic aspect to it," her lawyer said today.

Dr. Barbara P. Schneider, senior resident in general surgery at the Einstein College of Medicine-Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, and Morton Schneider, manager of the Eastside Housing Corporation, were married yesterday by Rabbi Reuven Bendelstein in the Fifth Avenue Synagogue.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 1 Beth Daniel, who is known on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour for exceptional distance off the tees and occasional displays of temper, won the Golden Lights Classic at the Wykagyl Country Club today as she beat Jo Ann Washam and Nancy LopezMelton by two strokes.
The recession may be a source of trepidation on Main Street but not on Wall Street.

JERUSALEM, June 1 Prime Minister Menachem Begin averted a Government showdown today over his proposed Cabinet shuffle by agreeing to continue as his own Defense Minister.

ST. REGIS RESERVATION, N.Y. "It's the longest siege in Indian history," said Howard Berman, a lawyer, as he walked through the traditionalist Mohawk encampment near Racquette Point on the St. Lawrence River, about eight miles northeast of Massena.

As the search continued yesterday for Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the former horse trainer and convicted murderer who escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention Saturday, the Bronx District Attorney's office reported that three weeks ago it had urged the Correction Department to be alert for an escape attempt.
LONDON, June 1 (AP) As many young women as men are now seeking help for alcoholism in Britain, the director of the country's largest alcoholism center said today.

In a handwritten journal he kept before the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima, President Truman expressed far more concern about the horrible effects of the nuclear weapon upon Japanese civilians than has been previously disclosed, even in his own memoirs 10 years later.

Susan Zwanger, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome Zwanger of Massapequa Park, L.I., was married yesterday evening to Dr. Steven L. Mendelsohn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris A. Mendelsohn of Pittsburgh. Rabbi Leonard Stern performed the ceremony at the New York Hilton.

The white-haired squire of the graceful pink colonial mansion pointed out the doorway where Aldous Huxley appeared unannounced one dawn, the rosewood chair on which Robert Kennedy sat, the tile floor where a recent Brazilian President knelt in supplication during a conversation, the walls of portraits picturing the people who figured in the stories he was telling. Gilberto Freyre, the most widely known chronicler of Brazil's development, was reminiscing, and it was apt that his home, the centerpiece of an 18th-century sugar plantation, should serve as his principal prop.

The $40 million Cable News Network, which promises to make news programming available 24 hours a day to 2.5 million viewers, made its debut today. The network, conceived by Ted Turner, an Atlanta sports and business entrepreneur, conducted rehearsals for the last month to prepare its employees for the real thing, which began at 6 P.M. today.

The rating on Norfolk & Western Railway Company equipment trust certificates has been raised to AAA from AA, it was announced Friday by Moody's Investors Service, one of the top credit-rating services. Equipment trust certificates have a first lien on specific rolling stock of the railroad and are considered a top credit risk for that reason.
VIGNERON OF FRANCE CLEARS 18-10 1 2 FOR WORLD RECORD IN POLE VAULT

Dollar Down in Tokyo TOKYO, Monday, June 2 (AP) - The American dollar declined against the Japanese currency today, opening on the Tokyo exchange market at 223.50 yen. It had closed Friday at 224.35. Dealers said trading was lackluster but that the dollar rallied slightly to the level of 223.60-.90 yen.

The following article is based on reporting by Paul Delaney, Douglas E. Kneeland, Robert Pear and Wendell Rawls Jr. and was written by Mr. Kneeland. FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 1 - At 2:05 A.M. Thursday, in a parking lot at the Marriott Inn here, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., perhaps the nation's best known civil rights leader, was shot in the back and severely wounded by an unknown assailant.

If Robert Lighton had his way, the whole world would be colored khaki and everyone in it would be wearing khaki. Considering how fresh the cotton khaki clothing Mr. Lighton has designed looks, that might not be such a bad idea. His initial collection of men's and women's clothing, made almost entirely of cotton khaki (plus a couple of allied fabrics), is classic. Mr. Lighton, who is 29 years old, comes from the Kansas City, Mo., family that owns Woolf Brothers, a chain of Middle Western department stores. He was the buyer for the stores' young men's departments and in charge of the fur departments.

Navy's varsity crew won the championship final at the Intercollegiate Rowing Association's regatta today on Lake Onondaga. The regatta had been delayed a day because of rough water conditions yesterday and the lake remained rough today. The Midshipmen rowed into a 15-knot wind and finished in 6 minutes 46 seconds, one and a half seconds ahead of Northeastern, and 2.2 seconds ahead of Brown. They were followed by the eight-man crews from Wisconsin, Cornell and Syracuse.

Canada's state-owned oil corporation and private investors plan to build the fourth commercial oil sands production facility in northern Alberta. PetroCanada and the Alberta Gas Trunk Line Company have announced that they will spend $100 million (Canadian) preparing a joint submission to regulatory authorities by 1982 to construct a 140,000-barrel-a-day plant by 1990.

Europe's four largest makers of helicopters are preparing for a series of joint assaults on the world helicopter market that is being expanded by rising military tension and the boom in offshore oil drilling. But the alliances being forged among Britain's Westland Helicopter, Augusta of Italy, West Germany's Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm and Aerospatiale, the French state-owned aerospace combine, illustrate a more general trend in Europe toward collaborative production of expensive military hardware. Such joint projects increasingly threaten the export sales of American arms makers.

The marriage of Diane Sue Ashley, an account executive at Ted Bates Company Inc., to Jack Etheredge Burson, a vice president and management supervisor at Grey Advertising Inc., took place at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Nathaniel T. Helman performed the ceremony in the hotel's Versailles Room.

In his introduction to "The French Defense" by Gligoric, Uhlmann and Karpov, Mikhail Botvinnik dismissed the Sicilian Defense, remarking, "It is so worn out that in the near future it will turn into rags." Five years later, the rags are still fluttering.

IF Klaus Tennstedt impresses as one of today's least replaceable conductors, it is not because he cultivates heroic interpretive vagaries, or feats of spit-and-polish precision. His art seems altogether more selfless, and more meaningful.

OFTEN, the Cowgirl in Agnes de Mille's "Rodeo" is played by a dancer who is or who can look-short. But as American Ballet Theater's Saturday matinee at the Metropolitan Opera House demonstrated, there is no reason why she has to be a wee mite.

BETHESDA, Md., June 1 John Mahaffey, a 32-year-old Texan who has never been rated a long driver, beat the 7,054-yard Congressional Country Club course today to win the Kemper open with a course-record total of 275, five under par. He won with two birdies, on the 71st and 72d holes, that he did not need.

Charges were filed in New London, Conn., yesterday against a man accused of shooting three persons on a passenger train Saturday night. One victim was a trainman who asked the suspect for a ticket, another was a passenger sitting with her young daughter and the third was a security officer who had been called to help, according to a passenger who watched.

RECIFE, Brazil The white-haired squire of the graceful pink colonial mansion pointed out the doorway where Aldous Huxley appeared unannounced one dawn, the rosewood chair on which Robert Kennedy sat, the tile floor where a recent Brazilian President knelt in supplication during a conversation, the walls of portraits picturing the people who figured in the stories he was telling.
A 25-year-old Manhattan man was charged with firing three shots early yesterday at Reggie Jackson, the New York Yankees outfielder, after the two men had exchanged angry words on East 83d Street.

To the Editor: Deputy Energy Secretary John Sawhill argues cogently for the 10-cent-a-gallon oil import fee (Op-Ed May 26). It is a necessary conservation measure; it will protect our national security and foreign policy; it will demonstrate our resolve - it is ''the best and indeed the only available way to get on with this important national priority.'' nfortunately for him, the ''fee'' is a tax, and only Congress may levy Federal taxes. The Constitution (Art. I, Sect. 8) is very specific on the matter.

The Ponderosa System, operator of steakhouses, said that it would ''take all appropriate action'' to prevent the General Host Corporation, a food company, from acquiring more shares of Ponderosa. General Host, which owns 7.6 percent of Ponderosa stock, said it planned to increase its position to 20 percent, a stake that would enable General Host to include that much of Ponderosa's profits in its own profits.

The marriage of Jane Wendy Olian to Thomas Joseph Mooney, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Mooney of Clinton, Iowa, took place in Sands Point, L.I., yesterday. State Supreme Court Justice Vincent R. Balletta Jr. performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Howard Olian. The bride, a soprano who will make her debut this month with the Central City (Colo.) Opera, graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. She has performed with the Hidden Valley Opera Ensemble in Carmel, Calif., and at the Aspen (Colo.) Music Festival. Her father is chairman of Westwood Inc., textile manufacturer. Her mother is curator of the costume collection at the Museum of the City of New York.

As the search continued yesterday for Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the former horse trainer and convicted murderer who escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention Saturday, the Bronx District Attorney's office reported that three weeks ago it had urged the Correction Department to be alert for an escape attempt. The police have issued an all-points alarm for the apprehension of Mr. Jacobson, who they feared might have left the country. They have also arrested a former business associate of Mr. Jacobson, charging him with impersonating a lawyer to gain entrance to the Brooklyn jail and aid in Mr. Jacobson's escape.

It's the longest siege in Indian history,'' said Howard Berman, a lawyer, as he walked through the traditionalist Mohawk encampment near Racquette Point on the St. Lawrence River, about eight miles northeast of Massena. Since mid-August 1979, Mr. Berman's clients, a small group of traditional - or longhouse - Mohawks, have lived within a fourbuilding compound in sight of the international bridge that crosses the St. Lawrence from the United States to Cornwall, Ontario. Although the ''besieged'' have not been forced to leave, they have stationed sentries to warn them in case state or tribal authorities try to enter, which they did once last year, making several arrests.

Heather McKay, an Australian who lives in Toronto, defeated Shannon Wright of Las Vegas, Nev., 21-10, 21-7, today in the final of the Women's Professional Racquetball Association championship at the All Sports Fitness and Racquetball Club.

Cale Yarborough dueled first with Darrell Waltrip and then with Dale Earnhart today before surviving an empty gas tank and the heat to win the NASCAR 400 at Texas World Speedway. Yarborough, who had earned the pole position with a speed of 170.709 miles an hour, kept his Chevrolet running cool while other drivers dropped behind with overheating problems in the muggy 90-degree weather.

SUGAR is once again prominent in the commodity futures markets after being relatively dormant for six years. Not only has the price of unrefined sugar shot upward recently, but the open interest is now the fifth highest of all futures markets. There are few stronger indications of a bull market than when prices and open interest (in effect, the number of outstanding contracts) both move up together. While prices have been advancing steadily for more than a year, it has only been in recent weeks that the open interest has shown a strong increase.

Grand Metropolitan Ltd. of London announced Friday that it had extended its offer to purchase all outstanding shares of the Liggett Group Inc. until tomorrow morning. The offer had been scheduled to expire at midnight Thursday.

Negotiators for the Aluminum Company of America and the Reynolds Metals Company signed tentative agreements with the Aluminum Workers International Union yesterday, company spokesmen said. The contract, which would offer 18,600 hourly workers 60 cents more an hour over the next three years, would replace one expiring at midnight. It is subject to ratification by eight union locals. The contract includes several increases in fringe benefits and continues a quarterly cost-of-living adjustment, according to joint statements by the companies and the union. The general wage increase would be 25 cents an hour immediately, 20 cents an hour in June 1981 and 15 cents in June 1982.

EAST BERLIN, June 1 (Reuters) East Germany prohibited Soviet bloc visitors today from buying gasoline for cash in a move apparently aimed at keeping Czechoslovak and Polish motorists from crossing the border to fill up on cheap fuel.

BONN, June 1 A West German Cabinet official voiced serious doubts today about his country's ability to finance its share of the European Common Market compromise budget agreement reached on Friday, jeopardizing acceptance of the agreement by the Bonn Government.

If Robert Lighton had his way, the whole world would be colored khaki and everyone in it would be wearing khaki. Considering how fresh the cotton khaki clothing Mr. Lighton has designed looks, that might not be such a bad idea.

PARIS, June 1 Sixteen-year-old Bettina Bunge put top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd through an unexpected ordeal today in the third round of the $617,00 French open tennis championships, yielding by 4-6, 6-4, 6-3.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 1 (AP) Violent storms swept through the Middle West today, spawning more than 20 tornadoes that injured at least eight people, knocked down power lines, uprooted crops and blew the roofs off buildings.

IT was written here recently that in all the long history of baseball, no breath of suspicion ever touched an umpire. "Umpires have been stupid, arrogant, selfish, obstinate, lazy, ungenerous, domineering, concupiscent, quarrelsome, tasteless, profane and blundering, but never dishonest. Neither players, club owners, bankers, clergymen, statesmen, butchers nor journalists can make the same claim."

WASHINGTON, June 1 Just before the House rejected the proposed Federal budget last Thursday, Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. was asked why he had joined the opposition. The first thing he mentioned was a loss of 50,000 jobs under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act, known as CETA.

PICASSO mania, triggered by the mammoth exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, gets another booster shot, to night at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, with "Picasso: A Painter's Diary." This is not a tour of the exhibition.
Judith Ellen Colodny and Alan Edward Lieberman were married yesterday by Rabbi Daniel Wolk at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y.
ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP) The first of America's newest and most sophisticated jet fighters, a $27 million craft of computer wizardry, has been delivered to the Navy.

In response to an inquiry from a reader, I noted that a funeral pie was so named because it had good keeping qualities and that it was a custom in Pennsylvania Dutch country to send this pie to the members of the bereaved family. I pointed out that it was made with raisins, nuts and spices and added that my source of information was a small booklet of recipes published by a moving and shipping concern known as the Pacific Intermountain Express. I was taken to task by a reader for not giving the recipe in toto. This is it:

First Albert, a 16-to-1 shot, held off the fast-finishing Big Doug to win the $113,800 Cinema Handicap by a head before a crowd of 43,048 at Hollywood Park today. First Albert, ridden by Francisco Mena and carrying 113 pounds, took the lead shortly after the turn for home but was hard-pressed to hold off Big Doug in the late going.

Nadja von Hoyer-Booth, daughter of Baroness Otti von Hoyer-Booth of Hillsboro, N.J., and Graz, Austria, and the late Baron Oleg Nicholaiavitch von Hoyer-Booth, was married at Bear Mountain State Park yesterday to Jan Degenshein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Degenshein of South Nyack, N.Y. Town Judge Murray Jacobson of Clarkstown, N.Y., performed the sunrise ceremony at the Perkins Tower at the summit of Bear Mountain. The bride, who attended Rockland Community and Mercy Colleges, is a translator. She will retain her maiden name professionally. Mr. Degenshein, an alumnus of Washington University in St. Louis, received Bachelor of Architecture and M aster of Science in Planning degrees simultaneously from Pratt Institute. He is president of Jan Degenshein, Architect-Planner, in New City, N.Y., and a doctoral candidate in the environmental psychology program at the City University of New York Graduate Center. His father is president of the B.H.D. Development Corporation, apartment builder in South Nyack.

Under his commencement gown at Bucknell University yesterday, Davis Johnson Jr. accepted his bachelor's degree wearing an unusual Tshirt: ''Bucknell Class of 1980,'' it said on the back. But on the front: ''Class of 1930.'' Mr. Johnson, who is 74 years old, had re-enrolled at the Lewisburg, Pa., school last spring, hoping to complete the four credits he lacked toward a degree when he dropped out of college during the Depression.

To the Editor: Since neither President Carter nor Senator Kennedy can unify the Democratic Party, Democrats will in effect decide which candidate will lead the party to defeat. The sad alternative of a President Reagan would only drive further away our allies and accentuate the decline of American prestige. have confidence in both Democratic candidates that they possess the greatness of character to subordinate personal ambition and step aside. I am sure that a Muskie-Mondale ticket would not only win but give new hope and purpose to America and the world. NATHAN LEVINE Englewood, N.J., May 16, 1980

To the Editor: It would interest me to know how many of the 12 valiant men who rescued three goats, 18 chickens and ''numerous'' hamsters from ritual slaughter in a Bronx tenement (news story May 24) went home and didn't eat meat for dinner.v.hy bust poor Hispanic people when animals are being slaughtered by the million in the factory farms of our country? That the 10 New York policemen involved in the raid could be better employed hardly needs saying.
IRISH ECHOES

Sixteen-year-old Bettina Bunge put top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd through an unexpected ordeal today in the third round of the $617,00 French open tennis championships, yielding by 4-6, 6-4, 6-3. Meanwhile, Jimmy Connors, Vitas Gerulaitis, Wojtek Fibak and Hans Gildemeister moved into the men's quarterfinals. Miss Bunge, a West German citizen who lives in Florida, won the first set on a forehand shot to the corner and took a 3-1 lead in the second before Mrs. Lloyd waged a successful comeback to reach the quarterfinals.

The recession may be a source of trepidation on Main Street but not on Wall Street. ''Recession years tend to be good ones for the stock market,'' commented Leon G. Cooperman, a partner at Goldman, Sachs & Company and chairman of the firm's investment policy committee. Indeed, despite a spate of profit-taking last Thursday, the market has advanced more than 90 points since April 21, when the Dow Jones industrial average closed just below 760, a two-year low. Last Friday the widely followed market indicator, after falling sharply in the morning, finished at 850.48, up 4.60.

PICASSO mania, triggered by the mammoth exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, gets another booster shot, tonight at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13, with ''Picasso: A Painter's Diary.'' This is not a tour of the exhibition. Compiled by Perry Miller Adato with the cooperation of the Museum of Modern Art and the French National Museums, the 90-minute program offers a portrait of the artist and a chronological survey of his career and ideas. Included are interviews with two of Picasso's children, Paloma and Claude, and with such close friends as David Douglas Duncan, the photographer, and Joan Miro, the painter. The words of Picasso himself and several people who figured prominently in his life, from Gertrude Stein to Jean Cocteau, are spoken off camera by actors.

The only requirement for attending is that each camper be able to swim 100 yards. Campers may bring their own boats or use camp equipment. The camp is located in northern

Lionel Lefebvre, a 50-year-old former jockey, works during weekday afternoons as a parimutuel clerk at Keystone Race Track near Philadelphia. That is, after he spends his mornings as a painter and before he spends his evenings as an art student at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts.

MADRID, June 1 (UPI) Alan Jones of Australia won the Spanish Grand Prix in a malfunctioning Williams today and picked up enough points to give him the lead in the world championship standings. But whether that lead would stand was in question because of a rules controversy that threatened to nullify any points awarded in the race.

WASHINGTON, June 1 Another dispute is shaping up between Congress and the Administration over the disposition of 18.4 metric tons of gold taken from Czechoslovakia by Nazi Germany and held by the United States and Britain since World War II.
TEN years after its premiere on CBS-TV, "And David Wept" re ceived its first live staged performance Saturday night at the 92d Street Y, a production in this season's "Jewish Opera at the Y" series.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) New pricing regulations affecting the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) could raise the price of Sohio gasoline by as much as 18 cents to 20 cents a gallon, Federal officials announced.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reuters) Former Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel said today that he hoped his resignation would spur the Begin Government to modify its policies and conclude an agreement on Palestinian autonomy with Egypt.

Churchgoers across South Dakota returned to their cars yesterday to find brochures featuring pictures of a dead fetus and of Senator George McGovern's face slashed with a large X, along with the assertion that he ''has continuously voted tax dollars to kill preborn children.'' Until tomorrow, when Mr. McGovern faces his first Democratic primary challenge in his 18 years in the Senate, all South Dakotans, churchgoers and nonchurchgoers alike, will be unable to listen to their radios for long without hearing commercials denouncing the Senator as a big-spending liberal who is weak on national defense.

The Cosmos, playing before 53,351 fans, the largest crowd to watch a North American Soccer League game this season, subdued the Washington Diplomats, 2-1, in a shootout today at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium. Robert Iarusci, a former fullback with the Cosmos, had put the Diplomats ahead in the 35th minute on a penalty kick, and Giorgio Chinaglia tied the game in the 56th minute with his 10th goal of the season and 500th of his career. Vladislav (Bogie) Bogicevic scored the only goal in the shootout.

Dr. Barbara P. Schneider, senior resident in general surgery at the Einstein College of Medicine-Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, and Morton Schneider, manager of the Eastside Housing Corporation, were married yesterday by Rabbi Reuven Bendelstein in the Fifth Avenue Synagogue. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric Schneider of New York. Her father is a partner in the General Service Centers, an automotive-repair business in Queens Village. Her mother, Gertrude Schneider, is an adjunct professor of education at the City University. The bride expects to become chief resident of surgery at Einstein-Montefiore on July 1.

The Atlantic alliance's eastern flank should be a center of military power strong enough to deter the Soviet Union and its allies from adventures in the Persian Gulf. Instead the flank is militarily weak and politically chaotic as a result of the continuing feud between Turkey and Greece. Add the recurrent waves of anti-Western agitation in both countries and it is easy to understand why leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization fear that there would be no coherent defense if a war in the Persian Gulf spilled over into the eastern Mediterranean.

There is a new kind of skyscraper going up in New York. The new model is not an isolated phenomenon, like a corporate headquarters reaching conspicuously for the sky, or a World Trade Center, setting a record in the tallest-building derby. The new kind, bigger and bulkier than anything the city has seen before, arises because of skyrocketing building costs, and there is nothing to stop it, certainly not New York's permissive zoning practices. Massed together in midtown, the resulting superbuildings will make the city's familiar concrete canyons seem intimate. Sixteen of these huge buildings are already in construction or in advanced planning within a concentrated midtown area. They will all be highly profitable and generate business. But their collective scale raises serious concerns about density, pedestrian mobility and air, sun and shadow patterns, and eventual structural gridlock. Even their economic benefits will be overconcentrated, while other areas in need of development go begging.

With the sun well on its way to disappearing under the edge of the Pacific Ocean, a half-dozen fishing boats started lining up to enter this tiny cove. Dan Freitas, captain of the Intrepid, was one of the first to arrive, and he and his crew had enjoyed a good afternoon: They had shoveled more than five tons of rock cod out of the hold. Mr. Freitas, a bearded man in his early 40's, has been in the fishing business for more than two decades. He smiles easily and is not given to worrying; the worries he does have center mainly on the falling prices of fish, on the threat that big fishing operations pose to himself and his friends, and on toughened environmental regulations, some of which he concedes to be useful.

Rick Bass drove in three runs with a triple and a double, and his Hawaii teammates turned three double plays as the Rainbows beat St. John's, 7-2, tonight in a second-round game of the College World Series. Earlier, California rallied to eliminate Clemson, 6-4. St. John's, which dropped to the losers' bracket in the doubleelimination tournament, will play California tomorrow night. Tonight's victory gave Hawaii a 59-16 won-lost record, while St. John's fell to 30-10.
Juan Carlos Harriott, the captain, scored four goals as Argentina defeated the United States national polo team, 10-6, yesterday and clinched its sixth consecutive Cup of the Americas championship.

For minority auto dealers, especially those who have been in business a decade or less, the severe downturn in the automobile market has been especially difficult, the Commerce Department said. ''While all of the auto dealers are under pressure right now, with sales down so low, the black, Hispanic and other minority dealers are having special difficulty because they have been in business too briefly to accumulate capital and can't get financing,'' said Daniel P. Henson 3d, director of the Minority Business Development Agency, a branch of the Commerce Department.

A United States District Court jury has moved in favor of Great Western Cities Inc. in 41 of 42 suits filed by leaseholders who purchased land at Cochiti Lake from the development firm, owned by two members of the Hunt family. The 42 suits sought a total of $660,000 in damages. In the only case that went against the company, the jury on Friday awarded $8,000 to a woman identified as Marie Cosper, a leaseholder. The jury deliberated some 12 hours over a two-day period before returning the 42 separate verdicts.

Susan Daryl Bauer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Bauer of Hicksville, L.I., was married yesterday to Richard Stephen Lincer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Lincer of Plainview, L.I. Rabbi Julius Goldberg performed the ceremony in the Plainview Jewish Center. The couple are lawyers. She is with the New York firm of Levin & Weissman; he is with Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton, also in New York.

An electronic baseball game that also includes nine other games, Fabulous Fred is hand-held, battery-powered and portable. The device has nine numbers that are programmed for 10 different functions. To start the baseball game, for instance, the select button must be pressed until No. 8 flashes. The player taking the role of the pitcher then pushes the start button, causing the light to flash randomly from number to number. The batter pushes the hit button; this causes the light to stop on a number that registers a hit or an out. The baseball game comes with a stadium diagram, red or blue playing pieces, and an explanation as to what each of the nine numbers means in terms of hits or outs. Among the nine other games contained in Fabulous Fred are roulette, space attack, submarine hunt and mind benders, all explained in an accompanying booklet. Fabulous Fred, a creation of the Mego Corporation, sells for about $35, not including batteries, at most major toy outlets. Insulated Creel for Fishermen
Deborah Rachel Matt, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Hershel Matt of Highland Park, N.J., was married last evening to Milton P. Erdfarb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Erdfarb of the Bronx.

CHITTAGONG, Bangladesh, June 1 (AP) A mysterious disease has claimed at least 70 lives in the last week in three villages along the mouth of the River Ganges, the Bengali newspaper Ittefaq reported today. A medical officer said that the disease attacked mostly young men who experience high fevers and die within three or four hours.

The United States is "woefully unprepared" for new interruptions in oil imports and should cut gasoline consumption by 20 to 25 percent to insure its future international security, a Harvard University report released yesterday said.

Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J., was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Marla Lynn Herman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Joseph Herman of Passaic to Jeffrey T. Segelman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Segelman of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The bride's father, spiritual leader of the temple, performed the ceremony Cantor Isadore Singer and Cantor Jeffrey Shiovitz assisted.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 1 (Reuters) Teheran's main race track, commandeered last month as a detention center for drug addicts, is to be returned to the horses, the Iranian state radio reported today.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., June 1 Direct Scooter, driven by Warren Cameron, registered his ninth straight victory last night, winning the $122,500 Graduate Series pacing final at the Meadowlands.

SUGAR is once again prominent in the commodity futures markets after being relatively dormant for six years. Not only has the price of unrefined sugar shot upward recently, but the open interest is now the fifth highest of all futures markets.

CODEX and Genuine Risk will run the Preakness over again today-over and over and over. Several hundred feet above the bend of the Pimlico oval, where first they met, the colt and the filly will stage their stretch run this time on a silver screen of beaded glass crystals.

The tolls on the two bridges over Jamaica Bay will increase this morning to 75 from 50 cents. In addition the cost of going over the Henry Hudson Bridge, which connects the Bronx and Manhattan, will rise to 60 from 50 cents.
The numbers picked Saturday night in New York State's weekly "Lotto" drawing were 16, 39, 32, 31, 38 and 10. The supplementary number was 29.

WASHINGTON A NEW ROUND of trade negotiations has quietly begun to deal with the thorny issue of impediments to trade in services. It is a Wash ington initiative, and there is a lot of money at stake for United States companies.

It's been two years since California's voters fired the first big volley for a national tax revolt - a constitional amendment to cut their local property taxes by more than 50 percent. The paint has begun to peel off some schoolhouse walls, and public libaries have cut their hours. Yet, all in all, thanks to a $6-billion state reserve, the $7 billion in cuts precipitated by Proposition 13 have not yet been disastrous. Emboldened by victory at Lexington, the commander-in-chief of Proposition 13, Howard Jarvis, is moving on Concord with a still bigger weapon. Proposition 9 on the California ballot tomorrow would further amend the state constitution to cut income tax rates in half. In one blow, the state treasury would lose an additional $4 billion or more. The prospect has sent a new shiver down the spines of municipal leaders, who know that they will be the main casualties.

To the Editor: Your May 17 editorial on Port Authority tolls, ''Storm Signals at the Port Authority,'' stresses that the agency has generously helped automobile, water and air transportation. What it fails to note is that these forms of transportation - most particularly the automobile - have fully paid the authority for its help. In fact, motorists are paying far more than their fair share.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy yesterday brushed aside President Carter's olive branch, saying he did not think the two of them should sit down after tomorrow's final primaries and try to settle the platform for the Democratic National Convention. Mr. Carter's offer on Saturday to ''make concessions in every direction'' on the platform to promote unity was spurned by his rival, who said that despite the President's large lead in delegates, ''I expect to be the nominee.''

A state audit says that some members of the now-defunct Jones Beach State Parkway police on Long Island were apparently stealing gasoline - so much, in fact, that it looked as if their police patrol cars got two miles a gallon or less. The report, released yesterday by the State Department of Audit and Control, examined the financial condition of the Jones Beach State Parkway Authority at the time it was dissolved, in June 1978.

A 25-year-old Manhattan man was charged with firing three shots early yesterday at Reggie Jackson, the New York Yankees outfielder, after the two men had exchanged angry words on East 83d Street. No one was hurt. The shots apparently sailed harmlessly overhead, although a couple later reported that a bullet had gone through a window of their apartment.

At the end of his working day, Eric Soderholm possessed the first five-hit game a Yankee has had in almost three years, a new fan belt and a car that was badly in need of gasoline, water and coolant. Soderholm did not say he was lucky to go five for five in the Yankees' 11-7 victory over Toronto at the Stadium yesterday. He said he was lucky to have got to work at all. Soderholm, who began the season as a part-time designated hitter and backup third baseman, and had not played in nine days, had four singles, a triple and drove in two runs against the Blue Jays. Tom Underwood, who came to the Yankees from Toronto last November and began the season as a relief pitcher, won his fourth consecutive decision for the longest winning streak of his career. Bobby Brown, who belonged to five teams last year, drove in four runs, three on a homer, his fifth in his last 11 games.

Judith Toby Seligson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Seligson of Branford, Conn., was married yesterday noon to Stephen Ted Schaffer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Schaffer of Woodbridge, Conn. Rabbi Arnold Wolf performed the ceremony in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School. The bride, a cum laude graduate of Radcliffe College, is a painter of abstract oils. Her father is professor and chairman of the department of laboratory medicine at the Yale-New Haven Medical Center. Her mother, Harriet Seligson, is a lecturer on laboratory medicine at Yale University.

WASHINGTON A NEW ROUND of trade negotiations has quietly begun to deal with the thorny issue of impediments to trade in services. It is a Washington initiative, and there is a lot of money at stake for United States companies. American services sold abroad - banking, insurance, shipping, air transport, motion pictures, hotel and restaurant franchising, accounting and data processing - amount to some $50 billion a year. But the United States Trade Representative, Reubin O. Askew, is upset about the increasing numbers of barriers that are checking the growth of these businesses.

Deborah Rachel Matt, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Hershel Matt of Highland Park, N.J., was married last evening to Milton P. Erdfarb, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Erdfarb of the Bronx. The ceremony was performed at the Highland Park Conservative Temple by the bride's father. He was assisted by Rabbis Jonathan Matt, the bride's brother, Yakov Hilsenrath and Benjamin Helfgott.

PROPOSITION 295,2,295,0SANTA BARBARA, Calif. - Foes of the controversial Proposition 9, an initiative that would cut California's state income tax in half across the board and that goes before the voters tomorrow, maintain absurdly that it would cripple local governments and curtail public services. The proposal, which could radically change the state's tax base, is fathered by Howard Jarvis, who co-authored Proposition 13. Adopted by the voters in 1978, that measure drastically cut property taxes and gave rise to similar laws in at least 10 other states. It was followed in 1979 by Proposition 4, limiting state and local spending. According to the best estimates, if Proposition 9 passes, localgovernment revenues will be cut by 7 to 10 percent at most. But far larger cuts - say, 15 to 25 percent - are well within the capacity of local governments, in California and in other states, to absorb. In fact, the quality of public services could actually increase if municipalities made intelligent changes in response to such tax cuts.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D. Churchgoers across South Dakota returned to their cars yesterday to find brochures featuring pictures of a dead fetus and of Senator George McGovern's face slashed with a large X, along with the assertion that he "has continuously voted tax dollars to kill preborn children."
LEXINGTON, Ky., June 1 (AP) Torrance Watkins of Boyce, Va., and her mount, Poltroon, captured first place in the Olympic equestrian trials that ended today at the Kentucky Horse Park.
PITTSBURGH, June 1 For a while today, the New York Mets were up to their new tricks, winning an argument with the umpires and ruffling the feathers of the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates.
The rating on Norfolk Western Railway Company equipment trust certificates has been raised to AAA from AA, it was announced Friday by Moody's Investors Service, one of the top credit-rating services.

JOHANNESBURG, Monday, June 2 Guerrillas attacked three strategic fuel installations near here last night, setting off explosions at seven storage tanks and igniting fires that could be seen nearly 50 miles away.

The Broadway theater, maintaining the upbeat tempo of the last seven years, has once again established highs for theater attendance and box-office revenue in the season that ended yesterday. During 1979-80, the number of ticket sales rose to 9.62 million, slightly higher than for the 1978-79 season, and box offices took in $146 million, or $12 million more than in 1978-79.

Guerrillas attacked three strategic fuel installations near here last night, setting off explosions at seven storage tanks and igniting fires that could be seen nearly 50 miles away. The attacks shortly before midnight were the most serious in more than 20 years of sabotage and violence by guerrillas working to overthrow South Africa's white-minority Government.

With the imposition of full martial law and the creation of a military-dominated advisory council of undefined function but apparently great power, South Korea's progress toward democracy is feared by Koreans and diplomats to have gone into reverse for an indefinite time. President Choi Kyu Hah, a civilian, and Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the dominant military leader, have affirmed that ''political development'' remains their goal, but their concurrent emphasis on creating order and stability appears to Koreans to be more relevant and ominous.

The $40 million Cable News Network, which promises to make continuous news programming available to 2.5 million viewers, made its debut today. The network, owned by Ted Turner, an Atlanta entrepreneur, conducted rehearsals for the last month to prepare its employees for the real thing, which began at 6 P.M. today.

The work of 57 artists from the city's public housing projects was displayed at the Museum of the City of New York, at Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, in an exhibition organized by the city housing authority. With the museum's collection of 18th-century art in the background, paintings, photographs, sculptures and a patchwork quilt were shown by tenants from projects in each of the five boroughs. They had been chosen from 375 entries.

HOWARD DAVIS had packed his bags, again, and now they were stacked around him in the living room of the house on Long Beach Road a suitcase next to his right knee, a suitbag at his feet -as he waited for the limousine last Wednesday evening that would take him to the airport for a flight across the Atlantic Ocean. He had never been to Glasgow, but this was still a trip Davis would rather not make. If circumstances were different - if Davis held the World Boxing Council lightweight championship - he might not have to sit through a flight to London and another to Glasgow, where he will fight against Jim Watt of Scotland on Saturday. Davis might not have to bring over his own cook, as he planned for this trip, or deal with unfamiliar sparring partners. One day, he hopes, the limousine will take him to Nassau Coliseum, or maybe Madison Square Garden.

Lionel Lefebvre, a 50-year-old former jockey, works during weekday afternoons as a parimutuel clerk at Keystone Race Track near Philadelphia. That is, after he spends his mornings as a painter and before he spends his evenings as an art student at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. A selection of Lefebvre's works will be on display with some prominent artists beginning on Thursday at the Spectrum Fine Art Gallery, 30 West 57th Street. The fine-arts tribute to thoroughbred horse racing will run until June 27. Lefebvre's contribution includes a pastel study of Secretariat.

The credit markets last week ran into the first real roadblock since their surprisingly strong spring rally began in early April, and so the direction of least resistance this week seems to be toward higher interest rates and still lower prices. Over the course of 1980, however, the consensus is still that short-term interest rates will decline more while long-term bond yields will remain relatively close to the levels they reached at their lows in May.

President Carter flew here late this afternoon to visit Vernon E. Jordan Jr., president of the National Urban League, who was shot and seriously wounded early Thursday by an unknown assailant. After spending a half hour in the intensive care unit at Parkview Memorial Hospital, where the 44-year-old Mr. Jordan was reported in stable but serious condition, the President told reporters that he had not meant to suggest that the shooting was politically or racially motivated when he characterized it as an ''assassination effort'' in a speech in Cleveland Thursday night.

Alan Jones of Australia won the Spanish Grand Prix in a malfunctioning Williams today and picked up enough points to give him the lead in the world championship standings. But whether that lead would stand was in question because of a rules controversy that threatened to nullify any points awarded in the race. Jones, winner of the first grand prix of the season in Argentina, completed the 164.4-mile race in 1 hour 43 minutes 14.1 seconds. With only five other cars finishing what turned out to be a race of attrition, West Germany's Jochen Mass was second in an Arrow, 50.9 seconds behind Jones. An Italian, Elio de Angelis, was third, 1:12.3 further back.

A BEHIND-THE-SCENES debate in the inner circles of the higher education establishment may significantly influence the way the nation's colleges and universities prepare for the lean years ahead. The very question of whether those years will actually be as lean as is widely feared is at the heart of the debate.

While puzzled investigators interviewed inmates at the Brooklyn House of Detention about the escape Saturday of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the police placed the judge and three persons who played important roles in Mr. Jacobson's murder conviction under guard.

EFFORTS in Congress to produce legislation providing financial aid for college students in the next five years have come down to a pair of delicate balancing acts in which lawmakers are trying to satisfy constituencies with conflicting needs. The focus of this activity is the renewal of the Higher Education Act, a multibillion-dollar bill that will determine the formulas and authorization levels for the Federal Government's student aid programs. Legislation expected to reach the floor of the Senate this week is similar to that approved in the House last November.

Gold prices moved up smartly today on world markets, prompted by various rumors and what traders said might be a renewed interest in the precious metal after weeks of apathy. On the London bullion market, gold closed at $563 an ounce today, up from Friday's $534.50 an ounce. In Zurich, gold ended at $561.50 an ounce, and in New York it was $563.

Commonwealth Edison filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a proposed public offering of $60 million in first mortgage bonds due June 15, 2010. * San Fernando Electric Manufacturing Company, in the process of changing its name to SFE Technologies, filed with the S.E.C. for a proposed offering of 700,000 shares of common stock to be sold through a Drexel Burnham Lambert group.

French argument about foreign policy and relations with the United States still uses the Gaullist vocabulary of ''independence,'' ''initiative,'' ''dialogue'' and, on occasion, the same high-handed gestures. But it is changing. There are new doubts, mostly just below the surface. They stem from the visible facts of change in world power. It is common now for the French to speak of their country as a ''middle power,'' and even, when they are worried, as a ''small part of the European peninsula.'' While the European Community has developed a greater capacity than ever to work out joint political declarations, there is also greater awareness of how far it is from the consolidation that would bring weight in the world equal to the sum of its parts in population, economics, technology.

A judge has issued a ruling in a challenge to New York City's policies on taxing property that, if allowed to stand, could nullify nearly 125,000 similar cases and save the city $1.3 billion, city officials said yesterday. The ruling, by Justice Mary Margaret Mangan in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, was on a challenge by Colt Industries to city tax assessments on its 18-story office building at 430 Park Avenue at 56th Street.

The Israeli Parliament defeated a Labor Party motion of no confidence in the Begin Government late tonight by a vote of 58 to 48. Absent from the benches of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Likud bloc during the vote were four officials believed to be considering leaving the party, including Agriculture Minister Ariel Sharon.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, June 2 (AP) - Day-shift policemen of the Royal Newfoundland Constabulary failed to report for work today in a spreading protest against the appointment of a deputy chief that they said bypassed normal promotional channels. Some 30 members of the overnight shift had earlier called in sick.

While the Preakness stretch run was shown 78 times today on film, two stewards of Pimlico Race Course testified that they still saw no evidence of ''bumping'' or of Angel Cordero's striking the filly Genuine Risk with his whip. Edward Litzenberger and Clinton Pitts Jr. were the first witnesses called before a hearing of the Maryland Racing Commission. Both are former jockeys who voted with a third steward not to take down the number of Codex, who was ridden by Cordero, after an objection by the filly's rider, Jacinto Vasquez.
The body of a 15-year-old girl who had been stabbed to death was found on the roof of a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday, the police reported.
JERSEY CITY, June 2--When the polls close tomorrow on the race for Hudson County Sheriff, it will bring to an end another old-fashioned campaign of the kind that seems to happen here regularly.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 2 (AP)-- Dwight David Eisenhower's worn, blue, felt-covered rocking chair sits on the back porch where he liked to entertain visitors or paint portraits.
