The Control Data Corporation has signaled its intention to remain a major factor in the market for supercomputers, those largest of data processing machines used by the engineering and scientific world.
FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 2--The Caligente Chili Company of Austin, Tex., brought out its new "Two-Alarm Chili" last fall, and picked Fort Wayne as its test market because the city is so normal.
Bill Madlock's appeal of his $5,000 fine and 15-day suspension for striking an umpire, Gerry Crawford, was rejected yesterday by the National...

A memorial service for Dr. Julian P. Boyd, emeritus professor of history at Princeton University and editor of "The Papers of Thomas Jefferson," will be held June 12 at 9 P.M. at the Princeton University Chapel. Dr. Boyd died last Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The Justice Department told the Senate Ethics Committee today that it would not be able to complete its investigation of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, until next Sept. 1.

Like borrowers trying to keep one step ahead of their creditors, the Treasury is busy these days raising cash quickly to pay off debt just as it comes due. The Government's debt managers are hobbled by the failure of Congress to raise the $879 billion temporary ceiling on the debt. It was to have expired last Saturday but was extended until Thursday.

Kirk Kerkorian, the financier, offered $5 a share today for the newly created Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company, but withdrew the offer a few hours later because the stock traded at more than $8 a share on the New York Stock Exchange. A spokesman said that Mr. Kerkorian had not made a decision about whether or not to proceed with a new tender offer. The withdrawal of the offer set back Mr. Kerkorian's plan to gain control of the new film company, which was created on Friday by a split of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. The split into a film company and a hotel and casino company, MGM Grand Hotels Inc., was approved at a special shareholders meeting at which Mr. Kerkorian indicated that he intended to acquire control of both new companies.

American auto makers, troubled for more than a year by sagging car sales, will reduce production of new passenger cars this month by 32 percent from a year earlier, to 562,000, for the lowest June level since 1961, according to Wards Automotive Reports, an industry statistical source. Further, Wards reported, as a result production for the April-June period will fall to 1.67 million, 33 percent below the 1979 period and 8 percent below the similar period in the recession year of 1975.

Alcan Aluminum Ltd. said it will undertake a joint feasibility study with a Mexican company of a smelter in Mexico with an annual capacity of 45,000 metric tons. * Boeing Company said Northwest Orient Airlines had ordered two more 727 jet aircraft. * Bristol-Myers Company's Mead Johnson and Company unit said it won approval from the Federal Drug Administration to market Klotrix potassium-chloride slow-release tablets.

The National Academy of Sciences is supposed to be an authoritative, impartial source of scientific advice to both the public and Government - a Supreme Court of Science. But its latest report on healthful diets is so one-sided that it makes a dubious guide to national nutrition policies. The report can only increase the confusion of health-conscious eaters bombarded with conflicting counsel. Some of the report's views are widely accepted: use salt in moderation to reduce the risk of hypertension; keep your weight under control by eating less and exercising more. But its conclusions on fat and cholesterol run counter to the advice of at least 18 major health organizations and the Federal Government. The academy found no reason for the average healthy American to eat less fat, saturated fat or cholesterol to reduce the risk of heart disease. It acknowledged that epidemiological, or population, studies show some correlation between their consumption and cardiovascular disease, but held that could be coincidental rather than cause and effect. The evidence that altering the diet can actually reduce heart disease is unimpressive, the academy said, and it may even be risky.

The trip to Iran by a delegation of 10 Americans headed by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark may turn out to be the first test of President Carter's ban on unauthorized travel to Iran, Administration officials said today. Mr. Clark's group, which failed to get the Administration to grant a waiver of the travel ban, arrived in Teheran today to attend an international conference on Iranian grievances against the United States.

Almost half of all Americans believe family life has deteriorated in the past 15 years, according to a Gallup Poll released today. Asked what three things were most harmful to family life, three in five persons listed alcohol and drug abuse. A decline in religious and moral values was cited by 40 percent and 29 percent answered poverty. Other harmful influences listed included overuse of prescription drugs, 23 percent; teen-agers' promiscuity, 20 percent, and homosexuality, 13 percent.

First-inning doubles by Rick Miller, Carney Lansford and Joe Rudi and a fifth-inning homer by Jason Thompson highlighted California's 15-hit attack as the Angels defeated the Toronto Blue Jays tonight, 6-3. Dave Frost (4-3) held the Blue Jays to five singles over six innings for his first victory in a month. The Toronto starter, Luis Leal (1-1), was in the game for eight minutes. The first five California batters got hits, starting with Miller, who doubled to right field. Lansford followed with a runscoring double, and Rod Carew and Thompson both singled, with Lansford scoring on Thompson's hit. Carew scored on Rudi's double and the Angels led, 3-0.

Dr. Harold N. Willard, director of ambulatory medicine at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford and professor of medicine at the University of Connecticut, died Sunday at his home in Killingworth, Conn. He was 63 years old.

To the Editor: On May 25, I boarded the next-to-the-last car of an F train bound from Coney Island to Jamaica. The car was covered with graffiti and littered with papers and bottles. Not surprising. It also was smeared with and reeked of human excrement. Needless to say, the car was otherwise unoccupied. Needless to say, I did not linger long in it. Needless to say, I reflected once again on a probable fare increase. PAUL ENGER New York, May 26, 1980
Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

It was all very sad, a reversal of the star-is-born fantasy. On Sunday morning, big advertisements in the Sunday supplements proclaimed the impending arrival of ''Camelot'' on Broadway, listing Kathleen McKearney as starring with Richard Burton, the only actor whose name was in larger type. By Sunday evening all that had changed. Miss McKearney had been told by the producers she was being let go from the lavish musical, which is to open here on July 2. For the little-known Miss McKearney, it would have been her Broadway debut. Instead, Christine Ebersole, who until Sunday's matinee was playing the part of Ado Annie in the Broadway revival of ''Oklahoma!,'' was chosen to take over the role of Guenevere, the part created on Broadway by Julie Andrews when ''Camelot'' first opened here in 1960.

Your article ''Lead Persists as Threat to Young'' (May 13) was a much needed reminder of the hazards of lead in children. Public consciousness of the ravages of this ubiquitous metal among urban youngsters seems to have slackened in the last decade, as the enthusiasm of governmental involvement in the 1960's waned. While resurgence of concern for the multiple sources of lead absorption in the young is important, the lack of attention to the dangers of lead poisoning in their parents remains sadly ironic. Lead poisoning in adults has received little notice in the press, including the Times's article. Yet, in this country, there are over a million workers exposed to lead in a variety of occupations, including soldering and paint removing. There are perhaps tens of thousands of cases of unrecognized kidney disease due to lead among these men. Ought not our concern for children extend to their families? Our government spends close to a billion dollars annually for artificial kidney treatments of end-stage kidney disease; virtually nothing is invested toward the prevention or treatment of lead damage to the kidneys of our adult population.

Mercedes-Benz opened the first foreignowned truck factory in the United States here today, a move that reflects the West German company's belief that diesel engines will offset the slumping sales of American-made, gasoline-powered trucks. Executives of the West German auto maker, Daimler-Benz of Stuttgart, said they were optimistic despite current economic conditions in the United States.

George C. Lamb Jr., 54 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the United Parcel Service, a major package-delivery company. He succeeds Harold Oberkotter, 69, who became chairman of the executive committee and who succeeded his brother, Paul Oberkotter, 75. James P. McLaughlin, 65, continues as president. United Parcel was founded with $100 in borrowed capital in 1907 in Seattle as a messenger service under the name the American Messenger Company. Now owned largely by its managers and supervisors, it operates on a national basis from a headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., and serves manufacturers, retailers and individuals. In 1979, the company delivered more than 1.4 billion parcels and earned $83.2 million on sales of almost $3.4 billion.

ANDERSON To the Editor: The attitude taken by the Carter Administration with regard to the Presidential candidacy of Representative John Anderson provides an excellent illustration of the kind of arrogance that has come to characterize the White House recently. espite significant voter interest in Mr. Anderson, the White House has decided that he is not a legitimate candidate but an election ''spoiler.'' Therefore, President Carter will not debate Mr. Anderson. The White House has announced that it is prepared to accept what it refers to as ''some flak'' for this decision, but the decision will not be reconsidered.

A convicted murderer, Jack Potts, stood firm today against renewing appeals that could spare him from Georgia's electric chair on Thursday, saying, ''I want to get it over with.'' The electrocution would be Georgia's first execution in 16 years and the fourth in the United States since 1977. Mr. Potts announced his decision after meeting with his attorneys, Millard Farmer and Andrea Young. ''I've been through the judicial system,'' said the 35-year-old condemned man. ''The courts have upheld my cases, and I don't see any sense in just prolonging it any longer. I want to get it over with.''

The last 442 Cuban refugees in the Peruvian Embassy in Havana were being flown here today, the Foreign Ministry said. The ministry said the arrival of the Cubans marked the end of the problem generated by a rush of refugees to the embassy on April 4.

POWERFUL drugs that revolutionized the practice of psychiatry over the past 25 years and facilitated the release of hundreds of thousands of patients from mental hospitals are coming under wider attack as their alleged misapplications multiply and their disfiguring, disabling side effects persist. The drugs, called neuroleptics, are prescribed frequently now, according to Dr. Shervert Frazier, president of the American College of Psychiatrists, by general practitioners who may not understand the differences between ordinary anxiety and depression and the psychotic disorders for which they are intended.

The Senate rejected today President Carter's request to triple the budget of the Federal Government's chief inflation-fighting agency. Most of the extra money would have financed a tougher program to monitor price increases. In a second vote that also apparently reflected dissatisfaction with the Government's anti-inflation effort, the Senate voted to repeal the law under which controls were imposed on consumer credit earlier this year. A third Republican effort to weaken the authority of the Council on Wage and Price Stability, which runs the antiinflation program, failed.

VILA, New Hebrides, Tuesday, June 3 (UPI)-- Rebels holding the South Pacific island of Espiritu Santo proclaimed independence today and named their nation Vemaranu. The move came despite reports that Britain and France, which administer the New Hebrides jointly, would use force to dislodge the insurgents.
LONDON, June 2--Gold prices moved up smartly today on world markets, prompted by various rumors and what traders said might be a renewed interest in the precious metal after weeks of apathy.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The State Department said today that the Carter Administration had not relaxed its concern over human rights violations in Argentina but was making efforts in other areas to improve relations with that country.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 2--An Iraniansponsored conference on United States "intervention in Iran" opened here today with a 10-member American group led by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark attending in defiance of President Carter's ban on travel to this country.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)--New orders received by the nation's factories fell 5.5 percent in April, the sharpest drop since the last recession, and outlays for new construction declined for the third consecutive month, according to separate reports from the Commerce Department.

A 15-member delegation of Chinese publishing leaders visiting here as guests of the Association of American Publishers is discovering that the writing, editing and selling of books in the United States are, as a business, as puzzling in the Occident as they are in the Orient.
A two-borough argument between Democratic leaders arose yesterday over plans by Staten Island Democrats to let State Senator John J. Marchi, a Republican-Conservative, into the Democratic primary.

The State Department said today that the Carter Administration had not relaxed its concern over human rights violations in Argentina but was making efforts in other areas to improve relations with that country. ''There has been no shift in our policy with respect to human rights in Argentina,'' said Hodding Carter 3d, the department spokesman. ''There has been no lessening of the commitment to that subject.''

Jim Craig is going home. The goaltender for the United States Olympic hockey team that won the gold medal in Lake Placid was traded yesterday by the Atlanta Flames to the Boston Bruins for two draft choices. Craig, who grew up in North Easton, Mass., about 20 minutes by car from Boston, said the trade was ''the ultimate that I could ever hope for.'' The trade grew out of what Craig considered a happy set of coincidences. The Flames, who have two other goaltenders and viewed Craig primairly as a box-office attraction, were sold two weeks ago and will be moved to Calgary, Alberta. The Bruins, who have been interested in Craig since he played at Boston University, have no healthy goaltenders. Gerry Cheevers one of the National Hockey League's premier goalies, is 41 years old and contemplating retirement, and Gilles Gilbert is bothered by serious back problems that may need surgery.

REMOVING BYLINE FOR SIGNATURE ''SSIM: One Night With a Lady Undertaker From Texas'' is a goodhumored piece of Americana, a one-woman show carried out by Mary Bozeman with such a natural flow of manner and language that you don't doubt for a minute that it is as though you had actually dropped by for a visit with this old lady who couldn't stop talking once she got going.

Scientists in Switzerland and Japan report that they have deciphered the structure of genes for varieties of human interferon, the natural virus-fighting substance. The achievements are reported in the May issue of Gene, a scientific journal, by two teams of scientists working independently but obtaining results described in an announcement from the publisher as ''strikingly similar.''

Precious-metal issues, responding to a jump in gold prices abroad, advanced yesterday as the stock market's strongest group. Gold and silver issues, recurring favorites earlier this year, had moved higher late last week. Market prices over all eased slightly, and the Dow Jones industrials dropped 3.5 points, to 847.35. Volume fell to 32.7 million shares from Friday's 34.8 million.

President Carter will go to Baltimore Thursday to speak at the opening session of the White House Conference on Families, it was announced today. The White House press office said the trip would take a few hours in the afternoon. Mr. Carter promised during his 1976 campaign to convene a conference on the American family and its problems. But planning for the event became embroiled in a variety of ideological disputes, ranging from women's rights and abortion to the special needs of the poor and the elderly.

8: Rich Dauer of the Orioles being tagged out at the plate by Charlie Moore, the Brewers' catcher, as he tried to score from second on a single in fifth inning last night in Baltimore. Umpire Jerry Neudecker called the play. Orioles won in 11th on a pinch-hit leadoff home run.

AFTER more than a year on Broadway and another year touring 66 American cities, Vinnette Carroll's ''Your Arms Too Short to Box with God'' has returned to New York, opening last night at the Ambassador Theater. This is both a revival and a revival meeting. The gospel truth is that ''Your Arms Too Short'' is an act of faith and musical glad tidings. Using songs by Alex Bradford and Micki Grant that would be equally at home in a church, Miss Carroll - as author and director - has taken the Book of St. Matthew and turned it into a musicalized sermon. A chorus as choir and soloists who need no amplification welcome us to their sanctuary - with a stained-glass window design by William Schroder - and fill the theater with their evangelical passion.

Pierre Arpels, chief designer of Van Cleef & Arpels, died after a long illness May 26 in Paris, where he worked out of the headquarters and flagship store of the jewelry company on Place Vendome. He was 61 years old. The youngest son of Julien Arpels, the company's founder, Pierre Arpels joined the concern in Paris as a young man and came to fashion jewelry worn by royalty and members of high society. His designs ranged from million-dollar crowns to brooches sold for a few hundred dollars.

NORMAN, OKLA. USING a variety of new devices and observation techniques, scientists are trying to learn what starts tornadoes, why their winds are far stronger than those in other storms, how to predict their occurrence and, perhaps, how to weaken them.

To the Editor: Professor Lowi (Op-Ed May 23) omits one election reform to help insure rational decisions by an incumbent President: Limit him to a single term of six years. This would end political expediency and restore reason and good judgment. MILTON A. GOTTLIEB Jersey City, May 23, 1980

Using a televison set as a prop and talking to a video cassette recording as if it were a real person, Mayor Koch yesterday linked a package of vetoed state aid to New York City's ability to pay for a labor settlement. The contention Mr. Koch sought to make was that unless the city got the state aid by June 30, when the current fiscal year ends, it would not be able to afford a key part of its proposed contract with its workers. To a large degree, though, the medium was the message.

The UMB Bank and Trust Company of New York yesterday lowered its prime lending rate a half point, to 13 1/2 percent, a reduction some analysts expect major banks to match this week. UMB is the United States subsidiary of Israel's United Mizahi Bank Ltd. Most major American banks have currently set their prime lending rates, the interest on loans to their most creditworthy business customers, at 14 percent.

A 15-member delegation of Chinese publishing leaders visiting here as guests of the Association of American Publishers is discovering that the writing, editing and selling of books in the United States are, as a business, as puzzling in the Occident as they are in the Orient.

The Science Book By Sara Stein. 263 pages. Ages 7-14. Workman Publishing, N.Y. Cloth $10.95; paperback $5.95 The ''Science Book'' is a compendium of living science to be found in the home. The author shows children how to grow their own popcorn, how to raise the I.Q. of a rat (a project guaranteed to delight any mother), how a Windex bottle with a straw and balloon can serve as a working model of the lung and what goes on within yeast, molds and the bacteria that inhabit the lower intestine. With assignments to fill summer days, Sara Stein introduces young readers to embryonic life from the outside in and helps them to seek out the invisibles - what really happens when you touch, taste, see, smell and think. Bacteria - How They Affect Other Living Things By Dorothy Hinshaw Patent. 118 pages. Ages 13 and up. Holiday House, N.Y. $8.95.

The Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago announced yesterday that, beginning Aug. 1, it will charge a $15 annual fee on its Mastercard and Visa accounts. William D. Plechaty, the bank's senior vice president for personal savings, said the fee was necessary for an increase of revenues to meet rising costs.

Volkswagen, the West German car manufacturer, said today that its net profits from the first quarter of the year dropped 27 percent, to $72.3 million. Earnings for the same period last year were $98.8 million at current exchange rates. In a letter to shareholders, Volkswagen said its worldwide firstquarter sales climbed 14.6 percent and production was up 7 percent from the first quarter of 1979. The company said uncertainties in international politics and energy made it difficult to project earnings results for the full year.

Late editions of Metropolitan Report on May 29 reported incorrectly on a $6.7 million medical malpractice award to Mary Margaret Noble, a 9-year-old girl from Ronkonkoma, L.I., who suffered brain damage because of prolonged anesthesia. Dr. Alfred G. Lieffrig, a surgeon at Smithtown General Hospital in Riverhead, L.I., who performed the appendectomy, was not a party to the settlement. According to an affidavit filed by the attorney for the plaintiff in State Supreme Court in Nassau County, ''the circumstances of the operation were such that the surgeon had no knowledge of the problem involved and was not really chargeable with such knowledge.'' The ''Careers'' column in Business Day last Wednesday incorrectly reported the site of Sam Houston State University. It is in Huntsville, Tex.

THE-SCENES debate in the inner circles of the higher education establishment may significantly influence the way the nation's colleges and universities prepare for the lean years ahead. The very question of whether those years will actually be as lean as is widely feared is at the heart of the debate. On one side of the debate are expert projections based on actual population trends. Eight years ago, the number of first-graders showed its first significant decline of some 600,000. The curve has gone steadily downward since.

BRUSSELS, June 2 (UPI)--The European Community Commission, the Common Market's executive body, today urged the market's nine member nations to increase production and outside purchases of natural gas to avert a possible shortage in the 1980's and to reduce the E.E.C.'s dependence on oil imports.

EFFORTS in Congress to produce legislation providing financial aid for college students in the next five years have come down to a pair of delicate balancing acts in which lawmakers are trying to satisfy constituencies with conflicting needs.

The Rev. Dr. Gilbert Darlington, an Episcopal clergyman who was the retired treasurer, publications director and investment officer of the American Bible Society, died last Friday of a heart attack at his home at 925 Park Avenue in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

Sam Shepard, the 1978 Pulitzer Prizewinner for his play "Buried Child," won an Obie award last night for the "sustained achievement" of his playwriting career. This was one of 30 awards made at the 25th Village Voice Obie ceremony honoring achievement in the Off Broadway and the Off Off Broadway theater.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The Supreme Court ruled today that a state court that issues rules governing the behavior of lawyers is acting like a legislature and is entitled to the same absolute immunity from lawsuits that is accorded to individual legislators.

To the Editor: The refusal of Iran to obey the order which the International Court of Justice issued on Dec. 14, 1979, in the case of the hostages might be excused by some on the ground that there has been controversy among scholars regarding the binding effect of such interim measures. But there can be no argument about the binding effect of the judgment which the court rendered on May 24. n 1951, when Mossadegh - not the Shah - was the dominant political figure in Iran and brought about the nationalization of the oil industry, the International Court of Justice, on the application of Great Britain, issued an order for interim measures of protection. When Iran refused to comply, Great Britain appealed to the United Nations Security Council under Article 94 of the Charter. The Iranian representative, Allahyar Saleh, argued that an interim order was not binding but admitted that ''the final judgment'' of the Court is binding.

Douglas E. Robinson, left, deputy administrator for policy at the Department of Energy, listening to a question from Senator Pete V. Domenici during a hearing of the Senate Energy Committee yesterday. Listening was Senator J. Bennett Johnston. Mr. Robinson said that the President would ask congress to adopt a plan that would cost $100 million and take more than a year to implement. He added that the plan called for a massive issuing of coupons and would have a substantial rate of error because of difficulties in keeping track of vehicle registrations.

An arbitrator ordered the Utah Jazz to pay Bernard King his full salary for the 1979-1980 season, the National Basketball Players Association said yesterday. The players' group came to King's defense after the Jazz had indefinitely suspended him Jan. 2, the morning after his arrest for alleged forcible sexual abuse in Salt Lake City. Frank Layden, the general manager of the Jazz, said at the time the suspension was designed ''to protect the integrity of our organization and the N.B.A.''

Conrad M. Black, Canada's brash 35-year-old financial whiz kid, walked away from the post of chairman of the troubled Massey-Ferguson Ltd. a week ago, but he insists that he is not abandoning his commitment to turn the troubled manufacturer around. Indeed, he remains chairman of the executive committee though he was succeeded as chairman and chief executive by Victor A. Rice, also the company's president. Mr. Black called the succession ''part of the next phase of the reconstruction of the company, begun in 1978,'' and said that it ''reflects the fact that the operational changes in the company are now largely completed.''

DIGESTIBLE PERFORMANCES There are so many performing artists in New York City and potentially so vast an audience that the city's concert halls and cabarets and lofts and workshops and all such places seem unable to contain everyone. And starting about this time every year, in early June, all spill into the streets and parks to either read poetry, dance, act, sing, play, or to watch and listen. And the price is usually right - frequently it's free.

Outrageously, tragically, predictably, terror follows terror in the West Bank. Only fanatic Palestinians and Israelis can encourage such savagery among their peoples. Only fanatics will claim ''credit'' for acts that create martyrs and cry out for vengeance. Too many on both sides are already scarred by hate, ready to murder and to maim, and to make sure that violence will never end the violence. But only the blind among the leaders of both peoples will deny that diplomacy is collapsing yet again into war. The swiftest prosecution of the bomb throwers on both sides will not validate Israel's endless occupation of Palestinians or the Palestinians' refusal to negotiate with Israel. The policies of both are untenable, and while they may not explicitly invite the terror, they make it impossible to contain.

ONE of the quirks shared by a good many scientists is a love for sage nonsense. Maybe a need for relief from intense cerebral labor breeds a taste for the outrageous non sequitur, the impossible perspective, the logical incongruity. Or maybe occasional eccentricities in the casual speech and writing of some scientists stem from their terrible difficulty in communicating hard ideas to others. Even answering questions like ''What do you do for a living?'' can challenge the wit. For whatever reason, scientists fall into the habit of speaking and writing in metaphor and allegory, often drawing from the art and literature of whimsy.

A government board's decision to censor parts of the Academy Award-winning film ''The Tin Drum'' has ignited another in a running series of emotional controversies here over what control, if any, governments should have over film entertainment. Under Canadian law, each of the 10 provinces has the power to screen all motion pictures before they are shown publicly. Each may prohibit any film outright or demand certain cuts be made before approval is granted. By general consensus, the Ontario Board of Censorship, a panel of seven men and women, is by far the most conservative in Canada, regularly demanding cuts or forbidding films that receive wide public acclaim and no censorship elsewhere, even in neighboring provinces.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy campaigned coast to coast yesterday in a last-ditch effort to defeat President Carter in three big Presidential primaries and somehow shatter the incumbent's overwhelming mass of delegates to the Democratic National Convention. With 580 delegates at stake in New Jersey, Ohio and California, and 116 more in five smaller states, Mr. Carter was secure in his expectation that no matter how many primaries Mr. Kennedy won today, the President's totals would still go substantially beyond the 1,666 delegates needed for renomination at the August convention in New York.

Mayor of Nablus ... 48-year-old Moslem ... One of the most widely known of the West Bank mayors ... Imprisoned and threatened with deportation late last year ... Accused of having supported terrorist actions ... Released by Israeli court order ... Highly militant Palestinian nationalist ... Spent almost entire adult life as political activist ... Said to be regarded as something of a black sheep in his family and among established Nablus clans ... A fiery speaker ... Was member of Syrian Baath Party in 1950's ... Jailed by Jordanians ... Fled after release to Syria, where he lived from 1959 to 1961 when factionalism broke out in Baath Party ... Fled to Egypt until shortly before 1967 Middle East war ... Returned to Nablus to work on farm ... Said to love animals ... Keeps 500 songbirds on his farm. Ibrahim Tawil

Teddy Brenner, a matchmaker who warns that ''marriages sometimes end in divorce,'' went to work yesterday for Bob Arum in what might be considered boxing's version of a Hatfield-McCoy wedding. Brenner, the matchmaker at Madison Square Garden for 20 years and an independent promoter for the last two years, said he would give it a try and go to work for Top Rank Inc., the company directed by one of his longtime bitter rivals.

AN airborne radar survey over the dense rain forest of Guatemala has led archeologists to the discovery of an elaborate network of ancient canals. This is considered the first strong evidence that the Maya civilization had a relatively advanced agriculture. Archeologists say that the discovery may provide the answer to one of the most puzzling questions about the Maya: How did they feed such a large population, estimated to be between 2 and 3 million at one time, in a region where crops are difficult to grow and game is scarce?

The Great Western Savings and Loan Association, the second-largest thrift institution in California, said yesterday that it had offered to buy Financial Federation, the parent company of another big California savings and loan, for about $52.65 a share, or $221 million. A fourth of the offer would be in cash and the rest in 10-year, 10 percent promissory notes. Financial Federation jumped $9.63, to $38.13 a share in response to the offer, after climbing $1.50 a share last week.

684,0About 100,000 people benefit from employment in the ''numbers'' business in Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant, Jamaica, Kingston, Buffalo, Syracuse and elsewhere throughout New York State, according to those who run the games. The business has been operated illegally since its beginning early in this century. Now, however, the state government has decided to compete with the illegal game by offering its own legal version of numbers betting in which players will pick a number from 000 to 999 in hopes of a 500-to-1 payoff on a minimum $1 bet, beginning Sept. 1. This legislation, approved in April, will not significantly benefit our state financially and will polarize further the economic and class divisions in our cities. Rather than establish a competing numbers game, New York State should issue franchises to operate the new legal game to those operating the illegal game. Amnesty would have to be granted for all past numbers violations. This franchise proposal has been wholly endorsed by a wide range of business, political, community and religious leaders throughout the state with whom I have discussed it.

First there was the rain, torrents of it, which delayed the start of the Yankees-Kansas City Royals game for 1 hour 13 minutes. Then there was the desertion as ABC-TV abandoned the heavily publicized contest between the American League's division leaders to go with the backup game between Cincinnati and Los Angeles. Then came torrents of runs, eight of them in the first inning - five for the Yankees and three for the Royals. And that was it for the rest of the game as the Yankees won, 5-3.

Sam Shepard, the 1978 Pulitzer Prize-winner for his play ''Buried Child,'' won an Obie award last night for the ''sustained achievement'' of his playwriting career. This was one of 30 awards made at the 25th Village Voice Obie ceremony honoring achievement in the Off Broadway and the Off Off Broadway theater. The presentation took place at the Roxy roller-skating discotheque. Special citations were presented to the Flying Karamazov Brothers, the actors of Peter Brook's Le Centre International de Creations Theatrales, and Ellen Stewart and La Mama Etc. David Jones and Richard Nelson were cited for their innovative programming at the BAM Theater, and Ntozake Shange was lauded for her adapatation of Bertolt Brecht's ''Mother Courage.''

Dwight David Eisenhower's worn, blue, felt-covered rocking chair sits on the back porch where he liked to entertain visitors or paint portraits. Nearby is Mamie Eisenhower's card table, where she played solitaire or watched television soap operas. Arranged just as the Eisenhowers had them, they are ready for tourists at the Eisenhower farm, which was donated as a national historic site and will open to the public on June 15.

California took an early 5-0 lead but needed a three-run homer from Dan McInerny to defeat St. John's, 8-5, tonight and eliminate the Redmen from the college world series. Earlier tonight, Bob Bastian scattered five Michigan hits and struck out eight to lead Miami to a 3-2 second-round victory over the Wolverines. In the final game of the night, Arizona stayed alive by eliminating Michigan, 8-0.

IN the middle of the night, deep in the Monteverde cloud forest nature preserve in Costa Rica, a woman intently watched a plant that grew on a nearby tree. Its clusters of flowers were bathed in red light from lamps set up on the forest floor, and a camera was aimed at the blossoms. Cecile Lumer, a botany student doing research for a Ph.D. degree, was trying to unravel a botanical puzzle that no one had yet solved: What kind of creature pollinates this particular air plant that lives above ground in tropical forests, and whose blooms open and emit nectar only at night?

The South African Government indicated today that it was contemplating stiff retaliatory action against the African National Congress, the banned black nationalist organization that took responsibility for the bombing of two synthetic petroleum plants and one of the country's largest oil refineries. The attacks, the most serious in two decades of sporadic guerrilla actions against the white minority Government, caused giant fires at two of the three plants. The fires were still burning, though apparently under control, nearly 24 hours after the midnight blasts.

IN ''Blood Wedding,'' that tragic tale of a peasant wedding, Federico Garcia Lorca created a darkly symbolic landscape dominated, as ever, by the twin obsessions of his imagination - passion and death. Employing verse and music and spectacle, it is more tableau than drama, more surrealistic parable than conventional narrative. As a result, it is a work that needs strong acting, and an even stronger directorial vision -qualities only partly realized in Maria Irene Fornes's new English adaptation now playing at Intar. The play is about fate, and the story, such as it is, seems simple enough: The bride (Brenda Feliciano), who is still in love with her old flame, Leonardo (Emil Herrera), dutifully goes off to wed her intended (Felipe Gorostiza), but after the ceremony meets her former lover and flees with him across the Spanish countryside. There the two men defend their honor in a knife duel. As the Mother - played with splendid and outsized emotion by Antonia Rey -predicts in the opening scene, there is but one outcome: the men must die and the women are all left to weep.

Brazil's coffee crop this year is expected to be 19.5 million bags (132 pounds to the bag), or 2.1 million bags less than the 1979 crop, according to a new estimate yesterday by IBC, the Government coffee agency. Octavio Rainho, the agency's president, said that the smaller crop for Brazil, the world's largest producer, would bring a decline in world supply that would strengthen the position of coffee-producing countries in world markets.
ONE of the quirks shared by a good many scientists is a love for sage nonsense.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)--An oversight in preparation for the Republican National Convention in Detroit is threatening to cause problems in media coverage plans, and some news executives are upset.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which began public hearings yesterday on a possible increase in subway and bus fares, disclosed last night that it had already begun modifying subway turnstiles to accept new, more expensive tokens.

Last month, members of the venerable University Club in Albany rejected a proposal to extend full membership to women. Last week, four judges of the New York Court of Appeals resigned from the club in protest. They made their point in just the right way.

In New York, with many players with substantial records of success on the national and international level, there are several players in the opposite situation.

The conductor of the Goldman Band, which has entertained New York audiences at free outdoor concerts for 62 years, says it will not perform this summer because it cannot find a financial backer. The band's longtime sponsor, the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, has decided to discontinue its support unless new funds are found.

TEL AVIV, June 2--The Israeli Parliament defeated a Labor Party motion of no confidence in the Begin Government late tonight by a vote of 58 to 48.

WASHINGTON, June 2--Officials at the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that they had completed security checks and other formalities for thousands of Cuban refugees who had yet to be resettled by private charities.
MIAMI, Tuesday, June 3--The Justice Department said last night that it had attempted to turn back a seagoing freighter with at least 850 Cuban refugees on board...

Keeping up with the nation's military budget is difficult enough in normal years. Members of Congress with weapons plants in their regions inevitably find procurement there inadequate. The military chiefs usually want more than the sitting Administration. And the public, even if it sees a need for more spending, is left confused about how to do it well. The confusion has been worse than usual this year. President Carter finally settled for an annual increase of between 4 and 5 percent for the next five years. The Joint Chiefs first supported him, then supported members of Congress who favor even more, then showed some doubt about the way the Congressmen wanted to spend the added funds. Meanwhile, the House, facing re-election, voted twice to raise defense spending and twice to lower it, thus recording itself in favor of both a stronger defense and a balanced budget.

President Carter's re-election headquarters is a narrow, 12-story building on K Street, a moderately secure place that a properly Nixonian plumber could probably crack long enough to get arrested. But aside from an eye-catching memo pad whose printed salutation cannot be quoted here, such a plumber, upon reaching the inner sanctum, would find nothing of strategic value unless Tim Kraft happened to be at his desk and agreed to a quiet chat about his life, which is to say, about politics.

THE opening season of the Brooklyn Academy of Music Theater Company has come to a smashing finale with ''The Marriage Dance,'' a duet of one-act farces by Bertolt Brecht and Georges Feydeau. And when I say smashing, I'm speaking both figuratively and literally. Brecht's ''The Wedding'' and Feydeau's ''The Purging'' are not only screamingly funny, but they also unleash as much physical havoc as one might hope to find in a civilized theater. In ''The Wedding,'' the guests at a nuptial feast slowly but surely destroy a living room chair by chair, limb by limb. In ''The Purging,'' an elegant Parisian study gradually becomes a sea of smashed porcelain chamber pots. Faint-of-heart theatergoers would be advised not to sit too close to the stage. As always, the Brooklyn company is calling our attention to plays that are rarely seen in New York. On this occasion, David Jones, the group's adventurous artistic director, has come up with two small but perfect gems written more than half a century ago. Both farces are models of craftsmanship that echo the major works of their authors. Both are presented in contemporary, but not gratuitously trendy translations. Andre Ernotte, the director of the evening, has lovingly recreated the high style of classic farce, and he has gotten the most out of a generally fine, if uneven, acting troupe. He has also solved the tricky problems of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ungainly Lepercq Space by setting a proscenium stage down in the middle of the theater and seating the audience on either side.

LAST fall, Congress was leaning toward a general tax cut and there was so much support for a proposal to cut business taxes by liberalizing depreciation that passage of the bill seemed a virtual certainty. Nine months later, the future of the bill - called the Capital Cost Recovery Act - is uncertain. Passage of the measure, cosponsored by Representatives Barber B. Conable Jr., the upstate New York Republican who is the ranking minority member on the House Ways and Means Committee, and James R. Jones, Democrat of Oklahoma, depends on whether there is an election-year tax cut. That, in turn, depends upon the course of the economy over the next few months, the final form of the Congressional budget resolution and the future of President Carter's proposed oil-import fee.
DEPENDENCE To the Editor: S. Baron's suggestion ''Toward Oil Independence via Electric Homes'' (letter May 17) is like offering a hot fudge sundae to someone suffering from chronic obesity.

The hot, humid air of Shubert Alley in Manhattan stirred ever so slightly yesterday by what at first-glance appeared to be a turn-of the-century rocket. But the contraption was not of the flying variety. It was an air-powered automobile. Terry Miller of Crestline, Kan., the inventor of the vehicle, said it cost about 2 cents a mile to run, was powered by compressed air, and could cruise at 29 miles an hour, though not for very long. Mr. Miller is still awaiting a patent on the valve his car uses.

Jorge Velasquez posted up his fifth victory of the day when Quintessential pulled clear in the stretch and beat Down The Drain by three-quarters of a length yesterday in the $31,000 West Hempstead Purse at Belmont Park. It was the fourth time that Velasquez has won five races in one day at a New York Racing Association track. Quintessential, a 3-year-old son of Bombay Duck-Bold Becky, carried 112 pounds over one-and-one-sixteenth miles in 1:45 2-5. The Boy Mikey was third, two lengths behind.

The Supreme Court ruled that in antifraud cases the S.E.C. does not have to prove that a stockbroker or any seller of securities acted with fraudulent intent, only that the seller was negligent or failed to take due care in representing the quality of the securities. The ruling upheld the agency's interpretation of one of its key enforcement mechanisms. (Page D1.) New orders received by the nation's factories fell 5.5 percent in April, to $143.8 billion, the Commerce Department reported. The drop was the steepest decline in more than five years. In another report, the Government said outlays for new construction fell 3.6 percent in April, to an annual rate of $221.7 billion. (D1.)

Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie intends to name John H. Trattner, a career official in the International Communication Agency, as the new spokesman for the State Department, Administration officials said today. He would replace Hodding Carter 3d, who is leaving on July 1. Mr. Trattner, 49 years old, has had previous experience in the State Department's news office and is currently executive assistant to Deputy Secretary Warren M. Christopher.

Dr. Harold N. Willard, director of ambulatory medicine at St. Francis Hospital in Hartford and professor of medicine at the University of Connecticut, died Sunday at his home in Killingworth, Conn. He was 63 years old. Before moving to Connecticut about eight months ago, Dr. Willard had been chief of community medicine at Genesee Hospital in Rochester and clinical professor of medicine at the University of Rochester. From 1967 to 1974, he was chief of continuing care at Yale-New Haven Hospital and professor of clinical medicine at Yale University.

Heat in the Arctic Ocean So much heat is carried into the Arctic Ocean by a branch of the Gulf Stream current flowing north between Greenland and Spitsbergen, a group of islands, that, were it uniformly distributed, it would melt the polar icecap covering that ocean. This melting would radically alter climates in the Northern Hemisphere, but sediment layers on the floor of that ocean show that no such melting has occurred for millions of years.

WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)--The Senate rejected today President Carter's request to triple the budget of the Federal Government's chief inflation-fighting agency. Most of the extra money would have financed a tougher program to monitor price increases.
The dollar was mixed in foreign-exchange trading in Europe and Japan yesterday, but later in the day it gained in New York on news of a rise in interest paid on overseas bank deposits.
An arbitrator ordered the Utah Jazz to pay Bernard King his full salary for the 1979-1980 season, the National Basketball Players Association said yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 2--Kirk Kerkorian, the financier, offered $5 a share today for the newly created MetroGoldwyn-Mayer Film Company, but withdrew the offer a few hours later because the stock traded at more than $8 a share on the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, June 2--The trip to Iran by a delegation of 10 Americans headed by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark may turn out to be the first test of President Carter's ban on unauthorized travel to Iran, Administration officials said today.

ZURICH, June 2 (Reuters)--About 35 young people and punk rock fans remained in jail today following weekend rioting at the Zurich Opera House in which one policeman died of a heart attack and 11 people were injured.

If report cards carried footnotes, the New York Mets' report card for the first four months of their well-advertised "new era" might carry a footnote today reading: "Signed Craig Swan in March to $3 million contract. Opened season in April. Got out of last place in May."

The Federal Reserve, intervening actively in the foreign-exchange markets in February, March and April, sought to stabilize the dollar, first to keep it from climbing too high and later to prevent it from falling too fast.

A two-borough argument between Democratic leaders arose yesterday over plans by Staten Island Democrats to let State Senator John J. Marchi, a Republican-Conservative, into the Democratic primary. ''There's a feeling that he's the only viable candidate,'' said Nicholas LaPorte, the Democratic leader of Staten Island, which makes up most of Mr. Marchi's district.

In most parts of the United States there are players who regularly win regional knockout team titles but have never come close to similar success on a national level. In New York, with many players with substantial records of success on the national and international level, there are several players in the opposite situation. Two of these won their first Reisinger knockout team title Sunday: Gene Neiger, who won both the Vanderbilt and the Spingold team titles eight years ago; and Dorothy Hayden Truscott, who owns three international women's team titles and will try for a fourth in the Netherlands in September.

Thirty of the nation's largest retail chains had an average sales gain of 3.3 percent in April over the year-earlier month, the smallest business increase in many months, Chain Store Age, a trade publication, reported yesterday. The month's trend compares with a 7.7 percent increase among the same retailers in the year through April, the publication found. THE title character in ''The Outsider'' is an American veteran who goes to Belfast to fight for the Irish Republican Army, and in some ways his story is the weakest part of this otherwise compelling movie. The reasons that Michael (Craig Wasson) travels from Detroit to Ireland are trumped-up to a certain degree, and so is a love story that aims to make his sojourn more interesting. And Michael's feelings about his grandfather (Sterling Hayden), which are supposedly at the heart of the matter, also seem tangential to the film's larger concerns. But ''The Outsider'' is vivid even if it isn't much of a character study, and energetic even though it's often clumsy. War-torn Belfast makes for a tremendously effective dramatic backdrop. And Tony Luraschi, who directed the film and adapted its screenplay from Colin Leinster's novel, creates a sense of authenticity that outweighs the shortcomings of the story line.

William and Anna Fisher, the nation's first husband-wife astronaut team, said here yesterday that they had both wanted to be part of the nation's space program since they were children and daydreamed about blasting off into outer space. ''When I was in first grade, my teacher wrote on my report card that I was too rocket conscious, and that all I did was draw pictures of rockets all over the wall,'' Dr. William Fisher said with a smile as the couple sat side by side on a couch in the Berkshire Place Hotel.
CAMPAIGN REPORT supporters of President Carter in Jersey City; Carter Refusal to Debate Anderson Opposed in Poll

The executive bureau of the International Automobile Federation ruled today that yesterday's controversial Spanish Grand Prix was ''illegal'' and not recognized by the highest sanctioning body of motor sports. The race thus will not count toward the 1980 world championship though the problem is expected to go to the international federation's appeals court.

Rick Monday, batting only .182, belted a pinch-hit home run with one out in the ninth inning to give the Los Angeles Dodgers a 3-2 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight. The triumph gave the Dodgers a two-game lead over the second-place Reds in the National League West. Monday was sent up to bat for Mike Scioscia after Bill Russell had struck out. Monday hit Doug Bair's second pitch for his first homer this season. Rick Sutcliffe (1-2) got the victory in relief.

Bill Madlock's appeal of his $5,000 fine and 15-day suspension for striking an umpire, Gerry Crawford, was rejected yesterday by the National League president, Charles S. (Chub) Feeney, who ordered that the suspension of the Pittsburgh Pirate infielder commence immediately.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; 2 Trains Collide in Sweden, Killing 12 and Injuring 50

A memorial service for Dr. Julian P. Boyd, emeritus professor of history at Princeton University and editor of ''The Papers of Thomas Jefferson,'' will be held June 12 at 4 P.M. at the Princeton University Chapel. Dr. Boyd died last Wednesday.

Like borrowers trying to keep one step ahead of their creditors, the Treasury is busy these days raising cash quickly to pay off debt just as it comes due. The Government's debt managers are hobbled by the failure of Congress to raise the $879 billion temporary ceiling on the debt. It was to have expired last Saturday but was extended until Thursday. Last Friday, the Treasury announced in the morning that it wanted to borrow $2 billion and get the cash that afternoon - the fastest financing that Treasury securities dealers could remember. The preceding speed record was set in April 1979, during another Congressional squabble over the national debt ceiling, when the Treasury announced three bill auctions early one evening and sold some the next morning.

The body of a 15-year-old girl who had been stabbed to death was found on the roof of a Brooklyn apartment building yesterday, the police reported. The girl, identified as Sara Clark of 777 Williams Street, was found nude from the waist down on the roof of 106-04 Glenwood Road in the Canarsie section. She had been stabbed several times, the police said.

By John Leonard CHINA MEN. By Maxine Hong Kingston. 308 pages. Knopf. $10.95. MAXINE HONG KINGSTON says: ''I want to talk to Cantonese, who have always been revolutionaries, non-conformists, people with fabulous imaginations, people who invented the Gold Mountain. I want to discern what it is that makes people go West and become Americans. I want to compare China, a country I made up, with what country is really out there.''

Policemen responding to a report of a disturbance at a Queens liquor store shot and critically wounded the store's armed proprietor yesterday in a sidewalk confrontation of confused shouts and waving guns.

The New York City Police introduced yesterday a program intended to help the handicapped avoid confrontation with criminals. The program, developed by the crime prevention section of the Police Department's Office of Community Affairs, will make information on crime prevention available to persons with impaired vision or hearing. The material has been prepared in large-print booklets, both in English and Spanish, in Braille booklets and on audio cassettes. A former victim of a mugging, William Bernstein, was at Police Headquarters for the introduction of the program. Mr. Bernstein, who is 60 years old, is administrator at the Lexington School for the Deaf in Jackson Heights, Queens. He praised the program after describing the trouble he had both with the mugger and then later with police officers.

World Bank Sets Loans The World Bank, officially known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, and two of its affiliates, the International Development Association and the International Finance Corporation, announced yesterday $369.2 million of loans to assist irrigation, power and other projects in Mexico, the Philippines, Burma, Bangladesh, Yugoslavia, Fiji and Honduras. The World Bank loans are at an 8 1/4 percent annual interest rate, and the International Development Association loans will be interest-free. International Finance Corporation loans are usually at close to market rates.

Rebels holding the South Pacific island of Espiritu Santo proclaimed independence today and named their nation Vemaranu. The move came despite reports that Britain and France, which administer the New Hebrides jointly, would use force to dislodge the insurgents. In a brief radio announcement, the rebels who seized control of Espiritu Santo last Wednesday said a seven-member Cabinet had been appointed with Jimmie Stephens, a plantation owner, as chief minister. Mr. Stephens is leader of the revolt on the island, the largest in the New Hebrides chain.

An oversight in preparation for the Republican National Convention in Detroit is threatening to cause problems in media coverage plans, and some news executives are upset. The Republican group running the convention sent out housing reservation forms to the media this month, but emphasized that the hotel space it has reserved covers only the July 13-18 period of the convention, and not the week before.

While puzzled investigators interviewed inmates at the Brooklyn House of Detention about the escape Saturday of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the police placed the judge and three persons who played important roles in Mr. Jacobson's murder conviction under guard. Investigators hoped that Mr. Jacobson, who apparently liquidated his assets in order to raise several hundred thousand dollars in the weeks following his conviction, might have hinted about his escape plans to fellow inmates.

Three more men's quarterfinalists were decided and Billie Jean King was eliminated today in the $617,000 French open tennis championships, but the biggest stir was caused by the nonmatch between Guillermo Vilas and Manuel Orantes. Their fourthround encounter was rescheduled for tomorrow after a dispute over whether Vilas should have been defaulted. Bjorn Borg, Harold Solomon and Corrado Barazzutti scored straightset victories on a hot and sunny day, which was in sharp contrast to the wind and rain that prevailed over the weekend. With Jimmy Connors and Vitas Gerulaitis having won yesterday, three American men were in the quarterfinals.
SUB**SUB**SUB By GLENN FOWLER

Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today accepted a plan for settlement of Britain's budget dispute with its Common Market partners, which had threatened ultimately to enfeeble and perhaps even destroy the West European economic alliance. In the view of many experts, it was the worst crisis in the 25-year history of the European Economic Community, as the Common Market is formally known. The argument revolved around seemingly arcane considerations such as net contributions to the costs of running the community, the free movement of lamb and mutton among countries, and the size of agricultural subsidies. But it went to the heart of the political relationships in Western Europe.

President Carter, who is currently locked in battle with Congress over portions of his 1980 and 1981 budgets, will begin the formal preparation of the budget for the fiscal year 1982 tomorrow, the White House announced today. ''Once again, as in the spring of every year, the President finds himself dealing with three budgets all at the same time,'' Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, said, explaining that Mr. Carter had found it necessary to clear much of his official schedule this week to deal with Congress.

Alaska's official sport, as mandated by the legislature, is dog-sled racing. Unofficially, it is ''Fed-kicking.'' Kicking the Federal Government dominates conversations, whips up enthusiasm for political candidates and has caused windfall profits for the bumper-sticker industry.

Sullivan's Bar at 783 Eighth Avenue sponsors two softball teams - Sullivan's Smokeaters from the firehouse across the street and Kitty's Kops from the Midtown North police station. When they win, the teams head for Sullivan's to raise a couple. When they lose, as happened the other day, nobody has the nerve to look Kitty in the eye. ''I know they got beat,'' Kitty was saying the other afternoon as she sat at the end of the bar staring glumly at the door. ''They're ashamed to show their faces in here.''

Dave Rosello belted a two-run homer to cap a three-run fifth inning tonight and Wayne Garland went six innings in his first start of the season to pace the Cleveland Indians to a 10-5 victory over the Oakland A's. After taking a 2-0 lead in the third on an infield out and Ron Hassey's run-scoring single, the Indians added two more in the fourth on a single by a rookie, Jerry Dybzinski, with the bases loaded. Hassey's single and a bases-loaded walk gave Cleveland a 9-3 lead in the sixth.

The European Community Commission, the Common Market's executive body, today urged the market's nine member nations to increase production and outside purchases of natural gas to avert a possible shortage in the 1980's and to reduce the E.E.C.'s dependence on oil imports. A report from the Common Market's Energy Commissioner, Guido Brunner, has been sent to the Council of Ministers, warning of possible shortages of natural gas supplies in the coming decades.

Q. Why do birds fly in V-shaped formations? A. ''V'' formations are generally observed during migration seasons, but scientists are not sure just why birds travel in that pattern. Some ornithologists suggest that a V-shaped flight is more efficient aerodynamically, minimizing the air friction for each bird as it flies in its neighbor's slipstream. However, studies of geese show that the angle variations in different flights are so frequent and great that any aerodynamic advantage is negated. Pelicans and ibises are also frequent V-formation fliers; however, very few other species actually fly in V formations. Q. What is ionizing radiation?
Scientists in Switzerland and Japan report that they have deciphered the structure of genes for varieties of human interferon, the natural virusfighting substance.
WASHINGTON, June 2--The Supreme Court today upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission's interpretation of one of its key enforcement mechanisms.

AFTER a career in the magazine business that has lasted 35 years and a lot more serious study of it than many of his fellows have given it, William Parkman Rankin can say, "at successful magazines people feel relaxed and happy."

TORONTO, June 2--A government board's decision to censor parts of the Academy Award-winning film "The Tin Drum" has ignited another in a running series of emotional controversies here over what control, if any, governments should have over film entertainment.

With the Federal Government, corporations and states and cities moving swiftly to borrow large amounts of money this week, interest rates rose and fixed-income securities fell in price. One large housing bond issue was postponed.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party easily won eight of the nine states that elected new governments last week, final results showed today.

Policemen responding to a report of a disturbance at a Queens liquor store shot and critically wounded the store's armed proprietor yesterday in a sidewalk confrontation of confused shouts and waving guns.

Peter Zazofsky of Newton, Mass., a 26-year-old violinist, placed second in the 29th Queen Elisabeth International Competition in Brussels. He was awarded 200,000 francs, approximately $6,600. First and third prizes went to two Japanese violinists, Yuzuko Horigome and Takashi Shimuzu. Mr. Zazofsky, the son of George Zazofsky, former assistant concertmaster of the Boston Symphony, and nephew of the oboists Harold and Ralph Gomberg, last year won first prize in the Montreal competition, worth $10,000. He has studied with Joseph Silverstein, Ivan Galamian and Dorothy DeLay.
WON'T BE FINISHED TILLL SEPT.1 By IRVIN MOLOTSKY

BALTIMORE IF the term ''media event'' weren't in the language already, we should have to get a Latin to invent it to describe what went on yesterday in the third-floor dining room of the Pimlico clubhouse. The Maryland Racing Commission was hearing the appeal of Bert and Diana Firestone on the decision of the Pimlico stewards, who on May 17 ruled that the Firestones' filly, Genuine Risk, had not been fouled in the 105th Preakness Stakes. Usually these affairs are just part of the racing routine, like a baseball manager's protest of an umpire's call. The hearing is conducted in an office, and the commissioners decide, with no great sweat, whether to uphold or reverse the judgment of their appointed judges. Much more often than not, the stewards are upheld.
Mayor Koch yesterday proclaimed June 2 to 8 as Puerto Rican Week.

Len Sakata belted a leadoff pinch-hit homer in the bottom of the 11th inning tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles to a 9-8 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers. Sakata, batting for Wayne Krenchicki, hit the homer off Bob McClure (1-2). Tippy Martinez (1-2), who faced one batter, got thevictory. He struck out Ben Oglivie with the bases loaded.

Immediately after taking over as chairman and chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation from Lewis W. Foy, who retired, Donald H. Trautlein has announced a reorganization of the top jobs in the company's executive office. Following what Mr. Trautlein described as a realignment of certain executive responsibilities, Frederic W. West Jr. chose to retire on June 30 at 61, after serving 39 years with the company. Mr. West, whose background had been in sales, was president of the nation's second-largest steel company after U.S. Steel from 1974 to 1977, at which time he was appointed a vice chairman. Mr. West said through a company spokesman that his early retirement was entirely of his own choosing and that he had been thinking about it for some time.

Fiat Motors of North America Inc. announced here today that it was raising sticker prices on its models by an average of $174, or 2.7 percent. Fiat Motors, a subsidiary of the giant Italian auto maker, said the price increases, which take effect immediately, affect its frontwheel-drive compact Strada and selected models of its Brava, X1-9 and Spider 2000 imported from Italy.

William J. Mitchel, considered one of the top commercial code experts in the world before his retirement in 1969, died Friday at a nursing home in Mountain View, Calif., after a long illness. He was 83 years old and had lived in San Francisco. Mr. Mitchel was the founder and a president of the Acme Code Company of New York, with offices in London and San Francisco. Commercial codes, as Mr. Mitchel once explained, have two main purposes: to cut cable and telegram costs and to keep messages confidential.

Thirty of the nation's largest retail chains had an average sales gain of 3.3 percent in April over the year-earlier month, the smallest business increase in many months, Chain Store Age, a trade publication, reported yesterday.

So much heat is carried into the Arctic Ocean by a branch of the Gulf Stream current flowing north between Greenland and Spitsbergen, a group of islands, that, were it uniformly distributed, it would melt the polar icecap covering that ocean.

AN airborne radar survey over the dense rain forest of Guatemala has led archeologists to the discovery of an elaborate network of ancient canals. This is considered the first strong evidence that the Maya civilization had a relatively advanced agriculture.
PARIS, June 2--Three more men's quarterfinalists were decided and Billie Jean King was eliminated today in the $617,000 French open tennis...

The Justice Department said last night that it had attempted to turn back a seagoing freighter with at least 850 Cuban refugees on board that was reported steaming for Key West, 150 miles south of here. But the effort apparently failed, and the Coast Guard said early today that the ship was expected to dock this morning, and that her master and crew would be arrested. Yesterday evening Atlee Wampler 3d, the United States Attorney here, said that the Federal authorities were using ''our best efforts'' to prevent the ship from landing in Key West. Mr. Wampler declined to describe the efforts, but said that if they were unsuccessful, the ship would be impounded and its owners and crew subject to arrest on felony charges of smuggling aliens.

THERE was a time when such glamour stocks as Johnson & Johnson, American Home Products, Eastman Kodak, Eli Lilly and more than 40 other issues dominated the stock market because they offered high growth and thus promised substantial capital gains. But that was years ago. Nowadays the shares of such companies are at such a low ebb that it is hard to believe they once provided leadership for the stock market.

Some 300 Army troops were ordered into Fort Chaffee today in a tightening of security after rioting by Cuban refugees who were upset at long delays in processing. The Governor of Arkansas said up to 2,000 National Guardsmen would also be available to maintain calm. In the disturbances yesterday, which involved about 300 refugees, soldiers and police were pelted with stones as people inside the compound charged the entrance. The insurrection left 40 persons, most of them Cubans, injured, and four buildings burned to the ground. Thirty-five persons were detained.

An Iranian-sponsored conference on United States ''intervention in Iran'' opened here today with a 10-member American group led by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark attending in defiance of President Carter's ban on travel to this country. The four-day international meeting, ordered by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini after the unsuccessful American attempt to rescue the 53 hostages in April, brought together several hundred nongovernmental delegates from what were described as ''anti-imperialist'' organizations in about 50 countries. The purpose is to hear reports prepared by Iranian officials on American policy in Iran.
PITTSBURGH, June 2 (AP)-- Vance Law, Dave Parker and Pittsburgh's winning pitcher, Don Robinson, drove in two runs apiece tonight to lead the Pirates to a 9-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.
NEW DELHI, June 2--Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party easily won eight of the nine states that elected new governments last week, final results showed today.

A coalition of the city's eight uniformed-service unions reduced its wage demands yesterday from 16 to 14.5 percent for each year of a two-year contract, but the city's chief labor negotiator called it an "insignificant movement."

The Southern and the Norfolk and Western Railways, two of the country's most profitable and efficient freight railroads, announced yesterday that they had reached a preliminary $2 billion agreement to merge into a single company by exchanging stock.
DETROIT, June 1--The early verdict from Detroit is two cheers for the sales rebates.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska-Alaska's official sport, as mandated by the legislature, is dog-sled racing. Unofficially, it is "Fed-kicking."
