IN the middle of the night, deep in the Monteverde cloud forest nature preserve in Costa Rica, a woman intently watched a plant that grew on a nearby tree.

PARIS, June 2--French argument about foreign policy and relations with the United States still uses the Gaullist vocabulary of "independence," "initiative," "dialogue" and, on occasion, the same high-handed gestures. But it is changing. There are new doubts, mostly just below the surface.
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, June 2 (AP)--Day-shift policemen of the Royal Newfoundland Constabulary failed to report for work today in a spreading protest...

To the Editor: In running for President, George Bush spent $16 million, half of which came out of the pockets of the taxpayers of America. When we are advised of the other candidates' expenditures, we can be assured the total figures will be staggering. Two thoughts come to mind: First, the campaigns are too long, and second they are too expensive.v.e are subjected to an overdose of electioneering which is unnecessary and at best of dubious value. Our Congress made it possible by legislating the Primary Matching Fund, Chapter 26 of Title 26. Matching funds come from taxes that hard-working Americans must pay.
POLLUTION SITES AND AGREE ON NEED TO ACT By JOSH BARBANEL

Vance Law, Dave Parker and Pittsburgh's winning pitcher, Don Robinson, drove in two runs apiece tonight to lead the Pirates to a 9-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. The Phillies, who dropped three games behind the first-place Pirates in the National League's Eastern Division, held a 3-2 lead through four innings. But the Pirates, capitalizing on two errors by the Phillies' third baseman, Mike Schmidt, erupted for five unearned runs in the fifth off the losing pitcher Randy Lerch, whose won-lost record fell to 1-7.

Officials at the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that they had completed security checks and other formalities for thousands of Cuban refugees who had yet to be resettled by private charities. The last stage of resettling refugees has traditionally been managed by private agencies rather than the Government, the officials said.

Occupied West Bank, June 2 - The three most nationalist Palestinian mayors were targets of bombing attacks today in a terrorist operation that spanned four cities and left 10 people wounded, nine of them Arabs. Israeli suspicion focused on Jewish extremists, some of whom had threatened to adopt terror tactics and now hailed the attacks. No arrests were made.

HEINRICH ISAAC (c. 1470-1517) is generally regarded as one of the giants of Renaissance music, a Flemish composer who wrote prolifically and masterly in virtually every musical form of his era. If he is performed at all today, it is usually his secular works that receive attention, while his massive body of sacred music goes unheard. The Cappella Nova took steps to rectify this situation at its concert in St. Joseph's Church on Sunday night, offering the complete ''Missa de Confessoribus'' as well as a number of motets. Many of the motets are still unpublished, and they were transcribed by the group's director, Richard Taruskin. It was a lovely evening of music and very likely a revelation even for specialists - one could easily hear why Isaac was considered a precious adornment at the Medici court in Florence and later at the court of Emperor Maximilian I. The program presented the Mass, a late work, in sectional blocks framed by a number of motets drawn from all phases of Isaac's career, giving a very full picture of his extraordinary technical and inventive powers.

Gretchen Cryer, Geraldine Fitzgerald and other prominent theater women gathered at the American Place Theater at 111 West 46th Street yesterday to celebrate a phenomenon and reflect on its tardy appearance. The phenomenon was the growing visibility of women in such roles as playwright and director, and the event was ''Women: The Emerging Force in Theater'' - a panel discussion and entertainment sponsored by the Dramatists Guild Committee for Women and the Women's Project of the American Place Theater.

The Buffalo Bills today signed Jim Ritcher, a center who was their No. 1 choice in the National Football League's recent draft, to a series of one-year contracts. The terms were not disclosed. Ritcher, 6 feet 3 inches and 250 pounds, of North Carolina State University, last year won the Outland Trophy, which is awarded annually to the best collegiate interior lineman.

Pierre Arpels, chief designer of Van Cleef Arpels, died after a long illness May 26 in Paris, where he worked out of the headquarters and flagship store of the jewelry company on Place Vendome. He was 61 years old.

Precious-metal issues, responding to a jump in gold prices abroad, advanced yesterday as the stock market's strongest group. Gold and silver issues, recurring favorites earlier this year, had moved higher late last week.

When the polls close tomorrow on the race for Hudson County Sheriff, it will bring to an end another old-fashioned campaign of the kind that seems to happen here regularly. Just today, for example, there was a 200-car motorcade led by Sheriff John E. Gillen that wound through the county from Bayonne to North Bergen and on to Secaucus. There are plans to send out teams of street painters to stencil ''Gillen B-2'' on the pavement outside all 407 polling places in the county by 1 A.M. ''B-2'' designates the column and place Mr. Gillen's name will appear on the ballot.
There's room in this land for only one nation. Anyone who thinks Jews and Arabs can coexist is a fool.'' -Yossi Dayan, of the Israeli Kach movement. (A8:1.) *

International Attacks on three Palestinian mayors injured 10 persons, including two of the mayors and seven other Arabs. Israeli officials suspected Jewish extremists of responsibility for the carefully coordinated bombing attacks, focused on the leading nationalist mayors in the West Bank. (Page A1, Column 6.) Major firebombings in South Africa may lead to stiff Government retaliation against a banned black nationalist group that took responsibility for the attacks on one of the country's largest oil refineries and two synthetic petroleum plants. The attacks caused huge fires at two plants and estimated damage of nearly $8 million. (A1:4-5.) American ''intervention in Iran'' is the subject of a conference that opened in Teheran. The conferees include a 10-member United States group led by former Attorney General Ramsey Clark attending in defiance of President Carter's ban on travel to Iran. (A1:2.) A Common Market crisis was resolved as Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher accepted a compromise plan for settlement of Britain's funding dispute with its eight partners. Under the plan, Britain agreed to increased farm prices in return for a reduction in its contribution to the group's budget. (A1:3.) Italy's Prime Minister faced pressure to resign in an attempt to avert an impeachment-like procedure against him. The Communists vowed to collect the signatures needed to bring about a full-scale parliamentary inquiry into allegations that Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga revealed secret Government information to enable the son of a fellow Christian Democrat to escape arrest as a terrorist suspect. (A3:3-6.) Indira Gandhi's party easily won eight of the nine states that elected new governments last week, final results showed. Her party has won back the crucial Hindi-speaking heartland, but about half of India's 22 states are still controlled by the opposition. (A3:1-2.) National Rioting by Cuban refugees Sunday at Fort Chaffee, Ark., led the Government to send about 300 Army troops there and to tighten security after the revolt over long processing delays. The Governor of Arkansas said that up to 2,000 National Guardsmen would be available to maintain calm after the insurrection that left 40 persons, most of them Cubans, injured, four buildings burned to the ground and 35 persons under arrest. (A1:1.) A big freighter carrying 850 Cubans was reported heading for Florida and the Justice Department said it was trying to turn the ship back to Cuba. A Federal prosecutor said that if the efforts failed, the ship would be impounded and its owners and crew would face felony charges. (B11:5-6.) Edward M. Kennedy campaigned coast to coast on the day before final primary challenges against President Carter. With 580 delegates at stake in New Jersey, Ohio and California and 116 more in five other states, the President was secure in his expectation that no matter how many primaries Senator Kennedy would win today, Mr. Carter would still have substantially more delegates than he needs. (A1:4.) A church suffered a legal setback as the Supreme Court declined to bar a state investigation of its finances. California courts have ordered officials of the Worldwide Church of God to surrender thousands of documents that the state says it needs for its inquiry into allegations that leaders of the church were squandering its funds. (A16:1-4.) The Vernon E. Jordan shooting inquiry was pressed by Federal agents, who questioned the woman who was with the civil rights leader when he was severely wounded Thursday. Her attorney said that she had previously given ample details of the shooting to the police and that she had no involvement in the attack. (A14:1.) Concern over powerful drugs frequently used to treat anxiety and depression is intensifying. The drugs, called neuroleptics, have revolutionized the practice of psychiatry and facilitated the release of hundreds of thousands of patients from mental hospitals, but they are under growing attack as their alleged misapplications multiply and their disabling side effects persist. (C1:5-6.) Metropolitan City property-tax policies were upheld by a State Supreme Court justice in a ruling that New York City officials said could nullify nearly 125,000 similar challenges and save the city up to $1.3 billion. The justice affirmed the city's right to tax commercial and income-producing property at a rate different from other properties. (A1:1-3.) New York City is the biggest lobbyist in Albany, according to a state report. It said that the city and its semi-independent agencies spent $279,860 to lobby before the State Legislature and state commissions last year, more than any private or public organization. The city's chief lobbyist called the efforts ''very cost effective.'' (B1:6.) Plans for a higher transit fare were being expedited. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which began public hearings on a possible increase in fares on New York City subways and buses, disclosed it had already begun modifying subway turnstiles to accept new, more expensive tokens. (B3:2-4.) A halt in the Goldman Band concerts that have provided free, outdoor entertainment for New York audiences for 62 summers was disclosed. The foundation that has been the financial mainstay of the concerts has discontinued its support, citing sharply rising costs, and the ensemble has been unable to get alternative funding. (B1:1-2.) Richard (Rube) Marquard, a Hall of Fame pitcher whose 19 consecutive victories 68 years ago remain a major league record, died at his Baltimore home Sunday night following a lengthy illness. He was 90 years old.

LIMA, Peru, June 2 (AP)--The last 442 Cuban refugees in the Peruvian Embassy in Havana were being flown here today, the Foreign Ministry said. The ministry said the arrival of the Cubans marked the end of the problem generated by a rush of refugees to the embassy on April 4.
WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)--The Interior Department announced today that it was establishing three new wildlife refuges for migratory birds in Mississippi, Tennessee and Arkansas.

LAST fall, Congress was leaning toward a general tax cut and there was so much support for a pro posal to cut business taxes by liberalizing depreciation that passage of the bill seemed a virtual certainty.

A judge has issued a ruling in a challenge to New York City's policies on taxing property that, if allowed to stand, could nullify nearly 125,000 similar cases...

The Great Western Savings and Loan Association, of Los Angeles, the second-largest such institution in the United States, said yesterday that it had offered to buy Financial Federation also of Los Angeles and the parent company of another big California savings and loan, for about $52.65 a share, or $221 million.

The National Academy of Sciences is supposed to be an authoritative, impartial source of scientific advice to both the public and Government--a Supreme Court of Science. But its latest report on healthful diets is so one-sided that it makes a dubious guide to national nutrition policies. The report can only increase the confusion of health-conscious eaters bombarded with conflicting counsel.
The New York City Police introduced yesterday a program intended to help the handicapped avoid confrontation with criminals.
ANY ORGANIZATION By SELWYN RAAB

Following is a list of the 10 Americans who traveled to Iran. Mary Anderson, member of the American Friends Service Committee. Kay Camp, international president of the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. Ramsey Clark, lawyer, former United States Attorney General. John Gerassi, freelance journalist. Lennox Hinds, Rutgers University law professor. The Rev. Charles Kimball, a Baptist minister who was with a group that visited the hostages in December. George Wald, a Harvard biologist and Nobel Prize winner. The Rev. Paul Washington, an Episcopal minister and Philadelphia civil rights activist. Leonard Weinglass, a Los Angeles lawyer. The Rev. John Walsh, a Protestant chaplain at Princeton University who visited the hostages in December.

Jack McKinney, who lost his job as coach of the Los Angeles Lakers to Paul Westhead, was named tonight to replace Bobby Leonard as coach of the Indiana Pacers. The coaching change was announced by a spokesman for the National Basketball Association club, Ed McKee, who said earlier tonight that Leonard had received permission to look for a new position.

KANSAS CITY (AL) - Reactivated Hal McRae, designated hitter. Placed Steve Braun, outfielder, on waivers. MONTREAL (NL) - Placed Ellis Valen- tine, outfielder, on 21-day disabled list. COLLEGES SEATTLE PACIFIC - Named Claude Terry assistant basketball coach.

The Federal Reserve, intervening actively in the foreign-exchange markets in February, March and April, sought to stabilize the dollar, first to keep it from climbing too high and later to prevent it from falling too fast.

Hans Utsch, former president of Hans Utsch & Company, investment brokers, at 50 Broadway in Manhattan, died Sunday at his home in Westhampton Beach, L.I. He was 79 years old. Mr. Utsch, who was born in Germany, came to the United States in the late 1920's. In 1932, he established International Remittances, dealers in foreign exchange. He also established the investment brokerage at about the same time.

A murder charge against Max Dunlap in the car-bomb slaying of the newspaper reporter Don Bolles was dismissed ''without prejudice'' today because a key witness would not cooperate with the state. The action by Superior Court Judge Robert L. Myers came exactly four years after Mr. Bolles, an investigative reporter for The Arizona Republic who wrote about organized crime, was killed.

To the Editor: In your May 15 issue, William T. Golden writes sensibly on the Op-Ed page about the need for scientific insights in the Federal Government.$ Mr. Golden adds that the effectiveness of Frank Press (the President's Science Adviser) is limited by the fact that he doesn't have a Presidential Science Advisory Committee to back him up.

FOR the first time in the 75-year history of the Naumburg Orchestral Concerts, the organization put on a program Sunday night without fear of disruption by rain or the random noises that plague outdoor musical events in the summertime. For, you see, the concert was performed in the relative peace of Carnegie Hall, in celebration of the diamond anniversary of these free programs, rather than in the bandshell on Central Park Mall. Bargain-conscious New Yorkers have soaked up free music in the park, courtesy of the Naumburg family, without interruption since 1905. Oh, there was one reminder of the concerts' time-honored venue: someone apparently had brought an infant into the hall, and faint yelps and squeals could be heard intermittently during the first half of the program. However, the night went smoothly otherwise, to the obvious delight of a large audience that seemed about equally divided between the young and the elderly.

If report cards carried footnotes, the New York Mets' report card for the first four months of their well-advertised ''new era'' might carry a footnote today reading: ''Signed Craig Swan in March to $3 million contract. Opened season in April. Got out of last place in May.'' Nobody in baseball believes that success is measured in a straight line, but a lot of people think it is measured by dollar signs. As the Mets begin the fifth month of their new regime and the third of their regular season, the recent improvement in their report card is being explained in many ways: the hot hitting of Frank Taveras, the relief pitching of Neil Allen and Jeff Reardon, the maturing of everybody else, the tenacity of Manager Joe Torre.

PHOENIX, June 2 (UPI)--A murder charge against Max Dunlap in the carbomb slaying of the newspaper reporter Don Boiles was dismissed "without prejudice" today because a key witness would not cooperate with the state.
"SIM: One Night With a Lady Undertaker From Texas" is a good-humored piece of Americana, a one-woman show carried out by Mary Bozeman...

WASHINGTON, June 2--President Carter, who is currently locked in battle with Congress over portions of his 1980 and 1981 budgets, will begin the formal preparation of the budget for the fiscal year 1982 tomorrow; the White House announced today.
OMAHA, June 2 (AP)--California took an early 5-0 lead but needed a three-run homer from Dan McInerny to defeat St. John's, 8-5, tonight and eliminate the Redmen from the college world series.
WOLFSBURG, West Germany, June 2 (AP)--Volkswagen, the West German car manufacturer, said today that its net profits from the first quarter of the year dropped 27 percent, to $72.3 million.
FINANCESL814

NORMAN, OKLA. USING a variety of new devices and observation techniques, scientists are trying to learn what starts tornadoes, why their winds are far stronger than those in other storms, how to predict their occurrence and, perhaps, how to weaken them. The tools include aircraft armored against hailstones, rockets mounted on an aircraft to probe tornado funnels, a shock-resistant instrument package to be implanted ahead of an on-coming tornado, as well as airborne and ground-based instruments to track storms, their winds and lightning.

The early verdict from Detroit is two cheers for the sales rebates. According to most accounts, the unusual across-the-board rebates offered by Ford and Chrysler are doing little more than allowing the ailing auto makers to cut their losses. But the sales tactic is drawing a few more shoppers into the showrooms and helping to sell a few more cars, and according to auto executives, that is not to be sneezed at in today's market. ''It isn't turning the market around,'' John K. Givens, the Chrysler Corporation's marketing director, said of the rebate campaign, ''but sales are certainly doing better than if we didn't have it. The traffic is coming in, and people who are looking to buy are looking for rebates.'' He added, however, that ''the market is dead out there'' and that ''there's a depression out there in the marketplace.''

The conductor of the Goldman Band, which has entertained New York audiences at free outdoor concerts for 62 years, says it will not perform this summer because it cannot find a financial backer. The band's longtime sponsor, the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, has decided to discontinue its support unless new funds are found. The 54-piece ensemble, unabashedly old-fashioned in its presentation of both popular and classical selections, has long been part of the city's summer season, attracting thousands of listeners nightly to Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center.
The Caligente Chili Company of Austin, Tex., brought out its new ''Two-Alarm Chili'' last fall, and picked Fort Wayne as its test market because the city is so normal.

An executive of an upstate Offtrack Betting organization said yesterday that he had ordered delays in race calls at OTB headquarters in Schenectady in order to cope with what he called illegal bookmaking operations. The employee, Lee Frescatore, the mutuel manager of the Capital District Regional Offtrack Corporation, testified at a hearing in Manhattan before the New York State Racing and Wagering Board over alleged ''past posting'' at the upstate OTB office. Past posting is when bets are made after the winner of a race is known.

The Rev. Dr. Gilbert Darlington, an Episcopal clergyman who was the retired treasurer, publications director and investment officer of the American Bible Society, died last Friday of a heart attack at his home at 925 Park Avenue in Manhattan. He was 88 years old. Dr. Darlington was treasurer of the American Bible Society from 1920 to 1958 and led a worldwide program for the publication and distribution of the Scriptures, including an illustrated version of the New Testament in 1955.
REQUIRED WASHINGTON, June 2 - The Supreme Court today upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission's interpretation of one of its key enforcement mechanisms.

The goaltender for the United States Olympic hockey team that won the gold medal in Lake Placid was traded yesterday by the Atlanta Flames to the Boston Bruins for two draft choices. Craig, who grew up in North Easton, Mass., about 20 minutes by car from Boston, said the trade was "the ultimate that I could ever hope for."

Last month, members of the venerable University Club in Albany rejected a proposal to extend full membership to women. Last week, four judges of the New York Court of Appeals resigned from the club in protest. They made their point in just the right way. In theory, private clubs may be extensions of a person's home, and therefore thoroughly private places. But in practice, as in the Albany case, they are often extensions of the marketplace and world of affairs. The current effort in many places to strike down barriers against blacks, Jews, women and others is not just an effort by once excluded groups to find new company where they aren't wanted. It is an effort to throw open the meeting grounds of business and politics, and to eliminate, once and for all, barriers that are unquestionably rooted in discrimination. Clubs that prefer one member to another are indeed selective. Clubs that bar all women or blacks are usually discriminatory.

The Detroit Tigers are considering signing Roberto Salazar, a 26-year-old center fielder, when Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's ban against signing Cuban refugees is lifted at noon today. ''I think he's legitimate,'' said Bill Lajoie, the Tigers' vice president in charge of baseball operations, after consultation with Orlando Pena, the onetime Cuban pitcher who is now a Detroit scout.

The Supreme Court ruled today that a state court that issues rules governing the behavior of lawyers is acting like a legislature and is entitled to the same absolute immunity from lawsuits that is accorded to individual legislators. The unanimous decision, in a case involving the Virginia Supreme Court's refusal to relax its ban against advertising by lawyers, is potentially significant because it extends the concept of legislative immunity beyond the category of legislators.
AROUND THE NATION; Venting of Radioactive Gas At Three Mile Island Urged

Volkswagen, the West German car manufacturer, said today that its net profits from the first quarter of the year dropped 27 percent, to $72.3 million. Earnings for the same period last year were $98.8 million at current exchange rates. In a letter to shareholders, Volkswagen said its worldwide firstquarter sales climbed 14.6 percent and production was up 7 percent from the first quarter of 1979. The company said uncertainties in international politics and energy made it difficult to project earnings results for the full year.

John L. Moore Jr., the chairman of the Export-Import Bank of the United States, arrived here today to discuss loans to South Korea at a time of tense relations. Mr. Moore said that the routine annual talks were scheduled two months ago and that he had brought no political message to South Korea, which is the Export-Import bank's largest market for loans.

Following are facts and figures on today's primary elections in California, Ohio, New Jersey, South Dakota, New Mexico, Rhode Island, Montana, West Virginia and Mississippi: CALIFORNIA POLLS: Polls close at 11 P.M. Eastern daylight time. DELEGATES: There are 306 Democratic and 168 Republican delegates at stake. CANDIDATES: On the Democratic Presidential ballot are President Carter, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr., Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. and an ''uncommitted'' line. On the Republican ballot are Ronald Reagan, George Bush and John B. Anderson. There is a senatorial primary in which Alan Cranston, a Democrat, is seeking renomination and four Republicans are vying for the right to oppose him. There are ballot initiatives on cutting taxes and taxing oil companies.

Hunter executive vice presidentconstruction and New York engineering.
The Interior Department announced today that it was establishing three new wildlife refuges for migratory birds in Mississippi, Tennessee and Arkansas.

Then there was the desertion as ABC-TV abandoned the heavily publicized contest between the American League's division leaders to go with the backup game between Cincinnati and Los Angeles.
LONDON, June 2--Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today accepted a plan for settlement of Britain's budget...

The Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago announced yesterday that, beginning Aug. 1, it will charge a $15 annual fee on its Mastercard and Visa accounts. William D. Plechaty, the bank's senior vice president for personal savings, said the fee was necessary for an increase of revenues to meet rising costs.

Keeping up with the nation's military budget is difficult enough in normal years. Members of Congress with weapons plants in their regions inevitably find procurement there inadequate. The military chiefs usually want more than the sitting Administration. And the public, even if it sees a need for more spending, is left confused about how to do it well.

Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga of Italy, faced with the threat of a Communist-led impeachment-like procedure against him, was under growing pressure today to resign because of charges that he helped the son of a prominent politician escape arrest as a terrorist suspect.
The University of Southern California announced today that it must forfeit the National Collegiate track and field championship it won in 1978 because Billy Mullins was a member of that team.

The Control Data Corporation has signaled its intention to remain a major factor in the market for supercomputers, those largest of data processing machines used by the engineering and scientific world. Yesterday the company unveiled its most powerful computer system so far, a machine the company said was capable of performing up to 800 million arithmetic operations a second.

New orders received by the nation's factories fell 5.5 percent in April, the sharpest drop since the last recession, and outlays for new construction declined for the third consecutive month, according to separate reports from the Commerce Department. Carter Administration officials, including the President himself, have said in recent days that the economic declines previously reported in such areas as retail sales, industrial production and housing have been steeper than they expected, although they insist that the recession will be short.

A coalition of the city's eight uniformed-service unions reduced its wage demands yesterday from 16 to 14.5 percent for each year of a two-year contract, but the city's chief labor negotiator called it an ''insignificant movement.'' At a meeting in the New York Hilton Hotel, the Uniformed Services Coalition also proposed cost-of-living adjustments, possibly with a limit instead of a previous demand for ''uncapped'' increases to keep up with the consumer price index.

The prosecution team in the bank fraud case against Bert Lance, the former director of the Office of Management and Budget, has recommended that the charges remaining after a 16-week trial be dropped, according to reliable sources familiar with the case. The sources said that the prosecutors recommended last week to their Justice Department superiors that a new trial not be sought on the six bank fraud counts, including three against Mr. Lance.

World Airways announced yesterday a one-way night coach fare of $119.99 for its daily flight from Los Angeles to Washington-Baltimore and New York-Newark. The fare, applying to all seats without restriction, is said to be the lowest offered by any airline for the Los Angeles-East Coast route. The flight also provides a connection for London-bound Los Angeles passengers at an introductory fare available through June 18 of $311.09, about $28 less than the normal rate.

John W. Newell, former president of Walter B. Cooke Inc., funeral directors in the New York metropolitan area, died Monday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 72 years old.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3--California voters, who two years ago made Proposition 13 a national symbol of tax revolt, changed course in balloting today, apparently rejecting by a substantial margin a new tax measure, Proposition 9, that would have cut state income tax rates in half across the board.

A Federal grand jury in San Diego yesterday indicted a onetime Government informer on charges of swindling West Coast businessmen by using inside information about the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam operation for his own financial gain.

SOMETIMES the warhorses are best, after all. There is a tendency, in thinking about a program that includes the familiar and the not so familiar, to dwell upon the latter, if only because of its relative novelty. But last night at Avery Fisher Hall, as part of the New York Philharmonic's Beethoven Festival, it was Leonard Slatkin's account of the ''Pastoral'' Symphony that was the high point of the night. Mr. Slatkin counts as one of America's finest young conductors; he currently heads the St.Louis Symphony. His ideas about the ''Pastoral'' were Toscaninian in their Classicism and rigor, softened by an undercurrent of lyricism and a willingness to inflect the line with gentle rubato.

International Palestinians staged a general strike in the West Bank and East Jerusalem, and the mayor and city council of Bethlehem resigned in protest over Monday's bombing attacks in which two Palestinian mayors were severely injured. Arabs hurled stones in scattered incidents, but no major clashes were reported. (Page A1, Columns 2-3.) Ramsey Clark urged Iranian officials to free the 53 American hostages and volunteered to take the place of any of them to help end the crisis. The former Attorney General, who is leading an American delegation to a Teheran conference in defiance of a Washingtonimposed travel ban, said he was making the appeal to aid the Iranian revolution, the rights of the captives and world peace. (A7:1.) A decision to send nuclear fuel to India, announced last month by the United States, is being reconsidered because of Congressional opposition, White House and State Department aides said. An official said that action would be deferred until after closed hearings on the issue had been held on Capitol Hill. (A3:4-6.) West German concern about the U.S. and its leadership is growing and reflects a basic, negative change among many Germans, according to increasingly large numbers of people in both countries. They express concern that an erosion in confidence in the United States has become widespread and deep-rooted. (A2:3-6.) National President Carter won enough delegates in the final eight state primaries to secure the majority needed for renomination at the Democratic National Convention in August. Senator Edward M. Kennedy won the New Jersey and Rhode Island primaries, but Mr. Carter was victorious in Ohio and was easily assured of a majority of the 3,331 convention delegates. (A1:6.) President Carter reflected confidence that the final primaries had insured his renomination. He made it clear that he considered the Democratic Presidential contest over and he said that he would call Senator Edward M. Kennedy soon to ''congratulate him on a great campaign.'' (A1:5.) An executive-legislative budget fight intensified as President Carter accused Congress of reneging on ''commitments'' made last March to protect some domestic programs and to impose a controversial fee on imported oil designed to raise gasoline prices by 10 cents a gallon. Both the House and the Senate are expected to vote today to repeal the import fee in the face of a Presidential veto. (A1:6.) Fraud charges in the Abscam inquiry were handed up by a Federal grand jury. It indicted a man and his wife on 15 counts stemming from their alleged use of inside information from the F.B.I.'s investigation of political corruption to swindle West Coast businessmen. The unexpected resignation of Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan, occurred one day after the Supreme Court refused to review the case in which he was found guilty in late 1978 of mail fraud and falsifying payrolls. He was the senior black member of Congress. (A16:1.) (A16:5.) The legal status of the Cubans who have come to the United States in the last six weeks is to be discussed today by Administration officials and 30 to 40 members of Congress. The conference is to focus on legal issues and the social-service benefits that the more than 100,000 Cubans should get. (A18:4-6.) The bus-shelter arrangements have led to several investigations, but Mr. Wells said they had no connection with his decision to resign. (B3:4-5.) Business Digest, Page D1

THE letter sounded plaintive: ''Why doesn't anyone write on how impossible it is for anthropology majors to find jobs?'' Like so many other liberal arts majors, the letter writer apparently has a problem. Unlike those in engineering, pure science, business and a few other specialties, liberal arts gradutes often have great difficulty finding jobs. Many have to compromise and work in different fields - retailing, banking, publishing, advertising, the brokerage business - where a broad major like anthropology, English, or languages might be useful. An alternative for the anthropology major is to obtain a graduate degree in public health, social work or a related field. Another approach is to have a medical subspecialty.

Three leaders of American Jewish organizations yesterday vehemently condemned the bombing attacks against three Palestinian Mayors in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Monday. Theodore R. Mann, chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, called the action an ''obscene use of violence'' and said, ''We condemn those criminals who are guilty of it, whether they be Jews or Arabs.''

THE other day, a well-known man was going through his billfold to pay a taxi driver when, so he says, he suddenly became aware of something he had been doing for years. He was riffling through the wallet, looking for the most dilapidated bills. He was shocked, he said, but not too much, for within seconds he had rationalized that everyone paid off strangers with the oldest and most tattered bills in their possession.

The Phillips & Drew Kings International Tournament in London finished with a tie for first prize among three grandmasters - Anthony Miles of Britain, Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland. Each received 1,985 for his 8 1/2-4 1/2 score. FINAL STANDINGS
WASHINGTON, June 3--Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr. of Michigan abruptly resigned from the House of Representatives today, ending a Congressional career of nearly 26 years.

WASHINGTON, June 3--Congressional opposition has led the Carter Administration to reconsider its decision last month to provide India with new supplies of nuclear fuel, White House and State Department aides said today.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)--President Carter has decided to seek a curb on new Federal hospital construction in order to cool inflation in medical costs, a White House aide said today.

GENEVA, June 3--The seven-story office building that the United States built to house its mission to the United Nations here was officially opened today at a ceremony attended by Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall. The building, built at a cost of $10 million, is in the international quarter on the edge of Geneva.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)--The Senate today gave final Congressional approval to a $49.7 million appropriation that would allow the Federal Trade Commission to return to normal business.

NEW DELHI, June 3--India, hoping to capitalize on its traditionally friendly relations with the Soviet Union, has sent its Foreign Minister to Moscow to seek the unconditional withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, a Government source said today.

PARIS, June 3--Despite the onset of recession in the United States, the economies of the 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development should grow about 1 percent this year with a stronger upturn taking hold in the second half of 1981, according to a study by the O.E.C.D. secretariat released today at the group's annual ministerial meeting here.
A 25-cent toll increase on two bridges over Jamaica Bay has been postponed until June 16. The new 75-cent toll had been scheduled to go into effect Monday.

FLINT, Mich., June 3--A small muckraking newspaper, The Flint Voice, went to court today to seek an order restraining the local police from searching the paper's offices for evidence relating to the allegedly premature release of a city ombudsman's report that criticized Mayor James W. Rutherford.

A violent rainstorm thundered across the New York metropolitan area yesterday, blackening the skies, drenching the ground and causing power failures, flooding and delays for hundreds of thousands of commuters. In northern Westchester County, 25,000 Consolidated Edison customers in the Peekskill-Buchanan area were left without electricity after the failure of seven transmission lines. The lines included all three feeding into the Buchanan substation and three heavy-duty lines carrying power from the north into New York City. At least one of the lines was knocked out by lightning.

In a major reorganization of its management and operations, Walt Disney Productions Inc. announced today the consolidation of its principal activities into three operating divisions. Ronald W. Miller, the 47-year-old son-in-law of the late Walt Disney was named president. The reorganization comes at a time when Disney is trying to broaden its base of operations and revive its image as a motion picture producer. Although Mr. Miller, who has been with Walt Disney Productions for more than 20 years and is married to Walt Disney's daughter, has been considered the heir apparent for some time, his appointment to the presidency is seen as a significant step toward the company's new emphasis on its film production.

Iran's oil exports have fallen to about 300,000 barrels a day following the suspension in April of its crude oil shipments to Japan, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported here today. The newspaper said Iranian exports had been as high as 900,000 barrels a day before the April 21 suspension. Published reports last month had said Iran's oil exports were running at a 500,000-barrel-a-day rate, and Ali Akbar Moinfar, the oil minister, conceded recently that his country's exports had dropped as low as 700,000 barrels daily.

Foster O. Chanock, an associate in the corporate finance department of the First Boston Corporation, a New York investment banking concern, died of cancer Saturday at the National Institutes of Health in Washington. He was 27 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Chanock had been assistant to the White House chief of staff under President Gerald R. Ford. He had bachelor's and master's degrees from the University of Chicago and attended the London School of Economics.

When Sister Theresa Kane welcomed Pope John Paul II to Washington's Shrine of the Immaculate Conception last fall, she caused his visible annoyance and the embarrassment of other church officials with an appeal for admission of women to full ministerial rights in the Roman Catholic Church. Despite criticism for her boldness, Sister Theresa has continued to speak out, and in Detroit on Monday, she even predicted when the church would have female priests. It will happen within 20 years, she told a meeting of the Catholic Health Organization.

The New Democratic Coalition in the 17th Congressional District endorsed Thomas H. Stokes early yesterday to challenge the renomination of Representative John M. Murphy. The move dealt a blow to the candidacy of Mary Codd, a City Council member who had started lining up the support of prominent Democrats. Mrs. Codd had been considered the front-runner for the coalition designation and was expected to serve as the focal point for the opposition to Mr. Murphy, whose district comprises Staten Island and the lower part of Manhattan.

Jack Linsky, founder and former chairman and president of Swingline Inc., manufacturers of stapling machines and office stationery, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach.

WASHINGTON, June 3--A prominent environmental group charged today that the United States Forest Service was losing millions of dollars and subsidizing big timber companies at public expense by selling timber from national forests at lower than prevailing market prices.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 3--The account given to investigators by Vernon E. Jordan Jr., who was wounded by sniper fire here last week, was consistent with that of Martha C. Coleman, whose car he was leaving when he was shot, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

PASADENA, Calif., June 3 (AP)-- Two earthquakes only seconds apart were felt in Southern California and Mexico this morning, but they were minor and unconnected, according to Dennis Meredith, spokesman for the seismology laboratory at the California Institute of Technology. There were no immediate reports of damage from either earthquake.
Frank J. Costello, a former Mayor of Syracuse and former State Assemblyman, died Sunday at the Crouse-Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

WASHINGTON, JUNE 3--President Carter, opening a budget review for 1982 and beyond, expressed "consternation" today that Congress had gone back on "commitments" made last March to protect certain domestic programs and impose a controversial fee on imported oil.

WASHINGTON, June 3--He still wears thin Levi slacks and Hush Puppy shoes to parties on Manhattan's East Side. In his flat Texas twang he recites lengthy poems by W.H. Auden while entertaining visitors in his Greenwich Village apartment.

Frank J. Costello, a former Mayor of Syracuse and former State Assemblyman, died Sunday at the Crouse-Irving Memorial Hospital in Syracuse after a short illness. He was 78 years old. Mr. Costello, a lifelong resident of Syracuse, received a law degree from Syracuse University in 1924 and joined the firm of Costello & Gorman. He was a Republican and was elected to the Assembly in 1937, serving served until 1945 when he was elected Mayor.

To the Editor: It is a twist of logic that Dov Ronen (Op-Ed May 2) complains that no responsible Palestinian has given emphatic assurances concerning the future security of Israel. This demand is as valid as that of a surgeon prompting a patient who is about to have his legs amputated to undertake never to participate in a marathon race after the operation.ndeed, Israeli generals themselves are in the habit of boasting about the potency of their army and how relatively feeble the combined forces of the Arab states are.

The height of the swing era in the late 1930's is the focus of ''Stompin' at the Savoy!'', a musical revue that opens next Monday at 8:30 P.M. at the West Bank Cafe, 407 West 42d Street, for a monthlong engagement of Sundays and Mondays. The show, conceived and directed by Ron Stacker Thompson, will star the singer Ernestine Jackson, who starred on Broadway in ''Guys and Dolls,'' and the dancer Bernard Johnson, who is known also for his costume designing. Other performers will include Mr. Thompson, Sandra Reaves-Phillips, Cle Thompson, John Wohl, Brenda Pressley and Jeffrey V. Thompson.
EVIDENCE ON REPORTS RELEASE By IVER PETERSON

The Municipal Assistance Corporation formally urged the United States Treasury Department yesterday to allow New York City to use $900 million in backup Federal loan guarantees to borrow money over the next two years. The city had hoped to avoid using the guarantees, and instead try to raise all that it needs on its own and with the help of the corporation.

President Carter, confident that today's primaries had assured his renomination, said tonight that he would call Senator Edward M. Kennedy shortly to ''congratulate him on a great campaign.'' He turned aside questions about the Senator's criticism of him with a remark that ''that was during the campaign - it's over now.'' But Senator Kennedy said Democrats from coast to coast were not willing to concede the nomination to Mr. Carter ''and neither am I.'' Speaking at his Washington headquarters, he said that he would continue to fight ''in a way that helps, not hurts, that unifies the Democratic Party.''
PRIOR NOTICE OF OPERATIONS

Now that the Presidential primary elections are over, there are two questions: Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, and Representative John Anderson of Illinois. Should they continue their fight against Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan, the clear winners in the primaries, struggling on against almost hopeless odds into the summer nominating conventions and the final vote in November? A hard question; both are arguing for the unity of the nation, and running against Carter and Reagan because they don't believe either can unify his own party let alone the nation. But it's not clear that continuing the battle will make things better, and it may even make things worse.

REMEMBERING SPRING It will be 17 more days before this spring, used up and discarded, is gone. The summer solstice - when the sun is at a maximum distance from the equator - takes place at 1:47 A.M. on June 21, three months and one day after spring hit the street. And this has been a busy spring for Sonja Bullaty and Angelo Lomeo, two photographers. Even though the season still rests comfortably on our shoulders they have already photographed and mounted an exhibition: ''Central Park in Bloom: Spring 1980.''

The Folger Coffee Company, the nation's second-largest coffee roaster, announced yesterday that it had raised the wholesale price of its vacuum-packed ground coffee 15 cents a pound, to $3.23, effective immediately. The company also said it had increased the wholesale price of its instant coffee by three cents an ounce, to $1.23 per two-ounce jar. The action by Folger, a subsidiary of Procter & Gamble, follows identical price increases taken on May 23 by General Foods, the country's leading roaster and producer of the Maxwell House brand. General Foods raised prices on all its grocery store ground and instant coffee brands, including Maxwell House, Yuban, Sanka and Brim.

Japan's gold and international monetary reserves rose in May by $2.49 billion, bringing the outstanding balance to $21.4 billion, according to a report in Tokyo yesterday. A foreign-exchange market official said the gain was the result mainly of appreciation of the yen and dollar-support buying by the central bank.

USUALLY when a pianist and another musician appear together in recital, the pianist is an accompanist. But the appearance Monday night at the 92d Steeet Y of Richard Sher, a cellist, and the pianist Richard Goode proved a genuine joint recital.
On the final day of the 1980 primary marathon, President Carter achieved the nominating majority that had eluded him so long, but even this victory carried ill omens for the general election.
A FRIEND and neighbor recently observed that I have often offered recipes in this column that are basically Italian or variations on basically Italian dishes.

LAST Wednesday night at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery, Marjorie Gamso accomplished choreographically what one expects only expert pianists to accomplish. She made Beethoven's Diabelli Variations both entertaining and structurally coherent.

Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday that a hearing for Bill Madlock had been tentatively scheduled for early next week. The exact date and the location have not yet been determined, the commissioner said.

The last-place St. Louis Cardinals enjoyed the best of all worlds last night, using power hitting, strong pitching and faultless fielding to rout the New York Mets, 8-1, as the teams opened a three-game series at Shea Stadium.

IN Lyndhurst, N.J., a few years ago, 12 women picketed a house where three former mental patients were living. The picketers said the halfway house was too close to a children's playground and they feared for the safety of the children.
SOMETIMES the warhorses are best, after all. There is a tend ency, in thinking about a program that includes the familiar and the not so familiar, to dwell upon...

The Municipal Assistance Corporation formally urged the United States Treasury Department yesterday to allow New York City to use $900 million in backup Federal loan guarantees to borrow money over the next two years.

The New Democratic Coalition in the 17th Congressional District endorsed Thomas H. Stokes early yesterday to challenge the renomination of Representative John M. Murphy. The move dealt a blow to the candidacy of Mary Codd, a City Council member who had started lining up the support of prominent Democrats.

WASHINGTON, June 3--Carter Administration officials plan to consult tomorrow with 30 to 40 members of Congress about the legal status that should be accorded to the more than 100,000 Cubans who have come to the United States in the last six weeks.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 3--Ignoring a warning from the Coast Guard, the freighter Red Diamond V pulled into Key West this morning packed to capacity with 731 refugees and the relatives who had gone to Cuba to secure their release. It was the largest number of refugees to come to the United States aboard a single vessel since the freedom flotilla began in April.

LOS ANGELES, June 3--As Ronald Reagan awaited the results in today's final round of 1980 Presidential primaries, his chief advisers here worked to assemble a general-election campaign staff that will include long-time Reagan loyalists and associates of former President Gerald R. Ford.

WASHINGTON, June 3--The Senate today overwhelmingly approved legislation that would establish Congressional overseeing of United States intelligence agencies and require, except in rare circumstances, that Congress be notified before covert espionage operations could begin.

Fund-raising difficulties have jeopardized plans for the renovation of the Elgin Theater in Chelsea to provide a much-needed new Manhattan dance theater. Of a $1.6 million budget, a final $325,000 must be raised by June 15. The theater was purchased in January 1979 for $225,000 by Original Ballets Foundation Inc., an affiliate of the Eliot Feld Ballet, with a view to creating a theater suited in size, facilities and rental costs to middle-size modern-dance and ballet companies, many of which are hard-pressed to support the costs of a season at established New York theaters. The Elgin Theater, built in the early 1930's as a movie house, would be remodeled into a 500-seat dance theater with an enlarged stage and facilities and new lighting and sound equipment, designed by the architectural firm of Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer Associates. A rental fee of $12,000 a week is projected, to include technical staff and equipment and front-of-house costs. Weekly rentals for theaters used by most midsize companies range from $200 and 40 percent of the box office to $17,600, fees that include some services.

Congressional opposition has led the Carter Administration to reconsider its decision last month to provide India with new supplies of nuclear fuel, White House and State Department aides said today. Only a month ago, State Department aides said the United States was determined to go ahead with the export of 38 tons of enriched uranium despite opposition on Capitol Hill. Today, a senior State Department aide said that position was ''no longer in concrete.''

THE season's first Greenmarket opens Saturday at Union Square and 17th Street, marking the fifth year that New Yorkers will be able to shop outdoors for fresh produce grown and sold by local farmers and trucked into the city. Eleven other Greenmarkets, part of a nonprofit project of the Council on the Environment of New York City, will open in the next few weeks in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx. The markets are chiefly maintained with grants from the J.M. Kaplan Fund.

A woman who was critically wounded last weekend by a man who opened fire on an Amtrak train died late tonight, according to a hospital spokesman. A spokesman for Lawrence and Memorial Hospital said Diane Calise, 24 years old, of Providence, R.I., died in the hospital's intensive care unit. She had been admitted Saturday with a head wound.

The Orion Capital Corporation said the company and its directors had been named as defendants in a class action lawsuit filed by Stuart Wechsler, described as an Orion shareholder. The suit, filed in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, alleges that the plaintiff has been damaged by Orion Capital's decision not to negotiate an acquisition proposal from Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., Orion said. The offer by Shearson, which already owns nearly 5 percent of Orion shares, was for $17.50 a share, or about $145 million. Orion's directors formally rejected the offer yesterday. Orion management said it believes the lawsuit, which makes no specific damage claim, is without merit.
Two Small Quakes Felt on Coast

An unidentified teen-ager was struck by an express train and killed in the 86th Street West Side I.R.T. subway station at about midnight last night when he tried to cross the tracks. Detective Jerry Gallagher of the Transit Police said the youth had apparently been with three other young men on the street at Broadway and 86th Street. The group jumped the turnstile on the downtown side of the station, and then the other three youths went back out to the street, the detective said. The dead youth tried to walk across the four rows of tracks to the uptown side. He was struck by a downtown express train on the second track and was found dead under the fourth car of the train. Downtown traffic was delayed for 45 minutes while the body was removed.

Most foods prepared in molds are meant to be served cold, as first courses, salads or desserts. While the design of a mold should be appropriate to the food it contains, most molds are versatile and can be used interchangeably for ice cream, aspics or mousses. However, a tall, narrow bombe glacee would not be appropriate for aspic, which would collapse under its own weight. Metal molds are preferred by many cooks because they cool evenly and quickly and release their contents easily. Porcelain and ceramic molds are more difficult to handle. They warm up very slowly, and by the time the food is released it may almost be in a liquid state again.

J.C. Penny Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of $150 million of 10-year notes and $100 million of 30-year sinking fund debentures through a First Boston group. * General Telephone Company of the Northwest Inc. filed with the S.E.C. a proposed offering of $80 million of first series mortgage bonds due 2010 through a Blyth Eastman Paine Webber group.

A Federal grand jury in San Diego yesterday indicted a one-time Government informer on charges of swindling West Coast businessmen by using inside information about the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam operation for his own financial gain. The defendant, Joseph B. Meltzer, was indicted along with his wife, Hilda. They were charged in the 15-count indictment with mail fraud, fraud by wire and interstate transportation of checks taken by fraud. The businessmen were said to have been bilked of more than $140,000. Mr. Meltzer allegedly gained some of the information as an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation in an early phase of the corruption inquiry. According to Robert D. Rose, the assistant United States Attorney in charge of the case, Mr. Meltzer learned details of the operation when he was established in an office in Florida by the F.B.I. in the summer of 1978.
Disarmament Commission - 11 A.M., 3 P.M., 8 P.M. Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.
To the Editor:

DUNDEE, ORE. NOT long ago bettors would have put their money on California to produce the best American pinot noir, a red wine made from the same grape used for the exquisite red Burgundies of France. After all, California's other European varietals are the best wines in the land, so why not the pinot noir too? A small band of wine makers in the rolling hills of northwestern Oregon are proving the bettors wrong. Some of the best pinot noirs in the nation are being made here in the Red Hills above the Willamette Valley, confirming that the Burgundy country of France is not the only place where this stubborn grape can be cultivated successfully.

By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt NABOKOV: A TRIBUTE. Edited by Peter Quennell. 139 pages. Illustrated. Mor- row. $8.95. AS always when it comes to discussing the late novelist, an air of cultism suffuses this ''Tribute'' to Vladimir Nabokov, edited by the English biographer Peter Quennell. The point is repeatedly made in its various essays that not every reader will measure up to the demands of Nabokov's texts. We are informed that only the unwitting will read ''Lolita'' as a morality play or as a satire on American vulgarity. We are told that only a superficial reader of ''The Defense'' will think that just because its hero, Luzhin, has leaped out the bathroom window at the end, he is actually falling to his death. Nabokov's oeuvre is an obstacle course of traps for the unwary reader, we are given to know. Those who can measure up are welcome to the club of his readers. The Philistine and sentimental - the readers who foolishly imagine that his characters have a life beyond the words on the page - simply need not apply.

Ed Ott's two-out single in the ninth inning scored Vance Law from third base tonight and lifted the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies. Law singled to lead off the ninth and advanced to second on Dave Parker's ground out. Tug McGraw (0-2) intentionally walked Willie Stargell before John Milner pinch hit and grounded out to first, advancing both runners. Bill Madlock was intentionally walked to reload the bases and Ott came through with the winning hit.

MILAN, Italy, June 3 (UPI)--A large time-bomb exploded in a van parked outside police headquarters early today, damaging nearby buildings and cars but causing no casualties. The police said about 22 pounds of explosive in the stolen van exploded at 3:10 A.M.

Tornadoes struck parts of Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia today, ripping away roofs, overturning mobile homes and injuring more than 80 people. The police in Philadelphia said that a motorist was killed when a tree fell on his truck.

Aluminum or tin food molds in savarin, kugelhopf and brioche shapes are available at almost all houseware shops. Following is a list of stores that, in addition to a high quality standard line, offer an assortment of unusual and specialty molds.

Arthur Charles Nielsen, the Middle Western engineer whose little silver boxes are the controversial but uncontested scorekeepers of American television, died after a long illness in Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago on Sunday. He was 83 years old.
HENRIETTE KRISTHEA, soprano, and Gene Tucker, tenor, shared a program of arias, songs and duets in Alice Tully Hall last Friday night.
Room rates in the $22.3 billion lodging industry have been rising dramatically in the last year under the pressure of soaring energy, labor and material costs.

Fund-raising difficulties have jeopardized plans for the renovation of the Elgin Theater in Chelsea to provide a much-needed new Manhattan dance theater. Of a $1.6 million budget, a final $325,000 must be raised by June 15.

He still wears thin Levi slacks and Hush Puppy shoes to parties on Manhattan's East Side. In his flat Texas twang he recites lengthy poems by W.H. Auden while entertaining visitors in his Greenwich Village apartment. Once, at a political fund-raiser, he denounced ''the political power of wealth'' before the established guests and then proceeded to quote Jose Ortega y Gasset, Reinhold Niebuhr and Benito Juarez, causing one bejewelled woman to emit a deep snore.
A Tie for Father

As a search for Howard (Buddy) Jacobson continued yesterday, he was sentenced in absentia in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to a maximum term of 25 years to life imprisonment for murder. Mr. Jacobson escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention on Saturday. He was convicted on April 12 of killing his rival for the affections of Melanie Cain, a model.

A FRIEND and neighbor recently observed that I have often offered recipes in this column that are basically Italian or variations on basically Italian dishes. While it is true that I have not spent a great deal of time in Italy - perhaps a month in all over a period of years - I have many good friends who are Italian and with whom I've spent numerous hours in the kitchen.

To the Editor: The events which culminated in the capture of Kwangju by forces under the control of the military clique in Seoul are, above all, a devastating commentary on the role and character of U.S. policy.v.hile the Korean militarists were savagely suppressing the struggle of Korean citizens to achieve a measure of democratic rule, U.S. policy makers were preaching ''restraint'' on ''both sides.'' Even this ''impartial'' posturing, however, was tainted by the prompt U.S. approval to grant the militarists additional troop reinforcements which are under the command of the U.S. military authority in Korea.

The 100th anniversary of Bela Bartok's birth will be observed widely next year, and for its part, the Juilliard String Quartet will perform the Hungarian composer's six quartets in three Saturday matinees in Alice Tully Hall. The dates are March 28 and April 11 and 25. Each program will offer two Bartok quartets and one by Brahms.

Rebels holding the New Hebrides island of Espiritu Santo announced by radio today that they had formed a provisional Government. Jimmy Stevens, a local plantation owner who has had the support for years of French and American businessmen hoping to turn the island into a tax haven, was named chief minister. He wants Espiritu Santo to secede from the New Hebrides when the 74-island South Pacific archipelago and its 100,000 people become independent on July 30 of their joint British and French rulers.

Jack Linsky, founder and former chairman and president of Swingline Inc., manufacturers of stapling machines and office stationery, died yesterday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Palm Beach. In 1970, Mr. Linsky sold Swingline to American Brands for $210 million. Over the years, Mr. Linsky and his wife, Belle, who survives him, acquired a notable collection of paintings and French and English furniture. They twice paid record prices for French furnishings. In London in 1964, Mrs. Linsky paid $176,400 for a Louis XVI marquetry commode, which was then the highest price ever recorded at auction for a single piece of French period furniture.

Vincent Van Gogh used to cut off his ear and send it to ladyfriends as a gift. Afterward he would paint a picture of himself without his ear on. Everybody said he was a loser and possibly crazy. That was before paintings began fetching $5 million per canvas and sometimes $6.4 million at auctions. If people had known Van Gogh was doing such valuable work, they would have spoken better of him. It's wonderful how $5 million in a man's pocket improves the public's estimate of his character.

A strained thigh and an upset stomach indirectly led to a 6-5 loss by the Yankees in l0 innings to the Kansas City Royals tonight. The defeat cut New York's lead in the American League's Eastern Division to four and a half games. With Reggie Jackson unable to play right field because a thigh injury, the Yankees put Dennis Werth, normally a first baseman or a catcher, in that positon.
CAMPAIGN REPORT/; Anderson Criticizes Carter Over Cuban Refugee Policy

Dave Lemanczyk, the Toronto Blue Jays' leading pitcher during their expansion season of 1977 and the club's lone representative in the All-Star Game last year, was traded to the California Angels tonight for future considerations. Lemanczyk, a 29-year-old right-hander, appeared in 10 games for the Blue Jays this season, posting a 2-5 won-lost record with a 5.40 earned-run average.

Q. Do you recall the drink known as a pousse-cafe? It used to be much admired in fancy bars. A. Indeed it was, and I doubt that there are very many bartenders today who could describe it in detail. It consisted of several liqueurs in rainbow colors that were poured into a very small glass. The important thing in preparing the drink was to understand the specific gravity of each liqueur before adding them. When properly added, the liqueurs did not blend but rather remained in bright layers.

Advent Corporation, Cambridge, Mass., a manufacturer of speakers, tapes and video televisions, has named Bernie Mitchell, vice chairman and chief executive officer, to the additional post of president, succeeding William H. Anderson, who retired. * Bache Halsey Stuart Shields Inc. has named James J. Glynn a senior vice president. * Chemical Bank has named Thomas J. Harrington a senior vice president. * Continental Group, Stamford, Conn., engaged in packaging, natural resources and financial services, has elected G. William Sisley corporate secretary and corporate counsel.

FROM an Argentine point of view, prices in this country look stable and development opportunities in Manhattan are promising. Which explains why Jacobo Finkielstain is undertaking commercial development here. He has purchased the 26,500-square-foot construction site on the west side of Third Avenue between 54th Street and 55th Street from the Minskoff Organization, and plans to put up a modest-sized office building of about 450,000 square feet of space on perhaps 36 or 38 floors. The hope is to have it ready for occupancy in 1983.

Prices drifted lower on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in slow trading as investors continued to weigh the impact of the economic recession on corporate profits. Analysts also noted that stocks were consolidating after a seven-week rally that was triggered by plunging interest rates.

THE season's first Greenmarket opens Saturday at Union Square and 17th Street, marking the fifth year that New Yorkers will be able to shop outdoors for fresh produce grown and sold by local farmers and trucked into the city.

That small uprising by about 300 Cuban refugees at Fort Chaffee, Ark., elicited two public responses. Mostly there was outrage: Ship them back to Cuba! Occasionally, there was a sympathetic question: Why can't the Government process these people faster? These responses aren't necessarily at odds.
The National Bureau of Economic Research, the widely recognized arbiter of business cycles, declared yesterday that the nation was now in a recession, one that began in January.

Peter W. Rodino Jr., who became a national celebrity as chairman of the Richard M. Nixon impeachment hearings, won the Democratic nomination for a 17th term in Congress yesterday in New Jersey's 10th District.
"SKETCHBOOK" was the title of one of the works presented at the Dances by Albert Reid program Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.
Since they bought Pele in 1975, the Cosmos have gone on to purchase other famous and expensive players--fullbacks, midfielders and forwards. But they have never bought a goalkeeper in that class.

AT the beginning of the second act of Micki Grant's new musical "It's So Nice to Be Civilized," which opened last night at the Martin Beck Theater, several generations of a family surround a grandmother with love and attention.

LOS ANGELES, June 3--In a major reorganization of its management and operations, Walt Disney Productions Inc. announced today the consolidation of its principal activities into three operating divisions. Ronald W. Miller, the 47-year-old son-in-law of the late Walt Disney was named president.
WASHINGTON, June 3--A bomb exploded outside the home of the charge d'affaires of the Yugoslav Embassy early today, but he, his wife and nephew were not injured.

MOGADISHU, Somalia--The red, white and black flag with its golden eagle still flies high above the Egyptian Embassy on the outskirts of this seaside capital, in what has become a rare sight for an Arab League country these days.

A large time-bomb exploded in a van parked outside police headquarters early today, damaging nearby buildings and cars but causing no casualties. The police said about 22 pounds of explosive in the stolen van exploded at 3:10 A.M., set off by a timing device.

There are hundreds of marbles games, some with elaborate sets of guidelines, others neighborhood games with ad hoc rules concocted on the spot. But in Wildwood-by-the-Sea, N.J., in the National Marbles Tournament, there is only one official game, ''Ringer,'' and only one way to play. The arena is a circle, 10 feet in diameter, into which 13 marbles are placed in the shape of a cross - three to each arm and one in the center. Two players compete, shooting from the edge of the circle. The first to shoot seven marbles out of the ring is the winner. Each time a player knocks a target marble out of the ring he or she is entitled to a bonus shot. A player can keep shooting marbles out as long as his or her shooter remains inside the ring area.

Prices drifted lower on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday in slow trading as investors continued to weigh the impact of the economic recession on corporate profits. Analysts also noted that stocks were consolidating after a seven-week rally that was triggered by plunging interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average declined 3.58 points, to 843.77. Volume edged up to 33.2 million shares from Monday's 32.7 million. Meanwhile, energy issues on the American Stock Exchange continued to show gains. The Amex market value index rose 1.18, to 273.69. Advancing more than a point each in active trading were Ranger Oil and Francana Oil and Gas Ltd. Houston Oil and Minerals, benefiting from an advisory service recommendation, gained 7/8, to 23 7/8.

The entire West Bank and East Jerusalem were gripped by a general strike today, and the mayor and city council of Bethlehem resigned in protest over yesterday's bombing attacks in which two Palestinian mayors were severely injured. The atmosphere in the Arab sectors was tense but calm. There were scattered stone-throwing incidents, but no major clashes.Senior Israeli security officials were reported by a Government source to be conducting their investigation on the assumption that Jewish terrorists were responsible. The officials were said to be convinced that the attacks had turned ''a new page'' in the pattern of violence and that attempts might be made by the same forces against Israeli political leaders, including the Prime Minister.

A bomb exploded outside the home of the charge d'affaires of the Yugoslav Embassy early today, but he, his wife and nephew were not injured. Vladimir Sindjelic, 66 years old, his wife, Leposava, and his nephew, Slobodan Pesic, were asleep when the bomb went off at 4:09 A.M.
