Moose Haas pitched a five-hitter and Cecil Cooper cracked his seventh home run of the season tonight, leading the Milwaukee Brewers to a 3-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. Haas (6-4) struck out six and walked two.

The last-place St. Louis Cardinals enjoyed the best of all worlds last night, using power hitting, strong pitching and faultless fielding to rout the New York Mets, 8-1, as the teams opened a threegame series at Shea Stadium. All of the Cardinals' runs came on home runs, two by Keith Hernandez and one by Ted Simmons. And while the Mets called on four pitchers to try and halt the St. Louis barrage, the Cardinals needed only one.

The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had approved its acquisition of the consumer finance subsidiaries and the $2.3 billion mortgage servicing activities of the First Pennsylvania Corporation. The purchase, which is for $106.6 million, was proposed last October. Government approval was delayed by First Pennsylvania's worsening problems and its eventual need for a rescue operation. In late April the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a group of 26 banks created a $1.5 billion package to keep the $9 billion Pennsylvania banking company from possible failure.

Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, calling on the Iranian authorities today to ''free these 53 little people,'' volunteered to take the place of any of the American Embassy hostages if it would help end the crisis. His voice sometimes catching with emotion, he said he was making the offer because he was ''so sure that it is imperative that the hostages be released now; that it is so important to the fulfillment of the Iranian revolution, which it is damaging in a hundred ways; so important to the individual justice and rights of the hostages, and it is so important to peace on earth.''

Here we define the laws of physics,'' said Andrew Rubel, holding a beanbag between two cigar boxes. ''And here,'' he intoned, making the bag ''float'' without adequate means of support on the corner of one box, ''we break them.'' Mr. Rubel may have been talking about Isaac Newton to the gathering on a lawn of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, but his hands were conjuring up W.C. Fields in his role as juggler. In fact, the comedian's famous routine of forming a pyramid of cigar boxes in midair, also without adequate means of support, has become the Platonic standard for an unlikely troupe of would-be vaudevillians.
Award Is Named For Red Smith

AT the beginning of the second act of Micki Grant's new musical ''It's So Nice to Be Civilized,'' which opened last night at the Martin Beck Theater, several generations of a family surround a grandmother with love and attention. Grandma is treated like a precious but fragile relic; the name of the song is ''Antiquity.'' As played by Mabel King, the character looks as if she had stepped right out of a calico kitchen. However, as soon as the family leaves the stage, Miss King lifts her skirts almost to her knees and belts out a melodic gust of audacity suitably entitled ''I've Still Got My Bite.'' She has bite and bluster and the soul of a vaudevillian. Having banished any thought that she is aged or infirmed, Miss King gives us a knowing twinkle and retreats behind her Granny glasses. The singer and the song deserve the ovation.

Charlotte Elizabeth Wilder, a poet and former English teacher, died Saturday in a nursing home in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 82 years old. Miss Wilder, a sister of the late Thornton Wilder, was an assistant professor of English from 1928 to 1931 at Smith College. She joined the Smith faculty after teaching at Wheaton College.

An average of 29 million gallons of raw sewage from homes and industries in four Passaic County towns will be dumped daily into the Passaic River here for the next 19 days while repairmen insert a steel liner inside a 120-foot stretch of a cracked, undermined, 60-year-old brick sewage conduit. Rocco P. Ricci, chief engineer of the Passaic Valley Sewage Commission, said that about 50 percent of the sewage would be industrial waste from Paterson, Haledon, Prospect Park, and Hawthorne that ''probably'' contained ''some carcinogenic'' elements. But he said health risks would arise ''only if somebody was foolish enough'' to swim, fish, or boat in the river below Paterson.

Lyudmila Kondratyeva of the Soviet Union set a world record in the 100-meter dash with a time of 10.87 seconds at a track meet in Leningrad, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today. The time shaved a hundredth of a second off the record established by Marlies Oelsner of East Germany in July 1977.

Serious students of the game are likely to agree that a new book by a Norwegian author is the most important and original ever written on the subject of defensive signaling. It is ''Defensive Play in Bridge'' by Helge Vinje, and is available for $7.95 from Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025. Many of the author's concepts were developed two decades ago, but only one has become generally known outside his native country. He originated the idea of leading fifth best from a five-card suit and third best from a four-card suit, now favored by many American experts.

Nathan Abas, a former symphony leader and state director of the Federal Music Project during the Depression, died yesterday. He was 83 years old. From 1939 to 1942, Mr. Abas conducted Federal symphony concerts in the Bay area and performed with his own string quartet.
PARIS AS the cost of travel abroad esca lates with each passing season, so does the need to make the most of each journey.

WASHINGTON, June 3--The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Automobile Workers sued the Labor Department yesterday to reverse a decision that they said would deprive many workers of long-term unemployment compensation.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 3--Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, calling on the Iranian authorities today to "free these 53 little people," volunteered to take the place of any of the American Embassy hostages if it would help end the crisis.

JERUSALEM, June 3--The entire West Bank and East Jerusalem were gripped by a general strike today, and the mayor and city council of Bethlehem resigned in protest over yesterday's bombing attacks in which two Palestinian mayors were severely injured.
WASHINGTON--Now that the Presidential primary elections are over, there are two questions: Senator Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts, and Representative John Anderson of Illinois.

THESE days there is something to be said for world problems that simply simmer. The task of devising common accounting rules for com panies throughout the world would rank high on no one's agenda of urgent global issues. Accounting and financial reporting are among the least bellicose of relations across national boundaries.

The Folger Coffee Company, the nation's second-largest coffee roaster, announced yesterday that it had raised the wholesale price of its vacuum-packed ground coffee 15 cents a pound, to $3.23, effective immediately.

Foster O. Chanock, an associate in the corporate finance department of the First Boston Corporation, a New York investment banking concern, died of cancer Saturday at the National Institutes of Health in Washington. He was 27 years old and lived in Manhattan.

FROM an Argentine point of view, prices in this country look stable and development opportunities in Manhattan are promising. Which explains why Jacobo Finkielstain is undertaking commercial development here.

Sporting a Florida tan and having lost several pounds, George Bamberger is back in town in anticipation of returning to work as manager of the Brewers. ''I am kind of anxious,'' he said yesterday. ''After you go through something like I have, you want to prove something. You want to prove that you are healthy.''

B.J. Meredith, the president of the Dallas-based Docutel Corporation, has something of a Texas-sized problem: ''How do I convince people that we are here to stay?'' It was a problem that Docutel, which pioneered in the development of automated teller machines for the banking industry, did not foresee in the heady days of the early 1970's, when it had the young market all to itself. Even as late as 1977 Docutel enjoyed a betterthan-80-percent share of the business, but since that time the company has seen its share tumble to around 30 percent, the result of a series of tactical blunders and financial reversals.
REJECTION OF HIS APPEAL By MARJORIE HUNTER

To the Editor: Patricia and Mary are right about how to handle Georgie and the suspended cat (Op-Ed May 20) but wrong in thinking that military men and State Department technocrats would disagree with their diagnosis. nfortunately, our Iranian policy has been determined by a group of people who are neither understanding mothers nor tough-minded professionals and whose primary concern is with electoral politics and personal images. It is this amateurish team, abetted by the news media, which insisted on turning the hostages (Tabby) into a test of American prestige and influence (parental control) and continues to advertise the issue as the center of Presidential concern.

LAST Wednesday night at Larry Richardson's Dance Gallery, Marjorie Gamso accomplished choreographically what one expects only expert pianists to accomplish. She made Beethoven's Diabelli Variations both entertaining and structurally coherent. Set to a recording of Beethoven's monumental example of pianistic ingenuity, ''Port of Asides'' was a work for 22 people, although only at the beginning and end did everyone appear together. An opening scene in silence during which the cast walked quietly about proved to be a way of acquainting viewers with the variously assorted bodies on which Miss Gamso composed her choreographic variations.

uniformed guard to unlock one heavy wooden door. Walk through a metal detector. Hold out your right hand for an ultraviolet stamp. Wait for a guard to unlock another heavy wooden door. Walk through a big oval room surrounded by beige-painted bars. Walk past three more guards and several prisoners who stare, then walk up two flights and across to a small paneled room where James Scott, a loser a week ago Sunday for the first time in his boxing career, was sitting behind a desk. He was wearing a white shortsleeve shirt, brown pants, black shoes and his best smile. ''It's like Rudyard Kipling's poem,'' he was saying now in his prison boxing rehabilitation office. ''If you can meet with triumph and disaster and treat those two impostors just the same. If you. ... ''

Darryl Strawberry, a tall and versatile athlete from Crenshaw High School in Los Angeles, was the first pick yesterday in major league baseball's semiannual amateur draft. The selecting team was the New York Mets, who were one of at least a dozen clubs that were prepared to make Strawberry their first pick. Terry Gardner, a Pittsburgh Pirate scout, said he had spent only five minutes watching Strawberry earlier this year, because ''we knew we weren't going to have a chance at him with our late pick.'' Hugh Alexander, a scout for the Philadelphia Phillies, called him ''the best prospect I've seen in the last 30 years.''
Room rates in the $22.3 billion lodging industry have been rising dramatically in the last year under the pressure of soaring energy, labor and material costs.
JERSEY CONTEST; LAST PRIMARIES HELD,SENATOR VOWS TO BATTLE ON UNTIL THE CONVENTION-LEADS IN CALIFORNIA By ADAM CLYMER

The craft carrying the Hungarian astronaut Bertalan Farkas and his Soviet commander, Valery Kubasov, floated safely back to earth last night, landing in the dusty Central Asian steppes, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. Mr. Farkas, 30 years old, the first Hungarian ever sent into space, and Mr. Kubasov, 45, a veteran Soviet astronaut, went aloft May 26 for docking with the Salyut 6 orbiting station. It was the fifth Soviet bloc Intercosmos mission.

Since they bought Pele in 1975, the Cosmos have gone on to purchase other famous and expensive players - fullbacks, midfielders and forwards. But they have never bought a goalkeeper in that class. When Hennes Weisweiler took over as coach nine games ago, there were persistent rumors that this would be the time the North American Soccer League's most glamorous team would purchase a world-class goalkeeper.

Duane Kuiper, the Cleveland Indian second baseman who injured his right knee in last Sunday's game against the Seattle Mariners, is expected to face surgery and be lost for the rest of the season. Doctors at Lutheran Medical Center are trying to determine whether Kuiper suffered ligament and cartilage damage, as was indicated earlier.

William Carter Spann, the 34-yearold son of President Carter's sister Gloria, was arrested today on suspicion of violating his parole by taking amphetamines, and parole officers said it was likely that he would return to prison. The terms of his parole from a 10-year sentence for a 1976 armed robbery conviction require that he use no drugs or alcohol. He is in Sonoma County jail awaiting a hearing by the state parole board.

Arthur Charles Nielsen, the Middle Western engineer whose little silver boxes are the controversial but uncontested scorekeepers of American television, died after a long illness in Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago on Sunday. He was 83 years old. Mr. Nielsen was the founder and former chairman of the A.C. Nielsen Company, the largest marketing research organization in the world. Under his guidance, the concern, organized in 1923, grew into a multinational corporation -charting what the average family watches on television, what kind of aspirin it buys, what kind of shampoo it uses, what kind of cereal it eats.
EVOLUTION TO VIOLENCE By JOHN F. BURNS

SALSA Meets Jazz at the Village Gate, a series of Monday-night encounters between established Latin bands and jazz soloists, is only a few weeks old. But the shows, with the WRVR-FM disk jockey Roger Dawson playing host, are already attracting a large and loyal audience and threaten to become a Monday night institution. The most recent Monday evening found Billy Harper, a formidable tenor saxophonist, sitting in with the orchestras of Tito Puente and Bobby Rodriguez, and the music was consistently inspiring. Strong rhythm sections bring out the best in Mr. Harper, who has been heard with Max Roach and Gil Evans as well as with his own groups. During the portion of his first set with Mr. Puente that the reviewer heard, he played ingenious thematic variations, expertly weaving his hard sound into the Puente band's polished ensembles. But the real treat was the hotter, looser session with Bobby Rodriguez that followed. A long, steaming vamp brought some of the most impassioned playing this listener has ever heard from Mr. Harper, and on ''Tea for Two'' he played cleverly with the melody before he entered into a round of exchanges with Mr. Rodriguez, who also plays tenor saxophone.
Denis M. Hurley, former Corporation Counsel of New York City and partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Hurley Kearney Lane, died Monday at his home in Long Beach, L.I. He was 81 years old.
Three leaders of American Jewish organizations yesterday vehemently condemned the bombing attacks against three Palestinian Mayors in the Israelioccupied West Bank on Monday.
AS always when it comes to discussing the late novelist, an air of cultism suffuses this "Tribute" to Vladimir Nabo kov, edited by the English biographer Peter Quennell.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)-- United States imports of textiles and clothing exceeded exports by $839.6 million in the first quarter this year, the Commerce Department reported today.

NEW YORK department stores and boutiques are attracting new customers who come not merely to shop but to dine. In addition to serving lunch, many established places now offer bargain breakfasts, run full-scale bars and even stay open for dinner.

Growing numbers of West Germans and Americans are expressing concern that a basic, negative change is taking place in West German attitudes toward the United States. Some though not all of those who are worried about the situation fear that the movement goes beyond the cyclical changes of politics, beyond the failure of the American rescue mission in Iran and a few points in a public opinion poll, to reflect the central flow of popular thought in a country that is emerging as the leader of Western Europe.

Sandra Ogrean's job at Ogilvy & Mather, the advertising agency, is to make buyers think positively about a line of brassieres, but recently she has been gaining expertise in the collection, cleaning and sale of used clothing. David Lewis, the agency's chief promoter of a credit card and travel company, puts streetwise youths through ancient karate rituals. And Leslie Demus, an agency attorney, has cut through the city's red tape to make vacant lots, apartments and abandoned buildings available for the use of the East 117th Street Block Builders Association, a group formed by community leaders and Ogilvy & Mather.

Manuel Orantes, generally respected by his peers for his sense of fairness and gentlemanly behavior, was defaulted in the $617,000 French open tennis championships when he failed to appear today for his rescheduled fourth-round match with Guillermo Vilas. The match was originally scheduled for yesterday, but a disagreement arose over the time it was supposed to begin. The default moved Vilas into the quarterfinals of the Grand Slam event, in which he will play Harold Solomon of the United States. In quarterfinal action Vitas Gerulaitis of the United States defeated Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 6-3, 5-7, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, and Jimmy Connors eliminated Hans Gildemeister of Chile, 6-4, 6-0, 6-0. Gildemeister started well and was serving at 4-3, 40-0, at which moment Connors went into high gear. The two winners will meet in the semifinals.

The nation is in a recession that began in January, declared the National Bureau of Economic Research, an authoritative nonprofit group. ''It is clear that a peak has been reached and we are now in decline,'' said Martin Feldstein, president of the bureau and a professor of economics at Harvard. The average time from peak to trough of the six previous postwar recessions was just under a year. (D1.) Economic growth of 1 percent was forecast for the 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development this year, despite the onset of recession in the United States and rising oil prices. A stronger upturn is expected in the second half of 1981, the O.E.C.D. Secretariat said in Paris. (D1.)

Denis M. Hurley, former Corporation Counsel of New York City and partner in the Brooklyn law firm of Hurley Kearney & Lane, died Monday at his home in Long Beach, L.I. He was 81 years old. Mr. Hurley was Corporation Counsel from 1951 to 1954 in the administration of Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri. For many years, Mr. Hurley had been active in trials and appeals in New York State's courts and in Federal courts, including the Supreme Court. He had also been attorney for the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn and had an extensive corporate, contract, real estate and Surrogate's Court practice.

The Notes on People column Monday reported incorrectly the opening date of an exhibition of photographs by State Senator Emanuel R. Gold, Democratic-Liberal of Forest Hills, Queens. The exhibition will begin next Monday in the lobby of the American Standard Building, 40 West 40th Street. An article on the third Salute to Women in Jazz in The Times Sunday listed incorrectly the telephone number of the Jazz Gallery. It is 243-3666.

Television tapes and still photographs presented to Maryland racing officials today provided no conclusive evidence whether Codex interfered with Genuine Risk on his way to winning the Preakness Stakes two and a half weeks ago. On the second day of a hearing by the Maryland Racing Commission at Pimlico Race Course, Henry Lord, representing the owners of Genuine Risk, showed ABC-TV tapes that appeared to substantiate the owners' contention that their filly was bumped by Codex coming out of the final turn.

DAVID MILLER'S craft of metalworking took on a new cast three years ago when he inherited a set of eight Victorian copper food molds. ''No one had ever seen anything like them before or knew how they were made,'' he recalled. ''I decided to find out so I could produce them again at a reasonable cost.'' An indefatigable sleuth, Mr. Miller has investigated his subject in cooking libraries and historical societies on both sides of the Atlantic, including Harvard University's Schlesinger Library and the Museum of London. His knowledge of the use of the food mold and the method of its manufacture extends from the days of the Pharaohs in Egypt to the Roaring Twenties in America. Sipping tea in his rambling 17th-century house in Waltham, Mass., where molds from different eras are on display, Mr. Miller said simply, ''I know more about food molds than anyone else.''

EACH year, just about this time, it happens, and without formal announcement. Young children pull cigar or shoe boxes and home-sewn sacks out of winter storage at the bottoms of closets and go outside to play marbles in the dirt. They inscribe circles or outline squares on the ground, dig out holes and shoot marbles in games with names like Ringer, Killer, Knucks and Last Clams. They play for ''funsies'' or ''keepsies'' but they play. This June, it appears, is more than ever the Month of the Marble, because: - The 57th annual National Marbles Tournament will again convene in Wildwood-by-the-Sea, N.J., from June 23 to 26, and 65 boys and girls 14 years old and under will be hunched over in the sand trying to outshoot one another to win the crowns, the scholarships and the bluemottled agate shooters from Germany that are the winners' prizes.

Renault, the French auto producer, is considering buying parts from Canadian auto manufacturers, it was announced yesterday by the Automotive Parts Manufacturers Association of Canada. Morely Bursey, executive director of the association, said the the move could lead to purchases of more than $100 million in parts in coming years. Mr. Bursey said that Renault wanted to purchase parts for its Renault 5 and 18 models, which are now sold in Canada, and parts to supply a planned assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis.

United States imports of textiles and clothing exceeded exports by $839.6 million in the first quarter this year, the Commerce Department reported today. The deficit was well above the $693.4 million gap of the final quarter of 1979 but was down slightly from the $841.2 million deficit for the first three months of 1979, the report showed. The total textile and apparel trade deficit last year was $3.4 billion.

The General Motors Corporation changed its plans and said today it would not offer the air-bag crash-protection device on its full-size automobiles in model year 1982. The company told the Department of Transportation, which oversees auto safety regulations, that it would supply so-called automatic safety belts instead, citing their lower costs.

To the Editor: The U.S. Supreme Court has just relegated Puerto Ricans living on the island to second-rate citizenship. The Court, in a 6-to-3 decision reported in The Times on May 28, provided a lower level of Federal reimbursement for the island's welfare recipients than is provided for those in the 50 states. The vote reversed a ruling of the Federal District Court in Puerto Rico which held that the lower level violates the Constitution's equal-protection guarantee. States are reimbursed for up to 83 percent of their welfare costs; Puerto Rico is now limited to a 50 percent ceiling.

NEW YORK department stores and boutiques are attracting new customers who come not merely to shop but to dine. In addition to serving lunch, many established places now offer bargain breakfasts, run full-scale bars and even stay open for dinner. The genteel ladies' luncheon room, with its cafeteria-style trays, institutional cooking and weak coffee, is becoming obsolete. Instead, gleaming espresso bars, ice-cream parlors, industrious health food counters, wine cellars and even an aspiring French restaurant are drawing not only shoppers, but tourists, local residents and business people.

Ronald Reynolds, who had spent the last two years researching Bedford's history in preparation for the town's tricentennial pageant, died Saturday after suffering a heart attack. He was 45 years old and lived in Katonah. Mr. Reynolds was stricken shortly before the festivities were to begin marking Bedford's 300th birthday. Mr. Reynolds was a descendant of some of the original Bedford settlers.
Sugar futures dropped in all deferred contract months, some by as much as the expanded daily trading limit of 1.5 cents, as commission houses and the trade liquidated positions to take profits.
As a search for Howard (Buddy) Jacobson continued yesterday, he was sentenced in absentia in State Supreme Court in the Bronx to a maximum term of 25 years to life imprisonment for murder.

A drop in scrap prices early last month has led some major steel producers and mini mills to cut prices on such steel products as carbon bar and light structural steels by $20 to $25 a ton to keep their customers.

JOHANNESBURG, June 3--The guerrilla attack on South Africa's industrial complex was a long time coming.
Renault, the French auto producer, is considering buying parts from Canadian auto manufacturers, it was announced yesterday by the Automotive Parts Manufacturers Association of Canada.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)-- President Carter asked food processors today for "some degree of financial sacrifice on your pan" to hold down food prices.
Ever since the Mayor's Health Policy Task Force recommended, in 1979, the closing of Sydenham Hospital, in West Harlem, there has been a continuing, and increasingly heated, debate.

Holding the hostages takes the focus off the Shah. The Shah is the villain of the act. People are thinking about the hostages all over the world while the Shah eats his caviar over in Egypt. That, I think, is a serious mistake.'' - Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark in a speech in Teheran. (A7:1.)

BETTY displayed the antique porcelain Wedgwood mold he had used to produce the summer pudding that shimmered, vivid pink and crenelated, on a serving plate nearby. ''The hard part was getting the bread into the mold's ridges without crumbling,'' he said. ''It would be much easier to do the pudding in a plain metal bowl. But this is far prettier.''

SUNDAY could have been renamed Kyra Nichols Day at the New York State Theater, where the young New York City Ballet principal danced two new roles. In the afternoon, there was an exciting performance of George Balanchine's ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux'' from Miss Nichols and Adam Luders, who swept through its Soviet-style daredevilry as if shot out of a cannon with perfectly pointed feet. Miss Nichols brings a sense of classical phrasing to her work that is rare in dancers of her generation, and ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux'' gives her a formal classical framework within which to expand. Dressed in a handsome new costume, Mr. Luders surged authoritatively through his solo, a model of lyricism, neat finishes and sympathetic partnering.

The red, white and black flag with its golden eagle still flies high above the Egyptian Embassy on the outskirts of this seaside capital, in what has become a rare sight for an Arab League country these days.
DESPITE SUPPORT OF PRESIDENT BY MOST PARTY LEADERS By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN

One of the accepted truths of the 1970's was that great stretches of the ''inner cities'' were doomed. The poor people still living in them were regarded as helpless or criminal and, in any case, imminent casualties of the abandonment plague. Terms like ''South Bronx'' became generic usages, as in ''It looks like the South Bronx.'' And yet, in one city after another, some inner-city neighborhoods are stubbornly staying alive. These are not polished-brass restoration areas, with snob appeal, though there are many of those. Neither are these rare showpiece projects like Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration in Brooklyn. They are poor or working-class neighborhoods that have hung on, revived and even prospered to an extent that cannot be explained just by a flow of Federal urban aid dollars. The larger explanation is self-help.

The Queens District Attorney began an investigation yesterday into the shooting by police officers of the owner of a South Ozone Park liquor store on Monday. The owner had fired at a customer, who had allegedly attacked her with a bottle. The owner, Maude Kirkpatrick, 35 years old, was reported in ''critical but stable'' condition at Jamaica Hospital. She was shot in the chest after she emerged from her store, Fairway Liquors, at 131-21 Rockaway Boulevard, with a pistol in her hand. Moments earlier she had grazed Charles Wilson, 28, of 130-10 135th Place, Ozone Park. Mrs. Kirkpatrick had a license for the gun.

SEE the brave father. The brave father is standing in his stocking feet on the pavement in front of the apartment house at 10:30 in the evening. Inside the vestibule of the apartment house, a young man is pushing all the buttons on the intercom. As various voices answer with questions, the young man ignores them and goes on to push another button, hoping someone will be stupid enough to buzz him in. The brave father enters the vestibule, taps the young man on the shoulder and motions him to come outside. They have words. It is ridiculous to have words without shoes.

Norm Ellenberger, former coach at the University of New Mexico and once a big winner on the basketball court, continues to suffer setbacks in the legal courts. A Federal judge refused yesterday to dismiss indictments against Ellenberger. He is charged with mail fraud, wire fraud and interstate travel in the aid of racketeering in connection with recruiting and transcript-rigging violations within the university's athletic program. He is scheduled to go on trial June 16 at Roswell.

TO THE LIVING SECTION: Having conducted a workshop on the impact of divorce on children at the Columbia School of Social Work last fall, and as a part-time stepparent myself, I read with interest K.C. Cole's article (''The Travails of a Part-Time Stepparent,'' May 14). While I suspect you will get a bevy of positive responses from bewildered, anxious, irritated stepparents, I forward a dissenting note about what is yet another in a glut of media attention to an overworked topic. If you must assault us again with the travails of dealing with the ex-wife, the rejection of our cooking, and the agony of establishing relationships with the children - I suggest some fresh approach, and a less ''cutesy'' tone.

A convention representing Italy's 8,000 Baptists today accused President Carter, who is also a Baptist, of pursuing a foreign policy ''contrary to the gospel of Christ.'' A convention statement said a large majority of the 120 participants had signed an open letter to Mr. Carter attacking his handling of the Iran crisis, his plans to build the cruise missile and his call for European allies to increase military spending.

A bomb exploded in the base of the Statue of Liberty yesterday evening, damaging an exhibition room but injuring no one. The room in the fortress-like base of the statue on Liberty Island in New York Harbor contained historical material about the structure and a plaque with the text of Emma Lazarus's inscription. The room was vacant when the explosive device went off at 7:25 P.M. The last tourist boat from the island had left at 6:15. A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is investigating the blast because it occurred on Federal property, said early this morning that the bureau had received numerous anonymous telephone calls from persons taking responsibility for the bombing in the name of various groups.

Richard J. Wells, a key figure in several investigations into the awarding of New York City bus shelter franchises, resigned yesterday as executive assistant to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. Mr. Wells, a Goldin aide for six years, said that he had been considering the resignation for a long time and that it had nothing to do with the shelter controversy. He said that after a year and a half of looking for the right business opportunity, he had decided to become president of the Interconnect Management Corporation, a telephone equipment company based in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

TRANSIT FARE ALBANY, June 3 - Governor Carey is considering recommending a 10-cent increase in New York City's bus and subway fares if that will overcome the Legislature's resistance to new taxes to subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's deficit.

WASHINGTON, June 3--President Carter, confident that today's primaries had assured his renomination, said tonight that he would call Senator Edward M. Kennedy shortly to "congratulate him on a great campaign."

WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)-- The Associated Press Sports Editors Association established the Red Smith Distinguished Service Award today, to be given annually to an individual who has rendered outstanding service to sports journalism.
THERE are at least two legitimate ways to listen to a piece such as Martin Bresnick's "We're Weaving, We're Weaving," which had its first performance on Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
THE letter sounded plaintive: "why doesn't anyone write on how impossible it is for anthropology majors to find jobs?"

WASHINGTON, June 3--A senior Justice Department official said that the Energy Department moved to dismiss lawsuits against three oil companies involving more than $1 billion in allegedly excessive costs without the required concurrence of the Attorney General, thus raising doubts about the validity of the settlements.

EVER since May Day 1975 individual investors have paid brokers' commissions that are generally higher than those that were in effect before the Securities and Exchange Commission decreed that the New York Stock Exchange could no longer set rates.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; Yugoslav, on Moscow TV, Asks for Mutual Respect

A 25-cent toll increase on two bridges over Jamaica Bay has been postponed until June 16. The new 75-cent toll had been scheduled to go into effect Monday. David Baxley, a spokesman for the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, said that more time was needed to organize a new discount system for residents of the Rockaway Peninsula.

THIN, gracious and very European, she usually wore Givenchy gowns or maybe just slim black slacks with a shirt tucked inside, but she always looked elegant with just the right touch of mischievous wit. Men almost always named her as their idea of the ideal woman and women always said they would love to look like her. Whether she was eating lunch at a Swiss ski resort with Cary Grant or driving along the French Riviera in a Mercedes 300 with Albert Finney or just taking breakfast at Tiffany's, she seemed to lead a perfect life of charm and grace. Last week, Audrey Hepburn was back in New York, completing another movie, a comedy written and directed by Peter Bogdanovich, and she was sitting in the Cafe Pierre, eating mint chocolates and macaroons. It was an appropriate setting - the dusky pink walls reflected the glow of candles and musicians played a sarabande. Self-conscious by nature, she is overcome, she says, by size and strangers, and the intimacy of the hotel makes her feel safe.

Amfac Hotels and Resorts Inc. said it signed a lease agreement with MCC Development Company, Minneapolis, to build and manage a 600-room deluxe hotel in Minneapolis City Center. The hotel is scheduled to open in 1983. * Davy McKee Corporation, a subsidiary of Davy Inc., has been awarded a $75 million turnkey contract to build a thermoplastic rubber plant for the Shell Oil Company at Belpre, Ohio.

The Orion Capital Corporation said the company and its directors had been named as defendants in a class action lawsuit filed by Stuart Wechsler, described as an Orion shareholder. The suit, filed in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, alleges that the plaintiff has been damaged by Orion Capital's decision not to negotiate an acquisition proposal from Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., Orion said. The offer by Shearson, which already owns nearly 5 percent of Orion shares, was for $17.50 a share, or about $145 million. Orion's directors formally rejected the offer yesterday. Orion management said it believes the lawsuit, which makes no specific damage claim, is without merit.

The City Council is seeking to add up to 1,000 police officers to the number provided by Mayor Koch's proposed budget, it was disclosed yesterday. There were indications that the Mayor would go along with at least some additions. ''New York City is facing a police crisis and the department has fallen below tolerable levels,'' said Councilman Edward L. Sadowsky, a Queens Democrat who is chairman of the Finance Committee, which is making an increase in the police force a priority in its budget review.
A controversial documentary on the suicide of a 62-year-old Manhattan woman who took her life a year ago with the advance knowledge of family and friends will be shown June 16 on public television.

The New York State Court of Appeals ordered Citibank yesterday to refund several million dollars in illegally charged fees to between 150,000 and 200,000 customers who had paid their monthly Master Charge bills on time. The decision affirmed a June 1978 ruling by a state Supreme Court in a class-action suit brought by three Nassau County residents. The case had been affirmed by the Appellate Division last August. Yesterday's action constituted a final decision in the case and will mean reimbursements of up to $10 a customer, plus 6 percent annual accrued interest.

Ignoring a warning from the Coast Guard, the freighter Red Diamond V pulled into Key West this morning packed to capacity with 731 refugees and the relatives who had gone to Cuba to secure their release. It was the largest number of refugees to come to the United States aboard a single vessel since the freedom flotilla began in April. Soon after the aging red-hulled ship arrived at the United States naval station under Coast Guard escort at 8:30 A.M., her owner and captain, identified by the authorities as Peter Winston Phillip, was arrested and charged with transporting illegal aliens. Immigration agents also arrested 66 crew members and Americans on the ship, and an undisclosed number of the refugees' relatives on the charge.

Collin Tanabe drove in five runs with a homer and a double, and Bryan Duquette, a freshman left-hander, pitched a six-hitter as the Hawaii Rainbows upset the top-ranked Miami Hurricanes, 9-3, in the College World Series tonight. With the victory the Rainbows remained the only unbeaten team in the tournament. Each of the three other teams still alive in the series - Miami, Arizona and California - has lost once.

In a case that could affect thousands of tenants and landlords, a Housing Court judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that tenants do not have the right to sublet their apartments without approval from their landlords. The judge, Ferdinand M. Pellegrino, ruling on what lawyers for both parties called a test case of subletting rights, said that tenants generally had the right to move without penalty before their leases expired, but that they did not have the right to sublet their apartments to someone else unless their landlords approved.

ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Craig McMurtry, pitcher, and assigned him to Savannah of the Southern League. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Placed Dan Ford, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Ac- quired Dave Lemanczyk, right-handed pitcher, from Toronto for future consider- ations. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Kevin Maro- ney, outfielder. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Placed Larry Hisle, outfielder-designated hitter, on the 15-day disabled list. Called up Ed Romero, in- fielder, from Vancouver farm team. SAN DIEGO (NL) - Placed Von Joshua, outfielder, on 15-day disabled list. Re- called Tim Flannery, outfielder-infielder, from Hawaii of the Pacific Coast League. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Traded Jim Lentine, out- fielder, to Detroit for John Martin, relief pitcher, and a player to be named later. TORONTO (AL) - Signed Garry Harris, shortstop and the club's top draft choice, and assigned him to Alberta farm team. BASKETBALL INDIANAPOLIS (NBA) - Named Jack Mc- Kinney head coach, replacing Bobby Leonard. HOUSTON (NBA) - Signed Steve Hayes, who played for Anchorage of Continental Association last season. SEATTLE (NBA) - Traded Dennis John- son, guard, to Phoenix for Paul Westphal, guard. Announced that Zollie Volchok, general manager, had been named presi- dent of FNI Inc., the club's parent compa- ny.

IN Lyndhurst, N.J., a few years ago, 12 women picketed a house where three former mental patients were living. The picketers said the halfway house was too close to a children's playground and they feared for the safety of the children. Hundreds of similar episodes have occurred throughout the country in recent years, where states have tried to establish community mental health centers or have released hospitalized mental patients to residential settings.

Despite the onset of recession in the United States, the economies of the 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development should grow about 1 percent this year with a stronger upturn taking hold in the second half of 1981, according to a study by the O.E.C.D. secretariat released today at the group's annual ministerial meeting here. The main positive factors cited were the continuing strength of industrial investment in the West and the likelihood that the biggest balance-of-payments deficits induced by higher oil prices will fall on economically stronger countries, such as West Germany and Japan, which can afford to shoulder them.

United States imports of textiles and clothing exceeded exports by $839.6 million in the first quarter this year, the Commerce Department reported today. The deficit was well above the $693.4 million gap of the final quarter of 1979 but was down slightly from the $841.2 million deficit for the first three months of 1979, the report showed. The total textile and apparel trade deficit last year was $3.4 billion.
61 YEARS AGO Lillian Montaldo Doop, founder of Montaldo's, the 50-year-old fashion specialty shop chain, died Monday at her home, a 20-acre farm in Morristown, N.J. She was 95 years old.

Edwina Dakin Williams, mother of Tennessee Williams, the playwright, died Sunday at a nursing home in St. Louis. She was 95 years old and lived in St. Louis. Clues to the themes and characters of her son's major plays, ''Sweet Bird of Youth,'' ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' ''Suddenly Last Summer,'' ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' and ''The Glass Menagerie,'' whose character Amanda was widely regarded as being based on his mother, were given by Mrs. Williams in ''Remember Me to Tom,'' a book that combined a biography of her son and her autobiography. It was written in collaboration with Lucy Freeman and published in 1963 by G.P. Putnam's Sons.

Ever since the Mayor's Health Policy Task Force recommended, in 1979, the closing of Sydenham Hospital, in West Harlem, there has been a continuing, and increasingly heated, debate. I am not troubled that elected officials, community representatives, and union officials have disagreed with the decision. After all, as a member of Congress I opposed hospital closings in my district. What does trouble me is the intensity and divisiveness of the rhetoric. I have been accused of ''genocide,'' likened to Eugene ''Bull'' Connor, the late Police Commissioner of Birmingham, Ala., and charged with abandoning one of the most medically underserved areas in the country. I believe any fair review of my administration's decision would reach a very different conclusion, that it would show the closing of Sydenham to be in the best interests of changing the way the city delivers health care. New York City operates 17 of the country's 27 municipal hospitals, and it contributes over $400 million to cover the Health and Hospital Corporation's deficit, not including what it contributes in Medicaid payments. I am proud of this system. I also believe that it needs reform - that there are too few neighborhood clinics, that some of its hospitals do not provide the quality care New Yorkers deserve, that an excess of beds (there are nearly 2,000 empty beds in municipal hospitals every night) wastes resources that should be directed at real needs. The recommendation to close Sydenham had been made by past administrations but never carried out because of community opposition.

California voters, who two years ago made Proposition 13 a national symbol of tax revolt, changed course in balloting today, apparently rejecting by a substantial margin a new tax measure, Proposition 9, that would have cut state income tax rates in half across the board. However, Howard Jarvis, the caustic 77-year-old author of both Proposition 13 and Proposition 9, said in Los Angeles that he was not through with his efforts to cut California taxes, regardless of the outcome today.
The dollar gained sharply against the strong British pound but was down against the West German mark and Swiss franc yesterday. Gold prices fell after steep gains the previous day.

A bomb exploded in the base of the Statue of Liberty yesterday evening, damaging an exhibition room but injuring no one.

EACH year, just about this time, it happens, and without formal announcement. Young children pull cigar or shoe boxes and home-sewn sacks out of winter storage at the bottoms of closets and go outside to play marbles in the dirt.
SUNDAY could have been renamed Kyra Nichols Day at the New York State Theater, where the young New York City Ballet principal danced two new roles.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 3--A strained thigh and an upset stomach indirectly led to a 6-5 loss by the Yankees in 10 innings to the Kansas City Royals tonight. The defeat cut New York's lead in the American League's Eastern Division to four and a half games.

MOSCOW, June 3 (AP)--The craft carrying the Hungarian astronaut Bertalan Farkas and his Soviet commander, Valery Kubasov, floated safely back to earth last night, landing in the dusty Central Asian steppes, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

JERSEY CONTEST By HEDRICK SMITH

A special advisory committee to the Court of Appeals, New York State's highest tribunal, recommended today that television and radio coverage and still-picture photography be permanently allowed during appellate court proceedings in the state. The recommendation apparently had the endorsement of Lawrence H. Cooke, the Chief Judge of the court, who immediately asked the state's Chief Administrative Judge, Herbert B. Evans, to draft new court rules that could end the absolute ban on cameras in the state's courtrooms.

HENRIETTE KRISTHEA, soprano, and Gene Tucker, tenor, shared a program of arias, songs and duets in Alice Tully Hall last Friday night. There was a distinctly miscellaneous quality about the evening as the two singers ranged somewhat haphazardly over a great deal of different material, but at least no one could complain that their selection lacked musical variety. Both Miss Kristhea and Mr. Tucker dispatched everything with crisp, professional efficiency, and Marshall Williamson proved to be an alert, flexible accompanist at the piano. Still, it would take a pair of very sophisticated singers with an abundance of style and vocal technique to do justice to a program of such far-reaching scope, and in this respect the results turned out to be rather flat.

The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its planned 1980 spending on exploration and other major projects by $500 million from earlier estimates, to about $8 billion. The announcement was contained in the text of a speech prepared for delivery at a meeting of securities analysts in Boston by Jack F. Bennett, senior vice president of the nation's largest oil company.

Tornadoes struck parts of Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia today, ripping away roofs, overturning mobile homes and injuring more than 80 people. The police in Philadelphia said that a motorist was killed when a tree fell on his truck. Voters in Preston County, W.Va., had to cast their Presidential primary ballots by candlelight and kerosene lamp after a tornado knocked out power lines.

PARIS AS the cost of travel abroad escalates with each passing season, so does the need to make the most of each journey. In recent years, professional chefs as well as armchair gourmets have taken to mixing business with pleasure, combining those brief European vacations with visits to mozzarella factories outside Sorrento, truffle hunts with the famed Urbani family in Italy or sessions that help unravel the mysteries of puff pastry in the heart of Paris. This year in Venice, the legendary 15th-century Gritti Palace begins its sixth year of demonstration classes, with wine lectures and pasta-making sessions, while the newly renovated Venetian Cipriani Hotel reintroduces its cultural program with visits from Simone Beck and Marcella Hazan.

Despite denials from both North Korea and China that the Pyongyang regime plans to take advantage of the unrest in South Korea, some American military officials are still wary and the Carter Administration has sent a naval force to the area in an effort to dissuade the North Koreans from any military action. ''The North Koreans are extremely watchful,'' an American military official said, ''and their forces are very alert.''

India, hoping to capitalize on its traditionally friendly relations with the Soviet Union, has sent its Foreign Minister to Moscow to seek the unconditional withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan, a Government source said today.

As Ronald Reagan awaited the results in today's final round of 1980 Presidential primaries, his chief advisers here worked to assemble a general-election campaign staff that will include long-time Reagan loyalists and associates of former President Gerald R. Ford. The Reagan campaign director, William J. Casey, scheduled a news briefing for tomorrow at which, according to several campaign sources, he will announce the appointment of Lyn Nofziger to a post involving overall supervision of communications for the Reagan campaign.

Mayor Koch yesterday urged Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, to support a bill that would accelerate collections of state income taxes. He told the Binghamton Republican that Governor Carey had told him that if the measure, which has passed the Assembly, was enacted, he would support an appropriation of $70 million in aid for New York City.

Following are excerpts from the text of a bill approved by the New York State Legislature today setting forth conditions for courts to consider in dividing marital property and determining maintenance payments: Marital Property

THE American Ballet Theater gave Antony Tudor's ''The Tiller in the Fields'' and Glen Tetley's ''Sphinx'' their first performances of the season Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Both are recent works but, surprisingly, time has already affected them in contrasting ways. Mr. Tudor's ballet (1979) has lost something in edge and possibly conviction, while Mr. Tetley's view of the Oedipus and Sphinx legend (1978) has gained in the expressiveness it promised but did not totally deliver previously. The kind of performance each ballet received can help explain some of these effects, and ''Sphinx'' was superbly danced by Martine van Hamel, Kirk Peterson, and - returning as a guest in his original role - Clark Tippett. ''The Tiller in the Fields,'' however, suffered from the ambiguity of characterization offered by the current leads, Marianna Tcherkassky and David Loring.

Rafael Landestoy hit a two-run triple with one out in the eighth inning tonight to trigger a three-run rally that gave the Houston Astros a 3-2 victory over the San Diego Padres. Vern Ruhle (2-1) went the first seven innings to get the victory, with Frank LaCorte pitching the final two innings.

IT is, for some, the thorniest problem of contemporary New York manners and mores. It faces those who pay $3.76 per month for the New York Telephone Company's Call Waiting service, which enables more than 200,000 city subscribers to receive more than one call on the same line. How to cope with the ensuing complications? Say you're talking on the phone, and another call comes in. Which call do you take? And how do you ditch the caller you don't want? To resolve this contemporary crisis, Metropolitan Diary turned to Michael Korda for wise counsel. Mr. Korda is, of course, the author of ''Power,'' ''Success'' and, most recently, ''Charmed Lives.'' To Mr. Korda, the call-waiting problem is but a simpler subspecies of the great hold-button quandary:

Directors of the Cox Broadcasting Corporation yesterday declared a 2-for-1 stock split and increased the quarterly cash dividend on the pre-split shares to 23 3/4 cents from 21 1/4 cents. The stock split is payable July 31 to stockholders of record June 30, and the dividend is payable July 15 to holders of record June 30. Following the split, Cox will have 13.5 million common shares outstanding. Cox, based in Atlanta, owns five television stations and 12 radio stations and is active in cable television, publishing and motion picture production.

Rudolph H. Erda, a senior partner in the New York law firm of Erda & Leichter, died Saturday in New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Erda, who immigrated from Germany in 1936, specialized in international estate practice and was an attorney for the Consulate General of West Germany in New York.

That small uprising by about 300 Cuban refugees at Fort Chaffee, Ark., elicited two public responses. Mostly there was outrage: Ship them back to Cuba! Occasionally, there was a sympathetic question: Why can't the Government process these people faster? These responses aren't necessarily at odds. More than 80 people, some of whom presumably started the disturbance, have been thrown into the stockade. For a while, at least, that is where they belong. The sort of ''impatience'' that makes people burn down rescue centers and stone their rescuers deserves no sympathy whatever.

Banner Industries of Cleveland is to supply 5 million worth of pumps for an irrigation project on the Nile River. A company spokesman said a Banner subsidiary, the Patterson Pump Company, is to manufacture 128 high-volume, low-pressure pumping units for installation in 37 pumping stations along the Nile from the Aswan Dam 500 miles to the north. Delivery of the pumping units and related equipment is scheduled for completion by May 1982. The installations are part of a major project funded by a loan from the United States Agency for International Development to expand productive agricultural capacity through irrigation. The equipment will be manufactured at Patterson's Toccoa, Ga., plant.

Peter W. Rodino Jr., who became a national celebrity as chairman of the Richard M. Nixon impeachment hearings, won the Democratic nomination for a 17th term in Congress yesterday in New Jersey's 10th District.

FOR those who, like myself, generally consider the collected works of Richard Wagner to be an endurance trial, the prospect of three and a half hours of "Tannhauser" might well prompt spasms of fear and loathing.

Vincent van Gogh used to cut off his ear and send it to ladyfriends as a gift. Afterward he would paint a picture of himself without his ear on. Everybody said he was a loser and possibly crazy.
Mayor Koch yesterday urged Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader of the New York State Senate, to support a bill that would accelerate collections of state income taxes.

HEBRON, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, June 3--The Jewish settlers of Qiryat Arba, the largest of the West Bank settlements, observed a day of grief today, but it did not extend to the Arab mayors who were maimed in bombing attacks yesterday.
A controversial documentary on the suicide of a 62-year-old Manhattan woman who took her life a year ago with the advance knowledge of family and friends will be shown June 16 on public television.

The task of building socialism in a small country 90 miles from the largest and most powerful capitalist power in the the world has long been a formidable problem for the 10 million people of Cuba and their revolutionary leaders. The departure of thousands of Cubans to the United States is above all a reflection of this difficulty. While the United States news media have seized upon the refugees as proof of the ''failure'' of Cuban socialism, the recent pro-Castro demonstrations by millions in Havana indicate that the revolution is still very much alive and continues to evoke widespread enthusiasm and support.

A NEW musical, ''David Copperfield,'' translated to the stage from the Dickens novel by Al Kasha and Joel Hirschhorn, will open on Broadway in April, arriving by way of the West Coast. Mr. Kasha and Mr. Hirschhorn are responsible for the book, music and lyrics. The show is the newest venture of Don Gregory and Mike Merrick, the producing pair who are busy taking Richard Burton, in ''Camelot,'' to Broadway this summer and Rex Harrison, in ''My Fair Lady,'' to Broadway in the summer of 1981. No director or cast has been selected for ''David Copperfield.''

SKETCHBOOK'' was the title of one of the works presented at the Dances by Albert Reid program Monday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio. But Mr. Reid could also have given the title to his concert as a whole because his dances were choreographic sketches composed of wisps and squiggles of movement that, at their best, had the directness and spontaneity of first impressions. Ellen van Schuylenburch and Mr. Reid raced and ran and breezed their way through ''Blue Room,'' to an arrangement of Richard Rodgers's song of the same name. ''Sketchbook,'' a solo for Mr. Reid, went from ambling steps to peculiar wiggles and quivers, and if the movements looked disconnected, that was not really bothersome, because jottings in a sketchbook can often be disconnected. A preoccupation with strange quivering and flickering gestures was also evident in ''Vignettes,'' a trio for Peggy Florin, Jeannette Leentvaar and Mr. Reid. Given its bitsiness, ''Vignettes'' seemed as appropriate a title as ''Sketchbook.''

Occupied West Bank, June 3 - The Jewish settlers of Qiryat Arba, the largest of the West Bank settlements, observed a day of grief today, but it did not extend to the Arab mayors who were maimed in bombing attacks yesterday. The settlers held a memorial service for six Jewish worshipers who were killed in an Arab attack here a month ago. Those who spoke of yesterday's bombings expressed a sense of vengeance.

STORM DARKENS THE SKIES OVER NEW YORK: Street lights, headlights and neon lights reflecting off the wet pavement illuminated Times Square at 4:10 yester-day afternoon as a violent rainstorm thundered across the metropolitan area. The storm resulted in power losses, local flooding and delays for commuters. Page B2.

Carter Administration officials plan to consult tomorrow with 30 to 40 members of Congress about the legal status that should be accorded to the more than 100,000 Cubans who have come to the United States in the last six weeks. The meeting is to focus on legal questions about the status of the Cubans and the social-service benefits to which they are entitled. But Jack H. Watson Jr., a senior assistant to President Carter, said that the officials would be prepared to answer questions about the processing of refugees and the violence over the weekend at Fort Chaffee, Ark., one of four refugee relocation centers.

President Carter has decided to seek a curb on new Federal hospital construction in order to cool inflation in medical costs, a White House aide said today. The aide said that Mr. Carter had approved a domestic staff memorandum that describes empty hospital beds throughout the country as ''a major contributor'' to high hospital costs.

To the Editor: I wish to assure Oliver M. Mendell (letter May 27) that the toll machines at all Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority facilities where the passenger car toll is now $1 - the Throgs Neck, Triborough and Bronx-Whitestone Bridges and the Queens Midtown and Brooklyn-Battery Tunnels - accept the Susan B. Anthony coin. The coin has been accepted at the Verrazano Bridge since shortly after its introduction. GEORGE SCHOEPFER Executive Officer and Chief Engineer Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority New York, May 28, 1980

Richie Hebner belted a two-run pinch homer with two out in the ninth inning to give the Detroit Tigers a 4-2 victory over the Seattle Mariners tonight. Dave Roberts, the Seattle starter, had a no-hitter for six innings, but he lost it when Steve Kemp singled to left with one out in the seventh. Roberts was knocked out when Detroit tied the score with two runs in the eighth.

Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday that a hearing for Bill Madlock had been tentatively scheduled for early next week. The exact date and the location have not yet been determined, the commissioner said. Madlock is the Pittsburgh Pirate infielder whom the National League fined $5,000 and suspended 15 days for shoving his glove into the face of Umpire Gerry Crawford more than a month ago but who, through appeals to the league president and now to Kuhn, has twice won stays of the punishment.

Scott LeDoux was going to fight George Foreman, and his wife was going to be interviewed on radio. He remembered what Ron Stander's wife had said about her husband before Stander fought Joe Frazier, that ''you don't enter a Volkswagen in the Indianapolis 500 unless you know a short cut,'' and LeDoux was worried about what Sandy might say. The interviewer asked Sandy LeDoux how she felt about the women who always hang around boxers. ''I don't care,'' she replied. ''When he comes home, he still has to take out the garbage.'' Yesterday, as Scott LeDoux, one of the best-liked people in boxing, realized a longtime dream as his fight for Larry Holmes's heavyweight title was announced, he remembered that ''Sandy has always kept things in perspective for me.''

The Chrysler Corporation has reversed its decision to shut down in July its Lynch Road assembly plant, where its slow-selling full-sized passenger cars are made. The decision to close the Detroit plant had been announced last month. The company confirmed in Detroit that the Lynch Road plant would continue production into the 1981 model year. It said the decision had been reached after discussions with the city of Detroit and the United Auto Workers union, whose president, Douglas A. Fraser, is a Chrysler director.

Renault, the French auto producer, is considering buying parts from Canadian auto manufacturers, it was announced yesterday by the Automotive Parts Manufacturers Association of Canada. Morely Bursey, executive director of the association, said the the move could lead to purchases of more than $100 million in parts in coming years. Mr. Bursey said that Renault wanted to purchase parts for its Renault 5 and 18 models, which are now sold in Canada, and parts to supply a planned assembly plant in Kenosha, Wis.

A senior Justice Department official said that the Energy Department moved to dismiss lawsuits against three oil companies involving more than $1 billion in allegedly excessive costs without the required concurrence of the Attorney General, thus raising doubts about the validity of the settlements. Associate Attorney General John H. Shenefield said that the litigation was to have been dismissed in agreements that the Energy Department signed with the Cities Service Company, the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), which markets products under the trade name Amoco. The cases involved $574 million, $254 million and $183 million, respectively, Mr. Shenefield said. But he did not say how the sums were computed.

Earl Jones, the 6-foot-10-inch basketball center from Spingarn High School in Washington, will announce his college plans early next week and is leaning toward signing a letter of intent with the University of the District of Columbia, a largely black Division II school. According to William (Doc) Robinson, who has acted as an adviser to Jones since the highly recruited player transferred to Spingarn last fall from Mount Hope High School in West Virginia, Jones ''wants to go where he can give some assistance, feel comfortable and fit into the community life.'' The basketball team at the University of the District of Columbia, which had a 17-10 won-lost record last year and will move into a new field house in September, is coached by Wil Jones, a former assistant coach at the University of Maryland who scouted Jones in West Virginia.

A drop in scrap prices early last month has led some major steel producers and mini mills to cut prices on such steel products as carbon bar and light structural steels by $20 to $25 a ton to keep their customers. The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, for example, cut the price of carbon bars, which had been selling for $270 a ton, by $20, a reduction of 7.4 percent.

With interest rates higher than they were a week ago, investors moved quickly yesterday to purchase another unusually heavy volume of new issues of Government, corporate and state notes and bonds. By late afternoon, most of the new securities had been sold, investment bankers reported. In the Treasury securities market, the Government sold new 5-year 2 1/2-month notes at an average yield of 9.66 percent, while the new two-year notes auctioned Monday at a yield of 9.37 percent rose enough in price to lower their rate of return to 9.18 percent.

President Carter asked food processors today for ''some degree of financial sacrifice on your part'' to hold down food prices. The meeting was the seventh in a series that Mr. Carter has held with representatives of various industries. Earlier this year, he met with officials of a number of major supermarket chains. The results of those meetings were price freezes and some price reductions of varying duration on selected store-branded products. Some of the original price freezes were extended after they expired.

THE American Ballet Theater gave Antony Tudor's "The Tiller in the Fields" and Glen Tetley's "Sphinx" their first performances of the season Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Both are recent works but, surprisingly, time has already affected them in contrasting ways.
Japan's gold and international monetary reserves rose in May by $2.49 billion, bringing the outstanding balance to $21.4 billion, according to a report in Tokyo yesterday.

DUNDEE, ORE. NOT long ago bettors would have put their money on California to produce the best American pinot noir, a red wine made from the same grape used for the exquisite red Burgundies of France. After all, California's other European varietals are the best wines in the land, so why not the pinot noir too?

A NEW musical, "David Copperfield," translated to the stage from the Dickens novel by Al Kasha and Joel Hirschhorn, will open on Broadway in April, arriving by way of the West Coast. Mr. Kasha and Mr. Hirschhorn are responsible for the book, music and lyrics.

A trial is tentatively set to begin tomorrow for Bernard King, the suspended Utah Jazz basketball star who is charged with sexual abuse. King is accused of a New Year's Day assault on a Salt Lake City woman.

Cliff Johnson's two-run homer with two out in the 10th inning gave the Cleveland Indians a 6-4 victory over the Oakland A's tonight. The A's tied the score at 4-4 with three consecutive home runs in the top of the ninth after Cleveland's starter, Len Barker, had left the game with a stiff shoulder. Dave Revering and Mitchell Page led off the inning with homers to right field off Sid Monge, and Tony Armas followed with a blast to center off Victor Cruz.

ATTACKS CONGRESS ON OIL FEE,SAYS SOME LAWMAKERS RENEGED AFTER COMMITMENTS IN MARCH WASHINGTON, JUNE 3 - President Carter, opening a budget review for 1982 and beyond, expressed ''consternation'' today that Congress had gone back on ''commitments'' made last March to protect certain domestic programs and impose a controversial fee on imported oil.

Appointee of Southern Baptist Home Mission Board as chaplain at Princeton University ... One of seven-member ''fact-finding group'' that visited Iran from Dec. 23 to Jan. 3 at invitation of Iranians ... Group spent an hour Christmas day with Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, suggested international tribunal to investigate ''misuse of power during the Shah's regime'' and possible American involvement ... Born March 21, 1946, in Poplar Bluff, Mo. ... Degrees from Southeast Missouri State College in 1969, San Francisco State College in 1973, Pacific School of Religion in Berkeley in 1975 ... Summer missionary in Singapore and Malaysia 1966 ... Pastor in Painton, Mo., 1968-69, and Union City, Calif., 1969-73 ... Missionary first in Boston, 1975-77. Lennox S. Hinds

Marvin H. Tullman, a vice president of E. F. Hutton & Company, investment bankers and brokers, died of a heart attack Saturday while playing paddle tennis at the Westbrook Swim Club in Edison, N.J. He was 56 years old and a resident of Plainfield, N.J. He is survived by his wife, the former Nathalie Hart; a daughter, Sybil; a son, Mitchell, and a sister, Beverly Hoffman.

The account given to investigators by Vernon E. Jordan Jr., who was wounded by sniper fire here last week, was consistent with that of Martha C. Coleman, whose car he was leaving when he was shot, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today. Mrs. Coleman had told both Federal and local investigators that she was returning Mr. Jordan, the president of the National Urban League, to his room at the Marriott Motor Inn from her home where they had gone for coffee. This was at the end of an evening that included a reception and drinks after a banquet where he was the featured speaker at the Fort Wayne Urban League's annual meeting. Mrs. Coleman is a member of the local group's board of directors.

For seven months, 53 Americans have sat confined in Iran with fewer rights than if they were common criminals. Their only known offense is working for the United States. Thirteen of the prisoners, you may recall, were released after two weeks for no other reason than their race or sex. Thus the detention of mostly male whites became a bigoted as well as cruel show by which Iranians prove their manhood to each other and their non-Aryan credentials to the third world. Diplomats generally share the frustration of most Americans; they know that governmental kidnapping can immobilize their important work. Most governments, however, have become indifferent, absorbing the Iranian propaganda that America - more precisely, a once haughty America - is the only intended victim. With the honorable exception of Canada, they conduct diplomacy and most commerce as usual.

To the Editor: The May 24 letter about Westway by Charles Bell only proves that if you create fiction and state it authoritatively, maybe it will be believed. His letter is filled with errors: Traffic does not move well in lower Manhattan, and the local streets are jammed with traffic. Try going from City Hall to midtown any afternoon and see.

USUALLY when a pianist and another musician appear together in recital, the pianist is an accompanist. But the appearance Monday night at the 92d Steeet Y of Richard Sher, a cellist, and the pianist Richard Goode proved a genuine joint recital. The two men played a Mendelssohn Sonata in B flat (Op. 45), then Mr. Sher addressed the unaccompanied Bach Suite No. 2 in D minor, then, after the intermission, Mr. Goode did the four Brahms Piano Pieces (Op. 119) and finally the two joined again for the Beethoven Sonata No. 5 in D (Op. 102, No. 2), originally specified for ''piano and cello.''
