The National Bureau of Economic Research, the widely recognized arbiter of business cycles, declared yesterday that the nation was now in a recession, one that began in January. ''It is clear that a peak has been reached and we are now in decline,'' Martin Feldstein, president of the bureau and a professor of economics at Harvard University, said in a telephone interview early yesterday evening.

A significant decline in sales of automobiles, aircraft equipment, lumber and chemicals caused Canada's merchandise exports to tumble in April by 3.1 percent, Statistics Canada announced today. Exports dropped by about $200 million, to $6.16 billion, while imports increased by 8 percent in the month, the agency reported. As a result, the merchandise trade balance fell into deficit by $7 million in April after a surplus of $649 million in the previous month.

EVER since May Day 1975 individual investors have paid brokers' commissions that are generally higher than those that were in effect before the Securities and Exchange Commission decreed that the New York Stock Exchange could no longer set rates. That's ironic because the rationale for the shift was that free competition would force brokers to cut rates. Brokers do charge institutional clients considerably less than in years past. But individual customers, for the most part, are paying substantially more, in many cases 20 percent more than the schedule prior to May Day.

Japan's gold and international monetary reserves rose in May by $2.49 billion, bringing the outstanding balance to $21.4 billion, according to a report in Tokyo yesterday. A foreign-exchange market official said the gain was the result mainly of appreciation of the yen and dollar-support buying by the central bank.

Earl Jones, the 6-foot-10-inch basketball center from Spingarn High School in Washington, will announce his college plans early next week and is leaning toward signing a letter of intent with the University of the District of Columbia, a largely black Division II school.
BONN, June 3--Growing numbers of West Germans and Americans are expressing concern that a basic, negative change is taking place in West German attitudes toward the United States.
DAVID MILLER'S craft of metalworking took on a new cast three years ago when he inherited a set of eight Victorian copper food molds.

The height of the swing era in the late 1930's is the focus of "Stompin' at the Savoy!", a musical revue that opens next Monday at 8:30 P.M. at the West Bank Cafe, 407 West 42d Street, for a month-long engagement of Sundays and Mondays.
Darryl Strawberry, a tall and versatile athlete from Crenshaw High School in Los Angeles, was the first pick yesterday in major league baseball's semiannual amateur draft.
Edwina Dakin Williams, mother of Tennessee Williams, the playwright, died Sunday at a nursing home in St. Louis. She was 95 years old and lived in St. Louis.

BALTIMORE, June 3 (UPI)--Television tapes and still photographs presented to Maryland racing officials today provided no conclusive evidence whether Codex interfered with Genuine Risk on his way to winning the Preakness Stakes two and a half weeks ago.

The City Council is seeking to add up to 1,000 police officers to the number provided by Mayor Koch's proposed budget, it was disclosed yesterday. There were indications that the Mayor would go along with at least some additions.
VILA, New Hebrides, June 3 (AP)-- Rebels holding the New Hebrides island of Espiritu Santo announced by radio today that they had formed a provisional Government.

One of the accepted truths of the 1970's was that great stretches of the "inner cities" were doomed. The poor people still living in them were regarded as helpless or criminal and, in any case, imminent casualties of the abandonment plague.

WASHINGTON, June 3--Despite denials from both North Korea and China that the Pyongyang regime plans to take advantage of the unrest in South Korea, some American military officials are still wary and the Carter Administration has sent a naval force to the area in an effort to dissuade the North Koreans from any military action.

The New York State Court of Appeals ordered Citibank yesterday to refund several million dollars in illegally charged fees to between 150,000 and 200,000 customers who had paid their monthly Master Charge bills on time.

THIN, gracious and very European, she usually wore Gi venchy gowns or maybe just slim black slacks with a shirt tucked inside, but she always looked elegant with just the right touch of mischievous wit.

The National Broadcasting Company yesterday appointed Irwin Segelstein, an NBC executive of varied experience, to the newly created post of president of NBC Television, a position that makes him the clear No. 2 man after Fred Silverman, NBC's president.

GENERAL MILLS of Minneapolis, a consumer goods conglomerate with $4 billion in annual sales, is built around a simple bag of flour. It is Gold Medal, which this week is joining Maxwell House coffee, Baker's chocolate, Arm & Hammer baking soda, Ivory soap, Heinz tomato products and Morton's salt in that select circle of 100-yearold grocery brands. And for the folks at the company that Gen. Cadwallader Washburn built, the centennial of that product calls for a party with a play about the founder, General Washburn. Guests will include people from Dancer-Fitzgerald-Sample, New York, the brand's agency for 57 years - since it was called Blackett-Sample-McFarland and was based in Chicago. The party will be tonight, with dinner in the Minneapolis Institute of the Arts, and the performance will follow in the adjoining Children's Theatre.

THESE days there is something to be said for world problems that simply simmer. The task of devising common accounting rules for companies throughout the world would rank high on no one's agenda of urgent global issues. Accounting and financial reporting are among the least bellicose of relations across national boundaries. No time bomb is ticking, no sword hangs over the ledgers. No matter what the accountants do, they pose no threat to the planet. It is also true, however, that a fair amount is afoot in international accounting. More and more, governments are getting involved, both supranational, as well as national. The underdeveloped world, for instance, is turning to the United Nations, a friendly forum, to bring ''transnational'' companies under stricter scrutiny. The developing nations are pressing for more attention to matters like transfer pricing, an issue of great moment to them.

In an effort to speed up payments to the Chrysler Corporation without increasing its own risks, the National Bank of Detroit is considering the establishment of a separate bank to handle the checking accounts of the financially troubled automobile maker, according to bankers attending the International Monetary Conference here. Philip Lowman, an officer of the bank, who was reached by telephone in Detroit, confirmed today that the bank was considering setting up a separate bank to deal exclusively with Chrysler. But he declined to elaborate on his bank's plans, except to say that the establishment of a separate bank was one of several alternatives being weighed.

Dennis Johnson of Seattle, who was named the most valuable player in the 1979 National Basketball Association championship series that culminated with the SuperSonics beating the Washington Bullets, was traded yesterday to the Phoenix Suns for Paul Westphal. The on-again, off-again deal, which was completed at the annual meeting of the league owners in San Diego, was settled after many long discussions over the contracts of two of the premier guards in the league.

A prominent environmental group charged today that the United States Forest Service was losing millions of dollars and subsidizing big timber companies at public expense by selling timber from national forests at lower than prevailing market prices.

The value of new construction contracts in April fell to $11.1 billion, a 34 percent drop from the year-earlier level, according to a study released today by the McGraw-Hill Informations Systems Company. Contracts for residential building recorded the largest plunge, falling 39 percent, to $4.4 billion, while the value of contracts for commercial and industrial building fell 5 percent, to $4.1 billion, the study showed.

The Legislature approved today a bill requiring judges to distribute property in divorce settlements on the basis of the needs and contributions of each party to the marriage. Supporters of the measure, in a memorandum attached to it, said that ''modern marriage should be viewed as a partnership of coequals.''

The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and the United Automobile Workers sued the Labor Department yesterday to reverse a decision that they said would deprive many workers of long-term unemployment compensation. At issue is a decision by Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall to change the formula under which extended unemployment benefits are put into effect in the various states. The extended benefits give 13 weeks of unemployment compensation, in addition to the regular 26 weeks, in times of high unemployment.

George M. Foley, a New York lawyer who represented entertainers, died of a heart attack last week. He was 62 years old and lived in Highland Lakes, N.J. Mr. Foley's body was found Sunday in the shallow water of Highland Lake after his wife reported him missing Thursday night. Among his clients were Arthur Godfrey, George Gallup, the National Broadcasting Company and CBS Inc. In the late 1950's, Mr. Foley founded Astor Pictures and obtained the exclusive distribution rights for ''La Dolce Vita,'' the first Frederico Fellini film to be shown in the United States.

Alcan Aluminium Ltd., the Canadian-based aluminum producer, signed an agreement with the Spanish Government's industrial development agency to provide ''technology and operating resources'' to Empresa Nacional del Aluminor Endasa, Spain's largest aluminum producer. Alcan said the agreement would ''facilitate'' plans to increase its holdings in Endasa.

Serious students of the game are likely to agree that a new book by a Norwegian author is the most important and original ever written on the subject of defensive signaling. It is "Defensive Play in Bridge" by Helge Vinje, and is available for $7.95 from Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.

BOSTON, June 3--"Here we define the laws of physics," said Andrew Rubel, holding a beanbag between two cigar boxes. "And here," he intoned, making the bag "float" without adequate means of support on the corner of one box, "we break them."

MOSCOW, June 3 (UPI)-- Lyudmila Kondratyeva of the Soviet Union set a world record in the 100-meter dash with a time of 10.87 seconds at a track meet in Leningrad, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
B.J. Meredith, the president of the Dallas-based Docutel Corporation, has something of a Texas-sized problem: "How do I convince people that we are here to stay?"

Lillian Montaldo Doop, founder of Montaldo's, the 50-year-old fashion specialty shop chain, died Monday at her home, a 20-acre farm in Morristown, N.J. She was 95 years old.

PARIS, June 3--Manuel Orantes, generally respected by his peers for his sense of fairness and gentlemanly behavior, was defaulted in the $617,000 French open tennis championships when he failed to appear today for his rescheduled fourth-round match with Guillermo Vilas.

THE other day, a well-known man was going through his billfold to pay a taxi driver when, so he says, he suddenly became aware of something he had been doing for years. He was riffling through the wallet, looking for the most dilapidated bills.

Scott LeDoux was going to fight George Foreman, and his wife was going to be interviewed on radio. He remembered what Ron Stander's wife had said about her husband before Stander fought Joe Frazier, that "you don't enter a Volkswagen in the Indianapolis 500 unless you know a short cut," and LeDoux was worried about what Sandy might say.
TOKYO, June 3 (AP)--Iran's oil exports have fallen to about 300,000 barrels a day following the suspension in April of its crude oil shipments to Japan, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported here today.

Dennis Johnson of Seattle, who was named the most valuable player in the 1979 National Basketball Association championship series that culminated with the SuperSonics beating the Washington Bullets, was traded yesterday to the Phoenix Suns for Paul Westphal.

The Senate today gave final Congressional approval to a $49.7 million appropriation that would allow the Federal Trade Commission to return to normal business. The measure, approved Friday by the House, cleared the Senate 78-16. President Carter was expected to sign it promptly. Congressional opposition to the commission's policies had delayed funding, and on Monday, for the second time in a month, the regulatory agency had to suspend operations for lack of money.

The seven-story office building that the United States built to house its mission to the United Nations here was officially opened today at a ceremony attended by Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall. The building, built at a cost of $10 million, is in the international quarter on the edge of Geneva.

THERE are at least two legitimate ways to listen to a piece such as Martin Bresnick's ''We're Weaving, We're Weaving,'' which had its first performance on Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. If you happened to incline toward the old German school of abstract theorists who deplored the very idea of programs or scenarios, you could have heard the work as a fascinating mixture of late Romantic and modern minimalist styles. The opening and closing movements, cast in a densely chromatic idiom, were separated by a long section of humming and buzzing whose chief technical device was the overlaying of short motives on other short motives in such a way that phaseshifts created a disturbing instability and yet a kind of hypnotic tension. Mr. Bresnick, however, seemed to have more on his mind than abstractions, as a brief program note indicated. The piece, performed by the chamber group called Musical Elements, under Daniel Asia's direction, was based on a refrain from Heine's poem, ''Die Schlesichen Weber,'' or ''The Silesian Weavers,'' written out of sympathy for a workers's uprising in 1844. In the poem, according to the notes, ''the weavers ceaselessly weave the fate of their oppressors.''

Jerome B. Ruenheck, 41 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Burger King USA, following a restructuring of the organization of the fast-food chain by its owner, the Pillsbury Company. The move follows the resignation last month of Donald N. Smith, 39, as president and chief executive officer of the Burger King Corporation to become president of Pepsico Inc.'s new food-service division, with responsibility for the Pizza Hut and Taco Bell chains.

I HAVE not talked much about enamelized iron pots in this space before. The reason, I think, is that they have always struck me as an aberration, a gimmick in avocado green or so-cheerful yellow. Then the other day as I prepared a beef Burgundy in an iron pot glazed with orange enamel, a pot I frequently use for the purpose without giving it much thought, I realized that I may have turned my back on enamelized iron unfairly. So I started to look at the these pots more systematically than I had before. There is no question but that enamelized iron is an important addition to cookware. It distributes heat beautifully, is only moderately expensive and often very good looking. But it also heats slowly, tends to chip and is heavy to work with.

Now that Jimmy Carter has apparently won re-nomination for President, he is doing some fall campaigning by proclaiming a victory over inflation. ''We're turning the economic tide,'' he has said, and ''building a brighter economic future.'' The price indexes have indeed declined from the alarming heights of March. But the President's economic strategy now is nothing more than the late Senator Aiken's for Vietnam: simply announce a victory and quit. No matter how described, the Administration's economic policy remains a failure. The recession now under way was a last-ditch attempt to curb inflation by a President (and Congress) who could think of no better way. It is a disruptive, costly policy that will mean high unemployment and large losses of national wealth.

The Phillips Drew Kings International Tournament in London finished with a tie for first prize among three grandmasters--Anthony Miles of Britain, Ulf Andersson of Sweden and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland. Each received 1,985 for his 8 -4 score.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 3--The Chrysler Corporation has reversed its decision to shut down in July its Lynch Road assembly plant, where its slowselling full-sized passenger cars are made. The decision to close the Detroit plant had been announced last month.
With interest rates higher than they were a week ago, investors moved quickly yesterday to purchase another unusually heavy volume of new issues of Government, corporate and state notes and bonds.

ROME, June 3 (AP)--A convention representing Italy's 8,000 Baptists today accused President Carter, who is also a Baptist, of pursuing a foreign policy "contrary to the gospel of Christ." A convention statement said a large majority of the 120 participants had signed an open letter to Mr. Carter attacking his handling of the Iran crisis, his plans to build the cruise missile and his call for European allies to increase military spending.
George M. Foley, a New York lawyer who represented entertainers, died of a heart attack last week. He was 62 years old and lived in Highland Lakes, N.J.

Sandra Ogrean's job at Ogilvy Mather, the advertising agency, is to make buyers think positively about a line of brassieres, but recently she has been gaining expertise in the collection, cleaning and sale of used clothing.

OTTAWA, June 3 (UPI)--A significant decline in sales of automobiles, aircraft equipment, lumber and chemicals caused Canada's merchandise exports to tumble in April by 3.1 percent, Statistics Canada announced today.
ALBANY, June 3--The Legislature approved today a bill requiring judges to distribute property in divorce settlements on the basis of the needs and contributions of each party to the marriage.
WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI)--The Treasury Department proposed a tightening of Federal currency regulations today in a move to stem the flow of large sums of questionable money into Florida banks.

In a case that could affect thousands of tenants and landlords, a Housing Court judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that tenants do not have the right to sublet their apartments without approval from their landlords.
Richard J. Wells, a key figure in several investigations into the awarding of New York City bus shelter franchises, resigned yesterday as executive assistant to Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy easily defeated President Carter in the New Jersey Democratic Presidential primary, carrying every Congressional District despite the wholesale endorsement of the President by the state's Democratic leadership.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy won the New Jersey Presidential primary last night and edged ahead in California early today. But President Carter captured Ohio and took enough convention delegates to amass the majority needed for renomination at the Democratic National Convention here in August.

The value of new construction contracts in April fell to $11.1 billion, a 34 percent drop from the year-earlier level, according to a study released today by the McGraw-Hill Informations Systems Company.

FOR those who, like myself, generally consider the collected works of Richard Wagner to be an endurance trial, the prospect of three and a half hours of ''Tannhauser'' might well prompt spasms of fear and loathing. In some respects, tonight's ''Great Performances'' presentation, beginning at 8 o'clock on WNET-TV, Channel 13, would justify such a reaction. The story of the brave minstrel Tannhauser, torn between his passion for the goddess Venus and his idealized love for the innocent Elisabeth, is almost embalmed in a 19th-century Germanic heaviness typical of legend celebrations. And this production is true to the Wagnerian tradition of being so minimally lighted as to be almost invisible for long stretches, once again buttressing the theory that Wagner is meant to be heard, not seen.

The National Broadcasting Company yesterday appointed Irwin Segelstein, an NBC executive of varied experience, to the newly created post of president of NBC Television, a position that makes him the clear No. 2 man after Fred Silverman, NBC's president. In his new role, the 55-year-old Mr. Segelstein will oversee the day-to-day activities of all the TV operations except news. He had been president of NBC's television stations division and its radio group, and he has had a long working relationship with Mr. Silverman. Before coming to NBC, he spent many years in programming at CBS and at one time was Mr. Silverman's supervisor there.

Eduardo Cajuso, a 22-year-old Cuban shortstop, signed a one-year contract with the Detroit Tigers yesterday, as Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's ban on the signing of Cuban refugees was lifted. The Tigers said they believed Cajuso was the first Cuban to join a major league organization since the recent massive immigration of Cubans to the United States began. The Tigers will sponsor Cajuso's release from Campo Libertad, the refugee center at Eglin Air Force Base in Florida, and send him to their Class A team at Lakeland in the Florida State League. Depending on Cajuso's skill and fitness, he will either remain in Lakeland or join other Tiger newcomers at a rookie camp in Virginia next week.

John W. Newell, former president of Walter B. Cooke Inc., funeral directors in the New York metropolitan area, died Monday at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 72 years old. Mr. Newell had been with the Cooke company for 46 years when he retired in 1977. He became vice president of the company in 1957 and its president in 1971.

Jerry Koosman pitched a fivehitter and Rick Sofield drove in four runs with a double and a threerun homer tonight, powering the Minnesota Twins to a 9-4 victory over the Boston Red Sox. Koosman (5-5) struck out three and walked two while completing his third game of the season. Dwight Evans drove in all the runs for Boston with a two-run double in the second inning and a two-run homer in the seventh.

The Treasury Department proposed a tightening of Federal currency regulations today in a move to stem the flow of large sums of questionable money into Florida banks. The regulations, which apply to transactions of more than $10,000, would take effect in 30 days.

The Shell Oil Company, citing sluggish economic growth, rising energy prices "and the costs of conservation and stringent environmental standards," yesterday predicted a slowdown in the growth of United States energy consumption through the 1980's.

GRAND ISLAND, Neb., June 4 (AP)-- A string of seven tornadoes devastated this central Nebraska city last night, killing four persons and injuring 134. More than 550 buildings were destroyed, and hundreds of others were damaged.

Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was quoted yesterday as saying that his Government intended to establish 10 new settlements in the occupied West Bank and that these would be the last ones to be set up there.

Yogi Berra once said that a baseball game is never over till it's over, a philosophy that Edward Kennedy has applied to politics doggedly--and now profitably. The last round of eight primaries on Super Tuesday gave him much to cheer about.

William E. Simon, former Secretary of the Treasury and now policy chairman of Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign, has volunteered to organize a Republican Citizens for Koch Committee. It would aid an expected re-election bid by Mayor Koch in 1981.

SUMMER is the slow season on network television, so perhaps that is why the relentless stream of bad news out of NBC these days suggests something more akin to hemorrhaging. Yesterday, the network's beleagured public-relations staff telephoned to say how happy NBC-TV was to announce that it had acquired a new affiliate station, WXIA-TV in Atlanta, previously affiliated with ABC. More affiliates mean more viewers, which means higher advertising rates and larger revenues. What NBC did not announce is that it also lost an affiliate yesterday in Atlanta, WSB-TV, owned by the Cox Broadcasting Corporation, which shifted to ABC. It also happens that WSB, which had been an NBC affiliate since 1948, led the prime-time audiencepopularity ratings last season among Atlanta stations. Indeed, it led in nearly all aspects of its programming, even though it was saddled with an NBC schedule that dragged most other affiliates into last place in their markets.

A lineup that found Lee Mazzilli in center field for a second straight game, a strong seven-inning performance by Pat Zachry and errorless fielding all went for naught for the Mets last night as they were beaten by the St. Louis Cardinals, 1-0, in 10 innings at Shea Stadium. Ken Reitz's long home run into the left-field bull pen to open the 10th inning rewarded a superlative showing by 41-year-old Jim Kaat, the left-hander who was dropped by the Yankees in April. Kaat, who is starting his fourth decade as a major league pitcher, went the distance and fashioned a seven-hitter for his first victory as a Cardinal in four decisions.

Playing in the intense heat of a late-afternoon sun, Harold Solomon upset Guillermo Vilas and reached the semifinals of the French open tennis championships today. They battled for three and a half hours on the clay, which is not unusual in matches between the two baseliners. Solomon's 1-6, 6-4, 7-6, 7-5 victory moved him into a duel with Bjorn Borg, who defeated Corrado Barazzutti of Italy in a routine exchange from the baseline, 6-0, 6-3, 6-3.

Q. I have a 6-foot-long window sill that is made of pine. My husband finished this by sanding it to the bare wood, applying a stain and then applying three coats of spar varnish. However, for some time now, about two feet of this sill is bubbly and the varnish is sticky. I don't understand why this is happening in just this one spot. How can I remove the varnish and seal the wood so this won't happen again? -Mrs. H.M., Philadelphia. A. You are not clear as to whether this bubbly or sticky condition was present from the beginning, or whether it developed later. If it never dried, then there was something on or in the wood in that area that prevented the stain from drying properly before the varnish was applied. If it originally dried, and some time passed before the one area bubbled and got sticky, then chances are that something was spilled on the surface to cause the problem.

My hope was dashed when I learned that ''more than 50 Federal officials, plus numerous consultants'' are to shuttle between Washington and Detroit. y the way, figuring that each of them will get a modest governmental salary of, say, $50,000, plus shuttling and incidental expenses, should I ask who picks up the tab for these additional millions per year? DANIEL L. MORRIS Livingston, N.J., May 28, 1980

Nancy Luise Gartrell, who had been active in amateur theater production and the arts for a number of years, died Monday at St. Francis Hospital, Poughkeepsie, N.Y. She was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

By John Leonard SOLDIERS OF THE NIGHT. The Story of the French Resistance. By David Schoenbrun. Illustrated. 512 pages. E.P. Dutton. $15.95. IN a very long and very unfair letter to Albert Camus, published in Les Temps Modernes in August 1952, Jean-Paul Sartre cried out: ''You were the first servant of your moralism, and now you help yourself to it.'' Then he added: ''Are we dealing here with a racism of moral beauty?'' Although the dispute between Sartre and Camus had nothing to do, ostensibly, with the French resistance to Hitler and Petain during World War II -they were arguing about whether it was permissible to criticize Stalin's gulag - the words resonate. Yes, in fact, we are dealing with ''a racism of moral beauty,'' which is probably the single permissible racism. Only an ideologue could sneer at morals and beauty in the same sentence; the rest is tractors and five-year plans for human engineering.

AMONG life's eternal questions is: ''What are young people thinking about these days?'' One possible answer can be garnered at the 53d National High School Art Exhibition, founded and sponsored by Scholastic Magazines Inc., which opens to the public today. Beginning in 1927 as a painting and drawing competition, the exhibition has mushroomed to 15 separate classifications, encompassing graphic and textile design, pottery, jewelry and threedimensional design (crafts) in addition to oils, water colors, photography and drawing in various mediums.

The Toyota Motor Company may set up its first North American assembly plant in Canada, a source of various auto parts that it uses, Seisi Kato, an executive of the company, said today. Mr. Kato also said that the company, which earlier had announced it was considering building an assembly plant in the United States, had commissioned three research firms to conduct surveys on the economic viability of a United States plant.

Deng Xiaoping confirmed today that he plans to step down as senior deputy Prime Minister in late summer. He said he would remain vice chairman of the Communist Party Central Committee until 1985. Mr. Deng made the announcement at a conference of American editorial writers here. It had been reported in March that he planned to yield the post.

To the Editor: A third-party candidate can't be elected President? Especially if he wins no more than a minority of the total popular vote? It's been done. The third party: the Republicans. The time: 1860. The candidate: Abraham Lincoln. ARNOLD MOSS New York, May 30, 1980

Senator Edward M. Kennedy's strong victory in the New Jersey Democratic Presidential primary Tuesday underscored President Carter's lack of rapport with the state's rank-and-file party members and might indicate that there will be problems in the state for Mr. Carter in November, if he should win renomination as expected. Mr. Carter lost despite the endorsement of Governor Byrne and most of the state's Democratic leaders. However, the party line on the ballot regained its winning form in Congressional and local contests.

A Brahms program will make up the gala benefit concert opening Caramoor's 35th anniversary festival on June 21 in Katonah, N.Y. Sir Alexander Gibson will conduct the festival orchestra in the Venetian Theater in the ''Academic Festival Overture,'' the Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor and the Symphony No. 1 in C minor. The soloist in the concerto will be Youri Egorov. The concert will be preceded by a reception in the Spanish Courtyard and dinner in the Tennis Pavilion. The following afternoon, the festival's first recital of the summer will be given by Igor Kipnis, harpsichordist, in the Spanish Courtyard.

Bob Davis's two-run homer capped a three-run Toronto fourth inning, and Otto Velez added a two-run homer in the seventh as the Toronto Blue Jays defeated the California Angels, 8-2, tonight. The Blue Jays moved to a 24-23 won-lost record, the latest in any season that they have ever been over .500.

Results of a large-scale study show a new drug called nifedipine to be dramatically effective in treating a rare form of angina pectoris and suggest the drug may be valuable for a much broader range of heart patients. Angina is the chest pain that often arises in heart disease when flow of blood to the heart muscle is insufficient for the heart's work load. The patients in the new study all suffer from a rare condition in which spasms of the heart's coronary arteries impair blood circulation to the heart muscle. The drug appears to act directly to quell or prevent the spasms.

Why have interest rates dropped so far so fast? In March, money-market certificates fetched 15.7 percent, and now their yields have fallen to 8.2 percent. The prime rate, 20 percent as recently as mid-April, has dropped to 13 percent. The headlong plunge in rates, the steepest and most sudden since World War II, has bewildered savers and left analysts groping for an explanation.

Led by oil and precious-metals stocks, the New York Stock Exchange surged to its biggest gain in almost six weeks yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose steadily throughout the day to end with a gain of 14.25 points in active trading. The key barometer closed at 858.02, after losing 3.58 points on Tuesday. Volume was 44.2 million shares, up from 33.2 million on Tuesday. Analysts attributed the advances, in which winners outnumbered losers by 1,161 to 381, to Tuesday's primary election results, particularly in California, where voters rejected a proposed 10 percent surtax on oil company profits, and to the lowering of the prime lending rate to 13 percent from 14 percent by Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty and Marine Midland, among other banks.

James Holloway 3d.

WASHINGTON, June 4--President Carter announced today that he would nominate Don A. Zimmerman, minority labor counsel to the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, to be a member of the five-member National Labor Relations Board.

WASHINGTON, June 4--If milk production continues at its current record pace, the Carter Administration may soon have to ask Congress to postpone another increase in dairy price supports scheduled for October, Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today.

Mayor Koch said yesterday that he favored competitive bidding on a redevelopment plan for a valuable stretch of real estate on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and that as a result he has been withholding approval of a proposal by a private group aided by a number of large corporations.

WARSAW, N.Y., June 4 (UPI)-- Twenty-five tons of molasses that accidentally was spilled into Oatka Creek in Warsaw last week killed several hundred thousand fish in Wyoming and Genesee counties, probably leaving no fish alive in a 15-mile stretch of water, state conservation officials said today.

WASHINGTON, June 4--In the last days of the primary campaign, Senator Edward Kennedy flew around the country in what seemed the most hopeless of ventures. Mathematically, it was all over: President Carter was sure of a delegate majority. Yet those who saw Kennedy saw a man enjoying himself hugely.

Insects Poor growth or stunted leaves may indicate increased insect pests. Check with a hand magnifier. Signs include gossamer webs of spider mites; large weaving of leaves by webworms; sticky, honeylike secretion of aphids or scale; lacy or jagged leaves left by beatles or slugs; irregular blotches traced by leaf borers. If you discover bugs, don't panic. They're part of every garden, even in the city, and you may have some useful predators. Basic safe prevention of pests includes vigilance and weekly hosing of undersides of leaves. Once knocked off, many won't return. Hose plants early so the leaves dry by dark. If infestation is out of control, use chemicals with caution, spraying only the afflicted plant. For aphids and mealy bugs, use Malathion 50 (safe for edibles). For scale or leaf miner, use Isotox or Orthene (not safe for edibles); for mites, Kelthane or Diazinon (safe for edibles). Read every word on the label. Keep such equipment and supplies out of the kitchen. Avoid spraying on windy days. Be considerate when using poisons on terraces over streets or other people's gardens. Spring Harmony Study spring bulb catalogues now to plot a longer sequence of bloom with improved coordination of shrubs. While the memory of their color still lingers, orchestrate a better array for next year. Note successful (or dreadful) color combinations, relocating tubs of clashing forsythia, azaleas, rhododendron or crabapples. Plants to be transplanted can be dug up in fall or early spring. Fertilizing Heavy rains increase the leaching of nutrients from tubs. Begin biweekly feeding of summer flowering plants like petunias or tomatoes, and shrubs and vines like roses, clematis or hydrangea. Use a water-soluble fertilizer high in phosphorus (the middle number on the label). Use this also for a final boost for spring flowering shrubs and trees to help them set buds for next year. If new leaves of flowery evergreens like azalea or andromeda are mottled yellowishgreen, there may be an iron deficiency. Lightly work moistened sphagnum peat moss into their soil and fertilize with a product containing chelated iron, such as Miracid. Pruning Now that they've finished blooming, prune spring flowering shrubs and trees to improve their shape and keep them under control. If terrace space is diminishing, train branches out over the street. Remove or tie back eye-level twigs on terrace side. Trim interior stems to open the plant to light and air and to reveal the sculptural form of the branching. Wild Birds Birds are a delight to see and hear and will visit lush city gardens, where they help control insects. Bird feeders may be purchased at garden centers and seed at supermarkets. Hang feeders among the branches of shrubs where the birds feel sheltered and where the seed can't fall on the floor and attract pigeons. Pigeons can also be avoided by selecting a feeder with a dowel stick style perch.

Financial Federation Inc., of Los Angeles, a major savings institution, has announced that its board would hold a special meeting June 13 to consider a $221 million acquisition offer announced Monday by the Great Western Savings and Loan Association, the nation's second-largest thrift lender. The offer expires June 13. Edward Johnson, Financial Federation's chairman and chief executive, said that Great Western's proposal would ''require study'' but added that there was no pressing need to sell the company.

The 3-point goal, dismissed by some followers of the National Basketball Association as a gimmick that had no place in the rules of the game, is now a permanent feature of professional basketball. The league's board of governors voted at its annual summer meeting last night to retain the 3-point rule, which was tried on an experimental basis last season and was received with almost universal acclaim. The rule awards 3 points for shots made from beyond an arc that ranges from 22 feet to 23 feet 6 inches from the basket.

HERALDED as a ''revolutionary era'' in news dissemination, the Cable News Network, a 24-hour-a-day operation, was begun Sunday at 6 P.M. with a presentation of the colors and the national anthem. Overseeing the ceremonies at his Atlanta headquarters, was R.E. (Ted) Turner, the considerably less than humble president of the Turner Broadcasting System Inc., the parent company of CNN. Mr. Turner spoke of brotherhood, kindness and peace. One of his initial guests in a taped interview, President Carter, a fellow Georgian, referred to ''an exciting and historic thing,'' capable of delivering news in much more depth. In fact, the first few days of CNN's operation have revealed an instrument of considerable potential and nagging flaws. Some of the flaws are technical flaws. There is also a lopsided ''mix'' of news and features. There is a likelihood of personnel becoming exhausted and jaded. But CNN, with Reese Schonfeld as president, clearly represents a sign of the inevitable future.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed today for a 5.12 percent increase in its interstate and overseas phone rates. The higher rates, expected to raise company revenues $499 million, are scheduled to go into effect Friday. Customers who do not call long distance will not be affected, the company said. However, users of interstate services, including regular long distance, Wide Area Telecommunications Service and various business applications of private line service, will pay more.

Associates Corporation of North America filed with the S.E.C. a public offering of $100 million of senior notes due Aug. 1, 1987, through a Kidder Peabody group. * Goody Products Inc. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission a public offering of 500,000 shares of common stock through a Goldman Sachs group.

SHEET vinyl floor covering - the type that comes in wide rolls, rather than in individual squares or tiles - has been popular for many years, and in recent years its popularity has increased as manufacturers have introduced highly flexible, easy-to-work-with versions that are designed for do-it-yourself installers. Before, this type of sheet flooring was almost always installed by professionals only. However, even though the new sheet vinyl materials are much easier to work with than the older forms, many homeowners still are reluctant to tackle the job because of the tricky cutting and fitting often involved when working with these rolls, which measure either 6 or 12 feet in width. If not cut to a precise fit around the edges the installation did not look neat, and a wrong cut could often ruin a large sheet of material.

THERE is an extraordinary sight now to be seen in Central Park, a vision more remarkable in its way than almost anything on that 843 acres. And it is not, strictly speaking, an alteration to the park at all. It is simply the Sheep Meadow, the vast open area that has over the years been the site for rock concerts, symphonic performances, operas and political rallies, looking for the first time in many, many years as it was intended to look - like a great, rolling, soft and brilliant green lawn. The meadow, which sits in the mid-60's just a bit east of Tavern on the Green and west of the Mall, has been completely resodded. For years now it has been more brown than green, worn by literally thousands of pairs of feet; now it has been transformed, and the vision of green it offers in the middle of the park is truly startling. We are not used to seeing a real lawn in Central Park, which more often than not tends to look like a run-down vacant lot, despite the efforts of the current Parks Commissioner, Gordon J. Davis, and the Central Park administrator, Elizabeth B. Barlow, to maintain the park in the face of diminishing city resources.

IF what is happening at Essence magazine is a result of the recession then Edward Lewis, the publisher, would say, ''Let's have some more of the same.'' The service magazine for black women, which celebrated its 10th anniversary with the May issue, had its best year as far as advertising goes last year, and for the first eight months of this year it is 13 percent ahead of 1979 in ad pages and 27 percent up in ad revenues.

At a meeting of Arab League foreign and economic ministers in Amman, Jordan, on July 5, Iraq will propose a new offensive, aimed at Western European governments, for achieving Palestinian statehood. Iraq takes the view that there is no longer any possibility at this stage of history for a negotiated settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict. Negotiation, Iraq believes, cannot be effective so long as the Israelis enjoy military superiority and America's unquestioned backing and assistance. Iraq has therefore decided on a campaign designed to undermine Israel's economic links with Europe, and to put pressure on America to choose between its interests in the European alliance and its commitment to Israel.

To the Editor: A Topics item of May 16 pointed to my concern over the deterioration of air transportation service in West Virginia following enactment of airline deregulation. It is true that I am distressed over the results of deregulation in my home state. It was sold to Congress on the basis of creating a freer environment, resulting in better service and lower fares. Instead, in many instances, we have suffered from a loss of airline seats and skyrocketing rates.v.est Virginia air service has suffered considerably following deregulation, but it does not stand alone. Arizona, Nebraska, Idaho, Oregon, Tennessee and Illinois have filed appeals with the Civil Aeronautics Board, protesting the board's determination of essential air service. Connecticut, Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont as well as the New England Regional Commission have been granted extensions of time for appeals preparation.

Without Franz Beckenbauer, and with Wim Rijsbergen in midfield for the first time, the Cosmos defeated the New England Tea Men by 2-1 at Giants Stadium tonight. The North American Soccer League game, which drew a crowd of 34,723, was clearly dominated by the Cosmos, who outshot the Tea Men, 26 to 8. One shot by the Cosmos hit the crossbar, and they missed numerous other chances before Giorgio Chinaglia and Johan Neeskens scored goals in the second half to secure the victory, the club's ninth in 11 games.
The 26 major league baseball owners meet in Chicago tomorrow to review and presumably ratify the agreement that averted a baseball strike last month.

Results of a large-scale study show a new drug called nifedipine to be dramatically effective in treating a rare form of angina pectoris and suggest the drug may be valuable for a much broader range of heart patients.

voters in five states CARTER AND KENNEDY TO MEET TODAY TO COPE WITH DEMOCRATILC BREACH: BUT SENATOR, AFTER VICTORIES IN CALIFORNIA AND JERSEY, STICKS TO DEMAND FOR DEBATE ON 'THE GREAT ISSUES' By HEDRICK SMITH

President Carter's primary campaign, formally begun six months ago today, succeeded in winning the delegates necessary for his renomination but failed to force Senator Edward M. Kennedy out of the race or to broaden the President's political base nationwide. This was the morning-after assessment offered today by several of the President's political aides, who said that they were more concerned about the problems inherent in the general election than about any they had faced in the primaries.

The Big Three auto makers sold less than 500,000 new cars in the United States in May, their worst performance in this important spring selling month since 1962. Sales for the final 10 days of the month fell 38.1 percent, compared with the same period last year, and this despite auto rebates, dealer incentive plans and dropping interest rates on auto loans.

Price increases on all 1980 Mazda car models ranging from $150 to $300 were announced yesterday by Mazda of Los Angeles, the United States affiliate of Toyo Kogyo, the Japanese car concern. The company said the increases were necessary because of higher production costs in Japan. The new prices were effective June 2.

SINCE its premiere in New York in 1957, Meredith Willson was saying, there probably hasn't been a week when his ''The Music Man'' wasn't being presented somewhere. Tonight, the musical, starring Dick Van Dyke as the endearing charlatan, Prof. Harold Hill, opens at the City Center in its first Broadway revival. Last month, Mr. Willson said over luncheon, ''The Music Man'' was put on by the graduating class of Beverly Hills High School. Patrick Cassidy, the son of the late Jack Cassidy and Shirley Jones, who played the female lead in the movie version, was in the cast. Needless to say, Mr. Willson and his wife, Rosemary, came down from their home in Mandeville Canyon for the performance.

Two hours before dawn, before Hempstead Avenue was choked with traffic trying to escape the parkway tieups at the Queens-Nassau line, a horse van rolled quietly into the Belmont Park stable area yesterday with four exhausted but relieved passengers. The fifth passenger, the Mexican horse they call Pikotazo, survived in better condition than his human entourage an ordeal that had started 51 hours earlier. But then, how could a horse know that one of the engines on a chartered turboprop plane carrying him to the Belmont Stakes had failed?

AS the Milwaukee Brewers' manager, George Bamberger had to make decisions: Whether to change pitchers. Whether to use a pinch-hitter. Whether to put on the hit and run. Whether to bunt. But on March 6, during spring training at Sun City, Ariz., he woke up in the middle of the night with a backache that turned out to be a mild heart attack. And now, after tests at Mount Sinai Hospital in Milwaukee, he was confronted by Dr. Donald Schmidt, with a new decision for him: Whether to have heart bypass surgery.

Bernard King, the basketball star suspended by the Utah Jazz, was sentenced to two suspended one-year jail terms and a $2,000 fine after having pleaded guilty today to reduced charges of attempted forcible sexual abuse, which are misdemeanors. The 23-year-old King stood before Judge Christine Durham, who told him that she was suspending the jail terms so that he could play basketball and continue treatment for alcoholism. She also placed him on two years' probation.
Miami United Press International John B. Anderson, independent Presidential candidate, visiting H aitian refugees in Miami. Mr. Anderson is seeking to place his name o n Florida ballot.

Tresaury Secretary G. William Miller said today that the fight against inflation would remain the Carter Administration's ''No.1 priority'' in spite of the sharp decline in the economy. Mr. Miller spoke with some exasperation after a series of questions from reporters about the Administration's plans following the drop in various statistical indicators of economic health. He said there is too much alarm over the indicators of an economic slowdown, which he called the ''bitter medicine'' taken in an effort to cool doubledigit inflation.

William E. Simon, former Secretary of the Treasury and now policy chairman of Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign, has volunteered to organize a Republican Citizens for Koch Committee. It would aid an expected re-election bid by Mayor Koch in 1981.

To the Editor: Your May 19 editorial on handgun restriction does a vast disservice to your readers. Had The Times bothered to examine the Gun Control Act of 1968 it would have found that the Federal gun law does, indeed, prohibit ''anyone from going to South Carolina ... and buying a dozen pistols for resale.''t is a Federal felony to exhibit false identification and make false statements in order to purchase any firearm outside of one's state of residence. It is another Federal felony to bring a firearm so acquired into the state in which one legally resides. These carry penalties of up to five years in jail and/or a $5,000 fine.

SCHOOL is out, summer approaches, the travel season is starting - so maybe it's a good idea to talk some more about automobile stereo, even though I am about to honk a sour note in the audio motorcade. The big push in highway hi-fi, as noted last week, is for more power. Even in-dash radio/cassette combos nowadays run up to 20 watts a channel, and with trunk-mounted power amplifiers automotive wattage escalates into the hundreds. Dispassionate observers may conclude that car-stereo has gone power-mad; but, as in most forms of madness, there is a nub of rationality. The idea is to have enough wattage to override road and motor noises without forcing the system into distortion. The idea has basic merit. At their best, high-powered systems encapsulate the traveler in their sound, isolating him from audible intrusions of the environment. Whether the acoustic displacement of the real world is really what you want is another question. But many people like it and, as a psycho-sensual experience, it's definitely worth a try.

The Industrial Union department of the A.F.L.- C.I.O., finding in a study that pension funds are often managed in a manner against the best interests of workers, recommended today that unions seek a greater voice in the investment of pension assets through collective bargaining. It was the first time that an arm of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations had taken a position on the controversial issue of union control of pensions, according to Howard D. Samuel, president of the department.

State Department officials said that American consular officials in Israel had visited Rabbi Meir Kahane, who has been in custody there since his arrest last month in connection with alleged terrorist activities against Arabs. Rabbi Kahane, 47 years old, who heads the militant Kach Movement and the Jewish Defense League, has dual American and Israeli citizenship, the State Department said, and was therefore eligible for the visit from consular officials.

If milk production continues at its current record pace, the Carter Administration may soon have to ask Congress to postpone another increase in dairy price supports scheduled for October, Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today. He acknowledged this would be politically risky in an election year, but he said that even the dairy industry was becoming concerned over the current $1 billion cost of the program, nearly twice the amount President Carter's upcoming budget provides.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 4 (UPI)--Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that he had agreed to a request by the President of Iran that he form a commission in the United States to investigate American involvement in Iran during the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

Three historic items suffered minor damage in a bomb explosion at the Statue of Liberty museum Tuesday night, the National Park Service said yesterday. The cost of the damage was estimated "conservatively" at $15,000.

The 26 major league baseball clubs completed 15 more rounds of the semiannual amateur draft by conference call yesterday, and they did so in secret. The New York Yankees, however, chose to announce their top two picks, while the New York Mets chose to announce none. The Yankees, who were not entitled to selections in Tuesday's first two rounds, chose on the third round Billy Cannon Jr., a shortstop at Broadmoar High School in Baton Rouge, La. Cannon is the son of the 1959 Heisman Trophy winner, Billy Cannon Sr. On the fourth round, the Yankees chose Stephen Madden, an outfielder from New Hartford, N.Y.

In the last days of the primary campaign, Senator Edward Kennedy flew around the country in what seemed the most hopeless of ventures. Mathematically, it was all over: President Carter was sure of a delegate majority. Yet those who saw Kennedy saw a man enjoying himself hugely. Early one morning he was on the docks in Newark, at 6:30 the next at an aircraft plant gate in Burbank, Calif. Along with serious talk there were easy jokes, often self-mocking. Looking at an old adobe building in San Jose, Calif., he said it reminded him -and here his voice dropped into a gloomy parody of liberal stump orators - ''of that old Republican economic policy.''

THE Richmond Market Garden Center, a new agricultural research and demonstration center in Pleasant Valley, N.Y., will open to the public tomorrow. It is designed to show urban and suburban residents how it is economically feasible to grow produce on small pieces of land. The center is named for Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of New York and the only member of the House Agriculture Committee to represent a completely urban district.
TO EUROPE AND LATIN AMERICA IN A BID TO WIN SUPPORT By ALAN RIDING

Harangues in this space and elsewhere calling for an official inquiry into the reasons for the failure of the mission to rescue the American hostages in Iran have been answered - in part - by the appointment of a Pentagon commission headed by a retired old salt, Adm. James Holloway 3d. The Holloway commission will limit its study to shortcomings in planning and hopes to tell the Joint Chiefs that all concerned did a grand job, but that next time somebody should check the weather and somebody else should order crew chiefs not to wash down the choppers with salt water just before a big mission. High-ranking officers are not inclined to expose command weaknesses.

CHICAGO PERHAPS the most famous architectural competition of the 20th century was the contest in 1922 to select a design for the skyscraper headquarters of The Chicago Tribune. The newspaper was committed to building an architectural monument, and it offered the then-staggering prize of $50,000 to the architect who came up with the design its judges found best. John Mead Howells and Raymond Hood won, and their Gothic tower on North Michigan Avenue, completed in 1924, remains one of this city's distinguished landmarks. But the significance of the competition did not end with the construction of the winning design: The Tribune published a book of all 260 entries, which went on to become something of a classic; thanks to the book, many of the other entries to the competition have become famous in their own right. Indeed, one of them, Eliel Saarinen's second-prize winner, has been among the most influential skyscraper designs ever conceived, despite the fact that it was never erected.

Allied Chemical Company's Union Texas Petroleum Corporation said it had signed an agreement to build two natural-gas processing plants in Oklahoma. * Gelco Corporation said that it had obtained a $75 million, eightyear unsecured revolving credit term loan agreement to finance expansion of the fleet operated by the its container-transport unit.

SUMMER is a-comin' in, and with it the time for prolonged holidays, long country weekends and open doors and windows; time to think about where you are going to put your new gold neck chains, your collection of uncirculated silver dollars, that small Tibetan lap rug, your 30-year-old silver service, when you're not home. Well, if you are thinking safe deposit box you'd better be quick about it, for those oblong steel caches appear to be more and more difficult to come by these late spring days.

Michael Manley, the Jamaican Prime Minister, said yesterday that his Government was planning a major refinancing of its external debt after Jamaica's fifth general election, which will likely come this fall. Mr. Manley indicated that the refinancing would be accomplished without the help of the International Monetary Fund, with which Jamaica has broken off negotiations.

Stepping over a large crack on the front steps of City Hall, the president of the New York State Trial Lawyers Association delivered to city officials yesterday a carton filled with written reports on 5,000 potholes, sidewalk crevices and broken curbs.

JERUSALEM, June 4--They are dreamers; they are coldly logical. They speak of violence, and of peace. Most importantly, the militant idealists who have established Jewish settlements on hilltops throughout the occupied Arab West Bank have established themselves as an influential force in Israel's political landscape.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 4--It was not a good night for Cuban or Puerto Rican pitchers in Royals Stadium tonight. The Kansas City Royals bombarded Luis Tiant and Ed Figueroa for 11 of their 12 hits and all of their runs in trouncing the Yankees, 9-3.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The Federal Communications Commission formally stripped RKO General of three large-city television stations today, setting the stage for a court challenge of the disciplinary move--one of the broadest in broadcast history.
PEKING, Thursday, June 5 (AP)-- Deng Xiaoping confirmed today that he plans to step down as senior deputy Prime Minister in late summer.

WASHINGTON, June 4--The United States and China were reported today to be close to signing a series of agreements to significantly expand their already flourishing relationship. Among the steps contemplated by State Department officials is the opening of Chinese consulates in New York, Chicago and Honolulu.
Prices in the credit markets moved higher yesterday, buoyed by the successful auction of the Government's new five-year notes and the apparent success of several large corporate offerings.
LEKKERKERK, the Netherlands-- Anneke Verkerk showed a visitor through her new home here the other day. "It's very tiny," she said, "but I think it will work out in time."

Gordie Howe, a man whose name had become synonymous with the sport of professional hockey during a career that spanned 32 active seasons in five decades, announced his retirement this morning. Handing his grandson, Travis, over to the waiting arms of his wife, the 52-year-old Howe stepped to the podium in front of a large gathering at the Hartford Hilton without a show of sentiment over the expected departure.

There was a time when Gator Conley journeyed out of Texas and people would icily ogle his western clothes. ''You'd think you had a wart on the side of your head or something,'' says Gator, the name that is tooled into his leather belt and the only name most folks know him by. Nowadays, when Gator ventures outside Texas he runs into crowds of men decked out in western garb just like his, and he says, ''People don't look at you like a weirdo anymore.''

A major exhibition of German Expressionist art will open at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum on Nov. 14 and remain on view through Jan. 18. Organized jointly by the directors of the Guggenheim, San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and Museum Folwang, in Essen, West Germany, the exhibition, which encompasses the years 1905 to 1920, will show works by 18 artists, with emphasis on central figures in the movement: Nolde, Kirchner, Heckel, Marc, Kandinsky, Kokoschka and Beckmann.

Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the army strongman, has completed formation of a new administration dominated by generals that overshadows the civilian cabinet and existing Government, according to Korean and diplomatic sources. The general, acting behind the scenes and with no publicity in the heavily censored Korean press, made his move against American wishes but has reinforced his grip on power in this strategic nation where nearly 40,000 American troops are based.

NABLUS, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, June 4--The general strike called to protest Monday's bombing attacks against three Palestinian Mayors fell apart today as Israeli soldiers here and in several other towns forced Arab merchants to open their shops.

ALBANY, June 4--A Federal appeals court ruled today that Governor Carey could not be forced to find money to pay for the panel that monitors conditions at the Staten Island Developmental Center for the retarded if the Legislature did not want him to. The center was formerly known as Willowbrook.

Nelson Wright Freeman, a former president and chief executive officer of Tenneco Inc., died of cancer yesterday in Houston after a long illness. He was 71 years old.
ATLANTA, June 4--Jack Potts, a 35year-old convicted murderer, won a stay of execution tonight after he agreed to join in efforts to fight his death sentence.

WASHINGTON, June 4--A coalition of women's groups issued a warning to President Carter and the Democratic Party today that it does not consider the party's Presidential nomination settled despite the results of yesterday's primaries.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 4--Federal investigators say they have no suspect or motive in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr. and little prospect of solving the case unless a weapon is found or someone comes forward.

Jimmie Lee Allen was sentenced yesterday to four consecutive prison terms of 25 years to life for the murders of four Bedford Hills residents in May 1979. Acting Justice Duncan S. McNab imposed the sentence in State Supreme Court. Joseph West, the prosecutor, said the sentence provided a minimum of 112 1/2 years in jail - 100 for the murders and 12 1/2 years for a robbery in Brooklyn. Mr. Allen, 41 years old, was sentenced last February for the robbery. His co-defendant in the murders, Junius Gray, also 41, will be sentenced Friday.

Pete Rose singled in two key runs, and the Philadelphia Phillies beat the Pittsburgh Pirates by 4-3 tonight as Steve Carlton posted his 10th victory of the season. The left-handed Carlton stretched his league-leading won-lost record to 10-2, scattering seven hits. John Candelaria (2-5), the Pirate starter, was the loser.

Robert Young is probably best-known to television viewers as ''Marcus Welby, M.D.,'' the invariably cheerful family doctor whose skills seemed to cover every known malady. Now the 73-year-old actor is under a doctor's care, suffering from what Dr. Eduardo Ricaurte called hereditary ''chemical depression.'' In Rock Island, Ill., Dr. Ricaurte said yesterday that Mr. Young's problem, brought on by a lack of a biogenic amine, a chemical derivative of ammonia, causes the actor to appear ''dispirited, decelerated, joyless and unmotivated.''

NOW that the money squeeze has eased and interest rates have dropped, takeover rumors are being heard again - some of them, it appears, inspired by traders looking for quick profits. The one that got the most currency yesterday concerned the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), which, rumor has it, is planning to purchase the nuclear division of Kerr-McGee. According to the rumor, Elf Aquitaine of France, which recently suspended efforts to acquire Kerr-McGee, would buy the balance of the company. The rumored price: $120 to $140 a Kerr-McGee share for the package.

Willie Carson rode to his second successive victory in the English Derby today, guiding Henbit, the second favorite, to a three-quarter-length triumph over what was considered one of the weakest fields in years. Henbit, who Carson said stumbled twice during the rich race, walked off lame afterward. It was reported that he had broken a bone in a foreleg and might have to be retired.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, in the last eight Presidential primaries Tuesday, won the regions that a Democrat needs in a general election, but President Carter won the delegates that a Democrat needs to be nominated.

Our ceilings, he pointed out, are barely taller than he is; well below the normal eight-foot height. We'd never noticed. We're 5 feet 7 and 5 feet 4.

EAST BERLIN--When the official driver knocked at the door of the East German Finance Minister's country house one morning in May, there was no answer. Inside, the man found the two occupants, Finance Minister Siegfried Bohm and his wife, Ruth, Iying dead.

A Federal District Court judge in New York declared yesterday that the Interbank Card Association had a program to issue traveler's checks that did not violate antitrust laws. The ruling cleared the way for the sponsor of MasterCard to issue MasterCard traveler's checks by as early as the first quarter of 1981.

WASHINGTON, June 4--In a stunning rebuke to both President Carter and the Congressional Democratic leadership, the House of Representatives and Senate voted overwhelmingly today to reject a fee on imported oil that Mr. Carter imposed in March.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 4--Californians rejected a proposal to slash income taxes by an overwhelming margin yesterday, but there were indications that the outcome was not a result of a change of heart by voters who avidly embraced a similar cut in property taxes in 1978.

WASHINGTON, June 4--In a meeting today with representatives of the polluted Love Canal area, Federal officials offered to help displaced residents finance the purchase of new houses but said again the Government could not legally buy the old houses.

An off-duty agent for the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service was killed last night in Brooklyn when his .38 revolver was fired while it was being handled by one of two male companions sitting in a car with him at Avenue P and Ocean Avenue. The agent was identified as Joseph Aiello, 27 years old, of 1542 East 27th Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Aiello's companions told the police that the gun went off accidentally and a single bullet struck the agent in the head.

Fred Lieb, a longtime sportswriter and the first writer inducted to the Baseball Hall of Fame, died today at the age of 92. Mr. Lieb had been moved in February from his home in St. Petersburg, Fla., to a nursing home here by his daughter, Mrs. R.L. Pearsall.

The Maryland Racing Commission today denied a request by the owners of Genuine Risk that Codex be disqualified as the winner of the Preakness Stakes. The commission's Thoroughbred Board, having deliberated 55 minutes on the third day of hearings at Pimlico Race Course, voted by 3 to 1 to uphold the ruling by three stewards that Codex did not foul Genuine Risk on the final turn of the Preakness on May 17 at Pimlico.

TOKYO, June 4--The Toyota Motor Company may set up its first North American assembly plant in Canada, a source of various auto parts that it uses, Seisi Kato, an executive of the company, said today.
Sugar futures rebounded yesterday on renewed speculative buying and short-covering by the trade after a downward correction ended in London and carried over to the New York exchange.
AS the Milwaukee Brewers' manager, George Bamberger had to make decisions: Whether to change pitchers. Whether to use a pinch-hitter.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI)--The next Presidential inauguration will take place on the West Front of the Capitol, facing the White House, for the first time in history, a Congressional committee decided today.
ALBANY, June 4--The Senate and Assembly Health Committees have agreed to press for the legalization of marijuana for therapeutic medical use, particularly for cancer and glaucoma patients.

When legislators argued that New York couldn't afford to increase welfare benefits, Governor Carey was saying courageously that it could and should. But now Mr. Carey has shifted, to a plan that is a sorry, stingy gesture to 500,000 families in desperate need.
HOUSTON, June 4 (UPI)--Fred Lieb, a longtime sportswriter and the first writer inducted by the Baseball Hall of Fame, died yesterday at the age of 92.

A major increase in New York City subway and bus fares became a virtual certainty tonight when the majority leader of the Republican-controlled State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, told Governor Carey that he would not accept any of the Governor's plan to subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's deficit. The Republicans were expected to announce their own subsidy plan tomorrow, increasing the M.T.A.'s financing from existing state revenues and forgiving $100 million the authority owes the state. The plan would require some type of fare increase, but details of the proposal and the size of any increase were not immediately known.

Flowers Annuals Finish setting out all seedlings. Seed directly fast growing flowers such as zinnias, marigolds, gaillardias, sweet alyssum, cosmos. Pinch back snapdragons and petunias to induce branching. Perennials: Remove faded flowers from poppies, candytufts, peonies, irises. Feed fall-blooming asters and mums. Plant new perennials after soil is prepared and enriched. Pinch terminal shoots from mums to induce branching. Roses: Spray or dust every 10 days to two weeks for black spot/mildew control. Remove faded flowers. Feed once again toward end of the month. Daffodils: Pull up ripened yellow foliage. This is a good time to dig and replant clumps of overgrown bulbs. Vegetables Cultivate lightly and apply mulch between rows to keep soil moisture in, and weeds out. Start indoors the seeds of broccoli, cabbage, Brussels sprouts and cauliflower for planting outdoors in late July. Sow another row of carrots and beets. Cut asparagus until end of the month, then stalks must be allowed to grow. Apply fertilizer. Fruit Trees Hand-thin apples, peaches and pears so young fruits are six inches apart. Continue disease/pest control multispray mixture at least every two weeks and after any heavy rainfall. Lawns Set mowers to cut high (two or two and one-half inches). Mow often; do not rake up clippings, which supply nitrogen to grass. Use herbicides with caution in warm weather. Be alert for chinch bugs that may appear toward end of month. Insect Pests Gypsy Moth: If rampant, sprays on particular trees may be necessary; however, trees refoliate later in the summer. Slugs: Sprinkle with table salt when seen or use metaldehyde baits where there are no pets or children. Or circle cultivated areas with a band of wood ashes or sand to discourage their crawling. Aphids: Watch rose buds and nasturtiums particularly; use malathion or Orthene. Taxus Weevil: Watch leaves of rhododendrons and azaleas for scalloped leaf edges, a sign of their feeding; spray foliage with Orthene to control adults before egg laying. Lace Bug: Examine undersides of andromeda foliage; if present use Orthene or malathion. Shrubs Cut faded flowers from lilacs; scratch in around root area a half cupful or so of wood ashes to encourage better bloom. Prune spirea, mock orange, weigela, viburnums. Carefully dead head (pinch out faded flowers) from rhododendron. Good time to prune overgrown shrubs. Trees Check trunks of dogwood and mountain ash for oozing sap and frass, signs of borer entry; poke wire up into hole to kill borers or use commercial borer pastes. On dogwoods, cut out the upright growing branches called water sprouts. On magnolias, prune out suckers growing up from base of trunks. Spray birches again for control of leaf miner. Contract with tree arborists to thin out overgrown shade trees.
TO HELP RESTORE SERIES By KATHLEEN TELTSCH
Why have interest rates dropped so far so fast?

CORONADO, Calif., June 4 (AP)-- The 3-point goal, dismissed by some followers of the National Basketball Association as a gimmick that had no place in the rules of the game, is now a permanent feature of professional basketball.

President Carter announced today that he would nominate Don A. Zimmerman, minority labor counsel to the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, to be a member of the five-member National Labor Relations Board. Mr. Zimmerman, who is 40 years old and a native of Los Angeles, would succeed Betty Southard Murphy, who resigned last Dec. 16. The Senate must confirm the nomination.

Mike Buggs, a pinch-runner, scored on a throwing error by Ross Jones in the ninth inning tonight, enabling California to register a 4-3 victory and eliminate Miami from the College World Series. California, winning for the third straight time since a first-round loss, moved into the championship round against Arizona, which defeated Hawaii by 6-4 tonight in 11 innings.

The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges.

City people are often enchanted by the sounds they hear on a summer night in the country. They lie abed imagining the shapes of the animals that call, peep or hoot, or speculate about the destination, origin and cargo of the trains whistling sadly in the distance. But the imagination can also be stimulated in the city when the air-conditioning fails and windows are flung wide.

An off-duty agent for the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service was killed last night in Brooklyn when his .38 revolver was fired while it was being handled by one of two male companions sitting in a car with him at Avenue P and Ocean Avenue.

NEPTUNE, N.J.,June 4--A 31-yearold man, who had been accused of assaulting his former girlfriend, was killed here this morning when the stolen plane he was flying crashed into a house where the woman had taken refuge. Flames destroyed the house, but no one else was injured.
The Goldman Band began receiving money pledges yesterday aimed at preserving the free outdoor concerts the popular musical ensemble has performed for 62 years.

CALGARY, Alberta, June 4 (UPI)-- The police believe a cult is responsible for a mysterious series of animal mutilations similar to several cases last fall in which cattle were found with genitals and other organs removed.

Lieut. Gov. Mario Cuomo addressed the graduating class of Queens College yesterday and urged its members to reverse a trend among citizens and play a greater role in the nation's affairs.

SHEET vinyl floor covering--the type that comes in wide rolls, rather than in individual squares or tiles--has been popular for many years, and in recent years its popularity has increased as manufacturers have introduced highly flexible, easy-to-work-with versions that are designed for do-it-yourself installers.

PARIS, June 4--Playing in the intense heat of a late-afternoon sun, Harold Solomon upset Guillermo Vilas and reached the semifinals of the French open tennis championships today. They battled for three and a half hours on the clay, which is not unusual in matches between the two baseliners.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Industrial Union department of the A.F.L.C.I.O., finding in a study that pension funds are often managed in a manner against the best interests of workers.

Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel was quoted yesterday as saying that his Government intended to establish 10 new settlements in the occupied West Bank and that these would be the last ones to be set up there. He was said to have expressed the hope in an interview that his pledge of no further West Bank settlements would please the United States, which has been trying to bring about a resumption of talks between Egypt and Israel on autonomy for Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

Two Arabic-speaking gunmen walked into the Iraqi Embassy here today and opened fire, killing one Iraqi employee and wounding another. The assailants, who reportedly shouted ''Viva Khomeini!'' as they fired, left a brown leather suitcase containing a time bomb and fled. But embassy guards wounded one assailant outside and captured him. The other escaped on foot.

To the Editor: Anyone visiting the much-vaunted Picasso exhibit at the Museum of Modern Art is in for an unpleasant surprise: He will find that it is, apparently, a show for the handicapped. lthough, nowhere stated, there can be little doubt that the myriad absurdities that hedge the arrangements for this exhibition were imposed on the museum by Federal regulations, as one of the sponsors is the National Endowment for the Humanities.

an undulating ribbon of stainless-steel-coated glass panels and mirrors that Gunnar Birkerts, its architect, calls ''a linear periscope.'' The museum is a monument to man's ingenious handling of a material that was first formed naturally by volcanoes in the Stone Age. It covers 3,500 years of history in provocative displays of more than 19,000 objects. Conceived to tell the history of glass with masterworks as well as more conventional objects, the spaces within the museum reflect the highs and lows of developments in glassmaking.

Oppenheimer 086,2,675,0SAN ANTONIO - Maybe it is just Presidential fever that is imposing a national inferiority complex on this country. We are barraged daily by declarations of our national weakness and impending demise. Bombarded by politicians, columnists and the defense lobby, we are convinced (the polls show it) that America is a weak, pitiful giant and that the Russians are taking over the world. But if we examine Soviet advances, we note that gains in recent years have been made mainly in countries that are impoverished and burdensome rather than beneficial: Angola, Cambodia, Ethiopia, Laos, Libya, Southern Yemen.
