The price of gold jumped as much as $25 an ounce yesterday, while the dollar was mixed on major currency markets. The British pound rebounded somewhat from its steep losses in the previous day's session.

Federal investigators say they have no suspect or motive in the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr. and little prospect of solving the case unless a weapon is found or someone comes forward. Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Fort Wayne Police Department say that they have no indications of involvement by either white or black extremist groups or individuals, local or otherwise; no evidence of internal strife in the National Urban League, of which Mr. Jordan is president, and nothing to substantiate a theory that the victim had been stalked across the country to be shot in front of his motel room at 2 A.M. last Thursday.

The Government today approved a Common Market plan to reduce Britain's contribution to the market's budget and discussed in a 10-hour Cabinet session how to pay for its share of the cost. The issue of West Germany's increased contribution has strained Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's governing coalition and prompted critics to charge that the Government was poorly prepared when it went to Brussels last week for the talks that produced the new financing arrangements. Under the plan Britain's annual contribution to the market will be cut from $2.5 billion to $890 million and West Germany will be required to pay an extra $1.4 billion a year.

A tractor-trailer truck carrying 20 tons of lollipop sticks ran off Route 117 at about 2 A.M. today and overturned, scattering its cargo. Part of Route 117 was closed for hours after the accident.

Anthony DeRosa, a business associate of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, was indicted yesterday on charges of aiding the escape of the convicted murderer from the Brooklyn House of Detention for Men on Saturday. In a separate indictment, the Brooklyn grand jury charged Mr. Jacobson in connection with the escape, which allegedly took place after Mr. DeRosa, posing as a lawyer, visited him in the jail.

Paul L. Mahoney, founder and former chief executive officer of the Spraylat Corporation of Mount Vernon, N.Y., manufacturers of protective industrial coatings, died Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

Gasoline inventories rose 2.2 million last week, to 265.7 million barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Despite the Memorial Day holiday, traditionally a weekend of heavy demand for gasoline, analysts say this year's overall trend of a decline in driving prevailed. Daily gasoline production also increased 400,000 barrels from the week before, to 6.7 million barrels. Supplies of distillate fuel totaled 186.1 million barrels, climbing 4.8 million. According to the institute spokesman, the increase reflects a normal seasonal pattern.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Members of Congress urged the Carter Administration today to provide financial aid immediately to state and local governments to help them deal with the influx of Cuban refugees. But they said they saw no prospect of Congress's passing special legislation this year to clarify the refugees' legal status.
BALTIMORE, June 4 (UPI)--The Maryland Racing Commission today denied a request by the owners of Genuine Risk that Codex be disqualified as the winner of the Preakness Stakes.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, June 4 (Reuters)--China has signed a contract to buy 1.27 million tons of Canadian wheat and will pay in cash, Canadian Wheat Board officials said today. It is the first purchase of Canadian wheat in which the Chinese have not used credit.

Billions for defense - but not one dime for less energy dependence. That, apparently, is the prevailing sentiment on Capitol Hill. The same Congress that responded to a sense of declining American power by increasing military spending and reinstituting draft registration is unwilling to allow the President even a token effort at discouraging oil imports. It has now voted to deny Mr. Carter the right to levy a 10-cent-agallon fee on foreign crude that is refined into gasoline. The only hope for saving the fee is that a sufficient number of Congressmen will look to their responsibility and refuse to override the President's veto.

The Chelsea Theater Cabaret will end its ''Great Ladies'' series with ''An Evening with Sister and Miss Lexie,'' based on the writings of Eudora Welty. It will be performed June 18 to 21 and 26 to 28 at 11 P.M. The one-woman show will feature Brenda Currin, who, with the help of Miss Welty, adapted the writer's material for the stage. The ''Sister'' portion of the program is taken from Miss Welty's early short story ''Why I Live at the P.O.'' In it, Sister explains how callous treatment from her family ''forces'' her to take up residency at the local Mississippi post office. ''Miss Lexie'' is based on a character from the author's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, ''The Optimist's Daughter.''

When the official driver knocked at the door of the East German Finance Minister's country house one morning in May, there was no answer. Inside, the man found the two occupants, Finance Minister Siegfried Bohm and his wife, Ruth, lying dead. According to a police investigation that has never been published but that was disclosed privately to diplomats and other officials, Mrs. Bohm killed her husband with his revolver and then turned the gun on herself.

Dr. Lee William Gregg, head of the department of psychology and associate dean of the College of Humanities and Social Sciences at Carnegie-Mellon University here, died today after a long illness at the age of 54.

Anneke Verkerk showed a visitor through her new home here the other day. ''It's very tiny,'' she said, ''but I think it will work out in time.'' Mrs. Verkerk, 27 years old, her husband and their two children, five years old and two, had just a few days earlier moved into a mobile home on a lot that used to be an ice-skating rink in this little town near Rotterdam. The Verkerks are one of 269 families who were ordered out of their homes in a housing development here when it was found that their water supplies had been polluted by waste chemicals buried a decade ago.

Administration forces in the House tried today to fight off crippling amendments to a $5 billion foreign aid authorization for fiscal 1981. As they did so, however, they were conscious that they had still not been able to obtain enactment of an $8.1 billion foreign aid appropriation for fiscal 1980, which ends in less than four months.

To the Editor: As President Carter and Ronald Reagan achieve mathematical certainty of nomination in August, additional attention will be focused upon their choices for Vice President.$ Most of this attention will be directed at the Republican slate. It is generally being taken for granted that Walter Mondale will continue to be Carter's running mate.

Lawyers disagreed sharply yesterday on the impact of New York's new divorce measure, which was passed by the Legislature Tuesday and is expected to be signed shortly by Governor Carey. The measure requires judges to distribute property in divorce settlements on the basis of the needs and contributions of husbands and wives. Under present law, property stays in the hands of the spouse who holds the title. The new measure also allows a judge to decide whether to limit the time alimony, which the measure calls ''maintenance,'' must be paid, instead of being required to award it for life.

Mayor Koch said yesterday that he favored competitive bidding on a redevelopment plan for a valuable stretch of real estate on 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues, and that as a result he has been withholding approval of a proposal by a private group aided by a number of large corporations. The Mayor said he was not prejudging the issue and that the city would decide ''within two weeks'' how to proceed on plans for the Times Square area. He said the city would act after it received a recommendation from the City Planning Commission chairman, Herbert J. Sturz.

To the Editor: These are distressing times for the future of our country. School boards all across the land are cutting budgets and reducing programs and services. This is the very time when we should be spending more to educate the increasing numbers of children from the minorities and the poor to insure that they will be brought into the mainstream of American life. am not sure that this experiment in democracy has worked or will work in the future. We are suffering now from the waste of too much young talent in the past. We must change our ways. CHARLES D. WALTERS Prof. of Education, Hampton Institute Hampton, Va., May 30, 1980

IN one of the 11 vignettes that make up Ned Jackson's ''Scenes From the Everyday Life,'' running through the weekend at the Public Theater, Diane Kagan sits at a desk and extols every inanimate object within reach, from her typewriter to each individual pencil. Caressingly, she expresses her rapture for her ''tools.'' In our minds, we make a quick substitution: playwright for character. Clearly it is Mr. Jackson who is sitting at his desk desperately trying to overcome writer's block. ''What will I write about?'' he asks, and then answers, ''I'll write about my pencil.'' Most of the sketches are about people trying to combat ennui by immersing themselves in some questionable pursuit, as if in the misguided belief that the intensity of the activity would automatically make it interesting. The fact is that the scenes are largely a demonstration of boring from within.

President Carter intervened today in the Congressional deadlock over the 1981 budget but was unable to resolve the dispute that is threatening to bankrupt some government programs. Mr. Carter met at the White House for 50 minutes with the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees, Representative Robert N. Giaimo, Democrat of Connecticut, and Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina.

Hunter College held its 148th commencement yesterday, in the Felt Forum, at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue. Two new buildings that may enable the college to hold its graduation ceremonies on its campus on Park Avenue at 68th Street are more than two years from completion, A procession of 850 students in black robes with purple and white hoods began the two-hour ceremony. Almost 3,500 parents and relatives were present.

Sculptures popped up all over this city today, from a tiny structure in a window at the Smithsonian Institution headquarters to a huge aluminum giant stretchng and yawning his way out of the ground at Hains Point, in the southwest section of the city. For four days, the monuments and classic public buildings, the parks and squares, are the backdrop for the 11th International Sculpture Conference, which began today. From 35 countries and the United States, 3,000 sculptors, including Isamu Noguchi, Edward Kienholz, George Segal and Richard Serra, convened to discuss their art and the state of contemporary sculpture.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; Protestant Politician Is Slain In Northern Ireland Ambush

Steve Carlton and Mike Schmidt of the Philadelphia Phillies are the National League pitcher and player of the month for May, respectively, the league said yesterday. Carlton had a 6-1 won-lost record during May with a 1.65 earned-run average. Schmidt walloped 12 home runs and drove in 29 runs. He leads the league in home runs, runs batted in, total bases and slugging percentage.

By a close margin, a sampling of voters in New Jersey approve requiring public schools to teach sex education. They also still favor the gambling casinos authorized four years ago, especially if the casinos are confined to their present sites in Atlantic City. Both sex education and gambling have agitated New Jersey politics for years, and on Tuesday, as voters in the state's primary election left the polls, 1,432 of them filled out questionaires for The New York Times/CBS News Poll, which contained questions on both issues.

Jack Potts, a 35-year-old convicted murderer, won a stay of execution tonight after he agreed to join in efforts to fight his death sentence. The stay was granted by Federal District Judge William C. O'Kelley, who had turned down a request by a friend and a cousin of Mr. Potts to stay the execution, scheduled for tomorrow.

Mr. Bemberg's addled domestic drama, which opened last night at the Theater de Lys, is the kind of evening for which the word excruciating was invented. A few unappetizing characters are set down in a quaint New Hampshire living room and proceed to claw at one another for two long acts. One scene would have been more than enough. This play announces all that it has on its mind - and it's not much -in the first five minutes. After that, rigor mortis sets in. The living room belongs to a quaint New England family named Carsters. They're not a fun crowd. The brother, Bayard, is a priggish, megalomaniacal, middle-aged history professor who wears suspenders, a vest and a cardigan all at the same time. He's so uptight he makes Richard M. Nixon look like Gene Kelly. The sister, Harriet, is a 35-year-old, mentallly unbalanced spinster who wants to escape Bayard and marry a dashing young carpenter next door. Another brother, Andrew, shows up after a two-decade absence to settle some old family scores. Andrew has lately been in Rio de Janeiro, where he has picked up a drinking problem, a beloved pet mongoose and an extensive wardrobe of loud Hawaiian shirts.

Nelson Wright Freeman, a former president and chief executive officer of Tenneco Inc., died of cancer yesterday in Houston after a long illness. He was 71 years old. Mr. Freeman joined Tenneco in 1943 as manager of personnel and rose to the Houston-based company's highest echelon, where he served for nine years, in which the company's assets more than doubled. He retired Dec. 31, 1978.

The petitioners are the Crocker Com- mercial Services, the Irving Factors Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Bank. Debts amount to about $20,000. TEHERAN, 1960. A warm evening. The courtyard in which we were sitting was not very beautiful. There was a narrow strip of ground that ran along the edge of the wall, spotted with shrubbery and some insignificant roses; the rest was flagstone surrounding the customary small pool for ablutions, set like a turquoise in the center.

CORNING,N.Y. THE Corning Museum of Glass, housing the most comprehensive collection of glass ever assembled under one roof, opened here Sunday in its new home --an undulating ribbon of stainless-steel-coated glass panels and mirrors that Gunnar Birkerts, its architect, calls "a linear periscope."

SEOUL, South Korea, June 4--Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the army strongman, has completed formation of a new administration dominated by generals that overshadows the civilian cabinet and existing Government, according to Korean and diplomatic sources.

SCHOOL is out, summer approaches, the travel season is starting--so maybe it's a good idea to talk some more about automobile stereo, even though I am about to honk a sour note in the audio motorcade.

Price increases on all 1980 Mazda car models ranging from $150 to $300 were announced yesterday by Mazda of Los Angeles, the United States affiliate of Toyo Kogyo, the Japanese car concern. The company said the increases were necessary because of higher production costs in Japan. The new prices were effective June 2.

ALWAYS a master of the minimal, Samuel Beckett has continually worked at refining his vision, and his later plays are so short, so intense, that they seem to pivot on a single image. In the case of ''Footfalls'' and ''Not I,'' which Lawrence Sacharow has staged with appropriate austerity at La Mama, those images, a woman pacing a thin, white line on the floor and a spectral mouth floating in the dark, are stark indeed. But they are also powerful in their attenuation. They compress the author's lasting preoccupations with death and guilt into one dramatic gesture. A kind of fugue for two voices, ''Footfalls'' is the first and more substantial work. Suffering from a kind of metaphysical insomnia, a middle-aged woman named May, the name of Beckett's mother, walks back and forth endlessly, the clap of her heels on the floor marking the passage of time as insistently as any clock. It is a striking if somewhat self-contained tableau, and the vacant-eyed May, played with deliberation and restrained emotion by Margo Lee Sherman, looks hauntingly like the woman in Edvard Munch's painting ''The Scream.''

A coalition of women's groups issued a warning to President Carter and the Democratic Party today that it does not consider the party's Presidential nomination settled despite the results of yesterday's primaries. The group said that it would promote an open convention in August and that its support of the party's nominee would depend on a serious commitment to women's rights in the next two months. Iris Mitgang, chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus, noted that a continuing battle for the nomination would give leverage to women's rights activists seeking concessions from the candidates. ''We are elated that the situation turned out as it did last night,'' she said, referring to Senator Edward M. Kennedy's strong showing in the final round of primaries and his refusal to concede the nomination to President Carter.
companies' growth rates/table of top 10 drinks By STEVE LOHR

The first United States Government ship since 1949 docked here today. American officials said the arrival of the research ship Oceanographer opened a new era in expanded scientific relations between China and the United States and underlined the continued improvement in diplomatic ties. A small fleet of Government tugboats, barges and ferries accompanied the Oceanographer through the crowded harbor. As it nudged toward the quay and a welcoming party of Chinese and American officials, a coal barge crashed into the side of a police launch directing river traffic away from the American ship. The damaged police boat sped to shore.

City people are often enchanted by the sounds they hear on a summer night in the country. They lie abed imagining the shapes of the animals that call, peep or hoot, or speculate about the destination, origin and cargo of the trains whistling sadly in the distance. But the imagination can also be stimulated in the city when the airconditioning fails and windows are flung wide. Here follows a ''2d Avenue Nature Diary'': 1:15 A.M. A truck with square iron wheels turns corner and proceeds south. What kind of cargo requires such a vehicle and steel containers with loose lids? 2:07 A.M. Sixteen or more drunken persons argue over which saloon offers the best prospects after two o'clock in the morning. The naturalist aims to identify the sound of the winner and determine how many form a nasal sub-species from Philadelphia. Do they always travel in a pack? Are they old enough for antlers? 3:42 A.M. A fire engine from the little house around the corner leaves on a perilous assignment. What a lovely whistle! Will its mate soon follow? How it lingers at the corner, calling, calling. 4:26 A.M. A beaver resembling an air compressor sets to work on a sidestreet dam. Is it a green telephone beaver, a blue electric beaver or an orange consolidated telegraph variety? 5:45 A.M. The scavengers. They rattle their clever tails as they roll up the garbage bags from Sloan's birdfeeder. Do they attack people? 6:15 A.M. A crazy sound from the terrace. Is it Superman? Is it a plane? No. It's a bird!

Californians rejected a proposal to slash income taxes by an overwhelming margin yesterday, but there were indications that the outcome was not a result of a change of heart by voters who avidly embraced a similar cut in property taxes in 1978. The new measure, known as Proposition 9, which would have cut state income tax rates in half, was defeated by 61 percent to 39 percent. In contrast, Proposition 13, which sharply reduced local property taxes, was adopted by a 2-to-1 margin two years ago.

Among the thousands of acres that Burlington Northern Inc. acquired over the years, and put out of mind, was the land on the top of Mount St. Helens, which blew apart in the volcanic eruption of mid-May. ''What we now own up there is mostly crater,'' said S.G. Merryman, vice president of timber and land for the diversified railroad company. About 640 acres of Burlington mountaintop disappeared into the still-smoldering crater just below the peak, or drifted across the country as fine ash after that first big eruption in May.

The Government today reported the first decline in two and a half years in the commitment rate on mortgages. The commitment rate is the interest rate a thrift institution agrees to charge on a mortgage to be closed at a future date. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which oversees the nation's savings and loan associations, said the average commitment rate fell to 15.72 percent in May from a record 16.59 percent in April. It was the first drop in this lending rate since October 1977 and the largest on record, the bank board added. The decline indicates that conventional mortgage interest rates are coming down.

THE past decade has been one during which the machine-tool industry has sought to make major jumps in technology, and the concept of numerical control - computerized systems of machining parts with minimal assistance from operators - has become widely accepted. One such system, direct numerical control, or D.N.C., seeks to tie machines together into a system controlled by a central computer. Introduced in the early 1970's, it was part of an effort to cut the enormous amount of wasted time in shops, where parts spent as much as 95 percent of the time waiting in bins as they moved from one machine to another.

Lawyers disagreed sharply yesterday on the impact of New York's new divorce measure, which was passed by the Legislature Tuesday and is expected to be signed shortly by Governor Carey.

LEDYARD, Conn., June 4 (AP)--A tractor-trailer truck carrying 20 tons of lollipop sticks ran off Route 117 at about 2 A.M. today and overturned, scattering its cargo. Part of Route 117 was closed for hours after the accident.
The house tour season continues, with four events of interest scheduled for the coming week:

MEXICO CITY, June 4--El Salvador's main opposition coalition has begun a major effort in Western Europe and Latin America to win sympathy and financial support for its armed struggle against the United States-backed junta.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4-- Ole Algard, Norway's highly respected delegate to the United Nations, has some disturbing news for the Carter Administration. Mr. Algard is convinced that the critical Egyptian-Israeli talks over the fate of Palestinian Arabs have come to an indefinite halt and the time is now ripe for a new approach: bring West Bank Arabs to the bargaining table and invite the Palestine Liberation Organization to serve as their representative.

EPSOM, England, June 4-- Willie Carson rode to his second successive victory in the English Derby today, guiding Henbit, the second favorite, to a three-quarter-length triumph over what was considered one of the weakest fields in years.

Hunter College held its 148th commencement yesterday, in the Felt Forum, at 34th Street and Eighth Avenue. Two new buildings that may enable the college to hold its graduation ceremonies on its campus on Park Avenue at 68th Street are more than two years from completion.

LOS ANGELES, June 4--Among the thousands of acres that Burlington Northern Inc. acquired over the years, and put out of mind, was the land on the top of Mount St. Helens, which blew apart in the volcanic eruption of mid-May.
Nelson Bunker Hunt is still putting the finishing touches on his crumbling silver empire.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)--President Carter intervened today in the Congressional deadlock over the 1981 budget but was unable to resolve the dispute that is threatening to bankrupt some government programs.

Michael Manley, the Jamaican Prime Minister, said yesterday that his Government was planning a major refinancing of its external debt after Jamaica's fifth general election, which will likely come this fall.

Several major banks reduced their prime rate yesterday by a full percentage point, to 13 percent. Their action undercut banks that only last week lowered to 14 percent the interest they charge their most creditworthy corporate customers. The prime rate has now reached its lowest level since last September. The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third-largest bank, was the first to announce yesterday's reduction, followed by the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, the nation's fifth-largest bank, and the Marine Midland Bank, the 13th-largest. The Manufacturers Bank in Los Angeles also joined the downward move.

The New York Rangers are negotiating with Lars-Erik Sjoberg, veteran defenseman and team captain of the Winnipeg Jets, with an eye toward making him their chief European scout. Sjoberg, a native of Sweden, does not plan to return to the Jets for the next National Hockey League season. He is interested in joining the Rangers because he has an export-import business in New Jersey and because he would like to return to Sweden within the next two years.

A Federal appeals court ruled today that Governor Carey could not be forced to find money to pay for the panel that monitors conditions at the Staten Island Developmental Center for the retarded if the Legislature did not want him to. The center was formerly known as Willowbrook. The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York City reversed a lower-court order that Mr. Carey somehow find $342,000 in state funds to keep the panel operating. The action leaves in doubt the future of the panel, which oversees state compliance with an agreement to improve conditions at the center.

When legislators argued that New York couldn't afford to increase welfare benefits, Governor Carey was saying courageously that it could and should. But now Mr. Carey has shifted, to a plan that is a sorry, stingy gesture to 500,000 families in desperate need. The Governor proposes raising benefits by 10 percent for just six months, starting Oct. 1. By describing the supplement as an energy subsidy, he hopes Washington will not consider it an increase, which would trigger a reduction of Federal food stamps. This clever formula should satisfy legislators who feared a slight loss of Federal support for welfare. But if that obstacle has been overcome, there should be no excuse for letting welfare recipients stagger along without a serious adjustment for the inflation of the past six years.

Lieut. Gov. Mario Cuomo addressed the graduating class of Queens College yesterday and urged its members to reverse a trend among citizens and play a greater role in the nation's affairs. ''Unless there is reinvigoration of the people,'' Mr. Cuomo said, ''the very rich will get richer, too many of the middle class will become poorer, and the poor will become fixed in their desperation.'' The 56th commencement was held outdoors on the college campus yesterday after ceremonies were postponed by rain on Tuesday.

Cheating cases in the bridge world hardly ever reach the public courts, but two may do so in the United States in the next 12 months. In a Florida court, probably late this year, Steve Sion of Margate, Fla., and Allan Cokin of Pompano Beach, Fla., who were expelled for alleged cheating from the American Contract Bridge League last year after lengthy hearings, will sue for damages and reinstatement, using an antitrust argument. Soon afterward, a California court will hear the case of Dr. Richard Katz and Larry Cohen of Los Angeles, who resigned from the league, tendering an apology, in the course of the 1977 International Team Trials in Houston. Now they deny any guilt, and they, too, are suing for damages and reinstatement.

Senator Jesse A. Helms and Gen. David C. Jones made diametrically opposed contentions today as to whether the general would resign as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff if Ronald Reagan was elected President. Senator Helms, Republican of North Carolina, a long-time critic of the nation's top military officer, said, ''General Jones has agreed to tender his resignation in January if Governor Reagan is elected.''

TWO hanging systems designed for kitchens can, with some imagination, also be useful as storage racks in closets and bathrooms. A scissoring stainless-steel rack with five hooks, mounted on the wall, was made for nesting pots and pans vertically. When the scissoring mechanism is compressed, the pots nest and take up very little space. When the rack is pulled out, the pots separate and can be taken off the rack.

The Shell Oil Company, citing sluggish economic growth, rising energy prices ''and the costs of conservation and stringent environmental standards,'' yesterday predicted a slowdown in the growth of United States energy consumption through the 1980's. The nation's eighth-largest oil company also said that coal would be meeting a larger portion of the nation's energy demands, supplying 27 percent of needs by 1990, compared with 21 percent this year.

The ERC Corporation announced late yesterday that the Getty Oil Company had offered to pay $97 a share of all of ERC's common stock, in a deal worth about $582 million. Stanford Miller, ERC's chairman and chief executive officer, said in the announcement, ''I welcome the Getty proposal and intend to recommend that the board vote to endorse the offer.''

CODE ON LIABILITY LIMITS By CLYDE HABERMAN

Andre Dawson belted a three-run homer to snap a seventh-inning tie, and Gary Carter followed with a solo homer to support the nine-hit pitching of Steve Rogers as the Montreal Expos defeated the Chicago Cubs, 8-1, tonight. Rogers (6-5) walked three and struck out six, and he helped his cause with a two-run single in the eighth off Dick Tidrow. Dave Kingman of the Cubs hit his 10th homer of the season in the sixth inning.

SELBY, England--"Britain is an island built on coal and surrounded by fish," Aneurin Bevan, the postwar Labor Party politician and Cabinet minister, once said. It is an insight that was forgotten in the heyday of cheap oil during the 1950's and 60's.

WHEN people think of felt, they often envision hats or perhaps kindergarten children busily cutting and pasting. This image was a major concern for Paul Smith, director of the American Craft Museum, when he was considering mounting a show highlighting the ancient fiber technique.

THREE months ago, Abigail Huffman, 22, moved into her first apartment--a one-bedroom, fifth-floor walk-up in Manhattan. In the living room, a wellworn rug keeps lonely company with two chairs, two lamps, what appear to be two tables covered with brightly striped blankets and a four-drawer bureau.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Senator Jesse A. Helms and Gen. David C. Jones made diametrically opposed contentions today as to whether the general would resign as Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff if Ronald Reagan was elected President.

Dianne Wiest, who appeared as a hilariously fumbling restaurant patron in ''The Art of Dining'' at the Public Theater last fall, and Eric Peterson, the unlikely air hero of ''Billy Bishop Goes to War,'' the musical that will close tomorrow at the Morosco Theater, have been named winners of the 36th Clarence Derwent Awards. The awards, for ''the most promising female and male actors on the metropolitan scene,'' were established in 1944 by the late Mr. Derwent, the actor and president of Actors Equity, to help new talent rather than established stars.

Home runs by Chris Chambliss, Brian Asselstine, Bill Nahorodny and Glenn Hubbard backed Rick Matula's seven-hit pitching and carried the Atlanta Braves to a 7-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants today. Neither of the runs off Matula (4-4) were earned. Matula walked two and struck out three. Hubbard tripled and scored on Dale Murphy's sacrifice fly, and Chambliss followed with a solo homer to give Matula a 2-0 lead in the first inning. John Montefusco (2-5) was the loser.

International A West Bank strike was curtailed as Israeli soldiers forced Arab merchants to open their shops. There was fear and deep resentment among the Arabs, who began the general strike Tuesday to protest bombing attacks against three Palestinian mayors, but the region was generally calm and under heavy guard. (Page A1, Column 4.) The militant Jewish settlers in the West Bank have become a powerful force that no Israeli Government can ignore. The idealistic and wellarmed activists are determined that the occupied areas should remain in Jewish hands, and some Israeli analysts believe that their strength in numbers and in organization is approaching a point that may bar a voluntary Israeli evacuation without bloodshed. (A1:5.) Sharply expanded U.S.-Chinese ties are expected to be announced soon. State Department officials said that the contemplated accords included the establishment of Chinese consulates in New York, Chicago and Honolulu, direct air service between the two countries perhaps by this fall and permission for Peking to begin receiving benefits from the Export-Import Bank. (A1:4.) Firm military control of South Korea has been imposed by Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the army strongman, who has completed the formation of a new regime dominated by generals, according to Koreans and diplomats in Seoul. They said that the general had personally appointed more than 100 top officers, government officials and professors to 14 subcommittees covering all major affairs to report to his leadership council. (A1:1-3.) Wastes have forced the evacuation of 269 families in a Netherlands town near Rotterdam. They were ordered to leave their homes and live in mobile homes when it was found that their water supplies had been polluted by waste chemicals buried a decade ago. A resident likened the problem to the toxic-waste crisis in the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, N.Y. (A2:3-6.) An inquiry into U.S. policies in Iran during the rule of the deposed Shah will be undertaken in the United States, according to former Attorney General Ramsey Clark. He said in Teheran that he had agreed to a request by the President of Iran that he form a commission to conduct the investigation and that he might ''sue the Government'' to obtain information. (A3:4-6.) Foreign aid plans faced new snags as Administration forces in the House sought to fight off crippling amendments to a $5 billion authorization for the coming fiscal year. (A3:1-3.) Energy The oil-import fee was rejected overwhelmingly by both the House and Senate in a stunning rebuke to both President Carter and the Congressional Democratic leadership. The votes exceeded by an extraordinary margin those necessary to override a promised Presidential veto. Mr. Carter imposed the fee on imported oil in March as a budget balancing and energy conservation measure. (A1:6.) National An effort to close Democratic ranks is to be made at a White House meeting today by President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who were still at odds despite Mr. Carter's strong delegate majority for renomination. However, the Senator, who scored his best primary showing Tuesday with victories in five states, including California and New Jersey, still insisted that the President should debate him on ''the great issues.'' (A1:1-2.) The President's primary drive won the delegates needed for his renomination, but failed to broaden his national political base, several of Mr. Carter's aides said. They added that they were seriously concerned about the problems he faces in the general election and the complexities of the anticipated race against Ronald Reagan and Representative John B. Anderson. (B10:3-4.) Tornadoes ravaged Grand Island, Neb., injuring at least 134 persons and destroying nearly 600 buildings. City officials said they believed that four persons had been killed. Others were unaccounted for after seven twisters struck the city. (A16:1.) A stay of execution was won by a convicted murderer after he changed his position and agreed to join in efforts to fight his death sentence. The prisoner's dramatic reversal led to an indefinite postponement of the execution, which had been set for today. (A16:1.) Metropolitan A major increase in transit fares in New York City became virtually certain when Warren M. Anderson, the Republican majority leader of the State Senate, refused to accept any part of Governor Carey's plan to subsidize the deficit of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. (A1:3.) Republican aid for Mayor Koch in his expected re-election bid next year has been pledged by William E. Simon, who has volunteered to organize a Republican citizens committee and to seek endorsement by the New York City Republican Party. Mr. Simon, a former Treasury Secretary, is now policy chairman of Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign. The Democratic Mayor has expressed interest in running as a fusion candidate. (A1:1.) Legalizing marijuana for medical use is in prospect in New York State. The Senate and Assembly Health Committees have agreed to press for approval of such therapy, and leaders in both houses said that the legislation had an excellent chance of passage in this session. A spokesman for Governor Carey said he supported the measure. (B1:6.) Business Digest, Page D1

Relatives and friends of Andrei D. Sakharov, the exiled human rights activist, said today that they were coming under increasing pressure from Soviet authorities to stop relaying information to the outside world about conditions of his banishment in Gorky. Yelizaveta Alekseyeva, the prospective bride of Dr. Sakharov's stepson, Aleksei Semyonov, said that she had been warned by an official of the K.G.B., the security police, to stop passing ''slanderous information'' about Dr. Sakharov's life in exile to foreign correspondents here. Last month, she was informed that she would be prevented from traveling to visit him in Gorky, a city east of Moscow that is closed to foreigners.

The house tour season continues, with four events of interest scheduled for the coming week: June 8 - A guided driving tour, sponsored by the Greater Westbury (L.I.) Community Coalition, will visit the communities of Westbury, New Cassel and Old Westbury. In addition to public buildings, five homes of varying architectural design will be visited. Refreshments will be served at the last stop. Hours: Tour begins at 1 P.M. at Westbury Public Library on Rockland Street and ends about 5 P.M. Tickets are $2.50 and should be reserved in advance by calling (516) 334-4311 or (516) 333-5675.

JOHN McLAUGHLIN, the guitarist, and Shankar, the violinist, ended a short North American tour at the Bottom Line last Thursday night. The two musicians worked together for several years in Shakti, a pioneering acoustic ensemble that mixed Indian music with jazz, and in Mr. McLaughlin's most recent electric band, but at the Bottom Line they played separate sets. Mr. McLaughlin played a standard acoustic guitar rather than the instrument with scalloped frets that he had especially designed for his Indian-flavored work with Shakti. The first part of his set showed a definite Latin tinge, with several Brazilian- and Flamencoinfluenced pieces; the remainder consisted of jazz standards, new tunes and a number of Mr. McLaughlin's that was originally played with the Mahavishnu Orchestra. Throughout, the guitarist improvised superbly, tempering his multinoted flights with a firm sense of dynamics and pacing. He was ably seconded by the French guitarist Christian Escoude, who soloed in a contrasting, but no less captivating style.

An exhibition of 70 theater posters from Poland and the Soviet Union will be shown from June 30 to Aug. 7 in the Basement Auditorium Gallery of the City University Graduate Center, at 33 West 42d Street. The exhibition is being presented as part of a six-week humanities seminar organized by the National Endowment for the Humanities. The seminar, attended by 20 professors from universities around the country, focuses on Polish and Soviet drama of the last 25 years, a period in which there has been a renaissance in the art of the theater poster in Eastern Europe.

The Rexham Corporation, a Charlotte, N.C., manufacturer of packaging materials and machinery, has entered into a merger agreement with Schiller Industries of Cullman, Ala. Schiller, which makes components for navigational and computer systems, will become a subsidiary of Rexham and each of Schiller's 1.4 million shares of common stock will be converted into the right to receive $13.50 a share in cash. Rexham stock closed yesterday at 11 5/8, up 5/8, on the New York Stock Exchange. Schiller, on the American Exchange, closed at 12 1/2, up 3/8. Rexham, which had sales of $145.4 million last year, also announced it had entered into a trust that will vote all of its shares - about 59 percent of the shares outstanding - in favor of the proposed merger at a meeting of Schiller stockholders, expected to be held this summer. The proposed merger and trust agreement are subject to Government approval and completion of a business review of Schiller by Rexham.

Major industrialized nations pledged today to persevere with the economic austerity programs that they are now all following, despite signs that the soaring world inflation that made such policies necessary may be approaching its peak. Noting that these austerity measures were starting to yield ''positive results,'' foreign and finance ministers from the 24 member countries of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development ended their annual economic review with a communique saying it would still be ''a serious error to relax tight monetary and fiscal policies until the current surge in inflation has demonstrably been brought under control.''
VULNERABLE SECTIN OF SOCIETY By BAYARD WEBSTER

The next Presidential inauguration will take place on the West Front of the Capitol, facing the White House, for the first time in history, a Congressional committee decided today. The Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies voted unanimously today to move the site from the East Front, which faces the Supreme Court, to the West Front, whose broad terraces sweep down to Pennsylvania Avenue and the Mall.

THE SIMPLE LIFE? Last year Herbert H. Libertson, a photographer who has visited 120 countries, and Roni Neuer, an anthropologist and photographer, took a trip up the Braza River in Indonesian New Guinea and discovered, they say, 39 ''Stone Age'' people who have ''no knowledge'' of modern people, Mr. Libertson said. No knowledge of metal, no pottery, no clothing, ''just hunters and gatherers,'' Miss Neuer said. The Batsun people, as they seemed to call themselves - there was no effective linguistic communication - were given some Polaroid pictures the photographers made. But the ''tons'' of photographs taken were made with Nikon equipment. Nikon was one sponsor of the expedition, Polaroid another.

In an apparent effort to set the stage for the retirement of its top two officers, the Atlantic Richfield Company has added two additional vice chairmen to the one it already had. The big oil, gas and mineral company, with headquarters in Los Angeles, also named two new executive vice presidents and four senior vice presidents. Robert A. Anderson, 63 years old, is chairman of the corporation, and Thornton F. Bradshaw, 62, is president. A spokesman for Atlantic Richfield said that it had no mandatory retirement age but that the company ''operates on the assumption'' that senior management officials will retire at age 65.

Batus Inc. has appointed Hugh V. Cochrane senior vice president and chief financial officer of its retail division. * Carroon & Black Corporation, an international insurance brokerage firm, has elected Marnix L. Guillaume vice president, international, and Fred Michel Jr. a vice president. * Federated Department Stores, Cincinnati, has named Audian Dunham operating vice president, organization and management development. * Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio, has elected F. Vincent Prus president and chief executive officer of the Goodyear Aerospace Corporation.

Members of Congress urged the Carter Administration today to provide financial aid immediately to state and local governments to help them deal with the influx of Cuban refugees. But they said they saw no prospect of Congress's passing special legislation this year to clarify the refugees' legal status. ''We can argue about status later,'' said Representative Dante B. Fascell, Democrat of Florida, one of more than a dozen legislators who discussed the refugees' situation with aides of President Carter, ''but right now we have to provide emergency assistance to state and local governments. The local governments are picking up the tab on what is a national problem.''

The police believe a cult is responsible for a mysterious series of animal mutilations similar to several cases last fall in which cattle were found with genitals and other organs removed. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police confirmed that in two of three cases of mutilation now under investigation, the carcasses exhibited ''characteristics of those observed last fall.'' They refused to reveal the location of the new cases, the type of animals involved or the details of the mutilation.

Local planners of the Republican National Convention here in July, blaming the slumping economy, said today that they faced a $50,000 budget gap and had ordered some ''belttightening.'' But officials of the nonprofit, nonpartisan Civic Host Committee said that they could cover the deficit without canceling any of the expensive promotions to highlight convention week.

Nelson Bunker Hunt is still putting the finishing touches on his crumbling silver empire. The Goldfield Corporation, a Florida mining and electrical construction concern, announced yesterday that Mr. Hunt had reached an agreement in principle to buy a 4 percent interest in its St. Cloud silver exploration project for $400,000. Completion of the sale is scheduled for June 20, 1980, and is subject to the execution of definitive agreements. These acquisition terms were reached during the renegotiation of an earlier agreement in principle, on Feb. 13, 1980, that had called for Mr. Hunt to purchase a 20 percent share of the silver project for $2 million. It would also have given him an option to buy an additional 30 percent.

MOSCOW, June 4--Relatives and friends of Andrei D. Sakharov, the exiled human rights activist, said today that they were coming under increasing pressure from Soviet authorities to stop relaying information to the outside world about conditions of his banishment in Gorky.

PARIS, June 4--Major industrialized nations pledged today to persevere with the economic austerity programs that they are now all following, despite signs that the soaring world inflation that made such policies necessary may be approaching its peak.
CHICAGO PERHAPS the most famous architectural competition of the 20th century was the contest in 1922 to select a design for the skyscraper headquarters of The Chicago Tribune.

Several major banks reduced their prime rate yesterday by a full percentage point, to 13 percent. Their action undercut banks that only last week lowered to 14 percent the interest they charge their most creditworthy corporate customers. The prime rate has now reached its lowest level since last September.

The trade group for savings and loan associations, which are the biggest source of mortgage credit, accused Federal regulators today of blocking a recovery in housing construction this year with new rate decisions that it says will cost the mortgage market $17 billion over the next six months. The complex, little publicized action taken a week ago by the Depository Institutions Deregulation Commitee will insure that housing starts this year, despite the slide in interest and mortgage rates, will be the lowest since 1966, said the United States League of Savings Associations.

Dorothy Lamont Belknap, the wife of Chauncey Belknap, senior partner in the New York law firm of Patterson, Bel-knap, Webb & Tyler, died Tuesday of a heart attack at New York Hospital following a brief illness. She was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan and Weston, Conn.

Robin Yount's suicide squeeze in the eighth inning scored Paul Molitor from third base to give the Milwaukee Brewers a 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight. Molitor drew a one-out walk in the eighth from the Orioles' starter, Mike Flanagan (5-4). Flanagan trapped Molitor in a pickoff play, but he went to third when the Orioles' first baseman, Eddie Murray, threw the ball into left field trying to get Molitor at second.

Yogi Berra once said that a baseball game is never over till it's over, a philosophy that Edward Kennedy has applied to politics doggedly - and now profitably. The last round of eight primaries on Super Tuesday gave him much to cheer about. Not so many days ago, it will be remembered, President Carter was drubbing him weekly, by 2-tol margins. When people spoke of the vaunted Kennedy machine, it was in irony. Now, by winning five of the eight last primaries, Senator Kennedy has set an example of personal tenacity and philosophical commitment to his view of the Democratic tradition. President Carter may have come out of Tuesday with a clear majority of Democratic delegates, but he will have to work to keep them. The dominant message of Super Tuesday is not Kennedy strength. It is Carter weakness. Jimmy Carter likes to compare himself to Harry Truman who, in 1948, was also sorely beset in his campaign to stay in the White House. His popularity in the polls was plummeting. He faced a popular Republican opponent. He, too, was afflicted with an aggressive challenge from a third candidate, and a fourth.

The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next few weeks it will be written by A.G. Mojtabai, who lived in Iran 20 years ago and whose most recent novel, ''A Stopping Place,'' is set in the Islamic world. TEHERAN, 1960. A warm evening. The courtyard in which we were sitting was not very beautiful. There was a narrow strip of ground that ran along the edge of the wall, spotted with shrubbery and some insignificant roses; the rest was flagstone surrounding the customary small pool for ablutions, set like a turquoise in the center.

The President's oil-import fee was overwhelmingly rejected by Congress in a stunning rebuke to both Mr. Carter and the Congressional Democratic leadership. The House vote was 376 to 30 and the Senate's 73 to 16, despite a last-minute phone campaign by President Carter. The lopsided vote made a Congressional override of the President's promised veto almost certain. The fee was to have been passed along as a 10-cent-a-gallon rise in gasoline prices. (Page A1.) The Carter Administration may have to ask Congress to delay another increase in dairy price supports that are slated for October, if milk production continues at its current record pace, Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said. He acknowledged it would be a politically dangerous move in an election year, but added that even the dairy industry was worried about the program's $1 billion cost. (D1.)

Senator Edward M. Kennedy, in the last eight Presidential primaries Tuesday, won the regions that a Democrat needs in a general election, but President Carter won the delegates that a Democrat needs to be nominated. Mr. Kennedy won in New Jersey and California, where he said he had to. Mr. Carter won in Ohio, where he said he would, although he lost the northern, heavily industrial part of that state. Mr. Kennedy also captured Rhode Island, South Dakota and New Mexico, while Mr. Carter won Montana and West Virginia.

The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company and CBS Inc. yesterday announced a joint venture to market video cassettes and video disks of movies and television shows for use on home TV sets. MGM-CBS Home Video, as the venture is called, expects its first release of cassettes before the end of the year. The CBS Records Group will manufacture the video disks and distribute both disks and cassettes. Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer will provide its 1,600 films for use in cassettes.

The nearly empty subway train rolled up to the crowded 42d Street IND platform. A door opened, one passenger carrying a suitcase boarded and the train continued on its way to Kennedy International Airport. ''That burns me up,'' said Evelyn Alberto, waiting with throngs of others for an F train to Brooklyn on the same platform. ''What a waste.''

Three historic items suffered minor damage in a bomb explosion at the Statue of Liberty museum Tuesday night, the National Park Service said yesterday. The cost of the damage was estimated ''conservatively'' at $15,000. Paul Kinney, acting curator of the American Museum of Immigration in the statue's base, displayed a medallion -one used to raise funds for the pedestal -that had been bent by the blast. The explosion also tore a corner off an invitation to the Oct. 28, 1886 dedication of the statue and tore in half a ticket to board a steamboat on that occasion.

MOUNTAIN climbers do not customarily start off by trying to scale Mount Everest, but the Basically Bach Festival got its two-week season under way last night at Avery Fisher Hall with an assault on that peak's musical equivalent, Bach's Mass in B minor. Richard Westenburg, the festival's artistic director, led the expedition in the manner that one has come to recognize as his, which is to say with sobriety, devoutness and a willingness to compromise in matters of style and performance practice. As in the past, he scaled down his choral forces to the approximate number that Bach could have had at his disposal, using 18 male and 18 female voices. And as usual, Mr. Westenburg's Musica Sacra Chorus was a model of precision and suavity such as even Bach might have approved. The orchestra was about equal in number to the chorus, as it should be. But beyond keeping the vocal and instrumental forces in proper perspective, the conductor made few concessions to currently accepted standards for Baroque performance. Mr. Westenburg did sit at a harpsichord occasionally and help tap out accompaniment harmonies, but the other keyboard instrument used in the continuo was a thick-voiced electronic organ that gave out little suggestion of a Baroque instrument's tone. It is doubtful that Bach ever used both harpsichord and organ in his church performances, since he would have wanted to play both. So far as one could determine by eye and ear, the orchestra contained no authentic instruments. David Jolley, for instance, played his part splendidly on the modern, valved French horn, but the tone was much too ripe and furry to sound right in this music.
John Wockenfuss belted a disputed three-run homer to back Milt Wilcox's five-hit pitching as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Seattle Mariners, 8-2, tonight.

Grain trade was cautious yesterday as traders awaited a revised forecast of the winter wheat crop. The revised estimate, made at the close of trade, increased the projection to a record 1.74 billion bushels, based on June 1 conditions.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The State Department announced today that the United States had completed an agreement with Oman giving American military aircraft and warships access to airfields and ports near the Persian Gulf.

Fred Rodell, a retired Yale Law School professor who had been one of the country's ranking specialists on the United States Constitution and a vigorous civil libertarian, died Wednesday at the YaleNew Haven Hospital. He was 73 years old.

IT's difficult to keep up with one's favorite modern-dance "gypsies," floating as they do from group to group. New York/ Dance Ensemble, which performed at Theater of the Riverside Church on Wednesday, is a handy collection of some of the best of those gypsies.

To the Editor: Have you noticed that the recent increase in New York City taxi fares, which was supposed to approximate 22 percent, works out to closer to 40 percent over a familiar route? trip uninterrupted by traffic may indeed only go up by the lesser percentage, but there is hardly ever a ride in New York City that does not include a certain amount of waiting time - and that is the cause of all the trouble.

A garden-variety conflict is quietly under way in Congress. A seemingly innocuous piece of legislation - which would permit the patenting of new varieties of tomatoes, carrots, cucumbers, okra, celery and peppers - has aroused determined opposition from such diverse foes as the John Birch Society, the National Farmers Union and a number of Harvard professors. ''It's the most insignificant little piece of legislation,'' said Harold Loden of the American Seed Trade Association, a supporter of the bill, which was approved Wednesday by the House Agriculture Committee, 35-2. ''It allows you to protect six little vegetables, when you've already got 222 other food crops covered. So what?''

Following is the text of the speech delivered at commencement exercises at Harvard Univesity today by former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance: Yours is the first Harvard class to graduate in the decade of the 1980's. The decisions our nation makes now will shape the future of that decade.
IRAN TALKS CONDEMN BOTH U.S AND SOVIET

Wayne Gretzky, the young and talented center of the Edmonton Oilers, has won the Hart Memorial Trophy as the National Hockey League's most valuable player last season and the Lady Byng Memorial Trophy as the most gentlemanly player, the league announced today. Gretzky, who became 19 years old on Jan. 26, is the youngest player to win a major N.H.L. award. He would have been an obvious choice for a third honor but was ruled ineligible for the Calder Memorial Trophy as rookie of the year after the Oilers joined the league last year from the World Hockey Association, now defunct.

Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court today temporarily blocked the death sentence of Raymond Riles, who had been scheduled for execution in Texas on June 18 for a robbery-murder.

By LEONARD BUDER Jerry Attanasio and Joe McNally were talking the other day about their choice for president, but neither mentioned Jimmy Carter or Ronald Reagan: Mr. Attanasio said he was voting for Charlie, while Mr. McNally said he was all for Phil.

Mayor Koch's recommendation in his 1981 budget to abolish the Department of Ports and Terminals, transferring its functions to various other agencies and providing a savings of $916,000, may be well-intentioned but in the long run may be a costly, damaging blow to recent efforts to revive New York City's side of the port. The Mayor's efforts to save money should be applauded. However, any proposal to eliminate a department that is part of a vital economic sector generating thousands of jobs and millions of dollars in revenues by, among other things, leasing property to shippers and operating markets, would be counterproductive. Further, it would contradict Mr. Koch's efforts to encourage expansion of the privatebusiness sector. Indeed, the move is filled with contradictions that could lead to the eventual demise of import-export activities on city piers.

Journalists at Australia's Government-run broadcasting agency voted today to join for 24 hours a nationwide strike of their newspaper colleagues in a dispute over electronic editing terminals. The four-week strike, called by the Australian Journalists Association, halted production at two nationally circulated newspapers, The Australian and The Financial Review, and forced management to put out four Sydney newspapers and three in Melbourne. The union called the strike May 13 to protest the firing of 29 subeditors in Sydney for refusing to operate computer-linked video display terminals.

The U.S. Pioneer Electronics Corporation announced that it would begin marketing a videodisk system later this month. The company, which is manufacturing a version of the optical, or laser, videodisk player developed jointly by N.V. Philips of the Netherlands and Hollywood's MCA Inc., said its so-called Laserdisc unit would go on sale in Dallas; Madison, Wis.; Minneapolis and Syracuse by July 1. U.S. Pioneer will thus join the Magnavox Consumer Electronics Company as the only sellers of such a system. The RCA Corporation has said that it intends to start marketing a videodisk system of its own in the first quarter of 1981 for around $500. The RCA system is incompatible with the Philips-MCA videodisk.

AS impressively designed by Henry Millman, the stage at the American Place Theater has been transformed into a large, threatening factory. There is no view of an outside world; each pane of window glass is coated with a thick crust of dirt. It is as if we are in an antechamber of hell. One by one, seven women arrive, go to their lockers and change into their uniforms. The workers operate identical machines; they are, we are told, ''processing chemicals for reactor parts.'' As the day begins in Lavonne Mueller's ''Killings on the Last Line,'' we envision the possible consequences - personal disagreements, personnel conflicts, labor disputes and impairment of health, perhaps death, because of nuclear contamination. The ingredients are here for a provocative drama - combining shared activity, as in David Storey's ''The Changing Room'' and a dangerous, toxic atmosphere as in ''China Syndrome.'' However, most of the concerns that arise in Miss Mueller's play are unadventurous domestic dilemmas.

A second motorcyclist, Andrew Holme, died in a hospital today of injuries received during last Saturday's first leg of the Tourist Trophy sidecar race. Holme, a 29-year-old Briton, suffered internal injuries when run over by the sidecar unit in which he was a passenger. Martin Ames, a rider who was injured in the same race, died yesterday. Records show that Holme was the 128th competitor to die in the 68-year history of the Tourist Trophy races.

Harold B. Burnham, an engineer for Consolidated Edison for 47 years, died Wednesday at his home in Lakewood, N.J. He was 73 years old. He is survived by his wife, the former Marion Lobdell; two sons, Bruce and David; a daughter, Barbara Figiel, and nine grandchildren.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Committee Formed to Aid Reagan's Campaign Fund

WHILE a woman cawed like a bird, another woman ate an envelope and a man bayed like a dog. A woman commanded a glove, ''Fly!'' When the glove remained motionless, the woman chided herself, then gestured as if she were now trying to fly. An androgynous figure behaved like both a potentate and an invalid. These were only a few of the strange things that happened in the first act of ''Bird Devil,'' a three-act movement-theater piece conceived and directed by Lee Nagrin. It was presented by the Women's Interart Center Inc. and the Silver Whale Arts Foundation Inc. Wednesday night at the Silver Whale Gallery, 21 Bleecker Street.
SUNDAY By JOHN ROCKWELL

When the orchestra playing this week for the 26th constitutional convention of the United Automobile Workers played ''Taps'' in honor of members who died in the three years since the last convention, Lacey Brooks Jr., one of the 3,000 workers gathered here, remarked, ''They played it for us.'' Without cracking a smile, 50-year-old Mr. Brooks, a father of seven who worked for 16 years at the Dodge Main assembly plant in Detroit before it was shut permanently this winter, explained that he was not only out of a job, but also almost out of hope.

Frank Coe, a former Treasury Department official who was ousted as Secretary of the International Monetary Fund in the early 1950's after he was accused of being a Communist spy, died June 2 in Peking. Mr. Coe, who had lived in China since 1958, was 73 years old. The New China News Agency attributed Mr. Coe's death to a pulmonary embolism. But Charles J. Coe of New York City said his brother had undergone surgery for cancer eight months ago.

Hollywood could not have asked for more. Codex and Genuine Risk, whose apparent brush at the top of the Preakness stretch aroused one of the most bitter controversies in horse-racing history, will start side by side from inside posts in the Belmont Stakes tomorrow. Aware of the potential for ontrack violence between Angel Cordero, on Codex, and Jacinto Vasquez, on Genuine Risk, Belmont Park's stewards warned both jockeys yesterday against any rough-riding tactics in the big race.
AROUND THE NATION; Stricken City in Nebraska To Be Barred to Visitors

The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway's appeal of its order that another railroad operate a 34-mile section of the bankrupt Rock Island Railroad. The I.C.C. said its decision, which gives the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad, called the Katy, temporary operating rights over track between Dallas and Fort Worth as well as another 400 more miles north of Fort Worth, reflected the intent of recently approved legislation aimed at preserving some service on the Rock Island's 13-state system.

Russell L. Newcomb, a former vice president of Kersting & Brown, fund-raising consultants for educational institutions, including Columbia University, died Tuesday at his home in Norwich, Vt., He was 76 years old. He was a graduate of Dartmouth College and lived in Chappaqua, N.Y., before his retirement in 1969. Surviving are his wife, the former Louise Blazer; two sons, Danforth and Jonathan, both of New York City; three sisters, Mildred Boland of Squatum, Mass.; Edith Campbell of Peterborough, N.H., and Carol Emde of Katonah, N.Y., and two grandchildren.

The United Nations Security Council severely criticized Israel today for failing to protect Arab lives in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan. The Council's 14-to-0 vote, on a resolution condemning Israel, resulted from the car bombings on Monday that maimed the Palestinian Mayors of Nablus and Ramallah.

Rowland Office hit his first home run of the season, a two-run shot in the seventh inning, to back the six-hit pitching of Scott Sanderson and give the Montreal Expos a 2-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. After Warren Cromartie beat out a bunt with one out, Office slammed the first pitch by Dennis Lamp (4-5), the Cubs' starter, over the right-field fence.

Margo Wainwright Shean, daughter of Edward T. Shean and the late Caroline Wainwright Shean of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Linen Dana, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Dana Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Livingston, Mont. The Rev. Bryant Kirkland performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. A reception at the River Club was given by the bride's uncle and aunt, Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Wainwright of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Claire S. Shean was maid of honor for her sister and the bridegroom's father was best man. Mrs. Dana, a great-great-granddaughter of Jay Gould, the financier, was graduated from the Greenwich Country Day and Madeira Schools and from George Washington University. She will join INA Professional Services, an insurance concern, this month.

Kraft Inc., a dominant force in the packaged foods industry, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to merge with Dart Industries Inc., a housewares and chemicals manufacturer generally regarded as having more exciting growth possibilities.

ALBANY, June 5--The partisan dispute over how to subsidize the deficit of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority continued today when the Republicans presented their own plan, but attached so many conditions to it that the Democrats said it was no program at all.

PHOENIX, June 5 (AP)--James Robison was ordered today to be retried June 23 on a first-degree murder charge in the 1976 bombing death of Don Bolles, a reporter. However, a defense motion to dismiss the charge is to be heard June 13, ...

WASHINGTON, June 5--William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, shuffled the agency's top ranks today to fill a vacancy left by the departure of a senior official.

A Federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit by Gary Thomas Rowe, once an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who was trying to stop his extradition to Alabama for trial on murder charges. Mr. Rowe, who provided information on Ku Klux Klan activities in the 1960's, is charged with murder in Lowndes County, Ala., in connection with the shooting death on March 25, 1965, of Viola Gregg Liuzzo, a civil rights worker.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--Cancer insurance often does not cover many medical costs of disease and most consumers are unaware of that when they buy such policies, according to a Government study released today.

DOUGLAS, Isle of Man, June 5 (AP) --A second motorcyclist, Andrew Holme, died in a hospital today of injuries received during last Saturday's first leg of the Tourist Trophy sidecar race. Holme, a 29-year-old Briton, suffered internal injuries when run over by the sidecar unit in which he was a passenger.

THERE are eight other horses in the field, but no matter how you slice it the 112th Belmont Stakes remains a battle of the sexes. Maybe Genuine Risk, torchbearer for the distaff side, and Codex, the colt who treated her unkindly in the Preakness, will both be up the track when the winner finishes the mile and a half, but those are the two the public will be watching when they hook up in the race that management calls ''the test of the champion.'' Five weeks ago Genuine Risk captivated racing buffs by winning the Kentucky Derby, the first of her sex to do that in 65 years and only the second filly to make off with that gaudy event since it began in 1875. Two weeks later Codex, who didn't go to the Derby, came on from California to bully and beat the lady in the second event of the Triple Crown series.
BONN, June 5 (AP)--Lauritz Lauritzen, a former West German Cabinet minister, died today, the Social Democratic Party announced. He was 70 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP)--Brig. Gen. James C. Rosborough, who fought in the Battle of the Bulge in World War II, died Sunday at his home in suburban Newtown Square. He was 85 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Environmental Protection Agency data released today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy indicate that more than 100 waste disposal sites around the country may pose serious health or safety hazards to more than 600,000 people who live in their vicinity.

CAMBRIDGE, MASS., June 5--Cyrus R. Vance, in his first public appearance since resigning as Secretary of State in April, said today that the United States must not allow the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan to continue to delay Senate approval of the treaty limiting nuclear arms.

The credit markets continued to march toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday, causing the J.C. Penney Company to increase the size of its financing and schedule it for sale today, just three days after its was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Two more Soviet astronauts were rocketed into orbit yesterday in the first manned flight of a new and more sophisticated version of the Soyuz spacecraft.

PAINTINGS by Pre-Raphaelite, Symbolist and Art Nouveau and Art Deco artists, and prints, posters and decorative art works from 1880 to 1940 will be auctioned in a series of sales next Thursday through June 14 at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street.
ALBANY, June 5--A bill that could lead to more restrictions on the collection and use of confidential personal information by New York State agencies won bipartisan support in the Legislature today.

President Carter, who first called for the convocation of a national conference on the problems of the family four years ago when he was campaigning for the Presidency, today opened the first of three national White House Conferences on Families. In an impassioned talk, scattered with references to his own family, President Carter said he had called for the conference because he was ''deeply concerned that official America had lost touch with family America.''

WHEN Robbie Robertson telephoned to say he wanted to come over to discuss ''a project,'' Gary Busey was ecstatic. ''I thought it was going to be about making an album,'' the actor said. ''I had my microphones and amplifiers hooked up and my wrists loose for the drums.'' What Mr. Robertson, the lead guitarist of the Band, the nowdisbanded rock group, wanted to talk about turned out to be a motion picture about two young men who tour with a small carnival and the runaway young girl who comes between them.

NOW that the National Bureau of Economic Research has certified that the economy is in recession, with its decision that the last cyclical expansion peaked in January, the big question is where and when the bottom will be reached. At present, the economy is dropping as though the bottom had fallen out. Economists specializing in the measurement of gross national product estimate that in this second quarter real G.N.P. will fall at an annual rate of 8 to 8 1/2 percent. And George Perry, the top forecaster of the Brookings Institution, thinks it possible that in this or the next quarter, the economy could experience a double-digit rate of decline.

Grow Group Inc. announced a public offering of 500,000 shares of common stock through a Drexel Burnham Lambert group. * Southern Pacific Transportation Company plans to sell $27 million of equipment trust certificates maturing in 15 equal annual installments. * Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association plans to offer $50 million in mortgage-backed bonds in mid-June through a Salomon Brothers group.

Craig Swan, turning in the second outstanding Met pitching performance in a row against one of the strongest hitting teams in the majors, pitched a five-hitter last night as the Mets scored a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Swan's triumph, his fourth in eight decisions, followed a combined three-hitter by Pat Zachry and Neil Allen in a 1-0 loss to the Cards and their 41-year-old pitcher, Jim Kaat, at Shea Stadium on Wednesday night.

Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office denied an American press report today that the Prime Minister's Government had offered King Hussein of Jordan a territorial compromise that would restore parts of the West Bank to Jordanian rule. The Cox News Service, in a report published today by The Atlanta Constitution, quoted Mr. Begin as saying in an interview that the compromise was discussed at a meeting between the King and Moshe Dayan, then Foreign Minister.
The State Department announced today that the United States had completed an agreement with Oman giving American military aircraft and warships access to airfields and ports near the Persian Gulf.

A chartered bus carrying a group of Texas tourists went out of control early today on a dangerous mountain highway, slid down a steep embankment along a rocky bluff and smashed into trees, killing 20 persons and injuring 13. The driver and several passengers were thrown from the bus, a witness said, and parts of the vehicle were scattered along the twolane asphalt highway on Jasper Mountain and down the 50-foot bluff.

Bronx Republicans last night endorsed Alfonse M. D'Amato, Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, on Long Island, for the nomination for United States Senator. The endorsement came despite a last-minute appeal by Senator Jacob K. Javits, the fourterm Republican incumbent, that they support him. About 150 Bronx Republican county committeemen, who rarely meet, were convened by the party's county chairman, John D. Calandra, to listen to three Senate aspirants and then to ratify Mr. Calandra's choice of Mr. D'Amato.

Stock prices lost their upward momentum yesterday as the market once again ran into an area of potential selling pressure. After jumping 14.25 points on Wednesday in the wake of plummeting interest rates, the Dow finished at 858.70 with a token gain of 0.68 point. Turnover swelled to 49.1 million shares from Wednesday's 44.2 million. It was the heaviest volume since 63.8 million shares changed hands on March 27, when turmoil in silver futures trading spilled over into the stock market.

New York City should not submit to threats by real estate interests and meekly hand over an East Side playground in a swap in order to prevent destruction of two small parks in the middle of the private Tudor City development.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 5 (AP)--A volunteer for the National Organization for Women was indicted today on charges of offering a $1,000 bribe to an Illinois lawmaker last month to vote for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.
MIAMI, June 4--John B. Anderson paused in his perky, wide-eyed way this morning and offered the political world a new four-letter word.

Hollywood could not have asked for more. Codex and Genuine Risk, whose apparent brush at the top of the Preakness stretch aroused one of the most bitter controversies in horse-racing history, will start side by side from inside posts in the Belmont Stakes tomorrow.

OMAHA, June 5 (AP)--A two-out double to deep center field by Dwight Taylor in the bottom of the ninth inning drove home the winning run tonight as University of Arizona rallied for an 11-10 victory over California and gained a berth in the College World Series championship game.
DETROIT, June 5 (AP)--The General Motors Corporation's legal objections to the nation's first big synthetic gas project may delay it for a year, one of its developers said today.
JUNE is the time when flea markets, street bazaars, collectibles shows and antiques centers flower throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

A series of explosions ripped through the Chemical Control Corporation toxic chemicals dump in Elizabeth, N.J., last night during a brief three-alarm fire that left three men injured and recalled a more serious blaze at the same site in April.
HAVANA, June 5 (Reuters)--Cuba said today that it would never permit the last 33 refugees in the Peruvian Embassy here to leave the country.
