The Detroit Pistons ended months of guessing yesterday by naming Scotty Robertson, an assistant with the Houston Rockets last season, as their coach. Robertson is the 16th Piston coach since the franchise moved to Detroit from Fort Wayne, Ind., for the 1957-58 season. The Pistons gave Robertson a multiyear contract, but the details of it were not disclosed. The Pistons, who finished the National Basketball Association season with a 16-66 won-lost record, the worst in the league, had two coaches last season. Dick Vitale was dismissed after the Pistons had won only four of their first 12 games and was replaced by Richie Adubato, who served as the interim coach for the remainder of the season.

JUNE is the time when flea markets, street bazaars, collectibles shows and antiques centers flower throughout New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. And this weekend may be the busiest of the year for those in search of the trifles and treasures they collect - or that collect them. Whether the setting is an urban fair, a suburban bazaar or a rural festival, held indoors or in a meadow, a parking lot, a drive-in theater, a town green, a sidewalk or a race track, a flea market by that name or any other represents to thousands a chance to explore a fantasy world where nostalgia blooms at the sight of a necklace, cardboard box, cookie jar, antimacassar, toaster, ruby-red glass goblet or wind-up toy.

The credit markets continued to march toward higher prices and lower interest rates yesterday, causing the J.C. Penney Company to increase the size of its financing and schedule it for sale today, just three days after its was filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. New York State Dormitory Authority bonds were sold at yields below those contemplated last Monday. The strength in the credit markets, which became evident Tuesday, has resulted from investors' apparent willingness to buy the large number of new fixed-income securities marketed this week. There were no new economic developments to account for the continuation yesterday of the trend, but several traders said they expected the Government's reports today on unemployment, producer prices of finished goods and perhaps the money supply to add more pressure for lower interest rates.

The Palestinian Arab Mayor of Nablus, who lost his legs in a terrorist bombing Monday, was taken to Jordan today for medical treatment after his condition deteriorated. The Israeli Government, which has condemned the attack on the Mayor, Bassam al-Shaka, and two other West Bank mayors, first offered to take him to any hospital in Israel and then, when he declined the offer, sent an ambulance to drive him to the border crossing at Damiya, northeast of here. A Jordanian helicopter flew him to Amman.

A day after Democrats in California nominated a local Ku Klux Klansman to Congress, the national party chairman assailed the move as ''an acute embarrassment to me and to the party.'' In a statement released in Washington yesterday, John C. White said that the nominee, Tom Metzger, ''is against everything the Democratic Party stands for.''

''NIGHT of the Juggler,'' a thriller that starts out at an exhilaratingly brisk pace, winds up as breathless and overplotted as a thriller can be. A former policeman (James Brolin) has a daughter, and the daughter has blue overalls, and her overalls look disastrously like the outfit worn by another girl, a rich girl, whom a crackpot (Cliff Gorman) is planning to kidnap. He abducts the former policeman's daughter by mistake. The rest of the film is given over to the chase, which spans a lot of New York City locations and produces dozens of banged-up cars. Meanwhile, Mr. Brolin is hounded by a former police co-worker for whom he once caused marital trouble. Plots like this don't grow on trees, unless the trees have very strong branches.

ONCE again, in this period of reruns, documentaries monopolize the new programming picture. Tonight at 10, NBC News's ''Is There a Better Way?'' offers, in the words of its producer, Robert Rogers, ''an analysis of trends in the 1980 Presidential nominating process.'' Tomorrow at 9 P.M., WNET, Channel 13, is offering a twohour examination called ''Iran: Inside the Islamic Republic.'' And, Sunday at 8, WNEW, Channel 5, has ''Club Fighter,'' a portrait of a young New Jersey boxer reaching for national fame. NBC's ''Is There a Better Way?'' focuses on the ineffectiveness of recent reforms in the electoral process. Foremost among the targets is the limitation of campaign financing to $1,000 by an individual contributor. The motives, it seems, were admirable in attempting to cut off excessive control by fat cats. The consequences, however, have been ambiguous because fund raising has become the major emphasis of most campaigns, and politicians have been forced to devote most of their energy to money matters. In addition, the hourlong program questions the growing importance of primaries, as opposed to the ''wholesale politics'' and wheelingdealing practices of the old days, and the role of the press, the boys on the bus, in political campaigns. George Reedy, one of President Johnson's press secretaries, is on hand to criticize the ''snap judgments'' of news reporters. In the end, the program calls for ''not more reform but some refinements'' in the political arena.

A two-out double to deep center field by Dwight Taylor in the bottom of the ninth inning drove home the winning run tonight as University of Arizona rallied for an 11-10 victory over California and gained a berth in the College World Series championship game. Trailing by 10-9, Arizona opened the ninth with a single by Scott Stanley. He moved to second on a single by a pinch-hitter, Alan Regier.

Westchester County today tentatively selected UOP Inc. of Des Plains, Ill., to build a $100 million garbage disposal plant in Peekskill. The plant is expected to convert garbage from more than 30 municipalities into low-cost electricity for the Peekskill region. The action by the county's Industrial Development Agency represents the beginning of the final stage of a decade-old plan. The plant would begin operation in three years, assuming that the county and UOP conclude negotiations satisfactorily. Construction is expected to begin at the end of 1981.

The United States Steel Corporation plans to put about 7,000 clerical workers on four-day workweeks at plants across the nation because of declining orders, a company spokesman said today. The shortened schedules, first announced last week without reference to the number of workers affected, are in addition to the layoff of 17,000 U.S. Steel production workers nationwide.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 6 (UPI)-- Journalists at Australia's Governmentrun broadcasting agency voted today to join for 24 hours a nationwide strike of their newspaper colleagues in a dispute over electronic editing terminals.
INVESTORS are intrigued by the possibilities in the announced intention of the United Artists Theatre Circuit to buy all its publicly held shares.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI)-- The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to relax the rules of national stock exchanges that limit off-board transactions by their members.

Craig Swan, turning in the second outstanding Met pitching performance in a row against one of the strongest hitting teams in the majors, pitched a five-hitter last night as the Mets scored a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Frank Coe, a former Treasury Department official who was ousted as Secretary of the International Monetary Fund in the early 1950's after he was accused of being a Communist spy, died June 2 in Peking. Mr. Coe, who had lived in China since 1958, was 73 years old.

CAIRO, June 5--President Anwar elSadat threatened today to retaliate with force if Ethiopia interfered with Egypt's water from the Nile, some of which Mr. Sadat intends to divert to irrigate stretches of Sinai.
NEW CARROLLTON, Md., June 5 --In a squat building beneath a parking lot in the middle of a shoppingmall complex, Sugar Ray Leonard confidently and thankfully broke training camp today.

Mayor Koch's recommendation in his 1981 budget to abolish the Department of Ports and Terminals, transferring its functions to various other agencies and providing a savings of $916,000, may be well-intentioned but in the long run may be a costly, damaging blow to recent efforts to revive New York City's side of the port.

Stephane Grappelli seems much too young to be "the grand old man of European jazz," as one critic has called him. It's true that the urbane, white-haired violinist was born in 1908, but when one goes to see him perform, ...

WASHINGTON, June 5--A report on the unsuccessful attempt to rescue the American hostages in Iran, prepared for the ranking Republican member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, says that "major errors" were made in the planning and execution of the operation.

RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., June 5-- After meeting privately here today for 90 minutes, Ronald Reagan and former President Gerald R. Ford pledged to work together to elect Mr. Reagan President in November. The former President said he would "wholeheartedly campaign" in Mr. Reagan's behalf.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--The Interstate Commerce Commission denied today the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway's appeal of its order that another railroad operate a 34-mile section of the bankrupt Rock Island Railroad.

Greg Zorila of the Siwanoy Club, will meet Bruce Aubin of Dutchess tomorrow in the final of the Westchester Golf Association's 61st amateur championship. Zorila, who has won this tournament three times, qualified for the 36-hole final by eliminating 19-year-old Jon Doppelt of the host Brae Burn Club this morning, 1 up. Aubin, a 28-year-old lawyer from Millbrook, N.Y., defeated Dr. Jerry Sacks of Metropolis by the same score in the other semifinal match.

Having been a straight A student, ranking fifth in her class, Tina Bahadori was eligible to compete for the honor of giving the valedictory address at Atlantic City High School's commencement next Thursday. She won the competition, too, and was preparing her speech, when teachers at the high school forced her to withdraw as valedictorian, because Miss Bahadori is an Iranian national.

Anna Fitch Ardenghi, a philanthropist who in 1953 arranged to have potter's field in New Haven entirely refurbished, died Monday at her home in New Haven. She was 93 years old. Mrs. Ardenghi, the daughter of a well-to-do carriage manufacturer, offered to have redone the burial ground of hundreds of New Haven's homeless and peniless from plans drawn up by her own architect.

PARISI Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had developed a new battery system that would permit the manufacture of a practical electric car able to go 150 miles, at 55 miles an hour, without a recharge.

The 40th anniversary of the British Army's evacuation through Dunkirk and of the subsequent fall of France has been receiving unusual attention here. It probably is not entirely a coincidence that there is also an intense debate on defense policy, paralleling in a number of ways the debate in the United States, despite important differences in assumptions and capacities. The decision to attend the Moscow Olympics and President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's chat with Leonid Brezhnev are only one aspect of the French stance. Another is that Giscard's party has suddenly decided to proclaim a ''great festival of liberty'' this month as notice that ''freedom is under attack around the world.'' Moreover, the party has just issued a basic defense statement proclaiming that ''peace cannot be taken for granted'' but is ''a precarious situation, under increasing menace.''

President Carter today vetoed legislation rejecting his oil-import fee, and the House of Representatives quickly overrode his action by a vote of 335 to 34. The Senate, which rejected the fee yesterday by 73 to 16, was due to vote tomorrow. Like the House, it was expected to achieve easily the two-thirds majority required for an override. The House had voted by 376 to 30 yesterday to reject the fee of $4.62 on each barrel of imported oil.

THE BOSWELL SISTERS, the hit trio of 1930's songdom, are making a comeback next autumn, if not in person at least in the evocation of their life and times in an Off Broadway musical. The show, ''The Heebie Jeebies,'' has had an unusual amount of preliminary working out for Off Broadway, and all the advance work has made it an expensive undertaking for its 299-seat class. Spencer A. Tandy and Joseph L. Butt, the producers, said that they would raise $250,000 to present it. Mr. Tandy and Mr. Butt are in their early 30's, as are Mark Hampton and Stuart Ross, authors of the book, and they all came along well after the Boswell era.

President Anwar el-Sadat threatened today to retaliate with force if Ethiopia interfered with Egypt's water from the Nile, some of which Mr. Sadat intends to divert to irrigate stretches of Sinai. ''If Ethiopia takes any action to block our right to the Nile water, there will be no alternative but for us to use force,'' Mr. Sadat said in the Suez Canal town of Ismailia at a gathering of Second Army officers.

Bob Shearer, an Australian living in the United States, survived muggy heat and posted a nine-under-par 63 that set the first-round pace by two strokes today in the $300,000 Atlanta Golf Classic. Shearer, 32 years old, birdied nine of the 18 holes and called it ''my best round over here and probably my best as a pro.'' For Jack Nicklaus, it was one of the worst. ''It hasn't happened often, but I got down on myself,'' Nicklaus admitted after a variety of troubles produced a six-over-par 78 that put him 15 strokes back of Shearer. Nicklaus is in danger of missing the cut when the field is trimmed to the low 70 scorers and ties after tomorrow's second round.

The securities industry has devised a standard way to measure the yields of money-market mutual funds, which have attracted more than $71 billion from investors seeking high interest rates. The new standard, which has been approved by the Securities and Exchange Commission, is designed to enable investors to compare the yields offered by the funds. An industry organization, the National Association of Securities Dealers, is compiling the data and making a table available each Friday beginning this week for distribution to newspapers. unhappy with the standard, saying that the comparison is too simplistic. He would not identify those funds. He said some members of the industry fear investors will use the yield table as a ''shopping list'' in search of an investment. He said persons trying to decide whether to invest in a fund should look beyond the new table.

Around 4.30 P.M. on May 27, minutes after leaving his job at the local Coca-Cola bottling plant, Marlon Mendizabal stood waiting for a bus to take him home. Suddenly a car carrying four men pulled up beside him. Two of the men aimed submachine guns at him and opened fire. He died instantly. The 22-year-old Mr. Mendizabal was the fourth worker at the Coca-Cola plant to be killed in May and the third secretary general of the plant's union to be murdered in 18 months.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--The Government reported today that number of people filing initial claims for unemployment insurance remained at nearrecord levels in late May, bolstering expectations of a sharp jump in last month's jobless rate, which is to be announced tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The House of Representatives today approved legislation that would authorize $5.2 billion in foreign aid, including $53.7 million for Nicaragua, for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

PITTSBURGH, June 5 (AP)--The United States Steel Corporation plans to put about 7,000 clerical workers on four-day workweeks at plants across the nation because of declining orders, a company spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--The General Tire and Rubber Company, in a statement released at its headquarters in Akron, Ohio, said today that RKO General, a subsidiary, would appeal the Government's opinion that RKO is "unfit" to continue operating television stations in Boston, New York and Los Angeles.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., June 5 (AP)-- The United Illuminating Company said six of its workers were seriously burned today by an explosion of pressurized steam when a valve malfunctioned at its Bridgeport Harbor station.

Deviating from her normal baseline style, Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-2, 6-2, today and reached the final of the French open tennis championships for the fifth time. Her opponent Saturday for the women's title, worth $43,000, will be Virginia Ruzici of Rumania, the 1978 champion, who today defeated Dianne Fromholtz of Australia, 7-6, 6-1.

Stanford University said today it had learned that its teaching assistant's handbook section on plagiarism had been plagiarized by the University of Oregon. Stanford issued a release saying Oregon officials conceded that the plagiarism section and other parts of its handbook were identical with the Stanford guidebook. Oregon officials apologized and said they would revise their guidebook.

The ERC Corporation announced yesterday that its board of directors had voted unanimously to endorse the previously announced offer by the Getty Oil Corporation to acquire it. Late Wednesday evening Getty Oil announced that it was offering $570 million in cash, or $97 a share, for all the outstanding common stock of ERC, a leading reinsurance company based in Kansas City, Mo.

IT's difficult to keep up with one's favorite modern-dance ''gypsies,'' floating as they do from group to group. New York/ Dance Ensemble, which performed at Theater of the Riverside Church on Wednesday, is a handy collection of some of the best of those gypsies. With dancers like Lance Westergard and Dian Dong, the company has that look of care of a house full of cherished objects. The four new works on Wednesday's program were, however, a mixed bag. Oddly enough, the most successful piece was one by what is probably the nearest thing to a nonchoreographer. Amanda Smith, a writer on dance, seems to have studied Mr. Westergard's very individual performance style and come up with a solo that, while it is slight and doesn't much extend him, is rewardingly thoughtful.Set to three songs sung by Billie Holiday, ''Solitary Games'' plays jazz-dance bits against classical ballet steps and Mr. Westergard's customary look of a wild, rather impudent faun against his look here of a turn-of-the-century tennis player. That tension is to be found, as well, in the bitter honey of Holiday's voice and the songs she sings here.

Environmental Protection Agency data released today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy indicate that more than 100 waste disposal sites around the country may pose serious health or safety hazards to more than 600,000 people who live in their vicinity.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 5 (Reuters)-- A four-day Iranian-sponsored conference on "United States intervention in Iran" drew to a close tonight with denunciations of both the United States and the Soviet Union.

SHANGHAI, June 5 (UPI)--China signed a multimillion-dollar contract today with a consortium of foreign companies to build a steel complex described as the largest single industrial project in the country's history.

The reconvened annual meeting of the Hammermill Paper Company was adjourned again and is now scheduled to meet on June 19. It was also reported that the examination and challenge of proxies by representatives of Hammermill and Carl C. Icahn, a stockholder who has been seeking a seat on Hammermill's board, had been adjourned by the election judges until June 16. The company said the vote for election to its board continues to be extremely close.

An official commission of inquiry into the ''disastrous'' costs of Montreal's 1976 Olympic Games told a tale today of irresponsibility, incompetence, corruption, fraud and greed that led to a final deficit of well over a billion dollars. After a three-year study, the commission headed by Judge Albert H. Malouf placed most of the blame on Montreal's 64-year-old Mayor, Jean Drapeau, who for 25 years has enjoyed the support of the people for his penchant for large-scale projects and municipal prestige.

What comes out of Congress in the way of housing legislation this year will have a considerable effect for years to come on how Federal money is spent in New York City. Will it benefit only the poor or near poor, or will it benefit middle-income people too? Will it diminish the amount of new housing built for lower-income people in favor of putting more subsidy dollars into the existing rental housing supply? Will it ease the rental-housing shortage in areas such as the Upper West Side?

An article in Business Day last Saturday inadvertently omitted mention of changes in liquid assets as one of the 12 components of the Government's index of leading economic indicaors. A picture caption in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday incorrectly identified a City Councilman as Stanley E. Michels. The councilman was Herbert E. Berman.
A tornado-like storm struck this seaside resort today, flipping over dozens of vacation trailers and blowing out windows. Nine persons were reported injured, two seriously.

ANY handsome young actor can swagger on to a stage, throw his weight around and create a disruption. But when Peter Weller - jittery as an alley cat but not quite as mean - crashes on stage in ''The Woolgatherer,'' he isn't merely strutting his stuff. Cast in the role of a horny truck driver named Cliff, Mr. Weller won't settle for sheer energy or roughneck force. He has instead staked out a very particular piece of territory - that slender psychological boundary between sex and violence - and he straddles it for two hours without ever losing his balance. The result is a relentlessly volatile, scary, magnetic performance - the best of its kind since John Savage's in ''American Buffalo.'' Mr. Weller makes it all look easy, but it's a sure thing that his tightly defined intensity is the product of lots of hard and intelligent work. If this actor is the main reason to check out ''The Woolgatherer,'' which opened at the Circle Repertory last night, he is not the only one. This play also introduces a writer of promise, William Mastrosimone. ''The Woolgatherer'' is a young, rough-hewn work with structural problems, dubious plot contrivances and patches of overliterary dialogue. But the energy, compassion and theatrical sense are there. Though Mr. Mastrosimone hasn't pulled off his own ''Glass Menagerie'' or a blue-collar ''Talley's Folly,'' he convinces us that such achievements may eventually be within his grasp.

McGeorge Bundy told a commencement audience at the City University Graduate School yesterday that the public's instinct about major foreign policy issues was truer than that of "posturing politicians."

Paul Corvino, the businessman who had repeatedly denied entering into an agreement with Jeff Ruland, the Iona College basketball center, has now been quoted as saying that he does have such an agreement, for 10 percent of Ruland's gross earnings over the next four years.

Bronx Republicans last night endorsed Alfonse M. D'Amato, Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, on Long Island, for the nomination for United States Senator. The endorsement came despite a last-minute appeal by Senator Jacob K. Javits, the four-term Republican incumbent, that they support him.

ROBERT MANN has been first violinist of the Juilliard String Quartet since its founding in 1946 and has been largely re sponsible for the ensemble's continuity of style and the maintenance of its stature in international chamber-music circles.

Nathaniel Thayer Winthrop, a lawyer who was active in promoting international friendship and the study of religions for international understanding, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan.

BALTIMORE, June 5--President Carter, who first called for the convocation of a national conference on the problems of the family four years ago when he was campaigning for the Presidency, today opened the first of three national White House Conferences on Families.

Margo Wainwright Shean, daughter of Edward T. Shean and the late Caroline Wainwright Shean of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to John Linen Dana, son of Mr. and Mrs. William D. Dana Jr. of New Vernon, N.J., and Livingston, Mont.
LONDON, June 5, (Reuters)--Britain's two television networks today announced that they would reduce their coverage of the Summer Olympics in Moscow.

WASHINGTON, June 5--For the second time in seven months, a military computer has erroneously indicated that the Soviet Union launched nuclear missiles aimed at the United States, triggering American defenses into a higher state of alert.

Manfred Ohrenstein, the Senate minority leader, is feeling oracular these days. A few days before the 203d Legislature began, the Manhattan Democrat predicted: ''It's all going to be money, money, money, money. Things are going to be very tight. There's going to be a lot of wrangling, a lot of maneuvering, none of which will have a great effect on the election, but it will happen.'' The last five months in Albany have been all that and less. Senator Warren M. Anderson, the Republican majority leader, said last week that he wanted to close the session soon because ''as long as we're here, I think there will be no action.'' That was a safe prediction based on the Legislature's progress so far this year.

IN the roll call of local bands that have made good, one doesn't often think of the Isley Brothers, mostly because their success has been national for so long. But this sextet of five brothers and one brother-in-law - five of whom live in New Jersey and one in Westchester County, with offices in Manhattan - is surely as successful a local band as there is. The group's latest album is at the top of the soul charts and in the top 10 in the general pop charts. And tonight at 8 the group will headline a bill at Madison Square Garden. The Isley Brothers started out in the mid-1950's as a typical black vocal group with erratic and ever-shifting instrumental accompaniment. The hits started in 1959 with ''Shout'' and kept coming, off and on, throughout the 60's. But it wasn't until the early 70's, with a new business situation and the advent of a younger generation of Isleys, that the group's real commercial ascendency began. The younger Isleys brought instrumental skills the older, singing brothers lacked; henceforth the group would be self-contained on its records (with minimal outside help for the concerts). And since the record company, T-Neck, was owned by the band, which also wrote its own songs, produced its own records and booked and promoted its own tours, the Isley Brothers stand as a leading example of black entrepreneurship in the record business.

A volunteer for the National Organization for Women was indicted today on charges of offering a $1,000 bribe to an Illinois lawmaker last month to vote for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment. The indictment charges Wanda Brandstetter of Chicago with offering a $1,000 campaign contribution to Representative Nord L. Swanstrom, a freshman Republican from Pecatonica, in exchange for a ''yes'' vote on the equal rights amendment. Miss Brandstetter's attorney, Sheila Murphy, has said her client is innocent of any wrongdoing.

The news from South Korea is appalling, and its ugly essence is caught in a photograph of a soldier's boot smashing the face of a young dissident in the rebellious city of Kwangju. Having snuffed out the Kwangju uprising, Korea's generals are now engaged in a frontal assault on what remains of the democratic opposition. With speed and stealth, a shadow military regime has taken power, and it will draft a new constitution presumably tailored to the wishes of Gen. Chon Too Hwan, the emerging claimant to the throne of brass filled by the late President Park. Handwringing aside, can Washington do anything to halt Korea's slide back to military dictatorship? The junta that governs in Seoul evidently calculates Americans are too preoccupied with their own elections to trouble at the extinction of Korea's democratic hopes. Their cold-eyed assumption appears to be that the United States is too anxious about regional security to risk a cutback in military aid, including some of the 39,000 American troops stationed there. And they no doubt think Americans are too protective of their investments in a booming Korean economy to apply economic sanctions, especially through the Export-Import Bank.

To the Editor: If Ramsey Clark wants to speak for the American people, why does he not have enough respect for the democratic process to run for office? What mandate does he possess to discuss with officials of the Iranian Government issues that the elected officials of our nation have decided will not be discussesd until the hostages are released?v.hat tyranny is there in his soul that allows him to believe that he and a handful of North Vietnamese Communists or he and a handful of Iranian leftists can hammer out solutions or open dialogues that will affect millions of Americans?

Thambal Yaima will perform classical dances of Japan this weekend at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. The program includes a court dance, a palace festival dance and a snow fantasy. Shows are at 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Admission to the museum is by contribution; the show is free. Information: 873-1300. Flushing Fair Sunday

Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith announced today that he would run for the office of Hudson County Democratic chairman at the party's reorganization meeting on Tuesday. Mr. Smith pointed to President Carter's loss in Hudson in the Presidential primary on Tuesday, despite the organization's endorsement, as one reason for wanting to replace his handpicked chairman, State Senator Walter N. Sheil.

Several banks in Miami have been flooded with cash as a result of their alleged complicity in the drug trade, a Senate Committee was told today. The testimony, by Miami bankers and Government officials before the Senate Banking, Housing and Urban Affairs Committee, resulted from a Government attempt to crack down on banks in southern Florida that appear to be helping illicit drug dealers transfer funds overseas from the United States. The drug trade is believed by some Government narcotics officials to be southern Florida's biggest business, with a volume last year of $7 billion.

Five years ago she was the focus of a widely publicized matrimonial trial in which the judge ruled that, just as she helped put her husband through law school during the marriage, so must he help her through medical school after the divorce. Yesterday, Ethelyn Daniel became a doctor.
MORE than half a century has passed since Adelaide Hall sang "Diga Diga Doo" and "I Must Have That Man" in "Blackbirds of 1928." She recorded "I Must Have That Man"
JERUSALEM, June 5--The Palestinian Arab Mayor of Nablus, who lost his legs in a terrorist bombing Monday, was taken to Jordan today for medical treatment after his condition deteriorated.

Everyone knows that Gucci is a busy store. Sometimes it's darn near impossible to find a salesperson with a free minute to take one's money. Greenbacks flutter, credit cards and check books wave, and, alas, nothing happens. Time marches on.

SAVANNAH, Ga., June 5 (AP)--A Federal judge today dismissed a lawsuit by Gary Thomas Rowe, once an informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, who was trying to stop his extradition to Alabama for trial on murder charges.

The news from South Korea is appalling, and its ugly essence is caught in a photograph of a soldier's boot smashing the face of a young dissident in the rebellious city of Kwangju. Having snuffed out the Kwangju uprising, Korea's generals are now engaged in a frontal assault on what remains of the democratic opposition.
Charles Knox Robinson, a playwright, died Wednesday at Summit Park Hospital in Pomona, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Valley Cottage, N.Y.

FALLBROOK, Calif., June 5 (AP)--A day after Democrats in California nominated a local Ku Klux Klansman to Congress, the national party chairman assailed the move as "an acute embarrassment to me and to the party."

McGeorge Bundy told a commencement audience at the City University Graduate School yesterday that the public's instinct about major foreign policy issues was truer than that of ''posturing politicians.'' There is thus a great need for individuals to speak out during the Presidential campaign, the former national security adviser in the Administrations of Presidents John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson declared yesterday.

The Diamond International Corporation, the forest products company, announced yesterday that it was holding preliminary discussions in an effort to end its takeover battle with Cavenham Development Inc., the subsidiary of Cavenham Ltd., an Anglo-French supermarket and food-processing concern. The statement was contained in an amendment to a filing by Diamond with the Securities and Exchange Commission. ''No negotiation is being undertaken, nor is under way, by Diamond in reponse to the tender offer by Cavenham Development,'' the company said, ''except that representatives of Diamond are having certain preliminary discussions which might result in a tender offer by another company, financing for a tender offer by Diamond, or a standstill arrangement with Cavenham Development and its affiliates.''

Everyone knows that Gucci is a busy store. Sometimes it's darn near impossible to find a salesperson with a free minute to take one's money. Greenbacks flutter, credit cards and check books wave, and, alas, nothing happens. Time marches on. But a new era may be dawning. For some people. And about time. Should someone interested in an $11,000 handbag with an 18-karat-gold chain (but the chain can also be used as a necklace), an 18-karatgold minaudiere that weighs two pounds (for $22,000 one likes to feel some weight), or a $400,000 emerald necklace, be expected to line up behind someone buying a $28 key chain? No, no, and another no.

IT can safely be said these days that Louise Nevelson holds New York in the palm of her hand. A view of her work - or of the glamorous sculptor herself - can be had without much strain in almost any part of the city: for instance, two big Nevelson shows are running, at the Pace Gallery, 32 East 57th Street, and at Wildenstein, 19 East 64th Street, and a giant Nevelson sculpture in steel, ''Frozen Laces - One 1979-80,'' has just been installed at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street. And now, as a tribute for her 80th birthday (she was actually born in 1899, but some poetic license has been taken), as well as to its own 50th, the Whitney Museum has mounted a show (through Sept. 7) of the famous Nevelson environments, done mostly in the 1950's and 60's. They marked her first assembling of the sculptures she had made of carved, painted and ''found'' wood objects into massive walls, which established her firmly as one of the world's leading artists. So accustomed are we to the powerfully expressive presence of these works that it seems difficult in 1980 to remember a time when they were not a part of our image bank. As Edward Albee suggests in his essay for the show's catalogue, the world has looked different since we began to accept the Nevelson constructions, with their accretions of dream detritus that suggest the vast and secret baggage of a collective inner life. It isn't every artist who can ''mythicize'' in an unbelieving age, and the furious energy and conviction that saw the sculptor's vision through still excite our amazed admiration.

The United Illuminating Company said six of its workers were seriously burned today by an explosion of pressurized steam when a valve malfunctioned at its Bridgeport Harbor station. The company said the accident occurred at 10:30 A.M. as the station was being brought back into operation after having been out of service for several weeks for maintenance and overhaul.

The Justice Department sued the New York State Health Department today in an attempt to compel it to turn over studies of the health of several thousand people who live in and near the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, N.Y. In the action in Federal Court in Buffalo, the Justice Department said it needed the reports as part of the $124.5 million suit it filed last December against the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation for dumping toxic chemicals in the canal in the late 1940's and early 1950's.

William O. Collom, 48 years old, a long-time executive of Ryder System Inc. until last November, has been named president and chief operating officer of Jartran Inc. Jartran, a truck leasing and rental company, was created in October 1978 by James A. Ryder, 66, an industry pioneer who founded the giant corporation bearing his name in 1932, and who left it a few months before starting the new concern.

Following are the votes by Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the 335-to-34 rollcall, by which the House today overrode President Carter's veto of legislation that rejected the oil-import fee. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to override the veto. A ''no'' vote is a vote to sustain the veto. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. Voting ''yes'' were 193 Democrats and 142 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 34 Democrats and no Republicans. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

INVESTORS are intrigued by the possibilities in the announced intention of the United Artists Theatre Circuit to buy all its publicly held shares. The company, second-largest theater owner in the United States after the General Cinema Corporation, has 773 movie auditoriums - some with multiple theaters. They are mostly first-run houses and are situated in 24 states. The shares are traded over the counter. The company is currently studying a transaction whereby its motionpicture exhibition activities would become privately held by Robert and Marshall Naify, the company's principal owners, with 52 percent of the stock.

ARE folk music and dancing no more than exercises in ethnic nostalgia - celebrations of foreign places long ago and far away? Or are they living American art forms drawing on this country's multicultural population? For almost 15 years the Balkan Arts Center has been promoting the enduring value of ethnic music in the United States -good music played and danced skillfully with no costumes or gimcracks to get in the way of the artistry. Tomorrow the center will show off some of its musical discoveries at the fifth annual Queens Immigrant Ethnic Music Festival in Astoria's Bohemian Hall. In concerts and workshops beginning at noon, and a dance party from 6 P.M. to midnight, audiences can listen to, learn and join in the music and dancing of Armenia, Rumania, Greece, Italy, Yugoslavia and Scandinavia. (The Balkan Arts Center has never limited itself to the Balkans.) Instrumentalists will include players of the Pontic Greek lyra, a Bulgarian bagpipe, Calabrian tambourines and Norwegian fiddles. There also will be food: Dimitri Gesker, a member of Astoria's Greek community, will be roasting lamb over an open fire, and homemade dishes will be sold along with drinks of all kinds.
"JOHN SINGER SARGENT" at the Coe Kerr Gallery, 49 East 82d Street, is based upon the idea that there were two Sar gents: one who painted for the great world that loved and stifled him, and...
ANY handsome young actor can swagger on to a stage, throw his weight around and create a disruption. But when Peter Weller--jittery as an alley cat but not quite as mean--crashes on stage in...
WHILE a woman cawed like a bird, another woman ate an envelope and a man bayed like a dog. A woman commanded a glove, "Fly!" When the glove remained motionless, the woman...
The ERC Corporation announced yesterday that its board of directors had voted unanimously to endorse the previously announced offer by the Getty Oil Corporation to acquire it.

FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., June 5--Nobody wanted this instant city of barracks, barricades and barbed wire--not the 19,048 Cubans who have been flown here, not the state of Arkansas and certainly not the nervous citizens of nearby Barling (population 3,145), where the refugees are invariably referred to as "aliens."

GUATEMALA--Around 4.30 P.M. on May 27, minutes after leaving his job at the local Coca-Cola bottling plant, Marlon Mendizabal stood waiting for a bus to take him home. Suddenly a car carrying four men pulled up beside him. Two of the men aimed submachine guns at him and opened fire. He died instantly.

LOS ANGELES, June 5--The men who built the first airplane to make a sustained flight powered only by human muscles said today that they planned to fly the first aircraft powered solely by rays of the sun.

WASHINGTON, June 5--The Justice Department sued the New York State Health Department today in an attempt to compel it to turn over studies of the health of several thousand people who live in and near the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, N.Y.
NAIRN, Scotland, June 5 (AP)--A tornado-like storm struck this seaside resort today, flipping over dozens of vacation trailers and blowing out windows. Nine persons were reported injured.
WASHINGTON, June 5--Several banks in Miami have been flooded with cash as a result of their alleged complicity in the drug trade, a Senate Committee was told today.

QUEBEC, June 5--An official commission of inquiry into the "disastrous" costs of Montreal's 1976 Olympic Games told a tale today of irresponsibility, incompetence, corruption, fraud and greed that led to a final deficit of well over a billion dollars.

President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said today that the Common Market should slow plans to admit Spain and Portugal until the community's nine present members have resolved difficulties over agriculture. Addressing a group of farmers' representatives, the French President said the recent quarrel over Britain's share of the Common Market's farm budget showed that Britain was not yet fully integrated into the community. He said it would thus be unwise to embark on a ''second enlargment'' until the present members had completed the first, which gave membership to Britain, Denmark and Ireland seven years ago.

Two members of Congress from Philadelphia, the Mayor of Camden, N.J., and two lawyers from Philadelphia pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to bribery and conspiracy charges growing out of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam undercover operation. At an arraignment session in a packed courtroom, defense attorneys indicated that their strategy would be to try to get the charges dismissed before trial on the ground of ''prosecutorial misconduct'' in the form of ''leaks'' about the investigation that created ''pretrial publicity.''

Following the lead of some banks on Wednesday, several of the nation's larger banks lowered their prime rates a full percentage point to 13 percent yesterday. One small bank in Miami reduced its prime by one point to 12 1/2 percent. The reduction to 13 percent was taken yesterday by the Bankers Trust Company, the Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles, the First National Bank of Boston, the Bank of New York, the Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago and the Trust Company Bank in Atlanta.

Cyrus R. Vance, in his first public appearance since resigning as Secretary of State in April, said today that the United States must not allow the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan to continue to delay Senate approval of the treaty limiting nuclear arms. Addressing Harvard's 329th commencement exercises, Mr. Vance spoke with urgency about the need to approve

Kraft Inc., a dominant force in the packaged foods industry, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to merge with Dart Industries Inc., a housewares and chemicals manufacturer generally regarded as having more exciting growth possibilities. The agreement, which was completed less than four weeks after the first meetings between Kraft and Dart executives, would create the nation's 27th largest industrial company, to be called Dart & Kraft Inc.

The House of Representatives today approved legislation that would authorize $5.2 billion in foreign aid, including $53.7 million for Nicaragua, for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1. The vote, 221 to 147, followed a nine-hour debate in which conservative members expressed fears about an expansion of Communist influence in developing countries.

China signed a multimillion-dollar contract today with a consortium of foreign companies to build a steel complex described as the largest single industrial project in the country's history. The Baoshan Steel Works, on the estuary of the Yangtze River, is to be completed in about five years and will rank as one of the world's largest and most modern plants, annually producing six million tons of raw steel. Total cost of the project will be about $5 billion.

The clowns who call themselves the Cumeezi Bozo Ensemble enjoy surprising people. They appear unexpectedly on some street in the city and engage pedestrians in improvised, silent and comic encounters. But here is a tip. They will be at Lexington Avenue and 53d Street today from 12:30 to 1:30 P.M. Wearing outlandish costumes, playing kazoos and carrying butterfly nets, they will begin their summer series of ''Free Public Laughs.'' If you have clown ambitions, you may join a workshop on the four Saturdays in June taught by the group's director, Eric Trules, at 168 Mercer Street ($40 for the series). Information: 691-7950. FAMILY ON UPPER WEST SIDE

Despite an increase in seasonal apparel sales, retail business in May generally continued to reflect a trend of reduced consumer buying across the country, sales reports from the nation's largest retailers indicated yesterday. Five major chains said they had smaller sales gains or larger declines in the month compared with those reported so far in the fiscal year, which began Feb. 2.

Roy R. Bumsted Jr., the president and chief executive officer of the Unette Corporation, a custom packaging company in Parsippany, N.J., died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 60 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

ROBERT MANN has been first violinist of the Juilliard String Quartet since its founding in 1946 and has been largely responsible for the ensemble's continuity of style and the maintenance of its stature in international chamber-music circles. Now and then over the years he has turned up in a solo role, but like most musicians who opt for quartet life, Mr. Mann has submerged himself so successfully into his group that it is not easy to think of him as a separate artistic entity. However, last night's concert at the 92d Street Y let one understand that there is a Robert Mann who retains his own performing personality and viewpoint. Thirty-four years of sitting in a quartet might be expected to dull certain sensibilities and produce artistic callouses, but that has not happened to the Juilliard's leader.

Money for water projects has been dammed in the United States Senate. Although Congress has over the years approved projects in the West and South that could eventually cost Washington $30 billion, opposition to the frequent waste on waterworks has put a stop to appropriations. As a result, some sound projects have been left as high and dry as the unsound ones.

CENTRAL PARK was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux "to provide the best practical means of healthful recreation for the inhabitants of all classes," as an early plan for the park stated.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 5--When the orchestra playing this week for the 26th constitutional convention of the United Automobile Workers played "Taps" in honor of members who died in the three years since the last convention, Lacey Brooks Jr., one of the 3,000 workers gathered here, remarked, "They played it for us."

OTTAWA, June 5 (Reuters)--Canada's first-quarter trade deficit on the current-account basis fell to $680 million (Canadian), seasonally adjusted, from a downward revised $894 million deficit in the fourth quarter and a $1.59 billion deficit in the 1979 first quarter, Statistics Canada said today.

JASPER, Ark., June 5 (UPI)--A chartered bus carrying a group of Texas tourists went out of control early today on a dangerous mountain highway, slid down a steep embankment along a rocky bluff and smashed into trees, killing 20 persons and injuring 13.

MONTREAL, June 5 (AP)--Wayne Gretzky, the young and talented center of the Edmonton Oilers, has won the Hart Memorial Trophy as the National Hockey League's most valuable player last season and the Lady Byng Memorial Trophy as the most gentlemanly player, the league announced today.

Despite an increase in seasonal apparel sales, retail business in May generally continued to reflect a trend of reduced consumer buying across the country, sales reports from the nation's largest retailers indicated yesterday.

PARIS, June 5--Deviating from her normal baseline style, Chris Evert Lloyd defeated Hana Mandlikova of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-2, 6-2, today and reached the final of the French open tennis championships for the fifth time.
WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--A move to put the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in charge of a growing Government effort in automobile research was diverted today.

DETROIT, June 5--The Big Three auto makers announced today that because of poor auto sales, they would lay off 34,965 workers next week and temporarily shut down four more assembly plants around the country.
Earle R. MacAusland, the founder and publisher of Gourmet Magazine, died Wednesday at the age of 90 at his home on Nantucket, Mass.
Two letters from "Croatian freedom fighters" claimed responsibility yesterday for Tuesday night's bomb explosion at the museum in the Statue of Liberty.

MIAMI, June 5--A former Florida highway patrolman was indicted today in the first case in a Federal investigation of more than a dozen cases of alleged police brutality that preceded last month's racial violence here.

Stephane Grappelli seems much too young to be ''the grand old man of European jazz,'' as one critic has called him. It's true that the urbane, white-haired violinist was born in 1908, but when one goes to see him perform, the soul, elegance and vigor of his playing make the most lasting impression. He stands easily, swaying gently back and forth in front of the microphone, while his two acoustic guitarists, one of whom is some 50 years his junior, sit in chairs beside him. The 37-year-old American guitarist Larry Coryell, whom Mr. Grappelli says ''I like so much,'' has remarked that playing with the violinist had made him realize, ''when a cat is so good - he swings, he's creative, he's exciting - it doesn't matter how old you are.'' Tonight and tomorrow night at 9 and midnight, Mr. Grappelli will be performing at the Other End, 147 Bleeker Street, an intimate club that should be the perfect place to savor his supple lyricism. Admission is $7, with a $2.50 food or drink minimum; for more information or reservations, call 673-7030. Sunday, Mr. Grappelli will be at My Father's Place, 19 Bryant Avenue in Roslyn Village, L.I.; information, (516) 621-8700. The shows at My Father's Place should be particularly interesting because Mr. Grappelli will be sharing the bill with an exceptional young Indian violinist with experience in both Indian classical music and jazz, L. Shankar.

The Marsh & McLennan Companies of New York, the largest United States insurance broker, said yesterday that, in a further development of its takeover of C.T. Bowring & Company, the big London insurance concern, holders of Bowring convertible loan stock had approved acceptance of the American company's loan stock proposals. These make possible a purchase by Marsh & McLennan of 100 percent of the loan stock. Marsh & McLennan said that its offers for the ordinary and preference shares of Bowring had been declared unconditional in all respects and that its proposals to Bowring's convertible loan shareholders had become effective. As of Wednesday, Marsh & McLennan had received 103,420 ordinary shares of Bowring stock, representing 92.9 percent of the total ordinary shares outstanding.

TALK about intercultural: ''The Lion and the Jewel,'' now playing through Sunday at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater in Lincoln Center, is a story about a bush village by a Nigerian writer done as an American (Afro-American, if you prefer) musical by an American man of jazz. What's more, it has a message, a few messages, but they are so well phrased that you will have fun receiving them. ''The Lion and the Jewel'' was written a few decades ago by Wole Soyinka, the Nigerian dramatist. Three years ago, Billy Taylor, the jazz composer and pianist, was commissioned to do a score for it. The result is now a highlight of the International Performing Arts Festival at Lincoln Center, where it will play through Sunday and then, from next Wednesday through June 15, be seen at the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art, 36 West 62d Street.

Dr. Richard E. Weitzman, associate professor of medicine at the School of Medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, died Saturday at Columbia Memorial Hospital, Hudson, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 36 years old and had lived in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., before becoming ill. Dr. Weitzman was director of the section on hypertension in the Division of Nephrology and Hypertension at Harbor-U.C.L.A. Medical Center, where he formed the faculty in 1976 after a two-year research fellowship.

To the Editor: I couldn't agree more with Michel Jobert when he says that it is not easy for Europeans and Americans to understand each other (Op-Ed May 28). One reason for this may be the distortions that take place in former foreign ministers' minds when they write about events in which they participated. v.hen Jobert says that ''in 1973 and 1975, the United States put pressure on its European allies to accept the Helsinki conference on security and cooperation in Europe, an idea that the Russians had been urging and the Europeans had been rejecting since the 1950's,'' one can only conclude that six years out of office have had a powerful effect on his memory.

New York City should not submit to threats by real estate interests and meekly hand over an East Side playground in a swap in order to prevent destruction of two small parks in the middle of the private Tudor City development. Tudor City, 12 apartment houses with 5,000 tenants, between 41st and 43d Streets and First and Second Avenues, has two private parks, north and south of 42d St. A simmering controversy over construction of apartment towers on the park sites erupted over the Memorial Day weekend when Tudor City's owners sent workmen who boarded up one of the parks and positioned bulldozers nearby. The Tudor City Tenants Association obtained a restraining order temporarily preventing further work. At a news conference, the owners, represented by Helmsley-Spear Inc., stood firm, allowing only that they would not destroy the parks if the city agreed to turn over, in a swap, a public playground across the street from the United Nations, at the southeast corner of First Avenue and 42d Street.

ADELE is a carniverous plant with a foamy tongue and maggotty tendrils, and ''Dinner for Adele'' is her story. This Czechoslovak comedy, which is largely a send-up of spy stories, takes an incessantly madcap tone, suggesting that the people who made the movie had a grander, giddier time than you will. Nevertheless, while its high spirits seem exhausting and not entirely warranted, the film has an affable spirit and a good share of ingenious comic touches. ''Dinner for Adele,'' which opens today at the D.W. Griffith and New Yorker theaters, was directed by Oldrich Lipsky, whose joke on the cowboy film was ''Lemonade Joe.'' This time, Mr. Lipsky takes for his main character Nick Carter, the famed detective, presented here as a kind of antiquated James Bond. Nick Carter, as played by Michal Docolomansky, is impeccably suave and a little bit confused. He is also equipped with fancy pre-Bondian gadgets, gifts from friends named Laser and Edison and so on, that do him absolutely no good in a pinch.

The Black & Decker Manufacturing Company, the world's largest producer of portable power tools, says it will close two plants in Maryland for two weeks this summer because of a slowdown in sales. The shutdowns will affect about 2,200 workers at the company's Hampstead plant and 250 to 300 employees at its Easton plant, a company spokesman said today.

John B. Anderson paused in his perky, wide-eyed way this morning and offered the political world a new four-letter word. ''Lote,'' he said at a news conference, looking for an instant like an anthropologist greeting a subtribe of wire- and lensworshipers. ''Lote - 'the lesser of two evils,' '' the Republican Congressman explained, as his definition of what voters would face in a choice limited to President Carter and Ronald Reagan in November.

Major league baseball owners voted ratification today of a basic player contract agreed upon in principle last month under a strike threat. Ray Grebey, attorney for the owners, said the vote was 21 to 5 in favor. The five clubs voting against the pact were St. Louis, Oakland, Minnesota, Cleveland and San Diego, Grebey said.

The General Motors Corporation's legal objections to the nation's first big synthetic gas project may delay it for a year, one of its developers said today. Arthur Seder, chairman of the American Natural Resources Company, said G.M.'s stance is likely to force postponement of construction of the Great Plains Project, a $1.5 billion coal-gasification plant in North Dakota. Other members of the development consortium are the Peoples Energy Corporation of Chicago, Columbia Gas System of Delaware, Tenneco Inc. of Houston and Transco Companies, also of Houston.
The British Petroleum Company Ltd., the second-largest oil company outside the United States, said yesterday that its first-quarter profits rose 87 percent from a year earlier
Stock prices lost their upward momentum yesterday as the market once again ran into an area of potential selling pressure.

Eight thousand degrees were awarded by New York University in Washington Square Park yesterday. Trumpets blared, the park's usually dormant fountain gushed, purple banners waved, colored balloons floated overhead and relieved and triumphant parents applauded.
RECIFE, Brazil, June 5 (UPI)--An explosion in a store selling fireworks killed 3 people and injured 30 today in the northeast town of Garanhus, officials said.
WHEN Robbie Robertson telephoned to say he wanted to come over to discuss "a project," Gary Busey was ecstatic. "I thought it was going to be about making an album," the actor said.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--Following are the votes by Representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the 335-to-34 roll-call, by which the House today overrode President Carter's veto of legislation that rejected the oil-import fee. A "yes" vote is a vote to override the veto.

The transcontinental airline fare war escalated as four major carriers announced $99 one-way prices for nighttime flights this month between New York and California. The actions were touched off by Eastern Air Lines, which filed its new fare with the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday morning. United Airlines, Trans World Airlines and American Airlines each announced comparable $99 fares several hours later. None of the airlines placed advance-purchase, or minimum-stay restrictions on the new night-coach fares. The $99 fare is effective today on Eastern and American, and tomorrow on T.W.A. and United.

Dennis Leonard pitched a three-hitter and Frank White smashed a three-run homer tonight as the Kansas City Royals routed the Texas Rangers, 9-0. The Rangers, who have three starting pitchers out with injuries, gave Jim Kern his first start in four years. Kern gave up White's homer in the third. The Royals collected 14 hits, including two home runs, a triple and two doubles, against four pitchers.

The partisan dispute over how to subsidize the deficit of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority continued today when the Republicans presented their own plan, but attached so many conditions to it that the Democrats said it was no program at all. The ability to avert a major fare increase on New York City's buses and subways and on the M.T.A.'s commuter railroad lines remained in serious doubt.

President Carter vetoed legislation rejecting his oil-import fee of $4.62-a-barrel, provoking an immediate Congressional move to override the veto in a dramatic legislative defeat for Mr. Carter. The House, which voted 376 to 30 on Wednesday to kill the fee, was to vote on the veto last night, and the Senate, which turned the fee down by 73 to 16, was due to vote on the override today. Congress last overrode a veto by a President of its own party in 1952, when Harry S. Truman tried to block a controversial immigration bill. (Page A1.) Gulf & Western said the first practical electric vehicle had become a reality, because of a zinc-chloride battery system it had developed. David Jim Judelson, president, said the battery could be in production within four years and would save the country about 1 million barrels of oil daily by the year 2000. He said that a Volkswagen Rabbit equipped with the battery could carry four passengers 150 miles at 55 miles per hour after a six- to eight-hour charge. (A1.)

The Government reported today that number of people filing initial claims for unemployment insurance remained at near-record levels in late May, bolstering expectations of a sharp jump in last month's jobless rate, which is to be announced tomorrow. The Labor Department said that a seasonally adjusted total of 673,000 unemployed Americans filed first claims for benefits in the week ended May 24, down only slightly from the record 675,000 who filed claims the week before.

The Mobil Corporation said that ''mechanical difficulties'' had forced it to halt the drilling of one of its offshore wells in the Hibernia oil field, 190 miles off the Canadian province of Newfoundland.
WEEKEND SUB CAPTION WITH BALKAN PAGE C1 The New York Times/Edward Hausner Petar Avramescu, left, and Vasa Dodenc play in the Immigrant Music Festival. Page C21.

The District of Columbia government, which thought that it would run a municipal deficit of $90 million to $174 million this year, has suddenly been forced to start looking for $284 million additional to manage debts acquired over the last decade and almost $1.4 billion more to keep city pension funds afloat. As a result, expressions of alarm here about maintaining city services and civic peace under an operating deficit, which requires heavy cuts in police and other services, have taken on new gravity.

IN the revival of Meredith Willson's cheerfully melodic and rhythmically irresistible ''The Music Man'' at City Center, lanky Dick Van Dyke is taking his turn at playing the con man who persuades the gullible parents of a small Iowa town that their progeny are immensely gifted at playing cornet, fife and trombone. Late in the second act, things are rather catching up with him - especially since it's been discovered that he can't read a note a music - and there's a good bit of hot-footed pursuit going on in front of backdrops purporting to represent the Middle Western picnic grounds, ivied porches and moonlit hollows of 1912.

The Securities and Exchange Commission voted today to relax the rules of national stock exchanges that limit off-board transactions by their members. The rules currently prohibit most brokerage houses from buying and selling listed securities for clients over the counter - that is, off the floor of the exchange.

William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, shuffled the agency's top ranks today to fill a vacancy left by the departure of a senior official. Mr. Webster named Francis M. Mullen to be executive assistant director in charge of investigations, one of three supervisory positions on the level immediately below that of Director.

The Detroit Pistons ended months of guessing yesterday by naming Scotty Robertson, an assistant with the Houston Rockets last season, as their coach. Robertson is the 16th Piston coach since the franchise moved to Detroit from Fort Wayne, Ind., for the 1957-58 season.

WASHINGTON, June 5--Senator Edward M. Kennedy emerged from a private, 45-minute meeting with President Carter in the Oval Office today and announced that he had "every intention of continuing in this campaign as a candidate" for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), which markets its products under the brand name Amoco, reported yesterday that it had found a flow of natural gas with "significant production potential" from a wildcat well in northeastern Utah, part of the so-called Overthrust Belt.
PALO ALTO, Calif., June 5 (UPI)-- Stanford University said today it had learned that its teaching assistant's handbook section on plagiarism had been plagiarized by the University of Oregon.

NOW that the National Bureau of Economic Research has certified that the economy is in recession, with its decision that the last cyclical expansion peaked in January, the big question is where and when the bottom will be reached.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 5--Franklin Jacobs of Fairleigh Dickinson University failed to appear tonight for qualifying in the high jump at the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.

When word of the proposed merger between Dart Industries and Kraft Inc. reached one analyst yesterday, he said he surmised that Justin Whitlock Dart had determined that the time was approaching for a an extended stint in Washington.

For the second time in seven months, a military computer has erroneously indicated that the Soviet Union launched nuclear missiles aimed at the United States, triggering American defenses into a higher state of alert. The Pentagon disclosed today that before dawn Tuesday a computer in the North American Air Defense Command set off signals that Soviet missiles from submarines and Russian land bases were flying toward targets here.

Nathaniel Thayer Winthrop, a lawyer who was active in promoting international friendship and the study of religions for international understanding, died Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan. From 1955 until he retired in 1977, Mr. Winthrop was a member of the law firm of Shearman & Sterling. His son Beekman said yesterday that he had begun recently to intensify his interest in the Center for the Study of World Religions, affiliated with the Harvard University Divinity School.

To the Editor: So all the money is now headed south. Well, just look at it as a form of affirmative action to make up for the discriminatory freight rates and other such blessings bestowed upon us during the long years of Northeastern financial domination. T.H. JEWETT Atlanta, May 27, 1980

Associated Dry Goods Corporation has elected to its board Alfred J. Moccia, vice chairman and chief financial officer of the Sperry Rand Corporation. * Carson Pirie Scott & Company, Chicago-based retailer, has appointed Charles T. Reice vice president, finance and treasurer. * Enserch Corporation, Dallas, a diversified energy company, has named William Wallace 3d president and chief executive officer of Ebasco Services Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary.

Earle R. MacAusland, the founder and publisher of Gourmet Magazine, died Wednesday at the age of 90 at his home on Nantucket, Mass. Remembered by friends and colleagues as a man of great taste, style and foresight, Mr. MacAusland predicted the American interest in fine dining long before any other publisher made efforts in that direction. After positions with several magazine publishers, including the Butterick Publishing Company and the Parents' Publishing Company, Mr. MacAusland started Gourmet in December 1941. Years later he attributed the early success of his magazine, at least in part, to the period in which it was begun.

TWO Japanese films, as fascinating for their social and political implications as for their extraordinary cinematic values, open today at the Thalia Theater. They are Akira Kurosawa's ''No Regrets for Our Youth,'' made in 1946, only three years after his directorial debut and before he made such classics as ''Rashomon,'' ''The Seven Samurai,'' ''The Drunken Angel'' and ''Ikiru,'' and Mikio Naruse's ''Floating Clouds'' (1955), the work of one of Japan's finest directors who is still virtually unknown in this country. Because of the passage of time, the Kurosawa movie operates on several levels that didn't exist at the time it was produced. There's not a frame of this film that is not informed by our awareness of the body of work that the then comparatively young (36) director would go on to create. Then, too, one is acutely conscious of the conditions under which ''No Regrets for Our Youth'' was made.

Two more Soviet astronauts were rocketed into orbit yesterday in the first manned flight of a new and more sophisticated version of the Soyuz spacecraft. Tass, the Soviet press agency, called the spacecraft, designated Soyuz-T2, an ''improved model'' of the vehicle that has been the workhorse of the Soviet space program since the 1960's. The Moscow radio described it as a ''perfected'' space capsule, with innovations in the propulsion, life-support and navigation systems.

BECAUSE so much close supervision is required to run even one restaurant kitchen successfully, it is somewhat strartling to learn that Queh-yuen Tang is supervising the cooking not only at her original and very good Hwa Yuan Szechuan Inn on East Broadway in Chinatown, but now also at four other outposts scattered around the city. Even if the word ''supervising'' is given the loosest interpretation, it is hard to believe that any one person can exercise meaningful control over so large and far-flung a culinary fiefdom. Her newest effort is the seven-month-old Tang Tang on First Avenue, between 76th and 77th Streets, and on the evidence of recent visits and the sampling of some 20 dishes, Mrs. Tang is spreading her talents much too thin, even though it is said that she does most of the dinner cooking at Tang Tang. Although there are several dishes good enough to rely on if one is in this neighborhood, the kitchen's performance is so uneven it hardly seems related to the superior parent restaurant downtown. The management seems to be caught off guard so frequently that it is unprepared for busy evenings. The result is a sense of emergency that is communicated to diners, spoiling the easy relaxation that the simple and handsome modern wood-structured interior might otherwise impart.

Two stone bas-relief sculptures high on the facade of the Bonwit Teller Building under demolition on Fifth Avenue -pieces that had been sought with enthusiasm by the Metropolitan Museum of Art - were smashed by jackhammers yesterday on the orders of a real estate developer. The destruction of the Art Deco panels stunned some art appraisers and elicited expressions of surprise and disappointment from officials of the Met, where they were to have been installed by the department of 20th-century art. One appraiser placed their value at several hundred thousand dollars.

Nancy Lopez-Melton stepped out her front door today and shot a five-under-par 67. It gave her a two-shot lead in the first round of the 26th annual Ladies' Professional Golf Association Championship. This was Mrs. Melton's second round of 67 or lower in five days and it was achieved on the Kings Island Grizzly Course, where she and her husband, Tim, live in a house less than 100 feet to the left of the 18th tee. It also was another strong indication that her golf game may be back together again.

James Robison was ordered today to be retried June 23 on a first-degree murder charge in the 1976 bombing death of Don Bolles, a reporter. However, a defense motion to dismiss the charge is to be heard June 13, based on a possible conflict of interest because Gov. Bruce Babbitt, who was Attorney General at the time of the slaying, was said to have been another target of Mr. Bolles's alleged killers.

A move to put the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in charge of a growing Government effort in automobile research was diverted today. The House Commerce Committee voted to change pending legislation so that it calls for a study of the transfer, rather than the actual transfer, of various agencies' research to the space agency over the next two years.
An explosion in a store selling fireworks killed 3 people and injured 30 today in the northeast town of Garanhus, officials said.

MORE than half a century has passed since Adelaide Hall sang ''Diga Diga Doo'' and ''I Must Have That Man'' in ''Blackbirds of 1928.'' She recorded ''I Must Have That Man'' with Duke Ellington's orchestra in 1933, and now, when she is in her 70's, hearing her sing this same song at Michael's Pub, where she is making her first nightclub appearance in New York since the early 30's, one marvels at how little her singing has changed over all these years. Even with a slight huskiness, caused, she says, by going out on Fifth Avenue without a scarf, Miss Hall's voice has a vital, vibrant quality that coils around a listener's ears. On both this number and another ''Blackbirds'' song, ''I Can't Give You Anything but Love,'' her beat and her emphasis are precisely right, easy but swinging, projected with a secure, confident presence. And on a very different song of the early 30's, Duke Ellington's ''Sophisticated Lady,'' her simple, direct approach, her voice sometimes floating over the melody with a semispoken delivery, caught the mood of the song without overdramatizing it.

Most bridge experts are active all the year round, attending every convenient tournament and perhaps some that are inconvenient. A few, however, hibernate for a season or even a year or two, emerging when warm sunshine gives promise of good things to come and prospective partners beckon. One of these is Merle Tom of Cos Cob, Conn., a former National Open Pairs champion who has played little in recent years. He emerged during the past season to compete in the Grand National Team Championship. Although his team was defeated in this knockout event, he is, paradoxically, still in contention.

A 3-year-old girl and her 55-year-old grandfather died when fire swept their apartment on the top floor of a seven-story Harlem building, the Fire Department said. The victims, found about six minutes apart in separate bedrooms, were Grant Miller and Jaquel Wynn, according to a department spokesman, John Mulligan.

TEL AVIV, June 5--Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office denied an American press report today that the Prime Minister's Government had offered King Hussein of Jordan a territorial compromise that would restore parts of the West Bank to Jordanian rule.
BEIRUT, Friday, June 6 (Reuters) --The Beirut bureau chief of Reuters was shot and wounded early today by an unidentified gunman who fired at him from a passing car.
Anna Fitch Ardenghi, a philanthropist who in 1953 arranged to have potter's field in New Haven entirely refurbished, died Monday at her home in New Haven. She was 93 years old.

TRENTON, June 5--The New Jersey Pinelands Commission outlined a master plan today for preserving more than a million acres of the state's unusual Pine Barrens as a national reserve.

WASHINGTON, June 3--The District of Columbia government, which thought that it would run a municipal deficit of $90 million to $174 million this year, has suddenly been forced to start looking for $284 million additional to manage debts acquired over the last decade and almost $1.4 billion more to keep city pension funds afloat.

PARIS, June 5--President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said today that the Common Market should slow plans to admit Spain and Portugal until the community's nine present members have resolved difficulties over agriculture.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 5 (Reuters) --Riot policemen burst into the Public Pedagogical University in northern Bogota today, dislodging 800 students who seized the building last night. The police said 300 students were arrested.

Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that it had developed a new battery system that would permit the manufacture of a practical electric car able to go 150 miles, at 55 miles an hour, without a recharge.

A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with criminally negligent homicide in the fatal shooting of an off-duty Immigration and Naturalization Service officer. The police said they believed the shooting was a tragic accident involving friends but that the case would be presented to a grand jury.

Two members of Congress from Philadelphia, the Mayor of Camden, N.J., and two lawyers from Philadelphia pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday to bribery and conspiracy charges growing out of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam undercover operation.
