THE 80th annual convention of the American Booksellers Association opening in Chicago tomorrow comes at a moment in publishing and marketing when books are as varied and available as at any time in the last decade.

"I like New York in June. How about you?" This weekend, the answer to the question posed in that 1941 Burton Lane-Ralph Freed song has got to be a resounding "yes," as four neighborhoods celebrate the month that turns spring into summer and makes New York an extrovert.

David A. (Sonny) Werblin, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the New York Knicks, sent for General Manager Eddie Donovan and Coach Red Holzman on Wednesday while attending the annual meetings of the N.B.A.'s owners in California.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy emerged from a private, 45-minute meeting with President Carter in the Oval Office today and announced that he had ''every intention of continuing in this campaign as a candidate'' for the Democratic Presidential nomination. Moments later, Mr. Carter told reporters in his office that ''the most important difference'' separating them in their attempt to deal with the breach in the Democratic Party was the Massachusetts Senator's repeated call for a televised debate on the issues - a demand that Mr. Kennedy repeated today and that the President made clear he did not intend to meet.

The men who built the first airplane to make a sustained flight powered only by human muscles said today that they planned to fly the first aircraft powered solely by rays of the sun. The airplane, they said, will carry photovoltaic solar cells that convert the sun's rays to electricity and energize a conventional electric motor that will turn a propeller and carry the craft aloft. A flight of 100 miles is planned for this fall.

To the Editor: In your May 19 editorial ''Voting Rights and Wrongs,'' you state, ''Anyone setting out to discriminate no longer says openly, as the Mayor of Richmond, Va., said just a decade ago, 'Niggers won't take over this town.' '' was Mayor of Richmond at that time, and I have publicly denied having made that statement, which was attributed to the Mayor during an annexation case by a person who was being annexed.

Melba Liston, a pioneer as a female jazz trombonist in the 1940's and 50's who moved to Jamaica in 1974 to teach, is back in town, playing her horn again and heading a seven-piece all-woman jazz group called Melba Liston and Company. Miss Liston will start picking up her jazz career again at 8 tomorrow night in a concert at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street, that is part of the eight-day Salute to Women in Jazz. It will be a transitional appearance for Miss Liston because she will be playing not with the new group on which she is basing her future but with some male friends, including Leon Thomas, the singer, Cameron Brown, the basist, and Charli Persip, the drummer, who were part of her past. But, four of the six sidewomen in Miss Liston's ''Company'' are also appearing in the ''Salute'' at the head of their own groups: tonight at Symphony Space, Janice Robinson, the trombonist, leads her quartet, and Sharon Freeman, the pianist and French horn player, appears with her group, ''Eleven;'' Carline Ray, the bassist, will lead a band as part of a free concert at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center on Sunday that will last from noon until 9 P.M., and last Monday, on the second day of the ''Salute,'' Jean Fineberg, the saxophonist, appeared with her group, ''Deuce.''

Brig. Gen. James C. Rosborough, who fought in the Battle of the Bulge in World War II, died Sunday at his home in suburban Newtown Square. He was 85 years old. A veteran of World War I, he returned to Europe in World War II as a lieutenant colonel in the 28th Division. In the Battle of the Bulge, Hitler's final big offensive on the Western Front, he led a successful attack to rescue a group of American troops who had been cut off by a surprise German attack.

And since it wants to make a splash - the phrase used was ''breakthrough advertising'' - it has turned to George Lois and the troops at Lois Pitts Gershon. You know how George feels about breakthrough advertising. His own examples: ''When you've got it, flaunt it'' for Braniff; the current ''Newsbreakers'' campaign for WCBS-TV Channel 2 news; ''I want my Maypo,'' the Olivetti girl and the Edwards & Hanley brokerage advertising of yesteryear.

The final primary round on Super Tuesday confirmed what has been apparent for weeks - that Democrats are profoundly unhappy about nominating Jimmy Carter or Edward Kennedy, so much so that many threaten to bolt either candidate in the fall. But if the nomination of either thus risks a divided party, so does the only alternative, the ''dumping'' of Mr. Carter for some as yet unidentified third contender. Any such effort would have to rely mostly on Mr. Kennedy's considerable delegate strength, continuing the Carter-Kennedy conflict; and whether it succeeded or not, the losers would be hard to enlist in support of the ultimate nominee.

PAINTINGS by Pre-Raphaelite, Symbolist and Art Nouveau and Art Deco artists, and prints, posters and decorative-art works from 1880 to 1940 will be auctioned in a series of sales next Thursday through June 14 at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street. The gaveling begins with the dispersal of Pre-Raphaelite and Symbolist paintings and drawings Thursday at 10:15 A.M. A Gustav Moreau watercolor depicting St. Elisabeth of Hungary is the most important lot, carrying an estimate of up to $70,000. Other notable works are a Fernand Khnopff charcoal-and-pastel drawing of his sister, Margaret (up to $38,000); Leon Frederic's ''The Source of Life'' (up to $35,000), and Jean Delville's ''Dante Drinking the Waters of Lethe'' (up to $35,000). Dante Gabriel Rossetti is also represented, with a painting of Sir Lancelot in Queen Guinevere's chamber (up to $8,000).

Arraignment was postponed Thursday for five members of the Communist Workers Party who face rioting charges in connection with violence at an anti-Ku Klux Klan rally that left five of the Communist members dead last Nov. 3.

Bill Madlock, the Pittsburgh Pirate infielder who is in trouble with National League umpires, can rest assured that they will not seek retribution when the Pirates play the New York Mets at Shea Stadium tonight. Commissioner Bowie Kuhn yesterday set next Monday and, if necessary, Thursday for his hearing on the case, in which the National League originally suspended Madlock 15 days and fined him $5,000 for having pushed his glove into the face of Umpire Gerry Crawford early last month.

Governor Byrne will not block the average 11 percent increase in subsidized commuter bus and train fares voted by NJ Transit two weeks ago, his office said yesterday. The Governor left for China on Wednesday without vetoing the minutes of the meeting of the NJ Transit board of directors, and thus the higher fares - expected to raise $16.1 million - will go into effect June 29 for bus riders and July 1 for Conrail passengers. Mr. Byrne is to spend two weeks in China as the guest of the Seton Hall University Asian Studies program.

By Anatole Broyard HE/SHE. By Herbert Gold. 213 pages. Arbor House. $9.95. ''I CAN'T divorce myself,'' his wife says. ''I can't even divorce our child. I've got to divorce someone.'' This is the nameless wife in Herbert Gold's 12th and best novel, ''He/She.'' She wants a life of ''unboredom,'' and her nameless husband wants their marriage to be ''a festival.'' Like so many women now, she makes plans, while he still trusts to luck and to love.

Charles Knox Robinson, a playwright, died Wednesday at Summit Park Hospital in Pomona, N.Y. He was 79 years old and lived in Valley Cottage, N.Y. Mr. Robinson got his first job on Broadway with Daniel Frohman at the Lyceum Theater, where he became assistant general stage director. In 1931, he was offered an acting contract by M-G-M and went to Hollywood, where he sold a play he had written with Kenyon Nicholson to Warner Bros. that became the film ''Taxi,'' starring James Cagney. The next year, their play ''Sailor Beware'' opened on Broadway.

A bill that could lead to more restrictions on the collection and use of confidential personal information by New York State agencies won bipartisan support in the Legislature today. The proposal was assured passage with the joint endorsement by Warren M. Anderson, the Republican majority leader of the Senate, and Stanley Fink, the Speaker of the Democratic-controlled Assembly.

A former Florida highway patrolman was indicted today in the first case in a Federal investigation of more than a dozen cases of alleged police brutality that preceded last month's racial violence here. The indictment was the first sought by a Justice Department team sent here last week by Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti to examine recent instances of alleged police brutality against blacks.

Jerry Attanasio and Joe McNally were talking the other day about their choice for president, but neither mentioned Jimmy Carter or Ronald Reagan: Mr. Attanasio said he was voting for Charlie, while Mr. McNally said he was all for Phil.

JERSEY CITY, June 5--Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith announced today that he would run for the office of Hudson County Democratic chairman at the party's reorganization meeting on Tuesday.

The number of vessels awaiting refugee passengers in Cuba was apparently dwindling today as Panama joined efforts to stem the flow to the United States, officials said. By mid-morning, 42 boats had delivered 1,539 refugees, bringing the 48-day boatlift total to 109,163. The Coast Guard, cautioning that reports from returning boat captains were unconfirmed, said it had estimated that there were 20 to 80 boats remaining in the Cuban port of Mariel, the main embarkation point for refugees.

WHILE the Overture to Rossini's ''La Scala di Seta'' (''The Silken Ladder'') is a popular piece in the orchestral repertory - it was a favorite of Toscanini's - the opera itself is little known today. A few thousand schoolchildren were able to see it in an excellent professional production during the last two weeks in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's opera house. It was the latest work to be shown in the four-year-old program of the Children's Free Opera of New York, which is presented by the St. Luke's Chamber Ensemble, with principal financial support coming from Consolidated Edison. ''The Silken Ladder,'' written in 1812, is a one-act delight, with a libretto as charmingly ridiculous as a Feydeau farce and music in Rossini's most ebullient style. If the solo arias sometimes follow formula, the ensembles are almost worthy of Mozart.

The Big Three auto makers announced today that because of poor auto sales, they would lay off 34,965 workers next week and temporarily shut down four more assembly plants around the country. The new layoffs will add to the record 237,850 auto workers on indefinite layoff this week, a figure approaching the 300,000 workers that the United Auto Workers said were laid off during the peak of the 1975 recession.

Lauritz Lauritzen, a former West German Cabinet minister, died today, the Social Democratic Party announced. He was 70 years old. Between 1966 and 1974, under two Governments, Mr. Lauritzen served as Minister of City Planning and Building, Minister of Post and Communications, and Transportation Minister. Former Chancellor Willy Brandt said Mr. Lauritzen had spent the postwar years working for the party's social objectives.

Franklin Jacobs of Fairleigh Dickinson University failed to appear tonight for qualifying in the high jump at the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships. In what was to have been his final collegiate meet, the 5-foot-8 1/4-inch senior from Paterson, N.J., was not among the 38 starters in the competition at Memorial Stadium on the University of Texas campus. Jacobs won the N.C.A.A. indoor title in March, took the IC4A outdoor crown two weeks ago and has been America's top-ranked high jumper in recent years.

CENTRAL PARK was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux ''to provide the best practical means of healthful recreation for the inhabitants of all classes,'' as an early plan for the park stated. That recreation was planned for in detail in the deceptively rural landscaping of the park, from the healthful breaths of fresh air to be had as citizens skated round the Lake, to the confident step of ''even the most timid and nervous'' strollers bent on exploring the park on a summer afternoon. In no other single element were those aims of practicality, beauty and healthful exercise so neatly realized as in the little bridges that dotted the park. Some were carved stone, establishing the park as a place for lofty thoughts. Others - romantic replications of nature - were built from tree branches or the stone rubble cleared by the men and boys who turned out to build the park in 1858.

To the Editor: John C. Sawhill, Deputy Secretary of the Department of Energy, presented the Government's case for the 10-cent-per-gallon oil-import fee in these pages (Op-Ed May 26). It contains highly questionable assumptions and could lead to economically unsound consequences. e argued, first, that the fee is the most effective conservation measure available at this time without cutting into economic productivity. He estimates that 100,000 barrels a day in reduced consumption would be realized by the end of the first year, and 250,000 barrels by the end of the third year via a motor fuels tax that would replace the import fee.
The New Jersey Pinelands Commission outlined a master plan today for preserving more than a million acres of the state's unusual Pine Barrens as a national reserve.

A 21-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with criminally negligent homicide in the fatal shooting of an off-duty Immigration and Naturalization Service officer. The police said they believed the shooting was a tragic accident involving friends but that the case would be presented to a grand jury. Investigators said the Federal officer, Joseph Aiello Jr., 26, of 1542 East 27th Street, Brooklyn, had taken two friends from Brooklyn for a ride in his car Wednesday night. They were identified as Charles Shand of 1110 Avenue O, who was charged in the shooting, and Kenneth Rowletter, 17, of 1477 East 12th Street.

Following are the names of those who received honorary degrees today at Harvard University's commencement exercises, with quotations from their citations: Walter Cronkite, CBS television journalist, Doctor of Laws. ''In an era of instant news, he is a pre-eminent figure in contemporary journalism, friendly, reliable, percipient, forever telling us 'the way it is.' '' Ernst Mayr, professor of zoology emeritus at Harvard, and former director of Harvard's Museum of Cooperative Zoology, Doctor of Science. ''The learned heir of Audubon and Agassiz, he guided a great research museum to new pinnacles of distinction.'' John Morton Blum, Fellow at Harvard College from 1970 to 1979 and professor of American history at Yale, Doctor of Laws. ''An historian clear and discerning, a teacher kind and encouraging.'' Robert Merton, a sociologist, Doctor of Laws. ''Eminent scholarteacher, Harvard-bred; his path-breaking studies have advanced his discipline and enlarged our understanding of human organizations.'' Octavio Paz, Mexican writer and diplomat, Doctor of Letters. ''A public servant of integrity and courage, a poet whose metaphors define the alternating current of life.'' Joan Robinson, British economist, Doctor of Laws. ''With insight and elegance, she has examined the imperfections of the market and revealed the inconsistencies of poverty and wealth, scarcity and abundance.'' Richard Wall Lyman, outgoing president of Stanford University and next president of the Rockefeller Foundation, Doctor of Laws. ''Proudly we greet this son of Harvard, Stanford's leader in troubled times.'' Herbert Hart, Oxford professor of jurisprudence and legal theorist, Doctor of Laws. ''Illustrious professor and philosopher of law, he forges stronger links between law and morality, punishment and responsibility.'' Helen Frankenthaler, artist, noted for her free-flowing colossal canvases, Doctor of Art. ''Her influence as teacher and artist has beautifully refined the rough edges of abstract art.'' Bayard Rustin, longtime civil rights leader, Doctor of Laws. ''Though the fight is not yet won, his life exemplifies the unflagging struggle for opportunity and justice.'' Anna Freud, daughter of Sigmund Freud and a leading psychoanalyst, Doctor of Science. ''Seeing into the minds of children, she has championed their needs and enhanced our understanding of the growth of human personality.''
Philip Glass is a composer who expresses himself in so many musical forms these days that no one form can do him full justice. Still, his solo organ recitals present a fascinating facet of his music.

WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP)--The Justice Department announced today that it had ended its three-year-old Federal grand jury investigation of the General Motors Corporation for possible criminal tax violations. No charges were brought by the Government.

Following the lead of some banks on Wednesday, several of the nation's larger banks lowered their prime rates a full percentage point to 13 percent yesterday. One small bank in Miami reduced its prime by one point to 12 percent.
ALBANY, June 5--Governor Carey proposed a $275 million plan today to expand New York State's existing prison system.

Dr. Richard E. Weitzman, associate professor of medicine at the School of Medicine at the University of California at Los Angeles, died Saturday at Columbia Memorial Hospital, Hudson, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 36 years old and had lived in Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif., before becoming ill.
WASHINGTON, June 5--President Carter today vetoed legislation rejecting his oil-import fee, and the House of Representatives quickly overrode his action by a vote of 335 to 34.

Gold prices climbed to their highest levels since early March yesterday, while the dollar continued to be weighed down by declining United States interest rates, which tend to make the dollar less attractive for investment.

ONE by one, the grandees who came over for the Picasso celebrations have slipped out of town, leaving the sidewalks clear for the rest of us. As to who among them was the most important is not for me to say, but the most surprising by quite some way was the director of the Picasso Museum in Barcelona.

The Mobil Corporation said that "mechanical difficulties" had forced it to halt the drilling of one of its offshore wells in the Hibernia oil field, 190 miles off the Canadian province of Newfoundland.
The securities industry has devised a standard way to measure the yields of money-market mutual funds, which have attracted more than $71 billion from investors seeking high interest rates.

SEATTLE, June 5--In a scene that may have shocked some baseball purists, Charley Lau, the New York Yankees' special hitting instructor, was on the Royals Stadium field last night discussing the art of swinging the bat with Hal McRae, Kansas City's designated hitter.
What comes out of Congress in the way of housing legislation this year will have a considerable effect for years to come on how Federal money is spent in New York City.

ONCE again, in this period of reruns, documentaries monopolize the new programming picture. Tonight at 10, NBC News's "Is There a Better Way?" offers, in the words of its producer, Robert Rogers, "an analysis of trends ...

I consider mistaken the view that we and we alone are responsible for all the confusing changes that we see around us. This is a serious misreading of our condition, a perverted hubris that overestimates our power and our responsibility for ill and underestimates our capacity for good.'' - Cyrus R. Vance. (A12:1.)

After meeting privately here today for 90 minutes, Ronald Reagan and former President Gerald R. Ford pledged to work together to elect Mr. Reagan President in November. The former President said he would ''wholeheartedly campaign'' in Mr. Reagan's behalf. Mr. Ford also told reporters that he would would look forward to having ''influence and impact in whatever way he feels essential as he becomes the next President.''

Eight thousand degrees were awarded by New York University in Washington Square Park yesterday. Trumpets blared, the park's usually dormant fountain gushed, purple banners waved, colored balloons floated overhead and relieved and triumphant parents applauded. Ten thousand men women and children massed under the park's verdant trees and, 3,000 of the graduates were there in person. Police cars screamed past as the commencement address was being delivered by the university's acting president, Ivan L. Bennett Jr. He noted, somewhat apologetically that he was a medical doctor, not an academic one, and drew parallels between the problems of dealing with the body politic and with the human body.

JOHN SINGER SARGENT'' at the Coe Kerr Gallery, 49 East 82d Street, is based upon the idea that there were two Sargents: one who painted for the great world that loved and stifled him, and one who painted for himself. Warren Adelson, director of the gallery, has worked hard and long to prove the second half of this proposition, and the show offers 65 works, in oil or watercolor, many of them shown for the first time in this country. The notion in question has been mooted about many other successful late-19th-century painters. In England, Landseer's major paintings of stags and dogs have long been a joke, but his litle paintings of landscape are highly prized. In Germany, Menzel's reconstructions of life in 18th-century Potsdam have not aged well, but people will beat one another with their umbrellas to get at one of his drawings. In Russia, Repin's group portrait of parliamentarians looks stiff and unconfident, but the individual sketches for it get high marks for their brio. It is as if art at that time was in rebellion against the tasks that society set before it.

The General Tire and Rubber Company, in a statement released at its headquarters in Akron, Ohio, said today that RKO General, a subsidiary, would appeal the Government's opinion that RKO is ''unfit'' to continue operating television stations in Boston, New York and Los Angeles. General Tire called the official written opinion by the Federal Communications Commission, issued yesterday, ''the most unfair and discriminatory decision ever handed down by a Government agency.''

When word of the proposed merger between Dart Industries and Kraft Inc. reached one analyst yesterday, he said he surmised that Justin Whitlock Dart had determined that the time was approaching for a an extended stint in Washington. Mr. Dart, the 72-year-old chairman of Dart Industries, is one of Ronald Reagan's staunchest backers. And with Mr. Reagan's lock on the Republican Presidential nomination assured, the one-time Chicago Bears football player has been mentioned for a variety of Government roles should Mr. Reagan win the White House in November.

Historically, it has always been a delicate political moment when the victor met the vanquished after a strenuous struggle for a party's Presidential nomination, as President Carter, who has enough convention delegates for renomination, and Senator Edward M. Kennedy did today. And in the past, just as today, the stakes have always been high, especially for the winners, for failure to heal the breach in their own party has often been a factor in their loss of the general election. Today, Senator Kennedy's determination to carry on his fight had the ring of potential trouble for President Carter.

Hills Bros. Coffee Inc., the nation's third-largest coffee roaster, has increased the wholesale price for a one-pound can of ground coffee by 15 cents, or 4.9 percent, to $3.23. The action by Hills Bros., announced late Wednesday, followed identical price increases by the Folger Coffee Company on Tuesday and by the Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation on May 23. Consumers can expect the higher prices to show up at the retail level in about a month.

Remember when banks paid interest, and only interest, for your money? Today, many banks look more like catalogue showrooms, with deposit slips buried under toasters, espresso machines, video recorders and digital watches. Some banks are even offering the ultimate premium for new accounts: cash. ''Bring in a friend,'' the ads urge, and take home as much as $1,250. The bonus war means two things: First, the Federally prescribed limits on interest rates are obviously too low. If banks are willing to pay a finder's fee of up to 1 1/2 percent, then clearly they value your money by at least that much more than the interest they are allowed to pay for it. Second, the Government's techniques for controlling interest rates are plainly breaking down. The finder's fee is just one clever ruse around the limits. Paying the fee in television sets or refrigerators as well as cash creates the further problem of defining its true value. Not only the consumer but a bank's competitors will be hard put to know precisely where the market stands, and that opens the way to reckless competition.

Dow Chemical of Canada Ltd. said its previously proposed polyethylene plant, to have a capacity of 400 million pounds a year and to be built in Fort Saskatchewan, Alberta, is estimated to cost $75 million. * Gulf Oil Corporation completed divestiture of real estate development activities by selling its interest in Ocean Village, a condominium development in Fort Pierce, Fla., to a corporation owned by Harrison Land Development Inc.

Paul Corvino, the businessman who had repeatedly denied entering into an agreement with Jeff Ruland, the Iona College basketball center, has now been quoted as saying that he does have such an agreement, for 10 percent of Ruland's gross earnings over the next four years. An article in the current issue of Basketball Times quotes Mr. Corvino, of Mamaroneck, N.Y., as having said that he had given Ruland a total of $9,000 in the last year, plus shares of oil stock and other gifts. One of the authors, Stuart Berman, a freelance writer, claimed to be a reporter from United Press International at the news conference at which Ruland first announced his decision to stay at Iona for next season and not turn professional.

The Justice Department announced today that it had ended its three-year-old Federal grand jury investigation of the General Motors Corporation for possible criminal tax violations. No charges were brought by the Government. A department spokesman, John V. Wilson, declined to provide any reasons for the decision. The department said it had notified counsel for General Motors and Federal District Judge James B. Churchill in Detroit of its decision. G.M. executives could not immediately be reached for comment.
Disarmament Commission - 3 P.M. SECURITY COUNCIL

Cancer insurance often does not cover many medical costs of disease and most consumers are unaware of that when they buy such policies, according to a Government study released today. The study, done for the National Credit Union Administration Board, joins others in criticizing cancer policies and the way they are sold. The board may use it as justification for regulation of Federal credit unions that encourage their members to buy the policies.

The Standard Oil Company (Indiana), which markets its products under the brand name Amoco, reported yesterday that it had found a flow of natural gas with ''significant production potential'' from a wildcat well in northeastern Utah, part of the so-called Overthrust Belt. ''This is the discovery of still another field in the Overthrust Belt,'' said a spokesman for Standard of Indiana in Chicago. ''And it reinforces the notion that the Overthrust Belt is a very rich energy area.''

Fred Rodell, a retired Yale Law School professor who had been one of the country's ranking specialists on the United States Constitution and a vigorous civil libertarian, died Wednesday at the Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 73 years old. Mr. Rodell, who had left Yale in ill health six years ago, suffered a heart attack in the hospital at midday and died shortly before midnight Wednesday.

ONE by one, the grandees who came over for the Picasso celebrations have slipped out of town, leaving the sidewalks clear for the rest of us. As to who among them was the most important is not for me to say, but the most surprising by quite some way was the director of the Picasso Museum in Barcelona. The museum is a relatively new one, but it already has the third largest attendance of any in Spain. It occupies two handsome palaces in the so-called Gothic quarter of Barcelona and it is about to take over a third one. In Franco's day it was not popular with the Government - in fact it wasn't even allowed to have an official opening, but simply opened its doors from one day to the next - and it still doesn't get a peseta from Madrid. But it's big in Barcelona, the vivid and unprovincial city where Picasso spent the best years of his youth; and in 1981, Picasso's centenary year, it will mount an exhibition in which architecture, music, literature, fashion and many another aspect of Catalan life will mark Picasso's association with Barcelona.

Money for water projects has been dammed in the United States Senate. Although Congress has over the years approved projects in the West and South that could eventually cost Washington $30 billion, opposition to the frequent waste on waterworks has put a stop to appropriations. As a result, some sound projects have been left as high and dry as the unsound ones. The Domenici-Moynihan bill, already reported out of the Committee on Environment and Public Works, would make up for the water legislation for which money is no longer available. It proposes a guaranteed $1 billion a year for such projects and, at least for five years, it would help many more states than are aided by today's procedures. The bill deserves support.

Two letters from ''Croatian freedom fighters'' claimed responsibility yesterday for Tuesday night's bomb explosion at the museum in the Statue of Liberty. The New York City Joint Terrorism Task Force, established recently by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Police Department, said it was ''leaning rather heavily to the strong possibility that the Croatians are the people responsible.'' No one was injured in the explosion, but three historic items were damaged slightly.

Governor Carey proposed a $275 million plan today to expand New York State's existing prison system. He acted in the face of Mayor Koch's recent decision not to support a state plan to acquire the detention complex on Rikers Island in New York City. The key components of the Carey plan, which would add 4,000 beds by 1984, are: - Construction of maximum-security wings at the Wallkill and Woodbourne Correctional Facilities. Another prison unit would be attached to a still unselected site near New York City. Among the sites in the New York area apparently under consideration for wings are the Arthur Kill facility on Staten Island and the Queensboro facility in Long Island City. The three wings, each with 512 beds, would cost an estimated $149 million.

ELIOT FELD'S ''At Midnight,'' one of dramatic ballet's deepest works of the last 15 years, was revived after several seasons by American Ballet Theater Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The only member of the original 1967 cast on hand was Cynthia Gregory, who also appeared on the program with Alexander Godunov in the ''Black Swan'' pas de deux. ''At Midnight'' was Mr. Feld's second ballet, and it is remarkable how a young choreographer could create so shattering an emotional aura through such strong use of structure. It was good to see Miss Gregory again as the female outsider, a role whose straight-lined shapes she renders with actual thrust and poignancy. But debuts by George de la Pena, partnering Marianna Tcherkassky, and Victor Barbee, also went well.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 5-- The United Nations Security Council severely criticized Israel today for failing to protect Arab lives in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan.

Some banks are even offering the ultimate premium for new accounts: cash. "Bring in a friend," the ads urge, and take home as much as $1,250.

WASHINGTON, June 6--"This is a tough year for Democrats--the country is divided, but I'll strike a blow for unity this fall and save the country from President Ronald Reagan." So says Morris King Udall, a man who is ...

Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 24. 1. A man who brought lawsuits on behalf of the United States Government when he was Attorney General says he may bring a suit against the United States Government soon. Who is he and why may he sue?.

You have made the most eloquent argument for a Republican Congress that I have ever heard. May I issue an invitation to you to join the Republican Party?'' - Bill Brock, Republican national chairman. (21:4.) *

THE invitation said that Howard J. Ruff, author of the best-selling ''How to Prosper During the Coming Bad Years,'' would bring his ''trenchant economic survival philosophy'' to Manhattan in late May. Mr. Ruff, who was billed as ''middle-America's foremost financial adviser,'' did bring his course on how to beat inflation to New York, but he missed the first day of the two-day show and failed to deliver the keynote address to the group as advertised. (The reason, according to his staff, is that Mr. Ruff is behind schedule on his forthcoming book, which is to be a sequel to his current best seller.),

More troops and Federal agents have been called in to increase security at a Cuban refugee processing center here, officials announced today. The extra security was ordered after refugees made a series of unauthorized trips around the base and off it, according to Robert J. Adamcik, the top official at the site from the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

This is a tough year for Democrats - the country is divided, but I'll strike a blow for unity this fall and save the country from President Ronald Reagan.'' So says Morris King Udall, a man who is going to need all the Democratic unity he can muster since he has been chosen by President Carter to be the keynote speaker at the Democratic National Convention. Mr. Udall, a liberal Representative from Barry Goldwater country in Arizona, will need every bit of the persuasiveness he is known to possess because many convention delegates are likely to remain loyal to Senator Edward M. Kennedy, while the independent Presidential candidacy of Representative John B. Anderson threatens to siphon away Democratic votes.

Tommy John got back on the winning track tonight, beating the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-0, with a two-hitter and earning his 200th career victory. The 37-year-old Yankee pitcher had won his first seven games this season, but then was knocked out of the box three straight times and was finding the 200-victory mark as elusive as the sinkerball pitches he throws so effecively.

When Al Fatah, the fighting arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization, ended an 11-day congress in Damascus on Sunday, it issued a policy declaration calling on Palestinians to settle for nothing less than the destruction of Israel through armed struggle. But representatives of the P.L.O. now say that the declaration was ''misunderstood'' and that Al Fatah would accept a political solution providing for an independent Palestinian state on territories recovered from Israel.

The comparisons seem inevitable. Both could sprint and jump with equal ability and world-class credentials. Both seemed blessed with strong characters. Now that Carl Lewis has won his first National Collegiate outdoor long-jump title as a freshman from the University of Houston, the 18-year-old athlete from Willingboro, N.J., moves a step closer to being linked to the career of the late Jesse Owens.

The discipline of history in the United States made a crucial error about 40 years ago. It tragically narrowed its audience to students and other academics. Though the research that historians have been writing for each other since then has often been excellent and truly innovative, a larger public audience, which had been addressed by good historians in the 19th and early 20th centuries, has been neglected. As a result, the public's historical sense has dwindled. Thus, the reading public has dropped most history from its list, while special groups concerned with their own past have found relatively few historians addressing them directly. Other potential clients for history have been equally neglected. For example, a promising, earlier initiative toward developing historical research designed for policy use simply withered; further, news-media interest in historical subjects took shape without the benefit of professional guidance, the result often being pseudo-history in, say, television films that purport to deal with the past.

Schafran To the Editor: The news that four of the seven New York Court of Appeals judges who are members of Albany's University Club will resign in response to that club's vote against admitting women (May 31) is welcome but insufficient.n 1979, the U.S. Senate Committee on the Judiciary recognized that membership in clubs that discriminate on the basis of race, sex, creed or national origin is incompatible with a mandate to enforce the Federal anti-discrimination statutes. Federal judicial nominees must now either resign such memberships before their confirmation hearings or agree to resign if offensive policies are not changed within a designated time.
GENEVA, June 6 (UPI)--The Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration said today that 1,976 Jews arrived in Vienna from the Soviet Union last month, the lowest monthly rate since July 1978.

NEW ORLEANS, June 4--Oilconsuming nations have absorbed this year's sharply higher oil prices with surprisingly little difficulty, world bankers say, but they warn that a severe testing of the international financial system lies ahead in 1981.

ALBANY, June 6 -- New York State's highest tribunal, the Court of Appeals, ruled today that a woman living with a man to whom she is not married may be entitled to a share of his assets if she can prove they had an "express" oral agreement.

WHITE PLAINS, June 6--The trial in the Bedford Hills robbery-murder case ended today as Junius Gray, the second defendant charged with killing four residents of that northern Westchester community 13 months ago, was sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison.

JERUSALEM, June 6 -- Mayor Elias M. Frej of Bethlehem and Mayor Rashad Shawa of Gaza rescinded their decisions to resign last night, citing the need for unity among the Palestinian officials in Israeli-occupied territories.

While New York City continued to escape the main consequence of the growing nationwide recession - a substantial increase in unemployment - the state as a whole reached a 19-month high in joblessness in May, according to statistics made public yesterday. In New Jersey, the increase in unemployment was also pronounced. The unemployment rate for New York City stood at 8.4 percent of the working-age population last month, compared with 8 percent in the same month last year and 8.8 percent in March 1980.

A friend of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson who was accused of having helped the convicted murderer escape from the Brooklyn House of Detention last Saturday had a stock certificate worth "in excess of $300,000" signed over to him by Mr. Jacobson, authorities disclosed in Criminal Court in Brooklyn yesterday.

PARIS, June 6--With an effective first service compensating for mistakes, Vitas Gerulaitis outlasted Jimmy Connors through five sets requiring 3 hours 57 minutes today and reached the final of the French open tennis championships for the first time.
A protest by Atlantic City high school teachers over the selection of an Iranian as a commencement speaker and her subsequent decision to bow out continued to stir controversy yesterday.

Robert Downey, who styles himself "a prince," is back and "Up the Academy" has got him, or perhaps it's the other way around. It's difficult to tell in a movie so cheerfully and rudely haphazard that, for reasons that remain mysterious as I write this, the name of its star is mentioned in neither the screen credits nor the publicity material.

Wim Rijsbergen, a defender for the Cosmos, has been fined by the North American Soccer League for a confrontation last April 10 with a New York Post sportswriter, the league said yesterday. In keeping with policy, the league did not disclose the amount of the fine.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, V.I., June 6 (UPI) -- Federal District Judge Warren H. Young, who presided over the 1973 trial of five black men who were convicted of murdering eight persons in the Fountain Valley Golf Club, died in his home today of lung cancer. He was 63 years old.
The Diamond International Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had ended its battle to prevent Sir James Goldsmith from purchasing a 90 percent interest in it.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The nation's unemployment rate shot up again in May, prompting forecasts that the recession now spreading through the economy would be deeper and longer than previously expected by the Government and economists.

ATLANTA (NL) - Signed a draft choice, Quin Lloyd, outfielder, University of Texas. CALIFORNIA (AL) - Released Ralph Garr, infielder-outfielder. CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed six draft choices: Steve Leppert, second baseman, Jacksonville State; Ken Scarpace, West- ern Michigan, and Scott Terry, South- western Texas, outfielders; Roderick Walker, shortstop, Houston; Anthony Threatt, pitcher, Murray State, and Mi- chael Murray, third baseman, Western Kentucky. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Signed a draft choice, Keith Creel, pitcher, University of Texas. METS (NL) - Signed a first-round draft choice, John Gibbons, catcher, and as- signed him to Kingsport of Appalachian League. MINNESOTA (AL) - Placed Mike Mar- shall, relief pitcher, on waivers. Called up Mike Kinnenun, pitcher, from Toledo farm club of International League. MONTREAL (NL) - Placed Larry Par- rish, third baseman, on 15-day disabled list. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Signed No. 1 draft choice, Don Collins, pitcher, Ferguson (Va.) High School. BASKETBALL BOSTON (NBA) - Named Jimmy Rodgers assistant coach. DETROIT (NBA) - Signed Bobby Wilson, free-agent guard, to multiyear contract.

The Nassau County police arrested a 24-year-old man yesterday and charged him with murder in the shooting 18 months ago of Lawrence Lever, a prominent Long Island real estate developer. The suspect, identified as Alan Golder, was arrested while in the custody of the Rye, N.Y., police, who had brought him from California on an unrelated charge of armed robbery.

They surely love birthday parties in Brooklyn. On Thursday night, when Brooklyn was 355 years old, the Borough Hall Restoration Foundation threw a fund-raising party to restore its handsome 131-year-old Borough Hall. Brooklyn was a city when the building was constructed - it did not vote to join New York until 1898 - and the hall was meant to outdo Manhattan's City Hall. This was the foundation's third birthday party and tickets were $355 a couple; last year, they were $354. As Howard Golden, the Borough President, said, ''The foundation has found a way to beat spiraling prices - tickets go up only $1 a year.'' And so there were drinks in the main-floor rotunda, whose centerpiece is a huge bronze bell that once hung in the Victorian cupola; dinner and dancing in the third-floor courtroom, with its marvelous coffered rotunda, and impromptu political meetings in Mr. Golden's refurbished office dominated by a huge portrait of George Washington. No one seemed to know who did the portrait or the ones of former Brooklyn mayors and borough presidents on the courtroom walls. ''We found them all dirty in the attic,'' said David Lee, home fashion director of Abraham & Straus, who is in charge of the interior refurbishing.

A spirit of cooperation and a desire for consensus seemed to prevail in many of the workshops at the White House Conference on Families here today. A total of 671 delegates from 15 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands sifted rapidly through hundreds of proposals. But the introduction of some provocative topics, such as abortion and alternative family structures, brought on angry debate. At one point, a contingent of more than 30 conservative delegates walked out, claiming that their point of view had been denied a fair hearing. The action occurred after lunch during the second day of the three-day Government-sponsored conference that is intended to produce new approaches to family problems.
The Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration said today that 1,976 Jews arrived in Vienna from the Soviet Union last month, the lowest monthly rate since July 1978.

The national chairmen of the Democratic and Republican Parties are well pleased with their respective candidates who survived the quadrennial ordeal of the Presidential selection system, but both are dissatisfied with the system. And, despite enormous legal and political obstacles, Bill Brock, the Republican chairman, and John C. White, his Democratic counterpart, are determined to begin working together after the 1980 election to make the process more compact and rational in the years ahead.

In a reversal of their positions in the book world in the last few years, China is making a great leap forward, and the Soviet Union appears fairly subdued at the American Booksellers' Association's annual trade exhibition here.

To the Editor: Your June 1 editorial which considers the nagging subject of Social Security reform reiterates the two proposals most frequently advanced to reduce the system's costs: (1) tax the benefits; (2) raise the eligibility age.t is tragic that such reductions are urged at a time when Social Security payments are the only source of survival for millions of older citizens.

WASHINGTON WHAT its inventor describes as the first ''windmill'' with no moving mechanical parts was patented this week. It is designed to be built on a large scale and produce strong electric power. Alvin M. Marks, president of the Marks Polarized Corporation in Whitestone, Queens, was granted patent 4,206,396 for his charged aerosol generator. A model is being tested by the Department of Energy in the company's laboratory.

President Carter's allies moved today for a showdown on the filibuster that is blocking the Administration's draft registration program. The Senate's Democratic leader, Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, filed a debate-limiting petition to shut off Senator Mark O. Hatfield's campaign to kill the registration plan by talking it to death. The petition was signed by 18 senators. That sets up a Senate vote Tuesday on whether to invoke cloture. If 60 senators vote for cloture, debate will end after 100 additional hours.

ISRAELIS ACT TO DETER ARAB DEFIANCE: Israeli military policemen stand by while an Arab shopkeeper pushes open the doors of his store in East Jerusalem. A general strike by Arab businessmen in the occupied West Bank failed Wednesday when Israelis forced the shops to open. Since then, the Arabs have shown scant resistance.

A Triple Crown season that started with all the excitement of sodden hay reaches a frenetic conclusion today with the 112th Belmont Stakes. Forget that there has been no Secretariat, Seattle Slew or Affirmed around, no genuine 3-year-old superstar for the grueling mile and a half. Today's crowd of 55,000 or so will see a wildly diverse collection of horses in a race that has overtones of sex, violence and foreign intrigue, among other things.

A wealthy land developer from Carson City, Nev., says that for the last 10 years he and a handful of friends have been giving money and advice to the dissidents who proclaimed a provisional government this week over the northern third of the New Hebrides in the South Pacific. The developer, Michael Oliver, who was born in Lithuania 51 years ago and spent four years in Nazi concentration camps, says he and his friends drafted a constitution for the dissidents, helped them produce flags and gave them a small amount of broadcasting equipment and an electric generator.

Robert Downey, who styles himself ''a prince,'' is back and ''Up the Academy'' has got him, or perhaps it's the other way around. It's difficult to tell in a movie so cheerfully and rudely haphazard that, for reasons that remain mysterious as I write this, the name of its star is mentioned in neither the screen credits nor the publicity material. The Mr. X of ''Up the Academy'' is none other than Ron Leibman (''Norma Rae''), and though he may want to keep his association with the movie a secret, it's impossible not to mention him after one has seen it. Ron Leibman IS ''Up the Academy.'' He's the maniacally evil heart and scroungy soul of this wayward lampoon of a comedy, which is being presented by Mad Magazine, and features - in the opening and closing shots - the presence of that toothy, apple-cheeked lunatic, Alfred E. Neuman.

Biaggi To the Editor: The suspension of shipments of U.S. arms to the Royal Ulster Constabulary, discussed in your May 28 editorial, must be put in perspective.t was my amendment to the fiscal 1980 Department of State appropriations bill which led to the decision by the State Department to suspend further sales or shipments of United States arms to the R.U.C. pending a full review of our policy.

MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP)--Wearing his familiar Milwaukee uniform with the No. 31, but with a new svelte figure, George Bamberger bounced up the steps of the Brewers' dugout. The impish grin was vintage Bamberger as he acknowledged the many media representatives waiting on the County Stadium field before the Brewers went out and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8-4, tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Prices charged by producers and wholesalers rose by only three-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Government reported today. It was the smallest one-month rise in 32 months and a sign that consumers can expect a further slowdown in retail price inflation.

In the middle of the 19th century, American painters saw nature as a bible and landscape as "a holy text which revealed truth." For them, the discovery of the native landscape was "an effective substitute for a missing national tradition."
ATLANTA, June 6 (AP)--Bob Shearer of Australia made an eagle 3 on the final hole to finish off a round of 71 and retain the lead in the second round of the $300,000 Atlanta Golf Classic today.

Three Americans returning here after attending an Iranian-sponsored conference on "United States intervention in Iran" said last night that customs officials at Kennedy International Airport had confiscated conference-related materials and a copy of the Koran.

Troops at the Cuban resettlement center here confiscated knives and homemade weapons today while searching a section of the center known for its black market, prostitution, homosexuals and occasional knife fights. The search of the area known as ''The Boulevard'' was requested by leaders whom the refugees elected earlier, said Lieut. Col. A.T. Brainerd. The area was believed to be the breeding ground of a riot last weekend that left dozens injured and several buildings burned.

Jr. To the Editor: ''If there's anything Lee (Iacocca) excels at, it's marketing'' was the response of a Chrysler spokesman to the Treasury Department's recent questions about the company's proposed pricing strategy of its new ''K'' car (news story May 27). pparently Chrysler executives are irate over the Government's concern with company plans to sell most of the fuel-efficient cars with profit-producing options.

Emorie Leiby, a former president of the Bergen County (N.J.) Historical Society, died Thursday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. Mrs. Leiby, who was 73 years old, lived in Bergenfield, N.J., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was the widow of Adrian Leiby, a historian and lawyer. She is survived by a daughter, Adrian Scott of Chagrin Falls, Ohio; two sisters, Katherine Van Riper of Fort Lauderdale and Virginia Bogert of Redondo Beach, Calif., and three grandchildren.

Helped by a broad early advance -the result of some favorable news on inflation - the stock market finished yesterday with a modest gain and at its highest level since early March. The Dow Jones industrial average closed yesterday at 861.52, a gain of 2.82 points. The volume was 37.2 million shares, off more than 10 million from Thursday's heavy turnover of 49.1 million.

The question being asked here is not, ''How do we save New York City's subway and bus fares?'' but, ''Which is worse: approving a new tax or being blamed for a fare increase?'' The answer depends on where one sits, and that accounts for the deadlock in trying to put together a package to subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's huge deficit. For Governor Carey, a fare increase is anathema. Mr. Carey ran for re-election in 1978 pledging to hold fares on all the state's transportation systems at current levels. He also traded a commitment to hold fares at 50 cents on New York City's subways and buses through 1981 for Mayor Koch's reluctant agreement to support the Westway as a replacement for the defunct West Side Highway in Manhattan.

Yale will try tomorrow to end Harvard's dominance of nearly two decades in their annual rowing showdown. This year's race on the Thames River is the 115th between crews of the Blue and the Crimson. Harvard has won for the last 17 years. In their one earlier race this spring, Harvard defeated Yale by one length in the Eastern Sprints Regatta on May 11.

Bruce Aubin, helped by having only three hours of sleep and a sharp putting game, beat Greg Zorila of Siwanoy, 5 and 4, today and captured the Westchester Golf Association's 61st amateur championship.

The Rank Organization, a film producer, owner of movie houses and the Xerox Corporation's European partner, said today that it was pulling out of film production and canceling eight major feature films with a projected total budget of $57 million. The eight new films, including ''HMS Ulysses,'' ''The Rocking Horse Winner'' and ''To the Manor Born,'' were announced at last month's Cannes Film Festival and were in early stages of production.

The nation's unemployment rate shot up again in May, prompting forecasts that the recession now spreading through the economy would be deeper and longer than previously expected by the Government and economists. The rate rose by eight-tenths of a percentage point last month, the same as the April increase, to 7.8 percent of the work force, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today. The two-month increase was the biggest in the nation since such records first were kept, according to Janet L. Norwood, director of the bureau. National records began early in this century.

Most of the eight plays in ''Marathon 1980'' deal with obsessions. In this three-week festival of one-acts, which ends this evening at the Ensemble Studio Theater, characters can be manic about a single subject - everything from sitting in a treehouse to maintaining equilibrium in the middle of an apocalypse. The plays are generally of a comic nature, but the best also have an edge of omen and mystery. In each of the three programs, one play stands out: Robert Pine's ''Landscape with Waitress,'' about a lonely writer's selfdramatization of his solitary life; Jonathan Ringkamp's ''Bella Figura,'' the temptation of a Franciscan brother, and on the final bill of three one-acts, Katherine Long's ''Two Part Harmony.''

As temperatures reached the mid-80's under sunny skies yesterday afternoon, some of the members of the cast of ''A Chorus Line'' joined employees of the Shubert Theater for a break in the sunshine outside the stage entrance on Shubert Alley. Today's weather is expected to be partly sunny and cooler with a chance of thunderstorms.

The price of gold passed the $600-anounce mark in New York yesterday for the first time in three months after earlier hitting that level in London. The dollar, meanwhile, was lower, but steady, in world foreign exchange trading.
THE invitation said that Howard J. Ruff, author of the best-selling "How to Prosper During the Coming Bad Years," would bring his "trenchant economic survival philosophy" to Manhattan in late May.

CHICAGO, June 6--In a reversal of their positions in the book world in the last few years, China is making a great leap forward, and the Soviet Union appears fairly subdued at the American Booksellers' Association's annual trade exhibition here.

Books of The Times Seeking the Sublime By ANATOLE BROYARD NATURE AND CULTURE: American Landscape Painting 1825-75. By Bar- bara Novak. Illustrated. 323 pages. Ox- ford University Press. $35. In the middle of the 19th century, American painters saw nature as a bible and landscape as ''a holy text which revealed truth.'' For them, the discovery of the native landscape was ''an effective substitute for a missing national tradition.'' In the absence of cultural antiquity, ''landscape offered an alternative past,'' one that stretched all the way back to the creation.

Bob Shearer of Australia made an eagle 3 on the final hole to finish off a round of 71 and retain the lead in the second round of the $300,000 Atlanta Golf Classic today. ''I was just trying to get it close,'' Shearer said of the 30-footer on the 18th hole. ''I got lucky and it fell in.'' Jack Nicklaus, meanwhile, made a mighty effort to recover from an opening 78. He fired a no-bogey, five-under-par 67. But his 145 total failed to qualify him for the final two rounds. It was the first time he had missed the cut since this tournament two years ago, spanning 23 appearances.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission was honored by the Municipal Art Society yesterday for 15 years of dedication to ''a just balancing of the importance of civic progress on the one hand and, on the other, of the saving for all the generations to come of the most precious examples of our complex urban past.'' The commission was awarded the 1980 bronze plaque, and 10 other individuals, buildings and community efforts received certificates of merit at the society's 88th annual meeting, held at the New Apollo Theater, 234 West 43d Street.

As a matter of law, policy and probably style as well, the Carter Administration is unwise to threaten Ramsey Clark & Co. with prosecution for defying the ban on American travel to Iran. Nothing that Mr. Clark and his nine companions may say or do could possibly embarrass the United States as much as a petty legal assault on their attempt to liberate American hostages while attending a conference on ''America's crimes'' in Teheran. Moreover, a restrictive reading of travel laws might look a bit silly from a Government that itself ignored the letter of the law when it penetrated Iranian territory during the recent rescue attempt. That attempt was defended, rightly, on the ground that Iran's bizarre assault on the norms of diplomacy required a strong if unconventional response. The same reasoning should apply now to freelance American participation in a Teheran propaganda show. Former Attorney General Clark and his fellow envoys conveyed two messages: that America erred grievously in past sponsorship of the Shah's regime and that Iran's militants now err grievously by refusing to liberate their American captives. So unwelcome was the latter message that Mr. Clark was condemned, in an apparent sideswipe at President Bani-Sadr, as ''the vilest American agent'' by Teheran Radio.

Franz Josef Strauss, who is lagging badly in publicopinion polls in his election campaign against Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, presented a team of associates today who will become cabinet members if the Christian Democrats take power after the national election Oct. 5. Some are politicians generally regarded as more liberal than Mr. Strauss, the Premier of Bavaria, whose reputation as a conservative has been the theme of intense attacks by the Chancellor's Social Democratic Party. The team apparently has the task of deflecting these attacks.

In 1976, New York's City Council decided to permit the city to seize title to properties on which taxes were in arrears for a year or more. The result was a disaster. The city quickly found itself the reluctant landlord of 10,000 buildings and 26,000 families. Worse, it had to start covering the huge operating deficits that led the owners to walk away.

MOSCOW, June 6--Soviet officials have begun to acknowledge that far fewer foreign visitors will be coming to the Moscow Olympics this summer than were expected before the American-led boycott movement began.
Evelyn Byrd Gates, daughter of Mrs. John Monteith Gates of Boca Grande, Fla., and the late Mr. Gates, was married in Manhattan yesterday to William H. Metcalf Jr. of Arlington, Va.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 6 -- When Al Fatah, the fighting arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization, ended an 11-day congress in Damascus on Sunday, it issued a policy declaration calling on Palestinians to settle for nothing less than the destruction of Israel through armed struggle.

The New York Times begins publication today of a weekly table measuring the performance of money-market mutual funds. It is designed to eliminate some of the confusion surrounding these highly popular investments.

WASHINGTON, June 6--The national chairmen of the Democratic and Republican Parties are well pleased with their respective candidates who survived the quadrennial ordeal of the Presidential selection system, but both are dissatisfied with the system.

The Arlen Realty and Development Corporation, which has had severe losses for several years through its real estate operations, is planning to enter the steel business, it was disclosed yesterday. The Whittaker Corporation, a West Coast conglomerate, and Arlen, based here, have been holding discussions on the acquisition by Arlen of two steel company subsidiaries of Whittaker, a Whittaker spokesman said yesterday in Los Angeles.

More than 50 cases of a recently discovered disease, whose cause and complete symptom pattern are still not understood, have occurred in 13 states, killing seven persons, medical scientists from the national Center for Disease Control reported to a Senate subcommittee yesterday.

ALBANY, June 6(UPI)--The Court of Appeals, New York's highest judicial body, today upheld the conviction of Dr. Mark Gerard, a Long Island veterinarian found guilty of fraud in a horseswitching incident at Belmont Park in 1977.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)--About 600,000 unemployed workers and former servicemen are becoming the first victims of the Congressional stalemate over a new Federal budget.

Stewart Richer, who was just voted a Special Coty Award for the freewheeling young clothes he makes for his store, Reminiscence, was reminiscing recently about his circuitous route to success in the fashion world.

TACOMA, Wash., June 6 (AP)--Al Neumann, a heavyweight boxer from Renton, Wash., will meet Ron Lyle of Denver, a former contender, in a bout here June 19 promoted by Muhammad Ali Professional Sports Inc.
The lesson of "The Hearse," which may be something a lot of us already knew, is that it's a bad idea to live alone in a house filled with mean-spirited apparitions.
The World Series-champion Pittsburgh Pirates opened a four-game series with the New York Mets at Shea Stadium last night, but they did so without Bill Madlock playing third base.
PRINCETON, N.J.--Many of us who are college students are bewildered, not by the staggering realities of the contemporary world but rather by the lack of vision of those who govern it.

Just last year, which is ancient history in the mercurial world of Manhattan underground rock, there was a band called the Model Citizens. True to its name, this consisted of four people up front (plus a two-man backup rhythm section) that looked positively superhuman. In contrast to the scruffy, bizarre imagery that predominates on the punk/new-wave scene, the Model Citizens were eerily perfect: physically beautiful, conservatively yet artfully dressed. Yet their perfection was really too perfect, a kind of fractured vision of the 1950's. And thus, of course, it was really even more bizarre than the competition. Last November the Model Citizens broke up, spawning three new bands. All three, encountered recently in Manhattan clubs, purvey a musical style at least partly reminiscent of the mother-band. The Model Citizens flouted the prevailing dance-rock styles by making a music that was deliberately disjunctive and eccentric. Captain Beefheart seemed an inspiration, along with some forms of new jazz and the kooky flamboyance of Lene Lovich.

The Diamond International Corporation disclosed yesterday that it had ended its battle to prevent Sir James Goldsmith from purchasing a 40 percent interest in it. Responding to the surprise truce between the American forest products company and the European industrialist, Diamond's stock plummeted 11 1/8 a share in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, closing at 38 7/8. Wall Street professionals, after gambling more than $100 million that Diamond would be able to arrange a friendly takeover, have lost an estimated $25 million.

Geoff Zahn, offered as trade bait earlier in the week, hurled a one-hit shutout as the Minnesota Twins stopped the Toronto Blue Jays, 5-0, tonight. Zahn, a veteran off to a slow start this season, had a no-hitter going until John Mayberry slapped a clean single to left with two outs in the seventh. The left-hander, who had been offered to the Red Sox for Butch Hobson, walked three batters and struck out six.

Jane Blalock, who learned her golf while struggling with nor'easters over a links course near Portsmouth, N.H., fought successfully against gusts that reached 30 miles an hour today and tied Nancy Lopez-Melton and Sally Little for the lead in the second round of the 26th annual Ladies' Professinal Golf Association Championship. The 34-year-old Miss Blalock said, ''It was a three-club wind at least.'' By that she meant that when she was playing into the wind she had to use a club at least three numbers lower than she would normally use for the distance. But she did this with such skill on the 6,313-yard Kings Island Grizzly Course that she shot three-under-par 69 for 139 after 36 holes.

A disturbance tonight at the Hawaii State Prison left one inmate dead and one seriously injured, the police said. One guard was reported slightly injured. Dozens of heavily armed police officers surrounded the prison after the disturbance broke out at 6 P.M. A group of armed inmates was reported holding out in one section of the prison two hours later.

The Federal Department of Energy agreed today that New York State would not have to accept ''any additional nuclear wastes of any kind'' in return for Federal help in cleaning up the defunct nuclear fuel storage center at West Valley, N.Y. In a joint statement, the administrations of President Carter and Governor Carey agreed to press for the Federal legislation authorizing the Federal Government to pay 90 percent of the cost of solidifying and removing highly radioactive liquid waste at the West Valley site, formerly a nuclear waste reprocessing plant, 30 miles southeast of Buffalo.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation has arrested a 38-year-old female Cuban refugee on charges of hijacking a plane to Cuba 10 years ago. Roger Young, an F.B.I. spokesman, said that agents arrested the woman, Graciela Quesada Zamora, yesterday afternoon at the Cuban refugee center in Fort Chaffee, Ark. She was charged with air piracy and kidnapping in the hijacking of a Delta Airlines flight from Atlanta to Miami on May 25, 1970.

IN the two months they were married, Martha Knowings never got Herman Knowings to explain why his old friends from Harlem called him Copter. Sometimes when they went out together, men would wave at her husband and say, ''Hey, Helicopter Man.'' She knew that he used to play basketball, but that was not central to their short life together. They met at the Paradise Baptist Church up on Fort Washington Avenue. Once, when the 6-foot-5-inch Knowings presented himself for baptism, the Rev. Lee Arrington had to ask him to scrunch himself up, because the baptism pool was not otherwise large enough to contain Herman Knowings.

The men and their $100,000 machines had long since left the Indianapolis Motor Speedway last week, and yet Janet Guthrie remained behind, trying without much hope to salvage a racing career that has produced more publicity than success. There is a race tomorrow in Milwaukee, and Miss Guthrie knows that it could be her last.

BALTIMORE, June 6--A spirit of cooperation and a desire for consensus seemed to prevail in many of the workshops at the White House Conference on Families here today. A total of 671 delegates from 15 states, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands sifted rapidly through hundreds of proposals. But the introduction of some provocative topics, such as abortion and alternative family structures, brought on angry debate.

The Senate killed President Carter's oilimport fee today by voting 68 to 10 to override a Presidential veto. The vote enacted legislation rejecting the fee, since the House of Representatives voted by 335 to 34 yesterday to override the veto. The lopsided votes, during a week in which Mr. Carter appeared to have won enough delegates to secure renomination at the Democratic National Convention, demonstrated that, even among Democrats, the President could not count on Congressional support on specific issues. It was the first override of a President by a Congress controlled by his own party since June 1952, when Harry S. Truman tried to block the McCarran-Walter immigration bill. Unlike Mr. Carter, however, Mr. Truman had announced that he would not seek renomination.

Neil Amdur of The New York Times was named yesterday the first winner of the annual Jesse P. Abramson Memorial Award for excellence in track and field journalism. Mr. Amdur was selected by the Track and Field Writers of America and was honored at the organization's annual meeting in Austin, Tex., during the National Collegiate track and field championships.

Harry D. Margulies, a retired lawyer who had been an expert on workmen's compensation, died Tuesday at the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in the Bronx. He was 73 years old and had lived in Manhattan. A graduate of New York University and the New York University Law School, he wrote ''A Guide to Workmen's Compensation'' with Max Blum, and ''The Worker and the Law.'' They were considered the first books addressed to the layman on his rights under workmen's compensation laws.

Apple Computer announced a major expansion program that includes two new plants and five new regional distribution and support centers. * Coastal Corporation said its newly formed Libyan exploration unit had signed an agreement with the Libyan National Oil Company to participate in exploration and development of potential petroleum reserves in Northeastern Libya.

C. Malcolm Davis, chairman of the board of Fidelity Union Bancorporation of Newark, was killed in a two-car accident Thursday night in Livingston, N.J, according to the police. He was 62 years old and lived in Morristown, N.J.

About 600,000 unemployed workers and former servicemen are becoming the first victims of the Congressional stalemate over a new Federal budget. A special unemployment benefits fund began running out of money today across most of the country because Congress has yet to approve President Carter's request for more money.

He was a large and feared man in the old times, those hard, tumultuous years of the Great Depression and the 1940's, when union men made the nation tremble as they fought for the right to organize. He is Emil Mazey. This week Emil Mazey retired. Standing up to company men, to cops, to hired sluggers, he was one of the leaders who helped build the United Automobile Workers. He is among the handful of men left from labor's celebrated days of the building of industrial unionism.

To the Editor: In a classic flip-flop, the Administration now condemns Ramsey Clark's presence in Iran as an obstruction to the eventual release of our hostages. Is this not the same Ramsey Clark who was dispatched on an Air Force plane to solve the problem when it began?v.hy can't this Administration get its act together just once and stop making Americans look like such incompetents. Really, we're not all that bad; just some of us are. GEORGE TILGHMAN New York, June 3, 1980

Philip Caruso, a 45-year-old Manhattan foot patrolman, was declared the winner of the election for the presidency of the Patrolman's Benevolent Association last night with a margin of 177 votes, but his opponent, while congratulating him, refused to concede and called for a recount. Charles Peterson, the 53-year-old incumbent who appeared to have been defeated, said he did not suspect manipulation of the votes, but simply wanted another count because the tally had been so close: 6,826 votes for Mr. Caruso and 6,649 for Mr. Peterson.

Consumer installment debt fell by nearly $2 billion in April as Americans paid off more than they borrowed for the first time since May 1975, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The drop was the largest in the 37 years that the Government has been keeping consumer credit data, according to a Federal Reserve official who asked not to be identified.

The real estate developer who ordered the destruction of two basrelief sculptures that adorned the partly-demolished facade of the Bonwit Teller Building says he does not know what has happened to a rare bronze grillwork that is no longer in the same building. Both the sculptures and the grillwork had been promised to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The gilded 20-by-30-foot grillwork of interlocking geometric designs built into the main entrance of the Fifth Avenue building on the northeast corner at 56th Street was offered to the museum last February by the Trump Organization, along with the two Art Deco sculptures if they could be successfully removed.

Interest rate futures, particularly on United States Treasury Bonds, moved sharply higher yesterday on the basis of Federal statistics that confirmed a sharp economic downturn because of the recession.

They surely love birthday parties in Brooklyn. On Thursday night, when Brooklyn was 355 years old, the Borough Hall Restoration Foundation threw a fund-raising party to restore its handsome 131-year-old Borough Hall. Brooklyn was a city when the building was constructed--it did not vote to join New York until 1898--and the hall was meant to outdo Manhattan's City Hall.
