SEATTLE, June 6--Tommy John got back on the winning track tonight, beating the Toronto Blue Jays, 3-0, with a two-hitter and earning his 200th career victory.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 6--Following the second fire in barrels of toxic wastes here in the last week, workers today speeded efforts to clean up the dump site, loading canisters of chemicals on trucks for shipment to other dumps.

Craig Lefferts, with relief help from Greg Bargar, held off repeated Hawaii attempts to rally and paced Arizona to the National Collegiate baseball title with a 5-3 victory over the Rainbows in the College World Series tonight. Hawaii, the surprise team of the tournament, threatened the veteran Wildcats until Bargar came on in the seventh and retired the last seven Hawaii batters down in order.

Dr. Wilbur K. Jordan, who was president of Radcliffe College from 1943 to 1960 and took part in its postwar merger of courses with Harvard University, died Tuesday in Lexington, Mass. He was 78 years old. In his tenure Dr. Jordan carried out the agreement for the joint education of Harvard and Radcliffe students. Until 1943 the latter received all instruction in quarters separate from Harvard students. Dr. Jordan inaugurated the women's archives and the Radcliffe seminars. As president, he oversaw the doubling of the physical plant at Radcliffe and the tripling of its endowment.

Unemployment shot up to 7.8 percent of the workforce in May, the Labor Department said, prompting forecasts that the nation's recession would be deeper and longer than previously thought. The rise, eight-tenths of a percentage point, was the same as in April, and the two-month increase was the largest in history, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. (Page 1.) Inflation slowed markedly at the producer level in May, the Commerce Department reported, damped by the recession. The Producer Price Index rose by three-tenths of 1 percent, it said, giving hope that consumers can expect a slowing in retail price increases. The advance was the smallest one-month rise in 32 months, and amounted to an annual rate of 3.7 percent. Prices were increasing at an annual rate of 18.9 percent in the first quarter of the year. (1.)

Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie said today that the Carter Administration was working actively toward bringing the treaty on the limitation of strategic arms before the Senate regardless of the status of the Soviet troops in Afghanistan. Asked to comment on the speech yesterday by his predecessor, Cyrus R. Vance, calling for Senate action on the treaty this year, Mr. Muskie said that the Administration was ''committed to the SALT process and we have under active consideration - and do on an almost constant basis - strategies for pursuing that objective.''

Federal District Judge William P. Copple sentenced a Utah man Monday to the stiffest penalties yet imposed under the Archeological Resources Protection Act of 1979. Thayde L. Jones, 37 years old, who pleaded guilty to a felony for damaging an archeological resource on May 5, was sentenced to 18 months in jail and was fined $1,000. His brother, Kyle R. Jones, 27, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor, was also fined $1,000 and sentenced to one year in jail. A co-defendant, Robert E. Gevara, 39, who pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor on April 28, was sentenced by Judge Copple on May 29 to one year in jail and was fined $1,000.

Actors protest the destruction of several Broadway theaters. The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association calls for a public referendum on pay increases for police. Harry B. Helmsley agrees to a six-month moratorium on construction of an apartment tower in a Tudor City park. A Transit Police officer describes a nearmurder on his beat. The chief executive officer of a corporation with distillery interests tells City Council members why an excise tax on beer and liquor is onerous. To the untutored eye, they are average New York City events. To those at the center of city government, running it and reporting on it, each bears a personal stamp, a monogram: John Scanlon, George Douris, Howard J. Rubenstein, Mortimer Matz, Paul Buiar. They are among the most prominent of the public-sector public-relations men who work New York City, and though their names may not be familiar, you certainly will know them by their deeds.

Humberto Calderon Berti, Venezuela's Minister of Energy and Mines and currently president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, expressed pessimism today that any agreement would be reached on a return to a unified oil price system at the group's ministerial meeting in Algiers, which is scheduled to begin on Monday. In an interview here, Venezuela's chief representative at the OPEC meeting stated ''that we're very interested in achieving a normalization of prices, but this is a complex point due to the differences that exist among our members, and it will not be easy.''

Denying any disloyalty to the Democratic Party, Mayor Koch made an animated, arm-swinging appearance before the Republican Presidential platform committee yesterday, urging more Federal help for cities and smilingly declining an invitation to switch parties. ''You have made the most eloquent argument for a Republican Congress that I have ever heard,'' the Republican national chairman, Bill Brock, said during the Mayor's testimony in the echoing rotunda of Federal Hall in lower Manhattan. ''May I issue an invitation to you to join the Republican Party?''

I went to a mail-order store to order a tire-pressure gauge. ''I want to order a tire-pressure gauge,'' I said to a woman at a computer terminal. ''What is your telephone number?'' she asked. ''218-2676,'' I said. She played the phone number on the keyboard, then studied the results on the computer screen. ''Your name is Herman Irving,'' she said. ''How did you know that?'' I cried. ''You live at 723 Elm Street,'' she replied. ''Astonishing,'' I said. She looked pleased. ''I'll bet you could get that machine to tell how old I was when I had the mumps and whether my liver is enlarged,'' I said. She played the keyboard again. ''You've never had the mumps,'' she said. ''Just measles, whooping cough and scarlet fever. Appendix removed when you were 17. Eighteen stitches to close a bad cut resulting from an automobile accident when you were 39. Afterwards you were charged with drunken driving.''

New Yorkers of All Ages Nine-month-old Khadijah Canns seemed perfectly content to lie back in her stroller and stare at George the Clown during performance yesterday by The Cumeezi Bozo Ensemble on Lexington Avenue at 53d Street.

When Kipchoge Keino, then over 30 years old, won track gold medals at the Olympics in Mexico City in 1968, he helped establish Kenya as the home of great runners. He was to become a cult hero among over-30 Americans who took up jogging.

HARTFORD, June 6 -- An argument over the form of Hartford's municipal government brought the ouster of the City Manager today. Some high City Hall officials had already been forced out of office by the controversy, involving politics, personalities and past, loyalties, and the Police Chief is under pressure to quit.

Several large banks, including Citibank, the nation's second-largest, cut their prime lending rates to 13 percent from 14 percent yesterday, following the lead Wednesday of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third-largest...
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The Senate killed President Carter's oil-import fee today by voting 68 to 10 to override a Presidential veto.

FUQUAY-VARINA, N.C., June 6 (AP) --A school bus carrying 45 students was struck by a tractor-trailer cab today, and officials said that 20 students were injured. The authorities said that the bus was making a turn on state Highway 55 when it was hit by a truck that was attempting to pass.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 6--Bruce Aubin, helped by having only three hours of sleep and a sharp putting game, beat Greg Zorila of Siwanoy, 5 and 4, today and captured the Westchester Golf Association's 61st amateur championship.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 6--Virtually the last of the generation that helped organize and build the United Automobile Workers retired here this week, turning over the leadership to a team that is less seasoned but is, according to associates, just as dedicated to the union's goals as were the pioneers.

WASHINGTON, June 6--A Florida official charged today that lack of cooperation from Federal bank regulators and enforcement officials was hamstringing efforts to crack down on banks suspected of serving as conduits for drug trafficking funds.

When judges are unjustly criticized, lawyers have an ethical duty to defend them. The precept is sound: judges are not wholly free to defend themselves. Society wants them that way, above the battle, more dignified than the politicians or disgruntled litigants who often take cheap shots and call names. This admirable canon has just been stood on its head by the report of a special joint committee of New York's city and county bar associations. It charges that Justice Arnold Fraiman of Manhattan was unjustly criticized - not by some politico or uninformed citizen but by New York's Court of Appeals. Rarely, if ever, has the organized bar rallied to a jurist's defense at the expense of the authority of a state's highest court. Rarely has the bar's prestige been so misused.

My phone rang at 2 A.M. I did the only sensible thing: I unplugged it. The doorbell woke me early the next morning. Two cops were standing in the hallway. In almost 20 years as a reporter, I'd never seen cops look more disgusted. ''You Bernard Lefkowitz?'' one said. I nodded. ''Call your mother,'' the other said. My mother is 69 years old and I had visions of her in a hospital, gravely ill. Or worse. ''Is she alive?'' I asked. ''She's sick,'' one cop said. The other shook his head. ''Just call her.''

The Hudson's Bay Company said it acquired a 60 percent equity interest in Roxy Petroleum Ltd. through the purchase of treasury shares for about $32 million. Hudson's Bay said that Roxy was a recently incorporated private concern that had acquired the partnership interests in the 1978 and 1979 programs of CRA Explorations, a Calgary-based drilling fund. It said that Roxy held about 85,000 acres of petroleum and natural gas rights in Western Canada.

A 31-year-old plumber who was the father of six children was dragged to his death in Brooklyn yesterday under the wheels of a trailer truck that he and two friends tried to halt after it allegedly struck a parked car and drove on, the police said. After the victim, Jose Melendez, was killed, his two friends, whose names were not released, commandeered an automobile and pursued the trailer truck through the streets of the Bay Ridge section, the police reported. The two men got ahead of the truck on the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and persuaded toll booth officials to hold the driver, Jimmy Ray Sanders, 31, of Le Grange, Ga.

Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus today ordered the filling of the New Melones reservoir in northern California and warned the state's Congressional delegation that unless it pushed now to save a contested section of white water farther upriver from the dam he would order that area filled, too. The Secretary's action was the latest development in a heated, decade-long dispute over the Stanislaus River and the reservoir, which is now only partly filled. And it sets the stage for a new fight between state resource officials who oppose filling the big reservoir and the Federal authorities, responding to agricultural and electric-power interests, who say they fear power brownouts over the summer if the dam is not filled.

A friend of Howard (Buddy) Jacobson who was accused of having helped the convicted murderer escape from the Brooklyn House of Detention last Saturday had a stock certificate worth ''in excess of $300,000'' signed over to him by Mr. Jacobson, authorities disclosed in Criminal Court in Brooklyn yesterday. The friend, Anthony DeRosa, 46 years old, was arraigned yesterday before Judge Norman Felig on charges connected with the escape. He was ordered held in $1 million bond or cash bail of $500,000 pending a hearing on June 23.
MONTREAL, June 6--Toy manufacturers and other television advertisers have been thrown into confusion by a Quebec law that bans commercials aimed at children under the age of 13.

CHARLOTTE AMALIE, V.I., June 6 (AP)--About 650 passengers were evacuated today from the British cruise ship Cunard Countess after a fire broke out in her laundry room while the vessel was docked here, the Coast Guard announced.

The New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission was honored by the Municipal Art Society yesterday for 15 years of dedication to "a just balancing of the importance of civic progress on the one hand and, on the other, of the saving for all the generations to come of the most precious examples of our complex urban past."

Denying any disloyalty to the Democratic Party, Mayor Koch made an animated, arm-swinging appearance before the Republican Presidential platform committee yesterday, urging more Federal help for cities and smilingly declining an invitation to switch parties.

M.D. To the Editor: On May 14, you printed a letter by Dr. Gordon K. MacLeod of the University of Pittsburgh on Three Mile Island and infant deaths in which he discusses the problem of congenital hypothyroidism in Pennsylvania and in particular suggests that I may have clouded the issue by making an error on the incidence of congenital hypothyroidism. believe Dr. MacLeod has misinterpreted a statement attributed to me in the original news article (April 15). I told The Times that the general incidence of primary hypothyroidism in infants in North America was about one in 4,300 live births, as reported in the May 1979 issue of the Journal of Pediatrics. This figure is obtained from cumulative data from the five oldest screening programs in North America: Quebec, Pittsburgh, Toronto, Northwest Regional and New England Regional. It is consistent with the data from Europe and Japan as presented at the International Conference on Thyroid Screening at Pointe-au-Pic, Quebec, in September 1979.

The World Series-champion Pittsburgh Pirates opened a four-game series with the New York Mets at Shea Stadium last night, but they did so without Bill Madlock playing third base. In a surprise move just before the game, the Pirate infielder said that he was withdrawing his appeal of the $5,000 fine and 15-day suspension levied against him on May 6 after he made contact with Umpire Jerry Crawford during an argument in a game May 1.

Oil-consuming nations have absorbed this year's sharply higher oil prices with surprisingly little difficulty, world bankers say, but they warn that a severe testing of the international financial system lies ahead in 1981. ''The situation is considered fairly under control for 1980,'' said Wilfried Guth, managing director of the Deutsche Bank, the largest in West Germany, but he added, ''Critical developments are feared for 1981 and later.''

performance of money-market mutual funds. It is designed to eliminate some of the confusion surrounding these highly popular investments. A basic aim of this standardized approach is to provide comparative yields for various funds. The National Association of Securities Dealers will compile the data every Friday.

To the Editor: I'm tired of hearing people being urged not to vote for John Anderson because he can't win. I'm not voting for John Anderson because I don't want him to become President. However, if I did think he was the best choice, I'd vote for him without hesitation because the argument that brands that vote ''thrown away'' is fallacious.
14 By STEVEN R. WEISMAN

A New Jersey man wept today as he told a Senate panel of the death of his infant daughter and of disabling illnesses he and his neighbors have suffered, all of which he attributed to pollution of their drinking water by hazardous waste in a nearby dump. The statements by the man, James G. McCarthy of Jackson Township, and other witnesses led Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, to assert that Federal, state and local officials had been remiss in not acting immediately to help people, rather than waiting for the completion of scientific studies.

Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, who defied President Carter's travel ban to attend an Iranian-sponsored conference on ''United States intervention in Iran,'' was denounced in its final document today as a ''latter-day Rudolf Hess.'' The statement, issued after the close last night of a four-day conference that the Teheran radio said was attended by 350 nongovernmental delegates from 54 countries, pictured Mr. Clark as a possible secret agent of President Carter. Citing a theory that is doubted by most historians, the conference document said Hitler sent Rudolf Hess, his chief deputy, to Britain in 1941 on a psychological warfare mission against the British, and it suggested that Mr. Carter sent Mr. Clark on a similar mission to Iran.
Dancers from several New York companies will appear in a gala benefit for the newly formed Catskill Ballet Theater on Monday at 8:30 P.M. at the Woodstock (N.Y.) Playhouse.
WASHINGTON WHAT its inventor describes as the first "windmill" with no moving mechanical parts was patented this week. It is designed to be built on a large scale and produce strong electric power.
ALBANY, June 6 -- The question being asked here is not, "How do we save New York City's subway and bus fares?" but, "Which is worse: approving a new tax or being blamed for a fare increase?"
AUSTIN, Tex., June 6--The comparisons seem inevitable. Both could sprint and jump with equal ability and world-class credentials. Both seemed blessed with strong characters.

LONDON, June 6 (UPI)--The Rank Organization, a film producer, owner of movie houses and the Xerox Corporation's European partner, said today that it was pulling out of film production and canceling eight major feature films with a projected total budget of $57 million.
WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)--The Energy Department gave gasoline dealers and wholesalers permission today to increase their charges 1.2 cents a gallon on June 15.
Just last year, which is ancient history in the mercurial world of Manhattan underground rock, there was a band called the Model Citizens.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 6 -- Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, who defied President Carter's travel ban to attend an Iranian-sponsored conference on "United States intervention in Iran," was denounced in its final document today as a "latter-day Rudolf Hess."

The lesson of ''The Hearse,'' which may be something a lot of us already knew, is that it's a bad idea to live alone in a house filled with mean-spirited apparitions. It is doubly bad if the locale is a town where everyone thinks you are the wicked reincarnation of your late Aunt Rebecca. I think we knew that, too. Nevertheless, Trish Van Devere does all these foolhardy things in ''The Hearse,'' which opened yesterday at the Rivoli and other theaters. The house was her family's, and she has just gone through a divorce plus the death of a parent, and so perhaps this explains her curious daring. In any case, she busies herself with painting and spackling and tidying the old place up, in hopes of making it cheery. Nothing doing. Soon she is being seduced by some demons and chased by others, including the ghostly driver of the title vehicle and the town's crew of leering delivery boys. The reasons for all this remain obscure even after they have been explained.

The men and their $100,000 machines had long since left the Indianapolis Motor Speedway last week, and yet Janet Guthrie remained behind, trying without much hope to salvage a racing career that has produced more publicity than success. There is a race tomorrow in Milwaukee, and Miss Guthrie knows that it could be her last. Since 1977, when she became the first - and to this day the only - woman to drive in the Indianapolis 500, Miss Guthrie, because of inadequate sponsorship, has run in only seven races. Having failed to qualify for this year's 500, the 42-year-old former physicist decided that ''if I can't put together a full race program, that will be the end.''

Jerry Korman, a former purchasing director for The New York Times, died yesterday at his home in Palms Springs, Calif., after a short illness. He was 67 years old. Mr. Korman worked for The Times for 42 years before his retirement in 1976. He is survived by his wife, Helen, and three sisters, Ruth Saginor, Miriam Allbright and Ethyl Morse.

Questions appear on page 17. 1. Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, heading a 10-member American group that attended an Iranian-sponsored conference called ''United States Intervention in Iran,'' said he might use the Freedom of Information Act to sue the Federal Government for information on American involvement in Iran during the Shah's rule.

Leonard Smith, the man found not guilty by reason of insanity in the slaying of Lyman Bostock, the baseball star, is scheduled to be released from a state hospital on June 20, an official in the Lake Circuit Court said today. Judge Felix Kaul yesterday signed an order authorizing the release, the judge's clerk said. The term of Mr. Smith's commitment to Logansport State Hospital expired yesterday, and the Lake County prosecutor, Jack Crawford, said doctors at the hospital had requested an order for the release. The judge's order said psychiatrists at the hospital had found that Mr. Smith ''is not mentally ill and not in need of care or treatment'' and had requested authority to release him.

Spectacular Bid could become the leading money-winner in thoroughbred racing history as he heads a field of seven for Sunday's $319,450 Californian at Hollywood Park. If all go to the post, the mile-and-an-eighth race will be worth $184,450 to the winner. Spectacular Bid needs only $184,001 to surpass the career earnings record, set last year by Affirmed. Should any one of the seven be scratched, the purse would be lowered by $2,000 for each withdrawal.

Call him Paddy, he suggests, adding, ''Everybody does.'' He is Irish, of course, and he speaks a brogue with the texture of a stew. For the love of peat Paddy came to Central Africa, and he works the bogs here. Patrick Keating, a reed-thin man built for work, is the cutting edge of an aid project significant for its ambition and its practicality. Tiny Burundi is one of the poorest, most overpopulated countries in the world, a high, chilly republic whose four million people have denuded the landscape for heat. The idea now is to exploit the peat, so Paddy has been at it for three years.

MASON, Ohio, June 6--Jane Blalock, who learned her golf while struggling with nor'easters over a links course near Portsmouth, N.H., fought successfully against gusts that reached 30 miles an hour today and tied Nancy...
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 6 (AP)-- Authorities with search warrants raided department stores in several north Alabama cities today and confiscated thousands of pairs of counterfeit blue jeans.

WAUKESHA, Wis., June 6--Ida Garcia has been sitting in the "hot seat" as a claims taker at the unemployment compensation office here for five years, and she has learned the rhythms and cycles of joblessness here in the Milwaukee area.
The nation's basic money supply slipped in the week ended May 28, as signs of a rapidly weakening economy continued to appear, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday.

A wealthy land developer from Carson City, Nev., says that for the last 10 years he and a handful of friends have been giving money and advice to the dissidents who proclaimed a provisional government this week over the northern third of the New Hebrides in the South Pacific.

WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)--Consumer installment debt fell by nearly $2 billion in April as Americans paid off more than they borrowed for the first time since May 1975, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Wim Rijsbergen, a defender for the Cosmos, has been fined by the North American Soccer League for a confrontation last April 10 with a New York Post sportswriter, the league said yesterday. In keeping with policy, the league did not disclose the amount of the fine. Commissioner Phil Woosnam also ordered Rijsbergen to issue a written letter of apology for ''shoving or punching'' the sportswriter, Phil Mushnick. Woosnam said further fines would be imposed if Rijsbergen did not apologize.

In the public park opposite the main station a stirring choral rendering of the ''Internationale,'' the song of world revolution, was coming over the loudspeakers. It caused no visible emotions of joy or distaste among the Sunday strollers, who included large working-class families and well-dressed upper-crust citizens on their way home from church. Panels set up on the gravel paths proclaimed in charts and bright colors how many new schools, clinics, nurseries, swimming pools and summer camps had been opened by the Communist-run city administration in five years and urged the voters to return the Communists to power in the June 8 municipal and regional elections.

He could easily have used his social connections to start a successful, conventional practice designing houses for rich people,'' a friend once said of Jaquelin Taylor Robertson, member of a prominent Richmond family, Rhodes scholar and holder of an architectural degree from Yale. Instead, Mr. Robertson, who will become dean of the prestigious School of Architecture at the University of Virginia, according to an announcement yesterday, plunged into the maelstrom of urban design in New York City. In 1969 he was appointed head of the newly created Office of Midtown Planning.
PLAN By JOHN DARNTON

Following the second fire in barrels of toxic wastes here in the last week, workers today speeded efforts to clean up the dump site, loading canisters of chemicals on trucks for shipment to other dumps. One destination is a chemical dump in Niagara Falls, N.Y., an approved, secure landfill about two miles from the Love Canal area, which has been the focus of national attention because of its problems of chemical contamination. Today, 14 truckloads of diluted chemicals and crushed 55-gallon drums left the condemned chemical-disposal site of the Chemical Control Corporation here for the eight-and-a-half-hour trip to the Cecos International (Chemical Environmental Conservation Systems) landfill in Niagara Falls.

Evelyn Byrd Gates, daughter of Mrs. John Monteith Gates of Boca Grande, Fla., and the late Mr. Gates, was married in Manhattan yesterday to William H. Metcalf Jr. of Arlington, Va. The Rev. Beatrice Blair, assisted by the Rev. Alanson B. Houghton, performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest. The bride, a registered representative and office manager with the Washington brokerage firm of Julia M. Walsh & Sons Inc., was graduated from the Hewitt School and Pine Manor College. Her father, an architect, was a vice president of Steuben Glass and director of design for the Corning Glass Works. Her grandfather, the late David Dows, was Sheriff of Nassau County in 1930, and head of the Republican Party in South Carolina during President Dwight D. Eisenhower's Administration.
PHOENIX, June 6--Federal District Judge William P. Copple sentenced a Utah man Monday to the stiffest penalties yet imposed under the Archeological Resources Protection Act of 1979.
PITTSBURGH--The discipline of history in the United States made a crucial error about 40 years ago. It tragically narrowed its audience to students and other academics.

OMAHA, Neb., June 6 (AP)--Craig Lefferts, with relief help from Greg Bargar, held off repeated Hawaii attempts to rally and paced Arizona to the National Collegiate baseball title with a 5-3 victory over the Rainbows in the College World Series tonight.

In 1976, New York's City Council decided to permit the city to seize title to properties on which taxes were in arrears for a year or more. The result was a disaster. The city quickly found itself the reluctant landlord of 10,000 buildings and 26,000 families. Worse, it had to start covering the huge operating deficits that led the owners to walk away. But in the last few months, there is unaccustomed good news for which the Koch administration deserves credit. The city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development is learning how to run these buildings and even has a plan for disposing of some.

Several large banks, including Citibank, the nation's secondlargest, cut their prime lending rates to 13 percent from 14 percent yesterday, following the lead Wednesday of the Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's third-largest. Among the other big banks announcing the 13 percent rate yesterday were Bank of America, the nation's largest bank; Chemical Bank; Manufacturers Hanover; European American; Mellon Bank; United States Trust Company, and Irving Trust.

Mike Marshall was placed on waivers by the Minnesota Twins today for the purpose of giving him his unconditional release. The 37-year-old relief pitcher has a no-trade clause in his contract and has said he would not play anywhere else. Marshall also has a guaranteed contract calling for $250,000 this season and $300,000 next year.

A Federal judge said yesterday that he would declare unconstitutional a law that in effect restricts special low bulk mailing rates to the Republican and Democratic parties. His action will entitle minor political parties and Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois, who is campaigning for the Presidency as an independent, to the reduced rate now available only to the two major parties. Chief Judge JAck B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn said he would issue a formal order on June 20 in a case brought by the New York Civil Liberties Union on behalf of several minor political parties that challenged a section of the Postal Service Appropriations Act of 1980 that limits the special rates to parties whose last Presidential candidate received more than 5 percent of the total popular vote.
Miller/graph of producer prices By EDWARD COWAN

The Court of Appeals, New York's highest judicial body, today upheld the conviction of Dr. Mark Gerard, a Long Island veterinarian found guilty of fraud in a horse-switching incident at Belmont Park in 1977. The court handed down a unanimous decision against Dr. Gerard, who has been sentenced to one year in prison and a $1,000 fine. Dr. Gerard, a specialist in the care of race horses, had been found guilty in State Supreme Court of ''fraudulent entries and practices in contests of speed'' over the switching of a speedy horse from Uruguay named Cinzano, worth $150,000, for a horse name Lebon, worth $450. The conviction was subsequently upheld in the Appellate Division of Supreme Court.

A report in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified the member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee who asked the Defense Department for tapes of communications between Washington and the American force that tried to rescue the hostages in Iran. Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, originated the request.

Companies around the country announced this week that they would close more plants and lay off more workers because of the developing recession. The announcements included the following: * Black & Decker Manufacturing, Baltimore, is closing two plants in Maryland for two weeks, laying off about 2,500 workers. * Chessie System, Baltimore, is laying off 335 more workers, effective June 12. * Dana Corporation, Toledo, Ohio, is permanently closing a truckaxle plant and a light-truck parts plant, with layoffs totaling 2,975.

Federal District Judge Warren H. Young, who presided over the 1973 trial of five black men who were convicted of murdering eight persons in the Fountain Valley Golf Club, died in his home today of lung cancer. He was 63 years old. Local residents blamed widespread publicity about the murder by the national media for a drastic drop in Virgin Islands tourism that lasted several years.

CROWN POINT, Ind., June 6 (AP)-- Leonard Smith, the man found not guilty by reason of insanity in the slaying of Lyman Bostock, the baseball star, is scheduled to be released from a state hospital on June 20, an official in the Lake Circuit Court said today.

TEL AVIV, June 6 -- The Israeli Supreme Court today rejected an appeal for the release of Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the Jewish Defense League in the United States. He has been detained without formal charges since May 13.

While New York City continued to escape the main consequence of the growing nationwide recession--a substantial increase in unemployment--the state as a whole reached a 19-month high in joblessness in May, according to statistics made public yesterday.
HONOLULU, June 6 (AP)--A disturbance tonight at the Hawaii State Prison left one inmate dead and one seriously injured, the police said. One guard was reported slightly injured.

Harry D. Margulies, a retired lawyer who had been an expert on workmen's compensation, died Tuesday at the Workmen's Circle Home for the Aged in the Bronx. He was 73 years old and had lived in Manhattan.
The Nassau County police arrested a 24-year-old man yesterday and charged him with murder in the shooting 18 months ago of Lawrence Lever, a prominent Long Island real estate developer.

FORT CHAFFEE, Ark., June 6 (UPI) --Troops at the Cuban resettlement center here confiscated knives and homemade weapons today while searching a section of the center known for its black market, prostitution, homosexuals and occasional knife fights.

Three Americans returning here after attending an Iraniansponsored conference on ''United States intervention in Iran'' said last night that customs officials at Kennedy International Airport had confiscated conference-related materials and a copy of the Koran. The three - the Rev. Paul M. Washington of Philadelphia, Leonard Weinglass, a Los Angeles lawyer, and Lennox S. Hinds, an associate professor of criminal justice at Rutgers - met with reporters after spending an hour with officials of the United States Customs Service.

Richard Cottingham, a 33-year-old Lodi, N.J., computer programmer, was ordered held in $350,000 bail by a Superior Court judge in Hackensack yesterday after pleading not guilty to charges of homicide, kidnaping and rape in connection with a slaying Hasbrouck Heights on May 4.

Dancers from several New York companies will appear in a gala benefit for the newly formed Catskill Ballet Theater on Monday at 8:30 P.M. at the Woodstock (N.Y.) Playhouse. Among the dancers scheduled to appear are the American Ballet Theater's Cynthia Harvey and Gregory Osborne, who will dance the ''White Swan'' pas de deux; Peter Fonseca and Yoko Ichino, also from Ballet Theater, who will dance the ''Don Quixote'' pas de deux; the New York City Ballet's Lourdes Lopez and Gerard Ebitz, who will dance ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux,'' and Starr Danias of the Joffrey Ballet, who will appear with Brian Jameson in Robert Weiss's ''Autumn Bacchanale,'' part of a tribute to Anna Pavlova.

Jacobs12To the Editor: Since passage of the ''Government in the Sunshine Act'' in 1976, many, including some Government officials, have expressed doubts about the usefulness of this ''open government'' measure. have often been told how costly and cumbersome it is to taperecord every meeting of members of every collegial agency of the Federal Government. I have also been told that ''nobody ever attends our meetings, except sometimes people from the regulated industry.'' When I asked for tapes of closed meetings from the Export-Import Bank, I was made to feel that my citizen's inquiries somehow were interfering with the important work of the agency.

A Florida official charged today that lack of cooperation from Federal bank regulators and enforcement officials was hamstringing efforts to crack down on banks suspected of serving as conduits for drug trafficking funds. Gerald A. Lewis, Comptroller of Florida, told the Senate Banking Committee that, despite repeated attempts to discuss the problem with Treasury Department officials, a meeting had not yet been arranged.

A protest by Atlantic City high school teachers over the selection of an Iranian as a commencement speaker and her subsequent decision to bow out continued to stir controversy yesterday. Tina Bahodori, an 18-year-old straight-A student who was fifth in her class of 550 at Atlantic City High School, won a competition among top students to give one of the two commencement addresses. But, sensitive to the tense climate caused by the hostage situation in Iran, she withdrew after learning that 56 of the school's 140 teachers and 24 school employees had signed a petition opposing her selection.

Germaine Amendola, the widow of a leading Italian Communist and member of Parliament, Giorgio Amendola, died of a heart attack today at the clinic where her husband died 24 hours earlier, hospital officials reported. The French-born Mrs. Amendola, 69 years old, was stricken while visiting the clinic where Mr. Amendola's body was on public view. He died yesterday at the age of 72 after a long illness.

Mayor Elias M. Frej of Bethlehem and Mayor Rashad Shawa of Gaza rescinded their decisions to resign last night, citing the need for unity among the Palestinian officials in Israelioccupied territories. The two and their Municipal Councils had announced plans to step down in protest over the bombing attacks on fellow mayors and other Arabs Monday. Two Mayors, Bassam al-Shaka of Nablus and Karim Khalef of Ramallah, were crippled by bombs rigged to their cars. Eight other people were wounded.

Gelsey Kirkland will dance as a guest artist with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House tonight. Miss Kirkland will appear with Anthony Dowell in ''Other Dances.'' The ballet replaces ''Fantasie Serieuse,'' which has been withdrawn from the program because of an injury to Natalia Makarova. Miss Makarova will be replaced by Eva Evdokimova on Monday in ''Giselle.'' Miss Evdokimova, a guest artist from the London Festival and Berlin Opera Ballets, will be partnered by Alexander Godunov. Miss Makarova is expected to resume performing Wednesday, when she will appear in ''Giselle'' with Mr. Dowell.

Stewart Richer, who was just voted a Special Coty Award for the freewheeling young clothes he makes for his store, Reminiscence, was reminiscing recently about his circuitous route to success in the fashion world. ''I studied business administration,'' he said, ''and was a stockbroker once. Then I had a vending machine business, and sold encyclopedias for a while. Then I took recycled denim pants and started making different items. That evolved into antique clothing. When I opened the shop five years ago, it was basically antique clothes, then I started buying white surplus and dyeing it, then I got into manufacturing.''

Actors protest the destruction of several Broadway theaters. The president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association calls for a public referendum on pay increases for police. Harry B. Helmsley agrees to a six-month moratorium on construction of an apartment tower in a Tudor City park.
Helped by a broad early advance-- the result of some favorable news on inflation--the stock market finished yesterday with a modest gain and at its highest level since early March.

ROME, June 6 (AP)--Germaine Amendola, the widow of a leading Italian Communist and member of Parliament. Giorgio Amendola, died of a heart attack today at the clinic where her husband died 24 hours earlier, hospital officials reported.

Philip Caruso, a 45-year-old Manhattan foot patrolman, was declared the winner of the election for the presidency of the Patrolman's Benevolent Association last night with a margin of 177 votes, but his opponent, while congratulating him, refused to concede and called for a recount.

The real estate developer who ordered the destruction of two bas-relief sculptures that adorned the partly-demolished facade of the Bonwit Teller Building says he does not know what has happened to a rare bronze grillwork that is no longer in the same building. Both the sculptures and the grillwork had been promised to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Kraft Incorporated and Dart Industries Incorporated said the two companies, which announced plans to merge on Thursday, have not reached an agreement on the terms of the exchange for Dart's 2.6 million convertible preferred shares. However, the companies said they expect that each share of Dart preferred will be exchanged in the merger for one share of common stock in the new company, to be called Dart & Kraft Inc.

More stragglers from the Freedom Flotilla began making their way across the Florida Straits today, following the 90-mile path that has delivered more than 110,000 Cuban refugees to the United States in the past seven weeks. The Coast Guard reported that about 15 boats left Mariel Harbor early in the day. By dusk, nine boats had brought in 936 refugees, bringing the 48-day boatlift total to 111,081.

UF813 PARIS, June 6 - With an effective first service compensating for mistakes, Vitas Gerulaitis outlasted Jimmy Connors through five sets requiring 3 hours 57 minutes today and reached the final of the French open tennis championships for the first time.

About 650 passengers were evacuated today from the British cruise ship Cunard Countess after a fire broke out in her laundry room while the vessel was docked here, the Coast Guard announced. Petty Officer Keith Richter said the fire began at 4:30 P.M. and was confined to the laundry room in the bottom deck of the fourdeck, 534-foot vessel. It was reported out two hours later. No damage estimate was available.

Many of us who are college students are bewildered, not by the staggering realities of the contemporary world but rather by the lack of vision of those who govern it. We wonder whether the failure to answer today's challenges more boldly will undermine and perhaps destroy our capacity to influence the world's direction in the years when we will be leaders. I will be specific. No war in this century has so changed the balance of power in the world as has the energy confrontation of the 1970's. Western civilization is dependent on oil. The production and pricing of oil is controlled by an international cartel that does not perceive its interests to be our own. The greatest transfer of resources in history is taking place through increased energy prices. In the next five years, at present schedules, the United States alone will pay $500 billion for oil imported from nonaligned countries whose principal political objective is to be independent of us.

An argument over the form of Hartford's municipal government brought the ouster of the City Manager today. Some high City Hall officials had already been forced out of office by the controversy, involving politics, personalities and past loyalties, and the Police Chief is under pressure to quit. For the last six months, the state's second largest city, with a population of 146,000, has been stymied by a power struggle between its new political leaders and those still holding offices they got through the previous leadership. which was defeated in last November's election.

Puerto Rico will send a ''symbolic athlete'' to the Moscow Olympics, according to the president of the island's Olympic Committee, German Rieckehoff, who described President Carter's call for a boycott of the Games as an ''absurdity, a political game.'' Mr. Rieckehoff sent a message to the organizing committee in Moscow yesterday, the deadline for enrolling athletes in the Games, listing two athletes from the track and field and fencing federations.

International Ramsey Clark was denounced in Iran as a ''latter-day Rudolph Hess,'' who was Hitler's chief deputy. Mr. Clark, a former Attorney General, defied President Carter's travel ban to attend an Iranian-sponsored conference on ''United States intervention in Iran.'' He was was pictured as a possible secret agent of President Carter in a statement issued at the end of the four-day meeting. The statement also denounced the United States for what the conference leaders said was continued interference in Iran over 27 years. It did not mention the American hostages being held in Iran. Customs officials confiscated papers belonging to three Americans returning from the Iran conference on ''United States intervention in Iran,'' the three said after arriving at Kennedy International Airport. An official said documents had been copied and returned to the three. (5:5-6.) Rabbi Meir Kahane must stay in prison in Israel without being told why, the Supreme Court in Jerusalem ruled, saying that the evidence against him and an associate, indicating ''a plot to attack Arabs,'' was so serious that no moderation of the prison term could be considered. (3:5-6.) The P.L.O. reversed a policy statement calling on Palestinians to settle for nothing less than the destruction of Israel, issued by Al Fatah, the organization's most powerful faction, last Sunday at the end an 11-day meeting in Damascus. P.L.O. representatives said the statement was ''misunderstood'' and that Al Fatah would accept a political solution that would establish an independent Palestinian state on territories recovered from Israel. (3:1.) Submission of the arms pact to the Senate is still an objective of the Administration regardless of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie said. Responding to former Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance's call on Thursday for action on the pact this year, he said that the Administration was ''committed to the SALT process and we have under consideration strategies for pursuing that objective.'' (4:3-4.) Moscow will have far fewer visitors attending the Olympic Games this summer than had been expected before President Carter pressed for an international boycott. Soviet officials had planned on 300,000 foreign tourists. Moscow's Mayor and others now say that 70,000 are expected. (16:5-6.) Energy The Senate killed the oil-import fee, voting 68 to 10 to override a Presidential veto and thus enacting legislation rejecting the fee. The House on Thursday voted by 335 to 34 to override the veto. The fee would have raised consumer gasoline prices by 10 cents a gallon. The Senate regarded the surcharge as a tax that would be politically difficult to back in an election year, and felt that its authorization by the President was an usurption of Congressional authority. (1:4.) National The jobless rate increased again in May. It rose by eight-tenths of a percentage point, the same as the April increase, to 7.8 percent of the nation's total work force, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. The increase over the two-month period was the biggest in the nation's history, the bureau said, and it indicated that the recession would be deeper and longer than had been expected. (1:6.) Producer prices rose by only three-tenths of 1 percent in May, the Government said. It was the smallest one-month rise in 32 months in the Producer Price Index for finished goods, a sign that there will be a further slowdown in retail price inflation. (1:5.) Bert Lance will not be retried, with two co-defendants, on banking charges, the Justice Department announced. The department said it would move in Federal District Court in Atlanta next week to dismiss three remaining counts against Mr. Lance, President Carter's former budget director, and counts against his co-defendants. The three had recently been cleared of a series of other charges. (1:6.) The filling-in of a California reservoir was ordered by Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus, who warned the state's Congressional delegation that unless it presses now to save a contested section of white water on the Stanislaus River behind the reservoir's dam in northern California, he will flood that area, too. (6:1-2.) Metropolitan An unmarried woman may sue for redress when she separates from a man she had been living with. To receive a share of his assets, she must show that they had an ''express'' agreement, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled. California is the only other state which has given women the right to sue for a share of the assets of a former partner. The New York court acted in the case of Frances Morone, who had sued for financial support from the man she said she lived with for 25 years. (1:3.) Hartford's City Manager was ousted in a continuing political dispute over the the city's form of government. High municipal officials had previously been forced to quit and others, including the police chief, are under similar pressure. (1:3-5.) New York City's jobless rate rose less than the nationwide rate in May, although it went up to 8.4 percent from 8 percent in May 1979. New York State's unemployment rate reached a 19-month high last month, and New Jersey's rate showed a marked increase, according to the regional office of the Bureau of Labor Statistics. (7:4-6.) Business Digest, Page 25

The Energy Department gave gasoline dealers and wholesalers permission today to increase their charges 1.2 cents a gallon on June 15. Higher prices could begin showing up at the pump immediately, but a spokesman for service station owners predicted that competition would keep about half the dealers from imposing the full increase.

Ida Garcia has been sitting in the ''hot seat'' as a claims taker at the unemployment compensation office here for five years, and she has learned the rhythms and cycles of joblessness here in the Milwaukee area. The college kitchen and dormitory workers have been lining up this week, right on schedule, and next week, she knows, the school bus drivers and teachers' aides will appear. But why are the roofers and the foundrymen and the construction workers coming in too, she wonders, to apply for unemployment benefits now, in early summer, when they should be busiest?

The trial in the Bedford Hills robberymurder case ended today as Junius Gray, the second defendant charged with killing four residents of that northern Westchester community 13 months ago, was sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison. Speaking of Mr. Gray and his co-defendant, Jimmie Lee Allen, acting Justice Duncan S. McNab said in State Supreme Court: ''It is the hope of this court that Mr. Gray and Mr. Allen should not see the streets of this country again.'' Mr. Allen - who, like Mr. Gray, is 41 years old - received the same sentence Wednesday.

Most of the eight plays in "Marathon 1980" deal with obsessions. In this three-week festival of one-acts, which ends this evening at the Ensemble Studio Theater, characters can be manic about a single subject--everything from sitting in a treehouse to maintaining equilibrium in the middle of an apocalypse.

WASHINGTON, June 6--President Carter, making his first formal political speech since the final primary elections Tuesday, said today that Ronald Reagan and the Republican Party were "looking backward to the 1950's" and engaging in "demagoguery" and "simplistic answers to complicated questions."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, June 6 (UPI)--Puerto Rico will send a "symbolic athlete" to the Moscow Olympics, according to the president of the island's Olympic Committee, German Rieckehoff, who described President Carter's call for a boycott of the Games as an "absurdity, a political game."

A 31-year-old plumber who was the father of six children was dragged to his death in Brooklyn yesterday under the wheels of a trailer truck that he and two friends tried to halt after it allegedly struck a parked car and drove on, the police said.

The Israeli Supreme Court today rejected an appeal for the release of Rabbi Meir Kahane, founder of the Jewish Defense League in the United States. He has been detained without formal charges since May 13. Justice Yitzhak Kahan, who issued the ruling in Jerusalem, declined to specify the allegations against Rabbi Kahane, saying only that they involved ''a plot to attack Arabs.'' He said the evidence pointed to a plot so serious that he could not consider appeals to cancel or reduce the detention or to turn it into house arrest.

Al Neumann, a heavyweight boxer from Renton, Wash., will meet Ron Lyle of Denver, a former contender, in a 10-round fight here June 19. The fight will be the feature attraction of a five-bout card being promoted by Muhammad Ali Professional Sports Inc.

Wearing his familiar Milwaukee uniform with the No. 31, but with a new svelte figure, George Bamberger bounced up the steps of the Brewers' dugout. The impish grin was vintage Bamberger as he acknowledged the many media representatives waiting on the County Stadium field before the Brewers went out and defeated the Detroit Tigers, 8-4, tonight. ''This is worse than opening day,'' the 54-year-old Bamberger said of his return as Brewers' manager after heart bypass surgery March 26 from a heart attack he suffered in spring training. ''That's because on opening day the players and coaches are with you, know what I mean? This time I'm the center figure, especially when they're making such a big deal of it.''

When Kipchoge Keino, then over 30 years old, won track gold medals at the Olympics in Mexico City in 1968, he helped establish Kenya as the home of great runners. He was to become a cult hero among over-30 Americans who took up jogging. What most Americans don't seem to realize is that we Kenyans, Kip Keino included, have been running since we could walk, simply because we had to.

GALES FERRY, Conn., June 6 (AP) --Yale will try tomorrow to end Harvard's dominance of nearly two decades in their annual rowing showdown. This year's race on the Thames River is the 115th between crews of the Blue and the Crimson. Harvard has won for the last 17 years.

C. Malcolm Davis, chairman of the board of Fidelity Union Bancorporation of Newark, was killed in a two-car accident Thursday night in Livingston, N.J, according to the police. He was 62 years old and lived in Morristown, N.J.
He was a large and feared man in the old times, those hard, tumultuous years of the Great Depression and the 1940's, when union men made the nation tremble as they fought for the right to organize.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie said today that the Carter Administration was working actively toward bringing the treaty on the limitation of strategic arms before the Senate regardless of the status of the Soviet troops in Afghanistan.

SAN FRANCISO, June 6--Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus today ordered the filling of the New Melones reservoir in northern California and warned the state's Congressional delegation that unless it pushed now to save a contested section of white water farther upriver from the dam he would order that area filled, too.
WARSAW, June 6 -- Spring has come to Warsaw, a bit later than to most other parts of the world, and that means that the sun actually shines from time to time. The effect is wondrous to behold.

The authorities worked to restore disrupted utility services throughout the tornado-devastated city today and abandoned plans to close Grand Island to outsiders this weekend. Police Chief Howard Bacon said the proposal to barricade all entrances to the city was dropped in favor of closing and imposing curfews in five areas that suffered the worst storm damage.

Virtually the last of the generation that helped organize and build the United Automobile Workers retired here this week, turning over the leadership to a team that is less seasoned but is, according to associates, just as dedicated to the union's goals as were the pioneers. Some of the successors are expected by fellow members to be a bit more conservative politically than are many of their predecessors and the remaining liberal leaders, such as Douglas A. Fraser, the union's president. Several ranking union officials, however, said that they did not expect a dramatic shift in the politics or philosophy of the union.

Soviet officials have begun to acknowledge that far fewer foreign visitors will be coming to the Moscow Olympics this summer than were expected before the American-led boycott movement began. Vladimir F. Promyslov, Mayor of Moscow, and other officials say 70,000 foreign tourists are expected during the period of the Games, from July 19 to Aug. 3. The organizers of the Games were predicting as little as two months ago that 300,000 would attend.

BLUES FOR TONIGHT William Christopher Handy was known as the ''Father of the Blues'' primarily because he was the first person to publish a blues number. He had an academic as well as a musical background, and this, perhaps, led him to write down a lot of the music he came across. In 1909, he wrote ''Mr. Crump,'' for a Memphis political campaign, and in 1912, the song was renamed ''Memphis Blues.'' The ''St. Louis Blues'' was published in 1914. W.C. Handy also had many spirituals to his credit; ''I've Heard of a City Called Heaven'' and ''I'll Never Turn Back From Here'' were two.

Martha Veronica Haesloop, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gordon Haesloop of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., was married there yesterday to Robert Emmett Link 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Link Jr. of Great Neck, L.I. The Rev. Joseph Keane of Cathedral College, Douglaston, Queens, performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

VARINA, N.C., June 6 (AP) - A school bus carrying 45 students was struck by a tractor-trailer cab today, and officials said that 20 students were injured. The authorities said that the bus was making a turn on state Highway 55 when it was hit by a truck that was attempting to pass.

The United States military leadership of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, unquestioned until now, is being analyzed critically by the defense ministries and commands of many of the Western European allies. Doubts about the direction of American military and political policy, misgivings over arms-production potential and the prospect that future crises in the Middle East and elsewhere will find the United States unprepared have contributed to this malaise.

In the celebrated grudge match between the filly and the colt and their feuding jockeys, Genuine Risk won a measure of female revenge yesterday at Belmont Park by finishing seven lengths in front of Codex. But there was no tangle, no bumping, no shouting, no accusing, no hearing and no victory for either of racing's recent rivals.

Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate majority leader, said today that it was ''conceivable'' that Senator Edward M. Kennedy could still win the Democratic Party's Presidential nomination. ''At this point anything is conceivable,'' Senator Byrd said at his weekend news conference when asked whether he thought Senator Kennedy could win the nomination even though President Carter appeared to have won enough delegates to secure his renomination at the Democratic National Convention this August.

It all began perhaps 25 years ago, when horse show sponsors began to look around for new ways to attract spectators. Few people, with the usual exceptions, bothered to watch equestrian events, so show managers began seeking added attractions. ''The idea,'' said Dave Wright, manager of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club Show, which begins a six-day run in Darien, Conn., on Tuesday, ''was to try to entice the public into at least taking a look at a horse show here and there. It worked. And now there's hardly a major show in the East that doesn't have a special added attraction.''

SEASIDE HEIGHTS ON THE boardwalk, the tangy salt air mixes with the smell of fried onions and freshly baked pizza. On the beach, a small knot of early sunbathers gathers, their chatter mingling with the pounding of the surf and the electronic beeps of pinball machines. These are the smells, sights and sounds of yet another summer, and all along the boardwalk in this amusement-dotted resort the concessionaires go about their business with a sense of optimism that has not been evident in several years.

The hotel chef in ''The Shining'' is supposed to have remarkable psychic powers, but the movie never explains the strangest of this man's idiosyncrasies: he can smell trouble from Miami to Colorado, but he doesn't detect a killer standing 10 feet away from him, armed with an ax and wearing a horrible grin. The movie's ghostly butler starts out with the name of Charles Grady, but he somehow becomes Delbert Grady before the story is finished. The caption on a closing photograph of Jack Nicholson utterly defies explanation. And the director, Stanley Kubrick, once again leaves his audiences asking a familiar question: How can anyone make a film so fastidiously beautiful and still leave so many loose ends? ''The Shining'' may be a horror film, but it very much fits the Kubrick mold. First and foremost, it is mesmerizingly lovely, so handsome you may be halfway out of the theater before those nagging questions arise. Yet, like ''A Clockwork Orange'' or ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' this is a movie that barely makes sense upon examination. Most of the small details seem meticulously chosen, but there's no evidence that corresponding care has been taken with the film's central concerns.

A bill that would give Love Canal residents more time to sue private companies for injuries that they believe were caused by toxic waste dumping was approved by the Assembly this week. Current state law places a three-year limit on the time in which such civil suits can be brought. The legislation adds a two-year period starting from the time an injury is discovered. It also would allow people now barred by the three-year limitation one more year to begin court action. Assuming the bill becomes law, any questions of constitutionality in regard to extending retroactively the statute of limitations would remain for the courts to decide.

A New York City lawyers' group contends that the statutory charter proposed for the Federal Bureau of Investigation ''contains serious deficiencies and should not be enacted in its present form'' because it does not adequately protect civil rights and civil liberties. In a report issued last week, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York, a voluntary group of nearly 13,000 lawyers, said that it might endorse amended legislation if it provided more safeguards for civil rights, including more controls on certain investigative techniques.

To the Editor: The June 1 editorial about poison ivy recommends ''yellow soap ... a heavy lather of laundry soap'' as a remedy. This is bad advice. Contact with poison ivy has already irritated the skin. Vigorous rubbing with a heavy lather of coarse soap causes further damage. Washing the skin may remove some of the rhus irritant, but it should be done gently and with the blandest soap or detergent. SPENCER F. BROWN, M.D. Darien, Conn., June 1, 1980

Every once in awhile we suddenly step back and notice that an oldfashioned theatrical form, one we'd thought drained of energy if not safely dead and buried, is in fact simply waiting patiently in the wings, scenery intact, ready to be trundled out again in all its familiar furbelows. Not so much passe, let's say, as eternally patient. And, in some peculiar way, still useful. Take courtroom melodrama, for instance - which you may very well do by dropping by the Biltmore where Tom Topor's ''Nuts'' is now holding forth. By all the rules, if there are any rules, courtroom melodrama should have exhausted its ploys and counterploys as far back as ''Witness for the Prosecution,'' if not ''The Trial of Mary Dugan.'' Surely every leading question, surely every evasive answer, surely every ''overruled'' that can be rapped out with a gavel by a wigged or unwigged member of the judiciary has done its dramatic duty long since. We can smell a trap being baited by a wily D.A., can't we? And hear, virtually by ESP, the innocently admitted shred of evidence that is going to turn as treacherous as an envenomed toad? We may never have passed a bar exam, but we've played this game before.

THE winners of this year's Nassau County Department of Consumer Affairs consumer youth contest have shown that more than the three R's are part of the curriculums of most Long Island schools. Using communications media as subtle as poetry or as hard-hitting and sophisticated as videotape, the 17 first-place winners demonstrated their understanding of consumerism and smart shopping.

One of the odd things about the conduct of American foreign policy is that Secretaries of State never seem to tell what they really think about the world until they resign, at which point people and even most newspapers have stopped listening. Former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance, a Yale man, saved the best speech of his long and illustrious career for the Harvard commencement last week. And it seems clear from this carefully and personally written address (the text of which was published by only one or two American newspapers) that Vance resigned, not primarily because he opposed the U.S. military rescue mission in Iran, but because he had deep doubts about the political and military domination of the nations's foreign policy.

A citizens' group that last year predicted worsening conditions on the Conrail commuter lines issued a follow-up report yesterday, saying quality of service had indeed been declining ''precipitously.'' It concluded, as it had last year, that only a massive infusion of funds for maintenance could prevent further deterioration. The Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said its study of operations on the Hudson, Harlem and New Haven lines over the 12 months since May 1979 showed a 79 percent increase in the number of trains canceled en route. It said there was a 23 percent increase in trains running late and a 27 percent increase in the number of cars out of service on a typical day.

Darrell Griffith, Joe Barry Carroll and Kevin McHale probably will be the first three players selected in Tuesday's National Basketball Association college draft. The biggest question is the order in which they will be taken.

BUJUMBURA, Burundi--The North Koreans are building President JeanBaptiste Bagaza a new palace on the highest hill in town. The Cubans are training Burundi fighter pilots, though there is no air force to speak of yet. Soviet military hardware is on display in the capital. The Chinese just opened a textile mill.

FAR HILLS THE countryside in this part of Somerset County is beautiful, what with woods, rolling hills and fine homes. "If you ride down the back lanes in the fall or winter," Emily de Nemethy said, "you can sometimes catch a glimpse of the hunt. It's so pretty with all the pink coats and fine horses."
KEY WEST, Fla., June 7 (AP)--The"freedom flotilla" sputtered to a standstill today after bringing more than 110,000 Cuban refugees to the United States since early April.

The room itself is simple; mahogany twin beds pushed together, white hobnail bedspreads and red pillows, white throw rugs on a terrazzo floor and hunting prints on the walls. The room is full of the sound of the sea.

BRANFORD VIETNAMESE cooking has been a long time making its way to Connecticut, but it has arrived at Chez Bach, which faces the village green here.

Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who has remained neutral in the Democratic Presidential race, said yesterday that he would not be a delegate to this summer's Democratic National Convention because he did not want to displace someone who has "worked hard for their Presidential choice the last six to eight months."
New York City's new police union president urged yesterday that a coalition of uniformed workers set a strike deadline to coincide with the beginning of the Democratic National Convention on Aug. 11.

ROSENDALE, N.Y.--At the edge of a tangled wilderness tract near this Ulster County village, about 100 miles north of New York City, a van rumbled to a stop the other day, and five teen-agers wearing brand new hiking boots got out.
NEW JERSEY theatergoers can breathe easier now. The Paper Mill Playhouse will be rebuilt, with September 1981 as the target date for reopening.

Several thousand demonstrators marched through Dublin today demanding political status for 430 prisoners in Northern Ireland. The marchers were addressed by Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, a former Member of Parliament and longtime political activist, and Rose McCallister, who was recently released from the Armagh jail.

Delegates representing Democrats living abroad will divide their votes between President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts at the party's national convention. At a mini-convention this afternoon at the English-speaking Union in London, the Democratic Party Committee Abroad chose four delegates, two of whom support Mr. Kennedy and two of whom support the President. The committee, which is headed by Toby Hyde, a business consultant, includes 12 members from eight countries.

Rod Santomassimo scored three goals today and led Ward Melville to an 11-7 victory over Half Hollow Hills East for the Suffolk County scholastic lacrosse championship at the victor's field before a crowd of 2,000 today. It was Coach Joe Cuzzo's 204th triumph over the last 11 years, and it was Ward Melville's fourth county championship in the last five seasons.

MEMOIRS OF HECATE COUNTY By Edmund Wilson. With an Afterword by John Updike. 472 pp. Boston: David R. Godine/Nonpareil Books. Paper, $7.95. ''MEMOIRS OF HECATE COUNTY'' is Edmund Wilson's only collection of stories, among 40 or more volumes of criticism, drama, poetry, scholarship, travel and reminiscence. When the book first appeared in 1946, it also became his only best seller, before it was suppressed for obscenity by the New York State Court of Special Sessions. Its reissue (how notions of obscenity have changed!) is an occasion for rereading it, and a rewarding experience.

FAMILIES By PHYLLIS BERNSTEIN HEMPSTEAD SUMMER, and the living is easy. Or is it? Not for T.P. of Hicksville, a divorced, full-time working parent, who is hard put to find the extra funds to provide summer camp for her two youngsters. A harried Mrs. P. spoke of a special financial difficulty she faces this summer ''all by myself.'' She believes she has no choice but to provide safe and pleasant recreation for her children. Camp, she said, calls for a sacrifice, ''but when I'm at work, I want to know where they are - I can't leave them in the streets.''

The ease with which Ronald Reagan rolled through the Republican primaries has left the former California Governor optimistic about his prospects for winning the Presidency next fall but essentially untested for what his lieutenants expect to be a bitterly fought campaign. The central test, both Republican and Democratic strategists agree, is whether Mr. Reagan can make the election a referendum on President Carter's performance, or whether his own capacity for Presidential leadership will become the main issue.

President Carter directed the Justice Department today to move quickly to expel Cuban refugees who committed ''serious crimes'' in Cuba and to expel or prosecute those found to be responsible for the rioting last Sunday night at Fort Chaffee, Ark. In announcing the move, Jody Powell, the White House spokesman, acknowledged that there was no indication that President Fidel Castro of Cuba would accept those whom the United States wanted to send back.

Americans are more likely to change their membership in a church denomination for theological reasons now than they were in the past, statistics contained in the new edition of the Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches suggest. The study was published last week under the sponsorship of the National Council of Churches. Forty percent of the adult Protestants belong to a different church denomination than the one in which they were raised, according to a study conducted by C. Kirk Hadaway of the Southern Baptist Convention. The results were drawn from the composite data of samples, a total of 7,500 people, polled separately at different times by the Gallup Organization, the Roper Public Opinion Research Center and the National Opinion Research Center.

Judges are expected to be decorous, even-handed and, of course, sober. Judge Culver K. Barr of Monroe County Court in Rochester fell short of the mark last August. Appearing as a defendant in a nearby town court, he pleaded guilty to drunken driving. He was sentenced to three years' probation, fined $250, and had his driver's license revoked for six months. It was the second time in less than a year that he had been convicted of driving while impaired by alcohol.

When Patrick and Kathy Donahue of Stratford, Conn., decided they wanted to adopt a child, they flew to Colombia rather than waiting the three years they were told it would take to adopt a child through an American agency. They adopted their first daughter in 1977; their second in 1979. Today, Kyla is 3 years old and Katie is 9 months. Because of the travel to Bogota and the legal and agency fees involved, Mr. Donahue estimates it cost him $5,000 to adopt each of the girls - more than double the cost of an average adoption through an American agency.

In the 1980's, the 20 percent, maybe even 30 percent of the bottom performers in retailing will go down the tube in a shakeout that will affect many people and many businesses,'' said a speaker at a meeting last month of retailing executives. Jabbing a long cigar at his audience to emphasize his points, the portly, 38-year-old accountant continued his remarks, flavoring them with pungent expletives that visibly stirred his audience.

At a meeting of business leaders here recently, President Carter called the Equal Rights Amendment ''unfinished national business'' and urged his audience to work for its ratification. For more than three years, the march toward passage of the E.R.A. has been stalled. A step forward always seems to be matched by a step back. And while the amendment needs to be ratified by only three more states before June 30, 1982 to become part of the Constitution, the prospects remain gloomy.

THREE cheers for the long-predicted recession that we are supposed to have. A ''well done'' for Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who recently expressed hope that the business downturn would come ''the sooner the better.'' And hurrah for the former chairman, Arthur F. Burns, who said that, beyond a recession, America's fundamental need in the economy ''is to create a new environment.'' I agree. And let me assure you that I am not demented, rich, masochistic or insensitive to the havoc that a depression can cause. I lived through one. And so perhaps better than you, I remember squatter families living amidst garbage on the Jersey meadows, and the shuffling breadlines of bloody, broken men.

NEW JERSEY theatergoers can breathe easier now. The Paper Mill Playhouse will be rebuilt, with September l98l as the target date for reopening. One of the state's landmark structures, the 42-year-old playhouse in Millburn burned on Jan. l4. The roof collapsed, the stage, orchestra and lobby were demolished and water and wind further ravaged the building.

To the Editor: Your issue of June 1 carried stories of a deepening recession, stalled Middle East negotiations, the continuing hostage crisis in Iran, an unsolved murder attempt on a black leader and, to top it off, a forecast of hot, sticky weather for the metropolitan region.ne would think that on the day you raised the price of your (Sunday) paper 17.6 percent, you should have at the very least brought us some better news. MICHAEL ALEXANDER New Hyde Park, L.I., June 1, 1980

While members of 49 other state legislatures face the pressures of inflation, taxpayer revolts and threats of cutbacks in Federal revenue sharing, Alaska's lawmakers yesterday ended an appropriations spree that will spend an average of $6,250 this year for every Alaskan. At the same time the state's economy has bounced back from the low point that followed the end of construction of the trans-Alaska pipeline in 1977. Employment is up, building is up and projections are for more growth next year.

William McAlpin Shiland of Locust Valley, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Dianne Parsons Shiland, to John Cram Smith, son of Peter Smith of Mill Neck, L.I., and Mariana M. Smith of Washington and Rangeley, Me. An October wedding is planned. Miss Shiland, daughter also of the late Harriet Manice Shiland, made her debut at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball in 1976, the year she was a member of the Junior Assembly. She was graduated from the Green Vale and Foxcroft Schools and attended Boston College. She is with Trainer Wortham & Company, an investment counseling concern in New York. Her father is a lawyer in Manhattan.

3The Eden Roc. It's one of the landmarks of Miami Beach. But like other hotels there, the Eden Roc has fallen on hard times. Last week the Eden Roc was bought out of bankruptcy, and ambitious plans to renovate it are well under way. There the story might end, but this is not just another business transaction. Miami Beach is a winter retreat popular with the country's Jewish community, and the man who bought the Eden Roc is an Arab.

HARTFORD HIS city will shortly be the richer by an important new building on its west side--the Hartford Seminary Founda tion, designed by Richard Meier. Pending its completion, Mr. Meier is on view as both architect and artist in the Matrix Gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum.

The New York City Department of Health has cited 59 food establishments for health code violations. The department said two restaurants had been reopened after correcting violations and three had been closed for failing to do so.

Helen Van Slyke, the best-selling romantic novelist who died last July after undergoing surgery, is represented on not one, but two, best-seller lists this week. The novel she completed only two weeks before her death, "No Love Lost," is on the hardcover list, while her 1979 novel, "A Necessary Woman," is on the mass-market paperback list.

ALTHOUGH most homeowners think of window screens and screened-in porches or other enclosures only as a means of keeping out pesky flying and biting insects, many do not realize that there is a widely available type of fiberglass screen mesh that not only keeps these insects out, but also serves to keep a high percentage of the sun's heat out on hot summer days.
