The primaries proved that half the Democrats favor renominating Jimmy Carter, half the Republicans favor nominating Ronald Reagan and half the electorate favors neither. So we hear again that the system does not work, is in fact undemocratic, and requires radical reform. Fortunately, the eagerness for reform normally lasts only as long as the campaign season.

CRACOW, Poland--The Twelve Apostles, who used to bless passers-by on Grodzka Street, no longer stand on their high stone plinths in front of the Church of SS. Peter and Paul. Without them the 16th-century church seems denuded.

A 26-year-old unemployed laborer was in police custody here today charged with killing a little girl in a case that has brought an outpouring of civic concern, grief and unity that is revealing of the changing personality of Canada's largest city. With its three million residents Toronto is to Canada what New York City is to the United States, the national capital of commerce, communications, finance, fashion and culture. Where the two cities drastically differ is in violent crime.

The most important difference between President Carter and Edward Kennedy, says Mr. Carter, is that he won't agree to the debate that has become such a strange obsession with the Senator. This refusal might nevertheless be a miscalculation on the President's part, since Mr. Kennedy has promised to release his delegates to vote as they please if such a debate is held before the Democratic convention. Besides, Mr. Carter is beginning to look like a none-too-artful dodger, having already pulled out of a scheduled three-way debate with Mr. Kennedy and Jerry Brown in Iowa, then announcing in advance that he would not permit Representative John Anderson to take part in the Presidential debates next fall.

Members of the Democratic-led Assembly came back from dinner one evening last week and passed a batch of five bills appropriating more than $200 million for revenue sharing, upstate cities and school districts, welfare recipients and the types of community programs that make life more pleasant and help legislators get re-elected. They did so with the help of a ''message of necessity'' from Governor Carey, a legal device that allows them to circumvent the constitution's requirement that bills wait three days before being considered. In normal times none of this would raise an eyebrow, but these are not normal times in Albany. Passage of those budget bills marked the first time since March 1979 that the Democrat in the Governor's office had come to terms with the Democrats in the Assembly on a matter of money. ''The point is, there is a Democratic position, finally,'' said Robert J. Morgado, the Governor's top aide. ''The focus will be on the Senate, where it properly belongs.''

Like the Battle of Britain and other crises in the history of human civilization, the New York City transit strike brought to the surface a hidden reserve of human potential that usually ramains submerged. New Yorkers displayed resolve and creativity in getting to work. New modes of energy-efficient transport were developed (such as motorized roller skates); subway crime disappeared; common courtesy reappeared, and public officials became available on a daily basis.

THE scribbling was tiny and purposely deceptive, but when I deciphered the words on the inside cover of the beat-up six-year-old loose-leaf notebook, I knew that ''I stink at pitching'' was a confession to cleanse the soul. But what 9-year-old needs a press agent for the doubts aching his giant heart? To be truthful, my hero did stink at pitching. Billy could reach the Little League plate and could even make Cass stretch his catcher's mitt high in the air some of the time. But the only reason he was occasionally a pitcher was that someone had to pitch when our regular starter's strong arm died or when our backup faltered; Billy was better than any of the other outfielders or the kids on the bench.

THE weekly newspaper, that well-read amalgam of news, features, local advertising and legal ads, has long thrived on the Island, particularly on the rural East End, where more than a dozen community papers, all within 30 miles of one another, compete for advertising revenue, news and readers to serve 25,000 households. Now another newspaper is making its debut on the already crowded East End newsstands, just in time for the summer season. The new entry against the long-established East Hampton Star, The Southampton Press and the others is The Bridgehampton Sun. Its publisher is Leonard Saffir, who was press secretary to former Senator James L. Buckley of New York and whose last journalistic venture was The Trib, a short-lived New York City tabloid that expired in 1978.

If advertisers will grin through bad times, magazines can bear it. Or so the current strategy of the magazine industry seems to run, despite a recession that's not only official but going on six months old. The tumultuous, risky world of magazine publishing is thinking positively this time around - and is better-positioned than ever to weather a slump. Media People, New Dawn and Muse have folded recently, but that's no more than usual. Atlantic, Saturday Review, Cue, Us have been put on the block, but they've all found buyers, and now Harper's and New West are looking.

THEY are strangers who have lived in the same building, one for 10 years, the other for 20. They have eaten all their meals together, and they have slept in the same room for three of those years. They share intimate moments to which even the closest of kin - husband, parent or child - are not privy. They know a great deal about each other's past, present and future, yet they do not speak or communicate directly with each other.

Liane Marie Schulthess and David Mann Douglas were married yesterday by the Rev. Thomas Hughart at the Bedford (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church. The bride is a daughter of Yvonne Carole Schulthess of Bedford Village, N.Y., and Ernest Walter Schulthess of Bronxville, N.Y. Mr. Douglas is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Douglas of Center Square, Pa. Mrs. Douglas is a graduate student in special education at the University of Texas at Austin, where her husband is studying for a master's degree in business administration.

THREE authorities met in the Washington bureau of The New York Times late last year to discuss the Presidential nominating season that was about to begin in earnest. Last week, with most of the dust finally settled, the same experts - Austin Ranney, political scientist and resident scholar of the American Enterprise Institute, Richard G. Stearns, director of delegate selection for the Kennedy campaign, and David A. Keene, former political director for the George Bush staff - met again for a post-mortem on the nominating process. With them were correspondents Adam Clymer and Hedrick Smith and Michael Wright, an editor of The Week in Review. Excerpts from the discussion follow. Question. How would you rate the 1980 political primary season?

LIFE By GENE I. MAEROFF

The theater season has just drawn to a close, and it is a time for awards, some of which have been announced, some of which are to come. Among those just announced are those of the Outer Critics Circle, made up of New York theater writers for the out-of-town press, and the the Drama Desk, whose members cover New York theaters for New York (and elsewhere, too). The Outer Critics bestowed their Distinguished Achievement in Theater Awards on Mark Medoff's ''Children of a Lesser God'' as the most distinguished new production of a drama, and ''Barnum'' as ''the finest example of musical theater and professional skills.'' These critics also cited all the women in ''Mornings at Seven,'' -Nancy Marchand, Maureen O'Sullivan, Elizabeth Wilson, Teresa Wright and Lois deBanzie. Gerald Hiken was singled out for his characterization in ''Strider.''

No name means more in the history of American glass than Louis Comfort Tiffany. And no designs from Tiffany's fertile mind and prolific 50-year-long production mean more than the ones he devised for his own country home - Laurelton Hall, in Oyster Bay, L.I. How fitting, therefore, that the first special exhibition at the new Corning Museum of Glass, in Corning N.Y., is ''Tiffany's Tiffany,'' the architectural elements which survived the fire that destroyed the designer's extraordinary residence in 1957. The show of 80 selections, on view through Nov. 2, also includes a score of examples of Tiffany's art glass, his pottery and his stained glasstopped, bronze-based lamps. Thomas S. Buechner, director of the museum which opened in a new home last Sunday, recalls in the foreword to the catalogue on this show that when the museum came into being in 1951, Tiffany Studios was viewed as ''one of several producers of overly ornate, rather theatrical objects.'' All that began to change in 1953 when a revival of interest commenced in the works of this innovator, who had figured prominently as a designer from 1880 to 1930. And judging by the response of the public to this show and the skyrocketing prices in the marketplace, the interest which reached boom proportions more than a decade ago shows no sign of diminishing. ''He imagined, invented and brought into existence a vast oriental bazaar of riches,'' Mr. Buechner continued. ''This exhibition is about the world he made - the best of it, the things he chose to live with himself.''

Sixty Cuban refugees suspected of instigating last weekend's rioting at Fort Chaffee face confinement and hearings that could lead to their deportation, Federal officials said today. The 60 suspects, none of whom have been charged with any state or Federal crimes, were scheduled to be taken from the Fort Chaffee stockade and flown to an Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center at El Paso, Tex., between 8:30 and 9:30 P.M., central daylight time, today.

The lawsuit filed by the City Council read plainly enough: ''To all taxpayers, property owners and residents of the City of Corpus Christi, Texas,'' its preamble said in part, ''you are hereby notified that you and each of you have been named as a defendant ...'' It's not every day that a City Council sues its own constituents over the results of a referendum, or that the citizens retaliate by trying to recall the Council from office. But that has happened here in a clash of political wills and of civic values almost as old as the Republic.

One of the last of the maverick entrepreneurs may be bending to the weight of progress and age. After years of searching for a successor, tough-talking Justin Dart, the 72-year-old chairman of Dart Industries, seems to have found one. Last week, Dart Industries and Kraft Inc. announced that they planned to get together in what would be one of the largest mergers on record with an exchange of stock valued at $2.5 billion. The combination, agreed to by directors of both companies, would involve a tax-free swap of one Dart or one Kraft common share for each new share of stock in a new company, to be called Dart & Kraft Inc.

American intelligence officials have said that while the Soviet Union lived up to a pledge to withdraw some tanks and troops from East Germany, it has begun strengthening its remaining forces in Eastern Europe. The officials said yesterday that the program, when complete, would add 30,000 troops, 1,000 artillery pieces and more than 1,200 tanks and armored personnel carriers to 26 Soviet divisions in East Germany, Poland and Czechoslovakia. They asserted that these changes would more than offset the withdrawal of 20,000 troops and 1,000 tanks from East Germany, which was announced last October.

To the Editor:$ n an article on documentary films, ''Real Life as the Focal Point'' (March 23), Vincent Canby referred to the influence of Richard Leacock, D.A. Pennebaker and David and Albert Maysles on the documentary, but he failed to mention Robert Drew, an important pioneer in that form. Coming from Time-Life as a journalist, Mr. Drew realized the advantages of two people - a journalist and a photographer - covering a story, and he sought to apply that journalistic technique to film. He saw that a two-man crew could achieve greater intimacy with its subject, gain greater mobility and thus come closer to filming ''real life.''

The ''three lives'' of Joseph Conrad (1857-1924) - his first 16 years in Poland, his 20 years as a sailor, his last 20 years as a writer in England - examined by the scholar who edited his collected letters. Our reviewer John Romano called this sizable volume ''crucial for the study, not only of Conrad, but of his literary times.'' THE LASKO TANGENT, by Richard North Patterson. (Ballantine, $1.95.) When a stubborn, idealistic lawyer for special investigations looks into the financial manipulations of an important industrialist who's a close friend of the President, he finds that potential informants are always being knocked off before he can get to them. Newgate Callendar described this as a first novel by a man who knows the Washington scene and writes about it with real style and not a little cynicism.

In the aftermath of the Miami riot, black leaders and liberal politicians have advanced with renewed vigor the thesis that race riots result from racial discrimination. This is precisely the wrong lesson to draw from Miami. Clearly, racial discrimination played an important role in igniting the riot - especially the treatment blacks were receiving from the Miami police force - but the roots of racial violence in Miami go far deeper than discrimination. Unlike the race riots in the first half of this century (characterized by direct warfare between whites and blacks), the Miami riot (like New York City's during the 1977 blackout) was marked by the wholesale burning and looting of business establishments, both black- and white-owned. Like the riots of the 1960's, Miami's was primarily a result of class conflict. As Merrett Stierheim, county manager for metropolitan Dade County, said: ''There are probably thousands of jobs lost, of which the majority and probably 99 percent were held by black citizens. The violence was not just aimed at white entrepreneurs. There was no rhyme or reason. The whole community has paid a terrible price.''

Twill be a long political summer. The primaries proved that half the Democrats favor renominating Jimmy Carter, half the Republicans favor nominating Ronald Reagan and half the electorate favors neither. So we hear again that the system does not work, is in fact undemocratic, and requires radical reform. Fortunately, the eagerness for reform normally lasts only as long as the campaign season. The public may not be getting the leaders it wants, but an incumbent President is being severely challenged from every side. All mainstream viewpoints, and prejudices, are being heard.

The stage darkens. The band strikes up a fanfare. The man steps forward with his head kept low. He is wearing a blazer and a polkadot bow tie. He is somewhat heavier than when he used to move to the front of the stage 30 years ago and invite the audience to join him in a song in a Broadway musical called ''Where's Charley?''. Yes, it is Ray Bolger again and it seems that he is going to ask the public to join him in the same song. ''Once in love,'' he sings, ''with Visa.'' So it is not Amy but Visa, a polyester process developed by Milliken & Company, the textile manufacturer, with which Mr. Bolger is in love this week in the Milliken Breakfast Show at the Waldorf-Astoria.

To the Editor: The optimism expressed by the World Coal Study (''Coal; Bridge to the Future'') and The Times (''Coal as King; Americans as Saudis,'' editorial May 13) is based on an incorrect assessment of the environmental constraints facing a massive increase in coal use. hief among these, as The Times noted, is the buildup of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. The Times suggested that if the CO2 problem ''proves serious ... coal combustion can be cut back.'' We think that reasoning is flawed.

Tanner had one scare, however, when he turned his ankle and fell during the sixth game of the second set. Willie Carson rode Bireme to victory in the 202d Oaks for 3-year-old fillies today and became the first jockey since Lester Piggott in 1957 to ride the Derby and Oaks winners in the same season. As in the Derby, Carson had the pick of the Dick Hern-trained entrants and chose the right one. Dick Hollingsworth's 9-2 filly beat Vielle, also 9-2, by two lengths. The Dancer, also trained by Hern, was 14-1 and a head farther back in third.

If You Go ... to Bergen, S.A.S., the Scandinavian airline, operates four nonstop flights a week from New York, one on Monday, two on Tuesday and one on Saturday. The Apex advance purchase round-trip fare is $599. Other round-trip fares from New York: business class, $1,186; special economy, $1,050; first class, $2,026. The airline also operates a daily service to Bergen via Copenhagen; the Apex fare on this route is $732. Travelers can also fly to the city from Oslo, 190 miles away, or go by train. The train journey takes about seven hours because the line wanders through the mountains. One-way fare is $40. The best months for a visit to Bergen are May through August; it can be very rainy and windy at other times of the year. Further information can be obtained from the Norwegian National Tourist Office, 75 Rockefeller Plaza, New York 10019 (212-582-2802).

CONNECTICUT already reuses aluminum, glass, paper and garbage. Last week, it added asphalt pavement to the list. A New Britain contractor has begun ripping up and shredding a one-mile stretch of Route 4 in Burlington. The material is mixed with new sand and stone, with seven pounds of new material for each three pounds of old pavement, and from 2.5 percent to 3 percent liquid asphalt is added, about half the normal amount. It is shipped back to the job site at 275 to 285 degrees Fahrenheit and laid like conventional paving material, whose structural capacities it is supposed to match. The process saves 50 percent of the petroleum and 30 percent of the sand and stone, but right now, ''the bid prices are exorbitant,'' according to Robert Christman, an engineer at the Connecticut Department of Transportation, who has been working on the project for the last two and a half years. The cost per ton is $35.84, compared with $27 for virgin material, he said.

For a man with two death sentences on his head, Gilchrist Olympio displays the cool confidence of the successful businessman he has become since he fled Togo. Mr. Olympio, who is 43 years old, divides his time jetting between profitable deals in London, Paris and Houston and inveighing against Togo's undisputed ruler, Gen. Gnassingbe Eyadema.

EACH year in May there is one weekend day that, without specific previous planning, offers weather so perfect that it becomes the day for preparing the suburban house for summer living. This year that day was Saturday, May 17, when the sun was summer-warm, the air still and fragrant, and the atmosphere in one suburban neighborhood mellow and serene. Following is an account of a long-practiced ritual that philosophers would probably relate to man's primal stirrings, the age-old instinctive welcoming of summer. 7 A.M. - Lying in bed, trying to sort out whether this is another weekday with its jumble of problems, I see the sharp glint of sunlight through the shades and remember happily it is Saturday. The previous night's forecast has promised joyful weather for today, boxes of plants delivered earlier in the week exert a strong pull on my sensibilities. Perhaps it is the subconscious anticipation of the coming summer with its promise of long days and possible travel abroad, but I am suddenly motivated to get up and get busy.

What Presidential election?'' Charlotte Weaver, a 32-year-old San Francisco graduate student, asked after she cast her ballot Tuesday in the California primary election. ''All I care about are 9, 10 and 11.'' The objects of Miss Weaver's concern - 9, 10 and 11 - were not running for anything; they were ballot propositions related to taxes and rent control. And Miss Weaver's lack of interest in the Presidential race was reflected across the nine states that expressed their Presidential preferences Tuesday in the form of very low voter turnouts.

The National Herb Garden, an exquisite display of some 7,000 herbal plants from all over the world, will make its formal debut on Thursday as the newest attraction at the National Arboretum. The most ambitious herb project ever undertaken, the $418,000 garden occupies two acres of what was once a simple meadow. Veteran herbalists, window box gardeners and even the uninitiated will find there the old familiars - the rosemarys and thymes, the lavenders and mints and chives. But there are the more exotic herbs on display: the Chinese toothache tree, whose fruit is used to numb pain in the gums; the Japanese iris, whose roots are ground for face powder; the hops used in beer, the juniper berries used in gin; the paper plant, once used in printing paper money.

Charles Saxon, a cartoonist for The New Yorker for the last 25 years, has a problem: So many companies have been buying his drawings for their ads that last year he was able to do only 15 cartoons for the magazine, half his usual total. ''I was just swamped with ad assignments and my New Yorker work suffered,'' he said. ''This year, I'm setting aside more time for the magazine, which I consider my home and where I can really express myself.'' So it is with many New Yorker cartoonists. Madison Avenue has become a second home and generous paymaster for artists whose instantly recognizable, light-hearted styles provide an enticing lure for the messages of such big-time advertisers as Mobil Oil, Shell, Dow Chemical, the Bell System, Western Electric, General Electric, American Electric Power, Xerox, American Express, United Airlines, Burlington and Bankers Trust.

California, which has led the nation in many movements, provided momentum two years ago to the middle-class revolt against taxes when voters in one electrifying day at the polls slashed property taxes by $7 billion a year. Tuesday, the same voters decided almost as decisively - by a margin of about three to one - against cutting their state income taxes in half. Does this signal an end to the tax revolt? Careful analyses of the antitax movement suggest that just as Proposition 13 of 1978 did not start the movement - it had been quietly under way since 1975 - the vote against Proposition 9 and other ballot initiatives, last week, followed a national pattern that demonstrations there are limits to the tax revolt.

About three million Americans suffer from angina, the pain that arises when blood flow to the heart muscles is inadequate. In a minority of such patients, the angina arises from temporary spasms of the coronary arteries. A study published last week in The New England Journal of Medicine indicates that a drug called nifedipine can be dramatically effective in controlling the disease in those patients. The study included 127 patients over five years, and the researchers, headed by Dr. Eugene Braunwald of Harvard, found attacks had been totally eliminated in 63 percent and reduced by at least half in 87 percent. Only 5 percent had to stop the drug because they could not tolerate the side effects, which include dizziness, flushing and headache. The researchers caution that the study was neither blind nor randomized, but they believe the numbers are persuasive all the same. The study did not examine the majority form of angina, but researchers note that evidence is growing to show that arterial spasm may play a role in many heart diseases.

For the second straight game, the Yankees blanked the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome tonight. This time the score was 1-0, and the home team picked up only three hits off Tom Underwood in eight and two-thirds innings. Rich (Goose) Gossage got the final out. Killing off for good any belief in the jinx that had preceded them here, the Yankees also for the first time in their history won consecutive contests in this stadium.

Temperence Hill, a 53-1 shot so little appreciated that his name was misspelled in the program, scored a stunning upset in the 112th running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday - and somehow it had to end that way. For in a zany season in which the first two legs of the Triple Crown were won by different horses, a colt named after a Methodist church near Fordyce, Ark., returned $108.80 to any of his backers sinful enough to wager $2 on him.

O'Keefe of Cushman & Wakefield Inc., and George Comfort & Sons Inc.

ATTN GREG LEEDS Abraham Lincoln's mother, Nancy Hanks, was born there; George Washington's forebears lived nearby; and the Penns of Pennsylvania originally came from the district (before they moved to Buckinghamshire). This is the market town of Malmesbury, which this year celebrates the 1,100th anniversary of the royal charter granted by King Alfred that allows it to lay claim to the title of England's oldest borough. To celebrate the birthday, the town has planned a series of summer events, including a music and arts festival, with a specially commissioned requiem.

Nine years ago, two Xerox Corporation executives aboard a transcontinental flight began talking about their company's philanthropic endeavors and decided to expand them beyond financial contributions to worthy causes. On that flight, Archie McCardell, vice president, and James Wainger, director of personnel, mapped their plan: The corporation would award a fully paid leave of absence to employees who could prove they would use the time to help a cause they felt was deserving.

HELEN AND TEACHER The Story of Helen Keller and Anne Sullivan Macy. By Joseph P. Lash. Illustrated. 811 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $17.95. JOSEPH LASH's ''Helen and Teacher'' is part of the Radcliffe biography series about distinguished American women. It's a risky book in two respects. First of all, the lives of Helen Keller and her teacher Anne Sullivan Macy have already been told. Helen Keller wrote ''The Story of My Life'' and ''Teacher: Anne Sullivan Macy,'' and Nella Braddy did a good biography of Mrs. Macy in the 1930's. And William Gibson dramatized the story in his wonderful play ''The Miracle Worker.'' A second risk is that any book this long - 811 pages, to be exact - is bound to be put in the company of all those fat and mindless biographies we've been getting recently.

If You Go ... to Dahlonega, you will find it is easily reached in a little over an hour by car from Atlanta via Georgia 400 and U.S. 19. From the north it represents a logical side trip from the Great Smoky National Park area. For hikers Dahlonega is about 20 miles from Mount Springer, the southern terminus of the Appalachian Trail. Accommodations in Dahlonega itself are relatively limited. The Smith House, near the center of town, is a pleasant mountain hotel built in the 1890's directly over a gold vein of unknown value. The hotel has only 20 comfortable rooms, starting at $15, so reservations are definitely recom-mended; call 404-864-2348. The Smith House is popular with hikers resting up from the Appalachian Trail.

THE Nassau Republican County Committee not only is the most prosperous county political organization in the state - and maybe the country - but also is helping the nearly bankrupt Republican State Committee stay afloat. The Nassau organization demonstrated its fund-raising potential last month when it attracted 4,200 people at $150 each to its annual dinner at the Colonie Hill in Hauppauge. National political reporters and aides of Ronald Reagan, who was the principal speaker, agreed that it may well have been the largest political dinner in the country, netting up to $500,000 for the Nassau organization.

WESTCHESTER County last week opened an office for Vietnam veterans who were exposed to the herbicide known as Agent Orange and who are now concerned about health problems that some have linked to the chemical defoliant. ''The office is being established,'' said County Executive Alfred B. DelBello, ''in response to the growing number of Vietnam veterans in the county expressing concern over health problems possibly attributable to the herbicide while serving in Vietnam.'' Mr. DelBello said he thought the office was the first in the country to be opened by a local government.

YORKTOWN HEIGHTS IN most other suburban split-level houses, the room half a flight down from the front door is a ''family room.'' Not in Ellen Epstein's split-level. Tattered, cracked paintings rest on a table in the center, along with nine pieces of jade that originally were one, a cloisonne vase that is chipped, a sodden piece of an Egyptian sarcophagus and a reproduction of an enamel-on-copper portrait of Henry VIII that hangs in the Louvre, its gilt frame smashed and painted over with a bronze substance.

Jerry Korman, a former purchasing director for The New York Times, died Friday at his home in Palms Springs, Calif., after a short illness. He was 67 years old. Mr. Korman worked for The Times for 42 years before his retirement in 1976. He is survived by his wife, Helen, and three sisters, Ruth Saginor, Miriam Allbright and Ethyl Morse.

Carlo Donat-Cattin, forced to resign as vice president of the Christian Democratic Party a week ago, is one of Italy's most vocal anti-Communist politicians. His son, Marco, is in hiding as a suspected member of Prima Linea (Front Line), the terrorist organization that calls itself Communist but regards the official Communist Party as its chief enemy. Before a parliamentary commission that probed the disappearance of his son, Mr. Donat-Cattin turned back an embarrassing question from a Communist legislator with the answer: ''Why don't you ask my daughter, she belongs to the same party as you.'' Mr. Donat-Cattin resigned in hopes of preventing an impeachmentlike proceeding against Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga, who has been charged with giving Mr. Donat-Cattin information that allegedly helped him save his son from arrest. In a pointed warning to politicians of all parties, Mr. Donat-Cattin told the parliamentary comission: ''I have a list of 41 (prominent) Italian personalities with sons in the same conditions as mine.''

Laura P. Limbocker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Limbocker Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Stanley Stone 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stone Jr. of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The Rev. William D. Shively performed the ceremony in St. Christopher-by-the-River Episcopal Church. The bride studied at the Hathaway Brown School, graduated from the Madeira School and attended Bennett and Sweet Briar Colleges. She is manager of Rabbits Inc., a gift shop in Cleveland. Her father is vice president-corporate affairs of the Oglebay Norton Company, an iron-ore and steel company in Cleveland. Her grandfather, Courtney Burton, is chairman of the board of Oglebay Norton.

SEATTLE, June 7--For the second straight game, the Yankees blanked the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome tonight. This time the score was 1-0, and the home team picked up only three hits off Tom Underwood in eight and two-thirds innings. Rich (Goose) Gossage got the final out.

WASHINGTON, D.C. STATE and Federal officials are seriously considering a proposal by the Providence Worcester Railroad that it take over all of Conrail's freight operations in Connecticut and Rhode Island.

SOUTHAMPTON IT is not unusual for artistic gifts to run in families. The Peales, Morans and Mounts of an earlier era and the Wyeths and Soyers of today are a few of the celebrated clans that have produced several talents.

The 1979-80 season comes to an official, gaudy, cathartic finale tonight when the Tony Awards are presented before a nationwide television audience at the Mark Hellinger. Only a fool would predict how the Tony voters are going to swing--or at least make such speculations in print--and so there will be no predictions here.
THEY are strangers who have lived in the same building, one for 10 years, the other for 20. They have eaten all their meals together, and they have slept in the same room for three of those years.

CHEPSTOW, Wales, June 7 (AP)-- The United States maintained its commanding grip on the Curtis Cup women's amateur golf series today, defeating Britain and Ireland by a recordequaling 13-5 margin at the St. Pierre course.

Jane Hall Heist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Clark Heist of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Scott Howard Gamber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Gamber of Mechanicsburg, Pa. The Rev. David Philips performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church of Old Greenwich. Mary Elizabeth Lyman was maid of honor for her cousin. Robert Howard Elwell served as the best man. The bride, a member of the Junior League of Durham, N.C., was graduated from the Northfield Mount Hermon School and in 1978 from Duke University, from which she received an M.B.A. last month. She will be a market analyst in new product development, beginning this month, with the International Paper Company in New York. Her father is an executive vice president of Champion International Corporation, a Stamford, Conn., manufacturer of building materials, paper and allied products.

Last spring, this column reported that the Casals Festival in Puerto Rico, in trouble since the death of its founder, Pablo Casals, would continue under a new music director, Jorge Mester. Trouble didn't cease, however, though through no fault of Mr. Mester's. The members of the Puerto Rico Symphony Orchestra got into a dispute with the festival management. It could not be resolved, and the festival was canceled. Now the festival is set to reopen this week, the inaugural concert to take place on Tuesday, with Mr. Mester conducting and Zara Nelsova as cello soloist. The revival is taking place under a setup different from that governing the festival in the past. Originally, it existed as part of a Puerto Rican economic-development program. Other organizations shared in governmental grants, and contributions were not tax-deductible.

THE countryside in this part of Somerset County is beautiful, what with woods, rolling hills and fine homes. ''If you ride down the back lanes in the fall or winter,'' Emily de Nemethy said, ''you can sometimes catch a glimpse of the hunt. It's so pretty with all the pink coats and fine horses.'' Mrs. de Nemethy lives down one of those back lanes, in a charming 200-year-old house of brownstone and white clapboard. At each side of the house is a barn, and each barn is full of 17th- and 18th-century furniture from England, Wales, Scotland and Ireland, with a few American and Continental pieces as well.

The same computer that malfunctioned earlier this week and erroneously warned of a Soviet missile attack on the United States did so again yesterday, sending out another false signal of an attack, the Defense Department said tonight. The error was caught within three minutes, according to Thomas B. Ross, Assistant Secretary of Defense for public affairs. But once again the engines of some planes of the Strategic Air Command were turned on, he said, since the command responds automatically to any warning signal.

Marguerite Elaine Abell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Shepherdson Abell of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Thomas David Nurmi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aser Nurmi of Painesville, Ohio. Msgr. Joseph Corbett performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington. Ann Kenny was maid of honor and James Nurmi was best man for his brother. The bride was graduated from the Country Day School of the Sacred Heart in Bethesda, Md., Rosemont College and the Washington Montessori Institute. She was until recently a teacher and coordinator of the Montessori program at Our Lady of the Woods Academy in Bethesda. She is a great-great-granddaughter of Arunah Shepherdson Abell, founder of the Sunpapers in Baltimore. Her father, a lawyer and partner in the Washington firm of Nash, Ahern & Abell, is vice chairman of the board of the Sunpapers and of WMAR-TV in Baltimore.

The engagement of Claudia Anne Stone to Richard Wayland Clary has been announced by the bride-to-be's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Carl Henry Stone of Wellesley Hills and Marion, Mass., and Paris. Mr. Clary is a son of the Rev. and Mrs. S. Grayson Clary of St. Paul. An October wedding is planned. Miss Stone, an associate in the corporate-finance division of the investment banking firm of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company in New York, attended Aiglon College in Switzerland and was graduated from Wellesley College. She received master's degrees from the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy and the Yale University School of Organization and Management. She is a member of the Junior League of New York.

Bach, like Shakespeare and the Bible, can be interpreted in any number of ways - one reason, no doubt, for the composer's enduring popularity and appealing universality as each generation discovers fresh meaning in his music. New York's concertgoers are currently getting a big dose of him at the Basically Bach Festival, now at the midway point in Avery Fisher Hall. While this series offers a generally solid, middle-of-the-road approach to Bach, many other musical paths are open to performers and most of them can be heard on a variety of recent recordings. Karl Richter, who conducts this Friday's concert at Fisher Hall, has recorded dozens of Bach works over the past 25 years with his Munich Bach Choir and Orchestra, the latest being the mighty ''St. Matthew Passion'' (Archiv 2712 005, four disks). Collectors familiar with Mr. Richter's 1959 version will find the new recording different in many details, although the overall view remains the same: large forces, modern instruments, adult as opposed to treble voices and an interpretation firmly grounded in the mainstream Germanic tradition of Bach performance.

After a decade or more of pie-in-the-sky promises and publicrelations hullaballo, the ''new technology'' of communications is descending upon the nation at large. While the general public may remain understandably puzzled by all the talk of cable, satellites, cassettes, disks, optical fibers and teletexts, signs of current and eventual dramatic changes in the distribution of information and entertainment have become unmistakable. A recent convention in Dallas of the National Cable Television Association attracted 9,000 enthusiasts of assorted vested interests, up 50 percent from the 6,000 who attended last year's gathering in Las Vegas. Cable is moving toward the 20 percent ''penetration'' level of television homes in this country. Giant corporations such as Time Inc., which owns both Manhattan Cable TV and pay-cable's Home Box Office, are getting heavily into the already profitable act. The commercial networks are banned from owning cable companies, but CBS has announced that it will begin producing programs, or ''software,'' for cable systems.

It's hard to say whether reports from the New Hebrides, those South Pacific islands that will gain independence from Britain and France next month, portend big trouble or a bad movie. Maybe both. So here are answers to the questions everybody should be asking about Vemarana. What is Vemarana? A would-be breakaway nation on the island of Espiritu Santo in the northern New Hebrides. Since when? A few days ago. How? Several hundred warriors with bows and arrows, led by 50 men with shotguns, locked up the local constabulary. Who is the new president? A former bulldozer operator named Jimmy Stevens, a.k.a. Chief President Moses.

To the Editor: In a letter you published on May 8, Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr. of Wisconsin attacked a bill pending before the House which would protect third parties - with reasonable exceptions - from unannounced police searches for evidence in criminal investigations.

I BELIEVE that programs like the Gold Medal Games, to be played at Madison Square Garden on June 22 and on other dates at four other sites around the country, are an exercise in futility and contrary to some degree to the principle of the boycott of the 1980 Olympic Games by this country. I think it is a great honor to be selected for a United States Olympic team, but it should end there. We should not have alternative games, tournaments, tours with the Olympic athletes or exhibitions such as the Gold Medal Games, which match the men's Olympic team against teams of National Basketball Association players.

Chris Evert Lloyd today won the French open tennis championship for the fourth time, defeating Virginia Ruzici much more easily here than she did last month in Perugia, Italy, where the two played three sets in the Italian open final. In defeating Miss Ruzici, 6-0 6-3, today, Mrs. Lloyd won $43,000 and increased her career earnings to more than $2.8 million. To reach the final, Mrs. Lloyd endured difficult matches with Bettina Bunge and Hana Mandlikova, a couple of unseeded teen-agers who extended her to three sets.

NCE again Jimmie Lee Allen was in the large courtoom on the 10th floor of the County Courthouse last week - this time to be sentenced for the murders of four Bedford Hills residents 13 months ago. But this time he was more than a defendant on trial, more than a convicted murderer. This time he was acting as a lawyer. He was polite, articulate and self-assured in arguing before acting Justice Duncan S. McNab of the State Supreme Court that his guilty verdict be set aside.

Re the recent article ''Cross Sound-Bridge Gets a Boost in Albany'': While it is true that constructing the bridge will have its effects, calling it an ''environmental nightmare,'' in the words of a Bayville village trustee, seems an appeal to mass hysteria. Indeed, is it not environmentally unsound to waste billions of gallons of gasoline annually by forcing travelers to Westchester County, upstate New York or most of the New England states, for that matter, to drive an extra 45 minutes through the Bronx, with its already overly congested arteries? Similarly ironic was Mayor Stapleton's comment that the Legislature (by proposing the idea for the bridge) ''is listening to pressure groups and not the people.'' One must remember that a group of North Shore residents exerted so much pressure themselves in 1973 that they forced Nelson Rockefeller, the original advocate for the bridge, to completely reverse his position on this issue. Incidentally, that is why the Seaford-Oyster Bay Expressway ends abruptly a few hundred yards north of Jericho Turnpike.

WERE some ambitious emblematist to invent a set of symbols for New Jersey, he would have to include a toll booth as one of them. The state signifies a host of different things to different people, but among the most celebrated facts about it is that it has one of the oldest and most traveled turnpikes in the country and that it and New York are landlords of the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels. Turnpikes and tunnels mean toll booths. George Segal, one of New Jersey's most celebrated artists, undoubtedly had this in mind when he was commissioned by the Newark Museum, one of state's most celebrated museums, to create a sculpture.

Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who has remained neutral in the Democratic Presidential race, said yesterday that he would not be a delegate to this summer's Democratic National Convention because he did not want to displace someone who has ''worked hard for their Presidential choice the last six to eight months.'' But he added that he hoped to ''have a real impact on platform policy,'' particularly in regard to his two pet issues, energy security and economic growth.

The marriage of Joan Mary McManus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Ambrose McManus of Eliot, Me., to Robert Neill Ulick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Ulick of Rockville Centre, L.I., took place yesterday afternoon in Kittery, Me. The Rev. Harry Lapin performed the ceremony in St. Raphael's Roman Catholic Church.

To the Editor:$ v.hile I do not wish to defend or praise the advertising industry, I cannot help but object to the smug, condescending tone with which Benjamin DeMott characterizes it in his review of Michael Arlen's ''Thirty Seconds'' (May 4). Singularly absent from Mr. Arlen's fine book is the self-righteous, preening tone that runs through Mr. De-Mott's review. Mr. DeMott admits that as a ''schoolteacher'' he doesn't have ''a wide acquaintance among advertising folk,'' but that his glancing impression convinces him that this ''breed'' cannot ''speak, write or reason'' at a complex level. And yet, he claims, ''these people'' consider themselves ''important thinkers.''

TOMS RIVER AMANAGEMENT program that would expand the state's jurisdiction over coastal areas and set the course of waterfront development on a statewide basis will be discussed at public hearings here and at three other sites this week. Opposition is expected from builders, who say that some of the proposals are too restrictive and that the state's Department of Environmental Protection would be exceeding its statutory authority.

THE attractive old building at the junction of Routes 46 and 57 in Hackettstown was originally called the Warren House 1840 in honor of Gen. Joseph Warren, who died at the Battle of Bunker Hill. It functioned as an inn for more than 130 years, gradually becoming seedier and more neglected. Then, two years ago, Louis Falzarano, an interior designer, and his cousin, Deborah Falzarano, bought and remodeled the place and renamed it David's Country Inn.

New York City's new police union president urged yesterday that a coalition of uniformed workers set a strike deadline to coincide with the beginning of the Democratic National Convention on Aug. 11. ''In collective bargaining,'' said Philip Caruso, the new president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, ''the side of the table that wields the most potent threat emerges victoriously. I think the threat we could pose against the convention would make the Mayor and everybody else deal with us in more realistic economic terms.''

Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: On The Hudson June 12 - A cool cruise to view the shores of New York Harbor starts at 7:30 tonight aboard the yacht Cabaret for believers in the Asthmatic Children's Foundation of New York. Cocktails will precede a filet mignon dinner and dancing. The idea is to get away from it all, as is the idea behind the cure for the New York City youngsters aged 5 to 13 whose cure for their asthma is to get them to Ossining, N.Y., for 33 acres of fresh air in the foundation's 36-bed residential treatment center. Just getting the children away from their environment works better than the drugs they took before going for the country cure, from which they return home after several months. The return home after 11:30 from tonight's cruise is by chartered bus to points along the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Some passengers will bring back raffle prizes that include a pair of round-trip plane tickets to Paris, a week for two at Safety Harbor Spa in Florida, and an oil portrait to be done of the ticketholder or of the person he or she chooses. Tickets: $150 each, or $250 a pair from 988-1074.

The marriage of Amy Brauer to Coleman W. Hoyt Jr., son of Mr. Hoyt of Waccabuc, N.Y., and Woodstock, Vt., and Mrs. Louis V. Farrar of Katonah, N.Y., took place in Westport, Conn., yesterday. Judge Robert Satter of the Superior Court of Connecticut performed the ceremony at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Earle W. Brauer, parents of the bride. Lisa Brauer attended her sister as maid of honor and Andrew E. Hoyt was his brother's best man. The bride, assistant curator in the department of ancient art at the Fogg Museum of Harvard University, was graduated from Beloit College and received an M.A. degree from George Washington University. Her father is vice president for medical affairs at the Revlon Research Center in New York and associate professor of clinical dermatology at the New York University School of Medicine. Her mother is librarian of the Hunter College Elementary School.

ENERGY: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Algiers tomorrow, and when OPEC meets Americans can usually brace for higher oil prices. This time, things are a little different. Oil consumption has slowed in the sluggish economies of Western nations. OPEC estimates that world oil inventories have reached 5.3 billion barrels and Saudi Arabia is warning that such a surplus could threaten prices. Some OPEC prices now range $10 a barrel over Saudi Arabia's $28, and the Saudis want OPEC to get back to a united front by reunifying prices. The Saudis may try to close the gap by raising their price moderately. In the past, however, this tactic has only caused other OPEC members to match the increase.

To the Editor: Your May 31 editorial, ''The $120 Billion, and Counting,'' appears to suffer from a strange contradiction between the strength of its premise and the pathetic weakness of its conclusions.f all that the industrial nations can do about ''the frightening effects of the increase in the world's debt to oil exporters'' is recycle petrodollars and develop a wait-and-see strategy on the predicament of the less-developed ones, God help us. Recycling petrodollars may postpone the day of reckoning, but its effects would soon become intolerable without a steady depreciation in their purchasing power.

Sutton of St. Louis Park, Minn., and the late Mr. Sutton. The Rev. Edwin Tuller, former minister of the American Church in Paris, performed the Protestant ceremony at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Charles Saxon, a cartoonist for The New Yorker for the last 25 years, has a problem: So many companies have been buying his drawings for their ads that last year he was able to do only 15 cartoons for the magazine, half his usual total.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass.--In the aftermath of the Miami riot, black leaders and liberal politicians have advanced with renewed vigor the thesis that race riots result from racial discrimination.

The county attorney's office has subpoenaed photos and negatives belonging to The Daily Texan and taken at a demonstration Jan. 31 against Iran's former Ambassador to the United Nations. Nineteen Iranians and Arabs charged with disrupting the speech by Fereydoun Hoveyda are to go on trial in county court-at-law on June 16.

Louise Lennig Henry and James Dennis Kamihachi were married yesterday by the Rev. James Shand at St. Mary Anne's Episcopal Church in North East, Md. The bride is a daughter of Howard G. Henry of North East, Md. Her husband is a son of Mrs. James N. Kamihachi of Seattle and the late Mr. Kamihachi. The bride was until recently supervisor of the complaints department at Blue Cross-Blue Shield in Washington. Her husband will become director of the office of policy and evaluation in the mayor's office in Seattle this month.

Most people have insurance to cover losses, by fire and theft, of personal property and valuable items that are kept at home or in an office. As an aid to identification and possible recovery in the event of a theft, and as a further safeguard that helps to discourage theft, authorities tell us to also inscribe a social security number or other identifying mark on television sets, cameras, and other articles that are easily carried away.

The recycling of older sections of cities into quaint shopping centers is an idea that is spreading across Canada. Among the cities having one or more streets restored to former glory are Halifax, Nova Scotia; Victoria and Vancouver, British Columbia; Hamilton, Toronto and Ottawa, Ontario, and Montreal and Quebec City, Quebec. In Halifax, the waterfront district, called Historic Properties, has been restored with a nautical theme. Once-dusty, seedy warehouses dating from about 1800 are now bright, neat buildings containing 40 shops, restaurants, pubs and offices with names like King's Wharf, Clipper Cay, Pieces of Eight and the Barnacle.

REGARDLESS of the planning and tender loving care given a flower garden, midsummer often brings forth a failure or two. A winterweakened perennial might fail to survive, or unfavorable weather may bring about the demise of a tender, newly planted annual. Such failures seem to draw attention in an otherwise floriferous or wellgroomed garden and demand remedial action. Luckily, nurseries have begun to provide solutions. Instead of handling perennials and annuals only in the spring or at best having only ill cared-for, half-starved leftovers into the summer, they now stock healthy, well-maintained plants throughout the season.

The Worldwide Church of God, under investigation by the California Attorney General's office, has decided to plead its case to the public. ''We will spend whatever it takes,'' said Stanley Rader, the principal adviser to the church's 87-year-old founder, Herbert W. Armstrong. In full-page advertisements appearing in California newspapers this week and scheduled for other papers around the country later this month, Mr. Armstrong, a radio and television evangelist, has begun an appeal for public support of his church's constitutional battle with the state of California. The first advertisements appeared in three California papers this week after the United States Supreme Court decided that it would not hear an appeal by the church.

Virginia Marie Carey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs J. Paul Carey Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Mark Joseph McBride, who graduated last month from the Georgetown University School of Medicine. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. McBride of Franklin Lakes, N.J,. The couple were married in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection, where witnesses were their friends, John Barry, a permanent Roman Catholic deacon, and Msgr. Edward J. Mitty, who offered the nuptial mass.

A great many pianists come to New York at this time of year to make their debuts. They are almost always well trained, and many of them are obviously talented. Some rise above their colleagues in how well and originally they communicate. One of the latter is Jeffrey Chappell, who appeared at Abraham Goodman House on Wednesday night. A native of St. Louis, a pupil of Leon Fleisher at the Peabody Conservatory and Eleanor Sokoloff at the Curtis Institute, he is now on the faculty of Peabody and Goucher College in Baltimore. Mr. Chappell ended his program with a reading of Ravel's ''Gaspard de la Nuit'' which was one of the finest this writer has heard. It was not the glittering kind of performance ordinarily expected and given. Instead, it was carefully observant of the composer's detailed markings. The result was, for one thing, more muted. Ravel calls for pianissimo playing a lot oftener than pianists are willing to give. Mr. Chappell did everything that was asked. ''Ondine,'' the first piece in ''Gaspard,'' was mistlike in its fine-grained soft pianism, making the big arpeggio eruptions more dramatic than ever. ''Scarbo,'' the final piece, had a genuine mysteriousness.

The opening of a major exhibition called ''Post-Impressionism'' at the National Gallery of Art (through Sept. 1) has inevitably focused attention on both the origin and the meaning of this term, which for 70 years has served as a staple in the critical and art historical discussion of modernist painting. Because the present exhibition - organized by a team of scholars led by Alan Bowness, the new director of the Tate Gallery in London - proposes such a sweeping revision of the very notion of what the term can be taken to signify, it is important that we understand what, until now, Post-Impressionism has been generally taken to be. It was in November 1910 that this term was first used in the title of an exhibition organized by Roger Fry at the Grafton Galleries in London. The exhibition was called ''Manet and the Post-Impressionists,'' and it gave the British public its first serious look at the decisive changes that had occurred in French avant-garde painting since Gauguin, Van Gogh, Cezanne and Seurat had initiated a revolt against the tenets of Impressionism in the 1880's. Manet had been included as a way of indicating that the revoltes of the 80's, although highly original in their own right, could be seen to be upholding a pictorial tradition that the more naturalistic, ''scientific'' aspects of Impressionism had departed from.

When Mary Anthony came to New York for the first time, a friend introduced her to an astrologer who prophesied that she would spend her life in theater and education. The prophecy came true. Miss Anthony directs the Mary Anthony Dance Theater, which opens Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Programs feature six premieres, three by Miss Anthony, three by Daniel Maloney and Ross Parkes, the company's co-directors. But since 1954 Miss Anthony has also had her own modern dance school, the Mary Anthony Dance Studio.

There's no end to the new ways to spread the word around. For ages there was just the quill. Then came the fountain pen, the pencil, the mechanical pencil, the ballpoint pen, the throwaway ballpoint pen, the marker pen, the felt-tip pen, the felt-tip that wrote like a ballpoint and the ballpoint that wrote like a felt-tip. And now? The throwaway erasable ballpoint pen. It comes from Scripto, the company that years ago introduced the see-through mechanical pencil. Scripto has been ailing in recent years, running up 11 straight quarters of losses until the latest, which was in the black. The company is hanging its future on what it calls the Erasable.

Joe Niekro hurled a five-hitter, and Joe Morgan slammed two run-scoring doubles tonight to lead the Houston Astros to a 3-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants. All the hits off Niekro (6-4) were singles, as the Giants were shut out for the second straight night. Niekro struck out five and walked none in his fifth complete game.

The United States maintained its commanding grip on the Curtis Cup women's amateur golf series today, defeating Britain and Ireland by a record-equaling 13-5 margin at the St. Pierre course. Although they were held to 3-3 in the final singles matches, the Americans romped to their biggest victory on British soil and statistically matched the previous highest successes at Hot Springs, Va., and San Francisco in 1966 and 1974, respectively.

THE STORY OF STORY MAGAZINE A Memoir by Martha Foley. Edited and With an Introduction and Afterword by Jay Neugeboren. 288 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $12.95. THE hero of the short story, in case you might want to know, is Edward J. O'Brien, and after him Martha Foley, who with her husband Whit Burnett had founded in the very early 1930's in Vienna a magazine called simply Story, which was brought home in 1933 to New York and somewhat financed, or as the popular word these days goes, funded by Random House - and one might add the comically unavoidable word these days in the mouths of everybody hustling something or somebody like the Government and its special executive or experts, hopefully, that is. Funded at no real loss to Bennett Cerf and his partner Donald S. Klopfer, the first dead and gone punning all the way, and the second either retired or at his desk in the combine which bought out Random House at an enormous if meaningless and indeed useless profit to absolutely nobody.

AFTER an unenthusiastic reception by Albany legislators and continued squabbling among Suffolk County officials, the latest plan to ease the financial burden of the Southwest Sewer District has been scrapped, but a 10-member panel will be established to study the problem. The plan - announced with much fanfare not long ago as a joint effort of Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and Representative Thomas J. Downey - called for creation of an independent authority to buy the sewer project from the county. Through an intricate refinancing plan backed by a Federal loan guarantee, the authority, it was hoped, might be able to save the county as much as $303 million over the next 30 years and avoid the politically unpalatable step of using $197 million in county sales tax revenues, beginning in 1982, to help pay for the $932 million project.

ALTHOUGH most homeowners think of window screens and screened-in porches or other enclosures only as a means of keeping out pesky flying and biting insects, many do not realize that there is a widely available type of fiberglass screen mesh that not only keeps these insects out, but also serves to keep a high percentage of the sun's heat out on hot summer days. This type of mesh, referred to in the industry as solar screening, has a specially designed heavy ribbed weave with coarse strands that cut considerably the amount of heat absorbed by the window when the sun shines on it. It is produced by a number of manufacturers under various brand names.

OVER the years, one of the more reliable dining spots in the Hamptons has been Gordon's in Amagansett. Despite changes in chefs and ownership, residents and visitors in this resort area continually turn to Gordon's for pleasant dining. There are evenings, especially during the off-season, when Gordon's looks more like a club than a restaurant. Gordon's is a small, dressy storefront with the bar in the rear. On weekends, careful scheduling of seatings means that waiting time is kept to a minimum unless one seeks a particular table. The showcase location in the front near the windows is the most desirable. Toward the rear one is likely to be distracted by the clatter and clutter at the service station.

Despite California's rejection of a ballot initiative last Tuesday to cut state income taxes in half, the antitax movement has had such a pervasive effect around the country that the growth of state and local revenues has been checked and the current trend is expected to continue. The National Governors Association reports in a new study that state and local revenues, as a proportion of the gross national product, peaked in 1977 and began to decline in 1978 as the tax revolt took hold.

THE Three Village School District Superintendent, Pierce Hoban, has decided that there is more than one uniform that is appropriate for a graduation ceremony. Instead of the traditional cap and gown, a Marine uniform may be worn by Pvt. Michael Marine, who requested to do so to honor Marine Cpl. Steven Crowley, who was killed defending the United States Embassy in Islamabad, Pakistan. ''I find it very difficult,'' Dr. Hoban said in his decision, ''to tell a member of our armed forces that his or her uniform is not appropriate for any occasion.''

Deborah Bradford Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Alexander Smith 2d of Fairfield, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Cole Stack, son of Paul Nicholas Stack of Charlotte, N.C., and the late Elizabeth Cole Stack. The Rev. Adam Lewis performed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. Mrs. Richard S. Ritzel Jr. was matron of honor for her sister. Richard M. Quintal served as best man. The bride, until recently an administrative assistant with the board secretariat of the Exxon Corporation in New York, was graduated from St. John's School in Houston and Pine Manor Junior College. She is a member of the Junior League of New York. Her father is president of Helicopter Associates Inc. in New Canaan, Conn.

THEY call many of them orphans: abandoned repositories of hazardous wastes whose genealogy has long been lost. Some, like Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., whose lineage happens to be well documented, are deteriorating. Their poisons are slowly seeping into the ecosystem, posing the same sort of serious but little-understood threat to life that Love Canal has already inflicted on the hapless residents nearby. Nationwide, these troublesome sites run at least into the hundreds. There may be thousands; new ones seem to crop up weekly. Last month, a school in Islip, L.I., built near a landfill site, was closed when authorities discovered traces of a cancer-causing gas in the basement cafeteria. A few days later, the residents of Aurora, Mo., learned that a herbicide waste had leaked from drums buried on a nearby farm and may have contaminated well water. Then a report from Youngstown, Pa., said industrial chemicals had leaked from barrels stored in a warehouse and were threatening the water supply. And late last week, the Environmental Protection Agency said conditions at more than 100 of the 645 sites it has surveyed so far pose a serious threat to some 600,000 people. The E.P.A. knows of a good many more that it has not yet been able to investigate.

Most non-Communist countries get by with one government, but Gen. Chon Too Hwan thinks South Korea needs two. Last week, ignoring Washington's objections, a brass-dominated shadow regime took charge. Fourteen Chon-picked subcommittees to second-guess civilian ministries will report to the strongman and a 30-member ''standing committee'' including a dozen generals. Relinquishing the title, but not his power, General Chon resigned as chief of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency.

The future of the electric car lit up last week. Gulf and Western Industries unveiled a new zinc-chloride battery system that, spokesmen said, will power an electric car a record 150 miles at 55 miles an hour, without a recharge. Cost of the trip - the equivalent of 46 cents a gallon for gasoline, which now averages $1.25 a gallon. A pilot plant should produce a battery system a day by January; a full-scale production facility, 100 units a day by 1984. G&W's own electric car, carrying four passengers 200 miles on one charge, may be tested in nine months. Make That Cubist Sculptures For want of propitious appraisals, two Art Deco bas-relief sculptures of female figures atop New York's Bonwit Teller Building were lost - smashed by jackhammers last week. The building is being razed to make way for a $100 million 62-story apartment-office complex. The panels were destined for the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The hitch was the price: One appraiser valued the stoneworks at several hundred thousand dollars; others set their ''resale value'' at less than $9,000. With careful removal costing $32,000, the property's developer chose less gentle means.

THE ZERO-SUM SOCIETY Distribution and the Possibilities for Economic Change. By Lester C. Thurow. 230 pp. New York: Basic Books. $12.95. A NUMBER of recent magazine articles have called attention to the growing predominance of more conservative views among the leading economists of the younger generation. Lester Thurow, professor of economics and management at M.I.T., remains a notable exception to this trend. Widely re-garded as the most talented of the younger liberal economists, Mr. Thurow has also demonstrated considerable gifts at writing for a popular audience, as well as a willingness to address an impressive range of ethical, political and economic issues. All these qualities are in evidence in ''The Zero-Sum Society,'' a brief and lively analysis of some of the critical economic problems facing the United States in the decade ahead.

STAMFORD AT the second performance of the Hartman Theater Com pany's current production, ''The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui,'' which comes after the official close of its season, there were moments when the cast seemed to outnumber the 30 or so in the audience. However, at intermission there was talk in the lobby that the powers that be were considering extending the run for an extra week beyond the original closing date of June 15. This has now become fact. According to material provided by the management, Bertolt Brecht wrote the play in 1941 as ''an attempt to explain the rise of Hitler to the capitalist world by placing the action in a well-known milieu.''

LAST spring, a group of Westchester musicians decided to combine social and cultural aspirations by forming an orchestra of singles, and a year ago they made their debut as the Little Symphony. A concert tonight, then, is by way of an anniversary celebration. Anita Strauss, violinist and one of the orchestra's founders, discussed how things have changed in the year: ''For one thing, we've maintained most of the same players through this whole period, so we have been able to grow into a cohesive unit. In other words, even though we started out just looking for a fun way of meeting new friends through music - and it still is a more sociable experience for us than you'll find in most orchestras - we're a real ensemble now. It has been an exciting thing to watch the development as the musicians get more and more used to our conductor, Mati Lazar, and he gets to know exactly what he can expect from us. At this point, we all have high hopes of becoming a permanent fixture of the arts scene in the county.''

It was 200 years ago today that Joseph Murray was shot down, and in Middletown they're going to do something about it. The Poricy Park Nature Center is going to mark the event with a day of Colonial memories. Joseph Murray, you see, was a private in the First Regiment of the Monmouth Militia, and during the Revolutionary War he fell before the muskets of three Tories. There will be Colonial craft demonstrations, a display by the Brigade of the American Revolution (the volunteers who dress and drill in Continental Army fashion) and a tour of a farmhouse. The tour will be a fitting touch because, when Private Murray met his end, he was plowing a field behind his barn in what is now Poricy Park.

Following are excerpts from some commencement addresses this spring: The surface of the earth is ever increasingly becoming a fragile membrane, and the destruction of the James River is like an agonizing and perhaps irremediable rip which tears across the membrane, leaving its ugly infection to fester for untold decades. William Styron, author, at Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia. Good will and humility are two qualities that, as far as I know, have never really been seriously used in trying to make and keep the peace on this interdependent planet. Pauline Frederick, NBC correspondent, at Fairleigh Dickinson U. in Madison, N.J.

Officials of a sleepy South Pacific archipelago blamed outsiders last week for disturbances that threatened to spoil New Hebrides independence day on July 30. Backed by plantation workers armed with bows and arrows, 50 French-speaking islanders proclaimed a separatist provisional government on Espiritu Santo, largest of 74 islands in a chain with 100,000 people. Fearful that the English-speaking New Hebrides majority would break up their estates, they promised an international tax haven - protected, they hope, by the French Navy. Their chief minister, Jimmy Stevens, had lined up support in Paris, Los Angeles and Carson City, Nev.

THE bankers are restless. In the big, yellow ballroom with nine chandeliers and one potted plant, their morning has passed slowly, filled with "pre cipitous declines" and other "harsh market realities." They need a break.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, First Department, has halted the conversion of the Vermeer apartment house at 77 Seventh Avenue in Manhattan until the Appellate Division can hear arguments on the case Friday.

Like the Battle of Britain and other crises in the history of human civilization, the New York City transit strike brought to the surface a hidden reserve of human potential that usually ramains submerged.

The Federal Reserve is becoming everyone's whipping boy. If one listens to the Fed's critics, it seems that our central bank can never do anything right. THE Nassau Republican County Committee not only is the most prosperous county political or ganization in the state--and maybe the country--but also is helping the nearly bankrupt Republican State Committee stay afloat.

The Board of Estimate made an urban-renewal decision affecting the Lower East Side several weeks ago that would have been unthinkable at any time over the last 15 years. A majority rejected a plan to complete the Seward Park Extension project that had been approved by the local community board and by a prestigious Chinatown group.

In the modern world those who despair of reaching their goals by orthodox sensible means sometimes resort to a long shot: They do something absurd, or dramatic, or vio lent. This rerely serves to achieve the desired result, but rarely does not mean never.

VILA, New Hebrides, June 7 (Reuters) --The New Hebrides Government has formally asked Britain and France to send troops to put down a rebellion on the island of Espiritu Santo, Chief Minister Walter Lini said tonight.

WASHINGTON--"No man in this country is so high that he is above the law," the United States Supreme Court declared in 1882. For most of the century that followed, that noble pronouncement remained an empty promise for private citizens seeking legal redress from a government official who had violated their legal or constitutional rights.

THE Warnaco Outlet is a manufacturer's sale location with White Stag, Hathaway, Ro sanne, Puritan, Thane and Warner's own surplus merchandise along with that of some of Warner's signature licensees, among them Christian Dior and Ralph Lauren Chaps. Preinventory sales are held in spring and autumn.
LONDON, June 7 (Reuters)--Three exiled Palestinian leaders appealed to the European Economic Community today to press the United States and Israel to end the Israeli occupation of the West Bank.

EAGER to avoid the vacation ritual of putting her valuables in the safe deposit box, putting the dog in a kennel and notify ing the police and the mailman, Elizabeth Kimberly decided to seek a solution to the problem of leaving the house empty for a few weeks.
THERE will be diversions of every sort available within Westchester this summer, many of them offering amenities and activities special to the area.
