Top Democratic county leaders will very likely arrange the voting at Thursday's state committee meeting so that each of the three contenders for the Democratic nomination for United States Senate, Representative Eliza beth Holtzman, John V. Lindsay and Bess Myerson, gets at least 25 percent of the vote and thus automati cally qualifies for the Sept. 9 primary. Miss Myerson is favored to win a second ballot majority and thus become the official state committee designee. A week later, the Republicans will meet to designate their candidate, and aides of the incumbent, Jacob K. Javits, are tempted to try some arranging of their own. The Senator appears assured of a majority vote for himself while another Republican Senate hopeful, Alfonse M. D'Amato, the Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, L.I., seems assured of at least a 25 percent vote, largely because of his solid support in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. The two counties account for just under 20 percent of the vote alone. That leaves Bruce Caputo, a former United States Representatives from Westchester, with almost no organization support, even in his home county. It is generally believed that if Mr. Caputo were on the ballot, he and Mr. D'Amato would very likely split any anti-Javits vote. That is why downstate Republican county chairmen and Conservative Party leaders who are supporting Mr. D'Amato are pressuring Mr. Caputo to stay out of the race, while aides of Javits are tempted to give him a helping hand at the state committee meeting. It would require careful maneuvering, by which Mr. Javits would stop short of a majority on the first ballot, divert Javits votes to Mr. Caputo so that each of the three candidates would receive at least 25 percent to qualify for the ballot and then move for the majority on a second ballot and the state committee's designation. There is another option for Mr. Caputo. He could get on the ballot by collecting designating petitions. But he conceded that his principal paid political advisers - Roger Stone and Charles Black, both of whom played key roles in Ronald Reagan's drive for the Presidential nomination - had told him he would need $75,000 for a petition drive and at least 10 times that much for a credible primary campaign. Mr. Caputo said he was still considering, but he sounded as if he were leaning out of the race unless lightning struck at the state committee meeting. Mr. D'Amato will spend $100,000 on television commercials in the next 10 days to demonstrate to Republican state committeemen that he is a viable challenger of the Senator. Three commercials produced by Werner Steibel, producer of William F. Buckley's ''Firing Line'' television program, try to cast Mr. D'Amato as a real Republican and the liberal Senator Javits an ersatz Republican.

JoAnn Marie Heffernan and Richard Frederick Heisen of Bronxville, N.Y., were married yesterday in the Community Church of Pound Ridge, N. Y. The Rev. Richard Monkman, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony. The bride is the daughter of Jeanne Berger Heffernan of Silver Spring, Md., and the late Milton F. Heffernan. Mr. and Mrs. Carl Heisen of Pound Ridge are the parents of the bridegroom.

Gary Matthews belted a two-run homer, and Larvell Blanks hit a three-run double tonight to help the Atlanta Braves gain a 6-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Matthews hit his fifth home run of the season in the third inning off the Dodger starter, Dave Goltz, following a single by Chris Chambliss.

IN this most confusing of all Olympic years, with the United States' boycott and talk of alternatives and with the mixing of politics and sports, the bottom line for many of us who have been involved is the concern for the athlete. When the decision became final in April that the United States would not send a team to Moscow, it was also evident that no viable alternative program was on the horizon.

ALEASE arrangement by which the county would pay $48 million to rent a bus garage for 20 years has come under sharp attack as the transaction nears conclusion. Critics of the plan, most of them financial and real-estate specialists, are charging that the administration of County Executive Alfred B. DelBello is being overly generous in its proposed terms, to the point of providing a ''windfall'' for the group of private investors, the AGR Realty Company, who would build the garage. AGR is a partnership whose principal members are also the owners of Liberty Lines, the largest bus operation in the county. The bus garage, which would be Westchester's largest single capital project to date in the field of transportation, would be built in Yonkers at the site of the former Phelps Dodge Cable and Wire Company at 475 Saw Mill River Road, in an old industrial neighborhood.

BORN the year President John F. Kennedy was assassinated, they entered the first grade at the height of the demonstrations against the Vietnam war; junior high school when the oil crisis broke and high school during the surge of patriotism that accompanied the Bicentennial. Today they don cap and gown to become the first high school graduating class of the 1980's. What are they planning for the future? What are their career preferences? How do they feel about their country? About politics? About the climate of changing moral values? And what do they see as the legacy of their school careers?

Detroit's economic troubles may turn out to be a windfall for Atlanta's understaffed Police Department. Largely because of the worsening slump in the automobile industry, city officials here are predicting a budget deficit that could reach $140 million by next June. As a result, Detroit will lay off 700 of its 3,600 police officers by the year's end; 400 were let go last October. Many officers affected by last fall's layoff have taken temporary jobs outside police work in the hope that they will be called back. But as the economic picture grows worse, an increasing number feel that their best option is to leave town.

Two days after he had apparently sewn up the Democratic nomination for President last week, Jimmy Carter found himself in the position of a victor suing for peace with the vanquished. But after a 45-minute meeting at the White House, Senator Edward M. Kennedy remained unreconstructed, declaring his intent to carry his fight for the nomination to the Democratic national convention in August. The spectacle set party leaders to much wringing of hands. National Democratic chairman John C. White, referring to the party split that contributed to the defeat of the late Hubert H. Humphrey by Richard M. Nixon in 1968, warned: ''I think if we continue this division past the convention, we could do to Jimmy Carter what we did to Hubert Humphrey.''

Many plans aimed at making Times Square something more than a breeding ground for prostitutes, pornographers and drug pushers have been announced with great fanfare over the years, only to fade without making a dent in the sleaze. Barring a sudden change of heart by the Koch Administration, yet another such plan, perhaps the grandest ever, is likely to meet a similar fate. ''Effectively, we're out of business for now, at least until the city makes some decisions,'' said Donald H. Elliott recently. Mr. Elliott, former head of the City Planning Commission and president of The City at 42d Street, acknowledged the setback after members of his group met with Mayor Koch and learned that the city was withholding support. Last week, the Mayor cast further doubt on the plan when he announced that he favored competitive bidding, a time-consuming process that Mr. Elliott said would kill his efforts.

At a time when the American tourist industry is in a state of turmoil, keeping its fingers crossed while waiting to see what effect the twin evils of inflation and unemployment will have this summer, one segment of that industry is more than holding its own: That which caters to overseas visitors. This is expected to be the first year in which the number of overseas visitors to the United States exceeds United States citizen departures to overseas destinations. Estimates by the Commerce Department's U.S. Travel Service are that visits by foreigners will be up by 8 percent this year, to 21.6 million - more than 13 million from Mexico and Canada, and 8 million-plus from Europe, South America and Asia. Last year about a million Britons and a million Japanese visited the United States, and more are expected this year from both countries.

To the Sports Editor: I am writing in regard to the May 27 article about Eric Heiden in the Memorial Day bicycle race in Somerville, N.J. Part of the headline read ''Heiden Fails Again.'' You were right about the flat tire he had, but that was not his fault; at least he changed it and got back in the race. That is anything but failure. As he was trying to catch up with the other racers after the tire incident, he was far behind, but the crowd was cheering him on; they really wanted him to pull ahead.

THE FIRST BOOK OF EPPE An American Romance. By Roderick MacLeish. 354 pp. New York: Random House. $9.95. THE LOVE RUN By Jay Parini. 220 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown. $10.95. THE QUARTZSITE TRIP By William Hogan. 307 pp. New York: Atheneum. $10.95.

MIDDLETOWN BECAUSE of a continuing decline in mathematics skills among graduates of Connecticut high schools, businessmen say, many manufacturing jobs in the state are going unfilled, or are ultimately filled with workers who need extensive training. In what was billed as the first meeting of its kind, business leaders and mathematics teachers got together at Wesleyan University recently to address the problem of why Johnny and Jane can't add. Or subtract, or multiply, or divide.

ST. JAMES THE restoration and rehabilitation of the Mills Pond House for use as a community arts center is a striking example of the current efforts of preservationists to save old buildings by giving them new uses. An imposing Greek Revival structure on Route 25A in St. James, the house was built in 1838-40 for William Wickham Mills, a prominent Smithtown landowner and farmer. The house served as a Mills family residence until it was given to the Town of Smithtown in 1976 by three Mills descendants.

This letter is in regard to Vivien Raynor's review on Sunday, May 11, of the Connecticut and American Impressionism show (''A Full Portrait of American Impressionism''). As an art historian and author of several publications on American Impressionism, not the least of which centered upon the life and art of William Chadwick, I was amazed at Miss Raynor's estimation of the Chadwick painting, ''On the Porch,'' in the Lyme Historical Society collection.

On the cover of this month's Philadelphia Magazine, one of the most successfully irreverent of the country's city periodicals, there is a large color photograph of a smiling Mayor William J. Green, posed under studio lights in his dark gray mayoral suit, gold cuff links and boxing gloves, His left jab protrudes menacingly out from under a headline that says: ''Time to Get Tough - Bill Green Puts on the Gloves.'' But the Mayor's left eyelid is dropped in a ''don't-you-believeit'' Irish wink that says he is pulling his punch, at least this photographic one.

Judith Lynn Gilbert, daughter of Peter Gilbert of Buffalo and Shirley Gilbert of New York, was married yesterday to Neal Burton Rubin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Rubin of Holyoke, Mass. The ceremony was performed at the Tavern on the Green by Rabbi Barry Friedman. He was assisted by Cantor Jerrold Held. The bride and her husband are graduates of Brandeis University. She will be attending Columbia University's Graduate School of Social Work in the fall and Mr. Rubin is a candidate for a master's degree at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

SINCE last summer, Sunday afternoons have become a popular time for celebration and merriment at the Long Wharf Restaurant in Sag Harbor. Highly animated dancing and a near-bacchanal atmosphere often prevail. The catalyst for such abandon is a seven-man group spearheaded by the melodious steel drums and raspy vocals of Vivian Walsh, a resident of the tiny Caribbean island Dominica until he moved to the Island 16 years ago. When the unit - called the Merrymakers Steel Band - is playing, the harbor breezes are so resplendent with Caribbean sounds that any arriving boat crew might well imagine it had dropped anchor in the wrong port.

A lie detector test has ''absolutely eliminated'' any possibility that Martha C. Coleman was involved with the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader, her attorney said today. Charles F. Leonard told reporters that his client gave a satisfactory answer to every question asked of her in a two-hour polygraph test conducted yesterday morning by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

To welcome summer we have stamps for the flowers in full bloom, stamps for the many birds in the sky, and for the fish that abound in our waters. A lush, color-rich grouping of a garden bed of numerous flowers in summer bloom has made a timely appearance on a new commemorative from Canada. It is a 17-cent rectangular that does more than recognize the popularity of gardening in Canada, both the hobby of growing flowers and, increasingly, food gardening. It calls attention to Les Floralies Internationales de Montreal, an ornamental horticulture show described as the ''greatest floral exhibition ever staged in North America.'' The exhibition runs to Sept.1.

Ideally, there ought to be no reason why Jews cannot go up to a state-owned hilltop of untilled, stony land two or three miles from an Arab village and live there in peace. But it has turned out to be impossible. The barriers of religion, language, ethnicity and national identity are too strong, the suspicions too deep, the political conflict too tangled and intense. The rifts that run through all the ancient, bloody history of the Holy Land are as enduring as the stone. Still, about 20,000 Israeli Jews have tried to put down roots in Arab territories captured in the 1967 war. Their settlements, scattered across the Gaza Strip, the Golan Heights, the Jordan Valley and the rolling hills of the West Bank have raised tensions and created points of friction to which the most extreme combatants on both sides have been drawn, like moths to a flame. Last week, the dispute took a grave turn when the three Palestinian mayors most vehemently opposed to settlements became the targets, and in two cases, the victims, of bombs that investigators believe were planted by Jews.

Jim Watt of Scotland retained his World Boxing Council lightweight title today by outpointing Howard Davis of Glen Cove, L.I., in 15 rounds. It was the third successful defense for the 31-year-old champion, who built a commanding lead over the American in the early rounds before winning a unanimous verdict from the three judges.

I thoroughly enjoyed William Wilson's article on the latest incarnation of the horror story a la Stanley Kubrick and Stephen King (''Riding the Crest of the Horror Craze,'' May 11). Mr. Kubrick's perception of the essential ''optimism'' of ghost stories (after all, he said, they show that we don't die) was disquieting. It reminded me of what the late Alfred Hitchcock once said: ''If you could bring back the dead, what would you do with them?'' Horror upon horror, Mr. Kubrick, I fear we shall all soon see. RICK SCHULTZ, New Haven

While it may not exactly be the fastest-growing special-interest group around, the Long Island Dairy Goat Association is alive and well and planning a show today in Yaphank. Complete with milking demonstrations and goat-cart rides, the event will get under way at 10 A.M. at the Suffolk County Farm, Exit 66 on the Long Island Expressway, and it won't cost visitors a cent to see what's new in goatdom. STRAWBERRY FARE

HARTFORD THIS city will shortly be the richer by an important new building on its west side - the Hartford Seminary Foundation, designed by Richard Meier. Pending its completion, Mr. Meier is on view as both architect and artist in the Matrix Gallery of the Wadsworth Atheneum. His show, which continues through next Sunday, was organized by Jane Dillenberger, a guest curator, and features a model and seven drawings for the seminary, all on view for the first time. It also includes the models and drawings for Mr. Meier's Bronx Developmental Center in New York (1976) and the Atheneum in New Harmony (1979), the Indiana town that became famous in the early 19th century as a Utopian community. Last but not least, there is a group of nine collages dating from 1960 to 1978.

Maj. Gen. Thomas Hearn, retired, the chief of staff to Gen. Joseph W. Stilwell in Asia in World War II, died Wednesday. He was 89 years old. General Hearn graduated from West Point in 1915 and was a member of the Army's Mexican Punitive Expedition in 1915-17. In World War I he served in France. From March 1942 to October 1944 he was General Stilwell's top aide in the China-Burma-India Theater of Operations.

Deborah Lynne Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick MacGregor Campbell Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Lockhart Garwood Jr., son of Justice Garwood of the Texas Supreme Court and Mrs. Garwood of Austin. The Rev. Dr. Bradford Hastings of Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich performed the ceremony at the Campbell home. Louise S. Sams was maid of honor. Lewis N. Little Jr. was best man. The bride was graduated form Princeton University, where she was a member of Cap and Gown. Her father is president of Campbell Associates, a New York sports marketing concern. The bride is a granddaughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick MacGregor Campbell of Lewes, Del., and Mr. and Mrs. Allen Sharpe Mullin of Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Campbell is retired president of the Delaware River and Bay Pilots Association. Mr. Mullin, also retired, was head of production of the Link Belt Company in Philadelphia.

Many people think innocently of classical music as a realm of timeless masterpieces, immune to the ripples of fashion that make popular music so fickle. But fashions flourish in classical music, too - not so obviously but perhaps even more insidiously. Take the case of Karl Richter, who will be conducting a Bach and Handel program at Avery Fisher Hall this Friday, as part of the Basically Bach Festival. Mr. Richter has an honored name among Baroque enthusiasts for his many fine concert tours and recordings. His concert Friday is almost sure to be direct and honest in a manner that will give most members of the audience a taste of ''timelessness.'' But it is possible to see in Mr. Richter's career the rise and fall of a whole style of Baroque performance, one that seemed revolutionary 25 years ago and seems old-fashioned today. Mr. Richter is fully aware of that drama, and bitter about it.

Once again, that perennial budget battle - guns vs. butter - has broken out. But this year there's a difference. Not only is broad economic territory being fought over, the combatants are more than usually conscious of another campaign, the Presidential. Finally, there is a growing sense that the victor's spoils are diminishing. The conflict was dramatically highlighted a little more than a week ago when President Carter announced he would oppose Congress' first attempt at delineating Government spending for the 1981 fiscal year because it gave too much to the military at the expense of social programs. But fiscal priorities have overtly and covertly dominated the Congressional budget process for more than a year, as economic stringency and military needs clashed. The issue seems as unlikely to vanish. All three Presidential candidates are firmly committed to limiting Government spending.

THE United States Open, the nation's No. 1 golf tournament, returns this Thursday to the Baltusrol Golf Club, one of the oldest and most luxurious clubs in the world. Legend and tradition are revered there, and wealth is the passkey. Baltusrol's sprawling Tudor clubhouse sits, staid and stately, atop a commanding bluff. Its interior of chandeliers, dark beams and paneling, thick rugs and wide, creaking staircases evokes the milieu of an earlier, courtlier era.
A 27-year-old woman was stabbed to death in her bed in a Queens hospital yesterday by an intruder who escaped through an emergency exit.
END OF THE ROAD--If you driveto Fairbanks, you will find the directions are easy: Get on the highway, head northwest and stop only when you come to the end of the road.

"It's--well--gorgeous," said Barry Ingham, a Salt Lake City insurance executive, searching for the right superlative to describe Lake Powell in southern Utah. He and his family were casting off their 43-foot houseboat to spend a week cruising the sandstone cliff-edged waterways that break off the vast lake.

I should like to offer some thoughts on problems that have been troubling me and discuss the way they appear to me here in Gorky, a city closed to foreigners, in the depths of the Soviet Union, where I now live under vigilant surveillance by the K.G.B.

The recycling of older sections of cities into quaint shopping centers is an idea that is spreading across Canada. Among the cities having one or more streets restored to former glory are Halifax, Nova Scotia; Victoria and Vancouver, British Columbia; Hamilton, Toronto and Ottawa, Ontario, and Montreal and Quebec City, Quebec.

SPRINGFIELD THE United States Open, the na tion's No. 1 golf tournament, returns this Thursday to the Baltusrol Golf Club, one of the oldest and most luxurious clubs in the world. Legend and tradition are revered there, and wealth is the passkey.
A LEASE arrangement by which the county would pay $48 million to rent a bus garage for 20 years has come under sharp attack as the transaction nears conclusion.

WASHINGTON--Once again, that perennial budget battle--guns vs. butter--has broken out. But this year, there is a difference in how the lines have been drawn. New limits on economic resources and the strains of another campaign, the Presidential, have complicated and muddied the field.

A citizens' group that last year predicted worsening conditions on the Conrail commuter lines issued a follow-up report yesterday, saying quality of service had indeed been declining "precipitously." It concluded, as it had last year, that only a massive infusion of funds for maintenance could prevent further deterioration.
When Mary Anthony came to New York for the first time, a friend introduced her to an astrologer who prophesied that she would spend her life in theater and education. The prophecy came true.

A prominent architect who 50 years ago designed the huge Art Deco grillwork over the main entrance of the Bonwit Teller Building, now under demolition on Fifth Avenue, expressed astonishment yesterday that a real estate developer had lost track of the elaborate solid nickel ornament.

The Western Electric Company agreed today to pay $8.5 million to settle two class-action job discrimination cases covering all 4,150 female employees at its 11 offices and factories in New Jersey. In addition, the company consented to implement a four-year affirmative-action plan that will open to women higher-paying jobs in managerial, craft and a variety of other categories at two production plants that employ 2,200 women in a work force of 5,900. Those plants are in Kearny and Clark.

T20The big hit of the Spoleto Festival in Charleston has been the one-act ''Monsieur Choufleuri'' at the Dock Theater. One could see, during this jewel-like production, why Offenbach was called ''the Mozart of the Champs-Elysees.'' The score is witty, wonderfully melodious, and it also has a hilarious parody of Italian opera. If Offenbach was no Daumier, he was at least a Cruikshank, with an infallible but affectionate eye toward the absurdities of man and, even, music. Take that Italian parody. As Chrysodule Babylas explains to M. Choufleuri, who has to impersonate the great baritone Antonio Tamburini, it is not necessary to know the music. All that an Italian baritone has to do is sing ''bim-bum'' while pounding on his stomach. Baritones and basses do not have to do anything else. And so Choufleuri does, and carries it off brilliantly. If ''Monsieur Choufleuri'' has been universally loved, the Conrad Susa ''Transformations'' has given some listeners trouble, and at several performances a mini-exodus has been reported. But that is par for any intellectual stage piece. Yet ''Transformations'' has had musicians at Spoleto U.S.A. doing some serious thinking about the piece. Some like it, some have reservations, but all seem to agree that Mr. Susa has written a theater piece that cannot be easily dismissed.

Andrea Jaeger, a 15-year-old schoolgirl from the United States, won the women's final of the Beckenham tournament today by defeating Jo Durie, 19, of Britain, 6-4, 6-1. The victory was worth $2,320 to Miss Jaeger. In the men's singles final, Onny Parun of New Zealand defeated Sandy Mayer of the United States, 6-4, 4-6, 9-7. Mayer, 28, is attempting a comeback after a nine-month layoff caused by hand, chest and foot injuries.

Immediately after the game, the Mets' general manager, Frank Cashen, announced that the team had aquired Claudell Washington, a 25-year-old outfielder, from the Chicago White Sox in a straight trade for Jesse Anderson, a 20-year-old right-hander who had been pitching for the Mets' farm team at Lynchburg, Va., in the Class A Carolina League. Washington, a six-year veteran who batted .289 in 31 games this season with Chicago, had a career average of .280 before this year. His best season was 1975, when he hit .308 and stole 40 bases in 148 games for the Oakland A's.

The day may be drawing to a close when travel agents perform most of their services at no charge to their clients. A conviction appears to be growing among agencies that they can no longer survive on commissions alone. Many agents complain that the 8 to 11 percent commission that they receive for selling a plane ticket is not fair compensation for the amount of time they must spend on keeping up with constantly changing air fares, placing reservations and making sure that clients get the best deal possible. The question of charging the customer has been a long-simmering issue in the trade, but it comes to a boil again now mainly under the pressure created by today's confusing air-fare structure.

Lisa Tencza, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Tencza of Wayne N.J., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Randall Collins of Lansdale, Pa., son of Mr. and Mrs. Randall Collins of Hamden, Conn. The Rev. John Carnevale performed the ceremony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Pompton Lakes, N.J. The couple are graduates of Bucknell University.

To the Editor: Thank you for your June 1 news article on the danger and frequency of assaults on women runners (''Female Runner Staying Out of Harm's Way''). As a woman who feels the absolute need for solitude in nature, whether in the country or a city park, whether running, walking or sitting still, I am always glad to see some public recognition of what is for a woman a constant fear and an intermittent danger or harrassment. ut I was very angry to read the statement of Sharon Barbano that ''women often cause their own problems ... if they wear tight, seethrough clothes.''

When it comes to adventure, solo sailors are in a class by themselves. Those who started yesterday in the 3,000-mile Observer singlehanded trans-Atlantic race from Plymouth, England, to Newport, R.I., embarked on what is considered one of the more rugged sporting events. To sail alone on a small boat across the ocean is to face the constantly changing seas and winds, and to thrive on it requires a certain spirit.

Bill Almon singled with one out in the 13th inning today to score Tony Bernazard from third base and give the Montreal Expos a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Ken Macha started the rally hitting a single off Jim Otten, a Cardinal reliever. Bernazard, running for Macha, moved to second on Jerry White's single and went to third on a sacrifice bunt by Tommy Hutton, a pinch-hitter. Almon then delivered the winning hit.
DAYS AND NIGHTS OF A FRENCH HORN PLAYER By Murray Schisgal. 269 pp. Boston: Little, Brown and Co. $10.95. MAN, WOMAN AND CHILD By Erich Segal. 244 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95.

It's - well - gorgeous,'' said Barry Ingham, a Salt Lake City insurance executive, searching for the right superlative to describe Lake Powell in southern Utah. He and his family were casting off their 43-foot houseboat to spend a week cruising the sandstone cliffedged waterways that break off the vast lake. For five years, the Inghams's weeklong cruises have been seamless experiences, unmarred by the usual maintenance headaches and timeconsuming preparations that preoccupy most boat owners. Unlike most vacationers, the Inghams are among 250,000 persons in this country who participate in an unusual real estate scheme that allows them to buy vacation property only for so long as they need it. When their vacation is over, they turn the management details over to someone else.

1. Find a seat facing the direction in which you're riding, otherwise you'll be ''pulled'' to work. 2. Rip off a piece of the lid on your coffee cup and have a sip without burning your lips. All cups must remain three-quarters lidded for the duration of the ride unless your clothes are coffee-proof. 3. Try to ignore the elbows of the person sitting on your right, even though your ribs are getting sore. 4. Move slightly every five minutes to startle the person on your left. He's asleep and his head is too heavy for your shoulder. 5. Meditate and reflect on the fact that five people in your car will be standing for 50 minutes while you're sitting. Feel grateful. 6. Try to fall asleep. 7. Change seats with the person sitting next to the window. He and the aisle seat occupant have just discovered they are next-door neighbors and want to talk.

PRESIDENT CARTER and his supporters may be holding out olive branches these days to the rival forces of Senator Edward M. Kennedy in the interest of unity at the Democratic National Convention in August, but there still seems to be an uneasy relationship between the two sides in the Connecticut delegation. The state's 54-member delegation, which is split with 29 delegates for Mr. Kennedy and 25 for Mr. Carter, averted what had threatened to become a nasty fight last month by giving Governor Grasso, the President's staunchest supporter in the state, the title of chairman of the convention delegation but giving Representative Anthony Toby Moffett, a Kennedy delegate, control over the delegation's microphone and telephones on the convention floor.

HADDAM DURING the almost three centuries that they have been owned by the Haddam Congregational Church, two late-17th-century tankards and three other pieces of early pewter have symbolized, as much as any tangible article can, the continuity of the church here. Over the generations they have at times been stored for safekeeping in the homes of ministers and members and in a file cabinet at the local library as well as in the four meeting houses built by successive congregations in the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries. For a few minutes in the early morning last Nov. 14, they were set down for safekeeping on the edge of the southbound lane of Route 9-A. They had been rescued from a fire that was to destroy the typical white woodframed New England church house.

Margaret Wallace Drake, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip M. Drake of Greenwich, Conn., and Marion, Mass., was married yesterday to Thomas A. Clark 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark of West Simsbury, Conn. The ceremony was performed in St. Michael the Archangel Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich by the Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor. Holly Drake was her sister's maid of honor and the bridegroom's father served as best man. The bride, a graduate of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., will continue her study of communicative disorders at the Graduate School of Northwestern University in September. Her father is a partner in the law firm of Cummings & Lockwood. The bride is a descendant of Gen. Lew Wallace, author of ''Ben Hur.''

UNSUCCESSFUL efforts by a committee of the Connecticut Bar Association to bring about an official investigation into allegations of misconduct by the Bridgeport police have revived questions about the adequacy of investigative procedures and about the state's unusual justice system, in which prosecutors and judges are part of the same branch of government. After being turned down by the two authorities who could initiate an inquiry - the Superior Court and the Chief State's Attorney - the lawyers' group is planning to ask the Legislature to examine the overall question of civilian complaints against the police.

Living in the middle of a desert, the people of Tucson have made their city a national leader in water conservation, with average daily use reduced 30 percent in the last four years. Gene Cronk, the city water director, said that Tucson residents had reduced average daily use from 200 gallons to 140 gallons per household since 1977. Most of the cut came from reducing outdoor watering of lawns in the summer.

The Community Church of Douglaston, Queens, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Dr. Deborah Jean Hoadley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philemon Hoadley of Douglas Manor, Queens, and Nantucket, Mass., to Dr. Philippe Cote, son of Mrs. Arsene Cote of Woonsocket, R.I., and the late Dr. Cote. The Rev. John Meyer performed the ceremony. The bride, a summa cum laude graduate of Smith College, class of '75, received an M.D. degree May 30 from the McGill University Medical School in Montreal. She will begin an internship June 20 at the Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H., where her husband is an orthopedic resident. The bride's father is a Citibank vice president.

In Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I., yesterday afternoon, Harriet Brown Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Forman Reed Jr. of New York and Portsmouth, R.I., became the bride of Lieut. Peter Webster Harris, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pratt Upham Harris Jr. of Brookville, L.I., and Holderness, N.H. The Rev. Lorne Coyle, rector of the church, and the Rev. Mario Costa, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Betty N. Landercasper and Gene Dyer Palmer, cousins of the bride, were matron and maid of honor. The bridesmaids were Diana Delano, Beatrice Kernan, Anne O'Malley, Deborah Potts and Margaret Thorne. Jonathan Miller Harris was best man for his twin.

In the celebrated grudge match between the filly and the colt and their feuding jockeys, Genuine Risk won a measure of female revenge yesterday at Belmont Park by finishing seven lengths in front of Codex. But there was no tangle, no bumping, no shouting, no accusing, no hearing and no victory for either of racing's recent rivals. Two weeks after their collision at the head of the homestretch in the Preakness, the two thoroughbreds confronted each other only twice during the return bout. They broke from the starting gate side by side from adjoining 27-inch stalls along the railing. And a mile down the track, they finally came head-to-head as all of 10 horses in the Belmont Stakes maneuvered for the stretch run toward first prize of $176,220.

For the last few years New Canaan has been turning Flag Day, a largely ignored holiday, into a Colonial Festival. It will be observed Saturday from 10 to 4 on the grounds of the New Canaan Historical Society's Hanford Silliman House at 13 Oenoke Ridge. Tents are to be set up to simulate a Revolutionary encampment, and the Fifth Connecticut Regiment will perform drills and other exercises throughout the day. Costumed hosts and hostesses will escort visitors through the historic house, where old-fashioned ale, cheese and homemade bread will be served.

A legislative study of the state employees' pension fund alleges that ''disastrous'' management of common stock investments by Comptroller Edward V. Regan and Mr. Regan's predecessor, Arthur Levitt, cost the fund about $1 billion in lost income over the last 20 years. The Assemblyman who led the study, Frank J. Barbaro, Democrat of Brooklyn, said this week that the stock investments ''yielded a meager 2.2 percent return'' annually. Emphasizing that the investments could have earned more in a bank savings account, Mr. Barbero said that he would introduce four bills that would significiantly reduce the control that the Comptroller has over pension investments in the stock market.

Elisabeth Susan Harding and Thomas Charles Hutton, New York lawyers, were married yesterday at the Princeton Club. The Rev. Dr. James A. Stackpole of the Reformed Dutch Church of Flatbush in Brooklyn performed the ceremony. The bride, who will retain her maiden name, is with Seward & Kissel and her husband is with Gould & Wilkie. Mrs. Hutton graduated from the Residential College of the University of Michigan and from the Cornell Law School, where she was a member of The Law Review and The International Law Journal. Her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John S. Harding reside in Ithaca, N.Y., where her father is professor of psychology at Cornell's College of Human Ecology and her mother, Margaret Harding, is director of the Tompkins County Office for the Aging.

From the moment the 200 delegates stepped off the plane here last week, it was clear that this was no ordinary banking convention. Praline-sweet hostesses, adorned in the hoop skirts of the antebellum South, met the arrivals at the airport and brought them to a reception room heavily guarded by a corps of uniformed New Orleans policemen. Not only did the policemen protect the guests from around the world, but they also served as their porters and chauffeurs. The delegates were driven in unmarked police cars to their hotels. ''The funny thing is,'' said one police driver, ''these guys are used to this kind of treatment.''
HALL By LINDA GREENHOUSE

Sandra Palmer, the 1975 United States Women's Open champion, who has not won on the pro tour since 1977, shot a spectacular round of four birdies and no bogeys in a strong wind today and jumped into a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the 26th annual Ladies' Professional Golf Association Championship. The 39-year-old Texan, at 5 feet 1 1/2 inches one of the shortest women and shortest hitters on the tour, landed on all greens in regulation despite gusts up to 25 miles an hour. The result was a four-under-par 68 that gave her a 54-hole total of five-under 211 and a one-shot advantage over Sally Little.

WEST BABYLON THOSE who would widen Little East Neck Road say that the project would increase safety and aid economic development. But a growing number of opponents say that the proposed reconstruction would, instead, create a speedy route for scavenger waste trucks on their way to the sewage plant and line several Republican pockets. The recommendation, which appears in the 1980-83 Suffolk County Program, suggests that the current two-lane, winding roadway, now under the jurisdiction of the Town of Babylon, be taken over by Suffolk County and enlarged to a four-lane thoroughfare with a turning lane from Colonial Springs Road south to Route 109.

Mike Higgins and Wayne Grannum finished one, two in both the 100- and 200-meter dashes today to lead Uniondale to the team championship in the Nassau County boys scholastic track championship at the United States Merchant Marine Academy. Higgins was timed in 10.7 seconds in the 100, while Grannum finished at 10.8. The winning time for Higgins in the 200 was 22.0, just ahead of Grannum's 22.1. Glen Wortmann of Carle Place was another double winner, taking the 1,600 meters in 4:16.8 and the 3,200 meters in 9:16.2. Ed Finucan of Great Neck South won the 400 meters in 48.3, beating Mike Cotton of Uniondale, who finished in 48.5. Trevor Wylie of Lawrence won the shot-put with a put of 55 feet 3 1/2 inches and was second in the discus with a throw of 148 feet 4 inches. James Eaddy of Great Neck South won the discus with a throw of 148-10.

GLEN COVE COME July, the Central Opera Theater in Peking will have a new conductor. Clara Burling Roesch, founder and conductor of the Long Island Singers Society, has been tapped by the Chinese Government to ''help pick up the pieces after the Cultural Revolution,'' she said, by working to put one of that country's few surviving Western opera companies -perhaps, the only one - back on its artistic feet. ''For 14, 15 years, the singers were out in the fields,'' Miss Roesch said at her 27-room Victorian house here, ''and while I can understand the concept of doing that, I can't condone the impact it had on the individual's talents, ruining so many artistic futures. It's my job to take the survivors of the Cultural Revolution who are probably in bad shape and try to reintroduce them to Western music.''
The United States Soccer Federation is making a strong bid to persuade F.I.F.A., soccer's world governing body, that this country is ready to host an international tournament.

Helen Pettit Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Neilson Hinckley of Menlo Park and Inverness, Calif., was married in New York yesterday to William Bedloe Beekman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Struthers Beekman of New York.

Marguerite Elaine Abell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Shepherdson Abell of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Thomas David Nurmi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aser Nurmi of Painesville, Ohio. Msgr. Joseph Corbett performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament in Washington.

The Daily News, a morning newspaper, is considering publishing an afternoon edition that would probably appear on newsstands between 3 and 5 P.M. in time to catch people going home from work. This would put The News in direct competition with The New York Post, an afternoon newspaper.
Time for the annual Creative Advertising Copy Awards-- the coveted "Bloopies," which are five and a half times cleaner than Annys or Grannys. Plus you don't have to go to the dinner.

MURRAY KORSON had a nice little deck off the dining room when he bought his house in Yorktown 12 years ago. Today, he has a rambling deck that encircles the pool and is linked with two staircases, and he is not sure he has reached the end.

Six years ago, at the opening of Las Hadas, the $35 million resort Antenor Patino, the Bolivian tin baron, built in Manzanillo, Mexico, a swarthy man with the stocky build of a saloon bouncer moved through the jet-set assemblage until he came face to face with a 49-year-old Italian count named Rudi Crespi.

Jane Hall Heist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Clark Heist of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Scott Howard Gamber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Gamber of Mechanicsburg, Pa. The Rev. David Philips performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Church of Old Greenwich.

When Ruth and Jack Alford purchased their threebedroom home in Coram, L.I., nine years ago for $33,000, they did not realize that their 7 percent mortgage contract stipulated that if the property were to be sold the balance of their loan would immediately be due.

EAST SETAUKET, L.I., June 7-- Rod Santomassimo scored three goals today and led Ward Melville to an 11-7 victory over Half Hollow Hills East for the Suffolk County scholastic lacrosse championship at the victor's field before a crowd of 2,000 today.

The typical Alekhine Defense buff is a tease who pretends he is giving up something of value when he allows White to advance quickly in the center. His real intention is to prove that the supply lines to White's overextended pawn or pawns are thin and easily cut.

WASHINGTON The opening of a major exhibition called "Post-Impressionism" at the National Gallery of Art (through Sept. 1) has inevitably focused attention on both the origin and the meaning of this term, which for 70 years has served as a staple in the critical and art historical discussion of modernist painting.

AUSTIN, Tex., June 7 (AP)--The county attorney's office has subpoenaed photos and negatives belonging to The Daily Texan and taken at a demonstration Jan. 31 against Iran's former Ambassador to the United Nations.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 7 (Reuters)-- A United Nations special envoy said today that Turkish Cypriot leaders had rejected a United Nations initiative to resume talks on the divided Mediterranean island.
THE winners of this year's Nassau County Department of Con sumer Affairs consumer youth contest have shown that more than the three R's are part of the curriculums of most Long Island schools.

AFTER an unenthusiastic reception by Albany legislators and continued squabbling among Suffolk County officials, the latest plan to ease the financial burden of the Southwest Sewer District has been scrapped, but a 10-member panel will be established to study the problem.

WASHINGTON, June 7--President Carter directed the Justice Department today to move quickly to expel Cuban refugees who committed "serious crimes" in Cuba and to expel or prosecute those found to be responsible for the rioting last Sunday night at Fort Chaffee, Ark.
GUTTENBERG WHEN The Galaxy opened for occupancy some four years ago, it was touted as the "ultimate" in luxury living along the Palisades.

The Eden Roc. It's one of the landmarks of Miami Beach. But like other hotels there, the Eden Roc has fallen on hard times. Last week the Eden Roc was bought out of bankruptcy, and ambitious plans to renovate it are well under way.
Prospects have brightened that the Goldman Band, which has entertained New Yorkers for 62 years at free outdoor concerts, will receive the funds needed to perform again this summer.

"What Presidential election?" Charlotte Weaver, a 32-year-old San Francisco graduate student, asked after she cast her ballot Tuesday in the California primary election. "All I care about are 9, 10 and 11."

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 6--The lawsuit filed by the City Council read plainly enough: "To all taxpayers, property owners and residents of the City of Corpus Christi, Texas," its preamble said in part, "you are hereby notified that you and each of you have been named as a defendant ..."
TEL AVIV, June 7--Israeli soldiers crossed the Jordanian border today in pursuit of armed Arabs and killed two of them, according to a statement by military headquarters here.
The New York City Department of Health has released its annual summer list of public beaches that are approved and disapproved for swimming because of pollution.

THE United States Golf Association will stage its men's open championship this week at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Spring field, N.J., for a record sixth time but for only the third time on the club's Lower Course. Play will start on Thursday on this magnificent and deceptively strong 18 holes of golf, which was used for the 1954 and 1967 Opens.
Many people think innocently of classical music as a realm of timeless master pieces, immune to the ripples of fashion that make popular music so fickle.

In a commencement season with few heroes, graduates across the country are listening to orations--from scholars and businessmen, as well as the television newscasters and other personalities familiar over the last decade--that bemoan malaise in American life.
MONTREAL, June 7 (AP)--Bill Almon singled with one out in the 13th inning today to score Tony Bernazard from third base and give the Montreal Expos a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Peter O.A. Solbert of Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Alison Chapin Solbert, to Frederick Camp Paine, son of Ruth Eberhard Paine of Fallsington, Pa., and the late Arthur P. Paine.

WASHINGTON, June 6--A measure that would allow the public financing of a fast transportation system to Kennedy International Airport has advanced part of the way through Congress after some Representatives were assured that the money would not be used for other transportation projects in New York City.

I AM not quite sure what to make of Eddie Davis. But neither does Eddie himself, which leaves the hero of Murray Schisgal's novel even more in scrutable. Mr. Schisgal--author of the plays "Luv" and "The Tiger and the Typists"--has a way with comedy that can be described as freestyle. Gags, burlesques, caricatures and catastrophes are whipped together in a pastiche that both delights and palls.

THE effect of the nationwide recession on New Jersey has the state's economists worried about the possibility of a downturn rivaling the severity of the decline of seven years ago. But for the moment, the experts are hopeful that the results will not be as devastating as they were in 1973-75.

At 3 A.M. on Feb. 2, inmates at the New Mexico State Penitentiary and the guards they held hostage could hear a pleading voice from the basement of Cellblock 3. ''It wasn't me; I didn't do it,'' the man cried in Spanish. The voice was that of Archie Martinez, who was killed by the prisoners. He was probably the first to die in the riot that would claim the lives of 33 inmates by the time the 36-hour takeover ended at the maximum-security institution southeast of Santa Fe.

Darrell Griffith, Joe Barry Carroll and Kevin McHale probably will be the first three players selected in Tuesday's National Basketball Association college draft. The biggest question is the order in which they will be taken. The Boston Celtics, if they do not trade the first selection, will decide which of the trio will have the prestige of being first in the draft.

Mike Birch of Canada was leading the fleet in a trimaran two hours after the start today of the singlehanded trans-Atlantic race from Plymouth to Newport, R.I., but the 3-1 favorite did not make it to the starting line. The favorite in the race that is expected to take at least 18 days was Kriter VII, a 56-foot trimaran sailed by Tom Grossman of the United States. As she left historic Millbay Dock with the fleet this morning, Kriter collided with another yacht and suffered bow damage.

I was just about to give up when I saw the tiny yellow specks. Gold! I had really found gold! I struggled to understand the meaning of my find. Gold had been selling at more than $500 an ounce in London, and in a matter of hours markets from Hong Kong to New York should be reporting higher prices still. At these levels, my gold should be worth who knows what. As reason returned, it became apparent that my rise in net worth could be measured in pennies. Nevertheless, I still felt exhilarated. Taking some more sand and gravel, I started another panning. I was acting out this lifetime fantasy in Dahlonega, Ga., a friendly mountain community 70 miles northeast of Atlanta. As a correspondent for the trade publication American Metals Market, I had a professional interest in precious metals and my visit to Dahlonega (pronounced dah-LON-ega) was long overdue because it was here, in the foothills of the Blue Ridge, that the first real gold rush in United States history took place - two decades earlier than the California Gold Rush. I was not alone. The gold fever that has infected the American public has brought many visitors to Dahlonega.

I am writing to correct errors in Fred Ferretti's article about me and my book (Author of 'Winners' Calls County a Loser, May 11). First, let me say that Mr. Ferretti's interview was on the telephone. It was too bad that he was too busy to come to my home in person, which might have given him a more accurate view of me. It would also have given him a chance to see my home, which seems to have been a source of great and envious concern to him, even though he never saw it. From the headline on, the inaccuracies of the article are damaging and in my opinion journalistically irresponsible. I never said or implied I found Westchester a loser. I merely stated that here, as in all suburban communities, there is a small reactionary pocket I loathe. In my book, I was dissecting a small group, as does John Updike when he characterizes his pocket of suburbia as ''one stop past Mount Kisco.''

The Environmental Protection Agency has labeled inorganic arsenic a hazardous air pollutant and has announced that it is drafting regulations to control industrial emissions of the substance. The agency said yesterday that recent health studies had shown a strong link between arsenic and skin and lung cancer in humans. Inorganic arsenic joins a list of hazardous air pollutants that includes asbestos, beryllium, mercury, vinyl chloride, benzene and radioactive materials.

The World Coal Study offered some cheering news about energy last month: coal is now so much cheaper than oil that nations could easily spend large sums to clean it up and still come out ahead. If there is no catch in the calculation, most of the problems of coal - including air and water pollution, mine safety, black-lung disease and the scarring of the land - could be controlled. But there may be one problem that would not yield to money or technology. Burning coal generates large amounts of carbon dioxide and a commitment to coal could last far beyond the age of oil. In time, the release of too much carbon dioxide might cause a catastrophic change in the global climate. Is that the catch in coal? The carbon dioxide danger is not science fiction; it is a plausible possibility. Carbon dioxide levels in the atmosphere have been rising steadily, due primarily to increasing use of fossil fuels and secondarily to the destruction of forests whose dead trees also release carbons. If the use of fossil fuels grew by only 2 percent a year, the amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere might double in 70 years. That might raise global temperatures by an average of 3 degrees and even more at the poles. Weather patterns could be radically altered, causing agricultural belts to shift in unpredictable ways. A disintegrating polar ice cap could raise ocean levels by 20 feet and inundate many cities.

IN the paddock they cheered Genuine Risk and booed Angel Cordero and Codex, the pair that had done her wrong. As they walked into the starting gate, the filly was cheered and the colt booed. Two and a half minutes later, 58,090 immortal souls at Belmont Park fell silent, mouths agape. A 53-to-1 shot called Temperence Hill - a winner of the Arkansas Derby, no less, who was named for a Methodist church - had swept home in the 112th Belmont Stakes for a mutuel payoff of $108.80 for $2. John E. Anthony, an Arkansas lumberman, put up $20,000 to make Temperence Hill a supplementary starter and collected a purse of $176,220. If he had bet $20,000 in Las Vegas he would have made a million.

THE effect of the nationwide recession on New Jersey has the state's economists worried about the possibility of a downturn rivaling the severity of the decline of seven years ago. But for the moment, the experts are hopeful that the results will not be as devastating as they were in 1973-75. Dr. Joseph Seneca, who is on the staff of the state's Economic Policy Council, said he felt that ''the recession will approach the dimensions'' of the last one and ''will be similar, but not quite as severe.''

BRIDGEPORT CLOWNS and calliopes and bareback riders hardly seem to suggest affinity with images of towering trees, green grass and cool water rippling against a sandy shore. The vivid imagination fired by daring aspiration that could create ''The Greatest Show on Earth'' somehow does not seem to have much in common with the esthetics of simple nature. Yet, P.T. Barnum, the entrepreneur of all time who fascinated the world with Jumbo and Jenny Lind and Tom Thumb, who captivated young and old with his colossal traveling tent circus (it used to require 500 men and horses to tour the country), who cheerfully peddled ballyhoo and humbug (Of critics of one of his famous buncombes, ''The Fejee Mermaid,'' he said: ''Some persons always will take things literally, and make no allowance for mermaids.''), was the force, perhaps greater than any other, that transformed the Bridgeport of more than a century ago into ''Park City.''

GUTTENBERG WHEN The Galaxy opened for occupancy some four years ago, it was touted as the ''ultimate'' in luxury living along the Palisades. It boasted a fully equipped health spa, it would soon have a busy, toney, shopping mall complete with a 500-seat movie theater and the rents were more in line with Manhattan's East Side than anything that had been built previously in this quiet Hudson County town. But something didn't work. Although rental apartments just across the river were becoming exceptionally scarce and the market's taste for condominium ownership in North Jersey became a growing hunger, rentals at the then new luxury complex languished.
An abrupt tightening of Soviet emigration procedures has resulted in a decline in the number of Jews leaving for the West, according to Arye Dulzin, chairman of the World Zionist Organization.

MacGuigan of Greenville, Del., to Tweed Roosevelt took place at the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Katharine W. Tweed of Vineyard Haven, Mass., and Archibald B. Roosevelt Jr. of Washington and a great-grandson of President Theodore Roosevelt. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the River Club. Zoller.

The Justice Department said today that Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti had asked the Treasury Department to begin an investigation into the trip to Iran by Ramsey Clark and nine other Americans to determine whether they violated the law by defying President Carter's ban on such travel. Mr. Civiletti said in a statement that the results of the investigation would be reviewed by the criminal and civil divisions of the Justice Department.

Ramsey Clark and five other Americans who participated in the Iranian-sponsored conference on alleged American intervention in Iran met today with the Iranian militants who have held Americans captive for 31 weeks, sources close to the American delegation said. There were no details of the meeting between the American delegation and the militants, who seized the United States Embassy on Nov. 4 and are holding 53 Americans hostage. Revolutionary guards cordoned off the Hilton Hotel where Mr. Clark and the other Americans are staying and refused to admit reporters. In addition, members of the delegation kept away from foreign reporters and refused to discuss the meeting.

Police officers and agents of an animal protection society raided a garage in the Southview section of the Bronx early yesterday and confiscated 62 animals that they said were apparently being held for sacrifice by a religious cult. Three weeks ago, in the first major successful raid on secret cults practicing animal sacrifice, the police and agents of the American Society for the Protection of Animals interrupted a rite in the Bronx involving the slaughter of animals and issued summonses against a sect leader.

Mayor Koch, conscious that some colleagues feared that he would steal the show at the opening of the United States Conference of Mayors meeting here, said he was enlisting today as ''a soldier, and not a general,'' in the effort to press for more Federal aid for cities. Mr. Koch, who has emerged as the dominant spokesman among mayors on urban issues, said that cities of the nation were in a ''very deep recession that could be called a depression'' and that in such situations the Federal Government had a habit of acting three years too late.

The Federal Reserve is becoming everyone's whipping boy. If one listens to the Fed's critics, it seems that our central bank can never do anything right. There are those who claim that the Fed is largely responsible for our miserable inflation record - some extremists say the Fed is exclusively to blame. Part of this group also criticizes the Fed for having waited too long to tighten credit and that its steps last October were ineffectual. And then there are those who contend that those measures were sufficient to dampen the inflationary pressures and that the stringent credit controls and other restrictions imposed in mid-March represented overkill and will contribute to an excessively deep recession. And now, there are some who maintain that the Fed is easing too quickly. This melange of views reflects the woeful lack of understanding of our monetary processes and the difficult choices facing our central bank. To hold the Fed largely responsible for the inflationary spiral is about as credible as the accusations made at the Salem witch trials. The Fed's critics oversimplify what is an exceedingly complex set of relationships. The Fed, it is true, can abet inflation through following misguided policies; but in no way can the brunt of the blame be laid at its doorstep. There are many nonmonetary factors influencing price movements that seem to be virtually immune to the pressures of monetary policy. Also, when expectations and commodity speculation, such as in silver, are seriously affecting the behavior of prices, only drastic action appears to be able to counter such forces.

Larry Nelson, playing before a gallery that included family and friends, excelled on the back nine with a 31 today and took a two-stroke lead in the third round of the $300,000 Atlanta Golf Classic. ''It would mean a lot for me to win here,'' Nelson said after finishing with a four-under-par 68. His total after 54 holes was 203, 10 under par on the Atlanta Country Club course. First prize in the event is $54,000.

FOR some reason, restaurants make peculiarly clear the tendency of things to fall. There is a powerful field of gravity in the economics of the enterprise, dragging restaurants down - toward inattention and making do, toward what one of our county restaurateurs calls ''abbreviations.'' Restaurants can be maintained aloft, but only in the same way tennis bubbles are, by incessant pumping - that is, by a strong-willed, hawk-eyed, perhaps slightly fanatic management. And it is remarkable that managements can hold restaurants to high standards year after year - sometimes. Usually they can't, which brings us to Emily Shaw's Inn. For 40 years a restaurant of good reputation with beautiful old dining rooms - broad-board and slate floors and somber pine walls - it is one of only a half-dozen local dining places likely to be known outside Westchester. It is like one of the county's great-aunts by now, and it seems almost disloyal to tell the truth about it out loud, which is that it is only a so-so restaurant where you have to eat warily to eat well.

SOUTHAMPTON IT is not unusual for artistic gifts to run in families. The Peales, Morans and Mounts of an earlier era and the Wyeths and Soyers of today are a few of the celebrated clans that have produced several talents. These families are increasingly being examined as groups, often in an effort to identify common characteristics or sources in their art. In the current exhibition of work by the Porter family at the Parrish Art Museum, we find that each of the four artist members - the brothers Fairfield and Elliot, Elliot's wife, Aline, and their son, Stephen - works in a different medium and style. Each has pursued his or her own course independently, evolving individualistic modes of expression. In fact, few people realize that the late Fairfield Porter, the painter of gestural landscapes and family portraits, is related to Elliot, the nature photographer; Aline, the creator of delicate floral studies and assemblages, and Stephen, the sculptor of monumental, roughly hewn wooden carvings.

An alumna of the Solebury School in New Hope, Pa., and the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, she received a master's degree in nursing education from Teachers College of Columbia University. Her mother, Sarah Leigh Minkel, is a Montessori teacher at the Maria Katzenbach School for the Deaf in West Trenton. Her father is a retired librarian.

The Oakland Raider issue drags on as the National Football League continues to await the court decisions surrounding the intention of the Al Davis to move his team to the Los Angeles Coliseum without the approval of the other owners. At the league meeting in Atlanta last week the owners proposed that the various lawsuits be lumped together to make one, and that a single court outside the state of California make the decision. League attorneys are pursuing that course of action.

A day by the lake. If most Americans had their way, they'd be spending this summer weekend at the shore. A great many Americans whose life and livelihood is tied up with books have chosen to spend it on the shore of Lake Michigan, where the city of Chicago is playing host to the 80th annual convention of the American Booksellers Association. Today, the second of the convention's four days, some 20,000 booksellers, publishers and authors from all over the country - indeed, from all over the world - will be taking their pick from a large, varied smorgasbord of activities. For them, this day starts at 7, when the light of foot show up at the Best Western Lake Shore Hotel to take part in the third annual two-mile A.B.A. Fun-Run, sponsored by Bantam Books. It will end up in tonight's wee hours, when the last of the guests attending a cocktail party and buffet supper at the Hyatt Regency manage to make it back to their hotel rooms.

In the modern world those who despair of reaching their goals by orthodox sensible means sometimes resort to a long shot: They do something absurd, or dramatic, or violent. This rarely serves to achieve the desired result, but rarely does not mean never. Such behavior is possible in a technical way at the card table if the game is rubber bridge or team play, not duplicate. If you can see that your game or slam is doomed, it can occasionally be right to do something totally ridiculous. You are prepared to fail by an extra trick or two in the interests of confusing the opposition, although you know that the chance of confusing them to good effect is negligible.
