WASHINGTON A PLAN by the Pinelands Planning Commission to preserve the million-acre Pine Barrens was made public last week, but was quickly criticized, even by some longtime supporters of preservation, as going too far. At a briefing by the panel, several New Jersey Congressmen warned Terrence Moore, executive director of the commission, and Franklin Parker, its chairman, that Congress might reject the plan and cut off needed Federal funds.

In the Basque region of northern Spain there are signs of a popular backlash against the violence of the separatist organization E.T.A., which has benefited from the acquiescence or tacit support of many Basques. At the same time the police have become more vigorous in their struggle against E.T.A., which has slain 38 people this year. The most dramatic rejection of E.T.A. came at the end of last month when Juan Alcorta, a San Sebastian industrialist, published an open letter to the terrorist organization refusing its demand for a ''revolutionary tax'' of $150,000. ''I am not a hero and I do not want to be one,'' he said in his letter, which was published in all Basque newspapers except the one that serves as an unofficial E.T.A. organ. ''E.T.A.: I will continue to live the way I live now. So you will not have to come looking for me, as you say in your letter. It will be easy to find me.''

Advocates of the equal rights amendment believe they have the 107 votes for ratification in the Illinois House, but two blacks may withdraw their support. Representative Douglas Huff Jr. said he would not vote for it in protest against what he called ''somewhat racist'' stands of Gov. James R. Thompson, a supporter of the amendment. Representative William Henry also said he was considering withholding his vote but did not explain why. A vote may come Wednesday.

From the moment Vernon E. Jordan Jr. was shot in the back with a .30-06 hunting rifle there have been two theories - that the attack on the president of the National Urban League in Fort Wayne, Ind., was related to his civil rights activities, or that it had something to do with the personal life of Martha C. Coleman, a white board member of the League's local chapter who was Mr. Jordan's companion that night. Ten days after the shooting, law enforcement officials have apparently eliminated the first and made no connection to the second. Unless a weapon is found or someone comes forward, they say, there is little prospect of solving the case. Nevertheless, the possibility that the attack was racially motivated has not been ruled out. The simple fact of a black in the company of a white woman had provoked at least one incident. According to Mrs. Coleman, insults were shouted at the car in which she was driving Mr. Jordan from her home back to his hotel at 2:00 A.M.

The International Ski Federation raised from 23 to 31 the number of the men's World Cup races next season and also decided new rules for the overall standing, which should benefit Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden. After a three-day meeting, the federation ruled that top placings of each skier in each specialty - downhill, giant slalom and special slalom -counting toward the individual overall standing would be five, instead of four as in the previous season.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court, First Department, has halted the conversion of the Vermeer apartment house at 77 Seventh Avenue in Manhattan until the Appellate Division can hear arguments on the case Friday. The court unanimously stayed a ruling last month by State Supreme Court Justice Beatrice Shainswit, who denied a request for a preliminary injunction to halt the conversion plan involving the 353-unit building.

A review of Governor Byrne's achievements awes me with its magnificent incompetency. He has managed to impose a state income tax and cut the general level of services. Despite the warnings of lawenforcement officials, he brought casino gambling to Atlantic City, and he is now astounded that crime and corruption have accompanied it. The range of malfeasance within Mr. Byrne's administration runs from the trivial: from state cars damaged in personal use by his family to allegations of involvement in Abscam.

THEY are strangers who have lived in the same building, one for 10 years, the other for 20. They have eaten all their meals together, and they have slept in the same room for three of those years. They share intimate moments to which even the closest of kin - husband, parent or child - are not privy. They know a great deal about each other's past, present and future, yet they do not speak or communicate directly with each other.

Cuba moves to overcome huge so- cial and economic problems 1 Britain plans biggest military ex- ercise in over a decade 3 Jewish emigration drops after Soviet tightens rules 3 U.S. says Soviet bolsters its troops in East Europe 4 Ancient Polish city falls victim to pollution 5 Basque terrorists in Spain meet- ing backlash at home 7 Clark group meets militants hold- ing American hostages 8 New Hebrides appeals for help to end revolt 12 Disunity hampers Afghans in the United States 13 Little girl's killing arouses civic unity in Toronto 14 President of Togo is accused of bankrupting nation 16

Extortion charges were dismissed this week against the former vice president of an international charity in a case that raised questions about how forcefully religious contributions can be sought. The former official, Daniel Wingerd, had been charged in April 1979 with trying to extort $34,000 from a businessman in Westport, Conn., where the charity, Save the Children, has its headquarters. Mr. Wingerd said in court papers that he told the businessman, Michael Waldman, that he should tithe $34,000 dollars. He said he never intended any personal gain or harm to Mr. Waldman. He did not make it clear where the money was to be donated, nor was there any documentation that Mr. Wingerd had inferred that the charity was to handle the money.

Uncle Sam, it is said, is the biggest coin dealer in the business - and the reason becomes apparent when one considers the latest numismatic news out of Washington. Within the next few weeks, U.S. Government agencies will launch two separate sales involving coins and medals struck by the Bureau of the Mint. One is the final phase of the ''Great Silver Sale'' of 19th century silver dollars; the other is the opening segment of the gold medallion sale authorized by Congress in 1978. Both loom as multimillion-dollar operations, which are likely to draw not only collectors, but also the public at large.

Brandeis University will establish a research institute to study the causes of the Holocaust, the 15-year period in which more than 6 million Jews were killed in Europe, university officials announced today. By autumn the 32-year-old Jewish-sponsored but nonsectarian university expects to have a dozen junior and senior researchers at work planning conferences, lectures and articles on the period and the approximately 150 years of events leading up to it.

The New York City Department of Correction has instituted new controls on absences, overtime and pension costs and plans further curbs, department officials said last week as the State Comptroller released a report criticizing the department's practices in previous years. According to First Deputy Commissioner Mark D. Corrigan, the department has eliminated pension abuses, tightened payroll procedures and instituted a program of using more non-uniformed employees in place of correction officers, all of which were recommended by Comptroller Edward V. Regan. The report, which was released Thursday, suggested that more than $6 million could be saved by the changes.

Patricia Elizabeth O'Hara, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. O'Hara of Brooklyn, was married there yesterday in St. Ephrem's Roman Catholic Church to Dr. Walter Joseph Rok, son of Mrs. John J. Rok of Pawtucket, R.I., and the Mr. Rok. Msgr. Martin Bannan, Msgr. James Wilders and the Rev. Daniel McNulty concelebrated the nuptial mass. The bride, who had been head nurse in pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology at the New York University Medical Center, was graduated cum laude from the Boston College School of Nursing and received a master's degree in nursing from N.Y.U. Her father is associate general auditor of the New York Life Insurance Company.

In St. Martin's-by-the Lake Episcopal Church in Wayzata, Minn., yesterday afternoon, Pamela Stewart Whiteman, daughter of Mrs. Douglas J. Dayton of Wayzata, and H. Clifton Whiteman of New York, became the bride of Graham M.W. Kilvert, son of Charles A. Kilvert Jr. of Providence, R.I., and Nantucket, Mass., and the late Mrs. Kilvert. The Rev. Edward Eilertsen performed the ceremony. Susan and Elizabeth Whiteman attended their sister, whose other attendant was Mrs. Frederick P. McClure, sister of the bridegroom. Mr. Kilvert 3d served as his brother's best man.

Hilario Zapata of Panama retained his World Boxing Council light-flyweight championship today with a unanimous 15-round decision over his South Korean challenger, Kim Chi-Bok. There were no knockdowns.

SOMERS THE three sons of Eleanor Ryan Prouty, the retired Reader's Digest senior editor who was found strangled in her home here two weeks ago, sat together last week and reflected on their mother's life and work. Throughout the ordeal, members of the family have tempered their grief by reading letters written by Mrs. Prouty and by gardening, which one family member said was ''one of Ellie's favorite pastimes.'' The serenity that prevailed at the home of Norman Prouty Jr. last Monday as he and his brothers, John R. and James L., talked in an interview about their mother was a tribute to the woman they described as being like the fields of daffodils she planted each spring, ''blossoming with life.''

The Twelve Apostles, who used to bless passers-by on Grodzka Street, no longer stand on their high stone plinths in front of the Church of SS. Peter and Paul. Without them the 16thcentury church seems denuded. The monumental statues are in a wire-mesh cage in the courtyard. Their visages have been eaten away by acid so that they look more like masked robbers than saints. They will remain there until the authorities figure out what to do with them.

Shelby Hamilton Hayden, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Hayden of Yarmouth, Me., was married at St. Mary's Episcopal Church in Falmouth Foreside, Me., yesterday to Henry Lackman Miller, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Edward O. Miller of Castine, Me. The bridegroom's father, former rector of St. George's Episcopal Church in New York, performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Andrew Young, former United States representative at the United Nations.

Bernadette D.S. Macmillan, a film research and production assistant of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles S. Macmillan of Seattle, was married yesterday afternoon to Brad Fiedel, a composer and film producer, of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Fiedel of Bayville, L.I. Judge Warren M. Doolittle of the Nassau County District Court in Mineola performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents. The bride is a former photographer's representative. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Her father is a vice president of the Boecon Corporation in Seattle, a subsidiary of the Boeing Company.

As a professional football quarterback in the 1960's, Jack Kemp had an affinity for throwing the ''long bomb'' - the dramatic game-breaking pass. As a professional politician, he has spent the last three years promoting its economic equivalent: a 30 percent reduction in personal income taxes over three years that he claims would solve virtually all the fundamental economic problems confronting the nation. The tax-cut bill, co-sponsored by Senator William V. Roth Jr., Republican of Delaware, was first scorned and has been repeatedly frustrated by Congressional and expert economic opposition. But at last, Jack Kemp, a California-born Republican Congressman from New York, may have found the ultimate teammate in fellow Californian Ronald Reagan. Mr. Reagan has adopted the so-called Kemp-Roth bill as a cornerstone of his economic policy and has made Mr. Kemp a key member of his Presidential campaign staff.

THE Warnaco Outlet is a manufacturer's sale location with White Stag, Hathaway, Rosanne, Puritan, Thane and Warner's own surplus merchandise along with that of some of Warner's signature licensees, among them Christian Dior and Ralph Lauren Chaps. Preinventory sales are held in spring and autumn. Merchandise is on sale for half the retail price, and exchanges are possible within 15 days with a sales slip. Red-tagged items are further marked down, but are not exchangeable. Booths are available to try clothes on. Checks are accepted, but not credit cards.

A MILD winter and good spring weather have resulted in an early strawberry season. Even on the South Fork, where crops generally ripen a week or more later than in the Riverhead area, picking is expected to begin by the second week in June. It is already time to bake the shortcakes, whip the cream and set out the jelly jars. After the strawberries, there will be more opportunity than ever before for vegetable picking at local farms. The list has almost doubled. Peas, a labor-intensive crop like strawberries, are now being cultivated for pick-your-own by many farmers. One farm, Fritz Lewin in Calverton, is also offering corn on a pick-your-own basis.

WOMEN and Arts, a group of artists associated with the Westchester chapter of the National Organization for Women, is having a show in the lobby of the County Courthouse in White Plains, until June 27. It is not a very good show, but it raises interesting questions about the social uses of art these days. Women and Arts is described by its director, Barbara Arum, as a NOW ''task force'' formed six years ago ''to enhance opportunities for women in the art world.'' It has 35 members and has been highly successful in getting them shown, arranging about five group exhibitions a year. Twenty-four members are represented in the White Plains exhibition, which is sponsored by the office of County Executive Alfred B. DelBello.

Israeli soldiers crossed the Jordanian border today in pursuit of armed Arabs and killed two of them, according to a statement by military headquarters here. The report described the dead as members of ''a terrorist squad'' that was trying to cross into Israel in the vicinity of Neot Hakikar, an isolated Jewish settlement in the desert area south of the Dead Sea.

A specter is haunting publishing. As the American Booksellers Association holds its annual meeting in Chicago this week, that specter is barely visible but it is there. The specter is technological: magic shadows on a screen, or words on a disk or a fiche instead of books in print. Looking ahead to the Orwellian year 1984 and beyond, some publishers envision electronic changes that will revolutionize the way books reach readers - and perhaps even the way they are written. (A few authors are typing novels on electronic screens; they then get paper printouts for revisions.) These new systems, using computer terminals for transmission and reception, or videocassettes, or microfiche readers, are loosely referred to as electronic publishing.

I WAS in Toronto, a city whose team used to win the Stanley Cup, when the Islanders finally won theirs. ''Where are they going to have the parade? In someone's backyard?'' a Torontonian asked. ''No, on the Long Island Rail Road,'' his friend replied. The ''where'' of the parade was a source of amusement to these two, who saw the Island as an inconvenient place to get to just to see a hockey game.

Not far from the three-and-a-half-acre tent housing the main exhibits of the Chelsea Flower Show late in May hung a simple hand-lettered sign. ''This,'' it said, referring to the spindly implement that stood beneath, ''is the best leaf rake in the world.'' Although few of the 250,000 people who jammed the famous show took much notice of this small triumph, it seemed to symbolize today's Britain: a beautiful and amenable country obsessed with analyzing its industrial decline while continuing to lavish its ingenuity and pride on things almost defiantly uneconomic.

The independent black churches of South Africa, representing 2.5 million people, have severed ties with the politically active South African Council of Churches. Bishop Isaac Mokoena, president of the South African Theological College of Independent Churches, said at a news conference that his group had dissociated itself ''totally from a policy of confrontation with the state'' that he said the Council of Churches was pursuing.

Last March, when interest rates were soaring, investing in fixedincome securities was easy. Double-digit yields were abundant and millions of investors were able to earn as much as 17 1/2 percent. Fixed-income investing now is no longer so simple or so profitable, because, unfortunately for investors, last winter's bonanza didn't last long.

The public debate over the strained relationship between the police and Britain's growing black population has been rekindled in recent weeks. A riot in a western seaport city, the violent death of a civil rights demonstrator in London and growing parliamentary pressure for the repeal of a vagrancy law that blacks see as a threat have focused attention on the country's race problem.

Edgar Merkel, president of Jacques Isler Corporation, a millinery and handicraft arts manufacturer in New York City, died Wednesday in the White Plains Hospital Medical Center after a brief illness. He was 56 years old.

Hope Terbell Busk, daughter of Joseph R. Busk of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Gladys Terbell Busk, was married yesterday in the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich to William Allen Reis, son of Susan Sicard Reis of Old Greenwich, Conn., and the late Henry William Reis Jr. The Rev. Walter D. Wagoner performed the ceremony.

This Week: The arrival of moist humid weather accentuates fungus problems. Follow regular spray schedules especially for roses, fruit trees. . . .Check lawn grass blades for chinch bugs; if present, water lawn first and use Sevin, Dursban or Diazinon. . . . In late afternoon, check around bases of trees for gypsy moth larvae; they crawl up into trees at night to feed and are vulnerable to spray attacks while on the ground. . . . Sow another row of corn and lima beans for late harvest. . . . Last call to move house plants under shelter outdoors for summer vacation.

WASHINGTON THE way Representative Richard L. Ottinger projects his plan, ''a minority of voters'' in small states such as New Hampshire and Iowa would no longer be able to set the trend of selecting Presidential nominees through early-bird primaries and caucuses. The Westchester Democrat, who is beginning to press anew for one of his most cherished ideas, would substitute five regional primaries, beginning in 1984, for what he calls the ''hodgepodge'' and ''mishmash'' of more than 30 primaries that run candidates ragged and empty their war chests in a matter of months.

Crimes of violence, sex, drugs and theft were committed by foreign diplomats in London last year but none were prosecuted because of diplomatic immunity, the Government reported this week. A total of 284 alleged offenses, including 3 sex crimes, 3 violent assaults, 2 drugs cases, 34 thefts, 6 arrests for drunkenness and many driving violations were committed by foreign diplomats or members of their families, the Minister of State in the Home Office, Leon Brittan, informed Parliament.

The New York State Legislature last week took a long step toward making divorce settlements more equitable, but, some women's groups contended, not long enough. Under the ''equitable distribution'' bill, which passed the Senate after six years of dead-end attempts, the Family Court judge would consider 10 guidelines in arriving at a property settlement. These include age and health of the parties, and their respective contributions to the marriage, duration of the marriage, and the housing needs of the spouse with custody of the children.

The Carter campaign, after six months of intense effort that has captured the Presidential nomination in all but the most formal terms, has a new set of problems, and only one of them is Ronald Reagan. The others are Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who insists he still may be nominated; Representative John B. Anderson, starting a potentially formidable independent campaign; the recession, more severe than Mr. Carter predicted, and the difficult task of patching together enough electoral votes to win in November.

You bet I voted for Tom Metzger,'' Bill Davis said angrily, almost shouting. Standing outside Mr. C.'s pool hall, where he's one of the regulars, Mr. Davis - a Vietnam veteran, commercial fisherman and native of this community that calls itself ''The Avocado Capital of the World'' - was giving his views on Tuesday's victory by the Grand Dragon of the California Ku Klux Klan, Mr. Metzger, who won the Democratic Party's nomination for Congress in the nation's most populous Congressional district. ''I think Metzger's got good ideas,'' Mr. Davis said. ''This country is all screwed up; Metzger's the only guy asking the right questions; inflation, taxes, unemployment - nobody can get a job and we're giving money to all those refugees who are taking jobs from Americans.''

Dr. Mary P.A. Sheaffer of Washington and Harry E. White Jr. of New York were married yesterday afternoon in the First Church of God in Shippensburg, Pa. The Rev. Francis Burch, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The bride, daughter of Annie M. Sheaffer of Shippensburg and the late Joseph M. Sheaffer, is a professor of English at the Commonwealth State College of Pennsylvania at Millersville. She was graduated from Commonwealth College at Shippensburg, and received M.A. degrees from Tulane University, the Graduate School of Fine Arts of Rosary College at Villa Schifanoia in Florence and New York University. She also received a Ph.D. from Tulane and studied in post-doctoral programs at the Universities of London and Edinburgh and at Sophia University in Tokyo.

The precise future of Picasso's ''Guernica'' has been one of the hottest topics in town ever since Spain got itself a stable democratic government. It is a subject on which most of us have put in our 50 cents' worth at one time or another. But this particular observer, fired and fueled by a week in Madrid, inclines to see the matter as settled. Barring an unexpected development, that is to say, ''Guernica'' will be in Madrid by the end of this year, and it will be housed in what is popularly spoken of as ''the little Prado'' - a small and elegant building that stands just a short walk uphill from the Prado itself. (For the moment it harbors a collection of Spanish 19thcentury paintings, few of which can be said to perfume the memory.) Quite apart from that, and subject to the collective approval of Picasso's heirs, the assembled studies and postscripts to ''Guernica'' which are now in the Modern Museum retrospective will also be in the ''little Prado,'' which will therefore have the nucleus of an irreplaceable Picasso Museum.

Police in Prince George's County, Maryland, have been investigating reports of an alleged bookmaking and sports betting operation in the front office of the Washington Bullets basketball team, The Washington Post reported in today's editions. The secret investigation started six months ago and focused on Bullets' marketing director, Chip Reed, and at least three employees of the National Basketball Association club, according to sources quoted by the newspaper. The unidentified sources reportedly said that Reed had used his office at Capital Centre in Landover, Md., and other locations to operate a betting operation. The alleged bookmaking setup was said to be part of a larger betting ring in the Washington metropolitan area.

As early as page 28 of WHIP HAND by Dick Francis (Harper & Row, $9.95), Sid Halley meets Trevor Deansgate. ''I shook the hand offered: snow-white cuffs, gold links, smooth pale skin, faintly moist; well-tended nails, onyx-and-gold signet ring on little finger.'' That should be enough to set off alarm bells in any Dick Francis reader. In Mr. Francis' world, gentlemen do not have moist skin, much less onyx-and-gold signet rings on their little finger. Mr. Trevor Deansgate is in all likelihood a bounder. And so (it is revealing no secrets) he does indeed turn out to be. Sid Halley is the ex-jockey who was the hero of ''Odds Against.'' He had lost a hand, can no longer race, and now is a private eye. He is the ideal British type, even though he comes from a low milieu. He is smart, stoical, always a gentleman who lives by The Code - and is recognized as such by his peers. He is closed-mouthed, never complains, is determined to see a matter through to its end. In ''Whip Hand'' he also finds himself faced with a moral crisis. All the world thinks he is self-reliant. But only he himself, like Horatio Hornblower, knows how weak he is down deep. Mr. Francis, like C.S. Forester and his Hornblower, is a master at playing this game. Their heroes are everything they are thought to be, even if the heroes reproach themselves for being human. We the readers know how near-perfect they are.

MILFORD MORE than 70 ardent young stargazers voiced appreciative commentary -from ''Wow!'' to ''Fantastic!'' - as they participated in the Fourth Annual High School Astronomy Convention at the Joseph A. Foran High School here recently. Built in 1973 on 20 rolling acres in the southeastern part of this city on the Sound, the school has baseball and football fields, tennis courts, two indoor gyms and a swimming pool. But Foran also boasts a main-floor planetarium and a rooftop astronomical observatory.

CAMDEN GAUGED by outward appearances, Abscam has had little effect on City Hall here. Mayor Angelo J. Errichetti, the first New Jersey public official to be indicted in the sweeping Federal investigation into political corruption, still works a 12-hour day, retains control of the city government and enthusiastically promotes his major long-term project: the economic revival of his blighted, poverty-stricken home town of Camden.

In Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I., yesterday afternoon Harriet Brown Reed, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Forman Reed Jr. of New York and Portsmouth, R.I., became the bride of Lieut. Peter Webster Harris, U.S.N., son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Pratt Upham Harris Jr. of Brookville ...

The Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan in December brought protests from Afghans in the United States, but the trait that kept their nation independent for so long, individualism, has kept them disunited.

ALBANY, June 5--As the smell of newmown hay fills the air in parts of upstate New York, indicating the start of a new farm year, figures were issued here this week showing that the state's dairy farms produced a record $1.28 billion worth of milk last year, up 16 percent from the year before.
The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society has established a public affairs department to plan and initiate short-and longterm programs. The century-old society, which is an international Jewish migration ...
THEY are strangers who have lived in the same building, one for 10 years, the other for 20. They have eaten all their meals together, and they have slept in the same room for three of those years.

Every once in awhile we suddenly step back and notice that an old-fashioned theatrical form, one we'd thought drained of energy if not safely dead and buried, is in fact simply waiting patiently in the wings, scenery intact, ready to be trundled out again in all its familiar furbelows. Not so much passe, let's say, as eternally patient. And, in some peculiar way, still useful.

AKRON, Ohio, June 7 (AP)--Summit County Sheriff Anthony Cardarelli pleaded guilty yesterday to dereliction of duty and agreed to resign within 30 days in return for the dismissal of four charges of theft in office.

When it comes to adventure, solo sailors are in a class by themselves. Those who started yesterday in the 3,000-mile Observer singlehanded trans-Atlantic race from Plymouth, England, to Newport, R.I., embarked on what is considered one of the more rugged sporting events.

She awoke from the dream (whine, whine, whine) and stared at the ceiling. Why did she always find herself staring at the ceiling? Men never had to stare at the ceiling, because they were always on top. It wasn't fair, she thought.

As early as page 28 of WHIP HAND by Dick Francis (Harper Row, $9.95), Sid Halley meets Trevor Deansgate. "I shook the hand offered: snow-white cuffs, gold links, smooth pale skin, faintly moist; well-tended nails, onyx-and-gold signet ring on little finger."

WASHINGTON, June 7 (AP)--The Environmental Protection Agency has labeled inorganic arsenic a hazardous air pollutant and has announced that it is drafting regulations to control industrial emissions of the substance.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 7 (Reuters)-- More than five million people in the northeast of Brazil are being severely affected by a three-month drought, an official said today. There have been reports that some in the region are arming themselves to raid town markets for food. The Government has allocated $700 million for dams and wells, the official said.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 7 (AP)-- Advocates of the equal rights amendment believe they have marshaled the 107 votes necessary for ratification in the Illinois House, but two black lawmakers have threatened to withdraw their support.

The tabletop proscenium, complete with curtain and follow-spots, looked real enough to house a troupe of Lilliputian actors and made the living room of David Mitchell's Upper West Side brownstone look a bit like Santa's workshop. Mr. Mitchell bent forward and carefully adjusted the wires on a tiny trapeze, threading his fingers through a maze of spider-size rigging suspended above a miniature stage. ''There it is,'' he said proudly, stepping back for a better look at his handiwork. ''That's pretty much the way 'Barnum' looks on Broadway.'' David Mitchell is the man whose artful imagination transformed the stage of the St. James Theater into the rainbow-hued circus world of Phineas T. Barnum, the fast-talking hero of the hit musical by Cy Coleman, Michael Stewart and Mark Bramble. Mr. Mitchell's exuberant scenic designs have won him high praise and may win him a Tony Award at tonight's presentation ceremonies at the Mark Hellinger. (''Barnum,'' in fact, has been nominated in 10 Tony categories, including one for its acrobatic star, Jim Dale, two for its director and choreographer, Joe Layton, and another for ''Best Musical.'')

NOW that Gordie Howe has decided not to play hockey anymore at age 52, nearly a decade after he thought he had decided that the first time, his monuments tower above the sport - 1,071 goals, including a record 801 in the National Hockey League; 1,518 assists; 2,421 games; six N.H.L. scoring titles; six most valuable player awards (a record five in the N.H.L., and one in the World Hockey Association in the season he turned 46). But when asked about his accomplishments, Gordie Howe did not speak of goals or games or awards. ''The one record I'm very proud of,'' he said, ''is the longevity record.'' Over a span of five decades, Gordie Howe played 32 seasons in a bruising, often brutal sport. And he had no soft seasons. He played all 80 games for the New England Whalers last season. Throughout his career, he averaged 68 games a season, despite a severe concussion that hospitalized him during the 1950 Stanley Cup playoffs, dislocated shoulders, torn rib cartilege, more than 300 facial stitches and other assorted ailments. But to put those 32 seasons in perspective, consider other longevity records.

A MAN indicted last year on a charge of helping Poles enter the United States illegally and obtain work and Social Security cards is likely to escape prosecution on the ground of mental incompetence, according to Federal prosecutors and psychiatric reports. The officials said the possible incompetence was demonstrated in part by his repeated assertions that he was working for the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency. The man is Alexander Gorski, 43 years old, the proprietor of a travel agency in Newington. He was indicted by a Federal grand jury in New Haven last August on charges of conspiracy, making false statements to Federal agents, harboring and shielding illegal aliens, inducing the illegal entry of aliens, and mail fraud. Prosecutors said he had fraudulently obtained 90 Social Security cards and sold them to aliens.

International An inquiry into Ramsey Clark's trip to Iran, along with nine other Americans, to attend an Iranian conference on United States Intervention in Iran, has been ordered by Attorney General Benjamin Civiletti. The Treasury Department was asked to determine whether the 10 had violated the law in their defiance of President Carter's ban on travel to Iran. (Page 1, Column 5.) Britain will import more goods this year than it will export for the first time, an indication of the economic decline of the leader of the Industrial Revolution. Britain's Industry Secretary, Sir Keith Joseph, said the country has ''destroyed the natural habitat'' of its entrepreneurs. (1:3-4.) Israeli soldiers killed two Arabs said to have been members of ''a terrorist squad'' attempting to enter Israel from Jordanian territory. The Israelis crossed the border in pursuit of the suspected infiltrators. The suspected attempt by the Arabs to cross the Jordanian border was unusual because it has usually been tranquil since since King Hussein's expulsion of Palestinian guerrillas in 1970. (15:1-5.) National Moves to expel Cuban refugees who committed ''serious crimes'' in Cuba were ordered by President Carter, who also told the Justice Department to expel or prosecute those refugees responsible for the rioting last Sunday night at Fort Chaffee, Ark. Jody Powell, the White House spokesman, emphasized that the ''undesirable'' refugees were a small minority - less than 1 percent of the more than 110,000 who have arrived since April 21. (1:6.) President Carter faces new problems after six months of intensive campaigning that has all but captured the Democratic Presidential nomination. Mr. Carter and his backers still have Senator Kennedy refusing to withdraw and prominent Democrats to refusing to count him out; they also faced the problems of contending with Representative John B. Anderson, the recession and the difficult task of patching together enough electoral votes that will mean victory. (1:1.) Ronald Reagan is optimistic about winning the Presidency after the ease with which he rolled through the Republican primaries, but he is untested for what his aides expect to be a bitterly fought campaign. The big test, Republican and Democratic strategists say, is whether Mr. Reagan can make the election a referendum on President Carter's performance, or whether his own capacity for Presidency will become the main issue. (1:2.) The antitax movement's success around the country has checked the growth of state and local revenues and the trend is expected to continue despite California's rejection of a ballot initiative last Tuesday to cut state income taxes in half. A study by the National Governors Association found that state and local revenues, as a proportion of the gross national product, peaked in 1977 and began to decline in 1978 as the tax revolt took hold. (39:1.) Metropolitan Six South Bronx teen-age felons made a weeklong trip into the wilderness to learn how to survive by cooperating rather than by being hostile to the people around them. The trip, to the woodlands of Ulster County, was organized by the Community Service Society at a cost of $9,000. (1:1-3.) Management of the state pension fund has been ''disastrous,'' a New York State Assemblyman, said. Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro, Brooklyn Democrat, who headed a legislative study of the state employees' pension fund, said that the management of common stock investments, which forms much of the fund's income, under Comptroller Edward V. Regan, and his predecessor, Arthur Levitt, had cost the fund about $1 billion in lost income in the last 20 years. (39:1.)

The Koch administration and the Federal Department of Health and Human Services are nearing agreement, officials say, on rescuing the city's Metropolitan Hospital Center with a $45 million three-year project to demonstrate new ways of delivering health care to East Harlem's poor. The agreement, however, was reported to hinge on the Carey administration's willingness to share the financial responsibility with the Federal department in saving Sydenham Hospital in West Harlem, the city's oldest and smallest municipal hospital. Mr. Koch wants the hospital closed. The project calls for the state to help finance Sydenham's conversion into an alcohol and drug abuse treatment center, a cost that has yet to be determined.

The Agriculture Department's Beltsville Research Center near Washington has declared war on the old adage ''there is no accounting for taste.'' Scientists are convinced there is; the only question is chemically, botanically, scientifically how. It is a research battle spurred by ever louder consumer complaints that today's mass-produced fruits and vegetables are often insipid, that the flavor of fattened beef sometimes resembles tallow, and that America's highly specialized agriculture industry is interested mainly in raising food for high yields, appearance and ease of transport and, according to Dr. James C. Boudreau, a sensory physiologist at Texas University in Houston, ''to hell with how it tastes.''

LIVING in a small, cheerless flat and working at a dreary job, the eager young novelist harbors intimations of glamour and success: He will write his Bildungsroman, perfect his art and become a respected artist. Such is the portrait of the writer as a young man that emerges in the latest novels of William Styron and Philip Roth. In ''Sophie's Choice,'' Stingo, a callow Southerner not unlike the young Styron, comes to New York, where he reads manuscripts for a publisher by day and dreams by night of becoming ''a writer with the same ardor and the soaring wings'' of Melville or Flaubert. In ''The Ghost Writer,'' Nathan Zuckerman, an aspiring author who resembles the young Roth in his desire to escape the banality of his middle-class youth, quits his job selling magazine subscriptions and sets out to visit the secluded home of an older writer, hoping to find in the Master a spiritual father for his own Dedalean quest.

BRANFORD VIETNAMESE cooking has been a long time making its way to Connecticut, but it has arrived at Chez Bach, which faces the village green here. Chez Bach combines two worlds in its title and on its premises, with samplings of both Vietnamese and French cuisine. It isn't as unlikely a combination as it may seem at first, considering the long time the French spent in Indochina. Actually, there are other echoes here as well, for Chez Bach occupies the premises - and seems not to have much changed the decor - of a former Italian restaurant. The gold-flecked wallpaper and black plastic booths and chairs have a familiar look.

WHAT ever happened to the lofty dreams of transforming New Jersey into a paradise for boaters? It is not as if many powerful realtors and developers have not tried. The files of local Planning Boards in municipalities such as Belmar, Brielle and Toms River - and in state government offices - are full of proposals that would have embellished the state's extensive coastline. What had been envisaged by some was New Jersey as a capital of bigtime yachting - another Newport, perhaps, or a Fort Lauderdale North - with 60-foot luxury yachts steaming across the bays and rivers, deep-water docks leading to haute cuisine restaurants and high-rise condominiums on the water's edge.

A MILD winter and good spring weather have resulted in an early strawberry season. Even on the South Fork, where crops generally ripen a week or more later than in the Riverhead area, ...
ENERGY: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meets in Algiers tomorrow, and when OPEC meets Americans can usually brace for higher oil prices. This time, things are a little different.

I BELIEVE that programs like the Gold Medal Games, to be played at Madison Square Garden on June 22 and on other dates at four other sites around the country, are an exercise in futility and contrary to some degree to the principle of the boycott of the 1980 Olympic Games by this country.

LONDON, June 5--Crusader 80, Britain's biggest military exercise in more than a decade, will take place in September to test contingency plans for national mobilization, preparations for defense of the country and reinforcement of ground and air units in West Germany.
An abrupt tightening of Soviet emigration procedures has resulted in a decline in the number of Jews leaving for the West, according to Arye Dulzin, chairman of the World Zionist Organization.

Police officers and agents of an animal protection society raided a garage in the Southview section of the Bronx early yesterday and confiscated 62 animals that they said were apparently being held for sacrifice by a religious cult.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 7 (AP)--A lie detector test has "absolutely eliminated" any possibility that Martha C. Coleman was involved with the shooting of Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader, her attorney said today.

THE scribbling was tiny and purposely deceptive, but when I deciphered the words on the inside cover of the beat-up six-year-old looseleaf notebook, I knew that "I stink at pitching" was a confession to cleanse the soul.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 7 (AP)--The president of the Minnesota Twins says Mike Marshall's differences with the front office had nothing to do with the club's decision to give the relief pitcher his outright release.
REGARDLESS of the planning and tender loving care given a flower garden, midsummer often brings forth a failure or two.

MASON, Ohio, June 7--Sandra Palmer, the 1975 United States Women's Open champion, who has not won on the pro tour since 1977, shot a spectacular round of four birdies and no bogeys in a strong wind today and jumped into a one-stroke lead after three rounds of the 26th annual Ladies' Professional Golf Association Championship.

WALTHAM, Mass., June 7--Brandeis University will establish a research institute to study the causes of the Holocaust, the 15-year period in which more than 6 million Jews were killed in Europe, university officials announced today.

MILAN, Italy, June 7 (UPI)--Bernard Hinault of France won the 63d Tour of Italy bicycle race today. The 22d and final stage--114 kilometers around a central Milan circuit--was won by Pierino Gavazza of Italy.

SEATTLE, June 7--Mayor Koch, conscious that some colleagues feared that he would steal the show at the opening of the United States Conference of Mayors meeting here, said he was enlisting today as "a soldier, and not a general," in the effort to press for more Federal aid for cities.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 7--Extortion charges were dismissed this week against the former vice president of an international charity in a case that raised questions about how forcefully religious contributions can be sought.

WESTCHESTER County last week opened an office for Vietnam veterans who were exposed to the herbi cide known as Agent Orange and who are now concerned about health problems that some have linked to the chemical defoliant.

MIDDLETOWN BECAUSE of a continuing decline in mathematics skills among graduates of Connecticut high schools, business men say, many manufacturing jobs in the state are going unfilled, or are ultimately filled with workers who need extensive training.

LONDON--Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain will be greeted with less than complete enthusiasm when she joins her fellow Common Market heads of Government for a two-day meeting in Venice this week. Nor is she expecting the warmest of welcomes from President Carter when she returns to Venice on June 22 to confer with Mr. Carter and leaders of West Germany, France, Italy, Japan and Canada.

Almost overlooked in last Tuesday's voting was the defeat of an anti-abortion ordinance in Toledo, Ohio. The result was interesting not only because Toledo is a fairly conservative community but because legislators everywhere have been guessing about public attitudes on abortion without many recent tests of sentiment. Toledo voters were asked to approve an ordinance that, in the name of protecting the health of women, would have required doctors to notify the parents of minors or husbands of married women seeking an abortion and also to show the women pictures of a fetus while describing the pain it might suffer.

Consecutive doubles by Gene Richards and Ozzie Smith highlighted a three-run San Diego seventh inning as the Padres scored a 6-1 victory tonight over the Cincinnati Reds. Gary Lucas (3-2), a rookie, pitched the first six innings for the Padres and gave up just one hit, a solo home run by Dan Driessen in the fifth. Rollie Fingers provided relief help for the Padres while Cincinnati's Mike LaCoss (4-5) took the loss.

The Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society has established a public affairs department to plan and initiate short- and long-term programs. The century-old society, which is an international Jewish migration agency, has appointed Richard Kellerman to head the new department. Mr. Kellerman has held a variety of public relations jobs and has been the director of news planning for the National Broadcasting Company and a United Nations correspondent for The Daily News.

A 27-year-old woman was stabbed to death in her bed in a Queens hospital yesterday by an intruder who escaped through an emergency exit. The patient, Carol Jurlando, who lived with her husband and four children at 90-11 97th Avenue in the Ozone Park section of Queens, was knifed repeatedly in the torso, arms and legs during the attack, which took place at about 3 A.M. in her semiprivate room at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills. Mrs. Jorlando died 10 minutes later, the police said.

Despite conditions that have weakened rental housing as a longterm business enterprise, a few builders are pressing forward in Manhattan with plans for new luxury apartment buildings. If these plans come to fruition as expected, the early 1980's will witness a continuation of the modest level of residential construction of the last few years. The projects allay fear that the production of rental housing is ''dead,'' however unenthusiastic the attitude of the producers toward long-term rental ownership.

MURRAY KORSON had a nice little deck off the dining room when he bought his house in Yorktown 12 years ago. Today, he has a rambling deck that encircles the pool and is linked with two staircases, and he is not sure he has reached the end. Mr. Korson is typical of deck owners who start small and end big, and he will be joined by hundreds of others in the next few months, as the zest for outdoor living combines with the determination to stay home and save gasoline.

Three persons were killed here early this morning in a house fire that investigators said was started by a smoldering cigarette in an overstuffed chair. Flames quickly spread through the old two-family frame house just after 2:30 A.M. Walter McKinley, 56 years old, and his wife, Eileen, 51, were apparently asphyxiated in their bedroom. Their 14-year-old son, John, was attempting to escape from the window of his secondfloor bedroom when the living room window below exploded and flames shot upward, burning him to death, according to the deputy fire chief, Ronald Damon.

By all the rules of supply and demand, the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Algiers tomorrow should be smooth sailing. With nearly a million barrels of excess oil searching for buyers, with recession dampening Western demand, with 5 billion barrels stored in Western reservoirs and tankers, it should follow that the price would stabilize or even drop below the record sums of $35 or $38 a barrel some producers are charging. Yet experts such as Walter Levy, the international oil consultant, refuse to make predictions. ''It is such a confused situation, a messy situation, that neither logic nor economic reasoning are important factors,'' he said.

At the edge of a tangled wilderness tract near this Ulster County village, about 100 miles north of New York City, a van rumbled to a stop the other day, and five teen-agers wearing brand new hiking boots got out. A sixth, a 16-year-old boy named David, remained in the van, clutching a large transistor radio and turning up the volume on the rock station. ''I ain't going nowhere without my music,'' David said. ''I'll sleep in the van.'' A counselor with the group suggested gently to David that if he stayed behind he would be all by himself. David looked out at the forest in front of the van and reconsidered. He got out, shouldered a pack - awkwardly at first because he had never done it before - and joined the others on the winding trail into the forest.

Frank J. Macchiarola, New York City's School Chancellor, said yesterday that a plan by the finance committee of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to end half-fare transportation for public school students ''cannot be tolerated.'' The panel had recommended Friday that the 180,000 schoolchildren who use the city's buses and subways pay full fare. ''This is one further indication of how kids stand in the priority of things,'' Mr. Macchiarola said. ''This will further add to the difficulties that our children will face in already inadequate provisions made for them next year.''

The marriage of Beth Marci Bond, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bond of Merrick, L.I., to Scott David Levy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Levy of the Bronx, took place yesterday in the Hewlett East Rockaway Jewish Center in East Rockaway, L.I. Rabbi Stanley Platek officiated. The bridegroom's father is County Clerk and Clerk of the Supreme Court of Bronx County.

The hotel chef in ''The Shining'' is supposed to have remarkable psychic powers, but the movie never explains the strangest of this man's idiosyncrasies: he can smell trouble from Miami to Colorado, but he doesn't detect a killer standing 10 feet away from him, armed with an ax and wearing a horrible grin. The movie's ghostly butler starts out with the name of Charles Grady, but he somehow becomes Delbert Grady before the story is finished. The caption on a closing photograph of Jack Nicholson utterly defies explanation. And the director, Stanley Kubrick, once again leaves his audiences asking a familiar question: How can anyone make a film so fastidiously beautiful and still leave so many loose ends? ''The Shining'' may be a horror film, but it very much fits the Kubrick mold. First and foremost, it is mesmerizingly lovely, so handsome you may be halfway out of the theater before those nagging questions arise. Yet, like ''A Clockwork Orange'' or ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' this is a movie that barely makes sense upon examination. Most of the small details seem meticulously chosen, but there's no evidence that corresponding care has been taken with the film's central concerns.

In St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Chatham, Mass., yesterday, Nancy Elise Gustafson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clifton Stromberg Gustafson of Chatham and Naples, Fla., was married to Charles Farren Ault, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Wilson Ault of Wayne, Me. The Rev. Carl G. Carlozzi performed the ceremony. The couple attended Ripon College. The bride also attended the Mary C. Wheeler School in Providence, R.I., and was graduated from Miss Hall's School in Pittsfield, Mass., and the University of Maine. Mrs. Ault is a a former volunteer teacher's assistant in the Freeport, Me., schools. Her father, who is retired, was corporate insurance manager of the Fram Corporation, manufacturer of filters in Providence. The bride's grandfather, the late James Edward Bugwood, had been a founder of the company and its financial vice president.

A measure that would allow the public financing of a fast transportation system to Kennedy International Airport has advanced part of the way through Congress after some Representatives were assured that the money would not be used for other transportation projects in New York City. One plan under consideration by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport, would call for express buses along an abandoned right of way of the Long Island Rail Road in Queens.

When the Shah's rule in Iran collapsed before revolutionary mobs last year, it became fashionable among liberals on the cocktail party circuit in Johannesburg to ask: if in Iran, why not in South Africa? If an entrenched autocratic regime commanding a near monopoly of force could be toppled by strikes and demonstrations, why could not the same happen to the Afrikaner regime? Some day it may. But in the foreseeable future, the balance between authority and protest is likely to favor the Afrikaners, and not simply because they, unlike the Shah, possess an army and police force they can rely upon, whatever the bloodshed entailed. Difficult as it is for the proselytes of black revolution, hard evidence suggests that an essential ingredient - a black population ready by the hundreds of thousands to confront the whites - exists at the moment only in the columns of Pravda and The People's Daily.

It's not every Harvard University student who can cite his own books in the footnotes of his term papers. But Harry Gersh, 67 years old, is no ordinary Harvard student. Four years ago Mr. Gersh, then a newly retired journalist and public relations specialist, set out to obtain the college degree that had eluded him when he came out of high school in the Depression.

Jane Vollmer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Vollmer of New York and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to John Thomas Izzo Jr., son of Mrs. Izzo of Saratoga Lake, N.Y., and the late Mr. Izzo. The ceremony was performed by Justice William L. Ford of the State Supreme Court in the Hall of Springs at Saratoga Spa. Mr. Vollmer father is senior partner of Vollmer Associates, a New York consulting engineering and architectural concern, designers of the Saratoga Performing Arts Center in the Saratoga Spa State Park. The bridegroom's previous marriage ended in divorce.

Helen Van Slyke, the best-selling romantic novelist who died last July after undergoing surgery, is represented on not one, but two, best-seller lists this week. The novel she completed only two weeks before her death, ''No Love Lost,'' is on the hardcover list, while her 1979 novel, ''A Necessary Woman,'' is on the mass-market paperback list. Mrs. Van Slyke, who became a novelist after she was 50 years old, gave up a career as a successful fashion and cosmetics executive to write the so-called ''women's books'' that have sold more than 6 million copies. Many of her characters were affluent, middle-aged women much like herself. Divorced, blond and glamorous, she lived on Park Avenue and had last worked as vice president of creative activities at Helena Rubinstein. She had been president of the House of Fragrance before that, and also had been promotion and advertising director for Henri Bendel, as well as beauty editor at Glamour magazine. She died six days short of her 60th birthday.

EAGER to avoid the vacation ritual of putting her valuables in the safe deposit box, putting the dog in a kennel and notifying the police and the mailman, Elizabeth Kimberly decided to seek a solution to the problem of leaving the house empty for a few weeks. The answer turned out to be a house sitter. Mrs. Kimberly now prefers to hire someone to stay in her pre-Revolutionary War farmhouse in Norwalk while she is away. ''I just find it much easier,'' she said. ''And I'd just as soon leave the dog at home where he is comfortable and in his own surroundings.''

Conran's Sale Annex, adjoining the store at Exit 16 off Route I-95 in New Rochelle, is open only on weekends and offers 20 to 50 percent discounts on buyer and floor samples and discontinued merchandise sent from the chain's five American stores. Anyone who telephones to ask to be listed, however, will be invited by mail to see special purchases of imported and domestic furnishings at the annex on weekdays and will be notified of the special storewide sales in July and January as well.
YORKTOWN HEIGHTS IN most other suburban split-level houses, the room half a flight down from the front door is a "family room." Not in Ellen Epstein's split-Level.

A 43-year-old fireman died in an arson fire in Harlem Friday, and a 19-year-old resident of the building who had been feuding with his landlord was charged yesterday with setting the fire and killing the fireman.

Why have so many high-minded European experiments in art failed to flourish in America? Is there something about this country that causes even the grandest and noblest European idea to founder or were the experiments ill-conceived from the start?

WASHINGTON, June 7--The Carter campaign, after six months of intense effort that has captured the Presidential nomination in all but the most formal terms, has a new set of problems, and only one of them is Ronald Reagan.

It's hard to say whether reports from the New Hebrides, those South Pacific islands that will gain independence from Britain and France next month, portend big trouble or a bad movie. Maybe both. So here are answers to the questions everybody should be asking about Vemarana.
REGARDLESS of the planning and tender loving care given a flower garden, midsummer often brings forth a failure or two.

Virginia Marie Carey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs J. Paul Carey Jr. of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Mark Joseph McBride, who graduated last month from the Georgetown University School of Medicine. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. McBride of Franklin Lakes, N.J.

LOS ANGELES, June 7--The Worldwide Church of God, under investigation by the California Attorney General's office, has decided to plead its case to the public. "We will spend whatever it takes," said Stanley Rader, the principal adviser to the church's 87-year-old founder, Herbert W. Armstrong.

MORRISTOWN A PANORAMA of fields and trees, the view from the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences may not compare for majesty with, say, the Palisades, as framed by the windows of the Hudson River Museum in Yorkers.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 6--As Vernon E. Jordan Jr. begins the slow process of recovery from the gunshot wound he suffered eight days ago, the National Urban League and its affiliates in 117 cities are turning their attention to the impact of the shooting and Mr. Jordan's absence on the league and the civil rights movement.

ALTHOUGH most homeowners think of window screens and screened-in porches or other enclosures only as a means of keeping out pesky flying and biting insects, many do not realize that there is a widely available type of fiberglass screen mesh that not only keeps these ...

TEHERAN, Iran, June 7 (UPI)-- Ramsey Clark and five other Americans who participated in the Iranian-sponsored conference on alleged American intervention in Iran met today with the Iranian militants who have held Americans captive for 31 weeks, sources close to the American delegation said.
FALLBROOK, Calif., June 6--"You bet I voted for Tom Metzger," Bill Davis said angrily, almost shouting.

Americans are more likely to change their membership in a church denomination for theological reasons now than they were in the past, statistics contained in the new edition of the Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches suggest.

Cevil Taylor is the most controversial jazz pianist of the last 20 years. Long a vanguard artist, he was, with Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane, one of the three major figures who gave impetus to the jazz avant garde of the 1960's.

NETCONG, N.J., June 7 (AP)--A chartered bus carrying a bowling group from Queens slammed into the rear of a tractor-trailer while climbing a hill on Interstate 80 this morning, injuring 34 persons, the police said.

OVER the years, one of the more reliable dining spots in the Hamptons has been Cordon's in Amagansett. Despite changes in chefs and ownership, residents and visitors in this resort area continually turn to Gordon's for pleasant dining. There are evenings, especially during the off-season, when Gordon's looks more like a club than a restaurant.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 7 (AP)-- Twelve American journalists have been awarded Nieman Fellowships for a year of study at Harvard University starting next fall.
PORT SAID, Egypt, June 7 (Reuters) --President Anwar el-Sadat said today that he was prepared to go to Saudi Arabia to discuss Middle East peace and the restoration of relations with the Saudis.

MADRID, June 7--In the Basque region of northern Spain there are signs of a popular backlash against the violence of the separatist organization E.T.A., which has benefited from the acquiescence or tacit support of many Basques.

Carlos M. Rios, a former Democratic State Assemblyman from East Harlem and City Councilman at Large, died Friday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan, following a stroke. He was 66 years old and lived at 345 East 101st Street.

LONDON--By all the rules of supply and demand, the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Algiers tomorrow should be smooth sailing. With nearly a million barrels of excess oil searching for buyers, with recession dampening Western demand, with 5 billion barrels stored ...

A 43-year-old fireman died in an arson fire in Harlem Friday, and a 19-year-old resident of the building who had been feuding with his landlord was charged yesterday with setting the fire and killing the fireman. The fireman, Donald M. Bub, was the second firefighter to die in the line of duty this year in New York City. The first, Lieut. Robert R. Dolney, also died in a fire caused by arson. He was killed in Brooklyn on March 5 as he pushed a young fireman out of the way of a collapsing wall.

AS we enter the 1980's, the Connecticut state government is still struggling with the ramifications of an idea that was spawned in the 60's, took wing in the 70's and is now coming home to roost. The idea, a favorite with well-intentioned libertarians and budget-minded legislators, is this: ''Let's get the mentally ill out of the institution and 'back into the community.' '' Legislators are debating such alternatives as the allocation of funds for state hospitals versus local mental health agencies, as well as proposals aimed at controlling residences for those discharged from institutions but deemed incapable of independent living.

Christine Marie Corbin and Nathaniel Warren Weldon 3d, both of New York, were married yesterday morning in the Sanibel Island (Fla.) Community Church by the Rev. Bruce Milligan. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Richard Lee Corbin of Sanibel Island and Mrs. John Embry of New York and Mr. Weldon Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla.

Deputy Prime Minister Kim Woun Gi said today that the economy had not been as badly damaged by recent student unrest as a Government white paper on the subject, issued two days ago, alleged. The white paper, put out by the Information Office to justify the imposition of tough martial-law measures and the crackdown on student dissent last month, said the unrest had ''driven the nation's economy to the brink of bankruptcy.''

Phoenix Newspapers Inc., which owns the state's two dominant daily papers, is suing a local weekly and some of its own reporters for libel. The morning Arizona Republic and the afternoon Phoenix Gazette, with a combined circulation of 365,000, have been fighting the introduction of a newsroom labor union for about two years. The Newspaper Guild has won two certification elections, but management has broken off contract talks with guild representatives.

A prominent architect who 50 years ago designed the huge Art Deco grillwork over the main entrance of the Bonwit Teller Building, now under demolition on Fifth Avenue, expressed astonishment yesterday that a real estate developer had lost track of the elaborate solid nickel ornament. The architect, Otto J. Teegen, who also designed the Squibb Building at 120 Wall Street and many other structures in New York City, expressed incredulity at the decision of the developer, Donald J. Trump, to destroy rather than preserve two stone bas-relief sculptures high on the facade of the building on the northeast corner of 56th Street.

Helen Pettit Hinckley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Neilson Hinckley of Menlo Park and Inverness, Calif., was married in New York yesterday to William Bedloe Beekman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Struthers Beekman of New York. The ceremony was performed in St. James' Episcopal Church by Canon Edwin S.S. Sunderland of Cambridge, Mass. He was assisted by the Rev. Hayes H. Rockwell, rector of St. James'.

To the Business Editor: The New York Times has played a major role in the shift, evident in the United States and elsewhere, toward more sophisticated reporting of the relationship between corporate earnings and inflation. I was, therefore, disappointed to find that the article ''Steel Could Be a Buy - In the Long Term'' (May 11), which discussed the steel industry as an investment prospect, neglected to consider the impact of inflation in evaluating earnings. Regardless of one's views concerning the steel producers, the article would have been more insightful had it dealt not simply with the industry's historical costs-basis earnings but also with the information now available regarding the effects of inflation on reported earnings.

Remember when Indira Gandhi was vilified as a dictator? Many of her compatriots, if they haven't forgotten, apparently have forgiven. Results announced last week of elections in nine Indian states showed the Prime Minister's party won handily in eight. In a further demonstration of their devotion, legislators of the victorious Congress-I (for Indira) Party in Uttar Pradesh voted unanimously to make Mrs. Gandhi's 33-year-old son, Sanjay, chief minister of the northern state in which one-sixth of India's voters live. Mrs. Gandhi modestly refused on her son's behalf, noting that ''he has just become a member of Parliament.'' Deng Bowing Out

Ann Elliott, an artist, and Peter Gruen, chairman of the classics department of Manhattanville College, were married at Grace Episcopal Church yesterday by the Rev. James G. Munroe. Mrs. Strachan Donnelley and Mrs. Archie West attended the bride, who is a daughter of Mrs. William Adams Elliott of Pittsburgh, and the late Mr. Elliott. Harvey Stahl was best man for Mr. Gruen, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred L. Gruen, reside in Mahopac, N.Y.

A 43-year-old fireman died in an arson fire in Harlem Friday, and a 19-year-old resident of the building who had been feuding with his landlord was charged yesterday with setting the fire and killing the fireman. The fireman, Donald M. Bub, was the second firefighter to die in the line of duty this year in New York City. The first, Lieut. Robert R. Dolney, also died in a fire caused by arson. He was killed in Brooklyn on March 5 as he pushed a young fireman out of the way of a collapsing wall.

In a further demonstration of their devotion, legislators of the victorious Congress-I (for Indira) Party in Uttar Pradesh voted unanimously to make Mrs. Gandhi's 33-year-old son, Sanjay, chief minister of the northern state in which one-sixth of India's voters live. Mrs. Gandhi modestly refused on her son's behalf, noting that ''he has just become a member of Parliament.'' Deng Bowing Out

Ann Elliott, an artist, and Peter Gruen, chairman of the classics department of Manhattanville College, were married at Grace Episcopal Church yesterday by the Rev. James G. Munroe. Mrs. Strachan Donnelley and Mrs. Archie West attended the bride, who is a daughter of Mrs. William Adams Elliott of Pittsburgh, and the late Mr. Elliott. Harvey Stahl was best man for Mr. Gruen, whose parents, Mr. and Mrs. Fred L. Gruen, reside in Mahopac, N.Y.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 6--As Vernon E. Jordan Jr. begins the slow process of recovery from the gunshot wound he suffered eight days ago, the National Urban League and its affiliates in 117 cities are turning their attention to the impact of the shooting and Mr. Jordan's absence on the league and the civil rights movement.
