TEHERAN, Iran, June 7 (UPI)-- Ramsey Clark and five other Americans who participated in the Iranian-sponsored conference on alleged American intervention in Iran met today with the Iranian militants who have held Americans captive for 31 weeks, sources close to the American delegation said.
FALLBROOK, Calif., June 6--"You bet I voted for Tom Metzger," Bill Davis said angrily, almost shouting.

Americans are more likely to change their membership in a church denomination for theological reasons now than they were in the past, statistics contained in the new edition of the Yearbook of American and Canadian Churches suggest.

Cevil Taylor is the most controversial jazz pianist of the last 20 years. Long a vanguard artist, he was, with Ornette Coleman and John Coltrane, one of the three major figures who gave impetus to the jazz avant garde of the 1960's.

NETCONG, N.J., June 7 (AP)--A chartered bus carrying a bowling group from Queens slammed into the rear of a tractor-trailer while climbing a hill on Interstate 80 this morning, injuring 34 persons, the police said.

OVER the years, one of the more reliable dining spots in the Hamptons has been Cordon's in Amagansett. Despite changes in chefs and ownership, residents and visitors in this resort area continually turn to Gordon's for pleasant dining. There are evenings, especially during the off-season, when Gordon's looks more like a club than a restaurant.

SAG HARBOR SINCE last summer, Sunday af ternoons have become a popular time for celebration and merriment at the Long Wharf Restaurant in Sag Harbor. Highly animated dancing and a near-bacchanal atmosphere often prevail.
UNIONDALE I WAS in Toronto, a city whose team used to win the Stanley Cup, when the Islanders finally won theirs.

The marriage of Candace Cole MacGuigan, daughter of Virginia Duncan MacGuigan of New York and Dr. John F. MacGuigan of Greenville, Del., to Tweed Roosevelt took place at the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday.

LANDOVER, Md., June 7 (AP)--Police in Prince George's County, Maryland, have been investigating reports of an alleged bookmaking and sports betting operation in the front office of the Washington Bullets basketball team, The Washington Post reported in today's editions.

"In the 1980's, the 20 percent, maybe even 30 percent of the bottom performers in retailing will go down the tube in a shakeout that will affect many people and many businesses," said a speaker at a meeting last month of retailing executives.

Deborah Lynne Campbell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick MacGregor Campbell Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to William Lockhart Garwood Jr., son of Justice Garwood of the Texas Supreme Court and Mrs. Garwood of Austin.

The marriage of Dr. Gail Iles Genvert, a 1980 graduate of the Cornell University Medical College, to Dr. Robert Allan Reichert, a surgeon in St. Petersburg, Fla., took place in Westport, Conn., yesterday.

Jerusalem is a city made for walking, and almost any occasion is an excuse for someone to offer a walking tour. In a recent two-week visit I was able on one day to join a regular Friday afternoon procession of pilgrims, led ...

GLEN COVE THERE is something so intrinsicly celebratory about ''My Fair Lady'' that any major production of it signals a sense of occasion, or provides an excuse for one. Time has not tarnished nor memory magnified a real classic. The last Broadway staging of the Alan J. Lerner-Frederick Loewe musical adapted from George Bernard Shaw's ''Pygmalion'' was a 20thanniversary revival. The next will be a 25th, with the original star, Rex Harrison. In what can be called a 24th anniversary production, and a double event, ''My Fair Lady'' heralds a new life for the Northstage Theater-Restaurant, restored to owner-management after a sudden closing in March. Now in its seventh week, the show will run through July 6.

THREE cheers for the long-predicted recession that we are supposed to have. A ''well done'' for Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, who recently expressed hope that the business downturn would come ''the sooner the better.'' And hurrah for the former chairman, Arthur F. Burns, who said that, beyond a recession, America's fundamental need in the economy ''is to create a new environment.'' I agree. And let me assure you that I am not demented, rich, masochistic or insensitive to the havoc that a depression can cause. I lived through one. And so perhaps better than you, I remember squatter families living amidst garbage on the Jersey meadows, and the shuffling breadlines of bloody, broken men.

Temperence Hill, a 53-1 shot so little appreciated that his name was misspelled in the program, scored a stunning upset in the 112th running of the Belmont Stakes yesterday--and somehow it had to end that way.

SUCCESSFUL efforts by a committee of the Connecticut Bar Association to bring about an official investigation into allegations of misconduct by the Bridgeport police have revived questions about the adequacy of investigative procedures and about the state's unusual justice system, in which prosecutors and judges are part of the same branch of government.
DETROIT, June 7--Detroit's economic troubles may turn out to be a windfall for Atlanta's understaffed Police Department.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 7--Deputy Prime Minister Kim Woun Gi said today that the economy had not been as badly damaged by recent student unrest as a Government white paper on the subject, issued two days ago, alleged.

"MEMOIRS OF HECATE COUNTY" is Edmund Wilson's only collection of stores, among 40 or more volumes of criticism, drama, poetry, scholarship, travel and reminiscence. When the book first appeared in 1946, it also became his only best seller, before it was suppressed for obscenity by the New York State Court of Special Sessions. Its reissue (how notions of obscenity have changed!) is an occasion for rereading it, and a rewarding experience.

THE United States Golf Association will stage its men's open championship this week at the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J., for a record sixth time but for only the third time on the club's Lower Course. Play will start on Thursday on this magnificent and deceptively strong 18 holes of golf, which was used for the 1954 and 1967 Opens. Back in the days of hickory shafts and no sprinkler systems, the original Baltusrol course was used for the ninth Open, in 1903, when Willie Anderson beat David Brown in a playoff for the title. Jerome Travers won the Open there in 1915 before things began to change at the sedate establishment with the beautiful Tudor mansion clubhouse.

MINEOLA THE first hint of the Long Island Lighting Company's $228 million proposed rate increase was the loose-leaf notebooks. Unlike Lilco's annual report, which had contained 38 pages and a full-color sketch of the Shoreham nuclear generating plant, these four notebooks weighed 15 pounds and contained at least 500 pages. Each notebook contained page after double-spaced page of testimony from Lilco officials, who said that Lilco's financial picture, like that of other Northeastern utilities with large construction budgets for nuclear projects, was not all that bright.

The Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan in December brought protests from Afghans in the United States, but the trait that kept their nation independent for so long, individualism, has kept them disunited. Only a few thousand Afghans live in the United States, according to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, but at least 10 of their organizations are trying to arouse opinion against Moscow.

As the smell of newmown hay fills the air in parts of upstate New York, indicating the start of a new farm year, figures were issued here this week showing that the state's dairy farms produced a record $1.28 billion worth of milk last year, up 16 percent from the year before. ''It was a favorable year for the dairy farmer,'' said Lyle Newcombe, a dairy specialist for the state's Department of Agriculture and Markets. He added, however, that 1980 did not look nearly as good.

In a rare cooperative venture, 20 members of the 102d Engineers Battalion of the New York State Army National Guard yesterday helped a South Bronx neighborhood group clear a rubble-strewn lot that is to be turned into a park of grass, swings, picnic areas and sports courts. As part of their mandatory weekend duty, the guardsmen operated two bulldozers and three front-end loaders that they had brought with them from Camp Smith in Peekskill. They also worked with neighborhood residents putting soil in areas roped off for gardening.

Susan Ellen Stein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin A. Stein of Oceanside, L.I., was married last night to Gerald Joel Feit, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvan Feit of Rockville Centre, L.I. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. The bride, a graduate of Hofstra University, is a trade coordinator with the American-Israel Chamber of Commerce and Industry. Her father is a partner in Stein & Stein, certified public accountants in Hicksville, L.I.

The name given to a patient's mental or emotional problems didn't matter a few years ago, many psychiatrists say. With no tailor-made treatments available, accurate diagnoses benefited few. Today, 25 years into psychiatry's pharmacological revolution, diagnosis usually leads to a specific drug therapy. There are minor tranquilizers for anxiety, tricyclic antidepressants and monoamine oxidase inhibitors to help the depressed, lithium to still the emotional swings of manic depression, and antipsychotic, or neuroleptic, drugs to dispel the disordered thoughts and possibly violent behavior of schizophrenia. With these drugs and their promise of relief, however, has come a fearful question: What happens when the psychiatrist or other doctor makes the wrong diagnosis? What is the effect of taking the wrong medication? Or the right one in the wrong amount? The case of neuroleptics, dispensed to one to three million people in the general population yearly, offers a disturbing answer.

Last December Fidel Castro described Cuba's social and economic problems to members of the National Assembly and promised broad changes, but ''without traumas.'' ''We do not intend to do traumatic things,'' he assured them, adding in a reference to the Chinese upheaval of the mid-1960's, ''We do not intend to unleash a Cultural Revolution here.''

Crusader 80, Britain's biggest military exercise in more than a decade, will take place in September to test contingency plans for national mobilization, preparations for defense of the country and reinforcement of ground and air units in West Germany. The program calls for the movement to Continental Europe by air and sea of 20,000 troops of the Territorial Army and 10,000 regulars. The ability of the non-Continental members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to move strong forces into Europe in a crisis is essential to NATO's deterrent strategy, according to military and political leaders.

The 1979-80 season comes to an official, gaudy, cathartic finale tonight when the Tony Awards are presented before a nationwide television audience at the Mark Hellinger Theater. Only a fool would predict how the Tony voters are going to swing -or at least make such speculations in print - and so there will be no predictions here. But this is the perfect time to take a long, backward look at the season, and ask just what kind of year for theatergoing it was. For my money, this was no season for the history books, but there have nonetheless been plenty of thrills. Most of the best plays and musicals have been revivals - not a good sign - and yet most of the revivals have been exquisite. Some of our name playwrights (from Albee and Williams to Babe and Innaurato) have taken their lumps, but some bright new stars have begun to shine. In any case, here is a highly opinionated, far from all-inclusive list of some of the people, plays and things that made this theatergoer's 1979-80 season worthwhile. The BAM Theater Company. This new repertory company, guided by David Jones, a Royal Shakespeare Company veteran, is the miracle of the season. Not all of the productions have been successful, but Mr. Jones and his literary manager, Richard Nelson, have never erred on the side of caution. They have chosen plays ranging from the difficult (''The Winter's Tale'') to the obscure (Gorky's ''Barbarians''), produced them to the nines and staffed them with energetic casts. BAM's excavation of Charles MacArthur's obscure ''Johnny on a Spot,'' a Broadway flop of 1942, had the season's funniest second act. Brian Murray's portrayal of a French chamber pot manufacturer in Feydeau's ''The Purging'' (now playing on a double bill with Brecht's ''The Wedding'') is the year's most uproarious farcical performance. All in all, BAM seems well on its way to providing New York with the great rep company it so sorely needs.
To the Editor:

The fourth annual Plimpton Cup for the World Amateur Backgammon Championship will be held this week, Tuesday to Sunday, in Las Vegas, Nev. The popularity of this event is due in no small part to the $100,000 first prize. Prizes this substantial are rare in any sport or game, and are usually available only to the top professionals. The Plimpton Cup, however, is restricted to amateurs - professional players must compete in a separate ''open'' event. The caliber of play is not as high in the amateur event, but the competition is fierce. Under pressure, amateurs are more prone than professionals to commit errors. In particular, near the end of a long match, amateurs often meglect the subtleties of match play that never arise in nontournament play. The exact score of the match influences not only the doubling strategy but also the play of the checkers.

King Khalid of Saudi Arabia will visit West Germany later this month at the invitation of President Karl Carstens, the Government has announced. The visit, starting June 16, reflects West Germany's interest in developing closer ties with oilproducing countries.

Britches'' and ''The Legend of the Lone Ranger'' --------------------------------------------------------------------- Miles Beller is a West Coast writer who specializes in popular culture. By MILES BELLER

Jeff Bradshaw qualified in two events yesterday for the New York State schoolboy track and field championships next Saturday at Ithaca. However, the Brooklyn Tech senior will be 3,000 miles away when that meet is contested. Bradshaw, winner of the 1,600- and 3,200-meter runs at the Public Schools Athletic League title meet yesterday, has accepted an invitation to compete in the one-mile run at the Golden West allstar schoolboy event in Sacramento, Calif., next Saturday.

There is a long walk before one reaches the room, past white shuttered doors facing a dense tropical garden. The deep quiet is interrupted only by the swift flight of birds. The room itself is simple; mahogany twin beds pushed together, white hobnail bedspreads and red pillows, white throw rugs on a terrazzo floor and hunting prints on the walls. The room is full of the sound of the sea. This wing of the Jamaica Inn sits on the sand and opens onto the beach not with screens or glass but with a second room that is something between a porch and an English parlor. Upholstered furniture in a floral print is enclosed by three baby blue walls and a porch railing just high enough to make it more comfortable to walk around to the front door than to climb in from the outside.

PASTED in a window of a recently vacated store on Main Street here is a photograph of an old woman crying, and underneath it, a brief article written in Spanish. Translated, the story begins, ''These tears are yours, Fidel Castro. She is 78 years old and has left her land behind. In that land, she also left behind her youth, relatives, her language and her illusions ....'' Not long ago, 20 Cubans arrived here to make new lives for themselves. They are three families who came in mid-May to live with relatives, a fourth family who knew no one in America and moved one week ago into a dormitory at Marymount College where they will stay for an indefinite period of time, and three individuals who had been at the troubled Fort Chaffee relocation center in Arkansas since May 17. Like the woman in the photograph, and like the thousands who have fled Cuba in the past month, they have had to put behind them much that was familiar -but they have also come to a community in which they can feel at least partially at home.

HEMPSTEAD SUMMER, and the living is easy. Or is it? Not for T.P. of Hicksville, a divorced, full-time working parent, who is hard put to find the extra funds to provide summer camp for her two youngsters.

SEASIDE HEIGHTS ON THE boardwalk, the tangy salt air mixes with the smell of fried onions and freshly baked pizza. On the beach, a small knot of early sunbathers gathers, their chatter mingling with the pounding of the surf and the electronic beeps of pinball machines.
Despite conditions that have weakened rental housing as a long-term business enterprise, a few builders are pressing forward in Manhattan with plans for new luxury apartment buildings.

Many plans aimed at making Times Square something more than a breeding ground for prostitutes, pornographers and drug pushers have been announced with great fanfare over the years, only to fade without making a dent in the sleaze. Barring a sudden change of heart by the Koch Administration, yet another such plan, perhaps the grandest ever, is likely to meet a similar fate.

WASHINGTON The National Herb Garden, an exquisite display of some 7,000 herbal plants from all over the world, will make its formal debut on Thursday as the new est attraction at the National Arboretum.
WASHINGTON--At a meeting of business leaders here recently, President Carter called the Equal Rights Amendment "unfinished national business" and urged his audience to work for its ratification.

If Shirley Hufstedler were a bird, the Audubon Society might tell you to stop looking for her. She can't be observed, at least nut close up. She is either on a dais, in a limousine, behind closed doors or flying too far overhead in an airplane to be accurately sighted.

A chartered bus carrying a bowling group from Queens slammed into the rear of a tractor-trailer while climbing a hilll on Interstate 80 this morning, injuring 34 persons, the police said. The injured, all passengers on the bus, were en route to Rochester when the accident occurred at 9:10 A.M., according to hospital officials.

The typical Alekhine Defense buff is a tease who pretends he is giving up something of value when he allows White to advance quickly in the center. His real intention is to prove that the supply lines to White's overextended pawn or pawns are thin and easily cut. Even if Black does not succeed in this primary objective, he will still have the upper hand if White has to spend all his resources in maintaining an advanced pawn spearhead.

Ronnie Perry, Holy Cross shortstop, has been chosen the New England baseball player of the year in Division I of the Eastern College Athletic Conference. Perry, who was picked last week in the third round of the amateur free-agent draft by the Chicago White Sox, is expected to be selected in an early round of next Tuesday's National Basketball Association draft.

TO someone like Gary Morgenstein - born in the Bronx, raised in Jamaica and Selden, a player of street games, a Mets fan - opening day in major league baseball is always special. Last year was no exception. It wasn't simply that Mr. Morgenstein returned home from his job as an editor of the quarterly publication Baseball Stats Magazine to discover that the Mets had won. When the telephone rang, he also learned that his first novel was being bought by St. Martin's Press.

As Vernon E. Jordan Jr. begins the slow process of recovery from the gunshot wound he suffered eight days ago, the National Urban League and its affiliates in 117 cities are turning their attention to the impact of the shooting and Mr. Jordan's absence on the league and the civil rights movement. The consensus, based on telephone interviews with rights leaders around the country, both in and out of the Urban League, is that Mr. Jordan will be missed more by the civil rights community than by the league. The long-term effects, most said, will depend on the length of his recuperation and on whether the motive for the shooting is found to be related to his activism or to his companion at the time of the shooting.

The ''freedom flotilla'' sputtered to a near standstill today after bringing nearly 112,000 Cuban refugees to the United States since early April. The Coast Guard received reports of about 10 vessels crossing the Florida Straits from Mariel, Cuba. By early evening, one boat carrying 80 passengers had arrived at Key West, where officials have processed 1,768 boatloads, a total of 111,838 men, women and children. Many of the latest arrivals said they had been taken from jails throughout Cuba.

Karen Diane Kelley, daughter of John J. Kelley Jr. of Germantown, Tenn., and Mrs. George Adolph Papritz of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Alan Richard D'Zurilla, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis A. D'Zurilla of Middletown, N.J. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Riverside, Conn., by the Rev. Mark Sullivan with the Rev. James Beckwith, a Roman Catholic priest.

Stock and bond prices swept higher last week, buoyed mainly by plummeting interest rates. Providing the icing on the cake was the small May increase in wholesale prices, as measured by the producer price index for finished goods, reported on Friday by the Labor Department. Reaching its highest level since early March, the Dow Jones industrial average finished at 861.52, with a gain of 10.67 points for the week.

Twelve American journalists have been awarded Nieman Fellowships for a year of study at Harvard University starting next fall. The Lucius W. Nieman Foundation was established 43 years ago by Agnes Wahl Nieman in memory of her husband, who founded The Milwaukee Journal. The Nieman fellows receive a $10,500 stipend to cover living expenses during their year at Harvard.

The Board of Estimate made an urban renewal decision last month affecting the lower East Side that would have been unthinkable at any time in the last 15 years. A majority rejected a plan to complete the Seward Park Extension project that had been passed by the local community board and by a prestigious Chinatown group. The plan was presented as a compromise between those who advocate more low-rent public housing in the area and those who urge that the remaining urban renewal land be dedicated to commercial facilities. But the Board of Estimate made it clear that it wants no more public housing in the Seward Park Extension area, which is just north of Chinatown.

The United States Soccer Federation is making a strong bid to persuade F.I.F.A., soccer's world governing body, that this country is ready to host an international tournament. Gene Edwards, the president of the United States federation, announced last week that a youth tournament involving 19 of the 23 nations that comprise North and Central American and the Caribbean region, a region known as CONCACAF, will be held in four cities from Aug. 1 through 17. The tournament will qualify two nations for the Youth World Cup in Australia next year.
Arts/photo of walk at Greenburgh Nature Center By ELEANOR CHARLES

GROTON THE communities along the 15 miles of the Thames River, seeking to broaden and diversify their defense-dependent economy, are beginning an experiment in economic development unique to Connecticut. By next month, the governing board of the Thames River Development Corporation, representing area government, business and public interests, should be selected. The nonprofit organization will attempt for the first time to copy on a regional scale the success of municipal development corporations already at work in Meriden, Bridgeport and other cities. The corporation's large agenda - increasing use of New London Harbor and the State Pier, attracting industry, and promoting tourism - and the idea for setting up the corporation itself were proposed in a plan made public by the Office of Policy and Management in mid-May. This plan is the product of a $29,300 study, authorized in 1978 by the General Assembly, of ''the development of port and ancillary commercial and recreational facilities along the Thames River from the harbor in the city of New London to the city of Norwich.''
LONDON, June 2--The public debate over the strained relationship between the police and Britain's growing black population has been rekindled in recent weeks.

SEOUL, South Korea, Monday, June 9 (Reuters) The Martial Law Command announced here today that it had detained eight journalists on suspicion of spreading false and seditious rumors.
Artificial moves always look as if they should meet with an easy refutation, but there are times when brilliant play is needed to prove them wrong.

LOS ANGELES AFTER winning a special 1977 Academy Award for creating the 250 sounds of the robots, monsters and environments in "Star Wars," Ben Burtt has spent two years creating the 1,000 new sounds necessary for the "Star Wars" sequel "The Empire Strikes Back."
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) Beginning July 18, crates used for shipping dogs and cats must have more ventilation holes than they do now, the Agriculture Department has announced.

LISBON, June 8 (Reuters) The Angolan press agency said today that the nation's coffee exports were expected to drop 20 percent this year to about 53,000 tons, less than a quarter of the export level before independence from Portugal in 1973. The head of the coffee marketing board blamed a drought in 1978 and the guerrilla war in the north for the decline.
BOULDER, Colo., June 7 This town, which prides itself on being an advanced community, is now pursuing a small experiment in price controls on middle-income housing.

The huge exodus of refugees from Cuba is practically over, but the task of helping tens of thousands of new residents has barely begun. Community leaders here say that the area might be able to turn the inevitable short-term social, economic and political assimilation problems into a long-term advantage. These local leaders, who were as unprepared for the Cuban influx as were officials in Washington, say they are sure that despite Federal intentions to resettle as many refugees as possible in other areas of the country, sooner or later most of them will come to Miami to live.

Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie indicated today that the Administration might be lenient with the group of 10 Americans, including former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, who traveled to Teheran in violation of a Presidential ban. Mr. Clark, interviewed today in Paris, said that if he was prosecuted for traveling to Iran he would defend himself by asserting that he had inherent constitutional rights to travel, to assemble and to speak.

At the insistence of the United States Internal Revenue Service, American businessmen and journalists here are paying Soviet income taxes that it is unoffficially estimated may total as much as $250,000. The taxes the Americans pay in the Soviet Union, which might seem a paradox in light of the United States embargo of sales of high technology and millions of tons of grain because of the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan, is a result of a 1973 income-tax treaty between the two countries that the Russians began enforcing only last year.

Occupied West Bank, June 8 - Eldad Harel, a Jewish high school student who lives with his family in this well-fortified outpost north of Jerusalem, has an Arab friend. Eldad and the Arab youth, Taysyr, were brought together by a common interest in the wildlife of the harsh, dry land they share.Exploring it together using a gabble of Arabic, Hebrew and sign language, the two youths like to collect the brown and black snakes that slither across the barren, sun-soaked hills, and watch the nesting of the cuckoos down by the cherry grove. For at least a year, they saw each other nearly every day.

Five months before the general election, President Carter's re-election campaign has yet to develop the affirmative themes his aides realize will be necessary to convince voters that Mr. Carter deserves to be re-elected. The absence of an overriding, positively phrased campaign theme, something similar to his successful 1976 pledges to tell the truth and produce a Government ''as good as the American people,'' has become one of the most troubling problems of the entire re-election drive, Carter aides agree.

Three Cuban refugees from the Fort Chaffee relocation center have been charged in the burglary of a Barling residence, the authorities said today. Terry Geren, criminal investigator for the Sebastian County sheriff's office, said Jorge Lago Haimeniz, Florin Hernandez Gonzales and Alejandro Mora Durante were found hiding near Barling City Hall about 3 A.M. They had property with them, including a pistol and a knife, that had been reported stolen 10 minutes earlier, Mr. Geren said.

Sally Little became the fourth non-American to win a major United States women's golf title today when she overcame severe winds and captured the Ladies' Professional Golf Association Championship by three strokes. The 28-year-old South African, who plans to become a United States citizen in 18 months, was the only golfer to finish under par on the Kings Island Grizzly course. Her one-over-par round of 73 today gave her a four-round total of 285, three under par. Jane Blalock, with a 74 today, was second at 288.

When corporations become embroiled in social crises, such as the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its ''500'' radial tires, sympathy and a contrite heart are seldom on view. The executive response seems one of throwing up the barricades and limiting any financial liability. The Hooker Chemical Company has taken a tough posture since the tragedy of the Love Canal toxic waste contamination began to unfold in 1978, and, because of it, has been pilloried in the public arena.

The Rye Town Hilton Inn in Port Chester, N.Y., was the setting at noon yesterday for the marriage of Bonnie Ann Lewis, daughter of Leon Lewis of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Elaine Lewis, to John Michael Rodney, son of Mrs. John Carnevali of Elmsford, N.Y., and the late John Rodney. State Supreme Court Justice Alvin Ruskin performed the ceremony. The couple, 1975 graduates of Syracuse University, are studying for M.B.A. degrees, she at New York University and he at Pace University. The bride is a producer-writer with the audio-visual department of the Western Electric Company in New York. Her father is president of the Viclon Precision Corporation, a Mount Vernon, N.Y., manufacturer of precision machine parts.

WASHINGTON WHAT is the United States? The answer seems simple enough, but Federal bureaucrats have managed to make it complicated, and the disagreement is causing no end of confusion over one of the economy's key statistics: imports of foreign oil. The fracas is over whether the United States is (1) just the 50 states, (2) the 50 states plus Puerto Rico, which is the Customs area where tariffs are levied, or (3) the 50 states plus Puerto Rico plus Guam and other Pacific territories, which is the broader balance-ofpayments zone.

You're a foreigner so I can give it to you straight,'' the Brazilian official said in 1972 to Bruce Tippett, an American social worker trying to obtain Government backing for a program to aid small businesses in the cities of the poor northeastern part of the country. ''We're not going out of our way to help small businesses in Brazil. We want those people to provide labor for big business. The growth of this country depends upon big business, and that's who we're going to be dealing with.'' Eight years later, the same Government has endorsed Mr. Tippett's model, set up its own similar projects and, in a presidential decree, exempted small businesses from income taxes and onerous financialreporting requirements.

Hare Krishna groups are coming under increasing scrutiny by the police in California amid disclosures that they have been stockpiling large stores of weapons and ammunition. Lieut. Jeff Markham of the Lake County Sheriff's Department, whose jurisdiction includes a Krishna ranch near Ukiah where officers discovered a cache of weapons and ammunition last March, said, ''They have pretended for years to be a peace-loving group that was only concerned about their religion but events of the last six months have shown me personally that they are not what they pretend to be.''

Spectacular Bid established a career money-winning record for thoroughbreds today as he captured the $319,450 Californian at Hollywood Park in track record time. Ridden by Bill Shoemaker, the 4-year-old Spectacular Bid ran the mile and an eighth in 1:45 4-5, just two-fifths of a second off the world record and one-fifth of a second better than the mark set earlier in the day by Rich Cream. Before today, the mark had been 1:46 2-5, set by Colorado King in 1964.

BITS & PIECES,'' Corinne Jacker's 1974 Obie Award-winning comedy, could not be more perfectly named. Miss Jacker's title at once describes her play's plot, its theatrical technique and its failings. To put it another way, ''Bits & Pieces'' is an anecdotal, unfocused work about fragmented lives. But Miss Jacker does write with rueful, passionate humor, and in the spiffy revival at the Second Stage some of her fragments do shine. The playwright attempts the tough task of telling two stories simultaneously - one set in the present, the other in the past. The first is about death. Philip, an attractive young college professor played by Robert Fields, has died, and his wife, Iris (Robyn Goodman), is trying to cope with the pain of the loss. To do so, she decides to chase, quite literally, after the bits and pieces of her late husband's body: Philip had willed most of himself to a transplant bank, and now his organs and appendages belong to others.

Roy Alberti, a 45-year-old resident of the Co-op City housing complex in the Bronx, was shot dead in his doorway at 10 P.M. yesterday by an unidentified visitor after an argument, according to the police. Mr. Alberti was pronounced dead at his home, 120 Elgar Place.
PHILADELPHIA Never forget the admiration with which we in Britain regard America. When the chips are down and they are down now we stand by you as allies should.

Governor Carey and key state legislators of both parties have agreed on a bill that would make the courts rather than state psychiatric hospitals responsible for the custody of people found not guilty of crimes because of insanity.

WASHINGTON, June 8 Five months before the general election, President Carter's re-election campaign has yet to develop the affirmative themes his aides realize will be necessary to convince voters that Mr. Carter deserves to be reelected.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) The Administration changed its inflation control guidelines to reflect spiraling gold and silver prices.

BENNY GOODMAN had just passed his 71st birthday when he gave what has become an annual concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. His appearance and performance seemed virtually unchanged from recent years, but the cast around him was different.

TORONTO, June 8 Bell Canada and the Canadian Government are preparing a major field test of a new two-way communications service using home television sets to link private users with a vast array of computerized information banks.

To the Editor: Your May 14 editorial ''Insulate Houses - with Red Tape'' gave badly needed support to a major element in the nation's emerging energy program: the creation of Federal standards for saving energy in new buildings. or over a year, narrow special interests have worked to kill this vital conservation program. Yet the Building Energy Performance Standards (BEPS) will enhance the dollar value of the single largest investment most of us make, our houses.

Colorfully costumed majorettes squealed with surprise yesterday after a sudden shower drenched participants and spectators at the Puerto Rican Day parade on Fifth Avenue. Gov. Carlos Romero Barcelo of Puerto Rico and his wife, Kate, watched from reviewing; stand at 69th Street. Page B3.

Munich'' casts a long shadow. As the classic historical metaphor for appeasement, the name of the city recurs uncomfortably in views of the West's response to Soviet aggression in Afghanistan, the cracks in the Atlantic alliance, the suspicions of broken ranks in Europe. The nagging worry seems to be, Will 1980 be another 1938? Historical precedents are dangerous ideas. The threats today are more diverse, less concentrated in one man or idea. But what mattered in 1938 and what matters now is knowing a threat for a threat, and then deciding to deal with it.

Senator Frank Church, who mostly concerns himself with foreign relations, marched in the cherry blossom parade in Emmett, Idaho, this weekend. He later addressed a labor convention in Coeur d'Alene, in the northern lumber country, where thousands of loggers have been thrown out of work because high interest rates have depressed the home building industry. The loggers blame him. Senator Dale Bumpers attended an arts and crafts festival in Holly Grove, Ark., a typical community in his agricultural state, where produce is selling for less than the cost of production. The farmers blame him.

In Louisville, Ky., the General Electric Company said last week that it was laying off about 400 white-collar workers at its big Appliance Park operation. And more cuts are in the offing: 3,700 production employees are slated to be let go in July. In Moline, Ill., Deere & Company, the world's largest producer of farm equipment, has sliced its payroll by some 4,000 since mid-April. In Greenwich, Conn., the Bangor Punta Corporation has also reduced its work force by 4,000 in recent months. Sales of the conglomerate's recreational goods, such as sailboats and its wellknown line of Piper private aircraft, have fallen off sharply as the recession has deepened.

Kathryn Leonore Schwebel, who received a bachelor's degree in education summa cum laude May 19 from the University of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald B. Woods of Havertown, Pa., a professor of physical education at West Chester (Pa.) State College. The ceremony was performed in the Westtown (Pa.) School by the Rev. Dr. William F. Woods, minister of the First United Methodist Church in Carlisle, Pa., father of the bridegroom. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schwebel of Glen Rock, N.J., is a tennis professional. Her father is a vice president of the Bulova Watch Company in Jackson Heights, Queens.

Billy Bishop Goes to War,'' the musical that closed Saturday at the Morosco Theater, will re-open next Tuesday, June 17, at the Theater de Lys, 121 Christopher Street. This is believed to be the first time a play has moved directly from Broadway to Off Broadway. ''Billy Bishop Goes to War'' stars Eric Peterson as the World War I Canadian flying hero. It has a book, music and lyrics written by John Gray in collaboration with Mr. Peterson.

Economists with the United States Department of Agriculture predict corn and other feed grain prices will climb this summer as more grain is removed from the market through Government purchases and the farmer-owned grain reserve. The Federal Government has been using both methods to help isolate corn that would have gone to the Soviet Union but was embargoed in retaliation for the military intervention in Afghanistan.

Members of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began gathering here today for another attempt to set a single base price for oil and to ease some of the strains in the cartel. Although the ministers voiced sharply different views today, the door was left open for a compromise that could include a sharp price increase. Tayeh Abdul Kerim, Iraq's Oil Minister, proposed a compromise minimum price of $32 a barrel, $4 above the existing minimum. This would increase the cost to Western consumers for imported oil by $5 billion a year.

New York City produces more garbage than poetry. About 22,000 tons of it a day. The city has run out of holes in which to bury the solid waste, and no other locality has volunteered as the final resting place. Some European cities have proved that solid waste can be ignited under proper environmental controls to produce heat for steam and electricity. The obstacles to similarly productive re-use of waste in New York are more institutional than technical. The State Legislature can remove them by changing the rules under which municipalities may contract with private businesses for what is euphemistically called ''resource recovery''. Because large-scale recovery of the hidden resources in garbage requires capital that the city government cannot raise, a serious program will require private investment. New York hopes to sign with one or more bidders, each of whom would receive up to 2,400 tons of waste a day and share the profits with the city under a negotiated formula. But to attract such investors, the city finds it will have to commit its wastes for long enough -say, 30 years - to assure a reasonable return on the the cost of the plant. It will have to be free to choose the most reliable bidders, using criteria that are less easily quantifiable than the proceeds-sharing formula. It will have to let bidders build their plants by whatever contracting procedure seems most efficient. City Hall believes that the Wicks Law, requiring separate bids for construction, electrical work, plumbing and heating, should not be applicable in this case. Unlike Westchester, which is building with public funds, New York's contractors will provide their own financing.

Ireland's Des Smyth sank a 45-foot putt on the final hole for a three-under-par 69 today that gave him a dramatic one-shot victory over three rivals in the $90,000 Newcastle open. Smyth, a 26-year-old British Ryder Cup player, finished with a 12-under-par total of 276, one shot in front of Australia's Greg Norman, who closed with a 69, and Britain's Neil Coles and Graham Burroughs, who both had 68's. Britain's Mark James and Sandy Lyle, both Ryder Cup players, shot 67 and 71, respectively, to share fifth place at 278 - one ahead of South Africa's Hugh Baiocchi (69) and Britain's Peter Townsend (66).

Robert D. Wood, former president of CBS-TV, was appointed president of the Metromedia Producers Corporation today by John W. Klug, chairman and chief executive officer of Metromedia Inc. The appointment of Mr. Wood to head the production and distribution arm of Metromedia indicates that the company plans to become a major supplier of television programming to the networks. During the early 1970's, Mr. Wood changed the image of CBS with such programs as ''All In The Family,'' ''Mary Tyler Moore'' and ''M*A*S*H.''

SNIFF Montaigne thought it best not to smell at all. ''To smell sweet is to stink,'' he said. But perfumes have existed for thousands of years; folks just want to smell sweet. Now, at the behest of the Fragrance Foundation, Mayor Koch has proclaimed this week ''Festival of Fragrance Week.''

WASHINGTON: What's the fundamental difference between commercial television and taxpayer-assisted, ''public'' television? The answer: advertising. Not any more. Noncommercial television, which had its reason for being in the freedom from sponsor pressure for high ratings, has figured out a way to sell advertising on a grand scale -subverting Congressional intent and making the Federal Government a direct competitor to free-market magazines across the country.

AT MILWAUKEE The Brewers' four-game winning streak came to an end as the Detroit Tigers opened with five runs in the first inning off Bill Travers (3-3). Jim Lentine hit the fourth pitch of the game for his first major-league home run, and his leadoff double in the fourth sparked another Tiger rally, good for two runs.

VANCOUVER, Wash., June 8 (UPI) Little fir trees are springing back to life, reaching through volcanic mud and ash for sunlight near steaming Spirit Lake on the flank of Mount St. Helens, a geologist said today.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The unexpectedly bad news about unemployment and unexpectedly good news about inflation in the last two months has intensified the debate over the Carter Administration's continued emphasis on curbing inflation at the risk of more severe recession.

SAG HARBOR, N.Y. "Munich" casts a long shadow. As the classic historical metaphor for appeasement, the name of the city recurs uncomfortably in views of the West's response to Soviet aggression in Afghanistan, the cracks in the Atlantic alliance, the suspicions of broken ranks in Europe.

The resignation of Joseph Hoffman as president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation can only result in more disarray for New York City's health programs. A former first deputy police commissioner, Mr. Hoffman held the job for only 17 months. He's quitting, it is said, ...

WASHINGTON, June 8 Just as an unexpected auto repair or doctor's bill can wreak havoc with a family's finances, so an almost infinite variety of unexpected events can disrupt the most carefully laid budget plans of the President and Congress.
HARTFORD, June 8 The Republican Party, hoping to improve its fortunes at the polls in November, has been offering potential candidates advice on how to campaign.
Dr. John D. Isaacs, an oceanographer and former director of the University of California's Institute of Marine Resources, died Friday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 67 years old.
MERLE HAGGARD is one of the most successful singer-songwriters in the country-music field, but as his one-night stand at the Lone Star Cafe on Thursday demonstrated, he is much more than that.

RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 8 (UPI) Darrell Waltrip, driving right behind Neil Bonnett for the final four laps, took the lead with 300 yards remaining today to capture the NASCAR 400 at Riverside International Raceway.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 (AP) The president of the Atlantic Richfield Company, Thornton F. Bradshaw, forecast increased United States dependence on foreign oil in the 1980's and said America must face political realities in the Middle East.
A Jet Momentarily Loses Power As It Descends at Toronto Airport

LOS ANGELES AFTER winning a special 1977 Academy Award for creating the 250 sounds of the robots, monsters and environments in ''Star Wars,'' Ben Burtt has spent two years creating the 1,000 new sounds necessary for the ''Star Wars'' sequel ''The Empire Strikes Back.'' An amiable 31-year-old self-defined ''sound nut'' who began playing with tape recorders when he was 6 years old, Mr. Burtt relaxes by listening to movies. Because sound effects have most frequently come from studio sound-effects libraries, he insists that he can identify the studio that produced a particular 1938 or 1943 film simply by listening for a few minutes to the squealing tires, ringing telephones or barroom brawls in the movie.

In a potentially important test of their cohesiveness, the leaders of a coalition of New York City's uniformed workers will meet today to consider a proposal by the new police union president that they delay any strike until the start of the Democratic National Convention in mid-August. The coalition has stuck firmly to a strike deadline of July 1, when employee contracts with the city expire. It did not budge from that position even after a second coalition, representing nonuniformed city employees, suggested last week that an August date would constitute a bigger threat.

Officials plan to open a mental health clinic this week to help Cuban refugees at a Pennsylvania resettlement camp cope with the changes in their lives. Most refugees have been doing ''amazingly well,'' said John Wells, a mental health consultant at Fort Indiantown Gap. Of 18,800 Cubans at the military camp, 10 have been sent to psychiatric hospitals.

BENNY GOODMAN had just passed his 71st birthday when he gave what has become an annual concert at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. His appearance and performance seemed virtually unchanged from recent years, but the cast around him was different. The program was familiar, standard Goodman, ''Lady Be Good,'' ''Avalon,'' ''Body and Soul,'' ''Stompin' at the Savoy'' and so forth. Everything he played, except ''Here's That Rainy Day,'' came from his heyday in the 1930's and has changed only to the extent that his playing tends to be richer and more deliberate on ballads and has settled into well-worn patterns on faster numbers.

ONCE a year, the New York City Housing Authority Symphony Orchestra takes time off from its many music-making activities in the city's various communities, parks and housing developments to give a concert in more formal surroundings. That annual event took place in Alice Tully Hall yesterday afternoon under the baton of the orchestra's conductor, Karl Hampton Porter. As usual, the program was a varied one to show the musicians off in a variety of styles. Mendelssohn's ''Italian'' Symphony was the principal work, preceded by Beethoven's ''Egmont'' Overture and Faure's Pavane. Jorge Morel, the guitarist, appeared as guest soloist in the Adagio from Rodrigo's ''Concierto de Aranjuez'' and three excerpts from his own ''Suite del Sur,'' while the orchestra's concertmaster, Winterton Garvey, played the solo part in Wieniawski's ''Polonaise de Concert'' for Violin and Orchestra.

Dr. John D. Isaacs, an oceanographer and former director of the University of California's Institute of Marine Resources, died Friday at his home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. He was 67 years old. His achievements included the discovery of ways of determining growth and mortality rates in some pelagic marine species; discovery of a sedimentary record allowing the reconstruction of a calendar of prehistorical oceanographic and biological events, and the development of a number of instruments, in particular deep-moored unmanned instrument stations.

Italians voted today in the first of two days of regional and municipal elections in which the Communists are trying to reverse a two-year-old trend against them. At stake are municipal councils in 6,575 of Italy's approximately 8,000 cities and towns and the governments in most of the country's regions and provinces. The elections may also decide whether the Government of Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga will survive.

In the foreword to ''White House Years'' Henry Kissinger wrote: ''Treatment of classified materials in this book has been worked out with the office of the national security adviser, Dr. Zbigniew Brzezinski, to whom I express my appreciation.'' The acknowledgment seemed routine. It was not. The passage caught the eye of a publisher, Robert L. Bernstein, president of Random House. He wrote Brzezinski and asked ''how the clearing of the Kissinger book was actually accomplished.'' The Staff Secretary of the National Security Council, Christine Dodson, replied:

Mattel Inc., well known as a toy company, has introduced from its electronics division a ''thoroughbred horse race analyzer,'' calculated to make picking horses fun - and profitable. The gadget, which will sell for $100 when put on sale soon at Bloomingdale's in Manhattan, provides its picks for any given race when fed such information as a horse's earnings, past performances and The Daily Racing Form's speed ratings.

WHEN you see Fresh Start, the new heavy-duty detergent from Colgate-Palmolive, and Fresh Start advertising, realize this -you are looking at the results of the best research, product development and marketing that this major package-goods company has ever put behind a budding brand. And the tender loving care is beginning to show results. The product, already available in much of the country, has just been brought to market in the company's New York, New England and Atlanta regions, backed by Colgate's largest advertising and sampling programs ever. It has already racked up market shares as high as 10 percent in some areas, although the average has been 5 percent.

An Israeli yeshiva student has been arrested in possession of explosive detonators, an Israeli official revealed today. The young man, about 20 years old, was not identified but was said to be a friend of the two soldiers who were charged last month with storing explosives on the roof of a religious school here. The student was arrested in the wake of bombing attacks last week on three Palestinian Mayors and other Arabs in the occupied West Bank. However, he did not appear to be part of the right-wing Kach movement, led by Rabbi Meir Kahane, which has advocated terrorism against Arabs.

To the Editor: William Safire writes in his June 2 column (''Turning Whose Tide?'') that President Carter is being ludicrously optimistic by suggesting that the nation is now ''turning the corner'' on most of its ills. {resident} Carter's claims strike me as analogous to those of the New York Mets, who, despite another dismal season, steadfastly maintain that ''the magic is back.'' Baseball fans are not buying the Mets' promotional hype, as Shea Stadium attendance figures attest.

Gayle Suzette Shulman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Shulman of Bayonne, N.J., and Dr. Stuart Mark Greenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul H. Greenstein of Brooklyn, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at Temple Beth Shalom in Lawrence, L.I., by Rabbis H.Z. Rappaport, the bride's uncle; Joseph Singer, Isaac Mintz, Alvin Harris and Baruch Ben-Haim. The bride, a summa cum laude graduate of St. Peter's College in Jersey City, plans to begin studies at the New Jersey College of Medicine in September. Dr. Shulman is a urologist.

Kathryn Leonore Schwebel, who received a bachelor's degree in education summa cum laude May 19 from the University of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday afternoon to Ronald B. Woods of Havertown, Pa., a professor of physical education at West Chester (Pa.) State College.

WASHINGTON, June 8 (Reuters) The Federal Reserve Board recommended that the Commodity Futures Trading Commission approve the New York Futures Exchange application to trade futures contracts in long-term Treasury bonds and three-month Treasury bills.
The credit markets' recent forceful move toward higher fixed-income security prices and lower interest rates is likely to continue this week, many bond dealers and investors believe.
"XIAN," pronounced chee-an, is a Northern Chinese city that once served as capital of an empire. It is the sub ject of a documentary made by Sue Yung Li and Shirley Sun, American film makers.

"A DAY With Conrad Green" was written more than 50 years ago by that master of acerbic short stories, Ring Lardner, and it should make you laugh tonight at 8 o'clock on WNET-TV in its television version by Israel Horovitz, the playwright.

In bright sunshine and then through a tumultuous downpour, Puerto Ricans of all ages marched and cheered on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon as they celebrated the 22d annual Puerto Rican Day parade, a lively event savored by politicians as well as other spectators.
MONTREAL, June 8 (UPI) Ken Boyer, unable to turn St. Louis's offensive power into victories, was dismissed as manager of the Cardinals and replaced by Whitey Herzog today.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) The Senate this week will try to cut off the filibuster stalling a vote on President Carter's plan to register 4 million men for a possible draft.

AT CINCINNATI Charlie Leibrandt of the Reds and Randy Jones of the Padres staged a pitching duel that was won by the 23-year-old left-handed Cincinnati rookie. Leibrandt (5-3) allowed only three hits as he turned in his second shutout and his third completegame victory of the season.

MERLE HAGGARD is one of the most successful singer-songwriters in the country-music field, but as his one-night stand at the Lone Star Cafe on Thursday demonstrated, he is much more than that. The more successful Mr. Haggard has become, the more he has grown musically, and the more interested he has become in the roots of contemporary country music. He has recorded tributes to Jimmie Rodgers, the celebrated blues yodeler and the first big country-music star; to Bob Wills, the most popular exponent of that potent country-jazz hybrid called western swing, and to Hank Williams and Lefty Frizzell, the honky-tonk heroes of the 40's and early 50's. Each of these figures, and their musical idioms, have left their mark on Mr. Haggard's singing, and on the music played by his remarkable band.

A 44-year-old man was fatally stabbed aboard a New York City bus carrying a score of passengers on Manhattan's East Side Saturday night in an argument with an assailant who fled with a female companion. Nearly 20 passengers were believed to have witnessed the slaying, but all left the bus and disappeared, the police said. Investigators, whose only account was provided by the bus driver, who sped the victim nine blocks to Lenox Hill Hospital, appealed yesterday for the passengers to come forward with information on the stabbing. Witnesses were urged to call a special number, 477-7429, and were promised confidentiality.

Never forget the admiration with which we in Britain regard America. When the chips are down - and they are down now -we stand by you as allies should. In Britain we have now a Prime Minister, a woman who has the qualities which men are supposed to have but frequently don't. She has guts, loyalty and indomitable Churchillian resolution. She will not let her ally down and in this she speaks for Britain. Of course we in Britain sometimes question American tactics, and on tactics there is bound to be some dispute. But never in Britain on the grand strategy of your policies. The vast majority of Europeans still look to America as the hope of the future. We in Britain have a tough time in the European Community and this happens precisely because we have a common tradition with the United States. That tradition is the rule of law. In Britain as in America no one, President or Queen, Senator or Cabinet Minister, is above the law. On the Continent of Europe too often the law is regarded as yet another arm of the state. In Europe, they have ministers of justice who appoint the judges; you have a Supreme Court and our law lords are chosen by the judiciary themselves. It makes a difference.

Behind the leadership of a dynamic Baptist pastor, evangelical Protestants operating under the banner of Moral Majority of Alaska have seized control of Alaska's Republican Party. Delegations of Moral Majority members showed up unexpectedly at party district caucuses in February and elected a large majority of delegates to the state Republican convention, who made sure that Moral Majority's candidate, Ronald Reagan, won all 19 of the state's delegates to the party's national convention.

FOR MONDAY ''A Day With Conrad Green'' was written more than 50 years ago by that master of acerbic short stories, Ring Lardner, and it should make you laugh tonight at 8 in its television version by Israel Horovitz, the contemporary playwright. It is a story about a Broadway producer named Green whose quintessential right arm, a nonentity of a man who just did all the work, has died. His funeral is to be held that afternoon. During the day, Green, played with lugubrious humor by Fred Gwynne, has ample opportunity to display his duplicity, corruption, spinelessness and hypocrisy. Other than that, he's just another big-time producer, living richly although broke.

The Carter Administration's continued emphasis on curbing the rate of price increases despite the prospect of a deeper recession is adding to the debate over economic policy. As these policies become involved in the Presidential campaign, the President's rivals call for increased attention to joblessness. Some economists expect a shift in policy by mid-year. (Page A1.) Layoffs are spreading to a broad range of industries as the recession takes hold, and there are predictions that by year's end the unemployment rate could be 9 percent or more. A number of the layoffs come as a result of the ripple effects from the slump in housing and automobiles. (D1.)

The Toyota Motor Sales Company, the United States sales arm of Japan's largest auto maker, said that Toyota had no current plans to build an assembly facility in Canada. A spokesman for the company said Friday that ''feasibility studies under way were designed to help us make an assessment of financial and economical viability in building a manufacturing plant in the United States'' and stressed that Canada was not covered in the investigation. The spokesman clarified a statement made in a speech Wednesday by Toyota's chairman, Seishi Kato.

A funny thing happened at the Kingdome tonight. The Seattle Mariners scored against the Yankees. They also came up with an extra-base hit for the first time in the three-game series. But the most important happening was that after suffering two straight shutouts at the hands of New York, the Mariners bounced back with a 5-0 shutout of their own. Glenn Abbott, who hadn't pitched since last May 24 when he came down with a strained tricep in his right throwing arm, stopped the Yankees on six hits and won his fifth game against two defeats. The Yankees' ace left-hander, Ron Guidry, was the victim of the aroused Mariners.

Beginning July 18, crates used for shipping dogs and cats must have more ventilation holes than they do now, the Agriculture Department has announced. The department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service will require shipping crates to have enough openings to provide for at least 14 percent ventilation, as against the current 8 percent standard.

Under partly cloudy skies, the world's largest solar-cell power system was dedicated yesterday in the desert of southeastern Utah. Backup diesel generators supplying power to the park, 38 miles from the nearest power line, were shut off, and for a few moments the 300 people attending the dedication enjoyed the silence.

Three Brooklyn boys drowned Saturday evening in the Ridgewood Reservoir in Queens, the police said. Their bodies were recovered by scuba divers at 6 P.M. after the police had been summoned by people who saw the boys struggling in the water. The victims were identified as 8-year-old Jo-Jo Henderson, his 12-year-old brother, Larry, and their 6-year-old cousin, Quillis Mayhand, all of the Brownsville section. According to the police, the two younger boys had encountered difficulty swimming, which is prohibited in the reservoir, and the third youth drowned in an apparent attempt to assist the others.

Lynn McGlothen, a 30-year-old right-hander, started 29 games and worked 212 innings for the Chicago Cubs in 1979. The Cubs' press guide for 1980 describes him as ''one of the workhorses of the pitching corps.'' But this season, McGlothen did not start once in May, and yesterday in Philadelphia he opened a game for only the fourth time this season. The result was one of his finer efforts. McGlothen allowed only six hits before he needed relief help from Bruce Sutter in the ninth inning to maintain a shutout as the Cubs won, 2-0.

PROPONENT To the Editor: Elias Schwarzbart's assertion in his June 2 letter, ''The MX's Crucial Role in the 'Balance of Terror,' '' that ''it is no longer disputed that the SS-18's give Russia the pre-emptive ability to destroy our land-based missiles'' is factually wrong and reflects an irresponsibly injudicious analysis of the known facts: Based on secret, and therefore unverifiable, intelligence gleaned from monitoring Soviet ICBM tests, the United States Department of Defense assigned to the warhead of the SS-18 values of explosive yield, accuracy and reliability which, if true, would in theory give it a 64 percent probability to destroy a Minuteman silo. Since considerable uncertainty is unavoidably inherent in estimates of Soviet warhead performance, the actual probability may be substantially smaller.

Willy Carson of Scotland maintained his winning streak today aboard Policeman, a 54-1 shot, in the one-and-a-half-mile Prix du Jockey Club, the French Derby worth about $463,000. Carson, fresh from victories at Epsom, England, in the English Derby Stakes and the English Oaks with Henbit and Bireme, respectively, took his mount to the lead in the far turn and won by one and a half lengths over the Aga Khan's Shakapour, ridden by Yves St. Martin.

Ken Boyer, unable to turn St. Louis's offensive power into victories, was dismissed as manager of the Cardinals and replaced by Whitey Herzog today. The announcement of Boyer's dismissal came after the Cards lost the first game of a doubleheader, 6-4, to the Expos. Montreal won the second game, 9-4, sending the Cards to their 22d loss in the last 27 games.

WASHINGTON, June 8--Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie indicated today that the Administration might be lenient with the group of 10 Americans, including former Attorney General Ramsey Clark, who traveled to Teheran in violation of a Presidential ban.
Larry Vogel, the publisher of such standards as "Melancholy Baby" and "Shine On Harvest Moon," died Thursday after a week's illness in the Kingsbridge Nursing Home in the Bronx. He was 84 years old.
WHEN his name was put on the leader boards during the 1967 United States Open at Baltusrol, almost nobody knew who he was.

In a potentially important test of their cohesiveness, the leaders of a coalition of New York City's uniformed workers will meet today to consider a proposal by the new police union president that they delay any strike until the start of the Democratic National Convention at Madison Square Garden in mid-August.

WASHINGTON, June 8 The Carter Administration's policy toward the Cuban refugees, according to outsiders who have followed its evolution, resembles some of the frail refugee boats in that it is sometimes subject to the stormy whims of President Fidel Castro and, at other times, seems to drift along precariously.
WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) More than a year after President Carter's first standby gasoline rationing plan was defeated in Congress, the Administration is finally ready to try again.
OPHRA, Israeli-Occupied West Bank, June 8 Eldad Harel, a Jewish high school student who lives with his family in this well-fortified outpost north of Jerusalem, has an Arab friend.
ROME, June 8 Italians voted today in the first of two days of regional and municipal elections in which the Communists are trying to reverse a two-year-old trend against them.

If you catch a fish that you think might be eligible for a record, you must first fill out an International Game Fishing Association record application form. These forms are kept on hand by some tackle shops and fishing clubs.
POSING AS DELIVERYMEN By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

FOR all of his basketball life Carl Nicks has been performing in somebody's shadow. In high school in Chicago the spotlight was on Ronnie Lester, from a rival team. In Nicks's junior year of college, at Indiana State in 1978-79, his teammate, Larry Bird, was the player that everybody knew and came to watch, although Nicks averaged 19.6 points a game and helped his team become runner-up for the national championship. During his senior season, Nicks averaged 26.7 points, but Indiana State had a 16-11 won-lost record, failing to receive a postseason tournament bid. Going into tomorrow's National Basketball Association college draft, Nicks again finds himself overshadowed by at least half a dozen outstanding and more publicized guards, but he could still emerge as a late first-round or early second-round choice.
BOBBY UNSER VOCTOR; RUTHERFORD SECOND

Jennifer Lee and Robert E. Pachner were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles W. Pachner of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yin Lee of Taipei, Taiwan, where her father is a textile manufacturer and her mother is a physician. The bride is an underwriter in the special-risk department of the American International Insurance Group. The president of the Atlantic Richfield Company, Thornton F. Bradshaw, forecast increased United States dependence on foreign oil in the 1980's and said America must face political realities in the Middle East.

If the visiting Methodists from Texas were wondering why their brethren were singing with such gusto yesterday morning in the little white church six miles down a county road from Fordyce, Ark., the Rev. Clinton M. Atchley quickly let them know. ''I guess you're aware,'' Mr. Atchley told his congregation and a visiting group from Texas, ''that Temperence Hill, the horse named after our church, has won the Belmont Stakes.''

ROOMS? Why does the Justice Department object so passionately to the idea of letting lawyers accompany their clients into grand jury rooms? Answer: The Mob. The department fears that in organized crime and perhaps corporate crime investigations, the lawyer won't be the witness's mouthpiece but a company agent bent on keeping the witness quiet when he wants to come clean.

The people who say they are willing to pay Muhammad Ali a total of $20 million for fights with Bernardo Mercado and Larry Holmes have not yet paid him his promised $250,000 deposit, a member of the former heavyweight champion's entourage said yesterday. The Ali spokesman, who did not wish to be identified, said only $100,000 had been delivered. The deadline for the first deposit, which Ali could keep even if he changed his mind and remained in retirement, was June 3.

The United States dollar continued to lose ground against the Japanese yen today, opening on the Tokyo foreign exchange market at 219.00 yen, drown from Friday's close of 220.10. The dollar, which had lost value for three straight days before the weekend, continued to slipped to 218.50 yen in early trading.
PRICES By MOLLY IVINS

EVITA,'' the show about Argentina's Eva Peron, was named best musical of the 1979-80 theater season last night and ''Children of a Lesser God,'' about the relationship of a deaf woman and her therapist, was named best play as Broadway luminaries gathered at the Mark Hellinger Theater for the 34th annual Tony Awards presentation. ''Evita'' was the major winner, with seven awards in the category of musicals during the nearly two-hour ceremonies, televised nationally by CBS. It captured the Tony for best actress -Patti LuPone, in the title role, and best direction - by Harold Prince, who already had held the record for Tony's; this was his 14th. ''Evita'' also won awards for best book (by Tim Rice), best score (by Andrew Lloyd Webber) performance by a featured actor (Mandy Patinkin) and outstanding lighting (by David Hersey).

On a bright May morning, workers at the Tell Chocolate Company were turning out marshmallows when the sweet, sugary air in the Coney Island factory suddenly turned foul. ''It smelled like horses, lots and lots of horses,'' said Joyce Cohen, a worker at the plant. ''The workers came to me and complained,'' said Candido Arce, a factory supervisor. ''That room had the smell of a dung heap.'' What the candy makers were smelling was the biggest compost heap in New York City, which the city had placed next door to the chocolate factory and across the Boardwalk from a big stretch of beach.

OFF To the Editor: June 1 marks a truly deplorable event in the history of New York City: The Pothole Law went into effect. First, through inadequate procedures and lack of quality-control specifications for repairs by utility companies, the city permitted the streets to deteriorate into a condition similar to a moonscape. Now it has decided to escape the rising damage claims resulting from this condition by denying its liability.

SANTO TOWN, Espiritu Santo, June 8 (AP) "We don't want violence," says Jimmy Stevens, the leader of a group of rebels on this South Pacific island who are seeking autonomy from the rest of the New Hebrides.

In Louisville, Ky., the General Electric Company said last week that it was laying off about 400 white-collar workers at its big Appliance Park operation. And more cuts are in the offing: 3,700 production employees are slated to be let go in July.

WASHINGTON, June 8 President Carter sent a letter to President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today suggesting a formula for the resumption of the suspended Egyptian-Israeli negotiations for Palestinian self-rule in the occupied Gaza Strip, and West Bank of the Jordan River, Administration officials said.

PARIS, June 8 (Reuters) Sweden's inflation rate probably will jump to about 12 percent this year from 7 percent last year, the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development forecast in its annual report on the Swedish economy.
SEATTLE, June 8 A funny thing happened at the Kingdome tonight. The Seattle Mariners scored against the Yankees.

THE third annual Salute to Women in Jazz, which ended its eight-day run yesterday with a day-long outdoor concert at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, offered on Saturday evening a sampler of the work of women jazz musicians leading their own groups at a concert at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street.

A group of private sanitation carters said yesterday that minorities would be given at least 55 percent of the jobs covered by a new city contract for private carters to pick up garbage in residential areas of the city.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 8 "Killer" is a popular game for an increasing number of students in colleges as far west as the University of California at Los Angeles and as far east as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The strategy of the game is "to kill"; the novelty of it is that each player is simultaneously assassin and victim.

LIMA, June 8 (Reuters) Petroperu, the state oil concern, will start a joint venture with the Occidental Petroleum Corporation of the United States and Bridas of Argentina, Peru's Energy and Mines Minister said.

NEW DELHI, June 8 (Reuter) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi swore in three Cabinet ministers for her fivemonth-old Government today, including Vidya Charan Shukla, one of the most controversial figures of her previous Government.

Governor Carey and key state legislators of both parties have agreed on a bill that would make the courts - rather than state psychiatric hospitals - responsible for the custody of people found not guilty of crimes because of insanity. At present, such people need court approval for release, but most of the conditions of their custody - such as transfers, degrees of confinement and care after release - are decided by state psychiatrists. The new bill would require a minimum initial confinement of six months in a secure facility and would involve the court in the whole range of custody decisions.

Halfway through the outdoor season, American track and field athletes have yet to set any world records in Olympic events. But a more significant yardstick of the state of the sport in the United States may have emerged from the youth and depth that highlighted the final day of competition yesterday at the National Collegiate outdoor championships.

EXCEPT for her appearance at American Ballet Theater's 40th anniversary gala, Gelsey Kirkland has not danced with the company in a year. On Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, she came back as a guest in a stunning performance, a local debut in Jerome Robbins's ''Other Dances.'' She is the perfect Robbins dancer -she knows how to play with the gesture implied in the choreography and in this instance, she made her role one beautiful sigh. Her line became highly elongated, the movement was often slowly stretched. And yet this extreme silhouette could meld into a series of detailed small shifts in speed - in her first solo, Miss Kirkland seemed to be playing with an imagined shadow. Along the way, she swept her partner, Anthony Dowell into this world of make-believe. A sublime partnership.

There are still awed murmurs from the audience when the curtain goes up on the gem-strewn sets for George Balanchine's ''Jewels,'' 13 years after its premiere. The ''Emeralds''section glowed, ''Rubies'' twinkled and ''Diamonds'' burned with cold fire, as usual, on Tuesday when the New York City Ballet performed the ballet at the New York State Theater. A season without ''Jewels'' would probably not be a season for many City Ballet fans, for Mr. Balanchine has fashioned a classic that remains a tremendous crowd-pleaser. This is a crowd-pleaser, however, whose elements are endlessly touching and surprising, given the kind of performance it received on Tuesday. The odd ordering of dances in ''Emeralds'' has the initial effect of isolating it and the viewer from remembered form, so that by the time Karin von Aroldingen and Joseph Duell pick their way through their grave and dreaming walk, so much an evocation of the gentle Faure score, we are prepared to experience it as a major, though quiet, moment of ballet. Kyra Nichols caught the music's veiled lyricism and Gerald Ebitz got full romantic measure from his role as cavalier. Squiring Bonita and Elyse Borne, Jean-Pierre Frohlich added a good note of incisive flash.

THE United States Steel Corporation, one of the most conservative of business organizations, has recently offered the most innovative bond issue in some time. Last month, while corporations were still reeling over the high cost of money, U.S. Steel offered $48 million worth of tax-exempt industrial revenue bonds designed to raise the necessary funds to clean the air around its Fairless works in Bucks County, Pa., and in Provo, Utah, where the company has a major smelter.
CITIES By JOHN HERBERS

THE American Ballet Theater honored Jerome Robbins with an all-Robbins program Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. It was a fitting tribute, for Mr. Robbins danced with the company from 1940 to 1948 and it was for Ballet Theater that he created his first ballet, ''Fancy Free,'' in 1944. Although he has been one of Ballet Theater's most important choreographers, the company has staged only six ballets by him over the years, four of which were on Tuesday's program: ''Interplay,'' ''Les Noces,'' ''Other Dances'' and ''Fancy Free,'' the two works by Mr. Robbins that are no longer in the repertory being ''Facsimile'' and ''Summer Day.''
