Karen Beth Lehman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Lehman of West Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Eric Brizel Gurwin, who received his medical degree last Tuesday from the New York Medical College. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gurwin of Kings Point, L.I. The ceremony was performed in Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J., by Rabbi Eli Pilchik, who officiated at the wedding of the bride's parents 25 years ago. Rabbi Barry Hewitt Greene assisted yesterday.

Henry A. Kissinger experienced a short fall from grace on Saturday night. As he took a seat on the stage of a St. Louis hotel, where he was to address the Illinois Bankers Association, one leg of his chair slipped off the rear edge of the platform. Mr. Kissinger disappeared backward through a blue curtain and fell two feet to the floor. After a glass of water and some aid and comfort from members of the audience, the former Secretary of State joked about his fall, delivered his speech and flew back to New York City. He went to the emergency room of New York Hospital for X-rays and an examination. Hospital officials said said he was treated for head trauma and released.

You'd never know it from the statements of the Administration's anti-inflation force, but another disturbingly large wage settlement was signed last week in a pace-setting industry. The powerful United Steelworkers and the smaller Aluminum Workers International struck a bargain with the nation's aluminum producers that will bring employees an annual wage increase of about 11 percent in each of the next three years, plus improved pension benefits for those already retired. Sadly, there is no longer even surprise at such news. With an election looming, President Carter's alleged and voluntary wage restraints have been so modified that the major union leaders can make themselves out to be both defenders of their members against inflation and patriotic inflation-fighters. It has happened now in chemicals, autos, steel and aluminum; indeed, it could have been worse. The aluminum companies are doing well despite the recession and their workers might have held out for even more.

The New York Mets faced the heady prospect yesterday of sweeping a four-game series with the world champion Pittsburgh Pirates. But after rallying to win the first game, 6-4, before a Banner Day doubleheader crowd of 29,329 at Shea Stadium, the Mets were stopped in the second game on a combined five-hitter by Eddie Solomon and Kent Tekulve and lost, 3-0. The defeat broke the Mets' four-game winning streak, which included three straight over the Pirates. The Mets have won 10 of their last 16 games.

XIAN,'' pronounced chee-an, is a Northern Chinese city that once served as capital of an empire. It is the subject of a documentary made by Sue Yung Li and Shirley Sun, American film makers. The hourlong program will be carried on WNET-TV, Channel 13, tonight at 9 o'clock. The Xian of the present retains a formal layout that reflects the care, including the detailed advice of an astrologer, that went into the creation of the city. The film, made last year, contains some perfunctory shots of residents, including the now-familiar scene of early-morning tai-chi exercises in a public square.

By John Leonard HOW WASHINGTON REALLY WORKS. By Charles Peters. Foreword by James David Barber. 146 pages. Addison-Wes- ley. Hardcover, $10.95. Paperback, $5.95. LITERARY talents as various and snide as Henry Adams, Gore Vidal and Allen Drury have written books about Washington, where the donkeys and the elephants consort. We should by now have some fix on the culture of our nation's capital. That we do not have such a fix - that Washington remains for most people as mysterious as the dismal science of economics and what went wrong at Machu Picchu - perhaps accounts for the increasing numbers of Americans who decline to vote. To whom are we sending a message? It is as if the mock-marble columns were decayed teeth in an ancient skull, behind which cats ate butterflies and nobody answered the telephone.

Bell Canada and the Canadian Government are preparing a major field test of a new two-way communications service using home television sets to link private users with a vast array of computerized information banks. The new service, called Vista, has already successfully completed a small pilot project and will begin an $11 million trial this fall with between 500 and 1,000 users in the cities of Toronto and Quebec. Using handheld keyboards the size of a pocket calculator, these individuals and businesses will have access through their TV sets to 75,000 pages of computerized information and services ranging from making dinner reservations and selling airline tickets to displaying metric conversion tables, video games and soap opera summaries.

The resignation of Joseph Hoffman as president of the Health and Hospitals Corporation can only result in more disarray for New York City's health programs. A former first deputy police commissioner, Mr. Hoffman held the job for only 17 months. He's quitting, it is said, because Mayor Koch plans to name a new, full-time board chairman who would outrank him as chief policy maker. Whether Mr. Hoffman was being too sensitive and the Mayor not sensitive enough are minor questions now. The revolving door to the hospitals keeps spinning, depriving the city and its ailing citizens of reliable management in a critical area. Mr. Hoffman's record is hard to measure. Just five months ago the Mayor rated it as only 6 on a scale of 10. Now he praises the man's ''magnificant job'' in averting financial disaster. The first judgment was crude; the second, probably overstated.

STABILIZED' UNITS ONLY By PETER KIHSS

Bjorn Borg, coping with the carefully designed game plan of his opponent, became the first player to win the French open tennis championship five times today, scoring a 6-4, 6-1, 6-2 victory in the final over Vitas Gerulaitis. A crowd of 18,000 at Roland Garros Stadium saw Gerulaitis continually try to get Borg away from the baseline by returning short and using drop shots. The tactic seemed to be working in the first set, when Gerulaitis won three straight games after being down by 5-1. But after his initial awkwardness, Borg turned Gerulaitis's plan against him by slamming winning volleys and chasing down his opponent's lobs.

In a self-analysis, the late multibillionaire financier, J. Paul Getty, commented that he might be considered a bad boss. ''A good boss develops successors,'' he said. ''There is nobody to step into my shoes.'' For at least three years after Mr. Getty's death in June 1976, the Getty Oil Corporation remained static as if, with Mr. Getty's death, the life had also gone out of his company. ''For a good many years, I don't think any decisions were made about the direction of the company,'' said Herbert Hart, an energy analyst for Bateman, Eichler, Hill, Richards Inc., San Francisco.

Alan Elkin got lost on his way to his new job at the bakery the other day. He had to take two buses to get there, and a friend had gone with him on two dry runs to make sure that he would get it right the third time. But he became confused, the world seemed to close in on him, and the landmarks weren't where they were supposed to be. He wound up in a fire station, crying. Mr. Elkin is 21 years old. He isn't physically handicapped, retarded or emotionally disturbed. But he is ''learning disabled'' - a catchall term for people who are generally bright but slightly brain-injured. These minor neurological dysfunctions can bring a horde of possible afflictions: The victims may hear or see in abnormal ways (Nelson Rockefeller was one of these: a dyslexic, he had trouble reading and spelling); they may not be able to do things in sequence; their logic is poor; they are easily distracted, hyperactive, sometimes excessively frightened or impulsively reckless. That is just a sampling of what it can be like to be a learning-disabled person.

The Western industrial nations need to strengthen their commitment to fight inflation and cut their dependence on imported oil by preparing to accept a long period of high unemployment, the Bank for International Settlements said in its latest annual report, which was released today. For the first time in several years, the bank's annual survey of the world economy endorses the general direction Western economic policy is now taking. The survey reflects the private thinking of the major Western central banks, which own the Bank for International Settlements.

The Administration changed its inflation control guidelines to reflect spiraling gold and silver prices. The Council on Wage and Price Stability announced it was altering the voluntary Government guidelines to allow jewelry makers and other producers of precious metal products to pass on some of the high cost of buying gold and silver. Under a complicated formula, companies that receive more than 1 percent of their revenues from the sale of gold and silver products will be allowed to raise prices.

Melinda L. Wagner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hymen V. Wagner of Fair Lawn, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to Municipal Court Judge David B. Rubin of New Brunswick, N.J. He is the son of Judge Irving W. Rubin of the Juvenile and Domestic Relations Court of Middlesex County, and Mrs. Rubin of New Brunswick. Rabbi Simon Glustrom of the Fair Lawn Jewish Center performed the ceremony at the Short Hills in Milburn, N.J. The bride, an alumna of Rutgers University, is in her second year at the School of Dentistry of Fairleigh Dickinson University. Her father is president of Media/Distribution Services Inc., a New York media service for the public-relations field. Her mother is secretarytreasurer of the company.

THE price of orange juice is declining as a result of abundant supplies even as the cost of that other breakfast beverage, coffee, is rising. To stimulate demand for orange juice in hopes of stabilizing the price, Florida's Citrus Department has begun to advertise coupons offering 15 cents off on a can of frozen orange juice.
CAMPAIGN EFFORT By KENNETH A. BRIGGS

The Senate this week will try to cut off the filibuster stalling a vote on President Carter's plan to register 4 million men for a possible draft. A bill to finance the draft registration plan has already been approved by the House, but Senate action is being blocked by Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, who is leading what he calls ''an extended debate'' on the measure.

Dedicated bicyclists interested in increasing their stamina and mileage on the road might want to consider a new machine that incorporates some sophisticated technology. The Facet BioCam 50-speed bicycle has substituted the conventional chain and gears with a cam-operated power transmission system. The system, called the BioCam Drive, is said to use leg power more efficiently and thus prolong stamina, particularly for the long-distance cyclist. Other features of the machine include a gear range extending from 30 to 150, or 50 percent higher than conventional drives, 50 distinct gear ratios, easier shifting, and, because of the manner in which the BioCam drive functions, reduced pedal resistance. The Facet BioCam 2000 weighs about 30 pounds and costs $1,900; the BioCam 1000 weighs about 32 pounds and costs $1,500. Both have frame sizes ranging from 52 to 64 centimeters, but there are variations in some of the other features. For information as to where the BioCam may be purchased, write to Facet Cycle Inc., Post Office Box 50129, 2929 East Apache, Tulsa, Okla. 74150, (800) 331-3896. Taxidermy Kits

I have observed over the years that there is more interest in members of the onion family than in any other form of vegetables or herbs. Perhaps it is because onion-related ingredients - garlic, chives, scallions and so on - are so indispensable in a vast majority of American kitchens. Years ago, someone philosophized that if onions were as scarce as truffles, they would be twice as sought after and more costly than the ''black diamonds.'' Magical and medical properties have also been ascribed to various members of the onion family, garlic in particular. One of the most curious interests that has crossed this desk in some time has to do with a wild herb known as a ramp, also called a wild leek.

It would be a pity to remember Henry Miller only as the man who made it possible for Americans to write about sex. If there had been no sex in ''Tropic of Cancer,'' Mr. Miller's first and best novel, it would have been an even better book. Leon Trotsky said about Louis-Ferdinand Celine, who influenced Mr. Miller, that he walked into literature the way most men walked into their living rooms. The same is true of Mr. Miller, who was one of the earliest American authors to perfect a vernacular, conversational style and to use it to write an impressionistic, anecdotal novel about a comic, antiheroic character. In ''Tropic of Cancer,'' we can hear Celine's ''Journey to the End of the Night,'' Dostoyevsky's ''Notes From the Underground,'' Walt Whitman and a smattering of Joyce and Rabelais.

Laura Ruth Grant, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner L. Grant of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Franklin Harrison Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Zimmerman of Beachwood, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk performed the ceremony at the Sunningdale Country Club.

Rabbi Milton Richman performed the ceremony at the Westmoreland Club in Wilkes-Barre, Pa. She studied also at the University of Siena in Italy and attended the Sotheby's Works of Art Course in London. Her father is a lawyer with the Pennsylvania Life Insurance Company.

President Carter sent a letter to President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today suggesting a formula for the resumption of the suspended Egyptian-Israeli negotiations for Palestinian selfrule in the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank of the Jordan River, Administration officials said. According to the officials, if Mr. Sadat responds affirmatively to Mr. Carter's message, Sol M. Linowitz, the special envoy for Middle East negotiations, will invite the heads of the Egyptian and Israeli delegations to Washington to agree on a framework for completing the accord.

THE primary point of interest at the second Basically Bach concert, which took place in Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night, was the performance of Vivaldi's Gloria for chorus and orchestra. Although Vivaldi's large body of sacred choral music has been widely circulated on recordings in recent years, it has not made much headway in the concert hall compared with the general currency given the composer's even more numerous concertos. Vivaldi's style is just as unmistakable in his vocal music as in his instrumental works. There is the same driving rhythmic energy, simple but immediately arresting thematic material and effectively planned dramatic contrasts - all handled in the most direct and exuberant fashion. Perhaps these scores lack the fascinating complexity and capacity for endless rediscovery that one finds in the choral music of Bach, Vivaldi's contemporary in Germany, but such infectious music hardly deserves the neglect it has suffered over the past couple of centuries.

To the Editor: The United Nations playground at 42d Street and First Avenue is a public playground in an area that is already congested and overbuilt. Tudor City residents need their parks, but the other residents of the community, especially the young, require the United Nations playground.$ Midtown Manhattan is a wasteland as far as youth recreation goes. At this playground, a growing tradition of youth sports is emerging. It should not be destroyed by the proposed swap. Tradition in our city should not be confined to insular communities. JACK COLLINS New York, June 2, 1980

The Cosmos got their act together at home today prior to taking it on the road. With their most impressive performance of the season, the Cosmos routed the Atlanta Chiefs, 6-0, before 35,007 fans at Giants Stadium. The Cosmos' next three North American Soccer League games will be on the road, starting against Rochester on Wednesday night. ''The way we played today we could beat anyone,'' said Hennes Weisweiler, who remained undefeated as the Cosmos' coach after seven N.A.S.L. games. His streak is 10 games over all, counting the three games in the Trans-Atlantic Challenge Cup series. The Cosmos have a 10-2 won-lost record over all in the N.A.S.L.

Artificial moves always look as if they should meet with an easy refutation, but there are times when brilliant play is needed to prove them wrong. In the game between the Grandmasters Gyula Sax of Hungary and Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia in the Phillips & Drew Kings International Tournament in London, it took sizzling play by Black to reveal the flaw in the artificial 5 B-Q3.

For two and a half days, the more than 600 delegates to the first White House Conference on Families in Baltimore debated, studied, wrote proposals, circulated petitions, drew up minority reports and devised amendments to innumerable resolutions. They met in formal workshops to do assigned work and in hastily convened caucuses to devise strategy for feminist, minority labor and and youth interests. And when it was all over late Saturday afternoon, they had hammered out, in a reasonably harmonious manner, a 57-point plan of action for ways in which the Government, by direct and indirect action, could help the beleaguered American family cope with contemporary problems. As one New York delegate, Mary Bighorse, said, ''I came expecting a lot more controversy because people feel so strongly about the issues. But it's been very quiet.'' Inflation, like beauty, is in the eye of the beholder. That is the conclusion of some West German economists who say that Germany's remarkably low inflation rate, a startling comparison with that of the United States, is in part cosmetic. Using the same yardstick as the United States, and juggling the basket of consumer goods on which the country's consumer price index is based, they say West Germany's rate of inflation, rather than hovering at the modest 5 to 6 percent reported officially, might actually be a volatile 12 or 13 percent.

Queens detectives said yesterday that they had had no success so far in checking a few leads produced in their investigation of the fatal stabbing early Saturday of a patient in her bed at La Guardia Hospital in Forest Hills. Detective Owen Kelly said there was ''nothing solid'' to go on in the search for the knife-wielding 6-foot-tall intruder who killed 27-year-old Carol Jurlando in her bed on the sixth floor of the hospital. Mrs. Jurlando lived with her husband, Thomas, and their four children on 97th Avenue in Ozone Park, Queens. She had been admitted Wednesday after complaining of abdominal pains.

Just as an unexpected auto repair or doctor's bill can wreak havoc with a family's finances, so an almost infinite variety of unexpected events can disrupt the most carefully laid budget plans of the President and Congress. Both branches of the Government have been in agreement since March that the budget for the fiscal year 1981, which starts Oct. 1, should be balanced. Yet, even as House-Senate conferees tried last week to revise the balanced budget rejected by the House, events seemed to presage more spending than planned in 1981 and even in the few remaining months of the fiscal year 1980, which ends Sept. 30.
CUBANS APPARENTLY DEPENDS IN FUTURE N MOVES BY CASTRO By ROBERT PEAR

WHEN his name was put on the leader boards during the 1967 United States Open at Baltusrol, almost nobody knew who he was. ''Lee Trevino,'' he was identified in the list of starting times. ''Horizon Hills C.C., El Paso, Tex.'' New names always emerge in the Open, as they surely will when the world's most prestigious golf tournament returns to the Baltusrol Golf Club in Springfield, N.J., this week. But in 1967 this talkative Texan, then 27 years old, was also a new story. He had not intended to enter the Open, but his wife, Claudia, filled out the application and enclosed a $20 check to cover the entry fee. At the time $20 was a lot of money in the Trevino budget considering that his salary as the Horizon Hills pro was $30 a week.

If you catch a fish that you think might be eligible for a record, you must first fill out an International Game Fishing Association record application form. These forms are kept on hand by some tackle shops and fishing clubs. They may also be obtained from the association at 3000 Las Olas Boulevard, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 33136, telephone (305) 467-0161. The association requires a witness to the catch and another to the weighing. A photograph of the angler, his fish and the rod and reel he used is required, as well as one of the scales used to weigh the fish. In general, truly large fish such as bluefin tuna or blue marlin are photographed in a hanging position with the angler standing by with rod and reel in hand. Smaller fish are often photographed horizontal in front of the angler. In all instances the fish should be broadside to the camera and its fins extended.

Larry Nelson, playing before a cheering crowd of friends, neighbors, and family, shot a five-under-par 67 today and scored a seven-stroke victory in the Atlanta Golf Classic. The 32-year-old Nelson from nearby Acworth, Ga., posted the third victory of his career on the PGA Tour with a 72-hole total of 270, 18 strokes under par on the 6,945-yard Atlanta Country Club course.

The islands are to be granted independence July 30 after 74 years of being jointly administered by France and Britain.

They are not criminals, she says, not kidnappers or assassins. What they are is Iranian. {oor} Jaleh Poorooshasb! She is Iranian, but she is allowed to get her education at one of the most prestigious universities in the world, and she plans to join a Boston consulting firm. She has complete freedom to go and come as she likes, even to go to Canada to see her parents, who cannot come to see her here.

Asked by the Government to leave their automobiles at home today, West Germans did not. If the choice was a defeat for a kind of flashy environmentalism, it was also a victory over suggestions from above, a little referendum in favor of not doing what the Man says. In Munich, a small group of people shouted, ''Motor off, motor off!'' at cars, but drivers honked back, drowning out the voices. In Frankfurt, the extra personnel put on by the state railroad at the main station had nothing to do. And on the Rhine, a 20-minute forced march away from the Interior Ministry, where the Autoless Sunday plan got its official support, the ticket taker at the @Konigswinter-Mehlem car ferry said traffic was normal for a weekend, maybe even a little heavy because ''a lot of them must be thinking, 'Today I make very good time.' ''

T HE third annual Salute to Women in Jazz, which ended its eight-day run yesterday with a daylong outdoor concert at Damrosch Park in Lincoln Center, offered on Saturday evening a sampler of the work of women jazz musicians leading their own groups at a concert at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. One of the objectives of this concert, according to Cobi Narita, the producer of the Salute, was to demonstrate the variety found among women in jazz. The performers ranged from Ravella Hughes, an 85-year-old organist and pianist who recorded for the all-Black Swan record company in the 1920's, to Erica Lindsay, a saxophonist in her 20's who has just joined Melba Liston's group.

Roy P.M. Carlson, 57 years old, who last December became president and chief executive officer of the National Bank of Georgia, has also become its chairman after the retirement of John H. Stembler at the mandatory age of 67. The bank was once headed by Bert Lance, later the Federal budget director for a while. Mr. Carlson, who used to be a Bank of America official, gave a couple of clues on his approach to stimulating business at the Georgia bank. ''We see ourselves as well-equipped to handle a larger volume of commercial business, particularly companies in the small to mediumsize class,'' he said. ''We'll be going after these companies actively.''

The unexpectedly bad news about unemployment and unexpectedly good news about inflation in the last two months has intensified the debate over the Carter Administration's continued emphasis on curbing inflation at the risk of more severe recession. The steepness of the unfolding recession has also encouraged criticism of past Carter economic policies, which have included a number of policy reversals and a tough anti-inflation package imposed on March 14, just as the recession was beginning.

THERE are still awed murmurs from the audience when the curtain goes up on the gemstrewn sets for George Balanchine's "Jewels," 13 years after its premiere.
THE primary point of interest at the second Basically Bach con cert, which took place in Avery Fisher Hall on Saturday night, was the performance of Vivaldi's Gloria for chorus and orchestra.

A pair of Long Islanders, Tom Agresta of Chappaqua and Tom Childers of Westbury crossed the finish line together in the men's division, and Sharon Barbano of Yonkers was the runaway winner in the women's division yesterday in the Manufacturers Hanover Queens classic fivemile run in Flushing Meadow Park. Although Agresta and Childers crossed the finish line raising each other's arms in victory, the New York Road Runners Club officials awarded the first-place trophy to the 23-year-old Agresta, who was timed in 24 minutes 32.0 seconds. Childers was clocked in 24:32.1. The race attracted a field of 1,527 runners.

A record $1.8 billion of new tax-exempt bonds and some $1.6 billion of corporate bonds were sold to investors last week along with $14.2 billion of Treasury bills and notes and $2 billion of Federal National Mortgage Association securities. This was a formidable pace for the money and capital markets, but by Friday, most of these securities were trading above their original prices and dealers were optimistic that they could sell another heavy volume of new issues this week. In the corporate market last Friday, the volume of new-issue financing this week was projected at about $1.3 billion, but investment bankers said this amount might increase if investors remain as receptive as they have been for the past three weeks. Last week, they noted, the J.C. Penney Company announced $300 million on Tuesday and raised $350 million on Friday, and more financing could be completed quickly.

In the summer of 1978, when a day-care program was set up in the downtown Y.W.C.A. for the children of the chemically contaminated Love Canal neighborhood, the director of the program, Linda Forster, thought that many of them seemed ''shy, disoriented, bitter toward Hooker Chemical Company and the chemical industry in general.'' Last summer, as earthmovers worked to clear the chemical waste that had been dumped by Hooker years ago, the day-care center was opened again, this time for preschool children.

Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. said it had won a $50 million order from the Brazilian state-run oil company, Petrobras, for an oil-drilling rig. Construction is scheduled to begin in May 1982 in Campos Fields, off Rio de Janeiro, the company said.

It takes Graham North about half an hour to commute to his workplace, but it is no ordinary journey. It starts in a dark grubby cage that plunges 800 feet into the earth. He is stuffed into it with a dozen other miners from the Frickley-South Elmsall coal pit in this corner of England where he has worked for 23 years, since he was 15. He emerges in a world of long dark passages where the black earth is covered with gray ash, where walls of solid rock leave little room to move. He walks for about 10 minutes hunched over, careful not to bump his head against low steel beams that keep thousands of tons of rock from crashing down.

The British Government is moving toward one of the most important military decisions in the country's postwar history: whether to remain a competitive nuclear power through the purchase of Trident I submarine-launched missiles from the United States and the construction of four or possibly five new submarines to carry them. The United States Secretary of Defense, Harold Brown, in talks last Monday with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, left the impression that the deal for the missiles could be completed within months.

Killer'' is a popular game for an increasing number of students in colleges as far west as the University of California at Los Angeles and as far east as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The strategy of the game is ''to kill''; the novelty of it is that each player is simultaneously assassin and victim. ''Killer'' was introduced at the University of Michigan four years ago by Lenny Pape, a mathematics student who nurtured the game in his high school years at the Roeper City and Country School for Gifted Children in Bloomfield Hills. According to Robert Cantor, the current game executioner, or coordinator, at the university, requests for the rules have come in from schools across the nation.

Degrees were conferred yesterday on 2,000 graduates of the City College during ceremonies in which an official of Amnesty International urged them to seek ''the greater respect for the human dignity of individuals, groups and nations.'' Speaking at the South Campus Field at Convent Avenue and 133d Street, in Harlem, the official, Fernando Zalaquett Daher, said: ''You graduates of the City College are needed to join the many other young people who take an active role in these key issues of the world community.''

As a cannon signaled the start of the 11th annual Great Delaware River Raft Race here at 8:42 this morning, 71 captains sprinted down the cliffs to the beach. They leaped onto brightly colored rafts along the shoreline and their waiting crews began to pedal and row down the 24-mile course to Martin's Creek, Pa. In mist and fog, captains and crews took their positions. Some crews powered their crafts by rowing and others pedaled to turn paddle wheels mounted on the sides or sterns of the rafts. Rafts in the Class A category were mounted on one pontoon, built from a single row of 55-gallon drums. Rafts in the second category, or Class B, were mounted on two such rows of drums.

REPUTATIONS have a way of hanging on long after they have parted company with the reality that originally gave rise to them. For years to come John McEnroe will be perceived as a brat, no matter what he does to shake the image. Stock-car racers will be labeled ''good ol' boys'' even though a literate Yankee woman joined their ranks years ago. Some fans persisted in perceiving Jack Nicklaus as a Teutonic ''Ohio Fats'' long after he had slimmed down. Others believe Arnold Palmer will win again. Severiano Ballesteros, who in April, at age 23, became the youngest golfer to win the Masters, is Spain's equivalent of Tom Watson, and yet despite his record, envious opponents say Ballesteros is merely lucky.

In bright sunshine and then through a tumultuous downpour, Puerto Ricans of all ages marched and cheered on Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon as they celebrated the 22d annual Puerto Rican Day parade, a lively event savored by politicians as well as other spectators. Before families closely packed along Fifth Avenue from 44th Street to 86th Street, the procession started its way north just after noon. There were high school marching bands and beauty queens on floats, but what made the parade special was the distinctly Latin music of the bands, the disciplined squadrons of roller skaters and bicyclists, and a man on stilts named Tribilin.
Gayle Suzette Shulman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving Shulman of Bayonne, N.J., and Dr. Stuart Mark Greenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Saul H. Greenstein of Brooklyn, were married yesterday.

REPUTATIONS have a way of hanging on long after they have parted company with the reality that originally gave rise to them. For years to come John McEnroe will be perceived as a brat, no matter what he does to shake the image.
Why does the Justice Department object so passionately to the idea of letting lawyers accompany their clients into grand jury rooms?
THE United States Steel Corporation, one of the most conservative of business organizations, has recently offered the most innovative bond issue in some time.
TORONTO, June 8 (Reuters) An Air Canada 747 jumbo jet with 403 people aboard lost power in three of its four engines yesterday while preparing to land at Toronto International Airport.

If the visiting Methodists from Texas were wondering why their brethren were singing with such gusto yesterday morning in the little white church six miles down a county road from Fordyce, Ark., the Rev. Clinton M. Atchley quickly let them know.

ALGIERS, June 8 Members of the 13nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries began gathering here today for another attempt to set a single base price for oil and to ease some of the strains in the cartel.
Meets on South African situation at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY
WITH MRS. CHISOLM By FRANK LYNN

Little fir trees are springing back to life, reaching through volcanic mud and ash for sunlight near steaming Spirit Lake on the flank of Mount St. Helens, a geologist said today. Not far from the fir trees, Tim Hait of the United States Geological Survey said, cougar and deer tracks have been found, indicating that wildlife is filtering back into the 150-square-mile area that the volcano blanketed with ash.

Henry Miller, the Brooklyn-reared Bohemian writer whose bawdy, widely acclaimed 1934 novel, ''Tropic of Cancer,'' was banned in the United States until 1964, died Saturday at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 88 years old and had been suffering from circulatory ailments. As a writer and as a man, Henry Miller was an extraordinarily vigorous and intense individualist who happily and deliberately thumbed his nose at dozens of conventions and got away with it. He was so eager to express himself in words that he threw over his job and social respectability at the age of 33, determined ''never again to work for any man but to be my own master absolute.'' And he persisted in that resolve through years of penniless obscurity and poverty-stricken notoriety until he finally achieved, in the last decades of his life, a wide measure of recognition as a literary artist.

The following article is based on reporting by Carter B. Horsley and Paul L. Montgomery and was written by Mr. Montgomery. In a flurry of East Side real-estate transactions in the 22 months between his arrest for murder and his conviction, Howard (Buddy) Jacobson raised at least $1.2 million in cash that might have been available for his escape from prison nine days ago. Law-enforcement authorities, unsuccessfully seeking clues to Mr. Jacobson's flight since he assumed the false identity of a visitor and walked unmolested out of the Brooklyn House of Detention on May 31, are still trying to untangle all the threads of the millionaire's complex dealings. What has emerged so far is a picture of a meticulously planned escape, apparently known to only a few of his confidantes.

A group of private sanitation carters said yesterday that minorities would be given at least 55 percent of the jobs covered by a new city contract for private carters to pick up garbage in residential areas of the city.

Immaculate Heart College held its last graduation ceremony yesterday, marking the end of regular academic operations at the 64-year-old school. Because of financial problems, the school will officially close Aug. 31 after a limited summer session. The Hollywood college was founded by the Immaculate Heart Community, a Catholic teaching order, as a Catholic girls' school, but over the past 20 years it had become nonsectarian and coeducational.

Haruo Yasuda, a 37-year-old Japanese pro, captured the $113,600 Tohoku Classic golf tournament by two strokes today. Yasuda fired a six-under-par 66 for a 72-hole total of 273 on the West Sendai Country Club course. He had three birdies on the front nine and three more on the back.

Linda Irene Schaffer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Samuel Schaffer of Hartsdle, N.Y., and Leonard Otis Bell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Bell of Ardsley, N.Y., and Chilmark, Mass., were married yesterday. Rabbi Lyle Fishman and Rabbi Norton D. Shargell performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y. The bride, who graduated in May from Cornell University, will enter the dietetic internship program at the Yale-New Haven Hospital in September. Her father is a dentist and her mother is with the Day Travel Agency in Eastchester, N.Y.

The Love Canal evacuation order prompted by a Houston chromosome study came amid questions about the quality and scope of the study, and those questions have led to another: Why did neither state nor Federal environmental officials see fit earlier to do the type of comprehensive study they are now demanding? Public health officials talk of research expenses, inadequate proposals and lack of cooperation between various state and Federal agencies.

An interesting facet of Baltusrol history is the way Ed Furgol won the United States Open there on the final hole in 1954 - by reaching the 18th green of the Lower Course from the 18th fairway of the Upper Course. The approach was legal, and Furgol knew he was within his rights. It happened on the last day of the tournament on June 19. In those days the Open finished with 36 holes on Saturday. The setting then was the same as it is now - the 18th hole of the Lower Course, a par 5 of 542 yards, and the 18th of the Upper Course, a par 4 of 459 yards. The only difference is that the trees separating the two fairways are much taller now than they were then.

The zonal grand national team playoff match in Boston Saturday resulted in a comfortable triumph for New England over New York. Steve Ligas of Wollaston, Mass, Luke Gillespie of Wayland, Mass., Chet Davis of Arlington, Mass., M. Bennett of Hartford, Bart Bramley of Avon, Conn., and Merle Tom of Cos Cob, Conn., defeated a New York sextet headed by Bob Yellis of Great Neck, L.I., by 104 international match points. In the national quarterfinal in Chicago next month, New England will oppose a strong Florida team. The eventual winners of the event will be the first qualifiers for playoffs to determine the 1982 American world championship team.

The credit markets' recent forceful move toward higher fixedincome security prices and lower interest rates is likely to continue this week, many bond dealers and investors believe. The setback in the credit markets that lasted five trading days from May 27 through June 2 was much less pronounced than many investment bankers and money-market analysts had expected, and the decline brought to the surface a large amount of nascent demand for fixed-income issues. This demand, coupled with bad economic news and the suspicion that the Federal Reserve Board will encourage shortterm rates to decline still more this week, is the basis for the credit markets' current optimism.

The United States no longer can afford the pretension of ''exporting morality'' through aid and trade restrictions. We have so lost our competitiveness on the world market that we are faced with the simple choice of trade or fade. In the fervor of the post-Vietnam period, United States business has been saddled with a crippling variety of trade restrictions designed to enforce the observance of human rights, curb extortion and bribery abroad, protect the environment and effect a host of other single-issue social objectives. The punitive restrictions are applied to bilateral aid, the multinational agencies, investment guarantees, and credits vital for United States exports.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is expected to rule today on a proposal to vent radioactive gas to facilitate the cleanup at Three Mile Island. Experts on all sides of the nuclear debate agree that release of the krypton would pose no significant risk to anyone's physical health.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The country's major television manufacturers won a six-year legal battle today to prevent disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act of data about accidents involving television sets.

Philip Guston, a leading painter of the Abstract Expressionist school who in recent years had devoted himself to figurative work, suffered a heart attack and died on Saturday evening in Woodstock, N.Y. Mr. Guston, who would have celebrated his 67th birthday on June 27, had recently received a Creative Arts Award from Brandeis University, citing him for "notable achievement in the arts."
Mass transit is in deep political trouble and its friends are not doing enough.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that it has approved for human use a safer, more effective and less painful rabies vaccine that requires only five shots instead of 23.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Egypt and Israel have accepted an American proposal to resume the negotiations on Palestinian self-rule that have been suspended for a month, Administration officials said today. Talks are expected to begin in Washington the week of June 22 or June 29.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 7 The student said he was 28 years old, but he looked barely 16 with a bell of black hair hanging over his ears and eyes his white neck, shy expression and soft complexion. He wore a suit to make himself "look like an office worker."

WASHINGTON THE National Academy of Sci ences, which serves as a kind of semiofficial supreme court of science, has begun to search for a replacement for its retiring president amid controversy over the integrity of its reports and the style of its leadership.
A neighbor of the 27-year-old mother of four who was stabbed to death in a Queens hospital bed last Saturday was arrested last night and charged with the killing.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The United States Mint said today that it was delaying its gold medallion sales to July 15. One-half ounce medallions commemorating singer Marian Anderson had been due for sale June 16, and one-ounce medallions honoring painter Grant Wood were to be available July 1. Prices will be set daily, based on the previous day's closing price of gold on the New York Commodity Exchange.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 9 (AP) The woman who was with Vernon E. Jordan Jr. the night he was shot came out of seclusion today and said that she was willing to undergo hypnosis to establish her lack of involvement in the crime she believes was a "racial incident."
WASHINGTON:NEGOTIATIONS SET FOR JUNE 22 OR 29-MUSKIE CALLS ON BOTH SIDES TO HELP IMPROVE CLIMATE By BERNARD GWERTZMAN

Secretary of Defense Harold R. Brown has asserted that false alarms in the United States strategic air defense system cannot set off an accidental launching of nuclear weapons.But he has not persuaded skeptics, and a Congressional inquiry seems likely. In a letter released today, Mr. Brown wrote to Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, ''I can assure that our strategic command and control system is configured to insure that a false alert could not result in a nuclear launch.''
PAGE D15; News Reports On Computers

Bolivia's military commanders, who have demanded that the United States Ambassador be expelled for ''interference,'' called today for a one-year postponement of presidential elections scheduled for June 29. Members of the high command, speaking at a news conference, said the delay would provide time ''to reorganize the nation before the citizens go to the polls.''

Snow fell in the Adirondack Mountains and tornadoes touched down in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York yesterday as a cold front from Canada sent a wintry shudder through the Northeast and set low temperature records in New York City and many other communities. The temperature dipped to 47 degrees in Central Park at 5:30 A.M., eclipsing the record of 49 degrees for the date set in 1913, and the rest of the day was chilly and glowering, with occasionally sputtering drizzles.

SALZBURG, AUSTRIA AN American observer pondering the nature of education in the United States is bound to find that a seminar composed of European educators and scholars leaves him with a new, more benign perspective. Viewed on home ground, the deficiencies stand out like sore thumbs. Judged by Europeans and measured against their own problems, the virtues suddenly appear like the attainment of utopian dreams. In sharp contrast to the self-doubts of Americans, particularly on issues of social equality, the egalitarian accomplishments of the United States model still seem to Europeans, including those within the Soviet orbit, like a brave new world of a distant future.

Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today that his country would not agree to a rise in the price of oil unless other members of the oil-producing cartel would cut their prices. As the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries opened its two-day semiannual meeting here, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani told reporters he particularly wanted OPEC's pricing ''hawks'' - such as Iran, Algeria and Libya - to join in such a move. But when he was asked about the likelihood of agreement, the Saudi oil minister said, ''I am very pessimistic.''

Brig. Gen. Virgilio M. Cordero, retired, a survivor of the Bataan Death March in World War II, died today at the United States Navy Hospital in the Roosevelt Roads base. He was 87 years old. A spokesman for the base said that General Cordero, who retired from the United States Army in 1953 after 36 years of service, had suffered from a lung ailment.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and the premiers of the 10 provinces agreed today to a summer of intensive negotiation on a new constitution. The talks would lead to a formal conference Sept. 8. But in seven hours of negotiations behind the closed doors of the Prime Minister's residence, there was no agreement on underlying principles for changing the federal system. Continuing disagreement on major points was evident, particularly on the part of Quebec, where a recent referendum on sovereignty spurred the current drive toward change.
The Public Service Company of New Hampshire was told today to delay for three years its planned 1985 completion of the second reactor of the Seabrook nuclear power plant.
ALGIERS, June 9 Saudi Arabia's oil minister said today that his country would not agree to a rise in the price of oil unless other members of the oilproducing cartel would cut their prices.

Cvjetko Popovic, one of the last known members of the organization that assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914, has died in Sarajevo at age 84, the Yugoslav news agency Ta Mr. Popovic, a member of the Young Bosnia group, was sentenced to 13 years in prison after the assassination and remained jailed until the end of World War I. The Sarajevo killing set off a chain of events that led to the war.
SECURITY INTERESTS, TOO By JOHN VINOCUR

If white minority rule in South Africa ever gives way willingly to a future when blacks and whites share power it will be through a revolution in the thinking of Afrikaners, the people of mixed Dutch, German and French descent who consider themselves Africa's white tribe. The fountainhead of that revolution could be here at the University of Stellenbosch, which played a central role in evolving the ideology of apartheid, or separate racial development, and now leads efforts to move Afrikaners away from it.

To the Editor: As a member of the ''eating public'' referred to in your June 3 editorial ''A Confusing Diet of Fact,'' I will follow your advice and try to control my lust for eggs. would like to know, though, what advice you have for the noneating public. THOMAS CARPER Cornish, Me., June 4, 1980

The failure of the United States rescue mission in Iran highlighted shortcomings in the country's military operational capabilities. Yet the recent military-budget debate in the Congress has shed little light on the underlying reasons why spending over $1 trillion on defense since the end of World War II has left us with helicopters that break down, fighter aircraft grounded for lack of spare parts, and experienced military technicians leaving for more rewarding jobs in civilian industry. The military-readiness problem is real. The commander of the Atlantic Fleet Naval Air Force, Vice Admiral George Kinnear II, admits that 47 percent of his first-line F-14 fighters are not certified to fly peacetime missions because they are awaiting repairs.

Mary and Joe Jones are a tradition-minded New York couple in their early 30's. She is a homemaker and mother. He is an insurance adjuster and the sole support of the family. Title to the house and the car are in his name, although they have joint checking accounts. After 15 years, the marriage goes sour and the Joneses decide to divorce. She gets custody of the two children. The Joneses are a hypothetical couple. If their hypothetical divorce took place today, the results would be far different than if it occurred after the major divorce reform bill now on Governor Carey's desk becomes law.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that the price of all grades of its gasoline would go up immediately by 11 cents a gallon. A spokesman for the company said it was posting the increase in anticipation of a change in Federal regulations. The change will raise the cost of refining crude oil from the North Slope of Alaska, and Sohio has a 53 percent interest in North Slope oil. At company-owned filling stations in Ohio, the full-service price of regular gasoline is rising to $1.17 a gallon, unleaded to $1.21 a gallon and premium to $1.24 a gallon. The company's gasoline is sold under the Sohio name in Ohio, Boron in neighboring states and BP in the East.

Another season of free outdoor concerts by the Guggenheim Concert Band was assured yesterday. The ensemble's longtime sponsor, the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, agreed to provide up to $90,000 for the seven-week series. The first performance will be held in Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center on June 25 at 8 P.M., a week later than originally scheduled. A week ago, Ainslee Cox, conductor of the 54-piece ensemble, had advised its members that there would be no summertime concerts because it had proved impossible to fulfill the foundation's condition that half of the costs, estimated at $180,000 to $200,000, be contributed from other sources.

The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not bar out-of-state banks from competing locally for various kinds of banking-related business. The unanimous opinion was a victory for the Bankers Trust New York Corporation, the bank holding company, which was blocked in its effort to offer investment advisory services in Florida. In 1972, after Bankers Trust applied to open an investment management office in Palm Beach, the Florida Legislature in special session passed a law to prohibit out-of-state banks from providing such services.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 9 Eastern European countries, pressing for trade agreements and contracts with Iran, have significantly increased their share of the Iranian market in the past three months.

"It's So Nice to Be Civilized," the musical by Micki Grant, closed Sunday afternoon at the Martin Beck Theater after eight performances and 20 previews. The presentation was directed by Frank Corsaro and starred Mabel King and Vivian Reed.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The Carter Administration, in what was described as a humanitarian gesture, has offered American medical treatment to two Palestinian mayors who were maimed last week in bombings on the West Bank.

Laurie Platt Winfrey, a freelance picture editor, and Robert Beahan Shnayerson, editor and publisher of Quest 80 magazine, were married yesterday at their home in Clinton Corners, N.Y. The Rev. John Beaven of Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y., performed the ceremony.

Mary and Joe Jones are a tradition-minded New York couple in their early 30's. She is a homemaker and mother. He is an insurance adjuster and the sole support of the family. Title to the house and the car are in his name, although they have joint checking accounts. After 15 years, the marriage goes sour and the Joneses decide to divorce. She gets custody of the two children.

Edward L. Sadowsky, chairman of the New York City Council's Finance Committee, said yesterday that he would ask the Board of Estimate to add $60 million, largely in education and police funds, to Mayor Koch's proposed budget.

Partly out of fear that the Federal Government would otherwise make too many inroads into higher education, corpo rations are increasing their contributions and becoming a more important factor at colleges and universities.

"THE Search for Solutions," a three-part series beginning on WHET-TV tonight at 9, represents a lofty idea overwhelmed by visual overload. The programs attempt to demonstrate "how the game of science is played." Concentrating on "problem solving," they succeed in being merely puzzling.

The Dana Corporation, a major producer of automotive components and industrial products, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third fiscal quarter, ended May 31, plunged 65.6 percent, to $15.6 million, or 49 cents a share, from $45.4 million, or $1.41 a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales fell 19.8 percent, to $601 million, from $749 million.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 Trailing the California Angels, 4-0, in the sixth inning tonight and held scoreless for the last 22 innings, the Yankees erupted for four runs in the seventh, two in the eighth, one in the ninth and one in the 10th to win, 8-7, at Anaheim Stadium.

The Lykes Pasco Packing Company, one of the largest independent Florida frozen orange juice processors, announced yesterday that it would cut the wholesale price of frozen orange juice concentrate by 45 cents per dozen cans. The move should be felt by consumers in a about six weeks.
NEW DELHI, June 9 Additional security forces were being flown to Tripura and Assam in northeastern India to contain the spreading violence, an official report said today.

WASHINGTON, June 9 After all the clamor to reform and control America's intelligence agencies and months of debate over Congressional efforts to provide them with a comprehensive legislative charter, the four-page intelligence

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9 The United States has won the first round of a political battle with Cuba by gaining the aid of a United Nations agency in screening refugees from the island, American officials disclosed here today.
DALE is an attractive young Chinese-American who has made it in golden Los Angeles. He's not rich, he explains, but he is definitely "upper middle."
DETROIT, June 9--The Chrysler Corporation, which is run by Lee A. Iacocca and his former colleagues from the Ford Motor Company, has raided Volkswagen for small-car expertise.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The whole city seems to have gone puppet mad. From the Corcoran Gallery and School of Art to the Smithsonian Museum of History and Technology where Howdy Doody, Charlie McCarthy and Mortimer Snerd were starring, puppet celebrities were being ambushed and cooed over.
THE race by scientists and engineers to create ultra-small electronic circuits has become one of the most intense in the world's history.

To the Editor: With regard to Representative James H. Scheuer's May 22 Op-Ed article on the so-called ''drug lag'': The United States has the highest drug approval standard in the world. Drugs must be shown, by adequate and well-controlled studies, to be safe and effective before marketing. The system works well to assure all of us that the medicines we take will do what they're supposed to do, at minimum risk. uring the two decades after World War II, there was a golden age of drug discovery. More recently, there have been fewer dramatic advances. Some blame the slowdown in drug discovery on the 1962 law that requires drugs be shown to work before they can be approved; others blame it all on F.D.A., implying that the pipeline at F.D.A.'s Bureau of Drugs is clogged, with significant therapeutic advances being held hostage by uncaring bureaucrats.

Touch wood, the House of Representatives has finally decided that it accepts the reality of change in Nicaragua. It took nine hours of debate and a personal appeal by Speaker O'Neill, his first such plea on foreign affairs in 28 years; but in the end, the House did authorize $53.7-million in aid for Nicaragua as part of an omnibus aid package for fiscal 1981. Even so, President Carter will be required to report at 90-day intervals on the state of Nicaraguan democracy, a condition no one ever dreamed of imposing on American aid when the Somoza family ran the country as its estate. And Congress has yet to unfreeze a $75-million aid package that was promised to Nicaragua early last fall. That money cannot be released until the budget ceiling is raised, an action Congress may take this week.

New Jersey's school financing laws, which limit annual budget increases, have achieved property tax relief but failed to help poor school districts raise per pupil spending to equal that of wealthier districts, according to a study by Rutgers University released yesterday. Dr. Ernest Reock, author of the four-year evaluation commissioned by the Joint Legislative Committee on Public Schools, said: ''The finger points to enrollment. When enrollment goes down, expenditure per pupil goes up and the high spenders are losing enrollment faster than the low spenders. The trend is definitely toward less equality.''

For nearly 80 years, Tom Swift, Nancy Drew, the Hardy Boys and the Bobbsey Twins have lived over at Grosset & Dunlap. But now the Stratemeyer Syndicate, the book-writing concern that turns out these and other children's adventure series, wants them to have a new home (at least in paperback) down the street at Simon & Schuster. However, a Federal judge will have to decide if the move is legal. Stratemeyer, whose books have thrilled three generations of youngsters the world over, is being sued in Federal District Court in Manhattan by Grosset & Dunlap, its publisher since the early 1900's, for breach of contract.

Presse) - Iran's foreign press director was dismissed today in a dispute over Government policies toward foreign correspondents. Abolhassem Sadegh, director general of the Foreign Press Department of the Ministry of National Guidance, said he was given no reason for his dismissal but that it followed his recent charges in interviews that correspondents in Iran might be spies. His charges were published in the newspaper Islamic Republic and denounced by Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh as ''baseless'' and ''harmful to the country's interests.''
Senator Edward M. Kennedy was rebuffed by the United States Conference of Mayors today in his effort to appear at the same forum as President Carter.

The Food and Drug Administration said today that it has approved for human use a safer, more effective and less painful rabies vaccine that requires only five shots instead of 23. The new vaccine is injected into the arm instead of the abdomen, as is presently the case, and it may be taken preventively by those who run the risk of exposure to the disease.

Steel production declined to 1.83 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 1.8 percent from the previous week's 1.86 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., the brokerage house, said yesterday that it had offered to negotiate a merger with the Orion Capital Corporation, using $20 a share as "a negotiating level." At that price, Orion's stock would be worth about $150 million.

OTTAWA, June 9 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada and the premiers of the 10 provinces agreed today to a summer of intensive negotiation on a new constitution. The talks would lead to a formal conference Sept. 8.
Shell Oil Company today announced the donation of $2 million to finance tests of interferon in the treatment of human cancer.
Warner Wolf, the most colorful and perhaps the most popular New York television sportscaster, won the right in State Supreme Court yesterday to switch from WABC-TV to WCBS-TV.

For the first time since Alex Rose was welcome in the White House, Raymond B. Harding, a blunt-talking Bronxite who has emerged as the late Mr. Rose's successor as head of the Liberal Party, is expected to meet with President Carter there next week.

As more banks moved to lower their prime lending rates to 13 percent from 14 percent, the Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a small bank that tries to keep ahead of the field, cut its prime rate yesterday to 12 percent from 13 percent.

Howard M. Squadron, a lawyer from Riverdale, in the Bronx, was elected yesterday as chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. His one-year term will begin July 1. He succeeds Theodore R. Mann of Philadelphia.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 9 (AP) Brig. Gen. Virgilio M. Cordero, retired, a survivor of the Bataan Death March in World War II, died today at the United States Navy Hospital in the Roosevelt Roads base. He was 87 years old.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 9 The world economy could recover from the latest oil price rise after a period of recession and it could resume its growth, but a third huge oil price increase or a major interruption of supplies would bring catastrophe, a leading Western central banker has warned.

Interest rates on Treasury bills fell sharply yesterday, falling below 7 percent for the first time in two years, in a financing that was reduced by $1.6 billion to avoid exceeding the ceiling on the national debt. Bond prices advanced for the fifth consecutive trading day.

When a bomb tore into the home of the charge d'affaires of the Yugoslav Embassy early June 3, the first officer on the scene was not from Washington's police force. He was from the United States Secret Service, and he was there because it was his beat. ''We were the first law enforcement agency at the scene because we heard the explosion,'' explained Harvey E. Pryor, chief of the uniform division of the Secret Service, whose mandate includes guarding the 2,250 foreign diplomats living here. ''It's an area we patrol.''

SCIENTISTS To the Editor: The Times's May 16 editorial criticized the Union of Concerned Scientists' report on the removal of radioactive gas from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant. Yet you acknowledged that you had not actually read the report and that you did not speak with the U.C.S. study group's medical specialist as requested by U.C.S. because you were unable to reach him.,

Public Living Room' At the Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday, workmen completed a drainage channel through part of the fresh sod. The meadow, refurbished with aid of a state grant and donations of more than $400,000, will be fenced in for a while to allow sod to grow in. Park visitors were scarce in any case in unseasonably cool day. Page B2.
HERZOGS DEDUT A SUCESS

Patrick Dupond, a principal dancer with the Paris Opera Ballet, will make his debut with American Ballet Theater on June 20 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Dupond will be seen in Natalia Makarova's full-evening production of ''La Bayadere.'' He will also be seen in the ballet on June 23. He will dance with Marianna Tcherkassky and Miss Makarova at both performances.

Robert S. McNamara, the former Secretary of Defense, announced today that he would retire a year from now as president of the World Bank, the international agency that makes economic development loans to poor countries.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is expected to rule today on a proposal to vent radioactive gas to facilitate the cleanup at Three Mile Island. Experts on all sides of the nuclear debate agree that release of the krypton would pose no significant risk to anyone's physical health. The maximum radiation dose on the skin of someone standing at the edge of the site would be the equivalent of no more than a few hours' exposure to sunlight. Not a single case of cancer is anticipated. So the decision turns on psychological questions. Is the stress among nearby residents so great that the gas must be handled in a special way and, if so, how? In the adjoining columns today appears a letter from the Union of Concerned Scientists, a competent and responsible antinuclear group which takes us to task for minimizing the importance of psychological stress. But that is a misreading of what we have written on this subject. We never challenged the Concerned Scientists' contention that many people have been upset since the accident. We did and do challenge the group's formal proposal for alleviating that distress by making major changes in an admittedly safe krypton-venting plan.

District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said yesterday that he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate if party leaders would provide enough support at a Democratic State Committee meeting on Thursday to qualify him for the Sept. 9 primary. Democratic county leaders in the New York metropolitan area indicated that they would agree to Mr. Santucci's request. They had already agreed among themselves to give enough votes to three other Democrats - Representative Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, John V. Lindsay and Bess Myerson, both of Manhattan- to qualify them for the ballot.

ORPHEUS,'' a very sensitive ballet that requires special handling, is receiving such royal treatment from the New York City Ballet that it is hard to believe it once seemed past its prime. At its first performance of the season Sunday afternoon at the State Theater, Peter Martins repeated the absolutely compelling rendering of the title role he introduced in February. His co-stars are Adam Luders, who gives an extraordinarily nuanced performance of his own as the Angel of Death, and Karin von Aroldingen as an impassioned Eurydice, the beloved wife whom Orpheus seeks to retrieve from the world of the dead.

A retired police officer was arrested yesterday on a charge that he attempted to extort more than $100,000 last year from Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the convicted murderer who escaped 10 days ago from a Brooklyn jail.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The United States and Kuwait signed an agreement today to promote cooperation in science and technology for peaceful purposes. Signing the accord were Richard C. Atkinson, director of the National Science Foundation, and Kazam Behbehani, deputy director of the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research.

AKRON, Ohio, June 9 (AP) Summit County Probate Judge James V. Barbuto, on trial here on charges that he used his office to gain sexual favors from women appearing before him, "ran his office like a benevolent despot," a special prosecutor said today.

TRENTON, June 9 The New Jersey Supreme Court said today that a new state law protecting a reporter's confidential notes was designed to shield them from unnecessary scrutiny by a judge in his chambers.

ATLANTA, June 9 (UPI) George Hendrick hit a three-run homer in the 10th inning tonight, giving him five runs batted in for the game and making Whitey Herzog's debut as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals a success with an 8-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Sales of new homes fell to an annual rate of 364,000 units in April, the lowest level in nearly 14 years, as high interest rates kept potential buyers out of the market, the Government reported today.

Francis Warren Perching the only son of General of the Armies John J. Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force in World War I died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital following an emergency operation. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Administration specialists were briefly elated last week when the House passed a foreign aid bill that would authorize only $86.5 million less than President Carter requested for fiscal 1981. It had been a hard fight, but the House leadership had been able to sidetrack most of the damaging amendments and produce a $5.2 billion package. But the euphoria evaporated as the Administration officials took stock of the struggle with Congress that lay ahead if the United States was to maintain even a minimal aid program during an election year when inflation, budget cutting and increasing unhappiness with the world situation all seemed to combine against it.

This polyglot place of fresh troubles and tired luxury is a reminder of times past when refugees were viewed as a great torrent of opportunity and exploitation by American politicians. That is a time remembered now only by older politicians in the places of the old politics. Thus, in New York, where a modern Mayor now persues the middle-class vote beyond the traditional bounds of one party, Paul O'Dwyer can think back half a century to a different time, to his first days off the boat from Ireland. Then he found a room in a New York tenement whose landlady routinely pointed out the location of the neighborhood Democratic club, a hotbed for the politics of the have-nots.

Bernstein Let's invent a fantasy together, right now - and I mean a fantastic fantasy. No holds barred. Let's pretend that any one of us has become President of the United States, a very imaginative President, who has suddenly taken a firm decision to disarm, completely and unilaterally. I see alarm on your faces: This crazed artist is proposing sheer madness. It can't be done; a President is not a dictator, this is a democracy. Congress would never permit it, the people would howl with wounded national pride, our allies would scream betrayal. It can't be done. But of course it can't be done if everybody starts by saying it can't be done. Let's push our imagination; remember, we're only fantasizing. Let's dare to be simplistic. All right, someone would stand up in the Congress and demand that the President be impeached, declared certifiable, and locked away in a loony bin. Others would agree.

WASHINGTON THE National Academy of Sciences, which serves as a kind of semiofficial supreme court of science, has begun to search for a replacement for its retiring president amid controversy over the integrity of its reports and the style of its leadership. Long-standing complaints from consumer and environmental interests that the academy's reports are often biased toward the views of industry were renewed recently following a report by its Food and Nutrition Board disputing widespread opinion that cholesterol intake should be restricted. It was reported after the study was published that it had been financed by contributions from the food industry. Influential members of the panel have ties to the food, dairy and egg industries. They have asserted that such ties do not impair their objectivity.

Wiley Peck, a power forward who saw limited action in his rookie season, was sent to the Phoenix Suns today in the Dallas Mavericks' first trade as a National League franchise. The 22-year-old Peck, the first choice of the San Antonio Spurs and the 19th over all in last year's college draft, was chosen by Dallas in the expansion draft. He was dealt for a second-round draft choice and future considerations.

The Dana Corporation, a major producer of automotive components and industrial products, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third fiscal quarter, ended May 31, plunged 65.6 percent, to $15.6 million, or 49 cents a share, from $45.4 million, or $1.41 a share, in the year-ago quarter. Sales fell 19.8 percent, to $601 million, from $749 million. The Toledo-based company said it was hard hit by the big decline in the nation's truck production in recent months. ''Because of lower forecasted demand, we announced that we would close four vehicular plants during the third and fourth quarters,'' said Gerry Mitchell, Dana's chief executive.

The Martial Law Command announced today that eight South Korean journalists were being questioned on suspicion of spreading what it called ''vicious'' rumors related to the recent anti-Government uprising in Kwangju. It was the first official announcement of the questioning of any journalist since full martial law was imposed on May 17. ''There is a strong suspicion,'' the announcement said, ''that they, acting under the influence of organized, impure elements from outside, have hampered the nation's unity by spreading vicious, groundless rumors.'' It did not identify the ''impure elements,'' a phrase generally used to describe leftists opposed to the Government.

Media advisers to Ronald Reagan have begun planning a radio and television campaign costing $12 million to $15 million that will focus on President Carter's ''failure of leadership'' over the last four years. Peter H. Dailey, a Los Angeles advertising executive who was recently appointed head of Mr. Reagan's media effort, said in an interview that tentative plans called for using Mr. Carter's role as ''leader and administrator,'' coupled with Mr. Reagan's eight-year record as Governor of California, as the basis for the election drive after the Republican National Convention in July.

WHATEVER the occasional nicks and scratches, Broadway's Tonys remain the Rolls-Royce of televised award shows. In the course of 13 years, Alexander H. Cohen and Hildy Parks, the producers, have refined the occasion to a remarkably smooth-flowing celebration of New York and the theater that devotees choose to call ''legitimate.''

INVESTORS who are looking for stocks capable of resisting the recession are turning increasingly to smaller growth stocks. Generally speaking, such companies are found in areas of the economy that have very rapid growth characteristics such as oil service, specialty chemical and health care companies, among others. One mutual fund that attempts to identify companies in these rapidly growing segments of the economy is E.W. Axe & Company's Axe-Houghton Stock Fund. The managers of the fund, now a $70 million vehicle, have found that one of the most valuable guides to stock selection in emerging growth companies is the earnings outlook for the year immediately ahead.

Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan urged the city's Rent Guidelines Board yesterday to prohibit new rent increases until landlords disclosed their profits. He did so as building owners formally requested the right to pass along fuel-cost increases and planned to seek other increases involving 860,000 apartments under rent stabilization.

SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, June 9 (AP) Cvjetko Popovic, one of the last known members of the organization that assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria in 1914, has died in Sarajevo at age 84, the Yugoslav news agency Tanyug said today.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the extent of a state's legal obligation to provide education and training for the retarded.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The Carter Administration has decided not to propose any new actions intended to cut energy consumption to replace the oil-import fee killed by Congress last week, Administration officials said today.

The United States has won the first round of a political battle with Cuba by gaining the aid of a United Nations agency in screening refugees from the island, American officials disclosed here today. Since Wednesday, two specialists from the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees have been working in Washington and at Fort Chaffee, Ark., separating criminals from genuine refugees and helping resettle those who have left Cuba.

United States officials disclosed that the negotiators had accepted an American proposal for new meetings in Washington as Secretary of State Muskie, in a speech, urged both sides to resist unilateral moves that prejudice ''the final status'' of the occupied territories. The New Jersey Supreme Court said today that a new state law protecting a reporter's confidential notes was designed to shield them from unnecessary scrutiny by a judge in his chambers. The 6-to-1 decision overturned an order by Judge Michael Imbriani in Superior Court to Robin Goldstein, a reporter for The Red Bank Register. She had been ordered to submit as possible evidence two letters that had been sent to her by a prosecution witness named Patrick Pizuto in the trial of four men charged with murder and racketeering.

Q. What is the explanation for the condensation trails that form behind jet aircraft? Is it similar to skywriting? A. The exhaust from the combustion reaction in a jet engine includes fuel gases, carbon monoxide and water vapor. When these gases and steam are expelled from the hot jet engines and hit the cold upper air, they form cloudlike condensation and streams of water crystals. These crystals melt slowly in the cool air, leaving a faint trail.

TWO proposals involving catastrophes that enveloped the earth in sun-shading debris have been advanced to account for past episodes of widespread extinction and climatic change. One was a direct hit on the earth by an asteroid, causing an explosion whose debris cut off all or most sunlight for several years. This could explain the extinction of the dinosaurs and numerous other creatures some 65 million years ago.

The Carter Administration will propose no new energy-saving measures to replace the oil-import fee that Congress killed last week, officials said, for want of a politically acceptable alternative. As a result, the President will attend the economic summit meeting in Venice without the strong energy package that the Administration has argued is needed to set an example for other nations. (Page A1.) Saudi Arabia will not agree to raise its oil price unless other OPEC members cut their prices, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi oil minister, said at the group's meeting in Algiers. He cited the pricing ''hawks,'' Iran, Algeria and Libya, but added that he was ''very pessimistic'' that a pricing accord would be reached. (D1.)

The General Electric Company beat out British and other competitors and won a multimillion-dollar contract to build the first stage of the new British-operated early-warning radar system, according to Government officials.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; Japanese Premier to Remain In Hospital During Election

Phil Parkes is the main reason why the Chicago Sting attract attention like bees to honey. Parkes, the best goalkeeper in the North American Soccer League the previous two years while with the Vancouver Whitecaps, joined Chicago in the offseason and has helped the Sting post 11 victories in 14 games this season. Parkes led the league with a goals-against average of 0.95 in 1978 and 0.96 in 1979. After Parkes led the Whitecaps to their first league title last season, Vancouver refused to meet his salary demands. He went to Chicago thanks to the efforts of Lee Stern, the flamboyant owner of the Sting, who signed him to a two-year contract.
