WEISMAN MIAMI, June 9 - An angry crowd of several hundred demonstrators booed President Carter today in the heart of the Liberty City area, the scene of last month's racial rioting and looting.

Eastern Air Lines, the carrier whose tattered finances fed early qualms about airline deregulation a few years ago, is now forcing one of the most dramatic confrontations ever seen over air routes and fares. Last week Eastern began flying its fleet of Lockheed L-1011's on the most heavily traveled air routes in the country - between New York and California. The move forced other carriers on the routes to drop one-way fares to $99, from more than $300, in an atmosphere described by American Airlines' chairman, Albert V. Casey, as ''competitive madness.''

THE race by scientists and engineers to create ultra-small electronic circuits has become one of the most intense in the world's history. The future economic, social and military rewards are so promising, experts said in interviews, that it is worth the cost of one dollar's worth of development for every dollar's worth of product. The immediate objective is to jam as much microelectronic circuitry as possible into the smallest possible space a problem requiring a continuous stream of discoveries and inventions by specialists in nearly every branch of physical science and engineering. Experts at Bell Laboratories, International Business Machines, Texas Instruments and the handful of other leaders in the design of microcircuits believe that as many as one billion components may eventually be squeezed into one wafer-thin chip the size of a postage stamp.

A dismal doubleheader is forecast for the millions of sad, angry and bewildered soccer fans of Italy. Their depleted national team and the teams of seven other countries will contest the final round of the European Cup tournament starting tomorrow here and in Milan, Turin and Naples. On Thursday, a local court will begin hearing a case in which 33 Italian major league players, three club presidents and two selfdescribed bigtime gamblers will answer fraud charges, The trial is an outcrop of the worst soccer scandal since the sport came to Italy at the end of the last century and turned into a national passion.

President Carter presented the Medal of Freedom today to his mentor, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, and to 13 other distinguished Americans. ''I have said many times to a close circle of friends that with the exception of my father, no other person has had such a profound impact on my life,'' the President said of Admiral Rickover.
Ad Hoc Committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Decolonization Committee, Subcom- mittee on Small Territories - 3 P.M.
BUT THE CONTRIVERSIAL ISSUES REMAIN UNRESOLVED By PHILIP TAUBMAN

Summit County Probate Judge James V. Barbuto, on trial here on charges that he used his office to gain sexual favors from women appearing before him, ''ran his office like a benevolent despot,'' a special prosecutor said today. Judge Barbuto, 58 years old, a former Common Pleas judge, waived his right to a jury trial before jury selection was to begin this morning. He will be tried before Judge George J. McMonagle, a retired Cuyahoga County judge.

The Republican leaders of the State Senate announced today that the Senate would pass a bill restoring $177 million of the items vetoed from the state budget by Governor Carey, including full restoration of the revenue-sharing aid sought by Mayor Koch. But the measure is virtually certain to get nowhere in the Democratic-led Assembly, thus bringing the Legislature one day closer to a recess but no closer to a solution of the budget situation or most other major issues facing it.

Spacemen Return Safely Two Soviet astronauts ended a four-day visit to the Salyut 6 space station and returned safely to earth yesterday. Their flight was described as a successful test of an improved version of the Soyuz spacecraft.

To the Editor: As New York City and its employees once again wrangle at the negotiating table over wage rates and the spiraling cost of living, it is disturbing to see the city's hard-nosed attitude toward its workers striking so resonant a chord in the hearts of New Yorkers. The ''we versus them'' mentality prevalent during the recent transit strike threatens to emerge again. et the range and quality of services here, from mass transit to public health care, is truly outstanding. In the face of enormous difficulties, working with inadequate equipment under conditions often deemed hazardous, the city's employees continue to deliver consistent and conscientious service.

Mass transit is in deep political trouble and its friends are not doing enough. The major cities need bus and rail transit to stay alive, but the message - at least to New York City -from both Washington and Albany gets clearer by the hour: Necessity is not the mother of appropriations. More important than necessity is political muscle, including a little noise. If New Yorkers want to avoid a 75-cent fare this year and a $1 fare next year, they need to make the case for transit as strong as automobilists and other groups have made the case against.
WASHINGTON The failure of the United States rescue mission in Iran highlighted shortcomings in the country's military operational capabilities.

WASHINGTON, June 9 President Carter announced today that consumer representatives had been established in 35 Federal agencies, circumventing the Congress that refused to create a separate consumer affairs agency last year.
SEATTLE, June 9 Senator Edward M. Kennedy was rebuffed by the United States Conference of Mayors today in his effort to appear at the same forum as President Carter.

Steel production declined to 1.83 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, a decrease of 1.8 percent from the previous week's 1.86 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, June 9 (UPI) The Federal Government officially dropped the six remaining charges of banking irregularities against Bert Lance today, saying that the cost of retrying him and two codefendants was too high.

ROME, June 9 With the tabulation of votes in one portion of Italy's regional and municipal elections virtually complete tonight, the Christian Democrats appeared to have made slight gains at the expense of the Communists, the country's other major party.

Snow fell in the Adirondack Mountains and tornadoes touched down in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York yesterday as a cold front from Canada sent a wintry shudder through the Northeast and set low temperature records in New York City and many other communities.
Beginning today, the daily mutual fund table published in The New York Times includes 34 funds that have not been previously listed and deletes 56 others that have been included.
CHATHAM, Mass., June 9 Federal wildlife officials poisoned several hundred gulls on Monomoy Island over the weekend to protect the endangered nesting sites of terns.

The sale of ''drug-related paraphernalia'' would be prohibited in a bill that has won the approval of Governor Carey's chief counsel and leaders in both houses of the Legislature after a carefully worked out amendment narrowing the definition of such objects. The amended bill is expected to pass the Legislature this week and be signed by Governor Carey. The legislation's aim, according to a memorandum attached to the bill, is to close so-called ''head shops,'' which sell paraphernalia for the use of controlled substances such as marijuana, cocaine and heroin. The Drug Enforcement Administration of the Justice Department has estimated the sale of drug-related paraphernalia nationwide to total more than $600 million a year.

To the Editor: With regard to your June 5 story on the JFK Express, there are two main reasons why it is such a financial flop: * Most people going to Kennedy International Airport have baggage, and there are no facilities for getting baggage from train to bus. * The fare is too high. The $3.50 fare was set so as not to distress the Carey Company, whose bus fare from JFK to the city is $4 with baggage handling. lso, if the M.T.A. executives rode the subway, they would know that any one can take a train and a bus to Kennedy for only $1. You take the IND to Union Turnpike station and change to the Q-10 bus, which goes directly to JFK. SHELDON RITTER Fresh Meadows, N.Y., June 5, 1980

When Congress killed the G.I. Bill in December 1976, the Army gloomily concluded that the pool of potential recruits would shrink by as much as 36.7 percent. Today, the Army has the right to tell Congress: ''I told you so.'' Defense Department officials estimate that the Army is 50,000 short of its peacetime strength of 774,000 and 80,000 below projected wartime requirements. Military manpower problems have gotten so bad that it is doubtful our armed forces could respond effectively to a major crisis. All Army units in the continental United States, except the 82d Airborne Division, are substantially under strength. The Navy, in April, had to tie up a front-line ship, the oiler U.S.S. Canisteo, for lack of skilled sailors to man it.

Shell Oil Company today announced the donation of $2 million to finance tests of interferon in the treatment of human cancer. John Bookout, president of Shell, said the money will be divided equally between the American Cancer Society and a charity named the Interferon Foundation set up in Houston six months ago to sponsor trials of antivirus substance against human cancer. Dr. Frank J. Rauscher Jr., senior vice president for research of the cancer society described the gift as the largest single donation in the society's history and said that it will be used to provide interferon treatment for 150 to 200 patients.

Two Roman Catholic priests in St. Louis refused to go along meekly with the demands of a gunman. The robber, scuffling with the priests, was bitten and beaten so severely that he fled in terror, leaving his rifle behind. The Rev. Donald Murrin, pastor of St. Nicholas Church, said the gunman walked into the rectory Saturday and forced him and the associate pastor, the Rev. Thomas Liebold, to lie on the floor. After forcing Father Murrin to open a safe, the thief began stuffing money in a bag, and when he turned his rifle aside, the priest jumped on him.

Ben Rose, a photographer who devised new technology that extended the boundaries of his art, died Sunday of cancer at the North Shore University Hospital, in Manhasset, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Beechhurst, Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court ruled today that states can require the owners of private shopping centers to provide access to members of the public who want to circulate petitions or otherwise peacefully exercise their rights of free speech.

Let's invent a fantasy together, right now and I mean a fantastic fantasy. No holds barred. Let's pretend that any one of us has become President of the United States, a very imaginative President, who has suddenly taken a firm decision to disarm, completely and unilaterally.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The World Bank in 12 years under Robert S. McNamara has become the leading international instrument for the transfer of technical and financial assistance to the world's poor.

SALZBURG, AUSTRIA AN American observer ponder ing the nature of education in the United States is bound to find that a seminar composed of European educators and scholars leaves him with a new, more benign perspective.
LONDON, June 9 Roy Jenkins, the President of the European Commission, hinted strongly today that he plans to return to Britain early next year to form a new centrist political party.

CARLISLE, Pa., June 9 President Carter's supporters, in what they described as a bid for party unity, failed today to chip away at Senator Edward M. Kennedy's control of the closely divided Pennsylvania delegation to the Democratic National Convention. Mayor William J. Green of Philadelphia, a Kennedy backer, was elected chairman at a tense meeting.

ADEN, Southern Yemen, June 9 The Soviet Union, which has long had military ties with Southern Yemen, has turned this country at the southern tip of the Arabian peninsula into what one Western diplomat calls a "military warehouse."

WASHINGTON, June 9 Robert S. McNamara, the former Secretary of Defense, announced today that he would retire a year from now as president of the World Bank, the international agency that makes economic development loans to poor countries.
PARIS, June 9 Europeans are beginning now to take notice of Ronald Reagan, whom they had ignored as a negligible outsider during his three successive series of primary campaigns.

Precious-metal stocks, responding to renewed global tensions over the American dollar and the price of oil, chalked up strong gains yesterday. Energy issues advanced as the market's next best performing sector.

Baruch College conferred degrees on 2,050 students, 271 of them with honors, at its 12th annual commencement exercises yesterday morning. The ceremony was in the Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden, with more than 3,000 people in attendance. The commencement speaker was Dr. Marina v. N. Whitman, vice president and chief economist of the General Motors Corporation, who spoke of the diffusion of power, political and otherwise, and the resulting inability to deal effectively with social problems.

Precious-metal stocks, responding to renewed global tensions over the American dollar and the price of oil, chalked up strong gains yesterday. Energy issues advanced as the market's next best performing sector. Both groups have starred as recurring favorites for nearly two years, spurred by swelling corporate profits and the popular concept of these stocks as long-term inflation hedges.

To the Editor: Regardless of the circumstances or motives involved, every American citizen has the right to travel anywhere in the world and make a fool of himself without fear of criminal prosecution. This includes Ramsey Clark and his trip to Iran, or athletes traveling to the 1980 Olympics. t seems freedom has found a new definition under President Carter's ban on travel to Iran. We are free to be told by our Government where we may and may not go. It is about time President Carter realized that I am a free individual, and that I have the right to spend my summer vacation in Teheran, Moscow or Ethiopia if I choose to. NICHOLAS HENTOFF New York, June 3, 1980

Gregory P. Schwartz is planning to fly across the country in a single-engine plane he is building in his room on the fifth floor of Greenwich Hospital. He has already spent 50 to 60 hours on the 13-foot long, 275-pound plane, and needs, he says, another month to finish it. But time is an uncertain part of his life. In April 1977, Mr. Schwartz was told he had acute lymphatic leukemia, one of the more pernicious forms of cancer and usually fatal.

Do Government food grades such as AA, Prime and Fancy help you when you are shopping? The Agriculture Department is concerned that its system may not be meeting consumers' needs and is considering making some changes. The grading service is voluntary and is paid for by the food producers. Currently, grade nomenclature varies considerably between types of food. For example, meats are graded Prime, Choice, Good, while eggs would be graded AA, A, B, C and so forth and vegetables might have a grade such as Fancy.

Beginning today, the daily mutual fund table published in The New York Times includes 34 funds that have not been previously listed and deletes 56 others that have been included. These changes reflect changes in the reporting procedures of the National Association of Securities Dealers, which gathers and reports on fund performance. The 34 additions result from the N.A.S.D. now including funds with fewer shareholders than those previously listed. The 56 deletions are money market funds with net asset values that do not change from day to day. In most mutual funds, the fluctuating value of the investment portfolio is reflected in a changing net asset value, which is reported in the fund table.

Europeans are beginning now to take notice of Ronald Reagan, whom they had ignored as a negligible outsider during his three successive series of primary campaigns. It has suddenly occurred to officials and news directors that he may be the Mr. ABC they have been naming for months as their Presidential preference. ABC stands for Anybody But Carter, but it has come as a surprise to allies that the serious alternative to the incumbent is a former movie star whose probable policies are a mystery to them. The thought is chilling to people here, because however harshly and critically they may speak of an American President, they have a deep sense of his importance to their own lives and fate. Reagan was on French TV the other night, for the first time, in an interview beamed by satellite from his Los Angeles office. He got mixed reviews. Le Monde found him ''less apocalyptic,'' ''wiser'' than it had expected, but unclear and reserved. Serge Dassault, scion of the aeronautics fortune, found him ''evasive,'' ''uncertain,'' less decisive than he had expected, but intriguing.

American efforts to keep political issues out of the International Labor Organization were set back today when the agency's Resolutions Committee voted to give priority to discussion of a Jordanian motion calling for the condemnation of Israel for establishing settlements in ''Palestine and the other occupied Arab territories.'' The resolution calls on I.L.O. states to ''cease all assistance provided to the Israeli authorities which may support their settlement policy.'' It would also have the I.L.O. provide ''all types of assistance and support'' to Palestinians to help them ''counteract the effects of the Israeli occupation and settlement policy.''

DESPITE its rigorous structural underpinnings, Philip Glass's music has always provided a rich, sensual listening experience. This listener, at least, has grown accustomed to hearing it performed by the composer's ensemble of electric keyboards and woodwinds, and the bright, bold colors that ensemble produces have consistently breathed life into the music's strict developmental processes. Mr. Glass has given solo performances in the past, but they've always seemed weak compared to the work of his band. The small electric organs he used produced too narrow a range of colors, and without the steady timekeeping of his musicians, his tempos and articulation were occasionally erratic. So one went to his solo concert at Plymouth Church in Brooklyn Heights on Sunday, a benefit performance for Bargemusic Ltd., with mixed feelings. Happily, the large church organ Mr. Glass was playing on Sunday and the church's fine acoustics provided the body, warmth and textural variety the music needed, and the concert turned out to be both delightful and instructive. It was instructive above all because it placed Mr. Glass's music in a familiar context. The novel instrumentation of his ensemble and his additive rhythmic processes, which are derived in part from Indian music, have combined to make his work sound more exotic than it actually is. Hearing it in Plymouth Church, one realized how naturally much of it would fit into a traditional Christian worship service.

The Boston Celtics, faced with the savory problem of who to make the No. 1 choice in today's National Basketball Association college draft, decided yesterday to let the Golden State Warriors worry about who to pick.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 9 (UPI) President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today warned those favoring spy trials for the American hostages that such a course could have unwanted consequences.
INVESTORS who are looking for stocks capable of resisting the recession are turning increasingly to smaller growth stocks.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Secretary of Defense Harold R. Brown has asserted that false alarms in the United States strategic air defense system cannot set off an accidental launching of nuclear weapons. But he has not persuaded skeptics, and a Congressional inquiry seems likely.
Foote, Cone Belding, Chicago, has been assigned the Swift Company business that had been with the Leo Burnett Company, Chicago, until last week.

Spring 3100, for 50 years the New York City Police Department's official magazine, is going the way of the telephone number from which it took its name - out of existence. Following nearly a decade of budgetary and other problems, the magazine, which contains articles and photographs about the professional and personal activities of the department, is ending publication with the issue being distributed this week.

CHEMICAL BANK, having directed its advertising efforts elsewhere since January, yesterday returned to ''The chemistry is just right at Chemical'' image advertising campaign. It is convinced that the last time around it actually put money in the bank. The purpose of the advertising is to convey the feeling that each of the more than 250 branches of the bank gears its operation solely to the needs of the community it is in.

Eastern European countries, pressing for trade agreements and contracts with Iran, have significantly increased their share of the Iranian market in the past three months. Yesterday Iran and Rumania signed a trade pact under which the Rumanians are due to provide a wide range of industrial goods and foodstuffs in short supply here.

ALTHOUGH there are tax disadvantages for investors, corporate treasurers are reviving an old financing vehicle - exchangeable debentures that can be converted into the common stock of another corporation. For the issuing company, the advantage is lower borrowing costs. For the investor, the carrot is the possibility of sharing in the price appreciation of the other company's stock.

The Boston Celtics, faced with the savory problem of who to make the No. 1 choice in today's National Basketball Association college draft, decided yesterday to let the Golden State Warriors worry about who to pick. The Celtics traded the choice, along with the No. 13 selection in the first round, to the Warriors for an established center, 7-foot Robert Parish, and the No. 3 selection in the draft. For weeks, Red Auerbach, the Celtics' president and general manager; Harry Mangurian, the owner, and Bill Fitch, the coach, had been at odds on whether to make Joe Barry Carroll, Kevin McHale or Darrell Griffith the top choice. The 7-foot-1-inch Carroll, of Purdue, the 6-11 McHale, who played center and forward at Minnesota, and the 6-4 Griffith of Louisville, the college player of the year, all filled Boston's needs for a center or a guard.
Timely change in leadership is salutary both for institutions and for individuals.'' - Robert S. McNamara. (A1:3.)

Eddie Murray's sacrifice fly in the ninth inning scored Pat Kelly from third base and gave the Baltimore Orioles a 3-2 victory over the Oakland A's tonight. Before Kelly drew a walk, the Orioles had been held in check for more than six innings against the A's Rick Langford (4-5). After three straight hits in the second inning, Langford retired the next 22 batters in order.

The United States and Kuwait signed an agreement today to promote cooperation in science and technology for peaceful purposes. Signing the accord were Richard C. Atkinson, director of the National Science Foundation, and Kazam Behbehani, deputy director of the Kuwait Institute for Scientific Research.
MIAMI, June 5 This polyglot place of fresh troubles and tired luxury is a reminder of times past when refugees were viewed as a great torrent of opportunity and exploitation by American politicians.

MIAMI Eastern Air Lines, the carrier whose tattered finances fed early qualms about airline deregulation a few years ago, is now forcing one of the most dramatic confrontations ever seen over air routes and fares.

Standard Poor's Corporation lowered its rating of Michigan bonds by less than a full notch yesterday to A+ from AA as the result of deteriorating conditions in the state's economy and the uncertain future of the automobile industry.

WASHINGTON, June 9 Media advisers to Ronald Reagan have begun planning a radio and television campaign costing $12 million to $15 million that will focus on President Carter's "failure of leadership" over the last four years.
BIOGRAPHERS of literary figures face the challenge of how to write about a subject whose life consists largely of sitting alone in a room day after day.
CASH, THEY ARE FEAARFUL BYR MAKING WARY EFFORTS TO REGROUP By HENRY SCOTT STOKES

A PARASITE that until recent years was believed by most doctors to be harmless now heads the list of the most common intestinal parasitic infections in the United States and some other countries. The parasite is Giardia lamblia, which causes a diarrheal disease called giardiasis and, less often, lambliasis. Giardiasis has become the most commonly detected intestinal parasite in the 50 state health department laboratories in this country, as well as in similar laboratories in England.

The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence fell in May for the seventh consecutive month, bringing it close to the record low reached in the last recession, the business research organization reported yesterday. The index, which reflects consumers' attitudes toward current and future economic conditions, fell 11 points from the April level, reaching 41.9. That was the lowest since the record low of 39.9 in the final two months of 1974.

A neighbor of the 27-year-old mother of four who was stabbed to death in a Queens hospital bed last Saturday was arrested last night and charged with the killing. The police said that the suspect, Ronald De Casper, 26, lived across the street from the victim, Carol Jurlando, in Ozone Park, Queens, but that the motive in the murder was not known.

The Lykes Pasco Packing Company, one of the largest independent Florida frozen orange juice processors, announced yesterday that it would cut the wholesale price of frozen orange juice concentrate by 45 cents per dozen cans. The move should be felt by consumers in a about six weeks. The reduction by Lykes Pasco follows that of several of the nation's major independent Florida frozen concentrated orange juice processors, which announced wholesale price reductions in frozen orange juice of 30 cents per dozen cans.

For the first time since Alex Rose was welcome in the White House, Raymond B. Harding, a blunt-talking Bronxite who has emerged as the late Mr. Rose's successor as head of the Liberal Party, is expected to meet with President Carter there next week. Robert S. Strauss, Mr. Carter's chief messenger to politicians with doubts about the President, arranged the meeting shortly after Mr. Harding raised the possibility of endorsing the independent Presidential candidacy of Representative John B. Anderson of Illinois.

The whole city seems to have gone puppet mad. From the Corcoran Gallery and School of Art to the Smithsonian Museum of History and Technology where Howdy Doody, Charlie McCarthy and Mortimer Snerd were starring, puppet celebrities were being ambushed and cooed over. Naturally, that porcine puppet of pulchritude, Miss Piggy, was on hand, as were Kermit the Frog and Big Bird. That fleecy charmer, Lambchop, was also there. And Kukla and Oliver J. Dragon, known as ''Ollie,'' represented the Kuklapolitans.

Borough President Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan urged the city's Rent Guidelines Board yesterday to prohibit new rent increases until landlords disclosed their profits. He did so as building owners formally requested the right to pass along fuel-cost increases and planned to seek other increases involving 860,000 apartments under rent stabilization. Jane Benedict, chairman of the Metropolitan Council on Housing, a tenants group, told a guidelines board hearing at 1 Police Plaza that only 20 landlords filed hardship pleas last year with the Board of Conciliation and Appeals. ''Landlords don't need increases,'' she asserted.

The American Symphony Orchestra League has chosen Beverly Sills, general director of the New York City Opera, to receive its Gold Baton for 1980. The award, given annually since 1948, will be presented during the league's national convention at the Sheraton Center Hotel, next Monday through Friday. Miss Sills was cited for her ''cultivation and captivation of new audiences for the arts for over 30 years.''

The United States Mint said today that it was delaying its gold medallion sales to July 15. One-half ounce medallions commemorating singer Marian Anderson had been due for sale June 16, and one-ounce medallions honoring painter Grant Wood were to be available July 1. Prices will be set daily, based on the previous day's closing price of gold on the New York Commodity Exchange.
ROME A dismal doubleheader is forecast for the millions of sad, angry and bewildered soccer fans of Italy.
Data processing managers have emerged as pivotal figures in the way businesses control their daily transactions, according to a study released yesterday by a private financial research group.

STELLENBOSCH, South Africa If white minority rule in South Africa ever gives way willingly to a future when blacks and whites share power it will be through a revolution in the thinking of Afrikaners, the people of mixed Dutch, German and French descent who consider themselves Africa's white tribe.

Herbert Rivington Pyne Jr., a descendant of New York colonial families, died of cancer Saturday at Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 63 years old, and he lived in Medomak, Me., and Harbour Island, the Bahamas.

The Conference Board's index of consumer confidence fell in May for the seventh consecutive month, bringing it close to the record low reached in the last recession, the business research organization reported yesterday.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 9 (AP) Bolivia's military commanders, who have demanded that the United States Ambassador be expelled for "interference," called today for a one-year postponement of presidential elections scheduled for June 29.
WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) President Carter presented the Medal of Freedom today to his mentor, Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, and to 13 other distinguished Americans.

BONN, June 9 Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, the strongest advocate of American positions within the Cabinet of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, changed his tone in a major political speech last weekend.
WASHINGTON, June 9 The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not bar out-of-state banks from competing locally for various kinds of banking-related business.

The logic of Americans buying more and more guns to protect themselves can be tragic. But the explanation of a religious cultist for the cache of arms the police found stored at his Hare Krishna farm in California sounds even worse. He said, ''I want to protect the deity, Lord Krishna. I want to protect my god-brothers ... We're here to protect our god.'' One should not have to argue theology to oppose these arsenals of the International Society for Krishna Consciousness - those sometimes shaven-headed, saffron-robed people who for 15 years have been begging for money in cities and college towns. The Berkeley police say they know of thousands of dollars in recent gun purchases. Neighbors of a Hare Krishna commune in West Virginia have complained of incessant target practice. One of the cult's leaders has been arrested for violating Federal gun laws. And among the arms recently discovered on Hare Krishna properties, there weren't just pistols and hunting rifles but also riot guns, a submachine gun, a grenade launcher and assault rifles, with appropriate ammunition.

To the Editor: The growing disenchantment among West Germans with the ''big brother'' relationship between the United States and their country (news story June 4) could reflect not so much disillusionment with America's wavering leadership and erratic foreign policy as the maturing of the Federal Republic as a political entity and growing confidence among the Germans in their ability to formulate and execute their own foreign policy.

A TEAM of wildlife scientists investigating reports of dwindling numbers of elephants in Uganda has found evidence that poachers have engaged in a massive slaughter of the animals during the last few years, leaving the remaining small herds to face extermination within months unless the poaching is stopped. Similar killings of elephants and rhinoceroses have occurred in many nations on the African continent. But the team's findings in Uganda, revealed in a report released last month by the World Wildlife Fund, pinpoint what wildlife experts believe is the most extensive concentrated killing of elephants in any African nation.

Data processing managers have emerged as pivotal figures in the way businesses control their daily transactions, according to a study released yesterday by a private financial research group. Moreover, it said, poor monitoring of new electronic data systems, coupled with inadequate staffing of new technology, has left many companies vulnerable to a variety of abuses.

A leader of Al Fatah, a Palestinian guerrilla organization, said today that the organization intended to re-establish a major base in Jordan for military operations against Israel. Majed Abu Shrar, who was elected to Al Fatah's 15-member Central Committee during its congress in Damascus 10 days ago, said in an interview that Jordan was crucial to a decision made by his organization at Damascus to expand military operations against Israel. Al Fatah is the largest guerrilla group in the Palestine Liberation Organization.

Two persons involved in the $5.8 million theft from the Lufthansa air cargo terminal at Kennedy International Airport in December 1978 have been cooperating with Federal agents. One of those is Louis Werner, 47 years old, the only person so far convicted in the case. His cooperation was disclosed yesterday in papers his attorney, Jonathan Marks, filed in Federal District Court in Brooklyn in a motion to reduce his 15-year sentence.

The Chrysler Corporation, which is run by Lee A. Iacocca and his former colleagues from the Ford Motor Company, has raided Volkswagen for small-car expertise. Eight of 10 new executives named by Chrysler today to key positions in its diversified operations group, which is involved in product development and manufacturing, come from the ranks of Volkswagen of America, the West German auto maker's American subsidiary, which has been getting high marks for quality.

Ben Rose, a photographer who devised new technology that extended the boundaries of his art, died Sunday of cancer at the North Shore University Hospital, in Manhasset, L.I. He was 64 years old and lived in Beechhurst, Queens. Mr. Rose was able to move a camera with repeatable precision. A typical early device he used was a camera attached to a motor by a string. The motor wound the string onto a reel and the camera was pulled along a track with its shutter open, creating the feeling of motion that the photographer sought.

By James Atlas THE LIFE OF D.H. LAWRENCE. By Keith Sagar. Illustrated. 256 pages. Pantheon. $17.95. BIOGRAPHERS of literary figures face the challenge of how to write about a subject whose life consists largely of sitting alone in a room day after day. Not that writers' lives aren't interesting; the moment when Proust dipped a madeleine in his tea and experienced the involuntary memory that would inspire his great novel, or when Gibbon, loitering on the steps of the Colosseum, decided to write a history of ancient Rome, had the charged intensity of drama. They were the sort of epiphany that can transform a life; and it is these inward revelations that the literary biographer must illuminate.

Laurie Platt Winfrey, a freelance picture editor, and Robert Beahan Shnayerson, editor and publisher of Quest 80 magazine, were married yesterday at their home in Clinton Corners, N.Y. The Rev. John Beaven of Grace Episcopal Church in Millbrook, N.Y., performed the ceremony. The bride, who has been previously married and divorced, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Platt of Nantucket, Mass., and Hobe Sound, Fla. Her father, who is retired, was president of the international division of Marsh & McLennan, the insurance brokerage firm.

Trailing the California Angels, 4-0, in the sixth inning tonight and held scoreless for the last 22 innings, the Yankees erupted for four runs in the seventh, two in the eighth, one in the ninth and one in the 10th to win, 8-7, at Anaheim Stadium. Home runs by a rookie, Jim Lefebvre, and a veteran, Reggie Jackson, kept the Yankees in the game until Bob Watson came through with the winning hit in the first extra inning. Rich Gossage earned his first victory, while the Angels' newest pitcher, Dave Lemanczyk, acquired from Toronto last week, suffered his sixth defeat against two victories.

Partly out of fear that the Federal Government would otherwise make too many inroads into higher education, corporations are increasing their contributions and becoming a more important factor at colleges and universities. In 1978-79 corporate gifts reached a record high of 17.2 percent of total voluntary support, with alumni, other individuals and foundations giving most of the rest.

Tuesday Night Football - in the summertime, no less - will be introduced in the United States next month when Canadian Football League games will be televised over the new ESPN all-sports network. To the C.F.L. commissioner, Jake Gaudaur, this does not mean ''we're naive enough to think we can compete with the National Football League.'' But he said yesterday in Toronto, ''If the income from this becomes significant, it could help us expand the league down the road.''

Another season of free outdoor concerts by the Guggenheim Concert Band was assured yesterday. The ensemble's longtime sponsor, the Daniel and Florence Guggenheim Foundation, agreed to provide up to $90,000 for the seven-week series.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 9 Faced with a lack of customers, Iran is quietly cutting the prices of its crude oil by as much as $3 a barrel, according to diplomatic sources. Discounts are also reportedly being offered on refined fuel oil in an effort to dispose of Iran's large stockpile.
LOWELL, Fla., June 9 (AP) Rejecting arguments that prison is an inappropriate place for an infant, a judge has ordered officials to provide a special cell for a jailed mother and her newborn baby.
WASHINGTON, June 9 When a bomb tore into the home of the charge d'affaires of the Yugoslav Embassy early June 3, the first officer on the scene was not from Washington's police force.

The Association of American Dance Companies has named Harvey Lichtenstein, president and chief executive of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as the recipient of its annual Service Award. Past recipients have included Roger Stevens and W. McNeil Lowry.

ALBANY, June 9 The Republican leaders of the State Senate announced today that the Senate would pass a bill restoring $177 million of the items vetoed from the state budget by Governor Carey, including full restoration of the revenue-sharing aid sought by Mayor Koch.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) said yesterday that the price of all grades of its gasoline would go up immediately by 11 cents a gallon. A spokesman for the company said it was posting the increase in anticipation of a change in Federal regulations. The change will raise the cost of refining crude oil from the North Slope of Alaska, and Sohio has a 53 percent interest in North Slope oil.

ALBANY, June 9 Key Democratic and Republican staff members of the State Legislature worked out a compromise on handgun control today, but it was unclear if the Republican majority in the Senate would go along with it.
A PARASITE that until recent years was believed by most doctors to be harmless now heads the list of the most common intestinal parasitic infections in the United States and some other countries.
MIAMI, June 9 An angry crowd of several hundred demonstrators booed President Carter today in the heart of the Liberty City area, the scene of last month's racial rioting and looting.

Federal wildlife officials poisoned several hundred gulls on Monomoy Island over the weekend to protect the endangered nesting sites of terns. David Beall, manager of the wildlife refuge operated by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service on this uninhabited island off Cape Cod, estimated that 600 gulls had been killed. He said that more would die later from the poison, whose effects are said to be painless.

The General Motors Corporation has begun a new tooling program that in two years will make four-cylinder engines, which are expected to become the most important engine in the auto producers' line, the Metalworking News edition of American Metal Market reported yesterday. The trade newspaper said that the Chevrolet division of General Motors was investing $300 million in two new production lines at its Tonawanda, N.Y., plant. When the project is completed in the summer of 1982, General Motors will be capable of producing 890,000 to 900,000 four-cylinder engines each year, more than any other engine in the company's line, including the V-6's.

Roy J. Battersby, former vice president and director of public relations of the Hill & Knowlton public relations agency, died of cancer yesterday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 67 years old, and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Battersby, who was born in Brooklyn, was a reporter and editor for The New York Herald Tribune, The Daily News and The Associated Press. In World War II, he served as a combat correspondent with the Marine Corps in the Pacific.
ACCESS TO BACK FREE SPEECH By LINDA GREENHOUSE
POLICE814 By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

Herbert Rivington Pyne Jr., a descendant of New York colonial families, died of cancer Saturday at Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 63 years old, and he lived in Medomak, Me., and Harbour Island, the Bahamas. Until 1965, Mr. Pyne was a resident of Peapack, N.J., where he was active in local politics. Mr. Pyne left Princeton University in 1940 to join the Navy and was at Pearl Harbor when the Japanese attacked. He entered as an ensign and rose to lieutenant commander. He returned to Princeton after the war and obtained his degree in 1946.

Armco Inc. said its international division had purchased a major interest in Prolansa, a Peruvian steel wire and wire products manufacturer, for $4.5 million. * Atco Ltd. said that 21 million shares of IU International were tendered under its previously reported offer of $17 a share for 16.2 million IU shares.

Allied Stores filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $100 million of notes due in 1990 to be offered through a group headed by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. * Central Telephone and Utilities said it had registered $40 million of debentures to be offered through a Dean Witter Reynolds group.

A retired police officer was arrested yesterday on a charge that he attempted to extort more than $100,000 last year from Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, the convicted murderer who escaped 10 days ago from a Brooklyn jail. The former officer, Joseph Toscanini, 43 years old, was arrested at his home in Massapequa, L.I. He collapsed, apparently with a heart attack, and was taken to the intensive care unit of the Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow, where he was listed in critical condition.

It's So Nice to Be Civilized,'' the musical by Micki Grant, closed Sunday afternoon at the Martin Beck Theater after eight performances and 20 previews. The presentation was directed by Frank Corsaro and starred Mabel King and Vivian Reed.

The coalition of unions representing New York City's uniformed services presented a new proposal on a cost-of-living adjustment to city negotiators yesterday. The two sides discussed other economic issues at a bargaining session at the New York Hilton, but they remained far apart in the effort to reach a settlement by June 30, when contracts expire.
WITNESS TO JORDAN SHOOTING COMES OUT OF SECLUSION

DALE is an attractive young Chinese-American who has made it in golden Los Angeles. He's not rich, he explains, but he is definitely ''upper middle.'' He has mastered the art of ordering hors d'oeuvres at Scandia and knows just where to hang out in West Hollywood. Late at night, he takes his hot sports car out on the Ventura Freeway, downshifts and flies with the wind. Still, it hasn't been easy for Dale to escape the ''yellow ghosts'' of his childhood. ''My parents tried to cage me up in their Chineseness,'' Dale says. ''I had to work hard to be a human being just like everybody else.'' ''FOB,'' the new play at the Public Theater, tells what happens when Dale must confront the ethnic roots he thought he had severed. The subject of the evening is a very old one: the price that minorities pay to assimilate in mainstream America. But David Henry Hwang, the play's 22-year-old author, is too rambunctious to tell a familiar story in a tired way. In ''FOB,'' he deals with three distinct cultures, Chinese-American, American and Chinese, and writes in at least that many theatrical styles. Though the result is an unwieldy, at times spotty work, Mr. Hwang hits home far more often than he misses. Surely, ''FOB'' is the first show that has ever attempted to marry the conventional well-made play to Oriental theater and to mix the sensibilities of Maxine Hong Kingston and Norman Lear.

In national competition, long-lived partnerships are rare, and longlived teams are even rarer. In this respect, a group from Florida has no challengers. Cliff Russell of Coral Gables and Bill Seamon and Edith Kempt, a brother and sister combination, and Russ Arnold, all of Miami, have been together for two decades. Their high point was in the early 60's, when they won two national knockout titles. Last week they were in action again, winning their Grand National team zonal playoffs, and qualifying for the national quarterfinals in Chicago next month. Rounding out their team were Bill Passell and Dave Strasberg, both of Fort Lauderdale, who were one of New York's strongest partnerships in the 60's and have recently joined forces again as Florida residents.

As more banks moved to lower their prime lending rates to 13 percent from 14 percent, the Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a small bank that tries to keep ahead of the field, cut its prime rate yesterday to 12 percent from 13 percent. The St. Louis Bank, which on several occasions had been the first to post a new prime rate, said its move to 12 percent was intended to narrow the gap between the prime, which is the rate that banks charge their most creditworthy corporate customers, and other shortterm interest rates. Commercial paper, or corporate i.o.u.'s, for example, now carry an interest rate of about 9 percent.

Booth Fisheries Corporation, a Chicago-based processor and distributor of fish and seafood, has named James L. Rogula to the newly created position of executive vice president. * Carisbrook Industries, Iselin, N.J., a specialty textile-products company, announced that James W. Morrison would relinguish his duties as president and chief executive officer.

Philip Guston, a leading painter of the Abstract Expressionist school who in recent years had devoted himself to figurative work, suffered a heart attack and died on Saturday evening in Woodstock, N.Y. Mr. Guston, who would have celebrated his 67th birthday on June 27, had recently received a Creative Arts Award from Brandeis University, citing him for ''notable achievement in the arts.'' Mr. Guston's paintings of the 1950's, in which small, gestural patches of subtle color clustered on a larger field to create an illusion of light, space and air, were highly important to younger painters of the period. Although he worked in this mode for only a few years, his influence was second only to that of Willem de Kooning, and his art was in fact regarded as a kind of lyrical challenge to that of his more ''violent'' Abstract Expressionist colleagues. He was compared with the Impressionists, notably Monet, and labeled an ''abstract impressionist,'' a term he disavowed.

Billy Martin, the Oakland manager whose baseball life seems to be in constant turmoil, today asked Lee MacPhail, the American League president, to suspend Umpire Dale Ford. He charged that the umpire shoved him during an argument in the A's 6-1 loss to the Boston Red Sox yesterday. Martin and Ford gave MacPhail their versions of the argument that led to Martin's ejection and a near-fight afterward in a tunnel below the stands at Oakland Coliseum.

Warner Wolf, the most colorful and perhaps the most popular New York television sportscaster, won the right in State Supreme Court yesterday to switch from WABC-TV to WCBS-TV. Justice Burton S. Sherman dismissed WABC's contention that it was legally entitled to match any competing station's offer to Mr. Wolf. The 42-year old sportscaster has been earning $250,000 a year at WABC; he will earn $400,000 in his first year at WCBS and $450,000 in his second.

Like the trial lawyer he is, Raymond B. Harding, the Liberal leader, responded quickly when asked to give terse characterizations of other politicians and parties: President Carterfuzzy. Governor Careygutsy. Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomomoralistic. Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihanfeisty. Senator Jacob K. Javitslearned. Mayor Kochobnoxious. Conservative Partydying. Right to Life PartyLike Koch, obnoxious.

IN UNWANTED CONSEQUENCES TEHERAN, Iran, June 9 (UPI) -President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr today warned those favoring spy trials for the American hostages that such a course could have unwanted consequences.

A TRINITY John J. Karamon, a photographer, has created an art work involving photography, sculpture and music. He has constructed a mobile of six white panels. Each panel moves 360 degrees, and so does the whole mobile. At the same time, photographic slides - usually nature views and hand-made abstractions - are projected onto the revolving panels. The product is a visual experience. Patterns of the changing images are unlikely to repeat during the 35-minute cycle. Electronically synthesized music, composed by Bruce Haack and called ''The Icarus Odyssey,'' accompanies the projections. Mr. Karamon calls his creation a projected image mobile, or ''Primob: Kinetic Images.''

Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah, the world-record holder in the 110-meter high hurdles, will fly to the West Coast tomorrow with the intention of competing in the Athletics Congress national outdoor championships Friday in Walnut, Calif., his coach said yesterday. Jean Poquette, Nehemiah's coach, said the Scotch Plains, N.J., hurdler has been training twice daily since his last competition on May 11 in Los Angeles. Nehemiah, a student at the University of Maryland and the world's top-ranking hurdler the last two years, finished fourth in the meet and said afterward, ''I won't run again until I'm ready.''

The world economy could recover from the latest oil price rise after a period of recession and it could resume its growth, but a third huge oil price increase or a major interruption of supplies would bring catastrophe, a leading Western central banker has warned. Speaking here as oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries assembled in Algiers for new pricing talks, Jelle Zijlstra, the chairman of the Bank for International Settlements and governor of the Dutch central bank, acknowledged the oil exporters' significance by saying that the ''political risks'' facing the world economy now appeared ''more worrying than the purely economic ones.''
"ORPHEUS," a very sensitive ballet that requires special handling, is receiving such royal treatment from the New York City Ballet that it is hard to believe it once seemed past its prime.
WASHINGTON When Congress killed the G.I. Bill in December 1976, the Army gloomily concluded that the pool of potential recruits would shrink by as much as 36.7 percent.
WASHINGTON, June 9 Social events here mean hard work, and few work harder than the ambassadorial couples who give the diplomatic parties for which this city is famous.

District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens said yesterday that he would be a candidate for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate if party leaders would provide enough support at a Democratic State Committee meeting on Thursday to qualify him for the Sept. 9 primary.

With the tabulation of votes in one portion of Italy's regional and municipal elections virtually complete tonight, the Christian Democrats appeared to have made slight gains at the expense of the Communists, the country's other major party. The voting yesterday and today was for local governments in 15 of the country's 20 regions, 86 of 94 provinces and 6,575 cities and towns out of about 8,000. The polls closed at 2 P.M. today after opening early yesterday.

Diplomats and relief officials who have interviewed scores of Cambodians coming to the Thai border for food say there is mounting evidence of a rapid deterioration of the Cambodian food situation. The officials said that Cambodia's rice from the harvest early this year had been used up and that the Government of President Heng Samrin was distributing rice in sufficient quantity only in Phnom Penh, the capital. They said western Cambodia was being kept alive mainly with rice delivered on the Thai border by Western relief organizations over the opposition of the Phnom Penh Government.

THE Search for Solutions,'' a three-part series beginning on WNET-TV tonight at 9, represents a lofty idea overwhelmed by visual overload. The programs attempt to demonstrate ''how the game of science is played.'' Concentrating on ''problem solving,'' they succeed in being merely puzzling. It is always difficult, of course, to illustrate a process. Consider all the dreadful movies that have been made about artists without being able to convey a smidgen of insight into their creativity. In this television instance, the solution relies on sheer quantity. The production staff spent 14 months traveling to 14 countries on five continents. The compiled 200 hours of film contains 160 interviews.
CONCORD, N.H., June 9 (AP) The Public Service Company of New Hampshire was told today to delay for three years its planned 1985 completion of the second reactor of the Seabrook nuclear power plant.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 9 Gregory P. Schwartz is planning to fly across the country in a single-engine plane he is building in his room on the fifth floor of Greenwich Hospital. He has already spent 50 to 60 hours on the 13-foot long, 275-pound plane, and needs, he says, another month to finish it. But time is an uncertain part of his life.

ACCORDING to an old legend of Quebec, a servant girl named Perrine was entertaining her boyfriend in the parish house where she worked, when the priest returned home unexpectedly. The gallant beau hid in the pantry, where he was forgotten for six weeks until he expired.

Republic Airlines said it had signed a definitive agreement with the Summa Corporation and the estate of the late Howard R. Hughes to buy Hughes Airwest for $38.5 million more than $7 million less than the price agreed upon in March. The purchase is for cash and convertible debentures.
Baruch College conferred degrees on 2,050 students, 271 of them with honors, at its 12th annual commencement exercises yesterday morning.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 9 (AP) Billy Martin, the Oakland manager whose baseball life seems to be in constant turmoil, today asked Lee MacPhail, the American League president, to suspend Umpire Dale Ford. He charged that the umpire shoved him during an argument in the A's 6-1 loss to the Boston Red Sox yesterday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9 A leader of Al Fatah, the Palestinian guerrilla organization, said today that the group intended to re-establish a major base in Jordan for military operations against Israel.
AROUND THE NATION; Murderer Seeks to End Appeals to Stay Execution

Key Democratic and Republican staff members of the State Legislature worked out a compromise on handgun control today, but it was unclear if the Republican majority in the Senate would go along with it. Leaders of the Democratic-led Assembly indicated that the plan was acceptable and said they believed they had the votes to pass it. Senate Republicans, after a conference, postponed a decision until tomorrow.

Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating of Michigan bonds by less than a full notch yesterday - to A+ from AA - as the result of deteriorating conditions in the state's economy and the uncertain future of the automobile industry. After other recessions, Standard & Poor's said, Michigan rebounded along with the rest of the country, but this time changes in the auto industry ''dampen prospects for similar recovery.'' It noted that auto imports now accounted for 27 percent of the United States market, up from 17 percent two years ago. The rating service also was critical of the way Michigan accounted for certain tax refunds, contending that the state failed to use generally accepted accounting principles.
An obituary in The Times yesterday incorrectly identified the deceased, a publisher of popular music. His name was Jerry Vogel.

Tom Ryer sat shirtless, high in the bleachers of the steamy gymnasium at Brandeis High School and discussed his future with Floyd Layne, the basketball coach at City College. Ryer, 19 years old, was the youngest player to attend last week's five-day tryout camp on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, where 50 athletes of varying ability hoped to catch the eye of a scout from a National Basketball Association, Continental League or European team. Ryer's case was special and his aspirations different from most of the others - the powerfully-built, 6-foot-4-inch forward has played his only organized basketball at a maximum security prison in Elmira, N.Y. He was released on parole three weeks ago after serving a 30-month term for armed robbery.

Beatrice M. Ley, an artist and horticulturist, died Saturday at her home in the Bald Peak Colony Club in Melvin Village, N.H. She was 89 years old. Mrs. Ley, a former resident of Manhattan, had a retrospective of 50 years of her paintings and drawings at the Art Gallery of the Greenwich Public Library in Connecticut.

President Carter's supporters, in what they described as a bid for party unity, failed today to chip away at Senator Edward M. Kennedy's control of the closely divided Pennsylvania delegation to the Democratic National Convention. Mayor William J. Green of Philadelphia, a Kennedy backer, was elected chairman at a tense meeting. Carter supporters were told at a caucus that Vice President Mondale had felt it ''totally unacceptable'' that a Kennedy delegate be the sole chairman of the delegation in view of Mr. Kennedy's narrow victory in the primary. They sought to have the delegation elect two co-chairmen, proposing Al Benedict, the state Auditor General, as their man.

Faced with a lack of customers, Iran is quietly cutting the prices of its crude oil by as much as $3 a barrel, according to diplomatic sources. Discounts are also reportedly being offered on refined fuel oil in an effort to dispose of Iran's large stockpile. Two tanker loads of oil bound for India, the sources said, were sold last week at prices between $32 and $33 a barrel. The official price for Iranian light crude is a relatively high $36 a barrel, including two sets of surcharges.
The Federal Government officially dropped the six remaining charges of banking irregularities against Bert Lance today, saying that the cost of retrying him and two codefendants was too high.

Claudell Washington, the Los Angeles Dodgers and a cold rain arrived at Shea Stadium last night and injected some perplexity into the otherwise upbeat mood surrounding the New York Mets. The rain supplied the most immediate effect, wiping out the start of a three-game series and delaying the 1980 New York debut of the Dodgers until tonight.

Sales of new homes fell to an annual rate of 364,000 units in April, the lowest level in nearly 14 years, as high interest rates kept potential buyers out of the market, the Government reported today. Meanwhile, the National Association of Realtors said that sales of previously occupied homes fell to an annual rate of 2.42 million units in April, the lowest level since the 1974-75 recession. An annual rate indicates what would occur over a year's time if sales activity for a single month were continued for 11 more months.

Touch wood, the House of Representatives has finally decided that it accepts the reality of change in Nicaragua. It took nine hours of debate and a personal appeal by Speaker O'Neill, his first such plea on foreign affairs in 28 years; but in the end, the House did authorize $53.7 million in aid for Nicaragua as part of an omnibus aid package for fiscal 1981.

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 9 Diplomats and relief officials who have interviewed scores of Cambodians coming to the Thai border for food say there is mounting evidence of a rapid deterioration of the Cambodian food situation.

GENEVA, June 9 American efforts to keep political issues out of the International Labor Organization were set back today when the agency's Resolutions Committee voted to give priority to discussion of a Jordanian motion calling for the condemnation of Israel for establishing settlements in "Palestine and the other occupied Arab territories."

WASHINGTON, June 9 Administration specialists were briefly elated last week when the House passed a foreign aid bill that would authorize only $86.5 million less than President Carter requested for fiscal 1981. It had been a hard fight.

Precious metals futures prices continued to rise sharply higher yesterday, in part because of fears that an oil price increase by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could heighten inflation.

Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah, the world-record holder in the 110-meter high hurdles will fly to the West Coast tomorrow with the intention of competing in the Athletics Congress national outdoor championships Friday in Walnut, Calif., his coach said yesterday.
The coalition of unions representing New York City's uniformed services presented a new proposal on a cost-of-living adjustment to city negotiators yesterday.

ALBANY, June 9 The sale of "drugrelated paraphernalia" would be prohibited in a bill that has won the approval of Governor Carey's chief counsel and leaders in both houses of the Legislature after a carefully worked out amendment narrowing the definition of such objects.
TWO proposals involving catastrophes that enveloped the earth in sun-shading debris have been advanced to account for past episodes of widespread extinction and climatic change.

Rejecting arguments that prison is an inappropriate place for an infant, a judge has ordered officials to provide a special cell for a jailed mother and her newborn baby. In the first test of a new state law, Circuit Court Judge Wallace Sturgis ordered that a joint cell at the Florida Correctional Institution be given to Elizabeth Miller, 31 years old, who was convicted of grand larceny, and her infant son, Mark Stephen, born May 22.

Howard M. Squadron, a lawyer from Riverdale, in the Bronx, was elected yesterday as chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. His one-year term will begin July 1. He succeeds Theodore R. Mann of Philadelphia. Mr. Squadron, who is 53 years old, was re-elected president of the American Jewish Congress last month at its national convention in Washington. He is a member of the Manhattan law firm of Squadron, Elenoff, Plesent & Lehrer.

The Knicks signed Larry Rogers, a 6-foot-6-inch forward, yesterday. Rogers, who played last season at the University of Houston, was drafted by the Knicks on the fourth round last June as a junior eligible. The 23-year-old, 225-pound Rogers averaged 12.6 points and six rebounds last season for the Cougars, who had a 14-14 won-lost record.

The Association of American Dance Companies has named Harvey Lichtenstein, president and chief executive of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as the recipient of its annual Service Award. Past recipients have included Roger Stevens and W. McNeil Lowry. The association, which represents 350 dance companies, presents the award to figures outside the artistic field who have performed outstanding service to dance. Mr. Lichtenstein was honored for presenting major and innovative dance companies at the academy and for sponsoring young choreographers.

Themis Zambrvycki, a 21-yearold Brazilian who attends Brigham Young University, won the United States women's pentathlon championships yesterday. Linda Waltman, formerly of Texas A & M, finished second and Marilyn King, a 31-yearold two-time United States Olympian, was third. The five events in the competition were the 100-meter hurdles, 800-meter run, long and high jumps and the shot-put.

The World Bank in 12 years under Robert S. McNamara has become the leading international instrument for the transfer of technical and financial assistance to the world's poor. In addition to vastly enlarging its scope of operations, Mr. McNamara, a former Defense Secretary and a former president of the Ford Motor Company, has fostered significant changes in the bank's development strategy.

Francis Warren Pershing - the only son of General of the Armies John J. Pershing, commander of the American Expeditionary Force in World War I - died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital following an emergency operation. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan. In 1938, Mr. Pershing founded Pershing & Company, which became a member of the New York Stock Exchange the following year. The company was merged with the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation last year. Although Mr. Pershing retired shortly afterward, he continued his association with the concern as chairman emeritus of its Pershing division.

Additional security forces were being flown to Tripura and Assam in northeastern India to contain the spreading violence, an official report said today. In Tripura, bordering Bangladesh, serious clashes have occurred since last Thursday, when the local population began a protest against immigrants, mostly Bengalis from Bangladesh.

Stephen M. Goldfeld, 39 years old, has been named one of the three members of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Mr. Goldfeld will fill the prestigious position on the council of chief forecaster, which had been held by Lyle E. Gramley, who last month became a governor of the Federal Reserve Board. For the last nine years, Mr. Goldfeld has been the Class of 1920 Professor in Economics and Banking at Princeton University, where his specialties are money and financial institutions and econometrics. He has been on leave during the current academic year and was slated to become chairman of the economics department in the next academic year.

The Soviet Union, which has long had military ties with Southern Yemen, has turned this country at the southern tip of the Arabian peninsula into what one Western diplomat calls a ''military warehouse.'' Diplomatic sources and Southern Yemeni officials say that Soviet military activity in general has increased significantly since the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan last December. The Cuban and East German presence has also reportedly been increasing.

Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc., the brokerage house, said yesterday that it had offered to negotiate a merger with the Orion Capital Corporation, using $20 a share as ''a negotiating level.'' At that price, Orion's stock would be worth about $150 million. Shearson, which had received a cool reception from the insurance holding company with its earlier offers of $16 and then $17.50 a share, said that this was its ''final offer,'' and that it would remain open until June 19. Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Shearson, said the company was not interested in a hostile transaction.

The American Motors Corporation said today that it was expanding its rebate program with new consumer rebates of $200 to $1,000 on selected A.M.C. and Jeep vehicles. A $1,000 rebate will apply to Cherokee, Wagoneer and Wagoneer Limited models. Under the original rebate offering, effective May 19, about 75 percent of those models were eligible for $500 rebates. Jeep trucks now will carry $500 rebates. Only some truck models had been eligible for that figure before.

President Carter announced today that consumer representatives had been established in 35 Federal agencies, circumventing the Congress that refused to create a separate consumer affairs agency last year. At a news conference this morning, Mr. Carter said his action would ''lock the consumer perspective into the very structure of government.''

WASHINGTON, June 10 A zoning ordinance that limits development in the name of conservation does not necessarily violate the constitutional rights of affected property owners, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.
In a few weeks, the Koch administration will make a preliminary decision that will ultimately change a community, alter the city's skyline and resolve the first round in what has ...

The beginning of operations of Suffolk County's $932 million Southwest Sewer District, already two and a half years behind schedule has been delayed at least until the end of the year because of a dispute ...
Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is challenging Senator Jacob K. Javits for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, began a statewide $100,000 weeklong television campaign yesterday.
Amid the lights, cameras, noise and confusion in the ballroom of the Sheraton Centre, Joe Barry Carroll began his professional basketball career in a ...

WASHINGTON, June 10 The Nuclear Regulatory Commission decided unanimously today to authorize the venting into the atmosphere of the radioactive krypton that has blocked the start of decontamination work at the damaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Carter Administration will curb Federal funding and subsidies for new hospital construction and renovation as ...

Richard Pryor, the prizewinning comedian and writer, was in critical condition today after a flammable drug mixture apparently exploded in his face, badly burning the upper half of his body. Police Lieut. Dan Cooke said Mr. Pryor had told Dr. Jack Grossman, who treated him last night, that he had been burned when ether being used to make ''free base,'' a cocaine derivative, exploded in his face. The drug, created through a chemical reaction of cocaine with the highly volatile solvent, is smoked in a pipe.

President Carter said today that he was inclined to prosecute former Attorney General Ramsey Clark for traveling to Iran in violation of a Presidential ban. In an impromptu, 40-minute news conference with reporters aboard Air Force One on the way to Grand Island, Neb., from the West Coast, Mr. Carter said ''visits by misguided Americans like Clark'' could exacerbate the situation in Iran and further endanger the safety of the American hostages. He said it was his
President Carter came, saw but did not conquer in his visit yesterday to the scene of last month's racial rioting, black leaders here said today.

To the Editor: Professors speaking out against equal opportunity for handicapped citizens should verify facts before their unfounded opinions mislead the public. Mr. Levin's June 5 letter about access to the Museum of Modern Art's Picasso exhibit is riddled with misconceptions, misunderstandings and outright mistakes. irst, handicapped people are not a ''tiny minority.'' Government estimates indicate that there are 36 million permanently handicapped people in the United States - almost one-sixth of our population. Of these, the National Center for Health Statistics reports 11.7 million permanently physically disabled people, including 500,000 people who use wheelchairs. These figures are exceeded by an additional 12.5 million temporarily physically disabled people at all times in the U.S. Altogether - hardly a ''tiny minority.''

ELECTORAL Process: Recent Returns, Decaying Memories,'' Marc Grafe's program of performance pieces at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation on Thursday, didn't turn out perfectly. The chili Mr. Grafe cooked wasn't ready before the end of his prerecorded electronic tape of ''Pomp and Circumstance,'' and one of his two electric trains failed to budge. But everything worked out in the end, at least as far as the chili was concerned; after the program, it was consumed ravenously by the small audience. Aside from the homey chili-cooking lesson, Mr. Grafe's program included an interesting piece of found art, namely an official United States Government code relating to the performance of our national anthem. Various versions of ''The Star-Spangled Banner'' played while Mr. Grafe read the code, which stipulated, among many other things, that even unaccompanied vocalists should be careful to render the anthem in the key of A flat.

IN the older office buildings that cluster on Court Street and a few side streets of downtown Brooklyn the occupancy reflects the presence of governmental and judicial institutions. This is Brooklyn's civic center. Borough Hall and the massive courthouse loom near by. Educational institutions, public and private, crowd the neighborhood. The Brooklyn Archdiocese and the Board of Education's headquarters are centered here, and so are the large public utilities. The office occupants are no longer the insurance and banking institutions that once were prominent in downtown Brooklyn. Instead one finds mainly professional offices or small service companies or civic groups and, above all, law offices, sharing the estimated 2 million square feet of space in the larger prewar buildings.

NEIL ALLEN was scared. He was a 21-year-old rookie on his first day of spring training, in awe of every New York Met in the clubhouse. He was even in awe of the equipment manager. Mustering up what tiny bit of courage he could find, he tiptoed to the equipment manager and asked if the Mets could possibly spare a belt for his uniform.

THUNDERBIRD. Is it a bird, is it a plane, is it a car? Yes, all three, but it is also a graduate school of international management that gives a degree called master of international management. Each year the school graduates about l,000 men and women, who call themselves Thunderbirds, for the thunderbird is the school's logo and its nickname. The American Graduate School of International Management is its official name. The school, whose campus once was Thunderbird Field No. l, a deactivated pilot-training center in Glendale, Ariz., began as a nonprofit operation in 1946.

Two cars collided on Interstate 94 yesterday, killing seven persons. The authorities said that five victims, all Montana residents in their early 20's, were in one auto and an elderly Everett, Wash., couple was in the other. There were no survivors.

Gloria Vanderbilt is a celebrity. River House is a Manhattan residential structure in which apartments sell for $1.1 million. Miss Vanderbilt wants to buy a $1.1-million apartment in River House but River House's board of directors, which represents the building's tenants, refuses to sell it to her. Miss Vanderbilt is suing. She says River House is discriminating against her because she is a woman and is a friend of Bobby Short, a pianist and singer who is black. River House says it is not discriminating against her because of her sex or her friends' race, but simply does not want the ''unwelcome publicity'' she would bring to River House.
