ALGIERS, June 10--The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended its meeting tonight in disunity but with a tentative agreement that promises another increase in the price of oil.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the purchase by the Southern Pacific Transportation Company ...

Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned today that Iran was in ''chaos'' and said that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and the majority party in Parliament should mend their differences to avoid a danger that the Iranian Islamic Republic might destroy itself. In a speech to province governors, broadcast by the state radio, the Islamic revolutionary leader said that foremost among the problems facing the nation were the choice of a Prime Minister and the fate of the 53 American hostages held since Nov. 4.

The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries ended its meeting tonight in disunity but with a tentative agreement that promises another increase in the price of oil. After a stubborn, two-day attempt to reach common ground on pricing and production levels, the members of the oil cartel agreed to set the price of crude oil between a floor of $28 a barrel, which is the price that Saudi Arabia now charges for much of its oil, and a ceiling of $37 a barrel.

The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it would permit some Iranian students enrolled in American colleges and universities to extend their stays in the United States. David W. Crosland, acting commissioner of the agency, sent out instructions to all field offices granting, in effect, a reprieve to Iranian students who had been admitted to this country for a limited period, with a precise departure date stamped on their travel documents.

Mayor Koch acquiesced tonight in a compromise handgun control bill worked out by legislative and gubernatorial counsels over the weekend. His approval was thought to all but clinch passage of the measure. The bill would establish a mandatory minimum sentence of one year in jail for the unlicensed possession of a loaded gun on the street. Some sentencing discretion would be left to the courts and the district attorneys, however, for people with no prior criminal histories.

How has the recession affected booksellers and publishers? Walking up and down the aisles of the American Booksellers Association trade exhibition here, where the publishers display their fall line, you can hear a dozen viewpoints, but there is agreement that the business has had a rough time in the first half of this year. The reasons are the same as those that affect other industries - the high cost of production, soaring interest rates, the effort to keep prices stable for fear of losing customers while profit percentages are reduced, and caution in overstocking inventories because of buyer resistance. Added to these is the peculiar nature of the business that allows returns of unsold books to publishers for as much as a half-year after they have sat on shelves.

The American kitchen is returning to basics. That was demonstrated anew at the Eastern Gourmet Show, which opened at the New York Coliseum Sunday and continues through 1 P.M. today. It is a regional trade show, in partnership with the New York china and glass show, which offers buyers a taste of things to come at the major semiannual housewares show scheduled for Chicago next month. It did not matter whether one preferred an honest country feeling from down on the farm or a sleek technological style, for the frills were hard to find. The look was functional. Even in glossy plastic, straight lines and primary colors dominated.

Warren P. Munsell, secretary and general manager of the Actors' Fund of America and former business manager of the Theatre Guild, died Sunday at St. Clare's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Munsell was a former vaudevillian and actor whose association with the Broadway theater began in 1912, when he appeared in ''The Talker'' at the Sam H. Harris Theater. He had made his stage debut in 1908 in vaudeville in Iowa, where he was born.

Willie Aikens drove in four runs as the Kansas City Royals defeated the Cleveland Indians, 8-4, tonight. But the Royals lost George Brett, their star third baseman, with a leg injury. Aikens singled, doubled and hit his third home run - a two-run shot - in the third inning. Brett, who hit his eighth homer of the year in the first inning, suffered ligament damage to his right leg when he stole second just before Aikens's homer.

OPEC reached a tentative agreement that promises to raise oil prices. The pact fixes prices between $28 a barrel, which Saudi Arabia now charges, and $37, in a rebuff to Saudi attempts to hold down prices. Persian Gulf producers could raise prices by $2 a barrel and North African producers by $1 under the new guideline. In addition, producers may cut output to keep supply in line with demand, sources at OPEC's Algiers meeting said. (Page A1.) Oil industry sources suggest the oil surplus is surprisingly small. (D4.) Exxon has confirmed gas shows in the Baltimore Canyon, C.C. Garvin Jr., chairman, told securities analysts in Houston. (D4.)

With Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira hospitalized for 10 days with a heart ailment, reports that he might be forced to resign swept the capital today as political leaders pressed forward with a heated campaign for general elections on June 22. Mr. Ohira is taking no part in the campaign, and, although the Government has declined to confirm the reports, the Japanese press appeared to be assuming that his political career is close to finished.

The tiny principality of Andorra has in two decades rocketed from bucolic poverty to fabulous wealth, and in the process it has ruined its splendid mountain setting with urban sprawl and, just possibly, has jeopardized its 700-year history of limited sovereignty. Andorra's duty-free and virtually law-free status has been the reason for its prosperity. Cheap electronic gadgetry, video casettes, pocket computers, Chivas Regal, French cheeses, Pierre Cardin styles and other discounted luxury items each year draw more than seven million tourists, four million of them Spaniards, up its narrow valley between France and Spain.

Consumer prices in the 24-nation area of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development advanced 1.3 percent in April, bringing the increase over the past 12 months to almost 14 percent, the O.E.C.D. reported today.
France and Britain sent paramilitary policemen to the island of Tanna today to quell rioting in which one person was killed.

Few things have changed more radically in the lifetime of Americans over 40 than the legal definition of obscenity. Until the 1950's, important works by reputable writers had to be smuggled into the United States - such items as Lawrence's ''Lady Chatterley's Lover'' and even Nabokov's ''Lolita.'' But the most widely smuggled books were the novels of Henry Miller, who was clearly, almost proudly, disreputable. For a generation of American students, buying paperback copies of Mr. Miller's works was as much a Parisian rite as having a cafe filtre at Les Deux Magots in the hope of glimpsing some famous existentialist. How carefully these volumes were wrapped in deceptive dustjackets so that U.S. Customs would not encounter ''Tropic of Cancer.'' All the fun went out of the game when the courts decided in 1964 that Mr. Miller had redeeming social value after all.

The 28th season of the Stratford Festival, Canada, the sixth under the artistic direction of Robin Phillips, opened last night with a resplendent production of ''Twelfth Night,'' one that articulates the work's melancholic humor as well as its beauty and sagacity. Primary among its numerous assets, Mr. Phillips's production features Brian Bedford as Malvolio, a performance of grand comic dimension. It is Malvolio, Olivia's misanthropic steward, who gives us an ironic perspective on this fanciful world of shifting guises, an Illyria in which mistaken identity is carried to extremes of dissimulation. Malvolio is both an insufferable moralist and a harbinger of a society that would subordinate sentiment to reason. Unlike Tartuffe, whom he somewhat superficially resembles, he has a certain unquenchable integrity.

A dissident stockholder of the Carriers and General Corporation urged in a letter to other shareholders yesterday that they join him in opposing an amendment in the company's charter that would require a two-thirds vote, instead of the present majority vote, to approve certain transactions, including mergers.
To the disappointment of the credit markets, the Federal Reserve yesterday implicitly signaled that it would not encourage short-term interest rates ...

SAINT REGIS RESERVATION, N.Y., June 10 Tension remained high today after a series of confrontations between Mohawk Indians and New York State police officers that began last week on this reservation on the St. Lawrence River ...

PARIS, June 10 (UPI) Consumer prices in the 24-nation area of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development advanced 1.3 percent in April, bringing the increase over the past 12 months to almost 14 percent, the O.E.C.D. reported today.

SEATTLE, June 10 President Carter told a gathering of mayors and city officials today that if the current recession worsens significantly, he will propose new steps to help those who lose their jobs and to help cities hurt by a loss of tax income.
The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced that it had reached an agreement to sell four of its ships for $65 million to the Norman Group, made up of individual international shipowners.

ANDORRA, June 4 The tiny principality of Andorra has in two decades rocketed from bucolic poverty to fabulous wealth, and in the process it has ruined its splendid mountain setting with urban sprawl and, just possibly, has jeopardized its 700-year history of limited sovereignty.

IJMUIDEN, the Netherlands, June 10 (Reuters) Members of the environmental group Greenpeace blockaded a canal today to prevent a ship from leaving harbor to dump radioactive waste in the Atlantic Ocean, the police reported. The Andrea Smits was to sail tonight with low to moderately radioactive waste from nuclear power stations, laboratories and hospitals, packed in concretelined steel drums.
WASHINGTON, June 10 The Federal Reserve wants to let nonmember financial institutions borrow money from its discount window.

WASHINGTON, June 10 About this time last year, Thomas Graham Jr., a senior legal aide in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, was in Geneva, spending 16-hour days putting the final touches on the second Soviet-American strategic arms treaty.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in its third annual report to Congress on the accounting profession, said yesterday that it was still unclear whether accountants would effectively regulate themselves.
MANY people breathe a great sigh of relief upon returning home "safe and sound" from a trip.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The Department of the Treasury today ordered producers of beer, wine and distilled spirits, beginning in 1983, to list their products' ingredients on labels or provide a statement telling where consumers ...
WEST BERLIN, June 10 West andEast Germany are moving closer together, their relations improving despite the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and East-West tensions.
AS far as I can tell, the only thing wrong with "Album," David Rimmer's new play at the WPA Theater, is its length.

WASHINGTON, June 9 The Environmental Protection Agency, amid protests by environmental and health groups, has told the Procter Gamble Company that it would not object to the mass marketing of a detergent ingredient known to cause cancer in animals.

IN a scene midway through ''Bronco Billy,'' the best and funniest Clint Eastwood movie in quite a while, the cowboy of the title strides into a bank. And he starts to cash a check for $3, because in this movie all of the nice people are poor. Suddenly, two bank robbers burst in, and they scare a little boy, one of many innocent customers in the place. The little boy drops his piggy bank and it shatters. This is too much for Bronco Billy. He give the bandits The Look, an indignant squint that means, roughly translated, ''Grrr,'' and then he hauls off and fires away. What makes all this unusual for Mr. Eastwood, who directed the disarmingly boyish ''Bronco Billy'' and stars in the title role, is that the cowboy is more interested in the child than he is in the holdup men, and that he shoots the villains fairly politely, as if he didn't mean to do them any harm. Indeed, Mr. Eastwood is almost playing a very large Peter Pan. The locale may be Idaho instead of never-never land, but the feeling is that of a fairy tale, as Bronco Billy wanders through the West with a troupe of lost boys and girls. This is an emphatically American fable, which is perhaps why it ends with a chorus of ''Stars and Stripes Forever.''
AROUND THE NATION; Florida Inquiry Is Critical Of Pilot in Ship Accident

Maryland's highest court, the Court of Appeals, upheld the state's death penalty today but threw out the first capital punishment sentence imposed under the act because of a procedural problem. The Court of Appeals reversed the death sentence imposed last August on Richard D. Tichnell but upheld his conviction for the murder of a deputy sheriff.

Negotiators for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Brotherhood of Railroad Carmen representing workers on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson lines met throughout the day yesterday in an attempt to avert a strike threatened for midnight tonight. Negotiators met with a Federal mediator in a motel in East Brunswick, N.J., but a source close to the talks said there was no significant progress.

After 40 days on patrol in the 110-mile-wide Straits of Florida, monitoring the sealift of Cuban refugees and rescuing hundreds of people from vessels in distress, the Coast Guard cutter Dallas returned to her home base on Governors Island yesterday. Crew members spoke movingly of their involvement with what they called ''the freedom flotilla.'' Radarman Wesley T. Allely Jr. said: ''We've heard some people say the refugees are a burden for America, but when you've been there and seen what they've gone through, that's the furthest thing from your mind.'' His 11-year-old daughter, Teri, ran aboard to hug him as soon as the Dallas slipped into her berth, across from the southern tip of Manhattan, just after 8 A.M.

By Anatole Broyard SOHO MADONNA. By Ellen Alexander Con- ley. 205 pages. An Avon Original: paper- back $2.25. HERE is SoHo's first heroine, Jobina Anderson, queen of the reductio ad absurdum. If you called her that to her face, she would say that it's what married women are wearing these days.

The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, yesterday became the second Republican in a week to announce his support of Mayor Koch for re-election. The announcement came 17 months before the election. ''He is doing a great job,'' Mr. Purcell said. ''He is speaking out articulately for the cities, and that applies to the suburbs, too.'' He added that the Mayor had not sought his endorsement. ''He might not even want it,'' Mr. Purcell said.

A.M. Sullivan, a poet and former executive of Dun & Bradstreet Inc., a diversified business-information concern, died yesterday at a Montclair Nursing Homes in Montclair, N.J. He was 83 years old, and a resident of Montclair. Mr. Sullivan had a long and productive career as a poet while working as advertising and public relations director for Dun & Bradstreet and as editor of Duns Review. He edited the business magazine from 1954 - he had joined the company in 1934 - to his retirement in 1961. He was a consultant to the company until 1971.

Sales by the nation's retailers fell for the fourth consecutive month in May, with the drop since January far exceeding the four-month sales decline that occurred at the depth of the 1974-75 recession, the Government reported today. Retail sales fell from a seasonally adjusted $74.8 billion in April, to $73.7 billion in May, for a 1.5 percent decline, according to a Commerce Department report.

With two swift choices in the first round of yesterday's National Basketball Association college draft, the New Jersey Nets filled two open positions on their roster, but the New York Knicks were forced to wait until the second round to come up with a needed power forward. The Nets, smiling almost before the draft began, used their two consecutive first-round draft choices to obtain Mike O'Koren, a 6-foot-7-inch small forward from North Carolina - the No. 6 pick over all - and Mike Gminski, a 6-11 center from Duke, No. 7.

Americans, buffeted by conflicting advice from scientists, food producers, nutritionists and their own Government, appear more confused than ever about what is best for them to eat. ''If you go according to everything they tell you,'' said Jo Ann Terranova as she shopped for herself, her husband and their four children recently at a supermarket in Great Neck, L.I., ''you might as well stop living or become a vegetarian.''

The Senate voted 62 to 32 today to end a filibuster against draft registration, thus clearing the way for passage of the bill within 10 days. After the vote, Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, who is the most outspoken Senate opponent of the draft, said that he would continue to use every parliamentary tactic possible to delay final approval of the measure. Senate rules permit debate, amendments, votes and the like for 100 hours of legislative time after cloture is voted.

All mathematicians and most politicians have counted Senator Kennedy out, so what keeps him in the Presidential race? What makes Teddy run? You have to live in this goofy town in order to understand that this is essentially a psychological question. Nobody believes in logic around here, and almost everybody believes in the accidents of politics. From Warren Harding to Jimmy Carter, all sorts of unlikely characters have stumbled into the White House, so Kennedy soldiers on.

THE face of Wall Street has changed dramatically in recent years, with hundreds of firms falling by the wayside or merging with stronger houses in the last decade. Nevertheless, Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, which has been the largest firm by any measure for many years, continues in the top spot. In terms of capital, it is three times larger than its nearest competitor.

An Oklahoma pastor who is considered a rigorous conservative about the Bible, the Rev. Bailey E. Smith, today was elected president of the Southern Baptist Convention on a surprising first ballot. He won over five other candidates, gathering 5,739 votes for a slim 51.6 percent majority, but with nearly double the tally for his closest rival, the Rev. Frank Pollard, a Jackson, Miss., moderate, who received 2,382 votes.

To the Editor: Has anyone visited Battery Park lately? It is garbage-strewn and barely landscaped. The only snack bar in the park, Luchow's Garden, has a rundown ''garden'' which is also strewn with garbage. And all this only blocks from the headquarters of giant banks and brokerage houses.ot one executive of one of these corporations has the ima-gination to recognize that the city is incapable of taking care of Battery Park. Not one executive appears to be aware that their employees use the park. Or perhaps they know and they just do not care. DIANE JAMES New York, May 28, 1980

SOON, we shall be leaving the country, again. As Voltaire said on leaving Holland, ''Adieu, canals, ducks, rabble!'' Voltaire, as Bergen Evans has pointed out, said it better in French: ''Adieu, canaux, canards, canaille!'' We shall probably be leaving the country for the last time as a family. As you read these words, my son has graduated from high school and is on a raft on the Sewanee River; after a year at college, he will want to travel with someone more compatible than his father. And because he is going to college, his father will not be able to afford to leave the country. My son and his friends built their own raft. I remember a friend of mine who refused to be a paratrooper because, in those days, paratroopers had to pack their own parachutes, and my friend didn't trust his death wish. My son, however, is a stranger to the death wish. He is jumping into his future and my debt.

THE SUICIDE,'' a comedy banned in the Soviet Union that played to an admiring critical reception at the Trinity Square Repertory Theater in Providence R.I., last February, will open on Broadway in October - one of the very few Soviet plays to reach the American stage. It will have a capitalization of $800,000, a generous outlay for a straight play. It will bring along with it a number of firsts: It will be the first Broadway assignment for Jonas Jurasas, the Soviet emigre from Lithuania who directed it at Trinity Square. It will bring Derek Jacobi, the much-esteemed British actor who had the title role in the television series ''I, Claudius'' to the American stage for the first time as its star.

A Congressional subcommittee said yesterday that it had asked the Justice Department and two Federal agencies to examine information supplied by Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, plus sworn testimony by a former employee of theirs, to see if the brothers had violated the law. Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, the Queens Democrat who is chairman of the subcommittee, expressed concern that ''the Hunts may have felt themselves to be above the law.'' The Hunts were not available for comment, but one Hunt attorney, Roger Goldburg, said the charges were blatantly untrue.

The California Angels' third baseman, Carney Lansford, was fined $250 today and suspended for three games for bumping an umpire in Sunday's game against Baltimore. Lansford said he thought he could win an appeal of the case but would accept the league's decision.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP) An Oklahoma pastor who is considered a rigorous conservative about the Bible, the Rev. Bailey E. Smith, today was elected president of the Southern Baptist Convention on a surprising first ballot.

Americans, buffeted by conflicting advice from scientists, food producers, nutritionists and their own Government, appear more confused than ever about what is best for them to eat.
OTTAWA, June 10 Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that his planned meeting in September with the premiers of the 10 provinces represented a deadline for constitutional change.

KUWAIT, June 10 (UPI) The Soviet Union will supply Syria with heavy sophisticated weapons worth $3 billion without charge and exempt Damascus from 80 percent of its debts, a Kuwaiti newspaper reported today. The paper, Al Watan, attributed the report to "reliable sources" in Damascus. It did not state the nature of the weapons.

A retired police officer who faces a felony charge in the Howard (Buddy) Jacobson case remained in critical condition yesterday in the Nassau County Medical Center.
Negotiators for New York City and the uniformed services coalition yesterday discussed the cost of incorporating lump-sum payments already offered into wage rates, union officials said.
Gloria Vanderbilt is a celebrity. River House is a Manhattan residential structure in which apartments sell for $1.1 million.
WASHINGTON, June 10 President Carter said today that he was inclined to prosecute former Attorney General Ramsey Clark for traveling to Iran in violation of a Presidential ban.
IF you are flying in an airplane, all you do is wade through the pouch in front of your seat and scoop up the latest copy of the airline's in-flight magazine.
An express bus rolled over four times and plunged into a ditch today, killing 4 people and injuring 10.

President Carter told a gathering of mayors and city officials today that if the current recession worsens significantly, he will propose new steps to help those who lose their jobs and to help cities hurt by a loss of tax income. But in a speech before the United States Conference of Mayors, Mr. Carter made no specific proposals, and he declared that those programs he had already proposed were ''adequate'' under current economic conditions.

PLYMOUTH, CALIF. THE rugged foothills of the Sierra Nevada mountains are steeped in the lore of the Gold Rush of 1849, but now a new kind of legend is taking shape here. It is a legend involving some of the most extraordinary table wines made in the United States, wines whose fame is suddenly spreading across the country as more and more consumers experience them. They are the zinfandels of Amador County, the biggest, richest, spiciest, most intensely flavored red wines produced anywhere in the nation, mouth-filling wines with a texture so luscious that it can almost be chewed. They sometimes convey a hint of raspberries, at other times chocolate or mint, combined with the generous fruit of the zinfandel grape.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; Bolivia's Congress Rejects Call to Put Off Elections
Mudslides caused by torrential rains overnight killed at least 35 people, most of them poor people whose shacks collapsed, the police said today.

While the marijuana dealers peddled their wares yesterday (''Smoke, sir?'') like popcorn purveyors in a theater lobby, the Sidewalks Theater presented a Moliere satire to the noontime sun and sandwich crowd in Bryant Park. The sky was gray and the wind was chill, but Moliere, the 17thcentury Frenchman who loved natural comedy, might have been warmed by this.

The police said today that armed men tricked their way into the country home of Eulogio Gomez, a member of Parliament, last night and tried to kidnap him. Mr. Gomez foiled the attempt by grabbing a pistol and wounding the group's leader. The police arrested the leader but refused to identify him for fear of jeopardizing the hunt for his accomplices.

The World Team Olympiad in @Valkenburg, the Netherlands, will be held in October, and the North American representatives are hoping to improve on past results. Since this quadrennial series began in 1960 they have never won a major title in either the open or women's divisions. The Europeans have been dominant, although Brazil captured the open team championship in Monte Carlo four years ago.

The cookbook shelf, like the market, has seasonal highlights stocked alongside the year-round staples. The summer cookbook is particularly welcome because just when the produce is at its most bountiful, the cook inevitably begins to wilt in the heat. It takes recipes for pale, iced soups, inventive salads, vivid fresh vegetable dishes, simple grilled meat or steamed fish and the cool, voluptuous richness of ripe fruit to whet the appetite. Still at its classic best is Elizabeth David's ''Summer Cooking'' (Penguin, 1980, $2.95), first written in 1955 and reissued this year for the 13th time. The cover is new. ''Summer Cooking'' deserves to be a perennial favorite with a place in every summer cook's kitchen.

An interagency trade advisory committee has urged President Carter to negotiate a downward adjustment in duties on Japanese pickup trucks in exchange for new trade concessions by Japan. A series of options, all looking forward to lower duties but differing over what precisely should be sought from the Japanese in return, went to the President following what Administration officials said was intense debate.

Forest Oil announced the public offering of $65 million of 13 7/8 percent debentures due June 1, 2000, at a price of 100 percent. Shearson Loeb Rhoades Inc. is manager of the underwriting group. * Halliburton filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission $200 million of 25-year sinking fund debentures due June 1, 2005, through a group led by Lazard Freres.

The Federal Government filed a lawsuit today to recover $345 million in Medicaid payments it said had been improperly claimed by New York State. In court papers, the Department of Health and Human Services accused the state of ''a premeditated act of wrong- doing.'' The department's suit asserts that ''New York devised and executed a scheme to outwit H.H.S., thwart Congress and reimburse itself'' and that ''the scheme was not subtle: New York simply dipped into the United States Treasury.''

The Chilocco Indian School, often called ''The Lights on the Prairie,'' is closing after 96 years. It was the only Indian boarding school in the nation offering vocational education. ''The Government is taking away the last chance we've got,'' said Ralph Dent, an 18-year-old student from Perry, Okla.. ''I can't do English very good, but I can do vocational things,'' added Lantz McLendon, 20, a Seminole from Lakeland, Fla. The school was the one place where young Indians who had trouble with academic subjects could learn a skill. Wide Representation of Tribes

The Department of the Treasury today ordered producers of beer, wine and distilled spirits, beginning in 1983, to list their products' ingredients on labels or provide a statement telling where consumers can obtain such information. The regulation is the outcome of a battle between consumer groups and the alcoholic beverage industry over such labeling requirements and represents a compromise for both groups. Heavy lobbying by the wine industry continued right up until the time the regulations were released today.

United States businesses reduced their capital-spending plans for 1980 after the nation's economy weakened and fell into recession, the Commerce Department reported today. A survey completed last month showed that the nation's businesses intend to spend $194.6 billion for new plants and equipment this year, or 9.9 percent more than in 1979.

A convicted murderer, Jack Howard Potts, changing his mind about living or dying, persuaded a Federal judge today to let him drop a last-minute appeal that blocked his execution in Georgia's electric chair last week. Judge William C. O'Kelley agreed to cancel the stay he signed last Wednesday just 13 hours before Mr. Potts's scheduled execution. Mr. Potts, dressed in prison garb and with his head completely shaved, was taken into Judge O'Kelley's courtroom guarded by two corrections officers and two state troopers.
A small earthquake briefly shook the Texas Panhandle and western Oklahoma today, apparently causing no injuries or damage.

A zoning ordinance that limits development in the name of conservation does not necessarily violate the constitutional rights of affected property owners, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today. The Court rejected the argument of a California couple that environmental restrictions placed on their five acres of vacant land overlooking San Francisco Bay constituted a ''taking'' of the property without the compensation required by the Fifth Amendment.

When one world-class player loses to another in only 19 moves, particularly if he neither committed an outrageous blunder nor ran into a crushing opening innovation, it's an intriguing to learn what went wrong. In the game between Grandmasters Jan Timman of the Netherlands and Bent Larsen of Denmark in the last round of the Phillips & Drew Kings international tournament in London, it may be that Black thought to bluff his opponent out of a strong attack, but he had nothing to fall back on when his bluff was called.

TO THE LIVING SECTION: I would like to compliment Jane E. Brody for putting together ''The Evidence Builds Against Marijuana'' (Personal Health, May 21). This article accurately portrays some of the many problems that marijuana is causing. The author states the scientific truth that marijuana is harmful because of its long half-life, which has a subtle and cumulative effect on the fat-laden tissues of the body such as the brain and reproductive organs.

Cornell C. Maier, chairman of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Company, told a meeting of analysts in New York yesterday that his company would have ''significantly higher earnings'' this quarter than its $59.6 million, or $1.46 a share, of a year ago.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 10 (AP) Maryland's highest court, the Court of Appeals, upheld the state's death penalty today but threw out the first capital punishment sentence imposed under the act because of a procedural problem.
ANAHEIM, Calif., June 10 The California Angels rallied for three runs in the eighth inning tonight two of them on a homer by the 5-foot-4-inch Freddie Patek for a 5-4 victory over the Yankees.

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 10 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, asserting that he would fight for the Democratic Presidential nomination "all the way to the roll call" at the party's national convention in August, called today for a multibillion-dollar Federal program to combat the recession.

An influential Government advisory panel has recommended approving research that would be the first exception to the longstanding rule prohibiting release of products of gene-splicing into the environment.

SOON, we shall be leaving the country, again. As Voltaire said on leaving Holland, "Adieu, canals, ducks, rabble!" Voltaire, as Bergen Evans has pointed out, said it better in French: "Adieu, canaux, canards, canaille!" ...

WASHINGTON, June 10 Despite risks to Ronald Reagan's drive to promote Republican Party unity for the fall campaign, top strategists are moving toward replacing Bill Brock as chairman of the Republican National Committee, authoritative sources said today.
JERSEY CITY, June 10 Mayor Thomas F.X. Smith abandoned his challenge to State Senator Walter N. Sheil's chairmanship of the Hudson County ...

A Federal District Court jury has convicted a former Bishop College vice president of misusing $85,000 in school retirement funds. Two former college administrators were acquitted on similar charges. The jurors could not reach a verdict, however, on the bulk of the charges against all three. Jurors deliberated for 11 days before returning verdicts yesterday. Convicted on two counts of misusing retirement funds at the predominantly black liberal arts college was Reginald Lefall, 37 years old. United States Attorney Robert Prather alleged that the retirement funds had been used to pay bills of the financially troubled school. Mr. Lefall was indicted on 59 counts, but jurors could not agree on the 57 remaining charges.

History will mark the events in Iran, Afghanistan and Nicaragua in 1979 as a turning point in the invisible war between radical and moderate forces for control of the oil and destiny of the Middle East and control of Central America and Mexico. In the Middle East, the outcome of the process now gaining momentum might include the replacement of the royal families in the oil states of the Arabian Peninsula by radical anti-Western regimes. Among the effects of such a change could be the use of Israel and oil supplies as the fulcrum to divide America from Europe and Japan, which depend on that region for more than 70 percent of their oil consumption. While encouraging radical destabilization in the Persian Gulf area, the Soviet Union could use a diplomacy of conciliation with Europe and Japan intended to end any meaningful alliance with America.

Granola cereals contain 22 to 32 percent sugar, placing them in the mid-range of all cereals tested for sugar content, a research chemist for the Agriculture Department reported today. Kellogg's Country Morning had the highest average amount of sugar compared to the dry weight of the product - 31 percent - among three boxes each of 14 nationally distributed granola cereals tested, the report said.

The National Hockey League is considering the adoption of an overtime period in regular-season play. The league's rules committee has drafted a proposal calling for a 10-minute extra period to be played after ties, with the first goal winning the game. If no team scores, the game would end in a tie, with each team receiving a point in the standing, as happens now. The vote on the sudden-death overtime proposal in the rules committee resulted in a tie, but the proposal will be sent to the league's board of governors nonetheless. That group meets in Los Angeles in two weeks.

The Pentagon transferred one of President Carter's military aides after the Marine Corps major became embroiled in a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over nonpayment of taxes on religious grounds. Maj. Jeffery Zorn, who was given the White House assignment last December, said he had not paid income taxes since 1976, when he took a vow of poverty and began turning his military pay over to a small church that he heads.

Negotiators for New York City and the uniformed services coalition yesterday discussed the cost of incorporating lump-sum payments already offered into wage rates, union officials said. If the annual increases of $750 now being paid in place of cost of living adjustments were put into wage rates and used in calculating benefits, the cost would be greater.

The Court of Appeals today struck down as unconstitutional a state law that prohibited topless entertainment in bars licensed by the State Liquor Authority. In a 4-to-3 decision, the state's highest tribunal held that topless, or bare-breasted, dancing in bars by women was entitled to ''at least minimal protection'' as a ''type of expression'' under the First Amendment guarantee of free speech or expression.

International The deepening leadership split in Iran led to a warning by Ayatollah Khomeini that the country was in ''chaos.'' He said that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and the fundamentalist Islamic Party controlling Parliament should mend their differences to avoid a danger that the Islamic Republic might destroy itself. (Page A1, Col.3.) A tiny duty-free principality in Europe has rocketed in two decades from rural poverty to great wealth and, in the process, its bucolic setting in the Pyrenees has been transformed into an urban sprawl. The virtually law-free status of Andorra has attracted smuggled goods and money that may jeopardize its limited sovereignty. (A1:4-6.) New leadership in Japan is expected no matter which party wins the general elections on June 22. Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira is hospitalized with a heart ailment and reports swept Tokyo that he may have to resign. (A3:4-6.) Italy's regional elections resulted in modest gains for the governing Christian Democrats, but the Communists held on to governments in some of the biggest industrial cities. (A11:1.) Energy A new increase in the price of oil was in prospect as a result of the OPEC meeting in Algiers. An increase of about 3 cents a gallon in the retail prices of petroleum products in the United States is foreshadowed if all members of the oil cartel follow a tentative agreement reached by its ministers. But the accord apparently failed to win the support of Saudi Arabia, the largest OPEC producer. (A1:6.) National Ramsey Clark may be prosecuted for traveling to Iran in violation of a Presidential ban. President Carter said he was inclined to favor the move against the former Attorney General on the ground that the trip further endangered the safety of the American hostages. Mr. Carter also told reporters said that he was reconsidering his decision not to debate Representative John B. Anderson, the independent Presidential candidate. (A1:1.) A large budget deficit in the next fiscal year is likely to result from the weakening of the economy and the disapproval by Congress of the oil import fee, according to private statements by senior economic officials in the Carter Administration. Publicly, they have gradually stopped talking about balancing the budget and have begun stressing the aim of restraining growth in Federal spending. (A1:5.) Registration for a draft advanced as the Senate voted 62 to 32 to end a filibuster, clearing the way for expected passage of the bill within 10 days. The House has approved a bill for registering young men, and President Carter is believed certain to sign it. (A1:4.) Ronald Reagan made a medical pledge involving the issue of his age. If elected, Mr. Reagan, at 69, would be the oldest man to be inaugurated as President. In a wide-ranging interview about his health, he said he would have the White House physician test him periodically and would resign if serious evidence of senility or mental deterioration were detected. (A1:2-3.) Bill Brock may be replaced as chairman of the Republican National Committee despite consequent risks to Ronald Reagan's drive to promote party unity, according to Reagan campaign sources. They said that Mr. Brock, who is widely respected, would probably be offered a high post in the Reagan campaign if Mr. Reagan agrees with recommendations by his advisers to seek a new chairman. (A28:3-5.) A move to bolster the Carter campaign was reported by sources in the campaign and the White House. They said that Hamilton Jordan, who has been the main campaign strategist, was expected to leave his post as the White House chief of staff to devote full time to the Carter campaign. (A27:1-3.) Confusion about what is best to eat appears more widespread among Americans than ever before. The public has been buffeted by conflicting advice from scientists, food producers, nutritionists and the Government. If you follow everything they tell you, one shopper said, ''you might as well stop living or become a vegetarian.'' (A1:1-2.) The House censured a Representative for violating House rules by converting campaign funds to his own use. The Congressman, Charles H. Wilson of California, who was defeated in the Democratic primary on June 3, is the third House member to be censured in this century. (A16:1-2.) Conservation zoning was upheld by the Supreme Court, which ruled unaimously that an ordinance that limits development does not necessarily violate the constitutional rights of affected property owners. (A26:1-2.) Radioactive krypton is to be vented into the atmosphere to enable the start of decontamination work at the crippled Three Mile Island nuclear reactor. The decision was approved unanimously by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which, along with a major antinuclear group, has said that the venting would cause no measurable health effects. (A18:3-6.) Metropolitan Topless dancing in bars was upheld by the New York State Court of Appeals, which quashed a 1977 state law that prohibited such entertainment in premises licensed by the State Liquor Authority. Voting 4 to 3, the state's highest tribunal ruled that the prohibiton was unconstitutional because topless dancing ''is not inherently obscene'' and has been permitted elsewhere, including theaters. (B1:6.) Business Digest, Page D1

UNTIL something better comes along, James Bridges's ''Urban Cowboy'' is the most entertaining, most perceptive commercial American movie of the year to date. Here is a tough-talking, softhearted romantic melodrama that sees a world that is far more bleak than the movie, or the characters in it, ever have time to acknowledge. The film, which stars John Travolta in a fine recovery from his disastrous liaison with Lily Tomlin in ''Moment by Moment,'' will inevitably be compared with ''Saturday Night Fever,'' which transformed Mr. Travolta into the pop icon of the dying 1970's and was also about the class Evelyn Waugh called the Lower Orders, and about what the Lower Orders do when they hang out.

Recently, Dan Greenburg wit, man about town, author (''Love Kills,'' ''Something's There,'' ''How to Be a Jewish Mother'') - made a proposal of marriage to Suzanne O'Malley - wit, woman about town, writer and editor. Here is Mr. Greenburg's account: I hadn't specifically indicated that this was the night I intended to propose, but conceivably Suzanne knew that something was up. Before we went out, I bought her four dozen roses. It's not that I don't often buy her flowers, it's just that I don't often buy her four dozen at a crack.

One of the most complex factors contributing to the confusion at the two-day meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was the knotty question of just how big the worldwide surplus of oil is these days. According to industry analysts in the United States, the surprising answer is no longer very big. OPEC leaders repeatedly suggested that the group was producing at least one million barrels a day more than the world needed, and the subject was apparently a touchy one in Algiers. At one point, Ali Akbar Moinfar, Iran's oil minister, reportedly got into a shouting match over the issue with Tayeh Abdul Karim, the minister from Iraq. Mr. Moinfar accused Iraq of selling out to the West by increasing its production, thereby preventing Iran from selling all but token quantities of its higher-priced oil.

Brooks and Perkins Inc. said it had filed a suit in Federal court in Detroit against the AAR Corporation and its officers over AAR's purchases of Brooks and Perkins common stock. * Coca-Cola Company has sold the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Baltimore to a group of investors. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

The Soviet Union will supply Syria with heavy sophisticated weapons worth $3 billion without charge and exempt Damascus from 80 percent of its debts, a Kuwaiti newspaper reported today. The paper, Al Watan, attributed the report to ''reliable sources'' in Damascus. It did not state the nature of the weapons.

Richard Bonelli, American operatic baritone, died at his home in Los Angeles on Saturday. He was 91 years old. Mr. Bonelli was one of the most popular artists of his generation. His career began late, but it lasted a long time and encompassed radio, concerts, films, both light and grand opera and even television. He was proud of the fact that he sang in one of the first sound films, a Fox Movietone short; in the first radio broadcast of a complete opera from Chicago, and in an early experimental opera telecast. When he made his American debut with the Chicago Civic Opera in 1925, his success was recorded in The New York Times. The opera was Verdi's ''La Traviata,'' and his co-stars were Claudia Muzio and Antonio Cortis. The newspaper quoted Chicago critics as saying that he ''has a fine vocal sense, a good style for one of the most elegant of baritone parts, and an amply imaginative sense of the stage.''

The attention given to the setting of limits - whether limits on the growth of the average American's standard of living, or limits on the size and scope of programs designed to aid the poor and needy - has a strongly conservative cast to it. Arguments made about limits tend to be framed in terms of trimming the existing system of social and economic programs. For those whose current living standard and quality of life are insufficient, the discussion of limits appears to be a prelude to even grimmer times. As the argument is being cast by President Carter and some of his policy makers, by Mayor Koch and the Health and Hospitals Corporation, by Ronald Reagan and his advisers, the discussion of limits leads only to a sense of futility and powerlessness regarding our ability to shape and control the growing forces of economic contraction.

The beginning of operations of Suffolk County's $932 million Southwest Sewer District, already two and a half years behind schedule, has been delayed at least until the end of the year because of a dispute between the county and the contractor laying the final link of pipe across the Great South Bay. The contracting concern, Edward B. Fitzpatrick Inc., stopped work on the pipe on May 23 because of a disagreement over materials being used in the job. Its president, Edward B. Fitzpatrick Jr., said he ordered a halt because the county had refused to absolve the company of responsibility for possible future breaks or leaks in the pipe.

Joseph A. D. Sutton, a 74-year-old grandfather from Brooklyn, was among 3,538 men and women who received degrees yesterday at Brooklyn College's 55th commencement. Mr. Sutton, a retired importer of French lace who developed an interest in Sephardic Jews and decided to return to school, was awarded a Master of Arts degree in sociology. The main address was given by Speaker Stanley Fink of the New York State Assembly, an alumnus of Brooklyn College. ''Around us has been a rubble of discontent and uncertainty highlighting a lack of faith in one another and in our institutions,'' he said. The solution, he suggested, is a return to truth, ethics and morals.

Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith abandoned his challenge to State Senator Walter N. Sheil's chairmanship of the Hudson County Democratic organization tonight after a majority of the county's mayors sided with Mr. Sheil. Mr. Sheil was then re-elected by acclamation. Mr. Sheil's victory strengthened his hold on the office. His chairmanship of the party marks the first time since the days of Frank Hague that the Mayor of Jersey City has not been recognized as the county's political leader.

An Israeli border policeman on patrol near the Old City of Jerusalem was shot and slightly wounded today by an unidentified sniper from atop the ancient stone walls near Herod's Gate. Two other policemen with him raced along the wall in search of the assailant and the area was cordoned off. No arrests were made but five Arabs were reportedly detained for questioning.

To the Editor: Daniel Pipes (Op-Ed May 27) tells us that it is American, not Soviet, culture that horrifies Khomeini, endangering the Islamic way of life with alcohol, jeans, pop music, nightclubs, movies, dancing, mixed bathing and pornography (all of which is now part of Soviet culture as well). ut is the list illustrative or exclusive? What about junk food, and what about the automobile, which has cluttered the streets of Teheran? If Khomeini is against that, then I would say he is not so crazy after all. RALPH SLOVENKO Professor of Law and Psychiatry Wayne State University Detroit, May 28, 1980

THE Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute first opened its doors in this serene Berkshire countryside 25 years ago, and to mark its silver anniversary this summer the museum has organized three small exhibitions that commemorate certain aspects of the founders' varied artistic interests. Appropriately enough, one of these shows - bearing a delightful title, ''From Silver Spouts the Grateful Liquors Glide,'' drawn from Alexander Pope's ''Rape of the Lock'' - is devoted to fine silver. The others are a show of ''Master Drawings'' that includes examples of Durer, Domenico Tiepolo and Degas; and a miscellany of prints, books and drawings called ''Never Say Die,'' which is devoted to the theme of horses and horsemanship. This is a subject in which Robert Sterling Clark (1877-1955), well known in his day as an owner of race horses, had a passionate interest.

PRODDED by rising sugar prices, the weekly cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose six cents to $95.14 in the period ended June 6, according to the Department of Consumer Affairs. In the past month, the cost of the 41 items in the department's market basket rose only 12 cents, reflecting fairly stable food prices in recent weeks. Shoppers are now paying 6.4 percent more for these goods than they were a year ago, but the increase is considerably less than the overall inflation rate.

OF LEVY WASHINGTON, June 10 - The Supreme Court today upheld the right of a state to base its corporate income tax on a multistate corporation's entire income, rather than just the income earned from local operations.

BATAAN, Philippines Refugee children squealed in delight and their parents chattered happily i.n a variety of Indochinese languages. "Cake," said the volunteer teacher, pointing to a picture of one, and the children chorused back, "Kek."
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) The Treasury Department today ordered ordered the makers of beer, wine and distilled spirits to list on their product labels any food colorine or other ingredient ...

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The House today censured Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California. Mr. Wilson, who was defeated in the California Democratic primary on June 3, is the third member of Congress to be censured in this century.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Pentagon transferred one of President Carter's military aides after the Marine Corps major became embroiled in a dispute with the Internal Revenue Service over nonpayment of taxes on religious grounds.
RECIFE, Brazil, June 10 (UPI) Mudslides caused by torrential rains overnight killed at least 35 people, most of them poor people whose shacks collapsed, the police said today.

Two former college administrators were acquitted on similar charges. The jurors could not reach a verdict, however, on the bulk of the charges against all three.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Senior economic officials in the Administration have begun to concede privately that the weakening of the economy and the disapproval of the oil import fee by Congress will mean a substantial budget deficit for the 1981 fiscal year, which starts Oct. 1.

SEATTLE, June 10 (UPI) Jody Powell, the White House press secretary, denied today that Mr. Carter had refused to appear at the mayors conference on the same day as Senator Kennedy, and accused him of "looking for a chance to play off the President's visit."

A fierce street battle two weeks ago that left 27 dead and 60 wounded signaled the growing assertiveness of Lebanon's Shiite Moslems, a religious group that some feel might eventually challenge the Palestinians in southern Lebanon. During the last five years, Christian Phalangists have fought the allied Palestinians and leftist militia groups for control of Lebanon only to discover that neither is strong enough to vanquish the other. In this struggle the Shiites mostly supported the Palestinians.

Mayor Koch has stepped back a bit from his plan in January to cut New York's Board of Education budget by $154 million. His final executive budget calls for cuts of $89 million. But responsible citizens' groups, like the Educational Priorities Panel and the United Parents Association, believe classroom teaching will suffer if the Mayor doesn't relent further. They are right. Mr. Koch's responsibility to balance the budget has been made even harder by the evaporation of once promised Federal and state aid. But whether that aid is restored or not, classroom services ought to be at the top of the list of restorations as the Board of Estimate reviews the Mayor's proposals. The next generation of New Yorkers ought not to be further burdened by today's austerity.
Always in Fashion: A Navy Blazer

About this time last year, Thomas Graham Jr., a senior legal aide in the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, was in Geneva, spending 16-hour days putting the final touches on the second Soviet-American strategic arms treaty. These days, Mr. Graham reports, there are still ''bits and pieces'' of work to do around the office, but since early this year, he has had plenty of time to get reacquainted with his family at home.

Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, is expected to take a leave of absence soon to devote full time to the President's re-election drive. Sources in the Carter campaign and the White House report that Mr. Jordan, who has been the President's principal campaign strategist so far, will move over to become deputy chairman of the Carter-Mondale Presidental Committee.

In a few weeks, the Koch administration will make a preliminary decision that will ultimately change a community, alter the city's skyline and resolve the first round in what has become a bitter behind-the-scenes struggle involving some of the most prominent of the so-called power brokers in the city. Over the last several months, lawyers, builders, architects, financiers and public relations men have been fighting for the right to develop what the city calls the East River Development Project and what neighborhood residents ruefully call the ''Billion-Dollar Gold Coast'' - a stretch of prime waterfront property between the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive and the East River, from 16th to 24th Streets.

One of the most curious and interesting flavors that I have used in my kitchen over the years is an anise- or licorice-flavored spirit, known in Marseilles as pastis. The best known of these in France are Pernod, Ricard and Berger. Pastis was not originally designed for the kitchen but for the bar. It is normally drunk in a small glass and when water is added to it, it becomes milky or opalescent.

A ribbon of the city's cultural repositories, the ''Museum Mile'' on Fifth Avenue, held an open house and street fair yesterday evening to call attention to the area's treasures. All but the Metropolitan Museum among the 10 institutions from 82d Street to 105th Street along the avenue offered free admission from 7 to 9 P.M. There were strolling musicians and band concerts, balloons and banners, a road race and a two-hour respite from honking horns and thundering buses; Fifth Avenue was closed to traffic from 86th Street to 105th for the celebration.

The chairman of the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that the company had confirmed gas shows in one of its lease tracts in the Baltimore Canyon, about 100 miles east of Atlantic City. ''This is the most encouraging thing we have encountered so far,'' said the chairman, C.C. Garvin Jr., in a speech in Houston. Previously Exxon, the world's largest oil company, had drilled four dry wells in the Baltimore Canyon area in the Atlantic, according to a corporate spokesman in Houston.

Peter Cartmell, 59 years old, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Fidelity Union Bank Corporation of Newark, a $2.3 billion bank holding company. He succeeds C. Malcolm Davis, who died in an automobile accident last Thursday at the age of 61.

Ronald Reagan, who at age 69 could be the oldest man inaugurated as President, plans if he is elected to have the White House physician test him periodically and would resign the office if serious evidence of senility or mental deterioration were detected, the former California Governor said in a extensive interview about his health. ''If I were President and had any feeling at all that my capabilities had been reduced before a second term came,'' he said, ''I would walk away. By the same token I would step down also.''
I am worried that the Islamic Republic could be defeated by those who are on our side.'' - Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. (A9:1.)

An explosion from a bomb smashed a set of expensive bronze doors yesterday at a Fordham University building in the Bronx. No one was injured. The police said that three teen-agers had been taken into custody and charged with setting off the bomb. They had been ordered off the campus shortly before the 1:30 A.M. explosion at the Cardinal Spellman Building, which houses the university's language and arts department.

Last night, 61 members of the newly formed Mohawk Women's Cooperative gathered at the state police substation in Massena and demanded that the police stop making arrests on the reservation. The incidents came a little more than a year after a nine-hour takeover of the Akwesasne Community Center here by traditionalist Mohawks after the arrest of one of their chiefs. That takeover brought longstanding tribal divisions to the surface and led to a continuing dispute, in and out of court, over the rights of police on this reservation.

Henry Mannix, a senior partner in the New York law firm of White & Case until his retirement in 1974, died Monday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 82 years old and had been with the firm 57 years. Mr. Mannix was a graduate of City College and Fordham University Law School. He also received an honorary doctorate from Fordham. He is survived by his wife, the former Mary Margaret Friel; four sons, Dr. Henry of West Hartford, Conn., Joseph of Mount Kisco, John of Wilton, Conn., and Charles of Clinton, Conn.; four daughters, Sheila of Manhattan, Frances Ziminisky of Mount Kisco, Aileen Schaefer of Islip, L.I., and Delia Burke of Mount Kisco; a brother, Brian of West Islip, L.I., 47 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren.

AS far as I'm concerned, it was the social event of the Hamptons season. There weren't a lot of names you're apt to find in the society columns, with the exception of Gloria Jones, the widow of James Jones, who wrote ''From Here to Eternity.'' Willie Morris, the author, just missed it. He was down in Mississippi. On the other hand, some of the most prominent bartenders and restaurant owners east of the Shinnecock Canal (that's where the Hamptons begin for most of the writers and social folk who live out there) were there en masse to honor the nuptials of Joseph L. Luppi 3d and Melissa Weston.

An influential Government advisory panel has recommended approving research that would be the first exception to the longstanding rule prohibiting release of products of gene-splicing into the environment. The committee also recommended approval of production of interferon on a much larger scale, allowing more of the scarce antivirus material to be made in a week than can now be made in a year by conventional methods.

To the Editor: What has happened to the pride New Yorkers always took in their city? It no longer seems to exist. In other cities I visited, here and abroad, I could not only feel, I could see the pride the natives had in their cities.

A woman who got angry and fought off a band of teen-agers on a subway platform in Brooklyn got the red-carpet treatment at City Hall yesterday. The woman, Frances Zarecki, who came to the United States eight years ago, was praised by Mayor Koch for ''Polish courage'' in standing up to her attackers in the early hours of May 28. He also kissed her and gave her a cup of coffee.

After five years of all-out production, West Germany's auto industry is slowing. Sales of medium-sized and large cars are lagging, statistics show. The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the two American giants, have been slow to introduce their much-discussed ''world cars.'' As industry sources see it, Japan's aggressive auto makers could emerge as the short-term winners.

The state police arrested seven persons last night in a hotel near here and seized two tons of marijuana estimated to be worth $2.5 million. Arrested were Mark J. Koran, 24, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Ian K. Krebbs, 24, of Miami; Matthew J. Miller, 24, and Christine Ann Schafer, 25, of Seal Beach, Calif.; William A. Rebol, 27, of Melrose, Fla.; William O. Ware, 29, of Boca Raton, Fla., and James D. Woodside, 33, of Smyrna Beach, Fla.
ALBANY, June 10 The Court of Appeals today struck down as unconstitutional a state law that prohibited topless entertainment in bars licensed by the State Liquor Authority.
The chairman of the Exxon Corporation said yesterday that the company had confirmed gas shows in one of its lease tracts in the Baltimore Canyon, about 100 miles east of Atlantic City.
The Carter Administration sees little hope of achieving a political settlement that would help end the plight of starving Cambodians, a top State Department official said Monday night.

OSSINING, N.Y., June 10 Of about 1,600 inmates at the Ossining Correctional Facility, there were only eight Jews as of today, two short of a minyan, or the number required for a religious service under Jewish law.
The price of gold dropped below $600 an ounce and silver prices fell more than $2 an ounce yesterday, while the dollar was mixed.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 A fierce street battle two weeks ago that left 27 dead and 60 wounded signaled the growing assertiveness of Lebanon's Shiite Moslems, a religious group that some feel might eventually challenge the Palestinians in southern Lebanon.

ALBANY, June 10 Mayor Koch acquiesced tonight in a compromise handgun control bill worked out by legislative and gubernatorial counsels over the weekend. His approval was thought to all but clinch passage of the measure.
ON paper, the third program of Musical Sacra's Basically Bach Festival last night at Avery Fisher Hall seemed an assortment of snippets.

JERUSALEM, June 10 An Israeli border policeman on patrol near the Old City of Jerusalem was shot and slightly wounded today by an unidentified sniper from atop the ancient stone walls near Herod's Gate.

WASHINGTON, June 10 Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff, is expected to take a leave of absence soon to devote full time to the President's reelection drive.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 11 The Senate voted 62 to 32 yesterday to end a filibuster against draft registration, thus clearing the way for passage of the bill within 10 days.
AMARILLO, Tex., June 10 (AP) A small earthquake briefly shook the Texas Panhandle and western Oklahoma today, apparently causing no injuries or damage.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) United States businesses reduced their capital-spending plans for 1980 after the nation's economy weakened and fell into recession, the Commerce Department reported today.

Warren P. Munsell, secretary and general manager of the Actors' Fund of America and former business manager of the Theatre Guild, died Sunday at St. Clare's Hospital and Medical Center. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.
SAUTEEING thinly sliced zucchini in an enameled iron pan the other day, I removed the pan from the fire and watched as the butter in it kept bubbling.

Few things have changed more radically in the lifetime of Americans over 40 than the legal definition of obscenity. Until the 1950's, important works by reputable writers had to be smuggled into the United States such items as Lawrence's "Lady Chatterley's Lover" and even Nabokov's "Lolita." But the most widely smuggled books were the novels of Henry Millee, who was clearly, almost proudly, disreputable.
GAS

The Treasury Department today ordered ordered the makers of beer, wine and distilled spirits to list on their product labels any food coloring or other ingredient that can cause allergic or similarly adverse health reactions. In addition, as Carter Administration officials had disclosed yesterday, the order allows the industry the option of either listing all other ingredients or simply providing an address to which the consumer can write to obtain the information.

Amid the lights, cameras, noise and confusion in the ballroom of the Sheraton Centre, Joe Barry Carroll began his professional basketball career in a three-piece suit yesterday afternoon when the Golden State Warriors made him the first selection in the National Basketball Association draft. His real debut, however, will come in training camp, in a uniform, when the ball goes into the air. ''It's an individual's performance that matters,'' he said, ''regardless of what I say here, or in any other setting.'' It has always been that way for the 7-foot-1-inch, 240-pounder, Purdue University's biggest economics major. Carroll, the ninth of 11 children, was once an awkward high school player in Denver. He developed into the best college center in the country, with a good shooting touch and outstanding mobility, and last month became the first member of his family to receive a college degree.

The Government expelled all students today who are boycotting segregated mixed-race colleges, which the students charge are inadequately funded. The expulsion order affected 15 Government-funded colleges for students of mixed race, whom the Government calls colored. It was not immediately learned how many students were affected by the order. Those dismissed today can reapply for admittance, according to J.H.T. Mills, the secretary for colored affairs, but must supply good reasons for staying away from classes.

A Rumanian immigrant armed with a pistol took 10 persons hostage in a Queens savings and loan association yesterday and released seven of them before the police overpowered him. They disarmed him after entering the institution secretly in their stocking feet and remaining hidden for almost two hours. During the three and a half hours of negotiations, the gunman traded hostages for cigarettes, coffee and sandwiches as he awaited a response to his demands -a United States passport and a job with the Central Intelligence Agency.

THE DETERMINED ONE Acting since 1949, Sidney Poitier won the Academy Award's bestactor distinction in 1963 for his role in ''Lillies of the Field.'' In 1967 he played opposite Katharine Hepburn when she won her bestactress award in ''Guess Who's Coming to Dinner,'' and that same year he had a starring role in the best picture, ''In the Heat of the Night.''

Six past Tony winners or nominees will be among the performers at a benefit for Bandwagon, a theater group, next Monday at 6:30 P.M. at the Jan Hus Church, 351 East 74th Street. Taking part in the performance will be Nell Carter, who won a Tony in 1978 for ''Ain't Misbehavin','' and Charles Strouse, the composer of several award-winning musicals. Also appearing will be Leigh Beery, Taina Elg, Millicent Martin and Virginia Martin, all Tony award nominees, and Adelaide Hall, who was in ''Black Broadway.''

Steve Henderson sat in the locker room at Shea Stadium last night and considered the vital statistics: 27 years old, a .349 batting average in his fourth season in the big leagues and suddenly, almost historically on a team like the New York Mets, the leading hitter in the National League. But he was neither heady with success nor even very impressed, and he considered the vital statistics behind that stoical state of mind, too: the oldest of eight children in a struggling family in Houston's Third Ward, part-time jobs before and after school, threeand-a-half lonely years in the minor leagues, then three years in last place in the major leagues.

Representative John Hutchinson, a West Virginia Democrat, was sworn in today by Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, to fill the vacancy created last March 17 by the death of Representative John M. Slack Jr., also a Democrat. Mr. Hutchinson's election fills one of two vacancies in the 435-member House. The other was created last month by the resignation of Representative Charles C. Diggs Jr., Democrat of Michigan.

The tragic Miami rioting and the ugly protests that greeted President Carter there on Monday have been jarring reminders of a nightmare America has been eager to forget. Urban unrest obviously can recur, especially where the conditions that provoked it in the 1960's persist. Twelve years ago, the National Advisory Commission on Civil Disorders found that police brutality was the chief grievance in riot-torn neighborhoods. Outrage over police violence ignited many of the earlier riots. The needless resort to deadly official force does more than nullify a criminal suspect's right to trial. It may ignite community anger, especially among the urban poor who feel put upon by society and its guardians of justice. Police forces need constant reminder that they can contribute to the violence they deplore. And some rules on their conduct need tightening.

The maximum interest rate that commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations may pay on six-month money-market certificates issued during the week beginning tomorrow was stated incorrectly in Business Day yesterday. The correct rate is 7.75 percent for commercial banks and savings institutions alike.

Air Canada reported today that a near crash here last Saturday of a Boeing 747 with 403 passengers was caused by engines idling too slowly. The airline has ordered an inspection of the engines on its seven 747's. In the House of Commons, Transport Minister Jean-Luc Pepin said investigators would also examine an incident at Los Angeles on Sunday when a fire in an engine of another Air Canada wide-bodied plane forced 140 passengers to scramble down escape ramps.

There is a benignly brooding ''video portrait'' of John Cage greeting people in the lobby of the Walker Art Center here. That's only appropriate, because people are gathering for a nine-day festival called New Music America that began Saturday night. This is a follow-up to a similar festival held last June at the Kitchen in New York, and part of what is now hoped will be an annual event in different parts of the country, all devoted to the openly experimental spirit that Mr. Cage pioneered. There are good reasons for this second festival to be in Minneapolis-St. Paul, but the reasons are more institutional than creative. As Roy M. Close, music critic of The Minneapolis Star, points out in the festival catalogue, the Twin Cities have never been the home of a particularly strong school of experimental composers. But local institutions, above all the Walker Art Center and the St. Paul Chamber Orchestra, have more than made up the slack, and the result is an active audience and support system for such music. The festival is being presented by the center and The Star, and the first evening's performances were by the chamber orchestra.

The Federal Government notified the Ford Motor Company today that it had made an ''initial determination'' that defects exist in the transmission systems of 16 million automobiles. Such a finding usually results in a formal recall order. The Department of Transportation advised Ford Motor officials in a letter that the determination had been made in an investigation involving nearly all passenger models from 1969 through 1979.

To the Editor: As an American Jew, and a former resident of the Israeli development town of Kiryat Shemona, allow me to respond to Anthony Lewis's May 22 column, ''Israel and Its Friends.'' s we were located only 12 kilometers from the Lebanese border, we spent many nights in the bomb shelter. To pass the time and help forget the dull thudding of the shells outside, we would often read the English-language Jerusalem Post. In particular, the letters to the editor section proved most entertaining.

Holman Hamilton, professor emeritus of American history at the University of Kentucky and author of a number of books, died Saturday at his home in Lexington, Ky. He was 70 years old. Professor Hamilton, a former newspaperman, was a graduate of Williams College and held a doctorate in history from the University of Kentucky. Among the books he wrote were ''Zachary Taylor: Soldier of the Republic,'' ''Zachary Taylor: Soldier in the White House,'' ''The Three Kentucky Presidents: Lincoln, Taylor and Davis,'' ''White House Images and Realities,'' ''Prologue to Conflict: The Crisis and Conflict of 1850,'' ''The Democratic Experience,'' and ''Three American Frontiers.''

People in Turkey's Far East feel neglected. Some want a change of government, others dream of independence and many just want to get out. The major problem in this predominantly Kurdish area is unemployment; all day and every day the teahouses are full of young men and boys with nothing to do.

IN a scene midway through ''Bronco Billy,'' the best and funniest Clint Eastwood movie in quite a while, the cowboy of the title strides into a bank. And he starts to cash a check for $3, because in this movie all of the nice people are poor. Suddenly, two bank robbers burst in, and they scare a little boy, one of many innocent customers in the place. The little boy drops his piggy bank and it shatters. This is too much for Bronco Billy. He give the bandits The Look, an indignant squint that means, roughly translated, ''Grrr,'' and then he hauls off and fires away. What makes all this unusual for Mr. Eastwood, who directed the disarmingly boyish ''Bronco Billy'' and stars in the title role, is that the cowboy is more interested in the child than he is in the holdup men, and that he shoots the villains fairly politely, as if he didn't mean to do them any harm. Indeed, Mr. Eastwood is almost playing a very large Peter Pan. The locale may be Idaho instead of never-never land, but the feeling is that of a fairy tale, as Bronco Billy wanders through the West with a troupe of lost boys and girls. This is an emphatically American fable, which is perhaps why it ends with a chorus of ''Stars and Stripes Forever.''

Kirk Kerkorian, who owns 47 percent of the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company's stock, plans to sell the Cal-Neva Lodge, a Lake Tahoe resort owned by Mr. Kerkorian's Tracinda Investment Corporation, according to a filing with Nevada gambling authorities. The resort is to be purchased for about $10 million by Ronald V. Cloud, a real estate developer of Fresno, Calif., and his wife, Jessman.
HONG KONG, June 10 (UPI) More than 500 "boat people" from Vietnam arrived here and in Singapore today, and a new surge of refugees was expected to reach ports of asylum in Asia.
WASHINGTON, June 10 Defense Secretary Harold Brown has instructed deputies to emphasize the nation's high unemployment level in efforts to increase. military recruitment.

MALTA, Mont., June 10 (UPI) Two cars collided on Interstate 94 yesterday, killing seven persons. The authorities said that five victims, all Montana residents in their early 20's, were in one auto and an elderly Everest, Wash., couple was in the other.
