Corinne Cooke Wright, a former New York City schoolteacher who was the widow of Dr. Louis T. Wright, a noted surgeon and civil rights leader, died Saturday at University Hospital. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan. She is survived by two daughters, Jane W. Jones and Barbara W. Pierce, and three granddaughters.

Chemical Bank, New York, has appointed John A. Dorman senior vice president. * Collins & Aikman Corporation, New York, a producer of specialty textile products and wall coverings, has named Alfred S. Crimmins executive vice president, finance. * Connecticut Mutual Life, based in Hartford, has named S. Caesar Raboy executive vice president. * Irving Trust Company, New York, has appointed Peter D. Richardson a senior vice president and chief investment officer of the bank's fiduciary services GRoup.

The Federal Reserve wants to let nonmember financial institutions borrow money from its discount window. The proposed rules, issued today for public comment until July 15, would allow nonmember depository institutions to use the discount window under approximately the same rules covering members of the Federal Reserve System. Would-be borrowers are instructed to try to get money from commercial and other sources before turning to the Fed. The proposal stems from the Monetary Control Act of 1980, approved in March, which imposes reserve requirements on many institutions that are not Fed members. The new rules would affect about 8,900 nonmember commercial banks, 500 savings banks, 4,600 savings and loan associations and 22,000 credit unions.

Refugee children squealed in delight and their parents chattered happily in a variety of Indochinese languages. ''Cake,'' said the volunteer teacher, pointing to a picture of one, and the children chorused back, ''Kek.''

To the Editor: The conflagration in Florida cannot be written off to the special circumstances of Cuban and Haitian immigration. Miami has serious portents for New York and other large cities. ike Miami's blacks, minority communities across the nation have come to view government, and especially its law enforcement agencies, as their enemy. The days of the War on Poverty seem very far away to the residents of American ghettoes; now the war seems to be against them. The people of our inner cities suffer disproportionately from the lash of the American criminal justice system as well as the deprivation of tight-fisted Federal, state, and local budgets.

AS far as I can tell, the only thing wrong with ''Album,'' David Rimmer's new play at the WPA Theater, is its length. At 90 minutes, this is one evening that seems about a half-hour too short. Mr. Rimmer has created four real and likable characters, all high school kids of the 60's, and allowed us to enter their lives and dreams. When we finally must bid them goodbye, the morning after their senior prom, it's a rough parting. Like the teen-agers on stage, we could stay up all night. ''Album'' is a perfect illustration of the fact that there are no stale subjects, only stale writers. Mr. Rimmer has made some very familiar material seem new. ''Album'' is about adolescents coming of age, about the joys and pitfalls of young love, about the birth of a cataclysmic decade. As the title indicates, the play is set to the rock music that defined its characters' world. But this is not a rehash of ''American Graffiti'' or ''Vanities.'' Mr. Rimmer has his own observations to make; he describes his people with dead-on wit, no-nonsense intelligence and the kind of generous affection that is contagious. His writing is so specific that we don't need an epilogue to tell us what happens to his foursome after 1967. The lives on stage play on in our imagination well after the final lights go down.

In the year of the baseball brawl, the New York Mets exchanged knockdown pitches and punches with the Los Angeles Dodgers last night in Shea Stadium and later even rallied to subdue them, 5-4. They rallied, in fact, from a 4-0 deficit that the Dodgers inflicted inside three-and-a-half innings. But by then, Pat Zachry of the Mets and Ron Cey of the Dodgers had tangled on the pitcher's mound in a swirl of players from both sides.

The Kaiser Steel Corporation announced that it had reached an agreement to sell four of its ships for $65 million to the Norman Group, made up of individual international shipowners. The ships are owned by the Kaiser International Shipping Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Kaiser steel.Edgar F. Kaiser Jr., chairman and chief executive of Kaiser, said the sale was part of the company's plan ''to study each of our assets and operations and to convert assets into cash and modify operations if it makes economic sense to do so.''

PONTIAC, Mich., June 10 (AP) The Detroit Lions today signed Billy Sims to a contract that his agent described as the most lucrative ever given to a National Football League rookie. The terms were not disclosed.
The American kitchen is returning to basics. That was demonstrated anew at the Eastern Gourmet Show, which opened at the New York Coliseum Sunday and continues through 1 P.M. today.

The California Angels rallied for three runs in the eighth inning tonight - two of them on a homer by the 5-foot-4-inch Freddie Patek - for a 5-4 victory over the Yankees. After scoring one run in the top of the eighth, the Yankees led, 4-2. In the bottom of the inning, Bobby Clark batted for Larry Harlow and singled with one out off Rudy May. Then Patek hit a homer to left field - his first home run of the season - to tie the game.

A retired police officer who faces a felony charge in the Howard (Buddy) Jacobson case remained in critical condition yesterday in the Nassau County Medical Center. The former officer, Joseph Toscanini, 43 years old, suffered a heart attack Monday. He later pleaded not guilty to charges of trying to extort more than $100,000 from Mr. Jacobson, who escaped from the Brooklyn House of Detention on May 31.

The Mets announced yesterday that Monday night's rained-out game against the Los Angeles Dodgers would be played tomorrow, which had been an open date, starting at 8:05 P.M. in Shea Stadium. Tickets for Monday's game will be honored tomorrow night, or may be exchanged for another game during the season.

Never, in the closing days of its annual session, is the New York State Legislature a model of decorum, wisdom or judgment. All past absurdity pales, however, beside 1980's version of state government. The Senate's Republican majority leader, Warren Anderson, says he's dropping the curtain in his chamber after passing a few urgent bills in forms probably unacceptable to the Democratic Assembly. Other necessary measures would be abandoned. Governor Carey stands firm with a budget so unsatisfactory to both houses that they resist his other requests. And Assembly Speaker Fink will be left to negotiate between the branches with one house tied behind his back.

Italy's governing Christian Democrats made modest gains in regional elections, but the Communists, who form the country's second largest party, managed to hold their ground in some of the biggest industrial cities, where Communist-led local goverments had faced uphill battles. The Socialists improved their standing in regions and cities and enhanced their role as a power broker between the two leading parties.

Percy A. Wood, the president of United Airlines, was seriously injured this afternoon when a packagebomb delivered by a postal worker exploded at his home, the Federal authorities said. Mr. Wood, 60 years old, was reported in guarded condition at Lake Forest Hospital with injuries to his arm and side, a hospital spokesman said. Mr. Wood was reportedly opening the package when it blew up.

Princeton University conferred degrees this morning on 1,308 students, 451 with honors, at its 233d commencement exercises. More than 5,000 people gathered on the college campus outside Nassau Hall to hear valedictory and salutatory addresses, the latter in Latin, as well as a speech by William G. Bowen, president of the university. A longstanding Princeton tradition prohibits any outside speakers at commencement.

O'Neill Jr., the Speaker of the House, to fill the vacancy created last March 17 by the death of Representative John M. Slack Jr., also a Democrat. ORENSE, Spain, June 10 (UPI) The police said today that armed men tricked their way into the country home of Eulogio Gomez, a member of Parliament, last night and tried to kidnap him. Mr. Gomez foiled the attempt by grabbing a pistol and wounding the group's leader. The police arrested the leader but refused to identify him for fear of jeopardizing the hunt for his accomplices.

The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, yesterday became the second Republican in a week to announce his support of Mayor Koch for re-election. The announcement came 17 months before the election.

West and East Germany are moving closer together, their relations improving despite the Soviet intervention in Afghanistan and East-West tensions. The pace of visits between Government officials has increased since the beginning of the year, producing statements of an unusually friendly tone. Joint long-term projects are being accelerated.

ON paper, the third program of Musica Sacra's Basically Bach Festival last night at Avery Fisher Hall seemed an assortment of snippets. In practice, it turned out that Richard Westenburg had managed to blend the sombre with the spirited fairly well. Yet there was a nagging inconclusiveness to the evening, which was partly a fault of some of the pieces, partly of the performances and partly of the large, modern hall in which all this took place. Mr. Westenburg began with the sombre, in the form of Purcell's Funeral Music for Queen Mary. Here he chose to play the brass and drums music on the stage but to deploy his chorus in the rear of the orchestra seats. The division of forces was striking, but slightly eccentric, too. Still, the performance was a measured and noble one, befitting this measured and noble music.

The Carter Administration will curb Federal financing of hospital construction and renovation as one way of fighting inflation in the cost of health care, the President's chief inflation adviser, Alfred E. Kahn, said today. The initiative calls for more stringent reviews of new Federal construction projects and of grants, loans, loan guarantees and taxexempt bonds with which the Government subsidizes other projects.

Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that his planned meeting in September with the premiers of the 10 provinces represented a deadline for constitutional change. Mr. Trudeau thus sought to maintain a sense of urgency in the commitment he and the premiers made in a seven-hour meeting here yesterday to remodeling the Canadian political system to satisfy Quebec and other alienated provinces.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Anderson Would Accept Offer by Carter to Debate

David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, announced yesterday the formation of the New York City Partnership, a coalition of top corporate executives that he said would speak for the business community on such issues as rent control and the development of the Westway. Mr. Rockefeller, who will be chairman of the group, said at a news conference that ''a viable, successful city depends on a viable, prosperous, healthy business community.''

THE results of rising oil prices emerging from the meeting in Algiers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries spell bad news for the dollar, for the auto industry, for homeowners confronting rising electric bills, for unemployed workers, for deficit-ridden third-world countries and the banks that lend to them, and for the world monetary system. But amid the general wailing and gnashing of teeth over further OPEC price increases, the multinational and domestic oil companies have been able to maintain their composure. Indeed, as the French philosopher, Francois de la Rochefoucauld, observed, ''It is remarkable with what fortitude we are able to bear the misfortunes of others.''

Defense Secretary Harold Brown has instructed deputies to emphasize the nation's high unemployment level in efforts to increase military recruitment. Mr. Brown ordered a meeting of top aides tomorrow to discuss recruiting strategies. In a recent memorandum and at a meeting of a top military advisory panel on Monday, Mr. Brown recommended emphasizing the unemployment level, which was 7.8 percent last month, to potential recruits, including those already serving in the military and former service members.

Mayor Koch told City Council leaders yesterday that New York City's most recent wage offer to the municipal unions exceeded the amount of money allocated for labor in the proposed 1981 budget. Thus, he said, that problem would have to be solved before there could be any talk of increasing funds for the police, for education or for other services.
The Detroit Lions today signed Billy Sims to a contract that his agent described as the most lucrative ever given to a National Football League rookie. The terms were not disclosed.

CAUTION: Your home may be hazardous to your health. MANY people breathe a great sigh of relief upon returning home ''safe and sound'' from a trip. But few realize that the chance of accidental injury or death may be as great or greater in the ''safety'' of their own homes than in a plane or on the road. Home accidents have received little public attention because they are less dramatic than a plane or auto crash and, except for fires, rarely attract outside interest. But their toll in dollars and health is very high. From bedroom to backyard, you and those you live with may risk injury from falls, fires, poisons, electrical shock, suffocation, drowning, flying missiles or cuts.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The Immigration and Naturalization Service said today that it would permit some Iranian students enrolled in American colleges and universities to extend their stays in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 10--The Supreme Court ruled today that a defendant who chooses to testify in court can be questioned about his failure to turn himself in or to talk to the police before his arrest.
MIAMI, June 10 President Carter came, saw but did not conquer in his visit yesterday to the scene of last month's racial rioting, black leaders here said today.

ACCORDS To the Editor: The United States Helsinki Watch Committee seeks implementation of the human rights provisions of the 1975 Helsinki accords, among them the commitment by the 35 signatory nations ''to facilitate free movement and contacts'' across national borders.v.e believe that the spirit of that commitment is violated by the ban on travel to Iran. Without in any way endorsing the actions of the 10 Americans who recently traveled to Iran, we call on President Carter and the United States Department of Justice to renounce any intent to prosecute them and to rescind the Federal regulations imposing the travel ban.

Joe Barry Carroll, an all-America center with the size and ability to become a premier National Basketball Association performer, was the first player chosen yesterday in the college draft. The Golden State Warriors, who on Monday gave up Robert Parish, their veteran center, to the Boston Celtics in order to obtain the first pick in the draft, selected the 7-foot-1-inch Carroll, who led Purdue University into the semifinals of the National Collegiate tournament last March.

In an effort to bypass New York's usury restraints, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Chemical Bank have been investigating the feasibility of moving their credit-card operations to another state. Both Chase and Chemical have sent teams to South Dakota, where Citibank already has applied to regulatory authorities for permission to establish a limited-service bank to handle its credit-card activities. In addition, Chase has been considering such sites as Indiana, Arizona and Delaware, according to banking sources.

The House today censured Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California. Mr. Wilson, who was defeated in the California Democratic primary on June 3, is the third member of Congress to be censured in this century. The House Speaker, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts, pronounced the censure after the House voted to punish Mr. Wilson for violating House rules by converting campaign funds to his own use and for accepting money from a man with a direct interest in legislation before Congress.

UNTIL something better comes along, James Bridges's ''Urban Cowboy'' is the most entertaining, most perceptive commercial American movie of the year to date. Here is a tough-talking, softhearted romantic melodrama that sees a world that is far more bleak than the movie, or the characters in it, ever have time to acknowledge. The film, which stars John Travolta in a fine recovery from his disastrous liaison with Lily Tomlin in ''Moment by Moment,'' will inevitably be compared with ''Saturday Night Fever,'' which transformed Mr. Travolta into the pop icon of the dying 1970's and was also about the class Evelyn Waugh called the Lower Orders, and about what the Lower Orders do when they hang out.

Despite risks to Ronald Reagan's drive to promote Republican Party unity for the fall campaign, top strategists are moving toward replacing Bill Brock as chairman of the Republican National Committee, authoritative sources said today. Although a final decision awaits a Reagan-Brock meeting in Los Angeles Friday at a Republican ''unity dinner,'' these sources said, the leading candidate to replace Mr. Brock, chairman since 1976 when he defeated a Reagan-backed candidate, is Drew Lewis, a Republican national committeeman who is the Reagan campaign chairman from Pennsylvania.

OF all the theatrical productions mounted in the 1970's, two of the most memorable feature the extraordinary acting in tandem of John Gielgud and Ralph Richardson. One, in 1970, was David Storey's ''Home.'' The other, five years later, was Harold Pinter's ''No Man's Land.'' Fortunately, both have been preserved in British television adaptations remarkably faithful to the original productions. ''Home'' was presented on public television several seasons ago. Now, tonight at 10 o'clock, WNET-TV, Channel 13, offers ''No Man's Land'' in a 1977 Granada TV recording. The Peter Hall production, made for Britain's National Theater, has been directed for television by Julian Amyes.

Mayor Koch has stepped back a bit from his January plan to cut New York's Board of Education budget by $154 million. His final executive budget calls for cuts of $89 million. But responsible citizens' groups, like the Educational Priorities Panel and the United Parents Association, believe classroom teaching will suffer if the Mayor doesn't relent even more. They are right.

The nation's three largest retailers - Sears, Roebuck & Company, Montgomery Ward & Company and the J.C. Penney Company - are in the throes of one of the worst sales declines in their history. But retailing experts and analysts say the sagging performances owe as much to internal management problems as they do to the rapidly deteriorating economy. Sears, with $18 billion sales in the year ended Jan. 31, suffered a 60 percent drop in its first quarter ended April 30 from the year before. J.C. Penney, which had sales of $11.2 billion last year, registered a 58.9 percent drop in its net income for the first quarter ended April 30. Montgomery Ward, a unit of the giant Mobil Corporation, with sales of $5.25 billion in 1979, had the worst performance of the three in its first quarter ended March 28, reporting a $46 million loss against a $4 million loss in the yearearlier period.

The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today the purchase by the Southern Pacific Transportation Company of the 965-mile Tucumcari line of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad for $57 million. The line runs from Santa Rosa, N.M., just beyond Tucumcari, through Kansas City to St. Louis. The commission denied a competing application by the Missouri Pacific Railroad to acquire the Kansas City-to-St. Louis portion of the route.

Stock prices gained modestly yesterday in the wake of reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to raise prices. The market also responded to a resumption in a sharp decline in interest rates. The Dow Jones Industrial average finished 3.32 points ahead, at 863.99, as turnover ballooned to 42 million shares, from 36.8 million shares the day before. On Monday the Dow slipped 0.85 point.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in its third annual report to Congress on the accounting profession, said yesterday that it was still unclear whether accountants would effectively regulate themselves. Harold Williams, chairman of the commission, noted that the success of the S.E.C. practice section of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants ''as an effective self-regulatory body still is dependent upon further developments.''

More than 500 ''boat people'' from Vietnam arrived here and in Singapore today, and a new surge of refugees was expected to reach ports of asylum in Asia. Hong Kong officials said that 327 refugees had arrived in four boats since midnight, raising the number of arrivals this month toward the 900 mark. The total of arrivals this month is already higher than the 635 who arrived in the British colony in all of May.
Stock prices gained modestly yesterday in the wake of reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to raise prices.

A.M. Sullivan, a poet and former executive of Dun Bradstreet Inc., a diversified business-information concern, died yesterday at a Montclair Nursing Homes in Montclair, N.J. He was 83 years old, and a resident of Montclair.
In the year of the baseball brawl, the New York Mets exchanged knockdown pitches and punches with the Los Angeles Dodgers last night in Shea Stadium and later even rallied to subdue them, 5-4.
In an effort to bypass New York's usury restraints, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Chemical Bank have been investigating the feasibility of moving their credit-card operations to another state.

A new Democratic proposal to aid the Metropolitan Transportation Authority set off a flurry of negotiations last night between Governor Carey, the Democraticcontrolled Assembly and the Republican-led Senate. But by the early morning, no resolution had been found. The Senate, after more than two hours of debate, passed its own version of a tax on oil company receipts - one that the Democrats said was unacceptable. Nevertheless, Republicans and Democrats remained hopeful an agreement might be reached today.

The RCA Corporation and the Beta-Taurus Film Companies of Munich, West Germany, announced plans to form a joint venture to acquire programs and market them on the RCA Selectavision videodisk system for the German-speaking market in Europe. Beta-Taurus supplies television programs in the German-speaking market. It has home video rights to several thousand motion pictures and also has such rights to television programs from Germany and other countries and to a collection of children's programs and documentaries.

Alfonse M. D'Amato, who is challenging Senator Jacob K. Javits for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, began a statewide $100,000 weeklong television campaign yesterday. The campaign is keyed to the theme that Mr. D'Amato is the real Republican in the race.

NOW that gobs of women are spending their lunch hours discussing money, what have they left for the men to chatter about over their martinis and grilled chops? Well, according to a number of businessmen, life has taken a unique and, one might even say, a somewhat strange, turn. Men, quite a few of them, are talking about their personal lives. They are reflecting, reviewing and ruminating, and sometimes regretting what is, and what might have been.

Senior economic officials in the Administration have begun to concede privately that the weakening of the economy and the disapproval of the oil import fee by Congress will mean a substantial budget deficit for the 1981 fiscal year, which starts Oct. 1. Publicly, they have gradually stopped talking about balancing the budget, a goal the Administration disclosed with considerable fanfare in March, stressing instead the aim of restraining growth in Federal spending in hope of keeping the deficit as small as possible.
PORT VILA, New Hebrides, Wednesday, June 11 (AP) France and Britain sent paramilitary policemen to the island of Tanna today to quell rioting in which one person was killed.

ROME, June 10 Italy's governing Christian Democrats made modest gains in regional elections, but the Communists, who form the country's second largest party, managed to hold their ground in some of the biggest industrial cities, where Communist-led local goverments had faced uphill battles.

WASHINGTON, June 10 The Supreme Court today upheld the right of a state to base its corporate income tax on a multistate corporation's entire income, rather than just the income earned from local operations.

TORONTO, June 10 (UPI) Air Canada reported today that a near crash here last Saturday of a Boeing 747 with 403 passengers was caused by engines idling too slowly. The airline has ordered an inspection of the engines on its seven 747's.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 10 Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned today that Iran was in "chaos" and said that President Abolhassan Bani-Sadr and the majority party in Parliament should mend their differences to avoid a danger that the Iranian Islamic Republic might destroy itself.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Last month's eruption of Mount St. Helens has already cost about $2.7 billion and the end is not in sight, Congress was told today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 An interagency trade advisory committee has urged President Carter to negotiate a downward adjustment in duties on Japanese pickup trucks in exchange for new trade concessions by Japan.
JERUSALEM, June 10 Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel criticized Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie today for remarks attacking Israel's settlement policy in the West Bank.

Henry Mannix, a senior partner in the New York law firm of White Case until his retirement in 1974, died Monday at his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 82 years old and had been with the firm 57 years.

Of about 1,600 inmates at the Ossining Correctional Facility, there were only eight Jews as of today, two short of a minyan, or the number required for a religious service under Jewish law. But those who were here gathered this morning with a few other inmates and a selection of clergymen and prison officials to celebrate Rabbi Irving Koslowe's 30th anniversary as the Jewish chaplain at the prison that was known formally as Sing Sing until 1970.

A ribbon of the city's cultural repositories, the "Museum Mile" on Fifth Avenue, held an open house and street fair yesterday evening to call attention to the area's treasures.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) Granola cereals contain 22 to 32 percent sugar, placing them in the mid-range of all cereals tested for sugar content, a research chemist for the Agriculture Department reported today.
PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 Princeton University conferred degrees this morning on 1,308 students, 451 with honors, at its 233d commencement exercises.

President Anwar el-Sadat today met Armand Hammer, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, to discuss construction of a $400 million fertilizer plant. ''The President told us to go ahead with the project,'' Mr. Hammer said after the meeting. ''We will start building right away.'' He said Occidental had found phosphate in large quantities in Abu Tartour, in the Egyptian part of the Western Desert. Mr. Hammer said the phosphoric acid would be used as a fertilizer. The plant, he said, would produce 600,000 tons a year for export, at a value of $160 million.

SAUTEEING thinly sliced zucchini in an enameled iron pan the other day, I removed the pan from the fire and watched as the butter in it kept bubbling. The pan was so slow to release its heat that it persisted in cooking the vegetable for some time afterward. Another pot - one in copper, aluminum or stainless steel combined with aluminum - would have been more responsive, cooling faster and thus posing less a danger of overcooking. All heavy cast iron, including that encased in enamel, distributes heat well and retains it so that the simmering of a stew - a subject I discussed last week in this space - is marvelously done in a pot of enameled iron. But sauteeing the zucchini set me to wondering whether it made sense to have a whole set of enameled pots.

Governor Carey signed into law today a measure that would adjust New York's competitive bidding rules to let the state give preference to domestic companies when buying steel for public works projects. Mr. Carey had vetoed similar legislation twice before, in 1976 and in 1979. But in a memorandum of approval, the Governor said that ''the effect of the economic environment'' on the steel industry and changes in the bill had changed his mind. Mr. Carey cited ''a sharp decline in steel orders received by domestic firms'' and ''protectionist practices in other countries.''

The Supreme Court ruled today that a defendant who chooses to testify in court can be questioned about his failure to turn himself in or to talk to the police before his arrest. By a 7-to-2 vote, the Court held that cross-examination about a defendant's ''pre-arrest silence'' does not violate the defendant's constitutional right to a fair trial or privilege against selfincrimination.

The Carter Administration sees little hope of achieving a political settlement that would help end the plight of starving Cambodians, a top State Department official said Monday night. Speaking in New York at a forum on the United States role in Cambodia, Richard C. Holbrooke, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said, ''We are trying to find a political settlement, but I am not optimistic.''

Dick Peebles, sports editor of The Houston Chronicle for the last 22 years, collapsed of a heart attack in Houston Intercontinental Airport today and died before he could be taken to a hospital. He was 61 years old. Mr. Peebles was en route to Springfield, N.J., to cover the United States Open golf championship, which begins Thursday. An airport spokesman said the newspaperman had suffered the attack in a concourse while awaiting a flight.

IF you are flying in an airplane, all you do is wade through the pouch in front of your seat and scoop up the latest copy of the airline's in-flight magazine. If you are checking into a hotel, you can sometimes discover a special in-room periodical to snuggle up with. But what about the intrepid traveler whose idea of nirvana is a leisurely cruise on a big ship? What does he read? In-cruise magazines, of course. Starting in January, TL Enterprises will begin depositing magazines in the staterooms of ships on five cruise lines. At first, they will be annual publications, with the frequency increasing in time. The magazines are projected to stave off the potential cabin fever of 1,064,000 well-heeled passengers.

PARIS, June 10 Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that although the Iranian Government had paid for his trip to Teheran, allegations that he had been taken in by an Iranian propaganda ploy were "absolutely ridiculous."
Mayor Koch told City Council leaders yesterday that New York City's most recent wage offer to the municipal unions exceeded the amount of money allocated for labor in the proposed 1981 budget.
A Rumanian immigrant armed with a pistol took 10 persons hostage in a Queens savings and loan association yesterday and released seven of them before the police overpowered him.
Richard Bonelli, American operatic baritone, died at his home in Los Angeles on Saturday. He was 91 years old.

Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel criticized Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie today for remarks attacking Israel's settlement policy in the West Bank. ''I expected that he at least would have given me a hearing,'' Mr. Begin said in a television interview with ABC News. ''I assure the Secretary of State that, had he invited me to come to Washington especially for this talk on settlements, I would have postponed anything and rushed to Washington.''

The United States League of Savings Associations voted today to file suit against Federal regulators who recently eliminated certain interest advantages that the thrift institutions had over banks. The league said it would seek a court injunction against the change. The law in question, passed by Congress at the end of last year, was designed to phase out various interest rate ceilings over the next six years. A special panel of Federal regulators called the Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee was created to implement the law.

Charles White, Southern California's star back, came to terms today with the Cleveland Browns. The team's No. 1 draft choice was expected to challenge the veteran Greg Pruitt for a starting role. White's agent, Mike Trope, said the pact was for six years with a base in excess of $1 million and a potential for exceeding $2 million, based on performance.

The Environmental Protection Agency, amid protests by environmental and health groups, has told the Procter & Gamble Company that it would not object to the mass marketing of a detergent ingredient known to cause cancer in animals. In a letter to the company last month, Steven D. Jellinek, assistant administrator of agency for toxic substances, said that a review of the studies of the substance, NTA, or nitrilotriacetic acid, had shown that the risks of cancer associated with exposure to the detergent ingredient were low and that his agency saw no reason to take any regulatory action.

Underscoring his refusal to withdraw from the 1980 Presidential race, Senator Edward M. Kennedy dispatched two dozen special delegate hunters across the country today, then hit the campaign trail once more after a week of strategy sessions with a vow to ''close the gap'' on President Carter. By almost every calculation, Mr. Carter has already won enough delegates to be renominated at the Democratic convention in New York in mid-August. But Mr. Kennedy and his delegate hunters hope to woo away a sufficient number of Mr. Carter's supporters over the next two months to reverse the outcome.
The General Aviation Manufacturers Association announced yesterday that shipments of aircraft in May declined from the same month last year, reflecting the overall decline in the economy.

The winning of a major title by players who work together, as well as play bridge together, is a rare event. Bob and Jim Sharples, English twins who worked for the same bank for 40 years, were an outstanding partnership and came within a hairbreadth of winning the European team title.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 11 (UPI) Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned today for the second day that the Iranian revolution was threatened from within and he called on Iranians to protect it from all dangers, external and internal.

VISITORS to the splendid new American wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which opened yesterday, have a host of surprises awaiting them. Most of the period furnishings, stored out of sight throughout the five-year construction period, are back on display. And there are dozens of other late 17th- to early 20th-century examples now on view that have never been seen before at the museum.

After selling his books as the main selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club eight times - more than any other American writer (Winston Churchill, holds the overall record with 11) -James A. Michener, the most consistent best-selling novelist of our time, has sold book-club rights to his next work, ''The Covenant,'' to the Book-of-the-Month Club's arch rival, the Literary Guild, for what is believed to be the highest amount ever paid by a book club for a novel: reportedly $1,750,000. The transaction, completed a week ago, after strong bidding between the two major book clubs, has been kept secret by the publisher, Random House, and club executives because of the general feeling that prices paid for a handful of leading books have gone through the roof, and that revealing an actual amount encourages other authors and their agents to seek similar deals.

To the Editor: This election year is confusing enough without added obfuscation by those who would find a precedent for a 1980 Anderson victory in Abraham Lincoln's election in 1860, supposedly as the candidate of a third party (letter June 5).n no sense can the Republican Party of 1860 be considered a third party, for by that time it had completely supplanted the previous alternative to the Democrats, the Whig Party. The real third party in 1860 was the Constitutional Union Party, whose candidate, John Bell, won 39 of 303 electoral votes.

WHEN I'm big, I'll go to college.'' Not to have framed that sentence in childhood is to have missed out on one of the great human ambitions. But what will college look like? Estimates show that Canadian companies controlled by United States parent concerns will account for 42.8 percent of the $9.07 billion (Canadian) in capital spending by manufacturing industries this year, Statistics Canada said today. United States-controlled enterprises are expected to account for capital outlays of $3.88 billion, up $1.2 billion, or 44.8 percent, from last year, the Government agency said. The 1979 total represented an increase of $357 million, or 15.4 percent, from 1978.

The dust hangs in a thick colloidal suspension and the heat adds weight to every burden. The textile mills spew smoke and noise that settle on yet another industrial byproduct, expanding slums of cardboard and tin huts. The assault on the senses is unrelieved and privacy here is even more of an elusive abstraction than in the rest of India. But along with the harsh tumult there is also a hopeful vitality. The slums are cleaner than in other places. The raucous activity is purposeful and in this place, which was the home of Gandhi, there are still strong and idealistic personalities seeking to change and improve the general quality of life. There is, for example, Ela Bhatt, a small 45-year-old woman who steered the growth of a remarkable labor union of women who worked at the threshhold of the economy and lived at the margin of existence. These were the ragpickers, cart-pullers, porters, vegetable vendors and others who raised families while hiring out their labor for the lowest imaginable wages.

The Yankees, powered by two homers from Bob Watson and another hit by Reggie Jackson, took a three-run lead into the bottom of the ninth inning tonight. However, Bobby Murcer, a pinch-hitter, singled to right with the bases loaded and one out in the 11th, scoring two runs and giving the Yanks a 9-7 victory.

Smoking low-tar cigarettes may reduce a person's risk of getting cancer but there is no evidence that they reduce the toll from heart and lung diseases and complications in pregnancy, experts on smoking said today. The 75 doctors and scientists at a Government-sponsored conference agreed that little was known about the long-term effects of smoking cigarettes with low tar and nicotine levels, and they urged more studies. Some challenged the wisdom of Government efforts to encourage smokers to switch to the so-called ''lighter'' brands, and one group called for stern new warnings to discourage women from smoking in pregnancy.

Anderson, beaming through his dark-rimmed glasses and confidently forecasting success, concluded the opening drive of his campaign to get on the crucial California Presidential ballot in November as an independent with a noontime rally today on the lawn of the old Statehouse here.

With energy issues leading the way, the stock market climbed yesterday to its highest level since late February as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average. Meanwhile, the latest installment of a seven-week upswing in stock prices continued amid moderate trading volume.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 11 (AP) A package the size of a portable radio exploded last night outside the former Iranian consulate here. No one was injured and there was no damage from the explosion, which spewed shrapnel over a 75-foot area, the police said.

Cavenham Development Inc., one of many companies controlled by Sir James Goldsmith, said a formal agreement was expected to be reached late yesterday between Cavenham and the Diamond International Corporation, a forest-products company. Previously announced terms of the agreement provide for Sir James, who is seeking to purchase Diamond shares, to limit his investment to 40 percent for the next five years and to receive minority representation on the Diamond board of directors.

Charles H. Kirbo, President Carter's friend and unofficial adviser, visited Saudi Arabia recently as his personaL envoy to meet with members of the Saudi royal family. American officials, confirming the unpublicized trip, said the 63-year-old Georgian lawyer had met with Crown Prince Fahd and other leaders for a discussion of relations between the two nations.
SLIGHTLY CURTAILED:PANEL'S SECOND COMPROMISE WINS QUICK APPROVAL IN THE SENATE-HOUSE TO VOTE TODAY By STEVEN RATTNER

What values are there inside Jimmy Carter, what real beliefs? One wonders again at his strange intervention in the Ramsey Clark affair: his comment that he would like to see Clark and other ''American dissidents,'' as he called them, prosecuted for going to Iran. In terms of our legal system, the remark was a damaging faux pas. It is not the business of Presidents to make suggestions about prosecuting particular individuals. Those decisions are for the Justice Department, and Presidential intervention can only make the process look political. After Richard Nixon it should not be necessary to say so.

Jorge Orta hit a two-run homer in the seventh inning and a two-run single in the eighth as the Cleveland Indians defeated Kansas City, 8-5, tonight for a split of their doubleheader. The Royals, whose winning streak was halted at eight games, took the opener, 5-0, behind the two-hit pitching of Dennis Leonard, who hurled his second straight shutout.

ASPLIT rail fence in front of a Cape Cod cottage. A brick wall of the penthouse. A trellis over a garden gate. Add a climbing rose. The scene is complete, a tradition that will endure.

Prime Minister Indira Gandhi conceded today that ''uncertainties and delays'' over a shipment of nuclear fuel from the United States had compelled India to reduce the output of its 400-megawatt atomic power plant at Tarapur, near Bombay. Mrs. Gandhi, in answer to a question in Parliament on the delay in the shipment of 39.6 metric tons of enriched uranium, said her Government would wait and see whether the United States ''fulfills or breaks'' its commitment to supply the fuel.

As Michael Levin writes, the mandated changes in buildings and sidewalks to permit easier access for those in wheelchairs have been carried to excess. The damages are not only to the esthetic appearance of buildings. Have you noticed how many of the elderly are breaking their hips by slipping on the sloped curbs mandated by the Federal Government? I have yet to see a person in a wheelchair travel from street to sidewalk without aid by using one of these slopes in the concrete. But I have seen a number of older persons slip on these surfaces when they are covered with ice. Some of them - and it is cruel, not ironic - have consequently ended up in wheelchairs. The Government has made the winter existence of all of us in Northern states more unsafe with its alleged concern for the handicapped.

My young nephew, Mahmoud, had already pronounced me to be without manners or breeding - a peasant, although I had offered him the correct sweets in the correct order, pressed them upon him twice. I had taken a second refusal - from a child, after all - as final. I didn't want to sound like a nagging mother. Mahmoud, a mischievous but well-bred boy, had been waiting for the obligatory third offer, to which he would have responded with both hands. In my ignorance, I never made the third offer, and Mahmoud sat on his hands for the rest of the visit.

Top Israeli scientists and economists have told the Government the time has come to channel Mediterranean Sea water across the country to the Dead Sea to produce energy. The project would take advantage of the 1,300-foot difference in altitude between the two seas. It was proposed in the last century by Theodor Herzl, the founder of political Zionism, but has always been considered impractical. However, rising oil prices have increased the plan's feasibility.

Fried. Krupp, the parent company of West Germany's steelmaking giant, announced today that it had moved back into the black last year, following four years of either losses or minimal earnings, and said it was now looking for acquisitions to round out its steelmaking and manufacturing program. The company said that improved profitability in its steelmaking division, a result of recent heavy investments to streamline what has traditionally been its major activity, raised the company's overall performance in 1979, which was slowed only by heavy losses in the shipbuilding division.

Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini warned today for the second day that the Iranian revolution was threatened from within and he called on Iranians to protect it from all dangers, external and internal. His speech was broadcast as a debate continued among officials on whether the 53 American hostages, held since Nov. 4, should be tried as spies.

Barnwell Industries of Fairlawn, N.J., has formed a limited partnership to raise money for a geothermal drilling venture in Hawaii. Although funds of this type are commonly used to finance oil exploration, this is apparently the first time a drilling fund has been formed to explore for geothermal deposits.

The credit markets recovered yesterday, climbing out of the slump they entered Tuesday. Bond prices advanced, new corporate bonds sold rapidly, and some were increased in size. Shortterm interest rates dropped.

MADRID, June 11 (UPI) The Spanish Parliament began debating a bill today that would legalize divorce in Spain, one of only two countries in Western Europe where it still is banned. The debate was expected to be long and bitter, with opposition to the bill coming both from the powerful left-wing opposition and from the smaller right-wing parties.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) President Carter announced today that he would nominate Jack R. Borsting of Carmel, Calif., to be Assistant Secretary of Defense.

The Rev. Thomas J. Bauer, a Maryknoll missionary who served in China and Hong Kong, died of cancer last Wednesday in Chicago. He was 68 years old. He is survived by a brother, Joseph Bauer, of Williston Park, L.I.

Joseph Samachson, a retired clinical associate professor of oral biology at the Loyola University School of Dentistry in Maywood, Ill., died June 2 at Rush Presbyterian Hospital in Chicago. He was 73 years old and lived in Oak Park, Ill. He is survived also by a son, Michael; a daughter, Miriam Berkley; a brother, Jacob, and two sisters, Beatrice and Ethel.

Gunther van Well, state secretary in the West German Foreign Ministry, flew to Moscow today to prepare for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's visit to the Soviet capital at the end of this month. Mr. Schmidt's trip to Moscow will be the first by a Western leader to the Soviet capital since the invasion of Afghanistan.

To the Editor: Now really, what has the U.S. Postal Service against Frances Perkins, Labor Secretary during the F.D.R. Administration? The latest stamp, commemorating this dedicated public servant, depicts her in vertigo green monotone, with an anemic, oozing pizza dough sprawling over her head: another atrocious example of the banal, drab, uninspired stamps unconscionably turned out by the artshort Washington postal authorities. have had the privilege of seeing Frances Perkins. As I recall, her hat, which had become her trademark, had a crown, sitting on a narrow brim to which was attached a small veil reaching just above her eyebrows. It was tilted forward and a bit to the side. ELSIE K. BELMONT New York, June 5, 1980

Former Prime Minister Sir Harold Wilson, 64 years old, had major abdominal surgery today and was later listed in ''satisfactory'' condition. He was Prime Minister in Labor Party Governments from 1964-70 and from 1974-76.

Gholam Ali Oveissi, the commander of the Iranian Army under the deposed Shah, asserted this week that Iranians were tiring of the Islamic regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and predicted that there would soon be a counterrevolution. ''There is an explosion in the making,'' the former general said. ''There is little doubt that the Teheran regime's days are numbered. There is injustice being done in the name of Islam, and the Iranian people are becoming enraged.''

DARIEN, Conn., June 11 Leslie Burr rode the winners of the green and regular conformation hunter championships at the 51st Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today and then commented that she had spent little time training either of the mounts.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Inventories of the nation's manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers jumped 1.3 percent in April as sales slumped 3.3 percent, the Government said today.

NEW DELHI, June 11 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi conceded today that "uncertainties and delays" over a shipment of nuclear fuel from the United States had compelled India to reduce the output of its 400-megawatt atomic power plant at Tarapur, near Bombay.

WASHINGTON, June 11 House and Senate conferees broke their deadlock today and approved a Federal budget for the fiscal year 1981. The plan has a slightly smaller allowance for the military than was provided in the panel's first agreement, which was opposed by the Carter Administration and rejected two weeks ago by the House.
WASHINGTON, June 11 "Bob Byrd is paranoid at the thought that the Democrats are going to lose the Senate," said a veteran Democratic Senator who has long known the majority leader.

An explosion ripped through a drycleaning store on a quiet corner in the Fordham section of the Bronx shortly before noon yesterday, killing a 9-month-old girl whose mother was wheeling her along the sidewalk outside.

COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, June 11 (Reuters) Sri Lanka, which 18 months ago banned driving during a six-hour period on Sundays to conserve fuel, lifted the restriction today because the country has a surplus of gasoline.

OUT THERE Stan Brakhage took years to make a 40-minute movie of a mountain. He has photographed light through a heavy glass ashtray. He made a film of the tops of actors' heads and their feet, blurred faces and shaky camera movements. He has incorporated stray light, scratches and other technical flaws into his films. For almost 30 years he has been making films that are non-narrative, avant-garde and, these days, his personal vision - scenes of his family, his Colorado home environment, such as the mountain. His influence is significant because he has been exhibited in museums and won awards, he is a teacher at the Art Institute in Chicago and he is the quintessential experimental film maker.

A spokesman for Hare Krishna groups yesterday denied reports that they had stockpiled weapons and ammunition. Tom Allin, a member of the group's New York temple, said a Krishna devotee known as Hansadutta Swami was removed from his post as ''commissioner'' assigned to the Northwest after his arrest near the Berkeley, Calif., temple last month on charges of possessing firearms. ''Any institution is capable of having people who deviate from the standards,'' Mr. Allin said. ''When someone starts collecting guns, this is against our religion.''
ROCHESTER, June 11 The Cosmos defeated the Rochester Lancers, 4-2, tonight and kept intact Coach Hennes Weisweiler's unbeaten record since taking over the team.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, June 12 President Choi Kyu Hah promised today to speed up South Korea's constitutional revision process leading to elections and a transfer of power to a new government by the end of next June, but only if "public order and social stability" are maintained.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, created in 1969 to encourage private investment in developing nations, went to Congress today seeking a new mandate for export promotion and found itself confronted by skeptical senators and abandoned by the Carter Administration.

ALBANY, June 11 The New York State Senate gave final approval to two bills today and was expected to approve a third tomorrow that would permit New York City to raise a total of about $22 million more a year from existing taxes. But it narrowly defeated a proposal to allow the city to impose a taxi franchise tax.

CHICAGO, June 11 A Federal jury began deliberations today on a sixyear-old $900 million antitrust suit brought against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by the MCI Communications Corporation.

MADRID, June 11 The call by President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France last week for a slowdown in the expansion of the European Common Market has aroused disquiet and uncertainty in the two affected nations, Spain and Portugal.
MONTREAL, June 11 The National Hockey League draft, which was held here today, is a futures market.

DETROIT, June 11 The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was "temporarily delaying" payment to suppliers of $150 million in bills due yesterday until it can obtain loans guaranteed by the Federal Government.

Michigan officials have learned an unwelcome lesson in the difficulty of persuading the rest of the country, and their own voters as well, that the ailing automobile industry, on which the state depends, still has enough resilience to merit a vote of confidence, The state Capitol in Lansing was rocked Monday by a decision from the Standard & Poors bond rating service to downgrade Michigan's state bonds from AA to A, a level just above the cut-off line for investor grade securities, which only two other states share.

The State Board of Education today bowed to strong pressure from the Legislature and vocal community groups and retreated from its order mandating specific sex education courses at all grade levels in the schools, beginning with kindergarten. Although the board again unanimously endorsed the need for sex education in the public schools, it approved a revision of the family life education curriculum eliminating specific course topics and the requirement that sex education be taught in every grammar school grade. It also permitted local school boards to develop the curriculum and decide at which elementary level the courses would begin.

There is no time left for members of New York's City Council and Board of Estimate to inflate the hopes of constituents. An approved budget is due on the Mayor's desk today. Good arguments are easy to find for the familiar flow of promises: more policemen, more school spending, more aid for cultural institutions, and no new taxes. But the argument to make final and realistic choices makes more sense. The city will never have a better chance to balance income against outgo, without fictitious gimmicks. Mayor Koch urges a balance in the coming year (1981) but not because the law requires it. There is one more year to squeeze the last $150 million of borrowed money out of the cash income side of the ledger. But waiting until next year would make the task still harder. Perched precariously on a financial tightrope in fiscal 1982, the city would have to lop off at one stroke enough expenses to cover the as yet undetermined wage increases of its workers plus the improperly classified capital items. And it would probably not have the benefit of the hefty cash balance now in hand.

After the New Jersey Nets made Mike O'Koren, a 6-foot-7-inch forward from North Carolina, their top pick in Tuesday's National Basketball Association collegiate draft, O'Koren was approached for his reaction. ''I'll be right back,'' said the 22-year-old from Jersey City, chosen sixth over all. ''First I've got to find my mom.'' As O'Koren dashed off to hug Rose O'Koren, the Nets announced they had chosen Mike Gminski, a 6-11 center from Duke University as the No. 7 pick. Gminski, 21 years old, strode to the podium, then dodged reporters as he made his way back into the crowd to embrace his father.

Almost a quarter of the candidates for bachelor's degrees at the City University of New York now completing their sophomore year have not passed at least one of the basic skills tests in reading, writing and mathematics, university officials said yesterday. Students who fail any of the tests will have to apply for an extension to remain in college and to retake the tests. The testing program, begun in the fall of 1978, is being used by the university for the first time to insure that all students moving from the sophomore to the junior year meet certain minimum standards in addition to completing the required 61 credits of course work.

Fifteen hundred off-duty firefighters massed in Middle Village, Queens, yesterday for the funeral of Fireman Donald M. Bub, who was stricken with a heart attack last Friday while fighting a fire in a Harlem apartment. The blaze was later attributed to arson. ''Greater love hath no man than this, that a man lay down his life for his friends,'' his Engine 47 captain, Michael Loughran, quoted from the New Testament to 200 family members, friends and firemen who filled the Community United Methodist Church at 75-27 Metropolitan Avenue. The group included Mayor Koch and Fire Commissioner Augustus A. Beekman. The rest of the crowd spilled into the street.

The New York City Council and the Board of Estimate were reported close to agreement on a new city budget early this morning after the Board recommended a package that would add $34 million to the Mayor's original $13.58 billion budget proposals, including an extra $14.5 million for education and $5 million for the police.

Oil price increases by September were hinted at by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, despite earlier pledges to hold the line. A Saudi official suggested the increase might be one or two dollars a barrel over the present $28 price. Meanwhile, Kuwait, Venezuela, Qatar and Iraq increased their prices $2 a barrel starting next month. [Page A1.]

WASHINGTON, June 11 Backers of legislation to strengthen enforcement of a 12-year-old law banning racial discrimination in housing won a narrow victory today as the House opened debate on the only major civil rights bill to come before Congress this year.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 11 (AP) A Chinese mathematician who feared he was failing in his research and would disgrace his Government electrocuted himself at his apartment, authorities said today.

AL FRIEDMAN'S family has been in the telephone answering business for three generations. As services go, the Affiliated Telephone Answering Service Inc. is one of Manhattan's larger and healthier operations. Its 200 employees operate 50 switchboards around the clock while its 5,000 or so customers provide it with revenues of several million dollars a year.

Kuwait, Venezuela, Iraq and Qatar raised their oil prices today, following the two-day meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, while Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates qualified a previous stand against increasing their charges. The Saudi and Emirates oil ministers, who said yesterday that they would not change their prices, left open today the possibility of increases by next September, when OPEC is scheduled to meet in Geneva and try again to reach a uniform price for all its members.

In another episode in the two-year dispute over the appropriate compensation for Marvin Webster, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday turned the case back to the Special Master serving as an arbitrator in such basketball cases. In a 2-1 decision, the court asked Telford Taylor to determine whether the original award made by the National Basketball Association commissioner, Larry O'Brien, was significantly higher than Webster's fair value. After the Knicks signed the 7-foot free agent to a $3 million, five-year contract in the fall of 1978, the commissioner awarded the Seattle SuperSonics Lonnie Shelton, a first-round draft choice, and $450,000 as compensation. Under the terms of the 1976 settlement of the Oscar Robertson suit, the National Basketball Players Association appealed the award to Professor Taylor, who was appointed by Federal Judge Robert L. Carter to supervise the Robertson settlement.

PROSECUTION UNDER TRAVEL BAN WAS 'WRONG AND HARMFUL' PARIS, June 11 (UPI) - Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark said today that President Carter's comment yesterday voicing an inclination to prosecute him for traveling to Iran in defiance of a Presidential ban was wrong and harmful. ''I was disappointed and sad,'' Mr. Clark said in an interview, ''that President Carter would be commenting publicly on what may become a criminal case because it shows insensitivity to the rule of law.''

RECALLING 16 MILLION CARS-COMPANY DENIES DEFECTS DETROIT, June 11 - The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration confirmed today that it had made an ''initial determination'' that safety defects existed in the transmissions of some 16 million Ford Motor Company automobiles. Such a finding usually results in a recall of the automobiles.

Mr. Watson replaces Hamilton Jordan, who is taking a leave of absence from the White House to join the President's re-election campaign.

ALBANY, June 11 (UPI) The Mobil Oil Corporation, faced with a move in the State Legislature to impose a grass-receipts tax on oil companies as a way of paying for $235 million of mass transportation aid, has begun lobbying against the proposal.

Several key American civilian supervisors involved in building two new air bases for Israel have been replaced after labor disorders, an Israeli Defense Ministry spokesman said today. The announcement came two weeks after a quarter of the foreign laborers quit or were dismissed in a tense dispute at one of two Negev airfields that are to replace Sinai bases being returned to Egypt under the peace treaty.

Q. We recently had unfinished, brick-colored clay tiles installed around the stove in our kitchen. The installer did not put a sealer on them, and now there are grease stains on these tiles. Also, there is also a film of grout (cement) over all the tiles. Can you tell me what kind of sealer I should apply? - Mrs. J. L., McLean, Va. A. You should be able to wash most of the grout or cement off with hydrochloric acid, and this may also take much of the grease stains out. You can buy this acid in paint and hardware stores. Dilute it with two or three parts of water, mixing in a glass or plastic bowl, and wear rubber gloves.
RULING PARTY FIGHTING TO MAINTAIN MAJORITY By HENRY SCOTT STOKES

President Carter said today that he would nominate Richard C. Erwin, a state court of appeals judge, to a new Federal judgeship for the Middle District of North Carolina. Judge Erwin, 56 years old, has been an appeals judge since 1977.

Important revelations can come in ludicrous ways. In a midnight conversion to the views of Jimmy Carter, Ayatollah Khomeini declares that ''the masses cannot any longer govern'' Iran, that the revolution has become its own worst enemy, that the nation needs a government to address its terrible problems and finally end the distraction of the hostage game. Simultaneously, in pious surrender to a poll of the crowd, President Carter announces that he favors a trial for the Americans who defied his travel ban to Iran. Did Mr. Carter conclude that he cannot campaign without flailing the Iranian issue just as the Ayatollah discovered he cannot govern by flailing the American issue? We know who is coaching the Ayatollah. For this week, anyway, President Bani-Sadr has had the ear of the old man, proving to him that the continuing execution of Iranians and imprisonment of Americans are acts of defiance by extremists who value power for themselves ahead of the welfare of the country. These factions were close to strangling Mr. Bani-Sadr, condemning him as ''pro-Western'' and ''non-Islamic'' and using the hostages to dramatize his impotence. They have used their power on the Revolutionary Council to block negotiation for the release of the Americans, to hold out for a Prime Minister and Cabinet of their choosing and, thus, to let the economy slide toward chaos.

Two proposals by New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission to increase the number of taxis were opposed yesterday by the taxi industry, a drivers' union and an economist. The opposition came during a public hearing at 125 Worth Street on proposals for group riding and a night-fare surcharge. Under the first proposal, a 50-cent fee would be added to every fare between 9 P.M. and 6 A.M. for a six-month experimental period beginning Sept. 15.

Solar Dome, New York Hall of Science, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, 111th Street and 48th Avenue, Flush- ing, Queens. A permanently installed 23-foot solar geodesic dome will go on display as a greenhouse for vegetables and plant seedlings this Saturday at the entrance of the Hall of Science. Workshops on the design and construction of the dome will be offered as well as a howto guide book for building your own.

The New York State Senate gave final approval to two bills today and was expected to approve a third tomorrow that would permit New York City to raise a total of about $22 million more a year from existing taxes. But it narrowly defeated a proposal to allow the city to impose a taxi franchise tax. After the suprise defeat by one vote, the medallion bill was tabled, which means it can be reconsidered before the Legislature recesses later this week or at a possible special session later in the year.

The credit markets recovered yesterday, climbing out of the slump they entered Tuesday. Bond prices advanced, new corporate bonds sold rapidly, and some were increased in size. Short-term interest rates dropped. To many dealers, the main reason for the rebound in the fixedincome markets was the absence of the Federal Reserve from the money market as the Federal funds rate dipped. On Tuesday, the central bank had twice drained reserves from the banking system in actions that were widely interpreted as a sign that the monetary authorities did not want short-term rates any lower. By remaining out of the market yesterday, the Federal Reserve raised many doubts about this view.

The First National Bank of Boston lowered its prime rate yesterday by one percentage point, to 12 percent. It thus became the first bank among the nation's top 20 to have a prime rate below 13 percent. First National, the country's 17th-largest bank as ranked by deposits, matched the rate set Monday by the Southwest Bank of St. Louis, a smaller bank that often undercuts the big money-center banks.

The Spanish Parliament began debating a bill today that would legalize divorce in Spain, one of only two countries in Western Europe where it still is banned. The debate was expected to be long and bitter, with opposition to the bill coming both from the powerful left-wing opposition and from the smaller right-wing parties.

Elizabeth Craig, the doyenne of British cooking writers, has died at the age of 97. The Scottish-born expert on food and wine died Saturday at her rural English home in the village of Farnham Common, Buckinghamshire. Private funeral services will be held next Monday, the family announced.

The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee removed the Long Island Lighting Company's Northport plant from the list of power-generating plants that were to be converted from oil to coal, sparing Lilco conversion costs, put at $2.6 billion. The committee called for the oil-to-coal conversion of 80 other generating facilities in 15 states as part of President Carter's program to cut in half the country's consumption of foreign oil.

WHEN the three-month Treasury bill discount rate fell to 6.5 percent on Monday, investors holding maturing bills must have eyed the market nervously.

OTTAWA, June 11 (AP) Estimates show that Canadian companies controlled by United States parent concerns will account for 42.8 percent of the $9.07 billion (Canadian) in capital spending by manufacturing industries this year, Statistics Canada said today.
ROME, June 11 (AP) West Germany, a strong favorite, defeated Czechoslovakia, 1-0, today in the opening game of the European soccer championships in the Olympic Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 11 Gholam Ali Oveissi, the commander of the Iranian Army under the deposed Shah, asserted this week that Iranians were tiring of the Islamic regime of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and predicted that there would soon be a counterrevolution.

By Anatole Broyard OFF CENTER. By Barbara Grizzuti Harri- son. 305 pages. The Dial Press. $9.95. BARBARA GRIZZUTI HARRISON is a taster of culture. Usually, this results in her making a wry face.
