She's what you might call a modern woman made out of old-fashioned materials.
Meets on South Africa at 11 A.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY
MARKET IMPERILED BY PROPOSAL TO SLOW DOWN EXPANSION By JAMES M. MARKHAM

Staten Island Democrats endorsed last night one of the top-ranking Republican state senators, John J. Marchi, despite the opposition of the Senate's Democratic leader, Manfred Ohrenstein. The 23-member executive board of the county's Democratic Committee, meeting at Susan Wagner High School on Staten Island, unanimously endorsed Senator Marchi, a decision that was then acclaimed by the 250 committee members.
A Business Day listing yesterday of the largest brokerage companies inadvertently omitted Paine Webber. A corrective table appears on Page D9.

TO THE HOME SECTION: I have not been in New York long enough to know what Central Park was (''Design Notebook,'' June 5), so I can deal only with what the park seems to be today. Central Park on a Sunday afternoon is an extremely unpleasant place to be. My Chelsea neighborhood is quieter, more relaxing and less intimidating. To see Park Service rangers juxtaposed with drug dealers and sausage vendors is a tragedy. Police cruise the roads looking for violent crime, not having the time, resources or inclination to harass citizens on petty matters such as drug use, noise pollution, littering and the like. It is a bigger zoo than the zoo itself. Road races, softball leagues, carnivals, concerts and so on are obviously worthwhile activities, but their overall impact on the quality of the park is decidedly negative. The park should not be Disneyland.

The New York City Council and the Board of Estimate were reported close to agreement on a new city budget early this morning after the Board recommended a package that would add $34 million to the Mayor's original $13.58 billion budget proposals, including an extra $14.5 million for education and $5 million for the police.

Judy Hendren Mello, 36 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the First Women's Bank in New York, effective next Monday. The position has been vacant since the resignation last January of Lynn D. Salvage. The bank, which recently completed a stock offering that netted more than $800,000, lost money from 1975, the year it was founded, through 1977. But it turned the corner in 1978 and was profitable last year. Mrs. Mello, who is now at the Marine Midland Bank, addressed herself to the record of the First Women's Bank in a telephone interview.

The Overseas Private Investment Corporation, created in 1969 to encourage private investment in developing nations, went to Congress today seeking a new mandate for export promotion and found itself confronted by skeptical senators and abandoned by the Carter Administration. Luther H. Hodges Jr., Deputy Secretary of Commerce, told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that the Administration had ''no position'' on whether the agency's mission should be refocused on export promotion.

The Soviet press service Novosti reports that the Soviet Union hopes to get Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany to put off Atlantic alliance plans for deploying new nuclear missiles in Western Europe. The Novosti article was believed to reflect a Soviet effort to have West German public opinion focus on the issue before Mr. Schmidt goes to Moscow on June 30.

Bail was set at $200,000 for an armed 25-year-old Rumanian immigrant from Queens who took 10 persons hostage at a Queens savings and loan association Tuesday and demanded a passport and a job with the Central Intelligence Agency.

TAKE an avant-garde sculptor who creates clouds out of water molecules, place four dancers into this vaporous haze and you have one of the most striking dance pieces created by the experimental choreographer Trisha Brown. Rigor and austerity have often characterized Miss Brown's work, but at the same time she has also tended to set many of her dances in the most ingenious of environments. Now she has hit pay dirt in ''Opal Loop/Cloud Installation No. 72503,'' which had its premiere Tuesday night at 55 Crosby Street and which will be performed through Saturday.

SEATTLE, June 11 The nation's mayors wrapped up their annual convention in time-honored fashion today by passing resolutions asking for more money from the Federal Government more money for jobs, more for housing, more for transportation, pollution control and countless other ambitions that, given these times and this Congress and this Administration, they have no chance of fulfilling.
A former Wall Street dividend clerk was charged yesterday with stealing $160,000 from two Wall Street brokerage firms.

Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. said yesterday that it had been told by its corporate parent, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, that it may participate in Occidental's Talara oil project in Peru under recently renegotiated terms but that the Canadian company was not obligated to do so.

WASHINGTON, June 11 The Labor Department is pressing for an expansion of Federal jobs programs to counter the rapidly rising rate of unemployment, but its proposals are being rebuffed, at least for the moment, by the White House and economic policy makers in the Carter Administration, Government sources said today.

BOSTON, June 11 What values are there inside Jimmy Carter, what real beliefs? One wonders again at his strange intervention in the Ramsey Clark affair: his comment that he would like to see Clark and other "American dissidents," as he called them, prosecuted for going to Iran.
Two proposals by New York City's Taxi and Limousine Commission to increase the number of taxis were opposed yesterday by the taxi industry, a drivers' union and an economist.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Carmen voted 134 to 3 last night to strike the Port Authority Trans-Hudson Railroad at 12:01 A.M. today. The union members rejected a final contract offer from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. It was the first strike called since 1973 against the suburban railroad, which carries 80,000 commuters daily between New Jersey and Manhattan.

Clearly uneasy about changes in their lives and in the society around them, 13,000 messengers of the Southern Baptist Convention used their annual meeting here this week to reaffirm traditional Baptist ways. They did so by singing traditional hymns like ''Stand Up, Stand Up for Jesus'' and ''A Mighty Fortress Is Our God'' morning, noon and night, listening to dozens of sermons from the country's best Southern Baptist preachers and reaffirming confidence in the Second Coming of Christ. By the year 2000, through an operation called Bold Mission Thrust, they vowed that every living person on earth would have an opportunity to respond to the Gospel.

IT is odd that so few audio fans have tasted the rewards of making their own ''live'' recordings. One reason may be that microphones somehow seem more formidable than other audio components, though why this is so is quite puzzling. Possibly it's a matter of ''image'' - if that's a proper word for something so vague. We usually see pundits and politicians talking into microphones, so one might gain an impression that these devices are intended mainly for persons of prominence. But the fact is that a microphone (or two, if recording is to be done in stereo) will open whole new areas of audio activity for anyone with a good tape deck. After all, many families and almost every neighborhood has talents - amateur musicians, church choirs or perhaps theater groups - who would be pleased to have someone competently record their performances or rehearsals. Such recordings may stimulate selfcriticism, a trait sometimes underdeveloped in aspirants of the muses.

In the 1970's Americans discovered gourmet dining,'' said an executive of a major food corporation. ''In the 1980's people will be more interested in nutrition than anything else, and that concern will increase at every income level of our society.'' Evidence of that concern, said the executive, Juan E. Metzger, vice president of the Beatrice Foods Company and head of its Dannon Yogurt division, is leading to a growing emphasis in the industry on the marketing of nutrition as opposed to the mere selling of food.
INSURGENT SWEEPS By DREW MIDDLETON

The Carter Administration has clearly decided to play the ''China card'' vigorously. This has been signaled by the visit of Geng Biao, one of China's Deputy Prime Ministers, to the United States in May and the resulting agreement to provide military-support equipment to his country, and by Defense Secretary Harold Brown's trip to China in January. While playing the card makes sense from the perspective of preempting Presidential-campaign charges of the Administration's being ''soft'' on Moscow, and it makes Americans who feel impotent in the face of Soviet advances feel better, there are at least four reasons not to play the hand as it now is being played.

To the Editor: There has been entirely too much complaint about Messrs. Carter and Reagan and the political process, as though it were some vast, impersonal machine that had delivered up candidates nobody wants. I think The Times is falling irresponsibly short of its obligation to help people understand the actual political process better.ndeed we are going to have to choose between Carter and Reagan and possibly Anderson, but the reason for this is that these candidates have won the overwhelming number of primaries and thus the endorsement of American citizens who care enough to come out and vote.

John McEnroe and Vitas Gerulaitis, two of the top challengers for Bjorn Borg's Wimbledon crown, tuned up on grass courts today with first-round victories in the $125,000 Queen's Club tennis tournament.

George Hendrick drilled a run-scoring single with two out in the 10th inning tonight to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-3 triumph over the Atlanta Braves. With two out in the 10th, the Atlanta left fielder, Brian Asselstine, dropped Keith Hernandez's fly ball. Larry Bradford (1-4) then walked Ted Simmons intentionally and was relieved by Gene Garber.

The worldwide uranium industry, which is already experiencing severe oversupply and reduced demand, faces a substantial jump in productive capacity over the next decade, according to a recently published study of uranium mining operations. The increase in capacity is likely to accompany a marked shift to lower-cost mines, the study suggests, indicating that a number of present high-cost producers could be forced out of the market. The study was published late last month by the Commodities Research Unit, a London-based research consulting company that specializes in resource industries. The study is for sale at $30,000 a copy.

The winning of a major title by players who work together, as well as play bridge together, is a rare event. Bob and Jim Sharples, English twins who worked for the same bank for 40 years, were an outstanding partnership and came within a hairbreadth of winning the European team title. In New York, a group of players who work for the brokerage house of Bear Stearns & Company have in the past few years won a series of team victories at the local and national level.

Argentina's great port capital, hailed by poets as the Queen of the River Plate, celebrated today its foundation 400 years ago as an armed hamlet besieged by Indians. The settlement founded on the muddy estuary in 1580 by 74 colonizers led by Capt. Juan de Garay of Spain has grown into one of the world's 10 largest urban centers, with three million people in the capital and five million more in the 32 suburban municipalities that make up greater Buenos Aires.

IN an effort to limit exposure to asbestos, the Federal Government has announced that 1,200 companies must describe how they use the mineral in items ranging from pot-holders to dishwashers. The Consumer Products Safety Commission said that the companies singled out are those most likely to be manufacturers of household products containing asbestos, which can cause cancer. The new order will be published next month and the companies affected will have 60 days to supply information on asbestos used in products since Jan. 1, 1977. The commission then will decide whether any of the affected products should be regulated.
Carter during recent White House visit By WOLFGANG SAXON

JOSEPH E. STICKLAND and Fredric L. Berg are not the kind of guys who need a brick wall to fall on them to get them going on something. So when, as marketing consultants, they kept hearing clients asking them about the most efficient delivery system for cents-off coupons they set about developing one of their own. ''They were looking for the broadest reach with the lowest cost,'' said 40-year-old Joe Stickland, ''Suddenly, we said, 'God, we've got it and it's been there all along.' ''

BANGKOK, Thailand, June 11 With the seas seasonally calm and political repression and economic hardship continuing in Vietnam, the number of refugees leaving in small boats is again reaching its annual peak, reports from countries around the South China Sea indicate.

WASHINGTON, June 11 A hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee was abruptly adjourned today after Justice Department officials persisted in their refusal to turn over investigative files on 15 criminal cases involving allegations of political corruption.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 11 In professional golf, where the competitors keep a critical eye on one another week after week, the men best equipped to handicap a United States Open are the pros themselves.
WASHINGTON, June 11 Charles H. Kirbo, President Carter's friend and unofficial adviser, visited Saudi Arabia recently as his personal envoy to meet with members of the Saudi royal family.
SYDNEY, Australia, June 11 (UPI) Newsroom employees of Australian newspapers voted today to accept a compromise offer from publishers and end a strike in a dispute over electronic editing equipment.

DETROIT, June 11 Michigan officials have learned an unwelcome lesson in the difficulty of persuading the rest of the country, and their own voters as well, that the ailing automobile industry, on which the state depends, still has enough resilience to merit a vote of confidence.
WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The White House formally announced today a resumption of the Egyptian-Israeli talks on Palestinian self-rule, which have been suspended for over a month.
A spokesman for Hare Krishna groups yesterday denied reports that they had stockpiled weapons and ammunition.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 11 Edna O'Brien's "Virginia," which had its world premiere last night at the Stratford Festival, is a compelling portrait of genius and of madness. This dramatization of the life of Virginia Woolf is penetrating without being psychoanalytical, and it is inextricable from the performance of Maggie Smith in the title role.

DETROIT, June 11 The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration confirmed today that it had made an "initial determination" that safety defects existed in the transmissions of some 16 million Ford Motor Company automobiles. Such a finding usually results in a recall of the automobiles.

WASHINGTON IN an effort to limit exposure to asbestos, the Federal Government has announced that 1,200 companies must describe how they use the mineral in items ranging from potholders to dishwashers.

TRENTON, June 11 The State Board of Education today bowed to strong pressure from the Legislature and vocal community groups and retreated from its order mandating specific sex education courses at all grade levels in the schools, beginning with kindergarten.

Two months ago, at the start of preparations for the Venice summit meeting that President Carter will attend later this month, the American Embassy in Rome got a message from the Secret Service in Washington asking what provisions were being made for the Presidential motorcade. When the embassy answered that there was not going to be a motorcade, a huffy message came back saying, in effect, ''What do you mean, we have always had a motorcade wherever the President went.''

The International Labor Organization has become known in recent years for doing good economic and social work and adopting bad political resolutions. For 27 months, this combination deprived the agency of essential United States participation and budgetary support. Now, only months after America's return to the I.L.O., a new resolution concerning the West Bank threatens the understanding by which the return was arranged. The recurring problem comes not from the I.L.O.'s normal efforts to promote worker rights and employment but from the excesses and inconsistencies of its annual conferences. Member countries have been quick enough to condemn Israel over questions having little directly to do with labor practices but they have been inversely slow to investigate blatant violations of labor rights in the Soviet bloc. For a time, the American boycott seemed to induce restraint and more evenhandedness, as well as some important procedural reforms. But the American return has been greeted by a decision of the Resolutions Committee to give priority to a Jordanian motion condemning Israeli settlement policies on the West Bank. It is part of the Arab campaign to press the case against Israel in every international body.

Representative John B. Anderson appears to be making progress toward qualifying for the ballot in enough states to have a theoretical chance of being elected President. President Carter said yesterday that he would consider debating Mr. Anderson, or any other candidate, who could conceivably win in November. The statement reversed the President's earlier refusal to debate Mr. Anderson and reflected a growing sensitivity in the Carter camp to charges that they were harassing the independent candidate.
MIDEAST TALKS REVIVIED, U.S. SAYS

International West European leaders will meet today in Venice to search for ways to arrest what many of them view as a slide toward a world crisis. The chiefs of the Common Market countries are expected to call for the inclusion of the Palestine Liberation Organization in future Middle East peace negotiations. Another high-level Western meeting that will include the United States, Canada and Japan is also to convene in Venice, on June 22. (Page A1, Col.1.) Tight security safeguards in Venice have been prepared by a force of about 8,000 men, including hundreds of antiterrorist experts and a frogmen's unit in advance of the Western summit meetings. The city of canals poses special safety problems. (A1:2.) The Prime Minister of Japan died after a heart attack at the age of 70. The death of Masayoshi Ohira left his governing party leaderless 10 days before Parliamentary elections. (A1:4-5.) Britain is sending troops to New Hebrides and French riot police arrived in the South Pacific archipelago. London said its mission was designed ''to provide stability'' in the uneasy situation in the islands, which are to gain independence next month. (A5:1.) Energy Oil prices were raised by four members of OPEC. Kuwait, Venezuela, Iraq and Qatar increased prices as much as $2 a barrel. Saudi Arabia, the cartel's largest producer, and the United Arab Emirates left open the possibility of increases by next September, when OPEC is to meet in a new attempt to agree on a uniform price. (A1:3.) National A budget deadlock was broken as House and Senate conferees approved $613.6 billion in spending for the next fiscal year, with a slightly smaller allowance for the military than was provided in a previous agreement opposed by the Carter Administration and rejected by the House. The new plan won speedy voice-vote approval in the Senate, which sought to insure that the House would go along in a vote scheduled for today. (A1:6.) A new White House chief of staff was named. The appointee is Jack H. Watson Jr., who has been in charge of the Cuban refugee program and other domestic problems. He replaces Hamilton Jordan, who has been spending much of his time on Mr. Carter's re-election campaign and will now devote full time to accelerating it. (A1:4-5.) John B. Anderson seems to be gaining in his goal to qualify for the ballot in enough states to have a theoretical chance of being elected President. In response, President Carter's campaign is stepping up its efforts to challenge the independent candidate's legal position in several key states. (B12:2-5.) Government treatment of Haitians is the subject of a major legal controversy and a trial that could determine whether the thousands of refugees will remain in this country or are sent home. Lawyers for the Haitians contend there is a pattern of harassment and discrimination, but the Government says that this is not the case and that it has merely tried to carry out immigration laws. (A1:3-6.) Stress on the marketing of nutrition as opposed to the mere selling of food is rising in the industry in response to increasing consumer interest in proper eating habits. Food industry executives say that increasingly large sums of money are being invested in the research, development and advertising of nutritious products. (A1:1-3.) Registration for a draft advanced as Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, ended 31 hours of delaying tactics and cleared the way for a final Senate vote on the bill today. Passage is expected. The House has approved a similar bill and President Carter is considered certain to sign the final legislation. (A20:1-2.) The renomination of President Carter is considered certain by nearly all leading politicians in Washington. An exception is Robert C.Byrd, the Senate majority leader, who has declined to comment on speculation that he fears a Carter campaign might cost the Democrats their Senate majority. (B12:1-2.) Metropolitan Failures in basic skills tests among students now completing their sophomore year in the City University of New York were reported by university officials. They said that nearly a quarter of the students had not passed examinations in reading, writing and mathematics. Those who failed any of the tests must seek an extension to remain in college and to retake the tests. (A1:3-4.) A retreat in mandating sex education at all grade levels in New Jersey schools occurred as the State Board of Education bowed to strong opposition from legislators and community groups. The board sharply modified the proposed family-life program, eliminating specific course topics and permitting local school boards to develop the curriculum for the program, which is to begin in 1983. (B1:1.) A strike against the PATH railroad was called by the carmen's union. It voted 134 to 3 to reject a contract offer by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersy and to approve a walkout, beginning at 12:01 A.M. today. (B2:1-4.) Mayor Koch is courting minorities in what he terms a ''campaign'' to publicize his record. It is the second time in less than a year that he has begun a drive to enhance his image among blacks and other minorities, contending again that the strained relations are primarily due to his public image, a contention that some black elected officials dispute. (B1:6.) Business Digest, Page D1

It may soon cost a bit more to get married in New York City. The State Senate tonight authorized the city to increase to $5 from $3 the fee for a marriage license. The bill is expected to clear the Assembly and be signed into law by Governor Carey.

Ron LeFlore drove in his third run of the game with a two-out ninth-inning single that scored Chris Speier from second with the winning run as the Montreal Expos edged the San Diego Padres, 7-6, for their eighth straight victory tonight. Speier drew a two-out walk off a reliever, Bob Shirley, 5-2. Speier went to second when the winning pitcher, Elias Sosa, 4-2, lined a single into right field and then scored on LeFlore's hit.
Alice DeLury is a freelance writer. By ALICE DeLURY

Inventories of the nation's manufacturers, retailers and wholesalers jumped 1.3 percent in April as sales slumped 3.3 percent, the Government said today. April's inventory rise of $5.9 billion, to a seasonally adjusted $445.2 billion, follows an increase of nine-tenths of 1 percent in March, a figure revised from an original estimate of six-tenths of 1 percent, the Commerce Department said.

Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd. said yesterday that it had been told by its corporate parent, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, that it may participate in Occidental's Talara oil project in Peru under recently renegotiated terms but that the Canadian company was not obligated to do so. The parent company announced Tuesday that it had agreed with the Peruvian Government on renegotiating its production-sharing contract for the oilfield project at Talara, on the Pacific coast 600 miles northwest of Lima.

In professional golf, where the competitors keep a critical eye on one another week after week, the men best equipped to handicap a United States Open are the pros themselves. As the 80th Open begins tomorrow on the Lower Course of the Baltusrol Golf Club, the consensus today focused on Tom Watson, Hale Irwin, Jack Nicklaus, Severiano Ballesteros, Andy Bean, John Mahaffey, Larry Nelson and Lee Trevino's nomination for a long shot, Bill Rogers.

The credit markets recovered yesterday, climbing out of the slump they entered Tuesday. Bond prices advanced, new corporate bonds sold rapidly, and some were increased in size. Short-term interest rates dropped. To many dealers, the main reason for the rebound in the fixedincome markets was the absence of the Federal Reserve from the money market as the Federal funds rate dipped. On Tuesday, the central bank had twice drained reserves from the banking system in actions that were widely interpreted as a sign that the monetary authorities did not want short-term rates any lower. By remaining out of the market yesterday, the Federal Reserve raised many doubts about this view.
PROVIDE STABILITY'-FRENCH ANTIRIOT POLICE ARRIVE By WILLIAM BORDERS
813 By CHARLOTTE EVANS

The Cosmos defeated the Rochester Lancers, 4-2, tonight and kept intact Coach Hennes Weisweiler's unbeaten record since taking over the team. The Cosmos put on an awesome show late in the first half and in the early stages of the second, getting two goals from Julio Cesar Romero and one each from Angelo DiBernardo and Seninho, who replaced Romero in the 80th minute.
West Germany, a strong favorite, defeated Czechoslovakia, 1-0, today in the opening game of the European soccer championships in the Olympic Stadium.

Caumsett State Park, with its 67-room Marshall Field Mansion in Huntington, L.I., overlooking Long Island Sound, will be the scene of an instructional program in the summer under the auspices of Queens College. Called ''The Arts at Caumsett,'' it will offer studies in painting, chamber music and Shakespearean acting to residents of New York City and Long Island. According to Raymond Erickson, chairman of the music department at the college, participants will be involved in performances and exhibitions. Every student in the three disciplines will share a course on ''The Environment of Art: Form and Meaning in Visual Art, Music and Drama.'' Enrollment is limited, and academic credit will be given in most cases.

Airwick Industries, Carlstadt, N.J., a developer and manufacturer of household and professional products, has appointed John C. Lewis vice president-administration for Airwick Western Hemisphere. * Chicago Sun-Times has named Ralph Otwell executive vice president. * Corroon & Black Corporation, an insurance broker based in New York, has named Thomas N. Perez president of Corroon & Black Management, a subsidiary based in Nashville.

Even for a team with a talent for bizarre behavior, the New York Mets outdid themselves last night in Shea Stadium when they bamboozled the Los Angeles Dodgers for the second straight time. And this time, they soared to the outer limits, beating the Dodgers, 6-2, on a two-out, bases-loaded home run by Mike Jorgensen in the l0th inning. The grand slam was delivered one inning after Jorgensen had gone into the game on defense, trying to help the Mets protect a 2-l lead with three outs to go in regulation time.

Israeli policemen aided by helicopters and bloodhounds searched the Sharon Plain today for an 8-year-old boy and his abductors, who collected a $43,000 ransom but then failed to release the child. Kidnappings have become more frequent amid rising crime in Israel. The boy, Oron Yarden, disappeared Sunday evening from the shopping center of Savyon, a well-to-do suburb of Tel Aviv, where he lived with his parents and teen-age brother and sister.

There is a man who likes to work barefoot in the Carter campaign's omniscient watch over its convention delegates. This man, Tony Corrado, reads Goethe to unwind at the end of a long day of talking to 20 or so Carter delegates and reassuring them on such verities as their convention hotel reservations -precise room and telephone numbers are already entered in the campaign's computer bank - and the invincibility of the Carter majority. At this point, with partisans of Senator Edward M. Kennedy vowing to undo somehow the results of the completed primary season, Camelot's Grail has never seemed more deeply buried. A new metaphor for political saga - the self-willed ''Force'' and gadgetry of Star Wars, perhaps -seems required to measure the dominant Carter campaign as exemplified by Mr. Corrado and other intense workers of the President's special delegate-watching corps.
uf814 By MARTIN TOLCHIN

Newsroom employees of Australian newspapers voted today to accept a compromise offer from publishers and end a strike in a dispute over electronic editing equipment. A spokesman for the Australian Journalists Association said that the vote was 1,781 to 556 in favor of returning to work. The vote in Sydney was narrowly in favor of remaining on strike.

A package the size of a portable radio exploded last night outside the former Iranian consulate here. No one was injured and there was no damage from the explosion, which spewed shrapnel over a 75-foot area, the police said. The consulate has been closed as a result of President Carter decision to expel Iranian diplomats from the country. Bomb squad experts were trying to move the device when it exploded in front of the building. No one has claimed responsibility for the explosion, the police said.

Leslie Burr rode the winners of the green and regular conformation hunter championships at the 51st Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show today and then commented that she had spent little time training either of the mounts. Betty McGuire's Harvard Square won the green title with 23 1/2 points, while E.C. Andrews's April Rullah captured the crown for regular conformation foxchasers with 14 1/2.
There is no time left for members of New York's City Council and Board of Estimate to inflate the hopes of constituents.

Despite a national sales gain in May of only 1.9 percent over May 1979, sales at seven of New York City's largest department stores rose by an average of 7.7 percent in the same period, a monthly spot-check has found. The city's results represent a partial recovery from two prior months of depressed consumer buying.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Carter Administration is opposing a bill rewriting the nation's irrigation laws, contending that the proposal favored by the House Interior Committee would merely "fatten the profits of large landowners."

ST. LOUIS, June 11 Clearly uneasy about changes in their lives and in the society around them, 13,000 messengers of the Southern Baptist Convention used their annual meeting here this week to reaffirm traditional Baptist ways.
COLUMBUS, Ohio The Carter Administration has clearly decided to play the "China card" vigorously.
LONDON, June 11 (UPI) Former Prime Minister Sir Harold Wilson, 64 years old, had major abdominal surgery today and was later listed in "satisfactory" condition.

WOODBOURNE, N.Y. If others are clucking over the recent National Academy of Sciences report on cholesterol, the 240,000 white leghorns at Mountain Pride Farms here don't seem to have heard. Their eggs 1.26 million of them a week just keep rolling along.
Staten Island Democrats endorsed last night one of the top-ranking Republican state senators, John J. Marchi, despite the opposition of the Senate's Democratic leader, Manfred Ohrenstein.
WHAT makes a local sportscaster worth $400,000 a year, even if he is a feisty, fast-talking fellow alliteratively named Warner Wolf?

ALBANY, June 11 It may soon cost a bit more to get married in New York City. The State Senate tonight authorized the city to increase to $5 from $3 the fee for a marriage license. The bill is expected to clear the Assembly and be signed into law by Governor Carey.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J. IT'S the world's most prestigious golf tournament. But it's never sponsored by a show-biz personality. It's never preceded by a pro-am. It's never held at a course surrounded by condominiums. And its winner never is forgotten a week later.

The First National Bank of Boston lowered its prime rate yesterday by one percentage point, to 12 percent. It thus became the first bank among the nation's top 20 to have a prime rate below 13 percent.

President Choi Kyu Hah promised today to speed up South Korea's constitutional revision process leading to elections and a transfer of power to a new government by the end of next June, but only if ''public order and social stability'' are maintained. In a nationwide radio and television address, President Choi said that Government-drafted revisions of the Constitution would be put to the voters in a national referendum by the end of October ''at the latest'' if there is no turmoil like the riots in Kwangju and nationwide student demonstrations last month. Elections would then be held during the first half of 1981 and power transferred to a new administration by the end of June, he said.

An explosion ripped through a dry-cleaning store on a quiet corner in the Fordham section of the Bronx shortly before noon yesterday, killing a 9-month-old girl whose mother was wheeling her along the sidewalk outside. A dozen other persons were injured, one of them critically, when the blast, which was believed to have been caused by gas escaping from a street main, occurred at 11:18 A.M. The explosion blew out the brick walls of the one-story building at the southwest corner of Morris Avenue and 184th Street.

The Washington Capitals acquired Mike Palmateer, a goalie, from the Toronto Maple Leafs today. The Caps gave up Robert Picard, a defenseman, and Tim Coulis, a left wing. The National Hockey League teams also swapped draft choices, with Toronto getting Washington's second-round pick in exchange for a third-round selection.

WHEN the three-month Treasury bill discount rate fell to 6.5 percent on Monday, investors holding maturing bills must have eyed the market nervously. For those who reinvest in Treasury bills falling due now and in the next few weeks will have to settle for rates of well under half the peak yields of March.

President Carter announced today that he would nominate Jack R. Borsting of Carmel, Calif., to be Assistant Secretary of Defense. Mr. Borsting, 51 years old, has been academic dean of the Naval Postgraduate School in Monterey, Calif., since 1974. If confirmed by the Senate, he would replace Fred P. Wacker, who has resigned.

AL FRIEDMAN'S family has been in the telephone answering business for three generations. As services go, the Affiliated Telephone Answering Service Inc. is one of Manhattan's larger and healthier operations. Its 200 employees operate 50 switchboards around the clock while its 5,000 or so customers provide it with revenues of several million dollars a year. But for Affiliated Telephone and thousands of smaller answering service companies across the country the bells may not be ringing much longer. Telephone company rate increases, antiquated equipment and the prospect of the telephone company itself offering an automatic call answering service could well spell the demise of the ''live'' telephone answering industry.

A Federal jury began deliberations today on a six-year-old $900 million antitrust suit brought against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by the MCI Communications Corporation. The court battle between the two companies centers on a complaint by MCI, an 11-year-old Washington-based company, that the Bell System sidestepped orders by the Federal Communications Commission to provide local connections for an MCI long-distance phone system.

The General Aviation Manufacturers Association announced yesterday that shipments of aircraft in May declined from the same month last year, reflecting the overall decline in the economy. Shipments last month totaled 877 units, down 43.1 percent from the 1,542 units shipped during May of last year, the association said. Year-to-date shipments totaled 5,382 new aircraft, compared with 7,425 units in the same period in 1979.

The National Hockey League draft, which was held here today, is a futures market. Unlike many other sports, where draft picks are supposed to make an immediate contribution, hockey players drafted - most of them age 18 or 19 - are not expected to break into the N.H.L. for several seasons. Doug Wickenheiser of the Regina Pats, who was selected by the Montreal Canadiens to open the draft, is one of the few among the 210 players selected who are given much of a chance to play immediately. Because of the uncertainty involved in drafting such young players, general managers are beginning to borrow the tactics of horse trainers. They are drafting players with good ''bloodlines'' as Bill Torrey, general manager of the Islanders, put it.

With the seas seasonally calm and political repression and economic hardship continuing in Vietnam, the number of refugees leaving in small boats is again reaching its annual peak, reports from countries around the South China Sea indicate. But unlike last year, when the normal, clandestine exodus was overshadowed by the expulsion of tens of thousands of ethnic Chinese from Vietnam, the present rate of flow suggests that the Government is abiding by its undertaking at the Geneva conference on refugees last July to limit departures.
You have to come to the conclusion that someone in the White House has decided that John Anderson's candidacy is more than a fantasy.'' - Ed Coyle, Mr. Anderson's deputy campaign manager. (B12:2.)

ONE reason why ''Giselle'' continues to fascinate audiences and dancers alike is that its leading roles can be interpreted in so many different ways. Giselle can be shy and delicate. Or she can be playfully elfin. And although all Albrechts must eventually turn melancholy, this aristocrat, at his first entrance, can be either a cad who is only trifling with Giselle or an impetuous nobleman so truly enamored of her that he is willing to ignore class distinctions.

The Carter Administration is opposing a bill rewriting the nation's irrigation laws, contending that the proposal favored by the House Interior Committee would merely ''fatten the profits of large landowners.'' In a letter to the committee, Interior Secretary Cecil D. Andrus said the Administration found the bill unacceptable. He said that it would continue to provide federally subsidized irrigation water to rich farmers who did not need the subsidy and that it would do so at the expense of the family farmer for whom the water was intended.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; A Libyan Is Slain in Milan As Qaddafi's Deadline Ends

With his relations with New York City's blacks still frayed and marked by friction, Mayor Koch has started what he calls a ''campaign'' to publicize his record on issues affecting minorities. It is the second time in less than a year that Mr. Koch has embarked on a plan to change his image among blacks and other minorities. He has said each time that the problem is primarily one of public relations, but some elected black officials say more than his image is involved.

IT sounded like the plot of an old Hollywood movie. A week before opening night, the producers of one of the most expensive and eagerly awaited musicals of the season decide they need a new leading lady. They quickly hold auditions, find a young actress, and they tell her she has five days to memorize the lines and master all the songs and dances before she goes on stage. As in most old movies, the ending is a happy one. The actress not only learns the part, but also dazzles the critics. After years of waitressing and comedic roles, she is suddenly a star. It was not an old movie, though. It was one of those wonderful and improbable stories that happen only in the theater. The play, in this case, is ''Camelot,'' the revival of the Lerner and Loewe musical starring Richard Burton, which will open on Broadway July 2, following its current tryout in Toronto. And the new star is 27-yearold Christine Ebersole, who opened there last Sunday to critical and popular acclaim as Queen Guenevere - a role she prepared, remarkably enough, in three days of rehearsal and two previews.
2D SUB WITH AUTHORS CXS By MEL GUSSOW

ANAHEIM, Calif., June 11 The Yankees, powered by two homers from Bob Watson and another hit by Reggie Jackson, took a three-run lead into the bottom of the ninth inning tonight. But the Angels rallied to tie the game at 7-7 and send it into extra innings.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that Western Airlines be awarded nonstop routes between Anchorage and London for a three-year experimental period, and recommended that Northwest Airlines be designated as backup carrier. President Carter, who has the final word on decisions involving international routes, has 60 days to review the decision.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Smoking low-tar cigarettes may reduce a person's risk of getting cancer but there is no evidence that they reduce the toll from heart and lung diseases and complications in pregnancy, experts on smoking said today.

ALBANY, June 11 As the Legislature wobbled toward recess, Governor Carey's administration presented a new plan to the Republicans tonight in an effort to break the deadlock over a tax on oil company receipts. The tax is largely intended to subsidize the huge Metropolitan Transportation Authority deficit.

JERUSALEM, June 11 Several key American civilian supervisors involved in building two new air bases for Israel have been replaced after labor disorders, an Israeli Defense Ministry spokesman said today.
Despite a drop in daily gasoline output, stocks of gasoline remained unchanged in the week ended last Friday from the previous week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
Last graf cannot be cut By JOSEPH P. FRIED

In a written opinion handed down this week, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that a reporter was protected by the state ''shield law'' from producing a letter that had been subpoenaed by defendants in a murder trial. The case is being hailed by some First Amendment lawyers as a ''stunning reversal'' of a similar case in New Jersey two years ago, when M. A. Farber, a New York Times reporter, went to jail for 40 days and The Times was fined $286,000, because Mr. Farber refused to turn over unpublished material that had been subpoenaed by a defendant in a murder trial. At that time, the New Jersey Supreme Court held that the state shield law did not apply to Mr. Farber, because, in effect, the constitutional rights of the defendant seeking the information overrode the reporter's. It added, however, that in the future a hearing would be required before any reporter could be compelled to turn over unpublished material.
COMPANY NEWS; National Semiconductor Halts Plans on New Plant

The most frightening thing about that hotly disputed study of chromosome damage at Love Canal was its finding of ''supernumerary acentric fragments'' in the cells of several residents. Just the sound of those ominous polysyllables was enough to convince many residents, who had heard much truly frightening information about the nearby chemical dump, that they faced new, grave dangers. The kind of chromosome damage at issue, the study said, normally occurs in only one of every 100 people. Finding it in eight of 36 Love Canalers was startling. Even after the study was criticized for failing to include a control group, its director, Dr. Dante Picciano, and its sponsor, the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, held to the belief that the ''supernumerary acentric chromosomes'' might warn of something terrible. True, there were skeptics. Some chromosome experts said they were unfamiliar with the term ''supernumerary acentric fragments'' and wondered what Dr. Picciano was seeing under his microscope. Their doubts were not eased when he refused to show his evidence to the first group of expert reviewers. So E.P.A. wisely created another review panel to look at photocopies of the damning research photographs. That panel is about to submit its final report. According to its organizer, Dr. Roy Albert of New York University, it found no evidence of ''supernumerary acentric fragments'' - that is, excess material - in the chromosomes of any of the eight purported victims. It did find technical and interpretive errors in the study. And it did detect some chromosomal abnormalities among Love Canalers, but within normal limits.

SURFACE WHEN the paint around the outside of a house starts to crack, peel, flake or blister after only a year or two, the owner most often blames the paint. He may vow never to use that brand again - even if it was a top quality brand with a proven reputation for durability. But in most cases, the problem is not the paint, or even how it was applied. The fault more often lies in improper preparation of the old surface before the new coat of paint is applied. The directions printed on almost every can of exterior paint stipulate that to insure a long-lasting job the old surface must be clean (free of dirt, grease, dust and chalky powder) and in relatively sound condition (the old paint should not be cracked, peeling or flaking).
UNCLE Willy left us his three-room shack in upstate New York. A sunny morning found me calling from an outdoor booth in the nearby town to have his phone service hooked up again.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) President Carter said today that he would nominate Richard C. Erwin, a state court of appeals judge, to a new Federal judgeship for the Middle District of North Carolina. Judge Erwin, 56 years old, has been an appeals judge since 1977.

In a written opinion handed down this week, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled that a reporter was protected by the state "shield law" from producing a letter that had been subpoenaed by defendants in a murder trial.

TAKE an avant-garde sculptor who creates clouds out of water molecules, place four dancers into this vaporous haze and you have one of the most striking dance pieces created by the experimental choreographer Trisha Brown.

VISITORS to the splendid new American wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which opened yesterday, have a host of surprises awaiting them. Most of the period furnishings, stored out of sight throughout the five-year construction period, are back on display. And there are dozens of other late 17th- to early 20th-century examples now on view that have never been seen before at the museum. Closed since 1975, the wing is a sprawling 150,000-square-foot space more than six times the size of the Metropolitan's original American wing, which opened in 1924. Accommodated are 18 period rooms (seven more will be opened later), 11 decorative arts galleries and nine paintings and sculpture galleries offering the most comprehensive view anywhere of American art, antiques and domestic life.

A former Wall Street dividend clerk was charged yesterday with stealing $160,000 from two Wall Street brokerage firms. David Gold, 23 years old, of New York City, was charged in State Supreme Court in Manhattan with a total of 12 counts of seconddegree grand larceny. The Manhattan district attorney's office said Mr. Gold had falsely claimed to represent holders of millions of dollars in Federal bonds in order to charge the brokerage firms for interest accrued on the bonds.
Eli Waldron, a writer of short stories, died Monday when his car went out of control and hit a tree in Culpepper, Va. He was 64 years old and lived in Woodstock, N.Y.

To the Editor: My ticket for the Picasso retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art was, by coincidence, for the afternoon of the day Michael Levin's broadside appeared in The Times denouncing MOMA for making arrangements so that the handicapped could also participate in this unique artistic event. I can only wonder if we attended the same show. did not feel any ''discomfiture'' or notice ''innumerable inconveniences'' imposed upon those of us, such as myself, who are not physically disabled. True, the museum was very crowded, and the lines, both inside and out, moved slowly, but that surely is no fault of the handicapped.

After 31 consecutive hours of fighting a rear-guard action, Senator Mark O. Hatfield suddenly surrendered tonight to the Senate majority leader, Robert C. Byrd, and cleared the way for a final vote on a draft registration bill tomorrow. In agreeing to give up his campaign to delay the vote, Mr.Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, a strong opponent of registration in peacetime, said, ''I anticipate that the vote will be against my position.''

The nation's mayors wrapped up their annual convention in time-honored fashion today by passing resolutions asking for more money from the Federal Government - more money for jobs, more for housing, more for transportation, pollution control and countless other ambitions that, given these times and this Congress and this Administration, they have no chance of fulfilling. But outside the meeting rooms, in the lobbies and restaurants, there was evidence that many members of the United States Conference of Mayors had come to the realization that the Federal Treasury is not an open spigot.

The Mobil Oil Corporation, faced with a move in the State Legislature to impose a gross-receipts tax on oil companies as a way of paying for $235 million of mass transportation aid, has begun lobbying against the proposal. More than 300 Mobil heating-oil distributors in the state received letters today from the company warning that sales in the state could be cut back if the tax was approved.

Almost a quarter of the candidates for bachelor's degrees at the City University of New York now completing their sophomore year have not passed at least one of the basic skills tests in reading, writing and mathematics, university officials said yesterday.

After the New Jersey Nets made Mike O'Koren, a 6-foot-7-inch forward from North Carolina, their top pick in Tuesday's National Basketball Association collegiate draft, O'Koren was approached for his reaction.
PRAGUE, June 11 (Reuters) The leaders of Czechoslovakia and Cyprus called today for a United Nations-sponsored conference to settle the crisis between ethnic Greeks and Turks in Cyprus.

SOME like it hot, but nobody likes it hot and humid. Enter the airconditioner. Shopping for one, though, is rather confusing, because they come in foreign denominations of British thermal units, which baffle most people even when furnished with a definition, and energy efficiency ratios, which are easy to understand but hard to compare. To see how knowledgeable and helpful air-conditioner salesmen are, two New York Times reporters made an informal survey of five appliance stores. The reporters individually presented measurements and descriptions of a hypothetical apartment that had been devised by Dr. Mary Purchase, a professor of design and evironmental analysis and former director of energy programs at Cornell University. Salesmen were asked to recommend air conditioners for the apartment's bedroom and the living room.

Despite a drop in daily gasoline output, stocks of gasoline remained unchanged in the week ended last Friday from the previous week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Analysts said that this stability in inventories reflected the continued decline in demand for gasoline, even though the summer driving season is now at hand.

A Chinese mathematician who feared he was failing in his research and would disgrace his Government electrocuted himself at his apartment, authorities said today. The body of the scholar, Dr. Mai Mingcheng, 41 years old, of Peking, who was sent to Rutgers University by the Chinese Government, was discovered by his landlord Monday, the police said.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Kennedy Sees Possibility Of His Stumping for Carter
campaign By DOUGLAS E. KNEELAND

Unless business improves, ''Bent,'' the drama starring Michael York and Jeffrey de Munn, will close Saturday night at the New Apollo Theater. The drama about homosexuals in Germany during the Hitler era, written by Martin Sherman and directed by Robert Allan Ackerman, opened last Dec. 2.

With energy issues leading the way, the stock market climbed yesterday to its highest level since late February as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average. Meanwhile, the latest installment of a seven-week upswing in stock prices continued amid moderate trading volume. Mobil Corporation, the volume leader, advanced 3 5/8 points, to 80 3/8. In the strong energy group. Mobil gained additional support from an article in Forbes magazine commenting favorably on the company's drilling prospects in the Hibernia structure off Newfoundland.

President Carter today appointed Jack H. Watson Jr., who has been handling the Cuban refugee crisis and other domestic problems, as his new chief of staff. Mr. Watson replaces Hamilton Jordan, who is taking a leave of absence from the White House to join the President's re-election campaign. The move by Mr. Jordan to the re-election operation, disclosed yesterday by campaign officials, comes at a time when some of the President's political advisers have acknowledged that they are behind in plans for the expected campaign this fall against Ronald Reagan, the probable Republican nominee, and Representative John B. Anderson, who is running as an independent.

To the Editor: Prof. Michael E. Levin's patronizing and mean-spirited letter (June 5) complains of his being inconvenienced by arrangements at the Museum of Modern Art to make the Picasso exhibit accessible to people in wheelchairs. From there he goes on to attack efforts across the country to help the disabled lead more useful and satisfying lives by removing architectural barriers to access.Perhaps it is too much to expect some measure of compassion from a professor of philosophy at City College. But is it unreasonable to expect him to exhibit common sense, at least in his public pronouncements? Does Professor Levin suppose that the only reason the museum has ambulatory visitors enter on 54th Street is to reserve the 53d Street entrance for people in wheelchairs?

ASPLIT rail fence in front of a Cape Cod cottage. A brick wall of the penthouse. A trellis over a garden gate. Add a climbing rose. The scene is complete, a tradition that will endure. Actually, climbing rose is a non sequitur, for the plants do not climb. Their ancestors are the vigorous ''creeping'' species and the roses do not have tendrils to hook on, as sweet peas and morning glories do. Rather, climbing roses have long arching branches that need guidance and tying down to prevent them from tangling under their own weight.

The Civil Aeronautics Board recommended today that Western Airlines be awarded nonstop routes between Anchorage and London for a three-year experimental period, and recommended that Northwest Airlines be designated as backup carrier. President Carter, who has the final word on decisions involving international routes, has 60 days to review the decision.

The Labor Department is pressing for an expansion of Federal jobs programs to counter the rapidly rising rate of unemployment, but its proposals are being rebuffed, at least for the moment, by the White House and economic policy makers in the Carter Administration, Government sources said today. The Government officials said that the differences within the Administration over jobs programs involved questions of timing and political perception as much as substance.

VERY early in Rainer Werner Fassbinder's "In a Year of 13 Moons," Christoph prepares to leave his hysterically weeping mistress, Elvira. As Christoph gathers his things, Elvira follows him around ...
TEL AVIV, June 11 Top Israeli scientists and economists have told the Government the time has come to channel Mediterranean Sea water across the country to the Dead Sea to produce energy.
Sugar prices regained their upward momentum yesterday, advancing to the daily trading limits in most months because of renewed speculative buying on commission house recommendations.

TOKYO, Thursday, June 12 Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira died after suffering a heart attack early today, leaving Japan and the governing Liberal Democratic Party leaderless 10 days before Parliamentary elections. Mr. Ohira, who had headed the Government since December 1978, was 70 years old.

WASHINGTON, June 11 An American scholar with three decades of experience in Afghanistan predicted today that the Soviet military intervention in that country would confront the world with a refugee problem comparable to that of the Palestinian Arabs.

TEHERAN, 1960. It had been a difficult day for me, the first of many to come. The young relatives, in a show of respect, had first come to my house to visit. The children were hardest and most unforgiving. How could I not know the most elementary rules of politeness, rules that were clear to any 4- or 5-year-old?

ESSEN, West Germany, June 11 Fried. Krupp, the parent company of West Germany's steelmaking giant, announced today that it had moved back into the black last year, following four years of either losses or minimal earnings, and said it was now looking for acquisitions to round out its steelmaking and manufacturing program.

The leaders of Western Europe assemble tomorrow in this shimmering city of canals and palazzos to search for ways of arresting what many of them see as a slide toward world crisis. They are expected to issue a statement calling for the inclusion of the Palestine Liberation Organization in future negotiations on a Middle East peace settlement, in addition to discussing a wide range of other political and economic problems. The United States and Israel oppose a declaration on the Middle East, but the Europeans believe it is necessary if progress toward a broad settlement is to be resumed.

A major legal controversy over how the Government has treated thousands of Haitian refugees, which could affect whether they remain in this country or are sent home, is drawing to a close in a Federal courtroom here. Lawyers for the Haitians contend that there is a pattern of harassment and discrimination. But the Government says that this is not the case and that it has merely attempted to carry out the law. At the trial, which began last year, lawyers representing the Haitians produced what they said was evidence of ''a continuing pattern of illegal and discriminatory conduct'' by the Immigration and Naturalization Service in its efforts to deport Haitians back to their Caribbean home.

Dayton Power and Light plans to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission 2.5 million common shares and 300,000 shares of preferred. * Kingdom of Sweden announced a public offering of $150 million of 10 5/8 percent notes due 1990 and $100 million of 11 3/8 percent bonds due 2000, to be offered through a group headed by Salomon Brothers.

Fulton The New York Times/Edward Hausner Decks Are for Dancing on Cruise for Elderly Bertha Friendlich, 72, and Sam Shearer, 88, dancing yesterday on the upper deck of the hospital ship Fulton. People from various centers for the elderly throughout the city were treated to a cruise of New York's waterways.

Oil price increases by September were hinted at by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, despite earlier pledges to hold the line. A Saudi official suggested the increase might be one or two dollars a barrel over the present $28 price. Meanwhile, Kuwait, Venezuela, Qatar and Iraq increased their prices $2 a barrel starting next month. (Page A1.) Alaska's plan to use its oil royalties to spur industrial development is poised to move forward after a series of delays during a twoyear period. At the heart of the plan is an oil refinery that is expected to have a capacity of a 100,000 barrels a day, but which has been snagged by legal and financial knots. (D1.)

WHAT makes a local sportscaster worth $400,000 a year, even if he is a feisty, fast-talking fellow alliteratively named Warner Wolf? The answer requires a bit of background first. On Tuesday night, the 42-year-old Mr. Wolf switched from WABC-TV to WCBS-TV, making his debut on WCBS's 11 P.M. news program. WABC had sued to prevent its popular sportscaster from jumping ship, but late Tuesday, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court lifted an injunction, and Mr. Wolf became free to join WCBS a day earlier than he had anticipated. To answer why the two stations have been competing so hard to pay Mr. Wolf so much - he had been earning $250,000 under his previous contract -let's go first to television's bottom line, the audiencepopularity ratings.

A hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee was abruptly adjourned today after Justice Department officials persisted in their refusal to turn over investigative files on 15 criminal cases involving allegations of political corruption. There has been broad support among Republicans and Democrats on the panel for issuing a subpoena, if necessary, to obtain the records. Senator Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona, who presided at the hearing, said that he and Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah, would do so if the Justice Department did not agree to cooperate by 5 P.M. Friday.

PURELY utilitarian electrical outlet strips, appropriate for a kitchen or a workshop, have been available for a long time. Now two brightly colored contemporary versions, appropriate for any modern setting, have found their way into stores. On both models, the outlet box, which has traditionally been recessed into the wall, has been designed to hang right on the wall. Installation simply requires putting screws in the wall.

Barnwell Industries of Fairlawn, N.J., has formed a limited partnership to raise money for a geothermal drilling venture in Hawaii. Although funds of this type are commonly used to finance oil exploration, this is apparently the first time a drilling fund has been formed to explore for geothermal deposits. The company, which has interests in oil, gas and coal operations in the United States and Canada, said it had already started drilling the first of a series of exploration wells on the island of Hawaii, near the site of a successful experimental well completed by the University of Hawaii. The well will be drilled to a depth of between 6,000 and 7,000 feet, the company said.

THEY'RE not new, but fans are definitely staging a comeback. Last year the status cooling device was a ceiling fan. This season, it's the small personal fan. Energy-conscious consumers have heightened demand for these relatively thrifty appliances, for use in summer rooms and in offices where air-conditioning has been turned down. They have no effect on humidity, of course. But these diminutive fans, electric or battery-operated, will move air in a limited area, cooling tempers if not the whole room.
The Farmers Home Administration confirmed plans today to reduce the interest rate for most of its single-family home loans to 11.5 percent from 13 percent, beginning Saturday.

The Western Electric Company announced today that it was laying off about 300 production employees at its Allentown Works. A spokesman for the company, which is the manufacturing arm of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said that ''an adjustment of inventories and a softening of demand for electrical products and telephone equipment'' had forced the cutback. The company said the Allentown Works, which produces integrated circuits, transistors and other electronic components, would operate with 3,300 production workers and a total of 5,000 employees in all departments.

The Brotherhood of Railroad Carmen voted 134 to 3 last night to strike the Port Authority Trans-Hudson Railroad at 12:01 A.M. today. The union members rejected a final contract offer from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
CHARLOTTE, N.C. In the last year, parents in several hundred communities across America have organized to combat the use of marijuana by their children.

"IT'S a romantic story, I guess you'd say," said Dr. John C. Pollack, director of a national study on the elderly that was released yesterday. Marriage, by itself, added little or nothing to the respondents' perception of well-being, the study found, but a marriage that joined equally healthy partners substantially improved the respondents' outlook.
SEOUL, South Korea, June 7 A flat white field of many crosses in the ground and beside it a man kneeling, his head bowed to the ground in prayer.
WASHINGTON, June 11 There is a man who likes to work barefoot in the Carter campaign's omniscient watch over its convention delegates. This man, Tony Corrado, reads Goethe to ...

BONN, June 11 (UPI) Gunther van Well, state secretary in the West German Foreign Ministry, flew to Moscow today to prepare for Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's visit to the Soviet capital at the end of this month.

Despite a national sales gain in May of only 1.9 percent over May 1979, sales at seven of New York City's largest department stores rose by an average of 7.7 percent in the same period, a monthly spotcheck has found. The city's results represent a partial recovery from two prior months of depressed consumer buying. With their suburban branches, the city stores had an average sales gain of 7.4 percent in the four weeks ended Saturday, May 3l, the check found.
