A Saudi official suggested the increase might be one or two dollars a barrel over the present $28 price. Meanwhile, Kuwait, Venezuela, Qatar and Iraq increased their prices $2 a barrel starting next month. (Page A1.) Alaska's plan to use its oil royalties to spur industrial development is poised to move forward after a series of delays during a twoyear period. At the heart of the plan is an oil refinery that is expected to have a capacity of a 100,000 barrels a day, but which has been snagged by legal and financial knots. (D1.)
WARSAW, June 12 (AP) Two dissident writers and two printers went on trial here today charged with misappropriating an old Government mimeograph machine destined for the scrap heap.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., June 12 Vernon E. Jordan Jr., who was critically wounded by sniper fire here two weeks ago, was transferred today to New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York City. Meanwhile, the authorities here acknowledged that they were making little headway in finding the civil rights leader's assailant.

American Ballet Theater will honor Michel Fokine, one of the most influential figures in 20th-century ballet, with an all-Fokine program tonight at 8 in the Metropolitan Opera House. The celebration continues unofficially ...

IN the book that serves as a catalogue for the current Claes Oldenburg exhibitions at the two Castelli galleries in SoHo 142 Greene Street and 420 West Broadway (through tomorrow) there is a large, ...
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., June 10 Marguerite Perret thinks Representative John B. Anderson "doesn't stand a chance" of being elected President. But she intends to vote for him in November anyway.

Georgiana Harding Farr Sibley, a national church leader and a champion of civil rights, died of a stroke Tuesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 93 years old and lived with a daughter, Jane Auchincloss of Millbrook, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The push by Ronald Reagan's key strategists to replace Bill Brock as the Republican Party's national chairman has touched off mushrooming opposition and posed a test of Mr. Reagan's leadership on the eve of a Republican unity dinner in Los Angeles tomorrow night.

Three of the nation's largest banks, the Bank of America, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, cut their prime rates to 12 percent from 13 percent yesterday, reaching the level of last fall before the prime began surging.

VANCOUVER, Wash., June 12 (AP) Mount St. Helens in the third major eruption in a month, blew steam and ash more than nine miles high tonight and prompted the evacuation of some people in the area, officials said.

The Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant has been shut down to fix a leak of highly radioactive water inside the facility, plant officials said today. The shutdown yesterday was to allow technicians to fix a faulty valve that has been leaking one to two gallons of highly radioactive water a minute in the plant's containment area for nearly two weeks, the officials said. A spokesman, Steve Stoll, said none of the radioactive water had leaked out of the containment area.

Guillermo Vilas, the Argentine tennis star, will be operated on at the American Hospital tomorrow for appendicitis, his coach, Ion Tiriac, said today. The operation has forced Vilas to withdraw from Wimbledon later this month. He was bothered by stomach cramps during the recent French open, where he was eliminated in the quarterfinals by Harold Solomon of the United States.

Three of the nation's largest banks, the Bank of America, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, cut their prime rates to 12 1/2 percent from 13 percent yesterday, reaching the level of last fall before the prime began surging. Between November 1978 and September 1979, the prime rate fluctuated in a range of 11 1/2 to 12 1/4 percent before it began to climb, peaking at 20 percent last April 20.

At 7:10 this morning, Bronwin Russell took off down Baltusrol's first fairway carrying her husband's bag and clubs and becoming the first female caddie to work a United States Open men's championship. She was married to Arthur Russell, a professional golfer from Texas, last June 25 and has been caddying for him ever since. Three hours later, Pam Shuttleworth became the second female caddie in the 80-year history of the event when she stepped out carrying Jim Dent's clubs.

The Ford Motor Company , which is retrenching its operations in the United States, announced today that it would expand in Mexico by building a $365 million plant there to produce four-cylinder engines. Four-cylinder engines are expected to be the standard engine in most American automobiles this decade, compared with six- and eightcylinder engines in past decades.

In October 1977, President Carter stood amid South Bronx rubble and made a stirring commitment to use Federal agencies and money to revitalize this and similar areas of urban blight. Today, our inner cities are worse off.In the South Bronx, additional unprofitable buildings have been abandoned by landlords and more families have left. Despite millions of dollars in aid, the district is still declining. The South Bronx, where more than 20 percent of the population, mostly skilled middle-income residents, has moved out in the last 10 years, is a dramatic example of how orthodox urban policies have failed. Government action has actually aggravated the situation. Rent control has destroyed the private rental market, urban renewal has replaced old brick slums with new concrete slums, and costly Government programs aimed at attracting business have proved ineffective. While most ''experts'' continue to believe that pouring tax money into cities is the way to stop decay, on both sides of the Atlantic some new ideas have been taking hold.In the 1960's, writers such as Jane Jacobs, author of ''The Death and Life of Great American Cities,'' began to question conventional dogma. Urban-renewal planners, she argued, had failed to understand the crucial features of a successful city environment: the importance of old buildings, small businesses, mixed uses, individualism.

By a vote of 3 to 1, 13,000 delegates to the annual convention of the Southern Baptist Convention voted here today to ''exhort'' the trustees of their six seminaries in the United States '' to preserve the doctrinal integrity of the seminaries and other institutions'' by not employing or continuing to employ liberal members of faculty and professional staffs. The resolution, passed by a show of hands by the delegates, or messengers, said that only those teachers were acceptable ''who believe in the divine inspiration of the whole Bible, the infallibility of the original manuscripts and that the Bible is truth without any error.''

Benjamin V. Lambert, who with a group of his associates just agreed in principle to purchase Eastdil Realty Inc. from Paine Webber Inc. for an undisclosed amount, says he is eager to get back into business for himself. In fact, Eastdil, a real estate investment banking business at which Mr. Lambert serves as president and chief executive officer, has long been identified in the minds of many on Wall Street as synonymous with Mr. Lambert. ''You don't create one of these kinds of companies in the first instance unless you have a desire to be on your own,'' Mr. Lambert said. ''And there were some overlappings with Paine Webber's real estate that really prompted the sale.''

of Lynn Wyatt, Betsy Bloomingdale and the Prince de Lucinge By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON VERSAILLES, France - Not since the kings of France lived in the Chateau de Versailles has this sumptuous palace seen anything quite like it. Last Tuesday night, 1,038 formally dressed members of international society came to toast Florence Van Der Kemp, the American wife of the outgoing curator of the chateau, for receiving the Legion of Honor. And while there, they also gawked at the palace's newly restored rooms, which many of them had helped finance.

The Getty Oil Corporation will purchase the UNC Plateau Mining Company, a coal operation in Utah, from UNC Resources Inc., the companies announced yesterday. They said the transaction would cost Getty, which has been on something of an acquisition binge lately, about $60 million in cash. Getty's minerals division is already developing coal reserves in Utah and Texas, but at the moment the company does not produce any coal. Plateau owns and operates an underground coal mine about 100 miles southeast of Salt Lake City that produces about 850,000 tons of low-sulfur coal a year. All told, the company has an estimated 60 million tons of coal in place on some 5,200 acres of fee land and state and Federal leases in Utah.
Saburo Okita By HENRY SCOTT STOKES

A military judge today denied a series of defense motions seeking to block the court-martial of Pfc. Robert R. Garwood of the Marine Corps on charges of desertion and collaboration with the enemy in Vietnam. At a pretrial hearing Col. R.E. Switzer ruled that Camp Lejeune's commander, Maj. Gen. David B. Barker, acted within his authority in ordering the case to trial.

Gloria Vanderbilt's battle with River House ended yesterday. She dropped her suit against the board of directors of the exclusive East Side apartment building and agreed to withdraw the complaint of racial discrimination she had filed against it. The board had rejected her attempt to buy an apartment, and Miss Vanderbilt accused it of racial bias because of her friendship with Bobby Short, the black entertainer. The discontinuance of the suit also ends an injunction the heiress and jeans designer had obtained barring the sale of the $1.1 million apartment to anyone but her.
Estimate staff By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The United Automobile Workers union petitioned the Government today to raise tariffs and impose quotas on automotive imports, seeking at least a 20 percent reduction in foreign sales to give the domestic industry a chance to revamp to meet new market demands.

SISOPHON DISTRICT, Cambodia, June 12 The trails leading through the forest to the Thai border are thick with people heading for Nong Chan, where Western relief organizations distribute rice and rice seed to be carried back into the interior.

A 20-year-old Russian Jew, who came to the United States with his parents five years ago from the Ukrainian city of Chernovtsy, was one of 770 graduates from Yeshiva University at its 49th commencement yesterday in Manhattan.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 12 Willie Randolph did not reach base today. That was because the Yankees had the day off before beginning a four-game series against Billy Martin and the Oakland A's with a doubleheader tomorrow night.
Who would have thought that the insignia of a penguin, a rooster, a fox or an alligator could transport a simple cotton shirt from the confines of a sports arena onto the chests of middle America?

Nancy Drukker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Essex Drukker, was married at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club yesterday to Jonathan W. Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Morse. Both families are from Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony.
A 42-year-old teacher at a Bronx public school was arrested on charges that he had sexually abused four girls in his class. One of the girls is 11, another is 12 and the two others are 13.

DANVERS, Mass., June 12 (AP) Dale Lundquist, who has not finished higher than 18th place in any tournament this year, equaled the best round of her career with a four-under-par 68 today to take the opening-round lead in a $150,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament.
Minister Margaret Thatcher/photo of heads of government at meeting By R.W. APPLE Jr.

MILWAUKEE The Presidential candidate who gives the following speech, or a reasonable facsimile of it, will almost certainly not be elected. But he may take some solace in the knowledge that he will be assured of one vote. Though you have been solemnly advised otherwise, the Presidential election of 1980 is not a critical event in the nation's history. The preservation of civilization is not at stake. The future of the free world does not hang precariously in the balance.

The marriage of Patricia Ann Shea, an associate with the New York law firm of Wilson, Elser, Edelman & Dicker, to Robert Kevin Ryan, a foreign-exchange adviser with the Irving Trust Company, took place at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour last evening. Msgr. William J. Kenealy, pastor of St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Church in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., performed the ceremony. He was assisted by Msgr. Raymond Rigney, the Rev. John Barrett and the Rev. Carl Quinn. A reception was held at the St. Regis-Sheraton.
1981 By MARTIN TOLCHIN

To the Editor: The recent murder in Teheran of the 24-year-old son of Iran's exiled Anglican Bishop is the latest outrage in a two-year campaign of intimidation against Iran's Christian, Jewish and Zoroastrian communities.

The Joint Legislative Committee on Ethical Standards voted today to halt its investigation into allegations that the Democratic state chairman, Richard J. Coffee, had been offered a $50,000 bribe during the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam investigation and failed to report it to the State Attorney General. The committee's action came after questions were raised as to whether it had authority to conduct the inquiry. Mr. Coffee, who also serves as executive director of the Assembly Democratic majority, had been subpoenaed by the committee to testify this morning about the alleged incident, which is said to have occurred in June 1979, at a time when the Legislature was operating without a legislative code of ethics. He did not testify today, but the committee let stand the subpoena to insure a possible future appearance.

Management Assistance Inc. announced yesterday that it was abandoning its troubled Wordstream subsidiary and instead would concentrate its word-processing activities in its small-business computer operation. The company, which is based in New York City, said that it would continue to offer its DataWord II combined data-and word-processing software systems for use with its Basic Four computers.

It's a Perry Mason courtroom trick. The defendant on trial for cocaine smuggling takes the witness stand and denies the crime. On cross-examination the prosecutor produces a telltale piece of clothing that until now he would have been forbidden to bring before a jury. That's because the clothing was illegally seized during a warrantless search of the defendant's luggage. At least since 1914, the Supreme Court has said the Government may not prove the defendant's guilt with illegally seized evidence. But now the prosecutor says he wants to use that evidence not to prove guilt but only to attack the defendant's credibility as a witness. Objection, says the defense attorney. Objection overruled, says the Supreme Court. The evidence will be admitted for this ''limited'' purpose.

Buttressed by a squadron of teachers and students to fend off members of the press, Tina Bahadori - the Iranian student who withdrew from delivering a commencement address after some faculty members questioned her selection - graduated from Atlantic City High School today with her 544 classmates. Miss Bahadori, who had won a competition among nine of the school's top students to deliver a commencement address, rushed into a locker area 45 minutes before the graduation and hid there until the students filed onto Bader Field, where the ceremony was held.

Gambling stocks, market laggards so far in 1980, sprang back to life yesterday to share honors with precious-metal issues as Wall Street's best performers. Elsewhere, prices generally drifted lower and energy issues, in particular, were dotted with losses, in contrast to Wednesday's display of strength.

As an encore to Wednesday night's winning grand slam in the l0th inning, the Mets spotted the Los Angeles Dodgers five runs last night before rallying to win, 6-5, and sweep their series. The Dodgers were so confounded after wrestling with three evenings of the Mets' mystique that their manager, Tom Lasorda, said, ''We played a terrible game, we gave it away.'' They helped give it away last night with three costly errors.

The Bolivian armed forces, while expressing outrage at State Department charges that they were contemplating aborting national elections scheduled here for the end of this month, are giving every sign that they hope to do just that. In recent days they have put major garrisons on alert and made a series of arbitrary demands, insisting among other things on the expulsion of the American Ambassador within 72 hours as persona non grata.

The Japanese Cabinet met tonight in its first formal session since the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira early in the day, and prominent members of the governing party called on its quarreling factions to close ranks to win the parliamentary elections on June 22. Among those appealing for unity was Acting Prime Minister Masayoshi Ito, who, as chief Cabinet secretary, is Mr. Ohira's successor under the Constitution until the elections are held. He told political leaders that to the end, Mr. Ohira had wanted his Liberal Democratic Party to unite to fight an election in which, under heavy pressure, it would be defending narrow majorities in both houses of Parliament.

The House gave President Carter his first major civil rights victory today by passing a bill designed to strengthen Federal efforts to end housing discrimination. Later in the day, both the House and the Senate gave final approval to a budget resolution for the fiscal years 1980 and 1981. (Page D14.)

TRENTON, June 12 (UPI) The Senate Transportation Committee today unanimously adopted and sent to the Assembly a resolution asking Governor Byrne to veto the minutes of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which would prevent any new fare increases on its Hudson River crossings.
RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif., June 12 (UPI) Former President Ford had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee today for a flareup of an old football injury.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) The Transportation Department ruled today that, after July 23, all trucks equipped with air brakes must be manufactured with brakes that act on each wheel.

Elizabeth Tysen, daughter of Mrs. John C. Tysen of New York and the late Mr. Tysen, was married yesterday to Sven-Olaf Lindblad, son of Lars-Eric Lindblad of Wilton, Conn., and Sonja Lindblad of New York. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother.

ROME, June 12 (Reuters) The Italian Parliament decided today to begin an impeachment investigation against Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga over an allegation that he helped a suspected urban guerrilla flee the country.

TEHERAN, June 12 (Reuters) Ali Akbar Moinfar, the Iranian Oil Minister, said today in Teheran that oil revenue in the year ending March, 1981, was expected to be $10 billion compared to an original forecast of $25 billion.

PERSONALLY, I liked the quitters. Among the 10 or so members of a playground hockey team who spent a bit of their time whipping around backwards on roller skates and the rest of it leaning against dirty brick walls in "Practice," at the Perry Street Playhouse, there are at least two who want to wash ...

DARIEN, Conn., June 12 When the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic squad was named, the horse most conspicuous by his absence was F. Eugene Dixon's Jet Run.
As an encore to Wednesday night's winning grand slam in the 10th inning, the Mets spotted the Los Angeles Dodgers five runs last night before rallying to win, 6-5, and sweep their series.

The Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives and three other men were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on fraud, conspiracy and racketeering charges that grew out of an undercover inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. The six-count indictment, returned in Federal District Court in Houston and announced here by the Justice Department, named Billy Wayne Clayton, the Speaker of the Texas House; L.G. Moore, a labor union official in Houston; and two Austin lawyers, Donald W. Ray and Randall B. Wood.
Anderson, James L. Emery, Manfred Ohrenstein and Stanley Fink By ROBIN HERMAN

To the Editor: The restive Cuban refugees at Fort Chaffee, Arkansas, must learn that red tape in America takes a long time to cut. All things considered, the Administration is processing the refugees more efficiently than it is relocating our Americans living at Love Canal. RICHARD KLENER Briarwood, N.Y., June 5, 1980

Dorothy Tager, a former psychiatric social worker in various New York hospitals, died Tuesday at Memorial Hospital. Mrs. Tager, who lived in Manhattan, was 50 years old. She is survived by her husband, Sidney; two sons, Joshua and Seth; two daughters, Nina and Alexandra; her mother, Phoebe Fine of Boston, and a sister, Barbara Bernstein of Rockville Centre, L.I.

The United Automobile Workers union petitioned the Government today to raise tariffs and impose quotas on automotive imports, seeking at least a 20 percent reduction in foreign sales to give the domestic industry a chance to revamp to meet new market demands.

Willie Randolph did not reach base today. That was because the Yankees had the day off before beginning a four-game series against Billy Martin and the Oakland A's with a doubleheader tomorrow night. It is also about the only way the Yankee leadoff batter has been stopped during the nine games of the Western trip. Randolph, the second baseman, is first in the American League in onbase percentage, with a .450 average. He also leads in walks, with 46, and his .320 batting average is tops among the Yankee regulars. He leads the club in runs, hits, stolen bases and triples.

Representative Jim Leach of Iowa has dreamed up the spectacular scenario that John Anderson's independent Presidential campaign might finally result in the election of Gerald Ford as President of the United States next Dec. 15. Wild? Not so wild - not half as wild, for example, as some of the things that could happen if Congress had to choose a President and a Vice President because no one received a majority of the electoral votes. The Ford scenario may also make more sense than the idea that Mr. Anderson's campaign will result in the House having to elect a President.
WASHINGTON, June 12--The House gave President Carter his first major civil rights victory today by passing a bill designed to strengthen Federal efforts to end housing discrimination.

About 10 times a year, in a courtroom at 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, taxpaying Davids without lawyers confront Internal Revenue Service Goliaths, challenging I.R.S. rulings that the taxpayers owe the Federal Government more money.

The 60-year-old operator of a woodcraft business was charged yesterday with bilking some of the city's bestknown department stares of at least $30,000 by shipping them goods they had not ordered, then submitting exorbitant bills.

PARIS, June 12 (AP) Guillermo Vilas, the Argentine tennis star, will be operated on at the American Hospital tomorrow for appendicitis, his coach, Ion Tiriac, said today.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) Seismic signals indicated an underground Soviet nuclear explosion late yesterday at a test site in Siberia, Department of Energy officials reported today.

THE story began two decades ago and appealed to investors seeking a tax shelter with romantic overtones. Who could resist owning an orange grove, an asset that would grow in value as new trees bore fruit and increased in yield?

New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that an employer has a responsibility to accommodate employees who celebrate their Sabbath on Saturday, even if it means paying overtime to others to work in their place.

PLYMOUTH, England, June 12 (AP) Philip Weld of the United States grabbed the lead today in the singlehanded yacht race that started here and ends at Newport, R.I.

A Fourth of July parade up Broadway and another off Manhattan the following day with pleasure boats led by Argentina's tall ship and a Navy destroyer will highlight the city's Harbor Festival 1980 over the Independence Day weekend.

Sixto Lezcano drove in three runs, two with a double in Milwaukee's four-run eighth inning, to help the Brewers gain an 8-1 victory today over the Texas Rangers. Mike Caldwell (6-2) scatterd seven hits for the Brewers, who have won 14 of their last 19 games. The Rangers have lost seven of their last eight.

Following are the new taxes in the city budget and the anticipated revenue they will produce: Water and Sewer Charges: $39 million, raising charges for most single-family homes to less than $2 a month. Excise Tax on Beer and Liquor: $35 million, raising the retail price of a quart of liquor by 25 cents, a six-pack of beer by 7 cents. Parking Garage Tax: $11 million, affecting Manhattan only, which could increase the garage sales tax from 6 percent to up to 8 percent.

Cavenham Development Inc., one of many companies controlled by Sir James Goldsmith, disclosed yesterday in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the British-French businessman and two associates had been named board members of the Diamond International Corporation, a forest-products company. Diamond shares, responding to the formal truce between the two feuding companies, jumped $3 a share, to $42.50, in New York Stock Exchange consolidated trading, on a volume of 1,417,500 shares. Nearly 1.3 million shares changed hands late in the day on the Pacific Stock Exchange, making Diamond the most active issue on the consolidated tape.
JUMP 3 1/2 POINTS By JOHN H. ALLAN

Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf, friends and rivals since their student days at Ohio State, took over the 80th United States Open today with record-tying 63's that gave them a three-stroke lead in the first round. For each it was the best score he had ever shot in a major golf tournament. They matched the final-round score Johnny Miller shot in winning the 1973 Open at Oakmont, on the outskirts of Pittsburgh.

Calling the Nassau Country Club layout ''the best-conditioned course I've played this year,'' George Zahringer 3d of Sands Point won the medal with a two-over-par 72 in the Long Island Golf Association's 56th amateur championship today.
AFTER he fulfills an obligation to Columbia Pictures to direct and perform in two films, Sidney Poitier was saying, he will no longer try to combine the two functions.
IN his work as playwright and director with the Mabou Mines experimental theater company, Lee Breuer adapts his imagination to suit his surroundings and then reinvents his surroundings.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The United States has indefinitely postponed sending a high-level economic delegation to South Korea and has put all aspects of relations except a basic security commitment under active review as a sign of displeasure with the new military-dominated leadership, high-ranking Carter Administration officials said today.

THE auctions that the city's major houses offer each June usually try to tempt collectors whose enthusiasm exceeds their financial resources. This month's sales seem to be wooing collectors with a taste for posters from the turn of the ...
TORONTO, June 12 Thomson Newspapers Ltd. said today that it would exercise its option and buy onethird of the Montreal Gazette for $13 million (Canadian).

The Chrysler Corporation's financial rescue plan, carefully crafted by Congress over several months, has run into strong opposition from a small group of banks. Many of these are European banks, but a few American institutions are also resisting the plan.

TOKYO, June 12 The key political question here is whether the factions within the Liberal Democratic Party will use the death of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira to unite around a single new leader or whether they will continue to ...

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) President Carter announced today that he would nominate a career Foreign Service officer, William J. Dyess, to replace Hodding Carter 3d in one of his roles, supervising the State Department's publicrelations effort. Mr. Dyess, 50 years old and a native of Troy, Ala., will have the title of Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

Those who prefer to see international politics as a morality play must be puzzled by the conflicting reports from the OPEC meeting in Algiers. Who won the latest power struggle inside the oil cartel the "good guys" led by Saudi Arabia, allegedly arguing for price moderation, or the loose coalition of radical Arab "bad guys" who want to sock it to the West?

Smack in the center of Staten Island, on land sloping upward from a shopping mall on Richmond Avenue to the vast stretches of LaTourette Park, one of the largest bursts of new housing construction in the state has been under way for four years.

Gulf and Western Industries, the diversified conglomerate with holdings that include Paramount Pictures, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended April 30 swelled 17.7 percent, while sales advanced 5.8 percent.

Philip Weld of the United States grabbed the lead today in the singlehanded yacht race that started here and ends at Newport, R.I. On the sixth day of the race, the organizers said that Weld, of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., had 1,800 miles to go in the 3,000-mile trans-Atlantic race. The retired newspaper publisher is sailing a 51-foot trimaran named Moxie.

Judge James V. Barbuto spent two hours on the stand in Summit County Common Pleas Court today, denying that he ever offered judicial leniency and other favors in exchange for sexual relations from women. The 58-year-old probate court judge is accused of 12 sex-related charges. Five other charges were dropped today. Seven women have testified that they had sexual relations with Mr. Barbuto after the judge offered them special favors and judicial leniency.

The United States Supreme Court yesterday turned down a request that it suspend a New Jersey murder and racketeering trial until it can consider a constitutional challenge to the New Jersey shield law. Although the trial will proceed, the defendants are still entitled to file their formal appeal from this week's ruling by the New Jersey Supreme Court that the state's shield law protects a reporter, Robin Goldstein of The Daily Register of Shrewsbury, from having to turn over to the defense an unpublished letter from the state's key witness.

In the second such move in two weeks, the Federal Reserve today lowered the rate it charges banks for loans by a full percentage point, to 11 percent. The action appeared to signal, more than the similar move on May 28, an attempt by the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates by reducing the cost of money to banks.

WARSAW, June 12 A secret report prepared by more than a hundred journalists, scholars and intellectuals, many of them from the governing Communist establishment, portrays a deep crisis in Polish national life.
WASHINGTON, June 12 The Senate today passed a peacetime draft registration bill under which four million young men are expected to be required to sign up at post offices in late July.

TERRI KLAUSNER, who plays the title role in "Evita" at Wednesday and Saturday matinees, is spending her Monday nights at the Grand Finale, 210 West 70th Street, where she is making her New York nightclub debut with an act in which both conception and realization come together in a dazzling performance.

The marriage of Patricia Ann Shea, an associate with the New York law firm of Wilson, Elser, Edelman Dicker, to Robert Kevin Ryan, a foreign-exchange adviser with the Irving Trust Company, took place at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Saviour last evening.

GENEVA, June 12 The World Council of Churches said today that it had received "gruesome stories" of indiscriminate killing, rape and torture by South Korean troops during the student uprising in the provincial capital of Kwangju last month.

The Avenue of the Americas will kick up its heels Sunday with a festival appropriate to its name. For this First Annual Festival of the Americas the thoroughfare everyone calls Sixth Avenue will be closed to vehicular traffic and open to strollers and munchers ...
SEATTLE, June 12 (AP) Betty Morris of Stockton, Calif., last night took the Women's International Bowling Congress singles title for the second year in a row.

It's a Perry Mason courtroom trick. The defendant on trial for cocaine smuggling takes the witness stand and denies the crime. On cross-examination the prosecutor produces a telltale piece of clothing that until now he would have been forbidden to bring before a jury.
Gambling stocks, market laggards so far in 1980, sprang back to life yesterday to share honors with preciousmetal issues as Wall Street's best performers.

Martha Wright's singing career has been so interwoven with her relationship with Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II that it was inevitable she should be part of a salute to the musicals they produced.

GEORGE BALANCHINE's "Kammermusik No. 2" can be a compelling and surprising ballet. Presented for the first time this season on the New York City Ballet's Wednesday night program at the New York State Theater, this work to Hindemith retained its fascination.

Elizabeth Tysen, daughter of Mrs. John C. Tysen of New York and the late Mr. Tysen, was married yesterday to Sven-Olaf Lindblad, son of Lars-Eric Lindblad of Wilton, Conn., and Sonja Lindblad of New York. Civil Court Judge Charles S. Whitman Jr. performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother. The bride is studying for a doctorate in social anthropology at Columbia University, where she received bachelor's and master's degrees and where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. Her previous marriage ended in divorce. Her father was chairman of Previews Inc., a real-estate business in Greenwich, Conn.

The White House's wage and price monitors reported today that the economy's basic rate of inflation ''appears to have risen'' to 10 percent a year or a shade less and is unlikely to come down rapidly. The report by the Council on Wage and Price Stability was the highest official estimate so far of the underlying rate of inflation, stripped of the 1979-80 surges of energy prices and home-loan interest costs, which have been abating.

The Union Oil Company of California will announce soon the first phase of an oil shale complex in western Colorado that could produce 50,000 barrels of shale oil a day before the end of the 1980's, the company's chairman and president, Fred L. Hartley, told a meeting of security analysts in New York yesterday. The total investment for the complex will be $1.5 billion, he said.

In the opening skirmish today over the shape of the Democratic Party platform, President Carter advocated meeting the nation's problems with ''realistic, achievable solutions within our means,'' while Senator Edward M. Kennedy offered the view that recognition of ''the limits of government is no excuse for inaction.'' The candidates' presentations to the Democratic Platform Committee captured the similarities and the differences of the positions they have taken throughout their campaigns for the Presidential nomination.

Applying basic mathematics and political muscle, leaders of the Democratic Party put four candidates for the party's nomination for United States Senator from New York on the primary election ballot today. Delegates to the State Convention talked all afternoon in the recital hall of the Empire State Plaza to achieve what the leaders had decided to do at breakfast in the Fort Orange Club.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 12 Click. The movie projector lights up the screen in the darkened room and Jet players in the film dance backward and forward as Coach Bob Ledbetter presses an on-off switch.

RICHMOND, June 12 (AP) A Federal appeals court today upheld a National Labor Relations Board finding that J.P. Stevens Company was guilty of unfair labor practices at its seven plants in Roanoke Rapids, N.C.

The Columbus Boychoir has changed its name to the American Boychoir, and a drive has been started to raise a $7.5 million endowment to develop its school as a national institution. Announcement of the project was made at a dinner this week in Princeton, N.J., where the school is situated.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J. AFTER every three holes of a tournament, golf pros usually change to a new ball for maximum distance. On the fourth tee of the Lower Course at Baltusrol yesterday in the opening round of the ...
ALBANY, June 12 The New York State Senate gave final approval today to a bill that its supporters said was primarily intended to help parents "rescue" chilren who have joined religious cults.

ALAN RUDOLPH, who previously directed a couple of films ("Welcome to L.A." and "Remember My Name") that were turgid, humorless and quiet, has now made "Roadie," which is turgid, humorless and loud. Big progress. "Roadie" opens today at the Guild and other theaters.

MOSCOW, June 12 (AP) Nadezhda Olizarenko of the Soviet Union tied the world record in the women's 800-meter run tonight at the Soviet Olympic trials in Lenin Stadium. She overwhelmed a field of eight, including Tatyana Kazankina, whose record she tied by posting a time of 1 minute 54.9 seconds.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) President Carter sent Congress a proposed standby gasoline plan today that, in the event of a severe shortage, would set up a huge system for distributing "checks" redeemable for gasoline ration coupons. In effect, the plan would create a "second currency" managed by a giant accounting system.

DETROIT, June 12 The Ford Motor Company, which is retrenching its operations in the United States, announced today that it would expand in Mexico by building a $365 million plant there to produce four-cylinder engines.

Reports that Brazil had violated its own cocoa base price of $1.20 a pound in cash sales pushed futures sharply lower yesterday in a continually declining market of ample supplies and slow demand for the key chocolate ingredient.
A high percentage of business executives and Government officials believe that the gauging of executive performance on the fluctuations of quarterly profit reports is wrong.

New York State's highest court ruled yesterday that an employer has a responsibility to accommodate employees who celebrate their Sabbath on Saturday, even if it means paying overtime to others to work in their place. However, the court said, the employer could be excused from the requirement, which it called an ''affirmative duty,'' if the employer could show that in a particular case the shift would create ''undue economic hardship.''
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; 55 U.S. Soldiers Arrested For Drugs in Nuremberg

A-T-O Inc. said it would build new corporate headquarters in a business community it is developing in Richmond. * Calgary Power Ltd. said it had extended to June 20 its offer to buy 8.7 million shares, or 42 percent, of the stock of Canadian Utilities. * Coca-Cola Company said that its international trading subsidiary had purchased 20 percent of the common stock of Don Sophisticates Inc., a New York manufacturer of designer apparel.
We shouldn't let the impression go out that the young people are not willing to make the sacrifice to protect the national security of this country.'' -Senator Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia. (A16:4.)

The push by Ronald Reagan's key strategists to replace Bill Brock as the Republican Party's national chairman has touched off mushrooming opposition and posed a test of Mr. Reagan's leadership on the eve of a Republican unity dinner in Los Angeles tomorrow night. One top-ranking Reagan insider, who has opposed Mr. Brock, said tonight that the tide was beginning to turn and he expected Mr.Brock to survive, though a final decision had not yet been made.

President Choi Kyu Hah suggested publicly today for the first time that the South Korean political transition would stop short of the free and open democracy demanded by students and would include some features of the authoritarian rule favored by the army generals administering the country under martial law. The President, in a 35-minute address to the nation, also said that ''a purification campaign'' being conducted by Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan and the Martial Law Command would be expanded beyond purges of corrupt officials to ''eradicate various social ills and degenerative trends'' as well as ''irrationality on the campuses.''

The Senate Transportation Committee today unanimously adopted and sent to the Assembly a resolution asking Governor Byrne to veto the minutes of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which would prevent any new fare increases on its Hudson River crossings. Under the resolution, sponsored by Senator John Skevin, a Bergen Democrat, the Governor would veto the minutes until the Port Authority agreed not to increase bridge or tunnel tolls and to honor its $120 million commitment to the Transpac program, under which the state would buy 1,000 new buses.

LONDON, June 12 (AP) John McEnroe, Vitas Gerulaitis and Roscoe Tanner all highly rated challengers for Wimbledon tuned up their grasscourt techniques today and each won two matches to reach the quarterfinals of a $125,000 tennis tournament at the Queen's Club.

Representative Jim Leach of Iowa has dreamed up the spectacular scenario that John Anderson's independent Presidential campaign might finally result in the election of Gerald Ford as President of the United States next Dec. 15.
HELEN HUMES, whose first appearance at the cookery in 1975 produced an outpouring of critical acclaim, is back at the Greenwich Village restaurant singing in even better form than she did then.

DETROIT, June 12 The General Motors Corporation said today that it would place 18,000 workers on temporary layoff next week, bringing to a total of 155,000 the number of American hourly workers temporarily or indefinitely idled by the nation's largest automobile manufacturer.

WASHINGTON, June 12 Victor H. Palmieri, Coordinator for Refugee Affairs, said today that the Carter Administration planned to establish an interagency task force to deal with Cuban and Haitian refugees.

They say Friday the 13th is a bad day for beginnings, for getting married or launching ships, for starting a journey or eating something novel. And it's odd: much as we'd like to see the world less dreadful, less dependent on luck, less hesitant to start afresh and less willing to settle for bad lots, bad things do happen. Happiness turns on a chancy syllable in perhaps.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12 Donald F. McHenry, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has proposed that the Carter Administration return to the Security Council to seek the release of the hostages in Iran, American sources disclosed today.
PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, June 12 (UPI) Cambodian rebels ambushed a train and killed at least 150 passengers, survivors said today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 12 The Bolivian armed forces, while expressing outrage at State Department charges that they were contemplating aborting national elections scheduled here for the end of this month, are giving every sign that they hope to do iust that.

WASHINGTON, June 12 John Hurford Sharon, an adviser to President John F. Kennedy and a past president of the Children's Hospital National Medical Center here, died Tuesday of a blood disorder after a long illness. He was 53.
Simon Schuster yesterday won its suit for the right to publish new stories in the Tom Swift, Nancy Drew, Hardy Boys and Bobbsey Twins series in both hard-cover and paperback editions.

TALK about problem plays, Dennis the Menace, the kid who's always getting into mis chief, is headed for Broadway. Dennis, as if you didn't know, is the tow-headed 5-year-old who lives with his mother and father in the world of cartoon and comic strips. He is now about 30 years old, although he really hasn't aged at all.
JERUSALEM, June 12 An affluent Israeli has decided to emigrate from Israel, the joke goes, leaving his seaside villa and his expensive automobiles.

TURIN, Italy, June 12 (AP) Belgium and England played to a 1-1 draw today in the opening Group 2 match of the European soccer championship at the Stadio Comunale. The match was marred by rioting by fans of the English team, and the police were forced to use tear gas to restore order.

Lower interest rates in the United States sent the dollar reeling in late New York trading yesterday, with much of the damage coming after the Federal Reserve Board announced it had cut the discount rate to 11 percent, from 12 percent.

RICHARD LINGEMAN, who was once upon a time an editor of the satirical quarterly Monocle, then an editor of The New York Times Book Review and is now an editor of The Nation magazine, is described on the jacket of his fine new book as having been "a native of ...

Milburn Stone, a character actor who made his fortune as the irascible Doc Adams in the long-running television series ''Gunsmoke,'' died of heart failure yesterday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 75 years old.

The Senate today passed a peacetime draft registration bill under which four million young men are expected to be required to sign up at post offices in late July. In a related matter, the Senate Armed Services Committee voted to reduce the strength of the Army by 25,000 persons unless the Army recruits more high school graduates. It took the action in approving a $51.9 billion military authorization bill for weapons and research, $5 billion more than President Carter wanted and $1.2 billion less than approved by the House.

NEEDS To the Editor: In 1978, the Federal Government designated Harlem/East Harlem a ''medically underserved community.'' Few, if any, disagreed with that designation at that time. And indeed, today the situation is worse.@hortly after that designation, Mayor Edward Koch announced he would close two health facilities serving the area, Sydenham and Metropolitan. He cited budgetary savings, poor quality of care and an excess of 5,000 acute-care beds in Manhattan as reasons for the closings.

International Common Market countries reached substantial accord on the text of a declaration calling for the Palestine Liberation Organization to take part in Middle East peace talks. The declaration, which also envisages a multination fact-finding mission to the Middle East, is considered likely to be approved by the Western European government leaders meeting in Venice. (Page A1, Column 1.) American air power in the Middle East and Persian Gulf region will be pressed in a long-range plan disclosed by Gen. Lew Allen Jr., the Air Force Chief of Staff. As a first step, a squadron of 12 F-4 jets, along with 400 personnel, will be sent to Egypt for 90 days and train with Egyptian forces. (A1:1.) U.S. displeasure toward South Korea and its military-dominated leadership was reflected in steps reported by top Carter Administration officials. They said that Washington had postponed indefinitely a high-level economic mission to Seoul and was actively reviewing its ties with South Korea, except a basic security commitment. (A9:2-4.) A deep crisis in Poland's national life was cited in a secret report prepared by more than 100 leaders, many of them in the governing Communist establishment. The report said that unless the Government moved aggressively to reform major inequities and mismanagement, the shortcomings would worsen and might bring about ''open social conflict.'' (A2:3-6.) A new call for release of the hostages in Iran would be sought in the Security Council under a proposal by Donald F. McHenry, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, according to American sources. The proposal would cite last month's unanimous ruling by the World Court that the captives must be freed. (A11:1-2.) National Draft registration late next month is in prospect for four million young men. The Senate approved the registration by a vote of 58 to 34. The measure must be passed again by the House because of a minor difference in the two chambers' versions of the bill, but that action is expected soon and President Carter is expected to sign the legislation early next week. (A1:6.) A major civil rights victory was won by President Carter as the House passed a bill designed to strengthen Federal efforts to end housing discrimination. Approval came on a vote of 310 to 95, but only after the House rejected, by a vote of 209 to 196, an attempt to strip the Government of powers to fight discrimination. The bill now goes to the Senate. (A1:5.) The discount rate was lowered by the Federal Reserve for the second time in two weeks. The board's decision to cut the rate, which it charges banks for loans, to 11 percent from 12 percent, appeared to signal an accelerating attempt to lower interest rates. The move also apparently reflects a growing concern about the economy, which many economists say may show its sharpest slump since World War II in the second quarter of 1980. (A1:4.) A major corruption indictment that resulted from an undercover inquiry by the F.B.I. was issued by a Federal grand jury in Houston. The Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives, a labor union official and two lawyers were charged with fraud, conspiracy and racketeering. (A12:1.) Concern over two false nuclear alerts last week has led top United States officials to press efforts to find and correct the faults. The computer stystem of the North American Air Defense Command that is thought to be responsible has been disconnected, and a group of specialists has been sent to the site to study the system. (A16:1-2.) Doubts about an interest in nutrition among many Americans are expressed by scientists, who are questioning whether those who say they seek improved nutrition have altered their eating habits. Experts say that most Americans continue to consume to much fat and sugar. (A1:5-6.) A big urban renewal plan is opposed strongly by merchants in a court suit in Pittsburgh. The plan calls for replacing small stores with a $150 million office tower complex. In contrast, a pioneering renewal program transformed a slum into a stunning group of skyscrapers in the city's Golden Triangle 30 years ago after strong pressure was exerted by a powerful mayor and a leading philanthropist. (A12:2-5.) Metropolitan A transit fare rise of 10 cents in New York City and an average increase of 20 percent on commuter lines would result from a tentative accord reached by key legislators in Albany and Governor Carey. The accord would provide $235 million for mass transportation systems, with $200 million of it going to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, through a new tax on oil companies. (A1:2-3.) A $13.6 billion budget was approved unanimously by the New York City Board of Estimate and was expected to win easy passage in the City Council. The budget contains $141 million in tax increases and provides for slightly higher new funding than Mayor Koch originally proposed for education, the police and posssible raises. (A1:1-2.) A PATH rail strike caused tie-ups and delays for hours during rush periods. Scores of additional buses and shuttle trains were pressed into service between New Jersey and Manhattan, but they were clearly not enough to carry the 80,000 daily commuters who normally use the railroad. No new negotiations were set on the first day of the walkout by carmen, and both sides said the strike might be long. (B1:5-6.) Business Digest, Page D1

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday obtained a temporary restraining order halting further work by a contractor it contends was responsible for an explosion in the Bronx Wednesday in which a 9-month-old child was killed and a man was critically injured. The Willets Point Contracting Corporation, however, emphatically denied any responsibility for the blast. The restraining order was issued by Justice Herman Cahn of State Supreme Court. The Willets Point company is required to show cause why a permanent injunction should not be issued Monday.

A high percentage of business executives and Government officials believe that the gauging of executive performance on the fluctuations of quarterly profit reports is wrong. A survey by Louis Harris & Associates said 71 percent of 400 individuals questioned preferred more varied criteria for a manager's report card. These include return on investment, cash flows, several components of earnings statements (such as operating and nonoperating income, fixed and variable expenses) and changes in financial position.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The Speaker of the Texas House of Representatives and three other men were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on fraud, conspiracy and racketeering charges that grew out of an undercover inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

DETROIT, June 12 (AP) The Ford Motor Company said today that it had extended rebates to its luxury line by offering a return of $1,000 to purchasers of its Lincoln models. The company is already offering rebates of as much as $500 on Ford and Mercury models.

AS summer approaches, thoughts of New Yorkers inevitably turn to garden restaurants. For 20 years, one of the most beguiling has been the large, informal, somewhat Bohemian setting tucked away behind Ruc, the ...

VENICE, July 12 Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany warned other leaders of the European Common Market today that they would not strengthen the community politically by admitting Spain and Portugal unless they drastically cut the financial subsidies they pay their farmers.

DETROIT, June 12--The Ford Motor Company has retained William T. Coleman Jr., the former Secretary of Transportation, to defend it against charges by the Department of Transportation that more than 20 million Ford vehicles are equipped with defective transmissions.

Spurred first by a new prediction of lower interest rates from a leading economist and then by the Federal Reserve's one-point reduction in the discount rate, prices in the credit markets soared yesterday and interest rates dropped. It was the seventh advance for bond prices in the last eight trading days.

The marriage of Danielle Paule Andre, daughter of Mrs. Charles Francis Clement Jr. of Haverford, Pa., and the late Marc Andre, chancellor of the Belgian Embassy in Washington, to Jorge Angel Pesquera of New York took place yesterday in St. Colman's Roman Catholic Church in Ardmore, Pa. The Rev. William Pope performed the ceremony. The bride is manager of marketing information and her husband is assistant director of personnel and director of personnel and training for the Caribbean and Latin America for Hilton International New York. Mr. Pesquera is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilberto Pesquera of San Juan, P.R. His father, former head of the Department of Tourism in Puerto Rico, is vice president of public relations for El Commandante Race Track in San Juan.

A secret report prepared by more than a hundred journalists, scholars and intellectuals, many of them from the governing Communist establishment, portrays a deep crisis in Polish national life. Unless the Government acts dramatically to reverse the situation, the report says, ''the negative changes will progressively grow and may reach the avalanche stage, which would threaten open social conflict.''

Cambodian rebels ambushed a train and killed at least 150 passengers, survivors said today. The survivors said that between 150 and 200 people were killed in the daylight attack Tuesday 42 miles northwest of the capital. At least 200 of the wounded, many in serious condition, were brought to hospitals in Phnom Penh. More than 100 others - those suffering from lighter injuries - were taken to clinics in the provincial capital of Kompong Chhnang. The 70-car train was carrying an estimated 8,000 passengers. Witnesses said the travelers were jammed into the boxcars, with those who could not get in riding on top or clinging to the sides.

The Air Force Chief of Staff disclosed today that the United States intended to deploy jet fighters to Egypt as the first step in a long-range plan to establish land-based air power in the Middle East and Persian Gulf region. Air Force officers said that a dozen F-4 Phantom fighters would be sent to Egypt in July for 90 days with 400 pilots and operations, intelligence, technical and supply staffs. The planes will operate from Cairo West, a military airfield not far from the pyramids at the edge of Cairo.

About 10 times a year, in a courtroom at 26 Federal Plaza in lower Manhattan, taxpaying Davids without lawyers confront Internal Revenue Service Goliaths, challenging I.R.S. rulings that the taxpayers owe the Federal Government more money. The occasion is a visit by one of the 26 judges of the Washingtonbased United States Tax Court. The judges periodically travel to more than 100 cities across the country to hear taxpayer appeals, which result when an auditor insists that a taxpayer did not report all income received in a given year, or claimed a beneficial filing status that was not warranted, or took improper exemptions or deductions.

President Carter sent Congress a proposed standby gasoline plan today that, in the event of a severe shortage, would set up a huge system for distributing ''checks'' redeemable for gasoline ration coupons. In effect, the plan would create a ''second currency'' managed by a giant accounting system. Unless Congress blocks the plan by a joint resolution within 30 days, the rationing system would be set up over the next 12 to 15 months at a cost of about $103 million.

The State Legislature early today approved a bill that was described by its sponsors as the toughest gun-control measure in the country. The legislation is intended to restrict plea bargaining and require a minimum one-year prison term for most persons convicted of carrying an unlicensed loaded handgun in public places.

An affluent Israeli has decided to emigrate from Israel, the joke goes, leaving his seaside villa and his expensive automobiles. ''But why?'' asks a friend in disbelief. ''You have everything!'' ''Two reasons,'' says the man. ''First, the Government is in disarray. Its policies are deplorable, and it's leading the country to ruin.''

Brad Mills, a rookie, drove in three runs with a pair of singles and Charlie Lea scattered eight hits over eight innings in his major league debut as the Montreal Expos coasted to a 9-1 victory over the San Diego Padres tonight for their ninth straight triumph.

Creditors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad approved the bankrupt company's reorganization plan, the railroad's trustee, Richard Joyce Smith, announced yesterday. Both classes of bondholders cast more than 93 percent of their votes to reorganize the railroad as an investment company. Six percent of the common stock of the Penn Central Corporation and $36 million in Penn Central preferred stock would be the major assets of the new company. But a spokesman for the New Haven said the reorganized company might seek a merger partner to use tens of millions of dollars in tax loss carry-forwards.

Thomson Newspapers Ltd. said today that it would exercise its option and buy one-third of the Montreal Gazette for $13 million (Canadian). The Toronto-based newspaper chain, which operates 56 newspapers across Canada, officially had until Saturday to make the decision on this option to buy into Montreal's one remaining English-language daily. The move was part of a deal made between Thomson's subsidiary, F.P. Publications Ltd., and Southam Inc., owners of the Gazette.

The term "par" in bridge is related to golf usage, but there is a distinction. If you and your partner do as well as you can theoretically do, you have scored "par." If the opponents do the same, you have "absolute par." You can only "beat par" if the opponents fall short of their target.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 12 (UPI) Islamic revolutionary guards opened fire today on tens of thousands of rival demonstrators rioting around the United States Embassy.

Yet it is not clear that their interest in health and nutrition has spread through broad segments of the population, or even that those people who say they are interested in improved nutrition have altered their eating habits.

VENICE, June 12 The Common Market Nine managed to draw back from the brink of financial civil war just in time to avoid spoiling the sparkling delights of Venice for the heads of government.

Mount St. Helens, in the third major eruption in a month, blew steam and ash more than nine miles high tonight and prompted the evacuation of some people in the area, officials said. ''It's a major eruption,'' said Pete Rowley, a United States Geological Survey geologist. He said pebbles of pumice half an inch to an inch in diameter were reported falling in Cougar, about 10 miles south of the mountain.

To the Editor: The more that is disclosed about the attempt to rescue the American hostages in Iran, the more bitterly appropriate seems the pitiful and nationally embarrassing failure of the mission.Any happier outcome - any outlandish turn of chance that might have produced a successful conclusion -could only have served as a coverup for both the slipshod and woefully inadequate planning involved in the mission and the dangerously overstated ''official'' estimate of this nation's military preparedness as a whole.
Ruth Moore of Rockville won the annual Women's Cross County Golf Association championship by two shots today with a 54-hole total of 246.

One of Ronald Reagan's defense advisers said at a news conference here today that he would urge Mr. Reagan, if elected President, to end the United States arms embargo against South Africa, set up a Navy presence at the Simonstown base and help the South African armed forces to strengthen themselves in aspects relating to the security of the Cape sea route, particularly in the field of helicopters. The adviser, Joseph Churba, is president of the Center for International Security, a conservative research body in Washington. He said he was expressing his own views, not speaking for Mr. Reagan. But he said that Mr. Reagan, if elected, would be certain to order a ''fundamental re-evaluation'' of the Carter Administration's policies toward South Africa, which have combined harsh strictures against apartheid with restraints on some aspects of trade.

Two dissident writers and two printers went on trial here today charged with misappropriating an old Government mimeograph machine destined for the scrap heap. If convicted, they face jail terms of one to five years. In Poland, where there is censorship, it is against the law to own mimeograph machines without authorization.

A 20-year-old Russian Jew, who came to the United States with his parents five years ago from the Ukrainian city of Chernovtsy, was one of 770 graduates from Yeshiva University at its 49th commencement yesterday in Manhattan. The emigre, Anatole Trakhtenbroit of Bridgeport, Conn., who was voted the ''pre-med of the year'' by his classmates, will continue his studies at the university's Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

12 DIE AS PLANE CRASHES IN NEBRASKA: Heavy thunderstorms last night caused an Air Wisconsin twin-engine plane to crash into a muddy farm field 15 miles west of Omaha, killing 12 people and injuring three others. Efforts by rescue workers were hampered by ankle deep mud at the scene. Tractors were used to transport victims from the plane. Wreckage was scattered over two fields, with wings about 400 yards from fuselage.

There has been a noticeable drop in gasoline prices in the metropolitan area for the first time since last summer's gasoline shortage, New York City's Consumer Affairs Department said yesterday. It was attributed to adequate supplies for the current cutback in driving - and to competition among retailers. The prospects, however, are for price increases soon again.

HOME sales plunge to the lowest level in 14 years. Auto production falls and steel output slumps. The inventories of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers shoot up as sales drop. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries raises its prices again. Unemployment climbs fast and the gross national product falls at an annual rate of 8 percent. But out of this fire storm the stock market rises like a phoenix. What explains the market's optimism? The general view on Wall Street is that the worst of the recession is coming now, and that recovery will begin early in 1981.

"CARNY," which opens today at the Cinerama 1 and other theaters, is an unfocused but not unappealing little movie about life with a traveling carnival troupe, particularly about the transformation of a restless, unhappy smalltown girl, sweetly played by Jodie Foster into a tough-skinned "carny," or professional carnival trouper.

WASHINGTON, June 12 In the opening skirmish today over the shape of the Democratic Party platform, President Carter advocated meeting the nation's problems with "realistic, achievable solutions within our means," while Senator Edward M. Kennedy offered the view that recognition of "the limits of government is no excuse for inaction."

Cavenham Development Inc., one of many companies controlled by Sir James Goldsmith, disclosed yesterday in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission that the British-French businessman and two associates had been named board members of the Diamond International Corporation, a forest-products company.

A $13.6 billion budget containing $141 million in tax increases was approved late last night by the New York City Board of Estimate and the City Council. It included increases over the Mayor's original proposal in funds for education, the police and possible wage rises.

A major effort to introduce "nonsexist" language into regular use in local churches was recommended yesterday by the National Council of Churches in a report by a special group made up of scholars and lay members.

CHICAGO, June 12 Hispanic Americans here filed a class-action suit against the Bureau of the Census today, alleging that they would suffer politically and financially from what they expect to be a "serious undercount" by the agency in their neighborhoods.
VERNON, Vt., June 12 (AP) The Vermont Yankee nuclear power plant has been shut down to fix a leak of highly radioactive water inside the facility, plant officials said today.

JERSEY, Channel Islands, June 12 (AP) Sir Billy Butlin, the flamboyant British multimillionaire who followed the motto "Sell yourself big" and made his fortune through vacation camps, died today at his home, his family reported.

ALBANY, Friday, June 13--A tentative agreement was reached late last night to subsidize much of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $388.6 million deficit, thus holding the increase in New York City's bus and subway fares to 10 cents.

WASHINGTON, June 12 Back in the fresh, eager, learning-by-doing days in the first year of his Administration, President Carter decided that he and his staff could profit from a speedreading course in the White House.

Though you have been solemnly advised otherwise, the Presidential election of 1980 is not a critical event in the nation's history. The preservation of civilization is not at stake. The future of the free world does not hang precariously in the balance.

Donald F. McHenry, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has proposed that the Carter Administration return to the Security Council to seek the release of the hostages in Iran, American sources disclosed today. Mr. McHenry is understood to believe that last month's decision by the International Court of Justice provided Washington with a good opportunity to demonstrate again that the world's governments want the American captives freed.

A $13.6 billion budget containing $141 million in tax increases was approved late last night by the New York City Board of Estimate and the City Council. It included increases over the Mayor's original proposal in funds for education, the police and possible wage rises. The budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 represents a relatively small $4 million increase in total spending over the Mayor's original proposal. Consequently, the Mayor said, it was what he had sought - the city's first truly balanced budget in more than a decade.''

KANSAS CITY (AL) - Called up Rawley Eastwick, relief pitcher, from Omaha of American Association. Sent Jeff Twitty, pitcher, to Omaha. John Hurford Sharon, an adviser to President John F. Kennedy and a past president of the Children's Hospital National Medical Center here, died Tuesday of a blood disorder after a long illness. He was 53. A graduate of Princeton University and the George Washington Law School, Mr. Sharon was for eight years a law partner of Clark M. Clifford, the former Secretary of Defense.

Manchester Bank, Manchester, N.H., has named Francis J. Haines Jr. senior vice president and manager of the commercial banking group. * McGraw-Edison Company, a manufacturer and supplier of electrical and mechanical products based in Rolling Meadows, Ill., named Robert A. Kenkel president of the company's Metal Products division and James Fischer president of the Gravely division.
Marguerite Perret thinks Representative John B. Anderson ''doesn't stand a chance'' of being elected President. But she intends to vote for him in November anyway.

John McEnroe, Vitas Gerulaitis and Roscoe Tanner - all highly rated challengers for Wimbledon - tuned up their grass-court techniques today and each won two matches to reach the quarterfinals of a $125,000 tennis tournament at the Queen's Club. McEnroe, seeded No.1, was the only one of the three who did not drop a set during the long day. He beat Paul McNamee of Australia, 6-4, 7-5, and then eliminated Brian Gottfried of the United States, 7-6, 7-6, in two closely contested tiebreakers.

THE Mickelberry Corporation, which is involved in printing, processed meats and advertising, will be increasing its income from that last category with the acquisition of 17-year-old Nadler & Larimer, the 57th-largest American ad agency. Mickelberry, which has owned Daniel & Charles Associates (the 43d largest) since 1972, will become the parent of N.&L. when the agency is bought by Newcourt Industries, 84 percent owned by Mickelberry. The deal, ''for cash and supplemental payments'' based on future agency earnings, is expected to be closed within 30 days.
Former President Ford had arthroscopic surgery on his left knee today for a flareup of an old football injury.

The Common Market Nine managed to draw back from the brink of financial civil war just in time to avoid spoiling the sparkling delights of Venice for the heads of government. A bright sun and a fresh breeze off the lagoon sweetened the rancid atmosphere, after the fight over Britain's payments to the Community ended in compromise last week. But the scars and resentments remain, the basic issues were only deferred, and the core question of what Europe can actually do was left unanswered.

A major effort to introduce ''nonsexist'' language into regular use in local churches was recommended yesterday by the National Council of Churches in a report by a special group made up of scholars and lay members. Among its proposals is that the council make available a compendium of Scripture passages that are most commonly used in accordance with standards designed to eliminate or minimize male nouns and pronouns.

As a candidate for the degree of Master of Fine Arts at the University of Texas in 1956, Harry Blackstone illustrated his thesis, "Levitation From the Deus ex Machina to the Present Time," by causing a man, a piano, a horse and a 12-piece orchestra to rise without apparent human agency from the stage of the university auditorium.
There has been a noticeable drop in gasoline prices in the metropolitan area for the first time since last summer's gasoline shortage, New York City's Consumer Affairs Department said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The White House's wage and price monitors reported today that the economy's basic rate of inflation "appears to have risen" to 10 percent a year or a shade less and is unlikely to come down rapidly.

AKRON, Ohio, June 12 (UPI) Judge James V. Barbuto spent two hours on the stand in Summit County Common Pleas Court today, denying that he ever offered judicial leniency and other favors in exchange for sexual relations from women.

ALBANY, Friday, June 13 The State Legislature early today approved a bill that was described by its sponsors as the toughest gun-control measure in the country.

The Getty Oil Corporation will purchase the UNC Plateau Mining Company, a coal operation in Utah, from UNC Resources Inc., the companies announced yesterday. They said the transaction would cost Getty, which has been on something of an acquisition binge lately, about $60 million in cash.

Tens of thousands of interstate commuters packed buses and trains yesterday and endured hours of delays on the first day of what both sides said could be a long strike by carmen of the Port Authority Trans-Hudson Railroad.

IN the so-called "golden age" of the 1950's, few series attained the consistent quality level of "Omnibus." This was television's first 90-minute magazine. Funded by the Ford Foundation, it began on CBS on Saturday afternoons.

The trails leading through the forest to the Thai border are thick with people heading for Nong Chan, where Western relief organizations distribute rice and rice seed to be carried back into the interior. For months the people here in Battambang Province have been going to Nong Chan, taking two or three days to reach the border. Now people travel for as long as two weeks in the hope of getting through the cordon of Vietnamese Army patrols to obtain food and seed.
Square By BEN A. FRANKLIN

Twenty-nine refugees identified as suspected criminals or troublemakers have been flown from the Fort Chaffee relocation center to a Federal prison in Atlanta. Edwin Chauvin of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service said that the refugees were suspected of having committed serious crimes in Cuba. He said some of them were involved in the June 1 riot at Fort Chaffee.

Here, in question and answer form, is an explanation of how the draft registration program approved by the Senate today will work: Q. Who must register? A. Young men who were born in 1960 and 1961. Beginning next January, all 18-year-olds will be required to register, and the program will continue enrolling 18-year-olds each year.

The Ford Motor Company has retained William T. Coleman Jr., the former Secretary of Transportation, to defend it against charges by the Department of Transportation that more than 20 million Ford vehicles are equipped with defective transmissions. The Federal agency confirmed yesterday an earlier report that it had issued an ''initial determination'' that a safety defect existed in the transmissions of nearly every passenger car and many trucks made by Ford in the 1969 through 1979 model years. The charge could result in the recall of 16 million vehicles, the largest in industry history, and cost Ford an estimated $200 million or more.
