A tentative agreement was reached late last night to subsidize much of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $388.6 million deficit, thus holding the increase in New York City's bus and subway fares to 10 cents. Meanwhile, a compromise bill to toughen New York State's law against illegal handgun possesion cleared the Legislature after lengthy debate. It passed the Democratic-controlled Assembly by a vote of 89 to 55 just before midnight, and cleared the Republicancontrolled Senate by a vote of 38 to 18 early today. The bill has the support of Mayor Koch and of Governor Carey, who is expected to sign it. (Page B6.)

The Federal budget is finally in balance, but don't rush to memorize the numbers. The $613.6-billion spending plan now moving through Congress for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 is already a fantasy, the fourth version of a Federal budget that will be followed by a fifth, sixth and seventh before the actual outlays and receipts are determined. This is not a criticism, merely an observation. There would have been less confusion if President Carter had offered one budget instead of two during the first seven weeks of 1980 and if the Congressional budget committees had prevailed with their first compromise revision instead of the second. But the budget process is confusing by definition, for it must serve two distinct purposes. It is not only a framework for battling out spending priorities but also a fiscal weapon that the Government uses along with tax policy to stimulate or restrain private economic activity.

The New York State Senate gave final approval today to a bill that its supporters said was primarily intended to help parents ''rescue'' children who have joined religious cults. A major provision in the bill would authorize a judge to appoint a temporary conservator with the power to supervise a person over the age of 15 who has ''undergone a sudden and radical change in behavior, life style, habits and attitudes'' as a result of associating with a group that uses ''deception'' in the recruitment of members.
The Transportation Department ruled today that, after July 23, all trucks equipped with air brakes must be manufactured with brakes that act on each wheel.

Gambling stocks, market laggards so far in 1980, sprang back to life yesterday to share honors with precious-metal issues as Wall Street's best performers. Elsewhere, prices generally drifted lower and energy issues, in particular, were dotted with losses, in contrast to Wednesday's display of strength.
Seismic signals indicated an underground Soviet nuclear explosion late yesterday at a test site in Siberia, Department of Energy officials reported today.

The General Motors Corporation said today that it would place 18,000 workers on temporary layoff next week, bringing to a total of 155,000 the number of American hourly workers temporarily or indefinitely idled by the nation's largest automobile manufacturer. The layoffs by G.M. were the largest scheduled today among the Big Three auto makers. The Ford Motor Company said it would temporarily idle more than 7,000 workers next week and the Chrysler Corporation said that its layoff plans were unchanged.

Sir Billy Butlin, the flamboyant British multimillionaire who followed the motto ''Sell yourself big'' and made his fortune through vacation camps, died today at his home, his family reported. He succumbed to bronchial pneumonia at the age of 80. It is legend that in 1921, he had the equivalent of about $25 in his pocket and a dream of opening Britain's first vacation camp. Twenty-five years later he had amassed 1 million, or about $4 million at the time, and his name was synonymous with vacations for hundreds of thousands of people. In 1964, he was knighted as Sir Billy.

VENICE, June 12 West European foreign ministers reached substantial agreement tonight on the text of a declaration calling specifically for the Palestine Liberation Organization to take part in future Middle East peace negotiations.

Many people can tell you about the summers they spent in the Catskills. They were busboys or counselors, lifeguards, comedians, waitresses, arts and crafts teachers or guests. They stayed in tiny bungalow colonies, farmhouses or grand resorts.

Milburn Stone, a character actor who made his fortune as the irascible Doc Adams in the long-running television series "Gunsmoke," died of heart failure yesterday at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 75 years old.

The difference is not that Mary Decker trains with men. The difference is that after 10 years of competition, after all the highs and lows and hurts, how she feels has become as important as how fast she runs.

C.R. Bard Inc., a manufacturer of hospital and surgical supplies with headquarters in Murray Hill, N.J., announced that it had signed a letter of intent to purchase two subsidiaries of the International Paper Company for about $48 million in cash and notes.

Creditors of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad approved the bankrupt company's reorganization plan, the railroad's trustee, Richard Joyce Smith, announced yesterday.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Anderson Might Apologize If Iran Freed the Hostages

Those who prefer to see international politics as a morality play must be puzzled by the conflicting reports from the OPEC meeting in Algiers. Who won the latest power struggle inside the oil cartel - the ''good guys'' led by Saudi Arabia, allegedly arguing for price moderation, or the loose coalition of radical Arab ''bad guys'' who want to sock it to the West? The question may be unanswerable. Indeed, it may be irrelevant. For it is becoming increasingly clear that OPEC is not in the normal sense a cartel of sellers banding together to determine total output and price. The decisions of individual exporters may at times perceptibly influence the market. But in the end the price and availability of oil has far more to do with luck and the behavior of the importing nations. The primary responsibility for coping with oil scarcity rests inevitably with the consumers.

Nadezhda Olizarenko of the Soviet Union tied the world record in the women's 800-meter run tonight at the Soviet Olympic trials in Lenin Stadium. She overwhelmed a field of eight, including Tatyana Kazankina, whose record she tied by posting a time of 1 minute 54.9 seconds.

THE story began two decades ago and appealed to investors seeking a tax shelter with romantic overtones. Who could resist owning an orange grove, an asset that would grow in value as new trees bore fruit and increased in yield? The company behind the idea, American Agronomics, had purchased farm land in an area of Florida far enough south to avoid almost all frosts and nearly 25 miles inland from the Gulf of Mexico so that wind damage from hurricanes, it was hoped, would be minimal.

f1013 By WILLIAM SERRIN Millions of Americans are increasingly concerned with good nutrition and keeping fit. Yet, it is not clear that their interest in health and nutrition has spread through broad segments of the population, or even that those people who say they are interested in improved nutrition have altered their eating habits.

Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany warned other leaders of the European Common Market today that they would not strengthen the community politically by admitting Spain and Portugal unless they drastically cut the financial subsidies they pay their farmers.

HOME sales plunge to the lowest level in 14 years. Auto production falls and steel output slumps. The inventories of manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers shoot up as sales drop. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries raises its prices again. Unemployment climbs fast and the gross national product falls at an annual rate of 8 percent. But out of this fire storm the stock market rises like a phoenix. What explains the market's optimism? The general view on Wall Street is that the worst of the recession is coming now, and that recovery will begin early in 1981.

Victor H. Palmieri, Coordinator for Refugee Affairs, said today that the Carter Administration planned to establish an interagency task force to deal with Cuban and Haitian refugees. In addition, he said, the Administration plans to announce soon a package of measures to define the refugees' legal status and their eligibility for federally financed benefits.

A 42-year-old teacher at a Bronx public school was arrested on charges that he had sexually abused four girls in his class. One of the girls is 11, another is 12 and the two others are 13. The teacher was identified as Maximiliano Morales, the father of two children. He is on the staff of P.S. 28 at 1861 Anthony Avenue, but because of a fire in that building in April, the school's classes are being held at P.S. 63, at 169th Street and Franklin Avenue.

THE encore for "Bull Pen" comes in the shape of a night stroll after the show toward the subway at Eighth Avenue where the reality of what you have just seen is underscored in still more vignettes along 42d Street.
According to the program notes of "Mass Appeal," the author, Bill C. Davis, "is not now, nor ever has been, a seminarian."

WASHINGTON, June 12 The Air Force Chief of Staff disclosed today that the United States intended to deploy jet fighters to Egypt as the first step in a long-range plan to establish land-based air power in the Middle East and Persian Gulf region.

ALBANY, June 12 Applying basic mathematics and political muscle, leaders of the Democratic Party put four candidates for the party's nomination for United States Senator from New York on the primary election ballot today.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 12 (Reuters) A Spanish airliner and a Colombian Air Force plane collided on a runway at Bogota International Airport today, but there were no casualties, a spokesman for the Civil Aviation Authority reported.

The Consolidated Edison Company yesterday obtained a temporary restraining order halting further work by a contractor it contends was responsible for an explosion in the Bronx Wednesday in which a 9-month-old child was killed and a man was critically injured.

To the Editor: In the midst of all of the effort supposedly being devoted to maintaining the 50-cent fare, some consideration should be given to the elimination of free mass transit for the 44,283 employees of the Transit Authority, as well as countless retirees, family members and perhaps friends who avail themselves of this privilege.
CHOICE To the Editor:

They say Friday the 13th is a bad day for beginnings, for getting married or launching ships, for starting a journey or eating something novel. And it's odd: much as we'd like to see the world less dreadful, less dependent on luck, less hesitant to start afresh and less willing to settle for bad lots, bad things do happen. Happiness turns on a chancy syllable in perhaps. Good and bad luck aren't just private happenstances. It matters famously that the current crops of Alaskans, Arabs and Albertans live on vast pools of oil. Blind luck.

While the Carter Administration has played down the significance of the two false nuclear alerts last week, officials have reported that the incidents have stirred deep concern in the Defense Department and the White House. At the Pentagon, officials disclosed that General David C. Jones of the Air Force, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, today visited the headquarters of the Strategic Air Command in Omaha, Neb., to confer with senior officers there on the false alarms. Tomorrow General Jones is scheduled to visit the Air Force's underground complex at Cheyenne Mountain, Colo., the site of the North American Air Defense Command.

The Federal Reserve lowered the discount rate to 11 percent from 12 percent. The central bank cited recent declines in short-term interest rates. But analysts viewed the Fed's second cut in its loan charge to banks in two weeks as evidence of anxiety about the state of the economy, which many economists say may show its sharpest contraction since World War II in the second quarter. (Page A1.) The prime rate was cut to 12 1/2 percent from 13 percent by a number of banks, including the Bank of America, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover. It, thus, slipped to the level where it had been last fall before climbing to a peak of 20 percent. (D1.)

Gulf and Western Industries, the diversified conglomerate with holdings that include Paramount Pictures, reported yesterday that its earnings in the third fiscal quarter ended April 30 swelled 17.7 percent, while sales advanced 5.8 percent. The company said net income in the latest quarter rose to $60 million, or $1.03 a share, from $51 million, or 84 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Sales were up to $1.47 billion, from $1.39 billion.

Mike Easler of the Pirates continued his torrid batting streak by hitting for the cycle today as Pittsburgh overpowered the Cincinnati Reds, 10-6. Easler, who has 12 hits in his last 20 times at bat, became the first Pirate to hit a single, double, triple and homer in one game since June 1974 when Richie Zisk did it.

THE Eagles may be the quintessential Southern California rock band of the 1970's, but by now it can claim the status of America's most popular group. On Sunday the band will demonstrate its popularity before a crowd that will probably total 60,000 at Giants Stadium in New Jersey. It will be the first Eagles concert in the metropolitan area in three years. The Eagles came together when Glenn Frey and Don Henley met in 1971 as members of Linda Ronstadt's backup band. The music on their first album, ''Eagles,'' in 1972 was classic Southern California country rock, with breezy harmonizing and a happily hedonistic projection of male heterosexuality. That combination of elements made the band an instant hit, but it was never content to rest easy with success. Instead, in conjunction with such other Los Angeles singersongwriters as Jackson Browne and John David Souther, the Eagles kept picking insistently at the assumptions behind the California life style.

Alexander's Inc., one of the area's largest retailers, increased its net loss in the third fiscal quarter ended May 3 to $692,000 from $572,000 in the similar 1979 quarter, as a result of higher operating costs, the recent transit strike and a loss in a specialty store chain acquired last year, the company said yesterday. Net sales rose 9.2 percent, to $99.7 million, from $91.2 million, partly because the sales of Margo's La Mode Inc. were included in the quarter. That apparel specialty-store chain, which operates in the South and Southwest, was acquired by Alexander's in July but while its sales were up, it operated at a deficit in the recent quarter.
AROUND THE NATION; Court Says Child Can Sue In 'Wrongful Life' Case

Dale Lundquist, who has not finished higher than 18th place in any tournament this year, equaled the best round of her career with a four-under-par 68 today to take the opening-round lead in a $150,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament. Miss Lundquist was one of the first golfers to complete her round in the 72-hole event, and her one-stroke lead over Pam Higgins held up.

The major issue in the antitrust suit brought against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company by the MCI Communications Corporation is whether the Bell System might emerge with its phone market - and its image - reduced. If the jurors now considering the case, after a four-month trial here, find for MCI, their verdict is likely to encourage other small phone companies to chip away at A.T.&T.'s huge phone business. Competitors most likely would cite the case as an argument for Congress to erect safeguards that would prevent the Bell System from using its monopoly power to stop competition. Legislation is now being drafted in Congress that would permit A.T.&T. to engage in communications services beyond the phone business, including data processing.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 12 Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf, friends and rivals since their student days at Ohio State, took over the 80th United States Open today with recordtying 63's that gave them a three-stroke lead in the first round.

WASHINGTON In October 1977, President Carter stood amid South Bronx rubble and made a stirring commitment to use Federal agencies and money to revitalize this and similar areas of urban blight. Today, our inner cities are worse off. In the South Bronx, additional unprofitable buildings have been abandoned by landlords and more families have left.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The House and Senate resolved their differences over the 1981 budget today and approved a compromise $613.6 billion plan that almost everyone expects will end up deeply in the red.

When the United States Equestrian Team's Olympic squad was named, the horse most conspicuous by his absence was F. Eugene Dixon's Jet Run. Probably the most surprised member of the equestrian set was Mike Matz, who during the last four years has ridden Jet Run to dozens of championships, including the gold medal in the Pan American games.

The World Council of Churches said today that it had received ''gruesome stories'' of indiscriminate killing, rape and torture by South Korean troops during the student uprising in the provincial capital of Kwangju last month. The Council said that reports reaching by way of Japan described the army action in quelling the May 27 uprising as a massacre. ''At least 40 people were killed the first day by the bayonets of paratroopers and girl students were raped and tortured,'' the Council said.
Champ Summers belted two two-run homers and Alan Trammell knocked in three runs with two doubles tonight, leading the Detroit Tigers to an 8-4 decision over the Minnesota Twins.

Hispanic Americans here filed a class-action suit against the Bureau of the Census today, alleging that they would suffer politically and financially from what they expect to be a ''serious undercount'' by the agency in their neighborhoods. In their suit, the Hispanic Americans allege that as a result of the anticipated undercount, they will have ''proportionately less political representation than other groups and less than they are legally entitled.'' The suit also alleges that Hispanic institutions will receive proportionately less governmental financing from agencies that base their allocations on census data.

Georgiana Harding Farr Sibley, a national church leader and a champion of civil rights, died of a stroke Tuesday at Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. She was 93 years old and lived with a daughter, Jane Auchincloss of Millbrook, N.Y. Mrs. Sibley was the widow of Harper Sibley, a former president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. She was a slight, energetic woman and maintained a lively interest in world fellowship, religious cooperation, scientific farming and the status of women.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J. AFTER every three holes of a tournament, golf pros usually change to a new ball for maximum distance. On the fourth tee of the Lower Course at Baltusrol yesterday in the opening round of the United States Open championship, Tom Watson's caddie, Bruce Edwards, handed the world's best golfer a new black Hogan 3 and glanced at his notes. ''It's 150 yards to the hole,'' the caddie said. The fourth hole was listed at 162 yards, but that distance was measured from the tee to the middle of the green. Yesterday the cup had been cut on the left front, only 21 feet beyond the wide pond that guards the vast sloping putting surface on this famous hole.
A Federal appeals court today upheld a National Labor Relations Board finding that J.P. Stevens & Company was guilty of unfair labor practices at its seven plants in Roanoke Rapids, N.C.

President Carter announced today that he would nominate a career Foreign Service officer, William J. Dyess, to replace Hodding Carter 3d in one of his roles, supervising the State Department's public-relations effort. Mr. Dyess, 50 years old and a native of Troy, Ala., will have the title of Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs.

Back in the fresh, eager, learning-by-doing days in the first year of his Administration, President Carter decided that he and his staff could profit from a speed-reading course in the White House. An instructor was brought in to put the President, his wife and others through their paces one evening in the White House library. In the first session, the fiercely competitive Mr. Carter, author of ''Why Not the Best,'' came in second. The one who finished first was Jack H. Watson Jr.

Smack in the center of Staten Island, on land sloping upward from a shopping mall on Richmond Avenue to the vast stretches of LaTourette Park, one of the largest bursts of new housing construction in the state has been under way for four years. At least 12 builders are working in that area, according to Joseph Margolis, executive vice president of the New York City Builders Association, who says the name ''Heartland Village'' has become the locally accepted designation for the area though maps call it New Springville. Several hundred housing units have been produced already, largely in the town-house condominium form, and more are coming.

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 12 Calling the Nassau Country Club layout "the best-conditioned course I've played this year," George Zahringer 3d of Sands Point won the medal with a twoover-par 72 in the Long Island Golf Association's 56th amateur championship today.

The United States has indefinitely postponed sending a high-level economic delegation to South Korea and has put all aspects of relations except a basic security commitment under active review as a sign of displeasure with the new militarydominated leadership, high-ranking Carter Administration officials said today. In interviews the officials said they had no doubt that Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan was planning either to assume power or to have a man of his choice do so, despite continued private and public American exhortations for a return to the period of liberalization that followed the assassination of President Park Chung Hee last October.

The difference is not that Mary Decker trains with men. The difference is that after 10 years of competition, after all the highs and lows and hurts, how she feels has become as important as how fast she runs. It was not always this way, she said, especially between the ages of 15 and 16, when she grew 6 inches. She was not accustomed to a new body and was training intensely for races every week. ''I always ran very fast,'' she said. ''I didn't know how to run slow.''

To the Editor: One doesn't have to be a strong supporter of President Carter to deplore Senator Kennedy's efforts to manipulate the rules of the Demo-cratic National Convention in order to obtain the party's Presidential nomination.v.hatever the limitations of the present primary system - and there are many - there can be no valid justification for changing the rules after elections have taken place.
Betty Morris of Stockton, Calif., last night took the Women's International Bowling Congress singles title for the second year in a row.

In an article on air-conditioners in Thursday's Home Section, the telephone number for the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers was incorrectly given. The correct number is (312) 984-5800. An article in the Spring Survey of Education on April 20 erroneously attributed the quotation that television ''exposed the modern child to a greater variety of cultures than the best traveled and most highly educated man of 50 years ago.'' The correct source was an article by Terry Borton in the Harvard Educational Review of February 1971.

The Ford Motor Company said today that it had extended rebates to its luxury line by offering a return of $1,000 to purchasers of its Lincoln models. The company is already offering rebates of as much as $500 on Ford and Mercury models. Lincoln sales have been hard hit by the auto industry's current slump, falling 50 percent in the first five months of 1980 from the year-earlier level. The Lincoln rebates began June 4 and will end July 12. There was no explanation of the delay in announcing them. Buyers may apply the rebate to the down payment, Ford said.
NOTES By WINSTON WILLIAMS
Meets at 10:30 A.M. on renewal of mandate of United Nations force in Cy- prus. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

Islamic revolutionary guards opened fire today on tens of thousands of rival demonstrators rioting around the United States Embassy. Witnesses said more than 300 people were injured by gunfire and rocks in a five-hour battle that erupted after militants, supported by the revolutionary guards, attacked a leftist rally of an estimated 100,000 people.

To the Editor: Oh, unhappy day when first an Oscar winner used his (her?) acceptance speech to thank assorted producers, directors, cast members, technicians, teachers, family and friends, thereby setting a precedent for countless boring television hours.

Nancy Drukker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Essex Drukker, was married at the Glen Head (L.I.) Country Club yesterday to Jonathan M. Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin W. Morse. Both families are from Kings Point, L.I. Rabbi Jerome Davidson performed the ceremony. The bride is an alumna of the University of Bridgeport. Her father is a vice president of the Chemical Bank and her mother a freelance fashion photographer.

A tentative settlement has been reached in the seven-month strike against the New-York Historical Society, a state mediator said yesterday. The mediator, Solomon Kreitman, said the ratification vote on a three-year contract would take place today. The terms of the accord, which were not made public, were reported to cover wages and nonsalary issues. The strike by 22 employees, including editors, librarians and service employees, has impeded research by historians requiring access to the archives of the society on early America. The society is at 77th Street and Central Park West,

Who would have thought that the insignia of a penguin, a rooster, a fox or an alligator could transport a simple cotton shirt from the confines of a sports arena onto the chests of middle America? Yet according to retailers, the simple cotton knit short-sleeved sports shirt - epitomized by the classic Izod Lacoste shirt with the alligator trademark emblem - is outselling just about every other item in men's apparel this year.

Belgium and England played to a 1-1 draw today in the opening Group 2 match of the European soccer championship at the Stadio Comunale. The match was marred by rioting by fans of the English team, and the police were forced to use tear gas to restore order. In the other Group 2 match, Italy and Spain played to a scoreless tie. In the first half of the match between Belgium and England, play had to be held up for five minutes when the police fired tear gas into the crowd and fumes wafted onto the pitch. Ray Wilkins scored England's goal in the 26th minute and Jan Ceulemans tied the score for Belgium three minutes later.

C.R. Bard Inc., a manufacturer of hospital and surgical supplies with headquarters in Murray Hill, N.J., announced that it had signed a letter of intent to purchase two subsidiaries of the International Paper Company for about $48 million in cash and notes. The two subsidiaries are Davol Inc., a manufacturer of catheters and other medical products, and its corresponding company in Britain, Davol International Ltd.

THE burglary of a suburban Boston bank over the Memorial Day weekend, in which thieves escaped with $5 million in securities and other property, points up one of the common misconceptions about safe-deposit boxes.
Falling interest rates helped push the dollar somewhat lower on major currency markets yesterday. Gold prices climbed back above $600 a troy ounce in Europe and the United States.
The Bronx County Democratic committee voted almost unanimously yesterday to endorse the Republican county leader, John D. Calandra, for re-election to the State Senate.

PARIS, June 10--More timid than a wallflower, spring has only now dared plunge into the sidewalk cafes, filling them with leafy warmth. The tables are crowded, but there is no point in roaming the famous Left Bank boulevards or even the cobbled back streets in search of the intellectual table d'hote where Paris once philosophized for the world.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 13--First it was tornadoes in Kansas City. Then volcanic ash in Seattle and earthquakes during the California series. Tonight, the Yankees had to contend with Billy Martin and his Oakland A's.

WASHINGTON, June 13--Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie praised the European Common Market today for showing "a sense of restraint" in the phrasing of its call for giving the Palestine Liberation Organization a role in Middle Eastern negotiations. But he said the United States would refuse to deal with the P.L.O. as long as it was "bent on" Israel's destruction.
VENICE, June 13--A summit conference here is like a summit conference nowhere else.

To the Editor: Your editorial of June 5 presented an incomplete and misleading view of my position to increase welfare benefits. I have consistently supported an increase in assistance benefits to help offset the devastating impact of inflation on welfare families. My record in this area is clear and consistent.In my annual message to the Legislature in January, I pledged that the additional dollars generated by Federal welfare reform would be used to fund a much-needed increase in welfare grants. When it became clear that the current desire to balance the Federal budget meant an indefinite delay in Congressional action, I met with community leaders concerned with the adequacy of welfare benefits and reaffirmed my commitment to a 10 percent increase funded by the state. This proposal was passed by the Assembly two months ago. This bill has been met by a lack of responsiveness in the Senate.

The first of the buses that New Yorkers will be riding into the 21st century rolled quietly into a garage in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday, and engineers began preparing for the buses' debut next week on routes throughout the city. It was an arrival long-awaited and much-feared by officials and engineers of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, for the eight new buses from Grumman's Flxible Division are unlike any that have traveled the streets of the city.

Britain expelled the head of Libya's diplomatic mission in London today after he publicly endorsed the activities of Libyan assassination squads here. ''The Libyan authorities must understand that criminal actions in the United Kingdom must cease,'' Sir Ian Gilmour, Deputy Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons, announcing the expulsion of Musa Kusa, head of the ''people's bureau,'' as Libya now calls its embassies.

Defying Congress's new budget ceilings, the House Appropriations Committee approved $500 million today to keep Saturday mail delivery in 1981. The committee rejected by voice vote an amendment to cut the $500 million for Saturday mail deliveries out of a $9.6 billion appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1981, which starts Oct. 1.

Philip Weld of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., kept the lead today on the seventh day of the singlehanded trans-Atlantic yacht race. Weld is sailing toward Newport, R.I., in his yacht, Moxie, and has about 1,600 miles to go since starting out with 87 other boats last Saturday from Plymouth in the 3,000-mile race.

The House voted by a wide margin today to allow continuation of basic Government research into supersonic passenger aircraft. The action came as the House authorized $5.6 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in the financial year beginning Oct. 1.

Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week. Answers appear on page 28. 1. The first of two international meetings to be convened in a foreign city this month opened amid tight security. What meetings are they, and where are they being held?

Expensive or inexpensive, magnum or derringer, handguns of any breed pose a far greater threat to innocent members of society than they do to criminals - contrary to the National Rifle Association's assertions (letter June 5). As New York City Police Commissioner McGuire has repeatedly pointed out, shop owners and other citizens who attempt to defend themselves against criminals with handguns frequently injure or kill themselves or innocent bystanders in the process. That is why the Coalition of Merchants Against Crime, the Bronx Chamber of Commerce and 21 other merchant groups have unanimously endorsed stiffer handgun controls in New York. According to F.B.I. statistics, half of all murder weapons are handguns. A handgun can transform sharp words between drivers into a potentially deadly exchange (just ask Reggie Jackson). The easy accessibility and concealability of handguns make them the assassin's number one tool (just ask former President Ford). Because the 1968 Gun Control Act is so lenient in its restrictions on handgun purchases, no one in this country is safe from the homicidal rage of an irate friend, spouse or crazed acquaintance (just ask the family and friends of Allard Lowenstein).
To the Editor:

WASHINGTON THREE officials of New York City's Department of Health have invented a method of detecting the use of drugs by analyzing body fluids. The narcotics traced include cocaine, morphine and barbiturates, and the presence of several can be disclosed simultaneously. Patent 4,207,307 was granted this week to Balkrishena Kaul, director of toxicology; Bernard Davidow, assistant commissioner for laboratories, and Stephen J. Millian, director of virology and immunology.

A Federal grand jury today indicted Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. of South Carolina, charging that he had shared in a $50,000 bribery payment from an undercover Federal agent and had attempted to obtain $125,000 more. Mr. Jenrette, a 44-year-old Democrat, became the third member of Congress to be charged as a result of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's two-year undercover operation known as Abscam, for ''Arab scam.''

Rodney Jenkins, who always seems to make it look easy, rode Second Balcony to victory in the open jumper class today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show and the mount appeared to be doing nothing more than engaging in a brisk trot over the fences. ''I try to save a half-step here and a few feet there,'' said the 35-year-old Jenkins, the country's leading professional show rider. ''Of course, a lot depends on the horse. I can lead him into a tight turn, say, but it's up to him to save the step himself.''

A scientific panel delivered a report to the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday that disputed the conclusion of an earlier study that some residents of Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., exhibited abnormal levels of chromosome damage.

f813Major food and beverage companies, responding to a sharp increase in the price of sugar in recent months, have begun to pass along rising production costs to consumers. Industry executives and economists warn that higher prices for sugar and products with a high sugar content should continue through 1981 and beyond. By the end of the year, according to an economist at the Department of Agriculture, consumers can expect to see an increase of 50 to 70 percent over January levels in the cost of packaged sugar, and an increase of 15 percent in the cost of products containing sugar, ''or possibly more, if current trends continue.''
VENICE, June 13--Following is the text of a declaration on the Middle East by the European Council, issued at the conclusion of a two-day conference in Venice this afternoon:
WARREN, Mich., June 13 (AP)-- Volkswagen of America Inc. announced today that it was recalling 155,000 diesel automobiles because of reports of surging, or self-acceleration speedup, in some engines.
A study to explore the possibility of a performing-arts center in Queens has suggested that the best spot would be in Long Island City, where transportation lines converge.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 13--Violence has been sweeping Iran increasingly in recent weeks, with kidnappings, murders and sabotage creating a climate akin to civil war.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 (AP) --Willie Stargell turned two Joe Niekro knuckleballs into a pair of two-run homers and helped the Pittsburgh Pirates end the Houston Astros' eight-game winning streak tonight.

PRETORIA, South Africa, June 13-- The Government disclosed today that ground troops and planes from bases in the disputed territory of South-West Africa struck deep into Angola this week, with casualties on both sides that were among the highest in the 15-year-old guerrilla war.
WALNUT, Calif., June 13--Ed and Shirley Burke qualified today for the hammer-throw final as The Athletics Congress national outdoor track and field championships began at Mount San Antonio College.
LONDON, June 13--Britain expelled the head of Libya's diplomatic mission in London today after he publicly endorsed the activities of Libyan assassination squads here.

Pete Karagozian was out talking to the boys the other day, pausing at a truck stop near the Ambassador Bridge to talk to other drivers. The boys seemed to like the wavy-haired man with the pencil-thin mustache, calling to him, shaking his hand. The owner of the restaurant asked for his autograph. Mr. Karagozian is a sudden star among truck drivers in this area, for, in a startling development in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Mr. Karagozian, a dissident, has won election to the presidency of Teamsters Local 299, the home local of James R. Hoffa, the once powerful teamster leader who has been missing since 1975.

Willie Stargell turned two Joe Niekro knuckleballs into a pair of two-run homers and helped the Pittsburgh Pirates end the Houston Astros' eight-game winning streak tonight. ''Let's just say the man can hit,'' said Niekro, who also served up a run-scoring single to the Pirates' first baseman in Pittsburgh's 5-3 victory. Stargell had a double as well, going 4 for 4.

To the Editor: Twice within a week, and for the third time in less than a year, our country's early-warning system, designed to inform us of an imminent Soviet nuclear attack, has falsely reported that such an attack had already begun. Had these errors, of such great magnitude in their potential consequences, not been corrected, we might well have had the predicted ''30-minute'' nuclear devastation in which the earth would have become a revolving mass of fire and of ashes. Yet the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. David Jones, blandly states that these alarms ought to demonstrate to the Soviets that we can respond to a real threat quickly and with incredible power.
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; 2 Polish Dissident Writers Given Suspended Sentences

Defying Congress's new budget ceilings, the House Appropriations Committee approved $500 million today to keep Saturday mail delivery in 1981. The committee rejected by voice vote an amendment to cut the $500 million for Saturday mail deliveries out of a $9.6 billion appropriation bill for the fiscal year 1981, which starts Oct. 1.

It's pretty, isn't it?'' Halston told well-wishers after the showing the other day of his fall made-to-order collection in his eyrie high up in the Olympic Tower. ''Pretty'' was his word. His admirers were using more extravagant terms like ''elegant.'' But the designer feels there is a place for understatement in the lives of women who can afford his custom clothes. They're a varied group, those clients, and he tries to take care of all of them: members of the theatrical set, like Bianca Jagger and Liza Minnelli; the wives of bankers and other corporate executives; the working women in high places, like Kay Graham and Mary Wells Lawrence.

Charles Harrison of the United States was eliminated from the British Amateur golf tournament today, losing in the quarterfinals on the 19th hole. The 47-year-old insurance man from Atlanta lost to Duncan Lindsay-Smith, a 33-year-old South African. Lindsay-Smith now meets another South African, David Suddards, in a semifinal match. Harrison never recovered from a shank on the 10th fairway when his opponent was in a bush and likely to go 3 down. After halving the 18th, Harrison drove into heather and then threeputted home on the sudden-death hole. Arthur Pierse, from Tipperary, Ireland, who defeated Hugh Evans, 2 and 1, and Duncan Evans, who ended the amazing run of 16-year-old Ronan Rafferty of Northern Ireland, 2 and 1, meet in the other semifinal match.

Tens of thousands of gypsy moth caterpillars have infested acres of woodlands and backyards in New York and New Jersey, turning verdant forests into wastelands and renewing an old controversy over how best to control the pests. If nature runs its course, the population of gypsy moths will eventually dwindle from famine or disease. But environmentalists and conservationists in the New York metropolitan area agree that there is no sign of such a collapse before the moths enter the pupal, or resting, stage within the next two weeks. This means that the moths will be back next year, perhaps in greater numbers.

A new Monday-to-Friday afternoon daily newspaper is scheduled to begin publication on Monday. The Wall Street Final, which is aimed at commuters, is designed principally to produce closing stock prices in time for the afternoon commuter rush. The paper will be sold only at Grand Central Terminal, Penn Station and a few other stations.

Questions appear on page 21. 1. Foreign ministers of the European Common Market nations convened in Venice, where representatives of seven leading industrialized nations, including the United States, are scheduled to convene later in the month.

New York State, which was the first state to license handguns, has had gun possession legislation for most of this century, and its law became a model of similar legislation in other states. But until the new law, there were nearly no restrictions on plea bargaining and no requirement for a mandatory minimum sentence. In 1911 the Legislature approved the first gun licensing act in the United States, popularly known as the Sullivan Law. It was named after its sponsor, State Senator Timothy P. Sullivan, a Manhattan Democrat and Tammany Hall leader. Until 1911 there were no restrictions in the state on the possession of concealed handguns.

After weeks of fitful bargaining, the Republican-led State Senate passed a bill early today that would allow the state to tax oil companies to subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The measure is intended to hold the fares on buses and subways in the city to 60 cents, a 10-cent increase. On the M.T.A. commuter lines, the increase would be an average of 20 percent. The bill would also provide money for upstate transit systems.

WIELICZKA, Poland--Part of Eastern Europe's charm is its fanatical devotion to spas, sanitariums, mineral baths and health clinics. It can make an American feel he is treading through a Henry Jamesian world of horsedrawn carriages, bubbling springs, tiled hallways smelling of sulfur and white-frocked doctors with tiny goatees.

PORTLAND, Ore., June 13--The third major eruption of Mount St. Helens in less than a month hurled a new downpour of volcanic ash across the coasts of northern Oregon and southern Washington last night, but strong winds and heavy rain today ameliorated the worst problems from the ash.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)--Industrial production plunged by 2.1 percent last month as the recession continued to spread through the nation's economy, the Federal Reserve reported today.

Arthur E. Friedland, who practiced law in New York City for 44 years and was active in several Jewish organizations in the city and in Yonkers, died yesterday at his home at 145 East 84th Street. He was 69 years old.

Eighteen young women were presented to society last night at the annual Fairfield Debutante Ball. The event, held in a pink and white striped tent at the home of Mrs. Hubert T. Mandeville in Greenfield Hill, Fairfield ...

JOHANNESBURG, Saturday, June 14 (Reuters)--The South African Government last night banned political meetings in all major centers, just two days before the fourth anniversary of the 1976 black student riots in Soweto.
ALBANY, Saturday, June 14--The Legislature early this morning revived a proposed constitutional amendment to allow casino gambling in New York State.

Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie appealed to Congress today to appropriate long-delayed foreign aid funds for a fiscal year that has less than four months remaining. Mr. Muskie said that if Congress failed to provide the funds, the United States could not meet commitments to give $75 million in aid to Nicaragua, $30 million for Cambodian refugee assistance and $20 million for relief for hurricane victims in the Caribbean.

To the Editor: The question of how to make public transportation accessible to disabled persons will be debated soon in the Congress. A proposal pending in the House would reverse the direction established by the U.S. Department of Transportation in 1979.Federal policy, implementing Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, requires access by the disabled to portions of mainline bus and rail networks over a period of years. On the other hand, the proposed Section 223 of H.R. 6417 would allow transit properties to avoid their Section 504 responsibilities by substituting segregated van transportation for the disabled.

Industrial production plunged by 2.1 percent last month as the recession continued to spread through the economy, the Federal Reserve reported today. The May drop in production at the nation's factories, mines and mills was the fourth consecutive monthly decline and reduced factory output to its lowest level in two years, according to the report.

More timid than a wallflower, spring has only now dared plunge into the sidewalk cafes, filling them with leafy warmth. The tables are crowded, but there is no point in roaming the famous Left Bank boulevards or even the cobbled back streets in search of the intellectual table d'hote where Paris once philosophized for the world. Jean-Paul Sartre died in April, and no one is taking his place. There may no longer even be a place to take, for the long French tradition of congregating around a master thinker has fallen into disuse and, for some, disrepute.

Summit County Probate Judge James V. Barbuto was found guilty here today of gross sexual imposition and of intimidation . Judge George J. McMonagle convicted Judge Barbuto of imposing himself sexually on a former female courthouse employee and of intimidating two detectives who investigated him in 1977.

With the cry of ''Play Ball!'' Justice Lawrence E. Kahn arbitrated a dispute yesterday in Albany's State Supreme Court in which a 16-year-old boy charged he had been tricked into signing an agreement to play American Legion baseball with a team he did not like. The teen-ager, Robert John White, an outfielder, had asked, in effect, to become a free agent and to be released from the Zaloga Post 1520 team. He had contended that, when he signed the agreement to play last year, he was told it was only for the 1979 season, not for this year. He claimed he was lured into signing with a promise of a trophy, a shirt with his name emblazoned across it, and a dinner that would be held in his honor. White asked to be permitted to join another team, for which many of his friends played.
WASHINGTON, June 13, Reuter--The House voted by a wide margin today to allow continuation of basic Government research into supersonic passenger aircraft.

TEATOWN LAKE RESERVATION, N.Y., June 13--Tens of thousands of gypsy moth caterpillars have infested acres of woodlands and backyards in New York and New Jersey, turning verdant forests into wastelands and renewing an old controversy over how best to control the pests.

MONTREAL, June 13 (AP)--Warren Cromartie stroked his fourth consecutive single to score Rodney Scott with the tiebreaking run in the seventh inning as the Montreal Expos edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3, tonight, tying a club record with their 10th victory in a row.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 13-- Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf, who shared a three-stroke lead in the first round of the 80th United States Open yesterday with record-tying 63's, parted company today in the second round.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 13 (UPI)--A man climbed over a chain link fence into a Consolidated Edison substation on Echo Avenue and was electrocuted when he touched a 45,000-volt power line today, the police said. Identification of the body was not immediately possible.

We are not among those who look to the British economy for instruction in the perfidy of the modern welfare state. That is why we do not count on Prime Minister Thatcher to show Americans the path to its reform. The economies of the industrial democracies are in many ways similar and intertwined, but each must look to its own strengths for salvation, and these remain obviously different.

The Legislature early this morning revived a proposed constitutional amendment to allow casino gambling in New York State. The head of a State Senate committee, who had been holding out for his own plan, gave his assent to eight different bills, covering a wide range of options. The variety of plans allows the Legislature to postpone until next year a decision on where casinos might be situated and who might operate them -the state or private companies.

The Army Chief of Staff said today that a proposed reduction of 25,000 soldiers would have to come out of combat forces deployed in Europe and South Korea. The cutback, part of a proposal approved yesterday by the Senate Armed Services Committee, is intended to improve the quality of Army manpower by reducing recruitment quotas at a time when insufficient numbers of high school graduates are enlisting. The plan would permit the Army to increase recruitment and strength if it could attract a larger proportion of high school graduates.

The following dispatch, by the Middle East specialist of Le Monde, was translated by The New York Times from the French By ERIC ROULEAU Le Monde, Paris

A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan has granted the Shubert Organization the right to manage the National Theater in Washington. The Nederlander Theatrical Corporation, the Shuberts' prime competitor in booking theaters for shows, had filed suit to prevent the Shuberts from taking over the management of the National, a Washington landmark and one of the capital's principal theaters. Judge Morris E. Lasker ruled that the Shuberts' management of the theater would not violate the intent of a 1956 consent decree that prohibited the organization from acting to ''restrain competition'' in theater bookings in any city.
A number of banks throughout the nation, led by Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty and Chemical, reduced their prime rates yesterday to 12 percent from 13 percent.

Volkswagen of America Inc. announced today that it was recalling 155,000 diesel automobiles because of reports of surging, or self-acceleration speedup, in some engines. The surging does not affect the safe operation of the vehicles, the company said. Owners are being asked to take their cars to dealers for modifications at the end of August. The repairs will be made free.

Pete Karagozian was out talking to the boys the other day, pausing at a truck stop near the Ambassador Bridge to talk to other drivers. The boys seemed to like the wavy-haired man with the pencil-thin mustache, calling to him, shaking his hand. The owner of the restaurant asked for his autograph. Mr. Karagozian is a sudden star among truck drivers in this area, for, in a startling development in the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Mr. Karagozian, a dissident, has won election to the presidency of Teamsters Local 299, the home local of James R. Hoffa, the once powerful teamster leader who has been missing since 1975.

About 70,000 workers at the Togliatti Automobile Plant on the Volga River southeast of Moscow went on strike for two days early in May, according to unconfirmed reports reaching here. It was not clear from the reports what had caused the strike or how it was settled. One version was that work stopped May 6 at the huge plant, about 500 miles from Moscow, to protest food shortages, particularly in meat and dairy products.

DARIEN, Conn., June 13--Rodney Jenkins, who always seems to make it look easy, rode Second Balcony to victory in the open jumper class today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show and the mount appeared to be doing nothing more than engaging in a brisk trot over the fences.

LOS ANGELES, June 13--Bowing to pressure from party moderates, Ronald Reagan agreed today to retain Bill Brock as chairman of the Republican National Committee. The decision averted the possibility of a split in the party a month before its national convention.

CHICAGO, June 13--A Federal court judge tonight ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to pay $1.8 billion in damages to the MCI Communications Corporation, a small telecommunications company, after a jury found that A.T. had violated Federal antitrust laws in denying service to MCI.

A scientific panel delivered a report to the Environmental Protection Agency yesterday that disputed the conclusion of an earlier study that some residents of Love Canal in Niagara Falls, N.Y., exhibited abnormal levels of chromosome damage.

At the Brick Presbyterian Church yesterday Claire Louise Coons, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Coons of Columbus, Ohio, was married to Michael Carter Tamm, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Tamm of Wyckoff, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson and the Rev. Richard L. Cosnotti officiated.

Brokerage-house stocks moved ahead briskly yesterday in a rising market that saw the Dow Jones industrial average close at its highest level since late February. Sugar issues also rose in response to higher prices for raw sugar.

Edmund S. Muskie By BERNARD GWERTZMAN WASHINGTON, June 13 - Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie praised the European Common Market today for showing ''a sense of restraint'' in the phrasing of its call for giving the Palestine Liberation Organization a role in Middle Easteern negotiations. But he said the United States would refuse to deal with the P.L.O. as long as it was ''bent on'' Israel's destruction.

Brooke Astor leaned back on a sofa in her red lacquered library high above Park Avenue, fingered the grape-sized pearls around her neck, laughed a throaty laugh and began talking about ''the development of a foolish young girl into a public monument.'' She was talking about herself. Mrs. Astor is the sleekly elegant and outspoken philanthropist about whom former Mayor Beame once said, ''She has done more for New York City than any other one person.'' As president of the Vincent Astor Foundation, founded by her late husband, Mrs. Astor has overseen the giving of $82 million to various New York City projects.

A bitter fight for control of the Diamond International Corporation - supposedly settled amicably in a 62-page agreement with Sir James Goldsmith only 24 hours before - took a new turn yesterday with the emergence of a multimillion-dollar mystery buyer of Diamond stock. Sir James is chairman of Generale Occidentale of Paris, which, in turn, owns Cavenham Ltd. of London, the British food company, and the Grand Union Company, the American supermarket chain.

A Federal judge today temporarily blocked the state's prosecution of Gary Thomas Rowe, former informer of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in the 1965 slaying of a civil rights worker, Viola Gregg Liuzzo. Federal Judge Robert E. Varner said that his order would remain in effect until June 23 or ''until the further order of this court'' and hinted that it might be made permanent.

Although he is a member in good standing, there is no mention of the Mister Flood Society in the long official list of organizations, including the National Academy of Sciences and the National Institute of Medicine, to which Donald Kennedy belongs. But now that he has taken on the additional responsibility of the presidency of Stanford University, the outlet for relaxation that Mr. Kennedy finds through the Mister Flood Society may be more important than ever.

Helen F. Kelly, a French professor who had taught languages at Stuyvesant High School in New York City, died Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. Mrs. Kelly, who lived in Manhattan, was 59 years old. She was a graduate of Hunter College, earned a master's degree at the University of Illinois and studied at the Sorbonne in Paris. She had been a language professor at Northeastern University.

The Philadelphia Phillies scored seven runs in the first inning, two on Mike Schmidt's 19th home run of the season, and held on to beat the San Diego Padres, 9-6, tonight. The first seven Philadelphia batters got base hits. The victim of the assault was Randy Jones (4-6), who left with an aggravated ribcage muscle pull after giving up five runs.

Every spring I dig up my yard. I rejoice in the smell of soil freshly turned and in the sight of ground properly raked. Breaking up clods of clay and mixing in the contents of a compost pile, I feel strong and virtuous. After a day's work, I am entitled to the illusion that I have cleared all the rocks. But, then, next spring my spade hits a two-pound chunk of quartzite just under the surface, heaved up from God-knows-where. The rock reassures me that it isn't quite the same soil I sift through every year; the ground is always in motion, sinking and rising and drifting sideways like the continents. I dig because I look for treasure. My immediate goal is to recover an onyx cuff link - a gift from a cousin in Mexico - that I lost five years ago. Then there is always a chance of finding something left behind by previous tenants and passersby, travelers and hunters.

WASHINGTON, June 13--A Federal grand jury today indicted Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. of South Carolina, charging that he had shared in a $50,000 bribery payment from an undercover Federal agent and had attempted to obtain $125,000 more.

GLEN COVE, L.I. June 13--Rich Serian, who has lived on the Island only six months, won two matches today and advanced to the quarterfinal round of the Long Island Golf Association's 56th annual amateur championship.

The first of the buses that New Yorkers will be riding into the 21st century rolled quietly into a garage in the East New York section of Brooklyn yesterday, and engineers began preparing for the buses' debut next week on routes throughout the city.

SEATTLE, June 11--President Carter, who has expanded Federal support for the cities by billions of dollars in the last three years, would trim the budget somewhat this year but promises "other steps" if the recession grows worse.

ALBANY, June 13--New York State, which was the first state to license handguns, has had gun possession legislation for most of this century, and its law became a model of similar legislation in other states. But until the new law, there were nearly no restrictions on plea bargaining and no requirement for a mandatory minimum sentence.

The Army Chief of Staff said today that a proposed reduction of 25,000 soldiers would have to come out of combat forces deployed in Europe and South Korea. The cutback, part of a proposal approved yesterday by the Senate Armed Services Committee, is intended to improve the quality of Army manpower by reducing recruitment quotas at a time when insufficient numbers of high school graduates are enlisting. The plan would permit the Army to increase recruitment and strength if it could attract a larger proportion of high school graduates.

The Big Three American auto makers reported today that sales of new American-made passenger cars continued to drop in early June, but the rate of decline appeared to be slowing. Customer rebates offered by the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation apparently helped auto sales, along with a greater availability of auto loans as interest rates have declined. Sales have been declining sharply for months because of the recession, the high price of gasoline and customer demand for vehicles that are smaller and more fuel-efficient than most of the Big Three's models.

Questions appear on page 21. 1. Foreign ministers of the European Common Market nations convened in Venice, where representatives of seven leading industrialized nations, including the United States, are scheduled to convene later in the month.

Probably since its inception in 1913 and certainly since the end of the World War II, the Federal Reserve has suffered from a credibility gap concerning changes in its monetary policy. In an attempt to maintain some uncertainty about its policies, the Fed has generally denied market assessments of changes in the central bank's monetary policy. As a result of the dramatic change it announced last October in the way it designs and implements its monetary policy, however, the very definition of monetary policy has been called into question. Some critics now contend that the central bank is using its moneysupply targets to disguise policy changes.

We are not among those who look to the British economy for instruction in the perfidy of the modern welfare state. That is why we do not count on Prime Minister Thatcher to show Americans the path to its reform. The economies of the industrial democracies are in many ways similar and intertwined, but each must look to its own strengths for salvation, and these remain obviously different. It is as curious allies, therefore, and not for metaphorical debate, that we record Mrs. Thatcher's first economic triumph after a year of ever-worsening trouble. Her relief came not in economic policy as such, but in a diplomatic deal with her compliant Common Market partners to excuse Britain from two-thirds of its contributions to the customs union, a deal worth about $2 billion a year. This could make possible some relaxation in the austerity measures that had her Tory back benches howling and even the British business community, her strongest constituency, begging for relief.

President Carter directed Government agencies today to begin experimenting with more flexible methods of regulation. More specifically, Mr. Carter asked for greater use of innovative regulatory techniques that give business more freedom in deciding how to meet Government standards. To date, most regulation specifies in great detail not only the goals, but also how they should be met.

A Federal grand jury today indicted Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. of South Carolina, charging that he had shared in a $50,000 bribery payment from an undercover Federal agent and had attempted to obtain $125,000 more. Mr. Jenrette, a 44-year-old Democrat, became the third member of Congress to be charged as a result of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's two-year undercover operation known as Abscam, for ''Arab scam.''

Outside, the fireflies flicker silently along the village green; there is no sound but the rustling of wind in the ancient trees overhead. Inside Town Hall, however, the lights are burning late as the Republican Town Committee meets to look over a couple of candidates for statewide office. They are particularly glad to see one aspirant to the United States Senate, and chat amiably with him for a while about taxes, about torrents of government paperwork for small businessmen, about incompetence in Washington. Finally the candidate winds up his talk, saying, ''I'm delighted to have a chance to represent the people I've grown up with and known all my life.''

Along with such pests as jackrabbits and kangaroos, Australia "a few years from now" is being afflicted by predatory motorcycle gangs. An elite leather-clad highway police force has been established to oppose them.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)--Defying Congress's new budget ceilings, the House Appropriations Committee approved $500 million today to keep Saturday mail delivery in 1981.

The executive vice president of the National Urban League, John Jacob, said yesterday that league officials were "disturbed at the slow pace of the investigation" into the shooting last month of the organization's president, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., in Fort Wayne, Ind.

A Federal judge today temporarily blocked the state's prosecution of Gary Thomas Rowe, former informer of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in the 1965 slaying of a civil rights worker, Viola Gregg Liuzzo. Federal Judge Robert E. Varner said that his order would remain in effect until June 23 or ''until the further order of this court'' and hinted that it might be made permanent.

Bowing to pressure from party moderates, Ronald Reagan agreed today to retain Bill Brock as chairman of the Republican National Committee. The decision averted the possibility of a split in the party a month before its national convention. At a joint news conference, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Brock said that Drew Lewis, a National Committeeman from Pennsylvania who is the Reagan campaign chairman for that state, would take a new post as deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee.

William Allan Patterson, a pioneer in the aviation industry who headed United Airlines from 1934 until 1966 and who remained as director emeritus and honorary chairman of both the airline and its parent company, UAL Inc., died yesterday in Glenview, Ill., after a prolonged illness. He was 80 years old. He was the first president of United Airlines and later was its board chairman. Mr. Patterson's career in commercial aviation spanned its growth from a curious oddity to the birth of the mass travel of the jet age, from the open-cockpit planes for the brave few in the 1920's to the pressurized airliners familiar to millions of business and vacation travelers today.

Despite opposition from the Carter Administration, the Senate Armed Services Committee has voted to add 100 multiple-warhead Minuteman III missiles to those already deployed, a move that could put the United States above the level specified in the recent strategic arms limitation agreement with the Soviet Union. The action, which was taken earlier this week in a closed door session, could push the United States above the treaty limit of 1,200 multiple-warhead missles.

The Atlantic Richfield Company said yesterday that it had bought out Halcon International Inc.'s interest in the Oxirane Companies for approximately $270 million in cash, plus the assumption of ''certain liabilities'' that the company did not specify. Oxirane was established in 1966 as an equal-partnership joint venture of Atlantic Richfield and Halcon, a chemical company. It produces propylene oxide and other chemicals at plants in the United States and abroad.

The confusion and the congestion that marked the first day of the strike against the Port Authority Trans-Hudson railroad on Thursday eased considerably yesterday. More shuttle buses were pressed into service and many commuters apparently took the day off.

DURHAM, N.C., June 13--Around this time of year, residents are bracing themselves for what some call "the invasion of the posture people," referring to that influx of lithe, well-proportioned young bodies, their carriage erect almost to the point of exaggeration, that signals the third season of the American Dance Festival here, beginning June 17.

Trans World Airlines, saying a return to "normality" was needed, announced yesterday that it wants to raise the one-way fare between New York and either Los Angeles or San Francisco to $250 from $99, effective July 1.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to discontinue a four-year-old half-fare program that affects 120,000 city schoolchildren.

The Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association officially named Bill Musselman head coach today, completing a housecleaning that began with the defection of Stan Albeck to the San Antonio Spurs earlier this week. Musselman had been hired by Ted Stepien, the Cavaliers' new owner, as director of player personnel.

The third major eruption of Mount St. Helens in less than a month hurled a new downpour of volcanic ash across the coasts of northern Oregon and southern Washington last night, but strong winds and heavy rain today ameliorated the worst problems from the ash. Threats of flooding from possible new mud flows and melted snow on the unpredictable mountain prompted the evacuation of hundreds of people. However, most of the evacuees were returning to their homes today as the mountain lapsed into relative quiescence, rains dampened the ash and the feared mud flows did not develop.

Virginia Root MacAdam, a soprano who accompanied John Philip Sousa and his band on a 13-month 45,000-mile tour in 1910-11, died June 2 in Springfield, Mass. Mrs. MacAdam, who lived for many years in Scarsdale, N.Y., was 96 years old. Mrs. MacAdam's career included concert appearances here and abroad. She was married to the late George T. MacAdam, a writer for The New York Times before World War I.

Richard Pryor, the comedian, who suffered nearly fatal burns, was taken off intravenous feeding today but remained in critical condition, his doctor said. ''He's more alert today than at any time since entering the hospital'' on Monday, said Gary Swaye, assistant executive director of Sherman Oaks Community Hospital. Doctors continued to monitor the 39-year-old Emmy and Grammy winner for infection or other complications, Mr. Swaye said at a news conference.

Trans World Airlines, saying a return to ''normality'' was needed, announced yesterday that it wants to raise the one-way fare between New York and either Los Angeles or San Francisco to $250 from $99, effective July 1. The T.W.A. proposal would also raise one-way first-class fares to $375 from $317. T.W.A. said the increase would ''return transcontinental fares to more realistic levels'' and noted that the fare would still be lower than the basic coach fare that prevailed in April, before the current price competition among transcontinental carriers broke out.

The Government disclosed today that ground troops and planes from bases in the disputed territory of South-West Africa struck deep into Angola this week, with casualties on both sides that were among the highest in the 15-yearold guerrilla war. Prime Minister P.W. Botha told Parliament that 16 South African soldiers were killed in the operation, which he said had destroyed the operational headquarters of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the guerrilla force fighting to end South African control of the territory. Mr. Botha said that more than 200 guerrillas had been killed in the strike and that more than 100 tons of Communist-made equipment used by the insurgents had fallen into South African hands.

Alexandra von Metzler, daughter of Mrs. Frederic Chapuisat of East Hampton, L.I., and Herbert von Metzler of Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married yesterday to Rodman C. Rockefeller, son of Mary Clark Rockefeller of New York and the late Nelson A. Rockefeller, former Vice President and Governor of New York. The Rev. William Sloane Coffin Jr. performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Riverside Church.

In Connecticut this spring, the General Assembly's price for approving a 7 percent increase in welfare benefits was a tough "workfare" bill requiring cities to find jobs or useful training for "employable" recipients of state aid. Welfare officials are understandably worried that it will prove to be merely punitive for some poor people or cost them state subsidies. It is much easier to thrust rakes into people's hands than to steer them into lasting jobs.

Cyril A. Smith, a senior executive of Reuters in North America, collapsed and died Thursday in London just before he was to attend the news agency's annual luncheon. He was 63 years old and lived in Merrick, L.I.

Titus Andronicus'' is Shakespeare's most savage pit - a caldron of rape, maiming, killings and cannibalism. It is tragedy without catharsis, Rome at the fall, ''a wilderness of tigers.'' In the pulsating Stratford Shakespeare Festival revival, directed by Brian Bedford, the point of the play is not the carnage but the relentlessness of the revenge and the remorselessness of the revengers. No one regrets a murderous act even as he condemns the homicide of others. Titus, like Lear, the Shakespearean character with whom he has most in common, is an unknowing instigator of his own and his nation's doom. Within minutes after Titus's triumphant return to the city - and after he declines the title of emperor - the entire monstrous plot is set in motion. Vengeance follows vengeance until the stage is blighted with corpses - a record 35 by the count of the Polish critic Jan Kott.

To the Editor: We were puzzled by Henry H. Wasserburger's article (''I Don't Understand Women Today,'' Op-Ed page, May 31.) Clearly he is angry, but the stories he relates fail to explain why his anger is directed against women.v.hen he describes the young, ''beautiful girl'' who is to be the weightlifter Joey's second wife, he credits her with ''understand(ing) his wild ways,'' yet within the same paragraph concedes that she thinks he's ''just out with the boys.''

Butch Hobson drove in two runs with his third home run in two games, leading the Boston Red Sox to a 3-0 victory over the California Angels tonight. The loss was the ninth in 10 games for the Angels, and the 14th in their last 17 at home, dropping them 14 games behind the American League Western Division leader, Kansas City.

Summit County Probate Judge James V. Barbuto was found guilty here today of gross sexual imposition and of intimidation . Judge George J. McMonagle convicted Judge Barbuto of imposing himself sexually on a former female courthouse employee and of intimidating two detectives who investigated him in 1977.

advance for SATURDAY JUNE 14!!!!!!!!!!!! The military academies which turn out future generals and admirals graduated their first women officers this spring. And now, when the ink is still damp on their commissions, here are Congress and President conniving to keep women out of the lower military ranks. I refer to the President's draft registration program being pushed through at the Capitol, which specifically excludes women from the right to be registered for the opportunity to do some service to the state. The President took the swinish male position at the outset on this one, declaring that he did not want women registered for the draft. Congress followed enthusiastically, as befits the last bastion of the spittoon and the well-chomped cigar butt.

The new owners of the Barbizon Hotel, one of best-known women's hotels in the city, are considering various possibilities such as converting it into a luxury hotel, an office building, an apartment building or keeping it as it is, those involved in the planning said in interviews yesterday. ''It's wide open,'' David Teitelbaum, a real estate developer who was hired as a consultant by a former owner in 1976 to help stem losses at the hotel and who has continued in the same role with the new owners, said yesterday.

Workers at the New-York Historical Society voted yesterday to end their six-month strike by ratifying a contract that will give them a weekly wage increase of $61 during the next two and a half years. It is the first contract between the society and its professional, clerical and technical employees. The strike, which began Dec. 3, did not close the society and its museum at Central Park West and 77th Street, but it had bitter overtones for the institution, which was founded in 1804. The society has been experiencing financial and fund-raising difficulties.

Arthur E. Friedland, who practiced law in New York City for 44 years and was active in several Jewish organizations in the city and in Yonkers, died yesterday at his home at 145 East 84th Street. He was 69 years old. Mr. Friedland specialized in estate, corporate and real estate law. He helped found the Bronx Council of Jewish Education and a Hebrew academy in the Bronx, and he served as chairman of the Greystone Jewish Center of Yonkers and as president of the Jewish Federation of Yonkers.

CLEVELAND, June 13 (UPI)--The Cleveland Cavaliers of the National Basketball Association officially named Bill Musselman head coach today, completing a house cleaning that began with the defection of Stan Albeck to the San Antonio Spurs earlier this week.

At 9:30 A.M., a half-hour before most of Manhattan's department stores unlock their doors for business, things are already stirring at Lord Taylor, where early arrivals are greeted with a free cup of coffee topped off with a rousing rendition of "The Star-Spangled Banner."

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 13-- The summer after her sophomore year at Old Dominion University, Nancy Lieberman found a perfect job. Dressed in the jazzy costume of a hostess for an oceanfront condominium, she barged up to strangers idling along Virginia Beach and persuaded them to take guided tours of a new apartment building.
