With the cry of "Play Ball!" Justice Lawrence E. Kahn arbitrated a dispute yesterday in Albany's State Supreme Court in which a l6-year-old boy charged he had been tricked into signing an agreement to play American Legion baseball with a team he did not like.

VENICE, June 13--West European leaders criticized the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today, charging that its continuing increase in crude oil prices threatened to inflict critical damage on the world's already fragile economy.

Jack Nicklaus and Tom Weiskopf, who shared a three-stroke lead in the first round of the 80th United States Open yesterday with record-tying 63's, parted company today in the second round. As a warm June day made the Baltusrol Golf Club's Lower Course drier and quicker, Nicklaus, a three-time winner of the Open, stayed in the lead, by two strokes, with a 71, one over par. This gave him a 36-hole total of 134, breaking by one shot the 36-hole record previously shared by Mike Souchak (1960), Bert Yancey (1968) and Tom Watson (1975).

Rich Serian, who has lived on the Island only six months, won two matches today and advanced to the quarterfinal round of the Long Island Golf Association's 56th annual amateur championship. Serian is 27 years old and plays out of Noyac in Sag Harbor. Today's two matches at the Nassau Country Club, he admitted, were only the fifth and sixth rounds of golf he had played this year. Yesterday, he shot a 76 to join 31 other qualifiers in match play.

The Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to discontinue a four-year-old half-fare program that affects 120,000 city schoolchildren. That action, which takes effect when the school year ends June 26, is expected to save the M.T.A. as much as $18 million a year. Unaffected by the decision are 369,500 schoolchildren who are covered by a plan that allows them to ride for free or to pay a one-way fare of 5 cents.

Brokerage-house stocks moved ahead briskly yesterday in a rising market that saw the Dow Jones industrial average close at its highest level since late February. Sugar issues also rose in response to higher prices for raw sugar. It was a market, analysts noted, that has been characterized this week by a rotation of group favorites. At midweek, energy stocks were the stars and two days ago casino issues scored the best gains. Yesterday, the energy issues generally lost ground.

Eighteen young women were presented to society last night at the annual Fairfield Debutante Ball. The event, held in a pink and white striped tent at the home of Mrs. Hubert T. Mandeville in Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn., will benefit the emergency room of the Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital.

The third major eruption of Mount St. Helens in less than a month hurled a new downpour of volcanic ash across the coasts of northern Oregon and southern Washington last night, but strong winds and heavy rain today ameliorated the worst problems from the ash. Threats of flooding from possible new mud flows and melted snow on the unpredictable mountain prompted the evacuation of hundreds of people. However, most of the evacuees were returning to their homes today as the mountain lapsed into relative quiescence, rains dampened the ash and the feared mud flows did not develop.

The Census Bureau said today that work on the 1980 count was running about two weeks behind schedule but expressed optimism that the census would be a success. Vincent P. Barabba, Director of the Census Bureau, said that 97 percent of the mailed census forms had been returned by respondents or retrieved by the census-takers who visit households that do not return the forms. However, many respondents who used the forms failed to answer all questions, he said.

Alison C. Wysong, a lawyer who had been attorney for the village of Sands Point, L.I., from 1920 to 1946, died Thursday in Hackettstown, N.J., where he had been living. He was 90 years old and previously lived in Port Washington, L.I., for 78 years. He was a founder of the First Federal Savings and Loan Association in that community. He is survived by a daughter, Marian of Mendham, N.J.; four sons, Alison C. of Florence, Ore., David G. of Higganum, Conn., William G. of Eugene, Ore., and James P. of Harrison, Me.; a brother, Donald of Ithaca, N.Y., and seven grandchildren.

International The Common Market leaders, at their meeting in Venice, urged full self-determination for the Palestinians and said the Palestine Liberation Organization should be ''associated with'' the Middle East peace talks. They also called for an end to Israel's ''territorial occupation'' of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, and said Israeli settlements in the occupied territories were ''a serious obstacle to the peace process,'' and that Israeli expropriation of Arab-owned land was ''illegal under international law.'' (Page 1, Column 1.) The Common Market nations' stand on the Middle East ''showed a sense of restraint'' and did not seem to jeopardize Washington's hope of progress in the negotiations with Egypt and Israel on Palestinian self-rule, Secretary of State Edmund S. Muskie said. He announced that Sol M. Linowitz, President Carter's special Middle East envoy, would resume the suspended autonomy talks with the heads of the Egyptian and Israeli delegations in Washington on July 2 and 3. (1:2.) South Africa said it destroyed, in a major ''shock attack,'' the operational headquarters in Angola of the South-West Africa People's Organization, the guerrillas opposing South African rule in South-West Africa. Prime Minister P.W. Botha seemed to indicate, in a report to Parliament, that the attack was continuing. (1:2-3.) National Ronald Reagan will not oust Bill Brock as chairman of the Republican National Committee, rejecting the advice of Senator Paul Lexalt of Nevada, his campaign chairman, and other advisers who had urged him to designate a more conservative chairman. (1:5.) A South Carolina Congressman was indicted in the F.B.I.'s Abscam inquiry. Representative John W. Jenrette Jr. was charged with sharing in a $50,000 bribery payment from an undercover Federal agent and with attempting to obtain an additional $125,000. A Democrat, Mr. Jenrette is the third member of Congress indicted as a result of the undercover investigation into political corruption. (1:2-4.) Mount St. Helens erupted for the third time in less than a month, showering volcanic ash across the coast of northern Oregon and southern Washington, but winds and heavy rains dispersed much of the ash. The explosion was heard 100 miles away. (6:1.) A reduction of 25,000 soldiers, proposed by the Senate Armed Services Committee, would have to be made in combat forces stationed in Europe and South Korea, said Gen. Edward C. Meyer, the Army Chief of Staff. The cutback is intended to improve the quality of Army manpower by reducing recruitment quotas at a time when insufficient numbers of high school graduates are enlisting. General Meyer said a formula for new enlistment levels was ''unmanageable'' and that it would be better to take the cut. (24:1-6.) Metropolitan A handgun control law was signed by Governor Carey, who said New York State now had ''the toughest handgun law in the country.'' The bill was signed only 10 hours after its enactment by the State Legislature. The law has two principal objectives: to provide a minimum sentence of one year for persons convicted of carrying a loaded, unlicensed handgun in public, and to reduce such a defendant's pleabargaining opportunities. (1:6.) Bills to allow casino gambling in New York State were revived in the Legislature when a compromise was reached by State Senator James H. Donovan and Assembly leader Stanley Fink, who had differing views on where casinos should be established and who should operate them. The State Senate and the Assembly were expected to finish passing eight bills by the end of the session. Passage by two consecutive Legislatures is needed to place an amendment on the ballot. (1:5-6.) An end to the half-fare program that has benefited 120,000 schoolchildren was voted by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which expects to save as much as $18 million a year. The program ends with the school year, June 26. The decision to end the four-year-old program does not affect 369,000 schoolchildren who ride free or pay a one-way fare of 5 cents. (25:4-6.) Michele Sindona was sentenced to 25 years in prison as a result of his conviction on March 27 of 65 counts of bank fraud that led to collapse of the Franklin National Bank in 1975, the largest bank failure in United States history. He was also fined $207,000. Federal prosecutors said they believed the sentence was the harshest ever given in such a case. Mr. Sindona is appealing his conviction. (25:4.) Shuttle buses eased the hardship among New Jersey commuters to New York stranded yesterday in the second day of the strike by PATH's carmen. A bus line provided emergency service from PATH stations in Hoboken and Jersey City to the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan, and to a makeshift depot on Canal Street on the Lower West Side. (26:5-6.) Business Digest, Page 29

The Golden State Foods Corporation said that GSF Holdings had increased its recent offer to acquire Golden State to $27.50 a share from $24 a share. Based on the 1.05 million common shares of Golden State stock outstanding, the new offer is valued at about $29 million. Golden State prepares and distributes food products to quick-service restaurants. McDonald's restaurants, its licensees and distributors accounted for some 92 percent of Golden State's sales for the 1979 fiscal year.

West European leaders criticized the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries today, charging that its continuing increase in crude oil prices threatened to inflict critical damage on the world's already fragile economy. At the end of their meeting, heads of government from the nine member countries of the European Economic Community said they were ready to try to negotiate a schedule of oil prices acceptable to the OPEC nations and to the oil-consuming countries. But they noted that the failure of the oil organization's 13 members to agree on a single price among themselves at their Algiers meeting this week made ''such a dialogue more difficult to achieve.''

A study to explore the possibility of a performing-arts center in Queens has suggested that the best spot would be in Long Island City, where transportation lines converge. The report was made by Anderson Notter Finegold Inc. of Boston for the Queens Performing Arts Center Advisory board under a state grant of $53,000, supported by the State Council on the Arts.

Ed and Shirley Burke qualified today for the hammer-throw final as The Athletics Congress national outdoor track and field championships began at Mount San Antonio College. Women do not compete in the hammer throw, an event for well-muscled men, but Shirley Burke is Ed Burke's coach and his wife of 19 years. Burke is a three-time national champion in the event (1966 to 1968) and is making a comeback at the age of 40 with a new style of throwing.

To the Editor: A full day has passed since the jackhammers destroyed the art deco panels on the Bonwit Teller building, and I am still trying to understand such supposed constructive destruction. How could New York allow such graffiti-free beauty to be ruined? I guess it's a way of showing we love New York. VAN TSAGARIS, New York, June 7, 1980

President Carter declared an emergency in Pennsylvania today, making the state eligible for Federal aid to help repair damage caused by tornadoes last week. A White House statement said that the action would permit the donation of Government-owned mobile homes to the state, to provide temporary housing for families who lost their homes.

Affiliated Publications Inc., publisher of The Boston Globe, said it had completed purchase of radio stations WHYN-AM and WHYN-FM in Springfield, Mass., for $5.1 million. * Adolph Coors Company said it will increase wholesale beer prices an average of 5 percent on July 14 to distributors in Arkansas, Nebraska and Missouri.

The military academies which turn out future generals and admirals graduated their first women officers this spring. And now, when the ink is still damp on their commissions, here are Congress and President conniving to keep women out of the lower military ranks.
WASHINGTON, June 13--The Census Bureau said today that work on the 1980 count was running about two weeks behind schedule but expressed optimism that the census would be a success.
More plant closings and layoffs were announced this week because of the developing economic recession. Among the announcements were the following:

VENICE, June 13--The European Economic Community backed full selfdetermination for the Palestianian people today and declared that the Palestine Liberation Organization should be "associated with" the negotiations for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

Bobby Turner, a senior from the University of Louisville, who was chosen in the seventh round of the National Basketball Association's college draft by the Knicks on Tuesday, received approval yesterday to sign a contract with the Knicks.

President Carter, who has expanded Federal support for the cities by billions of dollars in the last three years, would trim the budget somewhat this year but promises ''other steps'' if the recession grows worse. Senator Edward M. Kennedy wants to spend $12 billion additional to stimulate the economy, with much of the money going to cities and their residents.

The General Host Corporation announced that it had sold 430,600 shares of Ponderosa common stock to Ponderosa System Inc. for $7.3 million. The block represented about 7.6 percent of Ponderosa's outstanding common. The shares were acquired by General Host in May. Harris J. Ashton, chairman and chief executive of General Host, said his company would ''realize a gain on the transaction of approximately $2 million before taxes.'' Ponderosa operates a chain of steakhouses, and General Host is a manufacturer, distributor and retailer of foods.

PEKING (UPI) - New Jersey has established sister-state relations with the Chinese province of Zhejiang, Governor Byrne said yesterday. Mr. Byrne, currently on a tour of China, signed the protocol at a state banquet Thursday night in the city of Hangzhou. He said the two states hope now to develop extensive educational, cultural, scientific and trade relations. The Adirondack Ends Service Aug. 2 WASHINGTON (AP) - Service will end Aug. 2 on the deficit-plagued New York City-to-Montreal passenger train known as The Adirondack, Amtrak officials announced. The decision stemmed from a failure of Amtrak and New York State officials to reach agreement on continued subsidies for the service, which lost $1.8 million last year.

A number of banks throughout the nation, led by Chase Manhattan, Morgan Guaranty and Chemical, reduced their prime rates yesterday to 12 percent from 13 percent. Others, including the Security Pacific National Bank of Los Angeles, the Mellon Bank of Pittsburgh and the First Pennsylvania Bank of Philadelphia, lowered their prime rates to 12 1/2 percent, following similar reductions Thursday by the Bank of America, Citibank and Manufacturers Hanover Trust, three of the top lending institutions in the country.

The executive vice president of the National Urban League, John Jacob, said yesterday that league officials were ''disturbed at the slow pace of the investigation'' into the shooting last month of the organization's president, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., in Fort Wayne, Ind. ''We have grown increasingly disturbed and distressed over the diversion of public attention away from the horrible nature of the crime and onto matters of speculation, innuendo and gossip,'' Mr. Jacob said.

A Federal court judge tonight ordered the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to pay $1.8 billion in damages to the MCI Communications Corporation, a small telecommunications company, after a jury found that A.T.&T. had violated Federal antitrust laws in denying service to MCI. The jury decided that MCI suffered $600 million in damages as a result of A.T.&T.'s denying it the intracity phone connections it needed to complete a long-distance system on its own microwave network.

IN other years, if Jack Nicklaus had shot a 63 in the first round of the United States Open and followed with a 71 to establish a 36-hole record of 134 for the world's most prestigious golf tournament, the other pros would have conceded. But now Jack Nicklaus is 40 years old, he has not won a tournament for nearly two years and the other pros seem to be wondering if he can maintain his putting strokes through two more rounds. Without quite saying so, Jack Nicklaus seems to be wondering that, too. But he would rather not discuss it, thank you.After his record-tying 63, he was enduring his usual postround inquisition in the green and white striped press tent at Baltusrol when he was asked to talk about the self-doubts that have crept into his psyche.

Willie Aikens knocked in three runs with a pair of homers and a grounder, leading the Kansas City Royals to a 4-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight. Aikens's second homer of the game and fifth of the year, leading off the Royals' seventh, broke a 1-1 tie. The Royals made it 4-1 with a two-run eighth. U.L. Washington doubled and was driven in by Hal McRae's single. Aikens, who had homered in the second, knocked in the second run of the inning with a fielder's choice grounder.

Fritz Rikko, a member of the music faculty of the Juilliard School for 25 years, died yesterday at a Manhattan nursing home. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Rikko, a specialist in Baroque music, was familiar to New York audiences through a series of open-air concerts of the Collegium Musicum in Washington Square Park from 1956 to 1974.

In negotiations on the Koch administration's two previous budgets, the Mayor tended to dig his heels in and not move, despite the demands of the City Council and Board of Estimate. But this year Mr. Koch displayed a talent for accommodation. The result was a budget that contained nearly all the Mayor's priority requests, achieved in an atmosphere from which no elected official had to slink away battered and bruised. It was ''very significant,'' Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. said, that the Mayor could get a unanimous Board of Estimate vote and a nearly unanimous City Council vote on a spending plan that included $141 million in generally unpopular tax increases on such things as beer and liquor and water and sewer use.

To the Editor: The destruction of the Bonwit Teller building's bas-relief sculptures is an act of vandalism which is all too indicative of the value we New Yorkers place on our cultural heritage. The demolition of the building itself was bad enough; couldn't the so-called developers have stayed their destructive hands for an instant to preserve for the world a bit of America's artistic past?The crime outrages us all the more when we realize that its perpetrators have acted with an impunity that is guaranteed them by law.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Mrs. Carter, Visiting Illinois, Calls for Democratic Unity

The State Department deplored South Africa's raid into Angola today, saying it was ''particularly unfortunate'' at a time when prospects existed for progress toward an internationally recognized settlement in Namibia.

If the choice is between finding places in jail for people who commit crimes or finding more room in cemeteries for innocent people who die, I prefer to find the jail space.'' - Governor Carey. (1:6.)
ALBANY, June 13--Governor Carey declared today that New York State now had "the toughest handgun law in the country" as he signed a new measure 10 hours after it received final legislative approval.

William Allan Patterson, a pioneer in the aviation industry who headed United Airlines from 1934 until 1966 and who remained as director emeritus and honorary chairman of both the airline and its parent company, UAL Inc., died yesterday in Glenview Ill., after a prolonged illness. He was 80 years old.

ALBANY, Saturday, June 14--After weeks of fitful bargaining, the Republican-led State Senate passed a bill early today that would allow the state to tax oil companies to subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The new owners of the Barbizon Hotel, one of best-known women's hotels in the city, are considering various possibilities such as converting it into a luxury hotel, an office building, an apartment building or keeping it as it is, those involved in the planning said in interviews yesterday.
"It's pretty, isn't it?" Halston told wellwishers after the showing the other day of his fall made-to-order collection in his eyrie high up in the Olympic Tower.

A Federal District Court judge in Manhattan has granted the Shubert Organization the right to manage the National Theater in Washington. The Nederlander Theatrical Corporation, the Shuberts' prime competitor in booking theaters for shows, had filed suit to prevent the Shuberts from taking over the management of the National, a Washington landmark and one of the capital's principal theaters.

Bowing to pressure from party moderates, Ronald Reagan agreed today to retain Bill Brock as chairman of the Republican National Committee. The decision averted the possibility of a split in the party a month before its national convention. At a joint news conference, Mr. Reagan and Mr. Brock said that Drew Lewis, a National Committeeman from Pennsylvania who is the Reagan campaign chairman for that state, would take a new post as deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee.

The House voted by a wide margin today to allow continuation of basic Government research into supersonic passenger aircraft. The action came as the House authorized $5.6 billion for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, in the financial year beginning Oct. 1.

The confusion and the congestion that marked the first day of the strike against the Port Authority Trans-Hudson railroad on Thursday eased considerably yesterday. More shuttle buses were pressed into service and many commuters apparently took the day off.
Following is the text of a declaration on the Middle East by the European Council, issued at the conclusion of a two-day conference in Venice today: (1)

Governor Carey declared today that New York State now had ''the toughest handgun law in the country'' as he signed a new measure 10 hours after it received final legislative approval. The law, which is designed to restrict plea bargaining and require minimum one-year prison terms for most persons convicted of carrying unlicensed, loaded handguns in public places, cleared the Assembly shortly before midnight and the State Senate at 1:10 A.M. after sharp debates in both houses. It will go into effect in 60 days.

Felix Ira Shaffner, a former professor of economics at Harvard, died yesterday at his summer home in Laconia, N.H. He was 76 years old and lived in St. Petersburg, Fla. Mr. Shaffner, who retired in 1969, was an authority on business cycles. Mr. Shaffner was chairman of the War Assets Administration in 1952. He taught economics at New York University and at Georgetown University before going to Harvard.

To the Editor: To eliminate criticism of the JFK Express as wasteful, while preserving the basic service, transit officials could have non-JFKbound passengers, who pay the 50-cent fare anyway, board and get off at any scheduled stop in Manhattan (or at Jay Street in Brooklyn). Passengers bound for JFK would pay the additional fare, which could be collected at Jay Street.Permitting short-run passengers to use the JFK trains would alleviate congestion on the regular trains. Initially, signs and conductor announcements could alert riders to the limited stops. SUSANNE BERARD New York, June 5, 1980

The summer after her sophomore year at Old Dominion University, Nancy Lieberman found a perfect job. Dressed in the jazzy costume of a hostess for an oceanfront condominium, she barged up to strangers idling along Virginia Beach and persuaded them to take guided tours of a new apartment building. The fearless saleswoman, who also happens to be one of the world's best female basketball players, broke all known records for luring potential real estate buyers. At a commission of $5 a head, she earned $1,200 in four weeks, quitting early most days to shoot baskets at a local church.

By the time she found her way to a restored Victorian town house in the shabby Mission district, 28-year-old Diane had separated from her husband, lost her job and narrowly escaped dying in a hospital emergency room. ''I couldn't stop drinking,'' said Diane, brushing away her long dark hair with a hand that still trembled. ''I tried everything from dumping drinks down the sink to moving to a dry county, but it didn't help.''

Warren Cromartie stroked his fourth consecutive single to score Rodney Scott with the tiebreaking run in the seventh inning as the Montreal Expos edged the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4-3, tonight, tying a club record with their 10th victory in a row. Scott beat out an infield hit with one out. After Brad Mills moved him to second with a grounder, Gary Carter was walked intentionally. Cromartie then singled off reliever Steve Howe (1-3).

An elaborate ground-breaking ceremony for the new American Stock Exchange that was to be presided over next Tuesday by Governor Carey and Mayor Koch was canceled suddenly yesterday because of unexplained snags in lease negotiations. The project also ran into trouble in Albany, where a State Supreme Court justice surprised state officials by signing a temporary restraining order that would bar financing of the project.

President Carter, who has expanded Federal support for the cities by billions of dollars in the last three years, would trim the budget somewhat this year but promises ''other steps'' if the recession grows worse. Senator Edward M. Kennedy wants to spend $12 billion additional to stimulate the economy, with much of the money going to cities and their residents.
Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, was sentenced in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to 25 years in prison and fined $207,000 for his role in the collapse of the Franklin National Bank.

"O.K., here's a Guinness paper cup," David Boehm said, fishing out a cup from a swamp of products piled in disarray on shelves behind his desk. "Here's the Guinness board game. Awfully cute, I think. Now where are those greeting cards? How's this Guinness T-shirt strike you? Ah, here are some of the trading cards that go in bread loaves. Did I mention the Guinness movie?"

MOSCOW, June 13--About 70,000 workers at the Togliatti Automobile Plant on the Volga River southeast of Moscow went on strike for two days early in May, according to unconfirmed reports reaching here.

Probably since its inception in 1913 and certainly since the end of the World War II, the Federal Reserve has suffered from a credibility gap concerning changes in its monetary policy. In an attempt to maintain some uncertainty ...
WASHINGTON, June 13--President Carter directed Government agencies today to begin experimenting with more flexible methods of regulation.

WASHINGTON, June 13--Mayor Koch brought his coast-to-coast, two-party political roadshow back east to the Democratic Platform Committee hearings today, appealing to his party to call for aid to the cities in its platform for the Presidential campaign.
DETROIT, June 13--The Big Three American auto makers reported today that sales of new American-made passenger cars continued to drop in early June, but the rate of decline appeared to be slowing.
Vida Blue took no nonsense from the New York Mets or their mystique last night as he pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 3-1 victory and stopped the sizzling Mets cold on four hits.
AKRON, Ohio, June 13--Summit County Probate Judge James V. Barbuto was found guilty here today of gross sexual imposition and of intimidation.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 13--Severiano Ballesteros, the British Open and Masters champion, was disqualified this morning from the United States Open because he missed his 9:45 tee time in the second round.
SHERMAN OAKS, Calif., June 13 (AP) --Richard Pryor, the comedian, who suffered nearly fatal burns, was taken off intravenous feeding today but remained in critical condition, his doctor said.

DETROIT, June 13--Pete Karagozian was out talking to the boys the other day, pausing at a truck stop near the Ambassador Bridge to talk to other drivers. The boys seemed to like the wavy-haired man with the pencil-thin mustache, calling to him, shaking his hand. The owner of the restaurant asked for his autograph.

On this first weekend of the PATH strike, Conrail will not run its four emergency shuttle trains between Newark's Pennsylvania Station and Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan. Regular commuter trains will make that run.

SHARON, Conn.--Outside, the fireflies flicker silently along the village green; there is no sound but the rustling of wind in the ancient trees overhead. Inside Town Hall, however, the lights are burning late as the Republican Town Committee meets to look over a couple of candidates for statewide office.
The nation's money supply rose sharply in the most recent reporting week, the Federal Reserve said yesterday in a report that indicated the Fed's effort to ease credit may be working.

Along with such pests as jackrabbits and kangaroos, Australia ''a few years from now'' is being afflicted by predatory motorcycle gangs. An elite leather-clad highway police force has been established to oppose them. This is the flimsy plot line of ''Mad Max,'' which opens today at the Embassy 5, but it provides an adequate framework for some vivid chase-and-crash sequences across the unpopulated outback and a heavy dose of sadism with obvious homosexual overtones.

Richard Pryor, the comedian, who suffered nearly fatal burns, was taken off intravenous feeding today but remained in critical condition, his doctor said. ''He's more alert today than at any time since entering the hospital'' on Monday, said Gary Swaye, assistant executive director of Sherman Oaks Community Hospital. Doctors continued to monitor the 39-year-old Emmy and Grammy winner for infection or other complications, Mr. Swaye said at a news conference.
First it was tornadoes in Kansas City. Then volcanic ash in Seattle and earthquakes during the California series. Tonight, the Yankees had to contend with Billy Martin and his Oakland A's.

In Connecticut this spring, the General Assembly's price for approving a 7 percent increase in welfare benefits was a tough ''workfare'' bill requiring cities to find jobs or useful training for ''employable'' recipients of state aid. Welfare officials are understandably worried that it will prove to be merely punitive for some poor people or cost them state subsidies. It is much easier to thrust rakes into people's hands than to steer them into lasting jobs. But the law's effect need not be hostile to welfare. So long as ''workfare'' is taken to be a serious employment program, it may help show how to turn a work requirement into a useful job assistance program.

President Carter declared an emergency in Pennsylvania today, making the state eligible for Federal aid to help repair damage caused by tornadoes last week. A White House statement said that the action would permit the donation of Government-owned mobile homes to the state, to provide temporary housing for families who lost their homes.

The Midland Company of Cincinnati announced an agreement in principle to sell for $48 million all of the consumer loan receivables of its sudsidiary, the Midland Guardian Company, to the ITT Consumer Financial Corporation of Minneapolis. The price is subject to adjustment scheduled in August. Midland is a holding company with interests in mobile homes, river transport, finance and insurance. It said that Midland Guardian would continue to finance mobile home purchases and noted that the consumer loans receivables to be sold constituted about one-fifth of its outstanding finance receivables.
Hiroomi Kurisu, former Chairman of the Japanese Joint Chiefs of Staff, is running for Parliament in the June 22 general election on a one-plank platform of rearmament.

Severiano Ballesteros, the British Open and Masters champion, was disqualified this morning from the United States Open because he missed his 9:45 tee time in the second round. Ballesteros said he thought his starting time was 10:45 until he learned differently from the driver of the courtesy car that took him to the course from the Surburban Hotel in nearby Summit. The starting times had been published last week.

The executive vice president of the National Urban League, John Jacob, said yesterday that league officials were ''disturbed at the slow pace of the investigation'' into the shooting last month of the organization's president, Vernon E. Jordan Jr., in Fort Wayne, Ind. ''We have grown increasingly disturbed and distressed over the diversion of public attention away from the horrible nature of the crime and onto matters of speculation, innuendo and gossip,'' Mr. Jacob said.

First there was a move to deregulate the airlines, then trucking and then railroads, but now Chicago is pondering perhaps the ultimate step in loosening controls on a transportation industry: free enterprise for taxicab operators. A number of cities have opened their cab industries to most operators, but a measure introduced today in the City Council would not only facilitate entry but also permit cab operators to charge what they wished without the approval of the city government.

Michele Sindona, the Italian financier, was sentenced in Federal Court in Manhattan yesterday to 25 years in prison and fined $207,000 for his role in the collapse of the Franklin National Bank. Mr. Sindona, who is appealing his conviction, would be eligible for parole after serving one-third of his sentence. The bank, which failed in 1974, was an important economic force on Long Island and was the largest bank ever to have collapsed in United States history.

SAN FRANCISCO--By the time she found her way to a restored Victorian town house in the shabby Mission district, 28-year-old Diane had separated from her husband, lost her job and narrowly escaped dying in a hospital emergency room.

A bitter fight for control of the Diamond International Corporation--supposedly settled amicably in a 62-page agreement with Sir James Goldsmith only 24 hours before--took a new turn yesterday with the emergence of a multimillion-dollar mystery buyer of Diamond stock.

STRATFORD, Ontario, June 12-- "Titus Andronicus" is Shakespeare's most savage pit--a caldron of rape, maiming, killings and cannibalism. It is tragedy without catharsis, Rome at the fall, "a wilderness of tigers." In the pulsating Stratford Shakespeare Festival revival, directed by Brian Bedford, ...

Mayor Koch brought his coast-to-coast, twoparty political roadshow back east to the Democratic Platform Committee hearings today, appealing to his party to call for aid to the cities in its platform for the Presidential campaign. ''Did I do pretty good?'' he asked, and the answer he heard was that he had. So well, in fact, that one member of the committee asked that the Mayor be given five additional minutes to speak, and the participants in the otherwise dull session quickly agreed.

Vida Blue took no nonsense from the New York Mets or their mystique last night as he pitched the San Francisco Giants to a 3-1 victory and stopped the sizzling Mets cold on four hits. It was the seventh straight game won by Blue, who has not lost to anybody in five weeks. He flirted with the Mets' flair for mischief several times, most dramatically when they loaded the bases with nobody out in the third inning. But he struck out the next two batters, escaped at the cost of one run and prevented any late magic, rally or upset.

A Superior Court judge ruled today that the Grace Community Church in Panorama City, the largest Protestant church in Los Angeles County, could be sued for ''spiritual counseling malpractice'' in the suicide of a 24-year-old man. Judge Thomas Murphy said that the First Amendment's protections on the free exercise of religion did not preclude the man's parents, a Roman Catholic couple, from suing the church for wrongful death and negligence.

Beth Daniel had an eagle and Dale Lundquist had a birdie on the 18th hole today, and the results left them tied for the lead at 138 after the second round of a $150,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament. Miss Daniel sank an eight-foot putt for an eagle on the 492-yard final hole and finished with a 68. About an hour later, Miss Lundquist also approached the 18th green with a shot at an eagle, but her putt from 20 feet lipped the cup and she tapped in for a birdie that completed a round of 70.

One of the most unprofitable occupations at the bridge table consists of doubling opponents in a game they clearly think they will make. This should never be tried on the basis of high-card strength alone, unless there is good reason to think the opponents are out of their depth because of some confusion. Favorable indications are a bad trump break that will surprise the declarer, high cards well-placed for the defense, and an auction that shows the declaring side is at full stretch.

To the Editor: Representative Mario Biaggi insists in a June 7 letter that he, and some of his Congressional colleagues, are concerned above all with human rights in Northern Ireland and not in making political capital out of a tragic situation.However, Mr. Biaggi has been closely allied for many years with the U.S.-based Irish Northern Aid Committee (Noraid), clearly seen by the Irish Government and the overwhelming majority of our people, north and south, as a front organization for the Provisional I.R.A. Noraid members have been convicted of running guns for use in sectarian murders in Northern Ireland. Mr. Biaggi has also been associated publicly with prominent I.R.A. supporters on his visits to Ireland.

THE burglary of a suburban Boston bank over the Memorial Day weekend, in which thieves escaped with $5 million in securities and other property, points up one of the common misconceptions about safedeposit boxes. People rent safe-deposit boxes thinking they are purchasing safety, but, sadly, their valuables are not automatically protected against loss if the boxes are burglarized or destroyed by fire or flood. The standard language on the safe-deposit agreement between banks and customers usually limits the bank's liability to the ''exercise of ordinary caring.''

The Bronx County Democratic committee voted almost unanimously yesterday to endorse the Republican county leader, John D. Calandra, for re-election to the State Senate. The cross-endorsement of a Republican Senator was the second in three days. On Wednesday the Staten Island Democrats formally gave their backing to John J. Marchi, the second-ranking Republican in the Senate and chairman of its Finance Committee.

The Ford Motor Company today called a General Motors Corporation analysis of Ford's automatic transmissions ''as phony as a $3 bill.'' The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has said that Ford may have to recall 16 million cars because of 6,000 accidents, 1,700 injuries and 98 deaths in accidents where the car lurched into reverse after the driver thought he had set the car in park.

A Federal judge ordered A.T.&T. to pay $1.8 billion in treble damages to MCI Communications, after the jury in the case ruled that MCI had suffered $600 million in damages when A.T.&T. denied intracity phone connections needed to complete long-distance telephone calls on MCI's microwave network. The award is the largest ever set in an antitrust case. (Page 1.) Diamond International stock has been purchased by a mystery buyer. Wall Street professionals speculated that Harry A. Merlo, chairman of Louisiana-Pacific, was the multimillion-dollar buyer, but a Merlo spokesman denied this. Diamond supposedly had settled its takeover fight with Sir James Goldsmith only a day earlier. (29.)

Volkswagen of America Inc. announced today that it was recalling 155,000 diesel automobiles because of reports of surging, or self-acceleration speedup, in some engines. The surging does not affect the safe operation of the vehicles, the company said. Owners are being asked to take their cars to dealers for modifications at the end of August. The repairs will be made free.

At 9:30 A.M., a half-hour before most of Manhattan's department stores unlock their doors for business, things are already stirring at Lord & Taylor, where early arrivals are greeted with a free cup of coffee topped off with a rousing rendition of ''The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Although coffee by the dawn's early light has been a tradition at Lord & Taylor's Fifth Avenue store since 1930 - Claudette Colbert, Greta Garbo, Mrs. Douglas MacArthur and Leo Durocher are among the early risers who have sipped free coffee from the store's white porcelain demi-tasse cups - it is a tradition that still catches most shoppers by surprise.

Tom Paciorek and Jim Anderson each hit bases-empty home runs and the Seattle Mariners held on to beat the Baltimore Orioles, 7-6, tonight. Six Mariners drove in runs off Mike Flanagan (6-5) in support of their winning pitcher, Glenn Abbott (6-2). Abbott needed relief help from Shane Rawley and Dave Heaverlo.

Taylor Caldwell's daughter has obtained a temporary court order preventing her mother, a stroke victim, from being moved out of the Buffalo area. Miss Caldwell, the 79-year-old author of more than 30 books, was described by her daughter, Mary Fried, as being ''temporarily physically incapable'' of being moved. Mrs. Fried obtained a restraining order Thursday against Robert Prestie, who married Miss Caldwell two years ago and who intends to move her to Greenwich, Conn.

O.K., here's a Guinness paper cup,'' David Boehm said, fishing out a cup from a swamp of products piled in disarray on shelves behind his desk. ''Here's the Guinness board game. Awfully cute, I think. Now where are those greeting cards? How's this Guinness Tshirt strike you? Ah, here are some of the trading cards that go in bread loaves. Did I mention the Guinness movie?'' Every addict of superlatives is familiar with the Guinness Book of World Records that tells you things like the longest recorded distance for catching a thrown grape in the mouth (259 feet). But Guinness, not content being strictly a record book and a dark creamy stout, seems bent on setting a world mark for the number of licensing applications to spring from one product - the book. A veritable industry of Guinness products has come into being that generates millions of dollars a year of sales.

But now that he has taken on the additional responsibility of the presidency of Stanford University, the outlet for relaxation that Mr. Kennedy finds through the Mister Flood Society may be more important than ever.

Along with such pests as jackrabbits and kangaroos, Australia ''a few years from now'' is being afflicted by predatory motorcycle gangs. An elite leather-clad highway police force has been established to oppose them. This is the flimsy plot line of ''Mad Max,'' which opens today at the Embassy 5, but it provides an adequate framework for some vivid chase-and-crash sequences across the unpopulated outback and a heavy dose of sadism with obvious homosexual overtones.

A businessman, his wife and a medical student were killed today in separate attacks by unidentified gunmen, the federal police said. Carlos Bickford Schafer, owner of a furniture factory, and his wife, Krista Neutz de Bickford, were returning home from shopping when they were attacked. Their car went out of control and hit a tree, the police said. Both received several gunshot wounds.

The Census Bureau said today that work on the 1980 count was running about two weeks behind schedule but expressed optimism that the census would be a success. Vincent P. Barabba, Director of the Census Bureau, said that 97 percent of the mailed census forms had been returned by respondents or retrieved by the census-takers who visit households that do not return the forms. However, many respondents who used the forms failed to answer all questions, he said.

To the Editor: Much has been made of the attractive issue of being ''born again.'' Jimmy Carter has used this boon, however sincerely, for some time. More recently one finds reports from the Reagan camp that their candidate, although using the message in a more subdued fashion, is also a ''born again'' Christian, and why not? Anderson has, in effect, a different kind of symbolic version, a one-upmanship in becoming reborn in a new, independent candidacy and without his past strong conservatism.There are a lot of advantages beyond the religious support it may bring to be reborn. The attraction lies in the assumption that one is cleansed of past errors and now begins with a clean slate. One is given another chance of becoming perfect, shedding all the past mistakes, burdens and disappointments. Along the way, of course, one certainly disavows any connection with the Devil and other forms of corrupt association.

The Capital Holding Corporation, a Louisville, Ky., insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy the National Liberty Corporation, a mail-order health and life insurer based in Valley Forge, Pa., for about $359 million. The transaction is subject to a definitive agreement between the companies and approval by shareholders and regulatory agencies. It is scheduled to close in the first few days of 1981.

Just before the intermission - and well after the audience has abandoned all hope - there is a revivifying surprise in ''Chase a Rainbow,'' the new musical at the Theater Four. When the show's dutiful but dull cast slogs its way through an otherwise forgettable number about New York bag ladies, we suddenly realize that one person on stage is determined to have fun. Her name is Virginia Sandifur, and she is a tall woman with tousled brown curls, a modest grin and a voice tinged ever so slightly with whiskey. As she sails about the stage on very loose limbs -doing a precise turn here, selling a silly lyric there - Miss Sandifur doesn't look like any ragtag vagrant. She looks instead like the kind of open-hearted, self-assured musicalcomedy heroine that they don't write shows for anymore. The impression is confirmed in Act II, when Miss Sandifur, now playing a dreary suburban wife, gets to sing two ballads. The songs are nothing, but her delivery is so clear and honest that we tune them out and start to imagine her singing other numbers more to our liking. By the final curtain, I thought I had heard the actress do about half of the Sarah Brown songs from ''Guys and Dolls.'' For theatergoers who would like to see a good show on stage rather than conjure one up in their heads, not even Miss Sandifur will justify the time spent with ''Chase a Rainbow.'' This is a musical that seeks to celebrate mediocrity, and its style effortlessly echoes its content. The evening's hero, Richard, is a kind of poor man's Wallace Stevens. He's a ''weekend writer'' who can't decide whether to keep his cushy job at the Xerox Corporation or ''chase a rainbow'' and go after the Pulitzer Prize. By the end of the evening, he has sold an article to Field and Stream and decided, as Sammy Davis Jr. might put it, that he's gotta be me. Played by Ted Pugh with all the wan charm of a television game-show host, Richard is the dullest character to appear at the center of a musical since Liv Ullmann's Mama.

Felix Ira Shaffner, a former professor of economics at Harvard, died yesterday at his summer home in Laconia, N.H. He was 76 years old and lived in St. Petersburg, Fla. Mr. Shaffner, who retired in 1969, was an authority on business cycles. Mr. Shaffner was chairman of the War Assets Administration in 1952. He taught economics at New York University and at Georgetown University before going to Harvard.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Mrs. Carter, Visiting Illinois, Calls for Democratic Unity

In a four-hour speech before the Egyptian People's Assembly on May 14, President Anwar el-Sadat outlined his new program for peace, democracy and prosperity. Egypt, he said, would devote 5 percent of its efforts to peace and 95 percent to prosperity. On May 23, Egyptians, in a referendum, endorsed a number of constitutional changes that would guarantee democracy. How genuine is Mr. Sadat's democracy? According to its Constitution, Egypt is a socialist democratic republic. It is a mixture of a parliamentary and a presidential system of government, with the scales tilting in favor of the latter. The People's Assembly is elected by popular secret ballot every five years. The Constitution confers on the president the power to appoint 10 additional members to the Assembly, a prerogative that gives Mr. Sadat certain political advantage. Moreover, one of the new constitutional changes provides for a consultative assembly of 210 members, one-third of whom will be appointed by the president. It is not yet clear what powers the new assembly will have, but it is not expected to replace the People's Assembly.

Around this time of year, residents are bracing themselves for what some call ''the invasion of the posture people,'' referring to that influx of lithe, well-proportioned young bodies, their carriage erect almost to the point of exaggeration, that signals the third season of the American Dance Festival here, beginning June 17. In the shops and restaurants on the fringe of Duke University's East Campus, where the 300 full-time dance students will be in residence for the six-week session, it means the sudden appearance of striking women wearing leotards, wrapped in long billowing skirts and hair pinned up in chignons.

Regular commuter trains will make that run. Transport of New Jersey is discontinuing its shuttle bus service from Hoboken to Canal Street until Monday. Regular No. 63 buses will run from the Hoboken Terminal to the Port Authority terminal on Eighth Avenue. Some extra bus service from Grove Street and Journal Square in Jersey City will be available.

Just as unprecedented supplies of heroin are expected to reach the United States, the nation's drug policy is sputtering badly. Federal funds for drug treatment programs have been cut lately, and the White House Strategy Council on Drug Abuse has not met for seven months. Plainly, the Administration needs to put its drug policy in order. The danger seems indisputable. Huge new supplies of heroin from Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan are already recorded in Western Europe, where the number of addicts in several countries is rising sharply. From Euro, according to the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration, the stuff moves to the United States. More heroin on the streets would push prices down and potency up. Easier access will mean wider use. That's what happened in the late 1960's when 6 metric tons of heroin, most of it from Turkey, created a drug abuse crisis. This time, authorities say, more than 10 times the amount available in the late 60's may end up in the United States. Government is unprepared.

First there was a move to deregulate the airlines, then trucking and then railroads, but now Chicago is pondering perhaps the ultimate step in loosening controls on a transportation industry: free enterprise for taxicab operators. A number of cities have opened their cab industries to most operators, but a measure introduced today in the City Council would not only facilitate entry but also permit cab operators to charge what they wished without the approval of the city government.

Nine other selections, including Durand Macklin, picked by the Nets, were found to be improper because each of the players had college eligibility remaining.

George Zahringer, who tried to keep a stiff upper lip when his clubs were stolen two weeks ago, and Rich Serian, who did not know the location of the tournament course earlier this week, advanced to the final round of the Long Island Golf Association's 56th amateur championship today. The 36-hole final will be on the 6,648-yard, par 35, 35-70 Nassau Country Club course tomorrow. Both players won two matches today. Zahringer defeated Mark Diamond of Pine Hollow, 2 and 1, then turned back Don Lizak of Southampton, 6 and 5. Serian ousted Merrick McQuilling of North Hills, 1 up, and Peter Van Ingen of the Garden City Golf Club, 3 and 2.

Alice E. Ganzel's assertion in her letter to The Connecticut Weekly of June 1 that ''the plan is to buy up dilapidated inner-city real estate, fix up the buildings for group homes and then hire the unemployed to care for them,'' has the facts wrong. Mrs. Ganzel is writing about group homes for mentally retarded persons, and there is nothing in the history of the development of such homes in Connecticut to date that lends support to her statement.

The global population explosion is losing some of its force, a new United Nations . report says, but the biggest gains are taking place in the poorest nations and threatening new misery. By the end of the century the pace of population growth is expected to fall by 20 percent, to 16 births per thousand a year, compared with 20 per thousand now. This will still mean a rise in world population from 4.4 billion to 6.2 billion, causing ''explosive growth'' in the already overcrowded cities of the third world.

Evelyn S. Lampman, an author of children's books, died last night of cancer in a Portland hospital. She was 73 years old. Mrs. Lampman wrote 51 books since 1948, all but one for the juvenile market. The exception was ''Of Mikes and Men,'' a fictionalized account of her early experiences as a writer for Portland radio stations.

A spot check of two registered water-testing laboratories - the Stepney Water Laboratory in Trumbull and the Ellis A. Tarlton Laboratory in Danbury - indicates that testing of an individual water supply costs an average of $25 for the basic analysis.

GUILFORD IN the summertime a diner's fancy often turns to thoughts of the shore. Long a favorite of those who succumb to such siren songs is the Little Stone House, which faces the wharf and harbor here. The setting is a pretty one, and the sea breezes are usually cool and inviting. Would that the food were better! It is possible that the Little Stone House is a victim of its own popularity. Several large rooms are often packed with diners, who seem willing to put up with slow service and generally pedestrian food served on plastic mats (which get rather gummy on occasion) at steep prices. One supposes that the sense of eating fresh seafood on the shore overwhelms or suspends critical judgment.

More than three million Western Europeans, armed with cameras and guidebooks, are expected to take to the air for the United States this year. The European invasion of America, heavier this year than ever before, has three primary elements. The first is economic: newly affluent Europeans with strong currencies that give them greater purchasing power against the dollar.

To the Sports Editor: After spending three full days attending the appeal hearing on the decision of the Pimlico stewards to declare Codex the winner of the Preakness, I feel an obligation to praise the manner in which this most unusual proceeding was conducted. I am a racing enthusiast of the first order. I attended the Preakness and was a supporter of Genuine Risk with both my money and my mouth.

IF a neighbor runs his power lawnmower while you're having a family barbecue or installs a noisy air-conditioner right across from your bedroom window, what do you do? Most people turn a deaf ear or suffer in silence, according to the Westchester police. But if a neighbor turns up his stereo or has a loud late-night party, what then? That's when the police get called, but they don't usually issue a summons. They just ask quietly if the offender will please cut out the racket.

SUMMER will have its flies,'' grumbled Ralph Waldo Emerson, but summer also has its free outdoor concerts, so it's really not a bad deal after all. Today, for instance, you can start out with a 3 o'clock program in Hartford's Bushnell Park by the First Company Governor's Foot Guard Band with an alternate date for the same place tomorrow at 7 P.M. if it should be dastardly enough to rain. Then, at 7:30 tonight, the New Haven Symphony will present the first of three free concerts on the quiet, comfortable upper green at Yale, behind the churches on Temple Street. Murry Sidlin will be conducting what are billed as ''light, semiclassical and old Broadway favorites,'' but classical purists can take solace in the presence of such presentable fare as the Saint-Saens Introduction and Rondo Capriccioso for violin and orchestra, with concertmaster Paul Kantor as soloist, and Tchaikovsky's ''1812 Overture'' tonight, plus works to come on the next two Sundays by Mozart, Sibelius, Vaughan Williams and Elgar.

OUT of all the investigations of Connecticut nursing homes this year have come a myriad of recommendations for improving the quality of nursing-home care. One of the more perceptive proposals appeared here recently (''Help for Nursing-Home Patients,'' Opinion Page, May 25). Robert Schwartz, a special assistant to State Senator Joseph Lieberman and a professor of gerontology, touched on a significant point - the value of using advisory councils to monitor nursing-home facilities. Indeed, in addition to the Jewish Home in New Haven that Mr. Schwartz mentions, all other nonprofit nursing homes in Connecticut have such advisory groups, which are their boards of directors. This voluntary presence, whose only concern is to insure the best possible care for the homes' residents, is one of the keys to the high quality for which nonprofit homes are known. The boards are legally responsible for the facility's operations.

New York State's tourism slogan - ''I H NY'' - would be stamped on all state license plates manufactured after next Jan. 1 under a bill given final passage tonight by the Assembly. The new plates would appear on the streets next June. The ''I Love New York'' bill passed, 80 to 49, after a short, spirited debate. Assemblyman Dominick L. DiCarlo opposed it, saying every car would be ''a moving billboard.'' But Assemblyman John A. Esposito said: ''This is forever, this bill - can you imagine a Governor ever repealing it?''

THERE is not a baseball player alive who would not give anything to experience the joy and thrill of a five-for-five day at the ball park. However, as I recently have discovered, going 5 for 5 out of uniform can be pretty rewarding, too. In the last year, I sent applications to five law schools - Hofstra, Fordham, Seton Hall, St. John's and New York University - and I was accepted by all. I am as proud of that accomplishment as any cluster of singles, doubles or homers.

Logan Jr. of Springfield, Ohio, and a granddaughter of the late Dr. Sara M. Jordan, co-founder of the Lahey Clinic in Boston. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Edward L. McKenna of Concord, Mass.

Dr. and Mrs. Edward A. Edwards of Boston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Alicia Betsy Edwards, to Theodore Crump, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Crump of McCammon, Idaho. The wedding will take place early next year.

A two-run homer by Greg Luzinski and a homer by Mike Schmidt helped Steve Carlton become the first 11-game winner in the major leagues as the Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Diego Padres, 3-1, tonight. Carlton, who lifted his won-lost record to 11-2, allowed six hits and struck out 13 in eight innings. It was the 35th game in his career with the Phillies that Carlton has had 10 or more strikeouts.

For those who like their autos old, today's the day to get out on the road and take a look at some oldies - and, their owners say, goodies - that will be on parade at three special car shows. At Old Westbury Gardens, Old Westbury Road in Old Westbury, the Jaguar Drivers Club will stage its Classic Jaguar Car Show from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission of $2.50 - for children, 50 cents - also covers seeing the gardens, which are currently abloom with roses. The Long Island Triumph Association is settling into Eisenhower Park in East Meadow for its Third Annual Concours d'Elegance, which starts at 10 A.M. with the judging beginning at noon. Meanwhile, over in Dix Hills, the Half Hollow Community Library is showing no favorites. Any car owner can participate in the annual Vanderbilt Parkway Antique Auto Show and Rally, which begins at the library, 55 Vanderbilt Parkway, at 2 P.M., amid music by the Community Band, and then meanders along the Long Island Motor Parkway to Ronkonkoma.

The bride, a teacher at the William Woodward Junior Nursery School in Manhattan, was graduated from Ithaca College and received a master's degree from Teachers College of Columbia University. Her father is director of medical services for the Exxon Corporation.

There was a time in the nottoo-distant past when decorated interiors were like stage sets. They spoke volumes about the real or fancied character of those who dwelt in them--their economic status, their interests and, equally important, their sex. A woman's room inevitably would be soft and fluffy, and a man's room would be dark, rugged and as baronial as his coffers would allow.

Iris Fitzhugh Gordon, daughter of Mrs. Philip Newbold Gordon of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Mr. Gordon, was married yesterday afternoon to Edward Asbury McClintock 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. McClintock of Indianapolis. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme, Conn. The bride attended Briarcliff College and was graduated from the University of Arizona. She and her husband are assistant vice presidents of the Catalina Savings and Loan Association in Tucson. Mr. Gordon was a freelance commercial artist.

Idreamed I went back to Kansas City and stood on 18th and Vine,'' sings Big Joe Turner near the beginning of Bruce Ricker's film about Kansas City jazz, ''The Last of the Blue Devils,'' which has its New York premiere Wednesday at the Art Theater, Eighth Street and University Place. ''I shook hands with Piney Brown, and I just couldn't keep from crying.'' Unless one is a jazz historian, one doesn't know at this point who Piney Brown was (he was a black bartender who lent money to many jazz musicians), but one doesn't have to know to feel the mixture of poignancy and pride Mr. Turner is expressing. The Kansas City the singer remembers was a thriving Depression era metropolis where an entrenched political machine allowed bars, gambling dens, and bordellos to operate around the clock, thus providing work for hundreds of jazz musicians. As the film soon makes clear, with shots of boarded-up storefronts, pawn shops, and vacant lots near today's 18th and Vine, that Kansas City no longer exists; thus the poignancy. But there's ample reason for Mr. Turner's pride. Together with musicians like Lester Young, Charlie Parker, Count Basie and Jay McShann, he helped create some of the finest and most innovative jazz and blues America has produced.

Fired? Not to worry. A study by Eaton-Swain Associates, a New York consulting firm specializing in ''corporate outplacement and reentry counseling for executives whose employment is being terminated,'' suggests that being dismissed, from an executive job at least, carries a lot less of the stigma it once did. To get a reading on the outlook for its own business, Eaton-Swaine recently polled corporate executives and recruitors of corporate executives on their attitudes toward hiring the fired. ''We discovered that fired people need not skulk around,'' said Robert L. Swain, a partner in the firm.

WHEN I came to Columbia four years ago I was not sure what to expect. I did, however, have some clear-cut plans for my future - I knew that I wanted to major in biochemistry and that I was considering a career in medical science. Naturally I wanted to put these considerations to the test. I had heard a lot about the premed grind here, and it offered a rather bleak four-year outlook. I wanted more than that - a great deal more. I wanted to challenge myself, not merely by competing for those few spots in medical school, but by striving to do things I was not sure I could do. Many of my imagined adventures were intellectual, but I equally desired the physical challenges.

International The P.L.O. was dissatisified with the call Friday by the leaders of the European Common Market countries that it be ''associated'' with the Middle East peace talks. A Palestinian spokesman in Beirut said the declaration did not go far enough. ''The European communique has some positive points, but basic points are still missing,'' he said in a statement. ''They did not recognize officially and openly the P.L.O. and they also missed the recognitition of a Palestinian state.'' (Page 1, Column 3.) Millions of European visitors are expected this year in the United States -three million is the estimate - and most of them will have the advantage of currencies that will give them greater purchasing power over the dollar. The advantage over the comparatively weak dollar is possibly the major tourist attraction, but Europeans are also responding to American tourism campaigns undertaken by European tour operators and airlines and what seems to be an interest in American culture. (1:2-4.) National Reversal of the largest penalty believed to have been awarded in an antitrust case will be sought by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has been ordered to pay $1.8 billion to the MCI Communications Corporation. MCI, a Washington-based company that provides private telephone service to long-distance customers in 60 cities. (1:1-2.) President Carter's promise to provide more economic cushions, if needed, for people who have lost their jobs will be difficult to carry out, economists say. The specialists agree that a loss of a job no longer invariably means hardship because of the expansion of benefits in the last decade. They also believe that new benefit programs would be offered without any confidence that they would relieve the burden on people hardest hit by the recession because no mechanism has been set up to find out who needs additional assistance. (1:3-5.) Ronald Reagan won pledges of support from six of the men he beat in the Republican Presidential primaries as the first of a series of ''unity dinners'' was held in Los Angeles. The dinners will be held to help pay off the losers' campaign debts. (1:1.) The Pacific Northwest's image has suffered after three volcanic eruptions at Mount St. Helens in less than a month, leading to economic losses. Longview, Wash., withdrew a $3.5 million bond issue that was to be offered May 28, 10 days after the mountain's first eruption because national investors would not participate. The blow to tourism has been severe. (18:1-3.) Metropolitan Aid for the M.T.A. was approved by the Legislature in Albany before adjourning until the fall. The bills will provide a new tax and other aid to subsidize the authority's deficit that officials tied to a 10-cent increase in New York City's subway and bus fares. (1:6.) Governor Carey's bank aid plan collapsed when the State Senate recessed without reaching an agreement with the Assembly. Mr. Carey had strongly backed legislation that would have raised the ceiling on interests rates and expanded the lending powers of savings banks. (1:4-5.) Speculation by public officials in casinos in Atlantic City is so pervasive, government officials say, that it hinders the independence of city efforts to regulate the gambling industry and to provide for the orderly growth of the casinos that are the basis of Atlantic City's economic redevelopment. More than 50 local officials and government employees have bought or sold property for use by casinos, have invested in casino stock or have formed other financial links with the gambling industry. The financial ties are not illegal so long as the officials do not participate in actions affecting companies in which they hold an interest. (1:5-6.)

In a state where talk about regulating water use can be as unpopular as talk about gun registration, one of the nation's most far-reaching laws for managing ground water has gone into effect. The measure, a product of seven months of negotiations and years of debate, sailed through the Arizona Legislature in less than seven hours at a special session Wednesday.

elections come around, Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana has been bringing up his constitutional amendment to abolish the Electoral College and elect Presidents by popular vote. And just as regularly, the amendment has been defeated, mostly because of opponents' insistence that there is little real danger that a popular-vote loser will be an electoral-vote winner or that no one will win a majority of the electoral votes. Only three candidates have won the Presidency while losing the popular vote, they pointed out, and only once has the House had to choose a President from candidates none of whom had won a majority of the Electoral College. So the system has worked well enough; and as Bert Lance used to say, if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

This discussion is excerpted from an interview conducted last week by Richard L. Madden and Matthew L. Wald. Q WHAT do you have to offer the voters of Connecticut that the other Senate candidates do not have? A. A better understanding of Connecticut's problems, a better understanding of Connecticut's people, a record of close association and working with those problems over the last eight years in the State Senate, a commitment to solution of those problems rather than political rhetoric, and a willingness to discuss in a truthful, open manner my opinions on the problems facing us today, as opposed to the usual garble that emanates during the course of the campaign.

Father's Day at the Greenburgh Nature Center on Dromore Road in Scarsdale will be celebrated from 11 to 4 today with a camping symposium. A spokesman for the center explained: ''This is really for the small-scale camper. Before investing a lot of money in gear people need an opportunity to see what the options are.'' A variety of campsites will be set up on the grounds for bike camping, trailer camping, the standard tent camp and backpacking without a tent. Examples of camp stoves will also be on display. The staff and volunteers will be on hand to offer advice and provide information.

GIGI'S in Pelham is one of those not-bad restaurants worth knowing because it makes some dishes very well. Rather dimly lighted, it is laid out in two small plain dining rooms with a separate barroom as though designed to have the intimacy of a pub - which in fact the premises once housed. It is a neighborhood place whose management greets many of the diners by name, and the regulars, familiar with the strengths and weaknesses of the kitchen, seem to order pretty much what they want and how they want it. We found some items on the regular menu (made up almost exclusively of Italian, and generally of southern Italian, dishes) that needed no alterations. They had the happy versatility of being able to function both as appetizers and, in larger portions, as entrees: the mussels (zuppa di mussels, the menu says), fat, fresh and luscious, heaped in a bowlful of sea-scented broth accented with basil; and the calamari, tender rings of squid bathed in a well-proportioned light marinara sauce.

THE Thorpe Intermedia Gallery at the Dominican Convent in Sparkill (Route 340), across the Hudson in Rockland County, is offering a large and provocative show. Called ''Religious Art: Contemporary Directions,'' it includes paintings and sculpture, stained glass, weavings and other artifacts, together with numerous photographs of recent architecture. The show was organized by the gallery's director, Sister Adele Myers, and David Weinrib, the sculptor, and, financed in part by the State Council on the Arts, it will be on view through June 29. This is not as lavish or as star-studded an event as the exhibition of liturgical art in Philadelphia five years ago, and in fact, includes relatively few liturgical objects. On the other hand, it is rather more sophisticated, including as it does work inspired by Judaism and Eastern faiths, as well as by Christianity. The idea was, in any case, to find out what simply reflected, to quote Sister Adele, ''a sincere interest in spiritual matters,'' and it has on the whole been realized.

For the past week South Africa's all-white Parliament has been debating what Government spokesmen have presented as its most important piece of legislation in decades: constitutional amendments that aim at establishing a formal dialogue between whites and the other races on ways of sharing power. Even before the amendments have cleared the Assembly in Cape Town, nonwhite groups crucial to the plan's success have repudiated it, leaving the Government heading up what threatens to be a constitutional blind alley. Prime Minister P.W. Botha has indicated that he is determined to proceed with the plan, prompting black leaders to say it is less a break with the past than a new attempt to impose the white man's will.

Amy Louise Post, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman D. Post of Great Neck, L.I., and Dr. Dana Wiseman, son of Mrs. Irving Newman of Dewitt, N.Y., and the late Dr. Richard Wiseman, were married last evening at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I. Rabbi Donald N. Gluckman officiated. The couple were graduated from Hamilton College. The bride also received a degree in clinical psychology from Northwestern University, where she is a doctoral student in operations research in the department of industrial engineering. Her father is president of Robins Industries Inc., electronics manufacturers in Commack, L.I.

GREAT NECK MARLENE MONCHNIK is in her 30's, has two school-age children and is starting to feel a bit restless and bored after years of fulltime motherhood. Worse yet, all her friends have returned to school or work, leaving hers as the only emergency telephone number in town to be called in case their children get sick and have to be picked up at school. Marlene may sound familiar, but don't go looking for her at your local supermarket, tennis club or P.T.A. She's fictitious, the main character in ''Womansong,'' a musical revue by Barbara Sutton Masry.

AT a time of life - retirement -when relatives, friends and familiar surroundings take on an added importance, Dorothea and Rudolph Weick moved down to Port Charlotte, Fla. ''You feel your roots being torn,'' Mrs. Weick recalled. Now the Weicks are back and settled in a retirement community called Leisure Village, situated in Ridge, and they feel much happier. ''The minute I put my foot over the threshold here, I said, 'I'm home again,' '' Mrs. Weick said.

CHINA MEN By Maxine Hong Kingston. 308 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. AMONG Maxine Hong Kingston's earliest memories of her father are the sounds of his cursing. He slams his iron down and mutters obscenities; the obscenities refer to women. The sexual violence of his language shocks her; she has seen him as attentive, charming, a silent magician, an enchanting escort. Can he mean what he says? Does he hate all women? Does he hate her?

IS the answer to the Island's energy problems blowing in the wind? Probably not in the immediate future, but several efforts are under way, on the North Shore, the South Shore and the East End, in an attempt to determine how wind power - first introduced on the Island by the early immigrant settlers in the 1600's - can be harnessed by modern methods today to generate electricity inexpensively. But while wind power, because it is free, renewable and nonpolluting, is an attractive alternative to fueled sources of energy, or perhaps to solar power, the obstacles on the Island - both institutional and economic - are great.

Helen Brooke McLean, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William L. McLean 3d of Wynnewood, Pa., was married yesterday afternoon to Eldridge Thomas Katzenbach, son of Maude Thomas Katzenbach of Washington and the late Edward L. Katzenbach. The Rev. Timothy Pickering performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa. Elizabeth Ray McLean was her sister's maid of honor. Mr. Katzenbach 3d served as best man for his brother. The bride, who is known as Brooke, was graduated from the Agnes Irwin School in Rosemont, Pa., and recently completed her sophomore year at Duke University. She will begin her junior year at Smith College. Her father is president of Independent Publications Inc., in Philadelphia, owners of a number of small newspapers, among them, The Santa Barbara (Calif.) News Press. He is former editor and publisher of The Philadelphia Bulletin.

England is a peculiar place,as every visitor can see for himself, and the English are a very peculiar people. You don't even have to have been there to know it: novels will make it quite clear, and so will published letters and diaries, and so did the English movie industry when Peter Sellers was the coming young man. If you have any last doubts on the subject, a good place to dispel them is the Museum of American Folk Art at 49 West 53d Street, where a selection of ''English Naive Paintings'' from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Andras Kalman is on view through Aug. 17. This is a convert's collection. When Andras Kalman first came to England, it was as an amateur tennis player who was good enough to represent his native Hungary at Wimbledon. He liked England enough to stay on, and eventually he became an art dealer. Initially in the north of England - which is notably inhospitable terrain for activity of that sort - and later in London, he developed a line of his own among the artists of our own day. He also became interested in the untutored imagination as it manifested itself in English naive painting. In this he had a rival in the person of another foreignborn London dealer, Arthur Jeffress, but now that that gifted eccentric is dead Mr. Kalman has the field largely to himself. That is the origin of the collection which has been shown in Germany, Denmark, Sweden and Finland and is now on view in New York.

VALLEY STREAM AS a result of a disastrous fire in a synagogue here last Thanksgiving and a recent fire in a Hempstead church, a so-called ''gentleman's agreement'' privilege that has been enjoyed by most Nassau houses of worship may soon be scrapped. The agreement exempts houses of worship from the fire safety inspections that are regularly conducted in buildings of public assembly. The County Fire Marshal's office has honored this agreement, along with most municipalities, although nobody is quite sure how the exemption came about.
