The marriage of Ellen Jean Porter, a doctoral student in counseling and consulting psychology at the Harvard Graduate School of Education, to Charles Owen Honnet, who attends the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, took place at the Cedar Lane Unitarian Chapel in Bethesda, Md., yesterday. The Rev. Dr. Ralph Potter, a professor of ethics at the Harvard Divinity School, performed the ceremony. Barbara and Joan Porter, twin sisters of the bride, were maids of honor. They are the daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight J. Porter of Bethesda and Wintergreen, Va. Their father, a retired Foreign Service officer and former Ambassador to Lebanon, is a Westinghouse Electric Corporation vice president. Their mother, Adele Ritchie Porter, is an artist.

Andrea Jean Hill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Mitchell Hill, was married yesterday to Lieut. Robert Francis Lohneiss Jr., U.S.M.C., son of Mr. and Mrs. Lohneiss. Both families are of West Hartford, Conn., where the ceremony was performed by the Rev. Allan H. O'Neil in St. John's Episcopal Church. The bridegroom, who graduated last month from the United States Naval Academy, is stationed in Quantico, Va. Mrs. Lohneiss graduated last month from Wellesley College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa.

The primary cause of our current economic problems is that United States industry is not keeping up with world and domestic market opportunities. In many industries, United States firms are not producing the right goods of the right quality in sufficient quantity at competitive prices.

ALTHOUGH Benjamin Franklin achieved fulfillment in roles that few men play - statesman, scientist, author and inventor - he suffered disappointment, shame and sorrow in a role that most play successfully: that of a father enjoying the warm friendship of a loyal and sympathetic son. One of Franklin's sons, Francis, died at the age of 4. The other, William, became Royal Governor of New Jersey and lived to a ripe old age. But father and son became estranged when William opposed the Revolution, and the Great Patriot carried the wound with him to the grave.

A decade ago at 64, an age when most people are contemplating retirement, Anne Morrow Lindbergh took on what she described simply as ''a job.'' The job was the publication of her diaries and letters, which covered her life and that of her celebrated husband Charles Lindbergh during the period 1922-1947. With the publication of the best-selling ''War Within and Without,'' the fifth and last volume of the series, the task is now complete.

COLLINSVILLE MY tulips are trespassing. When I moved to a condominium in the spring of last year they told me it was different here, but I never imagined it would be like this, the kind of place where tulips trespass. ''It's not that we don't like them,'' said my neighbor, a little sheepishly, explaining that the board of directors of the condominium association commended me for my efforts (futile) to make grass grow in front of my unit. But the tulips, a whimsical October afterthought, had sprung up in May in a ''common area.''

uf913POINT PLEASANT BEACH FOR the second time this spring, the state's Department of Environmental Protection has been accused of violating its own regulations to permit building along the coast. It is, says the American Littoral Society, flying in the face of its own zoning and development policies by recommending the approval of a $9 million condominium project on the beach here.

Charlotte Evans's story about Richard N. Lander, ''The Man Who Fills the Jury Boxes'' (May 26), was to my wife, Ruth, and to me a delightful coincidence. We had served the first of two weeks' jury assignment, and the characterization of the gracious, efficient man was letter-perfect. We had a first-hand opportunity to hear him and to see him at work. He does more than justice (sic!) to his job. Mr. Lander's philosophy about spreading the duty ''far and wide'' became apparent at once. Three-hundred-eleven prospective jurors assembled in the Central Jury Room at 9:30 A.M. on May 19. Following specific orientation, the ''lotto'' drum was turned and names selected. In groups of varying sizes, we were then conducted by sheriffs to one of many courtrooms, civil and criminal. The use of random selection of prospective jurors and assignments spoke well for the equity of the system.

The United States Steel Corporation has notified a Federal court and government agencies that because of the slump in business, it may not be able to comply with a $400 million plan to clean up pollution in nine western Pennsylvania plants. The agreement, which was reached in Federal District Court last July after almost 10 years of litigation, was designed to bring U.S. Steel into compliance with Federal air standards by the end of 1982.

A singer of considerable technical polish, Erica Tanenbaum presented a difficult debut program at Carnegie Recital Hall last Sunday night, and she made light work of it. The soprano was first trained at the Leningrad Conservatory of Music, later studying at the Rubin Academy of Music in Tel Aviv, where she has been singing extensively for several years.

WEST NEW YORK HUNDREDS of Cuban refugees, many of whom fled their homeland with only the clothes on their backs, have found that their dreams of a better life in the United States - or at least in New Jersey - are difficult to realize. Standing in their way are economic conditions, the language barrier, poor housing and resentment among lower-income groups, particularly blacks, who see the new influx as a potential threat involving competition for jobs.

OUR best efforts on the property tax often seem to turn against us, as homeowners in the state are discovering. Because of our success at ''reforming'' it, homeowners are threatened with a radical increase; in many cases, property taxes may double or even triple. Some homeowners in Hamden have already taken to the streets in protest - perhaps the first signs of an impending property-tax revolt. Homeowners have fallen victim to recent reforms in the administration of the property tax. Although most state laws have long required that property tax assessments be uniform, this requirement was, until recently, honored in the breach. Today, the message from the Connecticut Legislature, as well as from courts in several other states, is that inequalities in assessments will no longer be tolerated. All properties must be assessed at the same percentage of fair market value.

Campbell of Woodstock, Vt., and the late Nelson Borland Lee. The Rev. Charles P. Scott, chaplain at Middlebury, performed the Episcopal ceremony. Abi Sessions was matron of honor. James Roberts and Peter Sawyer served as best men. The bride, a graduate of the Kent School and Middlebury College, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, studied in England under a Thomas J. Watson Fellowship and taught for two years at the New Day Montessori School in Middlebury. Her father is chairman of the Kessler-Ellis Products Company, manufacturer of electronic counting devices in Atlantic Highlands.

Having recently resisted political pressures to keep ''Death of a Princess,'' the controversial ''docu-drama'' about the execution of a Saudi Arabian princess, off the air, public television is now facing protests, primarily religious, about an hour-long documentary called ''Choosing Suicide.'' Scheduled to be carried nationally tomorrow at 8 P.M. on the Public Broadcasting Service, the program has already been rejected by a good many stations. As is customary when controversy ruffles its usually placid waters, the public-television system is offering a follow-up panel discussion. With Hugh Downs as moderator, ''Choosing Suicide: The Implications,'' will be broadcast live from a WNET/Channel 13 studio at 9 P.M. and will include among its guests Robert E. Neale, a professor in the program of psychiatry and religion at Union Theological Seminary and author of ''The Art of Dying,'' and Father Kevin O'Rourke, director of the Center for Health Care Ethics at the St. Louis University Medical Center. All well and good, but that still leaves the documentary itself. ''Choosing Suicide'' is certainly unusual. The program is also terribly unsettling, but in ways that probably were not anticipated by its participants or its critics. On the surface, the ''scenario'' is uncomplicated. Discovering in 1978 that she had cancer, 62-yearold Jo Roman decided to commit suicide. On June 10, 1979, a Sunday, she swallowed 35 Seconal capsules, each one containing 100 milligrams of the drug. Mrs. Roman was not an ''ordinary'' suicide. For years, she had been writing a book on ''rational suicide.'' She explains at the very beginning of the program: ''I don't think of myself now as 'killing myself.' I feel no desire to kill, or injure, or maim. To me, that's the difference between rational and irrational suicide. Irrational is neurotically involved with killing.''

DETROIT, June 14--The Chrysler Corporation said today that "full agreement" had been reached with the Michigan National Bank on the institution's participation in a lender-aid package designed to help the ailing auto maker obtain loans of up to $1.5 billion. Repayment of those loans will be guaranteed by the Federal Government.

A plan to help the banking industry by easing some of New York State's lending restrictions collapsed today when the State Senate recessed without reaching agreement with the Assembly. The plan would have allowed banks to charge higher rates on personal loans and credit card debts, and it would have allowed savings institutions to make a wider variety of loans. It was opposed by Democratic legislators because it would have raised a whole range of interest costs for consumers.

Mr. Sutter, now the publisher of The Penny Saver, a Long Island advertising circular, said those three weeks ''changed my whole way of thinking.''

Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated: Roof Raiser June 20 -It's disco, rock and jitterbug in Connecticut tonight at the Greenwich Country Club to raise money towards a $1-million goal to put a second floor under the roof of the Greenwich Library. Readers now stand elbow to elbow and on each others feet waiting to borrow books from the library, whose daily attendance has doubled from what it was ten years ago. The upper floor will ease crowding and also provide room for music and art rooms. The party for the library's development fund is the annual Edge of Summer Ball for the 25 to 30 year-old generation in Connecticut's Fairfield and New York's Westchester Counties. Alligator will be the disconaire at the black-tie dance. Tickets: $15 from (203)661-0171, or from the Greenwich Arts Council at the library, or at the country club door.

There is one practical matter these days that President Carter wants to get straight. This is whether the West German Government is prepared to go forward with the new missile construction sites in Western Europe or whether it is considering a ''freeze'' or postponement of this critical strategic decision. Washington has been getting some mixed signals from Bonn on this point. It has always been understood that the most modern U.S. missiles could not actually be put in place and made operational for three years, but that it would take three years to construct the sites for their deployment.

Fair Warning, one of the old-timers of the division, won the amateur-owner jumper championship with 12 points today at the Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show. The 51st renewal of the event, one of the biggest in the East, has been running since Tuesday. It concludes tomorrow with the $15,000-added Grand Prix for open jumpers.

THE PLAN OF ST. GALL A Study of the Architecture & Economy of, & Life in a Paradigmatic Carolingian Monastery. By Walter Horn and Ernest Born. Three volumes. Illustrated. 982 pp. Berkeley, Calif.: University of California Press. $325. THE plan of the Abbey of St. Gall was drawn between the years 820 and 830, probably by the Benedictine Abbot Haito, bishop of Basel. It is an absolutely extraordinary document. The well-preserved parchment contains, in manuscript form, not only fragments of text in highmedieval Latin (which is not all that rare) but also a blueprint from which one could construct the entire monastery of St. Gall - the church, cloister and annexes, including the barns and stables. Haito's plan covers the most minute, intimate details. It foresaw, for example, that the young monks or novitiates who lived in the seminary and the infirmary would need at least one toilet - purified by running water - for every two persons. In fact, there were provisions for toilets everywhere - for the clergy and for guests. These hygienic accomplishments were strikingly modern. In fact, they really have not been improved upon by the Hilton hotels.

WATERFORD DURING a five-week program under way now at the O'Neill Theater Center deaf students are being taught the basics of theater, along with something described by Robert Panara, an instructor, as ''a new art form that is beautiful to watch, and very creative.'' That art form is the unique theatrical technique pioneered by the National Theater of the Deaf. Through extensive national and international touring, the troupe, based here since 1967, has ''showed the deaf to be highly intelligent, and sign language to be a many-splendored thing,'' said Mr. Panara, who lost his hearing at age 10, and who, ''like others practice piano,'' spent many years working daily to maintain his speaking skills.

Negotiators for both sides in the strike of the Port Authority Trans-Hudson railroad (PATH) stayed away from the bargaining table yesterday. No date has been set for a resumption of talks between the parties - the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, whose 177 members struck the railroad last week. A spokesman for the Port Authority said traffic moved freely yesterday along the major Hudson River crossings, despite the elimination of the emergency bus and shuttle-train service provided for the first two days of the strike, Thursday and Friday.

When it comes to sheer guts, no play this season can beat the new version of Bertolt Brecht's ''Mother Courage and Her Children'' at the Public. Director Wilford Leach has staged an elaborate and iconoclastic revival: The cast is black, and the script has been adapted from Brecht by the black American playwright Ntozake Shange. About the production, which ends its run today, there will be no quibbles here. Who wouldn't want to see Gloria Foster and Morgan Freeman play all the great roles in theatrical literature? This ''Mother Courage'' features some of the best actors, black or white, in New York; they give the play a passionate reading. But what play are they doing? The text of Miss Shange's ''Mother Courage'' amounts to a whole new show, and it raises some troubling questions. What are an adapter's responsibilities to the original work? What are a playwright's obligations to history? Is it right to call a play ''Mother Courage'' when it in many ways violates the spirit of the drama we associate with that title? The motivations behind Miss Shange's adaptation may well be pure, but the result is a case study of what can happen when an exercise in literary adaptation goes wildly astray.

In the decade since wiretaps were legalized in New Jersey, law enforcement agencies here have employed more of them than in any other state, according to the Justice Department. And that record has prompted debate about the rights of those being tapped and the benefit to society of the police work in which they are used. ''We set out in 1968 to contain organized crime activity and I think we have succeeded, or are close to succeeding, with that goal,'' said Edwin H. Stier, the State Director of Criminal Justice, who credits the wiretaps with helping the state to ''develop the most significant organized crime cases of any state.''

The cause of discomfiture for this 34-year-old assistant professor at Long Island University's Southampton College was the discovery not long ago that he had been awarded both a Rockefeller Foundation Humanities Fellowship and a John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation Fellowship for the 1979-1981 academic year. However, the occurrence seems not to have been unprecedented and eventually he elected to take the Rockefeller Fellowship, inasmuch as one may not hold two such grants at once.

IT HAS been a bad year for the ''Sons of the Bad News Bears,'' as one mother dubbed the Cubs, and today the score resembles football more than baseball. With carefully blank faces, they have been pounded on the backsides and cheered by the winning team. Now they slump, streaked with sweat and mud (and, I suspect, tears in a case or two), listening to the wrapup. The three adult coaches pace tensely behind the chain-link fence that separates the players' bench from the playing field. The children look like defeated, caged animals facing their keepers.

Richard Schickel's article ''Far Beyond Reality'' (May 18) was of great interest to me as I spent over 10 years in the optical-effects field and was associated with three Academy Award-winning subjects. While Mr. Schickel confined his work to the field of theatrical motion pictures, a word should be said about the work done every day on film and videotape for the 30-second minidramas called television commercials. Thanks to Mr. Schickel for making so many people aware of the effort that goes into entertaining us. ARTHUR J. JACKS Scarsdale, N.Y. ------

FIFTY years ago, three Armonk men on their way home from a day of clamming in Cos Cob, Conn., stopped near the New York-Connecticut border to help the Greenwich Fire Department put out a small grass fire. They were given brooms with which to beat down the flames, and soon the situation on the Connecticut side was under control. The fire, however, had spread across the New York line and the Greenwich firefighters, their job officially finished, departed, leaving the three men with their three brooms to finish the job.

Her father, now retired, was proprietor of a retail book store in Paramus, N.J. Her mother, Annette Schiller, is a docent at the Ringling Museum of Art in Sarasota.
PAYS By NICHOLAS A. ASHFORD

A dispute over scallops and other marine matters is prompting Canada to consider ways not to cooperate with its neighbor and closest ally, the United States. The principal bone of contention is a fisheries treaty signed more than a year ago after laborious negotiations and now languishing in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, with poor prospects of early approval.

The Disorganization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is small comfort to oil consumers. Last week's price-setting meeting of producers in Algiers was exceptionally acrimonious, but it ended, in the words of Kuwait's oil minister, in ''a semblance of unity'' on price increases. The 13 cartel members agreed to an Iraqi formula: a new ceiling of $37 a barrel, which is about the price such ''hawks'' as Libya, Algeria and Nigeria are already charging for their oil, in return for an increase of the current benchmark floor price for Saudi light crude, from $28 to $32 a barrel.

HARTFORD TO most people, the word ''video'' implies ''Three's Company,'' ''Laverne and Shirley'' and ''Fantasy Island.'' To a Hartford-based group of young video artists, it implies locally produced documentaries, mixed-media presentations and programming for minority groups. ''Video can mean much more than 'Charlie's Angels' and 'Starsky and Hutch' reruns,'' said Anna Marie Piersimoni, director of MonteVideo Inc. of Hartford. Just how much more will be illustrated this week when MonteVideo sponsors the second annual Daniel Wadsworth Memorial Video Festival, named for the art enthusiast who founded the Wadsworth Atheneum here. The festival, which is being held at several locations here, began Friday and runs through next Sunday.

FARMINGDALE BY degrees, so many of Neil Simon's plays are autobiographically based, but none reflect his artistic soul's yearning more than ''The Good Doctor,'' a series of vignettes derived from Anton Chekhov's stories. When Mr. Simon wrote ''The Good Doctor'' in 1973, he was haunted by the shadow of the Russian master. It may be no mere coincidence that Chekhov was a physician and that Mr. Simon is commonly called ''Doc.''

LIKE many other intrepid home-buyers who had applied for mortgage loans in March, when interest rates reached the peak of their roller coaster-like ascent, Kevin and Anne Halpin are enjoying an unexpected benefit now. Their mortgage commitment from the Millburn-based Berkeley Federal Savings and Loan Association was revised twice prior to closing, and their current rate is a ''comfortable'' 12 3/4 percent.

Inever was interested in sharpening my talents to become a star,'' said Otto Luening the other day in his Riverside Drive apartment. ''I wanted to be a loyal servant of the art of music.'' He may not be a star, but this distinguished American composer and teacher - who is 80 years old today -has certainly served his art, and managed the occasional twinkle in the musical firmament while doing so. He has been a pioneer composer of electronic music, has turned out a vast and still largely unknown body of more conservative music for conventional instruments, has taught some of the leading young composers of the day and enjoyed a life rich in friendships and anecdotes.

Chris Evert Lloyd, looking to regain the Wimbledon title she last won four years ago, completed a successful tuneup today by defeating Evonne Goolagong Cawley, 6-3, 6-7, 7-5, in the final of a $100,000 women's grass tennis tournament. Amid gale-force winds during the two-hour match, Mrs. Lloyd posted her 22d victory over Miss Goolagong in 34 meetings. The 25-year-old Floridian earned $20,000, raising her total since returning to competition to $103,000. There were six service breaks in the first set and the Australian won only 8 points on her serve. The first five games went against serve in the second set, the American being broken for the third time with two double faults in the fifth game. Miss Goolagong led by 5-3 and appeared to have let her chance slip when she lost the next three games. But she took the set to a tiebreaker, which she took by 7-4.

Martin Gallent, the vice chairman of the City Planning Commission, is proposing to have New York City retain the ownership of the properties it takes over and lease the development rights to others. ''No developer in his right mind gets rid of the fee, particularly in the Central Business District,'' said Mr. Gallent. The word ''fee'' refers to the actual ownership of the land. His proposal, Mr. Gallent said, ''would give the city another tool to maximize its income and to help determine the future use of the property, to be used selectively and appropriately.''

At 6 o'clock on a recent Saturday morning, when New York City was mostly asleep, the Mohonk Mountain House, just 90 miles away, was bustling. About 200 guests milled about the spacious Lake Lounge, sipping coffee, eating Danish pastry, chatting about birds and plants and insects and each other and waiting eagerly to examine the outdoors. LaVerne Thompson, a retired teacher of bacteriology, took charge. ''Those who are waiting for the ecology walk,'' she called out above the din, ''please assemble on the porch. Birders, you stay right here in your nest for a minute, and we'll get to you as soon as we can. We weren't expecting such a big turnout, so we'd better forget about husbands and wives and that sort of thing - you can have breakfast with them later.''

owner and editor of The Suffolk County News, a weekly newspaper in Sayville, and wife of the Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, remains undaunted about losing her lawsuit against the Bayport-Blue Point Union Free School District. Under the New York State Freedom of Information law, she had asked the district to make available to the public records concerning contract negotiations between teachers and the administration before the school budget came up for a vote. According to Mrs. Cohalan, school districts on the Island sometimes require residents to vote on a school budget before contract negotiations have been completed.

AT THE outset, let me state that there's nothing personal in this. I just believe (Thus, the article appears as an Opinion Page piece, not as a Personally Speaking piece. - Ed.) that someone should state the case in opposition to the arguments presented by The Society for the Propagation of the Letter Q. For years, I, too, was sympathetic to the letter Q. It was a cute letter, a letter O with a tail on it. It seemed to be getting shortchanged by Webster in not receiving its fair kwota of words to begin.

President Carter will ''use all the persuasive power'' he has to bring King Hussein of Jordan into the Egyptian-Israeli peace talks when the King visits the United States next week, the President said in remarks made public today. At the same time Mr. Carter reiterated that he opposed the participation of the Palestine Liberation Organization in Middle Eastern negotiations at this time.

The Smithsonian Institution's series of jazz reissues started with a six-disk ''Collection of Classic Jazz'' that was definitive for five-sixths of the way (i.e., through the 1950's). Than came a series of individual albums that, while not groundbreaking in the sense of revealing material that was not already well known, established a pattern of firm foundations for a fundamental library of jazz recordings. This series included complete units of the work of major jazz artists -Duke Ellington in 1938 and 1939, Louis Armstrong with King Oliver in 1923 and with Earl Hines in 1928. There have been overviews of such influential musicians as Fletcher Henderson, from 1923 to 1937, Dizzie Gillespie from 1940 to 1946, and Teddy Wilson from 1934 to 1942. And there has been a summation of the development of the John Kirby Sextet from 1937 to 1941.

TOMS RIVER INFURIATED by what they see as a broken promise by the state and a move to sabotage their efforts to expand a clam program, the South Jersey/Ocean County Baymen's Environmental Protection Association has taken the state's Department of Environmental Protection to court. The suit - filed in the Appellate Division of Superior Court last week by Morris J. Kurzrok, the association's attorney - is the latest skirmish in a battle that has been going on for years between hard-shell clammers, or baymen, in Monmouth and Ocean Counties, with the D.E.P. caught in the crossfire.

NORTHPORT ERIC SLOANE has characterized himself as a ''sentimental realist,'' and he is unashamed of the frankly nostalgic point of view expressed in his paintings and drawings of rural America. The author of more than 20 books on early tools, barns, covered bridges and other aspects of Americana, Mr. Sloane is much admired for an art that appears to recapture a more natural, harmonious and selfsufficient way of life, filled with esthetically pleasing buildings and artifacts. The current exhibition of Mr. Sloane's paintings at the Verzyl Gallery concentrates on the late 1960's, when he was at work on his ''I Remember America'' series. Several of the works on view are studies from the series, supplemented by a selection of the cloudscapes for which he is also noted.
and Patrice Munsel --------------------------------------------------------------------- Ralph Tyler writes frequently on the arts. By RALPH TYLER

My father and I didn't spend much time together when I was growing up. He earned the money; my mother reared the children. I was the only daughter and my tie to my mother was strong. I know I felt my father's presence but it was conveyed to me by my mother, largely in his absence. As father and daughter, we were alone together only once: We were in a restaurant during its off-hours waiting for my mother to finish shopping. I didn't know what to say to my father. After a few silent moments, he looked around the restaurant, empty except for the two of us, and said: ''Let's go. I don't like being the only ones here.''

Hair - be it long, short, braided, curled, teased, powdered, oiled, bleached or dyed - has inspired painters, potters, sculptors, designers and craftsmen of every persuasion down through the ages. And in expressing themselves with symbolism, or with sexual images, or in high style designs, these observers have invariably also documented some fascinating aspects of the existing culture and the people who shaped it. Thankfully, some of these artists and artisans have also managed to accomplish this task with imagination and wit. That, in any case, is the provocative message of ''Hair,'' an exhibition that is a historical survey of styles, fashion and symbolism in hair design on view (through Aug. 17) at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street. The show of 350 selections is believed to be the first exhibition in a major American museum devoted to the subject. The results are so absorbing that one suspects it will not be the last such presentation.

The Fine Tool Shops Inc. in Westport has such a tasteful display that it ''looks like a jewelry shop,'' according to a local admirer. The catalogue reinforces the meticulous image for woodcarvers, sculptors, carpenters, cabinetmakers, furniture refinishers and craftsmen. The current brochure describes a sale for hand and power tools that lasts until Sept. 1. Professional-quality straight or curved-edge saws are $39.50 for 240- or 295-millimeter blades. In standard quality, a 270-millimeter straight blade or a 295-millimeter curved blade is $20.

ATLANTIC CITY--The Atlantic City ethics code, enacted by ordinance in April 1979 prohibits elected or appointed officials and city employees from taking official action involving companies in which they hold stock. It also requires about 150 key employees to file annual financial statements with the City Clerk each January listing, among other things, any stocks they or their spouses may own.

This is whether the West German Government is prepared to go forward with the new missile construction sites in Western Europe or whether it is considering a "freeze" or postponement of this critical strategic decision.

The frustrations and fatigue of both voters and politicians after this year's 36-primary Presidential marathon has led to new talk of reform and new moves toward regional primaries in the South, Middle West and Far West. In Congress, proposals for both regional primaries and spaced, one-a-month groupings of primaries are being revived. In such big states as California, Ohio and Michigan, political leaders and voters, irked by what they regard as the disproportionate influence of smaller states with earlier caucuses or primaries, talk of moving back their primary dates.

The Dance Theater of Harlem will perform Wednesday through Saturday as part of the American dance season of London's Sadlers Wells Theater, filling in for the Eliot Feld Ballet, which canceled its trip to London. The season will also include performances by the Erick Hawkins and Merce Cunningham Dance Companies.

In the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Faith Brayton Bushby, daughter of James C. Bushby of South Londonderry, Vt., and the late Diane Brayton Bushby, became the bride of E. Laurence White 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. White Jr. of New York and Washington, Conn. The Rev. Marsha Kleeper-Smith and the Rev. Thomas Guinan, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Margaret H. Page was the maid of honor, and William Osborn served as the best man. The bride, an alumna of the Taft School and Smith College, attends the Yale Graduate School of Architecture. Her father, a retired corporate lawyer, is proprietor of the Londonderry Inn.
The performances matched the weather today at the New York State high school boys' track and field championships: both were hot. Two meet records, including a state mark, were set.
Pepi Wiley scored an upset today and gave Mrs. Henry D. Paxson her third stakes winner at Monmouth Park in three weeks by taking the $46,500 mile-and-70-yards Post Deb before a crowd of 17,375.

At Speedwell Village in Morristown today, visitors can mix their celebrations of Flag Day (24 hours late) and Father's Day (right on time) with the village's own ''Patriots' Day.'' There will be music and a tree-planting ceremony. Speedwell Village is a National Historic Site, and it offers a look at crafts of Colonial times in a setting of 18th-century buildings and houses. It was formerly the site of the Speedwell Iron Works, and it was there in 1838 that Alfred Vail, son of the founder of that concern, helped Samuel F.B. Morse develop and first publicly demonstrate the telegraph.

Emily Morris Wood, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Wood of Mount Kisco, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to James Arnold Koegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Koegel of Granite Springs, N.Y. The Quaker ceremony took place at the Wood home. Mary C. Weidlein was the maid of honor and Gary Santini served as the best man. The bride, an alumna of the Cisqua School in Mount Kisco and the Westtown (Pa.) School, attended Cornell University. Until recently, she had been manager of Braewold, the family farm in Mount Kisco. Her father is a vice president of the Bank of New York.

Brenda Jean Fahey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dennis M. Fahey of Lexington, N.C., was married yesterday morning to Christopher Stephen Hartmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. William E. Hartmann of Bethpage, L.I. The Rev. Scott Alexander performed the ceremony in the Unitarian Church in Summit, N.J. The bride was graduated from the Shady Side Academy in Pittsburgh and cum laude on June 5 from Harvard College. She plans to join the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States in its actuarial program in New York in August. Her father is a research associate with PPG Industries in Lexington.

Although rising oil prices and resumption of Palestinian negotiations were at the forefront of the Administration's Middle East agenda last week, movement of the Soviet Union into the volatile region remained Washington's most pressing concern. The Administration pledge to resist Soviet advances presented a formidable strategic challenge, diplomatic and military planners acknowledge, but there was disagreement among Government and other experts over interpreting and responding to Moscow's moves.
KIRBO By TERENCE SMITH

COUNTRIES To the Editor: As a student of the international oil problems of the developing world -aren't we all - I found much to agree with in your May 31 editorial ''120 Billion, and Counting.'' Indeed, ''the recycling problem is not one problem but many,'' and ''solutions must be tailored to meet the specific needs of specific countries.'' But while loans and financing are an important avenue for meeting the higher energy bills of oil-importing developing countries, it should not be the only one.

Madlock says that any contact between his glove and Gerry Crawford's profile was unpremeditated, accidental and purely coincidental, not to say benign. Dale Ford says he did not punch, push, poke, prod or nudge Martin. The way of aggressors is hard.

Carl Yastrzemski hit a two-run homer, the 15th homer by a Boston player in the last seven games, to lead the Red Sox to a 7-3 victory over the California Angels today. Manager Jim Fregosi was not around to see his Angels suffer their 10th loss in 11 games and their 18th in the last 21 at home. He was ejected before the start in a dispute with Umpire Larry Barnett over an incident from last night's game.

FACTS OF LIFE, by Maureen Howard. (Penguin, $2.95.) One of our wittiest novelists recalls the anguishes and the satisfactions of growing up Catholic in Bridgeport, Conn., of discovering sex and elitism at Smith, of living on faculty row, of finding pain and freedom in divorce. Reviewing this mosaic of impressions and vignettes, Diane Johnson found it ''all very interesting and enjoyable.'' SALLY HEMINGS, by Barbara Chase-Ribaud. (Avon, $2.75.) Using facts that were ingeniously assembled by Fawn Brodie in her psychobiography of Thomas Jefferson, this novel spells out the byzantine relationship between the third President and Sally Hemings, his beautiful, elegant, brainy, fiery and indestructible slave-companion. It is told through a series of impressions that - according to our reviewer Martin Levin - compose ''a vivid, appealing portrait because of the author's passion for her subject.''
OFF CENTER Essays. By Barbara Grizzuti Harrison. 305 pp. New York: Dial Press. $9.95. By LORE DICKSTEIN

Some people who like to choose their own hours for making selections often use mail-order catalogues. Others prefer to visit a company's store to reassure themselves about the merchandise. The first anniversary sale Saturday and Sunday of a $200,000 inventory at the Lillian Vernon Distribution Center may lure those armchair shoppers to Port Chester and divert those more familiar with the Mount Vernon retail store to the scene of a saving of one-third to two-thirds off catalogue prices on overstocks, discontinued merchandise, and manufacturers' errors, according to a company representative. The company has notified many of its customers to get there on Friday between 4:30 and 8 P.M. for a private preview sale. Lillian Vernon's store in Mount Vernon will be closed next Saturday during the clearance of gifts, cookware, housewares, desk needs, Christmas decorations and men's accessories. A 20-piece service for four of Ironstone dinnerware, originally $39.98 in the catalog, will be $18; black-handled cutlery by Supreme, a five-piece stainlesssteel flatware set once $24.98, will be $10. A lucite-and-stainless flatware five-piece setting, formerly $10.98, will be $5; assorted imported soaps are 25 cents a piece; imported stationery with 20 sheets and envelopes, $3; and Bert and Harry or Sesame Street hand towels will be $1.98.

Big brother used to watch over Sugar Ray Leonard. Now it's the other way around. Roger Dale Leonard, who introduced his little brother to the sport he now dominates, remembers the old days when he would see trouble walking down the sidewalks of Palmer Park, Md., and how he would send shy and frail Ray Charles home. ''I was the big brother then,'' said Roger. He is still the big brother, except in the boxing business, and it is Sugar Ray who takes care of Roger's budding career as a worldranked contender.

Federal investigators seeking to solve the largest cash robbery in the nation's history - the $5.8 million theft from an air cargo building at Kennedy International Airport 18 months ago - have begun receiving significant new evidence.

Tonight, almost two decades after it was retired from the home screen, ''Ombibus'' returns. For veteran viewers with fond recollections of those often scholarly, sporadically adventuresome, occasionally brilliant, but always diverting ''Omnibus'' programs that were presented - usually at the awkward hour of 5 in the afternoon on Sundays -from 1952 to 1961, be advised that it is a new ''Omnibus'' now being offered, a program with a more pronounced emphasis on pure entertainment than its rather serendipitous forebear. This evening's ''Omnibus,'' on ABC from 8 to 9 P.M., will have Hal Holbrook as its host and will pair Metropolitan Opera tenor Luciano Pavarotti with country-and-Western star Loretta Lynn, singing together and separately (he will perform ''Torna a Sorrento,'' she will sing ''Pregnant Again''). Actress Meryl Streep will appear with members of the Theater of the Deaf in a hand-signing of ''America the Beautiful.'' There will be a sort of social history of Peter Pan, ranging from James Matthew Barrie's book to Sandy Duncan's flying on wires across the stage of the Lunt-Fontanne Theater in the current revival of the musical version.

IT all started when President Dwight Eisenhower played golf at one of Westchester's clubs and wondered aloud if something couldn't be done about the geese that were fouling the fairways and greens. The Department of Interior took up the problem, and in 1958 the United States Fish and Wildlife Service began relocating the county's Canada geese. The relocation eventually became an annual event, and tomorrow the ''Nuisance Canada Goose Roundup'' begins. During the last two weeks of June, the offending waterfowl are flightless; young birds are not yet fledglings, and the adults have lost their wingfeathers and are growing new ones.

Re L.I.R.R. steam locomotive No. 39 being refitted to haul excursions with a $75,000 grant from the Suffolk County Legislature, plus what money the Mainline Steam Foundation has been able to collect on its own, plus the hard work of a lot of railroad buffs (Long Island Journal). What a waste of the taxpayers' and other monies! For what? To rejuvenate an old rust bucket that has been lying around for 25 years to haul passengers who wouldn't have the slightest idea whether they were being pulled by steam, electric, diesel or other engine, including a jet or a moped.

The marriage of Stephanie Anne Jaffe, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ernst Richard Jaffe of Tenafly, N.J., to Dr. Stephen Joseph Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Henry Green of Portland, Me., took place yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Terrence Sempowski performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Tenafly. Katherine McCormack was the maid of honor and Richard Loranger served as the best man. The bride, a graduate of Mount Holyoke College, is a fourth-year medical student at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where her father is senior associate dean and associate dean for faculty, as well as a professsor of medicine and head of the division of hematology.

A NEW outdoor show will make its debut here Saturday when the combined Falls Village and Canaan Historical Society sponsors the first Canaan antiques festival in an old meadow just off Route 44, four miles from Canaan Center. The show will include 125 displays set up by antiques dealers from all the New England states, as well as from New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. The show promises a wide variety of furniture and accessories. Befitting a new entry on the summer circuit, the show will introduce several dealers who also are making their first bows in outdoor shows, and it is managed by a new director, Linda Forbes Hansen Turner. Mrs. Turner is the niece of Betty Forbes, a longtime show manager. Her face will be familiar to summer antiques aficionados, for Mrs. Turner has served her apprenticeship during the last 10 years as an assistant to her aunt.

One of the surest tonics for the securities markets is a severe sinking spell for interest rates. Last week, with a spectacular rate decline still in progress, the tonic worked its magic once again. Bond prices rallied and stock prices as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, hit new highs since February.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 14-- Ronald Reagan accepted pledges of fealty last night from six of the men he defeated in the Republican Presidential primaries in the first of a series of "unity dinners" aimed at helping the losers pay off their campaign debts.

JOHANNESBURG, June 14--For the past week South Africa's all-white Parliament has been debating what Government spokesmen have presented as its most important piece of legislation in decades: constitutional amendments that aim at establishing a formal dialogue between whites and the other races on ways of sharing power.

President Carter expanded his delegate total by three yesterday, picking up seven over previous projections in Colorado and losing four in Missouri as Democrats held state conventions to complete their selection of delegations. Senator Edward M. Kennedy added one delegate in Colorado and stayed the same in Missouri. Conventions also were held in Idaho, Iowa and Washington State.

About 90 American Jews, some of them prominent, have issued a statement aligning themselves with the Peace Now movement in Israel, which opposes the Government's policy of establishing further Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank territory. In advertisements in Jewish Week and other Jewish publications this weekend, the group, including Arthur Miller, the playwright, called on others to join American Friends of Peace Now and to contribute funds to allow Israeli members of that organization to come to the United States to speak to Americans.

Harry E. Figgie Jr., solidly constructed, hands in pockets, strolls under the brick arcade. As he discusses the Georgian Colonial style of the buildings in this wooded suburb of Cleveland and pauses to greet a gardener by his first name, he could be mistaken for a university president. Certainly the headquarters of A-T-O Inc., the corporation of which he is chairman and chief executive, looks more like a college campus than the soon-to-berelocated seat of a multinational conglomerate. But despite Mr. Figgie's soft voice and gentle demeanor, there is a glint of steel in his eyes when he talks about the measures he plans for A-T-O, a widely diversified industrial and consumer products company that managed to increase earnings per share by 28.8 percent during the 1974-75 recession. With another economic downturn under way, Mr. Figgie wants a repeat performance.

JACKSON TOWNSHIP BY FRIDAY, if all goes according to schedule, 167 families in this Ocean County community will be able to turn on their taps and, for the first time in 18 months, get water. It was on Dec. 21, 1978 that they were told to stop using water from their individual wells because it was contaminated. Since then, they have been using water trucked in, under court order, by the township. The ration has varied over the 18 months, but the latest allotment is 30 gallons a day a person. Now a new source of water, 900 feet below the surface, has been tapped. This week, it is expected to be supplying the 167 families through a township water system.

MY father was a feminist long before Gloria Steinem's aviatored face became famous. My memories of him are dominated by a man, no longer young, doing the dinner dishes. My brothers unkindly called him ''Susie'' for what they thought was unmasculine behavior. That must have hurt him deeply, but he kept on washing the dishes for my mother, who had gone back to work full time. He had been forced into an early retirement when our small town's major industry shut down. To him, washing dishes while my mother napped seemed the logical thing to do.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, facing a $1.8 billion penalty, the largest ever awarded in an antitrust case, said today that it would press on in its legal battle with a small company competing in the long-distance telephone business. A 12-member Federal District Court jury awarded $600 million to MCI Communications Corporation last night, an amount that Judge John F. Grady was required to triple under the punitive-damages provisions of the Sherman Antitrust Act. MCI had asked $900 million.

Bridge has been played in some peculiar settings, and many of these have been military: the trenches at Plevna, in modern Rumania, where the first recorded game of ''bridge'' was played just over a century ago; the headquarters of General Eisenhower, where he played with his staff while awaiting news of the North African landings; military hositals in Vietnam, where doctors between the arrivals of casualties. On a physically higher level was the school roof near London, England, where this columnist played during World War II on the assumption that moonlight would be present and German bombers absent. Playing while on the move is common in the comfortable lounges of the fast-vanishing ocean liners and in the relative comfort of commuter trains. Games in the air are rarer, partly because plane designers are less far-sighted and considerate than their train counterparts in providing reversible seats.

During this 40th anniversary season, the American Ballet Theater has centered several of its programs on specific artists associated in the past or present with the company. Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House was a ''Fokine evening,'' consisting of the season's first performances of ''Petrouchka,'' ''Les Sylphides'' and ''Le Spectre de la Rose.'' Among the novelties were Fernando Bujones's debut as the spectre of the rose in question and a two-minute finale from ''Firebird,'' which was a thematically logical way to keep a program from being too long and yet ending it with an allusion to still another of Michel Fokine's major ballets. The near absence of applause - it lasted a few seconds - suggested the public had expected the full 'Firebird'' or that it had not recognized the wedding ceremony from the ballet for what it was.

Karen Beth Osterweil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Osterweil of New York, was married yesterday to Alan David Walker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gene Walker of East Longmeadow, Mass. Justice Arnold L. Fein of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel. The bride, an underwriter with the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company in Hartford, was graduated from Union College, as was Mr. Walker, who is an associate product engineer with the Terry Corporation in Windsor, Conn.

Where else to start this story than at lunch. Raga, a stylish Indian place on 48th Street. Crowded. Susan Kamil - the subsidiary rights director at Simon & Schuster; dark pants and blazer, a woman of 30 with wavy dark hair - perches before a chicken dish. She is not exactly demolishing her meal. She is doing what she does professionally approximately 11 hours a day. She does it cheerfully, infectiously, lovingly, unrelentlessly. She is talking. ''We're a fulcrum for the whole industry,'' she is saying about her calling. ''We get the first third-party reads, the first reactions to books. A lot of this job is being an information bearer.''

PRESIDENT CARTER will travel to Venice, Italy's Queen of the Adriatic, in hopes of rescuing his sinking political fortunes at an economic summit conference next Sunday and Monday. But whether his fellow heads of government can or will do much to bail him out appears improbable. For one thing, with the United States economy in serious trouble both at home and abroad, Mr. Carter is scarcely in a position to present himself as an exemplar of economic leadership. And his fumbling of foreign policy, on such major issues as Iran, Afghanistan, and relations with the Soviet Union have further undermined his ability to lead.

Property, law students are taught, is ''a bundle of sticks'' - each stick a right to do something, or prevent others from doing something, with the property in question. Citing that adage, Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion in one of two cases last week in which the United States Supreme Court loosened the grip of property owners on two of their sticks - the right to exclude others and the right to be compensated for public action that threatens the value of their property. Both cases arose in California, where state courts have customarily been generous in their interpretation of public rights in private property. In the first case, PruneYard Shopping Center v. Robins, the Supreme Court upheld the state's right to require the owners of the shopping center to permit access by people who wish to distribute leaflets or otherwise peacefully exercise their First Amendment rights of free speech. ''It is true,'' wrote Justice Rehnquist, ''that one of the essential sticks in the bundle of property rights is the right to exclude others.'' But he went on to say that not every infringement on that right is a violation of the Constitution. The shopping center had not shown, he said, that the right to exclude others was so essential to business that the violation in question resulted in the ''taking'' of property without ''just compensation'' prohibited by the Fifth Amendment.

JUST like Datsun and Sony, another Japanese import is threatening the American economy - the golf economy. Isao Aoki (pronounced I-saho AH-oaki) is the cultured pearl of his sport. Around the greens, he has the touch of a lotus flower. His swing is as smooth as a silk kimono. Although virtually unknown in this country until the United States Open here at Baltusrol, he has been one of the world's best golfers in recent years. And quietly, he knows how good a golfer he is. ''How will you feel,'' he was asked when he was grouped with Jack Nicklaus for the first two rounds of the Open, ''playing with such a big name?''

A new Federal policy is intensifying the retailing wars between suburban malls and urban centers, a conflict fueled in recent years by the energy crisis and increasingly aggressive policies by municipalities and environmentalists. The new policy, which was issued as a White House directive Nov. 26 and is known as the ''Community Conservation Guidance,'' introduces the concept of ''extraterritoriality'' to planning considerations for new centers.

NORTHPORT THE students had arranged their desks in an informal circle, as usual, for Fred Craden's sociology class at Northport High school. Clad mostly in denim and soft shirts and running shoes, there was little, on the surface, that seemed unusual about the group, except for the student sitting nearly in the center. She had short, wavy gray hair, was wearing a dress and carried with her, as she does every day when she attends school, a shopping bag containing a thermos of chamomile tea, spare pencils, writing paper, a sweater and chewing gum.

TRENTON TWO New Jersey members of an interstate committee on hazardous wastes have resigned in protest over what they said was the ''secretive'' way that the state's Department of Environmental Protection introduced legislation to establish a corporation to control such wastes. Those who resigned from the Joint D.E.P.-Delaware River Basin Commission Advisory Committee on Hazardous Wastes are Frank J. Sudol, a member of the League for Conservation Legislation, and Diane T. Graves, conservation chairman of the state chapter of the Sierra Club.

OUR daughter's second child was on the way. For the first baby's homecoming I had been able to arrange a few days away from my teaching job, but Little Twosie was to make an appearance just a few days after a new term began, an impossible time for me to leave. My husband and I were talking about the problems faced by a young family that lives far from its relatives. Suddenly I thought of the solution.
Baker, Nancy and Ronald Reagan and John B. Connally By ROBERT LINDSEY

When President Carter flip-flopped last week and said he might debate John B. Anderson after all, it appeared to be a belated acknowledgment of a political reality - Mr. Carter and his advisers can't continue to shrug off Mr. Anderson's Presidential bid as ''fantasy.'' In fact, Mr. Anderson has attracted more than $2 million in contributions; his standing in the public opinion polls is inching upward. And, perhaps most important, he's meeting state deadlines and requirements for a line on the November ballot. Obviously, it's much too soon for Mr. Anderson to start measuring for drapes at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. Polls show that many voters still aren't quite sure who Mr. Anderson is. Others find the notion of voting for a independent candidate repugnant. In California, where he spent most of the week urging voters to ''put country ahead of party,'' he must collect more than 100,000 signatures by early August. Complying with complex state regulations won't be the end of it; many court fights are likely.

Samuel P. Metzger 3d, the insurance manager for Asarco Inc., a smelter of nonferrous metals, died Thursday in Riverview Hospital, Red Bank, N.J., after a long illness. He was 52 years old. Mr. Metzger, who also was president of Samuel Metzger Inc. of New York City, an insurance company, had been with Asarco since 1952 and had been manager since 1965. He was born in Rumson, N.J., and made his home in that community. He graduated from Admiral Farragut Academy in Pine Beach, N.J., and served for two years as a quartermaster in the Navy. He graduated from Brown University and attended Balliol College of Oxford University in England.

Maybe they'll call the next one Thug. This Father's Day, the fragrance industry is offering American men a wider range of choices than ever before. Twenty new men's fragrances, mostly colognes and after-shave lotions, have been introduced over the last year or so - an attempt to cash in on a market for men's scented toiletries that is expanding at a rate of 15 percent a year, outstripping the 10 percent growth in women's products. Men's products now account for $1.5 billion of the $4 billion a year in fragrance sales. ''There's been steady growth for the last decade,'' says Amelia Bassin, formerly in charge of product development for Faberge, where she introduced the male scent Brut. Now running her own consulting firm, Miss Bassin says: ''In a recession, people treat themselves to luxuries like fragrance. The industry could go through the roof if manufacturers stopped copying each other.''
Deer Park defeated Syosset, 2-0, on Joe LaDonna's two-run homer in the seventh inning today to win the Long Island scholastic baseball championship.

THE GREAT FREE ENTERPRISE GAMBIT By James Baar. 228 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $8.95. ARANSAS By Stephen Harrigan. 260 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $9.95. MUCKALUCK A Curious Episode in the Cavalry's Winning of the West. By Richard Andersen. 206 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $8.95. By MICHAEL MALONE THE business of America being business, movies have made a fortune creating films about the wickedness of making fortunes. Oddly enough, it is rarer that a novel wanders into an executive suite for longer than it takes to say ''No thanks.'' Racing there now with scalpels, old saws and blunderbuss, ''The Great Free Enterprise Gambit'' whacks open capitalist hearts and corporate souls right in their theater of operation. During this flurry of surgical slapstick, industrial waste flies like custard pies.

year reign of the Pahlavi family and of the effects of Mohammed Reza Pahlavi's dependence on the United States. SMILE PLEASE, by Jean Rhys. (Harper & Row, $10.95.) The unfinished autobiography of the late British writer, whose novels were notable for their astute, unfaltering prose. TIME OF DESECRATION, by Alberto Moravia. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) In his 21st volume of fiction, the Italian novelist has his surrogate relentlessly interrogate a beautiful Roman girl about her erotic experiences, thereby telling us some important things about the pointless violence of politics in our time. UNSETTLING EUROPE, by Jane Kramer. (Random House, $9.95.) Four elegantly written accounts of social and economic displacement in contemporary Europe: Yugoslav ''guest-workers'' in Sweden, Algerian and Ugandan refugees in France and England, and aged, alienated, orthodox Communists in Italy.

Nancy Kay Jones and Joseph Patrick Callahan, New York lawyers, were married yesterday in St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church. The bridegroom's uncle, the Rev. James M. Tubridy, Catholic chaplain at the United States Military Academy at West Point, N.Y., performed the ceremony. The bride, an associate with Haight, Gardner, Poor & Havens, is a daughter of Gardiner B. Jones Jr. of Honolulu, and Kathleen Jones of Kailua, Hawaii. Her father, a former associate editor of The Honolulu Advertiser, is director of public relations for the John A. Burns School of Medicine at the University of Hawaii. Her mother is director of public relations for the Hawaii Department of Education.

Barbara Lamb McLean, a member of the faculty of Milton (Mass.) Academy, was married yesterday to David O'Neil, a partner of Oldman O'Neil Architects in Cambridge, Mass. The ceremony was performed in the Cochran Chapel of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. by the Rev. J. Philip Zaeder, an Episcopal priest and Protestant chaplain of the academy.

WHEN Richard C. Bozzuto announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate last fall in the Hall of Flags at the State Capitol here, some politicians were skeptical about his chances. The 50-year-old Watertown insurance man was not widely known outside the State Senate, where as the minority leader of the outnumbered Republicans he occasionally gained attention with slashing attacks on the Democrats.

Touring by bus may not suit everyone's taste, but it could be an ideal way to cram a lot of sightseeing and relaxation into a short vacation at minimal expense. The Northeast is particularly rich in opportunities for bus touring and many choices are available in the New York area, particularly for people who can get themselves to starting points in Manhattan. Contrary to a popular impression, bus tours are not the preserve of solitary old people. Such tours do attract many widows and widowers, including some who are newly bereaved, because they provide an easy escape from depressing realities at home. But they also attract college students, young marrieds, couples seeking temporary relief from the cares of home and children and many foreign adults of all ages who want an easy way to see the United States.
In backgammon, many games become violent confrontations in which the less fortunate player finds himself facing a closed board with several men on the bar.
The Civil Aeronautics Board is allowing airlines, including foreign carriers, to compensate bumped passengers with free flights instead of cash payments.
PARIS, June 14 (Reuters)--A formerBlack Panther received a suspended fiveyear prison sentence here yesterday for hijacking an airliner in the United States in 1972.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 14 (UPI)--The son of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini criticized Moslem militants today for attacking leftist demonstrators Thursday in rioting near the United States Embassy. At least 400 people were injured and one was killed.

DR. MARTIN J. FELDMAN, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Suffolk County Executive last year, has emerged as a powerful, behind-thescenes figure in county government who is prob ably more influential than when he was a County Legislator.

President Carter expanded his delegate total by three yesterday, picking up seven over previous projections in Colorado and losing four in Missouri as Democrats held state conventions to complete their selection of delegations. Senator Edward M. Kennedy added one delegate in Colorado and stayed the same in Missouri. Conventions also were held in Idaho, Iowa and Washington State.

One of the surest tonics for the securities markets is a severe sinking spell for interest rates. Last week, with a spectacular rate decline still in progress, the tonic worked its magic once again. Bond prices rallied and stock prices, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average, hit new highs since February. The Dow finished at 876.37, sporting a gain of 14.85 points for the week. This advance partly reflected improving prices for such bellwether issues as General Motors, International Paper and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

HUMAN SCALE By Kirkpatrick Sale. 558 pp. New York: Coward, McCann & Geoghegan. $15.95. IT'S time someone wrote a truly systematic and convincing book to explain the virtues of small-scale institutions. The recent popularity of ideas about decentralization, appropriate technology, steady-state economics, self-sufficient living and participatory democracy provides an opportunity for an imaginative person to weave together the various strands of theory, social experiment and practical accomplishment to show what such proposals mean as a whole. Kirkpatrick Sale's ''Human Scale'' tackles this worthy project, but with disappointing results.

ON the grounds of the Hauppauge Country Club, situated along the stand of towering pines that marks the northern border of Blydenburgh Park, are two platform tennis courts. On a recent Saturday afternoon, although the season was not yet officially over, the courts lay vacant as a light breeze lazily opened and shut the door to one of the deserted decks. The adjacent courts, used for conventional tennis, were alive with activity as players took advantage of the balmy weather to sharpen their games. The abrupt exodus from the platforms to the ground-level game is one of the problems that have plagued John Lenaerts of Melville in his efforts to promote public platform tennis on the Island.

Mount St. Helens, erupting into modern folklore, is also the heroine of an old Indian legend about the ''Bridge of the Gods.'' The tale exists in several forms. According to traditions of the Klickitat Indians eventually published in a folklore study, ''Indian Legends of the Pacific Northwest'' by Ella E. Clark, the Great Spirit who lived in the sun had two brave sons: Wyeast, ruler of the Multnomah people who lived south of the Columbia River in present-day Oregon, and Pahto, chief of the Klickitat, who lived to the north in Washington. When war broke out between the tribes after many years of peace, the Great Spirit stopped the sun from shining. The cold, hungry Indians pleaded for fire from the Great Spirit.

Here's how to make big money on the stock market: ''You just watch the trends in the newspapers for a while, and see what looks good. In my case Tesoro Petroleum. You hold on to it and then short sell it after a few weeks.'' This is the counsel of one Michael Trolman. Mr. Trolman is a senior at Jericho, L.I., High School. He was the captain - and only member - of a stock market investment team at the school, one of many that participated in a portfolio management contest this spring organized by the Securities Industry Association.

Robert, once the standard for parliamentary procedure throughout the English-speaking world, were replaced by Picker's Rules, the consuming passion of Chief Petty Officer G. Nat Picker. It was not so much that Robert's Rules were no longer valid as that people observing them began making perpetual motions long sought by physicists but unacceptable among parliamentarians. Just when it seemed that Sam Rubin, the owner of John Henry, would be handing out cigars, along came Michael Berry's Sten in the closing strides yesterday to beat the favorite in the $144,250 Bowling Green Handicap on the turf at Belmont Park. Sten, an 18-1 shot in the nine-horse field, returned $38.80 for $2 to win in ending John Henry's six-race winning streak - all in stakes events. John Henry, who races under the Dotsam Stable banner, finished second, losing by a neck. A length behind the runner-up was Wildenstein Stable's Lyphard's Wish.

Marjorie Aileen Gavin, daughter of Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gavin of Chestnut Hill and Wianno, Mass., was married yesterday to Alan Churchill Ripley Lewis, son of Mrs. C. McKenzie Lewis Jr. of Washington and the late Mr. Lewis. The ceremony was performed in the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill by the Rev. Donald E. Bitsberger. He was assisted by the Rev. Linda C. Stahan. The bride had her three sisters, Patricia, who was maid of honor; Chloe Gavin and Caroline Gavin O'Neill, as her attendants. John Van Dusen Lewis was his brother's best man.

Hilary Halpern, daughter of Mrs. Raymond Halpern of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Halpern, was married yesterday to Charles Granville Cecil, son of Mrs. James McCosh Cecil of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Cecil. The Rev. Melvin Vandervoken, a Universalist Unitarian minister of the Church Center for the United Nations, performed the ceremony at the home in Manhattan of the bride's brother-in-law and sister, Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ausnit.

It was a safe bet when Martin Feinstein was appointed general director of the Washington Opera at the beginning of this year that the company would expand its activities. The former executive director of Kennedy Center in Washington who is also president of the National Symphony has always been particularly interested in opera and made the capital a livelier arts center in arranging for visits by several major European companies. He also joined the Washington Opera in time to help it celebrate its silver anniversary during the 1980-81 season, and it has seven productions lined up, five of them new. Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' will be one of the new ones, opening the season on Sept. 20 in the Center's Opera House. The cast will be headed by Teresa Zylis-Gara, Janice Hall, Mariana Paunova , Michail Svetlev (a Bulgarian tenor making his American debut) and Leo Nucci. Cal Stewart Kellogg will conduct, with Francis Rizzo, the company's dramaturg, staging the work in designs by Zack Brown.

The immediate questions as Japan prepares for elections next Sunday are who will be Prime Minister after the death of Masayoshi Ohira last week and whether the Liberal Democratic Party, which has ruled for 25 years unfettered by coalition partners, will have to take one on to hold a majority in Parliament. But undercurrents of opinion on what may be the key issue for Japan in this decade - the pace and extent of rearmament - may also be brought to the surface by the vote. Japan currently spends less than one percent of its trillion-dollar gross national product on the military, far below the average for Western industrial powers. Even if armed forces pensions and other items normally counted in North Atlantic Treaty Organization defense budgets are included, the total comes to less than 1.5 per cent of G.N.P., as compared to more than 5 percent for the United States.
To the Editor: ''There was very little planning for unexpected contingencies,'' says the report on the helicopter raid in Iran prepared for Senator Tower (news story June 6).
BEIZBOL' By MICHAEL CROSBY

WE'VE waited 27 years for this,'' said Anthony Posillipo, the Rye Town Supervisor, referring last week to the commercial development planned for 320 acres south of Westchester County Airport. ''Now Harrison and Greenwich want to take it away.'' The two municipalities have indicated in recent months, and last week during environmental hearings, that the three office buildings planned by Rye for the 1980's were not welcome in the neighborhood. It is dispute that has become more than a back-fence shouting match.

Wide-open spaceman. Today, Father's Day, the man whose books are reckoned to have sold more copies during the past year than those of any other writer is taking it easy with his family at his home in the hills of southern California. The rest is well deserved. Last week he weathered a grueling tour of eight Midwestern cities - Chicago, Moline, East Moline and Rock Island in Illinois, Davenport and Des Moines in Iowa, Omaha in Nebraska, Kansas City in Missouri - talking with press and television interviewers, autographing copies of his books for admirers, accepting keys to the cities of Davenport, Des Moines, Omaha and Kansas City. In a few days he will be on the road once more, again traveling in a superluxury bus of the style favored by Dolly Parton and Loretta Lynn, as he visits Nashville and Knoxville in Tennessee, Little Rock in Arkansas, Tulsa and Oklahoma City in Oklahoma. In Knoxville he will be made an honorary citizen of the city, in Oklahoma City an honorary citizen of the state. In Nashville, next Friday night, he will be saluted in music and words by the Charlie Davis Band on the stage of the Grand Ole Opry.

Nancy Benedict Staple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Staple of Fair Haven, N.J., was married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Red Bank, N.J., to Stephen Paul Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip H. Koch Jr. of Skidaway Island, Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Jonathan Miller performed the ceremony. The bride, until recently, a sales coordinator for Duracell Products in Bethel, Conn., was graduated from Alfred University, as was her husband. Mr. Koch, a former district sales manager in New York for Duracell, will become the Eastern regional sales manager for the company in Washington.

At St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday, Delancey Kane Hollos, daughter of Mrs. Paul E. Hollos of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., and the late Mr. Hollos, was married to Bruce Stewart Cook, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Frederick Cook of Little Silver, N.J. The Rev. Raymond Webster, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Norman Haight, performed the ceremony. Frederica Miller Davis was matron of honor for the bride, who had Marjorie Cook, sister of the bridegroom; Barbara Hough, and Susan Loney as bridesmaids. Ann and Kate Hollos were flower girls for their aunt. The bridegroom's father served as best man.

Starting next month, Alaska will begin sending out checks for $50 to $1,050 to 270,000 adult residents who qualify for a share in the ''dividend'' that Gov. Jay S. Hammond and the legislature have declared in the state's unique share-the-oil-wealth program. Mr. Hammond, a former bush pilot who sports a beard and who is something of a poet, is no socialist to be sure. He would rather be thought of as a Republican whose fiscal policies, while somewhat out of the ordinary, are fundamentally conservative. After winning his first term in 1974 (when he campaigned against ''malignant growth''), he quickly began pushing for creation of a special fund into which the state would place a significant part of the income it expected from the North Slope oil pumped from the ground at Prudhoe Bay. Voters approved the fund in 1978.

The cork has been popped off the campaign bottle by some prominent Republicans who call themselves ''Americans for Reagan.'' They're out to raise $30 million in so-called ''independent'' political contributions and they don't care if it shatters the law's restraints on private election money. The electorate can brace itself for the return of the big spenders whose money talks and whose gifts are not forgotten. We're in for a noisy campaign, just when it seemed that election reform laws might let us lower our voices. To give these highly organized individualists their due, they are probably within their constitutional rights. Congress tried to limit this kind of funding to $1,000 per person as part of a comprehensive Campaign Reform Act in 1974. It appropriated public funds for campaigning by the major party candidates provided they forgo private fund-raising and limit their spending to the ceilings set by Congress. The intention was to enforce the limit by charging candidates for every penny spent by anyone to advance their cause, except for $1,000 that individual citizens might choose to invest in electioneering by their own lights.

Larry Demic will further his education as a National Basketball Association power forward. Reggie Carter will get a lesson in what it takes to be a playmaking guard, and Hollis Copeland will get a try at switching from a small forward to a big guard. For Sly Williams, it will be another way to show the Knicks he belongs. These are some of the goals as the Knicks, for the first time, field a team in the Southern California Pro Basketball League. For many years, several N.B.A. teams have used the league as a training ground for their young players, draft choices and free agents.

SCRIPTS FOR THE PAGEANT By James Merrill. 235 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $8.95. ''SCRIPTS FOR THE PAGEANT'' is the third and final volume of an enormous poem, about 500 pages long, which James Merrill has been writing for the past five years. The first part, ''The Book of Ephraim,'' was published in 1976 as a section in Mr. Merrill's ''Divine Comedies.'' The second, ''Mirabell: Books of Number,'' was published in 1978. The entire poem is the record of many evenings spent by the poet and his companion David Jackson attending upon the Ouija board. ''The Book of Ephraim'' was composed of 26 separate but consecutive poems, corresponding to the board's alphabet from A to Z. ''Mirabell: Books of Number'' was divided into ten sections, corresponding to the board's numbers from zero to nine. ''Scripts for the Pageant'' consists of three sections, corresponding to the board's Yes and No.

THE LAST BULL MARKET Wall Street in the 1960s. By Robert Sobel. 242 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $12.95. THE best-performing stock groups in 1949 were the leathers, the utilities, the papers and the soaps. The Dow Jones Industrial Average hovered above 160, even lower than its level in 1936. Inflation was running at 2.7 percent - ''intolerable,'' Thomas Dewey called it - and 40 percent of Americans believed a new Depression was in the making. Of 375 middle-class Los Angeles families polled, only seven could name a single brokerage house.

Strikes aren't allowed in the Soviet worker's paradise, but reports circulated in Moscow last week that 70,000 employees in the huge automobile factory built by Fiat at Togliattigrad went out for two days in May. According to one report, they were protesting meat and dairy food shortages. In brief previous stoppages there, they reportedly won their demands. Bolivian Coup Again Threatened

And, although there are no rebel yells and no gray-clad cavalries charging through the pinelands, some prominent South Jersey officials insist they are not just whistling ''Dixie'' when they say they want to part company from the rest of the state.

WASHINGTON, June 14--President Carter traveled across the country this week emphasizing that cushions already in the economic system would help Americans who had lost their jobs avoid extreme financial hardship. He promised he would offer new measures if the cushions proved to be inadequate.

Three gunmen who took 36 people hostage in a Milan bank during a foiled robbery attempt yesterday surrendered early today after releasing their 22 remaining captives unharmed, the police reported. The gunmen gave themselves up 17 hours after two bank employees sounded an alarm to foil the attempt to rob the downtown office of the Banco di Roma.

As political machines go, the Citizens Charter Association was nearly unbeatable. In eight elections, beginning in 1959, its candidates for the Dallas City Council won 82 percent of the time. Yet in that same period the city was free of the kind of major scandals that plagued other machine-run towns. The reason was to be found in the nature of the Dallas machine. The Charter Association was not an organization of ward politicians and pork-barrel policies. Rather it was an alliance of powerful business interests that came together at election time to endorse and run its own slate of candidates for municipal office. During the association's years of power, Dallas was a city ruled by the business establishment.
