MONTVALE LIKE fishing, antiquing is an excuse to take an excursion into the countryside on a lovely day. One such excursion into northern Bergen County leads over country roads with eye-catching vistas of wood, field and stream, glimpses of beautifully landscaped homes in rural settings and a variety of antiques shops. Among them is Old Maple Homestead Antiques in Ridgewood, where the old, the good and the less desirable are jumbled together in several rooms in a barn behind an old sandstone house.

The Chrysler Corporation said today that ''full agreement'' had been reached with the Michigan National Bank on the institution's participation in a lender-aid package designed to help the ailing auto maker obtain loans of up to $1.5 billion. Repayment of those loans will be guaranteed by the Federal Government. With today's announcement, Chrysler has successfully lined up the backing of all Michigan lenders. The auto maker said that less than 10 potential lenders worldwide were still resisting participation in the lender-aid package.

John C. White, the Democratic national chairman, keeps saying hopefully ''the wheels are going to fly off this Republican unity, this shotgun wedding.'' He may be proved right. But it did not happen last week when it very easily could have, largely because Republicans have been paying unaccustomed attentioned to unity lately, and not just in the last few weeks. Indeed, when Ronald Reagan and Bill Brock sat down Friday and worked out the terms under which Mr. Brock will stay on as Republican national chairman through the election, they were reaching an agreement that was possible only because of the success of the efforts both of them have made since 1976.

WHEN modern conceptual artists started to use writing as part of their visual imagery, the act was hailed in some quarters as a major innovation. Of course, such a practice has been an artistic device used by the Chinese for many centuries. Chinese writing, or calligraphy, as it is known, is considered one of the highest forms of art in China, and the best of Chinese artists have used it as a means of expression.

The Rev. Joseph Wiley Cooper performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Turner Carter Bell of Windsor and Dr. and Mrs. Alexander Jr. of Winston-Salem, N.C. Mr. Bell is a partner in Bell Brothers Inc., a farm-equipment and supply company, and a tobacconist with the Universal Leaf Tobacco Company. The bridegroom's father is professor of neurosurgery at the Bowman Gray School of Medicine, Wake Forest University.

The recession: It's a ''slide.'' It's an ''adjustment.'' It's a ''short,'' ''steep,'' ''sharp,'' ''wide,'' ''speedy,'' ''severe,'' ''intense,'' ''deep,'' ''worse-than-expected,'' ''cyclical,'' ''unsustainable,'' ''precarious,'' ''plummeting'' slowdown. The words have the ring of newspapers and political oratory, but lately they are also the observations of people who are less prone to hyperbolic excess - the nation's bankers and their economists. In the hundreds of newsletters and economic reports that they and the Wall Street brokerage firms publish for their clients, most of their latest comments are grim.

Under a green and white canopy on the patio of a Washington home the other evening, a few dozen Congressmen supporting the President's renomination cheered and clapped as he exhorted them on to victory. Then he asked for everybody's votes for his 10-cent-a-gallon oil import fee. The silence was so resounding the English boxwood could be heard growing. ''Sometimes you get applause, sometimes you don't,'' Mr. Carter said wistfully. With that sort of stiff upper lip, the White House has been seeking to put the best face on the worst rupture in a long time with its nominal Democratic allies. The dispute with Congress came to a head early this month, as the leadership fumed over the President's opposition to their initial budget compromise. A week later, the legislators rushed headlong to override the President's veto of their repeal of the oil fee. Last week, the disagreement on the budget was patched up with a compromise that the White House claimed was a victory. But the fundamental issues - how to conserve energy, how to order Federal spending priorities - have been joined. The battle over them, in fact, is almost guaranteed to get more contentious as the year goes on.

Eugene Riguidel of France took the lead from Philip Weld of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on the eighth day of the singlehanded trans-Atlantic yacht race today.

At the age of 42, when most baseball players are back on the farm, Willie McCovey is back on the bench, and he's not happy about it. With 521 home runs in 22 summers, he ranks as the leading power hitter in the big leagues, tied with Ted Williams as the eighthranking home-run hitter in history. But like most senior citizens in the game, he resists the thought of letting go. And he is vexing his bosses on the San Francisco Giants by clamoring for more action. ''Willie thinks he can play forever,'' Manager Dave Bristol of the Giants said at Shea Stadium before the Giants played the Mets last night. ''It's an admirable quality, and he has won a few games for us this season with hits. But now he's ticked off at me for not playing him every day.''

Flickinger of Buffalo and Mr. Flickinger Jr. of East Aurora, N.Y. The Rev. Bert Marino of Seton Hall University performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Holy Trinity in East Hampton. The bride, an associate with the New York law firm of Cravath, Swaine & Moore, was graduated from the Spence School magna cum laude and Phi Beta Kappa from the University of Pennsylvania and from the Columbia University School of Law, where she was a member of The Law Review. Her father is a partner in the New York law firm of Brumbaugh, Graves, Donohue & Raymond. Her mother was formerly on the research staff of Life magazine. To the Editor: Interfaith Adopt-a-Building is a community-based organization on the Lower East Side that has worked in the last 10 years to defend our neighborhood and meet the housing needs of our low-income residents. This has included a variety of strategies such as tenant organizing, tenant self-management and the sweat-equity rehabilitation of vacant buildings using local labor.

THEY talk about it on commuter trains, in car pools, during coffee breaks and over lunch. They discuss it with strangers as well as friends. The world situation, the political campaign, the economy and even golf and tennis are forgotten. Instead, their conversations concern the size of lettuce heads, whether tomatoes have been staked and whether squirrels steal strawberries. More than ever, suburban men are expounding on the joys of tilling a vegetable garden. Car-poolers have been seen climbing into automobiles carrying flats of seedlings to share with a fellow rider or co-worker. Executives who once boarded the train clutching a bunch of just-plucked flowers intended for a city employee now carry shopping bags filled with lettuce. Wives complain about watery cocktails and cold dinners because husbands rush home, change their clothes and hurry to the garden to pick weeds.

South African troops withdrew from southern Angola today carrying tons of weapons and equipment captured in an incursion designed to destroy encampments used by Namibian guerrillas, a senior military spokesman said.

The hitchhiker seen near the Marriott Inn at about the time Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the civil rights leader, was shot has told the police that he did not see the shooting. Fort Wayne's deputy police chief, Ernest Walter, said today that the 19-year-old man, who was not identified, was interviewed by the authorities yesterday about the sniper attack on Mr. Jordan, the president of the National Urban League, who is recuperating at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.

The scene is the recent presentation ceremony for China's equivalent of the Academy Awards, just revived for the first time since the Cultural Revolution. Only instead of a sex goddess in a clinging gown rising breathlessly to accept a Chinese ''Oscar,'' the speechmaker is an earnest young soldier in the baggy green attire of the army. He has been selected as a representative of the military, ''to show the unity between the army and the movie industry,'' the program notes say, and he begins his talk with a crisp salute. ''We soldiers serving on the steppes of Inner Mongolia can go without vegetables for a month or two,'' the soldier intones solemnly. ''But we can't go without seeing a movie. Please produce more films.''

The 1950's occupy a special place in the development of contemporary photography. When the decade began, still and motion picture photography provided most of the pictures most people saw. By the end of decade, both had been replaced by television as the dominant pictorial medium, and photography had begun the move into museums and galleries that is such a conspicuous feature of its recent history. To provide an overview of this crucial decade is the aim of the exhibition ''Photography of the Fifties: An American Perspective'' at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue and 94th Street, through July 13. The exhibition is not about the 50's so much as about photography in the 50's, and it is more of a potpourri than a historical survey. There is no network of wall labels to guide the viewer through the decade's intricacies, and the novice may be pardoned some confusion when he looks up from William Garnett's semi-abstract aerial shots of sand dunes and eroded hills to see, in one direction, the elegant Vogue cover ladies of Irving Penn, and in the other, Richard Avedon's de-glamorized celebrities. Some of the photographers represented, though still active in the 50's, had already done their best and most characteristic work in previous decades -Imogen Cunningham and Ansel Adams, for example - and others, such as Philippe Halsman, are represented by uncharacteristic works.

Just when it looked as if pitching and defense had pushed the heavy hitters out of the limelight, Bobby Murcer came up with two out in the ninth inning today and hit a twostrike, two-run homer that enabled the New York Yankees to beat the Oakland A's, 2-1. Until that moment, Rick Langford of the A's had held the Yankees to no runs and four hits, while his mound opponent, Ed Figueroa, had surrendered one run on three hits.

ROUGH STRIFE By Lynne Sharon Schwartz. 200 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $9.95. FOR the upper-middle classes, it has been said, marriage is the only adventure left. This is a charming notion - a brave little bank of explorers sets off two by two for the mysterious and uncharted coasts of intimacy, while friends and relations cheer and toss in the air their copies of Psychology Today - but it's also a little sad. Are there really no new worlds to conquer except the ones in the bedroom and the kitchen? Must one's energies be focused relentlessly inward, as though society at large had no use for them?

A YEAR after two financially troubled area theaters -the Westchester Theater in Tarrytown and the nearby Nanuet Theater in Rockland County - reopened under new management, one is about to fold again while the other is flourishing. Dick Clark, the television host and producer, took over management of the Westchester Premier Theater - whose operation was marred by bankruptcy and criminal indictment - changed its name to the Dick Clark Westchester Theater and vowed to turn it into a financial success by bringing in show-business headliners who would appeal to the county's diversified population.

Dr. Marks encouraged women to demand that boards of education extend the school hours from 7:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., adding: ''Why should a parent already paying $3,000 a year in taxes for education have to pay another $700 a year for babysitting services inferior to what the public schools can offer?''

The Atlantic City ethics code, enacted by ordinance in April 1979 prohibits elected or appointed officials and city employees from taking official action involving companies in which they hold stock. It also requires about 150 key employees to file annual financial statements with the City Clerk each January, listing, among other things, any stocks they or their spouses may own.

COLLECTIONS at previously published essays, recycled work from yesterday's discarded newspapers and magazines, can be extremely gratifying for an author. Forgotten reviews, vaguely remembered interviews and articles are brought together in a seemingly permanent form for a new public. This is a chancy business, especially for writers of personal journalism; articles written in the flush of what-everyone-is-talking-about can seem frivolous, negligible or dated when embalmed between hard covers.

The small Fishermen's Museum on the waterfront in Gloucester, Mass., on Cape Ann, is a homemade museum in every respect. In fact, it has somewhat the aspect of a ''show'' small-town children might put on in a cellar - some old bones, some treasures dug up in the back yard, objects fished from the sea, a sheet for showing home movies. This museum, which is only three years old, is up the road less than 20 miles from the patrician, formal wealth of the East India Marine Hall of the Peabody Museum in Salem, Mass. The contrast with the glass-cased symmetry of East India Hall makes the gritty, salty reality of the Fishermen's Museum particularly welcome. It also gives adults a vivid memory of why children soon grow desperate in traditional do-not-touch museums: In the Fishermen's Museum, if it looks interesting to touch, it can be touched, handled or tried on. Bells are there to be sounded, whalebones to be stroked or grasped. The open seams of a wooden boat are yawning for cotton batting nearby, and the caulking tool is there if anyone wants to hammer it in. An oak plank is there to be drilled for a trunnel - a wooden peg, properly a treenail, that in the days of wooden boats was what kept the vessels tight. A foghorn can be pushed with noisy results; a line can be coiled.

When an executive takes a job at Siemens AG, the giant West German electrical company, he writes down on an index card the name of the person he wants to succeed him. This forward-looking management selection technique meant there was less uncertainty amoung shareholders and customers when Peter von Siemens, the 68-year-old chairman of the company's supervisory board, announced earlier this year that he would step down in the beginning of 1981 leaving the company without a Siemens family member at the top for the first time in its 133-year history.

One of the most bitter rivalries in the North American Soccer League produced plenty of excitement and drew the league's largest crowd of the season tonight as the Tampa Bay Rowdies beat the Cosmos, 4-3, in a shootout. After trailing on three occasions during the humid evening before a crowd of 54,247 at Tampa Stadium, the Cosmos tied the game with 47 seconds left in regulation time on Giorgio Chinaglia's second goal of the contest and 16th of the season.

Anne Mausolff calls the Vermont hike she leads an inn-to-inn ramble, but my wife and I, after embarking on the four-day venture, called it a hike for dilettantes. The idea seemed simple enough. Spend the night in a Vermont inn and set out next morning, after a country breakfast, on a hike that would end that afternoon at another inn. In a nutshell, it was outdoorsmanship without the lumps, hill and dale with showers, the call of the mild instead of the wild.

BUNCHES of fresh herbs are one of the joys of summer. Dry, graygreen flakes from a jar in the pantry serve their purpose at certain times of the year, but in many dishes there is no substitute for satin leaves of basil or sprigs of fragrant thyme plucked right from the garden. According to nurserymen on the Island, the interest in cultivating fresh herbs has steadily increased over the last three to four years. ''Our herb sales must be up 15 to 20 precent over last year,'' said Russ Ireland, owner of the Martin Viette Nurseries in East Norwich, where more than 80 varieties of herbs are cultivated. ''We have always specialized in herbs, but we see them becoming more and more popular.''

FREDERICK'S in Melville is a pleasant place to dine. The pair of tailored brown, beige and white dining rooms on the main floor of an unprepossessing white house just off Route 110 are furnished with attractively set tables and contemporary cane chairs. Flowers and a few framed prints soften the look. Another small room with a bar is up a narrow flight of stairs. Although the cuisine and its presentation are rather formal, and the restaurant has a smart look, the crowd tends to be somewhat casual. Jackets are not the unanimous style for men.

Elizabeth Locke Buck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Roome Buck of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday to Donald Lewis White, son of Edward White Jr. of Wyckoff, N.J., and the late Donna Louise DeVoe White. The Rev. Alfred H. Whisler performed the ceremony in St. Mark's Episcopal Church. Amy Merrill Buck was maid of honor for her sister. Thomas Whittier Day ws best man. Mrs. White, a 1976 alumna of Goucher College, received an M.B.A. last month from Duke University. Her father is president of the Texaco Oil Trading Company, a division of Texaco Inc. in Harrison, N.Y.

Still balanced, though definitely not bipartisan and one full month late, the 600-plus-page ''Budget of the U.S. Government Fiscal 1981'' last week became official. Or rather, Version No. 4 did (the first two were presented by the White House; the third, the product of the Congressional budget process, was voted down last month.) Impelled by the leadership's holding hostage sensitive 1980 spending measures, and with at least one eye on the voters back home, senators and representatives praised themselves for their discipline, and passed a $613.6 billion compromise budget for 1980 only slightly different from the version condemned by President Carter as too generous for defense and too harsh on social programs. (White House and Congress still at odds, page 4.) No one expects Versions No. 5 and 6 (under the Congressional budget process, two more votes are due before Sept. 30) to reflect the same discipline.

To the Editor: The trouble with the draft is that it is selective. Make it universal service instead. Require two years of national service for all young people, 18 to 20 or when they finish high school.

Tilney Jr. of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Anne Cutler Williams Tilney, was married in Gladstone, N.J., yesterday to Bernard Peyton 3d, son of Mrs. Tilney and the late Mr. Peyton Jr. The ceremony in St. Luke's Episcopal Church was performed by Canon John R. Morrow, assisted by the Rev. Linda Peyton, sister of the bridegroom. The bride, a graduate of Rosemary Hall and Trinity College, class of '75, received an M.A. degree in education from Trinity last month. Her father has been associated since 1951 with the Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital, where he was formerly chairman of the department of surgery.

In last weeks's review by Vivien Raynor of David Nash's environmental art at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences in Morristown, the name of Interpace Corporation of Parsippany was inadvertantly omitted as one of the sponsors.

More than 50 local officials and government employees here have bought or sold property for use by gambling casinos, have invested in casino stock or have formed other financial links with the gambling industry that is reshaping this resort city. These financial ties are not illegal so long as the officials do not participate in actions affecting companies in which they hold an interest. But some government officials say that the pattern of involvement is so pervasive that it hinders the independence of city efforts to regulate the city's gambling industry and to provide for orderly growth of the casinos that have become the catalyst for economic redevelopment here.

Priscilla Mills Clark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry B. Clark of Huntington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Andrew J. Daly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Daly of New York and Huntington. The Rev. William Rogers performed the ceremony at the Old First Presbyterian Church. He was assisted by the Rev. Patrick Grace, a Roman Catholic priest. Cynthia Iserson and Mark Daly, brother of the bridegroom, attended the couple as maid of honor and best man. The bride was graduated last year from Rollins College. She is an elementary teacher at the St. James Cathedral School in Orlando, Fla., where Mr. Daly attends the University of Central Florida as a member of the class of '81.

Bernard K. Johnpoll, a former journalist and script writer, is professor of political science at the State University in Albany. His documentary ''Years of Sackcloth and Ashes: 1929-1933'' will be televised in 1981. By BERNARD K. JOHNPOLL ALBANY Cold, gray Albany, New York State's capital city, is the new mecca for scholarly screen buffs. Within the State Archives, in the Nelson Rockefeller Empire State Mall, is the world's largest collection of film scenarios - the last remains of the state's movie censors, the Motion Picture Division of the Department of Education.

Mayor Koch's message of present sacrifice for ultimate fiscal redemption won over two important converts last week. The Board of Estimate and the City Council approved a $13.6 billion budget for 1981, almost identical to the Mayor's proposal. The Mayor declared the new spending plan the city's ''first truly balanced budget in more than a decade,'' and it came, as he had hoped, a year ahead of schedule. Mr. Koch also said the budget was ''veto-proof,'' apparently because he anticipates no insurmountable problems with the contingencies that threaten the balance.

Will Grand Prix racing be able to avoid the kind of split that crippled Indianapolis car racing last year? The odds favoring such a split increased last week when Jean-Marie Balestre, president of the Federation Internationale du Sport Auto, rejected a compromise agreement worked out by representatives of his organization and Bernie Ecclestone, head of the Formula One Constructors' Association. Under terms of the agreement, the constructors would have acknowledged the international governing authority of the federation in matters concerning Grand Prix racing. In return, the role of the constructors within that organization would have been formally acknowledged.

Vitagraph Studios in Brooklyn, a major movie production center in the heyday of silent films and since 1964 the site of the Yeshiva University High School for Boys in that borough, will re-emerge under a new name next year. It will be the second largest motion-pictureand television-production center on the East Coast. The largest is the Astoria Studios in Queens. The block-long property on 14th Street between Chestnut and Locust Streets in the Flatbush section has been sold to International Studio Systems Inc. for $1.6 million, according to Herbert Tenzer, president of Yeshiva University's board of trustees.

This summer's White Mountains Festival of the Arts, which will present more than 60 musical artists in performances ranging from pops to classical, will be in residence at the Mount Washington Hotel at Bretton Woods, N.H. The festival is moving there after several years at nearby North Conway. A performance shell and stage are being constructed on a grassy slope behind the 250-room hotel by the producers of the program, the White Mountains Center for the Arts. Spectators will be able to watch festival events from the quarter-mile-long wooden veranda that encircles the hotel. A lower veranda will provide additional seating.

FASHIONABLE department stores, reflecting both the ''high tech'' style in home decor and the fact that professional wares are a better investment, are doing a fast trade selling sturdy restaurant equipment as kitchen furnishings. Professional heavy-gauge cookware, stainless-steel utensils and institutional china and glassware are practical and made to last. Although the character of the American kitchen ranges from comfortable country charm to the sleek styling of a European prototype, the modern American cook has always sought efficiency in food preparation and cleanup. The ''form-follows-function'' design of professional wares dissolves the barriers of personal taste.

THE man who walked into the Pindar Gallery at 127 Greene Street in Manhattan one recent afternoon introduced himself to Martha Bjoza-Reinken, one of the founders of the gallery, as an artist. He carried a portfolio of his work - a collection of oil paintings and montages. He said he had taught art at a college in the Middle West before moving to Saratoga, N.Y., last year. On this particular day, he was knocking on the doors of galleries in SoHo, looking for one that would allow him to exhibit his work. The encounter reminded Mrs. Bjoza-Reinken, a paintor and sculptor from New Rochelle, of the days she spent walking the streets of SoHo and Manhattan's East Side, trying to find a gallery to exhibit her work.

An 89-year-old man was attacked by a fellow passenger shortly before noon yesterday on a crowded southbound Lexington Avenue subway train, the transit police said. They said the victim, Pierre See, was beaten by Robert Carlin, 39, who was then arrested as the train pulled into the Union Square station. The motive was unknown. Mr. See was treated and released at Cabrini Medical Center.

C., and the late Mr. Block, is an alumna of St. Mary's College in Raleigh, N.C., and the University of Georgia. Her father retired as president of the Block Southland Manufacturing Company, shirt manufacturer in Wilmington.

They emerged periodically to rant against the Federal Government or to echo the war cry of their presidentelect, Robey Clark: "Find more oil and gas!"

The Civil Aeronautics Board is allowing airlines, including foreign carriers, to compensate bumped passengers with free flights instead of cash payments. After granting applications for the change from American Airlines and Braniff Airways, it issued an order permitting all airlines to offer the free-transportation option. A C.A.B. spokesman said he expected most other airlines to adopt free-flight compensation. Under the new policy, airlines have the choice of offfering travelers bumped from overbooked flights a voucher for a free flight or a check for cash in addition to honoring the ticket the passenger bought but was unable to use. The C.A.B. stipulates that the passenger must have the option of a free flight or cash and that the the value of the free flight must be at least equal to the monetary compensation, which is based on the mileage of the overbooked flight.

By an odd coincidence, the recorded vocal recitals released over the past couple of months present an interesting dichotomy. On the one hand, there are half a dozen disks featuring some of the most glamorous voices of the day, singers whose principal attraction lies in the sheer beauty of the sound they make rather than in interpretive acuity, stylistic perception or musical intellect. On the other hand, there are also a number of recitals from singers less generously endowed by nature, yet who compensate by cultivating a specialized repertory with unusual refinement and sophistication. It hardly comes as a surprise that the first group is far and away more internationally acclaimed than the second. The world of opera in particular has always prized the pure sound of a voice above everything else, and while singers blessed with a throat of gold are not necessarily bereft of musical intelligence, they are principally admired for the innate quality of their voices. Only rarely does a Maria Callas appear, a singer with a flawed instrument who can still command world-wide attention through the indomitable force of a unique musical and dramatic personality. By the same token, a singer who combines vocal perfection with a riveting interpretive gift is an even rarer phenomenon.

Dave Kingman, the Chicago Cubs' slugging outfielder. was fined one day's pay today by General Manager Bob Kennedy for missing yesterday's game, a 7-6 loss to the Atlanta Braves. Based on Kingman's estimated annual salary of $225,000, the fine would amount to about $1,250.

Southern Yemen's former head of state and leader of the Yemeni Socialist Party, now under house arrest here, was strongly opposed to close relations with neighboring Arab countries, Government officials and diplomats here say. The deposed leader, Abdel Fattah Ismail, felt that the future of Southern Yemen lay exclusively under the tutelage of the Soviet Union, the officials and diplomats assert.

With draft registration expected to begin next month, a number of antidraft organizations have begun laying plans for demonstrations, vigils and civil disobedience this summer and fall. Many groups plan to urge 19- and 20-year-olds not to register. Other organizations, preferring not to counsel illegal action, are preparing to provide legal help for those who defy the law. Still other organizations, particularly religious pacifist groups, will call on those who register to sign up as conscientious objectors.

Mary Louise Fager and James Francis Hayden were married yesterday in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Wellesley, Mass. The Rev. Eugene Goll and the Rev. James MacColl performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles A. Fager of Wellesley. Her father is chairman of the department of neurosurgery at the Lahey Clinic in Boston.

With another recession under way, there is now an opportunity to invest in real estate and profit from the last downturn. This can be accomplished by buying so-called used units in real estate limited partnerships that were formed in the 1970's. Such partnerships pool investors' money and use it to form a limited partnership with a general partner, which is usually an experienced real estate firm. The general partner then buys properties, usually apartments, which provide tax-sheltered income to the limited partners of about 6 to 8 percent a year. The income, however, is almost immaterial compared with the capital gains investors can realize when the properties are sold, usually seven to 10 years after the partnership is formed.

Jane Owen Arneberg, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Dale Owen of Houston, was married yesterday to Peter Leslie Jarvis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Serge Jarvis of New York and Shippan Point, Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Mortimer Glover, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the Roofless Church (interdenominational) in New Harmony, Ind., a town established in 1824 by the bride's ancestors.

WHAT I am doing in this new book is claiming America,'' declares Maxine Hong Kingston. ''That seems to be the common strain that runs through all the characters. In story after story Chinese-American people are claiming America, which goes all the way from one character saying that a Chinese explorer found this place before Leif Ericsson did to another one buying a house here. Buying that house is a way of saying that America - and not China - is his country.'' Long snakes of galley proofs line the walls of the living room and small dining room of the Honolulu home she and her husband Earll, an actor, bought in 1978. ''We never really made a decision to stay here,'' she notes, though they have lived on the island of Oahu with their son Joseph for the last 12 years. But the deal on the new house was clinched when they discovered an office upstairs, ''the very writer's garret of your imagination.'' Their New England-style house looks good-naturedly incongruous in its setting. Five kinds of ginger bloom in the yard, which ends at a precipitous mountain slope lush with vegetation. Directly inside the front door is a place for leaving snowboots.

f913THE cheaper liquor prices predicted by Governor Byrne, Attorney General John J. Degnan and other state officials who fought for decontrol in 1979 should be appearing by now. And, state officials say, they should drop even more after July 9, when the last price controls end. After that, the only pricing regulation governing retailers of liquor, wine and cordials will be that they cannot sell below their wholesale costs.

The music publishing industry, which fought hard to win adoption of the Copyright Act of 1976, has fired the first legal salvo charging copyright infringements under the Federal law, with several still to come. In related suits filed in Federal District Court here May 29, three music publishers accused Longwood College, a state institution in Farmville, Va., and Dr. Louard E. Egbert Jr., a music teacher there, of illegally reproducing copyrighted music, passing out the copies to students and having the works performed.

Her father is vice president of the Business Coverage Corporation in Holmdel.
INCONVIENCE By JAMES P. STERBA

It used to be said of the death penalty in America that executions were random, without pattern, more like Russian roulette than a design for punishing crime. Indeed, the Supreme Court so held in 1972, finding capital punishment, as administered then, both cruel and unusual. That won't be quite so true if Jack Potts, after twice changing his mind about whether to appeal a death sentence, is electrocuted at Reidsville State Prison in Georgia. Of the four Americans put to death since executions were resumed three years ago, he would be the third who simply gave up the fight for life. Like Gary Gilmore in Utah and Jesse Bishop in Nevada, he would have succeeded in preventing others from battling to save him, although strong legal points could be made on his behalf.

As far as the United States Golf Association is concerned, Hubert Green set a championship record in the United States Open today when he shot eight consecutive 3's from the ninth through the 16th holes on Baltusrol Golf Club's Lower Course. ''We're putting it in the record book next year,'' said one U.S.G.A. official. ''And eight straight 3's will be the record until somebody proves us wrong. Until now the U.S.G.A. has not kept any such record.''

Nearly 13 months later, Harold Weston can still see everything clearly in his mind's eye. The official scorecards said that Thomas Hearns had gone ahead in the early rounds of their welterweight fight at Las Vegas. Weston says that Hearns was tiring by the sixth round, that his own plan was working, that he was in a position to win. He heard a voice in Hearns's corner say, ''Jab!'' He saw the left jab coming. It did not seem very dangerous until the thumb went in his right eye.

Completely repainting the interior of his $139,000 Dutch Colonial home in Fairfield, Conn., was the way that Sherman Moulton decided to tackle the difficult task of making his home more appealing in today's marketplace. Contracts for the sale of the house were scheduled to be signed this week. Meantime, while insisting that sales have been picking up in his area recently, Robert Preston of Westwood Homes, residential builders on Long Island, is offering three of his model homes in Holbrook furnished, together with a new car in each garage.

The Marine Corps awarded Bronze Stars yesterday to three journalists who had rescued a mortally wounded marine under enemy fire during the Tet offensive in 1968. The medals are the first to be given to civilians for Vietnam war heroism. The three journalists were Alvin Webb, of United Press International; David Greenway, then of Time Magazine and now with The Boston Globe, and Charles Mohr of The New York Times. They were covering a battle in Hue on February 19, 1968 when a marine was shot through the throat.

FRIENDS may desert you, your job might go sour, but your alumni association will never forget you. Shortly after graduation, between packing away the few textbooks that I didn't sell to overzealous juniors and awaiting my first job, subtle prods in business reply envelopes began to arrive, reminding me that for a limited time only I was eligible to join the alumni association at a special discount rate. For me, the letters began coming from the State University at Albany. As a freshly minted graduate, I found it amusing to suddenly be elevated into the position of ''one of our honored alumni.'' I had always pictured alumni as middle-aged men in tweed suits who drifted in and out of John O'Hara short stories worrying about who played on Yale's team when, and beat whom.

John J. Santucci says he does not have money, but he does have friends from a long career in politics and a conservative image in contrast to his three opponents in the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York. Mr. Santucci, the Queens District Attorney, had never formally announced for the Senate when, on Thursday, he went to the state convention in Albany and was, just as the three announced candidates, given a free-ride onto the primary election ballot - no petitions needed - by party leaders.

New York State sent 70 police officers to the St. Regis Indian Reservation yesterday to head off growing tension between rival armed groups of Mohawks, who had taken up positions along a state highway running through the reservation. Members of one faction agreed today to pull back from the positions in an arrangement with the state, which agreed to establish a temporary ''strong post'' of state troopers on or near the reservation, which is on the New York-Ontario-Quebec border.

For the past five years, Senator William Proxmire has been awarding a Golden Fleece of the Month to Federal agencies for wasting public money. Among the achievements recounted in this good-humored yet serious book: Research by the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration on why inmates wish to escape from jail; an investigation by the Department of Agriculture into how long it takes to cook eggs for breakfast; a study by the Federal Aviation Administration of the physiques of airline stewardesses.

Smith and State Senator Walter N. Sheil has deteriorated in recent months, and last Tuesday night it came apart. The split occurred when Mr. Smith challenged Mr. Sheil's reelection as chairman of the Hudson County Democratic organization, a post he assumed in 1977 with Mr. Smith's blessing.

THE best-performing stock groups in 1949 were the leathers, the utilities, the papers and the soaps. The Dow Jones industrial Average hovered above 160, even lower than its level in 1936. Inflation was running at 2.7 percent--"intolerable," Thomas Dewey called it--and 40 percent of Americans believed a new Depression was in the making. Of 375 middle-class Los Angeles families polled, only seven could name a single brokerage house.

A flurry of excitement rippled through the fishermen and sunbathers on the 69th Street pier in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon when someone spotted what looked like a 40-foot whale rolling offshore in Upper New York Harbor.

Kim Warwick, ranked No. 57 in the world, upset second-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-3, 6-4, in windy weather today and reached the final of the $125,000 Queen's Club grass tournament. John McEnroe, less troubled by the conditions, used his heavy serve to defeat Victor Pecci of Paraguay, 6-4, 6-0. Gerulaitis was the No. 2 seed.

Helen Wolff hefted a copy of what may well be the most unusual novel of the year -''Evening Edged in Gold'' by Arno Schmidt - and said without hesitation: ''He's the German James Joyce. The book is written in the style of 'Finnegans Wake.' And that's the way we are publishing it, with the peculiarities of language and the typography as close as possible to the German original. The book is 18 inches high and 12 1/2 inches wide, printed on yellow paper. Except for the authentic illustrations that are worked into the text, the novel is in typescript form.'' Who was the author and what is his book about? Mrs. Wolff explained: Arno Schmidt (1914-1979) lived in a little village in Hanover and wrote 20 books. He had an abiding interest in American and English literature. He translated Edgar Allan Poe and William Faulkner into German. His books were published by S. Fischer in West Germany, where ''Evening Edged in Gold'' (''Abend Mit Goldrand'') appeared in 1975. But none of his works had ever been published in the United States.

The police are taking radical measures to reduce traffic for the foreign motorists expected during the Olympic Games. The police, in their blue summer uniforms, have taken to throwing the book at car owners. They are increasingly flagging down drivers who exceed the city speed limit of 37 miles an hour, that is 60 kilometers, although Moscow traffic usually moves at closer to 50 miles an hour. The penalty for speeding is usually swift and simple. The motorist has his license plates removed on the spot and is told to come around and pick them up ''after the Olympics.''

Roberts of Upper Brookville, L.I. Judge Sol M. Wachtler of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony. The bride, who graduated with the class of '80 from Skidmore College, has joined the Albany office of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith. Her father is a lawyer with the New York firm of J. Robert Morris and counsel to Aetna Life and affiliated companies.

The engagement of Elise Rose Guadagna, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore J. Guadagna of Northport, L.I., to Robert John Quinn, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Quinn of St. James, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents. A December wedding is planned.

As a declaration of independence from American diplomacy in the Middle East, the European allies' pronouncement in Venice Friday was merely pathetic. No self-evident truths, no decent respect for the opinions of mankind, no pledge of mutual fortunes and honor. Just a petulant cry that Europe wants to play big-league power, too, and a cramped call for a ''comprehensive'' solution, their code language for a denunciation of Camp David. The Europeans did not even have the decency to mention, let alone analyze, that one solid achievement in the region so far. As a declaration of strategic purpose, their doctrine was absurd. The essence of the conflict, the agonizing tension between Israeli security and Palestinian rights, was simply asserted to be reconcilable. The anti-Israeli majority of the United Nations was put forward as a reliable guarantor of the peace. And the Palestine Liberation Organization, which only last week recommitted itself to the destruction of all Israel (''complete liberation of Palestine, the liquidation of the Zionist entity''), was promised a central seat at the negotiations and an early interview by Europeans as they design their ''initiative.''

Bill Russell hit a home run, and Pedro Guerrero added a three-run clout in a four-run third inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers romped to an 8-0 victory over Montreal tonight, halting the Expos' 10-game winning streak. Burt Hooton scattered six hits, struck out four and walked two to win his sixth game in nine decisions for the Dodgers. Ross Grimsley (2-4), the Montreal starter, was taken out after three innings and received a chorus of boos from the crowd of 44,585 home fans. Grimsley allowed eight hits and six runs, five of which were earned.

IT has been a bad year for the ''Sons of the Bad News Bears,'' as one mother dubbed the Cubs, and today the score resembles football more than baseball. With carefully blank faces, they have been pounded on the backsides and cheered by the winning team. Now they slump, streaked with sweat and mud (and, I suspect, tears in a case or two), listening to the wrapup. The three adult coaches pace tensely behind the chain-link fence that separates the players' bench from the playing field. The children look like defeated, caged animals facing their keepers. ''Listen you guys, and listen good,'' says Josh. ''You're in the major leagues now and this is serious.'' He recaps the game, 3 zip for the Cubs at the top of third inning, error after error costing run after run by the other team. ''It was like you guys gave up, or something,'' he says. ''I mean, you just can't do that.''

HAVING finished my teaching for the semester, I now have time to clean my closets and examine my soul. We are all, these days, searching in different ways for our true identities. A friend of mine was searching for hers in a consciousness-raising group, but she quit. The group contained the about-to-be-ex-wife and the about-tobe-second-wife of the same man, and my friend said the drama got to be too much. Sometimes, it's better to keep your consciousness low. But the 70's did teach us to seek our essences, souls, karmas. We learned not only to understand ourselves, but also to reveal them proudly, without shame. In the interest of a brave honesty, I have decided to describe the real me that emerged from my soul-searching. While going through a stack of junk mail the other day, I had a sudden insight. It is related to the following facts:
stucco building with covered arched walkways, a red-tile roof and that Mediterranean tower, Perona Farms has certainly grown from the simple boarding house started by the Perona family in 1917.

A yellow mite of a bird bursts out of a dense thicket, rockets 10 feet straight up into the air, where it seems to hang as it sings witchity witchity, and then drops like a stone back into the bushes. "Very obvious courtship ritual," says Berna Weissman of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., as she jots a note in a spiral pad.

Big-band fans have been talking wistfully about a hoped-for return of the big bands ever since they began fading away 30 years ago. But as such established big-band leaders as Duke Ellington, Guy Lombardo and Stan Kenton have died, a revival of the era has seemed more and more unlikely.
For baseball fans, the goal is Yankee Stadium. For racing enthusiasts, it is Indianapolis. For tennis freaks, Wimbledon.

ALBANY, June 14--In the waning hours of the Senate's closing session, the sergeant-at-arms stood within the Senate chamber blocking the handsome red-leather doors. He would unlatch the brass lock only on instructions from Senator Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader.
By Easter I was, like most Parisians, overcome by a longing for a quiet country holiday. But where was I to go? The chateau hotels were ruled out by the State of my bank account, Brittany was ...

It would have been an ideal arrangement. A woman had a room in a five-bedroom apartment on Central Park West in Manhattan that she wanted to sublet for the summer. Tina Ravitz, a law student from Virginia, needed a place for seven weeks while she worked as a summer associate at a law firm in Manhattan. In early spring, an agreement was struck between the two, but just weeks before Miss Ravitz was to move in, the tenant decided to stay in her apartment after all. Miss Ravitz arrived in Manhattan, having found temporary sanctuary on a friend's living-room sofa bed, and began her search for an apartment.

Ya'acov Levinson, a tall man in a starched white shirt, dark tie and gray suit, sits straight-backed in his spare office at Bank Hapoalim overlooking this city. He takes a long drag on an Israeli cigarette, sucks the air out of his cheeks and refills them with smoke, blowing it out so forcefully that he resembles the fairy tale image of wind, or perhaps God breathing life into Adam. The image fits. In his 11 years at its helm, this forceful man has breathed new life into Bank Hapoalim, which means bank of the workers (controlling interest belongs to the Histadrut, Israel's mammoth labor union). Mr. Levinson, who is 47, is credited with having turned a once lazy bank that was financing agricultural cooperatives and kibbutzim into a modern international banking group.

The ice cream soda, an American cultural import, has reappeared in Peking after an absence of 14 years. The Dong Fang Department Store in central Peking tried offering sodas June 8. Response was overwhelming, and the store is hurriedly building a permanent soda fountain, the shop manager, Wu Silu, reported. Served in glasses resembling root-beer mugs, the sodas cost the equivalent of 25 cents. Chinese shoppers lined up to buy them. The shop, open for only four hours each afternoon because of a shortage of syrup and ice cream, sold 1,500 sodas a day in its first three days.

Amid cries of ''magnifico,'' 130 Cuban refugees left this resettlement camp today for a flight to Miami and meetings with American sponsors. It was the first outgoing flight since the refugees began arriving here May 18 aboard 56 flights from Florida after reaching the United States in the boatlift from Cuba. The 737 jet left with every seat occupied. The Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration arranged the transportation. William Thoma, a committee member, said, ''We're trying to get every vehicle that we can to move them out.'' Miami has been the desired destination for many Cubans here.

The New Jersey Supreme Court issued rulings in two cases this week that were expected to affect thousands of divorce cases in the state and the support and maintenance agreements growing out of them. In the first case, Lepis v. Lepis, the court, for the first time, set forth guidelines and procedures to be followed in modifying support and maintenance agreements and ruled that a former wife's earning capacity must be considered before the amount of alimony or child support payments can be increased.

At St. Christopher's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio, yesterday afternoon, Siri Jennings Vail, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas V.H. Vail of Hunting Valley, Chagrin Falls, Ohio, became the bride of John Fairbanks Lacey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman F. Lacey of Mendham, N.J. The Rev. William Delbert Shively performed the ceremony. Mrs. Nathaniel Smith was the matron of honor. The other attendants were Mrs. William J. Miller Jr.; Nancy Lacey, sister of the bridegroom; Kate Bower, Wendy Avrett, and Mrs. Seth Low Pierrepont. Robert G. Hottensen Jr. served as best man.

VENICE HAVING patched together a compromise after theirfight over European Community funds, Common Market leaders were able to turn outward again last week and prepare for European participation in the meeting next Sunday of Western leaders. Italian Prime Minister Francesco Cossiga, who presided in Venice, said they sought to ''reinforce the role of Europe in the international context.'' French President Valery Giscard d'Estaing, speaking as usual in a somewhat different accent, said the meeting showed that ''despite difficulties, the European Economic Community is emerging as an independent, responsible influence in the world.''

Ivan DeJesus ripped four singles and scored four times and Larry Biittner and Mike Vail had three hits and three runs batted in apiece today as the Chicago Cubs snapped a four-game losing streak with a 10-5 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

WESTCHESTER'S city, town and village leaders now have a fine subject for essays on what they did on, or instead of, their summer vacations - filling out questionnaires on the adequacy of their community's housing and giving a 10-year projection for it. They won't be easy to complete. Housing was described last week as Westchester's ''most serious problem'' by County Executive Alfred B. DelBello when he welcomed most of the elected officials or their representatives at a meeting intended to draw the muncipalities into helping draft a county housing policy. The questionnaires are due in the office of the County Planning Board Sept. 10,

Beyond the toll in human life and damage to property exacted by three trip-hammer eruptions of Mount St. Helens in less than a month, the unpredictable volcano has done major damage to the image and the confidence of the Pacific Northwest. Despite the third major eruption, which surprised geologists two days ago, the region has made major strides toward returning to normal. Portland officials went ahead with the city's showcase Rose Festival today, complete with the Grand Floral Parade.

Barbara Alison MacDonald and Richard Lloyd Adler, who work for Levi Strauss & Company in New York, were married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Marcia Klepper-Smith performed the ceremony in the Waterman Chapel of the Second Congregational Church. The bride, a sales representative in the accessories division of Levi Strauss, is a graduate of Marymount College in Arlington, Va. She is the daughter of Mrs. M. Joseph Conte of Charlottesville, Va., and Douglas E. MacDonald of Greenwich. Mrs. Leo Adler of Deerfield Beach, Fla., and the late Mr. Adler are the parents of the bridegroom.
Lynda Diane Gutowski is a freelance writer. By LYNDA D. GUTOWSKI

Carter Administration officials, when pressing Congress for passage of $5.7 million in emergency military assistance for El Salvador on March 25, insisted that the request was for ''nonlethal'' equipment that ''will help strengthen the Army's key role in reforms.'' The package was approved a week later. According to Congressional testimony on March 25 by Franklin D. Kramer, Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, the aid would consist of $3.7 million for trucks and transport vehicles, $316,000 for riot-control gear, $1.2 million for communications equipment, and $400,000 for ''various other equipment to include trailers.'' The rest of the outlay was for transporting the materiel. What Mr. Kramer neglected to disclose in his public testimony was that the aid package in fact included combat-related equipment that stretches the definition of ''nonlethal'' beyond credibility. The Defense Security Assistance Agency had provided Congress with a list of the items in the military-aid proposal that was more detailed than the one made public by Mr. Kramer. The members of Congress who saw the list - it was given to the House and Senate Appropriations Committees, the House Foreign Affairs Committee and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee - accepted the ''nonlethal'' designation despite the nature of the equipment. When this gear reaches the field, however, any distinction between lethal and nonlethal will have been lost. As repression by Salvadoran security forces escalates daily in the countryside, this gear becomes vital to the junta's waging of counterinsurgency war. Under the Freedom of Information Act, the American Friends Service Committee has obtained copies of the ''Letters of Offer and Acceptance'' from the Department of the Army that detail the military aid approved by Congress. To be delivered (some equipment is en route, the Army says) are 7,500 CS tear-gas grenades, 250 ''Manpack'' field combat radios, thousands of batteries, and an unspecified number of tear-gas-grenade launchers. The sale of 50 portable PVS-2B night-vision devices blurs the supposed distinction between lethal and nonlethal weapons: These electro-optic devices are used for observation and nighttime weapons targeting. Night-vision-weapons technology and related equipment like the 12 ''Image Intensifiers,'' also included, were perfected for use in Vietnam. To help security forces preserve so-called law and order, the Administration is sending three communications-monitoring sets at more than $38,000 each. An Army aide says that security forces will use them to monitor the airwaves and track the exact locations of clandestine-radio transmitters: ''It's perfect for use against guerrillas and insurgents.''

Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah won the national 110-meter high hurdles title today. Because he won this title in 1978 and 1979, because he had been the world's leading high hurdler those two years and because he decimated the world record last year, winning here should not have been a big deal. It was. Nehemiah is a 21-year-old junior at the University of Maryland and lives in Scotch Plains, N.J. His indoor season was wiped out when he badly sprained an ankle playing basketball. Later, he quit the college team after a dispute between his college and club coach. Five weeks ago, he finished fourth in a Los Angeles race, and he did not compete again until the trials here yesterday. He has been plagued by hip, ankle and heel problems.

Atlantic salmon are returning to Maine's Penobscot River and the Connecticut River in astonishing numbers this spring. As of a few days ago (the season opened May 1) Maine anglers had caught more than 500 salmon in the Penobscot. Last year in the same period, the catch was about three dozen.

PRESIDENT CARTER will travel to Venice, Italy's Queen of the Adriatic, in hopes of rescuing his sinking politi cal fortunes at an economic summit conference next Sunday and Monday. But whether his fellow heads of government can or will do much to bail him out appears improbable.

A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a $100 million class-action suit filed on behalf of former residents of the polluted Love Canal area of Niagara Falls. The suit sought damages for the residents for injuries they allegedly suffered because of chemical contamination. The justice, Joseph Kuszynski, said last night that the suit, filed on behalf of more than ''100 potential claimants,'' duplicated other lawsuits. The suit was originally filed last September by two attorneys, David Feldman of Buffalo and Alfred Julien of New York, on behalf of four of the residents.

Nine thousand petroleum geologists came to Denver for their annual convention this week and disappeared into a world of almost impenetrable jargon that distinguishes their trade. They emerged periodically to rant against the Federal Government or to echo the war cry of their president-elect, Robey Clark: ''Find more oil and gas!'' Petroleum geologists come cleverly disguised as mild-mannered, pipe-smoking rock scientists. Actually, observed Wendell Cochran, editor of Geotimes magazine, ''they are really gamblers or prospectors.''

Mary Louise O'Boyle, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David J. O'Boyle of Glen Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Brian O'Neill, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Neill of Leonardo, N.J. The Rev. Steven Barrett performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Vincent P. Coburn, at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J. The bride is senior claims examiner and her husband is claims supervisor, both with New York Life Insurance Company in New York. Mrs. O'Neill was graduated cum laude from Chestnut Hill College in Philadelphia. Her father is a member of the New York law firm of Arthur, Dry & Kalish and is assistant general counsel for Uniroyal Inc.

Whoever is elected President in November, a friendlier, more cooperative relationship between Government and business is in the offing. Labor could also be involved, through European-style tripartite committees that take a broad approach to economic planning. The new rubric for the partnership approach to managing the economy is ''industrial policy,'' a phrase coming into vogue as rapidly as ''energy policy'' did in the 1970's. It took a series of legislative debates (some still under way) to give energy policy a precise meaning. What ''industrial policy'' might mean in this country remains to be determined.

Two years ago, as he prepared for what then seemed his final fight, Muhammad Ali pointed to the young sparring partner in the ring at his Deer Lake, Pa., training camp, and proclaimed: ''That is the 1980 Olympic heavyweight champion.'' Tomorrow, the 1980 United States Olympic boxing trials begin in Atlanta. Tony Tubbs will not be there, and the heavyweight picture has become a little brighter.

WITH its narrow streets and large Victorian homes, some of which have spectacular views of Hempstead Harbor, this North Shore village of 6,000 looks more like the turn-of-the-century resort it once was than the suburban community it has become. Local preservationists want to keep it that way. To help achieve that end, they have worked toward the passage of a landmark preservation law that will be the subject of a public hearing before the Village Board at 8 P.M. tomorrow.

A transportation aid package that officials have tied to a 10-cent increase in New York City's subway and bus fare received final legislative approval shortly before dawn yesterday. As the 1980 session drew toward a close, a weary and fractious Democratic-led Assembly voted the package, which will use a new tax on oil companies to help subsidize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's deficit.

The essence of liberalism,'' mused Leon Shull, executive director of Americans for Democratic Action, ''is the use of government to intervene on behalf of people.'' ''I don't think government is where it's at,'' said Senator Paul E. Tsongas, Democrat of Massachusetts, who gave the keynote speech at the organization's annual convention today. ''The Johnson-Humphrey Great Society approach is that government does work, but I think government has a deadening impact.''

Patricia Ann Park, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Park of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Union Congregational Church to James Martin Connell, son of Mrs. Raymond C. Connell of Montclair and the late Mr. Connell. The Rev. William Lutz and Msgr. Edward Fleming, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The bride, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Skidmore College, is assistant to the president of the Bio/Basics International Corporation in New York. Her father is senior vice president of the Christman Trading Corporation in New York.

To the Business Editor: The article, ''Who Pays? Cleaning Up the Love Canals'' (June 8), indicates a significant deficiency in industrial planning. This is the failure to plan for the long-term consequences of intense and broad industrial development and production. Waste in the production process and waste of outmoded products have become a potential social and economic cost of a magnitude that will require a whole industry itself to accommodate. Wise industrial planning would seem to include planning for waste as an integral part. It has been traditional to leave waste disposal to public authorities, or worse, to literally bury the waste and hope that a future public will bear the burden of disposal. This hidden cost of innovation and development is now becoming open. And the public cost will surely be returned to industry in the form of higher taxes or, more directly, through fines and assessments.

Two years ago, Guatemala had just held presidential elections which were won by a general who promised social reform and even a return to civilian rule. By last year, the country's two main opposition leaders had fallen victim to right-wing assassination squads and hopes for peaceful reform were fast fading. Today, a deeply divided Guatemala is caught up in a bloody underground civil war which could be the prologue to a leftist revolution. The speed of the political disintegration in Guatemala, the most populous of the Central American republics, has taken many outsiders, not least the United States, by surprise. While a battle to the end between left and right is perhaps not imminent, suddenly it seems unavoidable: no one is looking for a negotiated solution and everyone is preparing for war.

Among golf professionals, pressure is the same in any language. Isao Aoki, a 37-year-old Japanese who has won 32 tournaments abroad, felt none of it today as he birdied the last two holes in the third round of the United States Open to gain a tie with Jack Nicklaus. Aoki, recognized as one of the world's best players within 100 yards of the hole, helped make tomorrow's finale exactly the kind a United States Open should be - six players in contention, all within two strokes of one another.

A man who the police believe tried to hold up a Greenwich Village parking garage attendant was found slumped over the wheel of his car early yesterday after he crashed into a parked vehicle near MacDougal and Bleecker Streets. The man, whom the police did not identify, had been shot in the right side. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital where he was pronounced dead on arrival at 2:20 A.M.

The question of whether any outstanding ballet of its time does in fact outlive its time is one that continually springs to mind in regard to two special works, both of which are on view this season. One is the 1938 ''Billy the Kid,'' choreographed by Eugene Loring to Aaron Copland's score and the other is the 1948 ''Orpheus,'' by George Balanchine and Igor Stravinsky. Both have been dubbed classics of the American ballet repertory although by common consent, ''Orpheus'' is considered the masterpiece that ''Billy the Kid'' generally is not. And yet ''Billy the Kid'' has been able to endure the weak performances that ''Orpheus'' cannot. At its least successful, ''Orpheus'' has appeared sadly dated while ''Billy the Kid'' has appeared happily dated. That is, in poor production and performance ''Orpheus'' may not work at all, trapped in a symbolism and style of movement its dancers can no longer convey. ''Billy the Kid,'' whatever its lowest ebb, appears dated in the sense of a period piece - it proclaims its own period of creation, an era of Americana ballets in tune with the nationalist emphasis of its own time in American art. It is the kind of ballet that can still irritate an impatient audience no longer keyed to its deliberately naive style. But this very style is so watertight that the work can be recognized for what it is, a product of the 1930's. One can like it or dislike it but one can recognize it.

Just when people were beginning to wonder if the revolution was turning soft, the New York Mets struck one of their most dramatic blows last night: a five-run ninth inning peaked by a three-run home run by Steve Henderson that buried the San Francisco Giants, 7-6. Not only that, but there were two strikes on Henderson and two outs against the Mets. And, for a team that has been creating havoc lately against power clubs like the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Los Angeles Dodgers, there were even more flourishes: the Mets trailed by 6-0 after four and a half innings, they were held hitless by John Montefusco until the sixth, they were one strike away from losing in the ninth and Henderson had not hit a home run all season.

Dale Lundquist carded a six-underpar 66 today to take a four-stroke lead after three rounds of a $150,000 Ladies' Professional Golf Association tournament. The 26-year-old Miss Lundquist, a nonwinner in four years on the tour, had an eagle and five birdies to offset one bogey. She totaled 204, 12 under par over the 6,029-yard Frencroft Country Club course.

THE current supply of gasoline on the Island is ''excellent,'' according to industry officials, but the relatively stable price picture of recent months is now in doubt because of last week's price increases by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. Gasoline prices on the Island in recent weeks have varied between $1.19 and $1.37 a gallon for leaded regular, a difference that has brought competition back to the industry. Service stations are again open longer hours, some on a 24-hour basis and others on Sundays, and there is better service at the pump, with attendants looking under hoods, checking the oil and cleaning windshields.

HARTFORD AFTER 12 years as producing director of the Hartford Stage Company, Paul Weidner leaves next month for the Ivory Coast to serve for two years as an English teacher with the Peace Corps. For his final production, he has chosen to direct a play by Edward Albee, the most frequently produced playwright at the theater. The play is ''The Lady From Dubuque,'' which opened on Broadway last January and closed after 12 performances. One can only guess at its failure. In part it may be that standards are changed for successful playwrights. Each time out, more, different and better is demanded of them. And certainly the topic is an important consideration. New Yorkers have too many theatrical choices each season to pay to attend a play on a subject that most people would rather not face.

Margaret Ellen Tabell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Weber Tabell of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Robert Kasprak of Hartford. The Rev. John C. Belmont, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Stuart Country Day School, from which the bride was graduated. The bride, who is with the history and genealogy department of the Connecticut State Library in Hartford, was graduated from Colgate University and is studying for a master's degree in teaching at the University of Hartford. Her father is a partner with Delafield, Harvey, Tabell, Princeton investment advisers. The bride is a granddaughter of Mrs. Edmund W. Tabell of Riverside, Conn., and the late Mr. Tabell, who was a financial analyst and senior vice president of Walston & Company.

The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that the statement by the European Economic Community that the organization be ''associated with'' Middle East peace negotiations did not go far enough. ''The European communique has some positive points, but basic points are still missing,'' a Palestinian spokesman said. ''They did not recognize officially and openly the P.L.O. and they also missed the recognition of a Palestinian state.''

First the whistles shrill the signal that something is wrong. Lights flash, gauges ride upward with the temperature and pressure. ''You've just been through the first 20 minutes of Three Mile Island,'' says Dick Graham, who has just brought things to a halt with the push of a button.

The body of Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira was cremated today after a private funeral attended by 3,000 friends and political allies. Officials said the ashes of the man who led the Japanese Government for 18 months would be scattered at an official memorial service to be held after the national election June 22. Mr. Ohira, 70 years old, died in a hospital of a heart attack Thursday.

A flurry of excitement rippled through the fishermen and sunbathers on the 69th Street pier in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon when someone spotted what looked like a 40-foot whale rolling offshore in Upper New York Harbor. The behemoth, glinting in a brilliant sun, seemed injured as it lolled and drifted off Shore Parkway in Bay Ridge a mile north of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. So somebody called the police.

ONE of the most frequent problems that develop with a typical toilet tank mechanism, particularly in an older unit, is water dripping or running continuously from the tank into the toilet bowl after the toilet is flushed. Sometimes the flow can be stopped by vigorous jiggling of the handle or by flushing again, but this doesn't always work. Sometimes the leak is so rapid and steady that the water runs out almost as fast as it runs in and the tank never does fill properly until you jiggle the handle repeatedly. In other cases the leak is so slow that it does not interfere with the tank's filling and flushing properly. It's just that the water keeps on running indefinitely after the tank and bowl have filled.

Stuart Mittleman of the Central Park Track Club won the New York Road Runners Club 100-mile invitation run yesterday morning at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens.. The 29-year-old Mittleman led the field of 27 men and 2 women who started the long grind at 7 P.M. Friday. His time of 13 hours 4 minutes 9 seconds was the second fastest performance for the distance in the United States. Jose Cortez turned in a 12:54.31 clocking nine years ago in Rocklin, Calif.

BY now the roses in your garden should be filled with buds, or already in flower. If, however, a damaged bush remains, there is no need to wait another season to replace it. Potted roses make possible replacements anytime during the season or, for that matter, planting an instant rose garden in midsummer. When planting at this time of year, it is especially important to retain the soil in the roots; a plant in full foliage is unlikely to survive if its soil is lost. The soil should be well prepared, with peat, compost or well-rotted manure added in the amount of one fourth the total volume. It is essential that newly planted roses be watered well.

President Carter's eight-month delay in nominating a Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, as the agency faces some of the biggest challenges in its history, is puzzling immigration officials, members of Congress and Hispanic Americans. Since Oct. 1, the Immigration and Naturalization Service has been under the direction of a temporary appointee, David W. Crosland. The last commissioner, Leonel J. Castillo, had announced almost two months earlier that he intended to leave office by the end of September.

Big-band fans have been talking wistfully about a hoped-for return of the big bands ever since they began fading away 30 years ago. But as such established big-band leaders as Duke Ellington, Guy Lombardo and Stan Kenton have died, a revival of the era has seemed more and more unlikely. And yet, now that almost all of the celebrated bands of the bigband days are gone - the bands of Count Basie and Woody Herman are almost the only ones continuing to perform regularly -there is a growing interest in the big-band sound, an interest that has impelled the Bottom Line, that bellwether of popular taste, to put on a fiveday festival of big bands, starting Tuesday.

THE BUDGET: The Carter Administration, which can't be accused of following any policy out the window, appeared to abandon hope last week for a balanced budget. It was only in March that the Administration disclosed its budget-balancing goal for the fiscal year that starts Oct. 1. Now, with a weakened economy, heavy unemployment and the defeat of the oil import fee, a substantial deficit may be looming, White House officials concede. The Administration is said to be considering tax cut proposals and additional spending later this year if the economy gets worse.

President Carter traveled across the country this week emphasizing that cushions already in the economic system would help Americans who had lost their jobs avoid extreme financial hardship. He promised he would offer new measures if the cushions proved to be inadequate. Economists in and out of the Government agree that loss of a job no longer invariably means hardship because of the expansion of benefits in the last decade. But they say that it will be difficult for the Carter Administration to design new programs with any confidence that they will relieve the burden on Americans who are hardest hit by the recession.

In the waning hours of the Senate's closing session, the sergeant-at-arms stood within the Senate chamber blocking the handsome red-leather doors. He would unlatch the brass lock only on instructions from Senator Warren M. Anderson, the majority leader. If a legislator wanted to leave the chamber, even to go to the rest room, permission from Mr. Anderson was required. Senators making more distant trips were accompanied by a guard to insure their return to the chilly, air-conditioned hall.

The Force is with us but let's try to keep our heads. These things are certifiable: ''The Empire Strikes Back,'' George Lucas's sequel to his ''Star Wars,'' the biggest grossing motion picture of all time, has opened. On the basis of the early receipts, ''The Empire Strikes Back'' could make more money than any other movie in history, except, maybe, ''Star Wars.'' It is the second film in a projected series that may last longer than the civilization that produced it. Confession: When I went to see ''The Empire Strikes Back'' I found myself glancing at my watch almost as often as I did when I was sitting through a truly terrible movie called ''The Island.''

In the corridors of Congress, Senator Jacob K. Javits is treated with the deference due an elder statesman who has served 30 years - 24 in the Senate and eight in the House. But 10 days ago in the Bronx, the Senator was just another candidate, listening to a Republican opponent castigate him as a liberal out of tune with the times and pleading himself for the support of 150 Republican county committeemen who had already been told by their leaders to reject him. For the first time in his political career, Senator Javits faces a challenge from within that will provide a clear test of how far the once liberal New York Republican Party has drifted to the right. There is no track record of Republican statewide primaries by which to forecast the likely outcome. The conventional wisdom is that Mr. Javits is well ahead of his G.O.P. challenger, the relatively unknown Alfonse M. D'Amato, as well as his four Democratic opponents. But he is running as if he were behind, making unaccustomed appearances before Republican audiences on long weekends away from Washington.

Atlantic salmon are returning to Maine's Penobscot River and the Connecticut River in astonishing numbers this spring. As of a few days ago (the season opened May 1) Maine anglers had caught more than 500 salmon in the Penobscot. Last year in the same period, the catch was about three dozen. At the same time, nearly 130 salmon have returned to the Connecticut, with more than 100 picked up in the fish lifts operated by Northeast Utilities Water Power Company in Holyoke, Mass. During all of last season the entire Connecticut system had only about 60 returning salmon.

FOR 24 years, an 18-acre hilltop overlooking Waterbury has been one man's testament of spiritual devotion and has also attracted thousands of visitors a year. With a 50-foot metal cross as its centerpiece, the site atop Pine Hill has become known as the ''Holy Land.'' It has miniature representations of Bethlehem and Jerusalem, catacombs and more than 200 exhibits depicting biblical stories interspersed with hundreds of small signs with quotes from the Scriptures. The devotional panorama is the work of John B. Greco, an 85-yearold lawyer who lives on the hilltop and has been known in the area since the early 1930's, when he began giving religious speeches.
Barbara Lamb McLean, a member of the faculty of Milton (Mass.) Academy, was married yesterday to David O'Neil, a partner of Oldman O'Neil Architects in Cambridge, Mass.

Marjorie Aileen Gavin, daughter of Lieut. Gen. James M. Gavin, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gavin of Chestnut Hill and Wianno, Mass., was married yesterday to Alan Churchill Ripley Lewis, son of Mrs. C. McKenzie Lewis Jr. of Washington and the late Mr. Lewis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14-- The global population explosion is losing some of its force, a new United Nations report says, but the biggest gains are taking place in the poorest nations and threatening new misery.

Just when people were beginning to wonder if the revolution was turning soft, the New York Mets struck one of their most dramatic blows last night: a five-run ninth inning peaked by a threerun home run by Steve Henderson that buried the San Francisco Giants, 7-6.

MONTREAL, June 14 (AP)--Bill Russell hit a home run, and Pedro Guerrero added a three-run clout in a four-run third inning as the Los Angeles Dodgers romped to an 8-0 victory over Montreal tonight, halting the Expos' 10-game winning streak.

BUFFALO, June 14 (UPI)--A State Supreme Court justice has dismissed a $100 million class-action suit filed on behalf of former residents of the polluted Love Canal area of Niagara Falls. The suit sought damages for the residents for injuries they allegedly suffered because of chemical contamination.
