Once at a summer cocktail party in Menemsha I was asked by a lady: "Where on the island do you live?" In Vineyard Haven," I replied. She suddenly gave me a look that made me feel as if I harbored a communicable dis ease. "My God," she said, "I didn't think anyone lived there."

Barbara Anne Hunting, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Ives Hunting of Grand Rapids, Mich., was married in Grace Episcopal Church there yesterday to Richard Mills Osler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Bruce Osler of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Roy O. Ostenson performed the ceremony.

John J. Santucci says he does not have money, but he does have friends from a long career in politics and a conservative image in contrast to his three opponents in the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New York.

CHICAGO, June 14--The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, facing a $1.8 billion penalty, the largest ever awarded in an antitrust case, said today that it would press on in its legal battle with a small company competing in the long-distance telephone business.

IT has been a bad year for the ''Sons of the Bad News Bears,'' as one mother dubbed the Cubs, and today the score resembles football more than baseball. With carefully blank faces, they have been pounded on the backsides and cheered by the winning team. Now they slump, streaked with sweat and mud (and, I suspect, tears in a case or two), listening to the wrapup. The three adult coaches pace tensely behind the chain-link fence that separates the players' bench from the playing field. The children look like defeated, caged animals facing their keepers. ''Listen you guys, and listen good,'' says Josh. ''You're in the major leagues now and this is serious.'' He recaps the game, 3 zip for the Cubs at the top of third inning, error after error costing run after run by the other team. ''It was like you guys gave up, or something,'' he says. ''I mean, you just can't do that.''

Their leader is a ''general,'' their clergy ''officers,'' their seminarians ''cadets,'' their converts ''captives.'' Death is ''promotion to glory.'' And this military approach to the preaching of the Gospel - not to the already faithful, but to the poor, the wretched and the sinners in the streets -makes the Salvation Army one of the most colorful denominations in Christendom. All this was joyfully apparent here this weekend when some 12,000 uniformed Salvationists gathered from all over America, brass bands blaring and tambourines jangling, to celebrate their National Centennial Congress. Looking back over a century of success, they mapped strategy for another century of open-air evangelism and openhanded service to all.

Paul Althaus Smith, a retired professor of mathematics at Columbia University who had taught there and at Barnard College for a halfcentury, died Friday after a long illness at St. Luke's Hospital. Professor Smith, who lived in Manhattan, was 80 years old. A pioneer in the field of topology, the study of those properties of geometric figures that remain unchanged under distortion, he was considered by some to be a major figure in the development of mathematics in this country. Professor Smith also was known as an accomplished musician and a maker of medieval instruments that were played by his wife, Suzanne Bloch, a well-known performer and the daughter of the late composer, Ernest Bloch.

In backgammon, many games become violent confrontations in which the less fortunate player finds himself facing a closed board with several men on the bar. Because the outcome of such confrontations may be decided by a single roll, luck seems to predominate. Skillful play, however, is seldom more important than in these life-or-death situations. The successful player knows not only when to launch an all-out attack, but how to press it to final victory. In the diagrammed position, X has attacked O and has so far been successful. With five points closed in his home board, X needs only to make the 4-point in order to complete the close-out. Conversely, O, with two men on the bar, has only one hope for survival - to establish the 4-point himself. There is no question that, as X, you must ruthlessly attempt to squelch this hope -the only question is what is the most efficient and reliable way to do so.

I HAVE just returned from a weekend in the mountains. And what, you may well ask, with a touch of hauteur, do mountains have to do with our beloved Long Island flatlands, where a noble rise is a bump of terrain almost easy enough to scale in 10 minutes? Well, the mountains I visited were not exactly alpenstock country, but I would bet they are, in season, the most populous mountains in the world.

Beer with a head but a nonheady effect - malt-and-hops beer with the alcohol removed - was selling fast in Saudi Arabia, where Moslem laws forbid the consumption of alcohol. So a year ago this month C. Schmidt & Sons Inc. of Philadelphia joined the exporters of this product and shipped 32,000 cases to the Arab country. ''It did tremendously well - it sold very quickly,'' says Gus Economos, vice president of marketing. But Schmidt is out of the market, he adds.

The Minnesota Twins say they released Mike Marshall last week because of his deteriorating ability. But a yearlong series of unionrelated incidents provides a picture of a deteriorating relationship between Marshall and Manager Gene Mauch that might have been more relevant to the relief pitcher's release. Marshall and the Major League Baseball Players Association, of which he has been the most outspoken member, will use those incidents among other evidence to try to prove that Marshall's release was tied to union activity and therefore a violation of his contract and Federal labor law.

LAUGHING IN THE HILLS By Bill Barich. 228 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $10.95. AT that dicey age, edging up on 40, Bill Barich loses his mother to cancer, his marriage is ''childless and knee-deep in ruin,'' he has chucked his regular job and is writing nothing of consequence, and he sees America being defoliated by television rays and bulldozers. In short, he has unwisely ignored Satchel Paige's edict of never looking back for fear something might be gaining on you.

DRAINING a container of well water from her basement storage tank recently, a New Canaan homeowner was dismayed by its sulfurous odor. The well had been tested when the house was built 14 years ago, and she had never thought to question the quality of the water since then - even though the family was totally dependent on the well for water. Now she was worried enough to call in a testing laboratory. In Brookfield last February, a homeowner was troubled when the water from the family well ''started tasting and smelling funny.'' She called the local health department and learned that a neighbor's well, just tested as a result of the same concern, was found to be contaminated with gasoline.

Come the hot days of summer, what's the woman with yards of hair going to do with it? New Yorkers of all ages are going back to their schoolgirl days, wearing braids. It's a tidy way to get a lot of hair off the back of the neck and especially practical for bicycling, jogging or sunning at the beach.
New Yorkers will get a new afternoon newspaper today when The Wall Street Final, a five-day-a-week, 16page tabloid with sports, stock tables and other features, makes its debut.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., June 14 The neighbors, who never met Dwight and Mamie Eisenhower, are walking through the large, white-painted brick house with drawn window shades where the couple played bridge, watched Lawrence Welk on television and entertained the mighty Adenauer, Churchill, de Gaulle, Nehru and Khrushchev, among others.

MOSCOW, June 15 In a deserted corner of the Piskarevka Memorial Cemetery in Leningrad, burial place of 400,000 of the million who died in the 900-day blockade of the city during World War II, an old woman swept the withered flowers from the grassy mounds that stretched as far as the eye could see.
BRAINERD, Minn., June 15 (UPI) Paul Newman's Datsun ZX was involved in a fourth-lap accident today that forced him to drop out of a race at Brainerd International Raceway.

The European Community's statement on the Middle East rests on one central premise. That is that peace, whatever process is used to seek it, can only be attained in the end if there is respect for two political identities: Israeli and Palestinian.

Judges around New York State are engaged in an extraordinary conflict with the State Office of Court Administration, the agency responsible for the day-to-day administration of all New York courts, over the transfer of upstate judges to New York City and four other counties to reduce a backlog of cases.

Ed Ott and the Pittsburgh Pirates made the division races in the National League a little more interesting yesterday for fans in Pittsburgh and Los Angeles, not to mention causing some concern in Montreal and Houston.
CLARKSTON, Mich., June 15 (UPI) Mustafa Hamsho was declared the winner of a middleweight fight today that ended when Wilford Scypion was disqualified in the final round of a scheduled 10-round bout.

Dung Quoc Nguyen's claim to uniqueness is not easy to verify, because the clerk's office at the New York State Court of Appeals says the computer in Albany, which holds the names of all 187,000 lawyers registered to practice in New York since 1898, cannot even tell which are dead and which alive, much less which are Vietnamese. But as far as is known of all those lawyers, Mr. Nguyen, who is 37 years old, is the only Vietnamese refugee admitted to practice before the New York bar.

Instead of trying to find ways to end inflation and raise productivity, Congress seems content to sit in the grandstand tossing empty bottles down on a President as he struggles, however belatedly, to get a grip on the economy. Having rejected President Carter's fee on oil imports, retarded the Federal budget process for weeks and threatened to deprive the Council on Wage and Price Stability of money and staff to monitor inflation, Congress is shouting now for repeal of the Credit Control Act of 1969 - the one law that was available this spring to restrain borrowing without driving interest rates even higher. Some reform of the act is worth discussing, but that is hardly urgent. The law was never used by any President until last March and the credit restraints it made possible then are already being removed by the Federal Reserve. The recession has made them unnecessary. Some contend that the controls were not even necessary in March and have made the recession worse. Others say the controls served a vital function then, helping to end a speculative binge in the commodity markets and the accompanying fear of wild inflation.

The New York Mets drew, but disappointed, the largest Shea Stadium crowd in two years yesterday when they produced neither magic nor miracle and dropped a 3-0 decision to the San Francisco Giants. They were surrounded by 44,910 fans but were stopped cold by Bob Knepper, a 26-year-old left-hander who had lost seven straight games on the road this season. But this time, apparently untroubled by the five-run rally generated by the Mets in the ninth inning on Saturday night, Knepper allowed just seven singles, gave up only one walk and retired the last seven batters to avert any last-minute theatrics.

Glorious Song, a 4-year-old Canadian filly owned by Nelson Hunt and Frank Stronach, fought off Prince Majestic to win by a nose tonight in the $110,400 Michigan Mile Handicap at the Detroit Race Course. The triumph was Glorious Song's fourth in five outings this year. The winner's share of $66,240 lifted her 1980 earnings to $333,970. She won seven of her 10 races last year.

Kathy Anne Klingenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Klingenstein of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday evening to David Lynn Richey, son of Gladys Richey of Colorado Springs and the late John Walter Richey. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony in the garden at the Klingenstein home. The bride, an alumna of the Rye Country Day School and St. Lawrence University, received a master's degree in special education from Dominican College in San Rafael, Calif. Her father is chairman of the New York investment banking concern of Wertheim & Company, which her paternal grandfather, the late Joseph Klingenstein, helped found in 1927. Her grandfather, who was chairman emeritus of the board of the Mount Sinai Medical Center, served as president of Mount Sinai Hospital from 1956 to 1962. He and Mrs. Klingenstein established the hospital's Klingenstein Clinical Center and were among the founders of Mount Sinai's School of Medicine.

Max Beerbohm was an English theater critic back in late Victorian days, but that is not what made him incomparable - after all, he followed G.B. Shaw in that job - but he was an urbane and witty essayist and short-story writer, which is what led to the writing of ''The Incomparable Max,'' a comedy by Jerome Lawrence and Robert E. Lee that is being revived by the Manhattan Punch Line. ''The Incomparable Max'' first apppeared on Broadway in 1971, and it was a pleasant enough affair then. In its current reincarnation, it is still amusing and stylish theater, not a belly-laugher, but a chuckler full of epigrams and wit in the British way, which is to say that their reciter delivers them with irrefutable but charming arrogance that brooks no cappers in reply. It is refreshing to listen to.

With the economy expected to show further signs of weakening this week and with the money supply growing at a slow pace, interest rates are expected to continue to decline. There is ample proof that the economy is weak. Last Friday the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production had fallen 2.1 percent in May, the largest decrease in output since early 1975. This week housing starts, capacity utilization, personal income and orders for durable goods are scheduled to be released, and money market economists predict they will all show declines.

To the Editor: What critics used to say about the ''Imperial Presidency'' of former President Nixon pales into insignificance when one considers Carter (who is no President!) and the guided efforts of the so-called Democratic Party in setting aside a quarter of a million dollars or so in an attempt to prevent another candidate from running for the Presidency. For shame! JOHN J. MOSES West Hempstead, L.I., June 5, 1980

Dale Lundquist lost a four-stroke lead on the first hole but rallied over the final 14 holes today to gain her first victory in four years on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour in a $150,000 tournament. Miss Lundquist's final-day score was a 72 and the round was the first in which she failed to break par. It gave her a tournament total of 276 and a three-shot victory over Amy Alcott. Beth Daniel and Pam Higgins tied for third at 281 and Pat Bradley struggled to a 75 to finish at 283.

The marriage of Betty Louise Levin of Flushing, Queens, widow of Rabbi Herschel Levin, to Rabbi Frank Zimmermann of Forest Hills, Queens, a widower and former chairman of the department of Bible at Dropsie University in Philadelphia, took place in Great Neck, L.I., yesterday. Rabbi Robert Gordis, professor of Bible at the Jewish Theological Seminary, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kupferberg. The bride, daughter of Mrs. Meyer Tennenbaum of Louisville, Ky., and Haifa, Israel, and the late Mr. Tennenbaum, teaches Bible and Hebrew at the Sands Point (L.I.) Community Synagogue. Her first husband was spiritual leader of Temple Beth Sholom in Flushing.

QUESTION: During stroke play, my opponent's golf ball stopped near a fence that marked out-of-bounds. The fence interfered with his subsequent swing, and he termed it an obstruction because it was manmade. He then dropped away without taking a penalty and played toward the green. Was he correct? No. An out-of-bounds fence is not an obstruction. Your opponent should have incurred a three-stroke penalty, one for lifting the ball and two for not replacing it.

This city's Police Department, which has long been portrayed by Hollywood television dramatists as a model of modern police efficiency, is under growing criticism for alleged ''spying'' on citizens, brutality and other abuses. The criticism intensified recently after disclosures that detectives in disguise had monitored City Council meetings and infiltrated citizen groups that were investigating the department. It began more than a year ago after two policemen fired eight bullets into a black woman who had not paid her gas bill.

Risa Kaufman, daughter of Esther Kaufman of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Dr. Daniel R. Kaufman of Great Neck, L.I., was married yesterday to David Bernstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Bernstein, also of Great Neck. The ceremony was performed at the Tavern on the Green by Rabbi Mordecai Waxman, assisted by Cantor Benjamin Siegel, both of Temple Israel in Great Neck. The bride, an alumna of George Washington University, is director of publicity for Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, New York book publishers. Her father was a urologist.

Voters will decide on Tuesday whether to make Ocean Grove a separate municipality or whether to remain part of Neptune Township. Ocean Grove has been governed for 110 years by the Methodist Camp Meeting Association, but Neptune Township provides its municipal services. If voters decided to withdraw from Neptune Township, Governor Byrne would appoint an interim governing body.

Once a month, an inconspicuous late-model rented station wagon drives into Manhattan loaded with neatly stacked cardboard boxes. In the boxes, according to Sam Yang, a gun dealer, are brand-new revolvers and semi-automatic pistols. For nearly 10 years, one of Mr. Yang's employees has made the short trip - to Pennsylvania, Vermont or other nearby states - to pick up the dealer's monthly shipment. Last year, by his own rough calculations, Mr. Yang realized nearly $100,000 from his thriving business.

President Carter and Ronald Reagan built substantial leads over their rivals in the Presidential primaries on the basis of strong regional performances, particularly in the South, popular vote totals indicate. But while Mr. Reagan showed strength among Republicans in all regions, the President's geographical base was more limited.

At the Freeport (L.I.) United Methodist Church yesterday, Pamela Rochelle Monroe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eddie Monroe of Freeport, was married to the Rev. Josiah Ulysses Young 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Young Jr. of Somerset, N.J. The Rev. Burton Davison performed the ceremony. The bride, who is a lawyer for The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, was graduated cum laude from Cornell University and from the New York University Law School. S ELL July and September on rallies, buy January and March on dips,'' has been the recent advice of several commodity firms for traders of lumber futures. The reasons are simple enough. High interest rates and the recession have put a damper on home buying and, therefore, on lumber consumption as well. But by next year, the recession is expected to be over, and homebuilding will be responding to meet pent-up demand.

In a sense, Roberto Duran will be paid Friday night to punch his employer. Sugar Ray Leonard, who has rewritten most of the rules of fight promoting, is the de facto promoter in his defense of the World Boxing Council's welterweight title against Duran. ''He and Mike Trainer have done a great job,'' Bob Arum says with ad?iration for how the champion and his lawyer have arranged the finances. Arum is the titular co-promoter with Don King of Friday night's spectacular at Olympic Stadium in Montreal, and the finances he speaks of involve a bout that Arum confidently predicts will be the biggest money-earning event in boxing history.

IN THE LAST TWO PAPAL ELECTIONS Sergio Cardinal Pignedoli, one of the leading contenders for the papacy two years ago, died early yesterday while on a visit to his brother in the family's hometown of Reggio Emilia in north-central Italy. He was 70 years old and reportedly suffered a blood clot of the lungs.

The design of townhouses as a unified group, the making of a block of row houses that are a single, coherent work of design, is an art to which our time has paid little heed. There is good reason for this: the economics of urban construction today can barely justify the building of a single townhouse, let alone a unified block of them; when a site large enough for an entire row of houses becomes available for residential development, it inevitably is used for large, high-rise construction. All of this notwithstanding, the developer Sheldon Solow has planned for some time to erect a row of 11 houses on East 67th Street in New York City, just west of the sleek glass apartment tower he recently completed at the corner of Second Avenue. The land was purchased by Mr. Solow as part of the assemblage for the apartment house, and it now contains the apartment house's garage; the townhouses are to be built above the garage, so the economics become more feasible.

Thomas E. Barton, a director and owner of the international insurance brokerage of Johnson & Higgins, died of a heart attack Saturday evening while playing golf at the Montclair Golf Club in New Jersey. Mr. Barton, who was 54 years old, lived in Montclair. He was the principal expert on property insurance at Johnson & Higgins, the nation's oldest insurance brokerage with 5,000 employees worldwide. He also had extensive experience in industrial insurance.

JERUSALEM, June 15 Israel's Cabinet issued a vitriolic denunciation of the Common Market's declaration on the Middle East today, comparing it to the appeasement of Hitler at Munich and dismissing the offer of European security guarantees as no better than the empty pledges given Czechoslovakia in 1938.
LONDON, June 15 (AP) John McEnroe needed only one hour to defeat Kim Warwick of Australia, 6-3, 6-1, today in the final of the $125,000 Queen's Club grass tennis championship.

ST. REGIS RESERVATION, N.Y., June 15 A young man lounged on a blanket in the shade of an oak tree today, laughing easily with the young woman next to him and sipping lemonade. His shotgun lay within easy reach.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 15 Almost every other week now Yehuda Z. Blum, the scholarly Israeli delegate to the United Nations, trots over to the blue and cream Security Council chamber for another tongue-lashing over his nation's treatment of Palestinian Arabs.
Roland Petit and his Ballet National de Marseille will open at the Uris Theater on Sept. 2 for a three-week season. Three new full-length ballets by the French choreograher will be seen.

LOS ANGELES, June 15 This city's Police Department, which has long been portrayed by Hollywood television dramatists as a model of modern police efficiency, is under growing criticism for alleged "spying" on citizens, brutality and other abuses.

At the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's hearing on the appointment of Philip R. Trimble as Ambassador to Nepal, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan noted that Mr. Trimble had two outstanding qualifications. First, the New York Democrat said, Mr. Trimble has climbed Nepal's Mount Everest, the tallest mountain in the world, and, second, he has served ''in the hardship post as Deputy Mayor in New York City.'' The second accomplishment, Mr. Moynihan suggested, is more startling than the first.

Barry Offer was tooling around the parking lot of a local supermarket here last fall, trying out a pair of sneaker skates he received as a gift, when he hit a patch of gravel. His skates went up and he went down, breaking his ankle in three places, with one of the bones piercing the skin. The accident netted him five days in the hospital. This wasn't kid stuff, for Mr. Offer is a 35-year-old accountant with the Department of Housing and Urban Development. But he remains undeterred by his accident, still packing his skates along in his car trunk so he can step into them when the mood strikes.

Erskine N. White, who rose from assistant clerk to board chairman of the New England Telephone Company, died at Concord Hospital yesterday. He was 81 years old and lived in Center Sandwich. Mr. White retired in 1964 after 41 years with the company. He joined the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1923, moving to New England Telephone, a subsidiary, six years later.

The current recession will not end until early 1981 and unemployment will climb to a peak of 8.6 percent by the fall of 1981, according to a new forecast issued today by Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates. The analysis assumes that the mounting recession will lead to the passage of a $20 billion tax cut, which would go into effect in January 1981. Even without a tax cut, the forecast says, the Government will face a deficit of $45.6 billion in calendar year 1981.

The marriage of Virginia Geiss, a lawyer for the juvenile-rights division of the Legal Aid Society, to Andrew Seth Garson, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, took place at the Tarrytown (N.Y.) Hilton yesterday. Cantor George Weinflash officiated. The bride, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lester H. Geiss of Blairsville, Ga., was graduated from the Northfield School, Simmons College and the Suffolk Law School. Her father is a freelance writer.
TAMPA, Fla., June 15 The taste of defeat after a dozen games was not a bitter pill to swallow for the Cosmos and Coach Hennes Weisweiler.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Monday, June 16 The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees requested yesterday that Thailand postpone a mass repatriation of Cambodians scheduled to begin this morning, the commissioner's regional office here announced. No official reply was received by this morning, and a United Nations' source said the situation in the two border camps affected was unclear.

ALBANY, June 15 The New York State Assembly recessed today at 3:26 A.M., after a nonstop, 12-hour and 11minute session in which it gave final approval to a bill to outlaw "head shops" and killed a proposal to crack down on sweatshops.

WASHINGTON, June 15 The seven-nation economic summit meeting in Venice next week is expected to endorse a new program of energy conservation and supply and the continuation of the battle against inflation, according to American economic officials.

A young man lounged on a blanket in the shade of an oak tree today, laughing easily with the young woman next to him and sipping lemonade. His shotgun lay within easy reach. A dozen yards away, six other Indians stood sentry by a pickup truck on Racquette Point Road, blocking the only access by land to what, for some, had become their Dunkirk. In fact, they were guarding a two-square-mile parcel on the St. Lawrence River that is the stronghold of ''traditional'' Mohawks on this compound in a remote corner of northern New York State.

The seven-nation economic summit meeting in Venice next week is expected to endorse increased energy conservation and continuation of the anti-inflation battle in a gathering expected to be calmer and less devisive than prior sessions. (Page 21.) The Suez Canal was reopened five years ago this month, after an eight-year hiatus, by President Anwar el-Sadat while hostile Israeli troops patrolled just 13 miles away. The canal now stands as an example of efficiency and profitability in an otherwise erratic Egyptian economy. (21.)

Cut off even from Republican legislative patronage, deep in debt and getting deeper, the Republican State Committee in New York is ''bankrupt,'' according to its chairman, Dr. Bernard Kilbourn. Dr. Kilbourn made the statement last week, as the party prepared for its annual fund-raiser next Thursday, which will feature two of the nation's most prominent Republicans, Ronald Reagan and Gerald R. Ford. But the proceeds will be only a temporary palliative for the fiscally stricken state committee, which -despite what Dr. Kilbourn called its bankruptcy - may not actually go out of business because it was established by the state's election law.

The New York State Assembly recessed today at 3:26 A.M., after a nonstop, 12-hour and 11-minute session in which it gave final approval to a bill to outlaw ''head shops'' and killed a proposal to crack down on sweatshops.

On many occasions over the years I have noted that glass and metal measuring cups are designed for different purposes. Glass cups are designed for liquid. You add your water or milk or whatever to the cup, hold it up to the eye and thus determine the exact quantity in the cup. Metal cups, I have pointed out, are destined for measuring solids such as flour, sugar or salt. You add your solids to the cup, scrape off the top precisely and there you have an exact cup, half a cup, quarter cup and so on.

climbed in nine of the last 11 weeks, and most traders and investment bankers see no reason why this trend toward lower interest rates should not continue. This week, fixed-income financing activity will remain at the fast pace of the last month. The Treasury has scheduled two sales of bills - its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills this afternoon and a monthly sale of one-year bills on Wednesday. On Thursday it will sell $4.25 billion of two-year notes and on Tuesday, June 24, it will also offer $3.25 billion of four-year notes.

Almost every other week now Yehuda Z. Blum, the scholarly Israeli delegate to the United Nations, trots over to the blue and cream Security Council chamber for another tongue-lashing over his nation's treatment of Palestinian Arabs. Mr. Blum usually manages a derisive smile as Israel is deplored, regretted or otherwise chastised. As a rule the best he can expect is an abstention by the United States while the 14 other Council members vote against him.

In some of his recent recordings, Karl Richter has shown signs of unsureness. It was as if the newer, more modish performance practices had shaken his convictions about his own straightforwardness just enough to undercut his effectiveness. Mr. Richter, honed in the Bach style of his native Saxony, was never one to capitulate cravenly to what he calls ''the purists.'' But he seemed to have lost his confidence, his sense of purpose in the projection of his kind of musicmaking. But Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, as part of the Basically Bach Festival, Mr. Richter was in full command. This was neither the sometimes eccentric, authenticity-uber alles style of Bach-playing, nor the occasionally uneasy compromises that Richard Westenburg settles for. But Mr. Richter's Bach did not wallow in the Romantic bathos of an earlier generation, either. It filled the hall admirably with sound, it contrasted well with Mr. Westenburg's more timid approach, and it made for a highly effective concert.

Come the hot days of summer, what's the woman with yards of hair going to do with it? New Yorkers of all ages are going back to their schoolgirl days, wearing braids. It's a tidy way to get a lot of hair off the back of the neck and especially practical for bicycling, jogging or sunning at the beach. Braids can be twined right down to the ends of the hair or the bottom of the braid left loose in a brush effect. The braids themselves can be twisted into coronets or woven into circles.

The irony,'' Ron Silverman, producer of ''Brubaker,'' said in describing the decade he spent attempting to get some director, studio or star to make the film, ''is to try for 10 1/2 years to get a movie made and have it end up starring Robert Redford.'' Like ''The China Syndrome'' and ''Norma Rae,'' with which it has much in common, ''Brubaker'' is intended as a serious, socially significant film with a political point of view. Based on the experiences of Tom Murton, the warden who dug up three bodies on an Arkansas prison farm in 1968 and has not gotten a job in prison administration since, the $13 million movie details a pervasive corruption. There is not much to choose from among the prison-board member who sells the prison farm-insurance policies on nonexistent machinery, the doctor who treats only the prisoners who can pay for his services and the inmate kitchen helpers who steal the food meant for the prisoners and sell it back at 50 cents a bologna sandwich.

VILA, New Hebrides, June 15 (Reuters) France protested to Britain over the arrival of a British military force in the New Hebrides, saying it violated guidelines under which the two nations have governed the islands for 74 years, according to authoritative sources in the capital of this South Pacific island chain. In London, a British spokesman expressed puzzlement at the reported French reaction.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 15 It was Billy Martin T-Shirt Day at Oakland Coliseum today. But after the Yankees had finished battering the Oakland A's, 8-2, they almost managed to wipe the smile off Martin's face, which adorned the T-shirts given to all the youngsters in the crowd of 47,186.

Sergio Cardinal Pignedoli, one of the leading contenders for the papacy two years ago, died early yesterday while on a visit to his brother in the family's hometown of Reggio Emilia in north-central Italy. He was 70 years old and reportedly suffered a blood clot of the lungs.

Susan F. Baskin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Baskin of Little Neck, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Richard M. Gerwitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Gerwitz of Bayside, Queens. Rabbi Morton L. Gordon performed the ceremony at the North Country Reform Temple in Glen Cove, L.I. The bride is a screenwriter in Los Angeles, where her husband is a securities analyst with Merrill Lynch, Pierce Fenner & Smith Inc. Mr. Gerwitz's father is a retired deputy inspector of the New York City Police Department.

One-third of the men and women who normally assemble Pontiacs, Monte Carlos and Malibus at the General Motors Corporation plant in East Baltimore are on ''permanent and indefinite layoff,'' and there is no optimism that the changeover to 1981 models in July will revive sales enough to bring back the 2,300 second-shift workers. ''I have no idea when the second shift will come back,'' said Walter J. Gregonis, the plant manager. ''I do not foresee it in the next six months or the next year.''

In 1967, 17-year-old Madeline Manning won the national women's outdoor title in the 880-yard run. Today, 32-year-old Madeline Manning Mims won her fifth national outdoor title, and in doing so soundly beat Mary Decker, who broke the world mile record in January. The race was the women's 800-meter run on the third and final day of the Athletics Congress national outdoor track and field championships. Mrs. Mims led from the start and won by 15 meters in 1 minute 58.75 seconds. The time was a meet record and the second fastest by an American to her 1:57.90 in 1976.

Rodney Jenkins could hardly believe his eyes when he checked the scene. It was made to order for him. He climbed aboard Second Balcony and rode the mount to victory in the $15,000 added Grand Prix for jumpers today at the final session of the 51st Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show. ''It was a piece of cake,'' Jenkins said with a grin. ''It's a rare day when things are set up like this for me. And when they are, my horse usually is all form. But Second Balcony was going great, so the victory didn't surprise me at all.''

Denise Renee Littlefield, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Wattis Littlefield of Burlingame, Calif., was married yesterday to Adam Herbert Sobel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Aaron Sobel of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Chaim Stern at Temple Beth-El in Chappaqua, N.Y. The bride is a volunteer social worker at the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic of New York Hospital. Her father is retired chairman and chief executive officer of Utah International Inc., a mining company founded by the bride's great-grandfather, Edmund Orsen Wattis. It is now a division of the General Electric Company.

To the Editor: For years, I have admired the system with which we elect our Presidents. This year, however, my admiration has turned to disgust because of the hypocrisy that is inherent in the system, hypocrisy condoned in the highest office in the nation.

The World Bank is not really Robert McNamara's. It just looked that way during the extraordinary 12 years of his tenure as its president. It's not even the United States' or that of any of the 135 membernations. Mr. McNamara simply served longer than three of his four predecessors, also eminent Americans, and thus had the opportunity to leave a deep mark on the international aid agency. When he steps down next year, he will have carried through a fundamental shift in the global approach to poverty - a shift from power dams to pruning hooks, from a trickle-down strategy to aid programs that begin in the ground. That is not what might have been expected when Mr. McNamara took the job in 1968. He was a Detroit-trained hardware specialist who tragically misjudged the Vietnam War as Secretary of Defense, partly because he put too much faith in technology. Perhaps that experience caused him to rethink a World Bank development strategy that, in the spirit of its time, exalted growth and gave short shrift to fair distribution. The once invisible rural poor - there are about 800 million of them - found they had a friend at the World Bank (more augustly known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development) eager to underwrite dirt farming and family planning.

Freedom rather than Enterprise has been selected for America's Cup competition this summer, Dennis Conner, who will be the yacht's skipper, said today. The two 12-Meter boats belong to a syndicate representing the New York State Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, Enterprise having been launched in 1976 and Freedom in 1979. Both aluminum hulls were built at the Minneford Yacht Yard on City Island, the Bronx, to designs by Olin Stephens of Sparkman & Stephens.

When the New York State Senate and Assembly ended the legislative session this week, both houses technically ''recessed'' and did not adjourn. Politically, there is a major reason for doing so. By recessing, both houses gave their leaders the authority to call them back into special session rather than leave Governor Carey with the sole authority to do so, which would have been the case if they had adjourned sine die, or indefinitely. It also gave the leaders more potential political power in determining legislative priorities.

President Carter and Ronald Reagan built substantial leads over their rivals in the Presidential primaries on the basis of strong regional performances, particularly in the South, popular vote totals indicate. But while Mr. Reagan showed strength among Republicans in all regions, the President's geographical base was more limited.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 15 Political tension has eased here with word that the nation's armed forces will allow elections scheduled for two weeks from today to take place.

MONROVIA, Liberia, June 15 (Reuters) Liberia's military rulers have asked France to recall its ambassador to Monrovia following the arrest at the French Embassy of A.B. Tolbert, the son of the assassinated President, William Tolbert, the Liberian Foreign Minister said today.
DARIEN, Conn., June 15 Rodney Jenkins could hardly believe his eyes when he checked the scene. It was made to order for him.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Commerce Secretary Philip M. Klutznick said today that he saw no possibility of a tax cut before next year but that a reduction in taxes may be "very desirable" at that point.

In two days of carnage last Saturday and Sunday, nearly all of the Bengali residents of this village were killed in a raid by the indigenous tribal residents of the area. Today, the stench of death hangs in the air amid charred ruins of houses, stores and a tiny temple. A week ago this village, near Agartala, the capital of Tripura State adjoining the eastern border of Bangladesh, was milling with people. Today it is desolate, presenting mute testimony to the hatred that has involved the tribal people and the mostly Hindu Bengali immigrants from what is now Bangladesh in a fierce conflict.

Rokeby Stable's Winter's Tale easily won the $55,300 Nassau County Handicap at Belmont Park Sunday, but many of the 26,015 fans focused their attention on an unusual occurrence in the first race - the first double dead heat for the win and show positions in New York racing history. The oddity happened when Somebody Super, ridden by Mike Venezia, and Pillar Point, with Frank Lovato Jr. aboard, wound up in a dead heat for first. Here Dear, with Mike Gonzalez up, and Misty Irish, with Robert Attanasio riding, matched strides to the wire for the show position, two lengths behind the co-winners.

RELIGION To the Editor: Amid the charges and countercharges that have characterized the conflict surrounding the designation of Yeshiva Chofetz Chaim's Rice mansion as a landmark, important legal principles have been obscured.

At least no one can complain that Congress lacked decisiveness. By a combined vote of 403 to 44 the House and Senate rejected President Carter's 10-cent-a-gallon fee on imported oil. So emphatic a denial of the President's bid to ease dependence on foreign oil by taxing auto fuel is all too easy to explain. With gasoline temporarily in abundant supply and the election just months away, Congress was no more likely to respond in the affirmative than 5-year-olds asked to finish their brussel sprouts. But the gasoline tax will be back - if only because virtually every expert (privately including most leaders of Congress) sees it as the least disruptive way to curb oil imports. For now, one can only hope that proponents will learn from the defeat. To wit:

Jean Rondeau and Jean-Pierre Jaussaud of France overcame rain and a Porsche armada today to win the 48th Le Mans 24-hour endurance race. Rondeau became the first driver in the 57-year history of the event to win in a car of his construction. The 34-year-old Rondeau and Jaussaud, 43, who was on the winning team in 1978, held off a last-hour charge by Jacky Ickx of Belgium in a revamped Porsche 908.

Frank Richardson, a 25-year-old veterinary student from Ames, Iowa, won the Manitoba marathon today with a time of 2 hours 15 minutes 15 seconds, despite making an unscheduled stop for a passing freight train. Richardson said he could have covered the 26-mile-385-yard distance at least a minute faster if a Canadian National train had not temporarily blocked part of the route.

In the Roman Catholic Church of St. Francis Xavier in New York yesterday, Ellen Ann Jarocki, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Charles Jarocki of Brooklyn, was married to Dr. Andrew Charles Wormser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Mailert Wormser of New York and Stonington, Conn. The Rev. John D. Alexander performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass celebrated by the Rev. Joseph K. Parks. The Rev. Ronald Lafferty of St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York assisted. The bride, who is a nurse, until recently, was with the Sloane Hospital for Women of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. She attended the College of Mount St. Vincent and graduated from the Columbia University School of Nursing. Her father is a retired captain of the New York City Fire Department.

WASHINGTON TREASURY Department officials are confident that the dollar will hold up pretty well this year despite the precipitous fall in interest rates. They say the strength in current-account statistics will prevent a replay of the slumps of 1978 and 1979. The current account measures what the United States spends abroad compared with what it earns. Despite ever-higher oil bills, the expectation is that the account will be in balance this year.

New Yorkers will get a new afternoon newspaper today when The Wall Street Final, a five-day-a-week, 16-page tabloid with sports, stock tables and other features, makes its debut. The new publication is to be sold on newsstands in the Grand Central and Pennsylvania station areas in time to catch home-bound commuters. If all goes as planned, 15,000 copies with 3 P.M. stock market prices will reach the midtown newsstands at about 4 P.M. Another 30,000 copies with closing quotations are scheduled to be available at 5 P.M. or a bit later.

TOGETHER The European Community's statement on the Middle East rests on one central premise. That is that peace, whatever process is used to seek it, can only be attained in the end if there is respect for two political identities: Israeli and Palestinian. ''Two principles,'' the Community leaders said in their Venice declaration, are ''universally accepted by the international community: the right to existence and security of all the states in the region, including Israel, and justice for all the peoples, which implies the recognition of the legitimate rights of the Palestinian people.''

Congress will apparently soon pass legislation to permit private American companies to mine the ocean floor for minerals by 1988, whether or not a Law of the Sea treaty is in force by then, according to Administration officials. Both houses have already approved bills so similar that Congressional leaders say final agreement could be reached this week without the appointment of a joint conference committee.

In this time of seemingly endless bad news from Detroit, the situation is not entirely bleak. Despite the public's sudden aversion to traditional large cars and growing affection for Japanese imports, the General Motors Corporation has been selling all the Chevrolet Citations, Buick Skylarks, Oldsmobile Omegas and Pontiac Phoenixes it can make. These are the ''X'' cars, G.M.'s line of lightweight, fuelefficient, front-wheel-drive cars that represent the leading edge of the American automobile industry's new product wave.

The Long Island Lighting Company ''appears most vulnerable'' among the state's utilities to electric supply problems this summer, a state report says, but the company should be just about able to meet peak demand under average conditions. But, during a period of peak demand, if Lilco suffered a loss of generating capacity as serious as its worst in recent summers, then it would have to reduce voltage or black out some areas, according to the state report.

THE Comprehensive Care Corporation has arrived on the investment scene with no fanfare. Now that the company has began to show exceptional earnings growth, however, some people in Wall Street are beginning to take an interest in it.

WASHINGTON, June 13 A United States Representative will try on Thursday to evoke in Brooklynites memories of when they were young by throwing a party in memory of Ebbets Field, spaldeens and the good old days.

David Evans of Wales, a 6-foot-5-inch Welshman, overcame the elements to win the British Amateur golf championship yesterday. He beat David Suddards of South Africa, 4 and 3, in a driving rain and became the first Welshman to capture the 95-year-old event.
uf912To the Editor: There is something wrong with the people of New Jersey.

In that summer of 1945, they say, you could fairly hear the strain and tension in the voices of the chosen ones who bustled about Los Alamos, the Secret City on the Hill, the City of Fire, working feverishly toward the moment that would change the planet into a far more dangerous place. Dr. Norris Bradbury says he felt the tension, 35 years ago today, only a month and a day before he, Dr. Raemer Schreiber and others - one of the greatest collections of scientific brainpower ever assembled in one place - would finish their part of the work: the final assembly of ''The Gadget,'' ''Fat Man,'' the world's first atomic bomb.

As the carmen's strike that has shut down the Port Authority Trans-Hudson (PATH) line enters its fifth day, an estimated 80,000 commuters between New Jersey and Manhattan will be looking to emergency bus and shuttle trains today to help them get to work. Salvatore Raia, president of the striking union, Local 1330 of the Brotherhood of Railway Carmen, was reported yesterday to be trying to persuade bus drivers for Transport of New Jersey and smaller companies to stop providing service outside their routes. He could not be reached for comment.

For several days in late March, the financial world and senior Government officials waited uneasily to see whether the huge losses of Nelson Bunker Hunt and W. Herbert Hunt in the silver markets would topple any brokerage firms or banks. Although there appears to have been no permanent damage to anyone involved - except perhaps to the Hunts - four Federal agencies and four different Congressional subcommittees are studying the episode to decide if more regulation of commodities trading is needed.

central New Hampshire is sweet once again for most of its length. Fifty years ago, this good-size stream, which runs from Lake Sunapee west to join the Connecticut River in Claremont, was a highly regarded rainbow-trout stream. Pollution, industrial and domestic, ended all that, but in recent years Newport and Sunapee, communities on the river's upper reaches, have installed sewage treatment plants, and the Sugar's water quality has improved markedly. A few days ago, Victor Pomiecko of Claremont and I journeyed to the stretch of the Sugar that runs between the Claremont-Newport Highway and North Newport. Access to it is provided by the abandoned Claremont-Concord Railroad bed that runs along much of the river. The railroad's right of way in that area now belongs to the state, and because ties and tracks have been removed it is negotiable by automobile.

Is there such an organization as a humane tick society? I doubt that any member would say yes, but I have reason to believe that unthoughtfully some members of our so-called humane societies are aiding bear ticks to become kings among man and beast.

Political tension has eased here with word that the nation's armed forces will allow elections scheduled for two weeks from today to take place. Scattered protests against the United States Ambassador, Marvin Weissman, continued, however, and concern remained that the military had simply postponed its plans to stage a coup until after the elections.

AMONG all the beauty and chivalry of the fight mob, there may be a few individuals more knowledgeable than Paddy Flood, but their names don't come to mind. Paddy says Sugar Ray Leonard will whip Roberto Duran when the stylish young proprietor of the World Boxing Council's welterweight championship hooks up with the Panama City alley fighter in Montreal Friday night. Paddy Flood's opinions should be listened to at least as respectfully as Merrill Lynch's, but it says here that this time he is mistaken. Duran will introduce young Leonard to the seamy side of life. ''It's Ray Robinson against Jake LaMotta,'' Paddy says, ''Ali against Frazier, classic boxer against street brawler.'' The analogies are flawed. First time Muhammad Ali boxed Joe Frazier, the brawler knocked the classic boxer on his bustle and gave him a whipping. Their second bout was ruined when Tony Perez, the referee, let Ali grab and hold like a lovelorn octopus, yet some of us thought Frazier still earned a shade. Only in their third match, the ordeal in Manila, was Ali a clear winner, and even then he was losing until he blinded Frazier and punched him into obsolescence. Ali himself said it was ''next to death.''

Trading in shares of the MCI Telecommunications Corporation is expected to be brisk this week as a result of a $1.8 billion judgment the company won Friday night against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Last week, traders were eager to take profits or establish new positions in MCI as a Chicago Federal Court jury deliberated for three days over an antitrust judgment. The shares ended the week as the second most active stock in the over-the-counter market, closing down 1/2, to 7 5/8 bid.

WASHINGTON, June 15 Barry Offer was tooling around the parking lot of a local supermarket here last fall, trying out a pair of sneaker skates he received as a gift, when he hit a patch of gravel. His skates went up and he went down, breaking his ankle in three places, with one of the bones piercing the skin. The accident netted him five days in the hospital.
TEL AVIV, Monday, June 16 An Israeli naval vessel intercepted a rubber boat and killed three Palestinian guerrillas aboard it at daybreak today, the military command here announced.

JOHANNESBURG, June 15 The police used dogs, night sticks and tear gas today to break up groups of blacks gathering in Soweto to commemorate the anniversary of anti-Government unrest that broke out there four years ago.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J. UNDER a scorching sun, his gallery had resembled Caesar's legions as it marched across Baltusrol behind the yellow ropes.

WALNUT, Calif., June 15 In 1967, 17-year-old Madeline Manning won the national women's outdoor title in the 880-yard run. Today, 32-year-old Madeline Manning Mims won her fifth national outdoor title, and in doing so soundly beat Mary Decker, who broke the world mile record in January.
NEWPORT, N.H. THE Sugar River in west-central New Hampshire is sweet once again for most of its length.
MCENROE SWEEPS TO GRASS VICTORY

The 87-year-old candidate kicked off her shoes and ran up the narrow stairs to her election headquarters. ''Sorry about this place, it's really cramped up here,'' she said, leading the way into a room where half a dozen volunteers were crowded at desks. Fusae Ichikawa is waging what must be one of the least expensive campaigns for Sunday's parliamentary elections. Running as an independent for a seat in the upper house, the House of Councilors, she is hoping to come close to her 1974 total of 1.9 million votes nationwide, a total that made her one of the country's leading vote-getters.
A group of 64 scientists from 14 nations crossed the Himalayan border into Nepal yesterday after conducting a 10-day study of China's Tibetan plateau.

Former Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York City, who is running for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, tumbled from his bicycle and suffered a broken collarbone and minor cuts yesterday when an unleashed dog attacked him on a country road near his summer cottage in Bridgehampton, L.I. ''This is not the kind of break that a candidate hopes for,'' the 58-year-old Mr. Lindsay quipped after receiving treatment and a brace for his fractured right clavicle at nearby Southampton Hospital.

A look at the State Senate and Assembly payrolls shows that they include at least 37 relatives, former legislators, former state commissioners and Democratic Party and Republican Party leaders among the 3,928 employees. Their salaries range from $45,000 a year to $45 a week for part-time work. There is nothing illegal about such hiring - it is a practice as old as the Legislature itself. But it comes to light as the leaders of the State Senate and Assembly proudly describe their combined operating budgets of $76.5 million as lean. They also contend that they slightly cut the number of employees on the payroll this year.

An isolated pawn is rarely so weak that a direct attack on it will succeed; the preferred method of exploitation is to blockade it and then infiltrate around it. A good example of this strategy can be found in the game between Grandmasters Ulf Andersson of Sweden and John Nunn of Britain in the seventh round of the Phillips & Drew Kings International Tournament in London.
In Business Day on Thursday, the cash resources of the Texas Air Corporation, a new holding company, were incorrctly reported because of an editing error. The correct figure is $60 million.

Jack Nicklaus gained his fourth United States Open victory this afternoon by two strokes over Isao Aoki of Japan. What was important to him was not winning a fourth national championship, but just winning the 1980 Open so that he could put an end to all the speculation about the end of his career. This was his first victory since the British Open of 1978 and, a week afterward, the Philadelphia Classic. Today's victory also culminated what he called a year of hard work to restore his game to competitive shape.

Israel's Cabinet issued a vitriolic denunciation of the Common Market's declaration on the Middle East today, comparing it to the appeasement of Hitler at Munich and dismissing the offer of European security guarantees as no better than the empty pledges given Czechoslovakia in 1938. The Cabinet statement was read to reporters by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, who fled as a young man from Nazi-occupied Poland and served two

The Milwaukee Brewers have impressive offensive credentials. They lead the major leagues in home runs with 77 and in team batting with an average of better than .280. But the Kansas City Royals hit pretty well, too, as they proved yesterday in Milwaukee. They slugged four home runs in a 7-2 triumph over the Brewers that increased Kansas City's lead in the American League Western Division to seven games over the Chicago White Sox. None of the Royal home runs came from renowned sluggers. Amos Otis, who brought a .188 batting average into the game, knocked in three runs with his second and third homers of the season and added a single to the 14-hit assault on Moose Haas (6-6) and Jerry Augustine.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 15 King Hussein's visit to the United States this week is being viewed here as sensitive because of the potential repercussions at home and within the Arab world.

WASHINGTON, June 15 At the Senate Foreign Relations Committee's hearing on the appointment of Philip R. Trimble as Ambassador to Nepal, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan noted that Mr. Trimble had two outstanding qualifications.

Thomas E. Barton, a director and owner of the international insurance brokerage of Johnson Higgins, died of a heart attack Saturday evening while playing golf at the Montclair Golf Club in New Jersey. Mr. Barton, who was 54 years old, lived in Montclair.

SUDBURY, Mass., June 15 (UPI) Nancy Conz of Northampton, Mass., set a United States women's record today, winning the 25-kilometer run at the New England Athletics Congress meet in 1 hour 30 minutes 26 seconds.

Instead of trying to find ways to end inflation and raise productivity, Congress seems content to sit in the grandstand tossing empty bottles down on a President as he struggles, however belatedly, to get a grip on the economy.

Paul Newman's Datsun ZX was involved in a fourth-lap accident today that forced him to drop out of a race at Brainerd International Raceway. The suspension of Newman's car was bent in the crash. He had been running sixth over all and third in his class. Luis Mendez of the Dominican Republic took advantage of Walt Bohren's engine problems midway through the race to sweep to the victory in the Grand Prix 75-mile feature race.

An engine exploded in flames today as a Hawaiian Air DC-9 was taking off, forcing the pilot to abort the takeoff, officials said. Six people were injured as they were evacuated by the emergency chutes. All of the injuries in the incident at Honolulu International Airport were minor, officials said. The airline said it could not immediately say how many passengers were aboard the flight, which had been bound for Lihue, Kauai.

Differences of opinion between the United States and Western Europe over what role Europe can and should play in third world crises have marred trans-Atlantic relations in the months since Afghanistan and Iran.

PROMISE To the Editor: In August 1979, the Citizens Party was conceived. For the past 10 months, culminating with a national convention in Cleveland in April, 1980, membership was sought and a platform was researched and established. The Citizens Party and our issues are substantial today but, even more significant, they are designed for the future.

Stone Manor, a Kentucky-bred horse ridden by Pat Day, led from the start and won the 46th running of $150,000 Ohio Derby today by two and a half lengths over favored Colonel Moran at Thistledown. The winner, running out of the 13th post position on a sloppy track, broke inside upon leaving the gate and waged a neck-to-neck battle with Colonel Moran for much of the mile and one-eighth race.

NOT since 1972 when Ed McCabe, the writing ace at Scali, McCabe, Sloves, won four Gold Key and One Silver Key awards from the Copy Club of New York while president of the club, has there been the kind of pleasant coincidence as befell Jerry Della Femina Friday night at the Sheraton Centre. The voluble, talented chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, serving as chairman of the 21st annual Clio Awards Festival, saw his agency pick up six Clio statuettes, four for the New York office and two for Los Angeles. Isn't it wonderful the way things happen. All together there were 57 Clios awarded for television commercials -print and packaging having been dispatched on Tuesday and radio on Thursday. Each Clio was either for a major product category, which took care of most of the awards, or for a technical aspect of production, such as best actor, which was won by ''Mean Joe'' Greene of the Pittsburgh Steelers for his moving miniperformance in the McCann-Erickson spot for Coca-Cola.

Negotiations between the Consolidated Edison Company and leaders of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union were stalemated yesterday after only an hour of bargaining as the date of a strike, threatened for Wednesday, drew nearer.

A management reorganization at Corning Glass Works has resulted in changes in the responsibilities of two of its top officers. Thomas C. MacAvoy, 52 years old, president and chief operating officer, who previously had direct accountability for United States operations and was in charge of the ''inside'' staff, such as engineering and personnel, will now be responsible for all of the company's operations around the world. And James R. Houghton, 44, vice chairman, will add the title of chairman of the executive committee and become Corning's chief strategic officer with responsibility for all staff functions.

In the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday afternoon, Dorrie Elizabeth Mihic, daughter of Mrs. William H. Brownyard of New York, and the late Hubert Louis Mihic, became the bride of Barnabas Bradshaw Bufford Breed, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Bassett Breed 3d. The Rev. Thomas A. Nielson officiated. The bride, a graduate of the State University at New Paltz, attended the Sorbonne, in Paris. She is a partner in Cornucopia of Flowers Inc. Her mother is the owner of H.L. Mihic and Company, a New York-based advertising concern that was founded by the bride's father.

Somebody invented Sugar Ray Leonard. Irving Rudd thinks the invention resulted from ''taking the two best boxers of this century and combining them: Sugar Ray Robinson and Benny Leonard.'' Ray Charles Leonard, in fact named for the singer, has become a man who is regarded as the perfect boxer, and he is perhaps more nearly flawless outside the ring than inside. He is the American dream come true, a figure of comic-book-hero dimensions who grew up reading Superman, a smooth combination of Madison Avenue and Main Street.
Rocco A. Parella, who served as a judge in New York City courts for 35 years, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital following a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 The current recession will not end until early 1981 and unemployment will climb to a peak of 8.6 percent by the fall of 1981, according to a new forecast issued today by Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates.

The Long Island Lighting Company "appears most vulnerable" among the state's utilities to electric supply problems this summer, a state report says, but the company should be just about able to meet peak demand under average conditions.

ISMAILIA, Egypt, June 9 Five years ago this month, President Anwar el-Sadat, resplendent in the dress white uniform of an admiral, stood on the deck of an Egyptian destroyer leading the first convoy in eight years through the Suez Canal.

SAN SALVADOR, June 15 (UPI) A Panamanian Air Force plane carrying ammunition said to be destined for leftist Salvadoran guerrillas crashed today at a plantation east of the capital, a military spokesman said.

Bond prices have climbed in nine of the last 11 weeks, and most traders and investment bankers see no reason why this trend toward lower interest rates should not continue. This week, fixedincome financing activity will remain at the fast pace of the last month.

While his 74-year-old sister dabbed her eyes in the little church, family and friends held a memorial service yesterday for Harry R. Truman, the stubborn old man who would not leave his volcano. Mr. Truman, 83 years old, had spurned all warnings, including those from worried schoolchildren who wrote from as far as England asking him to move from his lodge at the base of Mount St. Helens.

SHEILA TIGHE grew up in a yellow house in a friendly neighborhood just up the hill from where the Staten Island ferry deposits its passengers from Manhattan. It is the kind of neighborhood in which everyone knows everyone else, and people passing by on the street wave and call out to the family sitting on the screened front porch. Sitting in the dark living room just off the porch, on one of the comfortable pieces of stuffed furniture, Mary Tighe (pronounced ''Tie''), Sheila's mother, was recalling a scene that took place time after time in the room during the course of her 18-year-old daughter's career as a basketball star at St. Peter's High School.

Tonight is not one of your frothier outings on the Public Broadcasting Service. After two hours on the subject of suicide, two original dramas explore the drearier aspects of life in New Jersey. ''Choosing Suicide'' documents the reasons behind the decision of 62-year-old Jo Roman, afflicted with terminal cancer, to commit suicide a year ago. Mrs. Roman, recorded between February and May 1979, is articulate on the subject of ''rational suicide.'' The essay, carefully avoiding sensationalism, is moving and disturbing in more ways than one. Predictably, a good many stations in the public system are refusing to carry the program.

The police used dogs, night sticks and tear gas today to break up groups of blacks gathering in Soweto to commemorate the anniversary of anti-Government unrest that broke out there four years ago. Before the police ordered reporters to clear the area, they saw at least one young black being beaten by a black policeman with a night stick. But the police appeared to be under orders to limit the use of force, and marksmen with automatic rifles, who were responsible for at least 600 deaths in 1976, remained in the background through most of the day. No serious injuries were reported.

After eight months of testimony in a Federal courtroom cordoned off by security equipment and personnel, 15 men and three women associated with the Northern California Hell's Angels are waiting for a jury's decision on charges that their motorcycle club is a racketeering conspiracy. Federal District Judge Samuel Conti, who has presided over the long and complex Hell's Angels trial, instructed the jury to begin its deliberations yesterday morning.

It was Billy Martin T-Shirt Day at Oakland Coliseum today. But after the Yankees had finished battering the Oakland A's, 8-2, they almost managed to wipe the smile off Martin's face, which adorned the T-shirts given to all the youngsters in the crowd of 47,186. Except for the fact the A's won only one of the four games in the series, Martin, the Oakland manager, should have been ecstatic over the abnormally huge crowds the games attracted. The total of 121,364 spectators for the three days broke the Coliseum record of 39,852.

Although Ward Seibert, a 33-year-old grammar school teacher from Long Island, cannot speak Japanese, and Isao Aoki speaks very little English, the two got along famously during the United States Open. Seibert caddied for Aoki, and the combination obviously worked because the Japanese golfer finished second to Jack Nicklaus. ''He understood what I was trying to get across to him 90 percent of the time,'' Seibert said. ''I got his messages most of the time.'' Seibert, a fifth grade teacher at Friends Academy in Locust Valley, L.I., met Aoki for the first time last March 26. ''My wife and child and I were visiting my parents, who have a home in Hilton Head, S.C., during my spring vacation week,'' Seibert said. ''I went over to the Harbor Town club to see if I could caddie for any of the pros playing in the Heritage that week. I learned Aoki was looking for a caddie, and we got together. I caddied a practice round for him Wednesday of that week, and he said O.K., so I caddied the tournament for him.''

The taste of defeat after a dozen games was not a bitter pill to swallow for the Cosmos and Coach Hennes Weisweiler. ''The win streak is finished,'' Weisweiler said, ''but now we must start another one. I have a good feeling, just like the players, when everyone plays with a good attitude and effort.''

There were the traditional bridesmaids, 13 of them. And to give the bride away, her uncle, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, did the honors. But Courtney Kennedy and Jeff Ruhe made sure there was a distinctive personal touch at their wedding in Washington on Saturday. Exchanging vows at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church, the daughter of Ethel Kennedy and the late Robert F. Kennedy and her bridegroom, a 28-year-old broadcasting assistant, recited, ''Oh God, our Father in heaven, we now kneel before You very happy, but somewhat nervous.''

The theory that any ballet with children is a family show holds sway over at the New York City Ballet and this is certainly true of its ''Harlequinade,'' given its first performance of the season Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater. Patricia McBride was back as Colombine, a role she created in 1965 and in which she continues to find new riches. She has been wooed by a series of harlequins over the years and one of the greatest is her current swain, Helgi Tomasson.

A Chinese official warned an American delegation led by the Governor of Maryland today that Ronald Reagan's proposal to re-establish diplomatic relations with Taiwan could ''endanger'' Chinese-United States relations. Zhao Xingzhi, a Deputy Mayor of Shanghai, told Gov. Harry R. Hughes and the other delegation members that Mr. Reagan's plan ''goes against the common interest of our two peoples.'' Mr. Zhao's comment followed an article by the official New China News Agency on Friday that charged that Mr. Reagan's proposal ''would wreck the very foundation of Sino-U.S. relations.'' The article was signed by a ''special commentator,'' indicating the Chinese Government attached unusual importance to it and that it was written by a senior official.

Five years ago this month, President Anwar el-Sadat, resplendent in the dress white uniform of an admiral, stood on the deck of an Egyptian destroyer leading the first convoy in eight years through the Suez Canal. Egyptian assault troops had retaken the canal's east bank only 20 months earlier. Mr. Sadat's decision to reopen it to international traffic - although Israeli troops remained as close as 13 miles and negotiations on a further disengagement of forces had just collapsed -was a gamble that has paid off for Egypt, both economically and politically.
KATMANDU, Nepal, June 15 (AP) A group of 64 scientists from 14 nations crossed the Himalayan border into Nepal yesterday after conducting a 10-day study of China's Tibetan plateau.

People, food and music mingled and flowed along the Avenue of the Americas yesterday at the first annual festival on the street-an event that might have been billed "the festival where no one could stand still."
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 15 Jack Nicklaus gained his fourth United States Open victory this afternoon by two strokes over Isao Aoki of Japan.

LE MANS, France, June 15 (AP) Jean Rondeau and Jean-Pierre Jaussaud of France overcame rain and a Porsche armada today to win the 48th Le Mans 24-hour endurance race. Rondeau became the first driver in the 57year history of the event to win in a car of his construction.
