The neighbors, who never met Dwight and Mamie Eisenhower, are walking through the large, white-painted brick house with drawn window shades where the couple played bridge, watched Lawrence Welk on television and entertained the mighty - Adenauer, Churchill, de Gaulle, Nehru and Khrushchev, among others. The Eisenhowers' 687-acre farm beside the somber Civil War battlefield memorial, open to the public after today, is expected to attract a long-running crush of the affectionately curious, according to its new owner, the United States Park Service.

International Israel harshly denounced the Common Market declaration last week on the Middle East that urged that the Palestine Liberation Organization be ''associated'' with the peace talks. A Cabinet statement, read to reporters by Prime Minister Menachem Begin, compared the European stand with the appeasement of Hitler at Munich and dismissed it as no better than the pledges given to Czechoslovakia in 1938. (Page A1, Column 6.) When King Hussein visits Washington this week he will try to make President Carter understand, if not accept, why most most Arabs still reject the peace talk formula followed by Egypt, Israel and the United States since the Camp David conference nearly two years ago, Jordanian officials said in Amman. (A1:5.) Bengali immigrants were massacred in the village where they had settled near the Bangladesh border by indigenous tribal people, who are ethnically and legally distinct from most Indians. Nearly all the Bengalis in the agricultural village of Mandai were killed in a raid last weekend. Indian Army troops, sent there, buried the bodies of 350 men, women and children. (A1:1-2.) Dogs and teargas were used by the police in South Africa to disperse blacks who were gathering in Soweto, a segregated black quarter outside Johannesburg, to observe the anniversary of anti-Government riots there four years ago. The police were enforcing a Government proclamation last week banning all political and commemorative meetings of more than 10 persons, the most repressive restriction on political activity in South Africa in nearly 200 years. (A3:4-6.) Harm to Chinese-American relations could result from Ronald Reagan's campaign proposal to re-establish relations between Washington and Taiwan, a Chinese official in Shanghai warned an American delegation led by Gov. Harry R. Hughes of Maryland. Zhao Xingzhi, Deputy Mayor of Shanghai, told Mr. Hughes that Mr. Reagan's plan ''goes against the common interests of our two peoples.'' (A19:3-4.) National The C.I.A. experimented widely in seeking new espionage techniques, according to records released under the Freedom of Information Act. However, the several thousand documents had been heavily censored. Among the projects were tests using trained seals and otters, monitoring the ''bioplasma'' fields of agents, and developing poison pellet guns. Stun guns, calibrated blackjacks and marsmallow barrages were also tested. (A1:1.) The Los Angeles police image of efficiency is under question in the wake of alleged brutality and ''spying'' on leftist groups and other organizations that have been critical of the Police Department. A local affiliate of the American Civil Liberties Union has released copies of records from police files, obtained in a lawsuit, that indicate that undercover police officers attended meetings of the City Council and the Police Commission and then gave reports to their superiors. (A16:1-2.) A layoff of 2,300 auto workers at the General Motors plant in East Baltimore has followed the drop in car sales caused by high gasoline prices and the switch to imports from Japan. The plant epitomizes the problems of many United States auto factories: outdated equipment, questions of product quality, absenteeism in the face of the layoffs and poor morale. (A16:3-5.) Metropolitan The Republican State Committee in New York is financially ''bankrupt,'' its chairman, Dr. Bernard Kilbourn, said last week as the party prepared for its annual fund-raiser Thursday, which is to be attended by Ronald Reagan and Gerald R. Ford. But the proceeds are expected to be only temporarily palliative. (A1:3-4.) Casino developers in Atlantic City attempted, with the help of the director of the Planning Board, to bend the city's pending master plan to avoid its casino site requirements. The Zoning Board later gave its approval and the Planning Board's director went to work for the casino developers. However, the State Casino Control Commission ultimately stepped in and forced the developers to modify their plan. The case illustrates what some officials say is a pattern of close relations between casino developers and local government officials since gambling was approved in Atlantic City in 1976. (A1:1.) Illegal-gun dealers thrive in New York City and are largely responsible for the 2 million unlicensed handguns sold in the city in the last 10 years. One dealer gets his guns from Pennsylvania, Vermont and other nearby states. He says made nearly $100,000 last year in unreported income and, he says, New York State's new gun-control law, which Governor Carey believes is the nation's toughest, will have little effect on his business. (A1:1.) The Assembly passed 250 bills in Albany in a little more than 12 hours, then joined the Senate in recessing. One bill that gained approval would outlaw ''head shops,'' according to its sponsors. (B1:5-6.) Electric supply problems this summer are expected to affect the Long Island Lighting Company most of all the state's utilities, according to a state report, that says Lilco should be just about able to meet peak demand under average conditions. (B2:1.) Relatives and cronies of legislators in Albany can still find a place on the Senate and Assembly payrolls, even though legislative leaders describe their combined operating budgets of $76.5 million as lean. (B5:1-4.) Business Digest, Page D1

Rocco A. Parella, who served as a judge in New York City courts for 35 years, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital following a long illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan. Mr. Parella, who was a Republican, was an assistant United States attorney under Thomas E. Dewey. He was first appointed as a Municipal Court judge by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in 1934, becoming one of the state's youngest sitting judges.

A problem that arises for players everywhere, except in France, derives from a quirk in the scoring of duplicate bridge. Making 10 tricks in a contract of four hearts or four spades will not be satisfactory if your rivals make the same 10 tricks in no-trump. The difference of 10 points, which counts for nothing in normal team play and virtually nothing in rubber bridge, can be worth a lot of match points.

The Cuban sealift persisted today with the arrival of a shrimp boat carrying 306 refugees. The 76-foot Gulf Prince II of Freeport, Tex., pulled up to the old Navy base docks, followed by two small boats. Two other small craft sank overnight and their passengers and crew were rescued by Coast Guard cutters, a spokesman, Carlos Martinez, said. No injuries were reported.

INQUIRY To the Editor: The vehement and emotional reaction of the editorial staff of The New York Times to the publication ''Toward Healthful Diets,'' which was released last week by the Food and Nutrition Board of the National Research Council/National Academy of Sciences, verges on the hysterical.
In Business Day on Thursday, the cash resources of the Texas Air Corporation, a new holding company, were incorrctly reported because of an editing error. The correct figure is $60 million.

Nancy Conz of Northampton, Mass., set a United States women's record today, winning the 25-kilometer run at the New England Athletic's Congress meet in 1 hour 30 minutes 26 seconds. The 23-year-old Miss Conz outdistanced the second-place finisher, Anne Sullivan, by 5:29. Her winning time knocked 2:39 off the previous mark of 1:33.05, set by Roxanne Bier.

The Princeton University Chapel was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Roberta Jeanne Marie Olson, daughter of Emma Pauline Hoops of Madison, Wis., to Alexander Buchanan Vance Johnson, son of Prof. and Mrs. Edward Dudley Hume Johnson of Princeton. The Rev. Ernest Gordon, a Presbyterian minister and dean of the chapel, performed the ceremony. The bride, an assistant professor of art history at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., was graduated from St. Olaf College in Northfield, Minn., where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and also studied at Carleton College and Oxford University. She holds an M.A. from the University of Iowa and M.F.A. and Ph.D. degrees from Princeton. The bride organized and was curator of the exhibition ''Italian Drawings 1780-1890,'' which opened in March at the National Gallery of Art in Washington.

Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark returned to the United States last night and said that Government officials should ''do their duty'' and prosecute him if they believed he had broken the law by attending an Iranian-sponsored conference on alleged United States intervention in Iran. Mr. Clark arrived at Kennedy International Airport at 7:15 P.M. on an Air France flight from Paris, where he went after the five-day conference in Teheran ended. Nine other Americans who attended the conference with him returned last week.

ASPHALT ACTION The Battery Dance Company refers to itself as Wall Street's resident dance troupe. It is supported in part by some folks in the neighborhood - 10 corporations. ''Dancing Downtown,'' is the title of Battery's financial-district offerings this month, in which they perform accompanied by the Apple Brass Quintet. The seven-member dance company has created pieces it feels fit well into the city's outdoors and are highly visible. The dances it performs are: ''Slang'' and the preciously titled, ''Loose Joints.''
"SELL July and September on rallies, buy January and March on dips," has been the recent advice of several commodity firms for traders of lumber futures.

On many occasions over the years I have noted that glass and metal measuring cups are designed for different purposes. Glass cups are designed for liquid. You add your water or milk or whatever to the cup, hold it up to the eye and thus determine the exact quantity in the cup.

WASHINGTON TREASURY Department officials are confident that the dollar will hold up pretty well this year despite the precipitous fall in interest rates. They say the strength in current-account statistics will prevent a replay of the slumps of 1978 and 1979.

DELCO, N.C. Is there such an organization as a humane tick society? I doubt that any member would say yes, but I have reason to believe that unthoughtfully some members of our so-called humane societies are aiding bear ticks to become kings among man and beast.

LES-DEUX-EGLISES, France, June 15 (Reuters) - Thousands of Gaullists marched today into this small village where Charles de Gaulle is buried, marking the 40th anniversary of his World War II call to arms against Nazi invaders. The crowd, estimated by organizers at more than 40,000, came in buses from as far away as Brittany and the Riviera. The Gaullists, who left their vehicles three miles from here, marched behind French flags bearing General de Gaulle's Cross of Lorraine emblem to this village where he died in 1970.

An Israeli naval vessel intercepted a rubber boat and killed three Palestinian guerrillas aboard it at daybreak today, the military command here announced. The announcement said the rubber vessel was on its way to Israel for a terrorist attack. It was intercepted at 5 A.M. off the coast four miles south of the Lebanese border.

Commerce Secretary Philip M. Klutznick said today that he saw no possibility of a tax cut before next year but that a reduction in taxes may be ''very desirable'' at that point. However, George P. Shultz, an adviser to Ronald Reagan, said ''I think we should have a reduction in taxes now.'' Mr. Klutznick's statement was consistent with Carter Administration policy, but there has been speculation lately that the deepening recession and election-year politics might force an earlier tax cut.

Roland Petit and his Ballet National de Marseille will open at the Uris Theater in New York on Sept. 2 for a three-week season. Three new full-length ballets by the French choreograher will be seen. ''The Bat,'' set to Johann Strauss's ''Die Fledermaus,'' will star Zizi Jeanmaire, Denys Ganio and Luigi Bonino. Mr. Petit will play the role of Dr. Coppelius in ''Coppelia,'' in which Dominique Khalfouni and Karen Kain will share the role of Swanilda, and Mr. Ganio, Peter Schaufuss and Jean-Charles Gil will appear alternately as Franz. The third work is ''Marcel Proust Remembered,'' a ballet in 13 scenes, inspired by Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past'' and set to music by favorite composers of the novelist.
AROUND THE NATION; Tiles on the Space Shuttle Pass First Critical Testing

The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees requested yesterday that Thailand postpone a mass repatriation of Cambodians scheduled to begin this morning, the commissioner's regional office here announced. No official reply was received by this morning, and a United Nations' source said the situation in the two border camps affected was unclear. Informed diplomats suggested that the requested postponement was connected with a visit to Vietnam by Zia Rizvi, the regional representative of the United Nations body. Mr. Rizvi, who was returning from Hanoi via Vientiane, Laos, could not be reached for comment.

Last Jan. 28 the White House produced a twoinch-thick, 636-page document entitled, ''The Budget of the United States Government, Fiscal Year 1981.'' It wasn't.

Belgium defeated Spain, 2-1, in Milan today to emerge as the surprising front-runner in Group Two of the European soccer championship, just ahead of favored Italy, which beat England by 1-0 in Turin. Both teams have 3 points from two matches, but the Belgians have scored more goals. If Belgium wins or holds Italy to a tie in Rome on Wednesday, it will advance to next Sunday's final, in which it will almost certainly meet West Germany, of Group One.

THE Comprehensive Care Corporation has arrived on the investment scene with no fanfare. Now that the company has began to show exceptional earnings growth, however, some people in Wall Street are beginning to take an interest in it. Comprehensive Care sets up clinical ''boutiques'' in hospitals that offer rehabilitative care to alcoholics. The company's program emphasizes psychotherapy. It has just hired Dr. Joseph Pursch, a leading authority on the problem, as its medical director. His past patients include Betty Ford, wife of Gerald R. Ford, the former President; Billy Carter, brother of President Carter, and Senator Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia. Dr. Pursch treated these well-known Americans while he was head of the Alcohol and Drug Abuse Center at Long Beach Naval Hospital in California.

Dr. Bernard J. Bamberger, a scholar of Reform Judaism and rabbi emeritus of Temple Shaaray Tefila, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital after suffering a heart attack in his Manhattan home. He was 76 years old. Rabbi Bamberger had been head of Temple Shaaray Tefila from 1944 until his retirement in 1971, when he was succeeded by Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum. The temple this year is observing its 135th anniversary and is one of New York City's oldest and most prominent Reform Jewish synagogues.

Gail Bonnie Woolf, daughter of Aileen Woolf of Troy, N.Y., and the late Leonard Woolf, was married in Peekskill, N.Y., yesterday to Bruce David Jaffin, son of Mrs. Martin Goldberg and Dr. Herbert Jaffin, both of New York. Rabbi Mordecai Kieffer performed the ceremony at the Colonial Terrace. The bride was graduated from Russell Sage College. Her husband, a civil-engineering graduate of the University of New Hampshire, received an M.B.A. degree in finance from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute. He will join the Turner Construction Company in Boston next week. His father is an obstetrician.

Two persons were killed over the weekend in traffic accidents that occurred on roads slickened or darkened by the volcanic dust. Rain disposed of some dust, but dry weather prevailed today.

UNDER a scorching sun, his gallery had resembled Caesar's legions as it marched across Baltusrol behind the yellow ropes. But now, in the twilight, the people who had been out on the golf course began to clog in the long shadows around the 18th green, joining those in the bleachers and on the grass in front of the majestic Tudor clubhouse who had been waiting to see Jack Nicklaus appear there as the United States Open champion. And when he marched up the hill to check the pin position, the shouting began. ''Sit down, sit down!'' those in the bleachers were yelling. ''Sit down, sit down!'' But this was a time for standing. For a standing ovation. And as Jack Nicklaus, his smile even brighter than his golden hair, walked up there, the standing ovation began. But moments later, it suddenly stopped.

By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LAUGHING IN THE HILLS. By Bill Barich. 228 pages. Viking. $10.95. BILL BARICH is not exactly the first person in history to turn to the race track as an escape from his sorrows. But the solemnity with which he undertakes the exercise must set some sort of record. At a bad time in his life a few years ago - when his mother was dying of cancer, his wife had just been operated on for a brain tumor she turned out not to have, and all over his home county ''town houses and condominiums were devouring orchards and vineyards just as they'd devoured the potato farms on Long Island'' - he began ''to long for an escape into orderliness and decided, with the same hapless logic that governed all my actions then, to leave home and spend the rest of the spring at Golden Gate Fields, a thoroughbred track in Albany, near Oakland and San Francisco. There were other things I might have done, friends who would have taken me in, but I was convinced there was something special about racing and I wanted to get to the heart of the matter. The track seemed circumscribed and manageable, especially when compared to the complex filigree of nature, hydrogen intertwined with embryos and tumors. I kept thinking about the fat man'' he'd met in an Off Track Betting parlor back East ''and the pulse I'd first heard beating on Long Island. I thought if I could touch it, I might come away renewed.''

Judges around New York State are engaged in an extraordinary conflict with the State Office of Court Administration, the agency responsible for the day-to-day administration of all New York courts, over the transfer of upstate judges to New York City and four other counties to reduce a backlog of cases. The transfers began last Dec. 31 as part of a plan worked out by the state's Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke. Judges are assigned to sit in courts other than their own for one or more four-week terms. On the theory that ''justice delayed is justice denied,'' the plan also reduced the judges' vacation time.

The marriage of Carol Jane Schwartz, daughter of Mrs. Nathan Schwartz of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Mr. Schwartz, to Richard Harold Hochman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Hochman of Brooklyn, took place yesterday evening in the Starlight Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria. Rabbi Yochel Fiskin officiated. The bride, a Queens College graduate, is the merchandise coordinator with Rhoda Lee Inc., a New York-based manufacturer of women's blouses. Her mother, Roslyn Schwartz, is an administrative assistant in the library of the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. The bride's father was president of the Empire State Blood and Plasma Service Inc. in New York.

A Panamanian Air Force plane carrying ammunition said to be destined for leftist Salvadoran guerrillas crashed today at a plantation east of the capital, a military spokesman said. In Panama, however, an official identified the plane's owner and pilot as a Panamanian citizen who runs a commercial airline. A spokesman for the 3rd Brigade, a Salvadoran Army unit in San Miguel, 84 miles east of San Salvador, said an estimated 22,000 rifle cartridges of Venezuelan manufacture were found in the wreckage of the plane.

Predictably, the answers were rather unpredictable, particularly in the case of Lerrin Lagrow, a 31-year-old, righthanded relief pitcher. LaGrow noted that the person he would most like to meet was ''Khomeini.'' His hobby was: ''Baseball.'' His favorite song: ''Take This Job and Shove It.''

Bent,'' the drama starring Michael York and Jeffrey DeMunn, and featuring Dennis Boutsikaris, which had been tentatively scheduled to close last Saturday at the New Apollo Theater, has been extended indefinitely because of an upturn in business after its closing was announced. Ed Ott and the Pittsburgh Pirates made the division races in the National League a little more interesting yesterday for fans in Pittsburgh and Los Angeles, not to mention causing some concern in Montreal and Houston. With Ott cracking a home run and two singles in three times at bat, the Pirates downed the Houston Astros, 4-1, in Pittsburgh and moved to within one game of the Montreal Expos, the Eastern Division leaders. And Houston saw its Western Division lead over the Los Angeles Dodgers shrink to one game. The Dodgers defeated Montreal, 1-0, yesterday.

FEARLESS FRANK'' is just about enough to break your heart. This British musical has a uniformly ingratiating cast and one of the wittiest librettos of the season. Its title character, the literary scoundrel Frank Harris, is a fount of devilish fun, and he is perfectly embodied by the sly Irish actor Niall Toibin. But if the show at the Princess Theater is always pleasant, literate and sweet, it never for a second catches fire. ''Fearless Frank'' lacks the one intangible ingredient that separates successful musical comedies from the also-rans - showbiz know-how. Such know-how consists mainly of hard, detailed work. In a musical, a lot of diverse components must somehow be assembled into a seamless theatrical organism. Unless each fine point of the production, from the first orchestral downbeat to the final blackout, is precisely tuned, the show remains earthbound. This precision is completely missing in ''Fearless Frank,'' as it is in many British musicals. For some inexplicable reason, English theater people, who are so smart about everything else, often come to grief when trying to assemble effective song-and-dance shows. Though British musicals can succeed here, it sometimes takes a Broadway hand to stir the raw materials into an incendiary mix. It's not happenstance that such current London-bred hits as ''A Day in Hollywood/A Night in the Ukraine'' and ''Evita'' have been staged, respectively, by Tommy Tune and Hal Prince.

New York State's new handgun law, described by Governor Carey as ''the toughest handgun law in the country,'' will increase the severity of penalties for possession of unregistered handguns and increase the illegal sale of guns from a misdemeanor to a felony. The law provides that anyone carrying a loaded unlicensed gun in a public place will be charged with ''armed violent felony.'' Plea bargaining will be allowed only after the suspect is indicted for a felony, and the minimum sentence will be a year.

The seven-nation economic summit meeting in Venice next week is expected to endorse a new program of energy conservation and supply and the continuation of the battle against inflation, according to American economic officials. But as the group's first meeting since the Iran and Afghanistan crises, the two-day session will also focus more heavily than in the past on political matters, although American officials neither seek nor anticipate dramatic new actions.

William George McGowan leaned back at his desk in his 17th Street office today, puffed on a small cigar and looked content, the big legal battle between his MCI Communications Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company having culminated in a $1.8 billion award in favor of MCI. Looks were deceiving, however. Tomorrow, in Federal Court in Chicago, he said, he would file for the award of damages. That means, he said, interest on the $1.8 billiion award would accrue at the rate of $2.6 million a week, $135 million a year, until the legal proceedings were concluded.

King Hussein's visit to the United States this week is being viewed here as sensitive because of the potential repercussions at home and within the Arab world. People, food and music mingled and flowed along the Avenue of the Americas yesterday at the first annual festival on the street - an event that might have been billed ''the festival where no one could stand still.'' From 34th to 50th Street there was a continuous wave of browsers and artisans, music makers and foot-stompers, street chefs and munchers. All the avenue was a moving stage. People were moving on foot and on roller skates, on bicycles and in baby carriages along the automobile-free streets. And those who paused along the way kept swaying to the ever-present music as they went from booth to booth.

The Central Intelligence Agency's secret experiments on new methods of espionage have included using trained seals and otters, monitoring the ''bioplasma fields'' of agents and testing the sonar of electric fish, according to documents newly made public. The experimenters also worked on developing such weapons as a poison pellet, electric stun guns, calibrated blackjacks and marshmallow barrages. The intelligence agency's research and development staff was also interested in the secret life of plants, peace pills and an array of other futuristic schemes that were discarded as impracticable or as quackery, according to about 3,000 heavily censored pages of study evaluations and other documents relating to C.I.A. activities from 1965 to 1975. The material has been made public at the agency's headquarters in Langley, Va., as a result of a request under the Freedom of Information Act initiated by The New York Times.

The season of communal al fresco activities is upon us. New Yorkers love parades, festivals, celebrations, demonstrations and entertainments, particularly when such occasions bring large numbers of them together outdoors. The finer the weather, the greater the urge to gather, the sweeter the siren call of causes. Over the years, these public events have moved around town. Union Square, long the scene of political oratory and promises of a better world, saw its last really good turnout for the first Earth Day, in 1970. The Battery and Lower Manhattan were the setting for an unforgettable Bicentennial celebration in 1976, and a few events since. But for some time now, the most popular place to gather has been the Sheep Meadow in Central Park, which was never meant to withstand the tramp of thousands of carefree or protesting feet.

Those fishing the Sugar River would do well to obtain a map of the section of the stream described in the accompanying article. The Sunapee quadrangle of the United States Topographic Map System (scale 1:62,500) is a good choice and includes the north and south branches of the Sugar, which also hold trout. This map covers the main stream to within a mile of the Claremont-Newport line. From that point on to where the river enters the Connecticut, one needs the Claremont, N.H.-Vermont quadrangle.

To the Editor: I want to protest against the use of the current subway poster for OTB with the headline ''40,000 Winning Bets Daily.'' I think OTB should be required to add a second headline, in equally large type, telling us how many losing bets there are daily.

In football circles, the month of June belongs to the punters and therefore to Doc Storey, their guru. Dr. Edward J. Storey, a 79-year-old retired high school football coach, is the star attraction at three kicking clinics: one held last week in Richmond, where Craig Jones was among his pupils; another that began Sunday at River Falls, Wis., and the third next week at Trenton. Storey, an authority on kicking, presents a threat to incumbent punters in the National Football League because one of his pupils may walk into a training camp next month and take someone's job.

GOLDEN, Colo. NEW forms of glass that may ultimately make sunlit homes warmer are under development, chiefly for use in solar energy applications. Although ordinary window glass seems to pass sunlight unimpeded, iron oxide within it, which comes from the sand used in production, absorbs a considerable percentage of solar energy. The new types of glass, in which the iron oxide has been altered or removed, allow far more energy to pass. Specialists see such glass as ultimately applicable to windows in homes that exploit passive solar heating, allowing sunlight to fall on heat-absorbing floors and walls.

FROM the self revelations of children that made up ''The Me Nobody Knows,'' Gary William Friedman, Will Holt and Robert Livingston, who, respectively, wrote the music and the lyrics and staged that unusual Off Broadway musical 10 years ago, have turned to the other end of the spectrum of life, to people who look in the mirror and find ''not the me I know.'' Their new musical, ''Turns,'' which opened last Tuesday evening at the American Theater of Actors' Chernuchin Theater, 314 West 54th Street, is about the viewpoints and discoveries that come with aging, based on writings by the elderly, just as ''The Me Nobody Knows'' was based on the writings of children. If aging means a diminishing and narrowing of one's life, it is not evident in the contributions of the various anonymous writers whose work Mr. Livingston has adapted as a script for this show.

THE Murderer of Pedralbes'' is a lengthy interview with a convicted killer, and as he tells his story it becomes less and less clear. Jose Luis Cerveto, the subject of this 1978 Spanish documentary, is examined from every conceivable angle during the course of the film, as jurists, neighbors, family friends and doctors try to account for his behavior. Mr. Cerveto explains his actions, too, detailing the most vicious aspects of his crime in a perfectly matterof-fact manner. ''The Murderer of Pedralbes,'' which opens today at the Public Theater, was directed by Gonzalo Herralde, who uses the combination of Mr. Cerveto's polite articulateness and his violent nature as the film's most inescapable irony. Mr. Cerveto speaks in a calm, helpful way as the story of his life unfolds, even as he describes the murder victims as ''the couple that caused me the problem I had.'' He shows the camera a diary and scrapbook, largely devoted to pictures of children, and then describes his history of molesting little boys. He is seen chopping an onion as he speaks of a fondness for machetes. His bloodthirstiness is mentioned repeatedly by the film's other interviewees, but in conversation Mr. Cerveto is almost frighteningly placid.

In some rare situations, the declarer will dispose of it by leading a trump, usually to make sure he can run dummy's suit without interruption. Saturday Night Live,'' the popular late-night program whose original cast of Not Ready for Prime Time Players helped catapult the show to cult status, will return in the fall, but with an entirely new cast and a new producer. Lorne Michaels, founder and producer of the show, decided to quit following long negotiations, at least in part because he could not win guarantees of autonomy he sought from NBC-TV. Mr. Michaels has agreed, instead, to an exclusive one-year deal with NBC to develop shows for prime time and late night.

Two members of the international governing board of the Hare Krishna sect said today that widely publicized incidents linking its members with the stockpiling of weapons had resulted from individual actions, not from policy. One board member, Shrila Acharyadev, whose responsibility is the San Francisco Bay area and Latin America, said Iskcon - the formal name of the Hindu sect is the International Society for Krishna Consciousness - ''has no purpose in keeping any stockpile of weapons or ammunition for any reason.''

The Carter Administration, hoping to avoid any repetition of the Love Canal problem, is planning to create an interagency team to deal with future toxic waste emergencies, Administration officials disclosed today. The plan was generated by the recent uproar that followed the release of a study suggesting that residents of the Love Canal area near Niagara Falls, N.Y., had suffered chromosome damage because of exposure to chemicals dumped by the Hooker Chemical and Plastics Company.

Bjorn Borg and Martina Navratilova, the defending singles champions, were seeded first today for the Wimbledon tennis tournament starting next Monday. Unlike lesser Grand Prix tournaments, Wimbledon does its own seedings and does not strictly follow the Association of Tennis Professionals computer ranking list. John McEnroe was placed at No. 2 and Jimmy Connors at No. 3.

When a defender has the master trump, the time at which he takes it may be of great importance. In some rare situations, the declarer will dispose of it by leading a trump, usually to make sure he can run dummy's suit without interruption. But in general, it is best to keep the winning trump lurking in the wings as long as possible. The right technique in such cases is often to insure that the defender can ruff a loser but not a winner. A good example is the diagramed deal played at the Mill Basin Club, 6177 Strickland Avenue, Brooklyn. Sitting North and South were Branco and Florence Solaric, who bid themselves to a reasonable slam contract against silent opponents.

The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a company accused of conspiring to violate the antitrust laws could force other members of the alleged conspiracy to share the cost of an unfavorable verdict. Whether Federal courts should create what is known as a ''right of contribution among antitrust defendants'' is currently one of the most controversial issues in antitrust law. Federal courts and legal experts are divided both on whether there should be such a right and on its likely consequences for antitrust enforcement.

Both sides in the strike against the Port Authority Trans-Hudson line agreed to accept an invitation by Federal mediators to meet Thursday at the Ramada Inn in East Brunswick, N.J. The meeting was disclosed as an estimated 80,000 PATH commuters continued to use alternative buses and trains with relatively minor delays.

Chris Chambliss drove in five runs with a homer and two singles tonight to lead the Atlanta Braves to a 6-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals. Chambliss, who went four for five, batted in the first Atlanta run with a first-inning single. He increased the Braves' lead to 3-0 in the third inning with another run-scoring single off Bob Forsch (5-5).

Abbott Laboratories, a diversified producer of health-care products, and Takeda Chemical Industries Ltd., the largest pharmaceutical company in Japan, announced a new joint project to develop and market pharmaceutical compounds throughout South America.

On a recent Monday night at the multi-milliondollar Equinox nightclub in the Dekwana quarter of East Beirut, Gloria Gaynor, the queen of disco, was crowning a couple in gold lame jump suits as Miss and Mr. Disco of 1980. At the same time, in the 30-square-block no-man's land of burnedout buildings that used to be the city's commercial center, snipers from some of the more than 20 different factions fighting here were launching the latest thing in hand-weapons - rocket-propelled grenades - at each other. ''If your only weapon is a pistol'' said a member of Al Mourabitoum, the Sunni Moslem militia, ''you're nothing.''

The INA Corporation said that about 814,350 shares, or about 91.4 percent, of the common stock of the Standard Life Insurance Company of Indiana had been tendered in response to its tender offer to acquire all of Standard Life's common stock and that the offer has now expired. INA said that, under the exchange plan, which was approved by the Indiana insurance commissioner and Standard Life's board, all Standard Life shares not duly tendered in the offer would be subject to appraisal rights of dissenting shareholders and be converted into the right to receive $28 a share.

ATLANTIC CITY Favorable casino zoning decisions by city officials have been the key to several fortunes and the background for considerable controversy since voters approved legalized gambling for this faded resort city in November 1976.

GIRDWOOD, Alaska, June 16 The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management has begun to prepare a plan for management of the Iditarod Trail, which runs about 1,500 miles from Seward to Nome and has enough side trails to surpass 2,000 miles over all.
A Queens man who had been convicted of manslaughter and arson was granted a new trial yesterday because the testimony included statements his former girlfriend asserted he made in his sleep.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) House and Senate negotiators formally agreed today on a $20 billion synthetic fuels bill but insisted that President Carter resume filling the strategic petroleum reserve.

Tchaikovsky wrote only three ballets. Yet for decades choreographers have successfuly borrowed his music -his chamber music, suites and tone poems, and even his concertos and symphonies - for new ballets of their own. The New York City Ballet's Sunday programs at the New York State Theater were devoted entirely to ballets by George Balanchine with music by Tchaikovsky. The matinee offered ''Serenade,'' ''Allegro Brillante,'' ''Meditation'' and ''Diamonds'' and the evening's bill, conducted by Hugo Fiorato, included Mr. Balanchine's curious but now rather tired-looking version of ''Swan Lake,'' the ''Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux,'' spectacularly danced by Suzanne Farrell and Peter Martins, and the season's first performances of ''Divertimento from 'Le Baiser de la Fee' '' and ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3.'' One soon realized why choreographers like Tchaikovsky.

West Germany's Hans-Dietrich Genscher has a special status in the foreign ministers' set. He is the only one who heads a party - the coalition partner in Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government - and is not simply an appointee of his leader. That fact gives his views a little extra weight, a little extra leeway. Mr. Genscher had no special grounding in international affairs, but he has been in office six years now, traveled the world, met all the major leaders, and learned prodigiously. Though he usually leaves most of the declaiming to Mr. Schmidt, he has developed firm positions which help to focus West German policy through the clouds of daily debate and diplomacy.

Bea Bower of Pelham shot 79 today and captured the medal in the 77th Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club. Pam Darmstatt of Winged Foot was second with an 80. Mrs. Bower, who won the title in 1966, 1974 and 1976, said: ''I'm not too happy with my round today, but conditions were quite severe. We hope for warmer weather for the rest of the week.'' Temperatures in the 50's and high winds hampered the field of 79 contestants.

By Mel Watkins CHARLIE BOY. By Peter Feibleman. 362 pages. Little, Brown and Co. $12.95. TAKE a psychotic killer, a street-wise black teen-ager and an insistently mundane and moralistic New England doctor. Mix them well in the steamy cauldron of New Orleans's French Quarter, then add the ominous touch of Southern Louisiana's bayou country and the threat of a rapidly approaching hurricane. What sort of fictional concoction are you likely to get? No more, one might justifiably expect, than a sensational, perhaps lurid suspense-thriller. But in the hands of playwright-novelist Peter Feibleman this disparate assemblage has been molded into an arresting tale that provides some striking portraits of both its exotic locale and its somewhat eccentric characters.

Continental Air Lines said yesterday that it would furlough an estimated 1,200 employees, or 10 percent of its entire work force, as a result of a planned cutback of its passenger capacity by 20 percent on Sept. 8. These moves, the carrier said, were intended to align its operations with the ''realities'' of the current recession. Alvin L. Feldman, the new president and chief executive officer of the Los Angeles-based company, stated: ''These actions are prudent responses to the economic situation the nation is facing now and into 1981. They will enable Continental to remain competitive at a time when the entire airline industry is beset with rising operating costs and declining revenues.''

Tim Foli drove in three runs, and Bert Blyleven gained the 150th victory of his career as the Pittsburgh Pirates defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 5-3, tonight. The Reds took a 1-0 lead in the second on doubles by Dan Driessen and Ray Knight. But the Pirates countered with three runs in the bottom of the inning, two unearned, off Frank Pastore (8-3).

The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that new forms of life created in the laboratory are eligible for patents under current patent law. The decision, upholding the award of a patent for a new bacterium that ''digests'' oil spills, opens the way for patent protection for the rapidly burgeoning field of genetic engineering.

475,0The energetic Northeastern states that 150 years ago led our nation into the industrial age are now leading it into the postindustrial age. Despite a clouded recent economic past, and less-thancheerful short-term national and international projections, many factors that contributed to our temporary regional eclipse behind the Sun Belt are emerging as our greatest strengths. How have these onetime liabilities suddenly become assets? The Northeast (New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, the six New England states) was considered even recently too crowded to be of any further economic use - at best, a questionable judgment. We form the core of the largest, most-affluent consumer market in the hemisphere, if not the world. Put the point of a compass at Syracuse, which is not far from our region's center, and draw an arc 750 miles in radius - that is, 24 hours by road, a relatively short distance by interstate-trucking standards. In this area are 54 percent of the population of the United States and Canada and 54 percent of the countries' personal income; 65 percent of the total United States-Canadian manufacturing output in dollar value; 55 percent of all United States wholesale sales.

Terry Crowley's two-run single capped a three-run first inning, and Jim Palmer and Tim Stoddard combined for a six-hitter tonight as the Baltimore Orioles beat the California Angels, 5-2. Ken Singleton drew a two-out walk to launch the first-inning rally against Chris Knapp, who lost his fourth game in five decisions. Singleton moved to second on a single by Eddie Murray and scored on Pat Kelly's double. Crowley singled to score Murray and Kelly. Murray's single stretched his hitting streak to 13 consecutive games.

Q. How well can fish hear sounds in the air above water? A. If whatever is creating the sound is in contact with the water or reverberates into the water, the fish will hear the noise. Water is an excellent conductor of sound and fish possess good hearing. Instead of eardrums, they have an ear formation connected with their swim bladder, an internal air sac somewhat like a lung that vibrates when sound reaches it.

President Aristides Royo has told the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation that the licenses of its two subsidiaries will not be renewed when they expire in April 1981, the company confirmed today. In New York, an I.T.T. spokesman said that the company had received notification from the Panamanian Government. ''We're in the midst of discussions'' about that decision, he said.

Volcker, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve Board, met with Chinese officials today after warning that a serious disturbance of the world economy might be caused by the large trade surpluses of oil-exporting countries. American officials said Mr. Volcker's visit to China was aimed at increasing both countries' understanding of financial and monetary practices. Mr. Volcker arrived in China yesterday.

Bacteria can indeed be engineered and redesigned in the laboratory, and genes can be spliced and manipulated.

Japan's trade deficit in May was $1.84 billion, down from $2 billion the previous month, according to a preliminary report issued today by the Finance Ministry. The country's trade balance has been in deficit since last July, mainly because of rising oil prices. The figures are computed on a customs clearance basis, which adds the costs of insurance and shipping to imports but not to exports.

To the Editor: In the controversy on the merits of Community School Board elections, media reports of the number who went to the polls have varied from 4 percent to 8 percent of eligible voters. The harshest critics of the elections have quoted unnamed Board of Elections officials as stating that only 150,000 persons voted.

THE relationship between education and television has entered a new phase. Originally, educators largely ignored the new medium; then they denounced it and tried to make it go away. Lately, school and television people have been working together in the hope that something constructive can be extracted from all the time children spend in front of their sets. These new efforts do not focus on educational programs specifically designed to supplement instruction in the same way as teaching materials such as textbooks. Instead, they focus on the regular programs - soap operas, situation comedies and dramas - that dominate daily schedules and the viewing time of many children. The most systematic new approach is a special ''curriculum'' just completed by Dorothy and Jerome Singer, co-directors of Yale University's Family Television Research and Consultation Center.

The voices of Richard M. Nixon and his inner sanctum people leaked out from the 32 sets of earphones, making the library buzz and burble metallically like the American summer at Locust Pine. Here is the newest memorial in the city of memorials, the daily playing of the Nixon Watergate tapes to a full house of ordinary American tourists who sit and blink and stare at the folly of humanity in wondrous places.

Cruising along in first place, the Yankees returned to Yankee Stadium last night and promptly registered two more successes: they defeated the Seattle Mariners, 6-3, for Tommy John's ninth victory, and they quelled the latest in their seasonlong series of low-key uprisings. John, the mesmerizing left-hander who has lost only twice, was not as overwhelming as he was 10 days earlier in Seattle, when he shut out the Mariners on two hits. He allowed 10 hits last night before Rich Gossage relieved him in the ninth. One of the runs was unearned, and three double plays helped thwart additional threats.

Brooks & Perkins Inc. said yesterday that it would renew its motion for a temporary restraining order in a United States District Court in Michigan to block the AAR Corporation from buying more of its stock and to try to force AAR to divest the Brooks & Perkins stock it already owns. The announcement followed an earlier statement by AAR that Brooks & Perkins had withdrawn its motion last Friday. AAR holds about 24 percent of Brooks & Perkins outstanding shares.

MONTREAL, June 16 The mood of Montreal's business community has grown increasingly optimistic in the weeks since Quebec voters rejected their provincial government's proposal to seek political independence from Canada.
LOS ANGELES A NEW study by an education professor at the University of California challenges the widespread view that vocational education is a democratic force in American society.

PANAMA, June 16 (AP) President Aristides Royo has told the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation that the licenses of its two subsidiaries will not be renewed when they expire in April 1981, the company confirmed today.

A Federal Trade Commission judge determined today that Litton Industries had falsely advertised that independent service technicians prefer Litton microwave ovens. The advertisements, which said that ''76 percent of the independent microwave oven service technicians surveyed recommended Litton,'' were carried in such magazines as Time and Newsweek and in daily newspapers between 1976 and 1978. John J. Mathias, an administrative law judge, said the surveys cited in the ads were ''fatally defective'' and that Litton ''knew or should have known'' of their flaws. The judge's decision may be appealed to the F.T.C.

Directors of Kraft Inc. and Dart Industries have approved a merger agreement between the companies, spokesmen said today. A holding company, Dart & Kraft Inc., will be formed as a parent to Kraft and Dart, which will remain as separate subsidiaries. Special shareholders meetings will be held in September to vote on the combination. The agreement is subject to approval of the holders of a majority of outstanding shares of Kraft common stock and the holders of a majority of Dart common and preferred stock, with all Dart shares voting together as a single class.

Delta Air Lines announced yesterday that it had been granted exemption authority from the Civil Aeronautics Board to operate nonstop service between Atlanta and Bermuda, a route that currently does not have nonstop service.

Scientists and industry analysts yesterday hailed the Supreme Court's decision that companies can patent life forms as a landmark ruling that will spur the development of the nascent genetic engineering industry. The industry now consists of at least a dozen companies, large and small, that are either working on developments in bioengineering or supporting the work of others. The attempt to move laboratory advances into the commercial arena seems to center on five small privately held concerns.

Returning to action for the first time since winning easily in his debut in Florida four weeks ago, Proud Appeal again showed his speed yesterday in capturing the $56,300 Youthful Stakes at Belmont Park. The 2-year-old son of Valid Appeal won the 67th running of the five-and-a-half furlong contest by beating the slightly-favored Kid Kas by six lengths. Dan Lasater's Lockjaw, a 36-1 shot, was third. The winner, owned by Malcolm H. Winfield and ridden by Jeffrey Fell, returned $10.20 for $2.

An unidentified youth was shot dead by a policeman late last night during a decoy operation in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn by a unit of the senior citizens robbery squad, the police said. The youth, a male between 16 to 20 years old, approached a female police officer posing as an old woman at 45 Parade Place and told her to hand over her purse or he would shoot her with a gun he held in his hand, the police said.

LABLast Friday, Dava Sobel, a science reporter from The New York Times, entered the human chronophysiology laboratory of Montefiore Hospital to begin 25 days as a research subject. She is cut off from the outside world. Only the doctors and technicians in the laboratory can see her. Freed of the constraints of the 24-hour day, her body is expected to establish its own biological day. The following reports is the first of several that Miss Sobel will file from the laboratory using a computer terminal. The dates below show when each section of this dispatch was received. Saturday, June 14 LEAVING my wristwatch behind, as the experiment demands, I am living alone in three small rooms of a laboratory where the boardedup windows and specially trained technicians keep me from knowing whether it is day outside or night.

The laudable intent of Harold Schmeck's article ''Interferon Studies Put Cancer Use in Doubt'' (May 27) was to explain why interferon therapy still cannot be tried in most cancer patients. However, its title implied fresh doubts about interferon's potential efficacy in human cancer. We attempt here to put this potential in proper perspective because it is the public's will and support that will make further progress possible. Preparations of interferon now available for clinical research are highly impure, containing less than one part in a hundred of the active protein. Even these unsatisfactory preparations are still very scarce, so experimental treatment can only be given for very short periods at daily doses, which are almost certainly too low.

President Carter went to the Japanese Embassy today to sign a book of condolences for Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, who died Thursday. ''I express the sorrow and condolences of the people of my nation at the death of a fine statesman,'' Mr. Carter wrote. ''Also as a personal friend, I feel the loss of Prime Minister Ohira.''
A review of Frank Sinatra at Carnegie Hall in The Times yesterday incorrectly listed the closing date of his 12-recital series. The last performance will be Thursday, June 26.

Canadians are wondering whether their American neighbors are fickle and even faithless. A few months ago, Americans in fulsome chorus were saying, Thank you, Canada. But gratitude for the hostage rescue faded quickly, and today, ratification of a vital fisheries agreement is being stalled by key members of the Senate. The irritation to Canadians is all the greater because so few Americans seem to care about a dispute that has aroused widespread indignation in the Canadian press and Parliament. As a wise diplomat has observed, fish cannot read treaties and are shamelessly indifferent to boundaries. That is sometimes also true of fishermen, whose disputes are a common source of diplomatic discord. Some arbitrary trade-offs are essential in any fishing agreement. And most are therefore vulnerable to attack by one or another adversely-affected fleet.

Although final negotiations on New York City's $13.6-billion budget began with thunder and lightning, they ended like a friendly picnic in the sun. Mayor Koch, the Board of Estimate and City Council seem to feel that others listened and tried to be accommodating. Without bursting the Mayor's stringent limit, funds were found to maintain the size of the police patrol force, to provide an extra $41 million for spending on classroom instruction and to aid cultural institutions and libraries. Amiability is a worthy discovery. The next problem is to make the budget stand up to reality. Balancing it will require the passage of taxes to which there will be loud objections, including taxes on beer and liquor, taxi medallions, parking, storage under sidewalks, and coin-operated amusement games, all of which are expected to produce $141 million in annual revenues.

Representative John B. Anderson has dropped one of his major fundraisers in a dispute over campaign tactics, it was disclosed yesterday, hours before the independent Presidential candidate met privately with Governor Carey. No commitments were asked or made, a top Anderson campaign aide said of the Carey-Anderson meeting, but he added that the two were likely to meet again. The Governor has not yet endorsed a Presidential candidate.

The first of Dome Petroleum's four drill ships is expected to enter the ice-choked waters of the Beaufort Sea tomorrow, signaling the resumption of Canada's most expensive hunt for oil. Led by the icebreaker Canadian Kigoriak, which broke out of her winter harbor at McKinley Bay on the remote Tuktoyaktuk Peninsula, the $350 million fleet of Dome's marine arm, Canadian Marine Drilling Ltd. (familiarly known as Canmar), will arrive at its drilling sites in a few days. The elusive prize it seeks is the huge oil reservoir believed to lie below the Arctic waters 4,000 miles north of here.

TRAINING By SHARON JOHNSON LOS ANGELES A NEW study by an education professor at the University of California challenges the widespread view that vocational education is a democratic force in American society.
SAVANNAH, Ga., June 16 (AP) A South Carolina pastor easily won election today as Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in America General Assembly.

PEKING, June 16 (AP) Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the United States Federal Reserve Board, met with Chinese officials today after warning that a serious disturbance of the world economy might be caused by the large trade surpluses of oil-exporting countries.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., June 16 (AP) The Tennessee Valley Authority and state officials today carried out a drill involving an imaginary nuclear accident to test emergency planning for the T.V.A.'s Sequoyah nuclear power plant.

THE Eagles, who drew a capacity crowd of 70,000 fans to Giants Stadium in New Jersey's Meadowlands on Sunday, have changed.
SEOUL, South Korea, Tuesday, June 17 (AP) South Korea's martial law command issued arrest warrants today for 329 persons, including professors ...

JERUSALEM, June 16 A group of Israelis who set up a tent city in Jerusalem to protest Government housing policies have met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin to discuss a remedy for the severe shortage of housing.
WASHINGTON, June 16 Saudi Arabia has asked Washington for missiles, extra fuel tanks and bomb racks for its force of American-built F-15 fighters.
MONTREAL, June 16 Roberto Duran, as happy-looking as a birthday cake, was in a playful mood today, before he nearly wrecked two sparring partners.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A Federal Trade Commission judge determined today that Litton Industries had falsely advertised that independent service technicians prefer Litton microwave ovens.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 16 (UPI) Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh said today that Iran saw no reason for any further United Nations attempt to solve the hostage crisis.

Egypt announced today that it was reimposing martial law in the inhabited regions along its western border, where it fought a brief war with Libya three years ago. The state of emergency, which goes into effect Wednesday, will include the Mediterranean seacoast town of Matruh and the territory running 130 miles westward to the Libyan frontier.
To the Editor: If the Metropolitan Transportation Authority wants to know how to run an efficient urban transit system, let Messrs. Ravitch, Berger, et al. visit Washington.

Is the Budget Committee going to be the all-powerful committee around here?'' Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. asked reporters this morning. Behind the question is the issue of where the power lies in the House in the Congressional budget process: with the chairman of the House Budget Committee or with the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

Roberto Duran, as happy-looking as a birthday cake, was in a playful mood today, before he nearly wrecked two sparring partners. Meanwhile, his opponent in what the beer trucks in town advertise as ''le face a face historique'' admitted he had been a few pounds lighter than he wanted to be for Friday night's World Boxing Council welterweight title fight.

Delta Air Lines announced yesterday that it had been granted exemption authority from the Civil Aeronautics Board to operate nonstop service between Atlanta and Bermuda, a route that currently does not have nonstop service. Delta, which has headquarters in Atlanta, said that the new service would begin as soon as possible after June 30.

GHOTBZADEH SEES NO REASON FOR THE PANEL TO RETURN TEHERAN, Iran, June 16 (UPI) -Foreign Minister Sadegh Ghotbzadeh said today that Iran saw no reason for any further United Nations attempt to solve the hostage crisis. He said the crisis could be solved only through a ''comprehensive settlement of all Iran-United States problems.''

Free parking at work is part of the American way of life. More than eight out of 10 workers commute to their jobs by car, and three out of four park free in spaces provided by their employers. Free parking seems harmless, but at least 25 percent more commuters drive to work alone when they park free than when they pay to park, according to our research for the United States Department of Transportation.

South Korea's martial law command issued arrest warrants today for 329 persons, including professors, students, politicians and reporters. They were charged with a variety of crimes, including corruption and instigating anti-Government disturbances. The command posted a $1,700 reward for 20 of them. It accused them of fomenting the rioting in the provincial city of Kwangju last month.

The New York City Transit Authority believes that man's best friend should also be put to work as his protector against muggers and other criminals on the subway system. Starting later this year, the authority's police department plans to assign about a dozen German shepherds to patrol duty, testing a practice used successfully for the last 15 years on the subways and streets of Philadelphia.

An adventurous Briton waging a decade-long crusade to protect the world's aborigines has brought his campaign to the United States, insisting that only the American Government and people can save 200 million tribal people from extinction.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) The House voted today to authorize up to $80 million for compensation of United States citizens and businesses that suffered economic losses as a result of the Mexican oil spill in the Gulf of Campeche.
TAKE a psychotic killer, a street-wise black teen-ager and an insistently mundane and moralistic New England doc tor.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland said today that President Carter had no plan to lift the ban on shipments of grain to the Soviet Union.

The Wall Street Final, a new afternoon business newspaper, made its debut a few hours late yesterday after being plagued by start-up problems. Because of delayed delivery of equipment, there were no dry runs before the newspaper started publication, Michael Goldstein, the editor, said.

DETROIT, June 16 (AP) The Chrysler Corporation will begin building its new front-wheel-drive compact cars two weeks earlier than planned, Lee A. Iacocca, chairman, said today.

PROVINCETOWN, Mass., June 16 Early on the morning of June 16, 1904, Leopold Bloom, the lapsed Irish Jew who is at the center of James Joyce's dense, enigmatic and lyrical novel "Ulysses," had a pork kidney for breakfast.

AROUND THE NATION; Pryor Develops Pneumonia Associated With Burns

Both houses of the General Assembly voted unanimously today to override Gov. Ella T. Grasso's veto of a bill that gives hospitals greater freedom in using bequests and other contributions. The legislature also overrode vetoes of a bill stiffening license requirements for plumbers and electricians, and a bill that commits the state to an $8.75 million home for the University of Connecticut Law School.

Democratic leaders here have agreed on a bill that would substantially dilute strict prohibitions in earlier legislation designed to keep cabinet officers and other high state officials from taking jobs with casinos after they leave their government posts. While the prohibitions in the earlier legislation would be kept for the Governor, legislators and the judiciary, the restrictions would be lifted for about 200 senior officials - those required to file annual financial disclosure statements.

A proposal for the Federal Government to issue identification cards or work authorization cards to American citizens and legal aliens was criticized today by civil liberties lawyers. Meeting with the staff of the Select Commission on Immigration and Refugee Policy, the lawyers said that there was great potential for abuse in such a system. John H.F. Shattuck, director of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union, said that identification cards would be ''tantamount to a form of domestic passport'' and should be considered only along with a constitutional amendment that set principles for the management of data by the government.

I look at modeling as a profession, not an ego trip,'' Connie Cook explained as Bill Blass draped a checked red and white silk fabric around her body to form a halter top. He had already pinned together a skirt in a striped silk of the same colors, still attached to the bolt. ''I like the back,'' she told the designer, who had twisted the material in a novel way and brought the ends to tie around the neck in the front. ''The back does look good,'' Mr. Blass agreed, continuing his draping. He then drew up a third bolt of fabric in the same colors but a different pattern and threw a piece of it over the model's shoulders to see how it related to the others.

Senator Lawton Chiles and some fellow reformers in Congress simply will not let go of their misguided pursuit of the ''grassroots lobbyist.'' Having usefully made lobbyists accountable for their conduct on Capitol Hill, they insist on pursuing them out among the citizenry to require disclosure of their propaganda tactics, sources of money and hidden hand in organized letter-writing to Congress. We think we understand the problem. Lawmakers' lives have, in fact, been complicated by the growing skill of special interest groups at stirring up the folks back home. But one group's special interest is another's public interest. And while a lobbyist in Congress and his paymasters should be known, their political communication and activities among the public should normally be free and uncontrolled. If Congressmen cannot distinguish between private mail from constituents and an organized barrage of letters from the National Rifle Association or Common Cause, they're probably in the wrong line of work. And if on some new issue they're in doubt, what's wrong with a little concern about the true views of their constituents?

The police opened fire today in racially segregated areas around Johannesburg and Bloemfontein to disperse unruly crowds gathering on the anniversary of the Soweto upheaval of 1976. The police reported no deaths, but at least 35 people were taken to hospitals with shotgun wounds. Among the wounded were 20 people hurt in an incident in a mixed-race area outside Johannesburg, 15 blacks near Bloemfontein, capital of the Orange Free State, and a youth who was hit in the leg in a clash in Soweto, Johannesburg's black satellite city.

In an effort to further diversify its construction activities, the Los Angeles-based Kaufman & Broad Inc. announced yesterday that it planned a tender offer for up to 462,000 shares, or 24.9 percent, of the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association of Miami. Kaufman & Broad said it intended to offer $35 a share, $10 a share more than the Empire Gas Corporation offered for the thrift institution. The boards of Kaufman & Broad and Biscayne Federal Savings will meet tomorrow to consider the offer. Should it be approved, the tender offer would commence Friday.

The Claremont Riding Academy on West 89th Street will be home on the range this week for a half dozen stuntmen and wranglers whose normal milieu is the Hollywood western. Rudy Ugland, Jerry Young and Billy Burton, all top western horsemen, are riding and shooting for Peter Yates's murder mystery, ''Eyewitness,'' set in New York City. Yesterday they continued shooting a scene centered on eight movie stunt horses, which stampede through the four-story stable and out into 89th Street while the actors, Christopher Plummer and Sigourney Weaver, take shots at each other. The filming of the shootout itself, said Judith Silverstein, an assistant at the stable, began last weekend and is being done around 4 A.M. ''to keep down the disruption of the neighborhood.''

The Sony Corporation reported yesterday that its net income in its second fiscal quarter rose more than fourfold, to $70.9 million from $16 million in the corresponding quarter of 1979. Earnings per depository share were 33 cents compared with 7 cents for the similar period last year. Each depository share represents one share of common stock. Sales and operating revenues for the quarter ended April 30 rose 48.5 percent, to $999.1 million from $672.6 million.

The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved the nomination of Gen. David C. Jones for a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff after he testified that his office must remain apart from the political tradition that calls on officials to resign when an Administration changes. To make the term of his office run concurrently with that of a President, General Jones said, would be to make the nation's senior military officer a political appointee. ''I cannot conceive of a circumstance under which I would submit my resignation on the change of Administrations,'' he said.

President Carter has sent a strongly worded message to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany cautioning him against suggesting an East-West freeze on the deployment of mediumrange nuclear missiles in Western Europe when he meets with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, in Moscow at the end of the month. The letter, delivered late last week, was divulged by the Hamburg magazine Stern today and confirmed here and in Bonn. American officials said that it was not fair to describe the letter as a ''warning,'' as Stern did, but that it was ''strongly written.'' It was the latest example of the continual friction between Mr. Carter and Mr. Schmidt, even though the West Germans have supported the United States on most key issues.

To the Editor: Ever alert, the Treasury Department has ordered the makers of beer, wine and liquor to list on the label all food coloring or other ingredients that might cause allergic reactions or have an ill effect on health generally. Ig-n@ored are the much more serious potentials of the alcohol involved.

Terry Puhl drew a bases-loaded walk to force in one run in the seventh inning, and Jeff Leonard, a pinchrunner, scored on a wild pitch today to give the Houston Astros a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Willie Hernandez (1-5) had retired 13 batters in a row and had gotten two out in the seventh when Alan Ashby singled for the Astros, who lead the Western Division of the National League. Bruce Bochy, a pinch-hitter, walked, and Bill Caudill came on in relief. Caudill then walked both Rafael Landestoy, a pinch-hitter, and Puhl to force in the tying run. Doug Capilla relieved Caudill and threw the wild pitch that allowed Leonard to score.
In football circles, the month of June belongs to the punters and therefore to Doc Storey, their guru.
Stocks managed to hold onto a slim gain yesterday as institutional activity offset profit-taking by individuals early in the trading session.

CHICAGO, June 16 (UPI) The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that its International Monetary Market division will open its foreign exchange market 45 minutes earlier and its 90day Treasury bill market 10 minutes ...

Early in yesterday's Women's Basketball League draft, one of the owners of the Dallas Diamonds congratulated Dean Meminger on the wheeling and dealing that had provided the New York Stars with six selections in the first three rounds.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) President Carter today proclaimed July 21 as Veterans Administration Day, celebrating the agency's 50th anniversary. "Our system of assistance and care for veterans is the most comprehensive in the world," he said in a proclamation.

Continental Air Lines said yesterday that it would furlough an estimated 1,200 employees, or 10 percent of its entire work force, as a result of a planned cutback of its passenger capacity by 20 percent on Sept. 8.
The recession has begun to affect the college job market. The class of 1980 was heavily recruited last fall and winter, but a report issued yesterday by the College Placement ...
PARIS, June 16 (AP) Libya, which supplies 3 percent of the United States' oil needs, may decide to raise oil prices "within a few weeks," the country's oil minister was quoted as saying today.
WATERLOO, Iowa, June 16 Stockholders of the Rath Packing Company of Waterloo voted today to give controlling interest of the financially troubled company to its employees.

Scientists and industry analysts yesterday hailed the Supreme Court's decision that companies can patent life forms as a landmark ruling that will spur the development of the nascent genetic engineering industry.

Stevens Company, the textile producer that has become a symbol of corporate resistance to union pressure, again demonstrates that for many Christians in the United States, Caesar and God are indivisible.
