REPLACE EAST SIDER By MAURICE CARROLL

After a bitter contest between Governor Carey and the Senate's Republican majority leader, Warren Anderson, the New York Legislature has recessed to leave both claiming something of a moral victory. The Governor held to a relatively austere budget as the legislators approach an election campaign. Mr. Anderson forced the Governor to break his promise to hold New York's transit fare at 50 cents. The transportation subsidy plan that was hitched to a tax on oil company profits may not survive the inevitable court tests. If the courts deny the stipulation that the tax not be passed to consumers, Mr. Carey would need a much larger fare increase than the indicated 10 cents or a new tax subsidy for which Mr. Anderson would exact a stiff price.

The Mets left their rallying powers at home tonight as they opened a 15-game road trip with a 3-2 loss to the Padres in San Diego Stadium. With seven of their last eight victories achieved with late-inning opportunism, the Mets again attempted the spectacular in their final turn at bat. They came up with a single and a double in the ninth inning, but they were done in by the third Padre double play of the game, the twin killing coming between the two hits.

The Interior Department's Bureau of Land Management has begun to prepare a plan for management of the Iditarod Trail, which runs about 1,500 miles from Seward to Nome and has enough side trails to surpass 2,000 miles over all. The plan is a step in a Congressional program to add Iditarod and three other historic trails to three existing national scenic trails under an overall designation of national historic and scenic trails.

The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that farmers in California's Imperial Valley are entitled to federally subsidized irrigation water regardless of the size of their farms. The opinion marks the end of 13 years of litigation over water rights in the valley, where federally subsidized irrigation has transformed a near-desert into one of the country's richest agricultural areas.

Marcia Webb Huhn, who for many years was active in raising funds for the West Side Day Nursery in Manhattan, died yesterday at the Westerly (R.I.) Hospital. She was 69 years old and lived in Stonington, Conn. She and her husband, the late George A. Huhn, who was an official of Ted Bates Inc., the advertising agency, had been longtime residents of Manhattan. Surviving Mrs. Huhn are her daughter, Marcia Lane of Greenwich, Conn., and three grandsons.

A group of Israelis who set up a tent city in Jerusalem to protest Government housing policies have met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin to discuss a remedy for the severe shortage of housing. ''We want Jerusalem to be ours,'' said Shlomo Dadon, a spokesman for the squatters in an interview last week shortly after they had pitched tents on Government-owned land within Jerusalem's pre-1967 municipal lines.

''THE Murderer of Pedralbes'' is a lengthy interview with a convicted killer, and as he tells his story it becomes less and less clear. Jose Luis Cerveto, the subject of this 1978 Spanish documentary, is examined from every conceivable angle during the course of the film, as jurists, neighbors, family friends and doctors try to account for his behavior. Mr. Cerveto explains his actions, too, detailing the most vicious aspects of his crime in a perfectly matterof-fact manner. ''The Murderer of Pedralbes,'' which opens today at the Public Theater, was directed by Gonzalo Herralde, who uses the combination of Mr. Cerveto's polite articulateness and his violent nature as the film's most inescapable irony. Mr. Cerveto speaks in a calm, helpful way as the story of his life unfolds, even as he describes the murder victims as ''the couple that caused me the problem I had.'' He shows the camera a diary and scrapbook, largely devoted to pictures of children, and then describes his history of molesting little boys. He is seen chopping an onion as he speaks of a fondness for machetes. His bloodthirstiness is mentioned repeatedly by the film's other interviewees, but in conversation Mr. Cerveto is almost frighteningly placid.

National headlines proclaim that taxpayer revolts threatens schools. Yes, my school. When I came to my school six years ago, its staff could justifiably brag about the level of college acceptances (high), the class load (small enough to allow for some individual attention), and community support. The budget had never been rejected. The principal prided himself on the no-frills building and lean administrative staff.

The Tennessee Valley Authority and state officials today carried out a drill involving an imaginary nuclear accident to test emergency planning for the T.V.A.'s Sequoyah nuclear power plant. The exercise was carried out in cooperation with Federal regulatory agencies that are reviewing Tennessee's plan for coping with an emergency at the plant. The make-believe accident assumed that a tornado struck the plant, resulting in the escape of radioactive steam.

WASHINGTON THE widespread use of low doses of human antibiotics as additives in animal feed may be diminishing the value of ''miracle drugs'' in the treatment of humans. That is the growing suspicion based on considerable but inconclusive evidence of doctors who have long wondered why they have had to administer ever larger doses of antibiotics to combat bacterial infections in their patients. Part of the answer may be that the doctors themselves have so overused drugs like penicillin and tetracycline that the bacteria have learned to fight back, so to speak, by becoming resistant.

A defense attorney, Leon Taylor, told a Federal court jury today that evidence in the trial of Norm Ellenberger will show that the former University of New Mexico basketball coach did not intend to defraud anyone. Ellenberger's trial on five counts of mail fraud, one count of wire fraud and one count of interstate travel in aid of racketeering began today with the selection of the jury and opening statements by attorneys.
Ramsey Clark said yesterday that he would initiate an inquiry into United States involvement in Iran if Congress refused to open one of its own.
A decision on whether to go on strike against the Consolidated Edison Company was scheduled for 4 P.M. today instead of 12:01 A.M. tomorrow by leaders of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union.

Joseph E. Cadden, president of the Day Care Council of New York and the Hamilton-Madison Settlement House on the Lower East Side, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton.

BONN, June 16 West Germany's Hans-Dietrich Genscher has a special status in the foreign ministers' set. He is the only one who heads a party the coalition partner in Chancellor Helmut Schmidt's Government and is not simply an appointee of his leader. That fact gives his views a little extra weight, a little extra leeway.

WALNUT, Calif., June 16 The five former American professional track and field athletes who were reinstated for amateur competition have been barred from the United States Olympic trials, which begin Saturday in Eugene, Ore.

The Government said today that a special security committee dominated by army generals assumed effective control of the Government on May 27 in order to speed up the transition to democracy, not to hold power indefinitely. The Government did not directly respond to, or even acknowledge, assertions last week by its major ally, the United States, that Lieut. Gen. Chon Too Hwan was bent on assuming power himself or putting a man in power whom he could control. Instead, it referred to ''groundless apprehensions'' by some South Koreans and foreign correspondents that ''a de facto military government went into effect with the special committee.''

Fireman Thomas Gerondel fell five stories but escaped serious injury when a stairway collapsed as he was battling a suspicious fire in a vacant South Bronx tenement. At the second floor, Mr. Gerondel, 33 years old of Pearl River, N.Y., glanced off Fire Capt. Anthony Alva of Garnerville, N.Y. Fireman Gerondel suffered a head cut, several broken fingers and bruises over most of his body, according to a Fire Department spokesman. Captain Alva was shaken up and went on medical leave, the spokesman said. Judge Leff Ignores A Court Transfer

Joseph E. Cadden, president of the Day Care Council of New York and the Hamilton-Madison Settlement House on the Lower East Side, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in East Hampton, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton. After graduating from Brown University in 1931, Mr. Cadden became secretary of the National Student Federation of America and editor of its publication, The National Student Mirror. He also served as executive secretary of the International Student Service, which helped students and professionals to flee Nazi Germany.

A crack in the wall of the Church of Santa Maria delle Grazie in Milan containing Leonardo da Vinci's 481-year-old ''Last Supper'' is posing a new threat to the much damaged masterpiece. The crack, about six feet long and the width of a finger, was detected a few days ago when electronic devices monitoring the wall's stability signaled a change in the structure. Experts in Milan said the crack had begun inside the wall on which the ''Last Supper'' is painted but had widened so that it is now visible on the surface of the famous work.

Three out of every five Philippine children between the ages of 2 and 13 are malnourished, according to a Government report published today. The report said parents who were ignorant of proper nutrition and ''economically restrained'' from buying nutritious food are the main reasons why many youngsters are not properly fed.

To the Editor: The eloquent and thoughtful speech of former Secretary Vance at Harvard University on June 5 should enable your readers to pinpoint the central failure of the Carter-Vance foreign policy. It is a good thing for the nation that Mr. Vance resigned, despite the respect he has rightfully earned for his honorable and dedicated service.

The leader of the opposition Democratic Socialist Party called today for ''a grand national coalition government'' to govern Japan after Sunday's parliamentary elections. Ryosaku Sasaki, who was campaigning in Fukui, 200 miles west of here, said the coalition should bridge the division between conservatives and progressives that has existed since World War II.

A decision on whether to go on strike against the Consolidated Edison Company was scheduled for 4 P.M. today instead of 12:01 A.M. tomorrow by leaders of Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union. Jim Joy Jr., business manager of the local, said negotiations would be broken off if no agreement was reached by 4 P.M. and there would be no way of preventing the walkout that would follow at midnight. Union leaders changed the deadline for making their decision so they would have time to set up picket lines and make other strike arrangements at 167 power plants and office sites of the company, Mr. Joy said.

Ronald Reagan has canceled plans for a trip to Europe after the Republican National Convention in July, according to a campaign source. The trip was intended to bolster Mr. Reagan's foreign policy credentials after he receives the Presidential nomination and would have included visits to West Germany, England, France and Belgium. But, the source said, it was canceled in favor of ''getting on with the business of getting elected here.''

In his first outing on the operatic stage, Joseph Losey, the film director, has given the Paris Opera a compact, cinematic and controversial ''Boris Godunov'' that opts for intimacy rather than grandiosity. By stripping ''Boris'' of its traditional pomp and ceremony, Mr. Losey has revealed a solitary character of Shakespearean stature and vulnerability. By such unfamiliar measures as placing the orchestra onstage, depicting the Russian people as a faceless, albeit downtrodden, mob and depriving Boris of his furs, crown and beard, Mr. Losey displeased some of the formally clad first-nighters and the more conservative critics.

Jim Sundberg drove in Pepe Frias with the decisive run tonight as the Texas Rangers put together eight singles in the ninth inning to erase a 3-0 deficit and defeat the Kansas City Royals, 6-3. Held scoreless and limited to four hits by Paul Splittorff and Dan Quisenberry (4-3) through eight innings, the Rangers began their rally with a leadoff single by Pat Putnam. One out later, Bump Wills singled and, with two out, Richie Zisk singled Putnam home with the first Texas run.

When New York City decided to charge private schools for city water and sewer services, parents organized demonstrations, priests voted protest resolutions, nuns wrote letters to the Mayor, and rabbis lobbied in Albany. Yesterday all these groups were quietly but proudly sharing the news that, together, they had fought city hall, and won. The fight began in the city's neighborhoods and was carried all the way to Albany. There, in the closing hours of the legislative session Saturday, lawmakers in both houses passed a compromise bill that will restore most of the exemptions from the water and sewer charges for small private schools, exemptions that the city had canceled.

King Khalid of Saudi Arabia arrived in Bonn for a four-day state visit and talks on a wide range of political and economic problems, including the possibility of a Middle East settlement, improving economic ties between the countries, oil supplies and recycling surplus oil funds. The 67-year-old King reviewed an honor guard this morning in front of the Palais Schaumburg, the residence of the West German President, Karl Carstens, with whom the King conferred later this afternoon. King Khalid will be guest of honor at a state banquet this evening at the Augustusburg Palace in Bruhl, near Bonn.

One way of investigating how the brain controls body function is to insert electrodes through the skull of an animal into various parts of its brain, apply electricity and observe the results. As a rule it is impractical to do this with human beings, which are the only animals capable of giving an experimenter a detailed description of what they are feeling. Two British scientists have reported in the journal Nature, however, that useful experiments can be carried out on living human brains without penetrating the skull. P.A. Merton and H.B. Norton of the National Hospital, London, said they have succeeded in sending electrical messages to the human cerebral cortex directly through the scalp and skull without penetrating the head mechanically. To overcome skull resistance, high voltages were used in the tiny shocks.

ALBANY, June 16 The 1980 session of the New York State Legislature left the impression that New York State is trading its image of pioneering in social change and expensive government programs for one of caution, if not retrenchment.
"I look at modeling as a profession, not an ego trip," Connie Cook explained as Bill Blass draped a checked red and white silk fabric around her body to form a halter top.

WASHINGTON, June 12 The voices of Richard M. Nixon and his inner sanctum people leaked out from the 32 sets of earphones, making the library buzz and burble metallically like the American summer at Locust Pine.

ALBANY, June 16 The 1980 session of the New York State Legislature left the impression that New York State is trading its image of pioneering in social change and expensive government programs for one of caution, if not retrenchment.

She's lost all sense of time now,'' Dr. Elliot D. Weitzman said yesterday after visiting Dava Sobel in the three-room apartment where she will live until July 7, cutoff from the outside world. Miss Sobel entered the apartment last Friday at 9 A.M. That night, at about midnight, she was told to go to sleep. She was awakened at 7 the next morning. This cycle -retiring at midnight and awakening at 7 A.M. - will continue through today. These hours were established after Miss Sobel kept logs of her normal sleep cycle for several weeks.
SUB**SUB** By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

Phil Weld of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., extended his lead today in the 3,000-mile trans-Atlantic singlehanded yacht race to Newport, R.I. He had opened a 100-mile gap on Eugene Riguidel of France and was more than 200 miles ahead of Oliver de Kersauson, also of France, who was in third place.

The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and Ecopetrol, the Colombian state oil company, said they had signed contracts of association covering five blocks, or about 12.3 million acres, in the Llanos area of eastern Colombia. Occidental of Colombia Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Occidental Petroleum, will drill four test wells in each block during the first year and must relinquish one-half of each block at the end of the first year.

Rick Manning's two-run single in the seventh inning broke a 3-3 tie and gave the Cleveland Indians a 5-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight. Manning's hit came off Mike Proly, the third Chicago pitcher of the inning. The Chicago starter, Ross Baumgarten, gave up a walk and Ed Farmer (5-1) came on and issued two more walks. Cliff Johnson's infield hit tied the game at 3-3, and Manning greeted Proly with his bases-loaded single.

TV WITH A BITE How did CBS News ''tear down the curtain of TV's wishy-washy coverage of Washington and assert its independence of governmental manipulation of the news''? Jack Gould, The New York Times television critic, said CBS accomplished this by its Feb. 23, 1971, broadcast, ''The Selling of the Pentagon.'' He called this documentary ''a devastating expose of the Pentagon's massive propaganda efforts on the home front to nurture the military complex.''
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; Pakistanis Accuse Russians Of Border Overflights

An ''alarming'' 21.8 percent, or 9,770, of the ninth-grade students in Connecticut have failed a minimumproficiency test in mathematics, the Commissioner of Education announced today. He said the results would require a new emphasis on the subject in the state's elementary and middle schools. The Commissioner, Mark R. Shedd, said that while the situation ''parallels test results around the country,'' it was ''very serious, very critical.'' He said the gap between the math results and those in reading and writing proficiency was far greater than had been anticipated, in the testing last March of 44,830 students.

IN simpler times, Gabe Paul would have mobilized the forces of truth, justice, the printing press and hometown jingoism into making this a better world for Jorge Orta of the Cleveland Indians. In that Eisenhower year of 1957, Paul, then the general manager in Cincinnati, connived to have seven Redlegs elected to the all-star team.
"I look at modeling as a profession, not an ego trip," Connie Cook explained as Bill Blass draped a checked red and white silk fabric around her body to form a halter top.

The 1980 session of the New York State Legislature left the impression that New York State is trading its image of pioneering in social change and expensive government programs for one of caution, if not retrenchment. Abruptly shaking off the lethargy of its first five months, the 203d New York State Legislature, which closed in the predawn hgours yesterday, managed to compile an impressive list of accomplishments -particularly impressive since virtually all took place in the last two weeks, and many in the last few hours.

Merrythought, Jack King's 46-foot sloop from Annapolis, Md., won the Astor Trophy race today as yachts congregated here by the dozens in advance of the start on Friday of the ocean race to Bermuda, an event held every two years. Merrythought's prize came for establishing the best corrected time in a fleet of 73 yachts that raced 175 miles from Oyster Bay, L.I., to Newport, by way of the Buzzards Bay tower and Block Island.

The New England Tea Men handed the Cosmos their second straight defeat, 2-1, in overtime tonight. Afterward, Hennes Weisweiler, who led the team to eight straight North American Soccer League victories before the latest setbacks, said he could not remember the last time a team he had coached had lost two games in a row. ''It's a good mentality that I don't remember, isn't it?'' Weisweiler said. A crowd of 28,356 watched the Tea Men improve their won-lost record to 6-10. The crowd was larger than the total number of fans who had attended New England's previous six home games. Until tonight, the Tea Men had averaged 3,857 fans.

The 39th annual Madrid Book Fair got off to an unusual start this month. As 269 makeshift bookstands raised their shutters in the tranquil setting of the Retiro, a park, policemen arrived looking for a book. They passed up Spanish translations of William Burroughs, Henry Miller and other authors whose works were banned under the Franco regime. They searched high and low for a small volume called ''The Red School Book,'' published in Denmark in 1968.

The recession has begun to affect the college job market. The class of 1980 was heavily recruited last fall and winter, but a report issued yesterday by the College Placement Council said companies cut back sharply in the spring. As a result, the total number of job offers for the academic year increased 8 percent from the last academic year as against the 13 percent increase that employers had predicted last fall.

IN 1,200 years, if the present trend continues, Earth's magnetic poles should do a flip-flop, and all those compass needles that normally point north will then be pointing south. For several years, scientists studying Earth through spacecraft observations have noted an apparently slight, steady decline in the intensity of the magnetic field. They postulate that this could be the early sign of an approaching magnetic reversal, which happens at intervals of 50,000 to 1 million years. The last well-documented reversal occurred 700,000 years ago. New data confirming this trend of declining magnetic intensity have now been gathered by the first American spacecraft expressly designed to study Earth's magnetic properties.

Nothing but big money for radic-lib candidates,'' said the notation next to Stewart Mott's name when it turned up on the socalled enemies list of the Nixon White House. And in fact that has become Mr. Mott's political persona, nearly as well-known as the vast vegetable garden he has cultivated atop his East Side quadriplex penthouse and the $2 million that is said to be his yearly income.
THE metric system conversion campaign of the 1970's seems to have lost some of its early crusading fervor.

CHICAGO, June 16 (UPI) The RCA Corporation expects to produce and sell more than 200,000 videodisk players and about 2 million disks by the end of 1981, Roy H. Pollack, executive vice president, said today at the International Consumer Electronics Show here.
WASHINGTON, June 16 President Carter has sent a strongly worded message to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany cautioning him against suggesting an East-West freeze on the deployment ...

WASHINGTON, June 16 The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a company accused of conspiring to violate the antitrust laws could force other members of the alleged conspiracy to share the cost of an unfavorable verdict.

THE metric system conversion campaign of the 1970's seems to have lost some of its early crusading fervor. This is a relief for those of us who felt guilty enough lusting after junk food without the added fear of stymying civilization by buying it in nonmetric containers. A more relaxed transition to an unaccustomed measurement system has been welcomed by a good many scientists, as well as most of the rest of us.

Ramsey Clark said yesterday that he would initiate an inquiry into United States involvement in Iran if Congress refused to open one of its own. Mr. Clark, who was Attorney General under President Lyndon B. Johnson, returned to the United States Sunday after a trip to Teheran during which he participated in an Iranian-sponsored conference on alleged United States intervention during the reign of the deposed Shah, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi.

Since the mid-1960's, Japanese politics have been dominated by one set of conservative leaders of the ruling Liberal Democratic Party, and the roster of these men has barely changed in 15 years. But in recent months a new generation of younger conservative politicians has begun to emerge, the old faces have started to give way and the stage is set for the appearance of a new group of Liberal Democratic leaders to head the party in the 80's.

The House voted today to authorize up to $80 million for compensation of United States citizens and businesses that suffered economic losses as a result of the Mexican oil spill in the Gulf of Campeche. The spill began June 3, 1979, when an offshore oil rig blew out and caught fire. It was not contained until almost 10 months later, after 140 million gallons of oil leaked into the waters of the Gulf of Mexico.

THE Eagles, who drew a capacity crowd of 70,000 fans to Giants Stadium in New Jersey's Meadowlands on Sunday, have changed. They were the most commercially successful American rock band of the 70's, and to many listeners they have always epitomized laid-back California country-rock. The last time they performed in this area, which was more than three years ago, they were laid-back. At the Madison Square Garden show this reviewer saw, they strung together ballads and medium-tempo harmony numbers for what seemed like an eternity; the proceedings grew spirited only when their newest member, Joe Walsh, was taking one of his barnstorming guitar solos. At the time, Mr. Walsh hadn't yet been effectively integrated into the lineup, and one wondered how the addition of this extroverted musician, who seemed so different from the other Eagles, would affect the band's approach. On records, the change has been one of degree rather than kind; the group rocks more, but the music is still carefully crafted and polished to a high gloss. On stage at Giants Stadium, the Eagles were a different band. They projected a steady, powerful intensity, and they projected it as a unit.

Ilie Nastase, frequently abusive and occasionally brilliant, carried Rumania past Britain today and into the final of the European Zone B Davis Cup tennis championship. Nastase defeated John Feaver of Britain in a singles match that had been suspended last night because of rain, 7-5, 8-6, 2-6, 2-6, 6-4. The victory gave Rumania the series, three matches to two.

The five former American professional track and field athletes who were reinstated for amateur competition have been barred from the United States Olympic trials, which begin Saturday in Eugene, Ore. They filed an appeal today, with The Athletics Congress, the sport's governing body in the United States, but their chances to compete in the trials appeared slim. The athletes are Brian Oldfield, who won the national outdoor shotput title yesterday at The Athletics Congress meet; Rod Milburn and Lance Babb, high hurdlers, and John Smith and Warren Edmonson, 400-meter runners. Milburn was a 1972 Olympic champion, and he and Smith are former world-record holders. Smith and Oldfield also were 1972 Olympians.

A small Illinois bank, in the town where the Chrysler Corporation makes some of its most popular cars, is among a handful of banks threatening to unravel Chrysler's plans for Federal loan guarantees that the auto company needs to survive. The Illinois troublemaker, from Chrysler's point of view, is David W. Knapp, a 44-year-old native of Vinton, Iowa, who is president of the American National Bank and Trust Company in Rockford, the 579thlargest bank in the nation, but more importantly one that could block $1.5 billion in Federal loan guarantees for Chrysler.

Early on the morning of June 16, 1904, Leopold Bloom, the lapsed Irish Jew who is at the center of James Joyce's dense, enigmatic and lyrical novel ''Ulysses,'' had a pork kidney for breakfast. Restaurateurs in this resort village on the eastern tip of Cape Cod were willing to reproduce that meal today for some of the 250 Joycean scholars who came here last Thursday for the first major American symposium on the dark, labyrinthian word puzzles the author created in his novels.

Saudi Arabia has asked Washington for missiles, extra fuel tanks and bomb racks for its force of Americanbuilt F-15 fighters, confronting the Carter Administration with a foreign policy quandary, Government officials said today. Two years ago, seeking to win Congressional support for providing Saudi Arabia with the F-15's, the Administration had said that the planes would not be equipped for military roles that could endanger Israel.

PLANT biologists are becoming increasingly concerned over the fewer varieties of food-crop seed that are available for both agricultural research and crop production. They fear that a diminishing gene pool would make it difficult to find an old genetic variety, or breed a new one, that could be used if the modern seed strains should prove vulnerable to sudden and unforeseen diseases or climatic changes. The slow erosion of the genetic diversity of food crops in recent years has been due mainly to the emphasis on planting only those seed varieties that will produce the most food for a growing world population.

The Supreme Court gave added protection today to defendants in criminal cases in a decision that placed new limits on the use of undercover tactics by the police. The Court ruled, 6 to 3, that Federal agents had violated a robbery suspect's constitutional right to the assistance of counsel by instructing a paid informer who shared the man's cellblock to report back on any incriminating statements the man made.

After he helped the United States Olympic team to a 97-84 victory over a National Basketball Association all-star squad at the Forum here tonight, Mark Aguirre of DePaul said, ''I like this type of basketball.'' ''I would love to play the Russians anyplace, anywhere, anytime,'' he went on, ''in a playground, in Red Square. I'd even let them call the shots.''
An unidentified youth was shot dead by a policeman late last night during a decoy operation in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn by a unit of the senior citizens robbery squad, the police said.

WASHINGTON, June 16 Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court majority opinion today by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and from the dissenting opinion by Associate Justice William J. Brennan Jr. in the case of Diamond v. Chakrabarty in which the Court held on a 5-to-4 vote that man-made life forms may be patented.
Following is a list of delegates to the World Conference of the United Nations Decade for Women, 1980:
JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 16 (AP) A bus caught fire yesterday after sliding off the side of a road near Sukabumi on Java and 21 people were killed, the newspaper Sinar Harapan said here today.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 16 The Government said today that a special security committee dominated by army generals assumed effective control of the Government on May 27 in order to speed ...

WASHINGTON, June 16 The Senate Armed Services Committee today approved the nomination of Gen. David C. Jones for a second term as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff after he testified that his office must remain apart from the political tradition that calls on officials to resign when an Administration changes.

Favorable casino zoning decisions by city officials have been the key to several fortunes and the background for considerable controversy since voters approved legalized gambling for this faded resort city in November 1976. An illustration is the case of Edgar E. Sims Jr., one of the city's busiest real estate speculators, who bought 15 acres of city land near the marina for $37,600 in 1975 and, after it was rezoned for casino development, ended up with an agreement to sell it for $20 million. But the zoning decision prompted a series of local objections and legal appeals, and last week a state judge overturned the variance, leaving the status of Mr. Sims's sales agreement unclear.

Half a century after the Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act was signed into law in a vain effort to protect domestic industry and jobs, the United States is again at a turning point in trade relations with its commercial partners. There are disturbing parallels between the situation today and on June 17, 1930, when President Herbert Hoover signed the legislation that touched off the biggest tariff increase since the founding of the nation. At both points, economic activity was falling, and major domestic industries petitioned for relief against imports.

Confrontations involving the Ku Klux Klan, the American Nazi Party, the Communist Workers Party and this city's law-enforcement officials continued here today as murder and rioting trials resulting from a ''Death to the Klan'' rally last year got under way.
A bus caught fire yesterday after sliding off the side of a road near Sukabumi on Java and 21 people were killed, the newspaper Sinar Harapan said here today.

New York City improved its offer yesterday to a 200,000-member coalition of municipal unions, proposing a two-year contract with increases of 6 percent in the first year and 5 percent in the second. Speaking for the coalition, Harold Melnick, president of the Sergeants Benevolent Association, said the proposal was unacceptable. But he added that the unions had reduced their demands -from 13 percent each year to 12 percent -in an effort to keep bargaining moving.

Mickey Klutts had three doubles and drove in two runs, and Dave Revering knocked in two runs tonight as the Oakland A's downed the Boston Red Sox, 11-8. The loss snapped the Red Sox' six-game winning streak. Oakland scored three runs in the first inning off Chuck Rainey (7-2) on consecutive triples by Rickey Henderson and Dwayne Murphy, a wild pitch and a run-scoring single by Mitchell Paige. The A's added two runs in the fourth on consecutive two-out singles by Murphy, Revering, Wayne Gross and Tony Armas.

Early in yesterday's Women's Basketball League draft, one of the owners of the Dallas Diamonds congratulated Dean Meminger on the wheeling and dealing that had provided the New York Stars with six selections in the first three rounds. ''I'll tell you,'' replied Meminger, the coach of the W.B.L. champions, ''you have the one I want.'' With their No. 1 pick in the 10-round draft, the Diamonds selected Old Dominion's Nancy Lieberman, surely the most famous and perhaps the most talented player to be drafted since the struggling league's inception in 1978. The Stars, reluctant to trade up and pay the $100,000 a year that Miss Lieberman is seeking, took another Old Dominion player, 5-foot-10-inch Chris Critelli, with the last selection of the first round.

Affected by the deepening recession, the nation's factories operated last month at only 78.9 percent of capacity, the lowest level since February 1976 and 2 percentage points below April's mark, the Federal Reserve reported today. The Federal Reserve said that the capacity rate had dropped nearly eight percentage points from 1979's first quarter, when the economy was still expanding.

A South Carolina pastor easily won election today as Moderator of the Presbyterian Church in America General Assembly. The Rev. Paul G. Settle, pastor of Second Presbyterian Church of Greenville, S.C., defeated four other nominees as the denomination's national governing body opened its five-day meeting.

MARKET To the Editor: A recent letter from North Dakota State Tax Commissioner Byron Dorgan defending exorbitant coal severance taxes deserves a reply. Texas, a coal-consuming state, has led the way to the conversion of industry and utilities from natural gas to coal as a boiler fuel to generate electricity. This conversion has since been mandated nationally by the Powerplant and Industrial Fuel Act of 1978. In the past, Texas utilities were induced to use Northwestern coal and to commit themselves to long-term contracts for buying that coal by low severance taxes and low freight rates for hauling the coal.

John Hun, a Conservative member of Parliament, called today for an end to the rule forbidding visitors from taking notes in the House of Commons. ''I have often watched some poor innocent member of the public who has the temerity to take out a pencil and a piece of paper being pounced upon by an attendant,'' he said. Journalists in the press gallery are allowed to take notes and an official record of proceedings is made by stenographers.
The Court has assured this country's technology future.''- Genentech Inc. (A1:6.) *

They are young and old, rich and poor, male and female, members of a range of racial and ethnic groups. They live in big cities, in small towns and on farms. They are career diplomats, community volunteers, professional and blue-collar workers. Separately, they have worked for a variety of women's causes, from equality in education and employment to the rights of lesbians and displaced homemakers. Together they comprise the 37-member United States Delegation to the World Conference of the United Nations Decade for Women, 1980, which convenes next month in Copenhagen.

UPI) - Martina Navratilova and Tracy Austin, seeded Nos. 1 and 2 at Wimbledon next week, posted first-round victories today in a $125,000 grass tuneup tournament. Miss Navratilova beat Bettyann Dent, 6-2, 6-3, and then forecast that she had a good chance of entering the record books with her third straight Wimbledon title.

Libya, which supplies 3 percent of the United States' oil needs, may decide to raise oil prices ''within a few weeks,'' the country's oil minister was quoted as saying today. Arab Oil and Gas, the French trade publication, also quoted the Libyan oil minister, Abdesselam Zagaar, as saying that the $37-abarrel price ceiling decided upon last week by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries at a meeting in Algiers ''should be much higher.''
Stocks managed to hold onto a slim gain yesterday as institutional activity offset profit-taking by individuals early in the trading session.
Ad Hoc Committee on World Disar- mament Conference - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. Decolonization Committee's subcom- mittee on small territories - 10:30 A.M.
"No person shall smoke or carry an open flame or a lighted match, cigar, cigarette or pipe in or on a public transportation facility." New York City Health Code.

After a bitter contest between Governor Carey and the Senate's Republican majority leader, Warren Anderson, the New York Legislature has recessed to leave both claiming something of a moral victory. The Governor held to a relatively austere budget as the legislators approach an election campaign. Mr. Anderson forced the Governor to break his promise to hold New York's transit fare at 50 cents.

TCHAIKOVSKY wrote only three ballets. Yet for decades choreographers have successfuly borrowed his music his chamber music, suites and tone poems, and even his concertos and symphonies for new ballets of their own.

Steel production totaled 1.77 million tons last week, 3.2 percent less than the previous week's 1.83 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 59.2 percent of capacity last week, down from 61.1 percent.

Twenty years ago, Billy Cannon landed in a courtroom because he had signed two professional football contracts, one with Pete Rozelle, then general manager of the Los Angeles Rams and now Commissioner of the National Football League.

Relax. In sanctioning a patent for new forms of life created in the laboratory, the Supreme Court gave no license to create a race of supermen or a strain of bacteria to spread epidemic in the world. It settled a narrow point of patent law and left the "gruesome parade of horribles," if there is to be one, to be controlled by Congress and the President.
THE political atmosphere for the Venice economic summit conference, which begins this weekend, could scarcely be less auspicious.

PARIS, June 17--President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France is not very enthusiastic about this week's summit meeting in Venice. Too crowded, he says, too many problems to be discussed in two days with too many elections coming up too soon.

WASHINGTON, June 17--The Senate approved a bill tonight that would authorize about $4.8 billion in American foreign assistance for fiscal 1981, after soundly rejecting an attempt to cut $150 million from a $2.2 billion aid program for Israel.

GREENVILLE, Pa., June 15--After three rounds of the 1980 United States championship here at Thiel College, Larry Christiansen, a grandmaster from Modesto, Calif., and John Peters, an international master from Los Angeles, share the lead with 2 - scores.

LONG BEACH, Calif., June 17 (UPI) --The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has given China a contract to produce parts for a new model of its DC-9 airliner in a move to tap a vast market, the company has confirmed.

Governor Carey exaggerates when he says New York State now has the toughest handgun law in the country. In fact, Massachusetts, with its mandatory one-year sentence, is still the state most feared by those who carry guns illegally. What New York has done is to increase the allowable penalties for handgun violations. That may have a deterrent value, especially if plea bargaining, as intended, becomes more difficult. But the law still gives judges wide discretion in deciding punishment and it remains to be seen whether it can be very effective at all. We hope it will be, and that the state's police, prosecutors and judges enforce it energetically. Too many New Yorkers are endangered by the still expanding arsenals of deadly weapons.

Stung by Government allegations that the Roman Catholic Church is among large rural landholders exploiting poor farmers in Brazil, the church hierarchy has offered to give some of its properties to the sharecroppers living on them and challenged its critics to do the same. Responding to a Government document listing 441,000 acres of church land and detailing several cases where prominent clergymen had sold properties in the knowledge that the wealthy purchasers would expel the squatters occupying them, Archbishop Jose Ivo Lorscheiter, head of the National Council of Brazilian Bishops, said he wondered if anyone would ever reveal ''the other side of the coin, which, it seems to me, would be much more surprising than the part that deals with us.''

Two men accused of a daring daylight robbery of a Peking bank went on trial here today, and the proceedings were opened to foreigners in a move apparently designed to demonstrate China's progress toward re-establishing a regular legal system. The defendants, a 23-year-old laborer and a 24-year-old unemployed man, both with criminal records, pleaded guilty to the January holdup, during which a bank teller was shot. At the time the robbery was widely discussed among Chinese, though not reported in the official press, and added to popular concern about a growing crime wave.

The Iranian central bank has transferred as much as 14 tons of gold, worth about $300 million, to Iran from several European banks in recent months, European gold dealers confirmed today. The most likely explanation for the transfers, the dealers said, was fear in Iran that the gold could have been lost if European countries decided to freeze Iranian assets, as the United States has done.

A 24-year-old nurse suspended in connection with the unexplained deaths of two hospital patients has been dismissed. Linda Kurle said yesterday that she had received a registered letter from Good Samaritan Hospital notifying her of its ''decision to terminate effective immediately.''

The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had approved ''a significant new drug'' to help stop premature labor that threatens 10 percent of the three million babies born in the United States each year. The agency said the drug, ritodrine hydrochloride, relaxes the uterus and ''may help prevent some of the thousands of premature births and fetal and infant deaths that occur each year.''

International The biggest clashes in South Africa in four years erupted in mixedrace areas around Cape Town. At least eight people were reported killed and 50 wounded in the fighting between the police and civilians protesting apartheid. Stoning, looting and burning were widespread in one crowded area that was in a state of siege. The police sealed it off and rushed in reinforcements. (Page A1, Columns 4-5.) A Jordanian-American meeting helped ''clear the air'' between President Carter and King Hussein, according to White House officials. But after the two-hour session they said that the King reaffirmed Jordan's determination not to join the American-sponsored talks between Egypt and Israel on Palestinian autonomy in the West Bank and Gaza as long as Israel continued to occupy the areas. (A1:3.) A U.S. military sale to Saudi Arabia is being considered because of the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan. Citing the changed ''security atmosphere'' in the region, the Administration said it might decide to sell to the Saudis missiles and other strategic equipment for American F-15's that it had promised Israel and Congress would be prohibited. (A10:3-6.) China opened a trial to foreigners in an unusual move apparently designed to show the country's progress toward re-establishing an orderly legal system. The two defendants pleaded guilty to a Peking bank robbery in which a teller was shot. The January robbery was widely discussed, but not reported in the official press. (A3:1-3.) Giving up some church land in Brazil to the sharecroppers living there was offered by the Roman Catholic hierarchy. The church, angered by Government allegations that it is among the large rural landholders exploiting poor farmers, challenged its critics to make a similar offer. (A2:3-6.) National A tax cut is under active consideration in a major policy shift, according to senior Administration officials. They confirmed that they had begun to discuss the size, shape and timing of a 1981 tax reduction that President Carter could propose this year, perhaps as part of the midyear budget review next month. (A1:1-2.) A reputed crime leader was charged with racketeering, conspiracy and fraud in an alleged plot to bribe public officials in Louisiana. A Federal grand jury in New Orleans issued an indictment against Carlos Marcello, reputedly a top leader of organized crime in the country, and three other men after a one-year undercover inquiry by the F.B.I. (A1:1-2.) Any action against Ramsey Clark for traveling to Iran despite a Presidential ban is to be decided by Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti, according to senior Carter Administration officials. They said that the White House had explicitly told him that the decision was his. (A12:1-2.) Two false nuclear alerts were caused this month by a failure in a 46-cent component in a computer at the North American Air Defense Command headquarters, a senior Pentagon official announced. He said that the damaged circuit would be replaced, that transmissions had been shifted to alternate routes for the present and that errordetection and correction procedures would be improved. (A16:5-6.) Military spending is rising and the continuing budget debate centers on how much it will increase. Arguments for increased defense spending have been led by Congress, particularly the Senate, and military leaders. (A16:1-2.) The irrigation ruling by the Supreme Court involving California's lush Imperial Valley has ended the dream of the doctor who brought the suit and has reinforced the dream of the valley's well-to-do landowners. The decision Monday, in which the court said that farmers are entitled to federally subsidized water regardless of the size of their farms, came after 13 years of court battles. (A14:1-2.) Metropolitan A 60-cent transit fare seemed certain to take effect in New York City. The 10-cent increase was recommended by the chairman and staff of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, along with proposals for a series of fare increases ranging from 7 to 45 percent on the commuter railroads of New York and Connecticut and the introduction of a $25 monthly pass and free transfers on all New York City buses. (A1:6.) Links between officials and casinos in Atlantic City have been disclosed in real-estate transactions and other financial records. A study shows that more than 50 elected and appointed officials have financial ties to one or more casinos, including several that have won official permission to bypass regulations. (B1:5-6.) Disclosures of Regents tests questions generated a furor. Copies of parts of at least three of the examinations were believed to be in circulation among some high school students in New York City. However, the State Commissioner of Education said that only ''isolated incidents'' of cheating were reported and were confined to the metropolitan area and he decided to proceed with this week's scheduled examinations across the state. (B4:2-4.) An opera gala was celebrated at the opening of the Metropolitan company's free summer concert performances in New York City parks. The performance of ''Rigoletto'' before a throng that filled Central Park's Great Lawn was particulary festive and included Luciano Pavarotti, the tenor who is probably now opera's biggest, most flamboyant star. (A1:4-5.) Business Digest, Page D1

STOMPIN' at the Savoy,'' the cabaret revue that is playing at the West Bank Cafe, 407 West 42d Street, on Sundays and Mondays through June, is a show that successfully pulls itself up by its bootstraps. The title might lead one to anticipate recollections of Harlem's Savoy Ballroom, celebrated in the song from which the show takes its title. Instead, this Savoy is an otherwise uncelebrated nightclub. And in this setting, while the club's show goes on, the relationships of three couples are explored.

Eleven new productions and revivals will highlight the 1980-81 performing year for American Ballet Theater, its first under the directorship of Mikhail Baryshnikov, who will assume his new post in September. The new repertory is an unusually diversified one, representing the work of an American modern-dance choreographer and three leading contemporary ballet choreographers, as well as Russian classical ballet.

The long-standing enmity between farmers in France and Spain over cheaper Spanish produce threatened today to turn into a serious international incident. After the dynamiting or burning of 10 Spanish trucks yesterday by angry French farmers, as many as 1,000 big long-haul trucks backed up on both sides of the Spanish-French border, between Catalonia and the southern French department of Pyrenees-Orientales.

Ananda Mohan Chakrabarty does not like to wait on the results of one project before undertaking a new one. So it did not surprise colleagues that the scientist had moved on with his genetic research while a legal battle on whether he could patent a new form of life he had created worked its way to the Supreme Court. ''He is a careful, highly imaginative but impatient researcher who is not seriously deterred by conventional wisdom that might say something isn't worth doing,'' Dr. Ronald E. Brooks, manager of the environmental section of the General Electric Company in Schenectady, N.Y., said of the 42-year-old geneticist and microbiologist.

Helen Drexel came looking for her husband's gold retirement watch. Doris Crandall hoped to find her bird cage. Arietta Slade was looking for her camera. The three, together with dozens of other burglary victims, went to a Police Department warehouse in Queens yesterday in the hope of recovering items taken from their homes in recent burglaries. ''I just about got over the robbery when I heard about this display,'' Mrs. Drexel said. ''I thought I would try.'' The display in the musty, concrete room included watches, jewelry, electronic equipment, art works and religious items - including a set of priest's vestments - all from three second-hand stores in Manhattan whose owner has been charged with selling property he got from thieves.

The State Commission of Investigation and the State Senate Select Committee on Crime are investigating the handling of at least $100,000 in ''walking around'' money in Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's 1977 mayoral primary and runoff campaigns.
SARA DAVIDSON, whose first book, "Loose Change," estab lished its author as something of an expert on the 1960's, gets off to a strong start in this collection of her magazine pieces from the 1970's.

An item that is painful in everyday life is popular nowadays with tournament players. They find more and more uses for the splinter, which was introduced in the 1960's by one of the top-ranked partnerships of that period, B. Jay Becker and Dorothy Hayden.

I HAVE always found fault with the Cuisinart, despite the fact that I believe it to be the best food processor around. It does have a powerful motor, good blades and disks that allow it to do a great many jobs-- from chopping meat to mixing dough-- well and fast.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--The Food and Drug Administration said today that it had approved "a significant new drug" to help stop premature labor that threatens 10 percent of the three million babies born in the United States each year.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Most of Ronald Reagan's top strategists are saying they now believe the former California Governor would be better off this fall with Representative John B. Anderson out of the race rather than continuing his independent Presidential candidacy.

LONDON, June 17 (Reuters)--Britain's postal service today began the first international public service for sending letters by satellite. Called Intelpost, the new service uses a satellite 25,000 miles above the earth to transmit letters and documents by facsimile.

ROME A man's shoulder-strap bag or hand bag, the ubiquitous borselio, is an essential part of his normal dress, an Italian court has just ruled. The decision pointed out that "The borsello in everyday reality is a substitute for pockets that in modern attire are missing or insufficient."

BONN, June 17--The Iranian central bank has transferred as much as 14 tons of gold, worth about $300 million, to Iran from several European banks in recent months, European gold dealers confirmed today.

WASHINGTON, June 17--President Carter and King Hussein of Jordan held two hours of talks today that White House officials said had helped "clear the air" between the two leaders, even if they failed to resolve their differences on ways to achieve peace in the Middle East.
THERE is not likely to be an abundance of hot drama at the Republican National Conven tion that will begin July 14 in Detroit, but that will not deter the three commercial networks' news divisions.

PRAGUE, June 17 (AP)--The Soviet Union may have difficulties because of the United States embargo on high-technology items, but will advance even if all American products are withheld, Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin said today.

An experiment designed to find out if women really belong in law enforcement will begin in earnest June 27 when the first all-female class of trooper candidates in the nation finishes a grueling 20-week training period and joins the ranks of the New Jersey state police. The 30 women will be monitored on the job by state police officials and by an independent team of observers from Seton Hall University. The resulting reports could provide guidelines for other states in training female recruits and in outlining their strengths and weaknesses.

A day after meeting privately with John B. Anderson, the independent candidate for President, Governor Hugh Carey of New York said yesterday that ''in this kind of a very curious year'' a thirdparty candidate could win the Presidential race. But in the next breath he said that ''in all likelihood'' he would eventually support a fellow Democrat. ''I have no plans to endorse anyone at this time,'' the Governor said a good-natured verbal fencing match with reporters before a ground-breaking ceremony for New York's Convention Center on West 39th Street. He avoided making any commitments, as he has throughout this Presidential season.

Most of Ronald Reagan's top strategists are saying they now believe the former California Governor would be better off this fall with Representative John B. Anderson out of the race rather than continuing his independent Presidential candidacy. Nevertheless, unlike President Carter's campaign, they are not attacking Mr. Anderson publicly or making any move at this time to block him from running.

I HAVE always found fault with the Cuisinart, despite the fact that I believe it to be the best food processor around. It does have a powerful motor, good blades and disks that allow it to do a great many jobs -from chopping meat to mixing dough -well and fast. But it seemed important to point out the shortcomings, the most significant of which was its limited use as a slicer. The limitation was the result of a narrow feed tube at the top of the machine that was not large enough to accommodate a whole piece of fruit like an apple or an orange and that forced the cook to shape potatoes with a knife so that they would fit the tube.

An item that is painful in everyday life is popular nowadays with tournament players. They find more and more uses for the splinter, which was introduced in the 1960's by one of the top-ranked partnerships of that period, B. Jay Becker and Dorothy Hayden. The basic idea is for an unusual jump to show a fit with partner and a singleton or void in the suit bid. The normal situations - four diamonds in response to one spade, for example - suggest a slam.
WITH NATO PLEASE USE LONDON, June 17 (AP) - Britain announced today that it would place 160 American-made, medium-range nuclear missiles 60 miles from London.

Jose A. Lima, of Mexico, president of Cindal, a Guatemalan subsidiary of the Swiss chocolate company Nestle, was kidnapped by a number of armed men today when he drove away from his home in a plush southern residential area of the capital, the authorities said. None of the extremist groups operating in Guatemala have yet taken responsibility for the kidnapping, they said.

ROME, June 17 (UPI)--Pope John Paul II will visit 13 cities, a jail and two leper colonies on his coming tour of Brazil, the Vatican announced today. The 12-day trip is the longest papal trip outside Italy in modern times.

The State Commission of Investigation and the State Senate Select Committee on Crime are investigating the handling of at least $100,000 in "walking around" money in Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's 1977 mayoral primary and runoff campaigns.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 16--The persistent refusal of King Hussein of Jordan to get involved in Egypt's negotiations with Israel has created a credibility problem not entirely of his making.

The Metropolitan Opera's free concert performances in New York City parks are nearly always notable events. But last night's "Rigoletto," played under clear skies on Central Park's Great Lawn to open the 1980 summer season, was special for its festive cast.

AGARTALA, India, June 16--The Chief Minister of the Communist-ruled northeastern state of Tripura says that if the Indian Government had heeded his pleas for help to put down the current tribal insurgency, the massacre at Mandai last week would not have happened.

The Treasury Department said in a letter to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission yesterday that it did not oppose plans of the New York Futures Exchange, a New York Stock Exchange unit, to trade futures contracts based on Treasury bills and bonds.

OVER the years I have written at times about menu terminology when dishes are listed as fish or chicken in Cham pagne sauce, beef Chambertin or other dishes that bear the name of a specific kind of wine.
DALLAS, June 17--Three years ago, after the owner was slain, Steven Riker paid $16,000 for a roach-infested house in a rundown area of East Dallas.
A City Bar Association committee has sharply criticized the recommended creation of a state commission to review sentences judges give to convicted defendants.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Supporters of President Carter and Senator Edward M. Kennedy today began to dicker, line by line, over the shape of the Democratic platform but the party's platform drafting subcommittee put off votes until tomorrow.
Before the game, Dennis Werth sat at a table in the Yankee clubhouse, painstakingly removing someone else's embroidered name from his new third baseman's glove.

PARIS, June 17 (Reuters)--President Valery Giscard d'Estaing will visit China in October, French officials said today. Elysee Palace is expected to make a formal announcement with the precise date shortly, they said. The Chinese Communist Party chairman, Hua Guofeng, visited France on his first tour of Western Europe last October.

To the Editor: Your June 11 news article on proposals for the East River Development Project presents an excellent description of what is awry with development in the city. Legal and political requirements for projects are so arcane that lawyers and public relations experts have become the key actors.

The Chief Minister of the Communistruled northeastern state of Tripura says that if the Indian Government had heeded his pleas for help to put down the current tribal insurgency, the massacre at Mandai last week would not have happened. In an interview here in the state capital, the 74-year-old Chief Minister, Nripen Chakravarti, said the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi started sending in reinforcements only after soldiers had found the bodies of at least 350 Bengalis at Mandai, 20 miles east of here.

Senior officials in the Carter Administration said today the White House had told Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti that the decision on whether to bring an action against Ramsey Clark for traveling to Iran was ''up to him.'' Despite President Carter's expressed ''inclination'' to seek to punish Mr. Clark, one Administration official said, ''no one at the White House has ever suggested to the Attorney General that he ought to bring a case whether or not he thought there was a case.''
COMMANDER OF IRANIAN REVOLUTIONARY GUARDS RESIGNS

A City Bar Association committee has sharply criticized the recommended creation of a state commission to review sentences judges give to convicted defendants. The recommendation was a major point of a 1979 report by Governor Carey's special committee on sentencing, which was headed by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan.

Gabriel Aufaure, 60 years old, who joined the Certainteed Corporation as president and chief executive officer a little more than a year ago, has resigned, effective July 7. The chief executive officer's title will be assumed by Michel Besson, 46, who will also become vice chairman, while Franklin R. Winnert, 47, the chief operating officer, will take over the presidency. Certainteed, based in Valley Forge, Pa., manufactures fiberglass, pipe and siding and other building materials. Its name is derived from an old company slogan: ''Quality made certain, satisfaction guaranteed.''

IF Sherlock Holmes were alive today he would have to add an expert knowledge of computer science to his formidable analytical skills. For business crimes by way of the computer are on the rise, so much so that they are creating new careers for people able to outwit dishonest computer experts. These machines, with their secretive impersonality, can hide all sorts of frauds. And even when a fraud is discovered it can be difficult finding out who pushed the buttons. This means that, as the use of computers grows, more and more trained personnel will be required to outwit technically adept crooks.
LONDON, June 17 (AP)--Britain announced today that it would place 160 American nuclear missiles at two bases 60 miles from London.

A rush of steam from roof vents on a building at St. Vincent's Hospital Center at 12th Street and Seventh Avenue awoke the hospital's Greenwich Village neighbors early this morning. It was quickly controlled without damage or injury. A Con Edison spokesman said the accident occurred as engineers from the utility were doing routine work on steam meters and a safety valve tripped.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Senior officials in the Carter Administration said today the White House had told Attorney General Benjamin R. Civiletti that the decision on whether to bring an action against Ramsey Clark for traveling to Iran was "un to him."

TEHERAN, Iran, June 17 (UPI)--Attempts by President Abolhassan BaniSadr to add to his authority apparently were set back today when the man he had appointed to command the revolutionary guards resigned.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Carlos Marcello, reputedly one of the top leaders of organized crime in the United States, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on racketeering, conspiracy and fraud charges. Mr. Marcello was accused of playing a central role in a scheme to bribe public officials in Louisiana.

JUNE is National Dairy Month, but if you're looking for special promotional sales at the dairy counter, don't bother. Despite increased production of milk, cheese, butter and other dairy products compared with a year ago, sales have held steady or declined, while prices have increased.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to double the size of a proposed fund for cleaning up inactive hazardous waste dumps and to make industry carry a bigger share of the costs.

Coming at a time when there is possibly more knowledge about the means of sound reproduction than there is about the sounds being reproduced, Bruce Ricker's ''The Last of the Blue Devils'' is something of a public service as well as a musical delight. The documentary feature, which opens today at New York's Art Theater, is a recollection of the music and the musicians associated with Kansas City, Mo., in the 30's when the city, which was then run by Tom (Boss) Pendergast and wide open to women and gambling, could support the kind of clubs where black musicians flourished. The film is a montage of footage shot by Mr. Ricker, a New Yorkborn lawyer turned film maker, at two reunions of surviving Kansas City musicians and at a concert performance by Count Basie and his band at the University of Kansas at Lawrence. Music is the subject of the movie, but the personalities who made it (some of whom are still making it) and their reminiscences are the movie's method.

A senior Pentagon official disclosed today that a failure in an electronic component about the size of a dime and worth 46 cents caused the two false alarms that put United States strategic nuclear forces on alert twice earlier this month. On June 3 and June 6, errors in a computer at the North American Air Defense Command headquarters inside Cheyenne Mountain, near Colorado Springs, caused the system to warn erroneously that Soviet intercontinental ballistic missiles had been fired at the United States.

When the United States Supreme Court lifted an economic cloud from the fertile soil of California's Imperial Valley yesterday, it ended the dream of Dr. Ben Yellen and kept alive the dream of a farmer named Don Cox. Dr. Yellen, a son of Jewish immigrants who grew up in Brooklyn and moved to the Imperial Valley for his health 45 years ago, had taken up a personal fight to make the Government enforce a 78-year-old law limiting the size of federally irrigated farms. He said he was doing it so that the poor farm workers he treated would have a chance of owning land.

Parents of a teen-ager who died in the 1978 air collision that killed 144 people have been awarded $76,000 in wrongful death damages from Pacific Southwest Airlines. Mr. and Mrs. Taha Taha, parents of David, a 16-year-old high school junior, received the award yesterday from a jury in San Diego Superior Court that deliberated 70 minutes after a day of testimony.

Sugar Ray Leonard said today that he has been suffering from a virus and sore throat ''about a week now,'' but that it would not affect him Friday night when he defends the World Boxing Council welterweight title against Roberto Duran. ''It doesn't bother me,'' Leonard said after a light 20-minute workout. ''I think it's just a change in the weather. I've got no fever at all, but I have a sore throat once in awhile.''

The Metropolitan Opera's free concert performances in New York City parks are nearly always notable events. But last night's ''Rigoletto,'' played under clear skies on Central Park's Great Lawn to open the 1980 summer season, was special for its festive cast. Among other things, the performance marked the first appearances at a park opera performance by James Levine, the Met's music director, and by Luciano Pavarotti, the tenor who probably counts as opera's biggest, most flamboyant star.

WASHINGTON, June 17--A senior Pentagon official disclosed today that a failure in an electronic component about the size of a dime and worth 46 cents caused the two false alarms that put United States strategic nuclear forces on alert twice earlier this month.

CAMP LEJEUNE, N.C., June 17 (AP) --A military judge today adjourned a pretrial hearing for Pfc. Robert Garwood, who is accused of collaborating with the enemy in Vietnam, and tentatively scheduled his court-martial for July 7.

"STOMPIN' at the Savoy," the cabaret revue that is playing at the West Bank Cafe, 407 West 42d Street, on Sundays and Mondays through June, is a show that successfully pulls itself up by its bootstraps.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 17--The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today that he was opposed to any extension of the alliance's frontiers to include areas, such as the Persian Gulf, that might be threatened by the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--The House today defeated legislation to extend for one year the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to study and regulate pesticides. The vote was an apparent signal that the House wanted Congress to have veto power over the agency's decisions on pesticides.
Walter A. Marting, who was president of the Hanna Mining Company for 14 years until he retired in 1974, died yesterday morning at his Gates Mills Home in suburban Cleveland. He was 70 years old.

The Administration is showing extreme displeasure with the new military-civilian junta in South Korea. President Carter has urged the regime to ''move as rapidly as possible toward a completely democratic government,'' adding that ''in the meantime we are making sure that Korea is kept secure.'' Punitive signals followed rapidly: Economic missions to South Korea were postponed, two Asian Development Bank loans were held up, and visits by high-ranking Americans must now be cleared by Richard C. Holbrooke, Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs. Negotiations for an Export-Import Bank loan, however, have been allowed to proceed.

The Carter Administration said today that the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan had altered ''the regional security atmosphere'' so that it was now considering selling Saudi Arabia equipment and missiles for its American-built F-15's that it had promised Israel and the Congress would be prohibited. Although both the White House and the State Department stressed that no decision had been made to provide Saudi Arabia with the military hardware that would enhance the planes' range and firepower, the Administration sought to provide the rationale if it decides to do so.
High-Tech Clothes

About 600 Cambodian refugees left two camps in eastern Thailand for the Cambodian border today at the start of a voluntary repatriation program directed by Thai authorities and the United Nations. However, most refugees here refused to join in the program.

NEW JERSEY'S Department of Environmental Protection is justifiably proud of its role in the successful effort to induce the endangered peregrine falcon to produce young in the eastern half of the nation. Working with specialists attached to Cornell University's Peregrine Fund, the D.E.P. during the last five years released more than 50 Cornell-hatched falcons from three locations along the Jersey coast: Brigantine National Wildlife Refuge, Sedge Island in Barnegat Bay and the tidal marshes near Manahawkin.

By PAUL L. MONTGOMERY A representative to the United Nations from the West African nation of Togo entered a civilian complaint last night alleging that police officers in Brooklyn had abused him in the course of a traffic incident.

A threatened strike against the Consolidated Edison Company at 12:01 this morning was averted yesterday with the announcement by Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America of a tentative contract agreement.

JOAO PESSOA, Brazil--Stung by Government allegations that the Roman Catholic Church is among large rural landholders exploiting poor farmers in Brazil, the church hierarchy has offered to give some of its properties to the sharecroppers living on them and challenged its critics to do the same.

VENICE, June 17--With one of this month's Venice conferences over and the other yet to begin, the city has been reclaimed for the moment by its usual June occupants--the tourists, the pigeons and the gondoliers.
Harper's, the 130-year-old magazine of literature and current affairs, will cease publication after its August issue.

Simon Sheib, the president and chief executive officer of Avnet Inc., an electronics company in Manhattan, died Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital of a thrombosis. He was 64 years old and a resident of Larchmont, N.Y.

The Environmental Protection Agency today released a scientific review tending to support a controversial study that found that some residents of the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, N.Y., had abnormal chromosomal matter in their cells. The report was appended to another evaluation, disclosed over the weekend, that disputed earlier conclusions of abnormal levels of chromosome damage in 11 of 36 persons tested.

The United States Patent Office has a backlog of more than 100 applications for patents on living organisms and now expects to process them, following the Supreme Court's favorable decision on the General Electric Company's patent for an oil-eating bacterium. Concerns specializing in gene-splicing research have filed many patent applications in recent years, although they knew that the pending case was delaying the award of patents on life-forms and processes related to gene-splicing.
WITH CARTER,DECLINES TO JOIN By TERENCE SMITH

A 49-member New York City budget analysis unit is going to be disbanded. According to a mayoral aide, the panel, the Legislative Office of Budget Review, is dying because it never learned that budgets are political as well as financial documents. The unit, which had a budget of $1.6 million, was created as part of City Charter revisions in 1977 to serve both the City Council and the Board of Estimate. It was quietly and unanimously discarded in last week's budget negotiations by the bodies it serves.

A jury deliberating on murder, loan-sharking, gambling and other charges at a 14-week-old trial here said yesterday that it was ''confused'' by the prosecution's attempt to prove the existence of organized crime. The state's main charge is that the four defendants belonged to ''a secret nationwide criminal organization,'' the Cosa Nostra. Six hours after the jury received the case, it sent Judge Michael R. Imbriani a note that said: ''Is it possible to explain the legal definition of nationwide? Kindly accept our apologies in this matter but we're confused.''
WASHINGTON, June 17--Through the din of debate over the nation's military budget that started last fall, one conclusion has emerged clearly: Spending for the military is going up.

WASHINGTON, June 17--The Environmental Protection Agency today released a scientific review tending to support a controversial study that found that some residents of the Love Canal area of Niagara Falls, N.Y., had abnormal chromosomal matter in their cells.
Don't talk turkey this week--buy one and freeze it for Thanksgiving. That was the advice of turkey producers, who said turkey prices are at a three-year low but are beginning to rise.
CHICAGO, June 17 (AP)--J.R. Richard and Joaquin Andujar combined on a three-hitter and Jose Cruz hit a three-run homer today to lead the Houston Astros to a 7-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

Copies of parts of at least three Regents examinations are in circulation among some high school students in the New York metropolitan area, the State Commissioner of Education said yesterday. But he said he had decided to go ahead with this week's scheduled Regents examinations for public, private and parochial students in the state.
In times of trial, real or imagined, personal or global, it has become instinctive to seek relief from our burdens in a bowl of chicken soup.

Diet-conscious consumers seeking an alternative to cottage cheese often turn to their local cheese shop for advice. When they ask for low-fat cheese, most dealers are likely to suggest Swiss Chris, a mild semisoft cheese made in Wisconsin. According to the label on the uncut cheese, it provides eight grams of fat per one-ounce (or 28.35gram) serving, for a total fat content of about 29 percent.

All state legislatures are famous for foolishness, but until last weekend none had ever thought of turning love into a requirement for operating an automobile. This oversight was repaired in Albany when the legislators passed a bill decreeing that, starting next year, New York motorists will have to display license plates bearing the pronouncement, ''I Love New York.'' Governor Carey can still save us from this with a veto on behalf of good sense and good taste and, being canny about politics, maybe he will.

When a couple of traditionally noncontending clubs like the New York Mets and San Diego Padres get together, good defense is usually the last thing you expect to see. However, at San Diego Stadium tonight, fielders from both teams backed up a pair of rookie starting pitchers with a stream of sensational plays. But once again, the Mets came out on the short end of a tightly played game as they dropped a 2-1 verdict when the Padres broke a tie in the bottom of the ninth. With New York's Tom Hausman hurling in relief, Bill Fahey bounced a one-out single off the pitcher's glove, went to third on a fielder's choice and an error and scored on a single through the hole by Gene Richards.
PASSANNANTE AND MR. ORHENSTEIN By JOYCE PURNICK
FOR JORANIAN COOLNESS ON CAMP DAVID ACCORDS By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN

Marvis Frazier, the Amateur Athletic Union champion, outpointed Mitch Green of Jamaica, Queens, in a heavyweight fight last night at the Olympic boxing trials with his father, Joe Frazier, in the audience. The former champion's son, giving away several inches in height and reach, swarmed on the 6-foot-5-inch Green in the first two rounds of the three-round bout. But the loser came back strongly with combinations before Frazier finished with a flurry in the final 15 seconds.

Two international track and field invitation meets scheduled in the United States next month have been canceled because of the ''highly politicized'' situation leading up to the Moscow Olympics, the head of The Athletics Congress announced tonight.
