Ollan Cassell, executive director of T.A.C., the governing body for track and field in the United States, said that officials at the University of Pennsylvania at Philadelphia decided to call off the meet scheduled for July 22-23. As a result of that action, Cassell said, T.A.C. would also cancel the other meet scheduled July 17-18 at the University of California at Berkeley.

Three years ago, after the owner was slain, Steven Riker paid $16,000 for a roach-infested house in a rundown area of East Dallas. Tomorrow a very angry Mr. Riker will tell the Dallas Board of Equalization that his home is not worth the $93,000 it was appraised at this spring. And even if it is, he will say, he is not about to have his local tax bill raised from $400 to $2,200 in one year. ''They are not going to get $2,200 out of me,'' he declared, adding that he could not possibly have improved the house that much in three years.

Gen. Ivan L. Bennett, a former United States Army chief of chaplains, died Sunday at the National Orthopedic and Rehabilitation Center, Arlington, Va., after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Arlington. A minister of the Southern Baptist Church, General Bennett had been an Army chaplain since World War I. In World War II he was chief chaplain on the staff of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur in the Pacific.

Simon Sheib, the president and chief executive officer of Avnet Inc., an electronics company in Manhattan, died Sunday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital of a thrombosis. He was 64 years old and a resident of Larchmont, N.Y. Mr. Sheib, a graduate of New York University and the Harvard Law School, practiced law before joining Avnet in 1960. He was named president in 1970.

REMEMBER those glorious days of yesteryear when the zinfandel was the all-purpose American red table wine, taken seriously by only a few devotees, priced low because it lacked panache, produced in vast quantities, available everywhere? As it happens, yesteryear is now, for the zinfandel is still an underrated wine that few connoisseurs hold in the same regard as the noble cabernet sauvignon, clearly the No. 1 premium red wine produced in the United States. But the sun is setting on the day when zinfandel can be considered a bargain, for its quality and personality are being recognized and prices are going up.

American Stock Exchange Inc. has named Joshua A. Rich fifth executive vice president, marketing. * Callahan Mining Corporation, Darien, Conn., has named William P. Lohden vice president and treasurer and William A. Nicely vice president, secretary and counsel. * May Department Stores Company, St. Louis, has named Steven J. Douglass vice president of corporate planning and analysis. * L.F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin, an investment banking and brokerage firm, announced that Matthew P. Deane, Walter W. Hess Jr., Stephen Kovacs, A. Robert Towbin and Thomas I. Unterberg had been appointed senior partners and that Richard H. Baer, Robert J. Kaufmann and Peter A. Cohn were becoming limited partners.
A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth who was killed Monday night after he allegedly robbed a decoy police officer was identified yesterday as Michael Furse of 83 Woodruff Place, in the Flatbush section.

WASHINGTON, June 17--The Carter Administration said today that the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan had altered "the regional security atmosphere" so that it was now considering selling Saudi Arabia equipment and missiles for its American-built F-15's that it had promised Israel and the Congress would be prohibited.

Americans will get their first full look at traditional Peking opera in more than 50 years when the Peking Opera Theater of China opens its first tour of the United States, starting Aug. 12, with 14 performances at the Metropolitan Opera House.

REMEMBER those glorious days of yesteryear when the zinfandel was the all-purpose American red table wine, taken seriously by only a few devotees, priced low be cause it lacked panache, produced in vast quantities, available everywhere?

WASHINGTON--The Administration is showing extreme displeasure with the new military-civilian junta in South Korea. President Carter has urged the regime to "move as rapidly as possible toward a completely democratic government," adding that "in the meantime we are making sure that Korea is kept secure."

IF there is one nutrient that has the decks stacked against it, it's fat. The typical American diet has a higher fat content than nearly any other in the world. While agreement on this issue is not universal, many scientists blame this high-fat diet for a number of our chronic health problems and killing diseases, among them heart disease, obesity and possibly cancers of the colon and breast.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 17 (AP)--The Oakland Raiders, apparently giving in because of legal obstacles to an immediate move to Los Angeles, said today that they would play in the Oakland Coliseum next season.

At least eight people were reported killed and 50 wounded today as clashes between South African policemen and demonstrators in mixed-race areas around Cape Town developed into the worst violence since the yearlong upheaval that began in Soweto in 1976. A police statement issued shortly before midnight said only that ''a number of people were killed and others wounded'' as daylong skirmishes developed into a night of stoning, looting and burning.

The Soviet Union may have difficulties because of the United States embargo on high-technology items, but will advance even if all American products are withheld, Prime Minister Aleksei N. Kosygin said today. President Carter imposed the embargo and also banned grain sales to the Soviet Union because of the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan.

Korvettes Inc., the New York area's third-largest retailer, confirmed yesterday that it plans to lay off about 2,000 employees, about one-third of its work force, over the next two to three months. John Cook, a company spokesman, said in a statement that the reductions would take place at its headquarters in New York City and its 36 stores throughout the country. The company has about 6,000 employees.

With one of this month's Venice conferences over and the other yet to begin, the city has been reclaimed for the moment by its usual June occupants - the tourists, the pigeons and the gondoliers. But the feeling is taking hold, among members of advance parties already here and among officials in Western European capitals, that an opportunity has been missed. No real progress seems likely toward a solution of the West's grave political and economic problems, and some people think that the difficulty is one of questions as well as one of answers.

ROME A man's shoulder-strap bag or handbag, the ubiquitous borsello, is an essential part of his normal dress, an Italian court has just ruled. The decision pointed out that ''The borsello in everyday reality is a substitute for pockets that in modern attire are missing or insufficient.'' The borsello has long ceased to be a neologism in the Italian men's fashion vocabulary. It's as commonplace now for men of all ages and in every social class as a wristwatch. It has also become the badge of the Italian traveler abroad.

The British Government opened the lucrative London-Hong Kong air route to three additional airlines today, ending the monopoly of state-run British Airways. Trade Secretary John Nott said in Parliament that he was authorizing British Caledonian Airways, Laker Airways and the Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific Airways to join British Airways in flying to Hong Kong.

Walter A. Marting, who was president of the Hanna Mining Company for 14 years until he retired in 1974, died yesterday morning at his Gates Mills Home in suburban Cleveland. He was 70 years old. Mr. Marting, who remained as a director until his death, presided at Hanna Mining as the Cleveland-based company grew from a large but regional producer of natural iron ore into one of the world's biggest independent producers of iron ore pellets, concentrate and natural ores. He was also chairman of Hanna Mining's largest affiliate, the Iron Ore Company of Canada, and headed other Hanna subsidiaries as well.

Yields on medium-quality corporate bonds declined yesterday as the credit markets first advanced and then retreated to end little changed from where they were Monday afternoon. The Federal Reserve added permanent reserves to the banking system by purchasing Treasury notes and bonds, but this action - generally expected by bond traders - had no discernible impact on the market. The Commerce Department reported a steep drop in housing starts in May, and that news also had little, if any, impact on the credit markets. At other times, these developments have pushed fixed-income prices higher and interest rates lower.

Pope John Paul II will visit 13 cities, a jail and two leper colonies on his coming tour of Brazil, the Vatican announced today. The 12-day trip is the longest papal trip outside Italy in modern times. The itinerary indicated that the 60-year-old Pope's trip, which will start June 30, will be the most grueling he has undertaken since he was elected 19 months ago. He will travel more than 17,500 miles and will celebrate 13 major masses.

Through the din of debate over the nation's military budget that started last fall, one conclusion has emerged clearly: Spending for the military is going up. Still unclear is how far. ''Despite the ups and downs,'' said a knowledgeable budget official on Capitol Hill, ''there really seems to be a consensus for higher defense spending.'' Officials in the White House and in the Pentagon agreed.

Three years ago, after the owner was slain, Steven Riker paid $16,000 for a roach-infested house in a rundown area of East Dallas. Tomorrow a very angry Mr. Riker will tell the Dallas Board of Equalization that his home is not worth the $93,000 it was appraised at this spring. And even if it is, he will say, he is not about to have his local tax bill raised from $400 to $2,200 in one year. ''They are not going to get $2,200 out of me,'' he declared, adding that he could not possibly have improved the house that much in three years.

Edith Lowenstein, a lawyer, died Saturday in Doctors Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan. Miss Lowenstein was born in Germany and came to the United States as an exchange student. After she received her law degree from the University of Chicago in 1939, she specialized in immigration cases. She served as an appellate attorney for the Criminal Division of the Department of Justice from 1939 to 1944 and as a trial attorney with the Office of Alien Property from 1944 to 1953.

FOR most young artists starting out in New York, dreams of good food vanish when their first rent bill arrives. But Robert Russell, a 25-year-old painter who supports himself with part-time carpentry and house painting, sits down every night to a splendid dinner and a bottle of wine. ''I need that relaxation at the end of the day,'' he says. ''I can't afford to go out to eat, so I do the cooking myself.'' He shares a loft near Washington Square in Greenwich Village with a friend, Anne Little. After work he shops locally for food that is quick to prepare and cooks it in his own unconventional and idiosyncratic way. He rarely consults cookbooks. ''But I do use Julia Child's if I'm doing a roast or something for which I need precise timing,'' he said.

In a country where the tastes of the first family can shape the policies of an entire administration, the seemingly irrelevant fact that the President's wife, Carmen Romano de Lopez Portillo, loves playing the piano has been enough to promote an extraordinary cultural boom in Mexico. Almost overnight, Mexico has not only been added to the tour circuits of the world's major orchestras, ballet corps, theater companies and art exhibitions, but vast sums are also being spent to promote culture among the population at large.

THE political atmosphere for the Venice economic summit conference, which begins this weekend, could scarcely be less auspicious. Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany plans to rush from Venice to Moscow for his own summit conference with the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev. President Carter has ''strongly'' cautioned Mr. Schmidt against proposing a freeze on the deployment of medium-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe. The members of the European Economic Community have further annoyed Mr. Carter by proposing that the Palestine Liberation Organization be ''associated with'' the Middle East talks. This does not satisfy the P.L.O., which wants official recognition for itself and endorsement for a Palestinian state, but it disturbs President Carter, who has opposed dealing with the P.L.O. until it recognizes Israel's right to exist.

The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the country's largest department-store chains, told its shareholders at the annual meeting in New York City yesterday that the current second quarter's net income will be down from the corresponding period in 1979. Allied, which operates the Gertz Long Island and Stern Brothers stores in New Jersey and other large stores in major cities, had reported substantially lower first-quarter net income. Thomas M. Macioce, president and chief executive officer, said that the company's new Bonwit Teller store on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan is expected to open in February 1981 at a cost exceeding $5 million. Allied acquired the Bonwit chain from Genesco Inc. last year, but the former Bonwit store on Fifth Avenue was not included and was closed by Genesco.

Stocks continued their cautious move higher yesterday, although hopes of a strong rally dissipated in late trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead more than 5 points at 3 P.M., ended the day up 1.54 points.

A delegation of Liberian Cabinet ministers was in Washington last week seeking emergency loans of about $50 million, food and military supplies and equipment to shore up the nation's new military regime.
Peter J. Solomon resigned yesterday as New York City's Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development to take a newly created position as counselor to Treasury Secretary G. William Miller.

WASHINGTON, June 17--Builders began new homes last month at an annual rate of 920,000 units, the lowest level in five years, the Commerce Department said today in a report that gave another major indication of the severity of the recession.

CHICAGO, June 17--Ananda Mohan Chakrabarty does not like to wait on the results of one project before undertaking a new one. So it did not surprise colleagues that the scientist had moved on with his genetic research while a legal ...

A 49-member New York City budget analysis unit is going to be disbanded. According to a mayoral aide, the panel, the Legislative Office of Budget Review, is dying because it never learned that budgets are political as well as financial documents.
Edith Lowenstein, a lawyer, died Saturday in Doctors Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan.
JERUSALEM, June 17--Prof. Jacob Leib Talmon, a Hebrew University historian, died yesterday during heart surgery at the Hadassah Medical Center. He was 64 years old.

FOXBORO, Mass., June 17-- Hennes Weisweiler, the Cosmos' coach, made two changes on the team today when he released Don Ebert, a striker who was the league's first draft choice last year, and Vidal Fernandez, a midfielder, on waivers.
PARIS, June 17--The long-standing enmity between farmers in France and Spain over cheaper Spanish produce threatened today to turn into a serious international incident.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 17 (AP)--A carpenters' strike spread to at least 30,000 construction workers in northern California today, dealing another blow to an industry crippled by the recession. Among projects idled was a $68 million restoration of the Statehouse.

At a ground-breaking ceremony marked by good humor and a moratorium on political infighting, Governor Carey, Mayor Koch and a crowd of officials yesterday hailed the beginning of construction of a $375 million exposition and convention center, a project 15 years in the planning.

Ehrhardt Henry (Ott) Heller, a former New York Ranger defenseman who played 27 years in professional hockey, died Monday at his home in Kitchener, Ontario. Mr. Heller was 70 years old and had been ill for some time.
JERUSALEM, June 17--When Golda Meir's autobiography was published in 1975, Kamal Abdel-Malek, then an Egyptian student working in Greece, bought a copy.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)--Pope John Paul II named Bishop James A. Hickey today to be the new Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington.

MEXICO CITY IN a country where the tastes of the first family can shape the policies of an entire administration, the seemingly irrelevant fact that the President's wife, Carmen Romano de Lopez Portillo, loves playing the piano has been enough to promote an extraordinary cultural boom in Mexico.

JOHANNESBURG, June 17--At least eight people were reported killed and 50 wounded today as clashes between South African policemen and demonstrators in mixed-race areas around Cape Town developed into the worst violence since the yearlong upheaval that began in Soweto in 1976.

Gen. Ivan L. Bennett, a former United States Army chief of chaplains, died Sunday at the National Orthopedic and Rehabilitation Center, Arlington, Va., after a long illness. He was 88 years old and lived in Arlington.

A carpenters' strike spread to at least 30,000 construction workers in northern California today, dealing another blow to an industry crippled by the recession. Among projects idled was a $68 million restoration of the Statehouse. Most nonresidential projects in 46 counties were shut down by the strike, which union officials said might ultimately involve 100,000 laborers.

A military judge today adjourned a pretrial hearing for Pfc. Robert Garwood, who is accused of collaborating with the enemy in Vietnam, and tentatively scheduled his court-martial for July 7. The judge, Col. R.E. Switzer, also criticized the marine's lawyers for presenting 62 pretrial motions. The 34-year-old private faces court-martial on charges of desertion and collaboration with the enemy in his nearly 14 years in Vietnam.

One of the handful of banks that have refused to go along with a restructuring of the Chrysler Corporation's debt announced today that it had reversed its position, bringing the auto maker a step closer to the Federal loan guarantee that it needs to survive. The announcement by the York Bank and Trust Company of York, Pa., came shortly after the Chrysler Loan Guarantee Board, a Federal agency, announced in Washington that it was postponing for 24 hours a meeting to consider final authorization of $1.5 billion in loan guarantees. The meeting is now scheduled for Thursday.

To the Editor: Already there is some speculation over the possibility that the Presidential election might be thrown into the House of Representatives. There may be no one at all who likes the archaic rules of the Electoral College, but they are the rules. To date, no ''faithless'' elector has accomplished more than an asterisk in tabulations. This time, faithful electors might make a significant difference.

The Senate approved a bill tonight that would authorize about $4.8 billion in American foreign assistance for fiscal 1981, after soundly rejecting an attempt to cut $150 million from a $2.2 billion aid program for Israel. The vote for passage was 58 to 32, with 22 Republicans joining 36 Democrats to provide the majority. As passed, the Senate bill would provide about $465 million less than the Administration had requested for the year that begins Oct. 1, and $378.5 million less than the House approved on June 5.

Deere & Company said it would lay off 5,800 workers at two Iowa plants. * Diamond International Corporation notified Brooks-Scanlon Inc. that its merger into Diamond was completed. * Empire Gas Corporation said it had extended its tender offer to July 25 to buy up to 307,000 common shares of the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association at $25 a share. * Exxon said it planned to consolidate its mineral operations into one company to be called Exxon Minerals.

The veto of a carefully crafted political deal to create a new judicial district for the Bronx was announced today by Governor Carey. The measure had been intended to give Bronx and Manhattan politicians greater sway over State Supreme Court judgeships in their boroughs. Mr. Carey said that a new judicial district for the Bronx would ''unnecessarily fragment'' the court system and that, because of constitutional limitations, such a law would preclude other action to realign the state's judicial boundaries for a decade. He added that the Legislature should wait at least until the 1980 census was completed to redraw the lines.

For openers, John McEnroe drew the toughest Wimbledon assignment among the seeded players yesterday with a first-round match against Butch Walts, the hard-serving Californian. Top-seeded Bjorn Borg and Martina Navratilova, seeking to repeat as singles champions, drew seemingly easy opponents for next Monday's start of the two-week tennis event outside London. Borg's first match is against a qualifier and Miss Navratilova meets Ilana Kloss of South Africa.

OVER the years I have written at times about menu terminology when dishes are listed as fish or chicken in Champagne sauce, beef Chambertin or other dishes that bear the name of a specific kind of wine. I feel that chefs often take a permissible latitude in naming these dishes. My contention is that as long as the chef uses an excellent wine, even one that might be obscure to the average restaurant-going public, no great damage is done if he replaces one good Burgundy with another, or a first-rate Alsatian wine with another. But a case could be made for the fact that if a menu lists a Champagne sauce in the dining room, you should indeed use a Champagne in the kitchen.

In times of trial, real or imagined, personal or global, it has become instinctive to seek relief from our burdens in a bowl of chicken soup. Chicken soup, richly golden with little globules of fat floating on its surface, submerged vegetables visible just beneath. Primordial psychological medicine, Jewish soul food, a mother's legacy, and best of all, cheap grub. Seems just the sort of thing we should be pursuing these inflationary days. And to help us along comes a bright little book, at once a guide to the gastronomic oddments of the New Jersey Pine Barrens and a book of recipes to help us meet the rising costs of food.

TO THE LIVING SECTION: As the president of California Strolee Inc., doing business as Strolee of California, I must take strong objection to the Personal Health column of April 23 written by Jane E. Brody. That article showed drawings of the Strolee juvenile car seat together with the General Motors car seat, labeling both seats as unsafe and picturing the Bobby-Mac Company car seat as safe. Such conclusions are totally unwarranted. Strolee is the world's largest manufacturer of juvenile car seats, selling in excess of 500,000 seats per year. The company has never had a reported instance of an injury to a child through a car seat failure. In this era of consumer litigation, if our car seat was not safe, would our company not have been sued? Yet our record is unblemished, no claims have ever been made and no lawsuits have ever been brought against us for injury to a child through car seat failure.

THAT which was Harvey Dreyer Associates and became Chalek & Dreyer is now Chalek Dreyer Comerford & Lubalin as the ''heirs apparent'' take their place in the corporate sun. The agency, which is in the $20 million class, has moved two executive vice presidents, James F. Comerford, 44 years old, and Peter Lubalin, 38, into partnership postions.

Hennes Weisweiler, the Cosmos' coach, made two changes on the team today when he released Don Ebert, a striker who was the league's first draft choice last year, and Vidal Fernandez, a midfielder, on waivers. The Cosmos will hold a news conference in New York tomorrow to announce officially the signing of Darryl Gee, the second player selected in the draft this year.

HE is 59 years old now, a little heavier, a little slower. But his nickname is still in lights. He lives in Los Angeles, where he is the chairman of the Sugar Ray Youth Foundation, and as the Leonard-Duran welterweight title fight approaches, perhaps it's time to remember the original Sugar Ray, the one his manager, George Gainford, always called ''Robi'son.'' ''There are no small fights for Robi'son,'' George Gainford once proclaimed. ''Only big ones.'' As the world welterweight, middleweight and almost lightheavyweight champion, Sugar Ray Robinson inspired the phrase that is now as much a part of boxing as the ring. The phrase is ''pound for pound, the best ...'' In recent years that phrase has been used to describe Roberto Duran, and after Friday night's extravaganza in Montreal it will be used to describe the winner. But over the telephone from his Los Angeles home, the original Sugar Ray would not pick a winner.

IN the 60's they called the impressario Sid Bernstein "The Rock Hurok" because he launched the Beatles "live" in America--at Carnegie Hall in February 1964, followed by the fever-pitched Shea Stadium concerts the summers of '65 and '66.

Eleven new productions and revivals will highlight the 1980-81 performing year for American Ballet Theater, its first under the directorship of Mikhail Baryshnikov, who will assume his new post in September.

Walter Hampton Mallory, an authority on China and the Far East and executive director of the Council on Foreign Relations for more than 30 years, died yesterday of a heart attack at Brooks Memorial Hospital in Dunkirk, N.Y. He was 87 years old and had lived in Manhattan and Manchester, Vt., before moving to Fredonia, N.Y., four years ago.

The International Business Machines Corporation, which has seen its share of the word-processing market decline to about 70 percent from 90 percent in the last five years, is introducing a wide range of text-editing products and programs. These moves, announced yesterday, are intended to increase I.B.M.'s leadership in the field.

COMING at a time when there is possibly more knowledge about the means of sound reproduction than there is about the sounds being reproduced, Bruce Ricker's "The Last of the Blue Devils" is something of a public service as well as a musical delight.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 17 (AP)-- The state's gaming enforcement director, Robert P. Martinez, said today the Atlantic City area was "prime pickings" for prosecutors investigating official corruption, and he predicted that "blood will be thick on the pavement" after wrongdoing was prosecuted.

The Allied Stores Corporation, one of the country's largest department-store chains, told its shareholders at the annual meeting in New York City yesterday that the current second quarter's net income will be down from the corresponding period in 1979.

The Avco Corporation, a diversified financial, technology and manufacturing company, reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended May 31, plunged 43.4 percent, to $20.7 million, or $1.10 a share, from $38.6 million, or $2.53 a share, in the similar year-ago quarter. Revenues rose 9.2 percent, to $530.3 million, from $485.5 million.

SEA GIRT, N.J., June 17--An experiment designed to find out if women really belong in law enforcement will begin in earnest June 27 when the first all-female class of trooper candidates in the nation finishes a grueling 20-week training period and joins the ranks of the New Jersey state police.

TOKYO, June 17--The candidate strolled sideways off the warm street into his campaign headquarters, stretching out an arm to greet a visitor and glancing over his shoulder for anyone else who might be waiting.

NEW JERSEY'S Department of Environmental Protection is justifiably proud of its role in the successful effort to induce the endangered peregrine falcon to produce young in the eastern half of the nation.

Policemen stormed a physician's waiting room in a hail of bullets today and shot and killed a ''staring and glazed'' Yugoslav gunman who had held 23 people for more than 20 hours. Josef Kis Lukac, 35 years old, took over the waiting room of Dr. Ladislaus Sedlak, a skin specialist, at midday yesterday and held 14 men, six women and three children, demanding to meet first with politicians and then with journalists.

To the Editor: The Mayor begins his statement (Op-Ed June 4) by referring to his Health Policy Task Force recommendations to close four municipal hospitals. It should be noted that the report was discredited by virtually all health-related organizations in New York City as well as the City Council.

A series of 10 concerts will be given in the garden of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday evenings, beginning Saturday. Called ''Music Under the Stars,'' the programs will be presented in the Cathedral Close, Amsterdam Avenue at West 110th Street, at 5:30 P.M. The Dover Woodwind Quintet will play the opening concert and, on June 28, Ray Sweeney, Maureen Hamill and Michael Gray will perform Broadway show tunes and new cabaret acts. The concerts will follow weekly through Aug. 23.

The Avco Corporation, a diversified financial, technology and manufacturing company, reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended May 31, plunged 43.4 percent, to $20.7 million, or $1.10 a share, from $36.6 million, or $2.53 a share, in the similar year-ago quarter. Revenues rose 9.2 percent, to $530.3 million, from $485.5 million. ''The predicted downturn for the second quarter was primarily due to the record high rates of interest and inflation,'' said a statement issued by James R. Kerr, Avco's chairman and chief executive and Ross M. Hett, the company's president and chief operating officer. ''In order to hold down increased interest expense, we curtailed our receivables' group in the finance and insurance group.''

George T. McDonald, whose first New York political involvement was as state director of Volunteers for Kennedy in the 1980 Presidential primary, announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for the House of Representatives from the 18th Congressional District. In doing so, he criticized Mark Green, who announced his candidacy for the seat on Monday. Mr. McDonald, who said he had lived in the district, on Manhattan's East Side, for 15 years, described Mr. Green, who moved there in April, as ''a visitor.''

IF there is one nutrient that has the decks stacked against it, it's fat. The typical American diet has a higher fat content than nearly any other in the world. While agreement on this issue is not universal, many scientists blame this high-fat diet for a number of our chronic health problems and killing diseases, among them heart disease, obesity and possibly cancers of the colon and breast. Fat is a more concentrated source of calories than any other nutrient and thus is the most fattening foodstuff we regularly consume. A gram of dietary fat supplies your body with nine calories, compared to only four calories per gram of carbohydrates or protein. Even alcohol has fewer calories (seven per gram) than fat. Thus, cutting down on fats is one of the best ways to reduce caloric intake and achieve and maintain a normal body weight.

The Labatt Brewing Company will brew Budweiser beer for sale in Canada and will market Michelob beer imported from the United States, company officials announced today. The licensing agreement was announced in St. Louis by August A. Busch 3d, chairman of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, and in Canada by Peter Widdrington, president of John Labatt Ltd. Canadian sale of the Anheuser-Busch products is expected to begin early this summer.

There is not likely to be an abundance of hot drama at the Republican National Convention that will begin July 14 in Detroit, but that will not deter the three commercial networks' news divisions. They will be there several hundred strong anyway, to cover the quadrennial exercise that avuncular news executives are fond of calling ''a national civics lesson.'' NBC-TV and CBS-TV will provide gavel-to-gavel evening coverage, and ABC-TV will cover it less continuously, breaking away from 8 o'clock to 9 the first two nights to offer special editions of ''20/20,'' its magazine program. In effect, ABC is opting for a middle ground: more coverage than they offered in 1976, but less than their rivals'. Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, has mixed feelings about saturation coverage. ''We don't want to do entertainment as usual, and the '20/ 20' specials will probably have a political slant,'' he said. ''But in our judgment, looking at what's going to be happening, we just don't think it's going to be worth straight news coverage all the way through. There is no contest, no major floor fights, no outstanding issues and not much scheduled but a parade of minor politicians who get to stand up on the platform and make speeches.''
AUTHOR OF BOOKS ON EVOLUTION OF TOTALITARIAN SYSTEMS By DAVID K. SHIPLER

A day after meeting privately with John B. Anderson, the independent candidate for President, Governor Carey said yesterday that "in this kind of a very curious year" a third-party candidate could win the Presidential race. But in the next breath he said that "in all likelihood" he would eventually support a fellow Democrat.

On the bottom line, commercial real estate is very democratic: apart from furnishings, each square foot that the chief executive occupies costs the same as each square foot that the lowest clerk occupies.
SAN JUAN, P.R., June 17 (AP)--Two key generators went back into service today, restoring service after an overnight power blackout that cut electricity to 30 percent of this island.

PEKING, June 17--Two men accused of a daring daylight robbery of a Peking bank went on trial here today, and the proceedings were opened to foreigners in a move apparently designed to demonstrate China's progress toward re-establishing a regular legal system.

CAIRO "EGYPTIAN pancakes at your service." Like the crepes of Brittany and the pizza of Naples, these pancakes, called feteer, are freshly made in a choice of flavors while you wait. One of the most interesting and attractive of the pancake restaurants and stands in Cairo is Fatarany el Hussein, adjacent to the bustling Khan el Khalili Bazaar.

LOS ANGELES, June 17--When the United States Supreme Court lifted an economic cloud from the fertile soil of California's Imperial Valley yesterday, it ended the dream of Dr. Ben Yellen and kept alive the dream of a farmer named Don Cox.

HARTFORD, June 17 (AP)--Jo McKenzie, a former Republican state chairman, and her husband are seeking a $108,000 Federal loan under a housing rehabilitation program for people with financial hardships.

BONN, June 17--Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany attempted today to steer a delicate course between Arab demands and Israeli anger by assuring Israel of continued West German support only hours before meeting King Khalid of Saudi Arabia for talks that were sure to include the Common Market's recent Middle East proposals.

The standby gasoline rationing plan proposed last week by President Carter is, to say the least, complicated. It is also, in the words of the Energy Secretary, Charles Duncan, "the best plan we could devise." The country will apparently have to settle for this goodhearted monstrosity until more Americans see gasoline rationing for what it is: an expensive and ungainly version of a gasoline tax.

The Toronto Stock Exchange said it plans to establish a financial futures market this year. The exchange facilities would trade contracts on 91-day Government of Canada Treasury bills and 18-year, 9 percent Government of Canada bonds. On Monday, the Ontario Securities Commission approved the plan and an exchange spokesman said he expects trading to begin in September.

BENTON HARBOR, Mich., June 17 (AP)--The Auto Specialties Manufacturing Company said today that the slump in the auto industry would force the closing on or before Aug. 1 of its Berrien County casting plant here.
Dizzy Reece, trumpeter, will be among the performers at the Second Annual New York City Jazz Festival beginning July 14 at the Citicorp Center, 53d Street and Lexington Avenue.
Helen Drexel came looking for her husband's gold retirement watch.

ATLANTA, June 17 (AP)--Marvis Frazier, the Amateur Athletic Union champion, outpointed Mitch Green of Jamaica, Queens, in a heavyweight fight last night at the Olympic boxing trials with his father, Joe Frazier, in the audience.

The House Ways and Means Committee voted today to double the size of a proposed fund for cleaning up inactive hazardous waste dumps and to make industry carry a bigger share of the costs. The panel voted 20 to 15 to increase the size of the fund to $1.2 billion, but it delayed a final vote on the entire measure. The bill, which was approved earlier this year by the House Commerce Committee, had called for creation of a $600 million fund financed by equal shares from the Federal Government and from the oil and chemical industry.

To the Editor: Another OPEC price hike! At the rate oil prices - and car prices - are going up, it will soon be cheaper to have a litter and bearers. This is progress? PATRICK J. O'CONNOR Danbury, Conn., June 11, 1980

The International Business Machines Corporation, which has seen its share of the word-processing market decline to about 70 percent from 90 percent in the last five years, is introducing a wide range of text-editing products and programs. These moves, announced yesterday, are intended to increase I.B.M.'s leadership in the field. Jay P. Stevens, an analyst of office equipment securities for Bear, Stearns & Company, commented that I.B.M. had not been paying enough attention to word processing in recent years but that now ''it will make its presence felt more than ever.''

Dizzy Reece, trumpeter, will be among the performers at the Second Annual New York City Jazz Festival beginning July 14 at the Citicorp Center, 53d Street and Lexington Avenue. There will be two free concerts daily at 12:30 P.M. in the Outdoor Plaza and at 6 P.M. in the Atrium, except on July 19, when there will be one performance at 8 P.M.

MIXED COUPLES,'' a comedy by James Prideaux, will go into rehearsal Oct. 20, play one stop out of town and arrive on Broadway the week before Christmas. It will star Julie Harris, Geraldine Page, Rip Torn and Michael Higgins, and will be directed by George Schaefer. ''You don't put a cast like that together with a couple of phone calls,'' Frederick Brisson, the producer, said. ''The challenge was finding the stars.'' Actually, ''Mixed Couples'' tried out briefly on the summer circuit last year, when it was called ''Slightly Delayed'' and had Miss Page and Anne Jackson in the cast. Miss Jackson was in the role to be played by Miss Harris. Then, Mr. Prideaux, who also wrote ''The Last of Mrs. Lincoln,'' plunged into rewrites. Nine months ago, Mr. Schaefer, who had directed ''Mrs. Lincoln,'' passed on the new script to Mr. Brisson. Naturally, Mr. Brisson turned to Miss Harris. She got one of her five Tonys for starring in ''Mrs. Lincoln'' in 1973.

The standby gasoline rationing plan proposed last week by President Carter is, to say the least, complicated. It is also, in the words of the Energy Secretary, Charles Duncan, ''the best plan we could devise.'' The country will apparently have to settle for this good-hearted monstrosity until more Americans see gasoline rationing for what it is: an expensive and ungainly version of a gasoline tax. The President's plan - a variant of one previously rejected by Congress because it did not guarantee gasoline supplies for agriculture - would work like this: In the event of a major interruption of oil supplies, the Government would estimate the amount of gasoline available and set aside enough fuel for the farmers. Then each state would be given a quota based in part on its past need for gasoline; the states, in turn, would make special provisions for government, business and hardship cases. Finally, what remained would be divided equally among the other vehicles - motorcycles counting as a quarter of a car, mopeds one-tenth. (No word yet on lawnmowers.)

A threatened strike against the Consolidated Edison Company at 12:01 this morning was averted yesterday with the announcement by Local 1-2 of the Utility Workers Union of America of a tentative contract agreement. After 24 hours of negotiations, James Joy Jr., business manager of the 17,000-member local, said a settlement had been reached that included a wage increase and major changes in the workweek. He declined to give details, but he did indicate the union had won more than a reported offer Monday night of 7 percent raises each year of a three-year contract.

The Toronto Stock Exchange said it plans to establish a financial futures market this year. The exchange facilities would trade contracts on 91-day Government of Canada Treasury bills and 18-year, 9 percent Government of Canada bonds. On Monday, the Ontario Securities Commission approved the plan and an exchange spokesman said he expects trading to begin in September.

While some 30 members of the Boise Kiwanis Club wolfed down stacks of pancakes, Frank Church, Idaho's senior Senator, talked about the nation's energy problems and his efforts to gain Government funds for the state's small, growing gasohol industry. But it soon became apparent that his audience at the breakfast session wanted to talk about foreign policy. He was asked why the hostage crisis in Iran had not been resolved, why the American military had failed in its effort to rescue the hostages, why Washington had not stopped Moscow from moving troops into Afghanistan, and why Mr. Church, as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, did not seem able to do anything about these problems.

Herbert Hilary Lyons Jr., a novelist, newspaper editor and a former editor of The New York Times Book Review, died of lung cancer May 18 at the Mobile (Ala.) Infirmary. He was 71 years old and lived in Mobile. Writing as Herbert Lyons, Mr. Lyons was the author of two novels, ''The Rest They Need'' (1950) and ''Other Lives to Live'' (1951). Mr. Lyons worked for The Times in the 1940's, eventually becoming acting editor of the Book Review. Later he returned to his native Mobile to become chief editorial writer for The Mobile Press.

The three children of Henry Miller will inherit the bulk of the author's estate, including books and manuscripts valued at $500,000, under provisions of his will. Mr. Miller, whose best-known book was ''Tropic of Cancer,'' died June 7 at the age of 88. He lived in Pacific Palisades. His will, dated Oct. 11, 1978, was filed for probate yesterday in Los Angeles Superior Court. His daughter, Barbara Sylvas Miller of Pasadena, was left Mr. Miller's record albums, an ivory head from Nairobi and a Cleo Usher collage entitled, ''Love.''
For openers, John McEnroe drew the toughest Wimbledon assignment among the seeded players yesterday with a first-round match against Butch Walts, the hard-serving Californian.

ERIC BRAM did not have the slightest doubt about the future of the New York City transit face. "Since the early 60's," he pronounces, "the price of a slice of pizza has matched, with uncanny precision, the cost of a New York subway ride. Right now, it is impossible for any discerning New Yorker to find a decent slice of pizza for less than 60 cents. The 50-cent fare was doomed."

Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx said yesterday that a $400,000 appropriation added to the 1981 capital budget would enable Hostos College to open a new building in the fall. The building is on the east side of the Grand Concourse at 149th Street, opposite the college. The money will be used to equip the building with classrooms and provide a security system, Mr. Simon said.
DOWNERS GROVE, Ill, June 17 (AP) --A 24-year-old nurse suspended in connection with the unexplained deaths of two hospital patients has been dismissed.

John Mendenhall, who had expressed unhappiness during various stages of his eight pro seasons with the Giants, has been let go. The former all-pro defensive tackle has cleared waivers and is now free to negotiate with any team in the National Football League.

ST. LOUIS, June 17 (AP)--The local authorities complained today that they did not know that John Larry Ray had escaped from Federal custody four months ago until he was charged in an Illinois bank robbery.

KHAO I DANG, Thailand, June 17 (AP) --About 600 Cambodian refugees left two camps in eastern Thailand for the Cambodian border today at the start of a voluntary repatriation program directed by Thai authorities and the United Nations. However, most refugees here refused to join in the program.

Korvettes Inc., the New York area's third-largest retailer, confirmed yesterday that it plans to lay off about 2,000 employees, about one-third of its work force, over the next two to three months. John Cook, a company spokesman, said in a statement that the reductions would take place at its headquarters in New York City and its 36 stores throughout the country. The company has about 6,000 employees.

GRAZ, Austria, June 17 (UPI)--Policemen stormed a physician's waiting room in a hail of bullets today and shot and killed a "staring and glazed" Yugoslav gunman who had held 23 people for more than 20 hours.

ALBANY, June 17--The veto of a carefully crafted political deal to create a new judicial district for the Bronx was announced today by Governor Carey. The measure had been intended to give Bronx and Manhattan politicians greater sway over State Supreme Court judgeships in their boroughs.
Two key generators went back into service today, restoring service after an overnight power blackout that cut electricity to 30 percent of this island.

Don't talk turkey this week - buy one and freeze it for Thanksgiving. That was the advice of turkey producers, who said turkey prices are at a three-year low but are beginning to rise. By Thanksgiving, according to growers, turkeys will probably cost more than 60 cents a pound, chiefly because growers have already moved to cut back on the production of birds. On Monday, the wholesale price was 56 cents a pound for hens, 53 cents for toms. A year ago, the New York wholesale car lot price for hens was 65 cents a pound; for toms, 61 cents.

After three rounds of the 1980 United States championship here at Thiel College, Larry Christiansen, a grandmaster from Modesto, Calif., and John Peters, an international master from Los Angeles, share the lead with 2 1/2- 1/2 scores. Christiansen defeated Peter Biyiasas, drew with me and defeated Walter Browne. Peters won from Arthur Bisguier and Vitaly Zaltsman and drew with Pal Benko.

By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt REAL PROPERTY. By Sara Davidson. 306 pages. Doubleday. $10.95. SARA DAVIDSON, whose first book, ''Loose Change,'' established its author as something of an expert on the 1960's, gets off to a strong start in this collection of her magazine pieces from the 1970's. In the first two essays - ''Real Property,'' about a real-estate boom in the Los Angeles suburb of Venice, Calif., and ''Last Days in Sinai,'' about a trip in the Sinai Desert the author took in 1979 - she contrasts in a series of finely tuned vignettes the short-sighted sybaritism of her new-world Venetians with the communal dedication and historical purposiveness she sensed among the Israelis she met.

Q. I have a passion for frankfurters. A friend of mine says that they are made from the cheapest cuts of pork. Is that true? A. I can assure you that the ingredients for frankfurters vary greatly from one manufacturer to another. One recipe source states that the meats used in preparing frankfurters range from lean bull or cow trimmings to regular pork trimmings, beef cheeks, skinned pork jowls, trimmed pork cheeks, fat pork trimmings, fat beef trimmings and pork fat.

To the Editor: Two events are the occasion for profound revulsion and disgust: The deplorable and mean-spirited stoning of President Carter's limousine following his address to black leaders in South Miami and the dastardly and reprehensible shooting of Vernon Jordan, president of the National Urban League.

A five-month Federal inquiry in Chesapeake, Va., resulted in the arrest of seven New York City men on charges of smuggling more than $12 million in contraband cigarettes. Officials said the operation at a Chesapeake warehouse marked the first major Federal crackdown on cigarette smuggling. The inquiry was conducted by undercover agents of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.

Americans will get their first full look at traditional Peking opera in more than 50 years when the Peking Opera Theater of China opens its first tour of the United States, starting Aug. 12, with 14 performances at the Metropolitan Opera House. Hailing the event as a ''breakthrough'' in cultural exchanges between the two countries, Sheldon Gold, president of ICM Artists, which is presenting the company, announced the 12-week 10-city tour at a news conference yesterday. Also at the news session were Anthony A. Bliss, executive director of the Met, and Chinese officials.

Continental Illinois announced plans for a $150 million six-year Euronote offering by Continental Illinois Overseas Finance Corporation, a subsidiary. Goldman Sachs International will lead a group making the offering.
To the Editor: Seeing the announcement of the Presidential Medal of Freedom awards today reminded me of an early lesson I learned on the style of the Carter Administration.

A delegation of Liberian Cabinet ministers was in Washington last week seeking emergency loans of about $50 million, food and military supplies and equipment to shore up the nation's new military regime. The five ministers, who were led by Dr. Togba Nah Tipoteh, Minister of Planning and Economic Affairs, attempted also to assure both the American Government and the business community of the new Government's stability, efficiency and popularity and of its commitment to human rights.

Ehrhardt Henry (Ott) Heller, a former New York Ranger defenseman who played 27 years in professional hockey, died Monday at his home in Kitchener, Ontario. Mr. Heller was 70 years old and had been ill for some time. The red-haired Heller spent his entire 15-year National Hockey League career with the Rangers, beginning in 1931. Only two others in Ranger history, Harry Howell and Rod Gilbert, played more seasons with the team. In all, Heller played in 647 league games. He wound up his career with the Cleveland Barons, a minor league club, in 1955.

The state's gaming enforcement director, Robert P. Martinez, said today the Atlantic City area was ''prime pickings'' for prosecutors investigating official corruption, and he predicted that ''blood will be thick on the pavement'' after wrongdoing was prosecuted. Mr. Martinez, with two weeks remaining as a state official, said official corruption is a bigger threat than organized crime in Atlantic City.

The Auto Specialties Manufacturing Company said today that the slump in the auto industry would force the closing on or before Aug. 1 of its Berrien County casting plant here. The plant produces cast-iron parts for light trucks and cars and employs about 210 workers. Production will be moved to a nearby casting plant in St. Joseph. The closing will result in the layoff of approximately 200 workers from the combined work force of the two plants, both of which have already been operating at reduced levels.

The House today defeated legislation to extend for one year the Environmental Protection Agency's authority to study and regulate pesticides. The vote was an apparent signal that the House wanted Congress to have veto power over the agency's decisions on pesticides. The bill would have strengthened the review of Environmental Protection Agency studies and decisions related to pesticides, but it apprently did not go far enough to satisfy House members.
AFTER-DINNER parlor games send shivers down a lot of spines, especially spines attached to heads that like good talk, or what is more loftily known as the art of conversation.

BOISE, Idaho--While some 30 members of the Boise Kiwanis Club wolfed down stacks of pancakes, Frank Church, Idaho's senior Senator, talked about the nation's energy problems and his efforts to gain Government funds for the state's small, growing gasohol industry.

The United States Patent Office has a backlog of more than 100 applications for patents on living organisms and now expects to process them, following the Supreme Court's favorable decision on the General Electric Company's patent for an oil-eating bacterium.

The atmosphere was terribly quiet yesterday afternoon at Harper's magazine, after the staff of 20 had heard that the 130-year-old periodical would perish with the August issue and that they would be out of work in two weeks.
The dollar gained against major world currencies in foreign trading yesterday before falling in later New York dealing. Gold prices were mixed but remained below $600 an ounce.
DETROIT--Labor disputes and strikes are not rare in the United States. But in the Soviet Union? In the shadow of the Kremlin? In the workers'--what is their word?--oh, "paradise?"
All state legislatures are famous for foolishness, but until last weekend none had ever thought of turning love into a requirement for operating an automobile.

Peter J. Solomon resigned yesterday as New York City's Deputy Mayor for Economic Policy and Development to take a newly created position as counselor to Treasury Secretary G. William Miller. Mr. Solomon, who has served longer than any of the 12 Deputy Mayors the Koch administration has had in its two and a half years, said he would leave city government at the end of the month.

PLEASE USE ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 17 - The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization said today that he was opposed to any extension of the alliance's frontiers to include areas, such as the Persian Gulf, that might be threatened by the Soviet Union.

For many years the Royal Bank has been Canada's No. 1 bank, the largest financial fish in a small market sprinkled across the broad northern flank of the United States. It still is. But more recently, under the leadership of Rowland C.Frazee, its outspoken president and chief executive officer, the Royal has moved aggressively onto the international scene to become North America's fourth-largest bank in assets, following the Bank of America, Citicorp and Chase Manhattan.

Members of Congress said today at a Congressional hearing that the Carter Administration was continuing to treat Haitian ''boat people'' much more harshly than Cuban exiles despite a new law designed to equalize the treatment of aliens seeking asylum in this country. At a hearing of the House judiciary subcommittee on immigration, refugees and international law, State Department and immigration officials denied charges by Congressmen that race made a difference in treatment, noting that many Cuban refugees were black, like the Haitians.

ERIC BRAM did not have the slightest doubt about the future of the New York City transit fare. ''Since the early 60's,'' he pronounces, ''the price of a slice of pizza has matched, with uncanny precision, the cost of a New York subway ride. Right now, it is impossible for any discerning New Yorker to find a decent slice of pizza for less than 60 cents. The 50-cent fare was doomed.'' THE GOOD SAMARITAN OF 73d STREET: What is to be said about this inspiring chronicle? It actually happened; it could only have occurred in New York, and the action involves a few of the usual suspects: a doctor who lives on Central Park West, a parking spot, Newark, a Bar Mitzvah. It began on a Monday morning, at close to 6:45. The doctor - James Stovin, M.D., a radiologist -approached his automobile and prepared to vacate his parking spot on West 73d Street, at the stern of the great ship Dakota. It seems that Dr. Stovin's father, Joseph, had voyaged across the continent from Palm Springs to attend the bar mitzvah of Dr. Stovin's son. The senior Stovins were leaving in plenty of time for the drive to Newark Airport, where Joseph Stovin was to catch an 8:30 A.M. plane back to California.

Peter Schaufuss and Peter Martins are two of classical ballet's greatest male dancers. And never has the difference between this pair of Danes been more apparent than in their guest appearances this week in Chicago with the company in which they were trained - the Royal Danish Ballet. Through a bold initiative from Geraldine Freund - producer of an annual event she calls the International Dance Festival of Stars - the entire company from Denmark has come to the Civic Opera House with six of the nine ballets it presented at Copenhagen's widely acclaimed Bournonville Centenary Festival in November. Last night, it also offered a new staging of the ''William Tell'' divertissement by August Bournonville - the cause of all this trans-Atlantic attention and very possibly the most popular 19th-century Danish Romantic choreographer in the United States.

The local authorities complained today that they did not know that John Larry Ray had escaped from Federal custody four months ago until he was charged in an Illinois bank robbery. Mr. Ray, the brother of James Earl Ray, the convicted assassin of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was supposed to arrive at a Federal halfway house here in February to finish serving a previous bank robbery conviction. He never showed up.

Be among those who will be able to say 'I was there!' '' go the newspaper ads here. Muhammad Ali and Joe Frazier will be there. So will Woody Allen and Norman Mailer, Frank Sinatra and Jean-Paul Belmondo, Joe Namath and Farrah Fawcett, Jack Nicklaus and Guy Lafleur.
ASTROS ROUT CUBS FOR RICHARD'S 9TH VICTORY

LAST Wednesday, the stock of Daniel Industries jumped 3 points, to 28 7/8, and the following day it traded at a record price of 33 3/4. Part of that run-up stemmed from a company presentation on Tuesday of last week before security analysts at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. But its chief impetus came from a ''buy'' recommendation issued Wednesday by a research team at Merrill Lynch that concentrates on ''emerging growth companies.'' Daniel Industries makes products to measure the flow of gas and oil, and produces pipeline valves and stud bolts that also are sold to the energy market.

For more than a century, Harper's magazine and The Atlantic Monthly have been an integral part of American literary, social and political history, creating and reflecting tastes and opinions in the nation for selective readers. The demise of Harper's with the August 1980 issue leaves only The Atlantic, recently rejuvenated financially under new ownership in Boston, as a national monthly with a great tradition in letters and politics that reaches back to the New England Transcendentalists.

A tentative settlement as been approved by a Federal District Court judge in two class-action suits that were filed in April seeking refunds on a travel package for people who have canceled plans to attend the Moscow Olympics. The tentative settlement, which calls for a refund of 86 percent to the 6,700 people who canceled their reservations before March 1 and a refund of 63 percent to the 4,019 who canceled after March 1 or did not cancel at all, was approved by Judge Lawrence W. Pierce of the Southern District in New York last Friday.

FOR most young artists starting out in New York, dreams of good food vanish when their first rent bill arrives. But Robert Russell, a 25-year-old painter who supports himself with part-time carpentry and house painting, sits down every night to a splendid dinner and a bottle of wine. "I need that relaxation at the end of the day," he says. "I cant afford to go out to eat, so I do the cooking myself."

Governor Carey exaggerates when he says New York State now has the toughest handgun law in the country. In fact, Massachusetts, with its mandatory one-year sentence, is still the state most feared by those who carry guns illegally. What New York has done is to increase the allowable penalties for handgun violations.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 17 (AP)-- About 20 Communists chanting and waving red banners in a rally outside the Alamo today were outnumbered by 200 bystanders waving American flags and singing "God Bless America."
"MIXED COUPLES," a comedy by James Prideaux, will go into rehearsal Oct. 20, play one stop out of town and arrive on Broadway the week before Christmas.
LOS ANGELES, June 17 (AP)--The three children of Henry Miller will inherit the bulk of the author's estate, including books and manuscripts valued at $500,000, under provisions of his will.
IF Sherlock Holmes were alive today he would have to add an expert knowledge of computer science to his formidable analytical skills.

A tentative settlement as been approved by a Federal District Court judge in two class-action suits that were filed in April seeking refunds on a travel package for people who have canceled plans to attend the Moscow Olympics.

CHICAGO, June 17--The consumer electronic industry's annual rite of summer--its trade show--traditionally is a time for buoyant forecasts and chest-thumping pronouncements about the industry's health.

MONTREAL, June 17--Sugar Ray Leonard said today that he has been suffering from a virus and sore throat "about a week now," but that it would not affect him Friday night when he defends the World Boxing Council welterweight title against Roberto Duran.

SAN DIEGO, June 17--When a couple of traditionally noncontending clubs like the New York Mets and San Diego Padres get together, good defense is usually the last thing you expect to see. However, at San Diego Stadium tonight, fielders from both teams backed up a pair of rookie starting pitchers with a stream of sensational plays.

Venezuela has notified oil companies that, effective Friday, it is raising the prices of its heavy fuel oil, the kind burned by electric utilities to make power and by large industrial, commercial and residential buildings to provide heat and hot water.
HE is 59 years old now, a little heavier, a little slower. But his nickname is still in lights.
A 60-cent bus and subway fare in New York City was recommended yesterday by the chairman and staff of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, virtually assuring its adoption.

Carlos Marcello, reputedly one of the top leaders of organized crime in the United States, was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on racketeering, conspiracy and fraud charges. Mr. Marcello was accused of playing a central role in a scheme to bribe public officials in Louisiana. The 12-count indictment, which grew out of a one-year undercover inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, was returned in New Orleans against Mr. Marcello and three other men: I. Irving Davidson, a Washington public relations man; Charles E. Roemer 2d, a former Louisiana state official, and Vincent A. Marinello, a New Orleans lawyer.

The candidate strolled sideways off the warm street into his campaign headquarters, stretching out an arm to greet a visitor and glancing over his shoulder for anyone else who might be waiting. ''It's a battle,'' he said with a weary smile. ''It's a struggle.'' Koji Kakizawa, 46 years old, is fighting his first campaign for the lower house of Parliament in a downtown Tokyo constituency. He represents the tiny New Liberal Club, a neoconservative group founded in 1976. It has been mentioned in speculation as a possible coalition partner for the governing Liberal Democratic Party if the Liberal Democrats lose their present slim working majorities in Parliament in next Sunday's elections.

EVERY WEDNESDAY ''Seven Hundred Years of Vocal and Instrumental Music (1200-1980)'' is quite a lot. But, undaunted, the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity is presenting this weekly series of lunch-time concerts that cover this temporal spectrum. Today's program will feature The Players Three, who play Baroque to contemporary chamber music for flute, cello and piano. They will play Debussy, Haydn, Hummel and Weber today in the program that starts at 12:30 P.M. The church is in downtown Brooklyn, at 122 Pierrepont Street. Admission: free, with donations accepted. Information: 875-6960.

In the 60's they called the impresario Sid Bernstein ''The Rock Hurok'' because he launched the Beatles ''live'' in America - at Carnegie Hall in February 1964, followed by the fever-pitched Shea Stadium concerts the summers of '65 and '66. There were those who referred to the rotund producer as ''Fat Sid,'' though ''never to my face,'' he notes. Nowadays his distinction is more domestic. Even strangers hail him with, 'Hey, you're the guy with all the kids!''

Coming at a time when there is possibly more knowledge about the means of sound reproduction than there is about the sounds being reproduced, Bruce Ricker's ''The Last of the Blue Devils'' is something of a public service as well as a musical delight. The documentary feature, which opens today at New York's Art Theater, is a recollection of the music and the musicians associated with Kansas City, Mo., in the 30's when the city, which was then run by Tom (Boss) Pendergast and wide open to women and gambling, could support the kind of clubs where black musicians flourished. The film is a montage of footage shot by Mr. Ricker, a New Yorkborn lawyer turned film maker, at two reunions of surviving Kansas City musicians and at a concert performance by Count Basie and his band at the University of Kansas at Lawrence. Music is the subject of the movie, but the personalities who made it (some of whom are still making it) and their reminiscences are the movie's method.

Harper's, the 130-year-old magazine of literature and current affairs, will cease publication after its August issue. Over the years the magazine has been an integral part of American literary, social and political history. It once brought to its literate readership such features as serializations of novels by Dickens, Thackeray and Trollope. Among its editors have been such figures as John Fisher, Bernard DeVoto, Frederick Lewis Allen and Willie Morris. ''The official announcement says we'll 'suspend operations,' '' said Lewis H. Lapham, editor of Harper's since 1976. ''But there's no use kidding anybody, it's the end of a fine magazine and a great tradition.''

John Mendenhall, who had expressed unhappiness during various stages of his eight pro seasons with the Giants, has been let go. The former all-pro defensive tackle has cleared waivers and is now free to negotiate with any team in the National Football League. Had a team claimed the 31-year-old Mendenhall, it would have been obligated to pay him his reported $115,000 a year salary for the remaining two years on the four-year contract he signed in 1978. Now he is free to negotiate new terms with a club of his choice.

A 16-year-old Brooklyn youth who was killed Monday night after he allegedly robbed a decoy police officer was identified yesterday as Michael Furse of 83 Woodruff Place, in the Flatbush section. The shooting took place around 11:30 after the youth allegedly accosted Officer Ellen Awill, who was disguised as an elderly woman, at 45 Parade Place. Officer Awill said Mr. Furse held his hand in his shirt with an object protruding from it and said: ''I've got a gun. Give me your money or I'll shoot you.''

A PRUDENT BUYERS GUIDE TO CHEESE THAT REALLY HAVE LITTLE FAT AND CHOLESTEROLDiet-conscious consumers seeking an alternative to cottage cheese often turn to their local cheese shop for advice. When they ask for low-fat cheese, most dealers are likely to suggest Swiss Chris, a mild semisoft cheese made in Wisconsin. According to the label on the uncut cheese, it provides eight grams of fat per oneounce (or 28.35-gram) serving, for a total fat content of about 29 percent. Thus, the fat in Swiss Chris is about the same as in Muenster, Edam, Gouda, Gruyere, Swiss, Port-Salut and Jarlsberg as well as most processed cheeses. It is a low-cholesterol, not a low-fat cheese - made low in cholesterol by substituting cholesterol-free vegetable oil for some of the cholesterol-laden butterfat. (Neither, for that matter, is Swiss Lorraine a low-fat cheese; rather, it is another widely marketed low-cholesterol product also made by replacing some of the butterfat with vegetable fat.)

A small New York bank reduced its prime lending rate to 11.5 percent yesterday, becoming the first bank to reach that level since last August. The UMB Bank and Trust Company, a subsidiary of Israel's United Mizrahi Bank, cut its prime, which is the rate banks charge on loans to their most reliable business borrowers, from 12.5 percent. Most banks are now maintaining their prime rates at 12 percent or 12.5 percent, but analysts expect the rate to continue to drop in the next several weeks.

The directors of the Chicago Board of Trade voted yesterday to establish trading in a 1,000-ounce silver futures contract, according to an exchange statement released last night. C. Odom, a board of trade director and chairman of the metal committee, said the new contract, which would supplement the 5,000-ounce silver contract now traded at the exchange, was designed to appeal to small commercial interests that are subject to great price volatility.

TOKYO, June 17 (UPI)--Construction of a $3 billion steel project being promoted by Brazil, Japan and Italy is scheduled to start next Monday, the Kawasaki Steel Corporation, the Japanese partner, said today. The mill, in Tubarao, on Brazil's Atlantic coast, will have an annual capacity of 3.4 million tons of crude steel.

GUATEMALA, June 17 (UPI)--Jose A. Lima, of Mexico, president of Cindal, a Guatemalan subsidiary of the Swiss chocolate company Nestle, was kidnapped by a number of armed men today when he drove away from his home in a plush southern residential area of the capital, the authorities said. None of the extremist groups operating in Guatemala have yet taken responsibility for the kidnapping, they said.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, June 17 (Reuters)--All Nicaraguan banks, financial companies and savings and loan associations will be consolidated into five banks to be run by the state's Corporacion Financiera Nacional, or Corfin, a governing member of the Nicaraguan junta, Arturo Cruz, announced at a news conference today.

A representative to the United Nations from the West African nation of Togo entered a civilian complaint last night alleging that police officers in Brooklyn had abused him in the course of a traffic incident.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 17 (Reuters) --A Yugoslav delegation met with Iran's oil minister, Ali Akbar Moinfar, today and asked for increased supplies of oil, according to a report on Iran's state radio. Yugoslavia is believed to be buying about 10,000 barrels of Iranian oil a day at present.
WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)--The personal income of Americans rose only one-tenth of 1 percent last month, the Commerce Department reported today.
