Part of that run up stemmed from a company presentation on Tuesday of last week before security analysts at Fort Lauderdale, Fla. But its chief impetus came from a "buy" recommendation issued Wednesday by a research team at Merrill Lynch that concentrates on "emerging growth companies."

SAN DIEGO, June 17 (AP)--Parents of a teen-ager who died in the 1978 air collision that killed 144 people have been awarded $76,000 in wrongful death damages from Pacific Southwest Airlines. Mr. and Mrs. Taha Taha, parents of David, a 16-year-old high school junior, received the award yesterday from a jury in San Diego Superior Court that deliberated 70 minutes after a day of testimony.

IN an unusual spurt of activity, WOR-TV's public-affairs department has developed two half-hour reports on the dangers of alcohol. Tonight at 10, the subject is "Alcohol and the Adolescent." Tomorrow at 10, it's "The Violent Drinker." Both reports, narrated by Tom Dunn, were written and produced by Stanley Friedman.

Labor disputes and strikes are not rare in the United States. But in the Soviet Union? In the shadow of the Kremlin? In the workers' - what is their word? - oh, ''paradise?'' Some 70,000 workers at the Togliatti automobile plant, 500 miles from Moscow on the Volga River, struck for two days in May, we are told. It isn't clear why - it may never be; the Soviet press and nightly news don't cover the labor beat so well - but one reason may have been to protest food shortages, particularly in meat and dairy products. Further, according to The New York Times, there are rumors of a strike of 200,000 workers at a major car and truck factory in Gorky last month - perhaps to protest food shortages, too; perhaps in solidarity with bus drivers assigned additional routes without extra pay.

IN an unusual spurt of activity, WOR-TV's public-affairs department has developed two half-hour reports on the dangers of alcohol. Tonight at 10, the subject is ''Alcohol and the Adolescent.'' Tomorrow at 10, it's ''The Violent Drinker.'' Both reports, narrated by Tom Dunn, were written and produced by Stanley Friedman. Compiled in association with Rutgers University, ''Alcohol and the Adolescent'' focuses on a drug-abuse prevention program, called Alternatives, in Brooklyn's Community School District 22. There is no lack of distressing statistics: nationally, about 75 percent of students in grades 7 through 12 are drinkers. The phenomenon often appears to be a ''generational thing,'' with children imitating parents. At the same time, the teenage alcoholic is hindered from getting treatment without parental consent.
BY JULY 1:FREE BUS TRANSFERS, MONTHLY PASS AND RATES 7% TO 45% HIGHER ON RAILROADS ALSO ASKED By DAVID A. ANDELMAN
WORLD NEWS BRIEFS; Rebels on New Hebrides Isle Ask for Talks on Crisis

Twenty years ago, Billy Cannon landed in a courtroom because he had signed two professional football contracts, one with Pete Rozelle, then general manager of the Los Angeles Rams and now Commissioner of the National Football League. Yesterday, Cannon was involved with another commissioner, baseball's Bowie Kuhn, because the Yankees want to sign his son, Billy Jr.

Before the game, Dennis Werth sat at a table in the Yankee clubhouse, painstakingly removing someone else's embroidered name from his new third baseman's glove. Werth, a 27-year-old rookie, has not played third base for the Yankees this season, but he has performed a variety of other duties. Last night he played first base and drove in three runs as the Yankees whipped the Seattle Mariners, 8-2. The victory, combined with Milwaukee's loss in Detroit, increased New York's American League Eastern Division lead to a season-high six and a half games.

Jo McKenzie, a former Republican state chairman, and her husband are seeking a $108,000 Federal loan under a housing rehabilitation program for people with financial hardships. Mrs. McKenzie and her husband, Robert, own the Copper Beech Inn, a restaurant in the Ivoryton section of Essex. They asked for a loan to renovate a house at 20 Charter Oak Place, just south of downtown Hartford.

The Ziff Corporation, the parent company of the Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, a New York magazine publisher, announced the formation of a data-based management consulting organization under the name Strategic Information. Wharton Econometric Forecasting Associates, which Ziff recently acquired from the University of Pennsylvania, will be an important part of the new organization, the company said.

Carter Administration officials are discussing a tax cut for 1981, particularly its size, shape and timing. The move toward a tax reduction, which the President may propose in his July budget review, represents a change in the White House's public policy. Previously, President Carter had refused to discuss tax cuts, arguing that the top priorities were fighting inflation and balancing the Federal budget. But the deepening recession and political pressures have forced Mr. Carter to consider tax relief, officials said. (Page A1.) Housing starts plunged 11 percent last month to a five-year low as the recession continued to depress the home construction industry. The Government reported that new homes were built at an annual rate of 920,000 units in May, well below last year's total of 1.8 million. But Philip M. Klutznick, the Secretary of Commerce, said that the recent trend toward lower interest rates could lead to increased demand for housing. (D1.)

The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has given China a contract to produce parts for a new model of its DC-9 airliner in a move to tap a vast market, the company has confirmed. The contract for 200 landing-gear doors on the DC-9 Super 80 marks the first time an American airplane manufacturer has asked the Chinese to make parts. John Brizendine, president of the Douglas division, which builds the twin-engine DC-9, said over the weekend that the agreement could lead to a contract for the manufacture of complete airplanes at China's Shanghai aircraft factory.
CAMPAIGN REPORT; Carter Delegates Invited To Meetings in Capital

Walter Hampton Mallory, an authority on China and the Far East and executive director of the Council on Foreign Relations for more than 30 years, died yesterday of a heart attack at Brooks Memorial Hospital in Dunkirk, N.Y. He was 87 years old and had lived in Manhattan and Manchester, Vt., before moving to Fredonia, N.Y., four years ago. Mr. Mallory, whose career in foreign affairs began while he was a student at Harvard, served as executive director of the Council on Foreign Relations from 1927 to 1959. He was also a past president and treasurer of the China Institute of America, and in recent years had been a member of the board of directors of the Asia Foundation.

Pope John Paul II named Bishop James A. Hickey today to be the new Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington. Archbishop Hickey, 59 years old, has been Bishop of Cleveland since 1974. He succeeds Cardinal William Baum, who was named head of the Vatican's Congregation for Catholic Education last January. In Cleveland Bishop Hickey was a leader in efforts to promote peaceful desegregation and racial justice. He has been a leader in efforts to aid Hispanic Americans, including founding the Mexican Apostolate in Michigan to assist the scores of Spanish-speaking migrant workers in that state.

A rush of steam from roof vents on a building at St. Vincent's Hospital Center at 12th Street and Seventh Avenue awoke the hospital's Greenwich Village neighbors early this morning. It was quickly controlled without damage or injury. A Con Edison spokesman said the accident occurred as engineers from the utility were doing routine work on steam meters and a safety valve tripped.

Because Mother Teresa of Calcutta, India, had to bow out as main speaker, Senator Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon opened yesterday's New York City prayer breakfast with a personal story about the Nobel Prize-winning nun.

The Treasury Department said in a letter to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission yesterday that it did not oppose plans of the New York Futures Exchange, a New York Stock Exchange unit, to trade futures contracts based on Treasury bills and bonds. The Treasury statement was viewed as increasing the chances for approval of the futures exchange's plans next month by the C.F.T.C. The Federal Reserve Board earlier advised the commission that it did not object to the contracts, provided that the exchange unit merged, as planned, with the American Stock Exchange's futures unit.
